column2: MUSICAL RADIO: For the next ten years advertisers and sponsors will continue to be barred from the radio in Britain. The ban was announced last Monday by the government. Broadcasting in England is paid for by a ten-shilling tax on all receiving sets; this levy will net the government about $5,250,000 in 1936.
CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP). -- Cincinnati's "kid team" took a double header from the Cardinals today, tossing them out of first place in the National League, and raising itself to third.

National campaigns grow longer. The American people never get a rest from politics. The present contest for the Presidency became intense in 1935 when a growing number of Republicans in Congress began to summon from the Supreme Court the courage to vote against New Deal legislation. Although the next week or two are supposed to mark what is quadrennially known as a "lull," politics will dominate all other news.

TRUE to tradition the entertainment ship of radio is in the doldrums. It is at this season of the year that listeners are heard to complain "there is little to listen to." A number of the shows which have been tuned in week after week since Autumn vanished with June and not until after Labor Day will these old favorites begin to troup back to the studios.
The final trial for candidates for the United States Olympic soccer team will be held this afternoon at Grand Stadium, Halsey Street and Irving Avenue, Brooklyn. Sixteen players will be selected.

THE University of London, which last week celebrated the centenary of the grant of its charter by William IV, is soon to enter upon a new phase of its life. The great new buildings in Bloomshury, which are to give this at present most invisible of universities a visible center, have progressed as far as the virtual completion of the Senate House block.

Hour of Opera by the "Music Hall of the Air" symphony orchestra of seventy-five players, Maurice Baron directing. The soloists are Louise Bave, coloratura soprano; Edwina Eustis, contralto; Jan Peerce, tenor, and Robert Weede, baritone: WJZ, 12:30 P.M.
THE opening of the Triborough Bridge next Saturday will be another major step in breaking down the natural and man-made obstacles which have jammed up traffic moving in and out of Greater New York.

IT has been clear for some time now that Sally Benson is one of the best of The New Yorker writers. All but four of the stories in this volume originally appeared in that magazine, and all of them -- as one might expect -- have the virtues of conciseness, irony and avoidance of the obvious.

WITH such distinguished persons as Mrs. Laurance Binyon, George Eumorfopoulos and John Maynard Keynes standing as godparents, and with many justifications by distinguished critics, "Abstract" art is being given difficult birth in London, at the Lefevre Gallery.

With Mayor La Guardia at the throttle, a steam shovel bit deep into a mound of ashes in Flushing Meadow Park last week, marking the official opening of construction activities for New York City's 1939 World's Fair.

NEARLY eighty years ago, when Francois Blanc, flushed with the success of his gambling establishments at Homburg, built his first Casino on the desolate rock at Monaco and called it Monte Carlo, every one said that it could not last long. In the Seven ties, the wiseacres gave it five years at the most to live.
CUERO, Texas, July 4 (AP). -- New rains upstream early today poured another burden of water into the sprawling Guadalupe River, which already had forced 200 families out of their homes at Victoria.

ITHACA, July 4. -- A new type of atomic "range-finder," which makes it easier for atomic bullets to find their target inside the hearts of atoms, was reported today at the closing sessions of the symposium on nuclear physics at Cornell University by Professor F. Rasetti of the University of Rome, Italy, now at Columbia University.

THE Municipal Art Committee's Temporary Gallery at 62 West Fifty-third Street is presenting its tenth group exhibition, which will be current until July 19. Both oils and water-colors are shown by artists many of whom are newcomers.

TOPEKA, July 2. -- Next Tuesday, when the Kansas Legislature will convene in special session to adopt a resolution to permit the people to amend the State Constitution so that Kansas may set up a social security program to meet Federal Government requirements, Governor Landon will face one of the most critical situations which has confronted him in his Presidential candidacy in his home State.

President Roosevelt's chance of carrying his home State of New York and thereby adding to the prospect of his re-election has been increased greatly by the announcement of Governor Herbert H. Lehman that he has reconsidered his decision to retire from public office at the end of his present term and will run again.

The Colombian Bondholders Committees announced yesterday that any unilateral offer made by the Colombian Government on its defaulted dollar bonds would be opposed by the committees as being not to the benefit of the bondholders.

NOT content with a short title which by itself is arresting, Mr. Beard further describes his book, on the title-page, as "An Inquiry into the Nature of the Statements, Assertions, Allegations, Claims, Heats, Tempers, Distempers, Dogmas and Contentions which Appear when Human Affairs are Discussed and into the Possibility of Putting Some Rhyme and Reason into Processes of Discussion."

DAFFODILS lend themselves with peculiar grace to naturalistic planting. Clumps of bright blossoms are cheerily at home when nodding at the base of a large tree trunk, blooming against the cold protection of a rock or springing from the grass as though marking the footsteps of Spring across the lawns.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 4. -- Down the straightaway he thundered with long, bounding strides and then the form of George Varoff of the Olympic Club soared through the air today in the greatest pole vault that man has ever made -- the incredible height of 14 feet 6 1/2 inches.

RADIO'S acts for the first half of 1936, upon which the curtain has dropped, comprised one of the most diversified "shows" ever crowded within six months. Broadcasts from the Zeppelin Hindenburg, from the R.M.S. Queen Mary, both on maiden voyages; the Schmeling-Louis fight and the national political conventions were the headline acts which might have blazed in bright electric letters over the marquees if radio had such signs to beckon the public.

The first serious fears among dry goods wholesalers as to the effect the drought in the West may have on the distribution of goods there developed only at the close of last week, they said yesterday. As yet, however, jobbers feel that heavy rains within the coming week or ten days may serve to save the major portions of crops in the areas affected.

Never before has public opinion been as intense concerning the subject of parole as it is now. Most authorities, including J. Edgar Hoover of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, are advocates of the principle of parole, but disagree with its present administrative procedure.

AN expedition sponsored by the New York Botanical Garden will leave New York next Tuesday to spend three months collecting plants and seeds from the peaks of the Rockies in Colorado, Wyoming and Montana.
LIMA, Peru, July 4. -- Jorge Prado, Presidential candidate of the National Front, will receive a tremendous ovation when he arrives here tomorrow.

TOKYO, July 4. -- A wave of eco nomic nationalism, in which the trade of certain nations and probably of Japan itself is bound to suffer severely, is setting in here and gives every promise of mounting to typhoon proportions during the coming months.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The Berkshire dramatic season will start tomorrow with the opening for the ninth year of the Berkshire Playhouse at Stockbridge. Sidney Howard's Pulitzer Prize play, "They Knew What They Wanted," will be given the first week, with Miss June Walker as the star.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 4. -- After five-days of marksmanship firing at Camp Smith, the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn, commanded by Colonel Frank C. Vincent, and the 105th Infantry of Troy, commanded by Colonel Bernard W. Kearney, are having a rest that extends to Monday when they begin a hard week of field manoeuvres.
The staccato beat of the riveter's hammer in various parts of Manhattan is heralding a broad upturn in building operations throughout the city.
MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. -- With hotels reporting the heaviest bookings since 1929 and Summer householders here to remain until after Labor Day, this island is settling down into its Summer routine.

NEW YORK'S waterfront offers the incoming ocean traveler the most striking of contrasts. There is, first of all, the enchanting view from a distance; coming closer, there are few sightseers who do not remark that lower Manhattan is a stupendous fabric. A glance at the East River shows that it is potentially one of the most interesting and picturesque great waterways in the world.

DO you know where, or what, Padre is? No? Well, Dorothy Childs Hogner and her husband had a slight advantage over you: they knew that Padre was a long, narrow island in the Gulf of Mexico, politically a part of Texas and almost but apparently not quite uninhabited.

CLEVELAND, July 4. -- Cheers for the Communist party and more than a few boos for the Republican party marked the response tonight of the American Youth Congress to five speakers who discussed the programs of the Democratic, Republican, Socialist, Communist and Farmer-Labor parties for youth in particular and the country in general.

BOSTON, July 3. -- The formal announcement by former Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire of his intention to try to recapture his old seat in the upper house in Washington was no surprise to his friends and anything but startling to the public.

HARTFORD, July 4. -- With the national conventions past and lines tightening for the campaign clash in Connecticut, admittedly a doubtful State this year, trouble has broken out in the powerful Republican organization of Fairfield County, peopled to a large extent by New York and Westchester business and professional men and women.
BOSTON, July 4 (AP). -- Tom Yawkey's Red Sox came out of a seven-game losing streak today and whipped the faltering Philadelphia Athletics twice before a holiday crowd of 25,000 by 1 to 0 and 5 to 4.

THE current week at the Stadium promises its audiences a wide variety of programs and features. Beginning tomorrow evening with the appearance of John Charles Thomas as soloist under Iturbi, other events will include the introduction to the Stadium of Paul Kerby, British conductor, who will direct the orchestra for one week, and an all-Gershwin program, under the baton of Alexander Smallens, The day and Friday nights.

The only swimming pool in the city with any discontented people in it yesterday was the one being built by the Park Department and the Works Progress Administration at 173d Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
New York was a subdued and orderly city yesterday.

PARIS, July 4. -- In a single session that lasted twenty-six hours, the Chamber of Deputies today completed with a vote of 357 to 215 passage of the bill proposed by the government, setting up a board to fix and control the price of wheat.

Nothing has impressed me more in this New Turkey that I am revisiting than the peace attitude of Mustapha Kemal Ataturk, President of the Turkish Republic. It is the more remarkable in that the Ottoman Empire was always a militant empire and that Ataturk himself was for years a general and finally the Ghazi, or Conqueror.
CHICAGO, July 4. -- Discovery, carrying the crushing burden of 138 pounds on his back, discovered today that the racing world must be against him.

BY one of the queerest of all twists of political fortune Sir Samuel Hoare is back in high office, only six months or so after he was driven from the Cabinet by an unprecedented revolt of public opinion. He is happy to feel power in his delicate hands again. He was miserable in retirement and was frank to admit it.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is formulating policies to deal with "unlisted" trading in securities on the stock exchanges under provisions of the Securities Exchange Act, as amended in the last session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Wisconsin, the first State to pass an Unemployment Compensation Law, is now making history by swinging into the period when its law, covering 400,000 workers, becomes actively effective in giving unemployment benefits, ranging from $5 to $15 a week, to men and women losing their jobs.

In the hope that Governor Lehman will clear District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of the charges growing out of the Drukman case on which his removal is sought, the Brooklyn Democratic organization was authoritatively reported yesterday to be willing -- even eager -- to relinquish more than $50,000 a year in political patronage from the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

EXPERIMENTS in providing the youthful musician with an opportunity to obtain experience in his art are always being discussed. One of the most interesting is that supposedly under consideration in San Francisco. Pierre Monteux, permanent conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, plans "to organize an amateur orchestra, which he himself will conduct, to be a supplement and possible feeder to the major body."
BISLEY, England, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- Services Week, in which the army, the navy and the marines compete, ended today at the Bisley ranges in bright sunshine after a week of rain.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, as an organization Democrat, frequently has taken political issue with Mayor La Guardia; but last week he was very sweet to him. The Mayor had flattered Mr. Lyons's borough pride by establishing the Summer City Hall in the Bronx.
MONTICELLO, Va., July 4. -- The text of President Roosevelt's Independence Day address today at the home of Thomas Jefferson follows:

Politically speaking, the nation went "back to normalcy" last week. Here and there, to be sure, party functionaries made their plans and kept up their refrain. Democrats insisted this was their year; Republicans claimed all forty-eight States. The country, however, comfortably forgot conventions and politics and looked out-of-doors, hoping for good weather over the holiday week-end.

DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H. -- In this White Mountain resort the activities for the coming week are all "firsts." Leading the procession of events is a duplicate bridge tournament, under the direction of Mrs. Robert Englar, scheduled for tomorrow evening. For Thursday Mrs. Englar is arranging the first of a series of morning bridge parties.

IN a few months we Americans shall have to cast our ballots in one of the most fateful elections for President that the nation has ever held. Men and measures will, as usual, be widely discussed, and this time there will be the deep note of constitutional questions which sounds only at the more serious moments of our national life.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 3. -- The State Government, under Miss Elaine W. Sheffler, superintendent of the division of minimum wage in the Department of Industrial Relations, is seeking to go ahead with its minimum wage law enforcement despite the decision of the Supreme Court in the New York case.

Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, told this writer in a recent interview that the army intended to continue as a powerful factor in Cuban life, but that it had resumed and would remain in its constitutional function as an executive arm of the new President of Cuba, Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez.

HITHERTO given but scant attention by psychologists, the "lookee" instinct has for the first time received important recognition and detailed treatment on the screen in a recently completed motion picture. And "scopephilia," the term which the director responsible for the picture has chosen to ascribe to that particular human failing, has received the approval of Dr. Frank H. Vizetelly, noted philologist.
Detailed plans for the administration of old-age pensions in conformity with the Federal old-age security program and recent State law were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

JOHANNESBURG. THE discovery of the egg of an aepyornis in a lumber room here is an interesting reminder of the curious birds which used to exist in Madagascar and the islands of Mauritius, Rodriguez and Reunion long ago.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4. -- Two-thirds of the 1,700 boys paroled from the Newark City Home between 1915 and 1930 have not been arrested in adult life and about the same proportion have succeeded in their work, according to Commissioner Pearce R. Franklin, Director of Public Works here, who is making public a series of reports on an investigation of the careers of the 1,700 youths.
OMAHA, Neb., July 8. -- The drought has been creeping up on the Corn Belt too close for comfort.

To enlarge the educational scope of its work and also to offer a set of concerts for the benefit of its scholarship fund, the National Orchestral Association will present a concerto series next season with Myra Hess and Rudolf Serkin, pianists, as soloists.

Business continued to wrestle with the provisions of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act last week, but made little headway in the solution of the problems which the act created. So much was this the case that one important group voted to request the aid of the Federal Trade Commission for specific interpretations.

OSLO, Norway, July 4 (AP). -- More than 3,000 delegates from sixty countries, including many world leaders in religious education, will attend the twelfth World's Sunday School Convention, opening here Monday.

BACK from Europe came Max Gordon the other day, and at least one result of his journey would seem to be a sea change in his schedule for next season. It is thinner. He wouldn't actually say that this, that and the other show had leaped or fallen overboard.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP). -- A former opera singer and her chauffeur were charged by Kentucky authorities today with the slaying of her brother, Captain Harry R. Miller, retired Cincinnati fireman, and the dismembering of his body. The two, Miss Flora Miller, 66, and Herber L. Hicks, both of Cincinnati, are held in Indianapolis for questioning.

The share market experienced diminished trading and irregularity of price movements in the five-day business week. With several key industries threatened with labor difficulties, and with business generally pondering the new Federal Tax Law with misgivings, the buying of stocks continues to be selective despite the otherwise optimistic business outlook.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 4. -- The chestnut mare, Winning Ways, today topped all her previous performances by winning the championship in the three-gaited saddle division for horses not exceeding 15.2 hands, and then going on to capture the grand championship for all saddle horses, in the final event of the thirteenth annual Fairfield County Horse Show.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS W. Va. -- There is to be a shoot at the Greenbrier Skeet and Trap Club this morning, staged by Carl Bradsher, internationally known marksman, who is director of this club. Among outstanding participants in this shoot are Mrs. George W. Crawford of New York and Pittsburgh and Mr. and Mrs. Chauncer Clark Woodworth of Palm Beach, Fla.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 4. -- By Request, the Trillora Farm's aged chestnut gelding, always a capable performer in the ring, came through with several splendid exhibitions today to carry off the major honors in the jumping division at the second day's competition of the Long Branch horse show.
The Red Queen looked up from her morning paper in a happy frame of mind.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- A dinner dance at the Maidstone Club tonight marked the opening of the Summer series of Saturday dances. Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Sutphen gave a dinner for their house guests, Admiral and Mrs. William H. Stanley and Admiral and Mrs. Emory L. Land.

FOR nearly three centuries wild ponies have roamed the pine woods and salty marshes of Chincoteague Island, off the Virginia Coast, and each year the islanders round up these animals for sale and exchange. This annual event, which has been scheduled for July 30 this year, attracts visitors from several States on the Atlantic seaboard.

Real estate investors who are accustomed to talk of New York City property deals in terms of millions of dollars are mindful today that there will be an opportunity soon to become an owner of Manhattan land at an outlay of only a few hundred dollars.

THE commercial airlines have recently taken pains to convince the public that the near-stratosphere is an ideal place to play bridge. Pictures have been made showing interested participants in mile-high contract games, and the modern passenger plane is so designed as to leave space in the aisle for setting up a card table.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 4. -- The 1,300 young men who only two days ago reported here for a month of army life in the 1936 Citizens Military Training Camp were urged this morning, in a colorful ceremony marked by the taking of the C.M.T.C. oath, to dedicate their lives to the perpetuation of the ideals contained in the Declaration of Independence.

A manifesto has been issued from London, signed by H.G. Wells, Virginia Woolf, Stefan Zweig, Thomas Mann, Romain Rolland and Jules Romain, assigning to Sigmund Freud the credit of being the pioneer, for two generations, in exploring the hitherto unknown regions of the mind, and asserting that the most memorable achievement of our generation will be the psychological one of Freud.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Hundreds of families, victims of the devastating drought in the West and Midwest, will be added to the large numbers already under government care as a result of previous similar disasters, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, predicted today in connection with a survey of relief conditions in the stricken areas.

FARGO, N.D., July 4 (AP). -- William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, in an address before a Fargo Townsend club picnic here today demanded an "honest and intelligent" old-age pension and termed the Townsend organization the "greatest and most patriotic in America."

Now that the season is here to tramp or travel on wheels or wings, let us warn Governors and Mayors who boast of beaches and mountains that those who visit them cannot live by scenery alone but must be well fed. A restaurant makes or breaks a tourist town. Quick communication now spreads the news of a good dinner many miles in several directions before its influence has passed.

ONE of the interesting results of the flight back to the land of which the last decade has grown very conscious is that when a brain-worker, interested primarily in things of the intellect, turns to the country there comes about a radical change in his attitude toward life, his ways of thinking and feeling about the world and mankind, his concepts of God and the universe.

In fair weather or foul, that coterie of metropolitan skippers who have been plowing down the Sound every July for the annual motor-boat championship race to Block Island will perform this annual feat next Saturday. Entries will close tomorrow with Chairman F.W. Horenburger of the New York Athletic Club's yachting department for this twenty-seventh annual event, certainly the most exacting of any of the power cruiser events held on the Atlantic seaboard.

BUENOS AIRES, July 3. -- Argentina assumed a leading position in world affairs this week by formally requesting that the League of Nations apply an American principle to all world problems, and more particularly to the problem that has arisen from the Italian annexation of Ethiopia.

SEEKING "to ascertain what are the outstanding sources of traffic noise on First Avenue," the Noise Abatement Committee of the First Avenue Association, headed by Clyde R. Place, recently conducted a survey and found that "trucks equipped with solid tires and with chain-drive equipment lead as noise creators."

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 4. -- The Cabinet resigned today and, as forecast yesterday, Premier George Kosseivanoff promptly formed a new Ministry to prepare the way for a return to constitutional government. His new list follows:

HOLLYWOOD. THEORETICALLY the 1936-37 season is a seller's year on the screen. With 661 major features on the local schedule, according to Variety's compilation (an increase of sixty-one over last year and a new all-time high), the demand for rare players with box-office appeal should be greater than the supply.

GENEVA, July 4. -- The League of Nations, in what was to all intents a race against time to free its delegates for Sunday and to cut its losses in the Italo-Ethiopian conflict, left Ethiopia to its fate and wound up both its Assembly and its Council sessions tonight.

HIS VISIT OVER: In December it seemed that Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, Japanese Christian labor leader, would not be allowed to enter the United States for a lecture tour. He was afflicted with trachoma, a communicable disease of the eyes.

A 7-year-old boy and a 44-year-old woman were trampled upon and slightly hurt about 8 o'clock last night when eighty passengers returning to their homes after spending the holiday at Coney Island stampeded on a trolley car in Brooklyn because of a fire scare growing out of a short circuit.

Volume of business equivalent to the annual sales volume of 208 average retail liquor stores has been restored to dealers in the metropolitan district by repeal of the Tariff Act clause permitting American tourists to bring up to $100 worth of liquor into the United States duty free, John J. Connolly, secretary of the National Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributors, Inc., asserted here yesterday.

Although the Advertising Federation of America convention in Boson last week started out with "Truth-in-Advertising" as its theme, unconsciously the urgency for American industry to resell itself to the people through a broad-scale advertising campaign on its many achievements became the dominating topic at most of the sessions, those attending the meetings agreed here yesterday.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., July 4. -- Holding it impossible to gain in college an adequate knowledge in any special field, Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology, predicted that in the future undergraduate engineering education would take the form of a single curriculum in general engineering.

SMALL stature and dark hair; a subtle smile and eyes that narrow at the outer ends; a quiet manner and a face as impassive as an Oriental's -- these belong to Mme. Alix. A few years ago she was unknown; today she is rated a great designer.

Gardnar Mulloy, junior at the University of Miami, annexed the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship yesterday at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, defeating George B. Dunn of the University of Pennsylvania in straight sets.

Local commodity futures markets were generally buoyant in the week ended on July 3, although silk, hides and wooltops lost ground moderately. The best gains appeared in coffee, rubber and cottonseed oil. In the cash markets all the grains, cotton and rubber made new high records. Gains were scored by print cloths, lard, flour, butter, eggs, pork, tins and Santos coffee. Declines appeared in hides, wooltops, antimony and silk.

Alfredo Valenti, stage director of the opera department of the Juilliard Graduate School, is artistic director of a series of six operas at Chautauqua, N.Y., this Summer, including "The Gondoliers," "Faust," "The Bohemian Girl," "Carmen," "Pirates of Penzance" and "Merry Wives of Windsor." Georges Barrere will conduct a series of symphony concerts there.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, July 4. -- The 135th anniversary of the birth of Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, hero at the Civil War battle of Mobile Bay, was observed today at Hastings when 3,500 persons participated in a joint celebration of Farragut Day and the Fourth of July.
PARIS, July 4. -- The Fourth of July was celebrated in Paris today by many ceremonies and with unusually close collaboration of French circles.

Support for the adoption of a new Declaration of Independence against "judicial tyranny and industrial autocracy" was asked by Dr. Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor and his party's State Chairman, at a rally yesterday in Union Square.

TOPEKA, July 4 (AP). -- Kansas legislators converged on Topeka tonight, called into special session by Governor Landon to consider a State Constitution amendment which would open the way for participation in major phases of the Federal Social Security program.
MADRID, July 4 (AP). -- All Spanish airports were placed under heavy guard today after receipt of confidential information that large sums of money were being shipped abroad clandestinely by air.

ABOUT three months ago a young Swedish tenor, Jussy Bjorling, came out of the nowhere and gave a recital in the little hall of the Musikverein. Those who expected just another bird of passage were rather astonished to read a day or two later a series of newspaper reviews that, for all reservations, had a swollen and empurpled aspect.
WASHINGTON, July 4. -- One of the Capital's largest baseball crowds of all time turned out today to get its first view of our stoical but none the less magical Joe DiMaggio.

Headed by Frank Bowden, a field of sixty-four players started in quest of the Queens County clay court tennis singles championship at the Seminole Club of Forest Hills yesterday. The former Columbian won his first-round match by default from William Adler of Forest Hills and will oppose Howard Marshall today.
PARIS, July 4. -- Workers threatened today to take over a candy factory on the fortieth day of the nation-wide strike movement involving more than 1,000,000 Frenchmen.

SYDNEY, Australia. CHAMOIS goats introduced to New Zealand thirty or forty years ago have become such pest and threat to the farmers living along the range of mountains known as the Southern Alps that the government has lifted its protection and is organizing parties of skilled hunters to shoot down every chamois that can be brought within rifle range.

ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.J., July 4. -- Ninety-nine yachts in ten classes sailed off the Island Heights Yacht Club today in the fortieth annual Fourth of July regatta, establishing an all-time record for entries for so early in the season. The events were the second in the championship series of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

With a few modern variations and some minor restrictions Americans everywhere yesterday celebrated the Fourth of July in accord with the counsel of John Adams, who many years ago urged them to show their love of independence with "parades and illuminations."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A varied program is offered for the entertainment of the host of visitors here for the holiday period. Theatricals of every kind, from opera to burlesque and including vaudeville featuring radio, stage and screen stars, can be enjoyed at the many amusement places along the Boardwalk.

Retail and wholesale stocks are in good shape and, although there are the usual season-end accumulations in some markets, no surplus of wanted merchandise exists, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Corporation and employe gifts continued yesterday to carry forward the effort of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee to fill its quota of $1,500,000. The committee's campaign, which was scheduled to end June 17, is being extended until the full amount is raised.

THIS is the story of an American town, Texas style. Out in New Hope, Deliverance County, in the days when electricity was a matter of wonder and a fringed-top surrey a matter of pride, all the skeletons were carefully locked in the local closets.
Some important dividend meetings set for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 4. -- The Fourth of July crowd's biggest cheer today came when Chief Justice del Toro, concluding his speech, asserted that no greater independence is obtainable than Puerto Rico enjoys under the American flag. Seemingly, it was an improvised statement following the reading of his set speech, but the crowd, eager to demonstrate against the independence activities of separatists, shouted and clapped as the Chief Justice turned from the microphone.

IN the growing educational life of Summer camps the library is assuming an influential role. Amid healthful rural surroundings, far from restless pavements, city children who at home showed themselves slow-witted or backward, with little interest in printed pages, turn to books with surprising relish and understanding.

BATON ROUGE, July 4 (AP). -- A turbulent session of the Louisiana Senate reminiscent of the political reign of the late Senator Long passed an act today reducing from 5 cents per barrels to 1 cent the State oil refining tax.
BAR HARBOR, Me. -- Many of the social colony will attend the first Bar Harbor Club Sunday evening buffet supper tonight, an event looked upon by many as the formal opening of the season.
TROY, N.Y., July 4. -- "Uncle Sam," the traditional figure used to symbolize the government, is to have a convention dedicated to his memory.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- America's Olympic diving team was strengthened by two capable performers today as Elbert Root of Detroit and Frank Kurtz of Los Angeles, finished first and second in the high board event of the final tryouts in the Lake Front Lagoon.

THE national balloon race, which was scheduled for any favorable day from Friday until sundown tonight at Denver, takes on a new importance this year with the revival of interest in this country in airships, due to the performance of the Hindenburg.

PACHUCA, Mexico, July 4. -- Arriving here this afternoon, fifty miles from the Mexican capital, the American and Mexican delegations marking the opening of the international highway, paused for a brief ceremony. Later they traveled on to the capital.
IT'S just about time -- the Fourth having come and gone -- to consider the new gadgets. Fresh trifles give one a brighter outlook on hot days.

FROM the beginning Kansas has been a State to which no one who knew anything about it could be indifferent. One might like it or resent it, admire it or deplore it, but one couldn't overlook it. It was and is a kind of touchstone for a certain sort of Americanism.

AT first glance one might not imagine that there was anything more than an antiquarian interest in a subject such as the allegorical love poetry of the Middle Ages; one might suppose that a study of this long-outmoded literary form had little more of living value to offer us than a study of the bones of the diplodocus.

NEEDLEWOMEN in all English-reading countries welcomed with joy this author's "Dictionary of Embroidery Stitches," and now they will be equally glad of this new book, which supplements and complements the previous work in highly satisfactory fashion.

THIS book, which will be of notable interest and value to all those whose duties include the teaching, the training, the care of handicapped children, had its origin in courses of lectures given by its author, who is Professor of Education and Psychology in the American University, Washington, during recent Summer sessions of the University of Colorado.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. -- Plans are going forward rapidly for Southampton's tercentenary celebration, which will be held on July 15 in conjunction with the Long Island tercentenary. Meetings of the various committees will be held this week, one of the important ones being scheduled for tomorrow night at the Town Hall.

Baseball's midsummer carnival, the all-star game, which, despite its brief existence, has grown in popular favor to rank second only to the world series, will be staged in Boston on Tuesday, when two picked teams, representing the cream of the American and National Leagues, clash in the fourth such contest.

The New York University Summer School will reach the season's registration peak this week. The opening of five additional educational units of the university is expected to increase the total attendance to about 7,000 students, increasing last year's enrollment figure by 800, according to Henry G. Arnsdorf, registrar of the university.

Converging upon Morningside Heights from virtually every State and from several foreign countries, more than 11,000 students, varying in age from 16 to 65, will have arrived by 4 P.M. tomorrow to enroll in the thirty-seventh Summer session of Columbia University, it was estimated yesterday by officials of the session.

LONDON. ON the strength of a comedy called "The Emperor of Make-Believe," by Madge Pemberton and Malcolm Morley, there is a temptation to write this week an essay on Hans Andersen, whose vain and vague love for Jenny Lind is here related, but the temptation shall be resisted, for the play, though harmlessly whimsical, cannot stand.
PARIS, July 3. -- During the past week French rentes have risen steadily, franc exchange has improved and gold has begun flowing back into the vaults of the Bank of France.

GENEVA, July 3. -- There is a disposition from afar to see in the present situation a new Europe mortified and chastened by successful Italian aggression and the menace of Germany's growing strength, and eager in consequence to reform itself lest it succumb before the new despotism.
WASHINGTON. -- More than 40,000 persons now are being rehabilitated by State agencies under the Federal Vocational Rehabilitation Act, recent reports to Washington reveal.

Any veteran of amateur theatricals knows how heavily the number of masculine roles outnumbers the feminine, generally in inverse proportion to the number of schoolgirls who hanker for the smell of grease paint and the heady excitement of footlights.

Closing a half-year period marked by substantial gains, both retail trade and manufacturing activity in the metropolitan area last week reflected confidence in further sales increases. Department store trade for the week was estimated to be about 15 per cent above the comparative 1935 period, with figures for the month of June expected to show an increase of 12 to 13 per cent. Retail advertising forged ahead as stores launched pre-holiday promotions.

FANS, to many of us moderns, are merely hot-weather conveniences -- electrically driven devices that stir up the air in homes, restaurants and subway trains. But to the collector the word "fan" usually suggests the dainty painted and carved accessories of the age of powder and patches, though he often includes in his collection fans decorated by modern artists who have chosen this creation of another century as a medium of expression for their art.

ALL too often, during the Summer season, there are periods when the garden abounds with annuals that seem harsh or spotty only because there is lacking a sufficient amount of the blending color of the sky. Blue has an ethereal quality which lifts and harmonizes the otherwise heavy yellows, pinks and reds.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were more diversified than in the preceding week and included many entire issues of securities now outstanding. The calls were principally for August. Those for July were mostly for small lots of municipal bonds. This month's total is now $660,766,000, compared with $304,058,000 in June and $442,438,000 in July, 1935, for corresponding dates.

THIS is beyond a doubt one of the most remarkable first novels produced by an American writer. It is also one of the best. I would go so far as to say that although it is not the equal in style or in artistic conception of such a first novel as Miss Roberts's "The Time of Man,"

Investigation of serious marine accidents involving loss of life will be taken from the hands of the local steamship inspectors by provision of the newly enacted Federal legislation. The new act is designed to revise several details of the government's activities in the field of steamship inspection.

MR. WARBURG has succeeded in writing a second book in the style of his "Hell Bent for Election" without seeming to repeat himself very much and without allowing his method of argument or his literary mannerisms to show conspicuous evidences of wear.

THE ancient art of puppetry -- a hobby which has enjoyed a continuous vogue since the early Greek and Roman days -- will enter a new phase this week when the nation's puppeteers, both professional and amateur, assemble in Detroit for the first American Puppetry Conference.

IN so far as the Germans are concerned, exploratory flight in the North Atlantic area will be made by the catapult-mother ship method, Otto Merkel, who arrived on the Hindenburg on her third trip and is now visiting New York, said last week.
The war of quotations from Jefferson now being waged so fiercely is a source of confusion to voters and of mingled irritation and amusement to students of history.
More than a half million Americans spent their holiday afternoon watching sports events yesterday and most of them devoted their time to baseball.

THE Twenties were for Polish literature an era of poetry. An eager, reborn people, busy creating a State, had no time for the building of monumental literary edifices and the creative artist was in no frame of mind for long and painful building.

CAPE MAY, N.J. -- Arrivals by train and private car in the last week have brought the population of this resort to almost mid-season density. Members of the cottage colony have arrived from Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York and other Eastern cities to open their Summer homes. City officials, hotel managers and realtors report a flood of inquiries for accommodations.

MORE than a hundred sculptors are represented in the collection gathered together by Mr. and Mrs. Archer Milton Huntington and installed at Brookgreen, in South Carolina. Brookgreen is a unique open-air museum, devoted not alone to sculpture, but also to flora and fauna.

IF the Philippines are to become independent under present conditions it will mean catastrophe for the islands, be of no benefit to the United States and remain an ineradicable blot on our statesmanship. Such, briefly, is the argument of Professor Kirk's expert and brilliant analysis, which cannot be too urgently recommended for study by all who are concerned with the matter.

OLD BRIDGE, N.J., July 4. -- A young couple returning from dance at the Wagon Wheel Inn here at 2 A.M. today was struck by an automobile on State Highway S-28 and killed instantly. The driver was arrested a short time later at his home. He had abandoned his car and fled after the accident, according to the police.

In the first six months of this year, Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday, the city's Law Department disposed of 1,770 negligence actions against the city, the largest number for such a period in the history of the department.

PATERSON, N.J., July 4. -- Announcements made this week, the climax of weeks of debate between silk dyers and their employers in North Jersey and New York State, indicate that the dyers' contract, expiring Aug. 31, will be renewed without recourse to strike. The pact now nearing its conclusion is the one which two years ago settled a strike which kept over 20,000 men and women out of the plants for several weeks.

PEIPING, July 4 (AP). -- James Lin, whose "East-meets-West" marriage to an American dime store salesgirl ended in divorce, is reported back in the good graces of his foster-father, Lin Sen, Chairman of the national government of of China, sometimes called the "President of China."

LOS ANGELES, July 3. -- The charge of radio politics was the basis of the latest chapter in the series of frequent conflicts here between Aimee Semple McPherson, pastor of Angelus Temple, and her assistant pastor, Rheba Crawford, better known as the "Angel of Broadway."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. -- Entering the July season, this resort finds an influx of visitors far in advance of other Summers. All units of Saratoga Spa will be open by tomorrow, when the west section of Roosevelt Baths, named for the President in recognition of his interest in the development of the spa, and the second wing of the Lincoln baths will go into use.

A "safe and sane" observance of the holiday, in which patriotic addresses, elementary economics, flag salutes and athletic contests were substituted for the erstwhile cannon-crackers and torpedoes, preoccupied several score children in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx yesterday.

WHILE the oratory, band music and bedlam of the national political conventions are rushing off into the emptiness of space toward other planets, the broadcasters who electrified the air are now discovering what the inhabitants of the earth thought about it all.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sunday, July 5. -- Fifteen years after the most sensational convention in its history the Zionist Organization of America was still holding deliberations at 12:15 this morning after opening its thirty-ninth annual meeting under circumstances as dramatic as those at the Cleveland gathering, from which Louis D. Brandels, Julian W. Mack and Stephen S. Wise bolted with a defeated minority.

IT used to be the fashion in certain circles to insist that Negro folk sources would provide the material for the authentic American masterpieces that were yet to be born. At best a sectarian notion, the theory has lost prestige and currency.

VIENNA, July 4. -- What has happened, Austria is asking, to have turned its usually loquacious Chancellor into a sphinx? Although usually a ready speechmaker, for several weeks he has been shunning all publicity.

THE repercussions of the Matteotti affair in the Spring of 1924 caused the ex-Premiers Giolitti, Orlando and Salandra to forget their mutual antagonisms and to form an Opposition at Montecitorio which they believed would overthrow Mussolini.

LONDON, July 4. -- Independence Day was celebrated here with an American Society dinner and ball at the Dorchester Hotel tonight. Ambassador Robert W. Bingham, who presided, stressed the need of Anglo-American friendship as a means of preserving world peace.

In the recent Federal theatre production "Triple A Plowed Under," which told the story of American agriculture since the war, one of the most dramatic effects was obtained in the scene describing the great Western drought of 1934. With a crescendo of repetition, a voice intoned that usually pleasing weather report: "Fair and warmer. Fair and warmer. Fair and warmer * * *."
DENVER, July 5 (AP). -- All entrants in the annual national balloon race which began here last night were reported landed tonight without getting outside Colorado.

After some exceedingly dull preliminary chapters, Mr. Phillpotts gets around to stating his problem, that of a police-inspector who is accused of murdering his son-in-law. The evidence against him is convincing to every one excepting his daughter, his immediate subordinates and his immediate superiors.
The seventh annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties will be staged July 20-22 at the Century Country Club.

The Shipping Board published yesterday a set of agreements affecting the operations of ships of the International Mercantile Marine Company and the combined Hamburg American-North German Lloyd Lines. Three agreements are ordered canceled and three new ones replace them.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Steel production in the current week has been at the highest rate of the year to date, the Department of Commerce reported today, on the basis of schedules announced by the Iron and Steel Institute. The Institute estimated the rate of production at 74 per cent of capacity, the department said in its weekly business survey.

PARIS, June 24. -- Americans are not the least assiduous among the many visitors to the exhibition of the Vine and Wine in Art, which will continue to be on view at the Musee des Arts Decoratifs, on the Rue de Rivoli side of the Louvre, until the end of July.

Bronzed by the sun and wind, 600 Czechoslovak athletes -- men, women, boys and girls from twenty cities in the United States -- competed in a series of gymnastic contests yesterday on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, bringing the two-day athletic competition of the Czechoslovak Sokol Union of the United States to a close and preparing for the mass demonstration which the union will present this afternoon in Madison Square Garden.

THIS is a book written by a scholar for scholars; it belongs properly to that vast and ever-growing department of literature known as Johnsoniana. The cornucopian exuberance of Dr. Johnson, as we all know, left scarcely a literary figure of his age untouched, godfathering many an idea begotten by contemporaries under the aegis of his abundant shadow.

Irrespective of which party wins the election, it is certain that in June, 1937, the Treasury will find the accounts short on the year's operations to the extent of at least $2,700,000,000, and possibly $4,000,000,000 or $5,000,000,000. This is the opinion of R.M. HAIG, Professor of Economics at Columbia, who has acted as a tax expert for numerous public bodies, including New York City and the Federal Treasury.

COMMERCIAL car and truck makers are well on their way to the most prosperous year in their history. Domestic retail sales for the first half of 1936 are close to 300,000 units, whereas in 1929 they were only 263,192 units.

DETROIT, Mich., July 3. -- The decision of Governor Lehman to run once more for Governor of New York is a tremendous temptation for Frank Murphy, High Commissioner of the Philippines and former Mayor of Detroit, to make a similar sacrifice for the Roosevelt administration and enter the race this Fall for the Governorship of Michigan.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 4. -- The Tabor Academy eight captured the Thames Challenge Cup in an all-American final with the Kent School crew today. The Massachusetts oarsmen won by four lengths in 7:44 in the Henley Regatta.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 4. -- To amend the Constitution would simply substitute new uncertainties for the present ones, whereas the true remedy is to change the attitude of the Supreme Court, Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, declared here today.

TO the thousands of American motorists planning trips into the Southern Republic over the Mexican Highway, officially opened last Wednesday, a few practical suggestions may be offered that might make their journeys more safe or pleasant.

Fresh-water anglers who seek the spots "way back beyond" to pursue their sport will tell you that Newfoundland is a good place to visit. The island at the mouth of the Gulf of St. Lawrence, a British possession but not part of the Dominion of Canada, is not as highly publicized as some of the provinces, but there are few places in the East that offer better salmon and trout fishing.

THE prairies are again face to face with a crisis. The record droughts of 1894, 1901, 1930, 1934 and now of 1936 raise questions that perplex farmers and meteorologists alike. What is the cause of these dry periods? Is the climate of the plains changing?

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP). -- The Browns and Tigers pounded out fifty-nine hits as they split a double header, the world champions taking the first 8 -- 3 and the eighth-place Browns the second, 13 -- 10. A crowd of 10,000 saw the holiday contests.

ST. PAUL, July 4. -- The severity of drought in the Northwest, worse in many localities than that of 1934, was emphasized today with the disclosure of Federal plans to provide emergency employment relief to heads of about 45,000 farm families in the Dakotas, Minnesota, Montana and Wyoming.

PLANS have recently been made to preserve the Tennessee log cabin in which Sam Houston once taught school. Texas sought to buy the old building as a monument to the man who led its successful fight for independence 100 years ago.

THE Allgemeiner Deutsche Musikverein recently celebrated its seventy-fifth anniversary with a conference at Weimar, the city where it was founded. The meeting was ushered in with a performance of Peter Cornelius's "Barber of Bagdad" at the German National Theatre and a Liszt festival in the City Church.

IF the phrase "white-collar worker" had been used in 1873 or 1893 it would have been listened to with a blank stare. Just before the World War and during the boom of the Nineteen Twenties it would have suggested a man whose pride led him to prefer a low-paid office position to a job carrying higher pay which would require him to wear overalls.

THERE is, of course, no use in trying to change the persistent delusions about history. It is useless, for instance, to attempt medication on the brain disease which makes Lafayette and not Rochambeau the great figure of the French aid to America in the Revolution; that particular mania became fixed in the lifetime of both and is as eternal as the hills.

PITTSBURGH, July 4. -- Industrial unionism sounded a demand for "recognition of the steel workers' constitutional and civil rights" tonight on the eve of two rallies heralding labor's "big push" to organize the half million men who work in the mills.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The seventeen resort colonies on the thirty-six miles of shore line here are crowded with holiday visitors, indicating a busy Summer season ahead.

IT would be idle to pretend that the International Congress of Publishers, now meeting in London for the first time since 1899, has made any great stir in the British metropolis. Indeed, a certain convention that was simultaneously being held in the far distant State of Ohio aroused greater attention in our daily press.

"Distribution and Public Relations" will be the theme of the eighth Boston Conference on Distribution, to be held Sept. 28 and 29 at the Hotel Statler, according to announcement yesterday by Daniel Bloomfield, director.

The Prospect Park Zoo, which observed its first anniversary yesterday. with its fifty-six birds and 131 animals, has grown in one year to be one of the foremost zoos in the world. About 2,200,000 persons have visited it since that opening day when former Governor Alfred E. Smith made an appeal to the nation for funds and animals.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 4 -- The $1,000 peace scholarship for study in Geneva, awarded annually by the American Federation of Women's Clubs in Europe, has been granted this year to Mrs. Dwight Ingersoll Chapman of Somerville, Mass.

On June 26, 1935, President Roosevelt signed an executive order creating the National Youth Administration and obligated this government to a new and deeper concern for the economic welfare of its young people. One year later almost to the day -- June 23, 1936 -- he placed his signature on a bill carrying an appropriation for the NYA in 1937 which exceeded by nearly one-third that for the year preceding.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP). -- Woody Jensen's triple with the bases filled climaxed a four-run Pirate uprising in the eighth inning in the second game today to give Pittsburgh a 7 -- 4 victory over the Cubs. The Cubs won the ten-inning opener, 3 -- 2, before 33,000 spectators.

IT is a mistake to believe that nothing but pulpwood is being cut in the forests of Maine. True, the days are gone when the Penobscot, the Kennebec and the Androscoggin Rivers were packed bank to bank in the Spring with the long logs that lumberjacks had chopped during the Winter months.
LONDON, July 4. -- King Edward VIII may don the crown of England next May with a second cousin kneeling at his side.

VIOLATING Formula No. 1, Laurence Olivier, hero of the London film "I Stand Condemned," entered upon a stage career with the express permission, and even at the suggestion of, his parents. Shattering Precedent No. 2, Olivier's pathway to stardom was without interruption.

DETROIT, July 4 (AP). -- W.C. Stroube's Croon, 5-year-old mare, won the $3,000 Liberty Handicap, last of three feature races on today's closing program for the Detroit Spring meeting. Billy Bee was second, a half length back, and Whisking was third.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Moonlight motor trips to the summit of Mount Whiteface, via the new Memorial Highway, will take their place this week in the list of events contributing to the enjoyment of Summer in the heart of the Adirondacks.
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 4. -- Motor-less flight records of several classes fell here today as the seventh annual national soaring meet of the Soaring Society of America neared the close.

MOSCOW, July 3. -- Yet another incident has troubled Soviet-Japanese relations this week. For unexplained reasons a Japanese cavalry patrol of three troopers and an under-officer entered Soviet territory near the town of Manchuli, where they were promptly apprehended by a Soviet frontier guard.

TORONTO, Ont., July 4. -- With foreign capital now entering the Canadian mining field in volume and with new ore regions being opened and developed with unprecedented speed, the gold mining industry in the Dominion is in a decidedly healthy condition.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. -- The all junior horse show to be held this afternoon in the Cavalier riding ring will be an annual event, it was announced yesterday when plans to open the show to any child rider in America under the age of 19 were projected by the junior committee in charge.

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 4. -- In spite of the holiday, more than 100 men and women representing business, the professions, industry and agriculture arrived this afternoon to attend the two-week sessions of the Summer Institute for Social Progress at Wellesley through July 18.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 4. -- Three miles under the 2:10 standard were chalked up in the light-harness program staged by the Central New Jersey Horsemen's Association at the Borough Park track today. One was a 2:08 mile, which marked the victory in the third heat and second race of J.I. Lyle's veteran trotter Hollyrood Onward.

IT was a fine day at the Polo Grounds and a goodly throng was there. The Giants were at work on their bats with bottle and bone in the home dugout. Some players prefer the common or garden variety of pop bottle for the massaging of the bludgeons. Others call on their favorite butcher for a solid segment of beef bone for the pressure process.

Although there is no science in which the emphasis is laid upon the past so heavily as in geology and its related fields, the 22-year-old author of this book attacks his subject from a refreshingly contemporaneous point of view. He does not burden the 11-year-old reader with the weight of aeons of time, nor confuse him with the sequence of geologic periods.

Youthful track hopefuls of the metropolitan district gathered at Castle Hill Park in the Bronx yesterday for the annual novice meet sponsored by the Athetes Development Committee of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. Nine events were run off, seven for men and two for women.

Diana Johns, fashion and publicity authority, has been appointed by the Knitwear Institute as fashion director for the $100,000 promotional campaign on women's knitted apparel, Iser P. Cohen, chairman of the institute, announced yesterday. Mme. Juliet Bolegard, prominent in foreign style circles, will act as Paris correspondent and head of the foreign office of the institute.

THIS is really more of a shipnews story. It might also find itself among the "Travel and Resorts," vaguely -- and by inference -- among "Sports" or even more properly allied to the news of doings in the night spots. But the Summer is long and hot, and Broadway is drowsing in the shade.

SHANGHAI. -- After maintaining for several years one of the moat inefficient and vexatious news censorships on foreign cables existing anywhere, the Chinese Government has made such sweeping changes and reforms that today, in the area directly under Nanking's control, the system of censorship has become so centralized, intelligent and effective that causes for complaint are practically non-existent.

A young man was shot and killed by one of two Negro hold-up men in Central Park about 11 o'clock last night while walking with a young woman friend along a secluded lane at the northern end of the park. The thugs escaped. The victim, Salvatore Moreno, 21 years old, of 57 East 111th Street, was the third citizen to be murdered in a public place in the last two months.

THE study of Eastern art and Oriental rugs will continue to be given at the Metropolitan Museum through the Summer session of the Free Adult Education Schools. Illustrated lectures and laboratory work supplement the course; also, field trips to many private collections.

VLADIMIR HOROWITZ will return to the United States next season for a three-month tour of forty concerts, opening with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Dec. 31 and Jan. 1, under John Barbirolli. He will play the Tchaikovsky concerto, in which he made his American debut in 1928.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP). -- The season's most intense and widespread heat wave rolled over the Midwest today as the "critical period" for a major segment of the nation's food-producing acres neared its first week's end.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- A crew composed of Harvard oarsmen supplied the surprise of a grand rowing day on the Schuylkill as their four-oared shell with coxswain slid over the finish line a length and a half ahead of the University of Washington today.

THE usual pre-holiday spurt in retail sales was reported from most sections of the country for the week. Even in drought areas the partial relief afforded by rains quickened trade. Vacation requirements are being purchased in larger volume.

AT almost the same time that the New York Department of Public Markets completed its first survey showing the distribution of the local consumer's dollar in the fruit and vegetable industry, Congress provided for a national investigation into total consumer cost, represented by the proceeds received by farmers, manufacturers, processors, warehousemen, middlemen and distributors.

IF your neighbor on the 5:15 suddenly bursts forth into uncontrollable laughter don't pull the emergency cord and have him carted to the nearest observation ward. The chances are ten to one that he will have been reading "Uncommon Law," by that irrepressible Member of Parliament, A.P. Herbert, who wrote "Holy Deadlock."

CONTINUED threats of libel and defamation action in the courts have alarmed the cinema. RKO's "Marie Bashkirtseff" for Katharine Hepburn has been abandoned because the estate of the European figure has said that no matter how satisfactory the film, legal steps will be taken.
The holiday concert given at the Lewisohn Stadium last night by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Jose Iturbi, attracted an audience of 5,000.
RICHMOND, July 4. -- President Roosevelt embarked here today on his official yacht, the Potomac, for a week-end cruise, following a rapid tour of Central Virginia which he began yesterday morning.

The Giants and the Bees entertained a holiday crowd of 35,000 with a noisy fireworks demonstration yesterday at the Polo Grounds, but after the close to five hours of pyrotechnics through two games honors were divided.

A section of timberland in the Blue Ridge Mountains near the western tip of North Carolina will be dedicated on July 30 as the Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest in honor of the soldier-poet of the 165th Infantry, who was killed in the Battle of the Ourcq on that date in 1918.

Practically all of the ingredients that go into any sort of light fiction are included in the one Summer that Lissa Barclay agreed to give to Lex Carson to help him straighten out his newly inherited estate. When old Hetty Carson died her enormous but non-paying luxury farm on the Maine coast went to her nephew Lex.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP). -- Two rallies at Homestead and Chicago tomorrow will signal the start of what may be an epic campaign to unionize the vast steel industry -- a campaign that may help determine within the week whether the American Federation of Labor will be welded into one fighting unit or split in two.

THE genesis of Mr. Farrell's book may be found in a letter to The New Masses (of July 3, 1934) "Authors' Field Day, A Symposium of Marxist Criticism." Various class-conscious authors took the occasion to complain that they never had any criticism, Marxist or otherwise.

THIS comprehensive, scholarly volume, written in the objective, scientific spirit of the social philosopher, offers to the student of this subject, to those wanting extensive reformation upon some one of its phases or to any one desiring a work of reference, a rich harvest of world-wide and all-time study of the wanderings of mankind.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4. -- Carroll B. Alker's fifty-foot sloop Ibis showed the way today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's fifty-fifth annual regatta on Long Island Sound, in which 156 craft were checked as they crossed the starting line, Ibis defeated Herbert G. Hanan's Spartan by 1 minute and 11 seconds over a nineteen-mile course.

ALBANY, July 4 (AP). -- New Yorkers have 20 per cent fewer places today in which to quaff alcoholic beverages than a year ago, John B. Judson, chief executive officer of the State Liquor Authority, said tonight.

THE numerous commemorative concerts already held in various Italian cities in memory of the late Ottorino Respighi bear witness to the wide popularity enjoyed by the Bolognese composer in his home country. The most far-reaching of these was a vocal-symphonic program of his works broadcast recently from all Italian stations, conducted by Mule, Marinuzzi, Zandonai, Pizzetti and Mascagni; Mario Labroca read a critical appreciation during the intermission.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 4. -- The largest combined expedition to Newfoundland in the twenty-five years that Princeton geologists have been making investigations there will be sent out by the university this year for Summer research work, it was announced today by Professor Edward Sampson, chairman of the Geology Department.

IN 1912 Robert Esnault Peltrie read a paper before the French Physical Society on rocket motors and the possibility of reaching other worlds by their means. As a serious French aeronautical engineer, a man whose airplanes were internationally known for their speed and power, he had no desire to court ridicule.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4. -- The Fourth of July was celebrated tonight with fireworks in several sections. The most elaborate of the displays was at the Glen, where Mrs. Moses Taylor entertained several hundred guests in honor of her son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Taylor.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 4. -- The national indoor champion and the national clay court and junior titleholder advanced to the final round of the invitation turf court tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club today.

MANY vacationists who formerly made annual pilgrimages to Europe are this year touring their own country. Never before has the prospective traveler been showered with so many elaborate pamphlets detailing the attractions of fast trains and planes, glistening buses, circle tours, wilderness camps, lake and river cruises.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 4. -- Clear skies, bright sunshine and a southerly 12-mile breeze marked the start of the 3,400-mile ocean race from Bermuda to Cuxhaven, Germany, today. A large fleet of Bermuda craft of many kinds and several American yachts watched the start from a line opposite the Fairway Buoy at the channel entrance off St. David's Head.

WINNIPEG, July 4. -- The incentive to take profits in wheat shaved fractions today from the high points of a week's advance in trading on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. The Independence Day holiday in the United States halted inter-market operations and the business was small.

WHEN the gods of applied science gave speech to the shadows of the screen, a few years ago, they furnished New York with another argument to buttress its boast of being the most cosmopolitan of all metropolises.

PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y., July 4. -- Fred Smith of Stamford sailed Epins to victory today as the Snipe Class took part in its first "ocean" race under the auspices of the Norwalk Yacht Club and the Port Jefferson Yacht Club.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Unprecedented advance reservations at the hotels here give indication of a Summer season surpassing any of recent years, provided weather conditions are favorable. The first of a series of feature nights on the Berkeley Carteret's Continental Terrace, where Hawaiian music will echo, is scheduled for next Saturday, when Queen Mary Night will be observed.

Is the 1936 London Naval Treaty to be weakened, perhaps jeopardized even, before it is due to come into effect Jan. 1, 1937? This question obtrudes itself because of two actions last week: the announcement that Great Britain would invoke the escalator clause of the 1930 naval treaty, in order to save its excess destroyer tonnage; and Japan's decision to refuse the invitation to adhere to the new treaty.

Backed by a group of leading manufacturers and wholesalers of nationally advertised drugs and toilet preparations, who have entered into contracts with retailers in this and other States where fair-trade laws are in effect, the New York State Pharmaceutical Association will open a new campaign this week on a broad scale to curb price-cutting in the industry.

ADMINISTER to rats both vitamin A and thyroxin (a hormone extracted from the thyroid glands which are buried in the neck) and the expected effect is not obtained. In other words there is no increase in body weight -- the usual result when vitamin A alone is administered.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 (AP). -- Keen to catch the drama of Miss Helen Jacobs's final success, the crowd out to see the last day's matches of the All-England tennis play released its pent-up emotions to give her probably the greatest and most whole-hearted ovation Wimbledon ever will know as the grueling match ended in victory for the girl who had tried so hard and so often to win England's classic title.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 3. -- National socialism seized upon the international ceremonies here this week in connection with the 550th anniversary of Germany's oldest university to bare its soul to the world.

KWEIHWA, Suiyan Province, China. -- The people of Inner Mongolia are waging a fight for political autonomy, hut unless another providential ally appears, like the Winter gales that drove out Chinese settlers during the Winter and saved the Mongols' grazing lands, it is more than possible that they will be submerged by one of the three forces now pressing in upon them.

THIS is the season for Cape Cod vacations and for Cape Cod novels. Sara Ware Bassett has written a particularly amiable one in "Eternal Deeps." The setting is Belleport again, with several of the village gossips and characters who figured in previous stories taking minor roles -- Lem and Becca Gill, Eben Snow and others.

SUCH an uninterestingly geometric thing as the "angle" is the basis of the box office, foundation of the films, capstone of the cinema. Occasionally one hears reference to them in Hollywood as "yangles," as in "We gotta get a coupla yangles for this one." O. Henry knew the value of angles.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Unprecedented advance reservations at the hotels here give indication of a Summer season surpassing any of recent years, provided weather conditions are favorable. The first of a series of feature nights on the Berkeley Carteret's Continental Terrace, where Hawaiian music will echo, is scheduled for next Saturday, when Queen Mary Night will be observed.

Is the 1936 London Naval Treaty to be weakened, perhaps jeopardized even, before it is due to come into effect Jan. 1, 1937? This question obtrudes itself because of two actions last week: the announcement that Great Britain would invoke the escalator clause of the 1930 naval treaty, in order to save its excess destroyer tonnage; and Japan's decision to refuse the invitation to adhere to the new treaty.

Backed by a group of leading manufacturers and wholesalers of nationally advertised drugs and toilet preparations, who have entered into contracts with retailers in this and other States where fair-trade laws are in effect, the New York State Pharmaceutical Association will open a new campaign this week on a broad scale to curb price-cutting in the industry.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 (AP). -- Keen to catch the drama of Miss Helen Jacobs's final success, the crowd out to see the last day's matches of the All-England tennis play released its pent-up emotions to give her probably the greatest and most whole-hearted ovation Wimbledon ever will know as the grueling match ended in victory for the girl who had tried so hard and so often to win England's classic title.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 3. -- National socialism seized upon the international ceremonies here this week in connection with the 550th anniversary of Germany's oldest university to bare its soul to the world.

KWEIHWA, Suiyan Province, China. -- The people of Inner Mongolia are waging a fight for political autonomy, hut unless another providential ally appears, like the Winter gales that drove out Chinese settlers during the Winter and saved the Mongols' grazing lands, it is more than possible that they will be submerged by one of the three forces now pressing in upon them.

THIS is the season for Cape Cod vacations and for Cape Cod novels. Sara Ware Bassett has written a particularly amiable one in "Eternal Deeps." The setting is Belleport again, with several of the village gossips and characters who figured in previous stories taking minor roles -- Lem and Becca Gill, Eben Snow and others.

SUCH an uninterestingly geometric thing as the "angle" is the basis of the box office, foundation of the films, capstone of the cinema. Occasionally one hears reference to them in Hollywood as "yangles," as in "We gotta get a coupla yangles for this one." O. Henry knew the value of angles.
BASKING on roofs is becoming increasingly popular in New York. Coats of tan are acquired without the aid of ocean beaches and ease is found on deck chairs far from the holystoned boards.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Summer activities will get under way in earnest in Burlington, on the eastern shore of Lake Champlain, with the opening of the University of Vermont Summer session tomorrow, bringing to the city a thousand visitors, many of whom take up residences on the lake shore.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 4. -- John D. Rockefeller Sr. will be 97 year old Wednesday, but it could not be learned what celebration, if any, is being planned in observance of the birthday.

PARIS, July 2. -- Color schemes were the most interesting features of the Grand Prix fashions. Violet-blue is forecast as a smart Fall accessory color. It looked charming with white, gray, brown or other shades of blue. Wine-red with beige, gray with rose were also notable.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- The supper dance tonight at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club attracted several hundred colonists and their guests. The driveways and grounds were illuminated and colored lights were used in the decorations of the terraces and ballroom.

THERE is good news for those who rate peaches and cream among the delectable Summer dishes. In most parts of the country where peaches are grown a bumper crop is in prospect, despite the severe Winter weather and the biting frosts of Spring.

THE irrepressible zanies who clutter up this cubicle of ours early in the week questing space in these columns for items of undoubted interest concerning one motion picture or another (they are particularly profuse now that our Mr. Nugent has departed for his annual respite) are, after all, likable chaps.

MANILA. -- With registration and drawing of the first class complete, the Philippines expects to have 40,000 men in training for military service by Jan. 1. This is the first contingent of the citizen army, under compulsory military service. It is chosen from young men who were born in 1916.

THE respective merits of various mulches for Summer use have long been a subject for argument. Paper mulches have a definite value, especially for a bank planting. Here they serve two purposees: that of a mulch and that of a safeguard for the planting.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The Republican campaign will be undertaken with vigor shortly after Governor Landon charts its course in his speech of acceptance. His first speech in the East will be made in his birthplace in Western Pennsylvania, after which he plans to invade New England for a brief tour, which will give him an opportunity to define the issues of special moment to the industrial and populous East.
BROCKTON, Mass., July 4. -- Father Coughlin today told a crowd estimated at 10,000 that "it sickens one to hear that the object of the government is to get men back to work."

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4. -- The hills and dales on the estate of Charles Arthur Moore, Round Hill, Greenwich, resounded today with the skirl of bagpipes and the voices of hundreds of Scottish lads and lassies, participating in the annual Cowal games held under the auspices of the Round Hill Scottish Games Association, Inc.

THE antique maple bedstead, a typically Colonial piece, can still be obtained at comparatively small cost. Fortunate is the owner of a fine example, for he finds it not only fits in with the present vogue for maple but gives a permanent air of distinction and individuality to a bedroom.

According to the report issued last week by the National Recreation Association, recreation facilities and the popular use of these facilities have more than doubled in the United States during the past ten years. Public bathing beaches, swimming pools, skating rinks, tennis courts, golf courses, playing fields of all kinds, have multiplied until now few communities are so small, poor or dull-minded that they do not provide opportunities for sports.

When at his best, as the author of Latin-American adventure tales, Mr. Scoggins is unrivaled, but in this novel he seems to be far off his top form and to have brought forth a mere noisy dud which starts out in grand style and fizzles to a weak conclusion.

VISITS to the Franklin exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum have made me feel that at last I know something, although but little, of Benjamin Franklin's elusive personality, heretofore escaping me whenever I thought I might have my finger on it.

TIPTON, Iowa, July 4. -- A fortune put at $112,000 in gold coin, gold and silver certificates and securities was discovered on a farm near Tipton, it was revealed today, and relatives of three aged bachelor farm owners, now dead, plan a second organized treasure hunt next week.
RICHMOND, July 4. -- The Virginia capital gave President and Mrs. Roosevelt a thunderous welcome today as they arrived from Monticello to board the Potomac.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 4. -- After five years in its modern building on wooded Mount Airy overlooking the Hudson, the Hessian Hills School, one of the outstanding experimental schools in the metropolitan area, has started a drive for funds with which to expand its present facilities.

The advantages of camp vacations for underprivileged children are outlined in a statement written by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, president of the Children's Welfare Federation, and made public yesterday by the federation.
