The organization is conducting a $1,650,000 drive in New York City to make it possible for 110,000 city children to attend this Summer 217 camps maintained by 142 organizations affiliated with the federation.

Bankers and brokers mingled on a common ground with mechanics and bricklayers yesterday, called each other by nicknames and spent a happy day as the Park Department opened for the tenth year the bowling green adjacent to the sheep meadow in Central Park.

In the two obedience tests that have been held to date under the new rules of the American Kennel Club, six dogs have been graduated from the novice class into the open class and are entitled to carry the suffix "C.D." after their names, signifying that they have completed the first tests and fulfilled the required conditions to have the right to the title of Companion Dog.
LONDON, July 3. -- Like many another good Socialist in this country, Herbert Morrison rages when he thinks of his comrades in concentration camps in Germany.

THE news of the issue of one more recording of Beethoven's Fifth will probably be greeted in some quarters with the usual recital of a long list of things that should have been accorded precedence over yet another version of the most recorded symphony.

Customs officials said yesterday that the arrival of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary at her pier at 7:30 A.M. tomorrow would mean a heavy task for them because other steamships were coming in at the same time and there were only 175 inspectors and five deputies available for the baggage examination.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 4. -- Washington, California, the New York Athletic Club and Pennsylvania will fight it out tomorrow for the right to represent the United States in the eight-oared rowing event at the Olympic Games.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP). -- The old Arch Street Theatre, linked with many names great on the American stage, is yielding to the urban demand for more space to park automobiles.

The long reign of the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York as metropolitan paddling champion came to an end yesterday on the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park as the Yonkers Canoe Club amassed a total of 61 points in seventeen events to annex the title for the first time.

A track and field meet that will, in many events, dwarf into insignificance the Olympic Games themselves will be staged in the new Randalls Island Stadium on Saturday and Sunday, when the final Olympic tryouts are conducted to determine what athletes will represent the United States next month at Berlin.

WITH increasing traffic on domestic airlines and with transpacific mail service being speeded up to a weekly basis this week and transatlantic plane service, at least of an experimental nature, now so imminent, the importance of uninterrupted schedules takes on new weight.

IN line with the tightening up of control of planes in the air, announced from Washington last week, appointment of a supervisor for airway traffic control, whose responsibility will be to provide for orderly and safe movement of airplanes along the Federal airways and in and out of major air terminals, was announced recently by Eugene L. Vidal, Director of Air Commerce.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- The issues in the steel industry labor controversy are being joined. The steel industry, through the American Iron and Steel Institute, has announced its unalterable opposition to the union campaign to organize its 500,000 employes.

IF all the European dancers who are announced for American tours next season actually get here, it will constitute a veritable hegira from the Old World. In the past, such advance schedules as these have proved more often than not to be what in polite language may be best termed tentative; however, here is the list as it now stands, and it may be taken for what it is worth.

THE attitude of many gardeners toward the time-consuming problem of watering is that of the Irishman who had a leaky roof which could not be fixed in rainy weather, and in dry weather did not need to be fixed.
NARRAGANSETT, R.I., July 4. -- Narragansett promises a gay season, with many new families here and most of the regular colonists returning.

The date of the annual Russian Students Ball, which is usually held after the Christmas holidays, has been advanced this year to Nov. 6. The event will take place in the grand ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. A Russian supper will be served in the Oval Restaurant and in the Palm Garden.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., July 4. -- George A. Brown, retired manufacturer, two relatives and a woman guest were robbed of $2,700 in cash and jewelry early today after being forced by two burglar bandits to help ransack the Brown home.
McRAE, Ga., July 4 (AP). -- Governor Eugene Talmadge, critic of the New Deal, became a candidate for the Senate today, declaring he wanted to go to Washington "to protect the nation."

PARIS. GLOVES and shoes play such an important part in the sartorial scheme this season that one is reminded of a saying of Napoleon Bonaparte: "I recognize breeding, hence veritable elegance, by the gloves and shoes. All the rest of one's dress is accessible to the efforts of imbeciles."

WEIMAR, Germany, July 4. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler assured a national assembly of National Socialist party functionaries from all parts of the Reich in a speech here today that they and their successors would retain unlimited authority in Germany for all time.

Before Empire City's largest and most distinguished crowd, form exploded in small pieces yesterday as favorite after favorite went down to defeat, including the three-ply Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt entry in the $9,525 Empire City Handicap where Esposa was the winner.

TRENTON, N.J., July 4. -- Driving his trim blue craft, the Shooting Star, at an average of 46.310 miles an hour, C. Mulford Scull of Ventnor City captured the five-mile free-for-all feature of the Trenton Yacht Club's annual Independence Day outboard regatta on the Delaware River today.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Apparently little progress will be made toward balancing the Federal Government's budget during the fiscal year which began last Wednesday, July 1. If there is to be an end to the Federal deficits which have continued unbroken for the past six fiscal years, that end is not definitely in sight.

Although it has taken her longer to achieve her goal, Miss Claudia Eckert of Chicago, or rather the Shawnee Country Club of Wilmette, Ill., to be exact, who replaced Miami's 12-year-old Mary Hoerger as national diving champion last week, began her aquatic career at almost as early an age as her predecessor.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4. -- A slashing backhand from Mrs. Hilda Krahwinkel Sperling's racquet at Miss Helen Jacobs's third-match point in the twelfth game of the third set crashed into the net. The American, who was poised there for a killer, made one exultant leap.

The movie industry is one of America's giants. Its capital investment is $1,750,000,000; each year it spends more than $110,000,000 on 6,000,000,000 feet of film which are seen in 13,750 theatres by a weekly audience of 80,000,000 persons, who pay $1,540,000,000 annually for their seats.

AS the Boy Scouts leave the towns and cities to rough it under canvas at Summer camps, their religious obligations are not neglected. Under the leadership of the various spiritual groups, they may worship at camp according to their faiths.

NEXT November for the first time in history the question of compulsory military training in American public schools and colleges is to come to popular vote. The referendum will take place in Oregon, where, largely through the efforts of college student peace workers, enough signatures have been obtained to an initiative petition to put the issue on the ballot.

The concerts scheduled at the Lewisohn Stadium this week promise to be of more than ordinary interest. Tonight John Charles Thomas will be the soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Jose Iturbi. The baritone will be heard in arias from Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" and Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera," to which will be added a song group.

WEST COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., July 5. -- Following the example of Presbyterian churches at Collingswood and Bridgeton, the elders of the West Collingswood Presbyterian Church barred from the pulpit today a minister from the West Jersey Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

J. Henry Smythe Jr., known in both Republican and Democratic camps as the man who looks decidedly like President Roosevelt and more decidedly opposes his reelection, took a walk for Governor All M. Landon yesterday.

GENEVA, July 5. -- The outstanding effect thus far of the threatening demand in the Council last night by the Nazi government of Danzig that the League of Nations disinterest itself in the Free City and leave it to Germany and Poland appears to be that it has distinctly shaken the Polish diplomatic position.

LONDON, July 3. -- One of the most interesting features in the current financial situation is the continuation of large purchases of gold by the Bank of England. In the last three weeks 13,245,000 of the metal has been bought, and since the beginning of the year the purchases have aggregated 21,636,000.

PARIS, July 4. -- The report of the Bank of France for June 26 shows an increase of 100,000.000 francs under the ordinary heading of bills discounted. The special item of "treasury bonds discounted" decreased 36,000,000 francs through the maturity of a block of these obligations.

Determined to press for the removal from office of William F.X. Geoghan, District Attorney of Kings County, Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the Drukman murder case investigation, will confer at the Executive Mansion in Albany with Governor Lehman at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 5. -- F. Thompson Brooks's Sue took today's contest for International Star Class sloops on the triangular course off the Seaside Park Yacht Club and as a result went into the point lead in the elimination series to select a Barnegat Bay entry for the world's championship.

Much interest has been paid to the Bank of England's large purchases of gold for the reserve against its note circulation. During the week covered by Thursday's statement 4,795,000 gold was added. The addition in the twelvemonth past has been 28,806,000; since January, 1933. when gold holdings stood at the lowest of the last three years, it has been 101,526,000.

Governor Landon was charged at the Philadelphia convention with having opposed Federal insurance of bank deposits. A little research develops that it is all too true. The Republican platform of 1932 pointed with alarm to the action of the House of Representatives with respect to the guarantee of bank deposits.

Praised by city and State officials as a force beneficial to building a perfect America, the four-day gymnastic festival of the American-Czechoslovak Sokol Union closed yesterday with an athletic rally at Madison Square Garden.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July . -- The time has come for the citizens "no longer to boast or to complain about this country, but to do some deep-root thinking about it," the Rev. Dr. John cDowell of New York, secretary of the committee on social and industrial relations of the Board of l'ational Altssi0ns of the Presbyterian Church, declared in an address here today.
From a political viewpoint, the Republic of Cuba stands at a turning point in history.

Staging a strong attack all the way, the Governors Island four found no need for a two-goal handicap in defeating the West Point Officers, 12-8, yesterday at Morris Memorial Field in an exciting match.

For a traditionally inactive Summer holiday week, last week's industrial performance gave a rather unusually good account of itself. Financial markets hardly stirred; but business activities moved ahead, steel output in particular rising to 71 1/2 per cent of capacity, the high mark of the period.

Again New York welcomes her Summer academic visitors -- so many thousands of them that together they would make a city of size. They come from every State, and even from other lands, chiefly teachers, but all looking to New York as the center and capital of the higher learning.
CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP). -- Steelworks operations, the magazine Steel said today, are expected to be resumed after yesterday's holiday at a rate "fairly close" to the high level of last week.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 5. -- Reserve and regular army chaplains on duty here with the Citizens Military Training Camp this morning called on 1,500 candidates and R.O.T.C. students, gathered under the pines, to resist radicalism as a "sister evil to pacifism."

BABYLON, L.I., July 5. -- Horace Havemeyer Sr., in Whistler, displayed his skill at sailing today when he defeated Edwin Thorne's fleet Star II, skippered by Eddie Fink, 1932 International Star world's champion by a scant second in the final Star race of the two-day invitation regatta at the Babylon Yacht Club.

Dwellers of the earth live "on an island" and their views and policies and those of "islanders," the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Fifty-sixth Street. He is the president of the Free Church Council of Great Britain and Wales and until recently was "pastor of the City Temple of London.

BERLIN, July 4. -- Good reports from the steel, engineering, electrical and automotive industries supported the Boerse this week. The announcement of a new 700,000,000- mark Reich loan depressed stocks at first, but this influence weakened later and the loan thereafter affected only the money market, on which a heavy demand was created, with a corresponding heavy expansion of Reichsbank credits.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Stronger bullish sentiment than has been apparent in the grain markets, and especially the wheat markets of the United States, Canada and in certain market centers of the leading wheat producing countries in the Southern Hemisphere, has created the most pronounced activity and rapid price changes that the trade has seen in a considerable time.

The Second, Third and Fourth National Investors Corporations, general management investment trusts, will report in statements to be issued today combined net assets of $39,017,022 on June 30 before reserves for taxes on unrealized profits, amounting to $1,732,000.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to 4,156,607,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

Under circumstances indicating that he may have been killed by a Stray bullet fired during a Fourth of July celebration, the body of Harold de Coursy, 35 years old, a WPA draftsman, was found early yesterday on the roof of his home at 1,909 Barnes Avenue, the Bronx.

No revision of the City Charter should restrict the power of the Board of Estimate over salaries of city employes by requiring a popular referendum on reductions of general salary scales, the Merchants Association declared yesterday in a letter to the Charter Revision Commission.

BRUSSELS, July 5. -- Captain Ernest Demuyter, noted Belgian balioonist, said in an interview at the Brussels Stadium this afternoon that an extensive study had been made by Belgian aviation authorities of the possibilities of a trans atlantic flight in a Gordon Bennett type of free balloon.

Delegations of citizens from all parts of the State will call on Governor Lehman at the Executive Mansion in Albany on July 15 to present a set of resolutions voicing their approval of his recent decision to seek a third term. The Governor will hold a reception for the delegates.

An upward trend in philanthropy, as measured by publicly announced gifts in New York and five other large cities during the first half of 1936, was reported yesterday by the John Price Jones Corporation, fund-raising consultants.
PORTSMOUTH, England, July 5. -- A new British air hub was in the making tonight while mechanics tuned up the first flying boat of a promised Atlantic fleet.

BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP). -- Newark closed its series with Baltimore by dividing today's double header, winning the first, 9 to 3, and dropping the nightcap, 5 to 2. Steve Sundra held the Orioles to nine hits in the first, while Pearce and Matuzak allowed the Bears the same number in the nightcap.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- Farmers are more disposed to sell their livestock because of the good prices, but the question of feed also is to be taken into consideration. This situation has led to liberal receipts at leading markets and made for an uneasy feeling.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- President Roosevelt may be faced upon his return tomorrow from a holiday trip to Virginia with making a decision as to whether the Federal Work Relief program is to be radically changed as a result of the spreading Western drought or whether purely emergency drought relief work is to be continued.

BOSTON, July 5 (AP). -- An eleven-run inning and some heavy slugging by the Red Sox delighted a crowd of 19,000 as Boston trounced Philadelphia today in a twin bill for the second time in two days. The scores were 16 to 2 and 8 to 2. The Athletics have lost twelve games in a row.

LENOX, Mass. July 5. -- Mrs. George K. Livermore was a luncheon hostess at Three Acres, Lenox, today. Dr. and Mrs. John Dodge Peters had a supper party for twenty-five tonight at Edgeholm, Great Barrington.

CINCINNATI, July 5 (AP). -- The Cardinals turned the tables on the Reds today, taking both ends of a double-header, 8 to 6 and 17 to 7, to climb back into the National League lead lost yesterday to the Cubs when Cincinnati won two. As a result, the Reds dropped from third to fourth place, only one percentage point ahead of the fifth-place Giants.

BERLIN, July 5. -- The press and the radio have united in a last nation-wide campaign to make every German a propagandist for the Third Reich in this Olympic Summer. The Nazi newspaper Angriff devotes its complete front page to an impassioned appeal to "every German citizen" to join the Summer's propaganda campaign.
PARIS, July 5. -- Demonstrations by Nationalists around the Arc de Triomphe, which have become nightly occurrences, tonight resulted in serious disorders in which more than 100 were injured.

LONDON, July 5. -- Representatives of the British army and air force will attend this year the great Autumn manoeuvres in Russia. This may be taken as an indication that although the two governments continue to differ on many points, relations are moving gradually toward a better understanding of their mutual points of view.

GENEVA, July 5. -- Sinister rumors regarding Italian activities and intentions in a newly acquired islet possession at the southern entrance of the Red Sea have aroused here among the exceedingly few cognizant of them forebodings only second to those caused by the conquest of Ethiopia.

Six-year-old Bernard Weiselberg believes his admiration for Wallace Beery should find expression in action. Thus yesterday afternoon at the annual field day of the Pride of Judea Children's Home, 992 Dumont Avenue, Brooklyn, the youngster displayed stamina enough to win a pie-eating contest and, at the same time, managed to pose half a dozen times for photographers.

With the majority of retail apparel buyers from out of town concentrating on their Fall requirements, the demand for Summer merchandise declined in the wholesale markets here last week. Pre-holiday re-orders for Summer wear produced some activity, however.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 5. -- A consistent winner during the first two days of the event, Miss Elsie B. Holdsworth of Seekonk, Mass., saw her string of horses conclude a highly successful campaign at the Long Branch Horse Show today.

A gold medal in recognition of thirty-eight years of safe driving was presented yesterday to Harold F. Bidwell of 41 Beacon Avenue, Jersey City. The presentation was made at Radio City and was broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP). -- As every President's wife is asked to do, Mrs. Roosevelt has presented a dress to the Smithsonian Institution.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP). -- The Phillies knocked Ray Benge out of the box in the second inning to score five runs and go on to an ultimate 7-to-6 triumph over the Bees today for their fifth victory in as many games.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 5. -- Governor and Mrs. Hoffman, with numerous guests, joined thousands of shore visitors who witnessed the first Sunday parade of the New Jersey troops encamped here at Camp Hoffman.

The Fourth of July was characterized as "not only a great American date but a shining date in the calendar of nations" by the Rev. Dr. Henry Prince of the faculty of Kings University, Halifax, N.S., who spoke yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street.
TRENTON, N.J., July 5. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin came here today and addressed than 1,200 officers of 400 New Jersey units of his National Union for Social Justice.

The movement of the foreign exchanges last week was a restricted affair, contrasted with the feverish trend in preceding weeks. Only a small amount of business was involved and this was chiefly of a routine character, the holiday here at the week-end limiting interest.
So the Sixth Avenue "L" is coming down! Well, I for one am filled with mingled emotions and a spot of foreboding. Have our noble city planners thought this thing through?

Total resources of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, New York, were $12,069,300 on June 30, against $11,116,697 on Dec. 31, 1935. Deposits were $10,092,277, compared with $9,243,574. Reserves were $179,873, against $108,002, and undivided profits $161,081, against $134,074.
BERLIN, July 5. -- Arthur Karl Greiser's speech in Geneva attacking the control of the League of Nations over the Free City of Danzig aroused enthusiasm in Berlin today.
BERLIN, July 4. -- Features of activity on the Boerse this week were the resumption of quotations on dollar bonds and heavy buying of colonial securities and overseas bank stocks.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 5. -- President Roosevelt closed a three-day visit to Virginia with a pilgrimmage to this Colonial State capital where he worshiped in old Bruton Parish Church, which was built originally as a combined house of worship and meeting place for the Assembly of the Colony of Virginia.

Gerard B. Podesta, 19-year-old University of North Carolina freshman, eliminated Frank J. Bowden, top-seeded netman, at 7 -- 5, 6 -- 0, in a quarter-final match of the Queens County clay court tennis championship at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

LONDON, July 5. -- Flying slowly at a height of only a few hundred feet, the Hindenburg, Germany's giant airship, sailed tonight over three British airports, the great docks at Southampton and the New Tank Corps base in Kent on her way home from the United States.

New high levels were attained by cotton futures here last week, after declines in the earlier trading on announcement by the Federal Government of a further release of loan cotton, news of more favorable crop weather, and the development of speculative liquidation.

BERLIN, July 5. -- The active participation by Germany in an early resumption of intergovernmental exchanges on the settlement of European issues appears taken for granted in official and diplomatic quarters here. No invitation to a conference of Locarno powers has reached Berlin, but it is believed that with the lifting of sanctions France and Britain will now press for early action on all issues concerning Western Europe and security.

Actuated by what it terms the "wholly false and misleading impression'' created by the publication of the salaries of executives of large corporations, the National Association of Manufacturers made public yesterday the results of a survey to disprove the popular belief that a large percentage of the nation's industrial payroll goes to a handful of ranking officials.

A Sing Sing parolee, a St. Paul (Minn.) hoodlum under indictment in the Hamm kidnapping, three other prisoners and $200,000 in stolen United States Treasury notes, were gathered in over the holiday week-end by Department of Justice agents who have been working more than a year to solve two Wall Street bond thefts in which the loot totaled approximately $2,000,000.

Carrying a placard which read "Mrs. Sarah Lory evicts disabled son and family," Kapal Lory, his wife, Teresa, and two of their children yesterday picketed the two-family house at 1,426 Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, where they had lived for two years.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP). -- The Pirates jumped on Lon Warneke for all their runs in the first three innings today to defeat the Cubs, 4 -- 2, behind the steady hurling of Bill Swift.

The theft of a painting highly valued by its owner, who is on home relief, was reported yesterday morning to the police of the Fifth Street station. The complainant described himself as Count Echevarria Juan de Regis, an artist and former theatre usher.

Demolition of the stately Morosini mansion in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx will begin this week to prepare the twenty-acre estate for a modern residential development. When completed the project will consist of twenty-six dwellings overlooking the Hudson River and will be similar to the neighboring Fieldston improvement.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 5. -- Impressive team work proved a valuable asset in carrying the Miami Valley Hunting and Polo Club team of Ohio to a 7-to-6 victory over a strong Westbury side in today's high-goal match on Bostwick Field.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 5. -- Three hours of calm held back a fleet of seventy-seven craft in the Knickerbocker Yacht Club's Long Island Sound championship races today. When a breeze finally came out of the southwest there was a scooting of the contestants around the courses east of Execution Light, with some finishes surprisingly close and others of a late and weird variety.

BERGENFIELD, N.J., July 5. -- This town paid court to its oldest resident today. She is Mrs. Kate Huyler of 115 Main Street, who celebrated her 100th birthday. Mrs. Huyler is said to be one of the few centenarians who has no advice to give on how to live long.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP). -- Cleveland and Chicago split their double-header before 15,000 today, the Indians taking the opener, 11 to 4, and the White Sox winning the nightcap, 4 to 2. The Tribe saved one contest out of the five-game series.

NEW ORLEANS, July 5. -- The cotton market here was fairly active last week. The volume of business increased and had a tendency to broaden, particularly in the speculative branch, which had been inactive for some time. There also has been fair trade buying, price-fixing and hedging with considerable profit-taking by satisfied longs.

Odds against the Yankees winning the American League pennant were placed at 1 to 4 yesterday by Jack Doyle, Broadway betting commissioner, as he released his annual midseason prices on the major league races. According to Doyle the McCarthymen at present are the shortest odds on midseason favorites in many years.

The manner in which city magistrates conduct the business of the Woman's Court and the Night Court is criticized in a report of the Woman's City Club, 22 Park Avenue, on the magistrates' courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn, made public today.
The Fourth of July week-end drew to a close with three drownings reported yesterday, bringing to ten the total in the metropolitan area for the holiday.
THE letter looked harmless enough, but it should have been marked: "Explosive. Do Not Open!" Lacking that warning, it was incautiously opened and the following words exposed to view:

HOMESTEAD, Pa., July 5. -- State relief was pledged here today by Lieut. Gov. Thomas Kennedy to steel workers who might lose their jobs in the drive by the Committee for Industrial Organization to unionize the industry.

Deploring the rise of dictatorships and the vast amount of unrest in European politics today, the Rev. Thomas Crombie, pastor of St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church, Glasgow, Scotland, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, that liberty was threatened throughout the world.

LONDON, July 3. -- Confidence in the domestic trade situation continues unabated and finds expression in an eager demand for almost all new industrial capital offerings. These obligations are appearing in a steady stream and, with few exceptions are being largely oversubscribed.
READING some of Sally Benson's short stories is a little like watching a surgeon operate on a brain. It isn't a comfortable experience, but it is one that you remember.

A new party was added yesterday to the political organizations now functioning in this State, when the State convention of right-wing Socialists, headed by Louis Waldman, voted to form the People's party.

Horses have no votes, but they have needs which should not be forgotten even in a Presidential campaign. While the political battle rages this Summer many thousands of horses will continue to draw their loads through the streets, under the hot sun, among the crowding motors.
PARIS, July 5. -- Police and Mobile Guards fought Rightists, estimated officially to number 15,000, along the Champs Elysees tonight.

MOSCOW, July 5. -- The second annual congress of Soviet Heavy Industry ended with a speech by Commissar Gregory K. Ordjonikidze, who warned his audience against the danger of resting on their laurels and thinking they already were "catching up and surpassing" America.

NEW HAVEN, July 4. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.1, which compares with 82.6 the week before, 82.5 two weeks before, 82.3 three weeks before and 81.2 four weeks before.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- The average of five estimates of this year's crop of Spring wheat, made last week by local statisticians, is 134,000,000 bushels, compared with 236,000,000 a month ago. The government's estimate of last year's crop, made as of July 1, 1935, was 273,000,000 bushels.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 5. -On their way to the Olympic Games, via Princeton and Randalls Island, athletes from the Deep South, Middle West and Far West have taken almost complete control of the American track and field situation.

Nineteen Scouts and Scout leaders, representing the Boy Scout Association of Poland, arrived, yesterday from Warsaw on the steamship Pilsudski of the Gdynia America Line. They were met at the pier in Hoboken, foot of Sixth Street, by a band and 300 American Boy and Girl Scouts, chiefly of Polish descent.
COWES, England, July 5 (AP). -- British Navy officials waited only the right kind of conditions tonight for the secret scuttling of the Britannia, King George's racing yacht.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- A detailed report of the cost of distribution of electricity, based on surveys and investigations of twenty-two private and municipal electric utility systems, was made public today by the Federal Power Commission. A summary was prepared in consonance with a resolution of Con-press and an executive order of President Roosevelt directing a survey of the nation's power resources.

In a news release Mr. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, praised the Republican platform and criticized the Democratic platform. He says: "The Republican platform approaches governmental policies from the standpoint of the welfare of the people."

Extensions of services in the city school system for problem children to cost more than $1,600,000 are recommended in a report of the special committee on delinquency and maladjustment, made public yesterday by the Board of Education.

BERLIN, July 4. -- Exports from Germany are increasing, as latest reports show substantial gains in shipments of iron, steel, non-ferrous metalware, automotive products, machine tools, cutlery and cement. Net receipts from shipping services, which in 1933 reached the lowest level for the depression and in 1934 and 1935 recovered slightly, show promise of a satisfactory increase this year.
Real estate deals announced over the week-end included sales of houses to investors. Some of the buildings will be altered.

Miss Margaret J. Eaton of 30-31 Murray Lane, Flushing, was designated yesterday by the Republican National Committee to act as assistant director of the national organization of young Republican women in the current Presidential campaign.

LONDON, July 3. -- The present condition of the securities markets here may be described best as a waiting mood. The undertone of confidence that was produced by the government's decision to abandon economic sanctions against Italy remains, but a formal lifting of these measures is required to stimulate an active interest in the markets.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 5. -- An 18-year-old youth, playing in his first grass court tournament, defeated the sixth ranking tennis player of the country today and a large gallery at the Nassau Country Club marveled that one so young could bring so much poise and skill to the court.
OSLO, Norway, July 5 (AP). -- Indian Scout, representing the United States, today won the coveted Gold Cup in the international yachting regatta, scoring her third victory of the series.

Berlin housewives for the duration of the Olympic Games have a serious laundry problem on their hands. They must not hang the family wash out on the line while so many foreign visitors are in town. It will be a hardship, but the German people are used to sacrifices by now, and are only too delighted to make them.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The American Newspaper Guild was certified by the National Labor Relations Board today as "the exclusive representative" for collective bargaining of all the New York City editorial employes of The Associated Press.

The New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, which is putting the finishing touches, after eleven months' work, to $3,350,000 worth of WPA projects, has submitted estimates for additional projects for the next twelve months valued at $4,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 5. -- The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, Brooklyn clergyman, was admitted to the Champlain Valley Hospital here shortly after 9 o'clock this evening. It was believed that he was suffering from an attack of appendicitis. Dr. L.G. Barton Jr., local physician, was called in for a consultation.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Improved conditions in the machinery industry were cited by the Department of Commerce in a statement issued today as a sound "indication that the country is in fact emerging from the depression."

TOKYO, July 5. -- The impossibility of developing China economically without Japanese cooperation will be stressed by the Japanese delegates to the conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations, which is to meet in Yosemite Park, Calif., from Aug. 15 to 29.

Supposing you had labored under most trying conditions, pioneering in a new field, home relief, for two or more arduous years, finally achieving, at much cost to your health of body and mind, the point where your competency was freely recognized by your employer. Suppose, also, that you had survived a reduction of staff from 18.000 employes to 9,000, being thereby considered, once again, worthy of your job.
Warnings against the growth of the drinking habit among young people, especially young women, were sounded by members of the clergy in their sermons here yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., July 5. -- Charley Morton, 20-year-old student at Polytechnic High School, Long Beach, Calif., finished first in the 66.8-mile Olympic bicycle road race final held through Paterson and Bergen County today. The time was 2:58:08 4-5.

A strange page was written into baseball's record yesterday at the Polo Grounds, when the Dodgers beat the Giants for the first time this season in the shadow of Coogan's Bluff. The sad event was sealed by a score of 3 to 1.

Bobbs-Merrill announce that they will publish this Fall the novel that recently won Mexico's first National Prize in Literature, "El Indio," by Gregorio Lopez y Fuentes. The English translation is being prepared by Anita Brenner. The title for the American edition has not yet been selected.

The membership of the fashionable clubs of the city, which reached low ebb in the depression years of 1929 to 1932, has been gradually returning to normal as business in general has improved, according to a study of a group of New York clubs, made public yesterday by Club Members of New York, an annual publication.

With the question of continued loyalty to John L. Lewis and his Committee for Industrial Organization as the principal issue before it, the executive board of the cap and millinery department of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union will begin its semi-annual meeting today at the Half Moon Hotel in Coney Island.

Two films concerning which there has been much speculation receive Class A2 rating in the latest list of the Legion of Decency, scheduled for release on July 9. They are "Anthony Adverse," adapted from the novel of that name by Hervey Allen, and "The Crime of Dr. Forbes," which was originally titled "The Mercy Killer."

A campaign which will be carried on for the next three months by the Esso Marketeers, of which the Colonial-Beacon Oil Company is an affiliate, starts today in newspapers with the announcement of the Esso picture title contest. Subsequent insertions will appear in newspapers several times a week during the peak gasoline gallonage season, with 1,000-line advertisements being backed up by smaller space during the week, according to J.A. Donan, advertising manager for Esso Marketeers.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5. -- America's weight lifters in the Olympics were selected today, following the week-end trials that came to a close at the Commercial Museum early this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5. -- Miss Consuelo Villa, daughter of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa, will be among the season's debutantes. Her parents, who have reserved Friday evening, Aug. 21, are giving a dance at their home, Fairholme, in her honor.
PEIPING, July 5 (AP). -- Lieut. Gen. Kanichiro Tashiro, ranking Japanese Army officer in North China, said today that Japan had no intention of further augmenting her Peiping and Tientsin garrisons.

Contracts awarded in the sixteen Southern States for building, engineering and construction projects in the first half of 1936 were valued at $423,355,000, compared with $235,563,000 in the same period of 1935 and $261,979,000 in the first half of 1934.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 5. -- Miss Mavis Freeman, 17-year-old star of the Women's Swimming Association, established a new American long course record for the 200-yard free style event to provide the feature of an A.A.U. swimming carnival for the benefit of the Olympic Fund at the Lido Country Club today.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Transportation operations for May of the Pullman Company, sleeping car company affiliate of Pullman, Inc., resulted in a deficit, after taxes, of $130,719, compared with one of $299,021 in May, 1935, the company announced today.

PITTSBURGH, July 5. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 74 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the rate of the two preceding weeks. The rate was computed on the basis of capacity for five working days, because of the holiday yesterday.

Manhattan, Season of Fruits, Seventh Moon, Year of Discovery four hundred and forty-fourth; of Independence one hundred and sixtieth, and of the Institution one hundred and forty-eighth, was celebrated solemnly and joyfully Saturday by the tribes in Union Square. "St." TAMMANY or TAMANEND, a Pennsylvanian, like Mr. LANDON, was represented by WHITE EAGLE, a Cherokee now domiciled in this reservation.

Despite the charm of its ideas and the flawlessness of its polished workmanship, Mendelssohn's "Italian" symphony is all too infrequently heard. Last night, however, it was the principal offering on a program of rather light caliber presented at the Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Jose Iturbi's direction.
WASHINGTON, July 5. -- Baseball fans of the nation's capital apparently quit on their Senators a trifle too soon.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 5. -- Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott of New York City drove off in an automobile for points unknown from his home near here today as reporters approached to ask him how he felt, as a leader in campaigns for a safe and sane Fourth, to be one of the few fireworks victims in one of the safest and sanest Fourths.

Arthur H. Chamberlain, executive secretary of the National Paper Trade Association of the United States, announced yesterday that Jacob K. Javits of Javits Javits, counsel for the association, had advised that undue confusion and alarm was being created with respect to the restrictions, of the Robinson-Patman Act.

Four damage maps covering the 1,031 acres in the Flushing Meadows Park, which is being leased by the city to the World's Fair Corporation as the site of the 1939 fair, have been turned over to the Corporation Counsel, Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 5. The Los Angeles Athletic Club's water polo team, with Phil Daubenspeck leading the attack and aiding in an impregnable defense in a scoreless second half, defeated the New York A.C., 3 to 1, today for the right to represent the United States in the Olympic games next month.

New York and the nation ended last night what was apparently one of the most free-spending holiday week-ends since the depression, as home-going travelers clogged roads, jammed trains and buses and taxed all transportation facilities.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- Corn belt States need rain which must come within a few days. Every day it is delayed, according to reports, will reduce the aggregate production. Speculative trading has increased in the staple, and prices are 151/2 to 153/4cents a bushel above the season's low on futures, with net gains of 41/2 to 61/2 cents last week, the latter on July.
Your editorial on the current deficit is not encouraging, leaving as the only probable method of a substantial saving an improvement of business to carry greater taxes and give more employment.

PROVIDENCE, Monday, July 6. -- After delegates to the thirty-ninth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America had upset the scheduled program yesterday afternoon to prey/de for a final settlement of the presidential issue today, lorris lqothenberg announced at a caucus of his folloyers at 12:30 o'clock this morning that he had .accepted the compromise proposal that will make Rabbi Stephen S. Wise head of the organization.

MORRIS, Minn., July 5. -- From here westward to the State boundary and north to the upper reaches of the Red River Valley farmers have despaired of having a cash crop of small grains, and many are beginning to turn their livestock into the fields so that something may be saved from the blighting effects of the drought.

PARIS, July 4. -- The price of gold in London, which was below French franc parity, may have given rise to some arbitrage operations, but the principal operator in the exchange market appears to have been the British Equalization Fund, which sent gold to Paris to support sterling.

The American Olympic Committee took a survey of its financial condition yesterday, ten days before the S.S. Manhattan sails for Berlin, and found that it was unsatisfactory in the extreme. A deficit of $149,924.56 was reported by Treasurer Gustavus Town Kirby, a huge amount to get by popular subscription in the short space of time that is left.
ARCHANGEL, U.S.S.R., July 5. -- Twenty-year-old Ivan Krukhoff related today the story of a grim voyage through the waters of the White Sea with a cargo of ten dead men.

WASHINGTON, July 5. -- The Roosevelt administration's silver -- purchase program has been economically injurious to the United States and the world, the Foreign Policy Association asserted today in a report prepared by John Parke Young of Occidental College, Los Angeles.

NORTHFORD, Conn., July 5. -- Noah Schulman, 26, of Hamden was fatally injured while sixty boys at Camp Clear View were watching here this afternoon, when a Fairchild monoplane, owned by the Cane Flying Service of West Haven, stalled at low altitude, and crashed directly in front of the camp.

NYACK, N.Y., July 5. -- Charles MacArthur, playwright, and Mrs. Helen Hayes MacArthur, his wife, returned to their Nyack home today to rest after the alienation of affections suit against the actress, which ended in Chicago on Friday when the plaintiff, Carol Frink, withdrew the action.
TIPTON, Iowa, July 5. -- A hunt for hidden treasure even greater than the $234,800 gold hoard already uncovered was organized tonight at the 880-acre farm of the three woman-hating Iwers Brothers.

HAVANA, July 5. -- The body of Sergeant Leopoldo Fernandez Rivero, who, together with four privates, went on trial before a courtmartial late yesterday charged with treason, was found hanging in his cell at San Severino military post, Matanzas, early this morning.
You hear a great deal about this subject of trout versus bass. It's a topic that is always ripe for debate wherever fresh-water anglers meet.

William Croon, 22 years old, of 121 Waverly Avenue, Newark, N.J., was killed and two girls were critically injured yesterday when their car crashed into a telephone pole at Evergreen and Frelinghuysen Avenues, Newark.

DENVER, July 5 (AP). -- The Goodyear entrant from Akron, Ohio, landed safely near Presho, S.D., today as the apparent winner of the twenty-fourth national balloon race. Presho is estimated by the Weather Bureau to be 385 miles northeast of here.

ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP). -- The champion Tigers gained revenge today for the defeat yesterday that ended their eight-game winning streak by pounding five Brown pitchers for twenty-six hits, including four homers, for an 18-9 victory.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 5 (AP). -- Great Britain will insist, at the Dardanelles Conference, which win resume its sessions tomorrow, on the right of her navy to enter the Black Sea if the British should be engaged in war.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- John P. Frey, president of the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor, issued a statement today attacking "the form of industrial organization now being advocated by John L. Lewis and his associates in the Committee for Industrial Organization."

Additional compensation for police captains who have served specified terms without promotion to higher rank is provided in an ordinance to be introduced in the Board of Aldermen by Majority Leader Murray W. Stand, it was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

The Olympic soccer football committee last night announced through The Associated Press the selection of seventeen players to form the squad which will represent the United States at the international games in Berlin. All except four of the players were chosen from the Philadelphia German Americans, national open champions, and the Brooklyn German Sports Club, national amateur titleholder.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 5. -- The most successful glider meet yet held in this country, which was marked by the high average performance of the contestants, closed here tonight. The champion for 1936 was Chester Decker of Glen Rock, N.J., with 295 points.

Hal Horne, the public relations counsel and advertising executive who abandoned his art for a producer's berth at RKO-Radio, has been assigned to supervise "Around the Town," with Joe Penner, Betty Grable and Nick Parkyakarkas. Joe Penner has been summoned from Europe for the event.

CHICAGO, July 5. -- The largest volume of business it has ever had and net earnings 25 per cent above those of the comparable period last year were reported today by the Federal Home Loan Bank of Chicago for the six months ended on June 30.

The. Rev. E. MacDonald Ross, pastor of St. Brycedale Church, Kirkcaldy, Scotland, was guest preacher yesterday morning at the Tremont Presbyterian Church, Grand Concourse, at 178th Street, the Bronx. The visiting minister is one of a group of sixty Scotch churchmen who are spending their Summer vacation in the United States and Canada.

The eloquence which President ROOSEVELT so frequently commands was never displayed to better advantage than in his tribute to THOMAS JEFFERSON at Monticello. His emphasis was on JEFFERSON'S unflagging passion for liberty. JEFFERSON himself gave the same emphasis to a life rich in its diversity; for on the monument that marks his burial place he chose only to be identified as author of the Declaration of Independence.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 5 (AP). -- Although only a little more than one-third of the full financial amount is in hand, Henry Penn Burke, chairman of the American Olympic rowing committee, announced tonight he was hopeful of sending a squad of thirty-two oarsmen, coaches and trainers to the Olympic Games at Berlin next month.
MOSCOW, July 5. -- The Bolsheviki have just discovered a "brain trust" lurking in their midst and have dealt it a most resounding crack.

Representatives of the intercoastal ship lines will confer today in another effort to draft a compact to govern the rates and sailing conditions of all operators in the freight service between the Atlantic and Pacific coasts.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., July 5. -- The first group of eight settlers will be greeted on the Jersey homesteads by Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, and Frank Schmitt, director of the construction division, when they arrive at the project Wednesday, according to Walter A. Simon, project manager for the management division.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 5. -- Miss Ethel Wickham gave a dinner tonight at Bonnie Bourne, her home here, for Mr. and Mrs. Sydney J. Smith and Mrs. Louis J. de Milhau, who are passing the holiday with her.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 5. -- An eight-oared crew that was as unruffled as the glassy water on which it rowed today won the right to represent the United States at the Olympic Games.
TOPEKA, July 5. -- Social security claimed chief interest in the State House today as Kansas legislators began arriving for the special session convened for Tuesday by Governor Landon.

Not, counting the WPA attractions, Broadway's Summer list of shows for tonight is down to a mere nine. But this number is not unusually light. On the corresponding Monday last year there were only nine, and two years ago there were eleven. . . .

JERUSALIM, July 5. -- An outbreak of poison cases caused by tainted fruits and fish spread alarm today among the Jews, particularly in the Old City of Jerusalem. More than 260 cases have been treated in hospitals here in the last two days. Thus far there has been one death.

Izzy Jannazzo, hard-hitting East Side welterweight, knocked out Steve Halaiko of Waverly, N.Y., in 1:15 of the fourth round of a scheduled ten-round bout before a crowd of 2,500 at Dexter Park last night.

SHANGHAI, July 6. -- Three proposals for peaceful settlement of the strained situation between the Central Government and Southwest China have been framed. These will be proposed at the plenary session of the Kuomintang (National People's party), in Nanking Friday, by delegates from the Southwest.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, announced here today that Samuel F. Pryor Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., a vice president of the American Brake Shoe Company, will serve as assistant treasurer of the Republican National Committee.

TORONTO, July 6 (Canadian Press). -- Oliver's single to center on the first ball pitched to him in the eleventh inning gave Toronto a 1-0 victory over Newark tonight. The hit drove in Miller, who had tripled.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6. -- The Federal deficit as a primary source of inflation was criticized here today by both capital and labor in prepared addresses by Orrin G. Wood, president of the Investment Bankers Association, and Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 6. -- Former District Attorney Elvin N. Edwards announced today that he would apply in Nassau County Court here next Thursday for a new trial for Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, condemned slayer of Mrs. Ada Appelgate.

LONDON, July 6. -- A permanent international congress of the British Empire and all foreign countries sending substantial exports of meat to the United Kingdom is contemplated in a new meat policy announced today by Walter Elliott, Minister of Agriculture. In any event, there is to be a permanent council representing Great Britain and all the dominions.

A four-month secret quest for Mrs. Anna Kunashevsky, 45 years old, head of a travel agency and private bank at 179 East Third Street, was brought into the open yesterday by the police Missing Persons Bureau when a general alarm for her arrest on a grand larceny indictment was broadcast.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that he had agreed to the "drafting" of Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to the Department of Investigation and Accounts, by the Association of the Bar to act as its counsel in disciplinary proceedings against J. Richard Davis before the Appellate Division.

" Your Correspondent in Kansas" gets a whole page in The Spectator to blow the horn of Kansas. The piece is called "Mr. Roosevelt's Opponent." English readers may be forgiven if they get the impression that Kansas is that Opponent. It is written from Kansas City, "the real capital of Kansas," and "the home of the most promising "schools of art and poetry in the "country."

WINNIPEG, July 6 (Canadian Press). -- A new heat wave blazed its way across Western Canada today, leaving permanent damage to wheat stands in South Central Saskatchewan and stunting growth across a wide stretch of Southern grain belt territory.

Total assets of the New York Savings Bank on July 1, 1936, amounted to $82,999,335, comparing with $82,874,506 on the same date in 1935. Deposits were $69,580,372, against $69,622,053, and surplus was unchanged at $13,020,821.
Plans of six-story apartment houses filed yesterday included a $125,000 structure for Manhattan and five Bronx houses to cost total of $690,000, as follows:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 6. -- While the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn, commanded by Colonel Frank C. Vincent, was engaged in a field problem within the boundaries of the Camp Smith reserve today, the 1,100 guardsmen of the 105th Infantry of Troy, led by Colonel Bernard W. Kearney, left camp on a six-mile march to Continentalville, where they will bivouac tonight.
SAYVILLE, L.I., July 6. -- The Olympic tinge that is coloring current rent sports spread to yacht racing today as the Star Class hit the trail that will lead one of its members to Kiel, Germany.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 6. -- Outstanding junior and boy stars of Westchester and Connecticut gathered today at the County Tennis Club as the Westchester championships got under way after a five-year lapse. A field of forty-nine juniors started, while nineteen went out to battle for the boys' title.

PITTSBURGH, July 6. -- Earl F. Reed, counsel for the Wheeling Steel Corporation, said tonight an "informal agreement" had been reached to settle the strike at the corporation's Portsmouth, Ohio, plant.

Seven men, a woman and two corporations, all accused of using the mails to obtain money from property owners on the false representation that they were connected with the Federal Housing Administration, were indicted yesterday on seventeen counts.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6. -- Anthony Barclay Rives of Cobham, Va., who will marry Miss Gwendolen Ella Rives Armstrong on Wednesday, gave his bachelor's dinner at the Muenchinger-King tonight. There were about twenty guests present. Tomorrow E. Maitland Armstrong, a brother of the prospective bride, will give a dinner for the wedding party.

Dr. German Wolter del Rio, Secretary of the Treasury of Cuba, in a statement on the Cuban public debt as reported yesterday in Wall Street intimates that negotiations looking toward an agreement on the resumption of service on the 5 1/2 per cent Cuban Public Works bonds due in 1945 will be instituted soon.

Readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 26 and 28 may have contrasted the proposal of Soviet Russia, the home of Stakhanoffism, to limit by constitutional means "payment for work according to its quantity and quality" on the one hand, with that of Henry A. Wallace that the United States abandon free competition in favor of cooperatives on the other.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 6. -- The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, noted Brooklyn preacher, underwent an emergency operation soon after 8 o'clock tonight at Champlain Valley Hospital here after a conference between Dr. George L. Buist of New York, Dr. Cadman's personal physician, and Drs. Lyman G. Barton Jr. and Sr., prominent Plattsburg surgeons, resulted in a diagnosis of a ruptured appendix.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation's holdings of preferred stocks, notes and debentures of 6,068 banks and loans secured by preferred stock which once totaled $1,066,016,003 have been reduced by the banks about 25 per cent to $756,915,566, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said today announcing that the First National Bank of Chicago had completed the retirement of the $25,000,000 of its preferred stock that it had sold in 1934 to the government corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- President Roosevelt today appointed Paul H. Nystrom of New York City to be a member of the Federal Board for Vocational Education for a term of three years.

The stock market derived yesterday little inspiration from the news over the holiday. On the contrary, the most important topics, the drought and the labor threats in the steel industry, were disquieting, so that trading was cautious, and the buying, at best, was selective in character.

IT'S about time that the National League side came home with a victory in one of these all-star ball games. President Ford Frick of the National League has dropped some hints to Manager Karl Johann Grimm on this point. There have been three such games so far and the best that can be said for the National Leaguers is that their play was consistent. They dropped all three.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., July 6. -- The Riding Club of East Hampton will have its formal opening for the season on Sunday afternoon, when a group of young people under the chairmanship of Miss Mary Esther Krech will hold a gymkhana and junior horse show.
Thirty thirsty horses drank deeply yesterday afternoon at the first of the watering stations of the Humane Society to be opened this season.

With six of her eleven children tagging at her skirts and a baby in her arms, Mrs. Dora Moskowitz, 35 years old, called yesterday at the Queens County jail and demanded that the children be fed while her husband served a ten-day jail sentence.

In an effort to speed the reorganization proceedings of Prudence Company, Inc., which have been in his court since Feb. 1, 1935, Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order directing all parties interested in the proceedings to appear before him on Friday afternoon and show cause why a date should not be fixed for the submission of a plan of reorganization.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Expenditures necessary to rehabilitate the Denver, Rio Grande Western Railway and the Denver Salt Lake Railway were put between $15,000,000 and $20,000,000 today in a report by W.W. Sullivan, examiner for the railroad division of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 6. -- Warned that internal politics seriously threatened the fundamental objectives of the Zionist Organization of America, delegates to the annual convention eagerly endorsed today the compromise that made Rabbi Stephen S. Wise their president.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Grain prices advanced the limit permitted under the regulations on leading North American Exchanges today on general buying induced by record-breaking heat and dry weather from Texas northward far into the three Canadian Provinces. Each day of continued drought, the trade fears, is reducing the prospective yield of all grain with the exception of Winter wheat.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 7. -- The charges on which the mutineers were sentenced today were murder, rebellion and disobedience to the commands of the Emperor.
DERBY, England, July 6. -- David Lloyd George, in a fiery by-election speech tonight, called Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and his Ministers "rats that scuttle the ship."

A united program for street meetings in New York during the Summer to acquaint the public with the objectives of the various national and local peace organizations was discussed by their representatives at an organization meeting held last night at the headquarters of the Emergency Peace Campaign, 71 West Twenty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Treasury regulations in the taxation of non-resident aliens and foreign corporations under the Revenue Act of 1936 were issued today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 6. -- Governor Earle today approved the speech made yesterday at Homestead by Lieut. Gov. Thomas Kennedy, who told steel workers that if they lost their jobs during the campaign to unionize the industry the State would care for them with unemployment relief funds.
DANZIG, July 6 (AP). -- Danzig's Nazi Senate President came home today from his startling Geneva visit, determined, apparently, to exterminate all opposition.

Good citizens, interested in the orderly development and discussion of relations between employers and employees in this country, will hope that the fair words of the steel workers and the steel manufacturers in Pennsylvania presage the character of the campaign to unionize the mills in that State.

The new Randalls Island Stadium, where the final Olympic track and field tryouts will be held on Saturday and Sunday, felt the imprint of the spikes of America's foremost athletes yesterday when more than a score of potential Olympic team members tested the cinder path, jumping pits and weight circles.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 6. -- A woman was killed and three members of the University of California crew were injured in an automobile accident on the Brunswick Pike five miles north of here early today.

NEW ORLEANS, July 6 (AP). -- A petition for a rehearing in the suit brought by the National Labor Relations Board to compel the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation to accept the provisions of the National Labor Relations Act was before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here today.

Five men arrested over the weekend as members of a ring that stole $2,000,000 in bonds from the Bank of the Manhattan Company and from the United States Trust Company were held yesterday by Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, in bail totaling $47,500.

Vincent Pimpinella, 145 1/2, Brooklyn, finished strongly to gain the decision over Johnny Horstmann, 144 3/4, of the East Side in the feature six-round bout before 1,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
CHICAGO, July 6. -- The drought intensified and extended its disastrous course today as 100-110 degree heat beat mercilessly down for the fourth straight day over much of the Midwest.

Philip Fern, 8 years old, of 201 Marshall Street, Elizabeth, N.J., was drowned in the Lower Bay off the government reservation at New Dorp Beach, S.I., at about 4 P.M. yesterday. His body was recovered by the marine police.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6. -- Provincialism was called a handicap to international good-will and to good government everywhere and the greatest danger threatening mankind in addresses today at the University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs.
GANADO, Ariz., July 6 (AP). -- The Navajo's two-day prayer for rain ended today -- and showers fell on the 15,000,000-acre reservation.

In European affairs today Poland must be counted as a Great Power. Its pivotal position, achieved by freeing itself from the irritating tutelage of France and by establishing amicable relations with Germany, was dramatically demonstrated last week by the repercussions of the German offensive against the League of Nations supervision over the Free City of Danzig.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on July 1 shows increases for the week of $99,000,000 in total loans and investments, $205,000,000 reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $116,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $235,000,000 in balances on deposit with domestic banks and $563,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.
Allied Mills, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, 25 cents more than the previous payment on Dec. 28, 1935.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 6. -- Britain submitted her own draft convention for the Turkish Straits to the Dardanelles Conference here today. Well received by Turkey and badly by Russia, its net effect is to restore the pre-war position where Turkey can play Britain against Russia as well as Russia against Britain, which is the present position.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Reports that the drought had seriously lowered the underground water table, an important source of moisture, prompted the Geological Survey today to begin an intensive study of fluctuations in the Dakotas, Montana and Wyoming.

At the last census a quarter of a million adults in New York City could not write their names in any language, and at least as many more could not read a word of English. Many of these persons are on relief.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 6. -- The 1,300 candidates attending this year's Citizen's Military Training Camp here put in their first whole day of drills today.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 6. -- In the first civil court proceeding growing out of the schism in the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, Vice Chancellor Francis B. Davis today denied a preliminary injunction to five members of the Collingswood Presbyterian Church who sought to prevent the Rev. Carl McIntire, the pastor, from preaching or conducting any service in the church.

LONDON, July 6 (AP). -- Faced by a threat of a "stay-in" strike of 16,000 civil servants, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, bluntly served notice tonight that clerks who laid down their pens would be dismissed instantly.

The four British six-meter boats which will sail against the United States team in the British-American trophy match on the Clyde are Vorsa, Lelange, Melita and Nike, according to word received by cable from Scotland yesterday by Van S. Merle-Smith, commodore of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club and chairman of the club's international national committee.

With heavy buyer attendance noted in the showrooms, the response to the Fall openings yesterday of dress and coat firms was described by producers last night as justifying the optimism that featured the preliminary portion of the wholesale season.

With the number of buyers here showing a sharp increase, activity in Fall ready-to-wear lines got off to a good start yesterday. It will require several days for buyers to view lines, but the indications were said to point to substantial early business. Coat lines are now complete, but dress showings will be scattered over the next few days.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 6. -- The books and records of William Fox, former motion picture producer, were scanned today in an effort to trace the loss of his huge fortune.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Following is the text of the speech made tonight by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America and chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization:
J.B. Walsh would restrict by law the privilege of filing plans for the construction of buildings to registered engineers.

BERLIN, July 6. -- The French Ambassador, Andre Francois-Poncet, and the British Charge d'Affaires, B.C. Newton, called today at the German Foreign Office to request the government to define its attitude in regard to the move at Geneva by Arthur Greiser, President of the Danzig Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- President Roosevelt promised late today to make two speeches next Fall to aid the Community Chest campaigns conducted in 352 cities, it was announced after a conference between leaders in this movement and President and Mrs. Roosevelt at a White House tea.
Housing and business structures in various communities were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

TOKYO, July 6. -- Ambassador Sir Robert Clive of Britain made strong representations to the Foreign Office today regarding the attitude of Japanese officials in Peiping during the investigation of charges against British soldiers in connection with the killing of a Japanese soldier.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- With Edward Freed, former collector for Al Capone, in custody for questioning on the murder of Miss Audrey Vallette, night club entertainer, police continued their search tonight for Freed's wife, Carmelia. Freed surrendered this morning, but his wife, a suspect in the slaying, remained in hiding, though friends had told the police that she also would surrender during the day.

It is customary for administration orators to find resemblances between the incumbent of the White House and his great -- or, at any rate, deceased -- party ancestors. Thus Mr. Roosevelt has been likened to Jefferson, Jackson and Cleveland, the three distinguished Democrats whom the Republicans have recently adopted, and to Wilson, while Governor Landon was early presented to the East as the "Kansas Coolidge."

The greatest emphasis on quality merchandise since 1929 will feature retail advertising in the Fall, according to views expressed yesterday by Thomas Robb, manager of the sales promotion group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Steadily improving business conditions, coupled with the fact that more and more people want better merchandise and are willing to pay more for it, are basic factors that will guide department store publicity, Mr. Robb said.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- The double holiday of July 4 was celebrated by the nation at a cost of 444 lives, revised fatality tables tonight disclosed.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- German tariff experts, headed by Dr. Rudolph Brinkermann, a director of the Reichsbank and chief adviser to the Finance Minister on tariffs and duties, began discussions with the Treasury Department today in the hope of bringing about the reduction of countervailing duties on certain products exported by Germany to the United States.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 6 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's marksmen, in common with those from elsewhere in the Empire, found the bull's-eyes harder to hit this year than formerly as the National Rifle Association's shoot got under way today.

LONDON, July 6. -- The stock markets here were generally firm today, although quiet because of the approaching holiday season and the unsettled international situation. British funds opened steady, but turned dull later and reacted. German issues were dull pending developments in the Danzig dispute, and Danzig securities also were weak.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 6. -- "The Wingate Affair," by Herbert A. Shapiro, the second of a series of ten new plays being presented weekly by Paul L. Berney of New York, opened tonight at the Beechwood Theatre.

Police Commissioner Valentine, in discussing yesterday the fatal shooting of a youth Saturday night in Central Park in a reported hold-up, said that all the police that could be spared previously had been assigned to protect visitors to the park, and added more lights should be installed in its many dark spots.

BERLIN, July 6. -- Prices on the Boerse were slightly weaker today, although activity was still strictly limited. Heavy industrials were mixed and unstable within narrow limits, Gloeckner gaining 1 point. Potashes were stagnant as usual. Machines were mixed, failing to establish any trend.

Loew's, Inc., earned a net profit of $7,390,495 in the forty weeks ended on June 4 after depreciation, taxes and other deductions, according to a statement to be released today by David Bernstein, vice president and treasurer. After allowing for dividend requirements on the preferred stock the profit was equivalent to $4.47 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding.

Price changes generally were small and trading was in moderate volume in the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange with foreign issues fairly strong. The turnover was $8,648,800, compared with $9,406,600 on Friday. Domestic corporation bonds were $6,910,000, against $7,031,000, while the turnover in United States Government obligations was $517,300, against $1,350,000.

CAIRO, July 6. -- Owing to the refusal of official circles to give information, any forecast of the details of the new Anglo-Egyptian treaty, which now needs only to be put in legal terms, must be speculative. Nevertheless, its broad lines are fairly reliably known.

The five county Democratic leaders in this city, determined to give united support to President Roosevelt, agreed yesterday that a Queens man should have the designation for President of the Board of Aldermen in the special election this Fall.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 6. -- Elsie Janis, actress, mimic and the "idol of the army" during the World War, hopes to give up all of her possessions and devote the rest of her life to charity.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 6. -- Statements that 55,000 persons had, been sterilized in Germany last year, that 225,000 had been condemned for political offenses since 1933, and that in 105 concentration camps conditions were such that suicides were daily occurrences, were made at the European Conference for Amnesty for Political Prisoners in Germany, held here yesterday.

Before leaving for Washington last night to attend a meeting today of Labor's Nonpartisan League for the re-election of President Roosevelt, Luigi Antonini, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers and chairman of the New York State committee of the league, declared that the league probably would offer a ticket of its own in this State, headed by President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6. -- Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former New York Police Commissioner and airline official, who has a Summer home at Lake Waccabuc, gave the Westchester Board of Supervisors a lecture this afternoon on the future of aeronautics and urged establishment of a county airport on the Sonn tract in Mount Pleasant.
CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP). -- Showers of stones pelted workers as they left the suburban Norwood plant of Remington-Rand, Inc., late today.

Two more American polo figures returned yesterday from England and the international matches there in which the United States successfully defended the Westchester Cup. They were Elbridge T. Gerry, spare, who played in the third match, and Seymour H. Knox, captain of Aurora, who went across to watch the matches.
A total of $204,544,865.54 was spent by the Works Progress Administration in this city from Aug. 1, 1935 to June 30, 1936, Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, disclosed yesterday.

Federal Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals declined yesterday to rule on an application by counsel for the Associated Gas and Electric Company for a stay, pending the latter's petition for a writ of prohibition in its fight to stave off reorganization.

Governor Lehman called upon District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn yesterday to answer within twenty days the Drukman special grand jury's charges demanding his removal from office. The prosecutor is accused of laxity, incompetence and failure to fulfill the obligations of his office in connection with the Drukman case, and of associating with persons of "ill repute."

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Best-quality hogs again were in good demand here, with prices steady to 10 cents higher than on Friday. The top moved up 5 cents to $11.15 a hundredweight, the highest level since the middle of February. Weights under 250 pounds sold readily, but heavier kinds were slow.

As the torrid temperatures went unrelieved over the holiday from Canada to Texas and the drought-stricken crops were further damaged, prices of grains automatically shot up yesterday to the limits permissible in a single day. After a moderate amount of profit-taking had been quickly absorbed, brokers were forced to stand idly by with sheaves of unfilled buying orders on their hands.

FARGO, N. D., July 6. -- Blistering heat blown before an eighteen mile wind across the Northwest today broke temperature records in many localities and caused Federal and State agricultural authorities to abandon virtually all hope for small grains in the Dakotas and a large part of Minnesota.
American chances of victory in the shot-put and discus throw in the Olympic Games are predicated on the little word "if."

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Chicago's two furniture and house-furnishings shows opened today at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart with a record attendance of buyers. Officials of both marts estimate that the total of sales and orders placed during the shows will reach $20,000,000.

The Commonwealth of Massachusetts awarded yesterday a new issue of $4,000,000 of notes to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at par plus a premium of $55 for 0.36 per cent notes. Dated July 10, 1936, and maturing on July 6, 1937, the notes were re-offered to the public on a 0.30 per cent basis.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 6. -- Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers lost her suit in Surrogate's Court here to set aside the waiver she had signed to the will of her late husband, Colonel Henry H. Rogers. She had sought to establish her full dower rights to his estate of $13,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 6. -- Low scores were the rule today as eighteen pairs registered in the 60s and five more of a field of thirty-seven twosomes were under par 72 for the 6,537-yard Gedney Farm course in the weekly Westchester pro-amateur one-day tourney.

The theologians of the Middle Ages who argued on the number of angels that could stand on the point of a needle are intellectual kin of our mathematical physicists who are trying to explain the nucleus of the atom. Like the angels, the protons, electrons, deuterons and neutrons about which we read are hypotheses.

BOSTON, July 6. -- Amid a world series atmosphere that the enthusiastic fans of this throbbing New England metropolis still fervently hope will be re-enacted next Fall, baseball clans from far and wide assembled here tonight for the fourth edition of the diamond's latest classic -- the all-star game which tomorrow will be staged on National League Field.
Walter J. Zeidner is in the branch office of Cohen, Simonson Co., at 142 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Following a two-hour conference today between President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley regarding the latter's status in his dual role of Cabinet member and chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Farley said the conversation would be discussed by the President at a White House press conference tomorrow.
