EDMONTON, Alberta, July 6. -- Brushing aside uniformed guards, a body of unemployed men, many of them avowedly Communists, took possession of the legislative buildings here for a short time this afternoon and demanded work from the Social Credit government.

Business leases led in volume of realty activity reported yesterday. Four parcels, comprising six five-story flats, were bought in by plaintiffs at Manhattan foreclosure auction sales. No Bronx properties were offered.

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 6 (AP) -- Dr. Colston E. Warne of the Economics Department of Amherst College told the Summer Institute of Social Progress here today that "the most immediate and pressing issue in the 1936 political campaign is that of relief."

TRENTON, N.J., July 6. -- Victor Ghezzi, who played so brilliantly in the early rounds of the recent national open golf, today teamed with Edward V. Quinn, also of Deal, and captured top honors in a pro-amateur tournament of the New Jersey P.G.A. at the Trenton Golf Club with 65.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott, in suffering a four-inch laceration of the forehead the night of July 4, was really the victim of his efforts to save friends from injury while they were celebrating with firecrackers. This was explained yesterday on behalf of the commissioner, long a foe of fireworks on the Fourth, by Richard F. Warner, secretary of the Fire Department.

Sturdy Gene Sarazen, who was America's leading hope in the British open this year, returned home yesterday on the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line fully satisfied with his showing in the event, in which he tied for fifth place.

WARSAW, Poland, July 6. -- Despite the alarming reports of an imminent coup in Danzig, Warsaw official circles remain calm. It is felt here that the violent speech by Arthur Grieser at Geneva, which he described as "the first attack" in the campaign for revision of the League status of Danzig, would not be followed by rash action that would mobilize against Danzig the entire League of Nations and result in Polish counter action.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 6. -- City Manager Colus C. Hunter's edict of "No work, no food" has proved successful in supplying to F.A. Canuso Son, sewer contractors, all the labor immediately needed on a PWA sewer leading to the city's new disposal plant.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 6. -- Mrs. John Gillespie Jackson gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at Pine Tree Cottage, her home here, for Mrs. Edwin A. Strong of New York, who is visiting Mrs. R. Swift MacGuire at the Playhouse.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, July 6. -- Captain George Eyston, leading another charge on world automobile speed and endurance marks, smashed one of his own today as his low-slung racer covered 162.529 miles in one hour.

MEXICO, D.F., July 6. -- President Lazaro Cardenas at an official reception this morning met the members of the United States delegation invited to attend the recent opening of Mexico's great highway from the United States border at Laredo to this city.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 6 (AP). -- Charges of setting up a "Huey Long machine," of failure to support Roosevelt and of using the WPA for political purposes clashed tonight at the close of Oklahoma's Democratic primary campaign.

The usual sag in eastbound transatlantic passenger sailings after the Fourth of July sailings will not occur this year, shipping men report. Capacity sailings that have marked the last three weeks will continue throughout the month and in some cases throughout August.

JERUSALEM, July 6. -- Large forces of British troops with machine guns, armored cars and tanks equipped with radios have started a search in the Nablus district. Thus far three Arabs have been killed and several wounded. The Arabs, apparently warned, hid in the mountains around Nablus.
Some time in the future historians may find, wonder and be amused at an official entry in the blotter of the Jersey City Police Department's First Precinct. It reads:

ROSLYN, L.I., July 6. -- Closing with a birdie 3 at the seventeenth and a par 4 at the final hole, Charles H. Mayo St. of Lids and Herbert Scheftel of Sands Point tied the Shoreview team of Frank Strafaci and Olin Cerrocki at 68 strokes today for top honors in a pro-amateur tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Coffin Burr, Inc., will offer today a new issue of $5,600,000 of West Virginia Water Service Company first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1961, at 100 and accrued interest. The bonds are to be dated April 1, 1936, and mature on April 1, 1961.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- The Weather Bureau said today that no rain was in sight for the grain States in the next thirty-six hours.

ST. PAUL, July 6. -- The National Labor Relations Board was restrained today by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here from holding hearings in St. Louis on charges of unfair labor practices in the assembly plant of General Motors Corporation.
Secretary of the Interior Ickes will speak at the ceremonies on Saturday marking the opening of the Triborough Bridge, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday at the Summer City Hall, in the Bronx.

AMSTERDAM, July 6. -- The Bank of the Netherlands announced today a further reduction in the discount rate from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent, effective tomorrow. The last previous reduction was made on June 30.

The committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that Hungarian Consolidated Municipal Loan 7 1/2 per cent bonds, due in 1945, and 7 per cent bonds, due in 1946, shall be quoted ex interest today; that the bonds shall be dealt in "flat" and to be a delivery in settlement of transactions made beginning today must carry the Jan. 1, 1937, and subsequent coupons.

ESTES PARK, Col., July 6 (AP). -- The Republican campaign will cost between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000, William B. Bell of New York, chairman of the party's national finance committee, predicted today.

Weights for 101 juveniles in the Wakefield Handicap at six furlongs with $2,500 added, at Empire City Saturday, were announced yesterday by John B. Campbell, handicapper. The top impost of 126 pounds went to A.G. Vanderbilt's Airflame. The weights:

The object lesson in brevity given by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, when he put his last annual report in graphic form, has not yet upset educational tradition, it became evident yesterday.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 6. -- Headed by Frank Parker, the defending cup holder, and Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles, national clay court and junior champion, sixty-four players will start tomorrow in the annual Spring Lake invitation clay court tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

The twenty-four Polish Boy Scouts and Scout leaders here on a good-will tour stood at noon yesterday atop the national headquarters of the Boy Scouts of America at 2 Park Avenue, where they were welcomed by American Scout officials and responded lustily by singing the Polish Scout anthem.
Although economic conditions in Cuba are still far below pre-depression standards, they show a remarkable improvement from the dark days of 1932 and 1933.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, opened tonight the steel organization campaign undertaken by a dozen American Federation of Labor unions by accepting "the challenge of the omnipresent overlords of steel to fight for the prize of economic freedom and industrial democracy."

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, in command of the Second Army Corps Area, designated yesterday the young men to serve during August at the Coast Artillery Citizens' Military Training Camp at Fort Hancock, N.J., and the Field Artillery C.M.T.C. at Madison Barracks, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- President Roosevelt today assumed personal direction of drought relief activities and turning thumbs down on recommendations by aides that large numbers of families be moved immediately from stricken areas, ordered an intensified drive to aid 200,000 farmers in plains and Southern States where high temperatures and lack of rain continue.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 6. -- After calling it a day and a season on Broadway only last week, Philip Merivale and Gladys Cooper called it a "White Christmas" this evening at the Red Barn in Locust Valley. At least for Mr. Merivale the transition was not as bewildering as the lack of time might indicate, for "White Christmas" is a comedy of his own authorship.

Strengthened by the daily decreasing supply of desirable grades of cotton and a rise of 5 cents a bushel in the quotations for wheat, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced again yesterday, going into new high ground for the season and ending with gains of 11 to 15 points.

TRENTON, N.J., July 6. -- Henry W. Jeffers St. of Plainsboro, Republican State Chairman, announced today the addition of five persons to the general committee to be in charge of the party's campaign, and at the same time named former Ambassador Walter E. Edge as chairman, and Arthur T. Vanderbilt as vice chairman.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for May, forwarded to Congress today, showed that repayment of $9,798,388 by banks and trust companies during the month exceeded disbursements, which fell off to only $3,239,378, practically all in advances to closed banks.

DENNIS, Mass., July 6. -- Such stuff as Philip Barry's earlier comedies were made on this substance of his latest traffic with the stage, "Spring Dance," which Ted Harris presented here in the elbow of Cape Cod this evening at Raymond Moore's Cape Playhouse.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP). -- Harry Thomas Thompson, convicted of spying on the navy for a Japanese agent, was sentenced to fifteen years in prison today, the first American penalized under the spy law enacted during the World War.

Gustavus Town Kirby, treasurer of the American Olympic Committee, denied emphatically yesterday the accuracy of widely circulated reports that the anti-Nazi drive had anything to do with the deficit of nearly $150,000 that confronts the Olympic team a little more than a week before sailing.
LONDON, July 6. -- The British Government took another step toward nationalizing public services today by announcing that 4,500 miles of main roads would be brought under State control by next year.

Walter Wanger, newest United Artists producer, arrived on the Queen Mary yesterday without declaring the following news items at customs: On next June 15 he hopes to begin production on his first Italian picture, probably with Sylvia Sidney and Henry Fonda under the august patronage of Il Duce himself.

The balmy holiday week-end produced plenty of grist for the saltwater angling mill. Big fish, small fish, odd catches -- old Father Neptune's domain was in generous mood. Let's skip from spot to spot along the waterfront and see what happened.

It has been remarked that if the islands on which this city stands were to take on board not only their own inhabitants but all who live within the bounds of regional planning, were then to put out to sea and anchor in mid-ocean, a stranger might wonder whether this new Atlantis belonged geologically, politically and ethnically to the Old World or to the New.

MOSCOW, July 6. -- Moscow staged a superb pageant of sport in Red Square today under the eyes oil Joseph Stalin, Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Mikhall Ivanorvich Kalinin, President of the Soviet Union, and other leaders, when 75,000 members of Moscow sports organizations marched past for hours with incredible variety and richness of color.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is prepared to consider applications by motor carriers of passengers and freight for loans secured by equipment-trust certificates, Jesse H. Jones, chairman, said today.

ATHENS, July 6. -- Further restrictions to the extent of about $7,000,000 a year are being imposed on Greek imports to save the rapidly dwindling gold coverage for currency. Part of the restrictions will bear on trade with countries having clearing agreements with Greece, part on trade with countries operating under free cash conditions.

MADRID, July 6. -- A youth, said to have been affiliated with the Spanish Phalanx, was shot dead here today, bringing the total of Fascist fatalities in clashes with Socialists in the past four days up to five. Two Marxist militiamen have been killed.

Few medals have been better deserved than the one bestowed on HAROLD F. BIDWELL of Jersey City. It was given for thirty-eight years of driving an automobile without an accident. It is a feat that staggers the imagination.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 6. -- Miss June Walker had the leading part in Sidney Coe Howard's 1925 prize-winning play, "They Knew What They Wanted," at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge tonight. It was the opening of the ninth season and the second under the management of William Miles.

Should Australian women continue to demand American merchandise with the same emphasis as heretofore, this situation will be strongly called to the attention of the licensing powers in that country by retailers there, it was stated yesterday by E.B. Myer, chairman of the directors of the Myer Emporium, Ltd., operating two of the largest stores in Australia.

BOSTON, July 6 (AP). -- President Roosevelt will start his vacation yachting cruise next week in a vessel which will afford him greater comfort, space and privacy than the Amberjack, on which he made his New England coastal cruise in 1933.

GENEVA, July 6. -- The League of Nations Coordination Committee unanimously decided today to end all sanctions against Italy on July 15, nine months after their start, and to arrange for a study of this experience in order to apply sanctions better next time.
TOKYO, Tuesday, July 7. -- The secret military tribunal that has been trying the February mutineers today sentenced seventeen officers and cadets to death and five to life imprisonment.

TOPEKA, July 6. -- On the eve of the opening of the special session of the Kansas Legislature tomorrow morning, legislative leaders today scrapped a proposed constitutional amendment on social security drafted by the Kansas legislative council and termed "completely satisfactory" by Governor Landon.

Most commodity futures were sharply higher in heavy trading here yesterday. Wool top and cocoa futures were irregular. On the cash markets there were no declines. All the grains, cotton and rubber sold at new high levels, while advances appeared in flour, coffee, cocoa, butter, lard, tins, printcloths and silk.

The five interstate tunnel and bridge facilities of the Port of New York Authority were used by 8,572,044 vehicles in the first six months of the year, it was announced yesterday. This represented a gain of 312,000 vehicles, or nearly 4 per cent, compared with the corresponding period last year, and the best record in several years.

Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Psychic Bid, one of the best sprinters in the East, got up in the last few strides to capture the Nyack Handicap over the short six furlong course at Empire City yesterday. Psychic Bid's margin was a scant nose over the Howe Stable's Cycle, 9-to-10 favorite, and a picture was necessary to decide.
BOISE, Idaho, July 6. -- Senator Borah pledged allegiance today to the Republican ticket and platform. "I have no intention of bolting the ticket," said the veteran Republican, adding:

A small advance guard of prospective workers in the Democratic national campaign was on hand yesterday at the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee, in the Hotel Biltmore, which are being extended in preparation for the drive to re-elect President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner.

Following a 90-minute conference yesterday afternoon with Mayor La Guardia in the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park, Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey disclosed that he would confer in Albany today with Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

One hesitates to take issue with any of the many suggestions emanating from the World's Fair management for fear that it will be regarded as opposing the general plan. In submitting my fixed opposition to the last proposal of Mr. Whalen's, which seems to have met with the approval of the President, I base it on certain recognized facts.

Commissioner William Hodson announced yesterday that all inquiries concerning the new administration of old-age pensions and all applications should be made only by mail to the Department of Welfare. His announcement came after several hundred persons sought to obtain information over the telephone and as many more called in person at the department offices, 902 Broadway, greatly taxing the facilities and personnel and causing delay to the old people.

ROME, July 6. -- When sanctions were imposed about nine and one half months ago, Italy was aflutter with flags from one end to the other. Today, that they have been lifted, the event passed almost unnoticed.

After trailing by 1 -- 4 in the final set, George Seewagen, third seeded player, rallied to beat Robert J. Kelleher, former Williams College star, by 7 -- 5, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, in the quarter-final round of the Queens County clay court tennis championship at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 6 (AP). -- The steel workers organizing committee prepared today to invite operators to negotiate wages, hours, working conditions and recognition of the proposed big industrial union.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- Striking Remington-Rand Company workers joined by strike sympathizers staged a mass demonstration in city streets while company officials reiterated a declaration that "the strike is definitely broken."

The appearance of John Charles Thomas, the American baritone, as guest artist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night at the Lewisohn Stadium was the signal for a prolonged outburst of applause from the gathering of 5,000 persons.
The new Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived early yesterday from Southampton via Cherbourg with 1,474 passengers who were roused at 5 A.M. to pass the immigration doctors and inspectors.

Proceedings in equity and under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Law, which were dropped last May when Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn ordered the return of all its assets to the Bush Terminal Company, were restored yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 7. -- The annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America adjourned tonight after the delegates had united almost without discussion in backing a program submitted by a committee headed by M. Maldwin Fertig of the Bronx.
College-trained chefs, experts in seasoned cooking, Southern style, are in the making at Tuskegee Institute.

BOSTON, July 7. -- Anyway, they had a fine day for it. The National League athletes had a slight edge in the first inning. They managed to hit the ball out of the infield. Billy Herman and Ducky Medwick made the outfielders move a trifle to haul down a couple of flies.
LONDON, July 7. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden left London tonight for a country retreat by order of his doctor, who said that he must have a week's complete rest.

ALBANY, July 7. -- Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, held today that the State correctly assessed Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse for a portion of his $10,000 salary which he voluntarily donated to the city.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- Charles H. Mayo Jr., Long Island amateur champion, set the pace over the Southampton Golf Club links today in a one-day tourney of the Long Island Golf Association by registering a sub-par round of 70.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 7, -- An exhibition of fifty flower paintings sponsored by the Garden Club of East Hampton, and loaned by several New York galleries and private collectors, will open in the Guild Hall art galleries next Tuesday, to continue there for two weeks.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7. -- Ecclesiastical trials were ordered today for five more militant Fundamentalist ministers who have resigned from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

Mayor La Guardia made a tour of four possible sites for an enlarged and improved East Side market yesterday, accompanied by Majority Leader Murray W. Stand of the Board of Aldermen; Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, and Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr.

The appearance of Governor LANDON yesterday before a special session of the Kansas Legislature, called to draft a State constitutional means to effect "social security," serves to remind overheated citizens that it is not the New Deal that is so much at issue between the parties as the means of assuring it.
BOSTON, July 7. -- Although the 1936 all-star game was voted a complete success by all of his National League colleagues, Dizzy (winning pitcher) Dean felt a bit cheated today.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- President Roosevelt granted to Postmaster General James A. Farley today a leave of absence from that office, effective from Aug. 1 until after the November elections.

Justice James C. Cropsey, in the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday awarded damages of $33,900 to three independent laundries in their suit against Jacob Mellon, "czar" of the laundry industry in Brooklyn, and fourteen of his associates in the Affiliated Laundry Owners Club.

From Washington yesterday came a strong hint that the 1936 duck shooting regulations will be no less drastic than those in force last year. The rules which will govern water-fowl gunning next Fall are expected to be announced within a few weeks.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 7. -- The "right" of a speculator to equal treatment with an investor was proclaimed here tonight by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

Due to yesterday's heavy buyer registrations, the total for the week ended yesterday was the highest since the week ended April 22, when 1,017 were listed. During the past week 917 arrivals were reported in THE TIMES as against 702 in the preceding week and 765 in the same period last year.
Three Summer camps in real country-like settings were opened yesterday within New York City for more than 500 young girls by the Manhattan Council of the Girl Scouts.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- A comprehensive program to give work relief or subsistence to 100,000 families impoverished by the drought and provide soon for another 34,000, in addition to 70,000 families already on subsistence relief in the drought areas, was set in motion today by President Roosevelt.

Negotiations in Hollywood between Joseph M. Schenck, chairman of the board of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, and Isidor Ostrer, president of the Gaumont-British Picture Corporation, Ltd., may result in either company buying out the other's interest in the British concern, Mr. Schenck said yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,892,300 barrels daily, compared to 2,969,150 in the preceding week, a drop of 76,850, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Declines of 46,650 and of 30,450 barrels, respectively, in the daily average outputs of Oklahoma and Texas were the important changes.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 7. -- An upward swing in the number of new stock companies formed in the first six months of this year was noted today by the division of corporations of the Secretary of State's office. Up to July 1 charters had been granted to 9,892 new concerns, an increase of fifty over the same period last year.
JERUSALEM, July 7. -- The death roll continues to mount, while Palestine sniping and acts of terrorism show no sign of abating.

The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation reported as of June 30, total resources of $34,196,713, compared to $20,904,317 on June 30, 1935. The amounts due customers were $18,745,067, against $9,192,272 a year ago. Cash on hand and due from New York banks was $4,555,578, against $2,094,369; amounts due from other banks, $1,134,989, against $1,030,008; holdings of United States Government securities, $14,226,596, against $6,943,634.

Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin reserved decision yesterday on an application by the Attorney General's office to continue a temporary injunction restraining Nat Gerber of 7,920 Nineteenth Avenue and Edward Fuerstein, 159 Eastern Parkway, both of Brooklyn, from doing business as Gerber Co. and the Gerber Corporation of 120 Wall Street.

The job of laying the groundwork for the World's Fair of 1939 will be in full swing by next week, it was revealed yesterday. The task involves the actual moving of more than 7,000,000 cubic yards of material in Flushing Meadow Park.

While admitting that passenger traffic had fallen off on some of their lines during June, executives of bus companies disagreed yesterday as to whether this was due to the competition of lower railroad fares or to the usual falling off of business for a few days following a holiday.

Plans for a permanent non-profit corporation to direct a World Two-Way Trade Fair as an annual event in New York were discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of rail and ship line traffic men in the auditorium of the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

Pledging themselves to cooperative action in the interests of the industry as a whole, liquor wholesalers and retailers met at a "get-together" luncheon in the Hotel Astor yesterday and laid plans for formation of a general committee composed of representatives of all branches of the industry.

CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP). -- Riotous running fights in which one company bus was burned, another wrecked and a third pursued into the Hamilton County Court House yard late today caused minor injuries to more than thirty persons and resulted tonight in a truce between Remington-Rand, Inc., and strikers at its suburban Norwood factory.

MONTREAL, July 7. -- The wheat surplus which has haunted the imagination and embarrassed the exchequer of two Canadian governments practically ceased to be a factor today when an official crop report confirmed Western reports of damage from sweltering heat and drought.
A variety of Manhattan property was sold yesterday, the deals including a house for a new bridge club, an East Side taxpayer, West Side apartment houses held by banks and a Marble Hill site.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 7. -- The wooded terrain of Gallows Hill, four miles north of here, resounded to the firing of rifles, machine guns and trench mortars for nearly three hours this morning as the 1,100 members of the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn, the Blue army, strove to check the advance of the 1,100 men of the 105th Infantry of Troy, the Red army, on a theoretical mission to seize the railroads at Peekskill.

Whether exaggerated importance is being given to the drought and the labor threats in the steel industry, stock-marketwise, remains to be seen, but yesterday there was no gainsaying the fact that these topics received full consideration. Admittedly, followers of the share market are never on sure ground when attempting to puzzle out widely fluctuating grain prices or highly involved labor controversies, and stock prices moved nervously yesterday. The list closed generally lower.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee gave a farewell dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and. Mrs. Milo Sargent Gibbs, and Mr. and Mrs. Van Courtland Moon, who will sail today on the Queen Mary to pass the Summer abroad.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7. -- The opening tonight of the Newport Casino Theatre's Summer season under the direction of the Actors Managers, Inc., of New York, with the presentation of "When Ladies Meet," starring Doris Dalton and Stephen Ker Appleby, was the occasion of the gathering of a large number of the Summer colony.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- On the eve of a momentous meeting of the American Federation of Labor's executive council tomorrow, President William Green today charged the committee for industrial organization, led by John L. Lewis, with thwarting the federation's plan to organize the steel industry by the united action of the labor movement.

MINEOLA., L.I., July 7. -- Picturing President Roosevelt as a "despot," benevolent, perhaps, in his purposes, and Governor Lehman as "blindly" following his leadership, State Senator George R. Fearon of Onondaga, who heads the list of aspirants for the Republican nomination for Governor, made here tonight one of the most aggressive verbal attacks on the New Deal on record so far.

The Japanese military has made a tactical retreat, but its strategic position remains unshaken. Yielding to domestic pressure, and with an eye to foreign opinion, the military high command has imposed the almost unprecedented sentence of death upon seventeen leaders of the February army revolt, during which three of the most prominent statesmen were assassinated.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Jubilant officials of the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart reported today that more furniture buyers have arrived for the opening days of the July market than ever before in Chicago's history as a furniture center.

San Francisco maintains politely but firmly that there need be no apprehension over a conflict of two "world fairs" in 1939, for the simple reason that "the Golden Gate International Exposition will open punctually on Feb. 18, 1939, whereas the New York World's Fair cannot reasonably open until 1940," according to an official spokesman, Walter Gaines Swanson, who is at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria on a brief visit here.

Profit-taking was the rule in the commodity futures markets here yesterday, following the protracted advance in some staples. Sugar and metal futures were firmer, however. On the cash markets, wheat, rye and lard eased, while cotton and corn made new high records and butter and tin advanced.

Matthew Alexander Henson, the Negro who accompanied Admiral Peary to the North Pole in 1909, is going to retire from the United States Customs Service on Sept. 1 on reaching the age limit of 70 years.

Although the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income equal to $1.49 on each share of 1,891,766 average number of common shares for the year ended on May 31, the directors, who met to consider the declaration of a common dividend, decided to take no action at this time.

The cotton producers' pool, a Government agency, completed yesterday the liquidation of its contracts for cotton for future delivery. Thus for the first time since 1930 when the old Federal Farm Loan Board started to aid cotton by operating in the futures markets, the United States Government is out of the contract cotton market.

More than 7,500 residents of Staten Island attended the dedication of the new Tompkinsville swimming pool at Pier 6 and Arietta Street at which Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Moses and other city officials spoke last night.
FREE CITY OF DANZIG, July 7. -- The National Socialist party, which controls the Danzig Senate, struck sharply at the Opposition here today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 7. -- Open defiance of John L. Lewis's campaign to bring them within the ranks of his industrial union was voiced today by several hundred employes of the Republic Steel Corporation in a mass meeting.

The 3-year-old Reminding, youngest racer and the only filly in the event, was first in the featured Briarcliff Handicap at Empire City yesterday. Five started and at the end of the mile and a furlong the Wheatley Stable racer had soundly defeated the others, five lengths dividing her heels from her nearest rival.

With an attack upon the new Nazi scientific ideals proclaimed at the recent Heidelberg University celebrations, and with a declaration of devotion to "truth for truth's sake," the "University in Exile" conferred its first degrees last night at commencement exercises in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Arnold Volpe, who more than eighteen years ago inaugurated the symphony concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium will return to the Stadium podium as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on July 18. On that evening Mr. Volpe will share the stage with Jose Iturbi, the Spanish conductor and pianist.

A banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 of water bonds of the city of Salem, Mass., on a bid of par for the 1936 to 1950 maturities as 3 1/2s, the 1951 to 1960 maturities as 3 3/4s and the 1961 to 1976 maturities as 4s.
TOPEKA, July 7. -- Following is the text of the address of Governor Alf M. Landon to the Kansas Legislature today:

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan's plan to dismiss five or six of his assistants "for the good of the service" met yesterday with unexpected and vigorous resistance from the second of the two aides who, so far, have been nominated for "a return to private practice."

An interest rate of .34 of 1 per cent, the lowest in the city's history, was obtained yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor on a $5,000,000 issue of five-month special corporate stock notes that was sold to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
CHICAGO, July 7. -- The heat wave again set records over the 100 degree mark in its fifth day of dominance in the drought stricken regions of the Central and Northwest States.

No development following the Drukman murder case has been more remarkable than the sudden reforms announced by Mr. GEOGHAN and the comments accompanying them. They constitute in themselves an amazing confession of previous laxity, and unveil a shocking system as if it had been known and accepted as a matter of course.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The New York Curb Exchange, at a hearing today before a trial examiner, Charles S. Lobingier, of the Securities and Exchange Commission, fought to have the commission rule that the unlisted trading privilege of the common stock of Bower Roller Bearing Company should be continued on the Curb.

Only one speech at the Triborough Bridge ceremonies on Saturday will be as much as five minutes long, and the others will be held down to three minutes. This should be regarded by the speakers not as a handicap but as an opportunity.

Twelve Manhattan properties were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. The largest parcels were the thirteen-story Film Center Building, at Ninth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, and a ten-story apartment house at Riverside Drive and 148th Street.

Lewis E. Lawes, warden of Sing Sing, is now at work on a new play for Brock Pemberton, the latter announced yesterday. The warden's collaborator on the script, which deals with prison life, is Jonathan Finn. Entitled "Chalked Out," the play will he produced next Fall under Antoinette Perry's direction.

PARIS, July 7. -- In its role of conservative custodian of republican liberty, the French Senate administered to the Blum government today its first check since it took power, after having obtained a somewhat reluctant promise from Minister of the Interior Roger Salengro that he would not permit a recurrence of the stay-in strikes.

The 1,415 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $44,163,734,954 par value on July 1, had a total market value of $41,618,750,056, according to a compilation by the Exchange, issued yesterday. On June 1 there were 1,413 issues, aggregating $42,255,103,407 par value, which had a total market value of $39,648,252,468.
LONDON, July 7. -- Tangible evidence of the government's uneasiness over the foreign outlook is found in the increasing pressure to accelerate rearmament.

Boys' and students' clothing and accessories for the Fall and Winter season will be more colorful than ever, it was indicated yesterday by the exhibits at the seventh annual convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 7. -- Italy's refusal to attend the Dardanelles conference was significantly followed here today by the adoption of a more conciliatory attitude toward each other by Great Britain and Soviet Russia.

A request from the Municipal Civil Service Commission for a $42,000 appropriation to aid in defraying the cost of civil service examinations for the rest of the year was referred to committee yesterday afternoon by the Board of Aldermen after an hour of bickering.
THE NEW YORK TIMES recent editorial "Getting Rid of the Slums" is quite right in asserting that New Dealers and old dealers must share the responsibility for the continuance of our slums.

PARIS, July 7. -- The newspaper Journal declared today that strikers at the Citroen automobile factory, near Chaumont, had locked up two company directors after the directors had refused demands for the dismissal of two engineers. The men were released, government officials said, after three hours' captivity.

James Loeb, retired member of the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., of which his father, Solomon Loeb, was a founder, left an estate appraised yesterday at $2,526,631 gross and $2,258,996 net when he died at Murnau, Bavaria, on May 27, 1933.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 7 (AP). -- Representative P. Josh Lee held a substantial lead in returns from the Democratic Senatorial primary race late tonight as Governor E.W. Marland pushed slightly ahead of Gomer Smith, national Townsend Plan vice president, for the other run-off post.

Business failures in the retail group in the United States in the week ended July 2 showed the largest decline from their average of any week so far this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the week was 87, compared with 91 in the previous week, showing a drop of 40 under the weekly average, the agency reports.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP). -- The Treasury Department has quietly started a new drive to tighten up enforcement of liquor laws and increase alcoholic tax collections during the 1937 fiscal year, just started.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, declared at the party's headquarters here today that the New Deal's crop-curtailment program has increased the hardships caused by the drought. His statement was supported by Senator L.J. Dickinson of Iowa.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- President Roosevelt announced today that he had written letters to all department and bureau heads asking them to make a real effort to save some portion of the appropriations made to their divisions by Congress.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Republican leaders were more confident than ever today of the success of the Landon-Knox candidacies in the Farm Belt upon receipt of news that The Omaha World-Herald, "a leading Democratic organ in the Upper Missouri Valley for more than half a century," had "turned its support to Landon."

ALBANY, July 7 (AP). -- Governor Lehman brought to a climax today the protracted dispute over Buffalo's $15,000,000 sewer project, which brought indictments accusing Mayor George J. Zimmermann of "political bribery" and subsequent dismissal of the charges in court.

The long and arduous work of translating the rolls of papyri discovered recently in Palestine by the Colt Archaeological Expedition began here yesterday at New York University and probably will continue for four years. The papyri, consisting of about fifty complete manuscripts and between three and four thousand scraps, arrived here aboard the steamship Queen Mary on Monday in the possession of H. Dunscombe Colt, leader of the expedition.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- General buying, based on the continued intense heat over the leading grain producing areas of North America, swept prices up to a new high level for the season at the start of trading today on the Board of Trade, with corn and oats both touching the maximum limits permitted for one day's operations under Exchange regulations.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 7. -- An hour after arriving from Louisville, Ky., Frank Parker, the defending cup holder, went on the court at the Bathing and Tennis Club this afternoon for his first match of the season in the East as the Spring Lake invitation tournament got under way.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today amended its ruling granting exemptions from Section 9 (a) (2) of the Public Utility Act of 1935, under certain conditions, to brokers and dealers in connection with acquisitions of securities of public-utility and holding companies in the ordinary course of business.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 7. -- Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding general of the Second Corps Army Area, Governors Island, will review the Citizens Military Training Camp regiment now in training here on Friday morning. General McCoy is expected here late Thursday, and will spend Friday inspecting the work of the young citizen soldiers.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- With more than 200,000 new works of art completed by WPA artists throughout the country and 120,000 of these already allocated to tax-supported institutions, the WPA has turned its attention to establishing galleries throughout the South, where such museums are not numerous.

Television staged its first "planned show" over the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon, favored by the atmospheric conditions of a perfect July day. The invited guests who viewed the performance at Radio City were licensees of the Radio Corporation of America.

BOSTON, July 7. -- An irresistible force met an immovable body today and the party of the first part came out second best. The American League, shackled for two-thirds of the way by the matchless pitching of Jerome H. (Dizzy) Dean and Carl Owen Hubbell, and subsequently by still another pitching wizard named Lonnie Warneke, finally succumbed to the National League in the fourth annual all-star game between the two major circuits.

TORONTO, July 7 (AP). -- The Toronto Leafs made it two in a row over the Newark Bears tonight as they cut a Newark rally short at one run in the ninth to win, 3 -- 1. Two runs in the seventh and another in the eighth gave the Leafs their margin.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 8. -- Nine of a group of airplanes that had deserted Southwest China appeared over Nanking this evening flying in formation and then landed on the airfield of the Central Government's capital.

The firm undertone in high-grade corporate bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was more than offset by the declines that spread throughout the list of secondary and more sensitive issues. The latter movement was attributed directly to the unsettlement in the market for junior securities and was reflected to the greatest degree among the lower-priced railroad and public utility bonds.

North Jersey commuters on the Pennsylvania Railroad from as far south as Point Pleasant are refusing to pay the supplemental charge of 15 cents for coming into Pennsylvania Station instead of changing at Manhattan Transfer to the Hudson tubes, it was learned yesterday.

COHASSET, Mass., July 7. -- That terrifying affliction, artistic genius, and the complications which it seems invariably to cause in human lives, is the subject, for treatment in Gordon Daviot's London drama, "The Laughing Woman," which had its first American showing here by the South Shore Players last evening.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- The United Cities Utilities Company of Chicago, a registered holding company, has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for exemption from provisions of Section 13a of the Public Utility Act of 1935 which prohibits, except in "special or unusual circumstances," performance of service, sales or construction contracts by a registered holding company for its associate utility companies.

LONDON, July 7. -- The stock markets here were again quiet today but the undertone was firm, helped by reports of a further decrease in unemployment and by a continuance of favorable trade reports. With the prospect of a resumption of borrowing by corporations soon and renewed talk of a big loan for national defense, British funds remained uncertain early but under the lead of the war loan they strengthened in the afternoon.

MEXICO, D.F., July 7. -- The Mexican Congress held a special session today in honor of the United States Senators and Representatives visiting here on governmental invitation after their tour of inspection along the new highway from Laredo, Texas, to this capital.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 7. -- American neutrality in the "next war" will be impossible, however ardently the nation desires it, and the "great decision" will be made in the light of the situation at the moment, Frederic R. Coudert of New York and P.H.W. Almy, British barrister, told a round table on international good-will at the University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs today.

Mr. FARLEY has made a wise move in taking leave of his office as Postmaster General during the campaign, but it would have been still better had he resigned the office. By every sound rule of democratic practice it is improper that the head of a great Government department, with many appointments at his command, should serve simultaneously as chairman of the political party in power.

Placards were up, telephones in and typewriters clattering on the fourth floor of the Hotel Biltmore yesterday. Department heads, save one, were at their desks and campaign activities of the women's division of the Democratic party were going ahead at a mid-campaign pace.

If the two party platforms of 1936 are to be taken seriously, the next Congress, regardless of who is elected President or which party has a majority in the House, will proceed vigorously to shore up the anti-trust laws. Criminal as well as civil statutes will be invoked by the next administration to punish acts in restraint of trade, and "regulation" will be abandoned in favor of actual suppression.

The sharp decline in the average rate of interest on Treasury discount bills noted in this week's sale of the usual $50,000,000 compared with the previous week's allotment was explained in financial circles yesterday as due to the demand for these bills from banks and corporations in Chicago.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 7 (AP). -- An official source said today that Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium had invited Italy to attend a conference of Locarno signatories and to specify the day for the meeting herself. Mr. van Zeeland, it was stated, told Premier Mussolini's government that any date between July 16 and 24 would be satisfactory.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 7. -- County Judge Cortland A. Johnson refused today to affirm or deny reports that he had asked Governor Lehman to commute the death sentence of Everett Appelgate, convicted slayer, to life imprisonment.

The body of George Ernest Gibson, at one time one of the foremost heating and plumbing contractors in this city, was found yesterday floating in the lower bay off Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Gibson, 61 years old, had been missing since June 29 after he had written to his lawyer and to members of his family saying that he was going to jump into the East River.

Baldwin Maull, vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, successor trustee under the indenture for Kreuger Toll 5 per cent secured debentures, has forwarded to holders of the debentures a report of the trustee's activities since Dec. 31, 1935, the date of its last general report.

MATUNUCK, R.I., July 7. -- Theodore Packard's new farce, "Crab Apple," was presented tonight at the Theatre-by-the-Sea. Mr. Packard's play deals with the taming of a household despot. A gay little comedy with bright dialogue and frankly presented, "Crab Apple" proved light entertainment for a Summer's evening.

PARIS, July 7. -- The funeral of General Charles H. Sherrill was held today in the American Cathedra Church of the Holy Trinity. His son, Gibbs W. SherriIl, arrived in Paris from the United States last night and was present with Mrs. Sherrill.

A campaign to organize 40,000 laundry workers in the metropolitan district into a union "as labor's reply to the Supreme Court" was planned yesterday by American Federation of Labor officials. The organization drive, which was decided on at a meeting in the offices of the Central Trades and Labor Council, is a result of the invalidation of the State Minimum Wage Law, intended to protect women workers in laundries.

LONDON, July 7. -- With the empire already facing an overdraft as the result of the rearmament program, the army, navy and air force are seeking additional money to build ships and airplanes and to whip the mechanization of land forces into first-class shape.

LONDON, July 7. -- The growing split in the American Federation of Labor was being watched anxiously today by European trades union leaders assembled in London for the triennial meeting of the International Federation of Trades Unions.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 7. -- Seeded stars, with one exception, came through with victories today as the Westchester junior and boys' tournament at the County Tennis Club progressed toward the final rounds.

SIR ARNOLD WILSON, author of "Walks and Talks Abroad" (published tomorrow by Oxford, $2.50), has served his country in various roles -- in the army, the consular services, the Indian Political Department and the Anglo-Persian Oil Company. He has written books upon such topics as Persia, Mesopotamia and the Suez Canal, and now occupies a seat in the House of Commons and edits a magazine called The Nineteenth Century and After.

BERLIN, July 7. -- The Boerse was almost entirely inactive today, only specialties showing a slight sign of activity. Heavy industrial stocks did not establish any tendency. Vereinigtesthal lost one-eighth of a point. Machine shares also were quiet, with a tendency toward weakness, Muag losing a half point.

Steel ingot production in the first six months of this year amounted to 21,326,355 gross tons, an increase of nearly 35 per cent over the output in the same period of last year, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. This was the largest output for any first half year since 1930, when 23,578,619 gross tons were produced.

WASHINGTON, July 7. -- William Prentiss Jr., Acting Controller of the Currency, announced today completion of the liquidation of sixteen bank receiverships in June, bringing to 405 the number of receiverships finally closed or banks restored to solvency since the banking holiday of March, 1933.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7. -- Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin gave a dinner and bridge tonight at Les Alouettes, her home on Lake Agawam, for Mrs. Samuel Sloan. Other guests were Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn, Mrs. William A. Lockwood, Mrs. Joseph Sill Clark, Miss Elisabeth Banks Brundige, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, Miss Etthel Spears, Mrs. Tillman Martin, Mrs. Albert Herter and Mrs. George W. Watson.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 7. -- Three teams came through to the second round of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club as the first round was completed today. All three matches were closely fought throughout, with Ox Ridge defeating the Aknusti Juniors, 7 to 4; Great Island downing the Camels, 5 to 4, and Governors Island turning back the Vipers, 9 to 7.

ROME, July 7 (AP). -- An unidentified Italian air general and nine aviators, including the famous flier Antonio Locatelli, were killed in an Ethiopian ambush several days ago, reliable sources said tonight, despite official denial.

The climax of the opening of the Fall garment season, which took place yesterday, was a remarkable success, according to manufacturers' reports. As on Monday it was not a day of buying but of observation, a series of individual style promenades in leading coat and dress establishments. It was not uncommon for 200 or more buyers to attend a single showing.
WASHINGTON, July 7. -- Disbursements by the Treasury on adjusted service certificates through July 3, with some slight additions on July 6, were estimated today at $1,066,018,000.

DARIEN, Conn., July 7. -- Miss Helen Bedford of Greens Farms, Conn., today won the right to hold for one year the $500 Corinthian Trophy, presented by Mrs. E.H. Wells for the leading event in the first day's program of the tenth annual horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, which opened this morning on the club's grounds.

TOPEKA, July 7. -- A group of announced representatives of labor and unemployed organizations, including the Kansas Allied Workers, appeared before the Judiciary Committees of the Legislature today after calling upon Governor Landon for permission to address the Legislature.

The theft of jewelry valued at $3,000, after the woman who owned it had been put to sleep by a cocktail, was revealed yesterday in Felony Court at the arraignment of Miss Siri Rydberg, 50 years old, a graduate nurse.

The deficit of the American Olympic Committee's fund shrank $10,000 in the last two days so that it now is down to $139,924, Treasurer Gustavus Town Kirby reported yesterday. Contributions started to come in since details of the Olympic team finances were made known after Sunday's meeting.

LONDON, July 7. -- A deal between Twentieth Century-Fox and Gaumont British, the largest British film company, capitalized at 7,000,000, is nearing completion, it is reported here, although Gaumont officials today declined to confirm or deny.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- Selected lightweight hogs were steady in early trading, but weakened later with other kinds, and at the close the general market was quoted about 10 cents a hundredweight lower, with some sales regarded as down more.

TRENTON, July 7. -- Governor Hoffman refused today to grant the extradition of Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives, to Brooklyn, where he is under indictment for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

" About this time," says the Old Farmer's Almanac in its astronomical observations for mid-June and July, "the major planet Bilborah will com- "plete its quadrennial period of orbital "revolution." Millions have been standing with their mouths open on the stairway of surprise, watching the western heavens.

Investment deals involving multifamily houses in various sections of the Bronx were reported yesterday. Among the houses figuring in the deal were the three five-story buildings at the northwest corner of 176th Street and Bathgate Avenue, known as 499 East 176th Street and 1,867 and 1,869 Bathgate Avenue, on a plot 108 by 129.6 feet.

No American has ever won the javelin throw in the Olympic Games and that singularly undistinguished record should remain unbroken this year. In the hammer throw, however, Irish-American giants ruled supreme until a native Irishman, Dr. Pat O'Callaghan, picked up the thread in 1928 and again in 1932.

They were all trying very hard last night, those Metropolitan Players who brought their "Nine o'Clock Revue" to the Heckscher Theatre. With all the good will in the world they played at their little sketches, sang their sad songs, even danced a turn or two.

As the five Republican leaders of New York City prepared to pick a designee for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen it was learned last night that they will make their selection without consulting Mayor La Guardia, who though nominally a Republican was elected on a Fusion ticket.

The Warner Brothers' latest excursion into the field of crime melodramma, "Public Enemy's Wife," will have its first Broadway showing this morning at the Strand. The lady of the title is Margaret Lindsay and she is assisted by Pat O'Brien, Cesar Romero, Robert Armstrong, Nick Foran and Joseph King, to mention only a few.

The Grace Line signed an agreement yesterday with the Dock Department for the lease of Pier 57, North River, for ships it operates between New York and the west coast of South America. The contract will be effective Aug. 15.

LENOX, Mass., July 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas of New York and Bluefens, Stockbridge, w/ll give a dbut ball for their daughter, Miss Frances P. Clucas, at the Lenox Club on Sept. 4. The next night, Miss Beatrice S. Procter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney Prtcter, will be presented to society at 0rleton Farm, Stockbridge.

Sales of the J.C. Penney Company in June and in first six months of this year established new high records for these periods for the company, it was announced yesterday. Sales in June of $21,474,807 were 19.7 per cent more than those of $17,934,548 in June, 1935.

They were all trying very hard last night, those Metropolitan Players who brought their "Nine o'Clock Revue" to the Heckscher Theatre. With all the good will in the world they played at their little sketches, sang their sad songs, even danced a turn or two.

As the five Republican leaders of New York City prepared to pick a designee for the Presidency of the Board of Aldermen it was learned last night that they will make their selection without consulting Mayor La Guardia, who though nominally a Republican was elected on a Fusion ticket.

The Warner Brothers' latest excursion into the field of crime melodramma, "Public Enemy's Wife," will have its first Broadway showing this morning at the Strand. The lady of the title is Margaret Lindsay and she is assisted by Pat O'Brien, Cesar Romero, Robert Armstrong, Nick Foran and Joseph King, to mention only a few.

The Grace Line signed an agreement yesterday with the Dock Department for the lease of Pier 57, North River, for ships it operates between New York and the west coast of South America. The contract will be effective Aug. 15.

Active leasing of suites for Fall occupancy is reported by brokers handling apartment buildings in and near Manhattan. In the long lists of rentals announced yesterday, following the week-end holiday, were several large apartments. Quite a few were in the Fifth and Park Avenue neighborhoods.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 7. -- A combination of luck and good sailing gave Edward V. Ketcham Jr. and his eighteen-year-old boat Draco another victory and a commanding lead in the Star Class Atlantic Coast Olympic semi-final series today.

Charging that they have been the victims of misrepresentation in the sale of shoes in the so-called "cancellation shops" operating in many sections of the city, representatives of department stores and specialty shops yesterday pushed plans designed to eliminate this form of merchandising.

The Nash Motor Company reported yesterday for its second quarter ended on May 31 a net profit, after deducting manufacturing and administration expenses and allowing for Federal and State taxes, of $353,516. This contrasts with a net loss, on the same basis, of $556,310 in the corresponding period of last year.

Miss Edith Parnell, editorial manager of Charles F. Higham, Ltd., London, and the only woman delegate to the Boston advertising convention last week, left for Montreal last night impressed with the progress of advertising in this country and making the prediction that the United States will follow the example of Great Britain with respect to radio advertising.

A group of nearly 100 Brooklyn property owners staged a demonstration in the tenth-floor corridors of the Municipal Building early yesterday afternoon after the Board of Standards and Appeals, following a hearing, granted an application for construction of an addition to an iron foundry in the Brownsville section.
BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 7. -- British marksmen led the way in today's events at the National Rifle Association's annual Bisley meet.

ALBANY, July 7. -- Governor Lehman announced tonight after a three-hour conference with Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey and Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook, who have been investigating rackets in New York City, that he would impanel immediately two more special grand juries and call Special Terms of the Supreme Court to continue the work started by Mr. Dewey.

ALBANY, July 7. -- In the fiscal year just ended, the State nearly halved its deficit, cutting it from $97,048,752.52 to $55,877,428.89 with the aid of emergency taxes, figures prepared by Controller Tremaine and released today by Governor Lehman showed.
HARRISBURG, July 7. -- Unemployment relief machinery in Pennsylvania came to a halt today with the relief treasury empty.
HEWLETT, L.I., July 7. -- L. James Gumpert and his son Ted won the first New York State father-and-son golf championship on the Seawane course today.

Referring to the letter of Alexander Michael, it seems to me an extremely narrow viewpoint to uphold the Roosevelt administration simply because Mr. Michael has personally benefited by it. As well might an undertaker rejoice in an automobile accident which might wipe out Mr. Michael and his entire family, on account of the revenue he might derive therefrom.

TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., July 7. -- One hundred rabbis are attending the Rabbinical Assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, which opened its annual convention here yesterday and will continue through Thursday.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 7. -- With negotiations between striking members of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America and the RCA Manufacturing Company virtually at a standstill, the union announced this afternoon a plan to picket the RCA offices in Radio City, New York.

NEWARK, N.J., July 7. -- Carrying out a ruling from Washington that, effective July 1, workers on Works Progress Administration rolls must be paid at the "prevailing" hourly rate, the New Jersey office of the WPA announced today the rates which will govern hours of work and earnings on the various classes of employment in the different areas in the State.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary is sailing today for Southampton via Cherbourg with 1,900 passengers. The list includes:

TOPEKA, July 7. -- Governor Landon, in a message to the special session of the Kansas Legislature, and a later statement to the press, took a broad stand today in favor of social security legislation, likening it to a dike built after some great disaster to prevent its repetition in the future.

Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday denied a motion by the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Company and the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company for the dismissal of a suit for $200,000 damages brought by Mrs. Mathilda Willmott of 200-07 104th Avenue, Hollis, for the death of her husband, Robert H. Willmott, captain of the steamship Morro Castle.

PITTSBURGH, July 7. -- The steel unionization campaign of the Committee for Industrial Organization will proceed regardless of what action the executive council of the American Federation of Labor takes, it was asserted this afternoon by Phillip Murray, mine union vice president, and director of the steel campaign.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 8. -- Visiting the Mount Washington today were Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes, who passed the last three seasons there, but this year took a cottage at Sugar Hill. They later were honored at a large tea in Chase Barn Theatre, Whitefield, given by the Yale Forty-niners and their patrons.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Constitutionality of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was challenged today in a special appeal filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia by the Diamond Match Company of New York City.

Barring "controversial" and costly matters at Mayor La Guardia's request, the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate, with the Mayor absent in the Bronx, spent more than two hours yesterday tossing wisecracks and millions of dollars carelessly about.
GLEN HEAD, N.Y., July 8. -- Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of Plandome proved today that golfing records can still be set at the famous Women's National Golf and Tennis Club course.
WARSAW, July S. -- The Polish Government's attitude in the Danzig situation was explained today in an article in the Polish Political Information, official publication of the Foreign Office.

BERLIN, July 8. -- The Boerse was again very quiet today, with tendency toward weakness at the opening and scattered signs of strength at the close. Heavy industrial shares showed some strength, Harpener gaining 1 point.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 8 (AP). -- New disturbances which brought thirty State policemen to Middletown for strike duty near the typewriter factory of Remington-Rand, Inc., caused Governor Cross today to cut short his Summer vacation.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8. -- War debts and the future of the League of Nations were further discussed today in the round-table conference on international good-will, which continues to attract more than half the men and women registered at the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs.

Federal Judge Vincent L, Leibell, who was appointed to the bench recently by President Roosevelt, received a lesson in philately yesterday at the trial of a stamp dealer accused of possessing 1,000 counterfeit 2-cent stamps and 130 revenue stamps from which the cancellation marks had been erased.

PARIS, July 8. -- The new government is proceeding slowly with its revision of the Bank of France, which formed one of the leading articles of its program. Instead of pushing through the bill assuring it a free hand for revising the bank's statutes, it is learned, the government will probably make some changes in the bill as it was recently presented to Parliament.

TOPEKA, July 8. -- Democrats in the Kansas Senate made a concerted effort today to pick holes in the Landon record as Governor, but were beaten down in all their attempts, which sought to prevent limitation of this special session to constitutional amendments paving the way for State participation in the Federal social security program.

Paul Kerby, the British conductor, made his first Stadium appearance last night before an audience of 4,500. Although he had often directed previously in this country, much interest was aroused as to the effect his interpretations and method of approach would make in the open air.
CHICAGO, Thursday, July 9. -- John M. Bolton, Democratic State Representative from the Second District, was assassinated by unidentified gunmen early today on the West Side.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 8. -- By way of showing that there was no accident in their first two victories, Eddie Ketcham and Bill Hayward in the yacht Draco won again today, this time by a greater margin than ever, to become the Atlantic Coast representatives in the finals of the Olympic Star Class elimination series

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration estimated today that the livelihood of at least 3,000,000 and perhaps 5,000,000 or more farm dwellers bad been seriously affected by the great Western drought, and during the day government agencies intensified their drive to cope with the situation, which hourly seemed more tragic.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 8. -- Miss Ruth Bedford Moran opened her home, The Studio, this morning for a talk on new fiction given by Miss Louise Maunsell Field. Among those present were Mrs. E. Clifford Potter, Mrs. W. Sterling Peters, Mrs. John Frederick Erdmann, Mrs. Frederick Fuller, Miss Laura Benet, Mrs. John White Howell, Mrs. John Griggs and Miss Griggs, Mrs. William Efner Wheelock and Mrs. Daniel O'Gorman.
HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 8. -- In a series of upsets favorites fell victims to unheralded players in the junior and boys' tournaments today at the County Tennis Club.

McKEESPORT, Pa., July 8. -- Officials of the National Tube Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, declared today their 16,000 employes, of whom 6,500 work here, were satisfied with the employes' representation plan and would withstand all appeals of John L. Lewis and his Committee for Industrial Organization that they join an independent union.

The complaint in the annulment suit by Alfonso de Bourbon, Count of Covadonga, son of the former King of Spain, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court, where the ease was listed under the name of "Alfonso de Borbon against Adelmira de Borbon."

LLOYD GEORGE tosses his white mane as he steps up his vocabulary. He began by calling STANLEY BALDWIN and ANTHONY EDEN cowards, and he now calls them rats. LLOYD GEORGE has discovered a peculiarly malignant species of rat.

For many salt water anglers, the arrival of bluefish signalizes the beginning of offshore fishing. That the fighting blue devils finally have put in a belated appearance is evident from recent reports reaching this column.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The national income may rise to approximately $60,000,000,000 in 1936, compared with a low of $39,500,000,000 in 1932, Secretary Roper said today in a resume of the semi-annual statement on business conditions to be made public on July 13.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 8. -- Governor Lehman issued orders tonight for two extraordinary special and trial terms of the Supreme Court in New York County to continue the work of Thomas E. Dewey in the investigation and prosecution of rackets.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- With heavy sales accompanying the record-breaking influx of furniture buyers into Chicago for the July market, several manufacturers announced today that they could not take orders on some items calling for delivery in less than sixty days.

Production of pig iron in June, according to The Iron Age, was at the rate of 86,208 tons daily, a gain of nearly 1 per cent over the 85,432 tons poured daily in May. With one less working day, however, June output declined to 2,586,240 tons from 2,648,40l tons in the preceding month.
BUENOS AIRES, July 8. -- The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 30 shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

The most real threat to democratic government in this country does not come from the Communist or the Fascist but from the industrial racketeer. Communism and fascism, in so far as they are not sheer theory for most Americans, are largely convenient epithets used by people to describe opinions with which they disagree.

Isidor Buxbaum, Brooklyn attorney, will be appointed as a Municipal Court justice to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of Justice Lawrence C. Fish, Mayor La Guardia announced at the Summer City Hall yesterday.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. won yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,000,000 of city of Providence (R.I.) 3 per cent school bonds, in a sale marked by unusually active bidding by about ten investment groups.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP). -- A conference of the legal staff of the Federal Trade Commission next week was called today to consider an enforcement policy for the Patman-Robinson Anti-Price Discrimination Act.

SUFFERN, N.Y., July 8, -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent three hours today inspecting Camp Jane Addams here and came away convinced that American Legion charges of Communist teaching at the National Youth Administration institution for jobless young women were completely unfounded.

A survey by five architects of the design and construction of school buildings in an effort to enhance their beauty and lower the cost of such structures was authorized yesterday by the Board of Education.

Midtown business leases reported yesterday included rental of 10,000 square feet in 444 Madison Avenue by the Harry Meyers Company, a furniture-making firm which has been in West Fifty-second Street for more than twenty years. The company will move to the new location, at East Forty-ninth Street, next Fall.

Hoboken detectives and Federal authorities had a "problem" prisoner last night in the person of 16-year-old Anna Logan. While the officials disputed jurisdiction Anna sat in the detention room in police headquarters half amused at "all the fuss over a 50-cent permanent and a few groceries."

That the drought in the middle and northern Grain Belt has damaged the crops of corn, of other small grains and of Spring-sown wheat is already evident. How greatly the final yield of these crops will fall below earlier expectations depends on continuance or interruption of the extreme heat and lack of rainfall.

GREEN MOUNTAIN FALLS, Col., July 8 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace declared today that "it may be necessary to purchase as much as $30,000,000 of drought cattle" with Federal funds unless there are general rains over the greater part of the Corn Belt during July and August.
BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 8 (Canadian Press). -- H.M.S. Drake continued its winning streak today by carrying off the Hamilton Leigh Challenge Cup at the National Rifle Association's meeting.

HARRISBURG, July 8. -- A stalemate between Governor Earle and the Republican-controlled Senate, which resulted in a stoppage of all relief payments this week, continued today, with needy families throughout the State appealing to their county relief boards for assistance.

LONDON, July 8. -- The stock markets here were cheerful today and business showed some expansion. British funds rallied and were firmer. The foreign bond market was quieter, but Danzig loans advanced on covering by bears.

The draw and plans for the national junior championship, next major event of the polo season, were announced yesterday by the United States Polo Association. The event starts Sunday on Schley Field at the Burnt Mills Polo Club, Bedminster, N.J., the same place where the games were played last year, the opening match bringing together Laddie Sanford's Hurricanes and the Miami Valley Hunt and Polo Club from Ohio.

Two persons were injured, one seriously, at 7:25 A.M. yesterday when an explosion occurred in a basement room housing air-conditioning equipment for Schrafft's restaurant at 46-50 New Street, in the Wall Street area. The building runs through to 48 Broad Street.

Boys' wear sales can be increased substantially if manufacturers and retailers analyze the occasions which warrant "more appropriate and varied clothing" and by education in quality, Paul Hollister, executive vice president of R.H. Macy Co., said yesterday in an address before the Fall buying convention of the Boys' Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MILWAUKEE, July 8. -- John D. M. Hamilton, in his address to Wisconsin Republicans, termed the Roosevelt administration "a personal government that has appropriated to itself more of other people's money than any other administration in American history."

The Federal Government, which tried last Spring to close the mails to New York contest corporations and to organizations promoting the legalization of lotteries, has begun an investigation, it was revealed yesterday, to determine if at least one of the groups has violated the mail fraud statute.

BERLIN, July 8. -- Reports that Germany has offered Austria a treaty guaranteeing the independence of that State and non-intervention in its internal affairs received added credence today when it was rumored that Franz von Papen, the Reich's diplomatic representative in Vienna, and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg had virtually initialed an agreement to that effect.

Charles Herbert, notorious racketeer, has regained control of the schochtim union and has served new demands on the operators of kosher poultry slaughter houses which would cost the sorely burdened industry $1,000,000 a year, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, charged yesterday.

Preparations now being rushed for the opening of the Triborough Bridge on Saturday include the most elaborate police arrangements made for any celebration since Charles A. Lindbergh's triumphal return from Paris in June, 1927.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 8. -- Many Berkshire residents and visitors attended the first matinee concert of the season by the Gordon String Quartet at Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn., this afternoon. Tea was served and Mrs. John R. Sanford, Mrs. John F. Calhoun and Mrs. Charles C. Lieb of Cornwall poured.

Secret organizations with anti-Semitic and Fascist aims, similar to the Black Legion, are rapidly increasing both in numbers and in strength in the Middle West, the Rev. L.M. Birkhead, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Kansas City, Mo., said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today amended Form A-1 for the registration by corporations of securities under the Securities Act of 1933 to cover financial statements in the event of change in stock ownership, property and business.

OTTAWA, July 8. -- Prime Minister Mackenzie King's government announced today that it would refer to the British Privy Council for final determination of their validity the four measures of former Prime Minister R.B. Bennett's New Deal, which may be classed as social security legislation.

HEWLETT, L. I., July 8. -- AIick Gerard Jr. of Southampton, 20- year-old son of the well-known pro at the National Links, again found the Seawane Club course to his liking today as he annexed top honors in the qualifying round of the annual New York State junior championship.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Cotton acreage in cultivation on July 1 was estimated today by the crop reporting board at 30,621,000 acres, or 26,769,000 got more than the 27,888,000 acres in cultivation a year ago. The 1936 acreage compares with 27,860,000 acres in cultivation on the same date in 1934, 40,248,000 in 1933 and the 1928-32 average of 41,424,000 acres.

On the eve of a meeting of the Tammany executive committee, which is scheduled for this evening to select candidates for vacancies on the Court of General Sessions and the City Court, it was rumored in Tammany circles that General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein would be denied the nomination for a full term.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8. -- Three bankers, led by Dr. W. Randolph Burgess, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, agreed here today that there was no such thing as "credit control."
WASHINGTON, July 8 (TP). -- Increases in wholesale and retail automobile trade department-store collections and exports of paper products were reported today by the Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Prices of hogs declined from 15 to 40 cents a hundredweight as the result of the largest Wednesday receipts since Jan. 22. Hot weather, it was said, had ,curtailed consumers' buying of fresh pork and all interests were disposed to go slow in taking hold.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 8. -- The provisional C.M.T.C. regiment here was occupied today with routine drills. Despite the heat, which unofficially was said to be close to 90 degrees in the shade, the 1,300 candidates carried through their complete schedule of work.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows, Quotations are in cents:

BOSTON, July 8 (AP). -- Returning to the form that marked her Maryland conquests, H.C. McGehee's Fair Knightess, 3-year-old bay daughter of Bright Knight, scored an easy victory in today's Suffolk Downs feature, the Priscilla Alden Purse, and paid $15.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

The General American Investors Company, Inc., reported yesterday that on June 30 it had net assets of $33,242,104 applicable to securities after deducting all taxes except the surtax on undistributed profits and except the excess-profits tax that might be payable if the appreciation in value of securities over cost were realized.

Two men were injured seriously in an automobile collision in Brooklyn last evening, while rushing a 6-year-old boy, who had been fatally when knocked down by a injured truck, to the Cumberland Hospital.
