Mayor La Guardia refused to become excited yesterday at the suggestion that the five Republican county leaders in New York City planned to name a regular Republican for the Aldermanic presidency, although his Fusion colleague, the late Bernard S. Deutsch, originally was elected to that post for four years.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday its acceptance of the order issued by the Public Service Commission on June 26, reducing certain of its rates and charges throughout the State so as to save subscribers about $4,200,000 a year.

ALBANY, July 8. -- New York State may legally tax income received by a resident in the form of rents and mortgage interest although the property is located in another State, the Court of Appeals decided today. The action involved Mrs. Annie Cohn of New York City, who received $50,783.62 income in 1931 and 1932 from New Jersey real estate.

In on effort to compel Lord Duveen, international art expert and head of Duveen Brothers, to answer certain questions in support of the suit brought against him by Carl Hamilton, art collector, for $2,000,000 damages for taking part in an alleged conspiracy to ruin his collection, argument was heard before Supreme Court Justice McGoldrick yesterday.

In a close competition which was decided on the degree of difficulty of the optional dives, Miss Ruth Jump, 16-year-old Los Angeles girl, yesterday became national high platform diving champion at the recently opened Astoria Park pool.

Ending a two-day deadlock in the wholesale rug market yesterday, the Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., withdrew their four-row Axminster-type rug, priced at $16.50 f.o.b. mill, from sale at the Fall opening of rug and carpet lines. Immediately afterward the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company and Alexander Smith Sons restored their four and two-third row Axminsters to the original opening price of $19.50.

Directors of the Grace National Bank of New York declared yesterday a semi-annual dividend of $3 a share, payable September 1 to stockholders of record on Aug. 26. This payment is an increase of 50 cents over the previous semi-annual disbursement.

In the hope of discovering new ideas and new methods which may aid this country in fighting droughts and in preserving its land resources F.A. Silcox, Chief Forester of the United States, sailed at midnight yesterday aboard the steamship Hensa on a four-month tour of Europe.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 8. -- President Roosevelt was urged by Rafael Martinez Nadal, president of the majority coalition, and Antonio R. Barcelo, president of the Liberty party, by cablegram today to dismiss the cases against Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, and seven other Nationalists charged with conspiracy to overthrow the Government of the United States, incite rebellion and recruit an army.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP). -- Count Morse, given a brilliant ride by Jockey Eddie Arcaro, won the fifth and feature race at Arlington Park today by a neck over T.C. Worden's Billy Jones. Joseph E. Widener's Silversmith finished third.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of securities of five companies, including those of the Reliable Stores Corporation and the Flintkote Company, formerly traded on the New York Curb Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A proposed commercial zone for New York City, within which motor carrier operations would be exempt from the regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission, was submitted to the commission today in a report by Examiner Kenneth J. McAuliffe.

Prohibition forces, working through local option elections last year, won an increase of 149 per cent in the number of towns and of 94 per cent in the number of counties voting dry, C.D. Williams, secretary of the United States Brewers Association, said yesterday in announcing results of a nation-wide survey on dry activities just completed by his organization.

Ellis Parker Jr. returned to his home and family in Mount Holly, N.J., last night and submitted to arrest in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, the disbarred Trenton attorney who made a hoax confession to the Lindbergh crime.

LONDON, July 8. -- Chancellor Hitler is giving way to Premier Mussolini over Austria. This sensational move of the Fuehrer's is the result of fear that Italy and Russia will come together in a pact for the defense of Central Europe against the German military menace.

Dr. A.H. Giannini, chairman of the general executive committee of the Bank of America, was elected to the presidency of the United Artists Corporation, motion picture producers and distributors, at a meeting of the owner-producer members of the corporation yesterday afternoon in Hollywood.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., July 8. -- Out in Buzzards Bay, which was sea-whipped by a spanking, smoky sou'wester, Gerard B. Lambert's Class J yacht Yankee today won the historic Puritan Cup, and in doing so gave Harold S. Vanderbilt's America's Cup defender Rainbow a beating.

MADRID, July 8. -- The Spanish Government's efforts to terminate labor conflicts all over the country which are causing havoc with the national economy met with a fresh setback in Madrid today when warfare among rival labor organizations again broke out.

TORONTO, July 8 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs found the hot weather to their liking and marked up their third straight victory over Newark, 7 -- 0, tonight. Mooty pitched great ball for the winners, letting the Bears down with two hits.

Steel-ingot output declined only 1 1/2 points to 70 per cent of capacity this week, heavy shipments against old orders sustaining the rate of production despite lighter demand, The Iron Age says in its summary made public for today. Although the trend of output is now definitely downward, the magazine finds, the backlog of steel mills' orders is believed to be sufficiently large to prevent any sharp drop in production this month.

Defying the ultimatum of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, calling upon the twelve organizations affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, to dissolve the committee on pain of suspension from the A.F. of L., the Cap and Millinery Workers International Union voted yesterday to stay with the committee.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- By easing tariff barriers and encouraging international commerce America can help the world out of its economic dilemma and prevent a war that would wreck civilization, Dr. William E. Dodd, Ambassador to Germany, said here today.

Asserting that June had been the banner business month so far this year, Matthew S. Sloan, president of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Lines, reported yesterday an increase of nearly, $1,300,000 in the net operating income of his road in the six months, compared with the corresponding period in 1935.

LONDON, July 8 (AP). -- The Baldwin government, target of attacks recently in and out of Parliament, won a 329-to-139 vote in the House of Commons tonight. The vote was on a matter of domestic policy and, in effect, a vote of confidence.
BOISE, Idaho, July 8 (AP). -- Senator Borah became a candidate today for re-election to a sixth term.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 8. -- The rare achievement of Frank Parker in winning a set without the loss of a point and the unexplainable slump which has overtaken Robert Riggs stood out at the end of two rounds of competition in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club today as the eight seeded players advanced to the quarter-finals.
ALBANY, July 8. -- The seven judgments found against Sam Faden for violating the banking law by lending money at usurious rates and without a license were upheld today by the Court of Appeals.

PARIS, July 8. -- On the Bourse today prices were well maintained and the situation seemed to be favorable for emission of the new Treasury bond issue that Vincent Auriol, Minister of Finance, has announced for Friday. The Minister will launch the issue with a radio speech tomorrow evening when he will announce the interest rate and make a special appeal to the small investor.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, July 9. -- The arrival in Nanking late yesterday of an airplane from Canton carrying General Yu Han-mou was one of the most startling and significant developments since the tension between Nanking and the Southwest began more than a month ago.

Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday that housing would become exclusively a function of government within the next twenty years because of its important relation to governmental control of public health.

An ex-convict, who admitted that he had participated In sixty "fixes" between 1926 and 1935, testified yesterday at the first of the trials of twelve policemen accused of trying to buy promotions that he had received $2,500 for promising to get the names of four members of the Police Department in preferred positions on the eligible list for sergeants.

PARIS, July 8. -- The Army Commission of the Chamber of Deputies, after having heard explanations by Defense Minister Edouard Daladier, approved today the government's bill for nationalizing the manufacture of war materials.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 8. -- The Dardanelles conference wrestled all day with the basic issue of whether in wartime, with Turkey neutral, the Straits should be open to belligerents, as Britain desires, or completely closed, as Russia insists.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America met here today to discuss the recently enacted Robinson-Patman (anti-chain store) act, described as one of the most far-reaching pieces of legislation ever adopted.

Point by point THE NEW YORK TIMES recent editorial carries along its comment on the chief problems of the country as treated in the two major party platforms. It points out the many places where the platforms coincide and it does not emphasize any fundamental difference until it comes to the economic phase of foreign policy.

COMING away from the All-Star struggle in the Boston ball park, Coach Arthur Fletcher of the Yankees sank into a Pullman seat and offered a few observations. The first was to the effect that Guest Conductor J. Vincent McCarthy, replacing the ailing G. Stanley Cochrane, had handled the American League forces admirably.

The New York County grand jury is expected to hand up indictments in the next few days against several members of a ring accused of defrauding insurance companies of about $500,000 a year in fake accident and fire-loss claims during the last three years.

MILWAUKEE, July 8. -- In a message sent from Topeka tonight Governor Landon told the Wisconsin Republican Convention that the people were ready to fight for "good government," thus increasing confidence of a Republican victory at the November elections.

Retail package deliveries for the week ended July 4 showed an increase of 24 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is the largest for any week since April 11, when Easter trade brought a rise of 28 per cent in the number of deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas.

For a great many years -- far too many -- the Postmaster General of the United States has been the bursar of patronage for the President of the United States and collector of delegates for the renominating conventions. To that official the White House and the other government departments have referred members of Congress and State politicians in search of jobs for their friends and retainers.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

ALBANY, N.Y., July 8 (AP). -- Walter E. Fitzpatrick, director of the accounting division of the Public Service Commission, charged the Eastern Greyhound Lines of New York, Inc., today with a "write-up" of $1,157,746 in its property value.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Fatalities increased to 120 tonight after the sixth consecutive day of exhausting heat had battered at temperature records from the Western plains to the Eastern seaboard. Death totals mounted hourly from heat and drowning as thousands fled to the beaches for relief. To yesterday's toll of fifty-four, fifty-nine deaths were added during the day.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 8. -- Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine Jr. gave a luncheon today at the clubhouse of the National Golf Links of America. Her guests included Miss Marguerite E. Valentine, Mrs. Henry Lorillard Cammann, Miss Louise B. Willard, Mrs. Henry Warner Slocum, Mrs. Charles Garfield King, Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine, Mrs. Richardson Dunham, Mrs. Thomas G. Condon and Mrs. Condon Pell.

NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (AP). -- Cotton prices advanced more than $3 a bale here today, carrying the July position across the 13-cent level in a spirited response to a bullish government acreage estimate of only 30,621,000 acres, while most crop commentators had expected a figure ranging from 31,000,000 acres upward.

THE NEW YORK TIMES printed the splendid recommendations to the New York Board of Education of the special committee on delinquency and maladjustment. I sincerely hope that public opinion will support the adoption of these recommendations for extensions and that the board will see fit to do so.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 8. -- A 96 degree temperature at Camp Smith today did not lessen the activities of the 2,200 guardsmen who have only three more days in which to complete their Summer training here.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 8. -- Since the more he has of them the better he likes each succeeding birthday, the ninety-seventh anniversary today of John D. Rockefeller Sr. must have rated in his own mind as the best one yet.

With total expenditures held likely to range between $5,000,000 and $6,000,000, an all-time record for newspaper advertising this year by the railroads of the country was foreseen yesterday. Newspaper advertising by Western railroads backing up the $1,200,000 institutional campaign in magazines by the Association of American Railroads is now breaking, and extensive publicity by Southern railroads is expected to make its appearance shortly.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Plans for the arbitration by President Roosevelt of the old boundary dispute between Peru and Ecuador were made here today. Representatives of the two governments will begin the presentation of their cases on Sept. 30, under the terms of a protocol signed Monday in Lima.

The Regional Labor Board has asked the United Licensed Officers Association to agree to a poll of the licensed officers employed on the ships of the Black Diamond Line and the Panama Railroad Steamship Company to determine the union which would represent them in negotiations with the lines for wage contracts, it was learned yesterday.

The twin screw steamship Acadia of the Eastern Steamship Lines, out of Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, for New York, gave the Police Department, the Coast Guard and the East River waterfront an anxious few minutes yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas, supported by Vice President Garner for Speaker of the next House, was appointed today by Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee as chairman of the Democratic Campaign Speakers' Bureau.

VIENNA, July 8. -- The Austro-German negotiations described by this correspondent in a dispatch published last Sunday have reached so advanced a state that it is safe to say the world is on the eve of a great surprise -- unless at the last moment unexpected difficulties should arise.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- A total of 839,123 workers was said to have been deprived of possible reemployment because of general lengthening of work hours by industry since the invalidation of the National Recovery Act in a report made to President Roosevelt today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
Mrs. Henry R. Caraway, president of the Women's National Republican Club, urged each of the 150 women at a tea at the club yesterday afternoon to "convert" ten Democrats.

Price changes were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with coffee, cocoa and hides decidedly lower in active trading, but rubber, silk and cottonseed oil futures higher. On the cash markets, new high levels appeared in cotton, corn, oats and rubber, while wheat, print cloths, eggs and tin also gained.
The old Irishman sat whittling away at a stick outside of his Tipperary cottage. A friend wandered along.

New Yorkers experienced yesterday the hottest weather this year as temperatures soared throughout the State. The highest temperature here was 93 degrees, three above the previous high of the year, but in several places up-State it rose above 100.

ALBANY, July 8. -- The Court of Appeals affirmed today without opinion decisions of the Supreme Court and Appellate Division, which held that the estate of Charles D. Beckwith, wealthy New York paving contractor, on Pelham Bay in the fashionable Davenport Neck district of New Rochelle could not be used for a public bathing beach.

A new investment banking company, to be called Schroder, Rockefeller Co., Inc., which is to succeed to the underwriting and general securities business formerly done by the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, was formed yesterday at the offices of the latter corporation, 46 William Street.

FORT NIAGARA, N. Y., July S. -- Training was under way today for 700 young Western New Yorkers under twenty-five Reserve officers of the 307th Infantry at the G. . T. C. camp here. The 2OTth Infantry has its headquarters in New York City, as a unit of the Seventy-seventh Division.

As one of the first moves in his campaign to revitalize the Sanitation Department and improve its efficiency and morale, Commissioner William F. Carey sent out yesterday a contingent of 150 foremen and assistant foremen to enforce the sanitation laws.

Two hundred and fifty buying office executives and manufacturers paid tribute yesterday to Emil Sostman, who recently retired after thirty-eight years of service as local representative of the May Department Stores, at a luncheon held in his honor by the Association of Buying Offices at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALBANY, July 8. -- The Transit Commission's action in directing the Long Island Railroad Company to charge a 2-cent-a-mile fare on its trains operated within the city of New York was upheld today by the Court of Appeals. The 2-cent-a-mile rate was established to conform to the Interstate Commerce Commission's order effective June 1 which reduced the rate in coaches to 2 cents a mile on all railroads.

With the 1936 all-star game written into the records, major league baseball today swings sharply back to its routine business. The two pennant campaigns enter the second half, and it is with strangely contrasting feelings that the three New York City pilots tackle this important stage of the season.

CHICAGO, July g (/P). -- The chief goal of Republicans in the Congressional battles will be to win back 180 seats in Congress captured by DemOcrats in 1932 and 1934, Earl Venable, executive secretary of the House Congressional Committee's Fall campaign, said today.

LONDON, July 8. -- Encouraged by their recent victories in France, Spain and Belgium, Europe's labor leaders met here today convinced that democracy was again on the upgrade in its struggle against dictatorships.
ENDICOTT, N.Y., July 8 (AP). -- The Endicott-Johnson Shoe Corporation announced today a 10 per cent pay cut for its 500 executives and salaried employes.

The Lusk Operating Company, which recently bought two sites at 323-331 and 324-330 East Seventy-first Street on opposite sides of the street for improvement with two eight-story apartment houses, purchased a neighboring parcel yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 8. -- Miss Sarah Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward, at her marriage on July 23 to Charles Arthur Moore 3d, son of Charles Arthur Moore of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Spencer T.W. Stewart of New York, will have but one attendant, her sister, Miss Ethel Woodward.

OTTAWA, July 8. -- Because President Roosevelt is the titular head of his country, it is Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General and therefore representative of King Edward, titular head of Canada, whom he will visit at Quebec on July 31.

Stocks closed firm and slightly higher yesterday, with railway issues stronger and many industrial groups recently under pressure recovering moderately. The market had tried its hand at discounting the news of the continuing drought and was entitled to some degree of technical recovery, at least.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 8 (AP). -- Governor E.W. Marland, lengthening his second-place lead in late returns, announced a determination tonight to contest for the Senate Democratic nomination in a run-off with Representative Josh Lee.
WINNIPEG, July 8 (AP). -- Breaking a drought over most sections of Saskatchewan, heavy rains today left property damage in their wake in central parts of the Midwestern Province.

Ronney Householder of Los Angeles captured the featured East-West Sweepstakes last night on the card of midget auto races at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City. The event, listed for twenty laps, was halted on the eighteenth lap because of a crash.

The list of the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines, due today from the Channel ports, includes John G. Winant, former Governor of New Hampshire and now the chairman of the Social Security Board, returning from the International Labor Conference at Geneva.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 8 (AP). -- Statisticians of the Travelers Insurance Company reported today that motor vehicle fatalities have decreased so far this year in thirty-one States and the District of Columbia.

GEORGE TCHITCHERIN, dead after six years of retirement, was the Commissar of Foreign Affairs during the period when the Soviet Union was more or less ostracized by the rest of the world. He himself was a figure of mystery, a little mouselike, soft-voiced man with small bright eyes and a mouselike habit of working only in the dark.

A block of 33,168 shares of Beatrice Creamery Company $5 dividend cumulative preferred stock, with common-stock purchase warrants attached, will be offered today by a group headed by Field, Glore Co. The offering price will be $102.50 a share, plus accrued dividends.

Architects filed plans for changes in a large number of buildings in Manhattan yesterday when specifications also were submitted for new tenement houses in the Bronx and a forty-eight-family brick flat in Elmhurst.

ALDOUS HUXLEY has been converted, but not by Rome or Russia. His new novel. "Eyeless in Gaza" (Harper, $2.50), is at once a satiric film and a sermon. The method of presentation is that of a Hollywood freed from censorship, transformed to high intelligence, but with all its memories intact -- very definitely including the memory of what is good box office.

LONDON, July 8. -- The centenary of Joseph Chamberlain's birth was celebrated today and the imperialists among the vast audiences that filled the Town Hall at Birmingham and the Albert Hall in London wished he were alive in the empire's present crisis.

United State Government long-term bonds assumed the leadership in the market for listed bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. On a turnover of slightly less than $1,000,000, the Federal loans responded to a broad demand which carried prices up from 1-32 to 7-32 point, as several of the lower-coupon issues approximated their highs for the year.

FREE CITY OF DANZIG, July 8. -- A stern warning that Poland would not tolerate an arbitrary and one-sided change in the statute of the Free City was addressed today to Arthur Greiser, Nazi President of the Danzig Senate, by Dr. Casimir Papee, the Polish Commissioner here, who has just returned from a visit to Warsaw.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 8. -- Judge Cortland A. Johnson in Nassau County Court here denied today a motion for a new trial for Mrs. Frances Q. Creighton, who is scheduled to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison next week for the fatal poisoning of Mrs. Ada C. Appelgate in Baldwin, L.I., last Sept. 27.

HAVANA, July 8. -- Alleging the discovery of a great conspiracy against the government, military police last night and today detained some forty former officers of the army who were ousted by sergeants in the coup of September, 1933.

Bonus money creeping into circulation has already found its way into the cinematic blood-stream. On the heels of a serious treatment of the theme by Metro entitled, "Bonus Money," Paramout has decided to take the lighter view and will produce a waggish yarn called "One Man's Bonus" with Charles Ruggles and Mary Boland.

BOWMAN N.D., July 8. -- The largest part of the Spring wheat area of the United States has been burned to a crisp. Montana and Dakota farms and many of those in Minnesota that earned for these States their composite title are now a picture of desolation that lifetime tillers of their soils say has never been witnessed before.

The highly interesting and attractively illustrated report of the Board of Education -- so attractive that every parent of a public school child would have real satisfaction in possessing a copy -- shows what is being done to reach" all the children." This, as often stated, does not mean the same method and content of education for all, but such adaptation of instruction as will enable all to have as full benefit as is possible.
LONDON, July 8. -- Organized labor was called upon to support the League of Nations today by Sir Walter Citrine, president of the seventh International Trades Union Congress.
PARIS, July 8 (AP). -- Communists defied Premier Leon Blum's government tonight to make good its promise to use force if necessary to prevent new factory occupations by striking workers.

William A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with Mrs. Julian and Mrs. Daniel C. Roper, wife of the Secretary of Commerce. They plan to spend a month in England, where they will be joined later in the month by Mr. Roper.

MOSCOW, July 8. -- The latest victim of the new campaign against "fake scientists" is Professor Chijevski, director of the Central Laboratory for Ionization of the Commissariat for Agriculture. He contended that ionization of the atmosphere made plants and livestock grow faster.

Since Senator FEARON now leads the field for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, his attack on the National Administration delivered in Nassau County has a certain importance it otherwise might not have. It can be taken as a keynote of the appeal he would make for votes, if nominated, in a State which may decide whether or not the President is to be re-elected.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- A belief that the period of intense heat and drought in the wheat and corn growing States might be drawing to a close, combined with reports of scattered showers in Alberta and Saskatchewan and a little moisture at several points in Illinois and Nebraska, resulted today in heavy profit-taking sales of both wheat and corn on the Board of Trade.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- A new high-jump record for thermometers came out of the drought-baked plains today: 175 degrees in less than six months.

Governor Lehman and the 1935 Legislature, controlled in both its branches by the Democrats, were held responsible for the State deficit by Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly, in a statement telephoned yesterday to Republican State headquarters in this city from his home in Norwich, N.Y.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP). -- A harvest time picture of gloom, etched against a background of crop losses ranging to total failure, was given today in up-to-the-minute summaries of the situation in the stricken territory by agricultural observers.

Senator GORE is at the foot of the poll in the Oklahoma Democratic Senatorial primary. The high man is Representative JOSH LEE, formerly "head "of the Public Speaking Department of "the University of Oklahoma; an au-"thor, widely known as a lecturer and "public speaker."

DARIEN, Conn., July 8. -- Championships and trophy competitions featured the closing session of the tenth annual horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today. In the hunter division the upstanding brown gelding Woodfellow, owned by the Wynfromere Farm of Miss Helen Bedford of Greens Farms, Conn., repeated his brilliant victory of last week at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

A rear wheel of a speeding racing automobile hurtled into the grand stand of the Madison Square Garden Bowl at Long Island City last night, causing injuries to three women and a man. Hundreds of other men and women were panic-stricken among the crowd of more than 15,000 but quickly calmed down as the wheel spun to a, stop.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 9. -- The protracted oil dispute between the Japanese Government and British and American oil companies has found a peculiar solution which gives the companies a substantial victory, but "saves the face" of the Japanese Government.
John O'Hara, author of "Butterfield 8," who had been staying here at the Hotel Pierre, has left for Hollywood, where he intends to complete work on his new novel, "So Far, So Good."

The cotton markets of the world were buoyant yesterday following the report of the Department of Agriculture estimating the area panted to cotton in this country on July 1 at 30,621,000 acres. Under an expanding buying movement prices on the New York Cotton Exchange gained about $3 a bale, the largest increase for a single session in several years.

A disguised $500 contribution to District Attorney Geoghan's campaign fund was provided last Fall by a nationally known bookmaker who was financially associated with Leo P. Byk, an alleged conspirator in the Drukman murder case, it was charged yesterday.

LONDON, July 8. -- King Edward VIII today inspected the newly expanded Royal Air Force from his own plane. Accompanied by the Duke of York the King made a 300-mile tour of air force stations. The flight was his fourth since his accession.

DETROIT, July 8 (AP). -- Miss Edith Estabrooks, the 15-year-old golfer from Dubuque, Iowa, shot her way into the semi-finals of the girls' Western junior open tournament under a blazing sun today with an impressive 7-and-5 victory over Miss Harriet Randall of Indianapolis.

Eight directors of the Davega Stores Corporation received in 1935 compensation of $120,940, the company disclosed yesterday in its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Of this amount the concern paid $21,080 to N.L. Cohn, chairman of the board; $22,580 to H.M. Stein, president, and $21,080 to A. Davega, vice president, the report showed.

Auctioneers conducted eleven foreclosure sales of Manhattan real estate yesterday. The auction mart trading included two vacant plots on Amsterdam Avenue corners. All eleven parcels were bought in by the plaintiffs in the foreclosure actions.

Workmen perched on narrow steel girders high over the Harlem Ship Canal at Spuyten Duyvil completed yesterday the most delicate operation in the construction of the Henry Hudson Bridge, largest hingeless single-arch span in the world.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Unless a "miracle" intervenes, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor will suspend eight national and international unions by next Tuesday night as a preliminary step toward purging itself of one-third of its membership.

The cotton market furnished more excitement to the financial community yesterday than it had clone in years when prices on the New York Cotton Exchange ran up about $3 a bale following the government's report on the acreage planted to that staple in this country.

ALBANY, July 6. -- The Appellate Division's ruling which annulled the action of the Public Service Commission in fixing temporary rates for electricity of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company was reversed today by the Court of Appeals.

Another $10,000 shrinkage in the deficit of the American Olympic Committee's fund was reported yesterday by Gustavus Town Kirby, treasurer of the organization. Thus the total still left to be raised to send the team to Berlin next Wednesday dropped to the round figures of $130,000.

Confused by the many interpretations of the provisions of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, nearly 1,100 representatives of all branches of business listened yesterday afternoon to lawyers and others discuss various phases of the new law.

Hirsch Jacobs, trainer of more victors than any other man for the past three seasons, forced his 1936 score to ninety-one when he saddled three at Empire City yesterday, including Action and Microphone, winners of the featured races. The other was Buzzin Around, first in the second event.
Social conditions in Cuba have improved to some extent, along with the economic revival that has followed the American sugar quota and tariff reduction.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8. -- Stroking consistently well all the day, Mrs. Mark McGarry of the neighboring Westchester Hills Golf Club today captured the premier laurels in the record field of 195 contestants in the second annual women's invitation tournament at the Gedney Farm Golf Club.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Robinson gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Miss Anna Katherine Flint of Los Angeles. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. McLean, Mr. and Mrs, Daniel L. Monroe and Stephen Kellogg.

A plan for extending the 6 per cent secured notes of the Minneapolis, St. Paul Sault Ste. Marie Railway Company from their maturity date on Aug. 1 to Feb. 1, 1938, with interest at 5 per cent a year during the interim, has been offered to holders of the notes with the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

HUNTINGTON, Ind., July 8. -- Mayor C.W.H. Bangs sweltered in the county jail here today as members of his City Council began preliminary action toward passage of an ordinance giving to them the power to remove him from office.

United States foreign trade is making progress toward recovery in world markets and the outlook is more encouraging than at the beginning of the year, according to a statement issued yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council and Association.

Michael F. Walsh, State Deputy of the Knights of Columbus, announced yesterday the appointment of most of the State Board of Deputies for the year 1936-37. The appointees and their districts in the Greater New York area follow:

WASHINGTON July 9. -- Alarmed by the dispute over craft and industrial unions which threatens to split the ranks of organized labor, representatives of the hitherto "diehard" group in the executive council of the American Federation of Labor began today to canvass the possibility of a compromise.
ROME, July 9. -- An official communique gives news of the most important fighting in East Africa since the official closing of the Italian campaign.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Railroad men are discussing a possible merger of the Denver Rio Grande Western with the Western Pacific, the resulting company to be controlled jointly by the Missouri-Pacific and the Chicago, Burlington Quincy, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, revealed today.

ARISING young janitor named George Varoff bobbed up in Palmer Stadium last Saturday to vault 14 feet 6 1/2 inches and only his immediate family and a few close friends knew in advance that the skyrocketing janitor was among those present in the national amateur track and field championships.

Having sold over 100,000 copies of Negley Farson's "The Way of a Transgressor," Harcourt, Brace have now decided to bring out a new illustrated edition with a first printing of 10,000 copies. The new edition will be larger in format, the binding and jacket will be changed, and several half-tones will be added.

Should the buying of cattle become necessary as the result of the drought, the government will handle the hides in such a manner as to avoid disturbing market conditions, it was announced yesterday by the committee of eight of the Tanners' Council.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 9. -- Mrs. Stanley W. Burke and her sons, Waring and Roger Burke, are at the Sea Spray Inn for the season.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9. -- Preparation for war in a far from peaceful world not yet ready for disarmament was urged today as necessary, especially for free peoples, in addresses delivered here by Brig. Gen. John Ross Delafield of New York and Hugo E. Prager of Zurich, Switzerland.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey declared yesterday he did not think the Federal Government "will want to be a party" to the case surrounding the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, but at the same time a strong likelihood developed that if no action was taken by any Federal grand jury in New York, the Federal grand jury for New Jersey would take it up.

Having scored a success last season with her first Broadway play, "Night of January' 16," Ayn Rand will next dramatize her own novel, "We the Living." She will spend the rest of the Summer adapting the book (published last April) which, it will be recalled, is a bitter attack on the Soviet Russia of the early Nineteen Twenties.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The Resettlement Administration declared a one-year moratorium today on rural rehabilitation loans to between 25,000 and 30,000 farmers in 268 drought-stricken counties, as searing heat led to increased crop destruction and further deaths in the Great Plains area.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Final figures on internal revenue collections for the 1936 fiscal year, issued today by the Treasury Department, showed receipts of $3,448,302,870 as compared with $2,773,213,213 for the 1935 fiscal year.
OTTAWA, July 9 (AP). -- Average Canadian crop prospects at the end of June were much below those of a year before and even a month before, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Three bridges over the Harlem River were closed to traffic yesterday afternoon when the intense heat caused the draws to expand beyond the limit allowed in construction so that they could not be shut.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 9. -- Skirmishing for control of important television patents reached the Federal courts today when Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company filed an equity action here against the Radio Corporation of America, asking Judge John P. Nields to direct the United States Commissioner of Patents to issue patents on inventions of Vladimir K. Zworykin.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Eastern Republican campaign manager, arrived here yesterday after conferences with Governor Landon and announced that preparations were under way for an intensive campaign in this city.

New York's record heat brought quick action yesterday from the heads of the city government's various departments in an attempt to alleviate the discomfort in the more crowded quarters of the metropolitan area.

William Z. Foster, Communist leader, who led the steel strike of 1919, issued a statement yesterday declaring as untrue the assertion of President William Green of the American Federation of Labor that the A.F. of L. executive council assisted the steel organization campaign of 1919 financially.

SUNDANCE, Wyo., July 9. -- The worst forest fire in many years in this part of Wyoming raced through the Black Hills Forest near here today, destroying livestock, wild game and thousands of acres of valuable timber.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9. -- Not only was this year's high temperature mark smashed today, but a new 1936 high for polo activity at the Meadow Brook Club was set too. Fifty players, using almost 300 ponies, participated in matches staged on six of the club's fields, with the Hempstead Cups tourney quarter-finals as the afternoon's highlights.

The Republican platform of 1936 indicts the New Deal administration for its failure to do anything toward the collection of our war debts. The Republican party pledges its sincere efforts to force our debtors to some sort of honorable settlement. The Democratic platform says nothing at all about the war debts.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 9. -- The East Arkansas farm laborers' strike, marked by charges of flogging and violence which prompted a Federal investigatioh, came to an end today.

Duncan MacInnes, First Deputy Controller and for many years chief auditor of the Department of Finance, was the guest of Controller Frank J. Taylor and the other executives and bureau heads of the department last night at a dinner at the Princeton Club.

With the demand for women's wear fabrics showing a sharp rise, business in the wool goods market was more active this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. There were more buyers in the market, the Exchange says, and mills booked a substantial number of orders for men's Fall suitings and overcoatings.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 9. -- Rainbow turned the tables on Yankee today and won all the way in the Eastern Yacht Club's squadron run here from Mattapoisett, over on the north side of Buzzards Bay. At the end of the twenty-five miles Rainbow had a margin of 3 minutes 30 seconds.

WASHINGTON. July 9. -- American public affairs are managed by about 175,000 separate Federal, State and local governments, the national resources committee reported to President Roosevelt today. The report added that many of these governing bodies also had separate departments working independently of each other and often in "apparent conflict."

Charles Herbert, alleged poultry racketeer, and two of his union associates were arrested as vagrants at 4 A.M. yesterday near a public market in the Bronx, although Herbert had $250 in his pocket. Taken to police headquarters for the line-up, they listened with polite smiles as Acting Captain John G. Stein intimated that Herbert at least has not hesitated at murder.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Endeavors to vitalize a party organization that reaches down into the precincts of Illinois, Iowa and other parts of the Corn Belt will be the special objective in the next few days of Harrison Spangler, who is in charge of organization work at Republican national headquarters.

Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the Supreme Court said yesterday that he would accept the order of Governor Lehman to preside over an extraordinary Special and Trial Term and a special grand jury in the Dewey racket investigation as "a call to an important public service."

HOMESTEAD, Pa., July 9. -- Members of the so-called company unions and advocates of independent unionism, as proposed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, are waiting to see what happens to a demand for a wage increase made by employe representatives in the Carnegie-Illinois Corporation plant here.
PARIS, July 9. -- A credit of 1,000,000 francs was voted by the Chamber of Deputies today for the participation of French athletes in the Olympic Games in Berlin.

PARIS, July 9. -- To enable it to meet inherited and new financial needs, the French Government will begin today to issue a new series of six-month and twelve-month treasury bonds bearing 3 1/2 and 4 per cent interest.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Scattered showers cheered sections of drought-ridden Western States today as the record-breaking seven-day heat siege assailed Eastern States with the hottest weather of the Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Denying application for confidential treatment, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the annual report submitted by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for 1935 showing remuneration of officers and directors and bonuses paid of $30,000 or more.

ONEONTA, N. Y., July 9. -- Sitting on a platform perched in the high hills here today, Governor Herbert H. Lehman heard Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., Surgeon General of the United States, hail his decision to run again for governor and put him forward as a candidate for President in 1940.

In its report for the fiscal year ended on June 30, issued yesterday, the Lehman Corporation reported a net income of $10,336,536, including realized profits on its investments, together with an increase of $9,593,151 in unrealized appreciation on investments, making for the year a total gain of $19,929,688.

UNION CITY, N.J., July 9. -- August Peter, 68 years old, vice president and treasurer of the William Peter Brewing Company of this city, hanged himself to a rafter in the attic of his home at 649 Hudson Avenue here today. The police said Mr. Peter had been suffering heart disease for several years.

LONDON, July 9. -- The Labor party won its most important by-election victory in many months tonight, largely as a result of the government's abandonment of sanctions and "betrayal" of the League of Nations.

HAVANA, July 9. -- President Gomez's message to Congress recommending the immediate passage of an amnesty which will release political prisoners and permit the return of exiles was made public this afternoon as a joint committee prepared to discuss the measure which has been so eagerly awaited by the nation.

A tour over the Triborough Bridge yesterday by two newspaper reporters revealed that the huge structure, which will be dedicated by President Roosevelt tomorrow, is up to the expectations of the public and the promises of its builders both in beauty and usefulness.
PARIS, July 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The superintendent of the National Tube Company's mill at McKeesport, Pa., said in our story yesterday that 55 per cent of the 8,000 employes are native born. But also present, as they say in the society columns, were 765 Slavs, 443 Hungarians, 395 Croatians and 359 Poles, or a total of nearly 3,000 foreign born.

PARIS, July 9. -- Simultaneously with the cessation of sanctions against Italy and the withdrawal of the British home fleet from the Mediterranean, France has informed Rome and London that the agreement made last November with Britain whereby she would place her ports at the disposal of the British fleet in the event of aggression has automatically come to an end.

LEWISBURG, Pa., July 9. -- Elisha Hanson, general counsel for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, charged in a lecture here tonight that the Roosevelt administration had attempted to control directly the press of the country and had failed, but despite this was persisting in an effort to control it by indirection.

Tammany Hall denied last night to General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein its nomination for the full term and designated Assemblyman Saul S. Streit of the Seventh Manhattan District as its candidate. Standing behind James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, the executive committee, in a meeting that lasted only ten minutes, unanimously declined to name the man whom Governor Lehman recently had appointed to fill the vacancy made by the death of Judge Otto Rosalsky.
THE TIMES news story is headed "State Deficit Cut $41,171,323 in Year."

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The fight of the Iron and Steel Institute against unionization of the steel industry has rallied the ranks of labor throughout the country solidly behind President Roosevelt in his campaign for re-election, John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, declared after a conference with the President today.

BERLIN, July 9. -- Since official quarters are neither confirming nor denying the reported Austro-German amity pact, its impending conclusion is taken for granted in neutral diplomatic circles here, which appear to be convinced that a political truce with far-reaching implications has been reached between the Berlin and Vienna governments.

It was George Gershwin night at the Lewisohn Stadium, and there were empty seats in the amphi-theatre last night. That is news. An all-Gershwin program several years ago attracted an immense overflow throng, and the management was hopeful that history would repeat.

Important, perhaps dramatic, changes in Germany's relations with Austria appear to be imminent. HITLER is said to be "offering Chancellor KURT "SCHUSCHNIGG a treaty recognizing "the sovereign independence of Austria." This probability was reported fully in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES.

Electricity consumers served by the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company will receive a total of about $805,000 in rebates or credits as a result of the decision of the Court of Appeals upholding the right of the Public Service Commission to fix temporary rates for public utility companies.

Under the roasting sun that sent the temperature above 100 degrees, 9,000 WPA workers awaiting pay checks argued, shouted and fought yesterday afternoon in front of and inside the building at 113-121 West Twentieth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

BOSTON, July 9. -- Massachusetts was at the mercy today of two storms of almost tropical intensity which swept the State, fifteen hours apart, caused damage estimated at $1,000,000 to lightning-struck homes and buildings, flattened crops and gardens, crippled utilities systems and uprooted trees.

The conviction of John A. Dilliard, president of the State Title and Mortgage Company, who was sentenced to six months' imprisonment for alleged false representations concerning the financial condition of his company, has been set aside by the Court of Appeals in a four to three decision.

OKLAHOMA, CITY, July 9 (AP). -- Gomer Smith, Townsend Club national vice president, contended tonight in the face of adverse unofficial returns that he had won second place in the Democratic United States Senate run-off primary election over Governor E.W. Marland.

TORONTO, July 9 (AP). -- The Newark Bears salvaged one victory from their four-game series with the Leafs as they trounced Toronto, 8 -- 0, tonight. The Bears collected twelve hits off three Toronto pitchers, while Chandler held the losers to seven scattered blows.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 9. -- Henry Canda of Greenwich, top-seeded player, won the boys' championship of Westchester today at the County Tennis Club by defeating Arthur Prochaska of Pelham, 7 -- 5, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5.

The Long Island Railroad announced late yesterday afternoon that it would put into effect a two-cents-a-mile rate for single-trip passengers within the city beginning tonight at midnight, in conformity with the temporary injunction obtained by the State Transit Commission from Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 9. -- E.T. Hamilton, vice president of the RCA Manufacturing Company at its Victor plant here, said today that 80 per cent of the factory's employes needed for a "revised production program" had returned to work despite the three-week organizational strike of the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- The grain markets fluctuated today in an erratic manner. Prices on the Board of Trade here dropped early on reports indicating good rains had fallen over a large part of the leading producing States, but later official returns showed the moisture, except in a few instances, was too light to be of material benefit and a strong rally followed.

Bankers have been invited to submit bids for a new issue of $2,000,000 of corporate tax-anticipation warrants of Cook County, Ill., award of which will be made on July 15. Further details of the offering will be announced later.

A further rise of $210,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System was reported for the week, ended on Wednesday in the system's statement, issued yesterday. The gain, due largely to continued heavy disbursements by the Treasury of funds previously accumulated, lifted the total of excess reserves to $2,880,000,000, compared with $2,040,000,000 three weeks ago.

Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons reserved decision yesterday at the close of the trials of three of the twelve policemen accused of attempting to buy preferment on the sergeants' eligibility list. Three other trials were put over until July 16.

OMAHA, Neb., July 9. -- The Middle West has known natural calamity in many forms -- in floods, in blizzards, in tornadoes, in prairie fires. But the most cruelly tantalizing is the drought, The difference is the difference between sudden death and dying by inches.

HEWLETT, L.I., July 9. -- Favorites ran true to form in the first two rounds of the annual New York State junior golf championship at the Seawane Club today when two of the first three qualifiers, Alick Gerard Jr. and Bobby Jacobson, came through successfully.

Under a continuation of the general buying movement, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward $1.50 a bale yesterday and after making new high records, reacted irregularly in the last half hour to close with a gain of 9 to a loss of 2 points.

MOSCOW, July 9. -- The new Soviet internal loan has proved to be a success in the first five-day period -- from the second to the sixth of July. Subscriptions mounted to 3,470,000,000 rubles or almost 87 per cent of the 4,000,000,000 required.

While some advance buying has already made its appearance in the textile industry in anticipation of further price increases, especially in the cotton and rayon divisions, it is not believed that this will be of sufficient importance to cause a corresponding drop in purchases for the Fall season later in the Summer, according to The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

RYE, N.Y., July 9. -- Finishing touches were put on the extensive horse show ring on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club today for the opening tomorrow of the sixth annual exhibition, which will continue through Sunday. Nearly seventy classes will be judged during the six sessions.
MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 9. -- The Dardanelles conference still was deadlocked tonight as the Rumanian delegate departed for home in a huff.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- President Roosevelt interpreted the willingness of Ecuador and Peru to submit their boundary dispute to his arbitration as a happy augury for the forthcoming Inter-American Peace Conference to be held at Buenos Aires, in a statement issued today to announce the approaching arbitral hearings.
Despite criticism from both Conservative and Liberal quarters, responsible officials of the State Department are satisfied that their Cuban policy has been an outstanding success.
Arthur Krock's timely comments on the monopoly planks are most instructive. It is not a matter of platform planks as such but of what may be expected of the two candidates and parties.

MONTREAL, July 9. -- Without any assistance from the Canadian-American trade treaty, which left the forty-two-cent duty on wheat unchanged, the United States has become second only to Great Britain as Canada's principal wheat market, according to official figures issued today.

For lack of corroboration, Miss Sira Rydhurg, 50 years old, a graduate nurse, was discharged by Magistrate Perlman in Felony Court yesterday in the alleged theft of $3,000 in jewelry from Mrs. Haff Seagle last June 25 at the home of Mrs. Seagle's sister at 145 West Twelfth Street.

CHICAGO, July 9. -Receipts of hogs here' today were heavy, arrivals of 17,000 being the largest for a Thursday since Feb. 20, with a liberal percentage of the run consisting of packing sows. The demand was fair, however, with prices generally steady to 10 cents a hundredweight lower than on Vednesday.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The $500,000,000 mark, maturity value, of sales of United States Savings or "Baby Bonds" has been passed, Wayne C. Taylor, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

DETROIT, July 9 (AP). -- Frank Murphy, who yielded today to the pressure of President Roosevelt's campaign managers and announced his candidacy for the $5,000-a-year job as Governor of Michigan, although it would cost him his $18,000 post as Philippine High Commissioner, will face at least one active opponent in the primaries Sept. 15.
LONDON, July 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

Spirited bidding in convertible and second-grade railroad issues was a feature in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Apparently placing more emphasis upon the current earnings position of the leading carriers than on the probable effect of the drought situation on the Midwestern and Southern carriers, operators bid eagerly for many of the lower-priced rail liens and forced prices up fractionally to nearly 4 points.

BOSTON, July 9. -- A driving finish by Jockey Georgie Watson brought victory to Mrs. Frank Coltiletti's Sandy Boot in the Worcester County Purse before a gathering of 10,000 today at Suffolk Downs. The winner paid $8.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

SPOKANE, Wash., July 9. -- Former Senator Clarence C. Dill won a divorce today from Rosalie Jones Dill, former suffragist leader, on his charge that she wrote to his parents that he was "drinking like a fish" and was losing his mind and eyesight.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 9. -- The finals in the Star class Olympic eliminations, which begin tomorrow, will be a three-boat test unless the fourth turns up unexpectedly. That was the outlook today, the day between the end of Atlantic Coast semi-finals and the start of the finals.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP). -- Wes and Rick Ferrell collaborated to give the Red Sox a 7-2 triumph over the White Sox today. It was the twelfth pitching victory for Wes, who was clipped for ten hits, and the fifth triumph in a row for his team-mates.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. John H.W. Ingersoll of Hillfield, Penllyn, gave a dinner tonight for Miss Harriet Kingston Archer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Archer of Wynnewood, and Mr. Ingersoll's nephew, Robert Sturgis Ingersoll Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sturgis Ingersoll of Forest Hill Lodge, Penllyn, whose marriage will take place Sept. 3.

After waging a losing fight for two years against creditors seeking to have the $700,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric Company reorganized under the Bankruptcy Act, attorneys for the company finally consented yesterday afternoon to allow an examination of its books to test its solvency.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP). -- A big ninth-inning drive today gave the Tigers a 10-7 victory over the Senators and enabled Detroit to remain in second place.

ROME, July 9. -- Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin's statement about the agreements that Britain concluded last December with various Mediterranean States and the announcement that the withdrawal of the British home fleet from the Mediterranean has been decided upon in London have created a very favorable impression in Italy, where they are regarded as the most important steps taken in recent times toward normalization of the European situation.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,474,000,000, an increase of $1,000,000, compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $1,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

In 1906 the seventieth anniversary of JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S birth was commemorated at Birmingham by Unionists generally in Great Britain and by Imperialists in the Dominions with much hullaballoo. At the centenary celebration in Birmingham Wednesday the Imperialist side of him was put forward with an enthusiasm that seems ironical in this day when the lesser breeds are so inconveniently obliging as to wish to relieve the White Man of his Burden.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 9. -- Mrs. Allan C. Bakewell gave a dinner tonight at White Shingles for her sister, Mrs. John Foster Dulles of Cold Spring Harbor, who joined her today, and for Mrs. Ford King, who is also visiting her and Mr. Bakewell. Other guests were Mrs. William F. Cogswell, Mrs. Franklin S. Richardson and Miss Rosalie Coe.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Secretary Ickes said today that he was dissatisfied with the cost of $7.39 a room which PWA is forced to charge for its first completed low-cost housing project, Techwood Homes, in Atlanta. He conceded that if price levels were as high on other PWA projects when finished it might be necessary to submit a revised Housing Bill to the next Congress.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 9. -- In a punishing match lasting close to two hours under a broiling sun, Bernard Welsh of Rockville, Md., came from behind twice to defeat Wayne Sabin of Los Angeles today in the quarter-final round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

PITTSBURGH, July 9. -- For a combination of reasons, including, presumably, the steel labor situation and the completion of steel orders placed at the lower second quarter prices, most lines of industrial activity in the Pittsburgh district declined only slightly during the week ended July 4, whereas normally there is a considerable letdown because of the holiday.

OTTAWA, July 9 (Canadian Press). -- Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada decreased $1,890,152 in the week ended yesterday, according to the weekly statement issued today. Deposits by chartered banks were down $2,885,813.

NANKING, Friday, July 10 (AP). -- A virtual mandate to open war against recalcitrant Kwangsi Province was expected to be handed to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek at an emergency session today of the Kuomintang Central Executive Committee.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP). -- A master in the Federal Court today recommended the liquidation "forthwith" of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company's huge Manchester, N.H., mills. "Reorganization is impossible," Arthur Black, the master, said.

Three Broadway houses will offer new films today: The Roxy will bring in Paramount's "Fatal Lady," with Mary Ellis, John HaIliday, Walter Pidgeon and Norman Foster .... At the Rialto will be "The Mine With the Iron Door," featuring Richard Arlen, Cecilia Parker and the late Henry B. Walthall in a Columbia adaptation of the story by Harold Bell Wright.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The general level of wholesale prices rose slightly during the week ended July 4, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average, rose to 79.5 from 79.4 a week before and compared with 79.1 on July 6, 1935.
BERLIN, July 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 8 is as follows, with changes from the preceding week. Figures are in thousands of marks.

Two indictments charging forgery and attempted grand larceny were handed up by the New York County grand jury yesterday to General Sessions Judge Koenig, in the plot, directed by a convict from Sing Sing where he was confined, to dispose of a series of bogus bonds of the Langerdorff-United Bakeries, Inc., of San Francisco.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP). -- Floradora, racing for Elmer D. Shaffer of Chicago and ridden by Jockey Nick Wall, defeated four other fillies in the fifth event at Arlington Park today.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- With sales of ice and modern ice refrigerators breaking all previous records by large percentages, directors of the country's leading firms in these industries met here this morning and appropriated more than $1,000,000 for the campaign to advertise modern ice refrigeration nationally during the coming year.
PARIS, July 9 (AP). -- Employers in several French cities called upon the government tonight to make good a promise to evacuate strike-besieged factories by using police "without bayonets."

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 9. -- While a majority of the players competing today in a one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Lawrence Farms Country Club suspended play because of the excessive heat, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Briar Hills won the low gross prize with a card of 81.

The New York Central System yesterday reported for May a net income of $73,493 after fixed charges. This compares with a deficit of $844,367 in May last year. For the five months ended on May 31 the system had a net deficit of $684,862, compared with a net loss of $3,423,198 in the corresponding period last year.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Frank Murphy, High Commissioner to the Philippines, submitted his resignation to President Roosevelt today so that he might enter the Democratic race for Governor of Michigan.

LONDON, July 9. -- The British Government took a giant stride toward reconciliation with Italy today by announcing that the warships rushed into the Mediterranean last Summer were coming home at last.

A Bronx angler, Alvah Bonham, tied into a six-pound large-mouth black bass in Sodom Reservoir, near Brewster, N.Y., on a recent evening. He caught it on a red and white plug near the shoreline, casting from a boat.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, renewed her request yesterday that the United Licensed Officers Association submit proof of its claim to represent a majority of the ships' officers of the Black Diamond Line and the Panama Railroad Steamship Company in negotiating wage agreements with their employers.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- A final decision is yet to be reached by the United States Navy as to the caliber of guns that will be placed on the two battleships that are expected to be laid down next year. Regardless of what Great Britain does, however, if there is any question about Japanese plans it is regarded as fairly certain that the United States will install l6-inch guns.
ST. LOUIS, July 9. -- Roy Parmelee returned to action as a starting pitcher today and completely baffled his old mates, the Giants.

The intense heat yesterday was no bar to activity in the security markets, nor to enthusiasm on the side of the recovery. Under the leadership of steel, motor, utility and various specialty issues, and with sizable gains in many of the leading railway shares and recoveries in farm-equipment issues, the stock market made its best gains since June 11.

CARL N. TAYLOR'S "Odyssey of the Islands" (Scribner's, $3), the story of his travels in the Philippines, sent me to the encyclopedia. Painfully ignorant, as it turned out, of the facts of the case, I had thought of our former Far Eastern territory as a sort of Oriental Puerto Rico, inhabited by a Christianized people and civilized by a generation of American rule to within an inch of independence.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 9. -- Continuing to set the pace, Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake of Plandome today enjoyed a nine-stroke margin over her closest challenger in the second round of the Women's Long Island Golf Association fifty-four-hole medal-play championship.

The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on May 31 a net profit of $4,384,510 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. This was equal to $4.42 a share on 945,000 shares of no-par common stock, after dividends on the 7 per cent preferred stock.

Drivers who through laziness, carelessness or "conceit" disregard the traffic laws, become "pirates" who "infest" the roads and are every whit as much "murderers at heart as a man who kills another with bludgeon or knife or firearm," Justice William Harman Black declared yesterday in the Bronx Supreme Court.

Bank clearings for twenty-two leading cities in the United States for the five days ended on Wednesday aggregated $6,079,098,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This is compared to $4,327,361,000 for the same week of last year, and is a gain of 40.5 per cent.

Pursuing some constructions of the limitations of Federal power by the Constitution, it would be possible for a logician to demonstrate that the Department of Agriculture is illegal. The opinions of some judges and the contentions of some lawyers would not require carrying logic to that point to prove that what the department is now doing to relieve the drought is unconstitutional.

Captain Boerge Rohde, gentleman-in-waiting to the King of Denmark and captain of the King's personal guards, arrived here yesterday on the Swedish liner Drottningholm to wed Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, United States Minister to Denmark.

The importance of the Triborough Bridge in easing traffic congestion in the city was stressed yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner, in making public instructions for reaching the span from main arteries in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (AP). -- Boston's Bees put on a fourth inning circus at the Cincinnati Reds' fiftieth anniversary celebration tonight to score six runs on five hits and an error and defeat the Reds, 6 to 5.

ALBANY, July 9. -- Drought conditions in New York State are becoming more serious, according to Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, and food production has been cut about 50 per cent. He declares this is certain to increase prices this Winter.

The New York Stock Exchange admitted yesterday to its list Standard Oil Company of New Jersey twenty-five-year 3 per cent debentures due in 1961, and announced that on July 30 there would be stricken from the list Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Corporation first-mortgage leasehold 7 per cent bonds due in 1934 and Stevens Hotel Company first mortgage 6 per cent bonds due in 1945.

The torrid heat yesterday which, fortunately for the stay-at-homes, was tempered by a light pleasant breeze, reached a degree of intensity which makes the record of temperature the highest of the season. At Hudnut's Pharmacy, corner of Broadway and Ann Street, the thermometer at 9 A.M. marked 86, at 12 o'clock 91, at 3 P.M. 101, and at 6 o'clock 99.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 9. -- A large dinner was given at the Breakers tonight by Count and Countess Laszlo Szechenyi.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 9. -- The results of the Finnish general election today showed small changes since the previous election in the relative strength of the Parliamentary parties, which is not surprising in view of the fact that the electorate was not compelled to take a stand on urgent political issues.

VIENNA, July 9. -- After having previously suppressed any reference to the highly important Austro-German negotiations, three Vienna newspapers today published identical statements declaring that reports of these negotiations published abroad were not correct and that in any case no important negotiations could be started before Autumn because of the approach of the Summer holidays.

The dismissal of two city marshals, charged with having withheld money paid to them for litigants in civil actions, was made public yesterday at City Hall. Dismissed last month were Marshal George Brayton of 3,350 Farrington Street, Flushing, Queens, and John J. Pizzi of 15 Garrison Street, Brooklyn.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted were at the lowest.

The American Olympic women's track and field team, first to be reduced last Sunday in the drive to keep all units within the budget limitations, came through yesterday in a far healthier state than it at first appeared.

ALBANY, July 9 (AP). -- Shirtsleeved legislative leaders began work in a humid Capitol today to select the personnel of investigating committees authorized by Governor Lehman to spend $142,500 within the next year. Announcement of the makeup of the groups is not expected before early next week.

Actual writing of orders for Fall coats and dresses gained sharply during the last two days, despite the handicap which extremely high temperatures here placed upon buyers' operations in the local apparel markets. Dress orders are now running from 15 to 20 per cent larger than a year ago, based on the average volume being placed with manufacturers.

PORT MORESBY, British New Guinea, July 9. -- A seaplane valued at $85,000 belonging to the American Museum of Natural History expedition overturned and sank during a squall in the harbor here while the expedition was absent, exploring the Fly River.

A substitute plan for the first stage of the new Delaware water system, intended to save the city $98,000,000, was submitted yesterday to Mayor La Guardia by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission. The plan is designed to replace one already decided on by the Board of Water Supply.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9. -- The Rev. James Francis Kelley, head of the Department of Philosophy of Seton Hall College, South Orange, was appointed president of the college today by Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark.
Three new playgrounds will be opened by the Park Department today in the Bronx and Queens. They will increase to 171 the number added to the park system since January, 1934.
There seems to be some dispute concerning the "narrowness" of Mr. McKinley's victory in 1896, according to your editorial yesterday.

In his telegram to the Republican State Convention in Wisconsin, Governor LANDON took the line of the Cleveland platform when he spoke of a public determination to "save for" themselves and their children the "things which we Americans hold "most dear."

The High Time horse, Isaiah, on from the West, sprang a surprise at Empire City yesterday when he came from behind to score at 15 to 1 in the featured Rhinebeck Handicap. It was an exciting finish even though the margin at the end of the short six furlongs was a length and a half.

New York and the East generally gasped in the highest temperatures in recorded weather history here yesterday as searing blasts of heat, borne out of the parched drought areas of the Middle West, converted city, town and country into one vast oven.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- A bit of rain and a slight breeze this morning partially broke Chicago's terrific heat wave, but in the afternoon Professor Stengel's Dodgers couldn't even make a dent in their season's losing record on Wrigley Field.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9. -- Fire which started at 6:15 this evening when scrap celluloid was set aflame by the intense heat caused $100,000 damage to five factories in "Down Neck" industrial district of this city. A workman was burned seriously, nine firemen and three volunteers were injured slightly or overcome by smoke, and three cows and forty pigeons were destroyed.

As the second half of the pennant race got under way at the Stadium yesterday the Yankees looked anything but the part of potential champions as they blew a four-run lead in the second inning and went down to a rather inglorious 11-4 defeat at the hands of the Indians.

Preparations were completed yesterday by the Queens Triborough Bridge celebration committee for borough exercises to mark the opening of the Triborough Bridge tomorrow morning as a protest against the leaving out of borough civic representatives and officials at the main observance to be conducted by the city at Randall's Island, Pierce H. Power, chairman of the committee, said last night.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9. -- The defects of the present system of taxing capital gains and losses, together with suggested remedies, were presented here today at the business and finance round table of the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

TANNERSVILLE, N.Y., July 9. -- The convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America today elected Eugene Kohn, president; Simon Greenberg, vice president; Alexander Basel, treasurer; Henry Fisher, recording secretary, and Arthur Neulander, corresponding secretary.
CALLANDER, Ont., July 9. -- It's a boy at the Dionnes -- just one, this time.

Wall Street sweltered yesterday but managed to complete a full day. In some respects the activity was greater than usual. Trading in stocks was heaviest since June 25, and in bonds, the heaviest since June 17. And, as prices advanced briskly on the day, there was no question but what financial hay was made as the sun shone.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 9. -- The citizens training camp regiment had another full day of drill and schools today, the 1,300 candidates being on the go virtually from reveille until the supper hour this evening. While it was a hot day, yesterday scorching heat was dissipated by two rainstorms, one during the night and another just after the lunch hour.

The Hamburg American liner Deutschland arrived yesterday a day ahead of her usual schedule to give importers plenty of time to enter cargo in advance of the countervailing duties scheduled to go into effect tomorrow against a wide range of German goods.

Four boys were drowned yesterday in Central Park, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, Gravesend Bay and New York Bay, while hundreds of thousands of men and women bathed at the beaches of the metropolitan area. A fifth victim, a man, was drowned in Atlantic City.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 9 (Canadian Press). -- It was public schools' day today at the National Rifle Association' meeting, and the honors went to Brighton College, winner of the historic Ashburton Challenge Shield, and, in a lesser degree, to Marlborough, which took the Cadets Challenge Trophy.

The five Republican leaders of New York City counties were in conference for four hours at the National Republican Club yesterday afternoon for the purpose of picking a candidate for the nomination of Aldermanic President to succeed the late Bernard S. Deutsch and run against Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens County, whom the Democrats have selected as their candidate.

With the savings banks now primarily interested in increasing the number of depositors rather than in the size of the individual deposits, the advertising linage of these institutions has forged sharply ahead. Yesterday, Robert W. Sparks, vise president of the Bowery Savings Bank, commented upon the new campaign which that bank is launching in English and foreign language newspapers in this city.

TRENTON, July 9, -- Governor Hoffman appointed Joseph A. Bower of Montclair today to succeed John J. Quinn of Red Bank as a member of the Port of New York Authority. Mr. Bower, who came from Detroit in 1915, is a banker and director of several utility and industrial corporations.

MONTREUX, July 9. -- The Dardanelles conference finished the first reading of the British draft convention regulating passage of ships through the Straits tonight after sitting for seven hours and riding out a storm caused by Nicolas Titulescu.

ST. LOUIS, July 9. -- Virtual retirement of Manager Bill Terry from first base duties for the season and the end of his career as a playing member of the Giants were announced by the club's pilot today when he rejoined the team after a hurried visit to Memphis, Tenn., to have his injured left leg treated.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- For the first time, total authorizations and commitments of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have passed the eleven - billion - dollar mark, standing at $11,052,028,161, it was announced today. Of this sum, $1,112,853,571 has been canceled and $939,394,639 remains available to the borrowers and to banks in the purchase of capital stock and capital notes.

TOPEKA, July 9. -- Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, as spokesman today for a general farm conference presided over by Governor Landon, outlined the broad principles of a farm program upon which he said Mr. Landon and himself were in entire agreement.

LONDON, July 9. -- The stock markets here opened quiet today, but the undertone was firm and trading become more active later. British funds moved narrowly. Foreign bonds were quiet. Home rails held firm. Canadian Pacific hardened on American influences.
