The School of Education of New York University opened its annual educational exhibition yesterday at the Brown Building, 29 Washington Place. Group and individual projects, prepared as student hobbies or supervised school work, which make up the exhibition, will be on display until July 20.

Prices of commodity futures generally were higher on the local markets yesterday. Raw hide futures declined. On the cash markets new high prices were made by wheat, corn, rye, cotton and rubber, while printcloth, silk and tins also advanced.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- President Roosevelt spent an extremely busy day today trying to clear his desk before starting on a cruising trip, during which he hopes to be completely free from the cares of office.

New Yorkers again flocked to the beaches, parks and docks yesterday in search of the elusive cooling breeze, and more than 1,000,000 found alleviation of their distress in those open spaces. Those who thronged the parks remained in large numbers until a late hour last night, apparently unconcerned over the overcast sky and occasional flashes of lightning.

The George W. Helme Company has amended its 1934 registration statement by filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission a list of its marketable securities as of Dec. 31, 1934. This shows holdings of bonds with a face value of $10,553,840, a market value of $9,964,501 and a cost of $10,256,063.

Nikola Tesla, inventor, who celebrated his eightieth birthday yesterday, foresaw an industrial civilization founded on cheap and unlimited power transmitted from a central point to any part of the globe without wires.

The battle of the employment and unemployment estimates still goes on. Last week the Department of Labor for the first time published an estimate of the number of persons now gainfully employed in the United States. There are 46,000,000 of them, according to Miss PERKINS, compared with 48,000,000 in 1930.

PEIPING, China, July 10. -- Under brisk questioning regarding yesterday's incidents, when Japanese soldiers forcibly prevented three foreigners from taking pictures of Japanese tanks in a parade through Peiping streets, Major Gen. Matsumuro declared the Japanese soldiers were merely protecting the secrecy of Japanese armaments.

A six-year war in the gasoline industry on the Atlantic seaboard was disclosed yesterday when the Seaboard Terminals Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Seaboard Midland Petroleum Company, filed suit in Federal Court demanding three-fold damages of $6,000,000 against the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and its two affiliates, the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and the American Oil Company.

After holding steady around par for more than two weeks, the French franc weakened suddenly yesterday in the foreign exchange market. It fell to 6.61 1/4 cents, the lowest price since June 26, and closed at 6.61 5/8 cents, off 1 5/8 points from Thursday.

IT is rumored, written and shouted that a grand rush is about to start somewhere along the East River front. The completion of the Triborough Bridge, the opening of the Randalls Island Stadium and the holding of the final Olympic tryouts have been jammed together for a triple play that is simply stunning in the kind of weather that has been poured over this sector of late.
If it be true that Congress loves the people for their votes, it is likewise true that Congress loves President Roosevelt for his vetoes.

When the advocates of the closed shop talk of "peaceful picketing" they mean "peaceful" so long as no workers willing to take the place of strikers seek employment. I have watched many strikes and have learned that the basic principle of all picketing is threatened physical interference with any persons who may wish to work in a shop where former employes are on strike.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The report of the Department of Agriculture giving the indicated production of grain as of July 1, issued today, was construed variously by the trade. The figures on wheat, showing an aggregate of 638,000,000 bushels. were only 7,000,000 bushels above the private returns issued earlier in the month, with Winter wheat placed 15,000,000 bushels above the estimates of local statisticians and Spring wheat reduced 8,000,000.

LONDON, July 10. -- Outstanding in the stock markets here today was strength in armaments, aircrafts and iron and steel shares, following the new supplementary estimates on the government's outlay on its defense program. British pounds were little changed despite resumption of corporation loan issues.

I am sure all friends of the blind and crippled can imagine with what happy anticipation the group from the sheltered workshops of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities are looking forward to an outing this Summer at Huntington Camp, the vacation home on the North Shore of Long Island maintained just for them.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 10. -- The text of the address by Governor Lehman today at the conference of the New York State Committee of the National Municipal League at Union College here was as follows:

Hot weather cut into retail trade in the metropolitan area toward the end of the week and reduced the gains for the period. Sales for the first three days of the week had been ranging around 15 per cent, but the high temperatures reduced the average gain for the week to about 10 per cent, store executives estimated.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The fact that many clergymen, missionaries and lay workers in religious activities desire to use their vacations for spiritual and mental as well as physical profit has led to more religious Summer schools and a fuller program than ever for this season.

Of the eleven swimming pools built by the city Department of Parks with funds advanced by WPA, four have been opened in time to meet the needs of a city perspiring in the heat of winds that have seared the Middle West. Ultimately some 80,000 a day will be able to wade, splash, swim, dive and forget the blistering sidewalks, the softened asphalt and the brick walls of crowded tenement districts.

Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new accident frauds bureau, revealed yesterday that in the preceding two days he had obtained indictments against eighteen men and women as the result of revelations of fraudulent accident claims by Jacob Hurwitz, insurance broker, who had an office at 110 West Thirty-fourth Street.

RYE, N.Y., July 10. -- The annual horse show of the Westchester Country Club opened today at the polo field of the club. It gives promise of setting an all-time record in attendance. The show will be continued through Sunday.

BERLIN, July 10. -- The silence that has surrounded the intense and superbly organized preparation by the German Olympic candidates will be broken this week-end when the final tryouts for the team take place at the same time as the American trials on Randalls Island.

Paul Kerby, British conductor, who was scheduled to conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium until Tuesday evening, will be able to fill only one more engagement at the uptown amphitheatre, that of tonight, it was announced yesterday by the Stadium management.
I note in THE TIMES of July 3 the heading "Camera Found Accurate," implying that the instrument itself might have been deemed faulty.
The following points in regard to Rhode Island State College weight throwers may be of interest:
As a one-time athletic competitor, later as an official and always as one deeply interested in amateur athletics, may I say a word concerning the coming Olympic Games?

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 10. -- Time beat Paul Richmond's Dixie from Houston, Texas; shifting breezes beat Glenn Waterhouse's Three Star Too from California and Eddie Ketcham's Draco was lucky but last as the finals in the Star Class Olympic eliminations got off on the wrong foot today.

Operators of kosher poultry slaughter houses were informed yesterday by Market Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. that the employment contract which the schochtim union is seeking to force upon them is in violation of a Federal court decree.

Here is Governor LEHMAN, hailing New York State's fiscal year just closed as "the most successful single year in the State's financial history." Here is Speaker IVES, very sarcastic about the Governor's "joyous hysteria over the State's $56,000,000 deficit." The man in the street may be excused for being a little bewildered.
SHANGHAI, Saturday, July 11. -- Kosaku Kayau, a Japanese, was shot in the head by an unidentified Chinese gunman last night and died early this morning.

A strike of longshoremen in Gulf ports, involving about 10,000 men, will be called Monday morning, it was announced last night by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Barriers in three boroughs in front of the far-flung outposts of the Triborough Bridge will fall at 1 P.M. today following formal dedication of the $60,300,000 structure by the President of the United States, the Governor of the State, the Mayor of the City and other public officials at ceremonies on Randalls Island at noon.

ALIQUIPPA, Pa., July 10. -- Prospects for the industrial unionization of the Jones Laughlin steel mill here, employing more than 11,000, are considered particularly promising by the organizing committee because of the corporation's conflicts with the Federal Government on labor policies.
CHICAGO, July 10. -- A thirsty West took heavy punishment again today as the blistering heat wave signalized its eighth day by encompassing most of the United States and much of Canada.

THE NEW YORK TIMES carries the news of the reversal by the New York Court of Appeals of the order of the Appellate Division, which annulled the action of the Public Service Commission in fixing temporary rates for electricity.
LONDON, July 10 (AP). -- J. Noji of Poland stole the show from Britain's best tonight with an impressive victory in the six-mile run as the British A.A.A. track and field championships got under way.

The chance of a wife becoming a widow is slightly greater today than it was in 1920, despite the fact that the average length of life has steadily increased, according to a report issued yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, who has endorsed the third-party candidacy of Representative William Lemke of North Dakota for President, declared here today his belief that President Roosevelt would be defeated in November.

Plans were filed yesterday for the erection of a six-story apartment house at Broadway and Nagle Avenue, in the Dyckman Street section of Manhattan. The building will cost $450,000, according to an estimate given by H.I. Feldman, the architect.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 10 (Canadian Press). -- Marksmen found conditions at Bisley to their liking today with the result that seven tied with possibles in the Conan Doyle and six with possibles in the Donegall.

Supreme Court Justice Fawcett in Queens granted an injunction yesterday on the application of the Manhattan Steam Bakery, Inc., of 36-50 Thirty-eighth Street, Long Island City, restraining Local 505 of the Bakers Union and Local 138 of the Teamsters from picketing customers of the concern.
MONTREAL, July 10 (AP). -- The Royals stretched their winning streak to five straight games tonight with a 3-1 triumph over the Bears in the opener of a four-game series.

Security and commodity prices were up sharply yesterday, leading stocks advancing 1 to 4 points; wheat, more than 3 cents a bushel, and corn, up the 4-cent limit permissible in a single day. The rise carried THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks up 1.34 points and the average of twenty-five industrial stocks up 2.16 points to new high marks for the year.

BOSTON, July 10. -- Under a rousing ride by Glenn Haines, Weston Adams's Colonel Greene drove to a neck victory in the March of Time purse, mile and a sixteenth main event at Suffolk Downs today. He was timed in 1:45 4-5 and paid $5.20 for a $2 mutuel ticket.

PARIS, July 10. -- A twenty-three-millimeter gun that can fire 800 shells a minute through the hub of an airplane propeller and destroy an adversary with a single hit was the subject of a high-tempered debate in the Chamber of Deputies this morning.

The Yiddish theatre, which heretofore has generally confined its local activities to Second Avenue and the outlying boroughs, appears to be making preparations for a move upon the Broadway front. It was learned yesterday that the Forty-ninth Street Theatre has been leased by the Shuberts to Joseph Buloff, late of the Yiddish Art Troupe, for a year, beginning in September.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- President Roosevelt -- himself a "navy man" -- has suggested that five of the nation's most famous vessels be berthed in the capital as a patriotic shrine.

The election of Brother Columba as president of St. Francis College, 41 Butler Street, Brooklyn, to succeed Brother Capistran, who has held the office for two years, was announced yesterday by the college board of trustees.

Continued inactivity in the market for tax-exempt loans at least for another week is indicated by the fact that new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $5,764,250, to be represented by one State and fifty-one municipalities.
Physicians of New York State as represented by their medical societies are evenly divided on the question of whether drinking has increased since repeal.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10. -- Following is a summary of the address appraising the Federal Social Security Act made by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank of New York, before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia tonight:

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- President Roosevelt closed his office late this afternoon in preparation for departure early tomorrow morning for a vacation trip planned to last three weeks. His plans include a fortnight's cruise in North Atlantic waters, visits to Hyde Park and Campobello, N.B., and a brief call on Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, at the latter's Summer home in Quebec.
CINCINNATI, July 10 (AP). -- Danny MacFayden checked his former Cincinnati team-mates today and pitched the Bees to a 4-1 triumph, their tenth in thirteen games with the Reds this season.

ST. LOUIS, July 10. -- Thirty-five athletes were thrown into battle at Sportsman's Park today for the second skirmish between the Giants and Cardinals which consumed thirteen innings and 3 hours 28 minutes. But the pathetic end to this prolonged session of tense baseball drama was the second defeat in as many days for the Giants, their fourth in a row and their eighth in the last ten engagements.

Two children were killed and five adults, including the children's mothers, were burned and injured, two seriously, yesterday afternoon in an explosion on the fifty-foot cabin cruiser Commodore that blew four of them into Long Island Sound at the foot of 154th Street, Whitestone, Queens.

A bill of between $250,000 and $300,000, covering all expenses of the special inquiry into the Samuel Drukman murder case, will be submitted to the City Controller on Monday by Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd, it was disclosed yesterday.

With most of the in-town night clubs just drifting along, with their cooling-systems and a few entertainers for effect, the Rainbow Room will make a mid-Summer gesture on Wednesday evening by presenting Diana Ward, singer, who recently appeared in London in "Anything Goes," and Leo Beers, the piano-monologist, as a new show.
TROY, N.Y., July 9. -- Twenty-nine women fainted during convention balloting of the Women's Auxiliary, State Veterans of Foreign Wars, today. The mercury registered 104.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10. -- The "shortcomings" of American colonial policy were discussed here this afternoon by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt in an address before the Virginia University's Institute of Public Affairs. Colonel Roosevelt was Governor General of the Philippines and Governor of Puerto Rico.

The notice in THE TIMES recently announcing the formation of a lawyers' committee for minimum wage legislation recalls the possible answer to a serious problem which arose when the Supreme Court nullified the New York Minimum Wage Law in the Tipaldo case.

Theodore F. Allen of Westport, Conn., has been appointed head of the Radio Division at the Eastern headquarters of the Republican National Committee. Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Eastern campaign manager, made the announcement this afternoon, prior to his departure for his home in Massachusetts.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., July 10. -- From Brooklyn and the Bronx there arrived today with their household furnishings the first seven families to occupy homes in the cooperative community near here, sponsored by the Federal Resettlement Administration.

After seventy-five seamstresses had been overcome by the heat and "mass hysteria" had threatened to develop as a result, some 800 women employed in the first shift by the Women's Sewing Project of the WPA in a loft building at 43 West Eighteenth Street were permitted to go home yesterday morning.

After absorbing heavy speculative profit-taking on Thursday, which had tended to arrest the upward movement, the cotton market resumed its advance yesterday with a gain of $1.50 a bale. A rush of buying orders soon after the opening of the Cotton Exchange lifted July to 13 1/2 cents a pound and ran all new crop deliveries above 13 3/4 cents.

This community will take notice from Tammany Hall's action in refusing to nominate Judge GOLDSTEIN for General Sessions that its new leadership stands by the old doctrine that the city judiciary shall be beholden to the Hall for designation and election. That may seem perfectly logical from the standpoint of Tammany, and a normal measure to protect its own power in the city.

WARWICK, R.I., July 10. -- Arthur Highland of the Lake Shore Athletic Club, Chicago, defeated an all-star field in the 100-meter freestyle final at the concluding Olympic swimming trials for men at the Rocky Point Pool tonight.

John G. Costello, 38 years old, a newspaper delivery driver of 1,510 East Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn, was shot in the left side of the chest and in the left thigh at 10:40 o'clock last night by Patrolman Robert Taylor of the West 123d Street station, during a fight in Fiftieth Street, just west of Broadway.

Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, the American Minister to Denmark, and Captain Boerge Rohde of the Danish King's Royal Life Guards, will be married this afternoon at 5 o'clock at St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church at Hyde Park, N.Y., in the presence of President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The physical health of the population in the metropolitan area as reflected by hospital records has been only slightly affected by the extreme heat, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.
Garfield Shirt Corp., in 45 W. 27th St.; S. Kay Cofflneau, optometrist, in 619 8th Av,, completing rental of buildings; Bastine Co., agents.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Use of the United States Navy short-wave wireless equipment at the United States Legation at Addis Ababa for outgoing messages has been outlawed for fifteen days by the Italian authorities in the Ethiopian capital. Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- After studying revised plans for Public Works Administration projects designed to lighten the burden on relief rolls, President Roosevelt announced today that he hoped to have the new program in full swing by Fall.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission amended and somewhat broadened today its rule 201 relating to the exemption from registration under the Securities Act of 1933 of securities other than oil royalties, where the aggregate offering price of the securities to the public is $100 or less.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, July 10 (AP). -- Germany gained a 2-0 lead over Yugoslavia in the final round of European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition today, winning both the opening singles matches.

Seeking relief from the heat at the beaches in the metropolitan area of New York yesterday, ten persons were drowned, two swimmers who disappeared were believed to have lost their lives also, and a score of bathers were rescued.

An echo of the Seabury investigation sounded yesterday at police headquarters when Patrolman George A. Heidt of the Elizabeth Street Station faced departmental charges alleging unexplained bank deposits of more than $70,000.

The funeral services for Leon H. Rouse, president of Typographical Union No. 6, New York local of the International Typographical Union, were held yesterday afternoon in the Bunnell Memorial Funeral Home, 41 Highland Avenue, Jersey City, and were attended by several hundred members of "Big Six."

The Consolidated Laundries Corporation reported yesterday for the first twenty-four weeks ended June 13 a net profit of $42,315 after deducting depreciation, interest, Federal income tax and other charges. After cumulative preferred stock dividend requirements for that period, the profit is equivalent to 7 cents a share on 400,000 shares of common stock issued.

The extreme heat yesterday and the decision in many offices to send employes home early in the afternoon brought extra worries to train dispatchers at Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station, and resulted in crowded suburban trains in midafternoon on the lines running from those stations.

A blistering heat wave that cut a path of death and distress through the Plains States and the Middle West continued to roll slowly over the Eastern seaboard for the third successive day yesterday, smothering city and town, hamlet and farm, under a hot blanket of devastation.

The Civil Service Reform Association urged Aaron L. Jacoby, Kings County Register, yesterday not to reappoint Hyman Schorenstein to the position of Commissioner of Records on the ground that the position would "be better vacant than filled by the present incumbent, whose services to the public have been of dubious value."
MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP). -- Siege guns of the American Association all-stars conquered the pennant-chasing Milwaukee Brewers in the third game of the annual series today.

Justice Edward J. Byrne in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday reserved decision on an application of Florence Ullman Breslav of New Haven, Conn., holder of ten shares of stock of the New York Queens County Electric Light and Power Company, for an injunction restraining the Consolidated Edison Company of New York from reclassifying the preferred stock of the New York Queens company preliminary to a proposed merger of the two companies.

The alleviation of conditions now affecting the country's idle youth was held to be a joint responsibility of employer, labor, social welfare, governmental and educational groups at a conference sponsored by the American Youth Commission of the American Council on Education yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PITTSBURGH, July 10 (AP). -- Chuck Klein, slugging outfielder, batted the Phillies to a ten-inning 9-6 victory over the Pirates today by smashing four home runs to set a new modern National League record for one game.
BISMARCK, N.D., July 10 (AP). -- Governor Walter Welford appealed to President Roosevelt for immediate aid for farmers plagued by prolonged drought today, saying:
I wish to inform you of the following facts:

United States Senator Wagner of New York will sail today on the French liner Champlain. John Russell, Canadian painter, also will sail for France to make the official picture of the unveiling of the Canadian Memorial by King Edward VIII at Vimy Ridge.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

FAIRFIELD, N.J., July 10. -- S.M. (Steve) Crothers of Chestnut Hill, Pa., who last week-end won the singles and all-around Pennsylvania championships, today took the lead in the Eastern zone title trap-shooting. He was high gun in the doubles, first of the championship events, and topped the A entries in the class competitions.

Fall advertising programs, planned in local agencies this week, contemplate expenditures ranging from 10 to 15 per cent more than in the corresponding season last year, executives said yesterday. The increased expenditures will affect both newspaper and magazine advertising.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the motion made by its counsel to transfer to Los Angeles the hearing in connection with allegations of manipulative activities in common stock of the Kinner Airplane and ,Motor Company on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange by C.C. Wright of New York and others. E.C. Johnson, trial examiner, ordered that the taking of testimony begin there on July 27.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Apparently weary of watching the sad adventures of his itinerant Dodgers, Casey Stengel wasn't present today to see them drop their third straight to the Cubs, 6 -- 2, but a ladies' day crowd of nearly 19,000 enjoyed every minute of it.
This heat wave offers us, in the almost verbatim immortal words of U.S. GRANT, no terms other than an air-conditional surrender.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 10. -- A jury in the Monmouth County Court of Quarter Sessions returned here tonight a verdict of guilty, with a recommendation to life imprisonment, in the case of John Tomaini, 31 years old, of 530 Springdale Avenue, Long Branch, charged with murder in the first degree.

The grain report of the Department of Agriculture giving the indicated yield of the principal cereals in this country as of July 1, issued after the close of the markets yesterday, was better than had been indicated by drought reports recently.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 10 (AP). -- A mad plunge from the third tier of State prison's death row here today gained for Henry Grier, 43-year-old wife-murderer, only a few painful hours respite from the electric chair.

Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, it was learned yesterday, has obtained an order from Surrogate James A. Foley to compel her sister-in-law Mrs. Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, and her brother-in-law, General Cornelius Vanderbilt, as executors of their mother's estate, the late Alice G. Vanderbilt, to appear in Surrogates' Court on July 21 to show cause why she should not be paid her legacy of $100,000 under her mother-in-law's will.
LONDON, July 10. -- Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, and Mrs. Norman sailed today for New York on the Bremen.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 10. -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman declared emphatically in a speech here this afternoon that he would "continue the policy of safeguarding the principle of home rule against legislative encroachment or mandate."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 10. -- C. Russell Auchincloss of New York arrived by motor boat at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, today. Robert P. Esty of Ardmore, Pa., Mr. and Mrs. E.O. Doane of Bridgeport, Conn., Mr. and Mrs. Howard Wardle of Philadelphia, William Rector of New York, Mrs. J.L. Stone and Miss Abby K. Stone of Mount Vernon, N.Y., are at the Bretton Arms.

A warning to all communities in the State not only to conserve water but also to seek new sources of supply immediately was issued in Albany yesterday by the Division of Sanitation of the State Health Department.

LONDON, July 10. -- Strenuous competition of foreign dealers forced the bidding to unexpectedly high levels when the first of the famous collection of drawings by old masters formed by the late Henry Oppenheimer was offered at Christies's, today.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 10. -- For the fourth successive year, Frank Parker advanced to the final round of the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament today at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

The volume of new bonds placed on the market this week was the smallest for such a period since the week ended on May 8, amounting to only $24,602,000, compared to $80,996,000 publicly offered last week. A year ago this week the total was $61,376,000.

Like the thermometer readings during the current hot spell, many a Yankee batting average soared yesterday, for the McCarthymen reaped a harvest of twenty hits from four Cleveland hurlers while 5,000 fans watched with approving eyes at the Stadium yesterday.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the three months ended on June 30 a net profit of $1,600,000 after charges and reserves, equal to 36 cents a share on 4,386,070 shares outstanding. Net profit in the preceding quarter was $400,000, or 9 cents a share, and in the June quarter of last year, $1,600,000, or 36 cents a share.
The Board of Standards and Appeals at a special session in the Municipal Building next Thursday morning will hear arguments on two cases of vital interest to real estate owners and builders.
Investment buying of apartment properties, especially in Harlem, provided realty deals of interest in yesterday's market.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Crop conditions as of July 1 were better than had been expected, in view of the severe drought conditions in many parts of the country, the Department of Agriculture found in its monthly estimate today.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 10. -- Criticism of President Roosevelt as inconsistent in his farm program came today from the Landon camp, in the form of a statement given out by Clifford R. Hope of Kansas, ranking Republican member of the House Committee on Agriculture, Mr. Hope was one of the participants in yesterday's farm conference, and his statement was given to newspaper men in Governor Landon's office in the State House here this morning.

ALBANY, July 10. -- Less than the usual decline in factory employment in the State was noted in June, it was announced today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner. Employment went down 0.4 per cent, but payrolls showed practically no change, from May to June, compared to the usual decrease of 0.3 per cent in that period.

MONTREAL, July 10 (AP). -- A team of eighteen swimmers, nine men and as many women, today were selected to represent Canada in the Olympic Games at Berlin. Whether all make the trip depends on financial conditions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- Bill Good of Reamstown, Pa., and David Mayor, Philadelphia, made alternate places on the United States Olympic weight-lifting team in the final tryouts held at the arena tonight.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 10. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stuyvesant Wainwright gave a dinner and bridge tonight at Duckwood Lodge for Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Seggerman of Red Bank, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. August Rust Oppenheim of New York, who joined them today for a visit.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 10. -- The work of the army with the citizens' miiltary training camps throughout the country, is making "manly self-reliant young citizens," Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, U.S.A., commander of the Second Corps Area, declared today following his inspection of the C.M.T.C. camp here today.

Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to place the employes of the the Home Relief Bureau in the competitive classification of civil service following conferences with James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 10. -- The 105th Infantry of Troy and the 106th Infantry of Brooklyn concluded major tactical manoeuvres in their Summer training this morning with an "occupation" problem worked out under cover of darkness on the hilly terrain of Canopus Valley, four miles east of Camp Smith.
Condition and indicated yield of corn, as estimated yesterday by the government in its report on that crop for this year, compare as follows with the estimates of July 1, 1935, and July 1, 1934:

The great span over Hell Gate, to be thrown open today to traffic, is much more than a bridge. As ROBERT MOSES has said, it is an immense new artery of travel in the very heart of the city, connecting three of the five boroughs and reaching far out to tap suburban arteries at the city's borders.
MITCHELL, S.D., July 10 (AP). -- Business halted, merchants bent their heads, and housewives knelt in supplication today as Mitchell's population prayed for rain.

While there was a further recession in retail distribution this week in the drought-stricken territories, the heat wave spurred the demand for Summer goods in most of the leading cities of the country, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- Definitely poorer crop prospects on July 1 than at that time in any previous year except 1934, but with prospective yields described by some officials as about ample for domestic needs, were reported today in the government's monthly forecast.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- As the first step in bringing under control the marketing of oil royalties where the aggregate price does not exceed $100,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had suspended temporarily in three cases the effectiveness of offering sheets by the filing of which with the SEC issuers obtain exemption from registration under the Securities Act of 1933.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- One lone scratch hit today separated Buck Newsom, Washington's husky right-hand pitcher, from baseball's hall of fame as he shut out the Tigers, 5 to 0, in the best pitched game he has ever turned in.

LONDON, July 10. -- About 750,000 will be added to the annual expenditure on unemployment assistance, which at present is about 38,000,000, by new regulations under which more than 250,000 persons will receive an extra "dole."

PARIS, July 10. -- Between 7 and 21 per cent has been added to industrial production costs in France by application of the new labor laws passed in consequence of the stay-in strikes, Paul Marchandeau, former Minister of Commerce, said today in the Chamber of Deputies.

The statement of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company as of June 30 showed total deposits of $18,558,681 and total assets of $49,272,652. The bank reported cash on hand and due from banks aggregating $5,502,249; investments in United States Government securities of $2,401,110; loans and discounts secured by bond and mortgage, deed or other real estate collateral of $4,115,716; loans and discounts otherwise secured of $2,702,145, and unsecured loans, discounts and bills of $1,415,899.

HEWLETT, L.I., July 10. -- Young Bobby Jacobson, who achieved fame along with Bobby Jones of Detroit and other sensation-producing youngsters in the national amateur two years ago, met his Waterloo in the semi-final round of the New York State junior golf championship today.

It will be a serious reflection upon America and particularly upon the Committee on Fair (sic) Play in Sports if the Olympic fund deficit is not promptly made up. Those who opposed American participation in the Berlin Olympics lost out and now they should be sportsmanlike enough to abide by the decision of the majority, unless they favor the minority rule of dictatorship.

Commodity futures continued to advance yesterday on the local markets, although cocoa and copper were irregular. Trading was firm at an active pace in most staples. On the cash markets new high prices appeared in cotton, corn, oats and rubber.

Gustavus Town Kirby, treasurer of the American Olympic Committee, gave full and up-to-date report of the finances of the organization to the Olympic Administration Committee in the Woolworth Building yesterday. It was encouraging and discouraging at the same time.

Despite the campaign promises and platforms of the other political parties, no complete solution to the economic and social problems of the day can be reached until the capitalistic system is replaced by a socialistic one, Norman Thomas, Presidential candidate of the Socialist party, declared last night.
Apartment houses, dwellings and business properties were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The condition of the principal crops on July 1 and the estimated production for 1936 were tabulated today by the Department of Agriculture as follows, with the corresponding figures for last year:

It is evident that those who shape the policy of British aviation now look steadfastly to water-going aircraft to assure swift communication for the far-flung empire, just as, in other generations, their forefathers looked to surface vessels, both military and civil, to justify the slogan, Britannia Rules the Waves.

The most important price movements in the listed bond market yesterday were toward higher levels. This improvement, however, was confined almost exclusively to the convertible and more speculative issues, which reflected the strength throughout the list of junior securities on the Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Prices of hogs dropped sharply today with the general market off 10 to 40 cents a hundredweight, while stock weighing under 170 pounds declined 40 to 50 cents. The demand was not aggressive, with reports indicating a solw demand for fresh pork. Fresh loins sold here 1/2 cent a pound lower at 14 1/2 to 21 1/2 cents wholesale.

BERLIN, July 10. -- Prices on the Boerse were firm and quiet today. Heavy industrials showed some signs of activity and some strength, Rheinstahl gaining 3 points and Vereinigtestahl 1 1/2. Potashes were slightly weaker, Aschersleben losing 1 1/2.

New York State is "away behind" on its highway building program, and next year's program should provide for from $35,000,000 to $40,000,000 worth of construction if traffic growth is to be properly handled, it was said yesterday by Captain Arthur W. Brandt, New York State Highway Commissioner.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10. -- Her upper canvas filled with breeze far above the height of the Brooklyn Bridge, Rainbow, the America's Cup defender of two years ago, today again defeated Yankee, the international campaigner.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Improvement in gross railroad operating revenues, both freight and passenger, in June over the same month last year were shown in preliminary estimates from sixty-four Class I railroads made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10. -- The Federal Social Security Act was declared a "danger to aggregate security" by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, in an address here tonight at the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia.

' NEWPORT, R. I., July lO. -- Mrs. Nicholas Brown entertained to'~ night at Harbour Court in honor of the commodore, the captains and the guests aboard the yachts of-the Eastern Yacht Club, which during the late afternoon arrived from i Vineyard Haven on their annual ' cruise.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 10. -- While technical and drafting experts worried today over details of the Straits convention relating to fortifications of the Bosporus and the Dardanelles, talk in conference circles centered on France's move in ending her provisional Mediterranean naval accord with Britain in the hope of getting Italy to attend the Montreux and Locarno conferences.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 10. -- G. Wayland Brooks, Republican candidate for Governor of Illinois, opened the State campaign for his party's national ticket here tonight by calling for the election of Landon and Knox to end the tendency toward centralized government.

PARIS, July 10. -- Many Frenchmen quit work tonight for four days of festive merrymaking ending in Bastille Day celebrations Tuesday, but a wary government was on its toes to prevent possible disorders.
United States Department of Agriculture. 1Keat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- While influential members of the executive council today were informally canvassing possibilities of a compromise solution of the craft-industrial union imbroglio in the American Federation of Labor, William Green, president of the organization, expressed the opinion that the minimum requirement for an amicable adjustment would be dissolution of the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.
THE TIMES published a letter from J.A. Marcus commenting on the amount of noise in New York City.

In the sharpest advance since the inflation days of 1933 The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced 3.7 points to 126.3 in the week ended on Tuesday from 122.6 (revised) the Tuesday previous. The rise reflected the spread of the drought in the Northwest.

Polly Adler was arrested early yesterday as a procurer. The arrest was the sixteenth in her career. Deference said to have been shown her by the police so angered Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine that he ordered an inquiry.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in June amounted to 886,065 tons, compared with 984,097 tons in May, a decrease of 98,032 tons, it was announced yesterday. Shipments in June, 1935, were 578,108 tons, and in June, 1934, 985,327 tons; and in June, 1933, 603,937 tons.
The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to dealings on a when-issued basis the rights to subscribe for stock of the Douglas Aircraft Company. Inc.

The $10,000 added Butler Handicap, richest race of the Empire City meeting, will be run this afternoon at the Hilltop course, and it bears very much the aspect of a championship test for the distaff side of the equine family. Four of the six horses named for the mile and three-sixteenths test are fillies, and the remaining two are regarded as the least likely to win.
A heat wave has its ripples. Here is an assortment of yesterday's:

MILES CITY, Mont., July 10. -- The worst consequences of drought, far more serious than financial losses involved, are now apparent throughout the sheep and cattle country. The morale of men who have ridden the range most of their lives is at the breaking point, and many already have reached "the end of the trail."

That matter of delay by inconvenient Seligson in his letter to THE TIMES, is opening of drawbridges, raised by Mr. an old grievance which the War Department has persistently and consistently ignored. The situation is not limited to Long Island and Jamaica Bay; it became so bad here in New Jersey that the railroads and the State Highway Department literally had to spend millions to provide high-level bridges.

Joseph M. Schenck, chairman of the board of Twentieth Century-Fox and chief negotiator in the pending deal between Fox and the widespread Gaumont-British Pictures Corporation for control of the latter company, reached New York yesterday by airplane from Hollywood.

Short casts: B.D. Crowninshield telephones this department from Boston that great schools of tuna were encountered three miles off Ipswich Bay, near Gloucester, on Wednesday. . . . He tried trolling with feather lures, eels and mackerel, but could not get a fish to strike. . . .

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, yesterday submitted to President Roosevelt names of five men who have been active in the shipping industry and whom he suggested as possible appointees to the Maritime Authority which will be created to administer the government's interests in the merchant marine under the new Shipping Act.

New York's greatest track and field show -- the final Olympic tryouts -- will be staged in the new municipal stadium at Randalls Island today and tomorrow to decide the fifty-nine remaining places on the Olympic team. It will be the court of final appeal for many outstanding American athletes who will make the boat within the next two days or miss it altogether.

RYE, N.Y., July 10. -- At the conclusion of a day of brilliant competion in the show ring and over the outside course, the Terre Haute Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Kaiser of Bethel, Conn., with its superb array of three and five gaited saddle horses stood out as the leading winner of the opening sessions of the sixth annual Country Club horse show at the Westchester Country Club today.

The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday that it had spent $12,725,439 in 1935. The funds were expended to advance the foundation's program in China and to continue its activities in the fields of public health, medical, natural and social sciences and the humanities.
TOKYO, July 10. -- A mysterious item of news evidently intended to prepare the public for a coming announcement appears in all the press.
Simon Schuster report that "Wake Up and Live," by Dorothea Brande, recently passed the 50,000 mark. Since its publication, Feb. 28, this book has maintained an average sale of 2,000 copies each week.

Miss Dee Boeckman, coach of the women's Olympic track and field team, disclosed yesterday that some of the girls who qualified for the team are virtually stranded in New York and are on the verge of hunger.

Of course the Ethiopian triplets won. When they trundled grandly up before the judges in their chariot -- a wobbly green wicker doll buggy -- poked their sooty black noses over the side, rolled bleary blue eyes and yipped feebly, they stopped the show.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 10. -- By the margin of six strokes, Mrs. Marion Turple Lake retained the title as the Women's Long Island Golf Association medal play champion. In the fifty-four-hole test, which came to a close at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today, Mrs. Lake accounted for a score of 239.

VIENNA, July 10. -- Franz von Papen, the German Minister, left Vienna tonight for Berchtesgaden, where he will see Chancellor Adolf Hitler and present the latest variation of the Austrian demands that are being embodied in the forthcoming Austro-German agreement.

MADRID, July 10. -- Because he felt he had been treated unfairly by the Spanish press and without proper consideration by Foreign Minister Augusto Barcia, Salvador de Madariaga tonight announced his resignation as Spain's permanent delegate to the League of Nations.

Is it not delightful, in this hot weather, to see how everybody is getting long leaves of absence? Postmaster General FARLEY'S employer gave him a long leave of absence so Mr. FARLEY can concentrate on the re-election of President ROOSEVELT.

A friend and I are planning on sailing a sixteen-foot boat from Long Island Sound up the Hudson River. We have been told that Hell Gate is very dangerous and that the Harlem River is very congested for a small boat such as ours. Could you inform me if there is any way by which we could get from the Sound to the river without encountering too much trouble?

Despite the absence of many traders from their desks yesterday, there was sufficient demand in evidence to carry many of the secondary railroad bonds up fractionally to several points in the two-hour trading period on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Developrnents in the hearings called by the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with charges that members of national securities exchanges have been guilty of violations of the antimanipulation provisions of the Securities Exchange Act have made it evident that a last-ditch battle will be fought out in the courts if the decision by the commission is adverse to any of the respondents.

Jesse Owens of Ohio State flashed over the Randalls Island Stadium cinders like a scarlet comet yesterday, qualified for two places on the American Olympic track and field team and established once more -- if there ever had been any doubt of it -- that he will be the chief United States 100-meter and broad jump hope at Berlin.

THERE are still Broadwayites who remember the day when hats were doffed to the now departed Charles B. Dillingham, Oscar Hammerstein, Henry W. Savage, A.L. Erlanger, Charles Frohman and Lincoln A. Wagenhals; when Mr. Dillingham was handsomely rewarded for the use of his name at the Hippodrome and when a playwright bowed before the impresario.

A funeral service for Thomas Meighan, star of the silent motion pictures, was held yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. A crowd of about 3,000 persons attended the solemn requiem mass and a group of friends representing many branches of the entertainment world served as honorary pallbearers.

THE Bette Davis situation, coupled with the avowed intention of many stars to limit the number of films they will make each year, has brought a reversal in the attitude of the studios. Once they rejected people because they too closely resembled existing stars.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- In the wake of the conventions of the two major parties, which defined the issues for the Presidential campaign, is arising an independent party based on radicalism that may become a formidable vote-getter in the November election.

ROME, July 10. -- It is very difficult to make an accurate estimate of the effect sanctions had on Italy, for the Italian Government suspended publication of all official figures likely to throw light on the financial and economic situation. It is only possible, therefore, to Judge by superficial symptoms, some of which may possibly prove incorrect when the facts become known.

THE first of the annual Summer shows presented at Mystic, Conn., by the Mystic Art Association opened in the charming art gallery there last Wednesday. It contains oils, sculpture, miniatures and examples of craftwork. This exhibition will be current through Aug. 9 and from Aug. 12 through Sept. 20, water-colors, pastels, black-and-whites and sculpture will be shown.

The National Court of Honor, Boy Scouts of America, awarded ten gold medals and eleven certificates to Boy Scouts who have saved the lives of others. Daniel Carter Beard, National Boy Scout Commissioner, is chairman of the Court of Honor.

LONDON. -- His present load of troubles Prime Minister Baldwin owes in a measure to his son, Oliver. That young man does not share the views of his father; he is a red-hot Socialist. In an article published some time ago, Oliver Baldwin revealed to the world the important fact that the Prime Minister intended to resign after King Edward's coronation.

MADRID, July 11. -- Although the authorities recently claimed that they were making headway in their efforts to check the flight from the peseta, it was admitted today by the Director General of Security [the National Chief of Police] that he is still busy tracking down operators on the Black Bourse or bootleg money exchange.

CENTURIES before either Plato or Pythagorus journeyed thither in search of knowledge, the wisdom of Egypt had become proverbial over all the ancient world. Her remarkable religious system, with its superb ritual and yet simple human appeal for the ignorant and the unintelligent, its philosophy and profound spiritual significance for the instructed and the intelligent, had then already endured for thousands of years.
On Dec. 26, 1934, Public Works Administrator Ickes issued Administrative Order 129, which shortly became a subject of great controversy in New York. It read:

BERLIN, July 11. -- Germany is good and is getting better. The German championships and final Olympic trials in track and field, which opened today, demonstrated beyond any doubt that the host team is going to provide dangerous competition for all comers, including the traditional Olympic victor, the United States.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 11. -- Starting tomorrow, the regular fortnightly movement of State Guardsmen will get under way, with 5,000 infantrymen moving in and out of the several reservations. The movement will be virtually confined to Camp Smith and Pine Camp, with the units at Fort Ontario and Fort Wright remaining in camp another week to complete their Summer training.

IT is indicative of how far the world has traveled in tolerance and in understanding divergent points of view that so impartial and laudatory a book as this on Ignatius Loyola, the founder of the Jesuit Order, the Society of Jesus, to give its official name, should come from the pen of a Protestant clergyman and carry an enthusiastic introduction by a nationally known Jesuit editor.

At least one ship of major importance is scheduled to arrive in port every day this week. The French liner Normandie will lead the parade, arriving tomorrow, and after her in order on successive days will be the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, Hapag Lloyd liner Bremen, Italian liner Rex, United States liner President Harding and Holland-America liner Statendam.

CLEVELAND, July 11. -No important change in the rate of industrial operations in this district has so far been reported in July, although a rather sharp decline in steel production was expected in trade circles. A large volume of unfilled orders carried over from the second quarter and more buying at the higher prices than was expected maintained production at not far from 70 per cent of capacity for the industry as a whole.

NEWARK, N.J., July 11. -- Amid the fastest trotting seen at Weequahic Park this season, the matinee track record of 2:07 1/4 was broken today when Mac Hanover, trotting gelding, owned by H.C.L. Miller of Plainfield, won the second and final heats of the Class A Trot and Pace in 2:06 3/4.

SOMEWHERE toward the end of "The Earth Trembles." the fifth volume of "Men of Good Will," can be found the millionth word of what already is the most immense novel of out times. And there are many volumes to come, the definite number depending upon how long Jules Romains continues to be so superbly the master of his great creative powers and upon the course which history takes.

ALBANY, July 11. -- Increases of 1 cent per half-pint bottle in the price of cream to consumers and from 15 to 25 cents per 100 pounds in the rates to be paid to producers for milk were ordered today by Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets after a hearing on drought conditions. A two-hour session of the Milk Advisory Board was held.

BERLIN, July 11. -- An agreement between Germany and Austria adjusting in principle the differences between them on lines forecast in recent dispatches from London, Berlin and Vienna to THE NEW YORK TIMES was announced simultaneously in Berlin and Vienna tonight.

Professor William E. Hocking's discussion of the Palestine problem reminds me of a well-known Jewish story. Says the narrator: "Jones went to Warsaw and sold coal and made a lot of money." Comments the auditor: "Quite right, only he did not go to Warsaw, he went to Cracow; he sold wood, not coal, and he went bankrupt."

PATERSON, N.J., July 11. -- The provisions of a two-year agreement, which will replace the working contract expiring on Aug. 31, were ratified today by members of the Federation of Dyers, Printers, Finishers and Bleachers of America at a meeting held by locals of this city, Passaic, Lodi and Englewood.

Mr. Jefferson wrote that in 1824. The National Resources Committee reported to President Roosevelt last week that public affairs in this nation are administered by 175,000 separate Federal, State and local governing bodies.

PARIS, July 10. -- Something of that belated courage that men are apt to show after the event has been displayed this week by opponents of the Blum government. It will of course impress many people and probably will ultimately have its effect.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Government agencies continued today their efforts to relieve suffering, both human and animal, in the blistered regions, as Oklahoma, Georgia and Kentucky were added to the official list of States which are at least partly suffering from severe drought.
UTICA, Ind., July 11 (AP). -- William Carr Lentz, corn king of the world, looked at his drought-burnt fields today and wondered whether he ought to abdicate.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Nation's Taste, given away by the Milky Way Farms Stable of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars in a contest and then bought back for $2,000, raced to victory in the Hyde Park Stakes at Arlington Park today. Nation's Taste conquered Hal Price Headley's Apogee by a head before a crowd of 25,000.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- As a result of the gravest discord since its inception fifty-five years ago the American Federation of Labor is now threatened with a split that may mean the physical creation of a rival labor federation. This possibility arises at a time when one group of unions is fighting for collective bargaining in the nation's most powerful anti-union industry -- steel, the so-called "citadel of the open shop."

BOY SCOUTS have various ways of raising money to meet the expenses of Summer camping. Scout training and resourcefulness help a good deal, although the Scout must observe the tenet of his law which permits him to "work for pay" but not to "receive tips for courtesies or good turns."
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 11 (AP). -- At 90 Mrs. Lydia Anne Browning, a great-grandmother, is an inveterate swimmer.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 11. -- A Princeton University alliance for the maintenance of the Christian heritage will be formed next Fall among all those in the university who are in sympathy with the Christian heritage, it was announced today by Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the chapel.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 11 (AP) -- To study the stresses in bridges, buildings, airplanes, streamlined trains and automobiles, a new photo-elastic apparatus was demonstrated today by John W. Forrest and Harold D. Straat, Rochester physicists.

For more than a week the one subject of dominant interest to the American public has been the great blanket of heat that has covered the whole country from the Rockies to the Atlantic seaboard. The hardship it has brought to urban areas is amply told by reports of intense suffering in congested areas.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 11. -- Mrs. John F. Sanderson and Miss Peggy Sanderson of Ridgefield, Conn., have joined Mr. Sanderson at the Mount Washington here.

Dawn-to-dusk flights across the Caribbean, putting parts of South America within twenty-four hours of New York and Chicago, will go into effect on next Wednesday, Pan American Airways disclosed yesterday.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y. -- Chautauqua Institution has opened its sixty-third Summer season with a more promising outlook than for seven years past, having, like all other non-profit-taking cultural centers, suffered during the depression.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP). -- The steel workers' organizing committee said today that twenty employes of the Hubbard Co. plant in Pittsburgh reported the mill had been closed because of union activities.

United States Senator Robert F. Wagner sailed on the French liner Champlain yesterday to spend a month abroad studying housing programs in Ireland and England. His trip is really a vacation but he said he would make a survey of housing, gathering information to aid him in writing another housing bill for the next session of Congress.

INTO Summer's hammock has dropped Transition, reborn, and edited not as before in the Rue Fabert, but instead at No. 113 West Forty-second Street. That in itself is news, and the hammock's lethargic July rhythm accelerates perceptibly.
SHANGHAI, July 11 (AP). -- Japanese civil, military and naval authorities conferred today on the killing of a countryman and on "better means of protecting Japanese life and property in Shanghai."

Eight hundred persons at Gilgo Beach, L.I., gave up bathing yesterday afternoon to watch while a 6-month-old German shepherd dog swam through a heavy surf in an effort to rescue a canine companion, and finally just succeeded in saving himself.

THIS volume, with its oriflamme of titles, the genuine modesty and restraint of its narratives, and the self-spoofing intrepidity of the exploits it relates, is an excellent illustration of what Punch would call "the English character."

The creation of a new "behind-the-scenes" tour of the store, "from sky to cellar," for visitors to New York, was announced yesterday by R.H. Macy Co. The store announced that it would provide special guides for the visitors to show them how a large department store operates.

Captain Rene Pugnet, one of the most versatile and picturesque seamen in the Atlantic trades, will terminate a career of thirty-nine years this month when he takes the French liner Normandie back to Havre. The liner arrives here tomorrow with Captain Pugnet in command for the last time.

BINGHAMTON, July 11 (AP). -- Seeking immediate funds for preliminary work, the executive committee of the Flood Control Council of Central-Southern New York authorized today the appointment of a committee to call on President Roosevelt at Hyde Park Monday.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 11. -- A fleet of 105 craft competed today in the annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, with H.G. Hanan's 50-foot class craft, Spartan, leading the field home in the race for larger boats.

Bound for Nottingham, England, to compete in an international tournament against the world's leading chess experts next month, Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Georgic.

QUEBEC. -- The forthcoming visit of President Roosevelt to Quebec to call upon the Governor General on July 31 promises to be one of the high social occasions of the season for members of the United States Summer colony here. Plans are being completed for a number of events in respect to the first visit to Quebec of the incumbent of the White House.

A year ago, when Governor Lehman empaneled an extraordinary grand jury to help Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey wipe out racketeering in New York City, the boss racketeers enjoyed a raucous laugh. They spoke of the special prosecutor as a "Boy Scout" -- not a respectful term in the underworld -- and went on with their pinochle.

The Triborough Bridge, dedicated yesterday, belongs to the age of steel, of streamlined cars, of speed and urban sophistication; yet the ceremonies marking its opening had about them the flavor of a country picnic in the horse-and-buggy era.

THREE times Marshal Jim Hampton with his picked posses and relays all along the mountain trail had run the King Bird and run him hard. Three times was enough, thought that wily young outlaw; so when night had come he slid into the Marshal's camp, gently awakened him and held converse with him!

LEWES, Del., July 11. -- Another group of marine treasure hunters has given up the search for the British sloop-of-war de Braak, which, with its reputed $800,000 in Spanish gold now lying at the bottom of the Delaware Bay near Cape Henlopen, has eluded salvagers for 138 years.

MOST of the lookers-on in the world of prints will be disposed to agree with me, I think, as to the gradual emergence of the medium of lithography from its modest place in the background of modernism to a place, still modest, but in the front row.

Revival of business in women's knitwear departments depends upon their being treated as "real fashion departments," according to a report especially prepared for THE TIMES by Tobe, fashion authority and consultant to over 100 leading stores throughout the country.

Damage by the drought has eliminated the possibility of important food surpluses and, while no serious shortages are indicated, prices are stiffening, placing sellers in an advantageous position, according to an extensive survey completed yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

"Topics of the Times" recently compared the Roosevelt New Deal with the Government of New Zealand over a long period of years and stated: "A great many of the plans and programs which the New Deal prescribes for the salvation of America and which Al Smith's friends call the end of American democracy are old stuff in the Antipodes."
A WORLD-WIDE census of radio sets reveals 56,168,451, according to the International Broadcasting Office at Geneva. This compares with 48,300,000 in 1935.

A NEW and more important role is in store for the jaywalker. With Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine's petition to the Aldermanic Committee on Traffic for authority to arrest pedestrians who cross streets in mid-block or against the lights at corners, the "reckless walker" has become a major factor in the traffic safety campaign.

ST. LOUIS, July 11. -- The Giants not only knocked Dizzy Dean out of the box today but they knocked him right into the hospital. Yet they lost their third straight to the Cardinals and left tonight for Chicago a forlorn band with only the consolation of escape from the enervating heat here.

One man was killed and three others injured shortly before 4 A.M. yesterday when the automobile in which they were riding overturned on City Island Road about a half mile from Pelham Bridge Road, the Bronx. The victim was Edmund Tucciarone, 25 years old, of 1,637 Crosby Avenue, the Bronx, who died an hour after the accident in Fordham Hospital.

IM WIRBEL DER BERUFUNG" is Gerhardt Hauptmann's title for his new book (S. Fischer, Berlin). He penetrates deeply into a phase of his development which was curiously, almost mystically bound up with the Shakespearean figure of Hamlet; his whole life was influenced by the problems arising out of this drama.

TOPEKA, July 11. -- The belief that Mrs. Landon will not play an active part in her husband's campaign for the Presidency was strengthened here today when Miss Natalie Couch of New York, head of the women's division of the Republican campaign in the East, said that she knew of no plans for Mrs. Landon's participation.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Activities of varied interest will claim the attention of members of the Summer colony during the coming week. It has been estimated that several thousand persons will witness the pageant to be presented Wednesday morning at Conscience Point to welcome the tercentenary historical marine cruise which will assemble there.

LONDON, July 10. -- The present foreign and domestic policies of the British Government are not in the slightest danger from public pressure, Parliamentary opposition or attacks on the Baldwin Cabinet. The personal political fortunes of individual Ministers may suffer from time to time whenever there is need for a scapegoat.

AMATEUR photographers of an ingenious turn are discovering in rapidly increasing numbers the unusual photographic results which may be achieved by the skillful and imaginative use of dolls and toy figures in small-scale interiors or landscape settings.
LONDON. QUEEN MARY next Autumn will move into Marlborough House, which has been vacant eleven years. It was built for the first Duke of Marlborough 227 years ago from designs by Sir Christopher Wren.

NEW YORKERS on a New England holiday are flocking to Cape Cod. They arrive by plane and car, by boat and train. Ask a New Yorker why he likes the Cape and he tells you it is "different." Sometimes he says it is "quaint."
CLEVELAND, July 11 (AP). -- The Townsend organization will open Wednesday a five-day national convention in which delegates may possibly signify their attitude toward third-party movements.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- With an estimated 87,000 families on direct relief, Chicago has only a monthly $1,600,000 in sight to provide for them. That, according to Alderman Arvey, administration leader in the City Council, is $2,000,000 less than enough to do the job.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 11. -- Many dinners were given tonight at various estates here for week-end guests. Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston were hosts at Old Trees for Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin. Among their other guests were Mr. and Mrs. J. Denennison Lyon, who have arrived at Sandymount for the Summer; Mr. and Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth and their guest, Mrs. Robert Livingston Stevens of Bernardsville, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson.

CINCINNATI, July 11 (AP). -- An appeal by Mayor Allen C. Roudebush of Norwood to strikers and Remington-Rand officials to continue peace negotiations drew from Floyd C. Williams, company attorney, late today a reply that "there is nothing to negotiate."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 11 (AP). -- A four-point program designed to speed the passage of legislation for reform of State, county and city government was approved today at the close of a two-day conference sponsored by the New York State Committee of the National Municipal League.
The heat wave that swept across the country from the drought-baked Middle West last week continued to scorch New York and virtually the entire East yesterday on its fourth successive day.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- To rehabilitate delinquent boys, more effective parole work and efforts to improve the home conditions to which they must return upon discharge from institutions must receive greater emphasis, it has been concluded from a study of 751 delinquent boys from five State institutions just reported on by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

FAIRFIELD, N.J., July 11. -- S.M. (Steve) Crothers of Chestnut Hill, Pa., added 200 consecutive targets to the 100 he made yesterday to win the clay target championship and take a long lead for all-around honors in the Eastern Zone trapshooting championships at the North Jersey Gun Club today.

McCOOK, Neb., July 11 (AP). -- George W. Norris, Nebraska's veteran Senator, quietly observed his seventy-fifth birthday today at his Wisconsin Summer home without answering the question whether he would run for a fifth term in the Senate.

OVER American farmland broods the feverish, piteous atmosphere of a sick room where a crisis impends. For half a year the indifferent heavens have sent down little more than half their customary rains. Last Winter the heavy snows covered the fields with moisture in abeyance, a promise of abundant water for the roots of the new crops.

MR. READ does not believe that sound history should or need be the preserve of scholars and academicians. Historians are, he says, under an obligation to present their scholarly findings in a form sufficiently interesting to the general reading public to challenge those writers of so-called popular history who depend chiefly on the sensational and the salicious.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- Handing the Tigers their second straight defeat, 10 to 7, the Senators today moved within a half game of second place as the Red Sox also were beaten. The victory enabled Washington to take the current series, two games to one.

ALL rights to the name of the Printing House of William Edwin Rudge, together with records, books, type, plates and the famous Jenson trade-mark redesigned by Bruce Rogers, have been acquired by William E. Rudge's Sons, Inc., organized in 1932 by two sons of the late William Edwin Rudge and three other men.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Professor Casey Stengel probably will move to have this date declared a municipal holiday hereafter. His Dodgers, either overcome by the heat or imbued with some strange spirit, actually defeated the Cubs on their home grounds by a score of 5 -- 3, leaving 5,300 fans stunned by this unheard of procedure.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11. -- To provide shippers of Charleston, Savannah and Jacksonville with a more frequent service to the Pacific Coast, the Arrow-Williams Joint Intercoastal west-bound service, already furnishing weekly sailings from Baltimore and Norfolk to the Pacific Coast ports, will be extended at once to include weekly sailings from Charleston, Savannah and Jacksonville.

THE Midyear Report of the twenty-fourth year of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund is offered on these pages today. It tells what progress has been made toward relieving the need of the 100 cases whose stories were first published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 1 last.

MONTREAL, July 9. -- Thirty workmen engaged in grading and leveling the Edmonton Highway at Beverley, a few miles east of Edmonton, will have the distinction at the end of this week of receiving the first taxable "prosperity certificates" issued by the Province of Alberta in pursuance of its pre-social credit plan of scrip issue to cure unemployment.

Its novelty does not lie in its foundation principle itself, but in the application of that principle of faith and imagination to problems, both personal and general, of this immediate day.

HOLLYWOOD. THOSE manufacturers of illusion, the press agents, have a sorry time making a glamour child out of Edward Arnold. Yet in this land of fictitious values, where not only the movie sets but the careers and talents and backgrounds of the inhabitants are made of chicken wire and plaster and where genius is as illusory as a transparency shot, he is an intriguing figure.

WHATEVER faults the Warner Brothers may have (and let that producer who is without blame cast up the first reminder), they still are the Noble Experimenters of the motion picture industry. They ventured forth with the first talking picture.

NO production on earth was ever quite so colossal as a producer. There is something Napoleonic about even a Class B producer -- trailing clouds of industrial preoccupation -- something above, however, the cheap stage trappings of tricorn hat, folded arms and hammy scowl.

TORONTO, July 11. -- This week brought heavy trading and sharp advances of prices in numerous volatile junior shares of gold-mining companies on the Toronto Stock Exchange and an influx of news that promised well for the immediate future.
SYRACUSE, July 11 (AP). -- After several months' silence as to his intentions, Mayor Rolland B. Marvin today announced himself a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Visitors to Republican National Headquarters today from South Dakota and Missouri reported enthusiastically on the party's activities in those States and the outlook for November.

Mingled emotions of jubilation and heartbreak greeted the visitor to the dressing room under Randalls Island Stadium last night at the conclusion of the first day of the final Olympic track and field tryouts.

A police teletype alarm was sent out from Brooklyn police headquarters last night for Joseph Kuhn of 1,015 Second Avenue, Altoona, Pa., who, in visiting the city for the first time, was separated from his wife, Mary, at the Thirty-sixth Street station of the B.M.T. subway in Brooklyn when Mr. Kuhn was pushed out of the train by milling crowds.

The Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda was delayed three hours in docking at her West Fifty-fifth Street pier yesterday morning due to being struck Friday night by the seventy-two-ton fishing boat, Benjamin W. Latham, owned by Charles Peree of 572 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, about eighty miles southeast of Ambrose Lightship.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Whatever the outcome of the industrial-craft union fight in the American Federation of Labor the Roosevelt administration -- unless its services are requested -- will meticuously avoid taking sides or intervening in any way before election, it was reported here today.
SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., July 11 (AP). -- Representative Prentiss M. Brown of St. Ignace announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Senator in the primary election in September.

ONE important point about the coming Metropolitan Opera season has not been sufficiently underscored. That is the fact that all arrangements are being made for just one season. Edward Johnson, the manager, has a contract for one year, and all his artists and staff are receiving agreements for that period.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- When the Weather Bureau announced a few days ago that "very little pasture is now available between the Rocky and the Appalachian Mountains" it delimited what may be the worst, though perhaps not the most extensive, drought in the past half century of American history.

NAMPA, Idaho, July 10. -- After more than two years of anticipation and waiting, Idaho's premier political contest at last has materialized. William E. Borah and Governor C. Ben Ross this week filed for the Senate seat which Borah has occupied for three decades.

THE story of a clannish English family group of the upper middle class, "Friendly Relations" is an entertaining novel by the daughter of E.V. Lucas. Its best points are its successful characterizations and its effective and engaging style.

PORTRAIT OF A LIBRARY" is a friendly little book which can give you a great deal of information about what the library can do for you and what you, as a citizen, can do for it, not only in your capacity as a pleased reader of the books it offers you for amusement or study, but also as a civic-minded person interested in the position of the library in the community in which you live.

Work for "a whole army of people" will be provided by the railroads of the country during the next fifteen or twenty years in the replacement of worn-out and obsolete equipment, Ralph Budd, president of the Burlington Railroad, told a conference on employment yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
ESTES PARK, COL., July 11. -- Far in the background of the 1936 Presidential campaign is Thee Cobb Landon, and there she intends to stay.

TO the vast bibliography about Jutland this book should be the capstone. Not in literary content, not in interest for the lay reader is this volume distinguished. But in patient and precise research, in the accurate assembly of a great mass of factual data, and particularly in the careful presentation of both the British and the German accounts and viewpoints, "The Battle of Jutland" seems to this reviewer unsurpassed.
James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, will hold his first press conference tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock in the party headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, July 11. -- The quinquennial Anglo-American Conference of Historians, which concluded today, is held to have done work of a wider significance and importance than benefiting students of history. The Times says editorially today that the ignorance of the history of the United States among well-educated Britons is appalling and that the relations between the two countries must be improved and the friendship increased by the kind of work the historians are doing.

NOT even the most optimistic promoters of the Left Book Club anticipated such a response as is now reported. Within a fortnight it has enrolled 12,000 members, and fresh applications are coming in by every post.

Stock prices and trading activity increased last week in direct ratio to the mercury. Trading exceeded 6,500,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, the largest turnover in any week since that ended on May 2. Industrial shares, as a group, mounted to new high marks for the year, and THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks gained 2.82 points on the week, the best showing since the week ended on June 13.

A plan of readjustment for bonds of the Republic of El Salvador, which is said to be the first plan in the foreign bond field providing for cash payments of matured unpaid coupons as welt as for the resumption of sinking-fund payments retroactively for eighteen months, was submitted yesterday to bondholders by the bondholders protective committee, of which F.J. Lisman is chairman.
