HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 11. -- A romance involving America's first woman diplomat culminated here today when Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, standing in an ivy-covered church where President and Mrs. Roosevelt sat in the pew they have held for thirty years, was married to Captain Boerge Rohde, Captain of the Royal Life Guards of King Christian X of Denmark, to whose court Mrs. Owen is Minister.

A small island in the British West Indies is the scene of this new story about Kent Murdock, the newspaper photographer who did the sleuthing in "Murder Without Pictures." Murdock and his wife, Joyce, are on a vacation on the island of Barotique, the property of Sir Stanley Bannister, whose daughter is Joyce's friend.

WOMEN who knit throughout the Summer in order to have a head start on an up-to-the-minute Fall wardrobe now may stitch themselves ensembles that have the appearance of plaid. An overstitch of wool is used which contrasts in tone of color with the wool that forms the background of the garments.

Coinciding with a smaller number of new security flotations for refunding purposes, fewer announcements than in the preceding week were made last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity. The calls were chiefly for future months and principally for public utility bonds.

Recently there was complaint that orators neglect to cite the sources of their inspiration for quotations. It seems to me this neglect is not due to willful intent. Neither does the failure appear to be a pose for the sake of impressing the public with the erudition of the speaker.

ST. LOUIS, July 11. -- President Ford C. Frick of the National League on a visit here as he makes a circuit of the league, today authorized umpires to doff their coats during the heat waves now sweeping the country.

I looked through your reports of the sermons of the clergy in New York City last Sunday, hoping to see some denunciation of Italy's action in Ethiopia and, of what was worse, the cowardly inaction of the League of Nations in not insisting that Italy shall abide by what the League of Nations stands for, namely, arbitration instead of war.

Featured by a strong revival of interest in better-grade merchandise, and with buyers' arrivals showing an increase of 15 per cent over last year, the Fall season in the women's apparel and allied markets last week got off to the best start of a seasonal period in close to a decade.
FRANKFORT, Ky., July 11 (AP). -- Waste from distilleries may be used to advantage as a fertilizer for worn out soil, Garth K. Ferguson, State Commissioner of Agriculture, said today.

The present Baldwin Government seems impervious to the blows of misfortune. Neither humiliations abroad nor defeats at home appear seriously to weaken it. Despite the latest reverse -- the victory over the Government candidate by the Labor opponent, PHILIP NOEL BAKER, in the by-election for Derby last Thursday to fill the seat vacated by J.H. THOMAS -- the Cabinet doggedly develops its internal program and prepares for a more "British" foreign policy.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 11. -- The Schubert production of Sigmund Romberg's operetta, "The Student Prince," with all of its romantic trimmings, was presented here tonight on the stage on Zach's Bay under the direction of Frortune Gallo before a capacity audience of 10,000 persons who filled every available seat in the Jones Beach Stadium.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 11 (AP). -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend today told Nebraska Townsendites the Roosevelt administration "constitutes the most gigantic bribery in the world" and that it should be turned out of office.

RENO, Nev., July 11 (AP). -- Mrs. Diana Dodge Davies, socially prominent daughter of Mrs. George D. Widener, won a divorce at Carson City, Nev., yesterday from Frederick Martin Davies of New York, it was learned today. The decree was granted on grounds of cruelty.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 11 (AP). -- "Federalization" is the biggest issue of the Presidential campaign, Mrs. Eugene Meyer, wife of the Washington newspaper publisher, told the Chautauqua Institution today.

President Roosevelt participated in the dedication of the Triborough Bridge yesterday in the course of a four-hour visit to New York City, during which he drove through long stretches of the Bronx and Harlem which he had not previously visited and traversed the three parts of the structure.

With its membership roster at a new high peak and its fleet augmented by twenty-two sizable craft, the Northport Y.C. is to have two cruises during the current season. Fleet Captain Lawrence Cross and his corps of assistants are to arrange runs to Black Rock and Port Washington.

James Murray, who rose out of obscurity as a Hollywood "extra" to become famous in the motion picture, "The Crowd," in 1928, was identified yesterday as the man who was drowned Friday night off Pier 86, North River. The body lay until shortly before noon yesterday at the morgue, where the actor's mother, Mrs. Christopher J. Murray of 412 East 202d Street, the Bronx, made positive identification.

EASTERN POINT, July 11. -- Max Marston, veteran golfer from Philadelphia and winner of many tournaments, paired with Miss Carol Smith of Hartford to win low gross and low net in the mixed foursomes at the Shenecossett Golf Club today.
LONDON, July 11. -- There are two interpretations in London of the new German-Austrian agreement, announcement of which reached here simultaneously tonight from Berlin and Vienna.
Civil liberties in the United States improved during the year ended June 1 over the "unusual preceding year," a report of the American Civil Liberties Union, just made public, said.

IT is reported from Philadelphia that Mayor S. Davis Wilson has received many congratulations on the success with which traffic was handled during the recent Democratic National Convention. One of the chief factors in the control of vehicular movements was a control booth on the roof of Convention Hall, from which officers directed traffic by means of a system of loud speakers, over an area extending two miles from their position.

FOR the past two years college students increasingly have been running their own bookstores, cafeterias, valet and laundry services, houses and clothing shops. Today there are more than 150 orthodox cooperatives owned and operated by undergraduates.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Five Summer stock companies will provide entertainment in the White Mountains for thousands this Summer. The Barnstormers of Tamworth have transferred their Wednesday performances from Holderness to the Meservey Auditorium at New Hampton.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP). -- The Federal Office of Education announced today allotments available to the States on a dollar-for-dollar matching basis for vocational rehabilitation during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1937.

GENEVA, July 11. -- How does the League of Nations face the future after its week of apparently unmitigated ignominy ending with it raising sanctions against a triumphant aggressor and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's spokesman thumbing his nose in the Council chamber after taking the first step toward a much more dangerous aggression?

DEFEATED: When Oklahoma's Democratic primary returns came in last week, United States Senator Thomas Pryor Gore, candidate for renomination, stood in fourth place. Strong pro-New Dealers and a Townsendite had defeated him.

EVERYTHING was perfect at the opening of the new Randalls Island Stadium, including the weather and the loudspeaker system that failed and thus enabled the spectators to avoid hearing the dedicatory addresses of the oratorical officials.

HAMBURG, July 11. -- Edgar Andre, a Belgian-German Communist and former leader in Hamburg of the Red Front Fighters' League, has been sentenced to death for "plotting treason and engaging in seditious and subversive activities."

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 11 (AP). -- Mrs. Ramona Rascon, widowed yesterday when the State executed her husband, Frank Rascon, remained ill here today, with prison officials and the attending physician somewhat in disagreement over the cause of her condition.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 11. -- More than 1,000 pounds of tuna fish, fresh caught by six amateur fishermen, was distributed among cottagers in this village today, and, the followers of Izaak Walton say, it is the largest catch ever recorded by any of them, individually or collectively.

Miss Katherine Rawls, diminutive blonde from the Miami Beach Swimming Club, fully proved she is this country's greatest all-around water woman by winning both the 100-meter free style sprint and the three-meter springboard diving event in the opening program of the Olympic swimming and diving tryouts at the new Municipal Astoria Park Pool yesterday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11. -- In reply to the defense of speculation made here on last Tuesday night by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, a renewed determination to keep the market for securities primarily an investors' market was declared in a prepared address here tonight by William O. Douglas, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

AMERICA'S highest mountain peak and the lowest spot in the nation are brought within easy motoring distance by the new Lone Pine-Mount Whitney road in Sequoia National Park, California, recently completed after three years of toil by CCC workers under the direction of the National Forest Service.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The trade agreements between Russia and the United States, which was concluded on July 13, 1935, to run for one year, was extended for another year through an exchange of notes in Moscow today between Loy W. Henderson, United States Charge d'Affaires, and N.N. Krestinsky, the Assistant Commissar for Foreign Affairs of the Soviet Government.

LONDON, July 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's special commission made a two-day preliminary study of the British cooperative movement and announced tonight it would leave tomorrow for Sweden to return later for an exhaustive survey.

IN spite of the trains, airplanes and automobiles that churn our people and rub one against the other until the rough edges have become almost smooth, our speech has not been standardized. Subtle differences -- that flat a of the "Daown Easterner," the soft drawl of the Southerner, the nasal quality of the Middle States and the breezy colloquialism of the Far West -- still betray one's place of birth.

THE most important musical developments of the past decade are transmission of music by radio, reproduction of music by the films and the growth of public school music in America, especially of instrumental music. A million youth today are seriously studying musical instruments in American public schools, half of them playing in school bands whose standards of performance would often do credit to professional organizations.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 11. -- Coming again to Hyde Park to begin a vacation planned to last for two or three weeks, President Roosevelt received a hearty welcome this afternoon from 400 of his neighbors, who gathered on the lawn of a near-by farm to celebrate the seventh anniversary of the forming of the Roosevelt Home Club.

Ernest Desmond de Hagen, also known as Lord Desmond, 47 years old, who was arrested in Los Angeles five weeks after leaving New York in May, returned here yesterday under police guard. He denied any guilt in the two grand larceny and two attempted extortion charges against him and Harold W. Hastings, Assistant District Attorney, he was willing to appear as a State's witness.

PARIS, July 11. -- Faced with the threat of a farm workers' strike and the continuation of stay-in strikes in different parts of the country which have, in some cases, resulted in disturbances, the government has decided to use its authority so as to prevent the degeneration of the movement into an attitude of latent revolt.

It is unfortunate that the New Deal program should, in common with that of the regular Communist party and so many other organizations, stir up class feeling by blaming the "predatory rich" for our economic ills. It is a mistake to assume that there is an economic conflict between labor and capital.

TORONTO, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Ontario's death toll in the four-day heat wave rose to 130 late today with reports from all parts of the Province attributing heat directly or indirectly as the cause of death.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- In a mass of cooling air ballooning over the Rocky Mountains, weather forecasters sighted tonight the end of the worst heat wave of recent years in the northern section of the nation.

WHAT is to be done? Europe, the world, look on the broken crockery and wonder. What is to be done? Can we save the peace of the world? Can we save the League of Nations? How is all this chaos going to end? A kind of anguish seizes people's minds like that which unnerves the child in the face of situations too puzzling for his tender mental powers.

THE movement for the conservation of wild flowers has made great progress during recent years, and has accomplished much toward saving for posterity what is left of America's natural beauty. Many gardeners feel, however, that there is need for the placing of more emphasis on the growing in gardens of these lovely denizens of wood, meadow and swamp.
LOS ANGELES, July 11. -- Death Valley Scotty came to town today, glanced at the weather reports and expressed his anxiety to get back to his "diggings" -- where it's 130 in the shade.

SYMPHONY concerts given in the parks under the Federal Music Project will be curtailed for the next few weeks, the only unit to give public performances being the New York Festival Orchestra. This move follows the announcement of a special symphony concert in Madison Square Garden July 29, at which the New York Civic Orchestra, the Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra and the Knickerbocker Little Symphony will be combined.

THIS biography of the wife of General Sherman might well be subtitled, "The Chronicle of a Happy Marriage." For through failure and disappointment, sickness, calumny and death, as well as through gladness and victory, the love of wife for husband and of husband for wife seems never to have faltered for a moment.

THOUGH New York's proposed world's fair seems still a long way off, there comes from San Francisco a useful reminder that it is by no means too early to begin making preparations. The latter city's exposition, planned for 1939, is equally far in the future, but already Adolph Bolm has outlined the program of a dance festival which has been given wide publicity.

BOSTON, July 11. -- The toll of death from a five-day sequence of fierce heat and violent thunderstorms in New England mounted tonight to thirty-five, with heavy damage from lightning and resultant fire.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The number of persons employed by WPA on June 20 was 2,268,542, representing the smallest number since large-scale operations began last November, according to Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The AAA announced that 600,000 pounds of dried beans in ten freight cars were en route to North and South Dakota for relief distribution. The beans were bought by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation.

ONE of the things which the garden novice takes longest to learn is to work ahead of the season. Failing in this, he often attempts, too late, to make up for the oversight. The feeding of plants which bloom in late Summer and Autumn is a case in point.
New York City was introduced formally yesterday to the Triborough Bridge and found it unlike any other bridge in the world.

Your editorial "America Today" is food for thought. It is true that all over the land there is an underlying emotion for the old America, "the large, loose and comfortable pattern which has always distinguished this country from all others whatsoever."

OFTEN it is only by looking back over a bit more than the immediate past that one can appreciate rates of growth. This is especially true of the air-transport industry. The airlines completed early this Summer their first ten years of scheduled operations. Last year there were 746,969 paid fares on the domestic airlines.

The "breathing spell" for the French franc appeared yesterday to have come to an end, and a renewal of the crisis in the gold-bloc currencies once more was at hand as the European gold moneys suffered heavy losses in the foreign exchange market on top of the weakness that started on Friday.

This department has no patience with the type of gunner who would ruthlessly destroy every bird that happens to include in its diet (because nature willed it so), some species of game bird or game fish.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 11. -- In line with the "sunspot theory" of economic and industrial activity, there has come from Harvard's astronomical observatory a declaration by Dr. Loring B. Andrews, astronomer, that sunspot activity can be correlated with such varied phenomena as weather conditions, economic tranquillity and distress, wars, floods and international crises.

ACCORDING to the latest statistics released by the Federal Music Project, 2,399,446 students unable to pay for private musical instruction attended the free classes of the project in its 140 music centers throughout Greater New York during the year ending June 30.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 11 (AP). -- Bolivia, with more jobs than workers, engaged today in rounding up all men between the ages of 18 and 60 years to put them to work.

Heavy rains, accompanied in some places by damaging lightning and high winds, struck several cities in Northeastern New Jersey last evening, bringing some relief from the high temperatures of the last three days.

ONCE again the movies have proved that they need wait neither for time nor tide. Should a shooting script demand a major catastrophe -- be it flood, fire, hurricane or interplanetary explosion -- the Mahomets of the film colony are not content to wait for the ordinary course of nature.
MADRID, July 11. -- The Filipino aviators Juan Calvo and Antonia Arnaiz arrived at the Madrid Commercial Airport at 5 o'clock this evening in their scarlet tourist plane, Philippine Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON July 11. -- With the 1936 Revenue Law fixing the rules under which processing taxes collected under the invalidated AAA may be refunded, the drive for refunds is getting under way. Through the AAA, the Federal Government collected nearly a billion dollars in processing taxes.

MOSCOW, July 10. -- One of the most difficult things in the U.S.S.R. is to estimate real wages. Official figures place the average monthly wage at around 150 rubles, but when one begins to investigate it soon becomes apparent that this calculation is little better than guesswork.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va. -- Tennis takes the spotlight this week at this spa in the Alleghanies. Net stars from many parts of the East will assemble to take part in the annual West Virginia State open tennis championship tournament, which will start Monday on the courts at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- Returning to the races after a three months' absence, Frank A. Carreaud's Time Supply drove home to a half-length victory in the Massasgit Handicap, mile and a sixteenth main event, today before 20,000 at Suffolk Downs.

THE supply of talent exceeds the demand 1,000 to 1, but still the ambitious unknowns storm the doors of radio. Every year thousands of applicants besiege the New York broadcasting chains for "auditions," radio's familiar synonym for hearing.

SARANAC INN, N.Y. -- Inaugurating the tentative schedule of golf events released by the board of governors of the Saranac Inn Country Club are a two-ball mixed foursome scheduled on Wednesday, and a junior championship handicap tournament announced for Saturday, open to players 20 years of age and under.
GENEVA, July 11. -- "Trains still run in Palestine, but all the passengers sit on the floor to avoid being targets for Arab snipers," Miss Katherine Lyman of Port Washington, L.I., said today.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- "Lake George -- Past and Present" will be the theme of a water pageant to be held next Sunday at the Sagamore Beach Club. Floats will depict the history of this territory for the past fifty years and there will also be a program of aquatic sports in which sailboats will predominate.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP). -- The mighty blasts of 18,000 locomotives throughout the West at 8 A.M., Central standard time, tomorrow will signal the opening of Railroad Week.

MOTOR car sales are showing surprising vigor as the industry goes into the second half of the year. Factories have had to extend their production schedules of 1936 models in order to fill dealers' requests, with the result that July's output will not be far below June's.

The Rev. Olin A. Lewis, until recently pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach. L.I., will succeed the Rev. Dr. Edward D. Staples, who resigned recently as associate minister of Central Congregational Church, Jefferson Street, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, of which the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman is minister.

SIR CHARLES HOLMES is an eminent authority on art and himself a painter of landscape. He has edited The Burlington Magazine, lectured at Oxford as Slade Professor and served as Director of the National Portrait Gallery in London and of the National Gallery itself.

THE enormously increased interest in "housing" in the last few years has been directed chiefly to slum-clearance projects and to multiple-dwelling construction. The one-family house and the countryside have been relatively neglected.

THE big parade through Ambrose Channel, bottle-neck for Europe-bound America, is now at its peak. It is a mighty parade that includes the world's largest, fastest and most luxurious vessels. Were sailings spaced evenly, a passenger ship would be sliding eastward past the Ambrose Light every six hours, day and night.

At this time last Summer European international relations were rapidly, degenerating. Serious tension arose between London and Rome over the war which loomed in Ethiopia. Critical days followed -- Britain ordered many of her mighty ships into the Mediterranean to be prepared for all eventualities; Italy reinforced her garrison in Libya, near Egypt.

GARDEN illumination at night, until recently, was expensive, for it required high-powered and high-priced floodlights. Now, with new types of lighting fixtures, developed within the last year or two, the cost of garden illumination at night has been reduced to a figure low enough to make it of interest to the average home owner.

ATLANTIC CITY. -- Experiencing what may be the greatest Summer season in its history. Atlantic City is calling upon all of its many facilities to provide for the entertainment and comfort of hundreds of thousands of visitors.

ALBANY, N.Y. TRAVELERS through New York State, whether going by way of the majestic Hudson River route, the wide-spreading Mohawk Valley, or other famous trails, will find a special objective next week at Albany, capital of the Empire State.

PARIS, July 9. -- From the gala dinner of "Cornflowers,'' one of the season's most successful fetes, come many interesting styles. A full-skirted white tulle frock had the decollete and a chignon of cornflowers, and an evening tailleur, printed with white horses, had the decollete and hem edged with white tulle ruching.

Five new motor coaches with novel features in design are scheduled to go into service between New York and Boston today as units of the Greyhound Lines. The first of the coaches was on exhibition all day yesterday at the Capitol Bus Terminal, in Fifty-first Street near Eighth Avenue.

ST. LOUIS, July 11. -- Drought in various sections of the Eighth Federal Reserve District has assumed serious proportions in the last week. Heavy rain in an Illinois area near St. Louis has been the only real relieving feature, and reports are not generally encouraging.

AT the rate of fifty a day, so many entries for the New York Song Contest have been pouring into the offices of the Municipal Art Committee that, although the closing date is still a month off, it is anticipated that the songs submitted will number more than a thousand.
RYE, N.Y., July 11. -- A gala dinner dance was held here tonight in connection with the sixth annual horse show of the Westchester Country Club. More than 600 persons were present.

THIS second novel picaresque by Louis Paul is, as its hero says of the war, a gyp. It is a funny, excruciatingly funny book of cockeyed adventures in a cockeyed world. The buffoonery is riddled, however, with sober asides for whose intrusion one enthusiastically expects to find an excuse -- in vain.

The ban decreed against the exhibition of the motion picture version of "The Green Pastures" in the Province of Ontario, Canada, has been lifted by an appeal tribunal headed by Premier Mitchell Hepburn. The decision to permit the picture to be shown was reached after a jury of clergymen had approved it at a special showing on Friday.

THE speech of New Yorkers has long been an object of interest -- sometimes surprise -- to outsiders. It has been a matter of occasional concern even to the inhabitants of the most cosmopolitan of American cities.

In a foreword to this book Ellery Queen explains why he did not use a title of the type that is common to all his earlier novels from "The Roman Hat Mystery" to "The Spanish Cape Mystery." The explanation is simple enough; "Halfway House" happens to be the perfect title for this story.

Queens residents, indignant because, they contended, their borough was neglected in the city's official celebration of the opening of the Triborough Bridge, held their own private celebration yesterday morning.

The United States Government faces the necessity of retiring or refunding within five years $13,734,501,050 of its securities, or 44.3 per cent of the direct government interest-bearing obligations outstanding on June 30 last, according to a statistical tabulation of United States Government financing prepared by Salomon Brothers Hutzler, investment bankers.

HARRISON, N.J., July 11. -- It was raining torrents this evening on the sand barge, Clara, tied up at the foot of Hamilton Street here, when Mrs. Nora O'Flynn Epperson, wife of the captain, heard her pet dog, Trixie, an undersized mongrel, howling on the deck for shelter.
Manuel Alonso, Spanish Davis Cup star, was the central figure on the courts of the Jackson Heights Tennis Club as the Eastern clay court championships got under way yesterday.

Thousands of Manhattan residents, eager to witness a part of the activities accompanying the opening of the Triborough Bridge and to catch a glimpse of President Roosevelt, braved yesterday morning's sun and lined 125th Street to watch a parade which preceded the formal dedication.
QUETTA, Baluchistan, India, July 11. -- Authorities have begun reconstruction of the area devastated by an earthquake May 31, 1935, with a loss of close to 60,000 lives.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, July 11 (AP). -- A strike at the Wheeling Steel Corporation's Portsmouth works, which had been in effect since May 22, was settled today under conditions which seemed to some to pave the way for the drive to unionize steel workers.

TROY, N.Y., June 11 (AP). -- The State Veterans of Foreign Wars, at the closing session of their convention today, asked the Legislature to legalize chiropractors and urged the Federal Government to pay employe-delegates during veterans' conventions.

In a setting of San Francisco cafes, night clubs and high-powered cars, "Uptown-Downtown" unreels an intrigue of love, blackmail, business, politics and a shooting -- with romance coming out on top. The author is out for sensational effects, and in a rather shoddy, stereotyped way he gets them.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11. -- An association, or league, of American nations, for which the Pan American Union is prepared to serve as a secretariat, was urged today at the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia by Dr. Adrian Recinos, Minister of Guatemala.

MANY private gardens in Newport, R.I., are open to the public each Tuesday, from 2:30 to 6 P.M. during the observance of the State Tercentenary. A small admission charge is made and the proceeds go to a fund for charity.

No swashbuckling history or highly colored romance flavors this Robert W. Chambers novel. It is an out-and-out success story. Ellie Lessing was 14 when the World War ended. The daughter of a gambler and an ex-actress, she lived in the Bronx and had never been south of Eighty-sixth Street.

The dearest hope of Elizabeth Derby's life was to take a long and lovely journey to far romantic places. When she came back from school to her mother and sisters and their home in a small Hudson River town, she was overjoyed to learn that her Uncle Joe planned to take her abroad, to Carcassonne and Vallombrosa, Canterbury and Oxford.

Intimate sketches and records of the tribal customs of the Indians of Minnesota, gathered more than three-quarters of a century ago, have been presented to the American Museum of Natural History. The records are contained in the charred remnants of the diary of Frank Blackwell Mayer, a Baltimore artist, and were presented to the museum's Anthropology Department by Morgan Marshall of Baltimore.

HEWLETT, L.I., July 11. -- Playing at a six-under-par clip, Alick Gerard Jr. of Southampton, completely submerged his opponent, Edwin Butler of Hempstead, in today's 36-hole final of the New York State junior championship, winning the event by one of the widest margins in golf history, 13 and 12.

THE annual Founders' Exhibition opened last week at the Grand Central (Vanderbilt Avenue) Galleries, to continue until Nov. 12, when the paintings and pieces of sculpture there assembled will, pursuant of custom, be distributed among the lay members of the organization.

Many of you who are here today can remember that when you were boys and girls the greater part of what are now the Boroughs of the Bronx and Queens was cultivated as farm land. Not much more than 100 years ago my own great-grandfather owned a farm in Harlem close to the Manhattan approach to this bridge.

NOORDWIJK, The Netherlands, July 11 (AP). -- John Van Ryn of Philadelphia was eliminated from the men's singles in the Netherlands tennis championships today, but, with Mrs. Ryn, reached the semi-final round of the mixed doubles and with Wilmer Allison became a finalist in the men's doubles.

Expiration of the Soviet-American trade agreement tomorrow will result in a renewal carrying a promise of a 30 per cent increase in purchases of American goods by the Russian Government, in the opinion of exporters here yesterday.

Reporting by far the largest monthly increase since the depression began, twenty-five leading chain-store systems in June had aggregate sales of $230,274,440, an increase of 17 per cent over the same month a year ago, according to the survey issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc., and Hammons Co., Inc.

IF there is no opera in England such as is to be found in the major cities of Europe, there are two opera festivals; one, old-established, at Covent Garden; the other, but three years old, at Glyndebourne. The former has a not wholly reputable tradition to live down.

RURAL proletarianism becomes increasingly the keynote of current Danish fiction Even Martin Nexo, whose Pelle the Conqueror was a pioneering rebel in industry many year ago, now shifts to rural scenes in the second volume of his story of childhood, as episodes unfold "Under Open Skies" on the island of Bornholm in the Baltic.

BELLPORT, L.I., July 11. -- Notwithstanding the holding of the second of the International Star Olympic tryouts at near-by Sayville, fifty-five boats took part in the regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club this afternoon. Included in this number were thirteen stars, the second largest group to race here this season.

SPAIN and Turkey, two countries that hitherto have done little to lure tourists to their territory, are now offering various concessions. Spain is to have a tourist peseta at a lower rate of exchange, while the Turkish Government has set aside 150,000 pounds (Turkish) to provide travel innovations.
A SUMMER exhibition of oils, water-colors, drawings and sculpture will open at the Museum of Modern Art next Tuesday, remaining current through Sept. 6. It has been installed on the fourth floor.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 11. -- Sinking a twenty-five-foot putt on the final green for a birdie 3, William S. Meany Jr. of Winged Foot gained the lead in the tenth annual Jess Sweetser victory cup tournament today with a score of 72 -- 74 -- 146, as a field of fifty-one amateur golfers completed the opening thirty-six holes of competition.
An international flavor, with at least two ingredients, seems likely to be concocted into America's premier motor boat classic this month to give even more distinction to the famous Gold Cup Regatta.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- The grain markets broke sharply today following an early bulge in corn and oats which carried all deliveries into new high ground for the season. At no time were prices of wheat as high as at the close of the markets yesterday, the trade construing the government report issued late yesterday as somewhat bearish, while the reverse was true on coarse grains.
The parade has begun. Up the Hudson they start during July, to diverge at Waterford for the far corners of the best inland cruising water in this hemisphere, if not this entire planet.

MANY of America's million school teachers are hedged about with more restrictions than are their own pupils, according to a survey of teachers' contracts just made by the National Education Association.

FROM Greenwich, which is almost New York, to Eastport, where Maine thrusts itself furthest toward Europe, the shores of New England are as rich and varied in their stones as they are in their scenes of beauty, and as they are, incidentally, in their busy industries.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11. -- The members of the Summer colony had their first neighborhood dance tonight, and it proved a decided novelty. The hosts were Mr. and Mrs. Archbold Van Beuren, who are occupying Indian House, and Mr. and Mrs. Manning Jacob of Morristown, N.J., and Mrs. G. Bogart Blakeley of New York, who are occupying the studio residence of Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, where the dance was held.

Centralization of government is one of the developments under the New Deal against which critics of the administration inveigh. The Republican candidates and platform have promised to reverse the tendency. They have also pledged themselves always to proceed, whatever the provocation, in strict conformity with the letter of existing law.

BALTIMORE, July 11 (AP). -- Firemen poured streams of water into the smoking wreckage of two three-story buildings here tonight, following an explosion, attempting to cool the debris sufficiently to allow a search for bodies of two persons.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (AP). -- Hyman Gorwitz, a shopkeeper, denied today setting big steel-jawed traps to catch the hands of little children.

LONDON, July 11. -- Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, today declared that Britain, at the earliest moment, was to have virtually a new fleet "strong enough to go anywhere." Speaking at Southampton he warned that if Britain's sea communications should be cut the people would be dead of starvation within six weeks.

Verdi's "Rigoletto" will be presented in English by the Steel Pier Opera Company tonight on the Steel Pier at Atlantic City. The cast includes Marion McAfee, as Gilda; Harrison Christian, as Rigoletto; Lawrence Power, as the Duke; Beulah McGorvin, as Maddalena; Jacqueline Leigh, as Giovanna; John Green, as Monterone and Sparafucile; Thomas Nelson, as Borsa, and Harry Martyn, as Marullo.

Prices generally moved sharply higher in the local commodity futures markets in the week ended on Friday. Coffee was a feature and prices advanced in the most active trading since early in the year. In the cash markets all grains, flour, coffee, butter, eggs, lard, tin, cotton, printcloths, silk, wool tops and rubber were higher, while cocoa, raw sugar and zinc were lower.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11. -- The Sao Paulo cotton market was agitated by heavy selling when holders released large blocks. A report apparently made in good faith now has been found to be spurious that the United States cotton crop was larger than previously had been estimated, resulting in a drop on the New York Cotton Exchange of mare than 40 points.

Trade conditions were spotty last week, with the record-breaking heat wave serving effectively to check the rising trend of retail sales in many sections of the country. The volume of business, however, remained substantially ahead of the totals for the corresponding period last year as the demand for lightweight apparel gained sharply as temperatures reached high levels.

IN this valuable study Mr. Tatum has done something more than summarize the diplomatic documents. He has attempted to fathom the motives which inspired the foreign policy of the great powers during the first quarter of the nineteenth century.

SIR ISAAC NEWTON was not merely a dreamer who sat in his garden waiting for an apple to fall on his head and propel him into the discovery of the laws of motion. While his reputation is based upon his successes as a mathematical physicist, his greatest achievements in this field, the calculus, the law of gravitation and the composition of light, were all made by the time he was 24
WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Despite the July 4 holiday, there was little change in the rate of industrial activity in that week, the Department of Commerce said today m its weekly survey.

EASTPORT, Me., July 10. -- Maine's big tidal power development at Passamaquoddy, falling as funds dwindled during the Spring months, has practically reached a standstill. The hand that poured $10,000,000 into Eastern Maine last July to start a year of prosperity at Eastport, while making a start on the Tidal Pool Dam, has turned against further expenditures.

MANTOLOKING, N.J., July 11. -- Well-filled entry lists in all classes and the most variable weather of the season marked the weekly regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association as the Mantoloking Yacht Club played host to the racing fleets of the bay today.

The new Triborough Bridge, a colossus of steel and concrete straddling Wards and Randalls Islands and flinging itself across the East and Harlem Rivers, Little Hell Gate and the Bronx Kills to link Queens, Manhattan and the Bronx in a Y-shaped sky highway, was opened officially to the public yesterday with elaborate ceremonies in a country-picnic etting.

THIS is a novel of genuine originality. No matter that its author has already been compared to Joyce and D.H. Lawrence, that the most casual reader can detect an acquaintance with Freud, that before long the author will also be compared to Dostoevsky and Aldous Huxley and certain morbid autobiographers.

HEAT records shot up the demand for Summer apparel and other seasonal supplies in the week, but had the expected effect of slackening general retail volume. Sales eased in most sections, the weather adding to the usual post-holiday slackening.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- A move toward clarifying the administration's attitude on the merit system was made today in the issuance of an executive order signed by President Roosevelt on July 6 which prohibits the blanketing of patronage employes into the civil service.

Mrs. Ellen Dunlap Hopkins, who founded the New York School of Applied Design for Women in 1892 and who is still its director, has won the Michael Friedsam gold medal awarded to "an individual who has contributed in the greatest degree toward the development of art in industry."

VIENNA, July 11. -- Any one anxious to maintain a reputation for consistency would be well advised to avoid expressing an opinion on the prospects of Central Europe today, for to maintain an oracular attitude insures that the oracle will be left high and dry by the rapid march of events.

In a smashing performance that set a new Empire City track record by two full seconds and established once more the uncertainty of fillies, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Good Gamble yesterday won the $13,475 Butler Memorial Handicap before 15,000 persons, including many distinguished visitors.

Seventy-five officers of the 311th Infantry, 78th Division, Organized Reserves, will leave today for Camp Dix, Wrightstown, N.J., to act as instructors to 2,000 C.M.T.C students assembled there tomorrow for infantry training.

PARIS, July 11. -- In presenting the news of the Austro-German economic and political agreement the French press makes an effort to put the best possible front on it. The accord is declared to be a victory for the Austrian viewpoint.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 11. -- Twenty-one boats answered the starting gun tonight in the annual Riverside-Stratford Shoals race, one of the features of the Riverside Yacht Club's racing season. Missing among the starters was last year's winner, the cutter Pendragon, owned by Henry Devereux of City Island, which returned yesterday from Bermuda.

THE title of this smoothly written history of the Old South suggests the romance of the plantation, with its gracious social life and nostalgic melodies of Negro song. The book, however, is neither romance in that sense nor rounded history in the conventional political and military conception of the term.

Share prices continued their advance yesterday in the heaviest trading experienced on a Saturday since April 4. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to 867,000 shares, against but 366,000 the Saturday before. THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial and combined railway-industrial averages reached new high levels for the year on gains of about 1/2 point.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 11. -- Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles and Frank Parker of Lawrenceville School and Spring Lake will meet again at the tennis net.

LONDON. IT was, I believe, no more than a coincidence that Heinrich Schnitzler came to England for a holiday at a time which enabled him to direct the production of his father, Arthur Schnitzler's play, "Professor Bernhardi," at the Embassy Theatre.

Standing out each year as the sole canine fixture of the month in the Eastern section of the United States, the Mount Desert Kennel Club will give its fifth annual show on Saturday, July 25, at the athletic field in Bar Harbor, Me. The final closing of entries for this popular Down East exhibition has been set for next Saturday.

WHEN Erasmus died, at Basle on July 12, 1536, he was the bugbear of the bigots, the terror of the tyrants, the hope of the moderates and the darling of the humanists. Four hundred years later his fame has both increased and changed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10. -- Unless the Owlett committee of the State Senate appeals and is upheld in the higher courts, Pennsylvania may not find out through the medium of a State Senate investigation whether the Democrats are "building up a political machine" with the help of the WPA, as the Republicans charge.
BOISE, Idaho, July 11 (AP). -- Senator Borah's opposition in the Republican primary diminished to one opponent today.

HIGH average performance, to a degree not heretofore attained, marked the seventh annual national soaring contest which ended last Sunday at Elmira. Despite the individual flights of outstanding merit which marked the meeting, it was this aggregate performance which most greatly encouraged Dr. Karl O. Lange, director of the contest, and other officials of the Soaring Society of America.

CHICAGO, July 11. -- Trade at both wholesale and retail resisted stubbornly the effects of the heat wave and drought. Sales of the larger department stores dropped below those immediately preceding July 4, but held ahead of 1935. There were good shopping crowds throughout the week, even on Friday, when the temperature reached 102 degrees.

The Blum Government continues to win votes of confidence from the French Chamber while stay-in strikes and walk-outs persist in Paris and the provinces and the Right and Left prepare for expected clashes on Bastile Day by vying with one another in proclamations of respect for constitutional methods.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 11. -- At the end of the first day's racing in the New York State outboard championship on Seneca Lake today Marshall H. Eldredge, East Weymouth (Mass.) professional pilot, led a field of fifty-six drivers in the competition for the Herbert H. Lehman Trophy, emblematic of the State title.

PITTSBURGH, July 11. -- The world's largest by-product coke ovens, where nearly 4,000 employes of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation convert 6,000,000 tons of coal each year into the fuel which stokes the corporation's blast furnaces throughout the country, make the little Monongahela River city of Clairton a strategic focusing point of the current drive to organize the nation's steel workers into one great industrial union.

IMPROVED radio service in the rural areas should be an aim of the broadcasters, Judge E.O. Sykes of the Federal Communications Commission told the National Association of Broadcasters at their Chicago convention during the past week.

A plan for the condensation, unification and possible eventual public ownership of all electric power and light properties in Great Britain is contained in the report for 1936 made by the Committee on Electricity Distribution, otherwise known as the McGowan report, to Leslie Hore-Belisha, Minister of Transport.

A FIFTY per cent increase over last year in the number of foreigners visiting the United States is predicted for this year by leading steamship and travel agencies. Most of the countries of Europe are represented in this counter-movement of foreign travel to America, with many Far Eastern and South American countries also sending tourists.

THE writing habit among radio listeners seems to be quite similar around the world, for the Radio-Times, official journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation, reports "every day some hundreds of letters from listeners arrive at Broadcasting House."

The U.S.S. Quincy, latest of the 10,000-ton "treaty" cruiser type, but widely differing in design from any of her predecessors, steamed into port with the haze of the early morning yesterday, and stood upriver to anchor off 132d Street in the Hudson.
More than 200,000 New Yorkers journeyed by car, by bus and on foot yesterday to the confluence of the Harlem and East Rivers to dedicate by use the new $60,300,000 Triborough Bridge.

Hardy Nurmsen, whose qualities match his name, turned his fifteen-foot canoe, the Estonia, into the basin at the Battery yesterday and ended a 7,220-mile "solo" voyage through the inland waterways of Eastern America. The 28-year-old youth, whose business is painting and decorating, but whose hobby is serious canoeing, had completed a lifelong ambition to encompass all the water routes of the Eastern half of the country in a canoe of his own building.

MR. SCHOLES is pre-eminently thorough in what he undertakes and carries through. A little while ago he achieved a complete exposition of what the Puritans did and did not stand for in the way of music, and especially exploded thoroughly the myth of the "blue laws," invention of a disreputable unfrocked clergyman.

THE justification for this sensational title is an analogy that the author gives involving the human mind and a modern locomotive. By streamlining the element of resistance of wind and water the modern engineer has made a ton of coal, a gallon of gasoline and a kilowatt of electricity carry us faster and further than ever before.
The Corinthians and their guests will meet Tuesday at 12:30 for a luncheon at the Harvard Club. A number of crew calls are being received from members who want amateur hands for cruises and racing.

AFTER two centuries of appreciation by musical cognoscenti, Johann Sebastian Bach now threatens to become a popular composer with the rank and file of concertgoers. Instead of frightening the average layman away, the Leipzig cantor's most formidable works are gradually becoming a strong drawing card when announced for performance.

YORK HARBOR, Me. -- This week finds cottage owners and former residents returning to York Harbor in increasing numbers and all signs point to one of the gayest Summers in recent years. At the York Country Club, which has been entirely redecorated, will take place tomorrow the first of a series of Monday tennis luncheons, followed by a round-robin tennis tournament.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- Announcement that the Sabath Congressional investigating committee would examine the financial structure of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company of Manchester, N.H., caused postponement today of action on a recommendation that the huge textile firm be liquidated.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 11. -- The Rev. Peter B. Duffee of New York, addressing the closing session of the twenty-first annual conference of the Federation of College Catholic Clubs today, denounced communism, which he called "the false front for international capitalism."

Daisy, 1,000-pound brown and white Guernsey, and her daughters, Kate (200 pounds) and Duplicate (160 pounds), put on an authentic barnyard performance last week for the edification of more than 100 curious youngsters and several dozen teachers at the Lincoln Experimental School of Columbia University.

FOR the first time in its history, Bermuda is duplicating its Winter season program in the Summer months. Thus Bermuda claims the distinction of being the only resort within two-week vacation range of New York that operates seriously on a year-round basis with a full program of sports and tournaments, deep-sea fishing and pageants and a gay program of social events.

TECHNICALLY, the implication behind the title of this book is really film versus theatre. For no matter how whitewashed the problem may be, it is still of burning significance. Just how far both go toward becoming permanent, ennobling arts is what Professor Nicoll of the History of Drama Department of Yale herein sets out to trace.

The first NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair will be held at Rockefeller Center from Nov. 5 to Nov. 19 next under the joint auspices of the National Association of Book Publishers and THE NEW YORK TIMES. The Book Fair is designed to present to the book public an interesting and comprehensive exhibition of what is being achieved both in American letters and in book publishing.

This novel is a prettily sentimental little tale based on the familiar two-sisters theme. Lillian was blond, beautiful and incredibly selfish and grasping. Paula, dark, romantic and self-sacrificing, pampered her little sister, waited hand and foot on her hypochondriac mother, cheered her discouraged father, and was championed by her young brother Ho-Ho (short for Horace).

Comparatively few changes were made in the last year in the portfolio of the Rockefeller Foundation, as it was revealed yesterday. At the close of the year the portfolio consisted of $66,504,571 in bonds and $109,276,748 in stocks, a total of $175,781,326. A year earlier the foundation had $71,547,719 in bonds and $110,363,549 in stocks, a total of $182,184,268.
VIENNA, July 11. -- To an astonished and completely unprepared public, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg announced tonight over the radio the conclusion of the agreement between Austria and Nazi Germany.

WARSAW, July 10. -- On the day that Colonel Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, returned from Geneva after the violent anti-League of Nations outburst of Captain Greiser, Nazi president of the Danzig Senate, a "friendly hint" was given by the censor to Warsaw editors not to repeat European press rumors of an imminent Nazi "putsch" in the Free City.

Paul Kerby, the British conductor, made his second and final appearance with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night before an audience of 3,500. The athletic-looking young director was scheduled to continue his activities at the outdoor amphitheatre until Tuesday evening, but on account of a sprained back he was advised by his physician not to carry out this plan.

LUCERNE, July 11 (AP). -- The Irish Free State won the Prize of Nations Trophy in the international horse show for the third straight year today, as the United States Olympic equestrian team finished third, with the French riders second.

Silvery notes of bugles, floating over acres of wooded ground and gleaming lakes soon after dawn tomorrow, will sound the "swimming call," and more than 2,000 Boy Scouts from the five boroughs of New York will blink their eyes, leap from their bunks and dash for "The Lake" -- for the huge camp at Ten Mile River in Sullivan County, N.Y., will be in full swing.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N.H. -- The week will start with a tea tomorrow, given by the New London Players for their subscribers, so that they all may get acquainted. The players will present "The Bishop Misbehaves" on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 11 (AP). -- Ministers in many churches throughout the country will offer tributes from their puipits tomorrow to William Holmes McGuffey, the Presbyterian schoolmaster whose textbooks contributed in large measure to the education of pioneer America.

JUST as shade is a relief from the glare of the brilliant sun, so black is a solace in contrast with the flashing prints and bright colors in which women bedeck themselves to meet the Summer days. Black is restful and consequently gives an impression of being cool.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 11. -- Governor Earle sent telegrams today to four Pennsylvania business men denmanding that they "release" the Republican State Senators and let them vote appropriations for relief.

IT was twenty-four years ago that Ted Parsons began gathering the first-hand war experience which he now turns to use as one of Hollywood's leading technical advisers on war pictures. "Wings" and "Hell's Angels," in the making of which he had a hand, could have been pages taken from his own aerial combat adventures.
TELEVISION'S million-dollar field test now under way in New York has stirred the radio industrialists and broadcasters to think more and more about the new science of ethereal shadows.

THE characteristic boast of native Californians that "everything grows larger" out there may well be applied to their bridge tournaments. A committee in Inglewood, Calif., is planning an outdoor tournament for the benefit of several charity organizations.

MOSCOW, July 11. -- It is an old commonplace to say the Soviet Union is in a state of flux and a land of sharp-edged contrasts, but it is truer today than ever before. Compare, for instance, the liberalism of the new Constitution with an incident that recently occurred in Minsk, capital of the White Russian Republic.

Last week I went to the Lewisohn Stadium to see Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman and their concert group in a dance program. I had not attended a dance recital in years and present-day fashions were unknown to me. I was disappointed in what I presume is the new choreography.
PARIS, July 11. -- Employers at Roubaix and Rouen again called on the government to remove "folded arms" strikers occupying several factories.

One of the most fascinating and popular of Long Island Sound races, the Bayside-Block Island auxiliary handicap event, will be started Friday, July 31, at noon, according to an announcement by Herbert F.L. Funke, chairman of the committee in charge.

Hot weather checked retail trade expansion in the metropolitan area toward the end of the week, but despite this handicap an increase of about 10 per cent over last year was estimated by department store executives. Trade during the first three days of the week had been running at the rate of about 15 per cent over the comparative 1935 period.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Mr. Roosevelt is setting his cap -- or perhaps one should say spinning the wheels -- for a new Presidential record. This Summer and Autumn the White House mileage marks are at stake.

THIS week there will be a new show at the Manhattan Theatre, home of the Popular Price unit of the Federal Theatre. If it is another such success as "Murder in the Cathedral," the first Monday evening of the run will bring milling playgoers to the lobby, many of them with their relief cards, for that is free-admission night to the accredited.

TOPEKA, July 10. -- With the special session of the Kansas Legislature brought to a close after having carried out his social security program to the letter, Governor Landon is now turning his attention to the notification ceremonies here on the night of July 23, at which he is expected, in his acceptance speech, to tell the nation his specific position on the principal issues of the campaign.

COLLECTING rare tobacco pipes is a hobby that is ridden by all sorts and conditions of men. A prominent New York physician who passed away recently left a collection of meershaums said to be the most important of its kind in the world.

GEORGE W. NORRIS, senior Senator from Nebraska, celebrated yesterday his seventy-fifth birthday. A veteran statesman who has spent fifty years in public life -- thirty-three of them in the halls of Congress -- he has just completed his fourth consecutive term in the Senate.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- Music lovers among the Summer colonists here have three events of interest ahead of them this week. This evening will see the opening of a series of Sunday evening concerts at the Newport Casino by the Rhode Island Symphony Orchestra under the leadership of Dr. Wasalli Lepps.

JERUSALEM, July 11. -- The people of Palestine have now become accustomed to the abnormal situation resulting from bombings and attacks, and as month after month passes one begins to consider these incidents as part of the ordinary daily routine.
BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's suggestion that five of the country's most famous vessels should be berthed in the capital brought protests today from two New England States.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa. -- Cape Town, the Palm Beach of South Africa and the Union's largest town, will soon rank with Singapore as a powerful British naval base if plans under consideration are approved. The port might even become the largest base for British warships in the southern hemisphere, putting Malta and Singapore to shame.

ALBANY, July 11. -- New York State will be host for the first time this week to the National Association of Secretaries of State. The association will open its convention here tomorrow. The delegates will visit the Spa at Saratoga Monday afternoon and will motor to New York City Tuesday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 11. -- Harvard scientists, working with an animal they prefer to keep anonymous "for fear of ridicule," have discovered the presence of mysterious "diurnal rhythms" controlling the sleeping and waking habits of lower animals and thus possibly of man.

Following a rise of 82 to 110 points in the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back 6 to 11 points yesterday under week-end profit-taking. The rapidity of the advance had attracted Indian and South American selling in Liverpool, while the rise in Southern spot quotations to 13 1/2 cents a pound had begun to bring out some of the 12-cent loan cotton.

Miss Carfrae has a gift for charming story-telling. Her new novel starts out in jolly fashion with the whirlwind courtship of two engaging, impecunious young Londoners. Elizabeth worked in a steamship line office, and was keen as mustard on her 40-shillings-a-week job.

ALTHOUGH its title, jacket and illustrations suggest colorful personal reminiscence, this book is in reality a plain and straightforward history of the development of transportation in California, with especial emphasis upon the organization of the express companies.
PINE ORCHARD, Conn., July 11. -- Many dinners preceded the weekly dance at the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight.

Guy M. Storey, Field Director of the American Red Cross in the eastern area, who will retire on July 15, sat in his office on Governors Island and recalled a few of his biggest experiences in seventeen years of service.

IT seems generally agreed among safety experts, including such motor vehicle officials as are such, that speed in and of itself has been overemphasized as a cause of accidents. With so many casualties involving automobiles traveling at from twenty to fifty miles an hour, the case against high speed as the chief villain in the accident tragedy falls down.
ROCKFORD, Ill., July 11 (AP). -- Mayor George S. Brydia of Prophetstown failed tonight to find the man who threatened to level the little community of 1,500 with dynamite unless he received $1.000.

MEDIA, Pa., July 11. -- Captain George Sykes, who recently joined the executive staff of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, died at the Media Hospital here last night of a fractured skull and other injuries which he received in a fall from a horse on Thursday morning.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 11. -- The Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club net team defeated the Rockaway Hunting Club, today, 8 to 4. The meeting was the sixteenth annual one between the clubs, and marked Seabright's first victory in three years.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 11. -- Off to a slow start but in command once they began clicking, the Ox Ridge riders today gained the final round of the annual Hempstead Cups polo with an 11-to-8 victory over the Foxhunters on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

While many buyers merely inspected Fall lines in the market last week, sufficient orders were placed to indicate a keen interest in new merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Hot weather brought some reorders for linen suits and white cotton Summer coats to retail at $5.95.

SPRING LAKE, N.J. -- With tennis matches occupying the attention of Summer visitors, tournament play today reached the final brackets and attendance in the galleries showed a considerable increase over that of previous years. Exhibition matches, featuring Manuel Alonzo and Francis Hunter among others, proved a feature of the early season meets.

OMAHA, Neb., July 10. -- Generally speaking, the Corn Belt is believed to be in rather better shape to sustain a prolonged drought this year than it was two years ago, when it had its most severe experience with the present dry cycle.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, July 11 (AP). -- Germany's two-man team today qualified for the inter-zone final of the Davis Cup tennis competition when Baron Gottfried Von Cramm and Heiner Henkel won the doubles for the third and deciding victory over Yugoslavia in the European zone finals.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11. -- Plans for a hunger march on Harrisburg, timed to coincide with the start of the eleventh week of the special session of the Legislature next Monday, were discussed here today as most of the 58,000 families on relief in the city continued to shift for themselves.

MR. GRAHAM'S novel is another of those excursions into tender fields that attempt to discover the human base of the war. What we have here is a child's vision of strife-torn Europe: history seems curious, without pattern or purpose; men undergo violent transformations for obscure reasons; and heroism is strangely confused with self-preservation.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The Treasury Department announced today it would put into effect at midnight the countervailing duties that it ordered a month ago under the authority of the Tariff Act of 1930. The action was taken despite pleas for a stay by American importers and despite the official representations of a German governmental delegation now discussing the whole situation with Treasury experts.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. -- Archery golf will be initiated next week at the recreation unit at Saratoga Spa at hours convenient to the Summer colony.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 11. -- Her 7,500 square feet of canvas pulling in a light easterly breeze, the Class J sloop Yankee swept in here today the leader in the Eastern Yacht Club's squadron run from Newport. It was her second victory in four starts.

RICHMOND, Va., July 10. -- The Democratic Governorship primary will not be held until August of next year, but already it is being discussed as potentially one of the most important political events in Virginia in many years. The reason is that it may determine whether Senator Harry F. Byrd will remain the dominant factor in Virginia.

MIDLAND, Mich., July 11 (AP). -- Development of a method for immediate identification of unknown crystalline chemicals through "finger-printing" their X-ray diffraction patterns was announced today by a chemical company here.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Leading the list of recreational events in the Summer colony at Burlington this week will be the State women's golf tournament, to be played on the course of the Burlington Country Club, opening tomorrow and continuing through Friday.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 11. -- Glenn Waterhouse and Woodbridge Metcalf in Three Star Too from California defeated their rivals twice today to gain virtually an impregnable position in the finals of the Star Class Olympic eliminations.

A RADIO mystery which intrigued fans on both sides of the Atlantic was ultimately traced to a patient encircled by a large coil of wire at an American hospital, according to Sir Donald Banks, Director General of the British Postoffice, when recently he opened a sub-station at Colchester.

With the completion of a new dormitory this Fall, Bard College, men's residential unit of Columbia University, at Annandale-on-Hudson, will increase its enrollment from 114 to 160, it was announced yesterday.

BETTER than other writing man Dane Coolidge knows Death Valley, that 150-mile stretch of torrid desert that lies 276 feet below sea level between towering ranges of mountains just over the lower Nevada line in California.

HARRISON, N.J., July 11. -- Thomas J. Sheridan, 60 years old, president of the Free Library Commission and one of Harrison's best-known residents, became the hero of the town at two minutes to 12 noon today when he foiled a bold attempt to hold up the Harrison National Bank, where he is an acting teller.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- Major R.S. Harrison of Toronto and Company Sergeant-Major H. Rusk of Ottawa scored possible 35's today in the Times, one of several events in which the Canadian Bisley team competed heavily at the National Rifle Association's meet.
LONDON, July 11. -- Stanley Wooderson, England's chief hope for the Olympic 1,500-meter championship, once again demonstrated his mastery over New Zealand's Jack Lovelock today.

FENCE-BUILDING now occupies the Congressman. The active season -- on the home ground -- is on. Countering opposition with political charm and strategy, winning the affections of the voters and preserving them -- this is what the 435 members of the National House of Representatives understand to be implied in the business of fence-building.

LONGER, and in many respects more arduous, than any air race yet run, an international speed race for landplanes from Paris to Saigon, in French Indo-China, and return will get under way from Le Bourget at dawn on Oct. 25.

With the announcement last week that another large producer of medicines will join other manufacturers in the plan, Dr. E.W. Newcomb, executive vice president of the National Wholesale Druggists Association, declared yesterday that there is a very definite trend to the consignment or agency form of selling in the drug industry.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 11. -- Danell, owned by D.F.B. Hickey, was the first of the six motor boats that finished the run from Pelham Manor by 10:30 tonight. The fact that the Hickey craft reached the new Coast Guard wharf at the entrance to West Harbor ahead of the others does not mean, however, that it is the winner of the motor boat class of the annual New York to Block Island lace.

The American Olympic team -- the largest ever to represent the United States in history -- will sail for Germany and the games at noon on Wednesday on board the United States liner Manhattan. Approximately 350 athletes will make the trip.

The United Licensed Officers Association announced yesterday the beginning of a campaign to enroll all officers of the merchant marine on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts as a prelude to submitting demands for proper wages and working conditions to the American merchant ship lines.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 10. -- It was with a feeling of dismay that many Georgians heard by radio the peroration of the address at McRae with which Governor Talmadge opened his campaign for the Senate against the incumbent, Richard B. Russell Jr.
BELFAST, July 11 (AP). -- Northern Ireland will become one of the noisiest and gayest spots in the world tomorrow as 250,000 Orangemen celebrate the 246th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne.

IF piano playing of utter magnificence means anything in your life, keep a sharp lookout for Emil Gilels. Up to a few days ago the name meant no more to the general run of musicians in this part of the world than it probably does to any in America who may read these remarks.

A SIDELIGHT on a memorable event in the history of the Orient is given by a 381-piece silver dinner service now being exhibited publicly for the first time by the New York Historical Society. The silver has historical interest because it is from a set presented to Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry after he opened Japan to the commerce of the world in 1854.

THE coastwise lights of England are welcoming many travelers this Summer. And many other Americans, staying at home, are thinking of travel, thinking of foreign lands, as they have not thought for years. Here in America we are reading travel books again, about several countries.

PROFESSOR THEOCRITUS LUCIUS WESTBOROUGH, who solved the mystery described in "The Fifth Tumbler," makes his second appearance in this book. The scene is Rumpelstiltzken, the Wisconsin estate of Arnold Bancroft.

DESIGNED primarily to show how life was lived a century ago, the centennial exhibition at the Newark Museum qualifies as a most interesting display of antiques. The marvelously realistic reconstructions of a life-size general store, a cobbler shop, a tavern and the parlor of a mansion bestow a living quality on the old furnishings which is absent when they are viewed by themselves.

At 80 TESLA dreams of the generation and transmission of energy in ways that must seem fantastic to engineers who build great central stations and send electricity 300 miles. Away with these wires, away with the cumbrous apparatus, is his cry. Let the planet itself be your conductor and inductor. China drawing its energy from Muscle Shoals -- why not?

The beaches in the metropolitan area yesterday were jammed again with crowds seeking to escape the heat. They traveled out of the city principally by automobile and train, but many of the poorer city dwellers journeyed in trucks.
BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- The White Sox pounded out a 9-to-1 victory over the Red Sox today, making six of their runs off Pitcher Jack Wilson in the fourth inning.

WHEN the public schools reopen in the Fall it is estimated that the number of children enrolled in elementary grades will have declined nearly 73,000 from the peak reached in 1929 and that the total will be lower than it has been at any time since 1914.

Mr. ADELARD GODBOUT. Premier of the Province of Quebec and leader of the New Guard Liberals, has announced, at least in part, the program on which he will go to the country in August. He is a farmer. Benefits to agriculture are foremost in his policy. He offers bonuses on beet sugar, butter, cheese and pigs for export, and for the building of up-to-date piggeries.

In a bulletin to members who are taking steps to protect themselves against a shortage of supplies in the event of labor troubles in the steel industry, the National Association of Purchasing Agents yesterday warned that such protection should include bituminous coal as well as steel stocks.

The shouts of joy and the general jubilation at the woman's Olympic track and field headquarters this week, when word came through that one of their number had just received the necessary money from her home city for the trip to Berlin, were almost pathetic.

WORLD'S fairs used to be isolated events, far enough apart in time and space so that they easily commanded the attention of a nation, and often of other nations. They were sources not only of civic pride but of national pride.

LONDON, July 10. -- Queen Mary will not attend the afternoon receptions at Buckingham Palace on July 21 and 22. In her absence the Duchess of York will act as hostess for King Edward, assisted by the Duchess of Gloucester, the Duchess of Kent and the Princess Royal,

TOPEKA, July 11 (AP). -- Charging that a "mistake was made for political purposes," State Senator Joseph McDonald, Kansas City (Kan.) Democratic critic of Governor All M. Landon, demanded tonight a correction in the printed journal of the Kansas Legislature listing a Republican as author of bills Mr. McDonald said he introduced.

NATCHEZ, Miss., July 11 (AP). -- Mayor E.W. Voght of Ferriday, La., said tonight that 14-year-old Charles Phillips Jr. told him he had killed his father while the two were squirrel hunting a week ago and concealed the body in dense undergrowth.

Germany and Austria raised a political storm early in 1931 when the two governments proposed to enter into a customs union, abolishing for a fixed period all tariff duties between them. Immediately France and other allied powers raised the cry of "Anschlus."

BUDAPEST, July 11. -- Hungarian Government circles are greatly satisfied with the outcome of the Austro-German negotiations. They emphasize that for more than three years Hungary has constantly advocated a policy of reconciliation in both Berlin and Vienna and has repeatedly offered her services as intermediary.

WHEN the Manhattan housewife says to her grocer, "Vegetables seem a little high today," and he tells her that it is because wholesale prices have gone up, more often than not she is in a position to check his statement against an official city market guide.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Uncle Sam will soon offer his Indian wards an opportunity to live on community homesteads. Under plans approved by the Bureau of Indian Affairs, houses and other buildings are now under construction at the Indian agencies.

AFTER building bridges and doing other technical work in China, Australia, Egypt and England, Karl Paul Billner, Swedish engineer, turned up in the United States just before we entered the World War. More engineering work followed, much of it involving the mixing and pouring of concrete.

WARWICK, R.I., July 11. -- Ralph Flanagan of Miami, Fla., completed his domination over Jack Medica of the University of Washington by adding the 400-meter freestyle triumph in tonight's final United States Olympic trial to yesterday's 1,500-meter triumph.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 11. -- Sunbeam, which belongs to H.E. Melslahn and L.R. Bowden Jr., led home the largest fleet of Star craft that has raced on Moriches Bay in the weekly regatta of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach off the Speonk shore today.

Picking themselves up where the Yankees had left them for dead late Friday, the Indians rose as one man at the Stadium yesterday and gave their reappointed manager, Steve O'Neil, a rousing vote of confidence.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 11. -- Long Island's tercentenary marine cruise of eight days got under way today from Manhasset, but by the time the colorful fleet had reached the first overnight stop at the Northport Yacht Club a large number of the smaller cruisers and windjammers had dropped out.

THOUGH Summer's drone has settled over Broadway, one office or another is quietly busy making up a schedule. The most clocklike, perhaps, is that arranged by Sam H. Harris -- three shows on the boards by Thanksgiving is the goal he has set, and the chances are that he will realize it and with something to spare.

LONDON, July 8. -- Only two shows are due next week in London, which amounts to a recess for this capital. On Wednesday, at the Duchess, J.B. Priestley and J.P. Mitchehill will resume their partnership by sponsoring "Spring Tide," a first play by George Gillam and Peter Goldsmith.

A little rain visited the nation's drought areas last week, but not enough. The parched plains desperately need long draughts of cooling water. If the rains come soon enough, it still will be possible to save many crops, but if there is much more delay we shall be in the midst of a major agricultural disaster.

PITTSBURGH, July 10. -- Apparently undisturbed by its controversy with the American Federation of Labor over the crafts-industrial union question, John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization is pushing ahead methodically with its $500,000 campaign to organize the 500,000 steel workers of the country into one union, a revival of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers.
A SON: On Thursday an eight-pound boy was born to Mrs. Elzire Dionne, mother of the quintuplets. He is her twelfth child; eleven are living.

Here we have another brilliant amateur sleuth, by name Stephen Steele. This is the first of his exploits to be published, but the author has supplied him with a ready-made reputation sufficiently impressive to cause the officers of the law to welcome his cooperation.

NOT all types of gardening can be undertaken this late in the season, but there is one which gives immediate results, and which may be used at any time. While porch flower-box gardening is "gardening" only in a limited sense, it does offer the possibility of creating pleasing effects with growing plants, and often it is the one type open to the Summer vacationists.

The Cunard White Star liner Georgic sailed at noon yesterday, for the Channel ports with 1,465 passengers and left four more standing on the pier at the foot of West Fourteenth Street after the gangway was lowered. They were Thomas Taylor of New York and Mrs. Terez Gerencsen of Bayonne, N.J., and her daughters, one 3 and the other 5 years old.

WHILE it was undeniably smooth and pleasing, Mr. Thorne's first novel clung tenaciously to a formula and had remarkably little to say. "Delay in the Sun" -- which had as its setting a drowsy Spanish village -- employed the old trick of isolating fortuitously a group of chance-met strangers.
ROME, July 11. -- The government announced tonight that Italy had declined the invitation extended by Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium to take part in the Locarno "preparatory" talks in Brussels.

COPPER coloring for the skin, until recently the monopoly of lifeguards, has been taken up by one of the country's leading beauty experts for the benefit of the feminine Summer world. For people who tan easily or not, one of the new copper make-up sets is adapted to the season's needs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP). -- The Athletics made a clean sweep of the three-game series with the Browns by capturing a doubleheader today. After winning the first game, 10 to 7, the Mackmen wiped out an early 5-0 disadvantage to take the second, 7 to 6.

THERE is a certain special fitness in the fact that the motto of Harvard is Veritas. Not all truth is luminous, as some universities assume. Shadows also have their verity. Down through the centuries Harvard has recognized this, especially in its moods of self-contemplation.
