THE lady driver, our authors assure us, "has of recent years progressed by leaps and bounds." So have all other drivers. So, we are reminded parenthetically, have their cars. Hence this book, which leaps and bounds itself, from one inspired absurdity to another, in text and picture, parody and allusion and straight burlesque, with unfailing nimbleness of wit.

PARIS. WINE seems to be going to our heads with a vengeance this Fall. All the vintage colors are being featured in what the Paris modistes call their pre-Autumn collections, which include the first authentic Fall millinery styles.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- A complete list of committees for "Ye Olde Shrewsbury Faire," to be sponsored by the Shrewsbury auxiliary of Monmouth Memorial Hospital on the afternoon and evening of July 24 at Shrewsbury Manor grounds, was formulated at a tea given at the home of Mrs. Lawrence Ylvisaker, president.

BERLIN. -- Because Germany expects the Olympic Games to accomplish nothing less than its rehabilitation in the eyes of a still largely hostile world, it has spent a small fortune on advertising. To date the Advertising Bureau of the Olympic Organizing Committee has issued through the advertising offices of the Reich Railways throughout the world no fewer than 6,167,000 booklets, 2,500,000 postal seals, 422,500 wall placards and 167,500 free postcards.

BOSTON, July 11 (AP). -- John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, will tour the New England States next week to confer with party workers. His schedule, announced tonight, calls for nine addresses in seven cities in four days.

The Socialist party expects to be on the ballots in every State in the nation with the single exception of Louisiana in the coming Presidential elections, it was announced yesterday at an all-day meeting of the National Executive Committee of the party at the Hotel Delano, 108 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- The National Labor Relations Board charged the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today with complicity in three separate assaults at Gadsden, Ala., on members and organizers of the United Rubber Workers of America.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 11. -- Captain Terrance Burrows of the steamship Catherine of the Bull Insular Line, who was attacked last night by a fireman with a knife, was flown 140 miles to San Juan Hospital tonight in a Marine plane, piloted by Lieut. Col. James M. Moore.

BERLIN, July 10. -- What Geneva politely terms the "Danzig incident" at the closing session of the League Council meeting aroused the greatest enthusiasm in Germany. Kicking the unresponsive League of Nations is a pastime here.

MONTREAL, July 11 (Canadian Press). -- A fifteen-member Olympic track and field team, featuring British Columbia athletes in both men's and women's division, will be selected as a result of two days of official trials in Molson Stadium which ended today.

The names of 133 students who attained the honor roll for the second semester of the school year in the day division of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance was announced yesterday by Dean John T. Madden.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 11. -- The Cornell Summer Theatre began its thirteenth season with the presentation of four one-act comedies by world-famous playwrights in the Willard Straight Theatre tonight. There will be productions on consecutive Friday and Saturday evenings during the remainder of the six-week Summer session, which began this week.
An item in THE TIMES states that "the United Kingdom is now the most 'densely vehicled' country in the world," with 2,171,000 motor cars and one to every nineteen of the population.

THIS book is the work of two young Oxford economists who, with the aid of the Rockefeller Foundation and the Commonwealth Fund, were able to spend some time in the United States and travel extensively about the country.
BEHOLD, of all things, the bicycle again, waving its handle bars, tinkling its bell like anything, exclaiming beamishly, "Hello, everybody! Didn't expect me, did you? Thought I was extinct, eh?"

PRIOR to the spirited controversy over the Resettlement Administration's recent three-reeler, "The Plough That Broke the Plains," which Hollywood spurned on the ground that it was New Deal electioneering, comparatively few of the cinema's cash customers realized that the Federal Government was active in the production of motion pictures.

RYE, N.Y., July 11. -- At the conclusion of one of the closest and most interesting competitions of the year in the hunter division, the chestnut gelding Double Entry this afternoon was awarded the Albee Trophy, one of the leading events of the second day of the Westchester Country Club's sixth annual horse show, repeating his victory of last year in this class.

THE fourth of a series of reports James G. McHugh giving the results obtained from tests in the N.A.C.A. twenty-foot wind tunnel to determine the interference lift and drag and the propulsive efficiency of wing-nacelle-propeller combinations has just been issued.
The letter of Dr. Samuel Johnson to Lord Chesterfield, which Robert Moses mentioned in reference to Harold L. Ickes, calling it one of the finest pieces of polite vituperation, follows:

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- An allocation of $171,500 of relief to be expended in 1936 for the manufacture of "talking books" for the blind has been approved by President Roosevelt, the Works Progress Administration announced today.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 11. -- Following evening parade tonight some 150 of the candidates in the Citizens Military Training Camp here were strutting their "stripes," as proud of promotion as only a newly made non-corn can be.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- First of the important flower shows of the season in the Berkshires will be that of the Lenox Horticultural Society at the Town Hall, Lenox, next Wednesday and Thursday. The Berkshire Garden Center and seven garden clubs will cooperate with the society in the exhibition, which will have 119 classes.

Superstitious persons who believe in "haunted" houses are challenged by the offer of a $10,000 reward to any one who can point to a "haunted" house that cannot be proved to be "either a hoax, a myth, or some natural or scientific manifestation."

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Commissioned and petty officers of the navy will be reallocated and redistributed in the fleet to provide fewer of them on ships, as a means of meeting the requirements of manning the new ships which are being placed in commission under the building program.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12. -- While a politically deadlocked Legislature prepared to resume its ten-week-old relief discussions at Harrisburg, police and charitable agencies speeded up their efforts today to meet the immediate needs of a half million destitute Pennsylvanians and delegations of unemployed completed plans for a "hunger march" to the State capital tomorrow evening.
BERLIN, July 12. -- Out of the two-year chaos of torn-up streets and buildings wreathed in scaffolding the new Berlin is emerging.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 12. -- Music figured prominently in Berkshire events this week-end. The South Mountain String Quartet this afternoon gave the first of a series of eight Sunday concerts in Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's Temple of Music, Pittsfield.

The re-election of President Roosevelt is urged by Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Henry Street Settlement, in a statement made public yesterday by the women's division of the Democratic National Committee.

The Republican National Committee will try to win support for the Landon-Knox ticket among women in seventeen Eastern States by means of a house-to-house "market basket campaign" in the rural districts, Miss Natalie Couch, director of the women's division in Eastern territory, declared yesterday.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12. -- The winning streak of Robert Riggs on the tennis courts was brought to an end today at the Bathing and Tennis Club by the player whom he defeated decisively in the national clay court championship final last month.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12. -- For the second day in succession Arthur Knapp piloted C.B. Stuart's Interclub sloop Ariel to victory today in a special regatta conducted by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. A fleet of forty-five craft sailed in the races which were held off Execution Light and in a fairly strong easterly breeze.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 12. -- The 1,300 candidates in the Civilians Military Training Camp here "loafed" most of today.

MONTREAL, July 12 (AP). -- The Newark Bears stopped the Montreal Royals' winning streak at six straight today, taking the second game of a double header 3 -- 1 after dropping the first game by the same score.

Prayers for rain in the drought-stricken sections of the country were offered yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street, where Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of Kings University, Halifax, N.S., assailed the old superstition that a drought was an affliction sent by "an angry God."
Arthur Krock's article on the intemperate abuse of President Roosevelt, circulated among the "rescued rich and well-to-do residents of New York's stately environs," has made me pause and think.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, July 12 (AP). -- World automobile speed records fell like tenpins tonight before the thunderous attack of Captain George Eyston at the wheel of his two-ton "Speed of the Winds."
NICE, France, July 12. -- Rightists, Leftists and police, numbering about 10,000 in all, fought up and down the main streets of Nice tonight, and fifty-five persons were treated in hospitals.

Literary research workers employed in the historical records department of the Federal Writers Project have substituted aluminum respirator masks for eyeshades and reading glasses in their quest for material, it was announced yesterday.

All indications point to record promotions this Fall of home furnishings lines, with newspaper and magazine linage totals likely to exceed those of any Fall for the last seven years. It is expected that the cumulative effect of pent-up consumer buying will push sales totals to new highs, a development foreshadowed by the marked success of the trade shows in lines ranging from furniture to lamps and draperies last week.
Word was received here yesterday of the death of a dog.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Republican strategists are mapping a vigorous campaign to reduce the overwhelming Democratic majority in the House and to hold their present strength in the Senate, party leaders said here today. The Democrats now outnumber Republicans in the House by about three to one and have a two-thirds majority in the Senate.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 12. -- Through a spectacular scoring spurt in the final two periods that produced half their goals, Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes dashed to a 10-to-5 triumph over the Miami Valley Hunting and Polo Club of Ohio as the national junior championship opened today on Schley Field.

PARIS, July 12. -- The importance of the Austro-German accord announced yesterday is decisive for Central Europe and may be considerable for the relations of the great European powers. The accord is capable of producing alarming consequences unless they are prevented while there is still time.

Two outstanding incidents in last week's news -- the spreading of devastating drought in the Western grain belt, and the threat by an outside labor combination to attack the steel trade's company-union policy -- would under ordinary circumstances have unsettled both trade and markets.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP). -- Howard Hughes, record-smashing aviator and film producer, was released from jail today in his own recognizance after his arrest in connection with the death of a 60-year-old man, killed, police said, by a car which sped through a safety zone.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 12 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, dedicated the expanded facilities of Radio Station WROK tonight with a plea for continued freedom of speech, press and radio and a warning against using radio "to spread wrong ideas and encourage wrong policies."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 12. -- Department and large specialty stores in the Pacific Coast States showed a distinct tendency in 1935 toward higher margins and profits in percentages of sales than were typical of stores elsewhere in the United States, acording to a report issued today by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School.
The Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance, entered the Clinton Street police station at 10:02 yesterday morning and rapped sharply on the desk.

PARIS, July 11. -- One of the government's essential points of financial policy being to cheapen money, the dearness of which was a heavy burden on trade and on the State, it was natural for it to urge the Bank of France again to lower its discount rate this week to a more normal figure.
LONDON, July 10. -- Security markets here are displaying commendable firmness despite factors which might be expected to cause hesitation and heaviness.
ST. LOUIS, July 12. -- Jerome Herman Dean, leading hurler of the National League, won't let a brain concussion interfere for long with his duties as a pitcher for the Cardinals.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP). -- The Eastern Steamship liner Yarmouth and the freighter Losmar, proceeding slowly in a dense fog, were in collision today in Boston Harbor. A score of the Yarmouth's more than 200 passengers and two of her crew were injured, one, W.J. Muise of Yarmouth, N.S., seriously.

RYE, N.Y., July 12. -- Firenze Red Tape, 9-year-old brown gelding owned and ridden throughout the exhibition by Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., this afternoon was awarded the Grand Hunter championship, the concluding competition of the sixth annual horse show on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 12. -- In a free scoring game which saw two women players participating in high goal competition for the first time, the polo team representing Long Island defeated a combination from Westbury by 12 -- 8 at Bostwick Field today.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 12 (AP). -- The Ecuadoran Minister of the Interior announced tonight the arrest of several persons, including a colonel and a captain, and the seizure of documents concerning a revolutionary movement by soldiers, workers and peasants.

Four persons were drowned yesterday in the metropolitan area, bringing the total number of deaths by drowning since the start of the heat wave on Wednesday to twenty-one. Yesterday's rescues totaled thirty-four. All but four of these were in the Rockaways.

John Heine, a milk truck driver of Port Richmond, S.I., was crushed to death yesterday when his truck skidded down the steep grade of Howard Avenue Hill there and overturned. An examination indicated that the brakes had locked as he started down the hill, causing the truck to jump the curb and skid across the sidewalk into the wall.

Star-crossed Hollywood may have another turmoil this week, one involving Universal and Margaret Sullavan. The actress owes two pictures on her Universal contract, which expires on July 24. Although Universal had a couple in mind for her, neither has been started, and there is every indication that Miss Sullavan will join the free lancers or perhaps the Walter Wanger forces when her contract expires.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 12. -- John Farley, 19 years old, of 41-12 Twenty-eighth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, and Alfred J. Flynn, 32, of 13 Meadow Street, Garden City, L.I., were killed near here today in separate auto accidents.

Selfish pursuit of our own business and indulgence in false gayety cannot bring us the real happiness of serving a cause greater than ourselves, the Rev. Dr. Horace Leavitt, pastor of the Central Union Church. Honolulu, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- A young woman who told the police that she was Margaret Louise Bell, alias Jean Costella, and that she had been held for weeks as a witness in the recent trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania, the New York racketeer, was found early this morning by the police in a gas filled apartment at 1,230 New Hampshire Avenue, where she had been beaten, bound and left to die.

Dr. Ralph Rotholz, 39 years old, who came to this country four months ago from Berlin to escape Nazi restrictions that left him penniless and wiped out a once lucrative practice, committed suicide yesterday morning by swallowing poison in a drug store about half a block from his home, 1,166 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx.

TOKYO, June 27. -- A list of eight new railway enterprises and one automobile road which Japan is willing to undertake in North China has been published by the Tokyo Asahi. They are confined to the two Maritime Provinces of Hopei and Shantung.

MONTGOMERY, July 12 (AP). -- Church doors remained closed in many North Alabama communities today as a precaution against spread of an infantile paralysis outbreak which has caused eight deaths. Social functions are almost at a standstill.

Intimating that a young woman answering the description of the one beaten in Washington was a grand jury witness, but not a trial witness, in the Dewey investigation. Captain Bernard Dowd, head of the New York police working with Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, admitted early today that an undercover man was in Washington investigating.

Mayor Daniel W. Hoan of Milwaukee was named chairman of the national campaign committee of the Socialist party for the coming Presidential elections during an all-day meeting of the national executive committee of the party yesterday at the Hotel Delano, 108 West Forty-third Street.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- A rush of new investment buying, combined with that by traders who went short of the market within the last few weeks, basing their operations on the general good appearance of the corn crop, enlivened the Speculative trade in corn on the Board of Trade last week to an extent that prices reached the four-cent level on the upturn, with the shorts said to be well covered at the close.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12. -- A three-alarm fire early today that wrecked the plant of the Parkhurst Products Company, handlers of cellulose scrap, at 250 South Street, and drove forty families from their homes, was laid to the hot weather by Fire Department officials.

Though slightly hampered by an emergency collecting system under which cars required an average of twelve to thirteen seconds to pass toll points, the new Triborough Bridge accommodated its first rush of Sunday traffic yesterday with ease and smoothness.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 12 (AP). -- Nazi Germany, intent on fostering vacations for everybody, planned pageants and exhibitions tonight to show the second world congress for "vacations and recreation" how she hopes to do it.
Religion is in a bad way when it permits the moral conscience of its generation to outrun it, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 12. -- Governor Curley's failure to reappoint Professor Walter Prichard Eaton of the Yale School of Drama, and a widely known author, to the Mount Everett Reservation Commission, on which he has served as secretary and treasurer without pay for twenty years, has caused an uproar in Berkshire County.

The threat of a strike of 100,000 workers in the woolen and worsted industry loomed larger yesterday after the National Association of Wool Manufacturers through its president, Arthur Besse, had refused to negotiate with the union on its demands for higher wages and improved working conditions.

ROME, July 12. -- The Austro-German agreement concluded yesterday has sent a thrill of triumph through the Italian nation, for it is regarded as definitely sealing the diplomatic victory that Premier Benito Mussolini gained over Britain and France, the two principal exponents of Geneva's policy of sanctions.

VERDUN, France, July 12. -- On the battlefield of Verdun tonight Peace Pilgrims of fourteen nations held communion with the dead. Some say 20,000 former soldiers were there, some say 30,000. It matters little. Had thrice as many come they would still have been outnumbered by the dead.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- National income produced in 1935 was estimated at $52,595,000,000 and income paid out, including disbursements from capital and surplus by business enterprises, at $53,587,000,000 in a study made public today by the Division of Economic Research of the Commerce Department.

LONDON, July 10. -- Britain's monetary situation at present turns largely on the position of the note circulation of the Bank of England. With a further increase of 3,464,000 this week it has reached a new high record at 443,106,000. As this was accompanied by an increase of 4,497,000 to another high record of 226,567,000 in its gold holdings, the Bank's ordinary reserve actually increased.

ALBANY, July 12. -- Deaths from cancer declined in May for the first time since February, 1935, Dr. J.V. De Porte, director of the division of vital statistics of the State Health Department, reported today. The rate was 138.9 per 100,000 population, compared with 150.2 in May, 1935.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 12. -- The eighth anniversary of the death of Captain Emilio Carranza, young Mexican good-will pilot who crashed in a thunderstorm near here on a flight from Roosevelt Field to Mexico City July 12, 1928, was commemorated today with services at the monument erected several years ago near the site of his crash at Chatworth.

Sudden storms which overtake men in their accustomed ways of life are useful discipline when aid is sought early enough and in the right direction, the Right Rev. Dr. Stephen E. Keeler, Bishop Coadjutor of Minnesota, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Rains and cooler weather inched eastward from the western sectors of the drought land tonight, following the path of the record-breaking heat which has plagued the nation for ten days and cost almost a thousand lives.

In the census of church attendance there should now be counted hundreds of thousands, rising into millions at times, who at least listen to sermons from outside church walls. One who had such a mighty national audience, in addition to his visible congregation in Brooklyn, was Dr. S. PARKES CADMAN, who will be mourned by multitudes of men and women, many of whom never saw him.

ST. LOUIS, July 12. -- Continuing to display equal disdain both for heat waves and pennant contenders, the astonishing Dodgers today flattened the league-leading Cardinals in both ends of a double-header and did it in a manner that left 17,000 spectators rubbing their eyes in disbelief.

No acute suffering or starvation has accompanied New Jersey's transfer of responsibility for unemployment relief from the State to local communities, in the opinion of officers of chambers of commerce there. Responding to a survey by the New York Board of Trade, the findings of which were made public last night, the chamber officials reported savings of from 15 to 50 per cent in relief costs.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa, July 12. -- The South African Wine Growers Association is exhorting its members to buy British automobiles, machinery and household appliances as the result of its disappointment at not being able to sell South African wines and brandy in the United States.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 12. -- Announcement was made today by the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton of the acquisition by the institute of the famous collection of Far Eastern literature belonging to Guion M. Gest of New York City. The collection, numbering more than 130,000 volumes, will be transferred to Princeton within the next few weeks.

AMSTERDAM, July 11. -- While the short-term prospects of the gold bloc have improved considerably, the long-term view is gloomy despite the optimistic tone of Vincent Auriol, French Finance Minister. It is doubted here that the favorable conditions of the new French bond issue will lead to an end of hoarding.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Before a crowd of 41,693 at Wrigley Field this afternoon the Giants touched a new low in reverse before splitting a twin bill with the Cubs and salvaging their first victory in their last seven starts.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP). -- Checked with one hit in the first game of a doubleheader, which the Phillies won, 4 -- 0, the Reds snapped a six-game losing streak today by taking the second contest, 4 -- 3, in eleven innings.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- About 600 well-known engineers will start from New York in a series of nine technical tours to the outstanding electric power developments in the United States and Canada to be conducted in conjunction with the Third World Power Conference which will convene in Washington Sept. 7 to 12.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, July 12. -- More than 5,500 Wheeling Steel Corporation employes celebrated today on the eve of their return to work Monday, following settlement of a violent strike which kept them idle for fifty-two days.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12. -- The story of the rescue of the crew of the Alton, which, as the Chicago, was the first of the navy's steel cruisers, and which foundered Wednesday night while bound here from Honolulu, was told today by Captain William Watson on their arrival here.

Over-enthusiastic partisans of the Democratic National Committee may share the board of James A. Farley, its chairman, and may still remain his political bed-fellows, but he will not be responsible for their manners. This pronouncement, as blunt as if it appeared as an advertisement in a newspaper's "agony" column, made its public appearance yesterday under the green-ink signature of the national chairman himself.
DUBLIN, July 12. -- Grover Whalen, president of New York's World's Fair Corporation, is spending a month's vacation here with his family in a villa at Greystones, overlooking the Irish Sea.

This week the Topeka carpenters will begin work on another Republican platform, stage for the "notification ceremonies" on the night of July 23. There will be grand-stand seats and bleachers, a speakers' stand, and all that. Retributory justice will get even with the speakers and with "distinguished guests."

With a large number of buyers from all sections of the country here to view the new lines for Fall, the wholesale women's apparel markets were unusually active last week. A fair volume of orders, running well ahead of the total in the corresponding period last year, was placed by retailers.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 12. -- With the arrival of the Ninety-third Infantry Brigade of the New York State National Guard at Camp Smith today the reservation for the first time this season is populated with a command made up entirely of metropolitan area Guardsmen.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,582,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP). -- Steel consumption remains relatively heavy for this season despite a decline in new specifications, according to the magazine Steel.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 12. -- The 10,000-ton passenger liner Iroquois ran high aground on Bald Porcupine Island when driven off her course by strong tides and dense fog early this morning. She was floated late this afternoon by the navy mine sweeper Owl.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- The Browns, who have been easy for the Senators in most of their engagements this season, whipped Washington today, 4 -- 3.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 12. -- The attitude of Czechoslovakia to the Austro-German pact is extremely reserved, so much so that the Foreign Office organ, the Prager Presse, refrains from comment.
LONDON, July 12. -- The Austro-German treaty just concluded is accompanied by two secret annexes. One deals with military problems and the other with the question of a restoration of the Hapsburgs.
PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP). -- The Bees pushed across four runs in the tenth inning off Cy Blanton to defeat the Pirates, 6 -- 2, in the first game of their series today.

WARWICK, R.I., July 12. -- Johnny Higgins of Providence, 20-year-old schoolboy, broke all records in the 200-meter breast-stroke for a fifty-meter pool when he won in the final United States Olympic swimming tryouts at the Rocky Point pool today.

ALBANY, July 12. -- The alcoholic beverage tax brought $21,321,751.89 into the State treasury for the fiscal year ending June 30, Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, stated today. Last year the total was $17,956,054.32, the increase for the year being $3,365,705.
PARIS, July 12. -- France opened the three-day celebration of her national holiday, Bastile Day, today with a great display of military aviation at Le Bourget Field.

WARSAW, Poland, July 12. -- The Austro-German settlement is regarded here as an explanation of the Nazis' attack on the League of Nations in Danzig and on the statute of the Free City. It is apprehended that Germany's flirtations with Austria and Italy may well mean the end of her other flirtations.

LONDON, July 11. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 70.6 on July 8, compared with 70.2 a fortnight before, 69.9 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, New York State Senator and Director of Publicity for the World's Fair in 1939; Otto Klemperer, conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, and Mrs. Charles H. Sherrill, widow of General Sherrill, former United States diplomat who died recently in Paris, are among the notables due today from Europe on the new French liner Normandie.

The Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., proposed yesterday that the 20,125 regular students of City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges should be required to pay an annual fee of $75 each to reduce the present cost to the taxpayers of approximately $250 a year for every student.

BREWSTER, N.Y., July 12. -- Ninety Girl Scouts of the Manhattan Council took part in a historical pageant today at dedicatory exercises in which a 58-acre tract, on which are an eight-room house and a lake, was named Camp Genevieve Brady in honor of Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, donor of the site.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 12. -- Paul B. Sawyer Jr. of Pocono Lake, Pa., carried off the honors in the ninth annual Geneva regatta today to win the New York State outboard championship, dethroning J.C. (Cab) Walier of Syracuse.

PARIS, July 12 (AP). -- Victories by Don Budge and Bryan (Bitsy) Grant clinched victory today for the United States tennis players in the informal eleven-match international team competition with France.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 12. -- The base of the statue of Hadrian has been discovered in the Agora, or Athenian market place, by the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, according to a report received here today from Dr. T. Leslie Shear, field director of the work and a member of the Art and Archaeology Department of Princeton University.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 12. -- The Rev. Dr. Parkes Cadman died at Champlain Valley Hospital here today at 1:22 P.M., after suffering a ruptured appendix seven days ago. During his illness he told his son, Frederick L. Cadman, that "there are ten more good years left for me."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hudson Budd gave a luncheon today at the clubhouse of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club for Mr. and Mrs. William Malcolm Mather, who are passing the weekend with Mr. and Mrs. Robert Manning McKeon at Plas-Ar-Lyn.
LONDON, Monday, July 13. -- Britain is still not sure whether to welcome the Austro-German pact wholeheartedly or to fear it as the...
CHICAGO, July 12. -- Ranges of prices of grains last week on the Board of Trade with net changes follow:

The Indians called this little island "Minnahanonck." A rather sad and dreary existence it has had till now, standing though it does close beside the famed island of Manhattan, upon which it has seen the towers mount to the skies while it has cared for cast-offs. For a long time after the coming of man it was a potter's field for the burial of the poor and stranger dead.
"How can one tell the difference between the large-mouth and small-mouth bass?" asks R.W.H.

Passenger and freight traffic between the United States and the Mediterranean has increased in recent months and is favored by conditions abroad to continue to grow, according to John E. Slater, vice president of the American Export Line.

A concert by a symphony orchestra of 210 musicians, augmented by a band of fifty-five players, will be given at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday evening, July 29, under the auspices of the WPA Federal Music Project, it was announced yesterday by Lee Pattison, city and State director of the project.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1936, as well as last price, for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:

Frequent inspection of automobiles to reduce traffic hazards was urged upon car owners yesterday by the National Safety Council, which said that recent tests on 1,000 cars showed 60 per cent to be defective in some vital point.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Margaret Louise Bell, red-haired 23-year-old witness against Charles (Lucky) Lucania, convicted New York vice lord, was found in an apartment here today with the initials "C.L." and the numerals "3-12" carved on her thigh and abdomen.
The cotton manufacturing industries in this country and in England continue to operate under unusually favorable conditions, according to The New York Cotton Exchange Service.

BERLIN, July 12. -- The conclusion of the Austro-German amity agreement was greeted by the German press today with an outpouring of jubilance second only to that aroused by the remilitarization of the Rhineland. Although editorial appraisals of the foreign political implications of the agreement move within cautious limits for the present, it is Austria's profession of membership in the "big Teutonic family" that chiefly warms German Nazi hearts.
It took the Yankees quite a time yesterday at the Stadium to swing into that superlative stride which thus far has enabled them to leave the rest of the American League straggling miles behind.

Experience proved its worth at the women's final Olympic swimming and diving tryouts at the Municipal Astoria Park pool yesterday as Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett and Mrs. Dorothy Poynton Hill won their respective specialties, the 100-meter back-stroke and the high platform dive, to qualify for their third Olympic team.

The "re-establishment" of Austro-German "relations on a normal and friendly basis," formally announced last Saturday night in Berlin and Vienna, is one of the most important events since the war. It will affect, possibly decisively, the existing balance of political forces throughout Europe.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., July 12. -- William Warnock, 68 years old, a resident of the Westchester County Almshouse here since 1927, was found dead today on grounds of the Fairview Country Club, Greenburgh. Caddies made the discovery in underbrush shortly before Tony Manero, Mike Turnesea, Jess Sweetser and Willie Turnesea began an exhibition golf match for the benefit of the Westchester County Children's Association.

While the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act puts the burden of proof of innocence upon the alleged violator, the English common law, which was the basis for the United States statutes, contemplated that in similar criminal prosecutions the accused should be considered innocent until proved guilty, according to the National Association of Manufacturers.

Prices of cotton made last week their broadest advance in years and reached the highest levels since September, 1934. Measuring the movement by the July and October contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, the net rise was 97 to 110 points. The net rise from March 1 to the end of last week was 322 to 373 points.

NEW ORLEANS, July 12. -- Last week was the most active one that the cotton market here has experienced in many months. There were active trade buying, good speculative trading for the advance and fair hedge selling, and although there was considerable profit-taking at the end of the week, the offerings were absorbed quickly.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 12. -- Dr. and Mrs. Truman Laurence Saunders gave a picnic luncheon on Bailey's Beach today and there were many luncheon parties at private homes.

Lauren D. Lyman, winner of the Pulitzer Prize this year for reporting in recognition of his exclusive story in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the departure of the Lindberghs for England, is the author, with C.B. Alien, aviation editor of The New York Herald Tribune, of a book called "The Wonder Book of the Air" published by John C. Winston Company of Philadelphia.

Spiritual belief plumbs the depths in the heart of humanity and makes possible the achievement of which the heart and mind of man may dream, the Rev. Dr. Claude C. Coile, superintendent of the New York District of the New York Methodist Conference, said in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

America flung out her challenge to the rest of the world yesterday with a series of magnificent performances as the final Olympic trials were completed before a capacity crowd of 21,000 in the new Randalls Island Stadium.

Modernization features including an elevator, dropped living rooms and an incinerator are being planned for the four tenement houses at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, purchased by a syndicate headed by Samuel Belkind.

BERLIN, July 11. -- The Boerse opened irregular and generally lower this week, with profit-taking in stocks and bonds occurring in connection with subscriptions to the new Reich loan. After the decline, foreign and arbitrage stocks recovered on Tuesday, with active buying of paper, pulp, steel and allied issues, with other industrials uncertain until Friday, when an all-round recovery began.

Delegates from 512 Jewish labor and social welfare groups in thirty-four cities decided yesterday to send five representatives to the forthcoming World Jewish Congress in Geneva. They charged they had been barred by the American Jewish Congress from the recent Washington meeting at which plans for the world conclave were laid.

God cannot be used to further man's little schemes no matter how generously they may be conceived, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-third Street.

If the heat wave continues today with the same intensity it has displayed since Thursday, it is unlikely that any person who treks to the elephant house in the Bronx Zoo to share in the thirty-third birthday of Peter the Great, the staid hippopotamus, will see very much of the city's oldest hippo despite his two and one-half tons.

Sir SAMUEL HOARE'S speech at Southampton Saturday was overshadowed by the Austrian-German agreement, but as a declaration of policy it is also of capital importance. As First Lord of the Admiralty Sir SAMUEL fully explains his policy as Foreign Minister. More than that, he furnishes the complete explanation of the weakness and wavering in the British course which have contributed more than any single factor to European confusion in recent months.

LONDON, July 12. -- More than 400 American social workers were among the 800 delegates from twenty-six nations who assembled here today for the International Conference on Social Service. The chief aim of the conference is to afford an opportunity to charity workers from all countries to discuss their problems and methods of work.

PITTSBURGH, July 12. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 70 per cent of capacity, down 4 points from the preceding week, when production was swelled because there was to be no work on the holiday, and the week's output was computed against capacity for five working days.

NEW HAVEN, July 11. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.8, which compares with 83.1 the week before, 82.6 two weeks before, 82.5 three weeks before and 82.3 four weeks before.

TOPEKA, July 12. -- Continued emphasis is being placed by the Landon camp on a drift back to the Republican column in the farm States, and steps are apparently being taken to insure that there is no recession in that drift for the present because of the direct Federal aid being administered in the drought areas.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP). -- A three-run attack in the ninth inning, featured by Earl Averill's fourteenth home run of the season, gave the Indians, a 5-2 victory over the Red Sox today. A crowd of 13,500 saw the home team lose.

The German airship Hindenburg was due over New York City this morning between 6:30 and 7:30 daylight time. Representatives of the Zeppelin company here in communication with the airship last night were informed by Captain Ernst Lehmann that he expected to cruise over the city by daylight.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- In line with the administration's policy of promoting lower interest rates, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today reductions, effective from the first of this month, in loan charges for various classes of borrowers.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 12. -- Memorial services for former officers and men of the 114th Infantry were held here at Camp Hoffman today when the 114th Infantry Association, composed of veterans of the wartime New Jersey regiment held their annual reunion in connection with the annual field training of the present-day 114th.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 12. -- A gambling resort patronized by politicians and others of prominence was raided by District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County yesterday afternoon, it was announced today.

More than 250 extra policemen were patroling the streets of Harlem last night and early this morning following an anti-Italian outbreak in which three patrolmen were injured, one of them seriously, as a mob of 400 Negroes hurled bricks, bottles and stones through the windows of a restaurant owned by Italians.

The mercury fell yesterday, but the humidity rose to continue New York City's distress. For the fifth successive day the blazing sun maintained its devastating intensity, though showers in scattered sections of the East afforded momentary respite from the blistering heat that originated in the Middle West.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Looking to an intensified drive against combinations in restraint of trade, the Justice Department has set up a "general staff" to direct investigations into alleged violations.

After most of the week had been passed in a quiet and composed state, with business at a minimum and rate fluctuations narrow, the French franc weakened suddenly at the week-end in the foreign exchange market and was carried down to 6.60 1/2 cents at the close, the lowest since June 25.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- With farmers in the Middle West, Northwest and Southwest rushing their livestock to market because of the scarcity of feed in the drought-stricken regions, there was a decided decline in prices here last week.

Without committing itself on any aspect of the transit unification plan submitted to the Transit Commission by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., the Merchants Association urged the commission yesterday to make all possible haste in holding public hearings on the project and formulating its own official plan for consideration by the local authorities and the traction groups.

BERLIN, July 11. -- Promising accounts of conditions in the consumers' goods industry, which is now recovering faster than the capital goods branch, and an official statement of the development of the German 200,000,000-mark credit to Russia on April 9, 1935, were bullish factors in local markets this week.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- It cost $11,750,000,000 more to run the government of the United States during the last six fiscal years than it did during the first 127 years of the existence of the republic, the National Economy League asserted in a statement issued today.

Eight little pigs went to market four months ago in Versailles, Ind., with Frederick William Tatton, 34 years old, at the wheel of his aunt's farm car. Tatton resolved to shake the farmyard dust from off his feet forever, and without his aunt's knowledge he neatly folded the $87 cash proceeds of the sale and boarded a train for New York.

The 157th anniversary of the storming of the British fort at Stony Point, N.Y., by General Anthony Wayne (Mad Anthony) and his troops will be marked on Thursday by the dedication of a new museum building erected on the site under the auspices of the American Scenic and Historical Preservation Society.

A reorganization plan for the Bush Terminal Company and the Bush Terminal Buildings Company is being proposed by a preferred stockholders' committee which is seeking the addition of former Governor Alfred E. Smith and George McAneny, president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, to the board of directors.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 12. -- Mrs. William Whittingham Battie and Mrs. Wallace Reid will be among those giving luncheons before the bridge on Tuesday afternoon at the Maidstone Club for the benefit of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry. N.Y. Mrs. Battie is chairman of the committee arranging the benefit.

Confessing himself very pleased with the Westport tryout last week of "The Difficulty of Getting Married," William A. Brady yesterday said that Grace George (Mrs. Brady) would quite definitely appear in the play on Broadway next season.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP). -- Varying reports on the possibility of a split in the American Federation of Labor Tuesday were heard tonight after a week-end of informal conferences among federation leaders.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 12. -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, former superintendent of the New Jersey State police, has accepted the post of vice president in charge of operations of the Middlesex Transportation Company, it was learned here today.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 12. -- President Roosevelt spent the first day of his Summer holiday in seeking relief from the heat wave which hung over this hill-locked section of the Hudson Valley. The temperature was slightly lower than yesterday, but thermometers still registered in the 90's.

The American Superpower Corporation, an investment trust, reported yesterday that the market value of all its assets on June 30 was $46,536,169, compared with $47,188,920 on Dec. 31, 1935. The assets were carried at $37,165,526.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 12. -- William G. Marquette; aged 22, of Pleasantville, N.Y., missing from the Marine Biological Laboratories since last Monday, was found dead this morning in Quissett. Medical Examiner Curry of North Sagamoe said death was self-inflicted.

Triborough Bridge is sure to add to the diversities of taste and personal predilections which are so large a part of the charm of life in New York. The new bridge will enormously stimulate discussion on the best way of getting out of New York and into New York by automobile.

THE big party on Randalls Island began with a familiar scene. Four fellows chased Jesse Owens to the tape but didn't come close to catching him. It was the first heat of the 200-meter sprint. Most of the athletes in the meet would have been content to earn one small berth on the boat for Berlin. Owens seemed to be striving for a three-room suite on the sun deck.
MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 12. -- A hole-in-one helped 22-year-old Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie to capture top honors in the tenth annual Jess Sweetser Victory Cup tournament today.

Officers of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America reported yesterday, at the close of a two-day conference with General Hugh S. Johnson, special labor adviser to the Radio Corporation of America, that a tentative agreement had been reached for settlement of the strike at the Camden plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 12. -- Missing his calculations of running time by only fourteen minutes, Neal R. Andrews won the annual contest of the New York Athletic Club for motor boats out here with his 56-foot express cruiser Hall By Herself, which was entered under the American Power Boat Association.

The large field participating is the ninth annual Eastern men's clay court championships at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club was narrowed down considerably yesterday as a result of a long afternoon of competition, Two victories by Frank Bowden, fourth seeded star, furnished the feature of the day's play.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Eighteen checks will be mailed by the Treasury tomorrow to the first beneficiaries under the Railroad Retirement Act, the first persons other than government employes to receive Federal-planned old-age pensions.

VIENNA, July 12. -- It is perhaps something more than a coincidence that the announcement of the agreement with Nazi Germany should coincide with the proclamation by the Austrian Government of an extremely severe "law for the defense of the State" as an emergency measure, which means it does not have to be passed by the Legislative Council.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 12. -- River thieves, surprised while moving part of a $20,000 stock of banjo and electric clocks from the Waltham Watch Company's plant at about 3:30 this morning, murdered Harry E. Bradley, 55, a watchman and father of ten children, after he had apparently shown them mercy by shooting over their heads to halt them.
DETROIT, July 12. -- Michigan sweltered in 100-degree heat today for the fifth consecutive day, and at least forty-four deaths brought the total of fatalities to 179.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges, who was overcome by the heat in St. Louis a week ago, made his first start since then today and pitched the Tigers to a 7-to-2 triumph over the Athletics.

Failure to receive holy communion causes spiritual death as certainly as failure to eat material foods results in physical death, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Committee for Industrial Organization is raising an immense war chest for the purpose of forcing upon the steel, automobile, rubber and other industries one particular kind of labor union, and what is known as the closed shop.

VIENNA, July 12. -- Announcement of the Austro-German compact was followed today by an exchange of telegrams between Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria and heads of allied Fascist States. To Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany he telegraphed:

BILLINGS, Mont., July 12. -- Through hundreds of rivulets and streams that drain the Big Horn and Pryor Hill country the week-end rains that brought new hope to Eastern Montana's sheep and cattle raisers were today rushing unimpeded on their course to the Gulf of Mexico.

WASHINGTON, July 12. -- Mrs. William A. Becket, President General of the Daughters of the American Revolution, announced today a complete list of committees and the names of their chairmen for the current year.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 12. -- Glenn Waterhouse and Woodbridge Metcalf and their boat Three Star Too from California today won the right to represent the United States in the Star Class Olympic sailing series off Kiel, Germany, but to do it they had to beat Eddie Ketcham and his Draco in a sail-off after losing in as hair-raising a finish as a major yacht race has produced in years.

Mrs. Cantacuzene-Grant, granddaughter of President Grant, will be one of the speakers at a Landon-Knox campaign tea to be given Wednesday at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, from 5 to 6:30 P.M.

Man's fight against the mechanized forces of nature was discussed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, until recently of City Temple, London, at the Broadway Tabernacle Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, July 12. -- Closing of spreads between lard and wheat futures made an interesting market throughout the week, with shorts covering their lard and in some instances taking the long side. Futures closed 7 1/2 to 10 cents a hundredweight net higher than the previous week, with July at $10.77 1/2, September $10.80-90 and October $10.92 1/2.
BERLIN, July 12. -- German hopes of success in the Olympic Games, which were high yesterday after the first day of the final track and and field tryouts here, were nearly wiped out today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- The coal fund of the Art Association of Newport was augmented tonight by a concert given at the association home on Bellevue Avenue under the direction of Mrs. Maud Howe Elliott, secretary and a founder of the association, and under the patronage of Summer colony members.

Peter the Great, mild-mannered dean of New York City's hippopotamuses, experienced the thirty-third anniversary of his birth yesterday without benefit of birthday cake. Peter doesn't like cake anyhow, although people have given him one every year for quite a while.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13. -- Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine gave a dinner tonight at Valmay Cottage for Mrs. Bradish John Carroll, who arrived today to visit her. They will be joined on Friday by Mr. Carroll.

As the American Olympic track and field team made ready yesterday to sail for Berlin on the S.S. Manhattan tomorrow at noon, athletic leaders surveyed the results of the final tryouts at Randalls Island over the past week-end, studied the personnel of the squad, and announced themselves satisfied that the United States was sending abroad its strongest Olympic team in history.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, through its finance division, has agreed to the request of a protective committee for shareholders of the Old Colony Railroad, controlled by the New York, New Haven Hartford, to solicit authorizations to represent stockholders in the reorganization of the New Haven.

I might as well tell you that there is some indignation here in St. Louis at the sight of New York displaying a temperature of over 100 degrees. We didn't mind so much the flaunting of the official temperature, but that subhead "Mercury Rises in Central Park to 145 Degrees and to 115 in Times Square," that's hitting low.

MADRID, July 13. -- Jose Calvo Sotelo, 47-year-old Monarchist Deputy and outstanding leader of the conservative opposition in Parliament, was murdered early this morning about six hours after a young lieutenant of Assault Guards, or shock police, had been assassinated.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The Townsend old-age pension and share-the-wealth movements are holding in abeyance their decision to indorse the Presidential candidacy of Representative William Lemke of the Union party.

Prospects for an early sale of the British properties of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, $405,000,000 utility - holding company, were linked in Wall Street yesterday to the imminent departure for England of Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 13. -- On the eve of the trial of Pedro Albizu Campos and seven other Nationalists on sedition charges in the United States District Court before Judge Robert A. Cooper tomorrow United States Marshal Donald A. Draughon said today no one would be admitted until after a search for weapons.

Steve Lakozeski, 46 years old, of 148 Freeman Street, Brooklyn, was killed and four persons were injured about noon yesterday when a freight elevator operated by Lakozeski in the National Sugar Refinery, Second Street and the East River, Long Island City, fell two floors.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13 (AP). -- Along the longest national coastline in America and on nine international borders, Brazilian authorities watched tonight to prevent the entry of Bela Kun, once Communist dictator of Hungary.
Francis H. Low, noted deep-sea angler, writes from Tucker's Town, Bermuda. And the note is especially interesting, as a cable from the sportsman also arrived shortly thereafter.

None the less sparkling despite fifty years of journeying, the International Challenge Cup, most cherished prize in polo, returned to the United States yesterday. The trophy arrived aboard the American Merchant liner American Merchant:

BASLE, Switzerland, July 13. -- Speculation over the Austro-German agreement, uneasiness in German and Italian quarters over the French financial situation and concern over crop conditions in Germany and Italy seemed to mark the talks of central bankers who are here today for the monthly meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements.

John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in an interview last night laid at the door of the Democrats responsibility for spreading rumors that he was anti-Semitic and that Jews who had been prominent in other national Republican campaigns were to be kept out of important positions in the Landon campaign.

A law passed three years ago to aid judgment creditors in collecting unpaid judgments, "should not be used to re-establish in our law imprisonment for debt," Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ruled in a decision disclosed yesterday.

ROME, July 13. -- No immediate development is foreseen in the Italo-German situation following the Austro-German agreement of last Saturday. The Italian Government takes the view that its reply to the invitation to attend the conference in Brussels of the Locarno powers has put the next move up to Great Britain, France and Belgium.
AMMAN, Transjordan, July 13 (AP). -- The Emir Abdullah, who once swept across desert sands with Lawrence of Arabia, sat in his tent surrounded by his Bedouins and said simply:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 13. -- Charging that Governor Harold G. Hoffman had sanctioned "legislation for political purposes by methods of political chicanery," Harry B. White, City Councilman, made public here today a confidential letter from the Governor which he contended supported this assertion.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 13 (AP). -- The chance arrival of a motor boat fishing party led by Mary Joyce, Alaska's "lady musher," who drove a dog team 1,000 miles last Winter to a Fairbanks ice carnival, helped save Father Bernard Hubbard when his boat was wrecked last week in the icy rapids of Twin Glacier River, the explorer disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Resettlement Administrator Tugwell and other high Federal officials will leave by plane tomorrow evening for Bismarck, N.D., to prepare plans for turning large areas of Western wheat lands back to pasturage and moving a considerable part of the population to other areas, Joseph L. Dailey, assistant administrator, announced today.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 14 (AP). -- The engagement of Mrs. Mary Fearn French, widow of Seth Barton French of New York and Virginia, to Prince Serge Wolkonsky, former director of the Russian Imperial Theatres, was announced today.

Representative Samuel Dickstein, member of the House committee that investigated un-American activities, obtained a summons yesterday in West Side Court, returnable July 24, against William Zenger, publisher of The National American, defunct pro-Nazi publication, alleging criminal libel.

TRENTON, N.J., July 13. -- Confronted today with an estimate of the State League of Municipalities that local governing bodies will require about $10,000,000 to finance relief for the next six months, the State Financial Assistance Commission announced it cannot supply more than $6,000,000 and that the municipalities must make up the difference.

Mayor La Guardia's associates at the Summer City Hall were among the thousands of persons who were pleased yesterday over the opening of a new four-lane concrete road to City Island, which relieved the congestion existing before the artery was finished.

ANNISTON, Ala., July 13 (AP). -- A detachment of militia and highway patrolmen hurried to rural Alexandria today under orders to "arrest and protect" a Negro accused of attempting to attack a white woman and wounding a posseman.

BRUSSELS, July 13. -- Considering that Italy's refusal to attend the Brussels conference of the Locarno powers has radically changed the whole situation. Premier Paul van Zeeland, who was charged with calling the conference together, has in effect handed back to London and Paris the responsibility of deciding whether any conference shall be held.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 13. -- Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County today set Sept. 15 as the date for a hearing to determine the ownership of $150,000 of jewelry, listed in the inventory of the estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton as an asset of his estate.

Jesse Jones, chairman of the Re- construction Finance Corporation, said nothing about the railroads in announcing reductions in interest rates charged some borrowers by the government agency. Most of the railroads which obtained loans from the RFC pay 4 per cent for the accommodation, although, if their credit is impaired by bankruptcy or receivership, the rate runs as high as 6 per cent.

With a registration of 400 buyers, twice as many as were recorded on the opening day of the Spring showing, the New York Curtain and Drapery Show was opened yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker. Prices on Fall cotton curtains were up 3 to 5 per cent, compared with Spring quotations, while other goods remained at approximately the same levels.

As a result of the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination law, the Eastern division of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has suspended all retail newspaper advertising, it was learned here yesterday. The curtailment of advertising allowances by food manufacturers, following passage of the price bill, was said to be directly responsible for the new policy, which is expected to be permanent, although that has not been definitely decided upon.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Police changed their tactics tonight in the case of Jean Bell, apparent victim of a mutilation attack, and subjected the girl to intensive questioning in an effort to break down her story.

LONDON, July 13. -- The stock markets here opened firm but became irregular in the afternoon on profit taking, and trading was less active. British funds were steady, while European securities strengthened in the foreign market, German and Austrian issues gaining because of the Austro-German agreement.

Watchers in Washington of the progress and methods of the New Deal over the last three years have been almost unanimous in the belief that the absence of strong or constructive opposition in Congress has been responsible for most of the President's mistakes. There is in him an impulsive trait, and among some of his favorite advisers an experimental quality, which could most usefully be checked by the right type of opposition.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Washington moved into third place in the American League today, defeating St. Louis 9 -- 3, as Earl White-hill registered his seventh triumph of the year. The Senators pushed ahead when the Indians defeated the Red Sox.
While the block party was at its height on Jefferson Avenue, between Ralph and Patchen, Brooklyn, on the night of July 1, 12-yearold Earl Bodie spotted the $5 bill.

Paced by Melvin Lapman, St. John's University freshman star, a field of seventy-nine juniors started out yesterday in quest of the Eastern junior tennis singles crown won last year by Edgar Weller of Austin, Texas.

BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, July 13. -- Crumbling three score world land speed records under the wheels of his thundering "Speed of the Winds," Captain George Eyston rolled on tonight hoping to beat the 48-hour record of 109.54 miles an hour.

A very small girl who wanted to show her doll what the Triborough Bridge looked like -- and did -- ended up yesterday with the distinction of being the only guest of the East 126th Street police station who didn't want to leave.

LAWRENCE, L.I., July 13. -- A man said by the police to have committed twenty-one burglaries recently in the Rockaway Branch Villages was held without bail for the grand jury when arraigned today before Justice of the Peace Ekenberg here on a charge of second degree burglary.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 13. -- Turkey has no intention of giving preferential treatment to or concluding bilateral pacts with absentees from the Dardanelles conference, Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras told the conference today.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A telegram from Mayor La Guardia of New York City, in which it is understood he sought to obtain a reduction of the interest rate on bonds of the Triborough Bridge Authority and the New York subway was received by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today and forwarded to Chairman Jesse H. Jones, who is on his way west on a vacation.

The five delegates to the World Jewish Congress chosen Sunday by the recently formed Conference for a United World Jewish Congress will face challenges on their right to be seated, Louis Lipsky, acting president of the American Jewish Congress, declared yesterday.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent for 24,000 shares of convertible $3 preferred stock of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation and co-transfer agent for 400,000 shares of no par common stock of the Youngstown Steel Door Company.

Three clergymen will officiate at the funeral of the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, known as "The Bishop of the Air," because he was the first radio preacher over an international hook-up. The service will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in the Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near, Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, of which Dr. Cadman had been pastor for thirty-five years.

An increase of approximately 250 per cent in the value of new building and alteration work in the borough of Manhattan for the first six months of this year over the corresponding period a year ago is shown by a report of Commissioner of Buildings Samuel Fassler given out yesterday.

BERLIN, July 13. -- It has taken several days for the full effect of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's sensational agreement with Austria to be felt in the chancelleries of Europe. It may be many weeks before all these effects are publicly visible, for this coup changes political situations all over Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on July 8 shows decreases for the week of $157,000,000 in total loans and investments, $49,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $12,000,000 in time deposits, and increases of $185,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $64,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

Governor Landon has made it clear that he favors action by State cooperation rather than by Federal authority. The statements concerning farm problems point to action by States in this most important question. There is a large body of citizens who are disturbed by the overconcentration of power in the hands of the central government who will welcome this policy proposed by the Kansas Governor.

Ernest Desmond de Hagen, alias "Lord Desmond," who was brought back from Los Angeles last Saturday on four indictments growing out of the so-called extortion ring inquiry, told Acting District Attorney Harold W. Hastings yesterday that he would turn State's evidence.

BERLIN, July 13. -- America will arrive for the Berlin Olympics a great or greater favorite than it has ever been in the past. European sport fans, thoroughly weary and disgusted with American domination of athletics, are not downcast.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 13. -- Two matches will mark the opening of play in the Wheatley Cups polo tournament, the annual nine-goal handicap event, at the Meadow Brook Club tomorrow afternoon at 5:30.

Actor Jimmy Cagney, who successfully sued Warners early this year to free himself of a contract calling for $4,500 a week, is reported to have been placed under a long-term contract by the infant Grand National Pictures Corporation.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The Boerse opened the week with a considerable display of strength, but profit taking set in later and the close was quiet. The initial upward movement was led by the heavy industrials, particularly the lignites.

Traffic over the gleaming spans of the Triborough Bridge ran smoothly yesterday with no tie-ups reported at the toll booths, although only fourteen of the twenty-two were in service. Official figures placed the number of vehicles paying tolls over the bridge since it opened at 1:30 P.M. Saturday up to 8 A.M. yesterday at 87,586.

CINCINNATI, July 13 (AP). -- The Reds were blanked for four innings today, then bunched hits in the two succeeding frames to score a 6-4 victory over Philadelphia and make it two out of three for the series. The box score:
BERLIN, July 13 (AP). -- The Reichssportfeld, 325 acres of play-land built at a cost of many millions of dollars, today formally was declared completed and ready for the Olympic Games, Aug. 1 to 16.

I FINISHED "The Earth Trembles" (Knopf, $3), fifth volume of Jules Romains's "Men of Good Will," with a mixed feeling of admiration and dubiety. Here, even a blind man should be able to see, is fiction noble in purpose, endlessly imaginative, gigantic in conception. Yet is it not at the same time fiction so protracted and dependent as almost to defeat its own ends? Is not Mr. Romains writing a sort of novelistic newspaper?

Two lawyers and a physician, the latter a brother of one of the lawyers, were sentenced yesterday in Special Session by Justices Bayes, Brady and Burlingame to terms of three months each in the work-house on guilty pleas to ambulance chasing in an accident claim on an insurance company.

One of the famous gems owned by Lillian Russell, noted comedienne and beauty, who died in 1922, the "flawless emerald," will be sold at public auction tomorrow, to satisfy various debts including a $1,150 claim based on a broken lease.

Both the police and Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's office acted vigorously yesterday on the story by a young woman in Washington. There was a decided atmosphere of skepticism in both groups, but they proceeded on the theory that the woman was telling the truth.

The Republican candidate with pardonable pride has published the letter and pledge of support received from WILLIAM CABELL BRUCE, once a Democratic Senator from Maryland. Mr. BRUCE in person is highly representative of the old Southeastern stock, more accurately designated as Cleveland than Jeffersonian Democrats, though in political decision he has been more of the best type of independent than the best type of partisan.

With Mischa Elman as the guest artist, last night's concert at the Lewisohn Stadium attracted the second largest audience of the season. Only the opening-night attendance exceeded the turnout to hear the distinguished violinist in the Mendelssohn concerto and in a solo group. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was directed by Jose Iturbi.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- The Giants today reached the conclusion that this would be a better world without Bill Lee, husky right-hander of the Cubs' pitching staff. Applying the calcimine brush as he did last June 28 at the Polo Grounds, Lee shut out the Terrymen before 10,000 at Wrigley Field.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP). -- The Tigers again beat the Athletics today for their tenth triumph in twelve games with the Mackmen and their second straight in the current series. The score was 5 to 2.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 13. -- Fifty-three New York City reserve officers under command of Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, 306th Infantry, today completed two weeks of duty with the C.M.T.C. regiment here and their work was taken over by another group of fifty-four reserve officers under command of Colonel Walter W. Metcalf, 305th Infantry, also from New York City.

A band of singers and performers from the Kentucky hills is paying its first visit to New York this week. From little Chad Gullett, 3 years old, to his grandmother, Mrs. Alice Williams, three generations of mountaineers are represented in the group of eight that Miss Jean Thomas has brought here.

Although the situation may not yet be so critical that it needs some modern Paul Revere to go dashing through the streets spreading alarms that there is trouble brewing on the Harlem, the admission must be made that Marse Joe McCarthy did not sleep very well last night, and the thing may, in time, become serious.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $35,000,000 of Commercial Investment Trust Corporation 3 1/2 per cent debentures due on July 1, 1951, by a banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co. and including Lehman Brothers, Lazard Freres Co., Inc., and Kuhn, Loeb Co. The debentures will be priced at 101 1/2 and interest.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 13. -- With the opening of official headquarters in this city today, the campaign of the Committee for Industrial Organization to sign up the 11,000 employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here as members of one industrial union got under full swing.

ALBANY, July 13. -- Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan tonight denied a motion of the Long Island Railroad Company for a stay of the Public Service Commission's order requiring it to charge passengers two cents a mile in coaches outside of New York City. This affects Nassau and Suffolk County riders.

More than 100 manufacturers opened their Fall corset and brassiere lines here yesterday, with attendance of buyers reported extremely good. Thirty-six producers are showing their lines at the Hotel McAlpin, with the remainder launching maniquin or showroow displays at their offices here.
HONGKONG, July 13. -- The question of launching a war of the Southwest (Kwangtung and Kwangsi Provinces) against the Central Government was in the balance in Canton today.

The American Olympic team, largest numerically and strongest athletically in history, will sail for Berlin tomorrow in debt. This was announced yesterday by Treasurer Gustavus Town Kirby after a five-hour session of the Administration Committee in its temporary Hotel Lincoln headquarters.

POTTSVILLE, Pa., July 13 (AP). -- The Schuylkill County Court imposed life sentences upon two brothers today and imprisoned four others of their family, three of them sons, for five slayings in Kelayres on the eve of the 1934 general election.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., July 13. -- Competition for the Long Island amateur-professional golf championship, which serves annually as a tune-up for the Long Island open, listed to begin tomorrow morning, was especially keen today as forty combinations toured the Rockville Country Club course in a best-ball struggle.
BISLEY CAMP, England, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- A Canadian entered the ranks of the first prize winners today at the National Rifle Association's annual meeting on the Bisley ranges.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, July 14. -- Canton's dictator. Chen Chia-tang, must relinquish his official positions in Kwangtung Province or fight to retain them.

FERRING - ON - SEA, England, July 13 (AP). -- James Bunting, a young scenario writer who says he has been to Hollywood, declared tonight he was "taking opinion of counsel" on his virtual excommunication from the Church of England.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Rainfall in the northwest sector of the drought land started cooler weather on a new march across the Plains States tonight as renewed onslaughts of heat to the east continued to break records and piled up the death toll.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Tuesday, July 14. -- The Finance Committee of the Republican-controlled Senate began reporting revenue - raising measures just before adjournment at 1:30 o'clock this morning which are part of a compromise $45,000,000 relief program on which agreement was reached between the Republicans and the Democrats.

Robert Edward Edmondson, through his lawyer, John S. Wise Jr., entered formal not guilty pleas in General Sessions yesterday to the indictments returned against him by the June New York County grand jury alleging he criminally libeled Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor; Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College and the Jewish religion.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Hot weather continues to curtail the demand for fresh pork, and as Western points received runs of hogs as large as on any Monday in four months prices here dropped 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight, packing sows and heavy hogs leading the decline.

George P. Montague, a resident at the Harvard Club, 27 West Forty- fourth Street, died yesterday afternoon at Bellevue Hospital of pneumonia and meningitis. Mr. Montague apparently suffered from a heat prostration while visiting friends Sunday night at 32 East Thirtieth Street.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 13. -- The veteran Winged Foot golf pro, Mike Brady, who won the metropolitan open in 1924 at Engineers in Roslyn, today displayed rare acumen in the selection of partners in the weekly competition of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association at Sunningdale.

We ought to find a few moments for cool judgment of Secretary Roper's business report. The first thing we may discover is that the estimated annual income of $60,000,000,000 is a rather vague creation. The Secretary does not say whether it is produced income or paid-out income. Only produced income represents new wealth.

One more auto fatality in the city last week than in the corresponding period of a year ago spoiled an otherwise improved record in the traffic safety campaign. Decreases were registered in all other categories -- for last week and for the week-end in comparison with the corresponding periods of 1935.

With the buyer in Stockholm and the seller in New York connected by transatlantic radio telephone as if they were in a single conference room, virtually all foreign match assets of the International Match Corporation were transferred yesterday to the Swedish Match Company in a $12,776,079 deal closing the intercompany agreements between former Ivar Kreuger interests.

LAKEHURST, N.J., July 13. -- The zeppelin Hindenburg landed here at 7:46 o'clock this morning, completing her ninth crossing of the North Atlantic in the last two months. On board were fifty passengers and a small cargo of mail and express.

A Democratic sweep in the nation and a big plurality for President Roosevelt in this State, now claimed by the Republicans, was forecast by Postmaster General James A. Farley, head of the Roosevelt forces, in his first interview, given at Democratic national headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore since the Philadelphia convention.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 13. -- Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, lashed out tonight at "alarmists and propagandists" who, he charged, "have tried for their own purpose to scare the consumer about food scarcity" as a result of the drought.
