WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Despite apparently growing doubt concerning the story by a young woman who gave her name as Margaret Louise Bell, alias Jean Costello, alias Jean Arnold, police today pressed their investigation of her assertions that a man invaded her apartment early yesterday morning, branded her and turned on the gas in an attempt to kill her.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 13. -- In a combination of a light northerly air, a calm and a southwest breeze, the America's Cup defender Rainbow set a pace today for the Eastern Yacht Club fleet on the run to Fort Pond Bay from Block Island.

The State of Maine will consider tenders tomorrow for a new issue of $1,000,000 of three-month temporary notes. The notes will be dated July 15 and become payable on Oct. 13, 1936. They will be issued in anticipation of the sale of longer-term bonds.

The current discussion of the new Federal taxes deals with the obvious. The real trouble is, of course, fundamental. Under the excise power corporations may be taxed to destruction. But under the income tax power Congress is supposed to tax income, not gross receipts -- real income on some reasonable basis, not factors of income.

Insisting that no charge had been proved and his client needed no defense, State Senator John J. McNaboe rested the case of Patrolman George A. Heidt of the Elizabeth Street station yesterday afternoon without calling him to the stand.

LONDON, July 13. -- Official confirmation of the fortnight-old report that Germany is kicking another hole in the Versailles Treaty by refortifying Helgoland was received in the House of Commons today without arousing the slightest interest.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Data filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the F.W. Woolworth Company, which were made public today, showed that in 1935 bonuses paid to eighteen officials aggregated $1,186,053. The highest to any individual was $309,880, received by B.D. Miller as a director and a member of the executive committee.

NEWARK, N.J., July 13. -- Former Ambassador Walter E. Edge accepted today the chairmanship of the Landon-Knox Campaign Committee for New Jersey, "on his own terms," which were that a small committee be in charge.
PARIS, July 13. -- Bastille Day began tonight with a torchlight procession round the City Hall district of Paris in anticipation of all-day parading tomorrow.

LONDON, July 13. -- The death of Dr. S. Parkes Cadman was mourned today by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York. his "friend and comrade for more than a generation.'' Recalling that Dr. Cadman had often spoken from the pulpit of the Free Synagogue, Dr. Wise said:

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 13. -- Shooting a 78, Mrs. Frederick Davis won medalist honors for the second year in succession in the qualifying round of the eighteenth annual women's invitation tournament over the Shenecossett course for the Griswold Cup.

Negro athletes furnished the biggest headlines for the Olympic tryouts on Randalls Island. They hewed to the line and let the world's records fall where they may. JESSE OWENS pursued the even tenor of his ways by qualifying for three events at Berlin. Two colored lads jumped higher in the air than men probably ever have jumped wholly unassisted.

THe lobby, the corridors, the elevators and the rooms of the Hotel Lincoln were swarming with athletes, coaches and officials of the Olympic team. Joe McCluskey, the black-haired steeplechaser and prominent Fordham alumnus, came along looking for Jake Weber, the veteran Maroon trainer, who is getting ready to make his fifth Olympic trip. McCluskey disappeared and along came Jake Weber, asking whether or not any one had seen McCluskey.

The letter from President CHURCH of the Carnegie Institute, published in yesterday's TIMES and setting forth the dilemma in which managers of large fiduciary funds have been placed by the investment market's course, touched on a problem with which all investors, great or small, are nowadays confronted.

WRIGHTSTOWN, N.J., July 13. -- To the tune of "Happy Heinie," regimental march of the Eighteenth Infantry, 1,500 youths from the metropolitan area of New York and Northern New Jersey detrained at Camp Dix this morning for the largest citizens' military training camp in the Second Corps Area.

A steady to firm undertone characterized routine trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trend among the lower-priced and more speculative issues was toward moderately higher levels, while the higher-grade investment issues held exceptionally firm in dull trading. Total transactions in the listed market yesterday were $10,389,700, compared with $10,966,900 on last Friday.

New Yorkers rolled down their sleeves, put on their coats and even turned off their electric fans for a few hours yesterday as falling temperatures gave the East a brief respite from the heat wave that has been baking a large area of the nation.

LINCOLN, July 13. -- Nebraska's corn crop, third largest in the nation, is slipping fast. Already an estimated 25 per cent of the crop has fallen victim to drought and burning temperatures, grasshoppers and cutworm. The next fortnight will determine whether there will have to be another "pig killing contest" in this State.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Despite efforts to speed up the navy's building program, work on forty-nine of the seventy-nine warships now under construction is behind schedule, the department disclosed tonight.

MOSCOW, July 13. -- The Austro-German agreement produced little surprise and less applause here. Somewhat sourly the Russians have come to recognize that one of the worst things about Chancellor Adolf Hitler is that he goes ahead steadily with his program, outlined in his book, "Mein Kampf."
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- A new test of the law of 1933 nullifying promises of payment in gold in contracts was sought today in the Supreme Court by the Holyoke Water Power Company of Holyoke, Mass.

With as much fanfare as attends a transatlantic sailing, but with none of the promptness, the municipal ferryboat Queens pulled out of Slip 3 at the foot of Whitehall Street yesterday on the first of twenty-eight trips that during the rest of the Summer will provide 40,000 women and children with a brief escape from the heat of the city streets and sweltering tenements.

An East Side business building purchase by John Thomas Smith, vice president of the General Motors Corporation, was reported yesterday. The structure, a twenty-three-story building at 180 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-fourth Street, was acquired from the Belcort Realty Corporation, representing the Belding Heminway Company, a silk firm. Mr.

Edward J. Worth, former deputy fire chief, who was in charge of the, city's fleet of fireboats from 1913 to his retirement in 1929, died yesterday of pneumonia at Parsons Hospital, Flushing. He was 74 years old.

Informed that National Youth Administration funds for vocational education in this State would be doubled next year and that the amount to be received by the city would be $492,000, Board of Education officials began to consider yesterday the revision and expansion of its program of job training in the city schools.

WINNIPEG, July 13 (Canadian Press). -- Heavy thunder showers scattered throughout South-Central Manitoba brought relief tonight from a nine-day wave of torrid temperatures. Cooler weather had come previously to Alberta and Saskatchewan.

The Port of New York Authority was host to more than 100 members of the Association of Chosen Freeholders of New Jersey yesterday at an inspection of the new Hudson Midtown Tunnel and the Weehawken Plaza. The Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue, where the Port Authority's executive activities are housed, and the George Washington Bridge also were visited.

Following profit-taking at the close of last week, a further decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange occurred yesterday, and the list ended with losses of 7 to 14 points. At one time quotations were off about 30 points from recent highs but below 12 1/2 cents a pound for October, selling pressure lifted, the market developed resistance and the list rallied sharply $1 a bale under covering by room traders.

A picturesque ceremony was held yesterday afternoon on the after sundeck of the French liner Normandie as she steamed up the harbor from Quarantine. It was part of a dual celebration connected with Bastille Day, July 14, and the commemoration of the fiftieth year that the Statue of Liberty has stood in the harbor.

Headed by Baron Gottfried von Cramm, a powerful delegation of German tennis players will compete in the United States tennis championships this Summer, it was announced yesterday through the United States Lawn Tennis Association by Walter Merrill Hall, president.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 (AP). -- Tiny Jim Chaplin pitched the Bees to their fifth straight victory and second successive conquest of the Pirates today. The score was 4 to 1. Chaplin, celebrating his twenty-ninth birthday, allowed the Bucs only six hits.

Bookkeeping for a whole nation is an ambitious task, but once a year the Department of Commerce publishes a report which serves in effect as a national ledger of the American people. Here are carefully prepared estimates of the total "income produced" in the United States in the form of goods and services, and of the total "income paid out" in the form of wages, salaries, interest, dividends and profits.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13. -- A birdie 3 on the final hole proved the margin of victory for Mrs. Sylva Annenberg and Ivan Annenberg over Mrs. W.G. Dyer and T. Suffern Tailer Jr. today in the eighth annual sister and brother Scotch foursome tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at Bonnie Briar Country Club.

Seven tired and begrimed youngsters trudged four miles from their homes to the Summer City Hall yesterday to ask Mayor La Guardia for a playground in their section of the Bronx and found their wish gratified as if Aladdin had rubbed his legendary lamp.

Although stocks closed irregularly higher yesterday, the market failed to exhibit the buoyancy that characterized the closing sessions of last week. Railway and farm-equipment shares led the improvement as the news over the week-end pointed to relief from crop-killing temperatures, if not the actual breaking of the drought.

BOSTON, July 13. -- Continuing where his stablemate, Time Supply, left off Saturday, Frank A. Carreaud's Mr. Pete won the Cambridge Purse, mile and a sixteenth claiming feature, beating B.N. Kane's Sand Baby by a neck before a crowd of 15,000 at Suffolk Downs today.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 13. -- Thirty-two players started competition today at the Amackassin Club in the annual Eastern junior girls' tennis tournament. Miss Patricia Cumming of Westfield, N.J., fourth ranking girl player in the country, lost only one game while she was disposing of two opponents.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Indians continued their heavy batting today as they pounded out seventeen hits, five of them for extra bases, and defeated the Red Sox 11 -- 3 for their third straight victor.

Age as well as youth was served as upsets cut the seeded list in half in the first day's play of the tenth annual national professional championship conducted by the Professional Lawn Tennis Association of the United States at the Tudor City Club yesterday.

Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd values his court room services in the Samuel Drukman murder case at $600 a day, and his grand jury appearances at $400 a day, he disclosed yesterday in presenting to the city his bill for $71,023 as his personal fee.

SEATTLE, July 13 (AP). -- Marion A. Zioncheck, Washington's capering Representative, told his constituents tonight he "had a feeling he was on exhibit," but that he was "exhibit No. 1, if you please."
QUEBEC, July 13. -- President Roosevelt will receive honors usually reserved for royalty when he arrives in Quebec on July 31 to spend the day as the guest of Lord Tweedsmuir, the Governor General.

In its first test in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, the National Labor Relations Act was upheld here yesterday, three judges unanimously deciding that Congress had not exceeded its powers in passing the law.

Two panels of 100 each will be drawn this morning for the extraordinary grand juries that on Aug. 5 are to take up further phases of the rackets and vice inquiries pursued by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey. The present grand jury will be dismissed at that time.

DICK RUSSELL, the Young Hope of Georgia Democrats, is serving out the unexpired term of the late Senator HARRIS. He is now seeking a second term. Since his opponent, Governor TALMADGE, seems a nearly "extinct volcano," the Senator is hardly called upon for any extraordinary exertion; but he is a born speech-maker.

The plight of German emigre publishers and authors in flight from Nazi persecution was described as tragic and "fantastic beyond belief'' by Mrs. Alfred A. Knopf yesterday when she arrived from Europe aboard the French liner Normandie.
DUBLIN, Ireland, July 13. -- Orange drums boomed all over Northern Ireland today as 60,000 Orangemen held their annual demonstrations in commemoration of King William's victory at the Boyne.

Prices of commodity futures were generally lower yesterday in quiet trading. Coffee futures were erratic. In the cash markets, oats, silk, butter and tins were higher, while wheat, corn, rye, refined sugar, lard, cotton, hides and rubber were lower.

ALBANY, July 13. -- Two obstacles face those trying to put Representative Lemke on the ballot in Illinois, according to the Illinois Secretary of State, Edward J. Hughes, who told the annual convention of Secretaries of State today that an attempt was being made by a group of Illinois voters to file a slate of candidates for a Union party unrelated to the Lemke group.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 13. -- A tour through the regions of the East which suffered from disastrous floods last March was planned by President Roosevelt today as he held a special conference, designed to spur action on preventive measures, with representatives of flood-control organizations in New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Ohio and adjacent States.
With Mayor La Guardia and the Republican leaders of New York City again at odds on the nomination of a candidate for Aldermanic President, major developments in the negotiations are expected today.
The suggestion of the Citizens Budget Commission that students of the three city colleges be required to pay an annual tuition fee of $75 drew Mayor La Guardia's wrath yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has obtained an agreement with the Sioux City Gas and Electric Company under which substantial changes, intended further to safeguard investors, have been made in the indentures of $9,000,000 of 4 per cent first-mortgage bonds and $1,500,000 of serial debentures that the company proposes to issue.

The pace of initial Fall buying activity in the women's apparel and allied markets became more active yesterday. More store representatives were here and the "number-taking" in dress and coat showrooms last week began to give way to actual order-placing.

Efforts of national maritime labor leaders to patch up difficulties between rival groups of leaders in the marine cooks' and stewards' field were described in affidavits filed yesterday in Supreme Court in the suit brought against David E. Grange, president of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union by a group of union members.

DETROIT, July 13 (AP). -- Michigan, sweltering in a heat wave more prolonged than any in its history, counted 393 deaths tonight attributed directly or indirectly to the six-day siege of 100-degree weather.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- With the zero hour for action by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor on the craft- industrial union dispute close at hand, indications tonight were that when discussion of the issue opens at tomorrow afternoon's meeting the eight members of the Committee for Industrial Organization summoned to appear will have ignored the summons.

VIENNA, July 13. -- The Austro-German agreement, it was ascertained today, is in two parts. The first, a brief official protocol signed by the two Chancellors, was broadcast. A further agreement dealing with every item of vital importance is certain never to be published, as it undoubtedly contains many secret clauses.

After congratulating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation yesterday on its new policy of lowered interest rates, Mayor La Guardia asked the RFC to cut the rate on $90,000,000 of city securities it holds from 4 to 3 per cent.
PARIS, July 13. -- Ambassador Vittorio Ceruti of Italy visited the French Foreign Office today to "explain" Italy's part in the Austro-German accord.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 13. -- Democracy in the United States today is endangered not by invasions of its basic rights of a free press and of free speech, nor by actual or threatened violations of constitutional principles and guarantees, nor even in a depression period by any actual inability to supply adequately the needs of the people, according to addresses delivered today before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 13. -- To the many translations, adaptations and general rearrangements which have already been made of Jules Romain's favorite French comedy, "Dr. Knock," add that by Lawrence Langner and Armina Marshall, which had its initial showing here this evening at Mr. Langner's breezy country playhouse.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Grain prices fluctuated in a nervous and erratic manner throughout the day reflecting the conflicting weather and crop reports. Weakness in Liverpool and reports of additional moisture in the Mountain States over the week-end caused a break of around 3 cents a bushel in wheat in the early business on the Board of Trade, with September at one time 9 cents below the high price of last week.

AMSTERDAM, July 13. -- Sir Henri Deterding, head of the Royal Dutch Shell Oil Company, received a rousing tribute today from several thousand of his Netherland employes and from hundreds of representatives of the company from eighteen European countries in connection with his recent seventieth birthday and his forty years of activity with the concern.
ROME, July 13. -- Italian troop ships steamed away from Libya tonight, carrying the first units of 40,000 troops home from the Egyptian frontier.

ROCHESTER, Pa., July 13. -- Governor Earle, renewing his campaign against Republican State Senators in their home districts, said here tonight that the Republican Senate majority "never had any intention of providing relief funds at all."
CHICHESTER, Sussex, England, July 13. -- James Bunting was under sentence of virtual excommunication from the Church of England today for failure to "honor thy father and thy mother."

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 13. -- After going scoreless for three straight periods, the Meadow Brook Ramblers regained their stride in an overtime session to conquer the Burnt Mills quartet, 7 to 6, in a first-round match of the national junior championship at the Burnt Mills Polo Club today.

Consolidated net income of the Gillette Safety Razor Company for the first half of this year, as announced yesterday, amounted to $2,234,817 after taxes and charges, equivalent to $7.21 a share of preference stock, and after preference dividend requirements for the period, to 73 cents each on the common stock.

George D. Widener's Sation, one of the greatest sprinters in the country, showed yesterday that he was back at his peak when he picked up top weight of 135 pounds and scored an easy victory in the featured Lenox Handicap at about six furlongs at Empire City.

LONDON, July 13. -- A tiny silverpoint drawing by Dirk Kouts, considered one of the finest and bestpreserved of the fifteenth century Flemish school, brought the top price of 4,200 at the second session of the Oppenheimer sale at Christie's today. Colnaghi Co. of Bond Street, the purchaser, outbidded M. Knoedler Co. of New York in one of the most exciting duels of the auction.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- A broader pattern of life for America's feminine wage earners was advocated tonight by Miss Charl Ormond Williams in her presidential address before the seventeenth annual board meeting of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

Narragansett Racing Association An offering of 140,000 shares of common stock, $1 par value, of the Narragansett Racing Association, Inc., will be placed on the market today by August Belmont Co. and Watson White at $8.75 a share. The offering does not con stitute new financing but consists of a part of the holdings of majority stockholders of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- To conform with the amendment to Section 15 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 passed by the last Congress, the Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted Rule 730 dealing with the requirement that, on or after Aug. 26, every registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 shall contain an undertaking by the issuer to file supplementary and periodic information as prescribed by the commission.

After starting with an advance sale of about 1,600 copies, of which 250 went to one store, Thomas Mann's "Stories of Three Decades" now is averaging a sale of 1,000 copies a week, Alfred A. Knopf reports. The book was published a little more than a month ago.

Taking his cue from Frank Parker, to whom he lost in the final at Spring Lake on Sunday, Robert Riggs of California started his quest for the Eastern clay court championship in steam-roller fashion yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

TOPEKA, July 13. -- The Republican program for restoring foreign trade and alleviating the farmers' ills, and ideas on currency stabilization were discussed for three hours today with Governor Alf M. Landon by George N. Peek, former AAA Administrator and former head of the Export-Import Bank.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- A protest against a move by the Tennessee Valley Authority to compel the Southern Railway to abandon its eleven-mile branch between Vasper and La Follette, Tenn., was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by Campbell County and the city of La Follette, Tenn.

Mayor La Guardia, whose favorite method of transportation is by airplane, utilized the "bathtub" or sidecar of a motorcycle policeman for a quick trip downtown from the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park yesterday afternoon, when his big official limousine was laid up for a few hours for adjustment of its police radio.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of 27,392 additional shares of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, to be issued in connection with the acquisition of the minority interest in Colonial Beacon Oil Company. The latter company's shares are to be acquired on the basis of one share of Standard Oil capital stock for each two and one-fourth shares of Colonial Beacon.
VERDUN, France, July 13. -- Heavy rain all through the day prevented the Peace Pilgrims of fourteen nations from meeting in the meadow outside this city today to swear collectively the oath of peace.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Seeking lower interest rates through a big refinancing move, the Commodity Credit Corporation announced today that it would sell $150,000,000 of one-half of 1 per cent collateral-trust notes maturing on Jan. 15 and backed by collateral notes which in turn are secured by commodities having an approximate market value of $218,000,000, or about 140 per cent of the total issue.

To its Manhattan Theatre the WPA tonight brings "Help Yourself!" The fourth offering of the popular-price unit, it is a farce comedy derived by John J. Coman from the Viennese original by Paul Vulpius, and in its cast are Curt Bois, Edward Forbes, George Le Soir, Camelia Campbell and Stephen Courtleigh.

OMAHA, July 14 (AP). -- Billy Cordingley, 18-year-old Des Moines youth, slugged his way over the Happy Hollow Club course in 68 strokes today to top the field in the first half of the 36-hole qualifying round for the Western amateur golf title.

Officials of interfaith groups will be seated in reserved pews at Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, this morning at the funeral of the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman. Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist area will preach.

BOSTON, July 14. -- Repeatedly shaking off challengers over the whole route, Gallant Prince, stout-hearted son of Gallant Fox, ran the fastest mile of the New England season when he spun that distance in 1:37 2-5 in the Middlesex County Handicap, feature of today's Suffolk Downs card before 14,000 spectators.

CRUISING WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT OFF THE COAST OF MAINE, July 14. -- After an absence of three years President Roosevelt today cast off the lines of official responsibility and returned to the first love of his boyhood, the role of skipper of a sturdy boat, for two weeks of aimless cruising in the waters of the North Atlantic.

Lone survivor of the seeded list, Charles M. Wood Jr. of the Somerset Hills Country Club, first-ranked, swept through two opponents yesterday to become the first occupant of a final-round berth in the tenth annual national professional tennis championship at the Tudor City Tennis Club.

TOKYO, July 14. -- An armament program spread over twelve years and requiring an expenditure of 3,000,000,000 yen (about $882,000,O00) in the first six years, is the main feature of army proposals submitted to the Cabinet today as part of the national administrative renovation plans.

While Bastille Day was being celebrated throughout France yesterday, a two-day observation of the 147th anniversary of French freedom came to a close on Bedloes Island in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty. The event was held in conjunction with the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of France's great gift to the United States.
Mayor La Guardia found conditions in the city dispensaries "discouraging" yesterday after visiting two of them on his way to the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park.
LONDON, July 14. -- The goal of a perfect gas mask for every man, woman and child in Britain came nearer realization today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 14. -President Roosevelt's commission headed by Jacob Baker, former Assistant WPA Administrator, has arrived here from England for a study of Sweden's cooperatives.
A letter in THE TIMES, from Thomas H. Greene, regarding war debts repeats many of the commonly accepted errors on this subject.

Price movements on the local commodity futures markets were irregular yesterday, with the volume of trading off. On the cash markets cotton and printcloths advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, lard, butter, eggs, rubber and Straits tin declined.
Auctioneers conducted seven foreclosure sales of real estate in Manhattan yesterday. All the properties were bought in by the plaintiffs and one sale was adjourned sine die.

Interpretations of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act by private interests cannot be employed legitimately at this time as an excuse "to upset traditional, normal and above-board methods of doing business," Irving C. Fox, Washington counsel of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday at a meeting of the toilet goods and cosmetic group of the merchandising division of the association in Gimbel Brothers' restaurant.

The estate of Mrs. Alice Gwynne Vanderbilt, widow of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, who died on April 22, 1934, will pay a transfer tax of $1,335,812.19, according to an order signed yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley, fixing the tax.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- The market here for hogs was unsettled today, and while the better grade of 175 to 250 pound weights was 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, other kinds were generally unchanged. The top was down 15 cents, at $10.35, while the day's average was unchanged, at $9.15.
F.S. Yantis Co. of Chicago reported yesterday an over-subscription to 111,666 common shares and $340,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Consolidated Biscuit Company.

Plans to swing the votes controlled by 1,000,000 organized workers in New York State for President Roosevelt in November will be discussed tomorrow morning at the first meeting of the New York committee of Labor's Nonpartisan League at the Hotel New Yorker.

MOSCOW, July 14. -- The first editorial comment on the Austro-German agreement appears in Izvestia today in an article by Karl Radek entitled "German Preparations." The article follows the lines indicated in these columns yesterday, with the important addition that Mr. Radek links it closely with the future status of Danzig.
Investment buying comprised most of yesterday's realty activity in Manhattan.

Continuation of the drought in various sections of the country has not affected, as yet, the advertising and promotional plans of large national advertisers, according to comment by their officials and agency executives yesterday. Since most campaigns are based on the sale of goods in those particular sections and since there has been little curtailment in orders, advertisers will go ahead with their present plans, which have been somewhat reduced, in line with Summer schedules.

CLEVELAND, July 14. -- A lot of nice old ladies and kindly faced old gentlemen gathered here today to fight for a comfortable old age of leisure at public expense and in the meantime to economize as much as possible. They were the followers of Dr. Francis E. Townsend assembled here for the second annual convention of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd.
THERE'S time for one last look before the good ship Manhattan weighs anchor and goes outward bound with our Olympic team.
PARIS, July 14 (AP). -- The Bourse and foreign exchange markets were closed today, Bastille Day.

Italians in lower Harlem, joined by fellow-countrymen from all parts of the metropolitan district, will begin today a three-day celebration of the Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel. The actual feast day is Thursday.

Top weight of the field and an outsider in the betting, the filly Patsey Begone, nevertheless, made her opposition look weak when she captured the Marigold Purse, feature at Empire City yesterday in a blanket finish.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 14. -- Ten tugboats pushed the giant liner Queen Mary into drydock tonight for an engineering overhaul that will extend almost from the tips of her funnels to the propellers.

The main body of listed bonds was responsive to a broad demand yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with virtually all classes of domestic issues, including secondary as well as high-grade investments, participating in the general upswing.

Two men were arrested here yesterday afternoon in connection with the alleged attack on a young woman in Washington and questioned for many hours. They will go to Washington this morning in company of detectives from that city.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP). -- The second place Tigers lost an opportunity to gain on the league-leading Yankees today, falling before the Athletics, 10 to 2. Detroit now is nine games behind the New Yorkers, who were idle today.

The almost perpendicular rise of the stock market during the last six trading sessions is being used as political capital by both Democrats and Republicans in Wall Street. The Republicans interpret it as presaging the election of Governor Landon; the Democrats hold that this interpretation is completely illogical, since any rise in the stock market before election day should improve the chances of the party in power.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 14. -- Justice Patterson in Supreme Court here denied today an application by Westchester County Treasurer William Coffey for an injunction restraining Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Corporation and Rosta Theatres Corporation from exhibiting the film "The Great Ziegfeld."

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 14. -- A sudden reversal of policy in London threw the Dardanelles Conference into an Anglo-Russian deadlock again this evening after it had been purring along all day toward the signing of a convention on Friday or Saturday.

NEWARK, N.J., July 14. -- The Federal grand jury for New Jersey prepared today to act on the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, disbarred Trenton attorney, provided the United States Attorney General's office finds that the jury has the jurisdiction to do so.

When drought strikes an area, the toll taken is widespread. It is no surprise, therefore, that the United States Bureau of Biological Survey describes the waterfowl situation in the drought-stricken sections, especially the Dakotas, as "critical."

Since the States in the Food Belt continue to be of essential political importance this year, the final position of George N. Peek is a matter of real political consequence. With characteristic caution, after conferring with Governor Landon at Topeka, the President's former Special Adviser on Foreign Trade, and what not else, has declined to proclaim his affiliation, preferring to await the candidate's speech of acceptance.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor agreed today to take definite action tomorrow in the case of the eight unions comprising the Committee on Industrial Organization, it was announced by William Green, president of the federation.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Colonel Bill Terry gave his line-up a vigorous shake-up today, but the results were negative. Dick Bartell was benched and Hank Leiber was back at his old station in center. But in any guise, it seems, the Giants are still the Giants, at least as far as the Cubs are concerned.

Copies of the May issue of Current History magazine have been confiscated by postoffice authorities in Kobe, Japan, presumably because of articles in that issue relating to Japanese affairs, it was learned yesterday.

The Long Island Railroad gave up temporarily its fight to continue the 3-cents-a-mile rate by announcing last night that beginning Saturday midnight it would charge single-trip riders in Nassau and Suffolk Counties 2 cents a mile.

LONDON, July 14. -- An attempt to bring both Germany and Italy into the proposed conference of Locarno powers will be begun in earnest tomorrow when Anthony Eden returns to London after a badly needed rest in Yorkshire. The young Foreign Secretary is said to be greatly improved in health and ready once more to tackle his discouraging and difficult task.

Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has agreed to accept from Paramount Pictures, Inc., a fee of $50,000 for his services in May and June in drafting a report suggesting methods for placing its picture production department on a more profitable basis, it was learned yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Philip Dater, whose marriage took place in New York in June, have arrived to spend the rest of the Summer with Mr. Dater's mother, Mrs. Henry Dater, who has the Spalding Estate. Mrs. Dater has sent out invitations for a party on July 26th in honor of her son and his bride.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 14. -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club carded a fine 83 to win the low gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association in a field of 88 starters over her home links today.

High military officials and other notables attended last night a service in memory of Quentin Roosevelt, youngest son of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, and in honor of his mother, on the eighteenth anniversary of young Roosevelt's death in action in France, where he was an American Army aviator.
New York City showed substantial results in its safety campaign the first six months of this year, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday through his safety bureau.

PARIS, July 14. -- This national day of celebration of the capture of the Bastille by a Paris mob and the beginning of liberty and democracy, not only here but in Europe, has been no ritual today. From start to finish it has been intense and vital.

All cash over a first mortgage of $103,000 was paid by Harry Ratner in purchasing the new four-story apartment house at 848 East Twenty-eighth Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. There are fifty-two apartments in the house, which occupies a plot 150 by 100 feet opposite the new Brooklyn College campus.

Ten indictments were on file yesterday in the office of the clerk of the United States District Court against six men who, as representatives of the famous Ringling brothers, are accused in more than 100 counts of willfully defrauding the government of $3,359,016.48 in income taxes for circus enterprises over a period of fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Resumption here today of the hearings in connection with charges of manipulating activities in the stock of the A.O. Smith Corporation on the New York Curb Exchange by White, Weld Co. and others was marked by new requests from the respondents that the proceedings be dismissed as violative of the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution and because the order of the Securities and Exchange Commission was arbitrary and unreasonable.

Pequot Mills, Salem, Mass., among the largest manufacturers of wide sheetings, sheets and pillow cases in the country, will establish their own selling organization on Oct. 1, Rudolph C. Dick, treasurer and general manager, said yesterday. For many years the company's products have been sold through Parker, Wilder Co. of this city.

Mayor La Guardia formally opened the new Highbridge swimming and wading pools in highbridge Park at 174th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, before a crowd of more than 4,000 last night. About 1,000 more who were unable to obtain admission to the seats surrounding the pool watched the proceedings through the iron railings.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Raw cotton exports from the United States to Japan in June fell 65,000 bales in volume and $3,803,000 in value below the exports of May, and 58,000 bales and $4,291,000 below the exports of June of last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Traffic over the Triborough Bridge maintained an average of more than 1,000 vehicles an hour during the first weekday since the span was opened, official figures showed yesterday. Up to 8 A.M. yesterday 116,463 cars, trucks and buses had used the new bridge.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP). -- Victorious Ann, racing in the colors of the Calumet Farm, owned by Warren Wright of Chicago, made her first appearance at Arlington Park today since last year and won the feature race at six furlongs by a length and a quarter.

Deep appreciation for the work done by Victor F. Ridder as Works Progress Administrator for New York City is expressed by President Roosevelt in his letter accepting Mr. Ridder's resignation, effective Aug. 1. The President's letter and Mr. Ridder's letter of resignation were made public here yesterday by the WPA officer.

A candy store at 176 East 101st Street, where the pennies of school children were ostensibly welcome, was revealed yesterday as the headquarters of a large-scale narcotic seller with the arraignment of a woman and two youths on charges of selling and transporting heroin.

A telegram from Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for President, was received last night by the First Voters League, at an organization meeting held at 400 Madison Avenue. Another telegram, voicing congratulations, was received from Kenneth M. Simpson, Republican leader of New York County.
BERLIN, July 14. -- The conference of Locarno powers planned at Geneva to take place in Brussels toward the end of July now seems likely to be held, if at all, late in August or early in September.

LONDON, July 14. -- After a quiet opening, operations on the London Stock Exchange became more active today. British funds were mostly better in price and European issues recovered further in the foreign market.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 14. -- The Roslyn team, scheduled to face the Hurricanes tomorrow in the initial semi-final of the annual junior polo championship at Bedminster, N.J., has defaulted to Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's side.

BOSTON, July 14 (AP). -- The Indians knocked the Red Sox out of the American League first division today by clubbing out a 5-to-1 decision behind the combined three-hit pitching of Oral Hildebrand and Denny Galehouse.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14. -- Dr. and Mrs. George Bolling Lee held a launching party today as their motor cruising yacht took the water here. Miss Julia A. Berwind broke a bottle of champagne against the vessel's bow to christen her Sea Rocket.

Friends of Carl von Ossietzky, the well-known German publicist and former editor of the anti-militarist weekly Weltbuehne, received word here yesterday from a reliable German source that he was seriously ill in a Berlin hospital. His illness, ascribed to conditions in the Pappenburg concentration camp where he had been interned since the Spring of 1933, was described as alarming because no adequate medical care was provided for him.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 14. -- Lightning struck the twenty-room English-style manor home of Carl H. Pforzheimer, New York broker, on his 400-acre estate here tonight, causing a fire that resulted in damages estimated at $100,000.

BERLIN, July 14. -- Trading on the Boerse was hesitant, and prices were irregular at the opening today, but firmness developed and the closing was marked by a spurt of strength. Financial commentators attributed the improvement to the satisfactory subscriptions to the new government loan and to prospects of expansion of Austro-German trade.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 14. -- Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Nationalist party, went on trial today with seven other persons, accused of conspiracy to overthrow the United States Government in Puerto Rico.

Taken to the West 123d Street police station under arrest, together with thirty-seven Negroes, Albert Martinet, a white man, shouted defiently: "I don't want to be an American citizen, you don't get enough relief," according to the police.

EASTERN POINT, CONN., July 14. -- The opening day of match play in the 18th annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Cup at the Shenecossett Golf Club today brought about the defeat of one of the 1935 semi-finalists, Miss Virginia Bascom of Worcester.
District Attorney Geoghan of Brooklyn may seek an extension of time in which to prepare his answer to the Drukman special grand jury's charges seeking his removal from office, he indicated yesterday.
As a New Yorker I was delighted to get THE TIMES of June 27 and enjoyed particularly the letter entitled "Noisy Again."

LAKEHURST, N.J., Wednesday, July 15. -- The airship Hindenburg, with fifty-seven passengers and a crew of fifty-four plus more than a ton of mail, baggage and express, sailed from the naval air station here at 12:04: o'clock this morning. She set her nose into a series of thunderstorms and began droning her way to her home port at Frankfort -on-the-Main, Germany, more than 4,000 miles away.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 14 (Canadian Press ). -- Canadian marksmen today continued their good showing in individual competitions in the National Rifle Association's seventy-third annual Empire meeting as Guardsman D.S. Fraser of Ottawa tied with two others for first place in the qualifying stage for the prized St. George's challenge vase.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The indictment of five corporations and twenty-one persons for alleged violation of provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Postal Fraud Laws by a Federal grand jury in Gainesville, Ga., was announced today by John J. Burns, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ST. PAUL, July 14 (AP) -- Alvin Karpis, once the most sought criminal in the nation who had boasted he would never be taken alive, muttered a subdued "yes" today to admit his guilt in the kidnapping in June, 1933, of William Hamm, St. Paul brewer, who paid $100,000 ransom for release.

The Citizens Budget Commission proposes a $75 tuition fee for students attending Hunter, City and Brooklyn Colleges. One of the arguments for the proposed movement is a comparison with the colleges in Charleston, Louisville, Cincinnati, Toledo, Akron, Detroit, Wichita and Omaha.

A new peak in the number of buyers registered in the market during the present buying season was established during the week ended yesterday. The total was the highest since the week of Jan. 29, 1930, when 1.448 arrivals were reported, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Maine, which will elect members of the House and Senate and State and county officers on Sept. 14, will go Republican, Representative Chester C. Bolton, chairman of the Republican Congress Campaign Committee, declared today.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP). -- Woody Jensen's homer with one on and Mace Brown's four-hit pitching job combined today to give the Pirates a 2-to-1 victory over the Bees for their first victory in four starts.

The Lehn Fink Products Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $286,616 after provision for Federal income taxes and undistributed profits. This was equal to 71 cents a share on 400,000 shares of common stock.

The discovery in the Athenian agora, or market place, of a priceless ivory statuette identified with the fourth century, B.C., was related yesterday by Professor T. Leslie Shear of Princeton University, who returned from Athens at the end of his sixth year as field director for the American School of Classical Studies.

An outstanding characteristic of Miss CARY'S critical approach to art was its unfailing kindliness. In commenting upon exhibitions or individual works of art she strove always -- yet apparently without effort -- to discover their best aspect. Those who knew her well will remember that often in conversation she would be very frank and sometimes delightfully caustic about the sort of thing or the specific thing in art that she did not like.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- In a program designed to promote stability and avert the danger of injurious credit expansion of an inflationary character, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System announced today that substantial increases in the reserve requirements of member banks would become effective Aug. 15.

The shipyards of the world were angaged in the construction of 1,951,005 tons at the end of June, an increase of 130,891 tons for a period of three months, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,947,700 barrels, compared with 2,892,300 in the preceding week, a rise of 55,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 37,850 and of 17,600 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and California accounted for the increase.

LONDON, July 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of June: Total imports, 67,640,000; exports of British products, 32,060,000; re-exports, 5,000,000; total exports, 37,060,000; excess of imports, 30,580,000.
New York and the East, refreshed by heavy rainfalls early last night, will enjoy today the coolest weather of the last seven days, Weather Bureau officials predicted.

ST. PAUL, July 14. -- Another heavy day of death and a revision of records set Minnesota's heat-wave fatality list tonight at 560. It was a new high figure for any State, topping even Michigan's toll.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- The forecast of a break in the heat wave over the main Grain Belt more than offset sensational reports of crop deterioration in the Canadian Northwest and in the United States Corn Belt States, and prices of grains declined today on the Board of Trade.

A number of diplomats are sailing today for Europe on the French liner Normandie. Among them are Constantin Fotitch, Yugoslav Minister to the United States; Marc Peter, Swiss Minister Plenipotentiary; Baron Paul Schell, Secretary of the Hungarian Legation, and Nicolas Khalil Bey, Secretary of the Egyptian Legation.

In the presence of three justices of the Supreme Court, 200 names were drawn yesterday in the Hall of Records for the selection on Aug. 5 of the two extraordinary grand juries that will continue the racket and vice investigations in New York County.

The American team will sail for Berlin and the Eleventh Olympic Games at noon today on the United States liner Manhattan without a single athlete stranded because of lack of funds. A twenty-four hour pursuit of the elusive dollar culminated in success last night as all teams reported themselves completely financed and ready to go.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The government has decided not to attempt an immediate appeal to the Supreme Court of a ruling by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here which held unconstitutional the provisions of the Federal Emergency Appropriations Act of 1935 that set up the Resettlement Administration, Assistant Attorney General Harry W. Blair announced today.

Dr. Rubin Klein, 39 years old, of 92 Humboldt Street, Brooklyn, who was arrested in his office last Friday in the investigation of Assistant District Attorney Bernard Botein, head of the new Accident Frauds Bureau, was indicted yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP). -- The Phillies evened the series with the Reds at two-all today, staging a three-run rally in the ninth inning of a free-hitting contest to win, 9 to 8, before 747 sweltering fans.

The Equity Corporation reported net assets on June 30 equal to about $2.10 a share on common stock after deductions for outstanding assumed debentures and preferred stock and accrued dividends thereon. This compared with $1.58 on Dec. 31.

Showing marked confidence in Fall trade prospects and actively interested in better grade merchandise, buyers representing department, specialty and other types of stores throughout the country arrived in the wholesale markets here yesterday in the largest numbers for any single day in more than six years, according to the buyers' arrivals list published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 14. -- A commission of five men, appointed today by Governor Lehman, made an examination of the mental and physical condition of Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, who is scheduled to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing on Thursday night, at the prison here this afternoon.

Melvin Lapman, top-seeded player, went a round ahead of the field yesterday as he gained the quarter-final bracket in the Eastern junior singles championship tournament on the clay courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. The St. John's University freshman star advanced at the expense of William Reiff of Brooklyn, winning in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6.

The sixth printing of "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell, making a total of 140,000 copies to date, is being rushed through the press, Macmillan reports, and orders will be filled this week. Motion picture rights to this novel have been sold to Selznick International Pictures, Inc.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to advance yesterday morning until the October was around 12 3/4 cents a pound and within a few points of its recent high record. Then the demand tapered off and at the close the list showed gains of 3 to 5 point.

WHITEFIELD, N.H., July 14. -- The Yale Forty Niners opened their fourth Summer season in the White Mountains tonight with "The Pursuit of Happiness." An audience which filled the Chase Barn Playhouse showed its pleasure in the "bundling" comedy of courtship in Colonial times.

In all the hustle and bustle at the Hotel Lincoln yesterday as the Olympic team and officials completed last-minute details on the eve of their departure, no one was busier than Mrs. Ada Taylor Sackett.

LONDON, July 14. -- Lord Duveen made a dramatic appearance at the final session of the Oppenheimer drawings sale at Christie's today, outbidding all rivals to buy Jean Fouquet's "Portrait of an Ecclesiastic'' for 10,200 guineas. This is a silverpoint head-and-shoulders study, probably of the Bishop of Treviso.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 14. -- The three seeded players remaining in the tourney were successful in winning third-round matches today in the annual girls' Eastern junior tennis championship at the Amackasin Club.

Per capita consumption of liquor in the United States now is two-thirds below the consumption in 1917, despite the fact that 79.6 per cent of the population now are free to drink beer, wine or hard liquor as compared to 35.4 per cent nineteen years ago, the United States Brewers Association reported yesterday.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Preparations for a strike of 8,000 workers were completed last night at a meeting of the Knit Goods Workers Union at the Amalgamated Temple, 11 Arion Place, Brooklyn. More than 3,000 attended and approved plans presented by Louis Nelson, president of the union, and Joseph Rapaport, chairman of the strike committee, for a general walkout in the industry in the event of refusal by the Metropolitan Knitgoods Manufacturers Association to grant the union's demands.

CLEVELAND, July 14. -- With more than 9,000 voting delegates expected here tomorrow for the opening session of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's second annual convention of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., there was every indication tonight that the organization would steer clear of entangling Presidential alliances in 1936.

At the end of a twenty-four hour automobile trip from South Carolina, Ernest Sutter of New Orleans, national intercollegiate champion, arrived in New York at 1:30 A.M. yesterday and undertook to play his opening-round match in the Eastern championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP). -Cotton consumed during June was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 556,323 bales of lint and 63,956 of linters, compared with 530,799 and 64,670 for May this year, and 383,982 and 60,821 for June last year.

The Consolidated Edison Company, continuing its policy of simplifying its corporate structure, petitioned the Public Service Commission yesterday for permission to merge the New York Edison Company, Inc., and the Bronx Gas and Electric Company into the parent company.

From his Summer home in Richfield, Conn., Walter Hampden yesterday confirmed the announcement that he would appear in motion pictures in some of the roles that have endeared him to theatre-goers for a quarter century. He has been placed under contract by Maxson F. Judell, who may produce the pictures himself, or may arrange engagements for him at one of the major studios.

Since the Federal Theatre is a serious project, pausing seldom to jest or even to smile, no little astonishment prevailed last night when it flung caution to the so-called breeze and laughed out loud.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Acting under the provisions of an act of Congress approved on April 13, President Roosevelt announced through the War Department today the creation of a special committee to study the question of proper tolls to be charged vessels using the Panama Canal.
CLEVELAND, July 14. -- Following is the program for tomorrow's opening session of the Townsend convention:

MADRID, July 14. -- Further bloodshed today marked the funerals of Jose Castillo, a shock police lieutenant, killed supposedly by Fascists because he belonged to the Union of Militant Anti-Fascists, and of Jose Calvo Sotelo, Monarchist Deputy and outstanding Conservative political leader, assassinated allegedly by shock police in revenge.

Mayor La Guardia took a hand yesterday in the selection now in progress of a Republican candidate to run for President of the Board of Aldermen this Autumn by defining the type of man that would be acceptable to him.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., July 14. -- The wind-swept Rockville Country Club course, a rather flat and well-bunkered layout, offered quite a test for the field of 132 golfers seeking the Long Island open championship, which got under way this morning. By sundown only three of that number had succeeded in shattering par figures and only two others had equaled them.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14. -- Four Fundamentalist ministers ignored today a citation by the New Castle Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America to appear at Smyrna, Del., for an ecclesiastical trial before a special commission.

ST. LOUIS, July 14. -- Two home runs by Pepper Martin, the second one in the ninth with the bases filled, shattered the Dodgers' hopes of achieving a four-game winning streak for the first time this season and gave the Gas House Gang the final of the series by a score of 11 7.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 14. -- Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a luncheon and bridge today at the Orchard, her home here, for Mrs. T. Charles Farrelly, who is visiting Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney at the Meadow Club. Among her other guests were Mrs. Stuyvesant Wainwright, Mrs. Kenneth M. Seggerman, Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin, Mrs. Winthrop H. Smith, Miss Candace Stimson, Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel, Mrs. Phillips B. Thompson and Mrs. J. Willmot Ingram.

BANGOR, Me., July 14 (AP). -- John D.M. Hamilton, manager of the Landon Presidential campaign, told Maine Republicans tonight that election of the Kansas Governor "will mean the return of common sense to government and the return of government to the American people."

As the site for a six-story elevator apartment house, a plot 87 by 100 feet on the east side of Loring Place, about seventy-five feet south of 183d Street, has been sold by Elvira H. Moore to a builder. The property is located opposite the campus of New York University and was sold in a deal closed through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., as broker.

The suggestion of Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, that this State follow New Jersey's example and turn the administration of relief over to local communities brought yesterday from Frederick I. Daniels, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, the retort that that was precisely the system that had always been in effect here.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today warned all operators of buses coming under its jurisdiction against issuing free passes or transportation except to their employes and other persons specifically exempted from the ban against free transportation contained in the Motor Carrier Act of 1935.

Acting on a suggestion by Victor F. Ridder, local Works Progress Administrator, that they endeavor to check radical activities in the Emergency Relief Bureau, representatives of the American Legion and other major veterans' groups formed a committee yesterday to investigate charges of Communist influence in the home relief organization.

BERLIN, July 14. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who is now in Britain, will visit Germany before the end of the month to study Germany's aviation equipment and he may be here for the opening of the Olympic Games. It is learned from the Air Ministry, which is handling the plans for his reception, that he has set no definite date for his arrival, but he is not expected before the 20th.

SOLEBURY, Pa., July 14. -- Eastern farmers know of the drought only from the papers. It has been hot for them, thousands of little chicks have been killed by the heat, there has been a noticeable decrease in milk production, the strawberry crop was not prolific and there were a few days when the tops of potatoes began to wilt, but these were the effects of heat, not of drought.

Ernest Desmond de Hagen, who posed as "Lord Desmond of England'' to frequenters of Park Avenue hotel bars before his flight to Los Angeles last May, unexpectedly pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a grand larceny indictment.
Mayor LA GUARDIA journeyed from Summer headquarters in Pelham Bay Park to an important meeting in the Empire State Building in the sidecar of a police motor cycle. His official car was under repairs.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 14. -- Mrs. William Warren Tracy, president of the Williamstown Garden Club, this afternoon gave a garden party at Ormeland in compliment to the garden clubs of Manchester and Dorset, Vt. First the guests visited the gardens of Mrs. Alah R. Lawrie at Buxton Hall, Mrs. Edward Crosby Doughty at Fairway, Mrs. George Alfred Cluett at Green River Farm, and Yeadon Farms, the estate of the late Mrs. James Wilson Bullock.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 14. -- Twenty yachts were ready this evening to begin the Larchmont Yacht Club's first race to Fire Island light vessel and return, a distance of some 320 nautical miles.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Inquiries were being made today to determine the identity of the persons who had profited on their purchases of debentures of Insull Utility Investments, Inc., made prior to the issuance today of the decision in New York affecting the securities.

SHANGHAI, July 14. -- Japan expects that the present Nanking-Southwestern crisis will be indefinitely prolonged and that even when it is ended it will not be definitely settled but only patched and compromised.

President Roosevelt defended the civil service record of his administration in a letter, made public yesterday, to Charles Gordon of 401 Broadway, chairman of the civil service committee of the Lawyers' Security League.

As evidenced by letters to the editor in the July 13 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Charles H. Ingersoll, John Light and Whidden Graham resent the efforts of ten large unions composing the C.I.O. to organize the steel industry.

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Cooling rains edged further into the drought land from the northwest tonight and pushed slowly eastward. Today's loss of more than 1,000 lives in the heat-scourged regions, however, placed the twelve-day toll at 2,996.

The Tri-Continental Corporation and its affiliated investment trusts, Selected Industries, Inc., the Capital Administration Company, Ltd., and the Broad Street Investing Company, reported yesterday increases in their net assets for the six months ended on June 30.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 14. -- The books and records of the All-Continent Corporation, created in 1930 by William Fox, and of which his wife, Eva, is now president, continued today to be the center of discussion in the bankruptcy proceedings concerning Mr. Fox here before Robert Steedle, Federal referee.
The Alton Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, continued in June to reduce its net deficits, it is shown in a statement issued yesterday. The earnings follow:

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 14. -- A southwest blow that swept through the hollows of the Long Island sand dunes today spoiled the last squadron run of the Eastern Yacht Club cruise. It was to have been twenty-six miles from Fort Pond Bay out around the buoy off Watch Hill and then to Sarah's Ledge, off the mouth of the Thames.

WASHINGTON, July 14. -Charged with selling confidential papers of the navy to an agent of the Japanese Government more than a year ago, former Lieut. Commander John Semer Farnsworth was arrested today and held in $10,000 ball by United States Commissioner Needham C. Turnage.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 14. -The payment of unemployment relief in Pennsylvania will be resumed tomorrow morning. Following eight days of want for 173,000 families, the Democratic House concurred in two bills today making available $3,000,000 for immediate relief and approved a measure transferring the money from the special funds to the general funds.

IN one of his prefaces Bernard Shaw tells of standing in a bookstore (I think it was) and overhearing a pompous customer ask for the works of the celebrated Buffoon. The phrase always struck me as priceless, and it seems even more so now that I have read the chapter on Buffon in Donald Culross Peattie's excellent "Green Laurels" (Simon Schuster, $3.75).

CHICAGO, July 14. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential nominee, said today that his present plans call for ten or even twelve weeks of campaign speaking and traveling that will carry him into every State in which there is a real contest.

PRETORIA, South Africa, July 14. -- Oswald Pirow, Defense Minister of the Union of South Africa, who arrived here last night following discussions with British Cabinet Ministers in London, said that "very influential quarters" in Britain were agreed that there could be no permanent basis for peaceful agreement with Germany "unless the Germans are given adequate compensation for their colonies, meaning territorial compensation not anywhere on the globe but in Africa."

The captains of discontent will gather this week at Cleveland. Today Dr. TOWNSEND'S old-age-pension movement is to begin its national convention. To this affair will come representatives of the surviving Share-the-Wealth Clubs founded by HUEY LONG, and also Mr. LEMKE, as self-appointed candidate of the new Union party, bearing the warm endorsement of Father COUGHLIN.

The Atlas Corporation recently purchased from American Superpower Corporation the latter's holdings of 75,000 Class B shares of Italian Superpower Corporation, or 50 per cent of the voting stock. The other half of the voting stock is owned by the Italian Government.
Stirring in its long Summer sleep, Broadway offers a bulletin or two this morning, in this wise:

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, his aides, and Howard O. Hunter, Assistant WPA Administrator, left Washington by plane late this afternoon for Bismarck, N. D., where they will begin conferences with local officials tomorrow on a broad program of longrange and temporary drought relief moves.

David E. Grange, president of the Marine Cooks and Stewards' Union denied yesterday in Supreme Court that he had received payments from ship lines with which he was supposed to negotiate wage and working contracts for the members of his union.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 14. -- Dust and electrical storms marked the late stages of today's polo activity at the Meadow Brook Club as Governors Island and the Vipers triumphed in the opening matches of the annual Wheatley Cups tournament for nine-goal teams.

Eight young men, called by the police "the cowboy gang" because of the rough way in which they carried out their alleged thefts, were booked yesterday at 5 P.M. on charges of assault and robbery at the Miller Avenue police station. They were to be arraigned in Felony Court today.

A warrant for the arrest of "Alfonso De Borbon, 36 years old, a clerk, of 463 Park Avenue," was issued yesterday by Magistrate Renaud after a traffic court attendant had called the name several times between 10:30 A.M. and 12:15 P.M. and no one had answered to it.

OTTAWA, July 14 (Canadian Press). -- Farm crops in the Prairie Provinces and most of Ontario have taken a disastrous beating from heat, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today in its fourth all-Canada crop report. The crop prospects in these four Provinces suffered a marked reduction in the last two weeks.

TOPEKA, July 14. -- Colonel Henry Breckinridge, independent Democrat who contested delegates to the Democratic National Convention with President Roosevelt in four States, announced tonight that he would support Governor Alf M. Landon and Colonel Frank Knox, the Republican nominees for President and Vice President, in the coming campaign.

The scenes in the Capitol at Harrisburg, where, after a wrangle among politicians, necessary relief funds were voted at last, should remind thoughtful citizens of some of the implications in the Presidential campaign. Despite comforting recovery statistics, the country is shadowed with destitution.

It is doubtless too early to say whether the Interstate Commerce Commission's policy of reducing fares on the Eastern railroads to a basic rate of 2 cents a mile has been successful, but the first month's results are sufficient to indicate that at least it has not failed.

TRENTON, July 14. -- The Court of Pardons commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentences imposed on Jacob J. Ciemiengo, who will be 17 years old Thursday, and George Hildebrand, 28, who were convicted of killing Herman Eilers, a Burlington, N.J., poultryman, in a robbery that yielded only $4.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 14. -- The R.C.A. Manufacturing Company, in a letter tonight under the signature of it president, E.T. Cunningham, gave the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America its "final answer" to the union's demands in the strike here, now three weeks old.

Retail failures in the United States in the five days ended July 9 totaled 86, compared with 87 in the previous full business week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dunn Bradstreet, Inc. Declines were also reported in the wholesale and manufacturing divisions. The detailed report is as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 14. -- A questionnaire is being circulated by the National League of Women Voters asking the attitude of candidates for the Senate and House on a number of governmental policies and problems.

Messages received at the local Coast Guard headquarters early this morning reported a collision between the freighter Golden Harvest and the steamship State of Virginia, a passenger vessel, in the Chesapeake Bay, a short distance from the entrance to Baltimore Harbor.
An extra dividend of 37 1/2 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 37 cents was declared yesterday by the Procter Gamble Company.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, July 14. -- Captain George Eyston of London humbled the speed world today -- but still wasn't satisfied.

Messages received at the local Coast Guard headquarters early this morning reported a collision between the freighter Golden Harvest and the steamship State of Virginia, a passenger vessel, in the Chesapeake Bay, a short distance from the entrance to Baltimore Harbor.
An extra dividend of 37 1/2 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 37 cents was declared yesterday by the Procter Gamble Company.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, July 14. -- Captain George Eyston of London humbled the speed world today -- but still wasn't satisfied.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals reversed yesterday a decision by Judge Julian W. Mack in the District Court by which he had dismissed five suits filed by Celia Kelly of Minneapolis to recover in behalf of herself and other Insull bondholders assets which she alleged had been pledged improperly for $14,500,000 loans.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 14. -- New Deal plans and policies were acclaimed, the administration praised for what it has done and proposes to do, and President Roosevelt was represented as deserving the "unreserved gratitude and support" of the American people in an open forum address delivered this afternoon before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia by John H. Fahey, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank board.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 14 (AP). -- Before a crowd of 16,000 the Red Wings came from behind to defeat Newark, 6 to 5, tonight in the first game of their important series.

OMAHA, Neb., July 15. -- Matt Zadalis, 26-year-old Lithuanian who operates a power lawn mower for the city of Omaha, worked over the Happy Hollow Club course today with his golf clubs to score a second dazzling 69 and win medal honors for the thirty-seventh Western amateur tournament with a 36-hole total of 138 strokes.

Meeting here for the first time in thirteen years, American osteopathic physicians opened their annual convention yesterday with discussions of eye ailments, said to be on the increase in this country.

By yesterday's announcement that, on Aug. 15, required reserves of member banks will be raised 50 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board adopts the recommendation made by the Advisory Council last December. Power to change reserve requirements was conferred on the board by the Banking Act's amendments of last August to the original Reserve Law.

The statement of earnings of the Bell System for the three months ended on May 31, made public yesterday, shows a balance of $45,196,739 applicable to stock of the American Telephone Telegraph Company, or $2.42 a share.

THE newest anti-horse-and-buggy book -- but one which is primarily an analysis rather than a criticism or a panacea-carrier -- is "The Modern Economy in Action," published today by Harcourt, Brace ($1.60). The authors are Caroline F. Ware and Gardiner C. Means. Miss Ware, who did the actual writing, is Professor of Economics at Sarah Lawrence College.

A cloudless sky hung over the Stadium yesterday and a gathering of 45,000 hung rather breathlessly inside the arena to provide a perfect setting for a number of momentous events. But somehow the show failed to come up to expectations by slightly less than one half.

The opening of Orchard Beach in the Bronx, originally scheduled by the Park Department for yesterday, has been postponed because of delay in providing the fine top sand for the beach. Park Department officials said that the beach would be opened some time this month, but that no definite date had been set.

Despite the record heat last week, infant mortality in New York City declined from the previous week and reached the lowest point since the week that ended April 18, the Health Department reported yesterday. Maternal deaths and the total of deaths from all causes, however, increased.

The sailing of the liner Manhattan yesterday with its Olympic array gave the impression of a holiday of youth. More than half of those making the trip had never been to sea before, to say nothing of participating in an Olympic voyage.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at Ranley House, their place in Halsey Neck Lane, for Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran Jr. of Hill Brooke, Rumson, N.J., who are visiting them. Earlier in the day Mr. and Mrs. Curran gave a luncheon at the clubhouse of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club for their guests.

Because of Italy's unsatisfactory financial condition, removal of the League of Nations sanctions from that nation will have no immediate effect upon American exporters' terms of sale to customers there, according to foreign traders attending the monthly discussion of foreign credit conditions at the Hotel Pennsylvania, arranged by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

The death of Donald Hastie, 3 years old, last Tuesday in St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken, renewed yesterday the controversy over the relief problem in Hoboken, where since May 1, when the State turned back relief to municipalities, the rolls have been reduced from almost 10,000 persons to less than 200.

BOSTON, July 15. -- John Hay Whitney's Singing Wood scored a handy victory in the six-furlong John Hancock Handicap at Suffolk Downs today before a crowd of 20,000 persons. He paid $3.60 for $2 in the mutuels and ran the distance in 1:11 2/5.

ALBANY, July 15. -- Responding to the felicitations of Maurice P. Davidson, chairman of the Statewide Citizens Committee for Lehman, at the Executive Mansion this afternoon, Governor Lehman told the group which came here to congratulate him on his decision to be a candidate again that in the campaign he would stand on his record.

CLEVELAND, July 15. -- Eleven thousand elderly men and women who hope in the near future to receive $200 a month from the Federal Government as a reward for living threescore years climbed on chairs and cheered this afternoon as one speaker after another at the second annual convention of Townsend clubs attacked President Roosevelt, the New Deal, and all its works.

TOPEKA, July 15. -- Governor Landon and his running mate, Colonel Frank Knox, devoted several hours today to an exchange of information about their respective acceptance speeches so that there would be little overlapping in the material covered.

Thorson yesterday won the Tuckshoe Handicap for Buckley Byers, college student and athlete, who generally is credited with being the youngest owner in racing. The test was the featured event at the Empire City course and young Byers was present for the score, which was by the scant margin of a nose at the end of a mile and a sixteenth.

HUREMBERG, Germany, July 15. -- A short German word -- "Lump" -- has kept Ludwig Hoffmann of Chicago, German-born American citizen, in jail for a fortnight, United States diplomatic inquiries disclosed today.

The Hitler-Mussolini Austrian coup cannot be ignored. Nor can the counter-move be long delayed. Plainly, it is now up to Great Britain and France, for MUSSOLINI has already placed them in the position of having to reply. The nature of that reply may indicate whether there is still a possibility of avoiding a sharp division of Europe into two camps, a cleavage which could only increase the danger of armed conflict.

Representative John J. O'Connor, Tammany member and chairman of the powerful Committee on Rules in the House of Representatives, is referred to as "banker-controlled and priest-kicking" in a protest against his renomination filed with James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, by the National Union for Social Justice, Father Coughlin's organization.

An agreement has been reached between the general reorganization committee of the Peoples Light and Power Corporation, of which Ralph T. Crane is chairman, and the committee representing holders of the company's first lien 5 1/2 per cent bonds, of which W.R.K. Mitchell is chairman, upon a modified plan of reorganization which has been adopted by the board of directors of the corporation, it was announced yesterday.

The case of the New Deal is not really going to be the big fight that some people have predicted in November, but it must come up for hearing in the court of public opinion. The forty-eight States will be in session from now on to weigh the evidence of the good deeds performed by the administration, as well as those that did not meet with the approval of the Supreme Court.

Lord Duveen, international art authority and dealer, who has been sued for $2,000,000 damages by Carl Hamilton, a collector and dealer, was directed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. McGoldrick to answer certain questions on an examination before trial but was upheld in his refusal to answer others put to him by Isidor J. Kresel, attorney for Mr. Hamilton.
BERLIN, July 15. -- Four more members of Catholic orders and a former nun were sent to prison in the last twenty-four hours on charges of immorality.

Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, sailed for England yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines to join Mrs. Roper, who is in London. The Secretary said his trip abroad was unofficial and that he was going for a vacation and rest.
Industrial and housing properties were included in the New Jersey realty transactions recorded yesterday.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 15 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's bid to capture the King's Prize -- most highly valued award of the National Rifle Association's empire meeting -- began today in promising fashion as Guardsman D.S. Fraser of Ottawa won the bronze medal for the highest score in the first stage.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- At the continuation today of the public hearing on charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that White, Weld Co. and others engaged in manipulative activities in A.O. Smith Corporation stock on the New York Curb Exchange, testimony was taken concerning the purchase of 500 shares in 1935 by Auchincloss, Parker and Redpath, New York brokers.
