LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15. -- Under a light northwest breeze, twenty yachts started this morning in the Larchmont Yacht Club's 320-mile race out around Long Island, the Fire Island lightship and back.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 15. -- As they passed the halfway mark in the fifteenth annual Long Island open golf championship at the Rockville Country Club today three professionals were leading the field in the 72-hole test, each with an aggregate score of 146, following a day of competition featured by numerous surprises.

Passenger revenues of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in June, when new low fares went into effect, were estimated yesterday to have gained 15 per cent from June, 1935. A like gain in July is indicated. For the first five months the B. O.'s passenger revenues gained 10 per cent from the like period in 1935, while in May, alone, the gain was 14 per cent.

BESA.NCON, France, July 15.Cardinal Binet was born in Juvigny, twelve miles from Soissons which later he was to help defhd from the Germans. He was ordained a priest Oct. 22, 1893, and after the war promotion came rapidly. He was made Bishop of Soissons on June 16, 1920, an Archbishop in 1925 and created Cardinal in 1927.

CINCINNATI, July 15. -- Playing under the lights in heat almost as enervating as that encountered in St. Louis, the Reds and Dodgers staged their second night game of the season tonight and the Dressen forces emerged victorious, 5 -- 3.

Helen Hayes, the actress, sailed yesterday for Europe on the Manhattan of the United States Lines with her husband, Charles MacArthur. They plan to spend several weeks abroad and motor through Scotland. Miss Hayes said she would return to New York in time to resume her part in "Victoria Regina" in the Fall.

LONDON, July 15. -- A North Atlantic air service is a step nearer with the announcement today by Viscount Swinton, Air Minister, of the conclusion of a five-year agreement with Imperial Airways for the inauguration in the Autumn of a weekly service between New York and Bermuda, carrying passengers, mails and freight.

Commodity futures were mixed in quiet trading yesterday. Cocoa and raw hide futures were moderately higher, while coffee was lower. In the cash market, wheat, corn, oats, rye, flour, cocoa, lard and wool tops advanced, while cotton, silk, tin and rubber declined.

PARIS, July 15. -- For the first time since Napoleon laid down the statutes of the Bank of France, more than 130 years ago, they are to be altered under a bill that Finance Minister Vincent Auriol will introduce in the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow with a demand for immediate discussion.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 15. -- The Dardanelles conference reached an agreement tonight in all its major deadlocks after Great Britain again had shifted her stand and made big concessions to Russia, Turkey and France.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 15. -- The New Deal was attacked today by Herman M. Langworthy of Kansas City and Mrs. George Wyeth of New York, Republicans, before the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it has issued an order prohibiting six manufacturing and sales companies in New York, Boston and other cities from "unauthorized use of several well-known trade names, such as Edison, Majestic and others" in the sale of radio sets.

Plans for a single North River terminal for ships operated by Furness, Withy Co. were announced yesterday. A lease on Piers 96 and 97, which was held by the Italian Line and which was to have continued in effect two more years, has been taken over by the Furness interests.

The Peoples National Bank of Brooklyn declared yesterday a cash semi-annual dividend of 50 cents a share and a dividend, payable in common stock on Aug. 1, of $50,000 par value to holders of common shares of record of July 14, which will be a distribution of one share for each five held.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Jersey City, Newark and New York City had the highest per capita costs for police protection in 1934 of all American cities with a population of more than 100,000, figures made public today by the Department of Commerce showed.

In your editorial on patents you comment on certain evils that call for correction. Our system invites infringement because we allow thousands of pirates to profit from disclosures until such time as the patentee can raise enough money to establish his rights.

ALBANY, July 15. -- Governor Lehman made public tonight the report of the commission which examined Mrs. Frances Q. Creighton in Sing Sing prison yesterday. The woman is scheduled to die in the electric chair tomorrow night for the killing of Mrs. Ada Appelgate, whose husband, Everett C. Appelgate, also is scheduled to go to the chair at the same time.

TOKYO, July 15. -- The Foreign Office has directed all Japanese Ambassadors in Europe to meet for a conference in Paris after the Montreux meeting on modification of the Dardanelles convention closes.
PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP). -- Mel Harder won his thirteenth victory of the season as the Indians came from behind to beat the Athletics, 6 to 4, today.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Labor's Nonpartisan League has approved of the creation of a separate league ticket in New York State headed by President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman, Major George L. Berry, chairman, stated today.
LONDON, July 15. -- Prices on the London Stock Exchange were generally firm today, but business was small, reflecting the approaching end of the account.

The sidewalks and streets of the upper East Side's Little Italy swarmed with thousands of pilgrims and penitents last night on the eve of the climax of the annual three-day celebration of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, the Madonna of Miracles to whom supplicants appeal for relief from illness and infirmities.

The "flawless emerald" and diamond ring owned by the late Lillian Russell, once valued as high as $75,000 and the subject of litigation for many years, was sold at auction yesterday for $4,950. The purchaser was Mrs. Edward F. Albee, widow of the vaudeville producer.
Yesterday, it wasn't the heat; it was the sun.

The final step in the simplification of the corporate structure of the Narragansett Electric Company will be taken today with the public offering of a new issue of $34,000,000 of the company's first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due in 1966, at a price of 102.83 per cent.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, returning from Europe yesterday, assailed the Republican platform as "economic nationalism of the most dangerous sort" and a complete renunciation of Republican leadership for a generation and of all Republican platforms since 1920.

PITTSBURGH, July 15. -- With his team floundering, Bill Terry virtually pulled himself from a hospital cot today at Forbes Field to save the Giants from becoming a complete wreck in a twin bill with the Pirates.

ROME, July 15. -- League of Nations sanctions against Italy, which began last Nov. 18, came officially to an end today and the Italians celebrated their victory in their economic war with manifestations that were less boisterous but no less joyful than those marking the triumph of Italian arms in Ethiopia.

When the President accepted a degree from Yale University in June, 1934, he made a glancing reference to the charge which was the subject of his letter to the Lawyers Security League, published yesterday, that his administration has flouted civil service reform.
Bitter comment came from Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Hotel Biltmore last night on the announcement that Colonel Henry Breckinridge would support Governor Landon.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15. -- A possible new basis for prosecution in the kidnapping, of Paul H. Wendel last February is under consideration by the Federal grand jury for New Jersey. It is the alleged mailing of a letter from Brooklyn to Ellis Parker Sr., chief of detectives of Burlington County, at Mount Holly, N.J., containing the "confession," later repudiated, that it was Wendel who kidnapped Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

Delegates to Dr. TOWNSEND'S convention are arranged in four classes and pay various rates of admission, none high. Especially interesting are the delegates of the Townsend National Legion, who have bought for a dollar the precious right, not to vote, but to speak.

Interest in the Republican choice of a candidate for Aldermanic President will center today on the joint outing of the Board of Aldermen and the City Hall Reporters at Travers Island, where the five Republican county leaders expect to discuss the matter with Mayor La Guardia.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15. -- Count and Countess Laszlo Szechenyi, who have the Countess's sister, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, as their guest, gave a dinner at The Breakers tonight. Mr. and Mrs. David Van Pelt also entertained at dinner there and Mrs. John H. Prentice had luncheon guests, as did the Misses Wetmore.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, announced yesterday the promotion of two men who have been assisting him at $1 a year as legal assistants to the rank of Deputy Assistant District Attorneys on his staff, and at the same time disclosed the appointment of a third man to this rank.

LONDON, July 15. -- Although the British Cabinet reached no decision on the matter at its session today, it is highly improbable that the Locarno powers will have their conference that has been scheduled for this month in Brussels.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Construction of two commercial dirigibles by private capital, with a Federal subsidy, to alternate with two foreign airships in transatlantic service is recommended in a program for American commercial and military aviation submitted to Secretary Roper today in an anonymous report by the Business Advisory Council, an organization of business men formed by the Secretary to act in an advisory capacity on business and trade problems.

Triumphant over all obstacles, the American team sailed yesterday aboard the United States liner Manhattan for Germany, where, at Berlin from Aug. 1 to 16, it will compete against the other nations of the world in the eleventh Olympic Games.

Michael Lerner, noted New York sportsman, yesterday was in between two deep sea fishing expeditions. However, he can not be in this position long, for he will sail this morning on the Eastern Steamship Line's Acadia for Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia. Yesterday, however, he was still getting back his sea legs from his trip to Bimini.

The State of Maine awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,000,000 of three-month temporary notes to the Eastern Trust and Banking Company of Bangor, Me., on a 0.134 per cent interest basis. The notes will be dated July 15, 1936, and become payable on Oct. 13, 1936.

The long anticipated action of the Reserve Board to reduce excess reserves found opinion in Wall Street not much changed from what it was seven months ago when the matter was being debated most actively. Those who were in favor of the action rejoiced yesterday while those who opposed it still saw no real justificatioin for the move.

Montagu Norman, Governor of the Bank of England, declared yesterday when he arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen that the new Federal Reserve regulations to stave off dangerous credit expansion were "a very good thing, but, of course, very experimental."

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP). -- Off to a five-run lead in the opening frame, the White Sox defeated the Senators, 6 to 4, today behind the eight-hit pitching of Vernon Kennedy. It was Kennedy's seventh straight victory.

CATSKILL, N.Y., July 15. -- Asserting that postal receipts "reflect accurately the current economic and business trends." Postmaster General Farley, in an address here today, revealed that the postal revenues for New York City during June had increased by $911,138, an advance of 18 per cent over the same month in 1935.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reported yesterday a net profit of $4,205,524 for the quarter ended on June 30, equivalent to $1.57 a share on 2,666,315 combined shares of common and preferred stock, the largest total for a quarter since the first three months of 1930.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15. -- Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake, holder of the Long Island match and medal play championships, added the association one-day tournament honors to her list of recent victories at the North Hempstead Country Club today.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Moderating masses of cool air from a Canadian high pressure area checked the stifling heat in the Great Lakes sections tonight and lent tempering effects as far east as New York, but western fringes of the Plains States continued to bake in the thirteenth day of oppressive heat.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, July 16. -- Despite many military and political defections, Canton's dictator, General Chen Chia-tang, apparently is actively preparing to fight rather than surrender his office and powers to his former aide, General Yu Han-mou, whom Nanking has appointed as his successor.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- As officials of the Navy Department and the Department of Justice continued today a policy of strict secrecy regarding the value and age of the naval secret papers allegedly sold by former Lieut. Commander John S. Farnsworth to a Japanese naval attache, it was indicated that other arrests might be made before Farnsworth was brought to trial.

Why is it we have not heard a chirp from the ardent Jeffersonian Republican press protesting the prompt action of our Federal Government in its attempt to relieve suffering in the present widespread drought area?

MINEOLA, L.I., July 15. -- Chief of Police Philip Kohut of the city of Long Beach and two of his chief assistants were arrested here today on charges of omission and neglect of duty after they had testified before the Nassau County grand jury in connection with the raid on the gambling establishment at 462 Park Place, Long Beach, last Saturday by District Attorney Martin W. Littleton and members of his staff.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP). -- The Cardinals started one of their typical ninth-inning rallies today, but it was stopped just short of its goal and the Phillies took the opener of a three-game series, 5 to 4.

The Black Diamond Steamship Company, American operator in the transatlantic freight conference governing commerce moving between New York, Antwerp and Rotterdam, won decisions yesterday in two controversies affecting its trade.
BERLIN, July 15. -- The American Olympic team, which left New York today for Hamburg, will have to undergo two public receptions before it can settle down to training.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 24 per cent over the comparative period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The gain is unchanged from that noted for the week ended July 4.

LONDON, July 15. -- Alexander Korda's London Film Company, which recently opened extensive new studios at Denharn, and the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Company are involved in the huge film deal between Twentieth Century-Fox and Gaumont-British, it was learned today.

The Underwood Elliott Fisher Company reported yesterday that its sales in the second quarter of this year were nearly 15 per cent larger than a year before, but that the consolidated net income of itself and its subsidiaries, amounting to $657,964 for the three months, was $92,898 less than in the same quarter of last year, due principally to unusual expenses.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General in New York; Lady Campbell and the Misses Naomi and Jean Campbell; Nathan L. Miller, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee, Marquesa De Villalba and Colonel and Mrs. J.W. Davidge are among those sailing tonight for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Estimates of the number of brokers and dealers in the over-the-counter market were raised today to approximately 11,000 when the Securities and Exchange Commission announced that it was sending letters to more than 5,000 persons in the securities business not previously registered who might be required to make applications under amendments made in the last session of Congress to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt was the guest of her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. John Boettiger, at luncheon yesterday at the Biltmore.

The response of the securities markets and of the banking community yesterday to the announcement of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System of a 50 per cent increase in the reserves required of member banks, effective on Aug. 15, was, on the whole, favorable.
BERLIN, July 15. -- Operations on the Boerse were quiet and prices were irregular today. The turnover was very small, all changes holding within narrow bounds.

A series of injunction suits to prevent the broadcasting of recorded music and phonograph records and the alleged "bootlegging" of radio entertainment was started yesterday in the Supreme Court and the Federal court.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 15. -- The eighteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Cup at the Shenecossett Golf Club moved past the quarter-final stage today, with indications of an All-Providence duel between Mrs. Frederick Davis and Miss Jean Bauer in the final.

BOUND for Berlin, perhaps the greatest athletic team ever to carry the banner of Stars and Stripes to the Olympic wars is now all at sea. There may be some excitement on the trip. Old salts who have since swallowed the anchor tell some strange tales of Olympic voyages of other days on the heaving deep.

Gordon Bergeron, a bus driver, of 3,229 Kitchener Street, Vancouver, B.C., always wanted to visit New York. On July 6 he got his chance. The manager of the bus transportation company for which he works in Seattle, Wash., offered him the opportunity to convey twenty-two adherents of Father Divine to the "heaven" in Harlem, and he accepted with alacrity.

An offering of 150,000 shares of American Cities Power and Light Corporation Class A stock, optional dividend series of 1936, priced at $47.50 a share, will be made today through an underwriting group headed by Riter Co. and including Eastman, Dillon Co.; Hemphill, Noyes Co. and E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc.

A jury in the Federal court in Brooklyn returned yesterday a verdict of guilty against three timekeepers on a WPA project at Jacob Riis Park, at Neponsit, Queens, charged with carrying "dummies" on payrolls. Judge Robert A. Inch remanded the defendants until Monday for sentence.

The Adams Express Company reported yesterday that the net asset value of its common stock on June 30, based on the market value of investments, was $15.73 a share, compared to $13.04 a share on Dec. 31, 1935, and $6.73 a share on June 30. 1935.

Once again Don McNeill, the Kenyon College freshman from Oklahoma City, found himself the center of interest in the Eastern clay-court championship yesterday as play came down to the last sixteen at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 15. -- An even 100 members and guests of the New York Athletic Club took part in the club's third one-day golf tournament of the current season staged today at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- With cooler weather and an abrupt falling off in receipts, prices of hogs here rose 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, virtually all classes sharing in the upturn. For the first time since June 30 the average price advanced, being lifted 15 cents to $9.30, while the top was moved up 15 cents to $10.50.

Accused of extorting $2,000 from Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, motion picture actress, Jerome A. Jacobs, 48 years old, an attorney, of 200 West Eighty-sixth Street, and another man who was listed by the police as Ray Derringer, 39, of 148 West Seventy-second Street, were arrested last night by detectives of the District Attorney's staff.

Hollywood's prize package of 1936, Warners' film transcription of Marc Connelly's "The Green Pastures," will have its local premiere today at the Radio City Music Hall. Besides playing the coveted role of De Lawd, Rex Ingram also appears as Adam and Hezdrel.

The teaching of automobile driving is "entirely too promiscuous," Charles A. Harnett, New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said yesterday in addressing the annual convention of the Association of Secretaries of State at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 15. -- Murry C. Becker, counsel for William Fox, admitted today that securities transferred to the All-Continent Corporation are still in the name of his client, although they are held by Mrs. Fox, wife of the man of motion-picture producing fame.

TOLEDO, July 15 (AP). -- The Ohio Oil Company, of Findlay, Ohio, won today before Judge George P. Hahn in Federal court most of the issues involved in its suit against the government for $7,000,000 paid in excess income and profits tax for the years 1917 and 1929.

BERLIN, July 15. -- It was officially announced today that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh would come to Berlin at the invitation of Air Minister Hermann Goering to visit military and civil aviation organizations. He is expected to arrive in his own airplane next Wednesday.

BOSTON, July 15 (AP). -- The Red Sex wielded their bats effectively behind good pitching today to end a five-game losing streak. They downed the Browns in both ends of a double-header, 11 to 3 and 9 to 1. Marcum held the Browns in check in the opener.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate to construct the West Side Improvement from St. Clair Place to Dyckman Street, connecting there with the Henry Hudson Parkway.

BERLIN, July 15. -- The National Socialist regime was able to register another victory when it announced today that the new government loan of 700,000,000 marks had been "oversubscribed" by several million.

Prime Minister STANLEL BALDWIN told a conference of British university men that the world's greatest need today is poets to sing world unity and peace. The work of the poets has never been put to such vicious use as the work of the chemists has been.

Jean Thomas and her group of seven from the Kentucky hills held a "Singin' Gatherin'" in a garden off Washington Square South at sundown yesterday. They sang and played the ballads, hymns, "lonesome songs" and "play game tunes" as they and their ancestors have sung and played them at hundreds of such meetings for centuries.
DUBLIN, July 15 (AP). -- Patrick J. Hogan, former Minister of Agriculture of the Irish Free State, was killed last night when his car crashed into a bridge.

An order barring loan brokers and money lenders, as well as advertisements of loan companies, from firehouses was issued yesterday by Acting Fire Commissioner Francis X. Giaccone. He explained that the order was a "preventive measure" since, he said, he had had no reports of loan agents soliciting business in firehouses. The order said in part:

UNION CITY, N.J., July 15. -- Judge Morris Umansky, insisting he has not resigned from the bench of the First North Hudson District Court although Governor Hoffman insists he has, presided as usual in his court here today. Between 9:30 A.M. and 1:30 P.M., when court was adjourned for lunch. he disposed of fifty-two cases.

An audience of 11,000 persons -- the largest of the season -- last night greeted Mischa Elman in his second appearance as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. Mr. Elman's first appearance last Monday night attracted an assemblage of 7,500.
An attempt made yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx to block the proposed Department of City Planning provided in the new City Charter was voted down in the Board of Estimate.

WARSAW, Poland, July 15. -- General Edward Rydz-Smigly, the late Marshal Joseph Pilsudski's successor in the army and inspector-general of Poland's armed forces, today stepped into Marshal Pilsudski's shoes as the nation's political leader when Premier Felicien Slawoj-Skladkowski officially proclaimed him the man who, like the Marshal, should be regarded as Poland's first citizen next to the President of the republic.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- A reorganization plan providing for a reduction of more than 80 per cent in fixed interest charges was filed in the United States District Court here today by the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad. The carrier has been in bankruptcy since June, 1933, and has not earned interest charges for several years.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 15. -- Miss Patricia Cumming of Westfield, N.J., fourth ranking girl player in the country, gained the final round of the annual girls' Eastern junior tennis championships yesterday at the Amackassin Club and will meet Miss Sylvia Worth of Bronxville for the title at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- The Cubs strengthened their grip on the National League leadership today by shutting out the Bees, 2 to 0, in the first game of their series. The victory sent Chicago one game in front of the Cardinals.

Four men accused of driving automobiles while intoxicated were found guilty yesterday by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Intoxication Court and fined or sentenced to jail. The driver's license in each case was automatically revoked.

Recognized as the dark horse of the competition, Joe Whalen of the Larchmont Shore Club, unrated 20-year-old star, gave further notice he will be a contender for the national professional tennis singles title by advancing to the semi-final round yesterday at the Tudor City Tennis Club.

The Bronx took the lead in building plans filed yesterday with projects for new houses representing a total cost of $1,030,000. The plans call for six tenement houses and a dwelling, five of the flats being projected by D. Houlihan Sons, Inc., of 4,200 White Plains Road, from specifications prepared by James P. Boylan, architect.

Sixto Escobar, bantamweight champion of the world, ran into a tartar in Indian Quintana of Panama in their featured ten-round bout at the Queensboro Arena last night, and it was well for the champion that it was a non-title fight. A crowd of 5,000 fans saw Quintana win the decision after taking eight of the ten rounds.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- Seven members of an alleged $10,000,000 stock-swindling ring surrendered here today and were released under bond after arraignment before United States Commissioner Edwin K. Walker.

Moving ahead in support of the program of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to provide play space in neglected areas, the Board of Estimate authorized Controller Frank J. Taylor yesterday to buy four playground sites at private purchase at an amount not exceeding $235,416 and authorized condemnation proceedings for sixteen other sites.

Play in the annual national Junior polo championship is slated to be continued this afternoon with a semi-final round match between the Meadow Brook Ramblers and the Jersey Coast quartet on Schley Field in Bedminster, N.J., starting at 6:15 o'clock.
VIENNA, July 15. -- The next move to placate the Nazis is due within a few days.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 15. -- Mrs. Stanley W. Burke and Mrs. Samuel G. Ordway gave a dinner and bridge for twenty persons at the Hedges Inn.

An accounting filed yesterday by the executors of the estate of Harold M. Lehman, nephew of Governor Lehman and former partner in the banking firm of Lehman Brothers, 1 William Street, disclosed the estate to be valued at $6,514,047.96.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP). -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, still silent on her national championship tournament plans, is playing better tennis now than when she defeated Miss Helen Jacobs to win the All-England title last year, her practice partner, Howad Kinsey, said today.

LENOX, Mass., July 15. -- The Lenox Horticultural Society opened its forty-third annual flower show in Lenox Town Hall this afternoon with 119 classes on display. In one group of exhibits, the Berkshire Center at Stockbridge and the Lenox, Great Barrington, Pittsfield, Richmond and Richmond Valley organizations cooperated as a unit with Mrs. John Bross Lloyd as general chairman.
The choice of the Book Union for August will be "The Big Money," a new novel by John Dos Passos, which Harcourt, Brace will publish.

MADRID, July 15. -- The government's Conservative opposition in the Cortes (Parliament) today energetically protested against the suspension of Parliamentary sessions and prolongation of the state of alarm by another thirty days as indications that the Left Republicans intended to establish a de facto dictatorship with Socialist and Communist support.

Mayor La Guardia turned thumbs down yesterday on a proposal that his office in the downtown City Hall be air-conditioned, though he had sat for five hours in a stuffy Board of Estimate chamber in his shirtsleeves, with a handkerchief tucked around his wilted collar.
PARIS, July 15 (AP). -- France and Belgium joined efforts tonight to induce Britain to attend a three-power Locarno conference and consummate virtual military alliances without Germany or Italy.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- President Roosevelt has instructed the Public Works Administration to resurvey some $80,000,000 to $90,000,000 of proposed projects to ascertain if these are justified as relief expenditures.

Atlanta penitentiary gates clanged yesterday on Ignazio (Lupo the Wolf) Saietta, oldest living public enemy in the United States. The grizzled Mafia terrorist, now in his sixtieth year and reputed to have banked in Italy more than $3,000,000 gleaned from New York rackets, was returned to the prison on a warrant signed by President Roosevelt.

Morey Lewis of Texarkana, Ark., and Don McNeill, Oklahoma City youngster, marched into the quarter-final bracket of the annual Eastern junior tennis singles championship yesterday on the clay courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Instead of suspending the twelve unions composing the Committee of Industrial Organization as had been planned, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor decided today to serve formal charges on the dissident unions and to cite them to appear for trial at federation headquarters on Aug. 3.

CHICAGO, July 15. -- The promised relief from the record breaking period of intense heat and drought over the leading grain producing States was regarded today by the grain trade as having failed to materialize, and while temperatures were reported somewhat lower than yesterday, there was no rain of consequence over night, and a rush to reinstate recently sold out lines of grain futures swept prices up sharply on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue $3,490,000 of equipment trust certificates to be financed under an agreement with the New York Trust Company.

Reductions in pay made as a result of the depression by the Consolidated Edison Company and its subsidiaries will be restored on Aug. 16 and Sept. 1, Frank W. Smith, president, announced yesterday. The restoration will cost the company about $3,500,000 a year.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15. -- Charles S. Okin, lawyer for Jacob Harris of Deal, N.J., has filed with the I.C.C. at Washington a complaint against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's practice of charging extra fares for passage between the Penn Station, New York, and Manhattan Transfer on through trains.

A $2 fine for failing to keep to the right was paid yesterday morning in Traffic Court, 300 Mulberry Street, for "Alfonso De Borbon," in reality Alfonso de Bourbon, Count of Covadonga and former heir to the Spanish throne. The count, a salesman for British Motors, Ltd., 463 Park Avenue, was said to be ill and did not appear.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 15 (AP). -- Steve Sundra held the Rochester Red Wings to three scattered blows to give the Newark Bears a 2-to-0 decision in a night game tonight.

Representative BOLTON, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, has led off with the expected when he prophesies that Maine, which holds its State elections in September, will choose Republicans this year from members of Congress to local officers. This result would be followed by immediate Republican claims that Governor LANDON is as good as elected President, for "as goes Maine, so goes the nation."

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 15 (AP). -- Toward dawn today somebody called Polly Moran's husband "Mr. Polly Moran" -- and soon afterward the movie comedienne herself, according to police, was facing a pistol in the hands of her husband, Martin Malone, a young lawyer.

I have supported and worked for every Democratic candidate since the time of Grover Cleveland. I am, however, after very careful thought and mature deliberation, going to vote for Mr. Landon and Mr. Knox. My reasons for doing this are many.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 15. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was the guest of Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York State National Guard, at Camp Smith here today. He was accompanied by Mrs. Smith.

Foreign holdings of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation increased sharply in the three months ended on June 30 and now are at the highest level since foreigners sold United States securities wholesale at the time of the World War, according to a report issued yesterday by the corporation.

LONDON, July 15. -- Britain formally invoked the escalator clause of the dying 1930 naval treaty today in order to keep 40,000 tons of overage destroyers that otherwise would have been due for scrapping next Dec. 31.
HONGKONG, Thursday, July 16, -- Cantonese leaders announced today their intention to establish an independent government within ten days.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 15. -- Justice Bleakley in Supreme Court here ruled today that a New York newspaper reporter who had caused to be published a story concerning a libel and divorce suit, the papers in which had been sealed by court order, wag not in contempt of court because "publication of an article may not be restrained in advance."

DETROIT, July 15. -- the Automobile Manufacturers Association at its annual meeting today announced that unless current trends are seriously disturbed the present year will be the second largest in the history of the industry, only exceeded by 1929.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP). -- The movement to unionize workers in the steel industry claimed tonight what it called its first real triumph in absorbing a "company union." Van A. Bittner, Western regional director of the steel workers' organizing committee, announced that "3,000 members of the Employes Representation Plan" at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company plant in South Chicago "came over in a body to the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers."

More than 150 members of the New York Young Republican Club, attending the semi-annual business meeting of the organization last night at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, were urged to win over the support of independent voters and "walk-out" Democrats for the Republican national ticket.

The Emergency Relief Bureau extended an open invitation yesterday to any person or organization in the city to present to it evidence of "misconduct, fraud or abuse of official trusts" on the part of ERB employes. A full and impartial investigation of all such evidence was promised.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 15. -- A comprehensive relief program "without limitation as to cost" was promised farmers and town dwellers of the Northwest drought area on behalf of President Roosevelt today by Howard O. Hunter, WPA administrator for that territory, in conference with other Federal and State relief officials.

BALTIMORE, July 15 (AP). -- A vague report of a misunderstanding in signals spurred an official inquiry today into the cause of a collision between a heavy freighter and a bay steamer carrying 197 passengers on a convention cruise.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the proposed admission on Aug. 1 of Thomas H. Benton to Dreyfus Nicholas and a change in the firm name to Dreyfus, Benton Nicholas.

Apprehension over the possibility of labor disturbances in the steel industry has been allayed by opposition shown by steel employes to the unionization drive of the Committee for Industrial Organization, the magazine Iron Age states in its weekly summary.

Hill Blackett, treasurer of Blackett-Sample-Hummert, Inc., Chicago advertising agency, who was recently named director of public relations of the Republican National Committee, will arrive in New York today to prepare plans for an advertising campaign in behalf of Governor London.

The first of a series of hearings on complaints of the Federal Trade Commission against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., alleging that the guild's style protection practices are in restraint of trade, was held yesterday before John W. Bennett, trial examiner, at 45 Broadway.

If the government spends nearly $9,000,000,000 in regular and extra disbursements, which it did in 1936, and if, in addition, the expenditures of State and local government based upon both borrowing and taxation are around $7,000,000,000 to $8,000,000,000 more, this is altogether too large a proportion of production and services which in last analysis is national income.

The Republicans are preparing for the most complete canvass of voters in the State that has been made since 1916, when Charles S. Whitman was the Republican candidate for Governor. The plans were laid at a conference yesterday between Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton and Clarence R. King of Onondaga, chairman of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee.
CLEVELAND, July 15. -- The text of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's address here today was as follows:

The Continental Can Company will launch on July 23 one of the largest newspaper advertising campaigns ever undertaken in behalf of canned beer, O.C. Huffman, president, announced yesterday. The drive, continuing through August, will be run in more than 200 leading newspapers in 193 of the largest cities in the country.

LONDON, July 15. -- Great Britain's four-year-old system of tariffs, subsidies and reciprocal trade treaties is working excellently and there is not the slightest reason to change it, Walter Runciman, president of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today in his first comprehensive review of the trade situation in many months.

" Bugles at Noon," a new play by Stephen Raushenbush, lately connected with the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry, will be presented tomorrow and Saturday evenings by the Cornell Summer Theatre at Ithaca, N.Y. . . . "The Distaff Side" will be the offering tomorrow and Saturday evenings at the Gloucester (Mass.) Summer Theatre, while the Atlantic Repertory Theatre of Atlantic City, N.J., will show "Liliom" on the same evenings.

ABOARD SCHOONER LIBERTY, SEAL HARBOR, Me., July 15 -- President Roosevelt dropped the anchor of the schooner Sewanna in this tree-fringed harbor tonight after thirty-five miles of sailing generally eastward under conditions that approximated a yachtsman's dream of heaven.
The meeting of the directors of the Pitney-Bowes Postage Meter Company, scheduled for yesterday, was postponed. No date was set for the deferred meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 15. -- Seven counties in Colorado and thirteen in Oklahoma were added today to the emergency relief area on the government's drought charts, the addition of Colorado raising to thirteen the number of States in the stricken district.

BERLIN, July 15. -- The German Foreign Office today denied the report from London to the effect that the Austro-German pact is accompanied by "secret annexes" dealing with military problems and the question of the Hapsburg restoration.

After a dull and listless all-day session, the New York County convention of the American Legion at the Hotel Pennsylvania came to life at midnight last night on the issue of sending the retiring Commander to the State convention at Syracuse as a delegate at large.

Tang Leang-li, Minister Plenipotentiary and adviser to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Chinese National Government in Nanking, arrived on the Bremen yesterday on his way home after a visit to diplomatic agencies in Europe.

With high hopes, 334 American athletes sailed yesterday on the liner Manhattan for the eleventh revival of the Olympic Games, to be held this year in the monster new stadium and pool at Berlin. Forty-eight of their fellow-members on the team of the United States are either already on the ground or shortly will follow.

ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN AT SEA, July 15. -- The first casualty of the American Olympic expedition developed when Harold Smallwood, national 400-meter champion and an 0:46.7 man, was stricken with an appendicitis attack before the ship was out at sea.

BOSTON, July 16 (AP). -- After blowing a 3-0 lead behind Lefty Grove to drop the first game, 6 -- 3, the Red Sox put on a successful ninth-inning rally today against the Browns and won the nightcap, 5 -- 4. As a result Boston went to fourth place in the American League standing.

ALBANY, July 16. -- A substantial increase in motor vehicle registrations for the first five months of the year "reflects the growth of transportation and a corresponding gain in the State's commercial and industrial activity," according to Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 16. -- Ray Billows of the Dutchess Club, whose sensational exploits in last year's State golf championship made him famous from coast to coast, made a great start in defense of his title today.

Judge Clarence G. Galston, in the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, tentatively approved yesterday plans of reorganization for the Brooklyn Academy of Music under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws. Under the plan the Brooklyn Academy of Music Corporation will be dissolved and the Academy of Music Building at Lafayette Avenue and Ashland Place will be taken over by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

Radio stations accused of "bootlegging" music through the medium of recorded selections played on the air intimated yesterday that they assumed the music is public property once a record is purchased, except in cases where public performance is expressly prohibited.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 16. -- The death of Senator Murphy forces Iowans to elect two Senators in the coming Fall elections. The situation is similar to that of 1924, when Senator A.B. Cummins died. At that time the Republicans won both offices.

According to dispatches from London, the Home Office has submitted to the House of Commons a supplementary estimate of 887,000 -- "the first step" toward providing millions of gas "masks free of charge." Thus are we reminded again of the horrors to mark the next war.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 16. -- Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton, 38-year-old housewife, and Everett Appelgate, 36-year-old former American Legion official, were executed at Sing Sing Prison shortly after 11 o'clock tonight for the poisoning of Appelgate's wife, Ada, at Baldwin, L.I., last Sept. 27.

The Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, for the last seven years rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Buffalo, and before that chaplain of Yale University, has accepted a call to the rectorship of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.
LONDON, Friday, July 17. -- The sharp eye of an unpaid London policeman -- a "special" -- helped to prevent serious consequences as King Edward escaped assassination yesterday.
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 16. -- The Southern New England contract bridge championship got under way here today, with forty teams competing for the mixed pair title.

PITTSBURGH, July 16. -- There was a setback in business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The index, adjusted for seasonal changes and for long-term trend dropped from 97.4 per cent of normal in the week ended July 4 to 93.2 last week.

With the 6 per cent of its production facilities, which formerly turned out special brand tires for Sears, Roebuck and Company, being switched to the output of its own brand lines as a result of the Patman law, Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is expected to broaden considerably its sales and advertising campaigns on independent dealer business.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 16. -- District Attorney Martin W. Littleton, the prosecutor who obtained the convictions of Mrs. Mary Frances Creighton and Everett Appelgate for the poison murder of Appelgate's wife, remained at his office tonight keeping a "death watch" and remaining prepared to offer to the Governor any information he might request in reference to the case.

LONDON, July 16. -- George Andrew McMahon, King Edward's attacker today, whose real name, it was revealed tonight, is Jerome Bannigan, is an Irishman whose family are natives of Cookston, Tyrone, and reside in Glasgow. He has lived in London for many years.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Disclosure that former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who threatened last Winter to "take a walk" from the Democrats in November, may be directing his footsteps toward the Republican camp was made here today by Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential candidate.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- John S. Farnsworth, former naval officer accused of betraying navy secrets, told a reporter today that he had shown photographs of naval aviation equipment to a Japanese agent while seeking a $50,000 job in the Japanese air force.

The economic outlook for the world showed further improvement in May, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in the Midyear Review and Forecast Number of The Annalist, to be issued today. Industrial activity rose to the highest level in more than six years, while international trade was the largest in almost four years, it is stated.

An educational campaign in the East through advertising, radio broadcasts and publicity to inform the voters in regard to the stand of Governor Landon of Kansas, Republican Presidential nominee, on relief and prohibition and thus combat "misrepresentation" by the Democrats is imminent, according to Hill Blackett of Chicago, advertising executive and public relations director for the Iepublican Hational Committee.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 16. -Joseph B. Ely, former Democratic Governor of Massachusetts, announced today, after a conference with John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, that he would support the Landon-Knox ticket in the election.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Sentiment appeared to be developing today among the twelve unions in the Committee for Industrial Organization, of which John L. Lewis is chairman, against appearing for trial before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor on Aug. 3 to answer charges of forming a rival or dual labor organization and of "fomenting insurrection" within the federation.

Catholics in the United States will aid the Mexican Bishops in establishing in this country a seminary for the training of priests for service in Mexico. The school will be situated in New Mexico. The plan is to buy a large hotel which was built by the Santa Fe Railway several years ago.

The will of Mrs. Elizabeth Robins Pennell, author and critic and widow of Joseph Pennell, the artist, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday, disposes of an estate valued at $60,000. Mrs. Pennell was 81 years at the time of her death on Feb. 21, last.

Second-day appreciation of the higher reserve requirements for member banks failed yesterday to draw forth any support in the market for United States Government long-term obligations. Although these bonds were not offered in such volume as on Wednesday, the price structure, nevertheless, proved to be vulnerable, as declines in the list ranged from 1-32 to 16-32 point at the close.

STONY POINT, N.Y., July 16. -Leaders of historical societies from seven States, distinguished diplomats and the crowd generally that assembled here today for the dedication of Stony Point Battlefield Museum had fresh drinking water throughout the ceremony.

Alfred McIntyre, president of Little, Brown, recently returned front a visit to Europe. He brought back with him the manuscript for a new novel by Louis-Ferdinand Celine, author of "Journey to the End of the Night." This novel has had a large sale in France, but because of its length and the difficulties it presents to the translator it will not be ready for American publication until next Spring.

The Hamburg-American liner New York will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports. Her passengers include several groups of German tourists who will visit many cities here. The liner's list has the following names: Obie Miller, Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Giese, Mrs. Margarete Zaoral, Adrian Rubel, Mrs. I. Dickinson, Dr. and Mrs. A.H. Rosenfeld, J.B. Mather, Captain Walter Kortbein and Miss Kathleen O'Brien.

In a fifty-four-page, 15,000-word report, dated June 12, to the directors of Paramount Pictures, Inc., Joseph P. Kennedy stated in an analysis of the company's affairs that "drastic and courageous revision of the management is called for," and urged the selection of an experienced motion-picture man as president of the company.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey signed contracts yesterday with three American shipyards for the building of eight oil tankers involving an outlay of $13,000,000. The order was said to be the largest of its kind ever placed by a private concern.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 16. -- Rumanian Nazis made themselves responsible for a particularly brutal murder tonight when Michael Stalescu, leader of the dissident Fascist group, Cruciada (Crusade), was shot many times by eight anti-Semitic Iron Guards in his hospital bed, where he was awaiting an operation for appendicitis.

HARWINTON, Conn., July 16 (AP). -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, described Governor Alf M. Landon today as a man brought up "on a horse-and-buggy maxim which says that a man's word is as good as his bond."

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- In spite of the drought, food supplies for the United States will be ample during the next year, but the prices of many farm products will be higher, according to A.G. Black, chief of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- Although outhit by the Senators, the White Sox made the most of their hits today to defeat Washington, 9 -- 7, for their second straight triumph.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Mrs. Elvina Orlicz-Dreszer, wife of General Orlicz-Dreszer, left Washington about two weeks ago to rejoin her husband in Poland, after visiting here for a month with her two daughters by a former marriage, Margaret and Elvina Rowe.

The Brooklyn political system was blamed yesterday by Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the Drukman murder case, for the development of a flourishing "fixing" system in the Kings County Court. Mr. Todd's criticism was made informally as he was leaving for a short vacation up-State.

The frequency of sinus and ear ailments in this country, said to claim more than 20,000,000 persons as victims, is often due to intermarriages among various races and nationalities, it was reported yesterday at the annual convention of the American Osteopathic Society of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology.

VIENNA, July 16. -- I am convinced that the conclusion of the Austro-German agreement represents not only a satisfactory settlement of the crucial problem of Central Europe, but it must also be considered an important advance on the road toward pacification of the whole Continent.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Treasury Department, which yesterday denied that its Secret Service was investigating the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, has discovered that two Secret Service agents did make such an investigation on their own responsibility and for undisclosed personal reasons.
LONDON, July 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

PITTSBURGH, July 16. -- President Horace Stoneham flew here from New York today to see what his Giants were doing and how they were doing it. He flew back tonight wiser and happier after a typical Giant road game which, contrarily, ended favorably.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Municipal Court Justices in New York City and in Yonkers, Utica and Albany do not have to retire when they reach the age of 70, Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan has decided in the case of Municipal Court Justice Frank E. Johnson of Brooklyn, who brought an action against the Secretary of State to determine the question.

President ROOSEVELT'S severest critics will admit that he has retained one attractive feature of the Old Deal. It can be observed in operation on board the schooner Sewanna now cruising off the Maine coast. It consists in the pleasant family picture of a father-skipper issuing orders to three stout men before the mast who are his sons.

For the leading roles in "And Stars Remain" the Theatre Guild announces Clifton Webb and Helen Gahagan, declaring further that this comedy by Julius J. and Philip G. Epstein will open the subscription season in the Fall. Rehearsals will begin, probably under the direction of Philip Moeller, in September for a brief out-of-town tour beginning Oct. 5.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 16. -- An all-Providence final in the eighteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Cup at the Shenecossett Club materialized today as Miss Jean Bauer and Mrs. Frederick Davis made their way into the closing round.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's infallibility was proclaimed today in an article in the Voelkischer Beobachter, Hitler's own newspaper and the central organ of the National Socialist party which lays down the law to the German people.

Business in wool goods was only moderately active last week, but prices continued strong in all divisions, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday. A number of lines of tropical worsteds for the 1937 season were opened during the week with prices 10 to 15 cents a yard higher than last year.

ELIZABETH, N. J., July 16.John A. Wacker, for many years an employe of the Bayway Refinery of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, died here yesterday at his home. He was born seventysix years ago in Queens County, New York. He was a Past Councilor and a member of Progressive Lodge, Knights of l:yihias, for fifty years. His widow, Mrs. Katherine Wacker; a daughtert five sons and a brother survive.

The two Western entrants, Don McNeill of Oklahoma City and Mercy Lewis of Texarkana, Ark., continued to dominate the Eastern junior tennis championships at the West aide Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

A new issue of $7,108,000 Bangor Hydro-Electric Company first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, series due in 1966, will be placed on the market today by Edward B. Smith Co. and E.W. Clark Co. The bonds will be priced at 104 3/8, to yield 3.50 per cent. Proceeds from this financing, together with other Treasury funds,

By keeping up a persistent attack that never assumed very large proportions, the Yankees pounded out another victory over the Detroit Tigers at the Stadium yesterday and made certain that the champions will not take anything from their lead during this series.
Commodore Rudolph J. Schaefer's yawl Edlu was in the lead last night in the Larchmont Yacht Club's 320-mile ocean race out around Long Island, the Fire Island lightship and return.

Since the defeat of the President is now the officially declared purpose of the delegates mustered in Cleveland by Dr. Townsend and addressed by Father Coughlin, the Republican attacks on that part of the New Deal which their own platform did not espouse will have to take Herbert Hoover's line that they represent a definite attempt to "Europeanize" the government.

SHANGHAI, July 16. -- While admitting that skirmishes are expected noon between the forces under General Yu Han-mou which are advancing southward, and General Chen Chian-tang's troops along the Canton-Hankow Railway, Central Government officials believe hostilities of any importance probably will be deferred at least ten days.
BERLIN, July 16. -- With the Olympic Games only a fortnight away, Berlin's hotel-keepers are bitterly disappointed over the acres of empty rooms still on their hands tonight.
News was scarce at City Hall yesterday as the Aldermen and reporters rode in buses to Travers Island for the annual baseball game and track meet between politics and the press.

HAVING divested himself of his coat, G. Stanley Cochrane, the Tiger Man of the diamond, settled himself in a chair in his hotel suite and looked glum. It was about high noon and a little later it would be high time to move toward the Bronx for another battle with Marse Joe McCarthy's league-leading Yankees. Anybody might feel glum under those circumstances.

OTTAWA, July 16 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits by the Dominion Government decreased almost $1,200,000 as deposits by chartered banks increased nearly $1,300,000, the Bank of Canada reported today for the week ended yesterday. The statement follows:

MOSCOW, July 16. -- Moscow is really becoming clothes-conscious. The dignified newspaper Izvestia, which is the official mouthpiece of the Soviet Government, published an article captioned "The House of Models," which follows:

Hot, drowsy weather when you'd rather be somewhere near a trout stream, or possibly out at sea with a gust of ocean breeze tossing in your face, was not particularly pleasing to our friend, an angler, who had to remain in New York.
Arthur Krock asserts that the Constitution has been ignored in the following cases:

Trading was quiet and mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday, with the general tendency of prices to slightly lower levels. Cash markets, on the other hand, showed marked gains, corn and cocoa making new highs, and wheat, oats, butter, lard, wool tops and silk all rose.
After reading Senator Ashurst's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES I am moved to make the following inquiries:

The plan of reorganization for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway proposed by the management was declared yesterday to be unsatisfactory by Dwight S. Beebe, vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company and chairman of a committee for $104,600,000 Rock Island first and refunding 4 per cent bonds which were defaulted on their maturity on April 1, 1934.

The appointment of a committee of Eastern railroad presidents to carry on coordination projects left unfinished by the Eastern regional coordinating committee was announced yesterday by the Eastern presidents' conference.

RUMSON, N.J., July 16. -- Women members of society following the shore circuit turned out in prints and pastels to witness the first of the three-day Monmouth County Horse Show conducted today on the grounds of the Thornton Farm, adjacent to the Rumson Country Club.

Peter van den Toorn, freight traffic manager of the Holland America Line, denied yesterday that his line had ambitions to enter Antwerp with shipments of grain in the expectation that the American-owned Black Diamond Steamship Company would be forced out of operation and eventually leave the general Antwerp trade available for Dutch ships.

Dry goods wholesalers continued to purchase large quantities of merchandise in the primary market this week, as the demand from their retail accounts for Fall Goods exceeded expectations. Although price advances on a number of lines have been a stimulant to buying, the point has been reached where jobbers are more anxious about obtaining deliveries than getting low prices.

SOME years ago Olaf Stapledon wrote a book called "Last and First Men." A reviewer in THE TIMES called it an extraordinary achievement, a masterpiece a triumph in the field hitherto pre-empted by Jules Verne and H.G. Wells. Mr. Stapledon has now written another book, entitled "Odd John" (Dutton, $2). This reviewer in THE TIMES cannot speak of the successor in the same flattering terms, but there is no doubt that it is extraordinary.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA., July 16. -- Republican charges against the New Deal made at the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs yesterday by Herman Lang-worthy of Kansas City and Mrs. George Wyeth of New York were answered today by John Dickinson,

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 16 (Canadian Press) . -- Canada's marksmen today failed in their bid to recapture the Mackinnon challenge cup and placed behind shots from other parts of the Empire in the Duke of Gloucester's prize and the Daily Telegraph.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Corn was the market leader today and responded in a vigorous manner to continued record-breaking high temperatures over the main producing States and unfavorable crop comments, and closed 4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday, the limit permitted for one day under the regulations of Grain Exchanges.

PARIS, July 16. -- By well over a 3-to-1 majority, the Chamber of Deputies this evening put an end to the reign of the regents of the Bank of France as it had existed for more than 130 years and set up a new board of administration which will represent the varied interests of the whole nation rather than only the bank's 200 largest shareholders.

The Paramount Astoria studios, where activity has been of a mild and short-subject variety lately, may come to life this Fall. Ferdinand Bruckner, who is in Hollywood writing a screen play from 'Hotel Imperial," which Ernst Lubitsch is attempting to salvage for Marlene Dietrich,
LONDON, July 16. -- Russia has replied to the German accord with Austria. A great strategical railway will be built, giving the Russian Army direct communication with Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and the same amount as reported for the corresponding week in 1935.

Two of the twelve patrolmen accused of trying to buy preferred positions on the sergeants' eligible list through alleged "fixers," were heard at Police Headquarters yesterday during departmental trials before Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,920,000,000, according to the weekly report of the system published yesterday. The gain, which was smaller than those reported in the previous three weeks, was due chiefly to the retirement from circulation of $52,000,000 of the extra currency called into use recently by the cashing of veterans' bonus checks.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 16. -- Displaying smooth team work all the way, and with F. Skiddy Von Stade Jr. excelling at No. 2, the Meadow Brook Ramblers today defeated Jersey Coast, 10 to 5, on Schley Field and galloped into the national junior polo championship final.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 16. -- William Fahnestock, New York broker and oldest member of the New York Stock Exchange at the time of his death at Katonah July 5, revoked bequests of about $90,000 to charities and friends in May of 1933, three months after he had written his will, according to the will and codicil filed for probate today.

Jerome Jacobs, 48 years old, a lawyer, and Raymond Derringer, 39, a private detective, were remanded to the Tombs yesterday in default of $50,000 bail each by Magistrate Farrell in the Felony Court on an extortion complaint made by Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, the motion-picture actress.

CLEVELAND, July 16. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, elderly founder of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd., and the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, recent convert from the ranks of Huey Long's share-our-wealth clubs, agreed today to hit the sawdust trail for Representative William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, and then hastened to scotch an incipient rebellion of the faithful seekers of the millennium and $200 a month.
LONDON, July 16. -- Following is the text of the speech King Edward delivered to tree of the Guards regiments today just before the attempt on his life:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 16 (AP). -- Two home runs enabled the Red Wings to come from behind twice to defeat Newark tonight, 10 to 8. Phil Weintraub drove a homer over the left field wall in the fifth inning to score behind Rothrock. In the sixth, with two on, Jack Sturdy clouted a homer.

NEWARK, N.J., July 16. -- The special committee of the Federal grand jury for New Jersey which has been studying the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, will meet here tomorrow to discuss a procedure to be followed in view of the refusal of Attorney General Cummings to advise the jury of its jurisdiction in the matter.

As a result of the major loss in this city, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday declined from the previous week and from last year's figure, after having risen in the two preceding weeks. The total for the twenty-two principal cities of the nation, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,022,153,000, against $5,862,756,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16. -- The fourth season of chamber music concerts arranged by Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead opened tonight at Beechwood, home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young. The concert, the first of three, was given under the patronage of the Summer colony and naval colony members.
TOPEKA, July 16. -- Governor Landon's visiting list is continuing to reflect, in the eyes of his supporters, the united front against the New Deal that the Republican party believes it has set up.

OMAHA, Neb., July 16. -- Comeback-bound Johnny Lehman of Chicago and slender Freddie Haas Jr. of New Orleans completed the rout of the Walker Cup delegation in the thirty-seventh annual Western amateur golf tournament today by brilliantly fashioned triumphs over Charlie Yates of Atlanta and Omaha's Johnny Goodman respectively.

HAVANA, July 16. -- Military police today shot and killed Antonio Flores, former chief of police of the town of Vueltas, and Domingo Gonzalez when they tried to escape from Fragoso Key off the north coast of Santa Clara Province near Caibarien, where five revolutionists had been trapped since last Tuesday.

Orders received by the General Electric Company in the second quarter of 1936 totaled $77,398,718, compared with $55,163,014 in the same part of 1935, a gain of 40 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, reported yesterday. This was the largest amount of orders received in any quarter since the second quarter of 1931, when they totaled $81,063,000.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Export subsidies and import control improved the German foreign trade balance by nearly 300,000,000 marks during the first half of this year, compared with the corresponding pre-subsidy period last year. Although export surpluses are shrinking these methods continue to keep German trade in black ink.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- An aggregate of 435,000,000 shares, or approximately 21 1/2 per cent of the total number of shares of equity securities outstanding of 1,755 reporting corporations, were owned directly or indirectly by officers, directors and principal stockholders on Dec. 31, 1935, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. Eliot L. Ward, who have the W. Tyson Dominy house on Lily Pond Lane this season, gave a dinner dance for forty young people of Southampton's and East Hampton's Summer colonies there tonight, for their daughter, Miss Nancy Lee Ward.

Air service between New York and Bermuda, British official authorization for which was announced in dispatches from London Wednesday night, will be a joint undertaking of Imperial Airways and Pan American Airways, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, July 16. -- Operations were quiet, but prices held firm, on the London Stock Exchange today. British funds were steady and foreign issues mostly higher, largely from renewed demand for German securities. Home rails were lower as a result of the week's disappointing traffic reports, while the foreign list was dull, Argentines sagging in the absence of support.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 16. -- An emergency and long-range program, designed simultaneously to bring immediate relief to drought-stricken farmers and to pave the way for fundamental land use changes in the Northwest, was announced today by Rexford G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, at the conclusion of the five-State drought conference.

Looking on at the spectacle in Cleveland, where the benign Dr. TOWNSEND and those rip-roaring clerics, Father COUGHLIN and the Rev. Mr. SMITH, have been rushing hopeful beneficiaries of the $200-a-month old-age pensions into approval also of their own crackbrained schemes and endorsement of their bitter prejudices, it is possible to conclude that, like many former heads of States, the President can be congratulated on his enemies.

The New York Stock Exchange's committee on bonds ruled yesterday that no member or registered firm should maintain with more than one broker, for execution on the Exchange, market orders or orders at the same price for the purchase or sale of the same bond with knowledge that such orders were for the account of the same principal unless specific permission had been obtained from the committee on bonds.

The General Motors Corporation reaequired in June 33,336 additional shares of its common stock, raising its treasury holdings to 607,325 shares, it reported yesterday to the New York Stock Exchange. In the same month the Consolidated Oil Corporation purchased 26,500 shares of its common stock, increasing its reacquired shares to 273,948.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- Police today classed the mutilation story of Jean Bell, 23, as "absolutely groundless," and announced that she would be turned over to Baltimore authorities to face a robbery charge.

CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis., July 16. -- Senator Louis Murphy, Democrat, of Iowa, was killed and his wife and two of their friends were injured today in an automobile accident near Bloomer, Wis., north of here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -Many members of the Garden Club of Southampton and their guests met this morning at Solterra, the home of Mrs. E.M. Horne. Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin, first vice president, presided in the absence of Mrs. Henry E. Coe, the president.

Voluminous correspondence, reports and records of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., were marked yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission at the hearing on its complaint alleging restraint of trade practices by the guild.

Representative Clarence E. Hancock of the Thirty-fifth Congressional District, composed of Onondaga and Cortland Counties, is urged by friends as a compromise candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, according to a report yesterday from Syracuse.

Although excess reserves of member banks continued to rise in the week covered by yesterday's report of the Reserve System, the increase of $40,000,000 reported was considerably below the recent rate of advance. This may have been due to the effect of recent payments to the RFC in retirement of capital notes and preferred stock.

Following is the text of the Declaration of Principles adopted yesterday by the State organization of Labor's Nonpartisan League after it had formed itself into an independent Labor party to function permanently in this State:

A veteran trainer who during gaps in having horses to work, had to take a job as a night watchman, had the satisfaction yesterday at Empire to see one of his charges, Whizzaway, survive a nose finish in a bitter drive which was decided as much on condition as on anything else.

BISMARCK, N.D., July 16. -- The program of the Resettlement Administration for meeting emergency drought problems in North and South Dakota, Montana Wyoming and Minnesota in drought designated counties, and such adjacent States as may hereafter be designated by the Department of Agriculture, is as followsS

John W. Garrity's war bonus was the means of exposing him to the police and also of saving him from jail, it developed yesterday when a financial transaction he entered into -- the police called it grand larceny -- was adjusted satisfactorily in the Kings County Court.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- Lon Warneke pitched a ten-inning shutout today to give the first-place Cubs a 1-to-0 victory over the Bees. It was Chicago's fourth consecutive triumph and enabled it to go two games ahead of the second-place Cardinals, who were beaten.

Quantity discounts must be the same to all retailers, whether they be department stores, drug stores, chain-store systems or syndicate groups, under the provisions of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, according to a preliminary report on the law issued yesterday by counsel for the Toilet Goods Association, Inc.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., July 16. -- Faced with a deficit of two strokes as the field entered the final eighteen holes, Charley Lacey, Lakeville pro, nevertheless finished five strokes in front to capture the Long Island open golf championship today at the Rockville Country Club, with an aggregate score of 289 for the seventy-two-hole test.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 16. -- The two chief investigators for the New Jersey State police in the Lindbergh kidnapping case were transferred from the detective division to the training school today, and one was demoted in rank and pay. They are Captain John L. Lamb and Lieutenant Arthur Keaten.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved irregularly over a 15-point range yesterday to end at the bottom with losses of 3 to 8 points. Throughout virtually the entire session the list maintained a slight advance, only to ease abruptly in the last half hour under hedging operations.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 16. -Assertions that 3,000 company union members at the South Chicago plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation had gone over in a mass movement to the new industrial union sponsored by John L. Lewis were denied this afternoon by officials of the company, who said only a small group had done so.

The great convention of the vesting interests is on. The buyers are here. As delegates from all the American Main Streets, from Fifth Avenue to Wilshire Boulevard, they are more vigilant and influential in their constituencies than any political representatives.
MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 16. -- The Dardanelles conference, completing first reading of a compromise Straits convention, decided tonight to hold a signature Monday.

Verdi's "Il Trovatore" was presented at the Lewisohn Stadium last night as the first of the operatic performances scheduled this season at the uptown amphitheatre. The complicated tale of the woes of the Duchess Leonora and her Troubadour lover was earnestly unfolded for the edification of an audience numbering 5,000 -- a figure less imposing than might have been anticipated, considering the popularity of this particular work.

RUMSON, N.J., July 16. -- Competition over the jumps featured the opening session of the annual Monmouth County Horse Show, which opened this afternoon on the Thornton farm, adjacent to the Rumson Country Club, to continue through Saturday.

Stockholders of the Callahan Zinc-Lead Company will receive rights pro rata to subscribe for the 747,518 additional shares of $1 par capital stock now under option to Frank Eichelberger, former general manager of the Sunshine Mining Company, it was disclosed yesterday in an amended application to list the shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

A field of 223 players, a record entry, will tee off in the qualifying round of the fifteenth annual national amateur public links golf championship beginning Monday over the Blue and Red courses of the Bethpage State Park, Farmingdale, L.I.

The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined 1.9 points to 124.4 on Tuesday from 126.3 the Tuesday previous, wiping out about half of the previous week's gains. Losses were greatest in wheat, hogs and steers.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 16. -- A margin of one stroke gave Mrs. Emmet Whalen of the Westchester Hills Golf Club low gross honors in the weekly Westchester-Fairfield women's tournament held today at the Silver Spring Country Club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP). -- Johnny Allen pitched the Indians into second place in the American League today, shutting out the Athletics with five hits. 7 to 0, as Detroit lost to New York. It was the sixth straight victory for Cleveland.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Federal Communications Commission was placed today in the light of backing large companies against smaller organizations in the battle for control of television.
CLEVELAND, July 16. -- A stenographic text of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's address before the Townsend plan convention here today follows:
ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean faltered today, so did the Cardinals and the Phillies won, 6 to 2. for their second straight victory in this series.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the acquisition by the Middle West Corporation of Chicago, a registered holding company, of 9,000 shares of $3 cumulative no-par preferred stock of the Copper District Power Company, a utility subsidiary of the holding company.

The State of Minnesota will consider tenders for a new issue of $1,500,000 of Department of Rural Credit certificates of indebtedness, award of which will be made on July 27. The certificates will be dated Aug. 1, 1936, and will mature on Aug. 1, 1941. They are to be sold at the lowest rate obtainable.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Wholesale price levels continued upward during the week ended on July 11, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100, rose to 80.3, compared with 79.5 the week ended on July 4, and 79.2 on July 13, 1935.

Your recent editorial "The Cost of the New Deal" is a fair and impartial treatment of a highly controversial subject, but I think your comment might have given more emphasis to the following points without being unduly critical:

Mount Sinai Hospital and Montefiore Hospital receive legacies of $50,000 and $25,000 respectively in the will of Mrs. Stella Heidelberg Abrahamson, widow of Dr. Isador Abrahamson, filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday. The residuary estate was bequeathed to her daughter, Miss Edith Abrahamson of 1,225 Park Avenue.
HARRISBURG, PA., July 16. -- The Senate today by a vote of 31 to 12 passed finally the administration bill increasing from one to four mills the State levy on personal property.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Delegates representing more than 400,000 organized workers met yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker and organized a Labor party in New York State which declared itself for the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman and called upon all labor to desert both old parties and enter upon the road of independent political action.

Federal Judge William Bondy yesterday reserved decision on an application for an order requiring the Lehigh Valley Coal Company to account for allegedly excessive royalties received since 1924 from Coxe Brothers Co., Inc., operators of anthracite coal fields, under a modified lease.
