Too many years ago Mr. J.B. OMAHUNDRO, better known as Texas JACK, used to give an Indian-and-trapper show. The heroine, wearing a Paris gown, silk stockings and diamonds in the depth of the forest, was a delight. But what gave the gallery gods most joy was the "Injuns." In Boston calumny whispered that they were "'port chucks" from Cambridgeport.

Perturbed over the drowning of three children in Central Park this Summer, the police began yesterday a rowboat patrol on the chief lakes of the park, with the object of keeping the children out of the water as much as possible.

The semi-annual financial statement of the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis, made public yesterday, shows gains of more than 50 per cent in mortgage collections, 27 per cent in collections on investment contracts and 9 per cent in new contracts written, with a decrease of nearly 4 per cent in loan grants to and surrenders by contract holders, in the first half of 1935.

ALBANY, July 16. -- Dr. Avery W. Skinner, director of the Examinations and Inspections Division of the State Education Department, retired today after forty-four years of service to the State. He has been connected with the department since 1909 and head of the division since 1920.

The share market moved irresolutely yesterday, but in general the list showed reasonable firmness at the close. Railway stocks, as a group, and some of the high-priced industrial issues made fair progress, as buying continued to be selective in character.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission faced a new problem today -- what procedure to take with recalcitrant witnesses -- when Chauncey Parker Jr., a local stock broker, refused to answer a question at the hearing on the commission's charges that White, Weld Co. of New York had manipulated the market for A.O. 2mith Company stock.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 16. -- The Dardanelles conference mopped up tonight in a plenary session all the minor points remaining except the question of the diplomatic mechanism for putting remilitarization into effect immediately.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 16. -- Governor Hoffman announced today the appointment of Isadore Haber of Union City to be judge of the First Judicial District Court of Hudson County, the position which Judge Morris Umansky, also of Union City, denies he resigned.

The Triborough Bridge registered its highest weekday traffic in the twenty-four hours ending at 8 A.M. yesterday. In that time 30,152 vehicles paid tolls over the span, a number greater by about 5,000 than that of the preceding twenty-four-hour period and more than 1,200 greater than the previous high mark of 28,877 from 8 A. M. Monday to 8 A.M. Tuesday.
PARIS, July 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 16. -Miss Helen Clevenger, 19 years old, of Great Kills, Staten Island, N.Y., was found shot to death in her room at an Asheville hotel this morning.

The directors of the El Paso Natural Gas Company, meeting yesterday in El Paso, Texas, declared a dividend of $26.25 a share to clear up arrears on the 10,001 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value. The dividend is payable on Aug. 1, to stock of record of July 22.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 16. -- The worst disturbance that has yet marked the three-week strike at the Camden plant of the Radio Corporation of America took place today between 2,500 strikers and strike sympathizers in an hour and a half tussle with some 8,000 RCA workers and virtually the entire Camden police force.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- The Corn Belt finished two weeks of the hottest, driest weather it has known today with no relief in prospect and fears growing that a crop disaster exceeding that of 1934 was in the making.

Grace and Ardith Miller of Brooklyn spent two hours of grave suspense yesterday, but everything turned out happily in the end and they sailed away on a West Indies cruise with all the nice dresses that they had been saving for the voyage.
MEXICO, D.F., July 16. -- Three thousand electrical workers went on strike today to force the Canadian-owned Mexican Light and Power Company to pay increased wages.

Plans for uniting all brewers in one national organization received a setback here yesterday with the announcement by Jacob Ruppert, president of the United States Brewers Association, that directors of that group have voted against affiliating with the proposed association on the ground that such a plan was impracticable now.

The younger generation of players in the Eastern clay court championship fairly outdid themselves yesterday at the, Jackson Heights Tennis Club to keep the gallery on tenterhooks throughout the long afternoon's grilling session.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Receipts of hogs today fell materially below expectations and, with a fairly active demand, prices advanced l0 to 35 cents a hundredweight. The top was $10,75, or 25 cents higher than yesterday, while the day's average rose 25 cents to $9.55. No change was reported, however, in the price of fresh pork loins, which were quoted at 14 to 20 cents a pound wholesale.
With America's largest and strongest Olympic expeditionary force safely on the high seas at last, efforts to clear up the financial muddle it left behind continued unabated on two fronts yesterday.

LONDON, July 16. -- King Edward, who has traveled safely to the ends of the earth and mingled freely with thousands of his subjects, escaped assassination today in the heart of his capital just outside the grounds of his own palace.

ROCHESTER, Minn., July 16 (AP). -A statement late today by the Mayo Clinic said that the condition of Governor Floyd Olson of Minnesota was "very comfortable" following an operation this morning to insert a feeding tube and facilitate treatment of a growth in the esophagus.

The contract under which the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has manufactured automobile tires for Sears, Roebuck Co. since 1926 has been terminated, according to an announcement yesterday by P.W. Litchfield, president of Goodyear. The contract accounted for approximately 6 per cent of Goodyear's annual business.

Directors of the Louisville Nashville Railroad have declared a dividend of $2.50 payable on Aug. 24 to stock of record July 28. The last previous dividend was $2, paid on Feb. 25 this year. On Aug. 24, 1935, the company paid $1 and on Feb. 25, 1935, a dividend of $1.50 a share.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 16. -- Finding little need for a one-goal concession, the Governors Island quartet rode into the last round of the annual Hempstead Cups twelve-goal tournament today on Whitney Field at the Meadow Brook Club by beating the South Shore polo team, 9 to 6.

The drive of the Committee for Industrial Organization to unionize the steel industry will continue unabated and "without compromise" regardless of whatever action the executive committee of the American Federation of Labor takes on the matter, Julius Hochman, general manager of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and a member of the steel organization committee, declared last night.
TOKYO, July 16. -- Yesterday's demands by the War Office for an armament program requiring 3,000,000,000 yen in six years aroused the first open criticism of the army's policy heard since February.
Receipts from the city's 2 per cent sales tax up to 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon totaled $9,435,432 for the second quarter of the year, it was announced last night by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

The Johns-Manville Corporation and subsidiary companies reported yesterday in its semi-annual income statement, a consolidated net profit of $1,474,901 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges. After dividend requirements on the 7 per cent preferred stock, the earnings equalled $1.62 each on the 750,000 shares of common stock outstanding.
The Board of Standards and Appeals, after hearings yesterday, reserved decision on two questions of vital importance to the city's building industry.

Apart from continued weakness in the prices of United States Government bonds, the financial markets continued yesterday to show no concern over the announcement of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System that it would increase the reserve requirements of member banks by 50 per cent on Aug. 15.

Joseph A. Solovei, who was attorney for the murderers of Samuel Drukman, replied yesterday to the grand jury's charges seeking his disbarment by disclaiming all participation in the conspiracy and by defending his "constitutional right" to refuse to waive immunity before the grand jury.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 17. -- Officials denied today that Rumania was to construct a new railroad connecting Czechoslovakia directly with Russia over Rumanian territory.

Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission sought additional testimony yesterday in the form of correspondence, resolutions and documents dealing with the operations of the Fashion Originators Guild of America in its action against this and affiliated organizations for restraint of trade in this field.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 17. -- In a day featured by sensational scoring, topped off by a hole-in-one, made by Tommy Goodwin, former titleholder, most of the favorites came through the first two rounds of the fourteenth annual New York State amateur golf championship with flying colors.

An outstanding feature of the final Olympic team trials at Randalls Island was the qualification of no less than ten University of Southern California athletes -- a performance for which due credit should go to their coach, Dean Cromwell.

A resumption of public utility refunding operations lifted new bond financing this week to $109,208,000 from the $24,602,000 of bonds offered last week. A year ago this week the amount was $234,148,000, which was marked by heavy utility financing.

The Joint Council Knitgoods Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday that it had ordered walkouts in four plants in Brooklyn and near-by New Jersey to prevent employers from scrapping the thirty-five-hour week and returning to the forty-hour week.

Taking cognizance of the age, health and "ignorance" of the accused man before him, Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell imposed yesterday a sentence of $1,000 fine and a six-month suspended prison term on Martin Garone, East Side realty man, for failing to pay an income tax for 1929.

ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, July 17. -- At a preliminary meeting of competitors and committeemen held today at the Grand Hotel, rules for the international chess masters tournament, scheduled to start tomorrow, were discussed.

Evidence that a woman politician obtained $6,625 from thirteen persons upon her promise to obtain political jobs, liquor and beer licenses and, in one case, admission to a medical school in return, was sent to District Attorney Dodge yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Bishop Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit will sail today on the Italian liner Rex for a visit to Rome and the Vatican, it was learned yesterday. The Italian Line's advance passenger list does not include his name, but it was learned elsewhere that both he and Bishop Joseph Schrembs of Cleveland would be aboard.

One of the most far-reaching codes of ethics ever proposed in an industry for government regulation of its own advertising was recommended yesterday at Providence, R.I., to the national conference of State Liquor Administrators by Ernest C. Kennedy of National Distillers Products.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17. -- An interesting constitutional situation has been created by the judgment of the judicial committee of the Privy Council in London overruling the decision of the Commonwealth High Court upholding the validity of legislation whereby sale of dried fruit is forbidden except through a board appointed by the Commonwealth.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 17. -- Thomas Brown, former St. Paul chief of police and recently head of the police auto theft division, was suspended today as testimony was given in the trial of Jack Peifer, night club owner, on kidnap charges that $25,000 of the $100,000 ransom paid for the release of William Hamm Jr. was for Brown.
WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The AAA announced today that it would begin the purchase and processing of 2,000,000 bushels of Pacific wheat next week to be doled out during the Winter to drought sufferers.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- A series of political planks for women, aimed generally at removal of discrimination against them in public affairs, was offered the feminine voters of the country today by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

Governor Lehman, who is awaiting District Attorney Geoghan's reply to the Drukman grand jury's charges of unfitness and incompetence, recently wrote to the prosecutor about another case, which, like the Drukman case, resulted first in exoneration, but later in the indictment of a defendant.

Word from the Coast is that because of the box-office success of "The Milky Way" Paramount has been emboldened to make an offer of sufficient attractiveness to lure Harold Lloyd from independent production. A contract probably will be signed Saturday calling for two pictures.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and including Wells-Dickey Company, Hemphill, Noyes Co. and Riter Co. offered yesterday to the public a new issue of $4,200,000 of Northwest Publications, Inc., 4 1/2 per cent debenture bonds due on July 1, 1948. The bonds were priced at par and accrued interest.

SOUTHAMPTON, July 17. -- Mrs. Henry Lorillard Cammann and her sister, Miss Louise B. Willard, entertained with a dinner tonight at Lougret Lodge for Mr. and Mrs. Bradish Johnson Carroll, who are visiting Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine. Others in their party were Mrs. Valentine and Mrs. Henry Warner Slocum, who is visiting Mrs. Cammann and Miss Willard.
PASTO, Colombia, July 17 (AP). -- A violent earthquake at noon today caused serious damage here and in neighboring villages of Narino Department. Communications were interrupted.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 17. -Hope for general trade improvement in the Lehigh Valley area was expressed by E.G. Grace, president of Bethlehem Steel Corporation, in addressing the joint annual Bethlehem Day meeting of the Service Clubs today.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Forty-three yachts, a record fleet, will put out from Belmont Harbor tomorrow afternoon for the twenty-ninth sailing of the Chicago Yacht Club's race to Mackinac Island, the longest fresh water race in the world.

A portrait of John Purroy Mitchel, Mayor of New York from 1914 to 1917, was presented yesterday afternoon to the officers and men of the United States Army air base at Mitchel Field, L.I., by Mayor La Guardia in a ceremony held in the lounge of the Officers' Club at the flying field.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP). -- Jimmy Foxx lifted the Red Sox back into third place today by hitting a ninth-inning single with the bases filled and driving in all the runs needed for a 2-1 triumph over the Browns.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 17. -- Miss Harriet K. Welles was a luncheon hostess today at Curtis Hotel, Lenox, in honor of Misses Georgiana W. Sargent and Ethel Brooks. At the Curtis are Mrs. Robert W. Patterson, Mr. and Mrs. Hiram C. Todd and Mrs. Hayden Butts.

Beneficial rains over parts of the Mississippi Valley and Eastern States influenced sentiment on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The market was under pressure from the start with sufficient selling activity to fill a large quantity of scale buying orders, uncover stop loss limits and carry October off half a cent a pound from recent high levels.

RUMSON, N.J., July 17. -- Outstanding in the polo division, the chestnut mare, Dixie Star, owned by Sheldon E. Prentice of Rumson, capped a series of first-class performances today by gaining the award of champion polo mount. It was the only title event of the second day of the annual Monmouth County horse show.

Business trends were mixed this week, with high temperatures holding down retail distribution in many sections of the country, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. While there was a moderate improvement in retail sales in drought-affected areas where rainfall occurred, the agency says that in sections where the thermometer held steadily above the century mark there was a decline of 3 to 5 per cent.

ST. PAUL, July 17. -- Charging through the blazing rays of a hot sun in the morning and later a wind and rain storm, five golfers gave par a four-stroke cut today to tie for the lead in the first round of the $5,000 St. Paul 72-hole open tournament.

Yesterday's slight firming in bankers' acceptance rates was not important in itself, but it was interesting as constituting the first natural hardening of interest rates in years, the jacking-up of call money last May having been wholly artificial.

SANDOWN PARK, England, July 17 (Canadian Press). -- Lord Astor's Rhodes Scholar today won the Eclipse Stakes by the handy margin of six lengths, with Lord Carnarvon's His Grace second and Fairey third.
HONGKONG, July 17. -- Chen Weichou, brother of General Chen Chia-tang, was seriously wounded by a gunman as he was leaving a conference in Canton today.

BERLIN, July 17. -- Trading on the Boerse was dull, and prices ended irregular today. Several specialties were able to register gains, but heavy industrials and other leading securities were generally weaker.

ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, AT SEA, July 17. -- The composition of the United States Olympic relay teams was the chief concern today of Lawson Robertson, track coach, who gave much thought to the possible combinations.
Why not carry out in New York the idea, which seems to be meeting with popular favor in the South, of night tennis in the public parks?

The letter signed by George M. Robinson was most interesting. I did not vote for every Democrat since I became of age -- which was some time after Grover Cleveland. I voted for Theodore Roosevelt in 1912 and for Woodrow Wilson in 1916 and have been a strong and loyal Democrat ever since.

THAD ST. MARTIN has done a fine job in his little novel called "Madame Toussaint's Wedding Day" (Little, Brown, $2.50). Lusty, witty and cleverly constructed, this is the sort of local-color story that deserves high praise and a wide audience. It is a small and unpretentious thing, but good.
CHICAGO, July 17. -- The fifteen-day-old heat wave softened its intensity in some States today, but not in the Corn Belt.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The Bureau of Mines estimated today that a domestic production of 2,936,900 barrels of crude oil daily would be required to meet the demand in August and provide for reasonable changes in stocks. The daily production recommended for next month is 19,700 barrels more than this month and 281,900 above August, 1935.
The Federal Theatre Project of the WPA finds itself pretty well preempting the local news dispatches this morning. The items are:

CAMDEN, N.J., July 17. -- Rioting broke out again late today outside the plant of the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company here after Justice Frank T. Lloyd of the State Supreme Court, sitting as a committing magistrate, had held 101 persons in total bail of $523,000 in connection with serious disorders yesterday growing out of the R.C.A. strike, now three-and-a-half weeks old.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 17. -- Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., won her second leg on the Griswold Cup today by heating Mrs. Frederick Davis, also of Providence, 3 and 1, in the final of the eighteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament at the Shenecossett Club.

Although the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company has discontinued all newspaper advertising in the Eastern district, it was a moot question yesterday as to whether housewives would be deprived of reading about food and drug bargains in their morning papers in the future.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 17. -- Power boat drivers opened the two-day seventh annual regatta of the Havre de Grace Yacht Club today with four dashes of world-record speed.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 17. -- With opening-day sessions marked by the appearance of Postmaster General Farley, New York State Postmasters and Postal Supervisors met in annual convention today, with the election of officers scheduled for tomorrow.

TOKYO, July 17. -- Keinosuke Ushio, Minister of Home Affairs, in a published statement today, exhorts the people to attend to their affairs with easy minds now that martial law is to be abolished and maintenance of order in Tokyo restored to the police.
Victor F. Ridder, local WPA Administrator, asked Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday to provide police protection against picketing to a member of his staff.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP). -- The White Sox today blasted three Washington pitchers for nineteen hits and an easy 16-5 decision over the Senators for their third straight triumph. It was the fourth consecutive series the Chicago team has won and its tenth victory in fourteen starts over Washington this season.
The bottom all but dropped out of the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

PARIS, July 17. -- By an even larger majority than it yesterday approved reconstruction of the Bank of France, the Chamber of Deputies today approved the government's bill providing for expropriation by decree of private armaments manufacturers and nationalization of the arms industry.

CINCINNATI, July 17. -- Although the heat wave receded somewhat here today the Dodgers bounced back to their torrid ways against the Cards to take the final game from the Reds, 5 -- 3, behind the seven-hit pitching of Van Lingle Mungo, while a meager crowd of 1,200 cheered in vain for the Dressen youngsters.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 17. -- John Applegate, 38 years old, of Neptune, N.J., was sentenced to life imprisonment as a habitual offender here today by Judge J. Edward Knight in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. It is said to be the first time the 1927 statute has been invoked in Monmouth County.
Industrial and residential properties were included in the Westchester realty turnover reported yesterday.

A brunette, attired in shimmering white silk, won easily in the twenty-first annual beauty, contest for babies, conducted yesterday by the Educational Alliance, atop its building at Jefferson Street and East Broadway.
BERLIN, July 17. -- The creation of "military communism" immediately on the outbreak of a new war is demanded in an article published in the important "Periodical for Military Technique."

ALBANY, N.Y., July 17. -- Twenty-five banks and trust companies have received certificates of authority from the State Banking Department to operate personal loan departments, pursuant to Section 114-A or Section 200-A of the Banking Law, the department announced today.

Mrs. Nathalie Sedgwick Colby, novelist, has joined the workers for the re-election of President Roosevelt as a radio speaker, it was announced yesterday by Miss Mary W. Dewson at her first press conference as head of the Democratic women.

BUFFALO, July 17 (AP). -- Rallying briskly in the final chapter for three runs, the Bisons defeated the Newark Bears tonight, winning 7-6, to boost their winning string to eight in a row and allowing Carl (Lefty) Fischer, league-leading curver, to win his eighth in a row since joining the local club.

CAPE SABLE, N.S., July 17. -- President Roosevelt had enjoyed his longest day's sail under canvas since his boyhood when he anchored the Sewanna late today at Cape Sable after a thirty-hour continuous cruise from Seal Harbor, Me., which harbor the Sewanna and its accompanying flotilla left at 10:15 o'clock yesterday morning.

TOPEKA, July 17. -- A statement praising Governor Landon, Republican nominee for President, and criticizing the spending policies of the national administration was issued here today by John R. McCarl, who has just completed his fifteen-year term as Controller General.

An eleven-year court battle over the provisions of his father's will ended yesterday when Robert S. Boggiano, 16 years old, who lives with his mother at 244 Beach 139th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens, received a signed order from Surrogate John Hetherington granting him $5,014.10 from the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 17 (AP). -- A strategic railway across Bessarabia to connect Russia and Czechoslovakia was revealed tonight as a project of the general staffs of the Little Entente -- Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia. The staffs conferred in Bucharest recently.

Relative to Wadsworth W. Mounts's complaint "Why should the people of New York have to breathe the heavy exhaust gases?" I, too, have often wondered why we are tolerating the filthy conditions of our surface cars, elevateds, subways and buses.

Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Minister to Sweden, and Mrs. Steinhardt gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Captain Boerge Rohde and Mrs. Rohde, the former Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, United States Minister to Denmark.
THE weather was fairly cool, and so was Marse Joe McCarthy, the skipper of the Yankee ball club. In fact, Marse Joe came close to being coldly critical.

SHAG HARBOR, N.S., July 17. -- President Roosevelt left the Sewanna this evening for the first time since he began his cruise to make a fishing excursion in a small motor boat in the shore waters off Cape Sable.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 17. -- A coroner's jury investigating the death of Miss Helen Clevenger, 19, of Great Kills, Staten Island, N.Y., who was found murdered yesterday morning in her room at a hotel here, this afternoon returned a verdict that she "came to her death at the hands of parties unknown to this jury."

LONDON, July 17. -- King Edward's grateful subjects descended by the dozens upon busy Scotland Yard today to tell the fateful story of his escape from assassination while physicians examined his assailant in a prison hospital mental ward.

Finding their plight rather desperate, Mickey Cochrane's dashing Tigers chose to throw science to the four winds at the Stadium yesterday and make their concluding number with the Yankees strictly a slugging affair.

OMAHA, Neb., July 17. -- Young Paul Leslie of Jefferson City, Mo., made a balky putter operate to perfection today on one all-important green, the thirty-eighth, to overcome Jack Munger of Dallas, the Southern amateur champion, in the five-star thriller of the Western amateur golf title tournament.

WARSAW, Poland, July 17. -- More than 40,000 demonstrated tonight in the streets of Warsaw against concessions to Danzig. This quite unusual gathering of Socialists, Fascists, pro-Government and Opposition forces, gentiles and Jews -- all opposed granting the demands of the Danzig Nazis.
WESTWOOD, N.J., July 17. -Recorder Edward Staunton was a defendant in his own court here tonight and had the further experience of hearing himself pronounced "not guilty."

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Seven stars of Minnesota's "thundering herd" are thundering along at a hot pace in the poll which 182 newspapers are conducting to select a collegiate all-star football team to meet the Detroit Lions, world's professional champions, at Soldier Field the night of Sept. 1.
I cannot refrain from taking part in the discussion generated by our participation in the Olympic Games. Whether pro or con, I think reasons given should be absolutely frank and sincere.
I would like to express my views on the All-Star game as it now is conducted and to offer suggestions that I believe would, if adopted, make the contest a really satisfactory attraction.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- Prices of corn continued today the advance that was interrupted yesterday when the upturn on the Board of Trade was limited by the Exchange's regulations preventing the market from soaring more than 4 cents in a day.

VIENNA, July 17. -- The first effect of the new Austro-German pact on the Legitimists was indicated today in the sudden departure of Archduchess Adelaide, Archduke Otto's eldest sister. It was stated in Legitimist circles that her contemplated return here in the Fall was now uncertain.
TOPEKA, July 17. -- The official program for the Landon notification ceremonies here next Thursday was made public today by Mark Drehmer, secretary of the Topeka Chamber of Commerce.

MOSCOW, July 17. -- Today is the sixtieth birthday of Foreign Commissar Maxim Litvinoff, which was marked by the Moscow press with displays almost covering front pages of the leading newspapers and editorials with such captions as "The Ambassador of Peace" or "The Stalinist Flag Bearer of Peace."
BERLIN, July 17 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 16 shows the following changes from the preceding week. Figures are in thousands of marks:
LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, July 17 (AP). -- A heavily chained and guarded Irish republican tonight defiantly challenged the right of a British court to bring him before the bar of justice.

A tenth edition -- this one of 10,000 copies -- of "Around the World in Eleven Years," by the Abbe children, is announced by Stokes. The total of copies printed of this best seller is now more than 50,000.

Reluctantly we must confess to a little disappointment of our expectations in regard to Chairman JOHN HAMILTON. He was so engaging, tactful and clever in promoting the candidacy of Governor LANDON that it was natural to attribute to him a genius for political management.

The filly Good Gamble, winner of the rich Butler Handicap last week in track record time, will again be the main reliance of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt for stake honors this afternoon. The filly is one of three entered to carry the Vanderbilt colors in the Yonkers Handicap, mile-and-a-sixteenth test at the Empire City course, which is expected to gross about $7,500 in value.

Challenging the claims of wholesalers that the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act permits "the granting of differentials to them simply because they are wholesalers," Irving C. Fox, counsel of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday that the attempts of wholesalers to write a wholesaler price-differential into the law "were definitely defeated prior to the passage of the act."

Plaintiffs yesterday bought in two properties in Manhattan and seven in the Bronx at foreclosure auction sales. The largest offering involved the sixteen-story apartment house at 410 Central Park West, south corner of 101st Street.

The incorrect attitude often taken by parents toward a child with abnormal hearing can easily result in the development of a "problem child," Dr. Fred J. Cohen of Witchita, Kan., warned yesterday at the annual convention of the American Osteopathic Society of Ophthalmology and Otolaryngology in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

MANILA, July 17 (AP) -- Rajah Muda, who threatened to fight for the Sultanate of Sulu, was proclaimed spiritual chief of the Moros today in a solemn ceremony in the sacred room of the Sultan's Palace on Jolo Island.

Most of a cross-section of teachers in the nation's secondary schools who voted for Hoover in 1932 will vote for President Roosevelt this year, according to the results of a survey the John Dewey Society for the Study of Education made public yesterday.

More than most agitators who attain power, HITLER is consistent with himself. In "Mein Kampf" he traces clearly what should be the lines of German foreign policy and asserts repeatedly that foreign policy is but a means to an end. That end, he declares, is to "assure the German nation the territory which is due it on the earth."

NEWPORT, R. I., July 17. -- Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbill opened their training ring building at their home, Oakland Farm, in Portsmouth tonight for the Sunflower Ball, given under the auspices of the Young Men's and Young Women's Republican Citizen's Leagues of this city.

On complaint of an insurance broker that he had been defrauded of $105,000 in cash and securities by a "short, plump, motherly looking woman of middle age," Assistant Attorneys General Joseph F. Ruggieri and William Koerner began legal action yesterday against Mrs. Margaret Robinson and sent out detectives of the Attorney General's staff to find her.

The second annual service for children in the Daily Vacation Bible Schools will be held in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Thursday at 11 A.M. More than 1,000 girls and boys are expected. Free transportation has been offered by the subway systems to all schools participating.

Practical farmers and agrarian economists may be able to find flaws in the immediate and long-term programs for the drought areas announced this week at Bismarck, N.D., by the Resettlement Administration, acting in cooperation with the WPA and the Department of Agriculture.
TOKYO, Saturday, July 18. -Japan will sign the Dardanelles pact with reservations safeguarding her rights as a non-member of the League of Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The American Liberty League has disavowed all connection with Henry Breckinridge, a former Democrat, who announced a few days ago that he would support Governor Landon for President.

BERLIN, July 17. -- Official Germany has been left cold by the news that France, Belgium and Britain, the three powers chiefly interested in the now-broken Locerno treaty and still faithful to their obligations under it, will meet in London next week to consider their position before a larger conference, to include Italy and Germany, is called for a later date.

Tuna fishermen, who have been making their headquarters at Manasquan, N.J., are finding the fishing better than it was at a corresponding time last season. The eleven boats sailing from the Manasquan Tuna Club have been averaging from ten to forty fish each on daily offshore trips.

PARIS, July 17. -- Colonel Francois de la Rocque's disbanded Croix de Feu was authorized by the Council of State to continue its "social work," a ruling which leaders tonight termed an "empty victory."
Net income of the Standard Gas and Electric Company for 1935 was $2,117,049 after all charges, according to a summary of the annual report issued yesterday.
MEXICO, D.F., July 17. -- The Conciliation and Arbitration Board of the government tonight declared that the strike of the workers in the Canadian-owned Mexican Light and Power Company is legal.

Lumber production last week showed an increase but the daily average was lower than in the previous weeks, when a larger allowance was made for the holiday. The decline was contrary to the usual seasonal rise and the adjusted index dropped sharply to 83.9 from 93.1 and compared with 63.6 for the corresponding week last year.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, July 18. -- Kwangtung Province's opposition to Nanking has collapsed. General Chen Chia-tang, Canton leader, is reported to have fled to the foreign concession area at Shameen last night to board a British gunboat, intending to go to Hongkong.
The logic and the political philosophy which are revealed in your editorial "Relief in Pennsylvania" are of a shocking nature and bound to alarm the American public.

BISLEY CAMP, SURREY, July 17 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's hopes for a major victory at the present National Rifle Association meeting were pinned tonight on the eight marksmen she sent into the final stage of competition for the King's prize tomorrow.

A.B. Cohen, former president of the Cloak and Suit Salesmen's Association of America, Inc., is now connected with the Schaeffer Garment Company of Cincinnati in a sales capacity and will travel on Aug. 1 in the Midwest.

Charging that Harry L. Hopkins, administrator of the Works Progress Administration, had acted illegally in denying vacations, two test suits filed yesterday called upon the United States District Court to grant twenty-six-day holidays with pay to workers on the WPA rolls.

BERLIN, July 17. -- The Ministry of Propaganda and Public Enlightenment opened today, in connection with the Olympic Games, a political propagandist exhibition of a type now familiar in Soviet Russia, Italy and Germany. It is the largest effort of its kind made to date by the Berlin propaganda authorities.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 17. -- Mrs. Walter Momm of Suburban carded an 87 today over the Forest Hill Field Club course to win her first low gross prize of the season in a New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament. Scoring was uniformly low, six of the players breaking ninety.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 17. -- Dr. Howard Beers, Associate Professor of Rural Sociology at New Jersey College of Agriculture here, received notice today he had been appointed as special assistant to the Resettlement Administration to work for two months on drought relief in the Middle West.

Favored by cooler weather, trade in the metropolitan area recovered quickly from the retarding effects of the heat wave and sales volume moved a head sharply. Estimates by retail executives here put sales at 15 per cent ahead of the comparative 1935 period.

Julius Hochman, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, is scheduled to be the choice of the Socialist party for Aldermanic President at its convention today, and his prospective candidacy may provide major developments in the city campaign this year.

Price changes were mixed yesterday in the markets here for commodity futures. Business generally was at a standstill, but hides were a strong exception. In the cash markets, corn and Rio coffee made new high marks and Santos coffee, hides and Straits tin advanced. Wheat, cotton, rye, oats, flour, print cloths, butter, standard tin, cocoa and silk became easier.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 17. -- The destroyer McDougal, the navy's newest 1,850-ton fighting ship, was launched today in the presence of a small group of naval officers, shipbuilding company officials and civilians at the plant of the New York Shipbuilding Company here.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17. -- Yachts of every description began gathering tonight for the opening of Larchmont race week tomorrow. It always is the banner session of the season's competition on Long Island Sound and this year all-time records in the number of competitors are expected to be surpassed and a new tonnage mark for recent Summers set.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 17. -Five adult, performing lions eat sixty pounds of fresh beef every day, which runs into money, as nobody knows better than Captain Fred Marks, owner of the beasts, who has to pay for it, and Harry Bernstein, Woodbridge butcher, who extends credit for it.

Retailers and consumers should join forces and present their views on all proposed sales tax legislation, Colonel Clarence O. Sherrill, president of the American Retail Federation, said here yesterday in making public the results of a survey made of sales tax legislation in various States of his organization.

The report of the Southern Pacific Company to the Interstate Commerce Commission on net income for June shows that the company has begun to credit to its accounts the $814,664 set aside for liabilities under the two railway pension laws now before the courts for review.

ASHLAND, Va., July 17. -- Senator Glass invoked the memory of Patrick Henry to fire a broadside at the New Deal today as he made an extemporaneous address here at the bicentennial celebration of the Virginia patriot's death.

Thomas P. de Graffenried, attorney, of Douglaston, has bought the Judge's Chop House at the northeast corner of Twombly Place and Archer Avenue, Jamaica, from Josephine and Louise Schiellein, sisters of the late Emil (Judge) Schiellein.

CLEVELAND, July 17. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend took a two-way walk tonight at the second annual convention of his followers, whom he seeks to lead into William Lemke's third party camp without calling upon them to announce their destination.

MOSCOW, July 17. -- What is claimed here to have been the biggest artificial explosion in the world occurred yesterday in the village of Korkina, near Chelyabinsk, in the eastern Urals, when 1,830 tons of ammonite were ignited in a terrific blast to enable easy access to a great new surface coal deposit.

The accomplishments of the WPA's educational puppetry project were demonstrated yesterday at the opening of an exhibition called "Backstage in Child Welfare" in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center.

MONTREAL, July 17. -- The City Council of Montreal today ordered its executive committee immediately to try to effect voluntary conversion of the city's $280,000,000 debt at lower interest rates by negotiation with Canadian and foreign holders of the city's bonds.

Fidelity Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that the net asset value of its stock on June 30 was $26.97 a share for the 131,024 shares outstanding, against $26.23 a share on March 31. After adjustment for the 100 per cent stock dividend paid on Feb. 15, indicated appreciation was 10.4 per cent for the first half of 1936 and 30 per cent since June 30, 1935.

PITTSBURGH, July 17. -- Carl Hubbell, master of the screwball, was the acme of perfection today at Forbes Field as, under the protection of a record assault, the Giants humbled the Pirates and took their third straight from Pie Traynor's band in a four-game series they should have swept.

The stock market absorbed profit-taking handily yesterday and closed higher for the ninth consecutive trading day. All THE NEW YORK TIMES stock averages touched new high points for the year, although pressure in the final hour sent prices down somewhat from the day's best levels.
MONTREAL, July 17 (Canadian Press). -- Canada's Olympic squad, its strength fortified by joining of last-minute members, sailed for Berlin and the 1938 games today.

James W. Gerard, former United States Ambassador to Germany, and Mrs. Gerard; Charles Bridgham Hosmer, American Consul at Naples; Colonel and Mrs. Cecil Rae and Colonel and Mrs. M. Sholtz are among those sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Rex.
Uptown housing properties featured the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.
New-home building and modernization of old dwellings is proceeding at a rate greater than that at any time since May, 1931, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 17. -- One of the best-played games in the twenty years of annual competition took place at the Rockaway Hunting Club today, with the Harvard Club baseball team defeating the Yale Club representatives, 5 to 0, in the second game for the third Adee-Marvin Trophy.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP). -- The Indians kept pace with the league-leading Yankees today, beating the Athletics, 5 to 1, for their seventh consecutive triumph.
LONDON, July 17. -- The British and French Governments have yielded to each other on the subject of the Locarno powers' conference, which originally was scheduled to meet in Brussels next Wednesday.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $6,002,446, the issues of two States and thirty-eight municipalities accounting for the total. It compares with the revised total of $8,064,250 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date is $22,653,323.

BOSTON, July 17. -- Unleashing a bolt of speed that squelched her stoutest challenger, Lady Higloss, Miss A. Doris's chestnut mare, flew her purple and white silks on top all the way to set a new track record of 1:10 4-5 in the Back Bay purse, six-furlong sprint feature, today before 10,000 fans at Suffolk Downs.

The first change in rates for bankers' acceptances since Oct. 24, 1934, and the first advance in them in nearly three years was effected yesterday when a few dealers raised their discounts on bills having up to four months to run. The change, which was an aftermath of the announcement on Tuesday of the Reserve Board's intention to increase member bank reserve requirements, was not followed by all dealers.

Conflicting price movements characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government loans declined still further in fairly heavy volume, although some bids were entered for their support in late trading. As a result, closing prices were slightly above the 10WS of the day. Net declines, however, ranged from 1-32 to 8-32 point.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17. -- The body of Albert Emanuel, 30, of 505 Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn, was found this afternoon under a pear tree on an abandoned athletic field in Upper Derby, a suburb. Deputy Coroner Charles H. Drewes of Delaware County said death was from a hemorrhage of the brain caused by a basal fracture of the skull.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Another controversy between the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and twelve unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization loomed today when William Green, president of the A.F. of L., stated that the council had adopted rules which gave it the right to suspend refractory national and international unions, a power not specifically accorded to it in the federation's constitution.

NEWARK, N.J., July 17. -- A special session of the Federal Grand Jury for New Jersey was called today for next Thursday, to hear the opinion of United States Attorney John J. Quinn on the question of jurisdiction in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

The semi-annual report of the American Chicle Company, to be given out today, shows a net profit of $1,459,835 after providing for all charges, including reserve for estimated income taxes. Earnings for the first six months of this year were $3.32 on each of 440,000 shares outstanding.

PIERRE, S.D., July 17. -- President Roosevelt's drought-relief mission moved swiftly today to meet an emergency situation throughout Southern South Dakota caused by a serious shortage of water for human consumption as well as for livestock.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

BOSTON, July 17. -- John D.M. Hamilton quoted tonight from a letter and application blank purporting to have been sent from the office of Governor Leslie A. Miller, Democrat, of Wyoming, to an applicant for a foreman's job in the CCC last year, in which, Mr. Hamilton said, the applicant was asked to tell what services and contributions he had given to the Democratic party.

Accused by the police of being members of a gang which committed numerous hold-ups in Brooklyn, eight youths were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Vincent J. Sweeney in Brooklyn Felonly Court. Three were held. Four who were dismissed were rearrested on other charges and one of these was freed.

Announcement was made yesterday of the signing of agreements governing distribution of freight and details of rates by ship lines operating in the westbound Atlantic trade and in the intercoastal service.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Operations of the United States Treasury in June, notably the payment of the veterans' bonus, exercised a marked influence on financial conditions in general in a month when excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System showed sharp decreases and the amount of money in circulation increased by $250,000,000 following the bonus payment on June 15.

President ROOSEVELT'S acceptance last week of the invitation of Peru and Ecuador to arbitrate their prolonged boundary dispute helps to revive a useful custom, somewhat overshadowed during recent decades by the development of more formal arbitral machinery.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- The small receipts of hogs here sold today at steady prices although common quality underweights and some heavy packing sows were weak. The extreme top of $10.75 a hundredweight was unchanged from yesterday as was the day's average of $9.55.

ALBANY, July 17. -- Fifteen members of the newly created State Board of Social Welfare, which, after July 1 next, will be in complete control of the State's relief activities, were named today by Governor Lehman. The new board, which includes several of the members of the old board of twelve, will meet soon and is expected to select David C. Adie of Buffalo as Commissioner of Social Welfare.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 17. -- "Howdy, stranger," a greeting typical of the Southwest, went up on an electric sign across the main entrance to the Fort Worth Frontier Centennial tonight as citizens prepared to open tomorrow this city's contribution to the 100th birthday celebration that marks Texas' independence.
The Eastern junior tennis titles yesterday became the property of the two Western players entered in the sectional championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- A vigorous defense of the reciprocal trade program coupled with a sharp attack on the critics who "maliciously distort" its effects on agriculture was made by Secretary Hull tonight in a statement which was generally interpreted as the administration's opening gun on the tariff question in the Presidential campaign.

I note your comment of "It isn't as simple as that" to my "Racing Camera" letter in last Saturday's TIMES. If there is anything "simpler" than the fact that the "line of vision," of a (one) human eye or the lens of a camera, is a perpendicular line directly in front, then I'm "from Missouri."

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- Representing seven insurance companies and one bank that hold $16,941,400 first mortgage bonds of the Western Pacific Railroad Company, Frederick H. Ecker, John W. Stedman and Reeve Schley have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for leave to intervene in the reorganization of the railroad, it developed today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17. -- Plans have been outlined for increasing the militia strength of the country to 35,000, as the nucleus of a force of 200,000 required to repel an aggressor, by attracting a greater number of volunteers through higher pay, improved equipment and greater social and sporting facilities.
BERLIN, July 17. -- In order to prepare them for the ordeal of the Olympics, Berlin's working population today began "a week of laughter" at the suggestion of the Labor Front.

At the Cleveland convention of the Triple Aginers the most emphatic note sounded was the shirtsleeves note. A family group picture of Father COUGHLIN, Dr. TOWNSEND and the Rev. GERALD SMITH of Louisiana shows not a vest among them.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Wally Berger's fourteenth home run of the season and a six-hit game by Bob Smith enabled the Bees to overcome the Cubs, 5 to 1, in the final game of the series today.

LONDON, July 17. -- Great crowds coming on a pilgrimage of thankfulness for the escape of King Edward from assassination yesterday waited all day long outside Buckingham Palace today to see him, thronging the pavements in rows ten and twelve deep and standing in hundreds on the steps of the Victoria Memorial.

ST. LOUIS. July 17 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean won his fifteenth victory of the season today after losing his sixth game yesterday, and the 5-to-4 triumph of the Cardinals prevented a sweep of the three-game series by the Phillies.

As a life-long Democrat and the son of one I am moved to ask your correspondent, George M. Robinson, whose letter states that he has been a Democrat since the days of Cleveland, if he would be willing to set down the chief reasons why in that long period he preferred the Democratic party to the Republican.

The Tanners Council of America charged yesterday that Governor Landon was encouraging State competition with private Industry and "violating the tenets of the Republican platform" by selling drought sheepskins, obtained from the Federal Government, in the open market.

LONDON, July 17. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were generally cheerful although it was the last day of the account. British funds were distinctly firmer because of a statement that a defense loan is not probable this year. French and Far Eastern securities rose in the foreign department, while German issues were irregular. The international list was eased by the view here of Wall Street uncertainty.

May I comment on the letter of George Gordon Battle that appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 11? Mr. Battle expressed the hope that the public would support the efforts of the Lawyers Committee for Minimum Wage Legislation in New York State that is headed by Frank H. Sommer, dean of the New York University School of Law.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday unanimously upheld Federal Judge John C. Knox in his refusal to issue temporary injunctions against Posfmaster Albert Goldman to restrain him from barring the use of the mails to the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman is the head, and the Association for Legalizing American Lotteries, Inc.

The sectional qualifying rounds for the 1936 national amateur championship will be held on Aug. 11 and 25, it was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association. The country has been divided into thirty-two districts, three more than last year, in anticipation of an even greater number of entrants than in 1935, when 945 competed.

Without waiting for Mayor La Guardia who had announced that he would make known his choice today, the New York City Republican county leaders designated yesterday Alderman Newbold Morris, representing the Fifteenth Aldermanic District, as candidate for nomination as President of the Board of Aldermen in the primaries.

CHICAGO, July 17. -- The queen of the American turf for 1936 will be crowned at Arlington Park tomorrow with the eighth running of the $10,000 added Lassie Stakes, richest race for 2-year-old fillies in the world.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Saturday, July 18. -- A slim band of invaders from New York turned back New England's best bridge players for the second time here early this morning, when a team headed by Sam Fry Jr. and Edward Hymes Jr. won the team of four play in the Southern New England contract bridge championship.

None of the boats in the Larchmont Yacht Club's 320-mile race out around Long Island and the Fire Island lightship had finished at midnight last night. The light westerly air that was blowing held out little hope of a finish in the near future.

The application by Robert W. Goelet for an order directing License Commissioner Paul Moss to approve his application for a moving-picture theatre license at 61 East Fifty-third Street met with strong opposition when it came before Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, July 17 (AP). -- Pedro Albizu Campos, leader of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party, who is on trial for conspiracy to overthrow the United States administration by force, asserted today the party was not guilty of conspiracy to revolt.
LONDON, Saturday, July 18. -- The government's decision permanently, to reinforce the British fleet in the Mediterranean already is being carried into effect, according to Hector C. Bywater.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 17. -- Arguments of four schools of political thought were presented today at the University of Virginia Institute of Public Affairs. The speakers were Secretary Ickes; former Senator Bingham of Connecticut, Republican; Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, and Earl Browder, Communist nominee for President.

DES MOINES, Iowa, July 17. -- The death of Senator Murphy in an automobile accident has thrown Iowa politics into confusion, and dozens of men have been mentioned within twenty-four hours as possible candidates to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- The Pan-American Conference to be held in Buenos Aires late this Fall at the suggestion of President Roosevelt to consider means for promoting peace in the Western Hemisphere will be held substantially to that main objective.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 17. -- John Hendron, 30 years old, of 10 Cedar Street, Tuckahoe, was shot by a masked hold-up man late last night on Scarsdale Road near Harney Street in a wooded district of North Yonkers. Police began a search today for the robber, who escaped with Hendron's coat containing a wallet with $47.
BOSTON, July 17. -- Following is the test of Chairman Hamilton's prepared address at a Republican rally here tonight:

DEPARTURE of America's athletes for the 1936 Olympic Games, which open in Berlin on Aug. 1, has focused the attention of the nation's philatelists on a new set of Olympic stamps. For this year's games, Germany has issued eight stamps of varying values, several of which portray sports which have not appeared before on stamp issues.

While drought conditions and the protracted heat wave seriously curtailed business activity in many sections of the country last week, particularly in the Middle West, trade held up remarkably well in other areas. Figures on retail distribution continued to show substantial gains over those for the same period last year in most districts.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 18. -- The youths comprising the Citizens' Military Training Camp Provisional Regiment paraded this evening, with their officers composed entirely of young men who themselves were trained only a year ago, and who are classed as "blue" trainees.

Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, which recently has discovered indications of a voters' trend away from President Roosevelt, was taken to task yesterday by Wilfred J. Funk, editor of The Literary Digest.

New Yorkers in widely separated sections of the city were closely observed last week in regard to their manners, dress, jewelry and reading habits by a force of amateur "detectives," members of a class in the psychology of advertising at the Columbia Summer session.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18.-- The Flag Officers' Ball tonight ushered in "race week" at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Visiting yachtsmen, their families and other guests were welcomed here by Commodore Rudolph Schaefer, Vice Commodore W.G. McCullough and Rear Commodore Harvey Conover, the flag officers of the club.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The fourteenth annual flower show of the Garden Club of Lake George will be held on Aug. 6 in the high school auditorium at Lake George village, afternoon and evening. The date was advanced so as not to conflict with the Glens Falls Garden Club show, which will take place on Aug. 20 and 21.

WOOSTER, Ohio, July 18 (AP). -- The Weekly Press of the near-by village of Rittman neared success today in a campaign to reopen the strike-closed Ohio Boxboard Company plant, said Editor Ernest Harrison, although the little printing establishment was closed and picketed.

ROME, July 17. -- In a recent interview Premier Benito Mussolini declared that, with the conquest of Ethiopia, Italy has definitely become one of the "satisfied nations," and this fact is certain to bring about a considerable change in her foreign policy.

IT is with a profound sense of sadness and loss that we record in this place the passing of Elisabeth Luther Cary. Our loss is the public's as well. These thousands of readers who from Sunday to Sunday for so many years have followed Miss Cary's articles will realize that something peculiarly fine has gone forever from these columns.

CRUISING WITH PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT OFF COAST OF NOVA SCOTIA, July 18. -- A 45-mile trip around the southern tip of Nova Scotia today gave President Roosevelt some of the most pleasant sailing of his current cruise, as he went at a smart clip from Cape Sable, his anchorage last night, to Shelburne.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 18. -- The three mad Marxes -- Groucho, Harpo and Chico -- launched their new scheme of testing out gags for their next movie here last night at the Minnesota Theatre, where they are to remain for a week. After personal appearances in three other cities, it is certain that any comedy sequences that don't click with the living audiences just won't be in the new picture.

BOISE, Idaho, July 17. -- The long-awaited contest between Senator Borah and Governor C. Ben Ross for the former's seat at Washington may have an unexpectedly hot prelude in Idaho's primary elections next month. Each of the two now faces strong opposition within his own party, a development that for long seemed improbable.

VATICAN CITY. -- The Italian conquest of Ethiopia has created a number of new problems for the Catholic Church, which is now at liberty for the first time to exercise its evangelical mission in perfect freedom in vast territories where its presence was formerly barely tolerated when it was not opposed with bloodshed.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Pilots must demonstrate their ability at blind flying to the satisfaction of Bureau of Air Commerce inspectors before being permitted to undertake instrument flights along civil airways, according to an amendment to the air commerce regulations announced today.

IN his own time and country Shakespeare was not only a prophet with honor but he was also a best seller. This not unreasonable conclusion may be demonstrated by simple arithmetical deduction. Of the earliest attempted definitive edition of his works, the celebrated First Folio, it has been estimated that about 500 or 600 copies were printed. Some 200 of them have survived these three centuries.

TO the inexperienced it may well seem that about the last thing to think of at this season of the year is the making of a new lawn. Probably 90 per cent of all lawns are still made in the spring; only gradually is it realized that late Summer or early Autumn is the best time for lawn making.

PHILADELPHIA. -- Those reports of communistic influences in Philadelphia public schools continue to give concern to some residents, despite the fact that Dr. Edwin C. Broome, Superintendent of Schools, in a preliminary communication the other day, following a two-month survey, said he had been unable to find evidence to substantiate charges that Red propaganda was being taught.

Culinary statisticians have calculated that the Olympic Village kitchen will need the following immense quantities of food to satisfy the ravenous appetites of the athletes during their fortnight's occupancy from Aug. 1 to 16:80 tons of meat and poultry; 7 1/2 tons of fish; 120 tons of vegetables; 55 tons of flour; 17 tons of butter; 34,000 gallons of milk; 280,000 eggs, 320,000 oranges; 52,600 grapefruit and 105,200 lemons.

In the next few days the A.E. Luders yard at Stamford is to launch one of the most interesting yachts of the year, the new 67-foot motor sailer Mercury IV, now being completed for Arthur E. Pew Jr., vice president of the Sun Oil Company.

WHITWELL, Tenn., July 18 (AP). -- Sheriff T.E. Coppinger said tonight he had arrested one man and held warrants for at least three others far floggings and property destruction by masked night riders in the coal mine district here. He added that he had reports that fifteen participated in floggings Thursday night.

FAR back in the mountains of Graham County, North Carolina, where the Snowbird Mountains run into the Cheoahs and the Cheoahs into the Unaka range and mountain streams drain into Little Santeetlah Creek, stands a magnificent forest of virgin timber -- perhaps the finest forest of its type in America.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended July 15, aggregated $8,323,000,000, or 1 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, which included only five business days, and 2 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

THIRTEEN years ago she was "Baby Peggy," child darling of the screen, and a leading film attraction of her day, Now, meet a new screen personality, Margaret Montgomery -- and don't mention the word "Baby." She doesn't like it.

ALL over the country needles continue to click, and justifiably so, for styles in knitting become better looking all the time. More distinguished designers are taking a hand in planning and working out beautiful garments for women who knit.

The original mistrust that surrounded the teacher-student relationship in the House Plan, extra-curricular activity center at City College, has been dispelled, according to Mortimer Karpp, director of the project. Mr. Karpp made public yesterday the first annual report of the House Plan, including a summary of the activities pursued by the 642 student and 62 faculty members during the last year.

BISLEY CAMP, Surrey, July 18 (Canadian Press). -- Sergeant L.D. Busschau of South Africa today won the historic King's Prize, blue ribbon award of the National Rifle Association's Empire meet, with a score of 272. Sergeant J.E. Johnson, also of South Africa, was second, with 271, and Lieut. Col. D. Bodley, another South African, third, with 270.

The arrest last week of a former naval officer and the recent conviction in Los Angeles of a former naval petty officer, both charged with espionage, have again focused attention on a war behind the scenes that is constantly but secretly waged in the United States as well as in other nations.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 18. -- The next four years will be a crucial period within which will be determined the kind of government under which Americans are to live, according to the speakers at the concluding sessions today of this year's Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 (AP). -- Onondaga Indians looked to the sky for rain today after invoking rites used by their forefathers to combat drought conditions which threaten their crops.

TORONTO, July 18. -- Ontario's gold mines produced gold and silver bullion to the value of $6,751,195 in June a total exceeded only once in the history of the Province, figures released by the Ontario Department of Mines reveal. The record for monthly production was established in December, 1935, when output from the mines totaled $6,894,686.

IN the reading room of the New York Bar Association at 42 West Forty-fourth Street is a heavily embroidered satchel inscribed with the Lion and Unicorn and Queen Victoria's monogram, "V.R.," with the date 1897, the year of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee.

Stocks closed generally higher yesterday in trading that aggregated 557,000 shares on the Stock Exchange during the two-hour session. The Saturday before the total was 867,000. Except in a few instances, gains were small, with some of the specialty stocks making the best showing.

WASHINGTON, Pa., July 18 (AP). -- Mr. and Mrs. John Myers of Hendersonville, Pa., and their 6-month-old twins were killed and two other children were injured seriously late today in an automobile accident that apparently went unnoticed for several hours.

PROFESSOR ARNOLD, who teaches law at Yale and who for many years has been writing iconoclastic articles for the unread pages of the professional law reviews, now addresses himself to a wider audience and in "The Symbols of Government" has written a very entertaining book.

THE Museum of Modern Art has provided the local art public and visitors from out of town with an opportunity to see a selection of works from the permanent collection. These paintings, watercolors, drawings and pieces of sculpture have been assembled on the fourth floor. The Summer showing opened last week and will continue through Sept. 6.

TRENTON, N.J., July 18. -- Like the small boy who looks in the back of his arithmetic book for the answers, New Jersey knows the answer to its emergency relief problem. What it thus far has been unable to do is to work out the problem to arrive at the answer -- which is money.

JERUSALEM, July 17. -- Arab terrorists continue to fire from the hills, to take potshots at Jewish quarters and settlements and to throw bombs. After three months' duration the general Arab strike is becoming intensified and Arab youths are more active than ever in enforcement of the strike.

Probably the reason why the respective Presidential campaigns of Messrs. TOWNSEND and LEMKE are observed by the average citizen with more amusement than apprehension is that, in no election of our history, has a "third party" won anything approaching a country-wide popular plurality.

The public affairs committee of the Socialist party of New York appealed to Governor Lehman yesterday to reconsider the appointment of Victor F. Ridder as chairman of the newly created State Board of Social Welfare.

STONY BROOK, L.I., July 18. -- The Rev. P.E. Vogan of Drexel Hill, Pa., opened the tenth annual conference of the United Presbyterian Church at the Stony Brook assembly her this evening with more than 200 delegates from New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and New York State.

DUNDEE, Mich., July 18 (AP). -- Nine persons were killed here today when a passenger train crashed into their automobile at a crossing, dragged it onto a trestle and hurled them thirty feet into the shallow water of the Raisin River.

Passengers on TWA's transcontinental airline who have tickets to Kansas City will be flown free of charge from Kansas City to Topeka and back to attend the Landon notification ceremonies. Company officials here said yesterday that this service would begin on July 22, the day before the ceremonies, and continue until all who desired to avail themselves of it had been returned to Kansas City by air.

THOREAU wrote, "I enter a swamp as a sacred place." Many agree with the sentiment. For it is in the dim recesses of swamps and bogs that one catches glimpses of a subtle beauty almost hidden among the ever-shifting shadows.

CHANCELLOR HITLER'S recent proposal for what might be called an educational truce between France and Germany makes it interesting to inquire just what difference there is between the spirit and methods of training youth in the two countries.

Unless the government cotton crop estimate due on Aug. 8 is very bearish, a development which is not expected, the primary cotton goods market will continue its current activity and strength until well into the end of the year, dry goods wholesalers agreed here yesterday.
HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 18. -- Seventeen alleged Kansas mules toppled out of a 24-foot trailer here today in a mishap fraught with tangled political symbolism.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 18. -- Frank Bailey, young New Brunswick, N. J., pilot, held the spotlight today in the program of auto races conducted on the half-mile oval at the Fair Grounds. The events were sanctioned by the contest board of the American Automobile Association and staged under the auspices of the various organizations of the Nassau County Police Department, which shares in the proceeds.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Former President Hoover has given assurance that he will participate vigorously in the Presidential campaign, officials of the Republican National Committee said today. He is scheduled to join the Republicans who will take the stump in Maine after Labor Day and then speak in many other sections of the country.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey reserved decision yesterday on an application for an injunction by the National Union Radio Tube Company seeking to restrain the Radio Corporation of America, the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company from canceling a license agreement under which the plaintiff manufactures millions of tubes a year.

George Coletti, 45 years old, of 186 Autumn Street, Passaic, N.J., who was arrested Friday in a tavern in Long Island City after a search of more than three years by Federal narcotic agents, was arraigned yesterday before Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn on a warrant charging him with being a fugitive from justice from the Federal court in Columbus, Ohio.

TOPEKA, July 18. -- Arrangements were virtually completed today for the handling of the huge throng of visitors due here, beginning on Monday, for the Landon notification ceremonies next Thursday night.
LIVINGSTON, N.J., July 18. -- Two teams were tied for the lead today in the second annual Cedar Ridge Country Club best-ball invitation golf tournament.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The fiftieth annual Monmouth County horse show held on the Harding estate, Thornton Farm, Rumson, today opens activities which will continue for the next two weeks throughout this shore region.

FINANCED by a $35,000 appropriation granted by the recent session of Congress, the Accident Prevention Conference, organized by Secretary Roper at the suggestion of President Roosevelt, is about to launch a broad campaign to check the nation's rising toll of accidents.
HONGKONG, July 18 (AP). -- The desertion of scores of Canton aviators flying sixty airplanes which they presented to the national Chinese Government was reported through Chinese sources today.

The largest concentration of home furnishings buyers in more than decade is expected here this week when approximately 10,000 representatives of retail and wholesale establishments in all parts of the country come here to attend Fall home wares trade shows.

IN resuming the minting of "perfect'' coins recently, the Treasury opened to the many thousands of collectors a new field of activity. Proof coins previously were issued as collection pieces and souvenirs, but their issue was discontinued sixteen years ago.

HERE is a book that carves to the very heart of the dominant issue in the Presidential campaign. It is the work of a critical mind of the first order that does not hesitate to say what it thinks with the utmost force and trenchancy.

HARTFORD, July 18. -- A decline, estimated at 8 per cent, in automobile deaths in the nation during the first half of 1936 is shown by an analysis of city and State reports by the Travelers Insurance Company.

Mrs. Herbert L. Fairfield of Great Neck, L.I., a sister of Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for Vice President, will speak at the third of the "Landon-Knox" campaign teas to be given at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street on Wednesday.

THE death of the fourth Earl of Yarborough, last Sunday, in London, turned bridge players' thoughts to the Lord Yarborough, an ancestor of the deceased, whose name is a byword in the whist family of games.

THIS is a welcome sequel to "The Turfcutter's Donkey," in which Eileen and Seamus, those intrepid explorers in fairyland, encounter new adventures on a visit to one of the islands off the coast of Ireland. Long Ears, the little gray donkey who always turned up when most needed: Rose, the cat, and Big Fella. the dog, all went along with the turfcutter's family to visit Uncle Miheal.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Julia Hoyt of New York will be guest star assuming the leading role in "The Second Man" at the Maplewood Casino, Maplewood Club, next Tuesday night. This will be the premiere for the White Mountains Repertory Theatre Company.

Joe Whalen of the Larchmont Shore Club emerged as the national professional tennis singles champion by upsetting Charles M. Wood Jr. of the Somerset Hills Country Club in a five-set battle on the Tudor City courts yesterday. Whalen prevailed after dropping the first two sets.

BY both their size and the nature of their content, record lists confirm the suspicion that Summer is upon us, but Victor's current first string album release would probably take its place at the top of any monthly issue.

Holders of defaulted dollar bonds of the Republic of Colombia and its political subdivisions and of the Colombian Agricultural Mortgage Bank will be notified in a communication dated tomorrow by Lawrence E. de S. Hoover, executive secretary of the Bondholders Committees for Republic of Colombia, that the committees are prepared to take such legal steps as are available to protect the interests of the bondholders.
The 2-cent-a-mile passenger fare for all but commuters went into effect on the Long Island Railroad last midnight. With the inception of the new rates three old-fare categories were discontinued.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Poconos have settled down to the Summer routine. The annual ladies invitation golf tournament, scheduled for the week of July 27 at the Shawnee Country Club at Buckwood Inn, is to be followed by the first annual horse show, also at Buckwood Inn.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Arlington Park race track, the only non-profit racing plant in the world, will soon be out of the red and all profits will be divided between Illinois charities and the race course for improvements and increased purses.

Official consideration by the New York Stock Exchange of the Securities and Exchange Commission's program of segregating the functions of brokers and dealers is expected to begin early this week when the SEC makes available to the Exchange 2,000 copies of its report of June 20 to Congress. Only a few copies of the commission's survey have reached Wall Street to date.

Japan's naval training squadron, composed of the Yakumo and the Iwate, coastal defense vessels of 9,010 and 9,180 tons respectively, with 2,847 officers, men and midshipmen under Vice Admiral Zengo Yoshida, squadron commander, will visit New York and anchor in the Hudson River off 129th Street on Aug. 25, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 18. -- Mark Wollner, 35-year-old violinist who has appeared on national radio hookups, was held for questioning tonight in the mysterious murder of 18-year-old Helen Clevenger, New York University co-ed.

Skippers along the South Shore front of Long Island are taking more than casual glances at the calendar these humid days, as they are awaiting the blue ribbon event of the season, the twenty-first annual race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 18 (AP). -- The rebellious troops reported in control of Spanish Morocco tonight took over the public services after fighting in which eleven persons were declared to have been killed.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 18. -- The average salary of the members of the class of '21 at Princeton University is slightly less now than it was in 1931, according to a questionnaire sent out in conjunction with the fifteenth reunion of the class and revealed today with the publication of the volume, "The First Fifteen."

THOSE who know Mr. Peattie's previous work will not expect to find this book prosaically academic, nor will they look for a false and overstrained "popularization" Like Mr. Duranty in a far different field, Mr. Peattie writes as he pleases.

As fashion turns backward in its flight, the examination of its earlier vagaries may take on a more than historic interest. But the author of "Elegant Modes in the Nineteenth Century" does not present his material in any spirit of comparison or suggestion.

BERLIN, July 18. -- Every radio station of any importance throughout the world will be connected directly or indirectly during the Olympic Games with the "forty-nation switchboard" in the cellar of the main Olympic stadium. The technical director of the Reich radio estimates it will be possible to broadcast from Berlin simultaneously 100 times, an astonishing accomplishment but one that for some reason embarrasses the authorities here.

WHEN the mercury hovers for days in the upper ranges, as it has been doing recently, and the city of brick and concrete and steel becomes a furnace of stored heat, the mind of the urban dweller turns toward the water.
