BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Oak Ledge, on Lake Champlain, two miles south of the Burlington business district and once the Summer home of Dr. W. Seward Webb of New York and Shelburne, Vt., now has become a Summer resort, catering largely to guests from New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Connecticut.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The social colony here is looking forward to the first Tuesday-evening Bar Harbor Club party of the new season, to be held this week. In years past these parties have been attended by the leaders of the New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Washington social groups and have had a special appeal to the younger sets.

Since Antediluvian, whose letter appeared in fast Sunday's issue, admits that the Humphrey-Weidman program which he had witnessed was the first dance recital he had attended "in years," it would seem obvious that his chief difficulty may lie in lack of orientation, the cure for which implies first of all seeing more of the "new choreography."

SAG HARBOR, L.I., July 18. -- Seven couples will march, as they did two generations ago, down the aisle of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Sag Harbor tomorrow morning, and under a flowery arch of white and gold will rephrase the marriage vows they made more than fifty years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 17. -- After a year's study of a miniature river in the National Hydraulic Laboratory, Bureau of Standards, scientists have reached the conclusion that clear water in a swiftly flowing stream has a greater scouring effect on the sandy bed of the stream than muddy water.

EXPERIMENTAL transmission from the new Norwegian short-wave station at Jeloy will begin in August and regular broadcasting is scheduled to start in September, according to William H. Beck, United States Consul General at Oslo.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. -- An entry list of close to 200 yachts is expected for the thirteenth annual regatta of the Edgartown Yacht Club, which is to be held next Friday and Saturday. Representatives of about fifteen clubs, competing in twenty-five classes, will crowd Edgartown's harbor.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 18. -- Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons announced today that the Commonwealth will take swift action to protect its marketing legislation designed to maintain a home consumption price on primary products to compensate for low export prices.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18.-- Commodore Rudolph J. Schaefer's yawl Edlu won the Larchmont Trophy in the Larchmont Yacht Club's ocean race out around Long Island and the Fire Island Lightship, and the Brooklyn Yacht Club ocean Challenge Cup as well.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Standing before 3,000 veterans of the World War, the remnants of the famous Second Division, which eighteen years ago brought glory to that corps with its brilliant assault against the Germans at Chateau-Thierry, Major Gen. James G. Harbord dedicated today on the ellipse south of the White House a marble-and-bronze memorial in honor of the division, which he commanded during the drive.

ST. LOUIS, July 18. -- Drought and high temperature, slightly relieved by scattered showers in the last two days of the week, have been serious factors in the Eighth Federal Reserve District. Business in general has slowed down. Rainfall reported has been of slight value to farm products and added but little to depleted water supplies.

WE admire the spunk of Grand National Pictures, a new outfit, which has never made a picture and hasn't even got hold of a studio yet, but which gave a cocktail party for the press at the New York Athletic Club on one of the hottest clays last week.

MUCH as the cinema industry dislikes to concern itself over the sordid, or commercial, side of things, a matter has arisen which permits of no escape from it. The exhibitors generally docile although always threatening to take steps about what they label abuses, are showing signs of rebellion.

WILD ferns are adapted to various places in the garden. Some look well in the rock garden; some make splendid "fillers" for plantings of rhododendron and kalmia; some may be used as edging plants; others may become a part of the bog garden.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Little Theatres are meeting with unusual success in Atlantic City this Summer and all performances are being attended by comparatively large and receptive audiences. Two groups are running a friendly competition for the patronage of Little-Theatre followers.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- A new placer gold field of great wealth, which, a competent authority has informed the writer, is "richer than Alaska," is now being developed in the desolate virgin territory of Eastern Siberia, about a hundred miles north of the little town of Okhotsk, on the fringe of the Okhotsk Sea.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Paced by Hal Trosky's pair of home runs, the Cleveland Indians today blasted out a 10-to-3 triumph over Washington for their eighth straight victory.

THERE has been talk here and there that the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra is in danger of folding up. Neither the orchestra nor the Columbia Broadcasting System seems to think so. They have signed a new five-year contract for the continuance of the regular broadcasts.

JOSE ITURBI'S first appearance of the season both as soloist and conductor, performances of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera "The Czar's Bride," and several contemporary compositions are on this week's agenda of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts.

ST. PAUL, July 18. -- Wearing a large sombrero and oblivious of a huge gallery, Wild Bill Mehlhorn of Louisville, Ky., left a sizzling trail of birdies behind him today to shoot 68 and lead the field into the final day's thirty-six holes of the St. Paul open golf tournament.

PARIS, July 18. -- Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos will go to London Wednesday to take part in the three-power conversations regarding the situation created by the German denunciation of the Locarno treaties. Refusal of Italy to join in the conversations unless Germany is present and the attitude to be adopted toward the various proposals that are being prepared for the future arrangement of Europe, will be discussed.

MR. MECKLER has performed a real service to letters in rendering and editing so admirably a portion of the Chassidic folklore. Like Methodism, of which it was a contemporary, Chassidism startled and penetrated its surrounding culture as have few movements in modern religious history, but the latter was unique in that it produced a more abundant and more entertaining folk-literature than most revivalist movements have been able to show.

STERLING, Ill., July 18 (AP). -- Eleven men were held in the Whiteside County jail at Morrison today charged with rioting, and warrants charging eight more with rioting and assault were issued following violence Thursday and last night in a twelve-day strike at the Northwestern Barb Wire Company's big plant here.

BUFFALO, July 18 (AP) -- The Bisons picked up another full game on the defeated Rochester Red Wings and cut the margin of the league leaders to a game and a half by trouncing the Newark Bears for the second straight time tonight, 11 to 6.

THE agreement which Adolf Hitler has induced the Austrian Chancellor, Kurt Schuschnigg, to conclude with him is more than an attempt to attain his aim of winning his native country for nazism. It is a step toward the recreation of pre-war "Mitteleuropa" and the addition of the missing link in the Central European and Balkan chain of States in which Germany would predominate.

Playing the finest tennis he has shown on clay in two weeks, Robert Riggs of Los Angeles brought the winning streak of Don McNeill of Oklahoma City to an end yesterday to gain the final round of the Eastern championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in Queens.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. -- Another recreation feature for children will be opened for use of the Summer colony and residents when the Lions Club completes tomorrow a sand pit near the wading pool, which the Lions constructed last Summer.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- The Woman's Rights movement, victorious so far as suffrage is concerned, is eighty-eight years old tomorrow.

THERE are about 4,000 inhabited islands in the Philippine Archipelago, and most of the natives are "Christian and thoroughly civilized." But not all. Carl N. Taylor had known the civilized Philippines and the civilized aspects of life in the islands for some time, because he had been a teacher in the University of the Philippines; in that institution's annual enrollment of 8,000 students, many had been pupils of his.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y, July 18.-- More than 10,000 visitors are expected to be present here at Camp Smith tomorrow to see Governor Lehman review the Ninety-third Brigade of Manhattan. The units making up the brigade are the 165th Infantry, the "Fighting Irish" of Manhattan, commanded by Colonel Alexander E. Anderson, and the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn, commanded by Colonel William R. Jackson, who is also acting commander of the brigade.

THE forty-second season of the Queen's Hail Promenade Concerts will open Aug. 8 in London, England, and continue nightly, except Sundays, until Oct. 3. Again, as during the past ten years of the "Proms'" activities, the concerts will be performed by the B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Sir Henry Wood.

KINGMAN, Ariz., July 18. -- A request for Federal assistance in stamping out the alleged polygamous colony of Short Creek was considered today by E. Elmo Bollinger, County Attorney, after a visit to the remote settlement on the Arizona-Utah border.

To city-bred Hetty, life in a caravan was an alluring prospect. The adventure began when her father put all his savings into a photograph gallery on wheels and ,together the two drove along the sunny roads of Ohio, stopping in each friendly country village long enough for father to photograph all the bridal couples, the family reunions, and the new babies of the neighborhood.

The Rockefeller Foundation began and continues its many-sided activities and benefactions at home, but it has given them world horizons. This is made especially manifest in the latest annual report. The work of all divisions is international in scope, and in some instances directly promotes cooperative relationships between nations.

CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP). -- Robert E. Clements, co-founder of the Townsend Pension Plan, who recently resigned from the organization, said tonight that "moneyed interests" were ready to spend 'as high as $200,000,000 to stop Roosevelt."

THE new Soviet Constitution is an outward and visible sign of an inward and spiritual change in the Russian people and its leaders. The world at large has doubtless been sur prised by the liberal and democratic character of the projected Constitution, which guarantees within the Socialist framework of course -- all the freedom and rights of mankind, and womankind as well.

Here is an omnibus volume containing three Agatha Christie stories: "The Murder of Roger Ackroyd," "Murder in the Calais Coach" and "Thirteen at Dinner" -- three first-rate detective stories for less than the regular price of one.

WHAT is a work of imagination? Is everything outside fiction and the drama to be excluded from this category? That is evidently not the opinion of the committee responsible for the Hawthornden Prize, which is awarded annually for the best piece of imaginative writing by a British author under 41 years of age.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Opposing ratification by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the appointments of Howard S. Palmer, W.M. Daniels and James Lee Loomis as trustees of the Old Colony Railroad Company in the reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford, the president and directors of the Manhattan Company of New York today asked the commission's permission to intervene.

FROM a practice stunt devised ten years ago to keep bird hunters in trim during the "closed" season to an international sport, loved by thousands of devotees for its own sake -- that is the story of skeet shooting, which today is being acclaimed as the "fastest growing sport" in the world.

AMERICA, coming of age, is seeking its cultural springs in the songs and stories of its simple folk. For the last half-dozen years -- and this year on a wider scale than before -- folk festivals have arisen in various sections of the country to dramatize a folklore that for generations has been buried in the more segregated communities of our hinterland.

WHILE Europe is an armed and arming camp, in so far as aircraft are concerned, the United States has little to fear as regards comparative performance of like categories of military planes, in the opinion of Thomas F. Hamilton, vice president and European representative of United Aircraft Corporation, who returned to the United States on the Hindenburg last week.

The will of William Gilman Low, lawyer and writer and oldest alumnus of Columbia University and a stepbrother of the late Seth Low, former Mayor of New York, was filed yesterday in the Surrogate's office in Brooklyn. The petition accompanying the will stated the estate of the decedent was valued at "more than $20,000 in real property and more than $20,000 in personal property."

THE most powerful and unscrupulous gang of horse-thieves, cattle rustlers and general all-round badmen ever known to Texas, making headquarters at Casota, in the Panhandle, was terrorizing the country for miles around.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 18. -- The Cave Grill at the Mount Washington, Bretton Woods, was opened tonight for the season. A throng assembled for the supper dance, when a Paul Jones and Lucky Favor dance were featured. Arrivals at the Mount Washington included Mrs. Clarence Low and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Huffe of New York, Howard A. Smith and party of Boston and William M. Wadsworth of Montclair.
Freight agreements of great importance to ship lines in the Atlantic and intercoastal trades are being studied by operators in the hope of ending controversies among the lines and with shippers.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Dr. Gardiner C. Means, Washington, D.C., economist, said that "flexibility of price mechanism" can no longer balance the activities between producer and consumer.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 18 (AP). -- Danger of avalanches from fresh snow on the summit of 13,260-foot Mount Waddington today delayed a party of American and Canadian climbers who hope to conquer the unscaled peak.

NAMELESS voices hang for hours in the British air never to be identified through the microphone. Despite perfect diction, friendly tone and accuracy in "the King's English" these disembodied voices are known by sound alone.

READVILLE, Mass., July 18. -- With perhaps scores of lives saved through the stoutness of new guard rails, four racing ears speeding ninety miles an hour on the east turn of the Readville track collided and overturned today before a crowd of 12,000. One driver was killed and three others critically injured.

MOSCOW, July 17. -- The tourist season here is in full swing. Hotels are so crowded with foreigners that they are beginning to overflow into the new and as yet unfinished Hotel Moskva, which up to now has been reserved almost exclusively to Russians on government business.
When I read of Miss Cary's death I put down my copy of THE TIMES and prayed for the repose of her soul. That was the least and the most I could do for one who was very dear to me.

How much of Dr. TOWNSEND is the Depression, how much is California climate, how much is Iowa farmer? It would be a help if the laboratory scientists who are always splitting up atoms and electrons would try their hand at the Old-Age Revolving Plan, and give us the approximate percentages.

THE New York Botanical Garden is battling the Japanese beetle by installing traps among the flower borders and also by having many of its workers pick off the pests by hand. About 15,000 beetles have been collected each day since the invasion began, July 10.

EARLY this Fall the American Bantam Car Company plans to introduce a small car, to sell around $300, designed to attain a speed of sixty miles an hour and deliver "forty to fifty miles on a gallon of gasoline, "according to R.S. Evans, president of the company.

DON'T you just love those huge, handsome, indestructible chaps of the British Secret Service who are always risking their lives to save the Empire? "Tiger" Standish, the hero of this book and of several that have gone before, is one of them.

PROJECT No. 138. The designation tells little. Actually it is concerned with the first comprehensive study of air pollution by one agency in the United States -- the Works Progress Administration. The workers are bacteriologists, engineers, chemists.

Vittorio Giannini's new work entitled "Requiem" is the first American composition to be accepted for performance by the Vienna Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde, or Society of Friends of Music. It will be performed by the society next March. Mr. Giannini's sister, Dusolina, is a singer with the Metropolitan Opera Association.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- Under the auspices of the Emergency Peace Campaign and the American Friends Service Committee, 175 college men and women are engaged this Summer at seven social work camps in five States. They are rebuilding settlement houses, leveling off playgrounds, constructing dams, grist mills, swimming pools, and, in general, learning by experience ways to change the world into a cooperative community by non-violent methods.

SALT LAKE CITY. -- Paradoxically the New Deal, which has brought a new order to so many phases of American life, is reviving the practices of a by-gone day in the cattle country, for the open range is being recreated through the administration of the Taylor Grazing Act by the Department of the Interior.

ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, At Sea, July 18. -- The American Olympic Committee faced a new and extremely troublesome problem today when it heard reports that some members of the team traveling to the games in Berlin had broken training regulations.

PEIPING, China, May 17. -- "It would be wrong to say that Sinanthropus Pekinensis, or the Pekin Man, is the Missing Link, but it has been proved beyond doubt that he is one of possibly many Missing Links," said Professor Franz Weidenreich in his laboratory at the Peiping Union Medical College.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Members of drought-stricken families consisting of at least 1,000,000 persons will be dependent on Federal aid for a livelihood in the Northwest this Winter, officials estimated today as WPA increased from 50,000 to 65,000 its quota of immediate emergency jobs in five Northwestern States.

WITH the dog days at hand, every one strives for coolness, both in fact and in effect. Crisp, fresh-cut flowers, knowingly arranged, help greatly in creating an atmosphere of spacious, breezy comfort indoors.

THE present tendency to use the simple, old-fashioned flowers more freely in gardens has extended itself to those twin favorites, pansies and violas. Not that they ever really ceased to be popular -- their many qualities have served to secure for them a prominent garden place always.

Harry S. Hechheimer, a New York lawyer arrested Friday in Laconia, N.H., in the alleged extortion of $2,000 from Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, film actress, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday by General Sessions Judge Morris Koenig.
