BULLETINS can be obtained giving particulars of the twelfth biennial contests for young artists offered by the National Federation of Music Clubs and the Schubert Memorial, Inc. Winners of first place for piano, violin and voice will he awarded $1,000 each, and the piano and violin winners will have an audition at which the instrumentalist to be given an appearance with the Philadelphia Orchestra will be selected.

LONDON. THE Lotingas, a stage family as well known and wide -- spread as the Lupinos, have yet another member aspiring to screen fame. She is blue-eyed, with long, dark hair and a happy smile. Her name is Doreen, she is Just 12 years old, and she is the niece of Ernie Lotinga, famous in low-comedy rises.

OMAHA, Neb., July 17. -- Twenty to thirty years ago there was quite a fever of ditch-digging for drainage purposes throughout the Middle West. Farmers thought then that their chief problem was the rapid disposal of surplus water. It seemed like good business to facilitate the run-off after rains.

With more buyers in the market than there were at the same period last year, orders were placed in good volume last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. In many instances budgets for Fall staple as well as fashion merchandise are about 10 per cent larger than a year ago.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- An outstanding event of the Summer here will take place during the coming week when the twenty-ninth annual flower show under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society will be held on Thursday and Friday in the parochial school in Hill Street.
PINE ORCHARD, Conn., July 18. -- More than two hundred persons attended the week-end dance at the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club tonight. Several dinners preceded the dance.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their week-end guests attended the supper dance tonight at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. Colored lights illuminated the grounds and terraces of the clubhouse.

THE Nash Motors Company will be 20 years old on July 29, the date on which Charles W. Nash, now chairman of the board, started as an independent manufacturer in Kenosha, Wis. He resigned as president of General Motors to make the venture.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 18. -- The first formal Sunday review of the 1936 Camp Dix Citizens' Military Training Camp regiment will be held on the camp parade grounds here at 5:15 P. M. tomorrow, according to an order issued today by Colonel Royden E. Beebe. regimental commander of the Eighteenth Infantry and in charge of CMTC training.

WEEK-END guests whose brains become addled by the heat to the point where they cannot think of a gift for their hostesses may have their mental work on this problem done for them. A New York shop has an imposing array of gift packages, handsomely wrapped, for host or hostess.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave a dinner for forty guests at Chetwode this evening. It was their last entertainment before leaving for a trip through the West on Thursday. Tomorrow is the first birthday of their son, William. Mr. and Mrs. Astor will be accompanied on their trip by Mrs. Astor's sister, Miss Virginia Middleton French, and by James Neville.

The metamorphosis from critic to crusader should not be a hard one to undergo. You gentlemen who sling the acid adjective and vitriolic verb could do untold good if you would bring your power into use for the purpose of striking out against the current high prices that make Broadway entertainment a barred feast to so many hungry drama lovers.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 17. -- With the formal announcement Wednesday of his candidacy for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination by State's Attorney Hugh M. Alcorn of Hartford County, Connecticut Republican politics started to take form earlier than usual.

Phelps Phelps, former member of the New York Legislature, who has just returned from a visit to Cuba, praised President Roosevelt's good-neighbor policy yesterday for having effected a "remarkable improvement" in our relations with Latin America, particularly with Cuba.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17. -- The cutting off of relief to nearly 600,000 destitute Pennsylvanians, leading to this week's hunger march on Harrisburg, was a natural outgrowth of a situation which began developing with the convening of the special session of the Legislature nearly eleven weeks ago.

MADRID, Sunday, July 19. -- Diego Martinez Barrio, Speaker of the Cortes and chief of the Republican Union, organized a new Cabinet today after the resignation of the government headed by Santiago Casares Quiroga. The Cabinet list follows:

IN the heart of the rolling, rich farmlands of Southern Minnesota two brothers have built at Rochester one of the most distinguished centers of medical practice and medical education in the history of science. There the scalpel is sceptre, but the scalpel, like any sceptre, must pass, for the two brothers are no longer young.
BERLIN, July 18. -- The Boerse ended the week today with prices showing a sagging trend. Some specialties continued in demand, but even these were more quiet than in recent days.

WHILE retail trade throughout the country was somewhat spottier than in recent weeks, improvement was noted where lower temperatures prevailed and rainfall alleviated drought conditions. Sales volume for the most part continued well ahead of last year, with most reports indicating a gain of about 12 per cent.

Brisk retail trade and substantial increases in Fall buying at wholesale featured business developments in the metropolitan area last week. Freed from the hampering influence of high temperatures, leading department stores here were estimated as having a 15 per cent gain in sales over the comparative 1935 period.
BOSTON, July 18 (AP). -- The Tigers pulled back into third place today when their right-hander, Elden Auker, scored his first victory in five starts against the Red Sox by a 6-5 margin.

CECIL ROBERTS went rustic five years ago, and this is the third book in which, from his Elizabethan "Pilgrim Cottage" in the Chilterns, he has brought to his readers, in his own quite individual way the charm and piquancy of the English countryside.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Representative William Lemke of North Dakota, Union party candidate for the Presidency, who is scheduled to make a personal appeal at Cleveland tomorrow for the Townsend vote, was a Chicago visitor today and held a series of conferences at the Lemke headquarters.

THIS year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of one of America's few women humorists, Marietta Holley, author of the beloved "Samantha" books which entertained thousands in the Eighties, Nineties and the early part of this century.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Secretary Perkins announced tonight that the Walsh-Healey act imposing wage and hour restrictions on firms contracting with the government would go into effect on Sept. 28.

Many of the leading stamp dealers in this city expressed little interest yesterday in the recent announcement by the United States Treasury Department that it was preparing to offer to the highest bidder the entire issue of the tax-exempt potato revenue stamps which were never officially issued.

George H. Kauss, a retired police captain who draws a $2,500 yearly pension from the city, is receiving a salary of $2,100 as chief of guards at WPA headquarters in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, it became known yesterday.

Subsidies to agriculture are justified by New Dealers as compensation against the protective tariff benefits enjoyed by Eastern manufacturers. Two wrongs do not make a right, and justice demands, of course, that both of these flagrant forms of special privilege be abolished. When a young man makes a choice of his, life vocation he is supposed to take into account the advantages and disadvantages of every alling under consideration.

The fleet Western star, Clang, holder of world sprinting records, showed that he could carry his speed over a distance of ground when he scored by a nose yesterday at Empire City in the Yonkers Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth. He came from behind in a manner to surprise most of the 12,000 spectators and earned $5,525.

The relations between Mayor La Guardia and the Republican organization of New York have been far from intimate. The Mayor, who was elected in 1933 on a Republican-Fusion ticket, declared for a completely non-partisan administration; the Republican leaders have complained that they were being completely deprived of patronage.

James W. Gerard sailed yesterday on the Rex of the Italian Line for Ville Franche, where he will put in two weeks of swimming. He will return on Aug. 20, when he expects to take part in the fund-raising campaign for the Democratic party. He would not state the amount the party has set for the campaign.

As the climax of a week of meetings here and in Philadelphia various societies affiliated in the study of osteopathic medicine, a general convention of the entire profession of osteopathic physicians will begin inhere tomorrow for one week. The convention, which will meet at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, is expected to draw 2,200 registered physicians. It will be under the auspices of the American Osteopathic Association.

A bitter fight for sales volume between manufacturers of privately owned brands and nationally advertised lines of foodstuffs, including all types of canned goods, was predicted here yesterday as manufacturers and distributors struggled to work out plans to comply with the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act.

BERLIN, July 18. -- The S.S. Manhattan seems to be bringing American weather with it. Berlin was struck today by a heat wave of New York proportions. If it continues, the problem of acclimatization will for the most part be solved.

The increasing use of scientific knowledge in social work was noted by Miss Anna Kempshall, director of the Institute of Family Service of the Charity Organization Society, in an interview yesterday. Miss Kempshall, who has just completed twenty years of service with the society, discussed changes in social work in the last two decades.
SEATTLE, July 18 (AP). -- Headlines in the world's newspapers just thirty-nine years ago today made the name "Klondike" a household word.

Headed by Mrs. Henry Dietrich, the defending titleholder and metropolitan champion, a field of ninety-six players will strive for the women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties in the seventh annual tournament which starts at the Century Country Club, White Plains, tomorrow morning.

NEGRO Americans in increasing numbers are taking to the crowded travel lanes leading to Europe, prompted by the desire to observe and study cultural and social developments in the Old World and by the prospect of enjoying a variety of recreational opportunities.

PITTSBURGH, July 18. -- The Dodgers broke into the victory column here for the first time this year when they won a see-saw battle today with the Pirates, 6 -- 5. A five-hit, three-run, ninth-inning rally against Mace Brown and Bill Swift decided the game.

A PLAUSIBLE conceit on the part of at least a half-dozen of the more important rural playshops which freckle our fair Summer landscape is that each, beyond reasonable doubt, is "America's most famous Summer theatre."

ITALY shows a certain pride, almost a kind of coquetry, in opening her two major international exhibitions -- the Milan Triennial and the Venice Biennial -- in this year of sanctions. Sanctions, whatever their effect may have been on the economic structure of the country, have not hindered this great effort in the domain of art.

THE Japanese Government has assumed a domination of that country's automotive industry unparalleled anywhere in the world. This is revealed in a translation of "Law No. 33," governing the automobile manufacturing industry, which has just been made for the Automobile Manufacturers Association office here.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- George Andrew McMahon, who sought to attack King Edward, told his wife in Brixton jail tonight, "I am neither traitorous nor disloyal and did not intend to shoot the monarch."

The Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York and affiliated unions will reaffirm their faith in the innocence of Tom Mooney at a mass meeting at the Hippodrome on July 30, the anniversary of the imprisonment of Mooney and Warren K. Billings for the Preparedness Day parade bombing in San Francisco in 1916.
YOUNG New Yorkers longing for more and better job training in any field, from auto mechanics to home-making, are to have their wishes granted in the public schools in the Fall of 1937.

WILDWOOD, N.J. -- The twenty-seventh annual Wildwood baby parade will be held on the boardwalk on Friday, Aug. 21, it was announced today. The parade, under direction of the Chamber of Commerce, will be sponsored by the city of Wildwood.
Twelve hundred youngsters from the five boroughs staged an athletic carnival in the new stadium on Randalls Island yesterday afternoon.

The title of this book is a perfect fit. The hoax is on the reader, who is led, through nearly 300 pages, to believe the worst, only to find that nothing very terrible has happened. The explanation takes a bit of believing, but since it extricates several very nice people from what looks like a nasty mess, one is willing to let that pass.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP). -- The White Sox continued their triumphant tour of the East by taking both ends of a double-header with the Athletics today, winning the first, 7 -- 4, and the second, 21 -- 14. The triumphs raised their streak to five in a row.

The end of the strike of 700 stuffed-toy workers late this week was predicted yesterday by Alexander Ravitch, secretary-treasurer of Local 18,230 of the Doll and Toy Workers Union, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor. Mr. Ravitch based his prediction on his announcement that six manufacturers had granted the union's demands and that as many more were on the verge of capitulating.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:
Notes and reflections on the sailing of the Olympic team:

HERSHEY, Pa., July 18. -- A charge of "political perversion of unemployment relief" in Pennsylvania as part of a "desperate effort" by the Democrats to capture the State in November was made by John D.M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, in a speech today before a State-wide assemblage of party workers.

JOHANNESBURG, Union of South Africa. -- Imports of Japanese goods have increased so rapidly, at the expense of imports from Europe and the United States, that the possibility of a reciprocity agreement between the Union and Japan has arisen.

THE Viking Press announces for publication in November the first complete edition of James Boswell's "Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides with Dr. Samuel Johnson." In 1927 Colonel Ralph Isham acquired from the present Lord Talbot de Malahide, great-great-grandson of Boswell, a large collection of Boswell papers, journals and letters, which scholars for years had thought lost, and arranged to have them privately printed for subscribers in an eighteen-volume set.

The dolls who lived in the attic of World's End were in a panic. Strange, snuffly noises issued from behind the door of the lavender bedroom of their house, sounds unlike which had been heard since they had been honorably retired to the dusky garret.

OF Hollywood, Denis Ireland remarked in a London paper: "Probably all right to be born there, but give me Boston in a snowstorm. An exotic, poisonous flavor seeps in from the Orient, unsettling to the Europeans.

Price changes were mixed on the local commodity futures markets in the week ended on Friday, with profit-taking and dullness lowering the prices of sugar, coffee, rubber, silk and cottonseed oil while cocoa, wooltops, hides and copper advance moderately.

Periods of devastating drought like the present one give aid and encouragement to a popular superstition that Nature is man's most aggressive enemy. Man proposes; GOD disposes, as the reverential old saw puts it. When Nature fails to cooperate man's labor in the fields turns to dust, and the sun, which is normally the good genie of this planet, becomes a fire of evil, consuming the earth with terrible flame.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Harchak of 288 Avenue C lost faith in banks in 1932 when many of them were closing their doors, so when a friend lost $7,000 in one that crashed they withdrew their life's savings from a local trust company.

PARIS, July 18. -- Passengers arriving at Le Bourget airfield from Madrid this afternoon were amazed at the news in the Paris press concerning trouble in Spain. Although at a loss to explain why Spain cut herself off from the outside world, Spaniards on board the plane declared Madrid was normal in every way when they left at 8:30 in the morning.

VIENNA, July 17. -- The vastly changed internal situation in Austria which will inevitably follow the Austro-German agreement will develop only gradually, largely because the government, despite its formal declarations, in reality is still far from convinced that Nazi Germany means to keep faith and intends to make slow and cautious progress.

Scoring more than twice as many points as its nearest rival, the West Side branch captured team honors in the national Y.M.C.A. outdoor track and field championships yesterday at Consolidated Field, Astoria, held under the auspices of Brooklyn Central and the Twenty-third Street branch of New York.

CLEVELAND, July 18. -- Appearing in the role of one who shatters the faith of children in Santa Claus, Norman Thomas, the Socialist candidate for President, appeared before 11,000 booing elderly men and women at the convention of Townsend Clubs today and told them flatly that their scheme for national recovery would not work.

EVERY ONE is now hearing about the Oxford Groups. Contacts with the movement, direct and indirect, multiply like chain letters. Friends interest friends who interest other friends, and thus does this most modern of revivals spread from place to place.

LONDON, July 17. -- Pilgrims of Great Britain gave a luncheon on Tuesday at Mayfair in honor of the Most Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States and vice president of the American Pilgrims.
WHAT is the effect on delinquent boys of training in a correctional institution? Do they return to community life and become well-adjusted to normal living? If not, why not?

In announcing last week an increase of 50 per cent, effective on Aug. 15, in the reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System, the monetary authorities were making a fundamental adjustment in the banking system of the country which extended far beyond any previous Federal Reserve measures of credit control, according to bankers and economists who have been studying the subject.

HOLLYWOOD. BARRETT C. KIESLING is home from the wars. He has oiled up his armor, shield and sword against the ravages of rust, has snuffed out the calcium light of his torch and has retired to rest and await another bugle's blast that, in a few months, shall send him forth to wrestle again with the Saladins of the crossroads.

MISS BRINKLEY, Associate Professor of English at Goucher College, has prepared an admirable anthology of seventeenth-century verse. Her long introduction is a fine essay on the changes in thought and interest in the century which has so rightly been called the beginning of the modern world.

LENOX, Mass., July 18. -- Mrs. Giraud Van Nest Foster was the honored guest at a birthday dinner given tonight by her father-in-law, Giraud Foster, at Bellefontaine, Lenox. A company of sixty was seated at small tables on the south porch, which was illuminated with Chinese lanterns and decorated with flowers and palms.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Drought continues the major factor contributing uncertainty to the business outlook, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey.

MURRAY BAY, Que. -- American members of the Summer colony here -- and they are more numerous this year than since 1929 -- are preparing for one of the most active seasons on record. Starting with the invitation golf tournament over the rolling fairways of the Manoir Richelieu Club today a gay round of social events is in prospect.

WINDHOEK, Southwest Africa. -- Nazi propaganda in Southwest Africa, a former German colony and now under League mandate to the Union of South Africa, has embittered relations between Nazi Germans and Union nationals in this province.
MADRID, July 18 (Passed by the Censor). -- The Spanish Government announces that an extensive plot against the republic has broken out.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 18 (AP) -- Three-year-old Stephen Zapatosky, whose feats of strength long since have ceased to surprise his family, caused scarcely a stir today when he strode up to the lawnmower and tackled the job of tidying up the front lawn.

Eastern stores are viewing with increasing interest the Pacific Coast markets for wearing apparel land home furnishings because of the large variety of styles now being exhibited for Fall promotion, the trends of which are sponsored by the motion picture colony at Hollywood, according to D. C. Greene, resident buyer of Los Angeles.

THE families of the Medici, the Sforza and the Borgia cast intermittent light and shadow over early modern history; and for several centuries during that period the Medici played the largest role in shaping the history not only of Florence and of Italy, but of France and the Papacy as well.

HARRISBURG, July 18. -- Relief "chiseling" in four Pennsylvania counties investigated so far by the State Auditor General's department ranged from 1.8 to 16.2 per cent, according to a preliminary report today.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- Summer activities are in full swing, with much entertaining by those who keep their homes open until after Labor Day and busy preparations for the annual events which are on the Summer schedule.
Almost 14,000 men and women, aged 60 or more, raises happy although somewhat angular voices in song last week at Cleveland. The above is sample of what they sang.
RAPID CITY, S.D., July 18. -- Federal drought relief program was ordered extended into eleven Southern, Central and Northwest States tonight by Roxford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- The Phillies couldn't stand prosperity today and lost to the Cubs, 8 -- 6, after dissipating a 5-2 lead over Roy Henshaw.

UPTON SINCLAIR, who is pre-eminently a writer of novels with a purpose -- the purpose usually being one that is not popular with the powers that be -- has chosen for his forthcoming novel the title "Co-Op."

WOODSTOCK'S season is gaining momentum and holding up extremely well, if the present group show (on until July 22) be a reliable indicator. Several of the leading artists associated with Woodstock are not on this occasion represented, but probably they will participate in the exhibition that is scheduled to open in the gallery here on July 24.

CLEVELAND, July 17. -- At the Townsend old-age pension convention here this week they have been doing things in the florid old-fashioned way of open floor fights, purple phrases and emotional appeals mellow as a violoncello's love song.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18 (AP). -- Police sought tonight to solve the mystery surrounding a woman discovered at noon in a downtown churchyard in a dazed condition from face wounds sewed up with black thread and buttons.

FOR the first time in its history the Boston Symphony will perform beneath a canvas canopy when it gives its three programs at the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, Aug. 13, 15 and 16, under the baton of Serge Koussevitzky.

IT may surprise the public at large to learn that there are many more people seeking babies for adoption than there are babies available, and that the child-placing agencies and adoption nurseries have long waiting lists of families who are eager to take other parents' children as their own.

BACK came George M. Cohan last week from foreign travels and, of course, was off at once for the ball games. Before he could take up residence at the Yankee Stadium, however, this department had a question or two for him -- i. e., What kind of a time had he had? and what had he seen that he liked? Thus Mr. Cohan, pen in hand:

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 18. -- Edwin Thorne, Horace Havemeyer Sr. and Horace Havemeyer Jr. finished one, two, three in the first of a series of Star Class races on Great South Bay today to select crews for the forthcoming world championships at Rochester, N.Y., and the North Atlantic at Westhampton Beach.

Mrs. Edward S. Harkness has presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art a large eighteenth century Chinese embroidered hanging which will be placed on exhibition this morning in the Room of Recent Accessions.

LONDON, July 9. -- On exhibition at the Tate Gallery is a recently discovered painting by John Singleton Copley (1737-1815), American-born member of the Royal Academy. The picture is that of a little girl playing with a dog.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- The usual midsummer slump in wholesale and retail merchandising is conspicuous by its absence in the Pacific Coast area. While there are numerous clearance sales advertised, particularly in men's apparel, these lines maintained a most gratifying level.

With the heaviest rains of the month over portions of Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia and a sharp break in the prices of corn, prices on the Cotton Exchange registered a further setback yesterday and closed at the bottom with losses of 7 to 14 points.

The people of New York City and the metropolitan area need more public swimming places of the better type, according to a report made yesterday by the Regional Plan Association, based upon a survey of existing facilities.

VISITORS to Silvermine (near Norwalk, Conn.) will encounter considerable art activity this Summer. The Silvermine Guild of Artists, Inc., is holding a series of exhibitions in the attractive and well-lighted Guild Gallery. Scheduled to continue through the week just concluded was a group show of portraits representing numerous artists, often very interestingly.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18. -- The annual movement of great rafts of logs from the Columbia River to Southern California has begun. These immense structures, built in cradles to form a cigar-shaped mass containing as much as 8,000,000 feet of lumber, are towed south during the smooth seas of Summer.

ON the Fourth of July, Helen Jacobs won the Women's Singles Final at Wimbledon, in one of the most exciting tennis matches that even that famous center court has known. Her autobiography was published five days later.

Straggling into the Stadium yesterday with their future behind them and the entire American League ahead of them, the tail-end St. Louis Browns did a couple of surprising things that may have set well enough with their mentor, the wily Rogers Hornsby, but certainly made no great hit with a gathering of 25,000 spectators.

LONDON, July 18. -- Ambassador Charles Corbin called at the Foreign Office today with the definite information that the French Government was willing to confer with the envoys of Britain and Belgium in London next week, instead of holding a more formal Locarno conference at Brussels, which Italy refused to attend.

AFTER Rimsky-Korsakoff had finished the initial version of his first opera, "The Maid of Pskoff," he was urged to revise it by Balakireff, on the ground that the composer was unlikely to write another work for the stage and so should do his utmost to perfect his sole venture in the field.

CINCINNATI, July 18. -- By the simple expedient of hammering four of the Reds' pitchers for 19 hits, the Giants today boosted their winning streak to four straight as they bounced back into the first division, just half a game behind the third-place Pirates, who bowed to the Dodgers.
Between an earthquake in Montana and her first twelve hours in New York, petite, pretty Erma Young found an odd similarity last night. Both left her breathless and a bit limp.

Conversion of several investment trusts into mutual funds to take advantage of the provisions of the Revenue Act of 1936 granting to trusts of the latter type exemption from the normal corporate income tax, as well as from the surtax on undistributed income, is expected by investment trust authorities in Wall Street.

CLEVELAND, July 18. -- Business sentiment continues buoyant in this section, although drought conditions grew worse in some parts of the district, especially in Southern Ohio and Eastern Kentucky. Corn in these areas has been particularly affected, and, while tobacco is not beyond saving, the damage has been considerable.

PIGS IS CRITICS: For several years scientists at Cornell University have been studying the nerve reactions of various animals. Last week they got around to the problem of pigs and music. First they exposed two pigs to the Brandenburg Concerto No. 3, and the subjects of the experiment uncurled and waved their tails and breathed in proper rhythm.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The whole question of this country's policy toward the Philippine Commonwealth during the more than nine years that must elapse before complete independence is achieved is unobtrusively but definitely to the fore in Washington just now.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- The Federal Power Commission today published a list of twenty railroads "showing the best possibilities for electrification."

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Bonus payments slowed to a trickle this week, with Treasury officials expressing surprise at the large number of veterans apparently preferring interest-bearing bonds to immediate cash.
Millions who will turn the dials to campaign orations may form quick superficial opinions for or against men or issues immediately following the conclusion of the addresses.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 18 (AP). -- Public health nurses, determined that sick children would not be left in need, carried milk to dozens of homes today after a strike of drivers tied up the delivery service of the Nashville Pure Milk Company.

MRS. WHITELEY modestly calls her monograph on the young men who, first and last, served Washington as aides-de-camp "a footnote to history." As such it is thoroughly documented, her researches extending to many and varied manuscript sources.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- The annual Shaw Festival, arranged by the Hedgerow Theatre at Rose Valley, near here, in observance of the eightieth birthday anniversary of George Bernard Shaw, will open on Monday night and continue nearly two weeks.

The names of 183 students who attained the honor roll for the second semester of the last academic year in the Evening Division of the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance of New York University were announced yesterday by Dean John T. Madden.

At no time in the entire history of the present system of Federal taxation has it been so important for corporate management to give consideration to matters pertaining to the disposition of corporate earnings and to the effects upon taxes of intercompany relationships as under existing revenue laws.
ALBANY, July 18 (AP). -- New York State weighed tonight a warning from a Federal Government engineer that it "may be facing a severe water shortage."
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Cool showers killed the heat wave today in the land where it killed the most people.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sunday, July 19. -- The prospect of a New England victory in the Southern New England contract bridge championships here became decidedly negative early today as an expeditionary force of masters from New York carried off seven of the first eight places in the qualifying rounds of open pair title play.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Whether, taken as a whole, the torrid visitation of July, 1936, will prove to be worse than that of July, 1934, which set a new pace in hot waves, remains to be seen. Of the event of two years ago a Weather Bureau official wrote: "

The arrest of Mrs. Margaret Robinson, stock broker, accused of having defrauded six clients of more than $250,000, was ordered yesterday by Assistant Attorney Gen. William Koerner of the State Bureau of Securities.

ISTANBUL, July 17. -- The Turkish Government has turned its attention not only to a program of permanent fortifications for the Dardanelles, to be initiated when the Turkish right to fortify is recognized, as doubtless it shortly will be, but also to the need of defending the Straits at short notice.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Sporting events will predominate in a crowded midsummer week in the Berkshires. On Friday and Saturday the eleventh annual Lenox horse show is to be held at the Dan R. Hanna Farm, midway between Lenox and Stockbridge.

In answer to Antediluvian's letter to THE TIMES, Sunday, the thought occurs to me that perhaps he has not realized that there is no Santa Claus, that we are living in an age when we must face real things, and art, having heightened that reality, has stopped kidding itself with having little curved cupids tied up in pink ribbons shower rose petals down upon a lifeless public.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- How an 8-year-old girl named Pomalova unwittingly caused one of the greatest train wrecks in recent years in the Soviet Union -- which killed fifty-one and injured fifty-two passengers -- was told yesterday at the trial in Chita of railroad officials accused of negligence.

I am one of those who believe very strongly that the destruction of forests and the cultivation of extensive grass lands have contributed to floods in this country. I agree with you, nevertheless, that our rivers overflowed their banks long before either the axe or the plow was known in America.

The sharp decrease in business failures for the first half of this year indicates that the record for 1936 will drop well below the unusually low figure for last year and approach nearer to the 1920 level of 8,891 suspensions, according to estimates by credit executives here yesterday.

THE fact that the book runs to only a hundred and a half of pages gives no idea of the length and scope of this remarkable poem by Chard Powers Smith, for the pages are approximately twelve by eighteen inches, and the epic is printed in double columns.

A GREAT many cocktails have flowed down a great many throats since that century long ago when first an earthly film was shown upon our well-known satellite, the moon. Since then producers have become more and more dependent upon the universe market for film profits.
An article on the future of the League of Nations by Senor de Madariaga in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine leads to some thoughts and conclusions which may be of interest.

In THE TIMES recently there appeared an editorial "The Capital Gains Tax" in which was discussed the observations of Mr. Parker and Mr. Nelson at the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia. The editorial emphasized the points made by these speakers that our policy of taxing capital gains is essentially wrong and that it causes hardships to our taxpayers.

The drought continued last week on its way toward becoming a major disaster in at least thirteen States. While there were rains, there were not enough; and although there were occasional breaths of cooling air, record high temperatures were established in many parts of the country.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., July 18 (AP). -- Governor Leslie A. Miller, Democrat of Wyoming, said today that John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Committee chairman, was "desperate indeed in his quest for power" if the Governor's letter to a Civilian Conservation Corps applicant was the "best evidence" he had to substantiate charges of politics in relief.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 18. -- Reuben Fine of New York made a brilliant debut today in the international chess masters' tournament which opened at the Grand Hotel by defeating the veteran Geza Maroczy of Hungary in the first round.

THE thirty-third running of the historic Gold Cup race for speed boats will take place on Bolton Bay next Saturday under the colors of the Lake George Club and under the sanction of the American Power Boat Association.

TRENTON, N.J., July 18. -- If the Federal Grand Jury for New Jersey is advised by District Attorney John J. Quinn when it meets in special session next Thursday that it has jurisdiction to investigate Paul H. Wendel's charge that he was kidnapped, it is expected that Federal agents will join in the search for John Arbitel of Trenton, regarded as a "key" witness in the case.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Organized cattle producers, packers, and wholesale and retail meat distributors have completed plans for a nation-wide domestic beef sale to be conducted during August, the National Livestock Marketing Association of Chicago announced today.

Operations of the Acme Steel Company and subsidiaries in the second quarter of this year resulted in a net profit of $513,774, after interest, depreciation and Federal income taxes. This is equal to $1.57 each on 328,108 shares of $25-par stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- While the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System and its experts have refrained carefully from any statements of policy, it appears doubtful that in the immediate future, at least, action will be taken to change the 55 per cent margin requirement covering the extension of credit by brokers to their customers.

SUMMER camps this season offer more than simple living in the out-of-doors. In addidition to catering to the physical well-being of the thousands of young people and adults who seek a few weeks of roughing it, most camps offer special training in languages, dramatics, music or science.
BOISE, Idaho, July 18 (AP). -- Sentor Borah is combing the Idaho sagebrush these days in a single-handed drive for the votes he needs to send him to the national capital for a sixth term.

May I comment on the very interesting article about John Wilkes Booth and his alleged visit to Paris three months before the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, which appeared in THE TIMES? The late Philip Hale was much interested in the problem and, being familiar with the journal of Edmond Got, he discussed the matter with me several times.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The Virginia Seniors Golf Association is completing arrangements for the eighth annual tournament, to be played during the week of Aug. 3 over the Old White championship course. The Virginia Seniors will play the West Virginia Seniors.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 18 (AP). -- Pennsylvania's long fight to regain a fallen coal trade will be reopened in Washington Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Weather Bureau has received reports of record-breaking temperatures from thirty-one of its stations during this Summer's hot spell. It is difficult to say which of these stations had the highest temperature, however, inasmuch as first reports are sent in telegraphic code providing for the use of only even numbers.

INTO this small book an American author, now well on in the fullness of distinguished years, portrays the childhood and the burgeoning years of a distinguished American poet, Edwin Arlington Robinson.

Commenting on the twenty-fifth anniversary this year of the enactment of the Compulsory Milk Pasteurization Law, Dr. William H. Best, Acting Commissioner of Health, declared yesterday that pasteurization virtually had eliminated cholera infantum.

With New York's forty-seven votes a key prize in the Presidential electoral grab-bag, the G.O.P. leaders in the Empire State are seeking a Republican candidate for Governor who will add most to the national ticket of Governor Landon and Colonel Knox.

Announcements of bonds called for redemption before maturity were, in number, little changed from the small volume of the preceding weeks. The calls, which were mostly for future months, included a variety of bonds, with those in the public utility category predominating.

Because he likes the excitement of fires Nuzzio Cusamano, 16 years old, of 1,665 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, tried three times yesterday to start a blaze in a row of fifteen frame houses on either side of 1,948 Cropsey Avenue that is being demolished to make way for an apartment house.

ONE of the most remarkable of Italy's many important outdoor musical productions was had in the recent first performance anywhere of "La Festa delle Panatenee," or Festival of Panathenaea, staged before the Greek temples of Paestum, with music for soprano, chorus, ballet and orchestra especially composed by Ildebrando Pizzetti.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18. -- TVA electricity flowing through a municipally owned distribution system now lights Florence, Ala., but the Alabama Power Company -- in effect -- still holds the mortgage. The city of Florence, perched on the bank of the Tennessee River beside Wilson Dam, realized a fifteen-year fight for municipal power on Wednesday when the Alabama power Company properties there are formally transferred to the city.

MONTREAL, July 17. -- The great wave of heat which baked New York after parching the American West inflicted more damage and cost more lives in Canada, in proportion to population, than it did in the United States.
SYRACUSE, July 18 (AP). -- Remington-Rand, Inc., won a temporary injunction against three unions today to limit picketing at the company's plant here and to prevent picketing of workers' homes.

Frank Fuka, 50 years old, whose clothing contained a card indicating that he lived at the Municipal Lodging House, East River and Twenty-sixth Street, was drowned yesterday afternoon when he jumped into the river in an attempt to rescue two men he had thrown into the water previously during an argument.

Gathered under the roof of Bellamy Batchelier are five of his surviving relatives. Six have been invited, but Francis Batchelier has declined the invitation. One or more of these six will probably inherit Bellamy's millions when he dies.

ONE hundred years ago William Holmes McGuffey, Professor of Mental Philosophy and Philology at Ohio's Miami University, published the first of his "Eclectic Headers" for elementary school children. Next Friday and Saturday educators, statesmen, industrialists and McGuffey readers will gather on Miami's campus to pay honor to the author of the celebrated textbooks.

MANUEL AZAHA, President of the Spanish Republic, with his new book, "Mi rebelion en Barcelona" (Espasa-Calpe), in which he proves his innocence of charges of disloyalty to Spain brought against him by the powers of corrupt political machines, has come to be acknowledged as so great a statesman that his status as a man of letters is in danger of being overlooked.

NOT long ago it used to be said, proudly if inaccurately, that the United States had conquered a continent. The boast went unchallenged, except for occasional protests from the Canadians and the Mexicans, who were under the impression that their land, too, was part of North America.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 18 (AP). -- One shot from a tower guard's gun frustrated today a well-planned plot of three or four Ohio Penitentiary convicts to escape over the west wall of the prison.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 17. -- Alf M. Landon will step out on the platform built over the south steps of the Kansas State House next Thursday night and formally launch his campaign for the Presidency.

IN Scout Summer camps throughout the land thousands of boys are now learning to swim. From the standpoint of fun, health and valuable skill, swimming is one of the most important of outdoor activities. Last season 16,290 Scouts were taught the art while at camp.

LONDON, July 15. -- Next week's assorted theatrical grab-bag begins on Monday at the Embassy with a few special performances for students of the Clemence Dane-Richard Addinsell version of "L'Aiglon," which New York has already seen with Eva Le Gallienne in the title role.

CRADLE IN THE AIR: It might be difficult to find an American family more air-minded than the Alexis Felix du Ponts of Wilmington, DeL To aerial transport they have given patronage, service, prizes and records.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Over a track fetlock-deep in mud, Apogee, daughter of Pharamond II -- Summit, owned by Hal Price Headley of Lexington, Ky., galloped to victory in the Lassie Stakes, richest race in the world for 2-year-old fillies, at Arlington Park today.

Antediluvian is to be congratulated on his ability to withstand the onslaughts of the moderns with their harsh angles and dissonant reiterations. In a world filled with indecision and contention it would be pleasant to think that the dance might be the one art that provides a realm of retreat from the bane of reality.

DANZIG, July 18. -- The Senate decrees issued here today were well timed for the week-end. The news was announced to the Danzig press at 1:30 P.M. and published at 4 o'clock, coming as a surprise to the Danzig population. The arrest of Opposition leaders is expected tonight in accordance with the decrees.

MILWAUKEE, July 18 (AP). -- Rehabilitation, employment and legislation to give them preference in government jobs were the major problems before the Disabled American Veterans of the World War today as the group opened its annual convention.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Reports from Germany that an agreement is being negotiated between this country and Germany with regard to claims growing out of the Black Tom and Kingsland munition plant explosions during July, 1916, for which it is alleged German agents were responsible, obtained at least partial confirmation today from Secretary Hull.

THE automobile factory worker is sharing in the industry's strong recovery. He is earning more per hour and a larger real annual income than in 1929, although he is working substantially shorter hours on the average per week.

CAPE MAY, N.J. -- Cape May's Summer population has increased to almost record numbers. The cottage colony is the largest in years, representing Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, Pittsburgh, Wilmington and other cities.

Howard S. Cullman, vice chairman of the National Committee on Safety at Sea, yesterday urged Secretary of Commerce Roper to assume responsibility for a thorough investigation of the merchant marine, with particular attention to safety and labor conditions.

LAKE HOPATCONG. -- Country club members are looking forward with interest to the social event of the month on next Saturday night, when a midsummer leap year dance will be held. An evening bridge party at the Yacht Club will be the attraction on Friday night.

The setting for the murder is Wimbledon, where Wynbolt, an Australian tennis player who has been considered as having no chance whatever, has reached the finals and seems to be a sure winner. His sudden death on the court saves a certain bookmaker 6,000 and removes a dangerous rival from the path of Harry Standish, who is in love with Anthea Pennington.

Current trends suggest that this year will mark the most important turning point in average department store profits since 1927, the last year when all volume groups reported a profit, and that net operating profits of most types of retail distributors during the second half of the year are likely to make the best showing since the boom days, according to forecasts made in retail quarters here.

HAVANA, July 18. -- Representative William I. Sirovich conferred for an hour today with President Miguel Gomez and presented a proposal that Cuba open her doors for at least 100,000, perhaps more, persecuted German Jews for whom American Jewry and international humanitarians of all creeds are seeking to find permanent homes in countries where immigration restrictions do not prove to be a bar.

AS the national political campaign progresses the broadcasters find themselves summoned into the thick of the fight with the metal-shelled microphone. Each week the demands from campaigners for more time on the air increase, and the verbal bombardment is expected to grow louder across the land as August approaches.

DESPITE the fact that it is the longest open-water stretch of scheduled flying ever attempted, the 2,410-mile leg of Pan American Airway's 8,500-mile transpacific air route which runs from Alameda to Honolulu is by no means a lonely or deserted waste from the air.

WE "subhumans," as Odd John calls us, could do worse this Summer than to read this testament of a "human" life. It is a fabulous fantasy that makes sense -- in the Wells manner. It is a report on a sane man in an insane world.

BINGHAMTON, July 18 (AP). -- Governor Lehman was urged today by the Binghamton Citizens Flood Control Committee to expedite signing of a compact with the government for immediate beginning of preliminary work on Federal flood control construction in Central-Southern New York.

BOSTON, July 17. -- Liquidation impends for what has long been known as the largest cotton textile mill in the world. This recommendation of Arthur Black, the master, on the possibility of reorganization, probably will be passed upon by Judge George C. Sweeney in Federal court Monday.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 18. -- Australia and Germany broke even today in the opening singles matches of the interzone final of the Davis Cup tennis competition.
TAMFA, Fla., July 18 (AP). -- Coast Guard craft searched by air and sea today for the British motor ship Nunoca, ten days overdue here with twenty-one persons aboard from the British West Indies.
UP to the present time few garden lovers have grasped the almost unlimited possibilities of garden and flower photographs made in full natural color which modern photographic processes offer them.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18. -- Impressive all-around performances by Captain D.T. (Nick) Craw and J. Barney Balding featured the victories of the Diehards and Vipers respectively in quarter-final round matches of the Wheatley Cups polo tourney at the Meadow Brook Club today.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., July 18 (AP). -- Senator Robinson, discussing Supreme Court invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, told a farmers' mass meeting tonight that "judges like other men are liable to err."

Spanish Morocco is the smaller of the two main zones, French and Spanish, into which the Sultanate of Morocco in North Africa is divided. It covers 18,300 square miles, with a population of 750,000, whereas French Morocco has an area of 200,000 square miles and a population of more than 5,000,000.

The Lincoln Cathedral Choir, noted a capella organization from Lincoln, Neb., will tour the cities and concert halls of the East during the next Christmas season, according to plans formulated last week at a meeting of the choir's Eastern committee presided over by Lily Pons, the committee's chairman.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Cooler weather, beginning Tuesday, lifted retail sales above last week's levels for a gain of around 18 per cent over 1935 with the larger department stores. Men's furnishing stores are turning in good sized increases. Bonus money is still a factor in the generally improved conditions.

One hundred and ten miles of high-speed motor-boat racing, most of it at a mile-a-minute clip or faster, will give a good many thousands of Adirondack vacationists the thrill of their Summer next Saturday on Lake George.

PARIS, July 16. -- Many new mid-Summer accessories are making their appearance. Amusing sun hats in smoked glass are cut like French haymakers' hoods. Velvet gloves and other velvet accessories are smart with pique, cretonne or Swiss embroidery frocks.

Plans for the coming Autumn field-trial season for pointers and setters are well under way in the Eastern section and a majority of the organizations giving meetings already have arranged their dates. In the territory within easy motoring distance of New York City the season will begin in mid-September to continue until late October.

THE article on painting and sculpture in the Americana Annual Supplement is written for the ninth year by Peyton Boswell, editor of The Art Digest. Brief extracts, indicative of Mr. Boswell's point of view and typical of his pungent style, follow:

HISTORIC Yarmouth, at the southwest point of Nova Scotia, will celebrate its 175th anniversary from July 27 to Aug. 1 with tournaments sports, yacht races and -- of greater significance -- a pageant reproducing the history that is peculiarly and outstandingly the heritage of this famous old seaport.

OFTEN a source of vogues in decoration, the exhibitions of French decorative art, including the one at the Musee Galliera in Paris, open until October, and the recent Salon des Artistes Decorateurs, are always viewed with interest by the Summer tourist.

BERLIN, July 17 -- There is a consensus among observers of European affairs that the Austro-German agreement makes for present peace -- peace, perhaps, for some years. But for how many years no prophet worthy of credence would dare predict, and as for permanent peace, that is quite a different matter.

PARIS. THE Grande Semaine is always packed with sartorial significance. At all the big races (the Grand Steeple; les Haies; the Drags; the Grand Prix) and at the luncheons that precede and the galas that follow them, one sees a complete summary of the fashions of the season and a forecast of what they will be like in the Autumn.

THE school assembly, long infamous as a place for hearing orders handed down from high Olympus or for the long, monotonous and boring classic "pieces" spoken by scared seniors to their callous classmates, has become, at Northeast High School in Philadelphia, a forum for a new and vitalized course in current world affairs.

ELIMINATION of the bear feeding ground at Old Faithful in Yellowstone National Park this season has furnished park rangers with proof of their contention that hungry bears will migrate quickly for as much as fifty miles if a fresh food supply turns up elsewhere.

The National Conference of Jews and Christians, 289 Fourth Avenue, announced yesterday three "institutes of human relations" would be held in August and September under its auspices in various parts of the country.

Those up-and-coming Raritan Bay yachtsmen think Captain Billopp was a slow-poke. A host of skippers, in fact two whole fleets of them, intend to prove on two occasions this Summer that his little sailing vessel, which in 1668 had its home port in Perth Amboy, must have been dragging one or more anchors.

WORLD statesmen, like national statesmen, have nowadays to invest their mental powers in short-term thinking and in long-term thinking. Some of the conflicts before them will not brook delay. But the main problem, of which such conflicts are but symptoms, admits of no immediate solution and can only be dealt with in collaboration with time.

When the late Otto H. Kahn was asked by a Senate investigating committee to state the difference between an investor and speculator he was unable to do so. To repeated queries he answered that the difference might be one of degree rather than function.

Complaints that foreign manufacturers are advancing prices and thereby depriving American importers of the benefits expected from tariff concessions granted under reciprocal trade agreements were voiced here yesterday by buyers planning to depart for Europe at the end of this month.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- More than 500 tennis stars, all ranking players of member clubs of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, have been invited to take part in the twenty-fourth annual July and August senior tennis tournaments at the Lake Placid Club.
STOCKHOLM, SWEDEN, July 18. -- The total eclipse of the sun is widely considered the grandest spectacle ever observed by man, and the eclipse of June 19 was no exception.

A rigid national licensing examination for osteopathic physicians and surgeons to supersede the present individual State tests and eliminate the need for re-examination by each State in which a physician wishes to practice was urged yesterday by Dr. Charles Hazzard, a member of the New York State Board of Medical Examiners.

IN the middle of the eighteenth century the English of Nova Scotia surrounded the French habitants of Grand Pre, burned their homes and, in a peculiarly brutal way, crowded them into ships and scattered them penniless along our eastern shores from New Jersey to Virginia.

In terms of altitude, Imogene Coca touched her zenith one frosty night last Winter when she found herself atop the R.C.A. Building regaling the parched and lacquered upper crust with song and antic in the Rainbow Room. Seek her out at her nadir, and one must turn the calendar back a good ten years and descend sixty-six stories to a Forty-eighth Street cellar -- the Silver Slipper.

OMAHA, July 18 (AP). -- Paul Leslie, 24-year-old Louisiana State University student from Jefferson City, Mo., and 21-year-old Bob Fraser of Omaha will meet tomorrow over the Happy Hollow Club course for the Western amateur golf championship in the thirty-six-hole final.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP). -- Uncorking the same burst of speed that marked his maiden start, Percy M. Pike's Supply House today gained his second victory in as many efforts in the Faneuil Hall, today's feature, at five and a half furlongs, at Suffolk Downs.

MEXICO, D.F., July 18. -- The strike begun three days ago by the syndicate of electrical workers against the Mexican Light and Power Company -- the most costly strike ever experienced in this republic -- is still in full force, and its end cannot be foreseen.

PARIS, July 18. -- The correspondent of the newspaper Petit Parisien at Behobie, France, on the Spanish border, reported tonight that the Italian Ambassador to Madrid had arrived there with a report "from official sources" of "movements" that had broken out in Northern Spain, Pamplona, Valadilid and Saragossa.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18. -- After being down in both his quarter and semi-final round matches in the New York State amateur championship at the Bellevue Country Club today, Ray Billows of Poughkeepsie, golf's Cinderella man, advanced to the title round of the fourteenth annual event for the second time in the last two years.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 18. -- Mrs. Maude Rutherford, speedboat driver from Palm Beach, Fla., climaxed two days of motor-boat thrills at the seventh annual Havre de Grace regatta by beating a world record today and coming back in a later race to better her own new mark.

A third suit seeking vacations with pay for WPA employes was filed in Federal Court yesterday by Frieda Lescher, a senior stenographer of the Living Newspaper. Unit of the Federal Theatre Project. She said she was suing in behalf of herself and thousands of other WPA workers who were not selected from relief rolls.

MONTREUX, July 17. -- The results of the Dardanelles conference may be expressed in several ways. In profit and loss of power it brings distinct gain for Turkey, Russia and the League and a loss for Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Japan, France and the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Two Western Senators, irked at what they called "dilatory tactics," called upon national livestock and farm associations today to urge railroads serving Western drought areas to reduce freight rates on livestock feed at once.

PORTLAND, Me., July 18. -- Hardy fisher folk in their blue denims and Summer colonists in their flannels and linens rubbed elbows today as they thronged the picturesque cottage studio of the late Winslow Homer at Prout's Neck to view the pictures, hung for the most part just as the famous marine painter had left them.

SOME day it may occur to the promoters of the Vienna festival weeks to take a leaf out of Salzburg's new book and decline to allow any and every musical function which happens to take place in a Viennese concert hall between June 7 and 21 to figure officially as "im Rahmen der Festwochen."

Mayor La Guardia recommended City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. yesterday for the consideration of "independent groups, Republicans and all interested in good municipal government" as his candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen in the Fall election.

Mayor La Guardia recommended City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. yesterday for the consideration of "independent groups, Republicans and all interested in good municipal government" as his candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen in the Fall election.

A novel issue on the right of a train passenger to a seat has been raised by Philip Davis, a lawyer, of 535 Fifth Avenue, in a claim filed with the New York Central, it was learned yesterday, Mr. Davis has written a letter to the railroad's claim department asking return of his fare and damages because he was forced to stand while riding from Albany to New York last Sunday night.

Had the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra played "For Auld Lang Syne" at last night's concert at the Lewisohn Stadium, that melody would have voiced the reminiscent mood of many of the 5,200 persons present when Arnold Volpe took up his baton to direct the second half of the evening's program.
BERLIN, July 18. -- The National Socialist Government in the Free City of Danzig staged this afternoon what amounts to "a cold Putsch" that will have far-reaching consequences.

SHANGHAI, July 18. -- Even before the excitement occasioned by Chen Chia-tang's overthrow and flight has begun to subside, it becomes apparent that new developments in the Southwest are certain to have most profound effects on Chino-Japanese relations.

HENDAYE, France, July 18 (AP). -- Reports from Spain tonight insisted that the rebellion that broke out in Spanish Morocco today had spread to Spain itself and that garrisons in cities throughout Andalusia were in revolt.

CENTRAL CITY, Col., July 18 (AP). -- Central City, just another mountain mining village yesterday, forsook humdrum life tonight to say "howdy" to the visitors swarming the steep streets and narrow sidewalks.

On more than one occasion Presidential candidates have used the medium of the acceptance speech as a means of elaborating or illuminating party policies. Mr. HARDING did this in 1920, when he discarded the Lodge reservations to the Treaty of Versailles and pledged his party to the negotiation of a new treaty.

So far the chief effect of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price-Discrimination Act has been to create uneasiness among business men, who do not know just what it does or does not make unlawful. Distinguished lawyers who have studied the bill for private concerns or trade associations seem to be no better off.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 18 (AP). -- Representative James M. Mead of Buffalo declared here tonight that the Postal Department "will pay its way this year."

In the letter signed Antedi luvian, printed in yesterday's TIMES, I take issue with the writer's condemnation of the "angles" in the dances of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman. By this same token, then, the Parthenon is utterly lacking in grace and beauty and the great skyscrapers are but lifeless masses of geometric patterns in stone.
MADRID, July 18, -- The Spanish Government sent warships and airplanes tonight to crush a military revolt in Spanish Morocco and the Canary Islands.

BOSTON, July 18. -- Retail trade in New England so far in July has been maintaining the same approxi mate percentage of gains as was shown during the months of May and June. Currently, merchants in leading cities report sales 10 to 15 per cent over those a year ago.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Dizzy Dean essayed a relief-pitching role, seeing action for the third straight day, but the Bees got to him for a run in the eleventh and beat the Cards, 6 to 5, in the opener of a three-game series today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- Harold S. Vanderbilt brought his sloop Rainbow, winner of the America's Cup in the last international series, home first with over three minutes to spare today in the first of the special series of contests with Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee and Chandler Hovey's Weetamoe.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 18. -- Nelson Vallis, having won a four-month fight against deportation to Bermuda, said today he was concerned with getting two important documents. One is a marriage license. The other is naturalization papers.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 18. -- The greater part of the substantial estate of Thomas Bell Meighan, star of the silent films, who died at Grenwold Park, Great Neck, July 8, will pass to his widow, Mrs. Frances Ring Meighan, according to his will filed with Surrogate Leone D. Howell today.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 18. -- Stepping into the situation created here by the strike, now in its fourth week, at the plant of the Radio Corporation of America, the National Labor Relations Board announced late today that it would conduct a hearing next Saturday to determine the labor organization entitled to become the collective bargaining agency for the empoyes.
MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 18 (AP). -- Immediate right to remilitarize the Dardanelles was granted to Turkey tonight by nine signatories to the Lausanne post-war treaty.

GREATER safety for the increasing thousands who travel by motor bus is the aim of a new regulation to control the working hours of bus drivers, which was adopted by the last session of the State Legislature and became effective on July 1.
PARIS, July 18. -- The bill for the nationalization of the French armament industry adopted yesterday by the Chamber of Deputies allows the government the widest scope for its practical application.

ERIE, Pa., July 18. -- A woman and her two children were beaten to death today and police held the children's father, a Sunday school superintendent, who was quoted as saying that he had committed "a scarlet sin" and wished to send his family "to heaven because they were white and clean."

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Contributions to the Republican National Committee through its dollar participation certificate plan have passed the $100,000 mark, C.B. Goodspeed, the party's national treaturer, announced today. Contributions of a dollar or more receive certificates which say that they are participants "in the work of bringing about a return to the fundamental principles of our government."

A long procession of lame, ill and otherwise afflicted persons, hoping that their faith and the reported curative powers of a relic of the mother of the Virgin Mary would make them whole, filed past the shrine of St. Anne yesterday at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.

NEWPORT. -- Three of the better-known Summer estates are to open their gardens on Tuesday afternoon for the benefit of the Civil League. The public will be admitted to the garden of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Vannest Gambrill at Vernon Court, to that of Miss Julia A. Berwind at the Elms and to that of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Barton Jacobs at Whiteholm.

TANGIER, Morocco, July 18 (AP). -- A rebel force numbering 20,000 men held complete control of Spanish Morocco tonight after having seized the chief military posts throughout the area, refugees reaching here reported.

WHILE the Hindenburg shuttles back and forth across the Atlantic and the Graf Zeppelin keeps up the South American service, there is arising in the minds of some naval men and of members of Congressional naval committees a feeling of pique that Germany should do so successfully something at which this country has largely failed.

A steady undertone characterized routine trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The moderate recovery in most of the long-term United States Government loans stood out as the most conspicuous group movement and halted the steady decline in those issues which began early in the week following the announcement by the Federal Reserve Board in lifting member bank reserve requirements 50 per cent.

RECKLESS drivers have occupied so much of the time and space of speakers and writers on safety matters that they might seem to a transient visitor from Venus to include all the occupants of the streets and highways of the country.

During the storm late last night, lightning struck an electric wire of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company, and sent it sputtering to the street in front of the Interboro Motion Picture Theatre at 3,462 East Tremont Avenue, between Greene Place and Eastern Boulevard, the Bronx.

A stock-selling woman spiritualist and a promoter represented by her during seances as a reincarnation of the man who built the Pyramids were temporarily enjoined yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin from selling "Super-Utilities" stock in this State.

The military rebellion that broke out in Spanish Morocco early yesterday is the culmination of a series of incidents by which many sectors of Spain's armed forces have expressed their dissatisfaction with the Leftist government.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Cliffs more than three miles high, and inaccessible, unmapped mountain peaks were photographed by members of the National Geographic Society's Mount McKinley Expedition on its first flight, according to advices from Bradford Washburn, leader of the expedition which was dispatched to Alaska early this month to record in still and motion pictures North America's highest peak and a vast little-known mountain area south and west of it.

Peter Dana, 20-year-old professional pilot and great-grandson of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, landed at the North Beach Airport in Queens at 4:38 o'clock last night after a flight from San Diego, Calif., with two unofficial records to his credit.

RADIO'S general practice is to schedule programs for thirteen or twenty-six weeks, but the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society sets a new record, having signed a five-year contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Bishop Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit, who is the superior of Father Charles E. Coughlin, expressed disapproval here yesterday of the language used by the priest Thursday night at Cleveland in referring to President Roosevelt. He emphasized, however, that he had not rebuked his subordinate.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Sensational reports of damage to the corn crop from the West and Southwest were more than offset today by reports of showers over parts of Northern Illinois, Iowa and Southern Wisconsin, and a rush of profit-taking by traders found the market poorly supported. The close on the Board of Trade was at the bottom with losses of 4 cents a bushel, the maximum permitted for one day under Exchange regulations.

PHYSICISTS these days are providing the public with excellent books showing how newly discovered facts and newly elaborated theories are altering the world picture. But readers interested in the nature rather than the results of physical theory have a harder time.

THIS is an exceptionally well told and diverting tale of a range war between those perennial enemies -- cattle men and sheep herders -- and of an equally bitter fight between two cowboys for the love of a girl.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., July 18. -- Judge J.H. Clement said this afternoon in Superior Court that he would sign an order on Thursday awarding 10 per cent of the net amount Anne Cannon Reynolds receives from the estate of her father, Z. Smith Reynolds, to three law firms representing Mrs. Anne L. Cannon of Concord, co-guardian of Anne Cannon Reynolds 2d, for services in the litigation over the distribution of the $33,000,000 estate.

THE scenery was flashing by the dining-car window and Mr. Alva Bradley, president of the Cleveland ball club, was sipping iced coffee and telling about the dogs he had around his house. He said the prize pair of dachshunds had taken distemper and had met an untimely death but the scotties and the airedales were in good health and loud voice.
MANILA, July 18 (AP). -- The political demands of a powerful Moro Princess confronted the new Sultan of Sulu tonight while the widows of his predecessor occupied the royal palace.

SIMPLE ideas evolved partly through a necessity for strict economy are proving feasible in military operations and bringing bombardment units of the Air Corps a degree of training not possible a few years ago.

ON land, as well as in the air and on the water, changes are renovating the travel picture. Slowly but inexorably a once-important factor in the linking of municipalities and suburban communities -- the interurban electric car -- is passing from the transportation scene.

Julius Hochman, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, was nominated unanimously as the candidate of the Socialist party for President of the Board of Aldermen at a city convention yesterday afternoon at Irving Plaza, Irving Place and Fifteenth Street.

THE American prototype of the English private press is missing in the experience of the average American reader. Most of us can differentiate between the artist who paints for his own pleasure (although he may not be averse to selling a picture) and the so-called "commercial artist" who contracts in advance for the sale of his work.

RUMSON, N.J., July 18. -- Once more undefeated, the chestnut mare, Winning Ways, owned by the Terre Heute Farm of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kaiser of Bethel, Conn., today was awarded the grand championship in the saddle division of the Monmouth County Horse Show, it being the culminating event of three days of sharp competition in the division.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- Since the successful Independence Day tournament, the present Hot Springs tennis colony has been brushing up its game in anticipation of the most popular tennis event of the season, the annual midsummer tournament, which takes place on the Casino courts throughout the coming week.

PARIS, July 17. -- By introducing bills in Parliament this week for reorganization of the control and direction of the Bank of France and for nationalizing the war industries, Leon Blum's government has carried out the two principal promises of the Popular Front electoral program.

The military rebellion that broke out in Spanish Morocco early yesterday is the culmination of a series of incidents by which many sectors of Spain's armed forces have expressed their dissatisfaction with the Leftist government.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Cliffs more than three miles high, and inaccessible, unmapped mountain peaks were photographed by members of the National Geographic Society's Mount McKinley Expedition on its first flight, according to advices from Bradford Washburn, leader of the expedition which was dispatched to Alaska early this month to record in still and motion pictures North America's highest peak and a vast little-known mountain area south and west of it.

Peter Dana, 20-year-old professional pilot and great-grandson of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, landed at the North Beach Airport in Queens at 4:38 o'clock last night after a flight from San Diego, Calif., with two unofficial records to his credit.

RADIO'S general practice is to schedule programs for thirteen or twenty-six weeks, but the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society sets a new record, having signed a five-year contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Bishop Michael J. Gallagher of Detroit, who is the superior of Father Charles E. Coughlin, expressed disapproval here yesterday of the language used by the priest Thursday night at Cleveland in referring to President Roosevelt. He emphasized, however, that he had not rebuked his subordinate.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Sensational reports of damage to the corn crop from the West and Southwest were more than offset today by reports of showers over parts of Northern Illinois, Iowa and Southern Wisconsin, and a rush of profit-taking by traders found the market poorly supported. The close on the Board of Trade was at the bottom with losses of 4 cents a bushel, the maximum permitted for one day under Exchange regulations.

PHYSICISTS these days are providing the public with excellent books showing how newly discovered facts and newly elaborated theories are altering the world picture. But readers interested in the nature rather than the results of physical theory have a harder time.

THIS is an exceptionally well told and diverting tale of a range war between those perennial enemies -- cattle men and sheep herders -- and of an equally bitter fight between two cowboys for the love of a girl.
LONDON, July 17. -- Although the country now is entering the annual holiday season, business activity continues at a higher level than usual.

Builders during the next three years will have to erect houses at double the normal rate to make up for the existing shortage in this country, according to a survey of residential construction made by the Alexander Hamilton Institute for the Wall Paper Exposition to be held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria July 27 to 31.

Despite the fact that five of their team-mates are bound for Berlin, lesser lights of the Women's Swimming Association upheld the prestige of the national outdoor team champions by making a clean sweep of the first places in the six open events on the A.A.U. program at the Beachwood Yacht and Country Club, Whitestone Landing, L.I., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- John S. Farnsworth, dismissed naval officer charged with espionage, today admitted to newspaper men that he had sold two articles, or monographs, on naval subjects to an agent of the Japanese Government for $1,000.
While the government in Madrid was so confused that it had three Premiers in twenty-four hours the Spanish military revolt gained headway.

BERLIN, July 19. -- Tomorrow at noon, when the steamer bringing the American Olympic team here will be approaching the coast of Ireland, the sun's rays, focussed through a magnifying glass, will light a torch at Olympia, original scene of the Olympic Games.

NYACK, N.Y., July 19. -- Charles Coppola, 20 years old, of 196 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn, was killed instantly near here today when he fell 250 feet from the top of Hook Mountain. The body was found by the police after a number of persons in the Hook Mountain Park had witnessed the fall.

BERLIN, July 18. -- The Reich's June foreign trade results are regarded here as favorable. The decline of export surplus to 11,000,000 marks, against 35,000,000 marks in May, is seasonal. In June, 1935, exports just balanced imports.

HONGKONG, July 19. -- General Chen Chia-tang, for five years !ruler of the important Southern Iprovlnce of Iwangtung, reached I-Iongkong today in flight before the advancing Nanking government armies sent to put down his opposition to the Nanking rSgime.

ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP MANHATTAN, at Sea, July 19. -Deep sighs of relief were heaved by the American Olympic Committee officials today at the model deportment displayed by the United States athletes following yesterday's sharp warnings as to behavior.

It is Laughter Week in Berlin. By way of preparation for the Olympic Games the Labor Front newspaper suggests that the next eight days be devoted to training courses in jollity. An intensive week's drill in merry hearts and friendly expressions will put Berliners on the top of their form to receive foreign guests.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 19. -- Officers today exposed seeming discrepancies in the story told by Mark Wollner, concert violinist, of his movements subsequent to the time when Miss Helen Clevenger of Staten Island, New York University co-ed, was shot to death in her room at the Battery Park Hotel here early Thursday morning.
