Total net assets of Massachusetts Investors Trust, a mutual or "openend" investment trust, were $100,481,425 on June 30, equivalent to $26.30 each on the shares outstanding. This compares with net assets of $78,171,412, or $24.03 a share on Dec. 31, 1935.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- In an analysis of the revenue laws of 1935 and 1936, published today, the American Liberty League charged that "The New Deal has prostituted the taxing power under the Constitution to accomplish social and economic ends remote from the raising of revenue."

Peltier's comet should become visible to the unaided eye tomorrow night as it approaches the earth while speeding on its orbit around the sun, Professor William H. Barton Jr. of the Hayden Planetarium said yesterday. About Aug. 4 it will reach its maximum visibility at a distance of 16,000,000 miles from the earth.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19. -Harry L. Maxwell's one-design 12-meter sloop Iris, John D. Archbold's 40-footer Vixen III, now in the large handicap class division, and J.B. Shethar's new 32-footer Valencia led the large boats home today in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club that was arranged to fill in the competition of race week.

The calling of a city-wide conference to consider independent political action will be discussed tomorrow at a joint meeting of executive committees of the trade union committee for a Labor party and the people's committee for a Farmer-Labor party.

Quiet Manhattan was a weak diet yesterday for the girl from Chateau, Mont., who wrote that she wanted to be "jostled by people who have no time to stare." So Erma Young, the 21-year-old college graduate whose poetic essay on "Why I Want to See New York" won her a trip here to live those reasons, journeyed to Coney Island for her second day of impressions.

A Holy Family Hospital ambulance answering an accident call, and a police radio car also on an emergency trip, collided last night at Bergen Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, causing injuries to the four occupants of the cars.

PARIS, July 18. -- The Bank of France's report for July 10 showed decreases of 440,000,000 francs in bills discounted and 358,000,000 francs in circulation. The bank's gold reserve gained 265,000,000 francs, the cover ratio improving from 57.87 to 58.32 per cent.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 19. -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today through its Philadelphia office that it had issued a complaint accusing the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company of this city of fostering and assisting the Employes Committee Union in its plant in violation of "company union" regulations of the National Labor Relations Act.

The American Osteopathic Association, which is to open professional sessions of its annual convention today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, held a business meeting yesterday and heard reports on the progress of osteopathic education.

GIBRALTAR, July 19. -- It is reported that infantry troops who landed at Cadiz from Spanish Morocco this morning are now en route to Seville to join the rebel forces there and then march together to take over the government.

MADRID, July 19. -- Between official broadcasts today from the Interior Ministry informing the Spanish people that the military rebellion in Morocco and a number of cities in Spain had been completely dominated by the government, radio listeners were diverted by phonograph records, the musical selections ranging from opera to "Who's Afraid of the Big Bad Wolf?"
LONDON, July 19 (AP). -- Great Britain said special prayers of thanksgiving today for King Edward's escape from a pistol attack while he spent a quiet week-end at his Fort Belvedere country home.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- With public hearings in the investment trust inquiry survey scheduled to start on July 27, the Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a list of the names of 921 investment trusts and investment companies whose activities come within the scope of the study being made at the direction of Congress.

Secretary HULL'S vigorous defense of his reciprocal trade treaties is described in the Washington dispatches as the Administration's opening gun on the tariff issue in the 1936 campaign. He warmly denies that the obvious advantages gained for the American exporter through a policy of reciprocity have been achieved by "selling out" the American farmer.

The first New York performances of Maurice Ravel's ballet "Daphnis and Chloe," in its full form as written by the composer, will be offered as the final pair of ballet presentations of the Stadium session, Thursday and Friday nights, July 30 and 31.

LONDON, July 17. -- Although the Bank of England's circulation reached a new record of 443,359,000, the increase this week was only 153,000, whereas the Bank bought 5,394,000 more gold. In continuing to buy the metal at approximately 5,000,000 worth weekly the Bank has in view a further expansion of circulation before the seasonal peak is reached next month.
SIDNEY, Neb., July 19. -- A revolution in farming in Western Nebraska's grain belt was visioned tonight as an effect of the drought.

Organization of the National Crime Prevention Institute, with headquarters at 425 Fourth Avenue, has been completed with Dr. Sheldon Glueck, Professor of Criminology in the Harvard Law School, who has accepted its presidency, it was announced yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19. -- It was Gay Nineties night at the Newport Casino tonight in connection with the second of the series of Sunday evening "pop" concerts by the Providence Symphony Orchestra under Dr. Wassili Leps. All attending had been asked by Mrs. Dan W. Jones, chairman, to appear in costume.

With ease and comfort such as were unknown back in the early years of the century, when the "Mother Hubbard" locomotive was the last word in railroading, 165 members of the New York chapter of the Railway and Locomotive Historical Society went on an excursion to Scranton yesterday behind one of the 35-year-old engines.

The vicious and uncalled-for attack on the President of the United States by the Rev. Charles Coughlin, in my estimation, as a member of the Catholic faith, is one that will be resented by them. By his attitude, I am I of the opinion that he has won for the Roosevelt administration thousands of votes.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., July 19. -With a total of fifty points each, the Pendleton Canoe Club of New York and the Yonkers Canoe Club of Yonkers, N.Y., tied for first place in the Atlantic Division canoeing team championship on Lake Sebago today.

What first strikes one about the new law reforming the Bank of France is its comparative moderation. The Blum government, it was widely assumed, would nationalize the institution, but it has rather democratized it. The change had become inevitable, and the strength of the sentiment for reform is illustrated by the overwhelming majority in favor of the bill -- 430 votes to 111.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 19. -Governor Herbert H. Lehman visited the National Guard training quarters at Camp Smith here today and reviewed the Ninety-third Brigade, an all-New York unit, at evening parade.

Modern publicity methods are being employed by Chairman HAMILTON of the Republican National Committee in bringing distinguished converts into the fold. Anti-New Deal Democrats, who have already taken themselves out of the President's following in terms so repetitious of the preamble of the Cleveland platform that they have nowhere to go but into the Republican camp, are officially "converted" with the aid'of the press, the radio and the movies.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- Predictions that the drought may yet be a boon to the farmers generally rose tonight from the Grain Belt as weekend showers poured new life into the corn crop. The rains were attended by high winds in some sections and there was some damage to buildings and electric lines.

One of the most absurd statements that can be made is that all persons must think alike in order to be children of God, the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson. Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Colorado, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

BOSTON, July 19 (AP). -- The gold-plated Red Sox showed their batting prowess once more at Fenway Park today when they trounced the world champion Detroit Tigers, 12 to 3, and drove Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe from the box.

City hospitals during the first six months of the year were taxed to 97.4 per cent of bed capacity, Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, declares in a report which will be submitted to Mayor La Guardia today. Seven of the hospitals, including the two largest, Kings County and Bellevue, were crowded beyond capacity in the same period.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 19. -- Eddie Thorne, sailing his 1932 world's champion Mist, again triumphed in the Atlantic Coast and international eliminations of the Great South Bay Fleet today. Thorne also won yesterday.

The "whole Far East is like a boiling pot" which is bubbling away and may at any moment boil over and cause a conflagration, Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, explorer and director of the American Museum of Natural History, said yesterday in an interview.

PITTSBURGH, July 19. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 70 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding week and only a trifle under the average for May and June, when tonnage was the highest since early in 1930.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, July 19 (AP). -While the jubilant rebels rushed troops from Spanish Morocco to the troubled peninsula today to spread their revolt throughout the nation, General Francisco Franco, their leader, declared that "only Madrid" was militantly opposing the revolution.

MOSCOW, July 19. -- The transfer of 6,500,000 acres of land from State farms to collective farms in the Ukraine, Kursk, Black Earth and Azov-Black Sea regions was ordered by the government today in another move designed to improve the lot of the socialized peasantry and to increase the quantity and variety of foodstuffs.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, July 19. -- Loyal Spanish aviators were reported tonight to have bombed the High Commissioner's palace in Tetuan, capital of Spanish Morocco, killing twenty persons, while a rebellious army claimed firm control of the zone and announced sweeping gains on the mainland itself.

MADRID, July 19. -- The rebellion, officially described as a criminal attack against the republic on a wide scale, is openly monarchist in its aims, but seems to have been stimulated and set in action by a recent "purification" carried out with particular thoroughness by the commander-in-chief in Spanish Morocco, General Gomez Morato.

SWANZEY, N.H., July 19 (AP). -- Speeding motorcycles killed two persons and injured eight others, one seriously, in the American Motorcycle Association's national championship 200-mile road race today. Richard Ashbrook, 20, of Washington, died when his machine hit a curve at seventy miles an hour and crashed into a tree.

MEXICO, D.F., July 19. -- Efforts to settle the strike of the 3,000 workers in the foreign-owned Mexican Light and Power Company received a decided setback tonight when it was announced that the Canadian and British owners of the utility had rejected the strikers' demands.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 19. -- Colonel Clyde E. Winterton of East Orange, commanding officer of the 113th Infantry, which opened its Summer encampment here at Camp Hoffman yesterday, is ill at the "Little White House," Summer Executive Mansion, where he was put to bed shortly after the arrival of the regiment yesterday.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, July 19. -- The Croat Peasant Defense Force, the military organization admittedly organized for defense against the "Serbian aggressor," held a public demonstration for the first time today and was reviewed by Vladimir Matchek, the Croat leader.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 19. -- G.H. (Pete) Bostwick set a blistering pace as he led a Long Island four to a well-merited 8-6 triumph over Tommy Hitchcock's Sands Point outfit in the weekly high-goal polo match at Bostwick Field today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- Governor Landon has a lead over President Roosevelt in the first returns made public today by The Farm Journal in its Presidential straw vote conducted among the nation's farmers.

BAIREUTH, Bavaria, July 19. -Baireuth's ninth Summer season of opera since the World War opened today with a new production of "Lohengrin" of historic magnificence and with a general effect that savored of medieval festivity and splendor.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- The grain trade last week encountered a most peculiar market. Unfavorable weather for growing crops, combined with speculative activity, lifted every grain to its trading limit once or twice in the six days of trading on the Board of Trade.
Woodsmen can determine the age of a tree by counting its growth rings. Now scientists find that they can tell the age of fish by much the same method.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Hall Aylesworth gave a beach party at their Dune Villa today in honor of their week-end house guests, Major and Mrs. Leslie Thompson of Larchmont, N.Y., and Mrs. Wiley Woodbury. Miss Nancy Mae Woodbury is spending the Summer here with Miss Dorothy Aylesworth.

PANAMA, Republic of Panama, July 19. -- The government of Venezuela is sending additional troops to the oil fields, where dozen police sufficed to keep order during the regime of the late dictator, Juan Vicente Gomez.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Washington's season of outdoor symphony concerts was opened tonight with the first of a series of "Symphonies on the Potomac" at the Water Gate of the Lincoln Memorial Bridge. Thousands of music lovers assembled along the banks of the river to hear the orchestra of eighty musicians under the direction of Alfred Wallenstein, guest conductor, in an impressive and well-rendered program of symphonic music.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., July 19. -Ray Smith, home club champion for the last three years, and his partner, Frank Bowen of the Maplewood Country Club, today won the second annual Cedar Ridge Country Club best-ball invitation tournament with a thirty-six hole total of 138.

The payment of the World War bonus has resulted in an unprecedented exodus of merchant seamen to their homes, many of them with plans to remain permanently, according to Mrs. Janet Roper, head of the Missing Seamen's Bureau of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

The astronomers confess themselves puzzled by the odd behavior of little Nova Lacerta, the star nobody knew until it swam into the ken of an amateur star-gazer in Ohio a few weeks ago. It seems that Nova has them all stumped. She exhibits a volatility the telescopes of Mount Wilson and other observatories have never reflected before.

Sunday statistics issued yesterday by those expert Summer mathematicians, the resort officials, presented a happy picture of more than 2,000,000 men, women and children swimming, bathing and playing in the sand on the shores of the metropolitan area.
Except for a covering of French francs by those who had sold at the approach af Bastille Day, business in the foreign exchange market last week was devoid of special feature.

TAMPA, Fla., July 19 (AP). -- The third day of a search by American and Cuban craft passed today without a trace of the British motorship Nunoca, unreported since leaving the West Indies for Tampa July 4 with twenty-one persons aboard.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 19. -"As I look into your smiling, tanned and enthusiastic faces, I would rather be one of you boys at this moment than Lieutenant Governor," Lieut. Gov. Bray said in an address at the Citizens Military Training Camp tonight.
ALBANY, July 19 (AP). -- New York State considered official warnings tonight against the possibility of a double emergency, forest fires and lack of water.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 19 (AP). -Dispatches from Melilla today said three Spanish warships sent to fight the army rebels had joined the insurrection and that all Spanish Morocco was in the hands of the revolutionaries.

About 300 Bowery derelicts will take a boat trip up Long Island Sound tomorrow as guests of the Wilson Line. The trip, arranged by the Bowery Mission, is an innovation in social welfare work among the "boys."

CLEVELAND, July 19. -- The second annual convention of Townsend Clubs came to a prayerful end tonight in a great outdoor stadium where Representative Lemke, third party candidate, promised to save the country, and won the approval of the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, one time exponent of the Share-the-Wealth Plan and now an ardent Townsendite.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 19. -- Sam Fry Jr. of New York and Miss Ruth Chase of Boston, whose names have appeared at the top of the listing in the Southern New England contract bridge championships ever since they arrived here Friday, carried off their second title by winning the open pair competition at the tournament's concluding session tonight.

Returning to the pulpit of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, after an absence of twenty-seven years, the Rev. Robert Davis, who now lives in Paris, asserted yesterday that lasting peace among nations was impossible until they adopted a more friendly attitude toward one another, based on the affection, tolerance and aid of the "family" spirit.

Mrs. Susan Frawley Eisele of Blue Earth, Minn., who writes a weekly column for the Fairmont (Minn.) Sentinel, has been judged the best country newspaper correspondent in 1936, it was announced yesterday by Wheeler McMillen, editor of The Country Home Magazine, which gives annual awards to rural newspaper men and women.

The new investment banking firm of Schroder, Rockefeller Co., Inc., will open for business today at 48 Wall Street. The formation of the new firm, which will succeed to the underwriting and general securities business formerly done by the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, was announced on July 8.
BOSTON, July 19. -- Newspaper advertising is found more important than anything else in leading women to choose the store at which to buy their dresses, says a research study made public here today.

TOKYO, Monday, July 20. -- Independent building, which will not involve competition with the United States, and strict secrecy are the governing principles of the new naval plans now before the Japanese Cabinet, the newspaper Jiji reports.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP). -- Cleveland's nine-game winning streak the Indians' best road performance in years finally was snapped today by Washington, the Senators taking the finale of a doubleheader. 9 5. after Cleveland had won the opener. 11 3.

To those long accustomed to regard The Emporia Gazette as the central heating plant of all the virtues, it is sad to find ingratitude, that marble-hearted fiend, sitting in the editor's chair. At Topeka the names of four or five Democratic dissenters are rolled like a sweet morsel under the tongue.

Victor J. Sudman, president of the Black Diamond Line, said yesterday that the controversial freight agreements, which were the basis of rulings last week by a Belgian arbitration committee and the Department of Commerce in Washington, gave weight to his contention, long held, that the ideal working arrangements between maritime nations should be on the reciprocal basis similar to that in effect for some years between the United States and Belgium.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- Farm boys who remember getting up at dawn to drive in the cows from the pasture for the morning milking are not going to believe what they hear about the Rosedale Dairy Farm, which is to be formally opened Wednesday over in near-by Virginia as an exhibit of the forthcoming third World Power Conference.
For the first time in eight weeks cotton prices last week ended with net declines for the period. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts had net recessions of 47 to 67 points.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 19. -The Princeton University honor roll for the last academic year is the smallest of recent years, it was revealed today with the publication of the list of 535 names, or 23.3 per cent of the undergraduate body, by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university.

In the report of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System explaining the rise in bank reserve requirements, it is said that otherwise an "injurious credit expansion" might occur, bringing in turn a "severe liquidation'' in a "deflationary cycle."

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, urged yesterday that the United States call an international conference to seek a solution of fundamental economic and monetary problems. He made this recommendation in his report as president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace to the endowment trustees.

STONY BROOK, L.I., July 19. -The tenth annual convention of the Eastern Conference of the United Presbyterian Church was resumed today following its opening yesterday at the Stony Brook Assembly. About 200 delegates from many of the Eastern States are attending.

Mrs. Jacob Riis, widow of the Danish-American author, will support President Roosevelt for reelection despite her many years of adherence to the Republican party, it was announced yesterday by the women's division of the Democratic National Committee.

The results of the Montreux conference are more than a victory for Turkey; they are a victory for the principle of conciliation and the practice of negotiation. The signature, scheduled for today, of a convention giving to Turkey the right to remilitarize immediately the straits of the Dardanelles and of the Bosporus is a proof,

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $1,156,523,800. They consist of Treasury bonds,, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.
LISBON, Portugal, July 19. -- General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Rightist rebellion, landed at Cadiz today with troops of the Foreign Legion from Morocco.

The time has come for people to lay aside childish things and grow up into the full bloom of maturity, the Rev. Dr. J. Horace Leavitt, pastor of the Central Union Church, Honolulu, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Soil Conservation Service, after a survey of 25,000 square miles in twenty counties of Texas, Kansas, Colorado and Oklahoma, said today that only about half of the land in the Southern Plains region, the area referred to as the "dust bowl" because of the recent wind erosion, had been seriously injured and that opportunity for agriculture there was "far from ended."

ABOARD SCHOONER LIBERTY, SHELBURNE, N.S., July 19. -- A chilling drizzle from low-lying clouds fell steadily on the schooner Sewanna today while President Roosevelt spent the sixth day of his holiday cruise carrying out his announced intention of "loafing.''

ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP). -- The Cardinals clipped Chicago's National League lead to a single game today by sweeping a double-header from the Bees, 8 -- 1, 7 -- 2, while the Cubs split a pair with the Phillies.

SUNDANCE, Wyo., July 19. -- Recalling the unguided resettlement of two million farm families ruined by drought during the past five years, Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, announced today a new plan for harnessing the tide of agricultural migration which already is well under way in the drought-stricken Northwest.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP). -- The Phillies did most of the hitting in their double-header with the Cubs today, but achieved nothing better than an even break, winning the second game, 4 -- 1, after dropping a 2-1 decision to the champions in the opener, which went eleven innings.
Sales of housing sites in Queens and residential properties in Westchester and Connecticut featured real estate activity in the metropolitan area over the week-end.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 19. -- More than 4,000 persons, including many from New York City and vicinity, attended the first formal review of the 1936 Camp Dix Citizens' Military Training Camp regiment here this afternoon on Division Hill, the camp parade grounds.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- A planned organization campaign for the rayon industry, to take in some of the largest manufacturers in Virginia. Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, West Virginia, New England and New York, has been worked out as a result of conferences of officials of the Synthetic Yarn Workers Federation and United Textile Workers of America, it was announced here tonight by the labor representatives.

BERLIN, July 19. -- The final Olympic eliminations for German competitors which took place today indicate that Admiral yon Tirpitz's declaration is still as wrong as it was in 1914. Even in sport Germany's future does not lle either on or in the water.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross, sitting yesterday in Bronx magistrate's court, denounced "snooping" policemen who raid card games in private homes, adding that they might better expend their efforts in reducing the crime wave by tracking down real criminals.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 19. -With entry lists reduced because of the damage to the racing fleet caused by yesterday's unusually violent wind and rain squalls the Seaside Park Yacht Club held its Sunday regatta today. Weather conditions were ideal compared with yesterday's blow.

TALL and sun-tanned, Mr. Walter B. Schleiter, the ex-president of the Bombay Baseball League, dropped in to file his official report on foreign affairs in sport. He is now enjoying one of his infrequent visits to his native land. Mr. Schleiter, it turned out, was not removed from the presidency of the Bombay Baseball League for malfeasance in office or because of a political upheaval in the Indian baseball ranks.

Charging that the Soviet Government was dumping matches on the American market, thereby ruining the American match industry, F.X.A. Eble, manager of the American Match Institute, made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt demanding that the government intervene.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 19. -Powerful Tommy Goodwin, 23-yearold son of the noted swimming star, regained the New York State amateur golf crown today as he defeated Ray Billows, Poughkeepsie printing salesman, the defending champion, by 1 up in as thrilling a final match as was ever played.

With preliminary hearings on the 1937 city budget having started before the Budget Director, the Citizens Budget Commission, 51 East Forty-second Street, issued a warning yesterday that the new budget would show a deficit of $10,000,000 to $20,000,000 unless operating costs were reduced below this year's levels.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP). -- The White Sox ran their winning streak to eight straight today when they took both ends of a double-header from the Athletics, 11 -- 5 and 8 -- 2.

With unexpected ease, Don McNeill of Oklahoma City yesterday won the Eastern junior tennis title from his Kenyon College doubles partner, Morey Lewis, in the postponed final round match at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 19. -The flying red outboard expertly driven by Jack Wood, youthful Detroit professional, featured the second annual Saratoga Lake Boat Club regatta today as he rode to victory in both the B and C professional classes.

OMAHA. July 19. -- Paul Leslie, black-haired youngster from Jefferson City. Mo., defeated Bob Fraser, one of Omaha's favorite golfing sons, today over the sun-blistered Happy Hollow course by 2 and 1 for the Western amateur crown.

TOPEKA, July 19. -- Governor Landon rested at home today in preparation for his most strenuous week, in which he will formally accept the Republican nomination for the Presidency and will meet for the first time a large number of party leaders.

MADISON, Wis., July 19. -- The reasonably good crop situation over a large part of Wisconsin demonstrates that a type of farming that conserves the soil is not altogether exposed to the vagaries of weather. Though there has been damage by heat and drought, Wisconsin farmers have hopes of good crops.

BEDMINSTER, N.J., July 19. -- Never trailing after the first few minutes, although hard pressed all the way, Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's Hurricanes today topped the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 6 to 4, to win the national junior polo championship before 4,500 spectators at Schley Field.
PRINCESS ANNE, Md., July 19 (AP). -- The lower Eastern Shore tomato crop, more abundant than in many a year, may pour $1,000,000 into the pockets of the farmers before the harvest is all sold.
Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles wound up his season on clay courts yesterday by adding another to his long string of conquests.

WARSAW, July 19. -- The Polish Foreign Office was flooded with resolutions adopted at today's demonstrations all over the country, protesting the new decrees of the Danzig Senate and urging the Polish Government to veto the Nazi government laws.

CHICAGO, July 19. -- With receipts of hogs here late last week smaller than they had been, prices advanced and on Friday were 25 cents a hundredweight higher than they had been a week before, while sows were up 25 to 50 cents. The top price on hogs at the close was $10.75, or 5 cents higher than a week before and the same price as three weeks ago.

There seemed to be an excellent setting at hand at the Stadium yesterday for the Yankees to wind up their third home stand of the year against the West with a grand flourish and two smashing victories over Rogers Hornsby's Browns.

ROME, July 17. -- The market here for State securities is active and promising despite the Summer season, which is usually a period of stagnation. Industrial stocks also are in an upward trend subject to normal fluctuations.

A demand for the withdrawal of Alderman Newbold Morris as the Republican candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen and the substitution of City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., who was recommended on Saturday by Mayor La Guardia, was mailed yesterday to Kenneth F. Simpson, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee.

LONG VALLEY, N.J., July 19. -- Will Searles, Schooleys Mountain farmer, opened his 1936 anti-nudist peeking season here today. The first day's peeking was poor, however, as Searles and a dozen other peekers were able to peek out and run to cover only one woman and two men nudists.
CLEVELAND, July 19. -- The text of Representative Lemke's address before the Townsend convention was as follows:

The executive committee of the newly formed Labor party will meet at the Hotel Edison this afternoon to consider plans for its New York State campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman. The party also will name Congressional, legislative and municipal candidates.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 19. -- Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world champion; Reuben Fine of New York and E.D. Bogoljubow, German entry, were tied for first place tonight in the international chess masters' tournament at the Grand Hotel.

A move to unite all borough councils of the St. Vincent de Paul Society in a protest against deductions by the Home Relief Bureau from benefits to families receiving aid from the society, was begun yesterday in Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, July 19. -- Professor Casey Stengel, not quite believing his eyes, watched his Dodgers complete a series sweep today by turning back the Pirates. 4 -- 2, and wind up their most successful Western tour since 1932.

Demand for the better grade of merchandise for Fall featured buying activity in the wholesale apparel and accessory markets here last week. Showrooms and offices were filled with buyers from all sections of the country and a heavy volume of orders was placed for merchandise for the new season.

Those who wish to live and do things in a "big" way should emulate the life of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Charles C. Peale of Columbus, Ohio, said in a sermon yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

I am writing about two voices that I heard here one stifling night. Joe and Sam had just been in the room where I sat, to ask Miss Judy very politely, as they had done nearly every night all through these last hot weeks in town: "Please! Now can't we go to camp?"

MADRID, July 19. -- Insisting that it had complete control of a rebellion in various cities of the peninsula, Spain's hard-pressed Leftist government today organized and armed many of the nation's masses of workers in defense of the regime.

Hundreds of thousands of Americans in the midst of a highly technical civilization, with its "dust and confusion," are in need of prayer to prepare themselves for the fray, said the Right Rev. Warren L. Rogers, Bishop of Ohio, yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

NEW HAVEN, July 18. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 83.3, which compares with 83.8 the week before, before, 82.6 three week before and 82.5 four weeks before.

ST. PAUL, July 19. -- Leaving a trail of birdies for a record-breaking 63 in the morning and wiping out a small disadvantage in the final round, Harry Cooper of Chicago pulled up on even terms with Dick Metz, Lake Forest, Ill., today to finish the seventy-two-hole $5,000 St. Paul open golf tournament in a tie for first place.

While old and new plays throng into the Summer theatres, Broadway surprises itself tonight with an opening of its own -- "Dorian Gray," an adaptation by Jeron Criswell of the Wilde novel, at the Comedy Theatre. Groves Quigley presents it, with a cast which includes Flora Sheffield and David Windsor, and the curtain rises at 8:40 P.M.

PARIS, July 19. -- A Havas News Agency dispatch received here tonight from Gibraltar states that rebel troops from Spanish Morocco who landed at Cadiz today later effected a junction with the Seville rebels.

PARIS, July 19. -- From dispatches to the press here, official statements issued by Spanish representatives abroad and fragmentary broadcasts by various Spanish radio stations tonight, it is evident that the fate of the current Spanish rebellion is still in doubt.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 19. -- Sheriff Brown said today that reddish stains were found on the clothing of Mark Wollner, Germanborn violinist, who is being held in connection with the murder of Helen Clevenger. These stains, the Sheriff added, were being analyzed.

STOCKHOLM, July 19 (Wireless) -On a continent intently engaged in choking itself with trade restrictions. Sweden presents the spectacle of a nation that achieved a booming recovery with virtually free trade.
HONGKONG, Monday, July 20. -- The future movements of General

CINCINNATI, July 19. -- For a few brief moments today the Giants were in third place in the National League standing. They downed the Reds in the first game of a double-header, a ninth-inning uprising in which Hank Leiber and Eddie Mayo collaborated giving them a 4-to-3 decision as the Dodgers tripped the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

ON BOARD U.S. TRAINING SHIP OKLAHOMA, AT SEA, July 19. -- After leaving Goeteborg, Sweden, the midshipmen's training squadron circled the British Isles, passing above the Orkneys around Ireland, then south to Latitude 46, before turning to head for Cherbourg, France.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 19. -- George Slobogan, 15 years old, a gasoline-station attendant, died tonight in West Jersey Homeopathic Hospital here of injuries he received earlier in the day when he was struck by an automobile at Cecil, his home.

Earl Browder, Presidential candidate of the Communist party, will begin a speaking tour on Aug. 5 before a Denver audience, it was announced yesterday at national headquarters, 35 East Twelfth Street.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP). -- Ray Murphy, national commander of the American Legion, announced today that he had declined to become a candidate for the Senate seat of the late Louis Murphy of Iowa.

As evidence of industrial recovery, the report of railway traffic was last week's most impressive incident. Loadings of freight very rarely, even in normal years, pass the year's previous high record in July. Cars loaded in this month's second week not only rose 28 per cent above the same week in 1935 but, except for two weeks in last October, went to much the largest figure of any week since November, 1931.

True tolerance rather than "futile neutrality" in human relationships was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in a sermon at Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

MOSCOW, July 19. -- Professor Boris Gerasimovitch, head of the Pulkovo Observatory in Leningrad, was accused today of "servility" toward foreign science by the newspaper Leningrad Pravda, chief organ of the Communist party in that city. The attack has created a stir in scientific circles here.

PARIS, July 18. -- The statute embodying reform of the Bank of France was intended not merely to enable the State to procure credits more easily but also to be part of a plan to reorganize the credit facilities of the nation. The State has always obtained funds when absolutely necessary, as was recently demonstrated.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 19. -Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sterner of Brick House, Richmond, gave a luncheon party yesterday for Charles Blair MacDonald of Southampton and Bermuda, for many years president of the National Golf Links of America, who is their house guest.

BERLIN, July 19. -- A special commission of jurists, charged by Chancellor Adolf Hitler with drafting the Criminal Code, was reported today to have proposed a maximum penalty of two years' imprisonment for any one "disturbing the peace" by willfully distributing false reports.

The Rev. Dr. Paul A. McNally, S.J. head of the Georgetown University-National Geographic Society expedition, which left New York on April 10 to observe the total eclipse of the sun at Kustanai, in Southwestern Siberia, on June 19, returned yesterday on the California of the United States Lines much disappointed at the result of his mission.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York had retired the entire $25,000,000 of capital notes which the bank sold to the corporation in 1933.

PARIS, July 18. -- The French index of wholesale prices in June, compiled by the Statistique Generale on the basis of the average for July, 1914, as 100, was 372, compared with 377 in May and 344 in June, 1935.
DENVER, July 19 (AP). -- Dr. Joyce C. Stearns has devised a house to keep out snowstorm, lightning, rats, and in fact almost everything but cosmic rays.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 19. -Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sterner of Brick House, Richmond, gave a luncheon party yesterday for Charles Blair MacDonald of Southampton and Bermuda, for many years president of the National Golf Links of America, who is their house guest.

BERLIN, July 19. -- A special commission of jurists, charged by Chancellor Adolf Hitler with drafting the Criminal Code, was reported today to have proposed a maximum penalty of two years' imprisonment for any one "disturbing the peace" by willfully distributing false reports.

The Rev. Dr. Paul A. McNally, S.J. head of the Georgetown University-National Geographic Society expedition, which left New York on April 10 to observe the total eclipse of the sun at Kustanai, in Southwestern Siberia, on June 19, returned yesterday on the California of the United States Lines much disappointed at the result of his mission.

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York had retired the entire $25,000,000 of capital notes which the bank sold to the corporation in 1933.

PARIS, July 18. -- The French index of wholesale prices in June, compiled by the Statistique Generale on the basis of the average for July, 1914, as 100, was 372, compared with 377 in May and 344 in June, 1935.
DENVER, July 19 (AP). -- Dr. Joyce C. Stearns has devised a house to keep out snowstorm, lightning, rats, and in fact almost everything but cosmic rays.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- A survey disclosed today that fifty-six tiny railroads, either uninformed of the order or acting in the belief it did not apply to them, had ignored the recent ruling of the Interstate Commerce Commission slashing passenger fares.

Plans for putting its own ticket in the field and for the enrolment of 250,000 dues-paying members from labor unions in this State were completed yesterday by the newly formed State labor party of Labor's Nonpartisan League when its executive committee met at the Hotel Edison.

SAM BASS, in case you forgotten your in dime-novel lore, was the fellow who had the world by the tail with a downhill pull for a time before he ended up in a Texas graveyard. Exactly eighty-five years ago today he was born on an Indiana farm; exactly fifty-eight years ago today he died, with a load of lead from Texas Rangers' guns in his body.

The Farm Journal, which has been polling the agricultural vote in Presidential elections since 1912 with professedly accurate results, has published the first returns of a new straw ballot, and at least one point emerges with great clarity. This is an impressive lack of evidence indicating a drift of sentiment in the rural areas toward a third party.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 20. -- As a committee of liberals, following an investigation, denounced today actions of police and courts in connection with the strike at the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company's plant here, Judge Frank Neutze in Camden Quarter Session Court refused an application for the release of eighty-five persons arrested in strike disorders last week.

The city of Minneapolis, Minn., yesterday sold two new issues of bonds, aggregating $876,000, to Phelps, Fenn Co. on their bid of 100.2066 for 2.10s. The loans consisted of $500,000 of public relief bonds and $376,000 of permanent improvement bonds, both dated Aug. 1, 1936, and maturing in 1937 to 1946.

Because of the heavy rain yesterday, Jose Iturbi postponed his appearance as piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. If the weather permits, Mr. Iturbi will appear tonight at the uptown amphitheatre in the dual capacity of soloist and conductor.

The Standard Investing Corporation reported yesterday that on June 30 its assets had an approximate market value of $7,714.210 and that there was outstanding $2,941,000 of debentures and $1,000.000 of bank debt. Asset coverage of the company's debentures and bank debt was equal to $1,957 of assets for each $1,000 of debentures, making the asset value of the preferred stock about $68.40 a share.

MONTREUX, Switzerland, July 20. -- All nine powers represented at the Dardanelles conference signed the Montreux convention tonight at 10 o'clock. The speeches reflected the desire of all present to make friends with Turkey, whom this treaty re-established in her position of armed possessor of the Straits.

LONDON, July 20. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has turned down the demand of the French Government that the Council of the League of Nations be called immediately for a special session to deal with the problem of Nazi activities in Danzig.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 20. -- Gloria Schoffel, 12 years old, daughter of Justice Louis A. Schoffel of Municipal Court, New York City, was killed and four other persons were injured in a two-car crash on the Bronx River Parkway Extension at Kitchawan today.

Arthur Krock's reflections of July 16, as evoked by the published correspondence between the President and the undersigned, on the state of the civil service, are in general enlightened and provocative.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 20. -- Lieut. Col. Eley P. Denson, commanding the Twenty-sixth Infantry, has received a medal from the American Legion of Queens County to be awarded to the outstanding candidate from that county attending the Citizens Military Training Camp.
Stench bombs emptied two theatres, one in Queens and another in Brooklyn, last night and sent three persons to the hospital overcome by the fumes.

NEWARK, N.J., July 20. -- The "rubber sandwich" of the old New York Raines Law days will not be allowed to masquerade as a dinner in New Jersey, D. Frederick Burnett, State Commissioner of Alcoholic Beverage Control, warned today.

A recent experiment in music appreciation in this city contradicts the results announced at Cornell. At Cornell, pigs showed a decided preference for Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 3 over "The Music Goes 'Round and Around." In New York twelve humans, selected at random, were made to undergo a similar test.

America must rely upon the public school system to solve the national crime problem and it is failing in that duty today, United States Senator Royal S. Copeland of New York declared yesterday. He spoke to 200 members of Lions Clubs from all parts of the country on their way to the national convention of the organization in Providence, R.I., at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Employes of the steel industry received weekly wages in March that were more than 18 per cent higher than the average wages of employes for all manufacturing industries, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The United Gas Corporation refunded yesterday $21,250,000 of bank loans at their maturity and added to its working capital by selling $25,000,000 United Gas Public Service Company 6 per cent debentures due on July 1, 1953, to the Electric Bond and Share Company at par and accrued interest.

ALBANY, July 20. -- Governor Lehman, speaking at the opening today of Albany's celebration of the 250th anniversary of its charter grant, said that the people of New York from the days of the early settlers had maintained a spirit of mutual forbearance and sympathetic understanding, although large groups of different nationalities, different races and faiths have composed the population.

Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday the names of six brokers who will comprise a special committee to receive the views of members of the Exchange on the program of segregating broker and dealer functions transmitted by the Securities and Exchange Commission to Congress on June 20.

PARIS, July 20. -- Stay-in strikes began today on a number of large farms around Paris and in the north as preparations were made for harvesting. No disturbances were reported, although some gendarmes had to intervene to protect milk distribution.

LONDON, July 20 (Canadian Press). -- Opposed by the strongest team of the tour to date, the Hon. R.C. Matthews's Canadian cricketers put up a strong game against the Free Foresters at Holyport today. After dismissing the English players for 196 runs, the youthful Dominion representatives hit up 125 for four wickets before stumps were drawn.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 20 (AP). -- The cutter Baccarat, owned by Russell Alger of Detroit and manned by a veteran crew, stood as the boat to beat tonight in the annual Detroit-Chicago sailing race.

Reporting the heaviest single day's attendance in its history, the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., opened its Fall showing of new furniture styles here yesterday with prices up an average of 5 per cent compared with Spring levels. Another general advance of about the same amount was reported likely by early August.

Jerome A. Jacobs and Harry S. Hechheimer, lawyers, and Raymond Derringer, motion-picture operator and pseudo private detective, were indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury on the complaint of Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, motion picture actress.

ST. PAUL, July 20 (AP). -- Light-horse Harry Cooper of Chicago left another trail of birdies behind him today to capture his third St. Paul open golf tournament by a four-stroke margin over Dick Metz of Evanston, Ill., in a 36-hole play-off.

As a result of the address last Friday in Boston of John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Committee chairman, officials in Washington, Trenton and Albany and in CCC camps in New York, New Jersey and elsewhere were asked yesterday to explain whether or not political preference played any part in the selection of applicants for technical or non-technical foremen or superintendents on CCC projects.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- About thirty-five investment bankers and security dealers from all parts of the country, representing the membership of the Investment Bankers Conference Committee, at a meeting here today unanimously approved a plan for the setting up of a nation-wide organization whose aim will be to keep the investment banking business on a high plane.

LYNCHBURG, Va., July 20. -- Senator Carter Glass snorted scorn today at critics in Virginia of his Patrick Henry speech July 17 at Randolph Macon College, Ashland, in which he denounced the present system of government in the United States as "a government of privilege and discrimination."

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Prices of hogs were generally steady to 15 cents a hundredweight higher here today except on under weights and pigs lacking quality. Some sales of the latter showed 25 to 50 cents lower than the finish of last week. The top was 10 cents higher at $10.90, while the day's average was 15 cents higher at $9.70.

There is "no such thing as an original design in the dress business,'' Barney Hirsch, president of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group, testified yesterday at a hearing before the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway. The hearing was one in the action of the commission against the Fashion Originators Guild of America and affiliated organizations for alleged restraint of trade in the dress industry.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 20. -Setting a scorching pace over the Lido Country Club's difficult championship course, Marshall Field of Meadow Brook and Henry Ciuci, Fresh Meadow pro, carded 32, 32 -64 to capture first honors in the Long Island Golf Association's oneday amateur-pro competition today.
TAMPA, Fla., July 20 (AP). -- The Coast Guard extended its search for the missing British motorship Nunoca outside this country's territorial waters today.

The Producers Association Agreement -- Hollywood's equivalent of the League of Nations -- is about to be seriously jeopardized by Paramount's $5,000,000 suit against Samuel Goldwyn over the services of Gary Cooper, according to many persons in the industry.

Out of an innocent-looking sky in Brooklyn last Friday afternoon tumbled a geranium-bearing flower pot, and, as a result, Irving Sigman, a quiet, retired business man close to 60, made his first appearance in court yesterday.

RABAT, French Morocco, July 20 (AP). -- Rebel troops announced reinforcements were being sent from Spanish Morocco for mainland "conquests" tonight in the face of a threatened bombardment by a strange fleet of seven loyal warships.

MADRID, July 20. -- General Jose Sanjurjo, well-known monarchist exile, was killed while leaving Lisbon, Portugal, today in an airplane, which crashed on the take-off for Spain, according to an official announcement broadcast here.

BOSTON, July 20. -- Smashing the New England record, the daily double at Suffolk Downs brought a pay-off of $3,289 today when F.G. Heller's Dilwin won the first race and Bayard Tuckerman's Petard took the third. Four tickets were sold on the combination.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- With the District of Columbia prosecutor's office hesitating about asking an indictment against John S. Farnsworth, former naval officer arrested on charges of selling naval secrets to a Japanese agent, an announcement that the Federal Bureau of Investigation is continuing its inquiry into alleged Japanese espionage activities was made today by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the bureau.

LONDON, July 20. -- The post of private secretary to King Edward, one of the most responsible offices in the empire, has been given to Major Alexander Hardinge, who was for sixteen years assistant private rate secretary to King George. He is the only surviving son of Baron Hardinge of Penshurst and is 42, the King's age.

Police Lieutenant John J. McLaughlin saw eleven months' service in France with the old Sixty-ninth Regiment but he never saw anything like the greenish-blue streak that ran through his Bronx police station yesterday. The lieutenant stood his ground, but two plasterers fell off their ladders before it disappeared.

ABOARD SCHOONER LIBERTY OFF CAPE NEGRO ISLAND, N.S., July 20. -- After being balked by a pea soup fog in an attempt to sail his schooner Sewanna out to sea this morning, President Roosevelt cruised this afternoon southwest from Shelburne for fifteen miles to this comparatively barren point on the coast of Nova Scotia.

Although he is rarely extolled, there are few more patient anglers than the surf fisherman. Along the beach he will spend hour after hour. Often at dawn and again at sundown, you will notice the same figure, ever casting out into the surf, hoping for a battle with a fish of unknown size.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 20. -- Australia needs only one more victory in her series with Germany to gain the challenge round in the Davis Cup tennis competition for the first time since 1924.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 20 (AP) -The spectrographic motion pictures, or "atomic movies," marking the entry of motion pictures into a new field of great value to industry, were announced today at the opening session of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology conference on spectroscopy.

The commodity futures markets developed some irregularity yesterday with about half the staples advancing. On the cash markets wheat, cotton, rye, beef, hides, rubber and tin advanced, while corn, lard, butter, antimony and silk eased.

GIBRALTAR, July 20. -- After much trouble your correspondent obtained permission to proceed to the Spanish frontier, where refugees encamped on neutral ground in the space dividing the British and Spanish frontiers gave details of yesterday's shooting at La Linea.

ST. CLOUD, Minn., July 20. -- The Minnesota farmer feels in a more secure position than he did four years ago. His mortgage debts have been considerably reduced by adjustment. On this phase, the Farm Credit Administration seems to have done an especially fine piece of work.

LONDON, July 20. -- Swarms of pursuit planes, able to fly at far at more than 300 miles an hour, are being turned out regularly now to defend the crowded cities and workshops of Great Britain against attack from the air.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on July 15 shows increases for the week of $52,000,000 in total loans and investments, $45,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $116,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $80,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

CLEVELAND, July 20. -- Faced with the prospect of a public airing tomorrow of his stewardship of the money invested by believers in his plan for pensioning the aged, Dr. Francis E. Townsend, the founder and head of the cult, tried desperately today to heal the wounds caused by his open espousal of Representative Lemke, third party candidate, at the convention of his converts.

One of John Golden's "major productions" of next season is the new Rachel Crothers play, of which two acts are completed. The author read them to Mr. Golden on Sunday, and he reported jubilantly yesterday that Miss Crothers was striking "a new quality of dramatic strength and power." The title is "Susan and God."

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- All hope of compromise in the struggle between industrial and craft unionists within the American Federation of Labor appeared dissipated tonight on the eve of a meeting tomorrow of the Committee on Industrial Organization to decide whether its members should stand trial before the American Federation of Labor Executive Council on Aug. 3.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20. -- Today's frustrated heroines were a couple of young ladies from Brooklyn -- the Misses Madeline Dooley and Eleanor Babel of the Sheepshead Bay Yacht Club.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 20. -Johnny Kinder, former New Jersey open and P.G.A. champion, teamed with Charles Whitehead, holder of the State amateur crown, to win the New Jersey P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Essex County Country Club.

Yesterday's advance of .26 point in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks represented the eleventh consecutive advance. The stock market, as measured by this index, has not declined since Tuesday, July 7. This is the longest string of advances in many years.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 20. -- The finest field to gather for the Longwood Bowl tournament in recent years started out in the forty-fourth annual holding of this turf court tennis fixture today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

MARION, Mass., July 20. -- A red flag buoy answering the specifications of the circular and a race committee craft displaying the code flag "R," meaning "the mark has gone adrift, this vessel is the mark," the two being about 200 yards apart, caused all sorts of confusion in the first race of the Roosevelt Bowl series under the Beverly Yacht Club colors today.

Earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the second quarter of this year, according to the preliminary report announced yesterday, equaled $2.06 a share on its common stock, including the dividend from General Motors investment amounting to $1.11 a share on du Pont common stock.

HENDAYE, France, July 20. -- Independent reports received at this border town from various sources appear to confirm the claim of the Spanish Government that the insurrection is now weakening in many parts of the country, although the situation in Andalusia is still threatening, particularly in Seville and Cadiz.

BABYLON, L.I., July 20. -Twelve years ago the United States Government turned over to New York State a fourteen-acre point of land on Gardiner's Island extending into Gardiner's Bay. Today the point, now consisting of but one acre -- at high tide -was turned back to the Federal Government.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20. -- A meeting of legislators, bankers and business men will be called soon, it is announced by Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa, to lay the groundwork for a bill to be presented by the government in September, creating a central reserve bank and regulating private banking in the country.

After next Thursday night it will, for the first time, be possible to find material to answer some of the many questions in the public mind about Governor Landon. Because of an almost unprecedented situation in American politics, the Republican nominee for President comes to the week of his all-important speech of acceptance less known to the electorate than any man in his position whose name comes to mind.

All of the officials at CCC camps in or near the metropolitan area declared yesterday that politics had played no part in the selection either of boys or veterans for admission to the camps, or in the selection of technical or non-technical foremen for CCC projects.

The real estate bondholders' protective committee of which George E. Roosevelt is chairman announced yesterday its disapproval of the plan for the reorganization of the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, outlined jointly by a bondholders' committee headed by Hunter S. Marston and a certificate holders' committee headed by Arthur W. Loasby.

LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP). -- The cash value of Gary Cooper, tall, blue-eyed movie star, was rated at $4,000,000 today when Paramount Pictures Corporation sued Samuel Goldwyn, film producer, charging that Goldwyn secretly raided the Paramount contract list and "stole" Cooper.

LONDON, July 20 (AP). -- Eric Tyrrell-Martin was suspended today by the Hurlingham Club polo committee as an aftermath to reputed riding jousts with H. Hesketh Hughes in the semi-finals of the Champion Cup tournament.

Several hundred persons on the platform of the East Side I.R.T. subway station at Grand Central Terminal witnessed the arrest of two men last night who are alleged to have assaulted Solomon Shapiro, 45 years old, a jeweler of 106 Fulton Street.

After having been actively engaged in the passenger steamship business, chiefly in the North Atlantic, for forty-six years, Arthur B. Cauty, director and joint general manager of the Cunard White Star Lines, has retired.

OTTAWA; July 20. -- Unless the government's efforts to combat the insect come to a rapid success the European spruce sawfly will in a quarter of a century have wiped out the Eastern Canadian spruce; on which American newspapers depend for the major part of their newsprint supply, it has been admitted officially here.

ROCKLAND LAKE, N.Y., July 20. -- An 80-year-old woman who had been held a prisoner in her home here without food or water by a woman fifteen years younger whom she had befriended, was rescued by neighbors this afternoon.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 20. -Charles Bulkley Hubbell of Cedarhurst, L.I., had an eighty-third birthday luncheon party today at his Summer home, Brookside, Williamstown, which his family has owned since 1755. The guests were Willard E. Hoyt, former treasurer of Williams College; Professor Philip Marshall Brown of Princeton, N.J.; Dr. Vanderpoel Adriance, Dr. J. Franklin Carter and Colonel E. Parmalee Prentice.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- A limited number of non-technical foremen on construction projects and similar works of the Civilian Conservation Corps are selected through political channels, it was stated today by officials of the Department of Agriculture and the Interior Department, which supervise the appointment of these employes.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 20.--Mrs. N. Johnson Van Vleck gave a luncheon bridge today at Ballyshear, her place in the Shinnecock Hills, for Mrs. Spencer Waters, who arrived today to visit her.

Three men who were arrested with two other men and three women in a vice raid on a seventh-floor apartment at 120 Riverside Drive last July 14 were permitted to change their pleas of guilty to charges of disorderly conduct to not guilty in Uptown Court yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, July 21. -- The Kwangsi Province leaders seem inclined to bide their time and await the turn of events before launching a war. They have already begun withdrawing their armies from Kwangtung Province, but announce that they will guard the borders of their province.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 20. -- A mysterious extra pass key, unaccounted for in the records of her hotel, offered a new clue tonight in the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger, 18-year-old New York University co-ed.
Louis H. Pink, State Insurance Commissioner, ordered yesterday the liquidation of the New York Safety Reserve Fund, at 1,780 Broadway, an assessment health and accident insurance organization.

Officially opening the new Republican State headquarters on the fifth floor of the Liggett Building yesterday, Melvin C. Eaton, State chairman, cited reports from a number of up-State Republican leaders to support his claims of greatly increasing strength for Governor Landon in this State.

The peseta was the center of attention yesterday in an otherwise dull foreign exchange market here, but the Spanish rate did no more than decline a few points on a few scattered transactions and then rallied to close unchanged on the day. The market for the peseta here is strictly nominal, held almost rigid by virtue of the fact that the rate is pegged to the franc.

WARSAW, July 20. -- Charles Dewey, the Polish Government's former financial adviser, who arrived here on his annual visit, already has had an opportunity to exchange views with leading Polish financiers and to discuss the situation created by recent developments in this country.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 20. -- Former King Alfonso of Spain today left Rauschenbach castle in Slovakia, where he had been staying with his brother-in-law, Count Zamtoyski, for Koenigswart Castle, near Marienbad in Bohemia, which belongs to Prince Metternich.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 20. -- A new farce comedy, "Miss Temple Is Willing" detailing the adventures of the wealthy heroine in search of a "man named Will," was presented here tonight by Paul Berney at the Beechwood Theatre.

BOSTON, July 20. -- Total assets and liabilities, at the same figure, of $24,792,502 were reported by the Cities Service Refining Company of Boston in a petition filed in Federal court today under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, seeking authority to reorganize.
BIARRITZ, France, July 20. -A battle between Spanish rebels advancing from Pamplona and workers armed by the government appeared probable to night at the important northern city of San Sebastian.

Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, said yesterday he had no intention of removing George H. Kauff, retired police captain, who receives a $2,500 annual pension, from his position as head of the WPA guards at the main office, 111 Eighth Avenue.

In the recent Democratic Senatorial primary campaign in Oklahoma Governor MARLAND represented himself as the one simon-pure Rooseveltian. He had patterned his administration upon Mr. ROOSEVELT'S. His affection and veneration for the President were unbounded. He shuddered at Senator GORE, who had opposed some of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S policies.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission reported today that three of four classifications of woolen and worsted textile mills had a higher rate of return on their investment for the first half of 1935, compared with either of the two six-month periods in 1934, and showed a profit.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The fading heat wave yielded additional ground today and the Corn Belt rejoiced in more seasonable temperatures in the wake of week-end showers which revived hopes in many secsions for its main crop.
DETROIT, July 20. -- The Giants and Tigers staged an exhibition game today before a yelling crowd of about 30,000 boys and girls and a few thousand grown-ups. The kids were guests of a local company.

Challenging the good faith of the five Republican county leaders in naming Alderman Newbold Morris of Manhattan as their candidate for Aldermanic President, Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that the "arrangement" gave Tammany Hall a "set-up" to win the election.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 20. -- A tall, slender gas station attendant from Philadelphia and a stocky Detroit employment manager shared the lead today with 71s as the first eighteen holes of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round in the fifteenth annual national amateur public links championship were concluded at the Bethpage State Park Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today named a new public enemy No. 1. Maurice Denning, a bank robber, was picked out for the place held lately by Alvin Karpis, who was captured recently.
James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, assailed yesterday the injection of any religious or racial prejudice into the current Presidential campaign.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 20. -The Bretton Woods choir boys opened their annual concert season tonight at Bretton Arms in compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Bemis. Assisting were the director, Frank R. Hancock of Brooklyn, baritone, and Allan Stewart of New York, tenor.

PITTSBURGH, July 20. -- The magnitude of the steel industry organization campaign undertaken by the steel workers' organizing committee four weeks ago and the progress made in that time were summarized here today by the field workers, who declared that "despite constant intimidation by steel managements" about fifty mills in the northeastern region have been penetrated by voluntary committees.

TOPEKA, July 20. -- Governor Landon, in his speech on Thursday accepting the Republican nomination for the Presidency, will take up five or six of the leading issues of the campaign and discuss them "from the view of a plain, average American toward the governmental problems of today," according to information relayed to reporters today by persons who have seen the speech in its virtually completed form.

Two departments of the American Bible Society changed headquarters yesterday from the old red Bible House, Astor Place, to a remodeled six-story building at Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street. The new headquarters is air-conditioned throughout.

Governor Lehman gave District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn an extension of ten days yesterday to complete his answer to the Drukman grand jury's charges demanding his removal from office. The date now fixed is Aug. 5.

MOSCOW, July 20. -- Memories of "the Red terror" in the early days of the revolution, when the Bolshevist regime was fighting for its life against civil war within and intervention from without, were revived today in nation-wide commemoration of the death of Felix Dzerzhinsky ten years ago.

With the trade and industrial news of the day cheerful in tone, the share market continued higher yesterday to mark the eleventh consecutive trading day of the advance. Profit-taking in some volume had to be absorbed, particularly in the late trading, so that the early moderate gains were reduced somewhat.
Summer finery gave way to somber clothing yesterday in the gloom of dour skies and intermittent rains. Umbrellas, raincoats and rubbers were the order of the day.

Control of the Gaumont-British Picture Corporation, long reported to be about to pass into American hands, will remain in English possession, it was announced yesterday. Twentieth Century-Fox, which owned 49 per cent of the stock of the holding company controlling England's largest film-producing corporation, has decided to sell half its interest to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, at Sea, July 20. -- Coaching assignments were distributed today by Lawson Robertson, head coach of the United States Olympic track and field forces, and a training routine was formulated for the week the athletes will spend in Berlin prior to the games.

Governor Landon has a "real fighting chance" in Virginia, North Carolina and Florida, and will sweep New England and Pennsylvania, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., his Eastern campaign manager, asserted here yesterday.
GIBRALTAR, July 20. -- The possibility that Royal Air Force pilots may fly to the aid of their British compatriots stranded in Spain was seen tonight in military orders.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PARIS, Tuesday, July 21. -- The latest news from Spain by radio and otherwise seems to confirm the government's assertions that the military rebellion has been broken and the government is master of the situation.

Wildcat O'Connor, Carbondale (Pa.) welterweight, will tackle Vince DeAngelo of Bensonhurst tonight in the star bout of eight rounds at the Coney Island Velodrome. The card has been arranged for the benefit of the Italian Red Cross Relief Fund, which will share in the proceeds.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The feature on the Boerse at the opening of the week today was continued strength in selected specialties, led by automobile and department store shares, although the rest of the market was extraordinarily quiet and, at the same time, irregular.

The suggestion that the La Guardia-Berle-Morris triangle over the nomination of President of the Board of Aldermen was all "pretty much of a misunderstanding" and that "the situation would be cleared up satisfactorily" was expressed by the Republican County Committee's designee, Newbold Morris, at a Ninth Assembly District Republican Club meeting last night.
MADRID, 8 A.M., July 20 (Delayed in Transmission). -- The following governmental communique was broadcast at 3 o'clock this morning:
PITTSBURGH, July 20. -- Some 2,500 baseball fans got their first glimpse of Joe DiMaggio today at Forbes Field in as fine an exhibition of distance running as ever a flychaser provided.

With the immediate influence of the new member bank reserve requirements on the market for high-grade, fixed-interest-bearing securities apparently spent, trading in bonds yesterday was much slower than last week. This was especially the case among United States Government obligations, which were quietly traded.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Although State Department officials watched the progress of the revolution in Spain with great interest today, most of the information reaching the department came through press dispatches. Little news came direct from the United States Embassy in Madrid, the chief statement being that the embassy had thrown its doors open to all Americans wishing to take refuge there.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20. -- Larchmont's race week ran afoul of a slant of unobliging nature today. Under a deluge of rain that blotted out wind an attempt was made to carry on with the second series regatta. There was a lot of cannon-fire on behalf of the race committee, and one-third of the fleet, the lucky part, in the course of two hours was unable to get across the starting line.

The Raleigh News and Observer, published by Josephus Daniels, published an editorial, "Spies and Spy Scares," in which it was stated that the number of military secrets available to spies is "small to the vanishing point."

Arrivals of buyers in the local wholesale markets continued heavy, with the home furnishings trade shows setting new records for attendance. Actual placing of merchandise commitments in these lines as well as in the women's apparel and accessory trades is gaining, with no unfavorable comparison noted between the number of buyers here and the amount of business booked.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 20. -Handicapped no little by a driving rainstorm that made playing conditions almost unbearable, a record entry of ninety-eight women started in quest of the Westchester-Fairfield open golf championship today at the Century Country Club.

OLYMPIA, Greece, July 20. -- The first of the 1,108 runners who will carry the Olympic flame through Greece on its trip to Germany left here today at noon. It will be taken over every kilometer by other Greek runners as far as Koula, where Bulgarian athletes will receive the flame.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 20. -- Defeating Dr. S. Tartakower of Poland in the third round tonight, Reuben Fine of New York moved into first place in the international chess masters tournament at the Grand Hotel, leaving Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the world champion, and E.D. Bogoljubow of Germany tied a half-point behind.

MADRID, July 20. -- In an official radio broadcast, Civil Guards in Saragossa, one of two sections which the government admitted still was troublous, were ordered to give up their arms to advancing peasants.
ALBANY, July 20. -- William G. Howard, in charge of the Division of Land and Forestation in the Conservation Department, said:
WINNIPEG, July 20 (Canadian Press). -- Hopes for salvaging Canada's Spring wheat crop received new setbacks today in the form of an adverse weather prediction and reports of storm and rust damage.
The Japanese beetles have landed on Governors Island, and, like the marines, apparently have the situation well in hand.

BROCKPORT, N.Y., July 20. -- Whether Idaho, a shaggy mongrel pup, is a frolicsome playmate or a vicious dog intent on attack is the question Justice of the Peace Homer B. Benedict will consider tomorrow morning at a hearing to decide the fate of the dog, charged with causing the death of a high school youth who was bathing in the barge canal near here.

ALBANY, July 20 (AP). -- Leaders of New York State's medical profession joined its Mayors tonight in affirming to the State Liquor Authority a belief that there was a general lack of "adequate, impartial temperance education for young people."

In a world beset by nationalism, dictatorships and civil wars it is usually still cheering to read the news from Sweden. Its last index of industrial production was well above that of 1929. Its foreign trade has recovered sharply from 1932 and 1933 levels, and, though still below 1929 levels, is at least within striking distance of them.
Nine Manhattan properties, including a twelve-story apartment house in Seventh Avenue, near Fifty-ninth Street, were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday, as follows:

Lady Clifford, wife of Sir Bede Clifford, Governor General of the Bahamas, is among the passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria. Others coming on the ship from Southampton via Cherbourg include: Frederick A. Dallett, Dr. and Mrs. C.A. Scott-Ridont, Eugene Pallette, James C. Stephens, Miss Elsie Ferguson, Mr. and Mrs. Howard P. Foley, Miss Annabelle Corrigan and Joseph Proskauer.

An investor in bank stock, who bought that security as a result of false representation, may void the transaction by demanding the return of his money and offering to give back the stock, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -Almost daily committee meetings are now being held for the annual village fair, which has climaxed the season here for forty years, and takes place this year on July 31. Mrs. William R. Maloney heads the general committee.

Harold Paroly, convicted "fixer" who insists twelve patrolmen agreed to pay him $1,500 each with the understanding that he get them preferred places on the sergeants' list, resumed the stand yesterday before Third Deputy Police Commissioner Michael A. Lyons and stuck to his story.
ISTANBUL, Tuesday, July 21. -- At 12:05 A.M., local time, Turkish troops entered the demilitarized zones along the Bosporus and Dardanelles. The occupation will be completed tomorrow.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 20. -- Although Henry H. Rogers Jr. gave promissory notes to his father, the late Colonel Henry H. Rogers, for $32,816 advanced to him, the son now asserts his father did not intend or desire to be reimbursed.

The prospectus for 675,000 participating certificates of Imco Participating Company, Ltd., which are being offered to holders of the participating preference stock of the International Match Corporation, is to be made public today, the new securities having been registered with the filing of information with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Mayor La Guardia threw a switch turning on the underwater lights illuminating the new Sunset swimming pool in Sunset Park, Seventh Avenue and Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, last night and thus formally opened it to the public. A crowd of about 3,500 persons, including hundreds of vocally enthusiastic children, was on hand.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 20. -- The rebel army led by General Francisco Franco is now established in complete control of Spanish Morocco.

Convinced that the Roosevelt administration has "failed miserably" in its objectives, Julian T. Bishop, a stock broker, is planning to show his "intense dislike", for the New Deal by selling his large quail farm near Carthage, N.C., and moving to Canada if the President is reelected.
In its first full week-end the Triborough Bridge carried 92,583 automobiles, buses, trucks and other vehicles, it was announced yesterday.

A new field for pickpockets was uncovered yesterday when two men with long police records were arraigned in Brooklyn felony court charged with jostling. They were held without bail for hearing Thursday by Magistrate James A. Blanchfield, after pleading not guilty.

Following last week's setback of about $3 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed resistance yesterday and recovered a quarter cent a pound at one time.
