Influenced by strong outside markets and high temperatures in Oklahoma traders shifted to the buying side and the list ended with gains of 10 to 15 points.

DANZIG, July 20. -- "The Opposition parties in Danzig must disappear," Albert Forster, Nazi district leader for Danzig and a member of the German Reichstag, declared today in a speech at a party meeting held in Sobowcz. "A new life now begins for Danzig.

July has been a month of wonders for Margaret Rush, who has spent more than half of her 14 years on a bed in the Neponsit Beach Hospital for Crippled Children, Beach 149th Street and Rockaway Boulevard, Neponsit, Queens.

SUFFERN, N.Y., July 20. -- Two women were killed and four critically injured when a car in which the six were riding to work this morning crashed into a brick truck on the Suffern-Haverstraw road a mile east of Mount Ivy. The injured are in Good Samaritan Hospital here.

Five suits aggregating $31,250,000 and entered by trustees of certificated mortgage issues sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company against the president and directors of the Manhattan Company were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Hopes that Germany's economic situation will be eased by a flood of foreign money left here by visitors to the Olympic Games are being shattered by pronouncements of authorities on the subject.
BALTIMORE, July 20 (AP). -- The Sun says former Governor Alfred E. Smith conferred today with John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Committee chairman.

Waterfront labor litigation of long standing in the courts, involving the right of shippers to use non-union labor, will be reopened soon by a group of shippers and business men who are now organizing to carry the case to Federal courts, it was learned yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., July 20. -- C.P. Wilber, State Forester, said frankly here today that no man could hope to get a job as non-technical foreman on a CCC project in this State unless he was on "Jim Farley's political list."
NEWPORT, R.I., July 20. -- Mrs. Skirvin Adams gave her first dinner party of the season tonight at Beach Mound. Mrs. Charles S. Whitman and Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse also entertained.

Like so many other persons who come from distant places to make up the population of New York, Miss Erma Young of Choteau, Mont., the 21-year-old college graduate whose prize-winning essay on "Why I Want to See New York" brought her here Saturday to realize her dreams, was changed by the metropolis yesterday.

The winning streak of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Action, 7-year-old converted jumper which had won seven in a row, was snapped in the mud and rain at Empire City yesterday afternoon. The black Nocturnal filly, Pretty Night, which is out of Flattery, was first by a length at the end of the mile-and-a-sixteenth of the Rye Beach Handicap.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP). -- Vern Oech of Minnesota bounced back into first place among the guards today for the only change of leadership in the all-star football poll.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Aubrey Williams, Assistant Works Progress Administrator, sent to assistant administrators and regional WPA administrators throughout the country today a memorandum establishing regular vacations and sick leaves for all administrative employes on WPA projects.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 20. -- Stars of the harness horse world were here tonight awaiting the start of the four-day Grand Circuit meeting tomorrow.

Joe Louis will meet Jack Sharkey, former heavyweight champion of the world, at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 18. The match was made yesterday by Mike Jacobs, secretary of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, under whose auspices the fight will be conducted.

The American Osteopathic Association opened its fortieth annual convention yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria with a declaration that life cannot he lengthened further "unless tranquillity of existence can become fashionable."

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 20. -- Phil Turnesa of Elmsford and his amateur partner, Sal Sava of the home club, posted a 33, 31 -- 64 to win the Westchester County Golf Association one-day pro-amateur tourney today over the Tamarack Country Club links.

The rare phenomenon of a waterspout in New York Harbor was reported yesterday afternoon by two Coast Guard officers to have occurred 500 yards off Pier 15, Stapleton, S.I. They said they believed it to have been 1,500 feet high and that it was visible ten minutes. The spout moved off northeast toward Brooklyn and disappeared.

Despite an increase in the number of week-end automobile accidents in the city, last week showed a decrease in the number of persons killed and injured, it was reported yesterday at police headquarters.

Gomer Smith, vice president of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's Old Age Revolving Pension organization, who faces removal as a result of his defense of President Roosevelt in a speech at the Townsendites' convention in Cleveland last week, will continue to crusade for the pension movement, but will campaign for President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Wheat resumed its normal leadership in the grain markets today. There was a noticeable let-up in general speculative interest in all grains. The greater part of the day's activity on the Board of Trade was at the opening.

Unscathed after a 150-foot plunge down the embankment of Riverside Drive, about fifty feet north of Claremont Inn, Herbert McLeggan, a Negro chauffeur, of 64 West 139th Street, stepped from the coupe he was driving at 12:45 P.M. yesterday and smiled.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., July 20. -- Will G. Metz, Works Progress Administrator for Wyoming, late today dispatched to John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, the following telegram defending Governor Leslie A. Miller on Mr. Hammond's charge of politics in relief:

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 21. -- An American plan to make a loan to China in excess of 100,000,000 yuan ($30,200,000) to be devoted to purchase of munitions is reported today by Japanese correspondents in China.

SOME time today, out in St. Louis, James Leroy Bottomley will submit himself to the medical inspection of Doc Hyland, and if Doc says "Home James!" the back-to-the-farm movement will have one more joiner and the national pastime will be losing one of its friendliest figures in flannels.

Newspaper advertising has a definite influence which can be evaluated accurately in the successful merchandising of women's ready-to-wear apparel, according to the results of a study made by Charles C. Stech, research specialist of this city.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Warmer weather began a general advance over the Corn Belt today. Higher prices in the market here followed quickly on reports of a renewal of warmer and continued fair weather. Corn rose the maximum allowed, 4 cents, July closing at 91% cents.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission of New York, authorized yesterday the Long Island Lighting Company and the Queens Borough Gas and Electric Company, its subsidiary, to sell $27,019,000 of 4 per cent bonds to refund an equal principal amount of outstanding bonds carrying higher interest rates.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 21. -- Mr. Watt, bay colt owned by H. Stacy Smith of Short Hills, N.J., and cleverly driven by Tom Berry of Lexington, Ky., today won the 2-year-old trot, feature event of the card of the Grand Circuit meeting over the historic E. Roland Harriman track.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision yesterday on the application by Thomas H. Hughes, principal of Public School 62, the Bronx, to restrain the Board of Education from removing him and others from additional posts in the city evening schools.

The osteopaths have stated an important truth, but in language a bit unfortunate. They say we cannot expect the span of life to grow longer "unless tranquillity of life becomes fashionable." No one can question the tranquillity.
MOSCOW, July 21. -- Many staple foods are scarce in Moscow. Eggs are so scarce in the markets that many housewives must go to villages for them.

Amateur star-gazers who peered into the sky last night hoping to see the brilliance of Halley's comet repeated by the newest celestial wanderer, the recently discovered Peltier comet, were considerably disappointed.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Better grades of hogs averaging 190 to 250 pounds were scarce here today and sold mostly at 10 cents a hundredweight advance, while other kinds were weak to as much as 25 cents lower, with unfinished lightweights showing the most loss.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 (AP). -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Veterans' Administrator, urged the convention of the Disabled American Veterans today to be cautious in making any recommendations for increased benefits to former soldiers.

Pressing forward with its campaign plans for the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman and its program of creating a permanent organization for independent labor political action, the newly formed State Labor party of Labor's Nonpartisan League rented the tenth floor of the Claridge Hotel, Forty-fourth Street and Broadway, yesterday for its central New York headquarters.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 21. -- Details of the flight on which an airplane belonging to Guinea Airways dropped food and gasoline by parachute for the Archbold scientific expedition, which was marooned in the wilds of Papua, have become known.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 21. -- Thus far the army rebels are maintaining their hold over Spanish Morocco, but government warships have been shelling Melilla and Ceua today.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 21. -- Australia captured the interzone final series today from Germany and will meet the defending English team in the challenge round of the Davis Cup tennis competition starting Saturday.

ALBANY, July 21. -- While relief costs in New York State have been sharply reduced, the State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officers warned the public today that officials must look forward to an upward trend in demands as the Winter approaches.

NEWARK, N.J., July 21. -- Two officers and directors of the D'Auria Bank and Trust Company of 139 Seventh Avenue, this city, which was closed last Wednesday, were arrested today, and warrants were issued for three other directors on charges of making false financial statements in violation of the Federal Reserve Act.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 21. -- A large gathering of the members of the Summer colony was present at the Casino Theatre tonight as the third week of the season of the Casino players opened with the presentation of "The Pursuit of Happiness."
CLEVELAND, July 21 (AP). -- The Indians quelled a Boston uprising in the ninth inning today to defeat the Red Sox, 6 to 5, in the series opener.

MANASSAS BATTLEFIELD Va., July 21. -- On this famous battlefield 2,000 marines and army men today re-enacted the first battle of Bull Run (Manassas), which seventy-five years ago was bitterly fought between Confederate and Union troops.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Plans by which seven Federal agencies will start preliminary work by August on a unified and comprehensive flood control program in New York State, Pennsylvania and Ohio were agreed upon today at a meeting here of Federal officials and representatives of regional flood control agencies.

The preliminary report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System for the fiscal year ended on June 30 shows a net income of $5,538,756 after all deductions, including minority interest of Brooklyn Queens Transit System, equivalent after preferred dividends to $5.49 a share on 735,664 no-par common shares.

To stimulate nation-wide research in child neurology and allied fields, a special committee is to be created under the direction of Dr. Bernard Sachs, New York physician and neuro-psychiatrist, according to The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Two officials of the Yorkshire Indemnity Company, 90 John Street, a subsidiary of a large British concern, were arrested yesterday in the investigation into many allegedly fraudulent accident claims by a ring of lawyers, physicians and others.

Richard Gregory, 22 years old, of 709 Tenth Avenue, and Thomas Donohue, 28, of 141 West Ninety-sixth Street, West Side dock loaders, were booked on charges of homicide late yesterday afternoon in the West Forty-seventh Street police station.

Enrico Venturi of Italy, European lightweight champion, continued his string of successes in this country by outpointing Joe (Honey) Mellody, Boston protege of Jack Sharkey, in the feature ten-round bout at Dexter Park last night.

LONDON, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Kent, runner-up to Derbyshire in the English county cricket competition, lost ground today when the County suffered a first-innings defeat by Middlesex. Derbyshire drew with the touring Indian team.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The present drought is as severe in the Western Corn Belt as it was in 1934, and is more severe in the Eastern Corn Belt and as far east as Central Pennsylvania and East Central New York, the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture stated today.

MOSCOW, July 21. -- Three Soviet fliers, attempting a 7,000-mile non-stop Arctic flight, reported tonight that they were "flying over the center of the Yakutsk Mountains," having covered about two-thirds of the projected distance.

The wedding trip of Christopher Mullady, an ex-convict and alleged member of a Brooklyn gang, with his 20-year-old bride was interrupted yesterday morning when the couple walked out of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Brooklyn, where they had been married a few minutes before.

Directors of the B.F. Goodrich Company approved yesterday a plan providing for the creation of a new $5 cumulative preferred stock and for the exchanging of these shares for the present 7 per cent cumulative preferred on the basis of 1.4 shares of the new stock, plus one-half share of common stock, for each share of the old preferred.

The appointment of an advisory committee to make a comprehensive study of and recommendations on dust collecting and eradicating devices and to suggest rules and regulations for the prevention of dust disease hazards in New York State was announced yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.
Sam Baron refers to my letter of July 9, but does not answer the questions, "Must labor be controlled from an office in Washington? The newest fear is 'monopolies.' How about a monopoly of labor?"

A growing cooperation between Mayor La Guardia and the newly formed Labor party which is backing President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman was indicated yesterday in the latest development in the controversy over nomination of an anti-Tammany candidate for Aldermanic President.

LENOX, Mass., July 21. -- The annual Lenox horse show at the Hanna Farm on Friday and Saturday will be a focus of week-end activity. The three-day Stockbridge golf tournament will start on Friday. The combined horse show and tournament ball will be held at the Stockbridge Club on Saturday.

Mrs. Margaret Robinson, stock broker, who was expected to surrender yesterday morning to Assistant Attorney General Joseph F. Ruggieri, who wanted to question her regarding the disposition of more than $250,000 she was alleged to have obtained from six clients through fraud, failed to appear in his office in the State Building.

TORONTO, July 21. -- "It isn't the throbbing needle of the diamond drill but the kleig lights of Hollywood that Billy Bell wants now," was the comment of Michael Dwyer, Nova Scotia Minister of Mines, on seeing a newspaper story based on a letter Bell had written to Alfred Scadding, who, with Dr. D.E. Robertson, was entombed for ten days in the Moose River gold mine in Nova Scotia last April.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 21 (AP). -- Governor Paul V. McNutt of Indiana tonight pictured another Governor, Alf M. Landon of Kansas, as "an individual particularly susceptible to the influences of stronger minds and more ruthless wills."

A banking group composed of Newman, Harrison Co., the Whitney National Bank and American Bank and Trust Company, all of New Orleans, and Welsh Green, Inc., Chicago; Harold E. Wood Co., St. Paul, and Johnson, Lane, Space Co., Inc., of Savannah, will offer to the public today an issue of $1,346,000 of 4 3/4 per cent refunding bonds of the New Orleans Levee District, La.

MADRID, July 21 (Times of London Dispatch) -- Now that the fog of war has somewhat cleared here, it is possible to outline the principal events in the rebellion, whose consequences cannot fail to alter the history of contemporary Spain.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Two United States warships, the battleship Oklahoma and the new 10,000-ton, 8-inch-gun cruiser Quincy, were ordered late today to Spanish waters to protect Americans in the rebellion-torn country and to evacuate them if necessary.

Mayor La Guardia presented prizes yesterday afternoon to winners in the contest conducted by the Municipal Art Committee of the City of New York for the best 200-word essay on "The Picture I Like Best in the First National Exhibition of American Art and Why."

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- Reports from Japan that gold advanced by the United States in exchange for Chinese silver would be used by the Chinese Government for the purchase of munitions and other war supplies were described as absurd in Treasury circles here today.
United Stales Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
Fishing conditions at Peconic Bay are satisfactory, judging from reports emanating from New Suffolk.

Frederick W. Ayer, whose partnership with Robinson Smith was recently dissolved, has teamed up with H. Philip Minis for the production of two plays next season. The first will be James Parish's "Distinguished Gathering," a melodrama which opened last November in London and became something of a hit.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday were again the most numerous in six years and established a new peak during the present buying season when the total exceeded the previous week's high figure. Last week's arrivals were also well ahead of the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

MARION, Mass., July 21. -- Lincoln Davis Jr.'s Starling came through in the last mile of the beat home to win the second contest for the Franklin D. Roosevelt Bowl for the thirty-square meter class today. The Bacardi had led for more than 12 of the 13 1/2 miles of the course, but was beaten by 15 seconds.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The Binghamton Washing Machine Corporation, Binghamton, N.Y., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for 60,000 shares of $10 par value common capital stock.
BOSTON, July 21 (AP). -- Right-hander Benny Frey defeated Ben Cantwell in a pitching duel today to give the Reds a 3-2 victory over the hustling Bees.
Mayor La Guardia visited the scene of another Harlem incident yesterday.
The Tanners Council of America, 100 Gold Street, announced yesterday that it foresaw no flooding of the market with hides of drought cattle purchased by the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated in June at 111 per cent of capacity on a single-shift basis, compared with 105.2 per cent in the preceding month and 74.6 per cent in June last year.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 27 published a dispatch from its Rome correspondent stating that at the meeting of the Italian Senate held for the proclamation of the Roman Empire Senators Albertini, former editor of Il Corriere della Sera; Bergamini, former editor of Il Giornale d'Italia, and Benedetto Croce, the philosopher, were present and voted for the empire.

CLEVELAND, July 21. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder and head of Old Age Revolving Pensions, tried unsuccessfully today to walk out on the courts of Ohio as he did on the Bell committee of the House of Representatives when it sought enlightenment on the financing of his movement.

A cablegram from Max Schmeling challenging James Braddock, world heavyweight champion, has been received, it was announced by the New York State Athletic Commission at its meeting yesterday. The German heavyweight's message said that Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, would put up $5,000 to support the challenge.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe in the French liner Ile de France was Ira A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, who said that France is safely emerging from a bloodless revolution, that the devaluation of the franc is inevitable, and that, in his opinion, the United States will be unable to keep clear of the next war.

Greta Mason, 35 years old, a waitress arrested July 14 in a vice raid at 120 Riverside Drive after detectives had tapped the house wires to get evidence, was held yesterday in $5,000 bail by Magistrate Alfred M. Lindau in Women's Court for trial in General Sessions on a charge of maintaining a disorderly house.

LONDON, July 21. -- King Edward's first garden party and reception at Buckingham Palace this afternoon was abandoned half way through when a downpour drenched hundreds of debutantes, ruining their lovely Summer frocks.

LONDON, July 21. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange continued cheerful today despite the unsettling Continental news. British funds became firmer, reflecting the good results of the new municipal loans. European and Far Eastern securities strengthened in the foreign department.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,978,350 barrels, compared with 2,947,700 in the previous week, an increase of 30,650, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 16,450 and of 12,700 barrels, respectively, in Kansas and Oklahoma accounted for most of the increase.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 21. -- For the second time within three days, a quartet of goals was scored by Billy Reynolds today and the team representing the Fauquier-Loudoun Polo Club of Virginia advanced into the semi-finals of the Wheatley Cups tourney at the Meadow Brook Club.

Both in 1927 and 1932 ten comets blazed in the sky, some of them simultaneously. But these could be seen only through a telescope. The present year is memorable for two visible at the same time without any optical aid. No flaming scimitars are these to strike terror into the hearts of savages, but barely perceptible blurs distinguishable only in the country on a moonless night far from the glare of the city.

The belief that a doctor of osteopathy should be able to detect the onset of infantile paralysis with his hands earlier than a doctor of medicine was announced here yesterday at the fortieth annual convention of the American Osteopathic Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 21. -Although playing conditions today were far better than those which confronted the field in the seventh annual Westchester-Fairfield open women's golf championship during yesterday's initial round only six of the entrants were able to break 90 over the Century Country Club course, whereas ten succeeded the previous day.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21. -- Brilliantly illustrated by Tallulah Bankhead in her first appearance on the Pacific Coast, George Kelly's "Reflected Glory" played to a capacity audience in its American premiere here last night.

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, announced yesterday that he would consult Governor Lehman and party leaders of the State within the next few days on the groundwork for the campaign in New York State.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP). -Summarizing May exports and imports, the Department of Commerce reported today that the United States had a "favorable trade balance" of $9,556,000 for the month. Exports were $200,666,000 and imports $191,110,000.

A Bronx property consisting of eight lots at the southeast corner of Pelham Parkway South and Bolton Street has been purchased by Richard M. Lederer from a client of Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., broker in the deal. The plot, 100 by 125 feet, is opposite two six-story apartment houses recently completed on land sold by Mr. Lederer through the same broker.
LONDON, July 21. -- Men of 60 as well as youths of 18 will be called on to take part in Great Britain's colossal defense effort, it was announced today.

Nineteen men, including a former clerk in the employ of the Bronx County Supreme Court, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury as result of an investigation into immigration frauds conducted by Sylvester Pindyck and Milton S. Gould, Special Assistant Attorney Generals.

It must appear to any critical reader that the foreign dispatches and the editorial comments on the new Austro-German accord do not tell a clear story. The whole business seems confused and contradictory. On one point nearly all are agreed, although without seeming to know why.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- The sum of $239,730 was allotted by the WPA to New York City today for the construction of five municipal camps for children. The allotment, approved by President Roosevelt at the request of Mayor La Guardia, was part of allocations totaling $1,028,300 for recreational area projects in twenty-seven States.

At a brief ceremony yesterday morning in Police Commissioner Valentine's office, he and Byrnes MacDonald, director of the Juvenile Aid Bureau, presented baseball uniforms to sixty boys representing the twelve units of the Police Department's Bureau of Crime Prevention.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 21. -With the arrest of two Negro employes of the Battery Park Hotel, authorities moved today on a new tack in their investigation of the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 21. -Pennsylvania's relief funds were exhausted again tonight and "hunger marchers" knocked at the doors of the Legislature for the second time in eight days, despite the $45,000,000 relief compromise reached last week by Governor Earle and the Republican Senate.

Unusual precautions, far more extensive than those used for the welfare of humans, were taken to safeguard Blenheim, one of England's greatest thoroughbred racing horses, which arrived here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

A collection of unpublished poems by A.E. Housman was discovered after his death last April, Alfred A. Knopf made known yesterday. Blanche W. Knopf obtained the rights to publish the book and brought the manuscript with her when she returned from London last week.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins, before sailing on the Statendam of the Holland-America Line yesterday for a three weeks' European trip, declared she did not regard the domestic labor situation as critical.

The consolidated income account of the Shell Union Oil Corporation and subsidiary companies for the quarter ended on June 30 shows a net income of $7,619,839 after depreciation, depletion, intangible development expenditures, amortization and abandonments and provision for Federal income tax, but not including any surtax that may accrue on undistributed profits.

ISTANBUL, July 21. -- This was a day of great rejoicing in Turkey because of the occupation of the Straits. In towns and villages buildings were beflagged, troops paraded and government offices closed early to permit officials to attend meetings' to hear the story of the Dardanelles.

GIBRALTAR, July 21. -- Many insurgent Spanish Moroccan troops at La Linea, Spain, have been transferred to Algeciras and now occupy the district around Gibraltar Bay. In the expectation that loyal warships arriving from Tangier would bombard the rebels at Algeciras and Cadiz, the insurgent forces displayed the greatest activity tonight.

LARCHONT, N.Y., July 21. -In a spanking breeze from east-northeast and jumping seas, 251 craft took part today in the regatta of Larchmont race week. H.G. Hanan's 50-footer Spartan, Van S. Merle-Smith's international 12-meter sloop Seven Seas and H.T. Von Frankenburg's one-design 12-meter Zio topped their classes in the big fleet.
BOSTON, July 21. -- Liquidation of the $25,000,000 Amoskeag Manufacturing Company at Manchester, N.H., largest cotton textile plant in the world, was ordered by Federal Judge George C. Sweeney today.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP). -- The Senators, vanquished three straight times by Chicago last week, bounced back for a 6-to-5 victory today to halt the White Sox winning streak at eight straight.

Showing the largest increase for a similar period this year, department stores sales in the metropolitan area for the period from July 1 to 15 showed an increase of 13.1 per cent, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mrs. A.A. Baroni's Ann O'Ruley, a 4-year-old daughter of Man o' War, which has been steadily improving, reached her top form yesterday and captured the West Point Handicap, which featured the racing at Empire City.

The mortgage servicing department of Pease Elliman has since last Jan. 1 placed about $4,000,000 in more than twenty-five new firstmortgage loans on apartment houses, Lawrence B. Elliman, president of the firm, reported yesterday.

The celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of the Statue of Liberty on Oct. 28 will be as elaborate as the first ceremony, according to plans announced yesterday. Fifty years ago the President of the United States and all the diplomatic corps took part in the exercises.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 21. -Another young Californian stepped into the lawn tennis picture alongside Robert Riggs today as a player marked for a distinguished career on the courts.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 21 (AP). -- President Luis Companys of the semi-autonomous Province of Catalonia, himself a rebel leader in 1934, announced tonight that the government was in full control of the situation in Barcelona.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated somewhat irregularly yesterday over a 15-point range to end with gains of 6 to 10 points. Strong outside markets and only partial relief in Oklahoma kept sentiment on the buying side, although beneficial showers in dry areas tempered this movement.
PARIS, July 21. -- An agreement as to what the meeting of the three remaining Locarno powers is to be about, has at last been reached, after long negotiations between Paris and London.

A bronze statue of General Philip Henry Sheridan, seven feet six inches tall and standing on a six-foot pedestal of granite, has been erected in Christopher Street Park at Sheridan Square by the General Sheridan Memorial Association. Major William J. Walsh is president of the association.

BERLIN, July 21. -- The Boerse was very firm today. The public was in the market with numerous small purchasing orders, which found little material on hand. Gains exceeding 2 points were frequent and extended to most fields.

WASHINGTON, July 21. -- By unanimous action today spokesmen for twelve unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization refused to appear before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor on Aug. 3 for trial on charges of fomenting "insurrection" and informed President William Green that, come what may, they would "carry on."

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 21. -Strong Liberal sentiment favoring former President Enrique Olaya Herrera for President in 1938 is seen in the appointment of Plinio Mendoza Neira as War Minister, replacing Benito Hernandez Bustos, who was transferred to the post of Minister of Industries.
ALBANY, July 21. -- While Albany celebrated the 250th anniversary of the granting of the city charter today, citizens waited for their mail and outgoing letters were delayed.

The check-up on Republican Chairman Hamilton's charges that applicants for jobs as non-technical foremen on CCC work must generally pass the Democratic political test reveals precisely this: that in filling non-relief, unskilled places in the CCC, the administration rule is the same as in all other departments.

More than 10,000 persons employed on Federal theatre, music and art projects in this city will receive vacations with pay under the order authorizing such vacations issued in Washington by Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, it was revealed yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., July 21 (AP). -- Parts of a ship washed in by the tide and reports of oil drums floating near the Dry Tortugas provided possible clues today in the search for the British motor ship Nunoca, missing with twenty-two persons aboard.

Trading in United States Government bonds presented yesterday further evidence that the market for those loans has shaken off the influence of the higher reserves required by member banks. The Treasury issues, after early hesitancy, turned uniformly strong and closed with net gains of 1-32 to 7-32 point in fairly active trading.
WINNIPEG, July 21 (Canadian Press). -- Showers spattering over the Canadian Spring Wheat Belt brought fresh hope today for grain stands of the West.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP). -The Pirates hammered four Philly pitchers for twenty-one hits and a 17-to-6 triumph today to break their five-game losing streak.
GIBRALTAR, July 21. -- Heavy fighting was reported at La Linea tonight as new contingents of rebel troops reached the mainland by plane from Morocco.

ALBANY, July 21. -- On the ground that the New York City Board of Education's action in dismissing him was "without support of credible evidence," William R. Hayward, 68-year-old dismissed principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School in New York City, applied today for reinstatement to Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education.
A sharp increase in infant mortality and the general death rate for the week ended July 18 was attributed yesterday by Health Commissioner James L. Rice to the recent heat wave.

MILES CITY, Mont., July 21. -Penetrating further into the primary drought areas of the Dakotas and Eastern Montana, the Federal drought relief mission headed by Under-Secretary Rexford G. Tugwell was freshly convinced today of the need for retiring millions of acres of this semi-arid country from cultivation and even grazing if it is to be of any future use.

Final and unqualified denials were made yesterday of persistent reports that District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan might resign from office rather than face the possibility of removal by Governor Lehman.

PARIS, July 21. -- J.W. Chalk, who was with a group of British tourists in San Sebastian, said on his arrival in Paris today that their hotel was invaded Sunday night by armed members of the Popular Front, who drove out the hotel staff.

" Uncle Bob" Sherwood, the last of Barnum's clowns, urged the Republicans yesterday to turn their prospective State caravan into a circus, and they seemed to like the idea. "Uncle Bob" offered to provide his own elephant and five donkeys.

While business failures declined in the manufacturing division in the week ended July 19, as compared with the previous five business days, there was an increase in both the wholesale and retail divisions, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Increased commutation fares sought by the Long Island Railroad -- 15 per cent within the city and 20 per cent in Nassau and Suffolk Counties -- were denied yesterday by the Transit Commission and the Public Service Commission in sharply worded rulings.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 21. -With a 17-year-old high school boy playing a heroic role, a youthful team from the Northwest today started the Warren G. Harding Trophy, emblematic of the intercity team golf championship of the United States, on its first trip to Seattle in the national public links tournament.

One of the city's better-known transients yesterday was the British author, James Hilton, who got in from Hollywood -- where his novel, "Lost Horizon," has just been converted into a film by Columbia Pictures -- and sailed eight hours later on the Statendam for England.

Yesterday's gain of 1.49 points in THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty industrial and railroad stocks represented the twelfth consecutive advance. This index has not declined in a single session since July 7. Not since 1928 and 1929 has the stock market generated enough steam to put together so long a string of advances.

Encouraging figures on the increase in American shipbuilding in recent months were presented yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the board of managers of the American Bureau of Shipping, by the president, J. Lewis Luckenbach. The managers who attended were Franklin D. Mooney, Joseph W. Powell, Samuel D. McComb, James Craig Peacock, John D. Reilly, Joseph B. Weaver and William D. Winter.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 21. -Conquering two rivals, Miss Joan Todd of New York led the field into the quarter-final round as play started in the junior girls' open tennis tournament at the Great Neck Country Club today.

TOKYO, July 21. -- Emperor Hirohito will personally conduct a solemn ceremony tomorrow before his ancestral shrines, at which the mutiny of Feb. 26 and its subsequent liquidation will be, in the words of the official statement, "announced to the spirits of the imperial ancestors."

ALBANY, July 21. -- An investigation of Communistic activities in New York City by a legislative committee was assured tonight with the announcement that the personnel of the committee has been completed with the exception of one or two names. The committee, it is expected, will be announced tomorrow, along with other commissions.

Approximately 1,000 persons attended a luncheon for Frank M. Ledwith, recently appointed a member of the State Mortgage Commission, given by the Associated Real Estate Boards of Metropolitan New York at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

BERLIN, July 21. -- Walter Schwertfeger, 35 years old, well-known Berlin newspaper man and nephew of Colonel Bernhard Schwertfeger, noted military authority, was sentenced by the People's Tribunal to life-long penal servitude today, charged with treason against the State.

The stock market overcame early hesitancy yesterday and moved confidently into new high ground for the year in trading that amounted to 1,584,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, compared with 1,424,000 the day before. Led at first by the rails and the coppers and later by the motor issues, the market completed its twelfth consecutive trading day of advancing prices.

MADRID, July 21 (Passed by the Censor). -- The government announced on the radio this evening that the rebels in Seville, which has been the focal point of the uprising in the south, had surrendered because they were depressed by the defeats their comrades had suffered in the last three days in Madrid, Barcelona and elsewhere.
ABOARD THE STEAMSHIP MANHATTAN, at Sea, July 21. -The arrival of the United States Olympic transport at Plymouth today disrupted the training routine of all the athletes except the wrestlers.

From Topeka comes the prediction that Governor LANDON will deal at some length with the problem of national finance in his acceptance speech tomorrow evening. No problem now before the country is of more outstanding importance, or more deserving of candid and realistic treatment.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 21. -- On the rain-heavy, wind-swept Quaker Ridge course today only one of the seventy-one starters could break 90 and only one other could equal that score in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

Into the quiet of a Locust Valley evening the proprietors of the Red Barn Theatre last night brought that Marie Baumer-Martin Berkeley play, "Seen But Not Heard," for which Broadway's trade circles have had a label these several months -- a play, the gossip said, about children and murder in a country house.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 21. -- The four-week-old strike at the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company's plant here, marked by repeated rioting and several hundred arrests, was ended late today when strikers voted unanimously to accept a five-point agreement approved earlier in the day by the R.C.A. management.

DETROIT, July 21 (AP). -- A charge by Dayton Dean, so-called Black Legion "executioner," that an unsuspecting Negro was lured to a lonely swamp and shot to death to entertain a group of terrorists on a Saturday night drinking party has been corroborated, Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea declared tonight.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 21. -- Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator, and Mrs. Hopkins of Washington, who have been in Maine, arrived today at Pecketts on Sugar Hill. They attended the Barnstormers' performance of "Juno and the Paycock" at the Hayloft Theatre.

Increases totaling $44,334 were requested in the 1937 budget estimates submitted to the Director of the Budget yesterday by the various commissioners of jurors. Of the total amount, $40,739 represents the sum affected by pay cuts, pay increases and additions to personnel.

Mr. PAUL GOUIN seceded with other young Liberals from the Liberal party of Quebec Province and founded l'Action Nationale Liberale. Its object was "to adapt provincial legislation to the "problems of the present moment, and "to give Quebec a national policy; that "is, one suited to the needs, aptitudes "and the aspirations of the mass of its "population, which is French-Cana"dian."

Trading was mixed yesterday in local commodity futures markets. Gains were shown by copper, coffee, cocoa, cottonseed oil and rubber, while other staples eased. On the cash markets, wheat, cotton, corn, rye, oats, butter, lard, cocoa, antimony, zinc and rubber advanced, and tin, silk and hides eased.

ABOARD THE SCHOONER LIBERTY OFF CAPE SABLE, N.S., July 21. -- With sails furled and using his auxiliary motor, President Roosevelt today brought his vacation schooner Sewanna through alternate fog and sunlight back to this anchorage where he stopped last Friday night.
ST. LOUIS, July 21. -- That high-geared Yankee baseball machine slipped quietly into reverse at Sportsman's Park today and lost the opening skirmish with the Browns the hard way.

DETROIT, July 21 (AP). -- The Tigers defeated the Athletics twice today, coming from behind to take the second game of a double header, 9 to 8, after Tommy Bridges had pitched an 8-to-0 victory in the opener.

Continuing his testimony yesterday at the Federal Trade Commission hearing against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., Benjamin B. Hirsch, manufacturer of popular-priced dresses, said he considered some of the guild practices "part of a scheme to restrain trade."
MADRID, July 21. -- The Spanish Government, massing armed columns of workers and peasants in defense of the capital, claimed success in important provincial cities tonight against rebel forces.

For President -- FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT: he did not shave for four days. When he went aboard the Sewanna at Rockland, Me., he was as clean as a whistle, and cheerful. When he boarded the Potomac four days later to push a button, thus opening the Fort Worth celebration, he was as innocent of a razor as a Maine lobsterman, and he was cheerfuller.

In the last paragraph of your editorial "Mr. Hull's Treaties," you cite the increase in export trade to Canada, Sweden and Cuba under the reciprocal trade agreements to show how beneficial these agreements have been. The assumption that the increase in export trade to these countries is due primarily to the trade agreement program is not warranted by careful analysis of the facts.

The Bowery seemed strangely quiet yesterday after 300 veterans of the Bowery Mission boarded the Wilson Line steamer State of Delaware for an all-day cruise up Long Island Sound almost to Bridgeport. But officials of the line were puzzled last night when a few hours after the end of the trip, a summons was served accusing them of violating the Cabaret Law.

It is entirely natural for partisan Republicans to cheer and for partisan Democrats to sputter whenever Senator GLASS makes a political speech. Each speech simply serves to drive further home the fact, well known for three years, that Mr. GLASS heartily disapproves of many aspects of the New Deal and intends, if re-elected, to use with the President and Congress, as a Democrat, his influence to reform it along the lines he considers traditional.

THIS is strictly a technical baseball dispute and the players of both big leagues are in it up to their respective necks. When Charley Grimm was coming away from the All-Star game in Boston he more than hinted that the late assault of the American Leaguers on his Curt Davis was due to the fact that the lively an American League ball was being tossed up to the hitters at that stage of the game.

New records for attendance and business volume were established again yesterday by all three homewares trade shows in progress here this week. Buying at the furniture market, where 940 retailers and jobbers registered during the day, exceeded that for any similar day in several years.

MOSCOW, July 21. -- The Kremlin regards the new Dardanelles convention as a victory for Soviet diplomacy, not only in the interests of the Soviet Union itself but in the general cause of peace, collective security and the League of Nations, it is made clear today in a leading editorial in Izvestia.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 21. -- A man sought in connection with the recent $400,000 jewel robbery on the Long Island estate of William R. Coe evaded an elaborate trap set for him here today by Federal men, Nassau County detectives and local police.

WOODMERE, L.I., July 21. -Five birdies and an eagle helped to counterbalance a disastrous 7 on the 400-yard fourth hole for Celestin Durand today as the youthful Garden City Golf Club star posted a par-equaling 71 to lead a field of sixty-three contestants in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Woodmere Club.

Sale of a leasehold on the seventeen-story Vanderbilt Avenue Building, opposite Grand Central Terminal, featured the Manhattan foreclosure auctions yesterday. The property was taken over on an $85,000 bid by the Chase National Bank, trustee, as plaintiff in an action against the Vanderbilt Avenue Building Corporation and others and a committee including Karl H. Behr and others, listed as intervening defendants.

While walking on the Boardwalk at Far Rockaway yesterday a woman was knocked down and painfully injured by a motor cycle on which three Queens municipal lifeguards were riding. One duty of the lifeguards is to enforce a regulation prohibiting riding a motor cycle or bicycle on the Boardwalk.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 21. -- An effort to show that William Fox, one-time film leader, while pursued by creditors tried to throw stock market losses into his own account and to put profits into the account of his trust corporation in the name of his wife and daughters, was made here today in Mr. Fox's bankruptcy suit.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 21. -Rudolph Friml's melodic operetta, "Rose Marie," began a week's engagement here tonight on the stage on Zach's Bay. About 8,000 auditors seated in the Jones Beach Stadium on the shore of the Bay enthusiastically applauded the performance.
HENDAYE, France, July 21 (AP). -- At least five northern provinces are under the control of Spanish rebels, two Leftist officials who fled over the border asserted tonight.

Three thousand fans welcomed the Dodgers to Ebbets Field yesterday and saw them fail for the fifth time this year to extend a winning streak beyond three games as they went down before the Cubs, 5 -- 3.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt will be an active speaker for Governor Landon throughout the country, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern Republican campaign manager, announced yesterday after a conference with the colonel at headquarters in the Liggett Building.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 21. -The trial of Police Chief Philip Kohut, Captain Thomas McGowan and Detective Sergeant Thomas Moore, charged with neglect and omission of duty in allegedly failing to close a gambling house here, was adjourned today by City Judge J. Charles Zimmerman at the request of District Attorney Martin W. Littleton Jr., who said his office had not completed its investigation of the alleged tie-up between the police and the gamblers.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- The corn market was on the upgrade virtually from the start today, and with a lack of pressure the close was at net gains of 3 to 4 cents, the latter mark being the maximum permitted for one day under Exchange regulations.

The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, which has been in bankruptcy since last August, will file in the Federal court at Denver tomorrow or Friday a plan of reorganization which will call for consolidating the line with the Denver Salt Lake, Denver Salt Lake Western and the Northwestern Terminal Railroad -- all companies controlled by the Rio Grande.

The nation-wide second anniversary campaign for "Better SightBetter Light" lamps will be launched in October with a goal of 1,000,000 lamp sales for the month, or one Illuminating Engineers Society lamp for every twenty-metered homes in the country, department store lamp buyers meeting at the Hotel New Yorker were told yesterday.
Harlem was the center of interest in Manhattan realty activity yesterday when banks, either as owners or acting for owners, disposed of several multi-family buildings.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, July 21. -- The Spanish warship Jaime Primero, in charge of a loyal crew, was bombed by two rebel airplanes as she entered this international port this evening. The ship replied with rapid-firing guns.
BERLIN, July 21 (AP). -- The draw for men's and women's fencing, field hockey and handball in the Olympic Games was announced today.
NEWARK, N.J., July 21. -- Newark opened a two-week home stay tonight by dividing a double-header with the Montreal Royals before a crowd of 12,000.

Disintegration of the servant class in England was described as "a terrific social catastrophe" yesterday to members of the Osteopathic Women's Association by Mrs. Anna Steese Richardson of The Woman's Home Companion magazine, who recently returned from abroad.

Charles R. Crane, former Minister to China; George W. Davison, chairman of the Central Hanover Bank, and Mrs. Davison; Kaye Don, British automobile racer; Mrs. Norman Armour, wife of the Minister to Canada, and Colonel Wrisley Brown are among the passengers due today from the Channel ports on the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line.

DULUTH, Minn., July 21 (AP). -Definite increases in every line of Great Lakes activity have been made this year in comparison with activity for the past several years, shippers and vessel men at the head of the lakes are agreed. In every phase of shipping and line of employment the trend of business continues up, while the latest report of vessels in commission shows considerably greater number than than last year.

Josi Iturbi has developed the task of being both conductor and piano soloist in a concerto into a rare achievement. Last night he directed and played the Mozart Piano Concerto in E flat, K. 482, managing his double duties smoothly and with musical effectiveness.
VERA, Spain, July 21 (AP). -- Victorious rebel troops who today captured and set up military headquarters in San Sebastian were reported tonight to have occupied most of Northern Spain.

Howard D. Joost, 59 years old, a former vice president of the Kings County Trust Company, pleaded not guilty in Kings County Court yesterday to two indictments charging him with grand larceny in connection with certain check transactions in which he is alleged to have engaged before his resignation in December, 1935.

LONDON, July 21. -- Consultations between the British, French and Belgian Governments will begin Thursday in London with the hope on the part of these three powers that the fact that they are holding a preliminary meeting will not cause the Germans to absent themselves from a full conference of all the Locarno powers later.

Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday that this country would be the art center of the world within the near future, because it has the talent, appreciation and resources to give it a commanding position in that field.

Hundreds of dilapidated tenements in New York City have been vacated and boarded up in the last thirty months by the Tenement House Department, it was learned yesterday, and many others have been ordered vacated as unfit for use.

Teeing off with three straight hits, which he tacked on to seven in a row which he made in a doubleheader in St. Louis last Sunday, Joe Medwick, clouting outfielder of the Cardinals, tied a National League record at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
TOPEKA, July 21. -- Governor Landon was virtually put on record today as favoring the setting up of a nonpartisan commission of experts to revise the Federal banking laws.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin ordered a jury trial yesterday in a suit brought by eleven structural designers to compel the Civil Service Commission and the New York City Tunnel Authority to give them jobs as designers for the Queens-Midtown tunnel and the vehicular tunnel planned to run from the Battery to Brooklyn.

Surrogate James A. Foley reserved decision yesterday after hearing arguments on a show cause order to compel the executors of the estate of the late Alice G. Vanderbilt to pay a legacy of $100,000 bequeathed to her daughter-in-law, Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt.

PARIS, July 21. -- Reports from French border stations reaching Paris tonight indicated great confusion in the northern part of Spain, where a large number of towns were said to be in possession of the army rebels, and refugees who succeeded in crossing the French border declared that a large rebel column was marching from the north toward the capital.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York, Democratic nominee for President in 1928, will amplify his views against the New Deal and President Roosevelt as the campaign progresses, in the opinion of John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman.

Reflecting the heavy increase in demand in both the foreign and domestic markets, the leading producers of copper here advanced the price yesterday in the domestic market from 9 1/2 cents to 9 3/4 cents a pound, delivered in the Connecticut River Valley.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Eastern railroads and truck operators transferred to Chicago today their fight over the establishment of a general free pickup and delivery freight service when H.W. Archer, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, took the testimony of shippers and others.

CHICAGO, July 21. -- Likelihood that the tangled affairs of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation soon may be corrected after extensive litigation was seen in the action today of Federal Judge William H. Holly in authorizing trustees of the Chicago Elevator Properties, Inc., principal Rosenbaum holding, to submit a plan of reorganization to stockholders.

BOSTON, July 21. -- Influenza, one of the unwhipped plagues of civilization, was declared by two Harvard scientists tonight to be a step nearer the fate of smallpox, yellow fever, diphtheria and typhoid fever.

CEUTA, Spanish Morocco, July 21 (AP). -- An announcement that the intensity of Communist propaganda in Spain had caused the present rebellion was issued today in the name of General Francisco Franco, leader of the insurrection.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 22 (AP). -- Catalonia proclaimed its loyalty to the Leftist Spanish Government tonight by setting up a military regime against Rightist revolutionaries.

HENDAYE, France, July 22. -- The fate of San Sebastian, key objective of Spain's Northern rebels, was still in doubt here tonight with day-long fighting reported in the streets and a loyal gunboat preparing to shell rebel positions from the harbor.
June foreign trade in merchandise for a series of years, with (+) indicating excess of imports ( -- ) indicating excess of exports, comPares as follows:
Shining Sun, from the stable of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, turned in a surprise yesterday by scoring at 6 to 1 in the mile and a sixteenth test for 3-year-olds which featured the card at Empire City.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 22. -- The National Coffee Department announced today that the government would assist the coffee market, buying if necessary, to maintain the price equilibrium and to compensate growers for their loss imposed by the sacrifice in the quota.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 22. -- The identity of the man who murdered Miss Helen Clevenger is known and his arrest may be expected in forty-eight hours, Sheriff Laurence E. Brown indicated tonight.

I am quite diverted by Arthur Krock's column of July 17, and now for the first time appreciate fully just what the popular term "oversimplifiction" means. Mr. Krock, with the facile air of a vaudeville prestidigitator, arrives at the following conclusions:

Further objections to the warranty required by the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., for the protection of original styles of merchandise were given yesterday at the hearing before the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway.
Three men found guilty of driving while intoxicated were fined $100 each yesterday in Intoxication Court by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, who also revoked their licenses.

DETROIT, July 22 (AP). -- The Athletics overcame a five-run Detroit lead, batted Elden Auker out of the box in the fifth and defeated the Tigers, 7 to 6, today in the third game of the series. The Athletics' scoring was confined to two innings, the third and the fifth.

WASHINGTON July 22. -- Members of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor declared today that there was no alternative left to them but to suspend from membership in the federation on Aug. 3 the twelve unions in the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis.

D. Richard Young compares total government expenditures for four-year terms of Presidents -- "McKinley spent $2,153,000,000; Theodore Roosevelt, $2,502,000,000; Taft, $2,800,000,000; Wilson, first term, $4,208,000,000; second (war) term, $43,241,000,000, including over $10,000,000,000 loans to allies; Harding, $14,529,000,000; Coolidge, $13,571,000,000; Hoover, $18,795,000,000, and Franklin D. Roosevelt, $31,373,000,000."

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Government revenue collections for the 1936 fiscal year amounted to $3,520,208,381, exceeding those of the year before by $220,772,808, despite a reduction of $454,585,151 in the processing taxes on agricultural commodities which were invalidated by the Supreme Court, according to figures of the Treasury Department issued today.

New Jersey will give Governor Landon a plurality of 250,000, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. was assured yesterday by New Jersey political leaders who visited him at the Eastern headquarters here.
Cottontail rabbits, that often dart across the road and then scoot back into the underbrush when be they notice your approach, have become a subject of scientific search.

That the United States Government's silver program is proving costly is indicated by the foreign-trade figures for the first six months of this year. In that period there was an excess of imports of silver of $116,028,000, which, on the basis of the current price of the metal, means that some 250,000,000 ounces were imported.
DRANESVILLE, Va., July 22. -- With a flick of his finger Secretary Ickes today set in motion perhaps the most elaborate electrically equipped farm in America.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- United States exports for June were almost $15,000,000 ahead of those in June, 1935, but imports increased almost $35,500,000 for the comparative months, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce announced today.

The shy and tongue-tied Englishman was not always thus. In our own time when an English son went off to fight in France he did not know how to say good-bye to his father, and the two finally shook hands in an awkward manner, as in J.M. BARRIE'S little play.

The directly implied approval of Governor LANDON has been given to a postscript which is apparently to be added to the Republican platform. In a statement issued with the official sanction of Landon headquarters, Representative HOLLISTER proposes to set up a non-partisan commission of experts "to be- "gin as soon as possible a basic study "of all our Federal banking laws, with "a view to their simplification and im-"provement."

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 22. -- After being beaten in the stretch in the first heat, Mrs. E. Roland Harriman drove Highland Bob to victory in the next two brushes and annexed the special trotting event for amateur drivers at Historic Track today.

Domestic copper sales on Tuesday were reported yesterday at 106,101 tons, the largest for any single day's trading on record. The heavy buying was due to the rush of consumers to cover requirements before the new 9 3/4-cent price went into effect yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Callahan Zinc-Lead Company capital stock transactions on Friday, unless for cash, shall be ex-rights, but suggested that open buy orders and open stop orders to sell be returned to principals for adjustment, in view of the conditions of the offering of rights.

Striking sharply at James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, Judge Jonah J. Goldstein of the Court of General Sessions announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for that post, which Tammany denied him.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 22. -- Although the local yacht club crew in the series of nine races to determine the junior champion of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association finished third, fourth and fifth today, it continues to hold a lead over its opponents after winning three straight yesterday.

For immediate improvement with a one-story business building the northwest corner of 167th Street and Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Harold I. Litwin from the Esdo Building Corporation. The plans are being prepared by Miller Goldhammer, architects.

TOPEKA, July 22. -- Governor Landon will make his bow to the country tomorrow night with an address formally accepting the Republican nomination for the Presidency, and tonight all arrangements were completed to make sure that the setting would be a fitting one.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22. -- The New Jersey Bar Association was asked today by the Lawyers Society of Essex County to make an investigation "to determine whether a practice has developed whereby an appointment to a judicial office is accompanied by an undated resignation."

New alternative offers of extension or of payment in "block" reichsmarks will be made by the Provincial Bank of Westphalia to holders who do not live in Germany of certificates of participation in a $3,000,000 five-year 6 per cent note of the bank which became due on March 1, 1933, according to an announcement yesterday.

To test the commonly accepted supposition that viruses can be transmitted through the air without losing their viability, Drs. W.F. WELLS and H.W. BROWN of Harvard have been conducting some grueling but obvious experiments during the last five years. They sprayed the virus of influenza into a sealed tank.

A syndicate headed by Edward B. Smith Co. will offer today an issue of $10,000,000 first-mortgage 4 per cent bonds of the Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company, due in 1951, at 98 and accrued interest. The bonds, which are dated July 1, provide for a sinking fund sufficient to retire the entire issue by maturity.
NEWARK, N.J., July 22. -- Bob Seeds, Montreal center fielder, individually beat the Bears today, when he drove in all the Royals' runs in a 4-to-2 victory over Newark.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sargent Shriver gave a dinner last night in the Summer Garden of the Ambassador for Miss Virginia Maureen Smith and Bernard Shanley Sd, whose marriage will take place Aug. 1 in Southampton. Other !guests were the Misses Molly i Shriver and Mary Schumacher, H. Wisher Miller anc Gregory Smith.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Administrative experts in three departments have been set to work digging up facts and figures on the results and expectations of the reciprocal trading policy with a view to meeting expected Republican onslaughts in the campaign.

The State of South Carolina awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,500,000 of highway certificates of indebtedness to a banking group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, on a bid of 100.13 for 2 1/2s. The certificates, to be dated July 1, 1936, will mature on July 1, 1940 to 1949.
In THE TIMES of July 21 was an article about Julian T. Bishop, who says he will move to Canada if President Roosevelt is re-elected.

IN his days as a rugged individualist Charley Grimm used to pack a banjo with him on baseball trips. But as a club manager he travels without a musical instrument and delivers his managerial speeches without notes.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22. -- The junior skippers in today's regatta showed their elders how to start a yacht race and how not to start one, all in the same afternoon.

Details of the plans of the American Rolling Mill Company to acquire an interest in the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation through an exchange of stock were disclosed yesterday in the application of the former to list 25,630 additional shares of $25-par common stock.

When Congress created the office of Controller General it gave to that official a non-successive fifteen-year term so that he would feel real independence of political pressure, and conveyed powers of control over Government expenditure which even the President could not contravene.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22. -- It is all even now among the three sloops of the America's Cup class, for Weetamoe, with her owner, Chandler Hovey of Boston, at the wheel, today crossed the finish line forty-seven seconds ahead of Harold S. Vanderbilt's Rainbow in the third of the series of races being held off here under the auspices of the New York Yacht Club.

MADRID, Thursday, July 23 (Passed by the Censor). -- Reports last night that Seville had surrendered to the government appeared premature this morning, when it was announced that "loyal forces, combined with Socialist militia, are advancing and the forces commanded by General Queipo de Llano in Seville are said to be deserting."

BERLIN, July 22. -- The Boerse was fairly active and firmish today. Heavy industrial shares led the market, Hoesch gaining 1 1/2 points and Mannesmann 1. Chemical issues also were active, Heyden gaining 1 point and I. G. Farben 1 1/4. AEG rose 3/4 point in the firm electrical list.

DETROIT, July 10 (AP). -- Five men charged with the Black Legion "thrill killing" of a Negro hod carrier during a drinking party at a lake resort were ordered held today without bail for examination Tuesday on murder and kidnap charges.

Izzy Jannazzo, East Side welterweight, improved his chances as a title contender by decisively out-pointing Johnny Jadick of Philadelphia last night at Dyckman Oval. The bout, which went ten rounds, featured a program arranged for the benefit of the United Palestine Appeal Fund.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 22. -- General T.I Alknis, head of the Soviet air force, and staff officers made a series of flights over Prague yesterday in a huge four-motored Soviet bomber which bright forty passengers from Moscow.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 22. --Wilmer Hines of Columbia S.C., the defending trophy holder and ninth ranking player of the country, was eliminated from the Longwood Bowl invitation tennis tournament today as three Californians and Frank Parker of Spring Lake progressed to the semi-finals at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The arrival of a boa constrictor, fourteen lizards (one deceased) and two giant ant-eaters aboard the steamship Toloa brought a gleam of pleasure to the eye of Captain R. Cheyne-Stout, zoological consultant of the Central Park Zoo, as he examined his new acquisitions at the United Fruit Line dock yesterday.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 20 per cent for the week ended July 18, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. This figure shows a decline from that of the previous week, when an increase of 24 per cent over the same period a year ago was reported.

A mild corrective movement prevailed yesterday most among domestic corporation bonds on the New York Stock Exchange, the reactions being more pronounced for issues which are influenced directly by stocks. At the same time the higher grade investments maintained a steady undertone in quiet trading.

James W. Gerard replied yesterday to a charge of "bluff" on his offer to bet $20,000 at odds of 2 to 1 on the re-election of President Roosevelt by directing that $10,000 of the money be placed with the person who alleged the "bluff."
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

William A. Parker, president of Incorporated Investors, Boston, says in his quarterly report that the new Federal tax legislation "is decidedly advantageous" from the point of view of the company's stockholders, as the possibility of double taxation has been removed.

LONDON, July 22. -- The market on the London Stock Exchange was cheerful again today, demand for industrial shares remaining good. British Government issues showed an upward trend. Industrial issues were strong, although buying was selective, with several iron and steel issues setting new high marks.

PARIS, July 22. -- In Northern Spain the success of the Rightists seems unquestionable. General Emilio Mola, in command at Burgos, who had expected to march toward Madrid today, was consolidating the successes obtained at San Sebastian and gathering more men to strengthen advancing columns.

VERA, Spain, July 22 (AP). -- About 800 rebels under the command of Colonel Luis de Villanueva waited for orders tonight to move on Irun, Spain's northern railway terminus. The reported plan of action was to join two other rebel columns of the northern insurgent army, one in San Sebastian and the other moving up the valley behind Irun.
TOKYO, July 22. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's success in forcing South china to Submit to the Central Government is viewed by the press here as a setback to Japan's aims in North China.

A machine lectured last night for fifteen minutes in defense of machine-age employment before an audience of industrial, scientific and engineering experts in the auditorium of the New York Museum of Science and Industry, RCA Building, Rockefeller Center.

Each new exchange of defiances between William Green and John L. Lewis, the respective defenders of the crafts and the mass production unions in organized labor, accentuates the fact that in a time when all bodies of normally common thought and interest are dividing, workers offer no exception.

Mobilization of the United States Olympic team for the Berlin games became complete yesterday with the sailing of the canoeing squad, the last unit to depart, on the United States liner President Harding.

Practically every one else having been named at one time or another, it is Jimmy Savo who has been signed for the leading male role of "White Horse Inn," that massive spectacle now being assembled for the Center Theatre. This is final and definite.
The Anaconda Wire and Cable Company has declared a dividend of 50 cents on the common stock. This is an increase of 25 cents a share over the previous dividend of 25 cents paid on April 23.

Out of a handful of charred paper ash, beaten into the soil of a vacant lot by two severe rainstorms and scorched by a week of hot Summer sun, two detectives of the Police Department's technical research laboratory have reproduced a copy of a forged stock certificate that is expected to send at least three persons to prison.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- One woman worker was killed and ten persons were injured late today in a terrific explosion and fire which demolished a narrow, three-story brick building at 1,406 North Halsted Street, housing the National Fur Dressing and Dyeing Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Belatedly recognizing only today that the Kansas Supreme Court in May rejected a Landon-sponsored law endeavoring to force payment by Kansas farmers for compulsory control of soil erosion, New Dealers contrasted the plan with the voluntary program set up by the Roosevelt Administration under the AAA, which died at the hands of the United States Supreme Court.

BAY SHORE, L.I., July 22. -- W. Kingsland Macy, Republican leader of Suffolk County, refused comment today when he was told that Assemblyman Hamilton F. Potter had withdrawn as a candidate for the nomination to succeed himself.

Frank Murphy, who took leave of his post as Governor General of the Philippines to aid President Roosevelt by getting in the race for Governor of Michigan, called on James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, yesterday to assure him that President Roosevelt had better than an even chance of carrying Michigan.

PERPIGNAN, France, July 22. -- After eighteen hours of continuous and eventful traveling as a refugee this correspondent arrived here today and can now tell the story of what has occurred in Barcelona since civil war broke out there last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- An indictment charging John S. Farnsworth, former Lieutenant Commander of the navy, with "peacetime espionage," will be asked of the District of Columbia grand jury, it was decided today at a conference by officials of the Department of Justice, the Bureau of Investigation and the District of Columbia.

Offering will be made to the public today by a banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and including Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Cassatt Co., Inc.; W.H. Newbold's Sons Co. and Graham, Parsons Co., of a new issue of $13,827,000 of first-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Indianapolis Water Company.

TOPEKA, July 22. -- The Kansas Soil Erosion Law, passed in 1913, and amended in 1933 and 1935, during Governor Landon's administration, was invalidated in May by unanimous decision of the State Supreme Court.

The United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation reported yesterday that its consolidated net profit for the six months ended on June 30, after charges and taxes, amounted to $312,237, equal to $1.45 a share on 215,203 shares of common stock outstanding, excluding 7,000 shares in the company's treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- President Roosevelt set up today a Great Plains Drought Area Committee whose chief objective will be to develop a long-range program to rehabilitate the stricken region and prevent recurrence of disasters such as that now prevalent.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- The will of Arthur W. Cutten, grain speculator who once controlled a fortune estimated at $100,000,000, was filed today with the clerk of the Probate Court. According to a statement prepared by Dwight H. Green, attorney, the estate is now worth about $350,000.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- All first, second and third class postmasters, 13,730 in all, will be appointed hereafter under the merit system and subject to the regulations of the Civil Service Commission under the terms of an executive order promulgated by President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, July 22. -- The names of Senators and Assemblyman who will serve on joint legislative committees and commissions authorized by the recent Legislature were announced tonight by Senator Dunnigan, president pro tem. of the Senate, and Speaker Ives of the Assembly.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 22. -- Twenty-year-old Frankie Strafaci of Brooklyn, protege of Wiffy Cox when the latter presided over the tees at the Dyker Beach course, was shorn of his crown as national public links champion today.

VIENNA, July 22. -- In official circles tonight the general lines of the amnesty communique to be issued tomorrow were made available to the press. Of the persons affected there will be about three times as many Nazis as Socialists, the official explanation being that the main Socialist amnesty was granted last Christmas.

It was a few minutes before game time at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the second encounter of the series with the Cardinals was almost at hand but the Giants were still thinking of something else. For it was Eddie Brannick's forty-third birthday and, as in all baseball, there is perhaps no more popular official than the Giant secretary.

ST. PAUL, July 22 (AP). -- Denial from the witness stand that he aided the kidnappers he was assigned to hunt was the answer today of Tom Brown, former police chief here, to charges which led to his suspension from the Police Department after twenty-two years as a member.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Representative Bertrand H. Snell of New York, who will make the formal notification address to Governor Landon at Topeka tomorrow night, said in Chicago today that New York was headed for Landon and Knox.
TOPEKA, July 22. -- Mrs. Alf M. Landon does not intend to accompany her husband on any of his campaign trips, and will devote the time from now until the election to the care of her family.

Poor posture is the underlying cause of most of women's ills, it was declared yesterday in a symposium conducted at the fortieth annual convention of the American Osteopathic Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
PARIS, July 22 (AP). -- Labor threw its support tonight to the government in an attempt to induce striking farmhands to return to work before the wheat harvest.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries report a net income of $23,020,115 for the twelve months ended June 30 after all deductions, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $2.39 a share on 5,503,193 no-par common shares, compared to $24,543,267, or $2.67 a share, for the preceding year.

The House of the Modern Age, a prefabricated all-steel house at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. It will be open to the public today, a 10-cent admission fee going to the Boys Brotherhood Republic.

TRENTON, N.J., July 22. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman held up today the payment of $20,000 to Attorney General David T. Wilentz for serving as prosecutor in the Bruno Richard Hauptmann trial. The Governor directed the State Controller, Frank J. Murray, not to honor the Attorney General's application for the money, which had been included in the Appropriations Bill adopted by the State Legislature, because he wanted to "look over" the items listed in it.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP). -- Johnny Whitehead shaded Earl Whitehill in a twelve-inning pitching duel today and the White Sox evened the series with Washington with a 3-to-2 victory. Chicago moved into fourth place, displacing the Red Sox, with the victory.

The National Labor Relations Board in New York announced yesterday the result of a vote among the licensed engineers employed on various lines of the International Mercantile Marine Company to select a labor organization to represent them in negotiations with the employers.

Not even Van Lingle Mungo, who ran his season's strikout record to 122, could stop the champion Cubs at Ebbets Field yesterday and they moved a notch higher in the National League lead by beating the Dodgers again, 3 -- 2. Thus their lead over the second-place Cardinals is three games.
KANSAS CITY, July 22 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace tonight outlined a four-point program which he said might be useful in guarding the nation against future droughts.
GIBRALTAR, July 22. -- Insurgent airplanes from Spanish Morocco this afternoon and this evening bombed three Spanish warships, which replied with anti-aircraft guns.
