The share market closed generally lower yesterday for the first time since July 7, as many traders claimed profits. The profit-taking, which was moderate enough, considering the fact that the market had enjoyed the unusual situation of a fortnight of steadily rising prices, did not induce "important" selling.

At this time of year many a man, particularly he who is "portly, a friend of omnibuses," prefers to take his exercise by proxy. Let those who have the gift be active in sport. The adepts of comfort sit, like courts and Congresses. They don't even dare to take a walk. The action might be misinterpreted.

LONDON, July 22. -- Although rain threatened King Edward's second garden party, the reception was carried out without interruption at Buckingham Palace this afternoon. It was attended by about 1,200 and 500 debutantes were presented.

Development of a strong contra-seasonal demand for nearly all products at prices the firmest since the extinction of the NRA assures the steel industry the most satisfactory mid-Summer operations in years, The Iron Age said yesterday in its weekly summary.

LENOX, Mass., July 22. -- Charles Scoville Wishard of Washington was the honored guest at a birthday dinner party given at the Curtis Hotel, Lenox, tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Ray Foote Purdy of Toronto, who are spending the Summer at Mrs. William Penn Cresson's cottage, the Dormouse, at Stockbridge.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 22. -- America has no need to complain about lack of publicity for its Olympic team. The rest of the world, on the contrary, ought to be getting a little jealous. Germany is acting as if the American team were the whole show.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- Allotment of $1,768,202 to carry on women's sewing rooms, canneries, park developments and other activities under the WPA was approved today by Aubrey Williams, administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A supplemental report of transactions in equity securities of corporations by officers, directors and principal stockholders for May and previous months, published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, revealed many gifts, sales and purchases in earlier months, some of the listed changes in holdings going back to last Autumn and Winter.

A witness in the departmental trial of Frank Schettino, one of the twelve policemen charged with having paid money for preferment on the civil service sergeants list, was arrested on a charge of perjury yesterday at Brooklyn police headquarters after he attempted, on the witness stand, to exonerate the patrolman.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP). -- Johnny Moore hit three consecutive home runs today as the Phillies crushed the Pirates, 16 to 4, to even the series at one game apiece.

The Long Island Railroad has lost every battle. When the I.C.C. ordered a reduction in general passenger rates on the Eastern railroads to 2 cents a mile, the Long Island tried in splendid isolation to maintain its old rates. It did not yield an inch of territory except after each court fight.

HENDAYE, France, Thursday, July 23. -- The claim of the Spanish Government that the rebel troops are now everywhere on the run except in Saragossa, Valladolid and Seville, the capture of which was claimed last night, is not borne out by news reaching this frontier town.

TRENTON, July 22. -- Of the 409 law students who took the April examinations for admission as lawyers to the New Jersey bar, 183 passed and 226 failed to meet the requirements, it was announced at the State Board of Bar Examiners hers today.

MARION, Mass., July 22. -- Overcoming a 45-second lead in the last mile to leeward, John S. Lawrence's Moose won her second victory of the day to beat Alfred E. Chase's Viking for the President Franklin D. Roosevelt Bowl by 1 1/2 points today.

Blackie may be just a mite gray at the temples, but otherwise he is handsome of countenance and fine of physique, and he bowed graciously to every one of the hundred persons who attended his twenty-first birthday party yesterday.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, July 22. -- After a warning by the powers represented in the government of this internationalized zone, the Spanish rebels promised tonight to respect its neutrality.

ST. LOUIS, July 22. -- Those old tormentors, the Browns, gave another demonstration of how to put a thorn in the sides of our Yankees when Rogers Hornsby's crew slapped their third straight defeat on the McCarthymen at Sportsman's Park today and whittled the Yankee lead in the American League to seven games.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, July 22. -- The official announcement tonight of the warning to the Spanish rebels said the Italian president of the Committee of Control. Peter Philips de Rossi del Lion Nero, had pointed out that "any attempts of violation of the International Zone would meet opposition by force."

BOSTON, July 22 (AP). -- A five-run rally in the eighth inning enabled Cincinnati to defeat Boston, 7 to 4, today, with Paul Derringer registering his twelfth victory of the season. Jim Chaplin held the Reds to two hits until the eighth.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A final program providing for consideration of a broad range of subjects was adopted today for the Pan-American Conference at Buenos Aires by the governing board of the Pan American Union, but with recommendations that preference be given means for consolidating peace in the Western Hemisphere.

VIENNA, July 22. -- For the first time since the conclusion of the Austro-German agreement an official statement on behalf of the German Government was made today through Franz von Papen, the Reich Minister. The speech, delivered before the Vienna Anglo-American Press Association, was notable for its attack on Soviet Russia and the principle of collective security.

Governor Lehman wrote to Governor Hoffman of New Jersey yesterday urging him to reconsider his recent action in refusing to surrender to the New York authorities Ellis H. Parker Sr., the Burlington County (N.J.) detective, who is under indictment in Brooklyn for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel last February.

BERLIN, July 22. -- Smiling and hatless, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, accompanied by Mrs. Lindbergh, dropped out of a sunny sky on the Staaken military air field outside Berlin this afternoon for a week's visit to Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Air Minister Hermann Goering and German civil and military authorities.

Four Atlantic liners are sailing today for Europe with 5,270 passengers which, steamship agents said yesterday, is the largest number for this late in the season since the Summer of 1929. The Europa of the North German Lloyd has 1,700, the Ile de France of the French Line has 1,270, the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, 1,250, and the Britannic of the same company has 1,127.

Affiliation of the People's party, formed recently by right-wing Socialists headed by Louis Waldman after the split which resulted in their exit from the Socialist party, with the newly formed Labor party of Labor's Nonpartisan League was advanced yesterday following a conference of a committee representing the Waldman group with representatives of the Labor party.

HELENA, Mont., July 22 (AP). -- Senator James E. Murray appeared virtually assured tonight of the Democratic nomination for re-election with a lead of more than 8,000 over Representative Joseph P. Monaghan. Returns from 829 of 1,237 precincts gave Murray 37,291 votes; Monaghan, 29,009.

The reports of the first seven railroads to issue earnings statements for June indicated that the gains made by the roads in the early months of the year were continuing. This group earns about 15 per cent of the aggregate revenues of Class I lines and about 19 per cent of total operating income.

BOSTON, July 22. -- Taking the lead at the half-mile mark, Sonny Workman's favorite spot for jumping his field, Time Supply today rushed on to a decisive victory in the $32,500 Massachusetts Handicap as 40,000 racing fans looked on.

Earl Beatty, son of the late Admiral of the British Navy, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for a short visit with friends and relatives. It is his first trip to America since he succeeded to the title. Previously he was Viscount Borodale.
WITH REBEL HEADQUARTERS IN NORTHERN SPAIN NEAR VERA, July 22. -- Raging battles, with scores of dead and wounded, were reported tonight to leaders of the northern wing of Spain's rebel army.

A marked upswing in advertising expenditures by corporations this Fall as the result of the new tax laws was predicted last night by Dr. Orestes H. Caldwell, trustee of the Museum of Science and Industry, Radio City, and editor of Radio Today, at a meeting at the museum sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22. -- This was young salts' day on the program of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week. The Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound held its eleventh annual regatta and the racing craft were skippered and crewed by boys and girls who had not reached their eighteenth birthdays.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 22. -- After a day of rest play was resumed in the international chess masters' tournament at the Grand Hotel today, and five of the six scheduled games were concluded.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 22. -- A score of S1, five over women's par for the round, gave Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, New York State champion, the low gross prize in the Long Island Women's Golf Association weekly one-day event at the Creek Club today.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 22. -- As striking employes of the RCA Manufacturing Company applied for their old jobs today on the basis of the settlement reached yesterday afternoon, Judge Frank F. Neutze of Quarter Sessions Court continued to fix high bail for prisoners accused of inciting to riot during the last days of the strike.

In the Spanish struggle, quarter is being neither asked nor given. The toll of killed and wounded is already larger than that of all the other armed conflicts of revolutionary and counter-revolutionary forces in Middle and Western Europe since the war. The priceless and irreplaceable heritage of the beauties of Seville, Toledo, Avila, Burgos, Granada and Madrid are being heedlessly endangered by artillery fire and bombings.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP). -- Federal Judge George H. Moore late today freed the Missouri Pacific Railroad from a $19,000,000 debt. He ruled that the road was not liable for that amount, which represents the unpaid part of the purchase price of terminal facilities at Kansas City and St. Joseph, Mo.

GIBRALTAR, Thursday, July 23. -- British authorities early today warned the commanders of Spanish warships that the guns of Gibraltar, one of the world's mightiest fortresses, were ready for instant action.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange approved yesterday the applications of thirteen companies to list securities, constituting one of the largest accretions to the Curb's list in several years. Of the total, ten were original applications, two were for additional listings and one a substitution for a security already listed.

The Transit Commission granted yesterday the application of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad for an increase in its intracity passenger rate to ten cents. The new rate, replacing the old seven-cent charge, becomes effective at once.

More than 5,000 persons, mostly children, attended a safety pageant last night at Roosevelt Park, Rivington, Forsyth and Chrystie Streets. The program was one of several that are planned to promote safety, decrease accidents, improve street cleanliness and give recreation.

ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, at Sea, July 22. -- Terming the 1936 United States Olympians the best-behaved squad ever sent abroad, A very Brundage, president of the American Olympic committee, gave an account of his stewardship to the American public today as the squad approached Hamburg and its Olympic goal.

BERLIN, July 22. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reich bank, was spending the day at the house in Hamburg of his friend the ship owner, Rudolf Blom. He sat at a great desk, his back to the window, through which one could see a magnificent panorama of Hamburg's lake and churches, hotels and villas.

BERLIN, July. -- Reich church Minister Hanns Kerrl was reported today to have issued instructions to all Reich and local authorities to break off all relations with the provisional administration of the Confessional movement within the German Protestant Church -- which stands in opposition to the official Protestant Church government appointed by Mr. Kerrl.

At a meeting featured by the declaration that the near future affords "the greatest opportunity in the history of the country for the sale of home furnishings," the Housewares, China and Glassware Buyers' Group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was formally organized yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Representative William Lemke, Presidential candidate of the Union party, criticized the policies and political methods of the New Deal in a luncheon address at the National Press Club today, at the same time deriding Democratic claims of national prosperity.

Consideration of the proposal that its lines be taken over by a State-created Long Island Transit Authority was urged upon the Long Island Railroad yesterday by Maurice Hotchner, counsel for the Association of Long Island Commuters.

Exploitation of relief recipients by employers who hire them for part-time work at low wages has reached the proportions of an organized system in this city, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday at the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park.

Hollywood reports that the film version of "Winterset" will move into production in the RKO studios today, with two replacements in its cast. Lionel Barrymore, who was to have had the role of the judge, was recalled by his home studio, Metro, and Edward Ellis will take the part. Stanley Ridges of "Crime Without Passion" and "The Scoundrel'' has been substituted for John Beal.

After a slight improvement in early trading, prices on the Cotton Exchange declined nearly $1 a bale yesterday and ended with losses of 10 to 17 points. Although drought in Oklahoma has been relieved only in part and the crop there is reported to be deteriorating, progress in several States induced profit-taking.

ALBANY, July 22 (AP). -- Representatives of various groups interested in State legislation spent more than $100,000 during the 1936 legislative session, according to records of lobbyists' expenditures filed with the Secretary of State.
CLEVELAND, July 22 (AP). -- Johnny Allen's pitching and nineteen hits, two of them home runs, gave the Indians an 8-to-3 victory over the Red Sox today and tightened the Tribe's grip on second place.

Hollywood reports that the film version of "Winterset" will move into production in the RKO studios today, with two replacements in its cast. Lionel Barrymore, who was to have had the role of the judge, was recalled by his home studio, Metro, and Edward Ellis will take the part. Stanley Ridges of "Crime Without Passion" and "The Scoundrel'' has been substituted for John Beal.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- The hog market was somewhat erratic here today, with better grades steady to 10 cents a hundreweight higher, while other kinds were as much as 10 cents lower, the latter on some rough packing sows. Buyers were more particular than of late and sorting was severe.

LONDON, July 22. -- Secretary Roper told THE NEW YORK TIMES today that in the passenger list of the liner Manhattan, upon which he arrived last night, was the best possible proof that America never before had been so "ship conscious."

PURCHASE, N.Y., July. 22. -- Learning that her seven-stroke advantage of the previous day had vanished completely at the turn of the final round, Mrs. Jonathan Thorne of Innis Arden rallied brilliantly as she played the last nine holes at the Century Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Regulations governing the unlisted trading privileges of securities on national Securities Exchanges, including those now having that status and those which will become eligible when amendments to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, adopted by the last Congress, become effective on Aug. 25 and Nov. 27, were issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, July 22. -- Sir Samuel Hoarse, First Lord of the Admiralty, speaking tonight before the Empire Parliamentary Association on British sea power, dropped a hint to Japan that she need not consider the new British naval base at Singapore as a menace.
HAWORTH, N. J., July 22. -- The resonant old fire gongs of North Jersey hung particularly silent this morning and the hush spread ominously toward the misty moors of the south.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER LIBERTY OFF WEDGEPORT, N.S., July 22. -- President Roosevelt anchored the schooner Sewanna in the Tusket River at its mouth on the Bay of Fundy tonight after a day of lazy sailing, in which he covered only thirty miles in eight hours.
A wide variety of realty in scattered sections of Manhattan, from downtown to Washington Heights, figured in yesterday's activity.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, yesterday bought in at foreclosure the sixteen-story building at 66 West Forty-seventh Street, on a plot 118 by 100.5 feet near Sixth Avenue, on a bid of $450,000. The property was offered by James R. Murphy, petitioneer, in an action by the trustee against the 66 West Forty-seventh Street Corporation.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 22. -- Mrs. Frederick Bronaugh gave a luncheon at the Hedges today. Mrs. Edward McCoy was a dinner hostess there. Mr. and Mrs. Frank Benjamin have arrived at the Hedges.

A bequest of $1,000,000 to the Assistance Fund, Inc., of 60 Beaver Street, for charitable purposes, was disclosed yesterday, when the will of Aaron E. Norman, merchant, philanthropist and former president of Sears, Roebuck Co., was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court. The value of his estate was not disclosed.

Mixed conditions prevailed yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, with trading in general fairly inactive and bringing no important changes. On the cash markets corn and copper reached new high levels and wheat, rye, tin, silk and hides advanced.

LONDON, July 22. -- The pleasant social tea party and conversation of Britain, France and Belgium at 10 Downing Street tomorrow, which British diplomacy has evolved -- or thinks it has -- out of the somewhat threatening preliminary gathering of flouted Locarno powers, seems likely to be only a one-day affair and harmless.

When Mary Margaret McBride, writer, lecturer and radio commentator, stepped down the gang-plank of the Ile de France Tuesday, she had Pierrot on a leash. He was a snow-white Angora goat, with a ruffled collar of blue organdie and a blue felt hat with a white feather.

A special checking department designed to meet the needs of individuals and requiring no minimum average balance has been opened by the National City Bank of New York, it became known yesterday. The new services, which were begun on July 15, are provided in all branches of the National City except at the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- An American woman was reported to have been wounded in fighting this morning at Guadarrama, about thirty miles northwest of Madrid, Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the United States Embassy at Madrid, informed the State Department in a dispatch tonight.
Edmund W. Olifiers is now manager of the corporate trading department of E.P. Frazee Co.

Ado Spoldi halted the comeback aspirations of Jackie (Kid) Berg, veteran English boxer, at Ebbets Field last night. The hard-hitting-Italian warrior stopped his rival in the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout.

Ado Spoldi halted the comeback aspirations of Jackie (Kid) Berg, veteran English boxer, at Ebbets Field last night. The hard-hitting-Italian warrior stopped his rival in the second round of a scheduled ten-round bout.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 22. -- While hunger marchers, making their third invasion of Harrisburg during the present special session, heckled legislators, bathed babies in the Capitol rotunda and hung out the family wash on marble statues of Boies Penrose and Matthew Stanley Quay, Pennsylvania's deadlock on unemployment relief continued today.

Mayor La Guardia ordered out the police yesterday afternoon to stop Park Commissioner Robert Moses, as a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority, from tearing down the municipal ferry terminal at Ninety-second Street and the East River, Manhattan, and from tearing up the street in front of it to make room for the East River drive approaching the bridge.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Important changes in the bigger personnel of the Public Works Administration were announced today by Secretary Ickes. The changes affect four divisions, the most important being the designation of Angelo R. Clas as assistant to the administrator, in charge of all investigations, with particular attention to construction methods and practices.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- John S. Farnsworth, former lieutenant commander in the navy, was indicted for "peace-time" espionage by the District of Columbia grand jury today in connection with the sale of confidential information to the Japanese Government.
JERUSALEM, July 23. -- Arabs threw a bomb at Jewish children leaving a school in Tel-Aviv today, wounding six, ranging in ages from 8 to 11. Two were sent to a hospital.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- A miniature dust storm blew over Kansas and surrounding States today, kicked up by the wheels of countless autos bringing Republicans to Topeka to meet their candidate for the Presidency.

Because of the serious situation for foreigners in Barcelona through the civil war in Spain the American Export liner Exeter, which arrived at Marseilles yesterday, was ordered to proceed to Barcelona and evacuate the American refugees, at the request of the State Department.

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador and noted attorney, had to be reminded sharply by his law partner yesterday by shore-to-ship telephone that he was in danger of losing his vote if he persisted in pursuing his first course in the "big bet controversy" with LeGrand B. Cannon.
TOPEKA, July 23 (AP). -- Notification day was just one dress change after another for Mrs. Landon.

Formal organization of a Major Electrical Appliance Group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association was proposed at a meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Edward List, manager of the electrical appliance department of Abraham Straus, Inc., was elected to serve as chairman of the group and reported tentative plans to coordinate the section with the Housewares, China and Glasswares Buyers' Group which was formed on Wednesday.

TRENTON, July 23. -- State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. said today that he would appoint an advisory council of twelve members to plan for enforcement of New Jersey's Minimum Wage Law adopted several years ago. There will be four persons representing labor, four representing employers and four representing the public on the council.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 23. -- Wages of all New Zealand workers were restored to pre-depression levels today with the passage of a Laborite act restoring wage cuts in State service and private industry, retroactive to July 1. The workers had expected increased back pay to March.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Harmonious relations and an end to friction are sought under an agreement to join in a freight rate association signed by thirteen intercoastal shipping interests and submitted for approval to the regulation department of the Shipping Board Bureau.

Edward H. Shelubov, the patrolman who claimed the four $100 bills found in an assembly room at police headquarters on May 28, went on trial for his job yesterday after having smashed the camera of a photographer who tried to make his picture in a headquarters hallway.

THE habit of collecting is a strange one, and its devotees follow strange paths. One man I know, for example, has gathered together a complete, file of a scandalous and short-lived weekly published more or less sub rosa in this city some years ago and presented the whole, with a profound bow, to one of the most austere libraries in the country.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- Preparing to give effect to legislation setting up a broad new ship subsidy program, President Roosevelt was represented in informed circles today as being almost ready to appoint a five-member maritime commission.

Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, warned 600 educators attending a Summer session conference on school administration at the university yesterday that unionization of teachers and school employes might lead to control of education by that "minority of people that belong to organized labor."

ST. PAUL, July 23 (AP). -- Returned from a tour of the Dakotas-Montana-Wyoming drought sector, Federal Resettlement Administrator Rexford G. Tugwell reported today that he found conditions "in some respects worse than in 1934."

Herbert L. Carpenter, a Brooklyn banker who has been in close contact with City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. in transit unification negotiations, wrote to Mayor La Guardia yesterday expressing his approval of Mr. Berle as a candidate for Aldermanic President.

The active buying and heavy attendance which have characterized home furnishings trade shows here this week gave no signs of abating yesterday. Contracts for immediate and later delivery were reported from housewares manufacturers exhibiting at the Hotel Pennsylvania, lamp producers at the Hotel New Yorker and furniture manufacturers who are showing Fall lines at the New York Furniture Exchange.
Newspaper comment on Governor Landon's speech of acceptance is for the most part favorable, as shown in the following extracts from editorials sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, July 23. -- Another link in the chain of Anglo-American good-will manifestations was added here today at a luncheon of the Pilgrims in honor of Secretary Daniel C. Roper and W.A. Julian, Treasurer of the United States.

A new issue of $30,000,000 New York Edison Company, Inc., first-lien and refunding mortgage per cent bonds, series E, due in 1966, is to be offered today by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., at 102 and accrued interest, to yield 3.14 per cent to the nearest date at which the bonds are callable at par.

LONDON, July 23. -- Grim by-play to the pleasant Locarno conversations in Downing Street occurred this afternoon and this evening in Leon Blum's room at the Hotel Savoy, where, snatching minutes during the interval beween official proceedings and afterward, the French Premier gave an audience to representatives specially sent to him by the Spanish Government in Madrid.

To enable policemen to familiarize themselves with the appearance of marijuana, pots of the narcotic weed have been placed on exhibition during the past few days in the assembly rooms of station houses in various sections of Brooklyn.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- Governor Landon is a speaker without gestures and with few of the tricks of the orator. When he stood before the throng gathered here tonight, he spoke simply, with his hands sometimes at his sides, sometimes resting on the lectern and sometimes fumbling with his coat.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- The Works Progress Administration today reported that 2,231,117 persons were employed on WPA projects in the week ending July 11.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 23. -- Little Pat, bay gelding by Hollyrood Bob, owned by Homer Biery of Butler, Pa., and driven by Charles Lacey of Cleveland, won the $3,900 Village Farm stake for 3-year-old pacers, feature event on today's Grand Circuit card at Historic Track.

Mrs. N.E. Doyle's Hoops, which had failed to finish in the money in his two previous starts, came back to his best form yesterday and led home a field of four starters in the mile and a sixteenth test which featured the racing at Empire City.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23. -- The arrest in East Chicago, Ind., of a young servant girl, who is said to have climbed out of a second story window of a residence in South Amboy, N.J., Sunday night, escaping with $10,000 in cash, jewelry and negotiable bonds, while her employers sat in another room, was announced by police here today.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 23. -- With half of the time he has allowed himself already gone, Sheriff Laurence E. Brown still insisted tonight that he is near the arrest of a suspect in the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger.

ALBANY, July 23. -- Governor Lehman set up an unofficial commission of experts today to study the subject of two cattle ailments, Bang's disease and mastitis. Recommendations based on the commission's findings are to be presented to the Legislature next Winter.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP). -- Bob Smith, the 38-year-old pitcher-coach, returned to active duty today and held the Reds to five hits as the Bees scored a 4-0 victory. It was the home team's first triumph in four starts.

The passenger list of the Hamburg American liner Hamburg, due to arrive today from the Channel ports, includes John Hoffman and Mrs. Hoffman, Dr. Werner Neibuhr, Helmuth Baur, Bernhard Lippert, attache at the German Consulate in New York; Dr. and Mrs. James Barrett Brown, Mrs. M.B. Hanscom, Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Barnes, Richard F. Hirsch, Dr. Georg Leisewitz, and seventy-one German tourists coming to see industrial centers.

Had CHARLES A. LINDBERGH deliberately set out to shock his fellow-men into a realization of the menace they are preparing for themselves and their children he could not have chosen an occasion better suited to his purpose than yesterday in Berlin. Breaking his long silence on public questions, he dramatically warned his hosts and the rest of the world of the potential destructiveness of military aviation.

TRENTON, July 23. -- Companies incorporated in New Jersey which remove their assets to another State in an effort to dodge taxes in this State were sharply criticized by the State Board of Tax Appeals in a decision made public here today.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 23. -- The almost uninterrupted march of Robert L. Riggs through the tennis tournaments of the Middle West and the East carried him into his seventh successive final today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23. -Eight more craft than ever have crossed a starting line in a regatta on Long Island Sound competed today in the race week series of the Larchmont Yacht Club. The record, 285, was established last year. This afternoon there were 293.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- Governor Landon started off today fresh and rested, happy and seemingly carefree. But only stern reminders on the part of his advisers kept him from getting all worn out before the day was over.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Virtually all the native Americans in Madrid, numbering more than 100, have taken refuge in the United States Embassy and the situation in the Spanish capital is becoming "very serious," Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the embassy, reported to the State Department in a dispatch sent at midnight, Spanish time.

TALLADEGA, Ala., July 23 (AP). -- National Guardsmen patrolled this strife-torn cotton textile center today while civil authorities made wholesale arrests as a result of a gun battle in which Deputy Sheriff John J. Bryant was slain and eighteen persons were wounded.

After drifting in uncertain fashion in the forenoon, the share market steadied yesterday under the leadership of the steel issues in the late trading and closed irregularly higher. The steels advanced fractions to 2 7/5 points. Railway stocks, as a group, did fairly well early and retained most of the gains through to closing, with the result that THE NEW YORK TIMES average of twenty-five carrier stocks established a new high record for the year.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- Republican leaders from all parts of the country, members of the national committee and the notification committee met today at luncheon in the roof garden of the Hotel Jayhawker, gave Governor Landon, nominee for President, an enthusiastic reception, and expressed a general conviction that the tide had turned against President Roosevelt and the New Deal and that there was every indication of a Republican national victory in November.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- Home State pride and Midwestern loyalty to a home-grown product united tonight to give Governor Landon a genuine ovation when he stepped out on a platform on the south steps of the State House to make his speech accepting the Republican nomination for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Objecting to the same men being named trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company and the Old Colony Railroad Company, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation received permission today from the Interstate Commerce Commission to present this opposition during the reorganization proceedings of the New Haven.

With Governor LANDON'S aspirations for the future of the United States, as outlined broadly last night in his speech of acceptance, all good citizens will be in active sympathy. The social and economic ills he enumerates call for remedy; and the spirit in which he offers to set them right, the restraint and modesty with which he takes up his responsibility, will have a widespread and merited appeal.

VATICAN CITY, July 23. -- Possible disciplinary action against Father Charles E. Coughlin in connection with his political activities tonight awaited the arrival in Rome of Bishop Michael Gallagher of Detroit.

Handicapped by the punctual rise of the incoming tide, 250 WPA workers were still busy on the east shore of Staten Island for a few hours yesterday building a boardwalk on a site which is under water at high tide.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- A new and stronger movement by the Federal Government and importers to protect the American market against cheap imitations of foreign liquors was believed to have been foreshadowed by the issuance today of a regulation regarding the labeling of American-made Scotch whisky.

Pleas of not guilty to charges of extortion and attempted extortion were entered in General Sessions yesterday for Jerome A. Jacobs and Harry S. Hechheimer, lawyers, and Raymond Derringer, a former motion picture operator, on the complaint of Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, motion picture actress.
TOKYO, July 23. -- Tokyo was plunged into total darkness tonight in the culminating phase of the annual air defense exercises, which began Monday on a larger scale than ever.
DETROIT, July 23. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, radio priest, today made public an apology he has written to President Roosevelt for having called the President a "liar" in a recent speech.

DANZIG, July 23. -- Bishop O'Rourke, Danzig Catholic prelate, defied the Nazi Senate's ban on political criticism of the Free City's government in a vigorous pastoral letter read in all churches and published yesterday in the Volkszeitung, the only surviving Opposition newspaper.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- President Roosevelt has ordered a curtailment of the investigating activities of various Federal agencies, according to reports in administration circles.

Mrs. Harriet J. Robinson, middle-aged stock broker, sought by the police for the last ten days on charges of having defrauded six clients of more than $250,000, was arrested last night in Fairfield, Conn., as a fugitive from justice.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 23. -- Germany's great pre-Olympics show, the magnified World Congress for Leisure and Recreation, hailed here as the largest of all international congresses, got away to a rousing propagandist start today.

Sales of copper in the domestic market on Wednesday were estimated yesterday in the trade at 25,409 tons. This brings total sales for the first twenty-two days in July in the domestic market to about 170,454 tons, the largest for any month on record.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The Republican National Committee issued a statement tonight terming President Roosevelt's order making all future postmastership appointments subject to civil service examination "an obvious concession to the public opinion which has arisen in all parts of the country to condemn the New Deal application of the spoils system."

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Leaders of organized labor, commenting tonight on Governor Landon's acceptance speech, criticized it as favoring company unions, asserted that he talked "the industrial language of the Nineties," and declared the speech full of "weasel words" and vague statements.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company yesterday reported for the six months ended on June 30 a consolidated net income of $5,279,363, after all charges, reserves and taxes, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to 60 cents a share on the 5,688,717 no-par common shares outstanding.

L'affaire Pierrot, involving a goat, the Bureau of Animal Husbandry, the French Line, the United States Customs and Mary Margaret McBride, writer, lecturer and radio commentator, had its denouement yesterday. The curtain went down on the brief episode amid few tears, some lukewarm recriminations and few scientific discussions on the goat as a carrier of disease.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23. -- The famous one second finish between Rainbow and Yankee during the America's Cup trials off here in 1934 was duplicated this afternoon between the Weetamoe and Yankee in the fourth race of the series being held this week between the three Class J sloops under the auspices of the New York Yacht Club.

Commissioner Goldwater's latest report on the overcrowded condition of the city hospitals is an eye-opener. It furnishes striking corroboration of the old and embarrassing truth that chronically ill persons are still being cast into the hopper of an unclassified hospital service, notwithstanding Dr. Goldwater's heroic remedial efforts.

BERLIN, July 23. -- In a speech that broke his own traditional reticence and far exceeded the framework of the usual exchange of international courtesies, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today warned the world the airplane had become such a powerful weapon of destruction that it had revolutionized modern warfare and stripped the armor from every nation in war.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, financing subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, is actively engaged with Morgan Stanley Co. and other investment bankers in drafting a refunding program under which part of its short-term debts to banks would be converted into a large debenture issue.
TOPEKA, July 23. -- Following is the text of the address of Governor Landon in accepting the Republican nomination for President:

Paramount Pictures, Inc. reported yesterday in its tentative financial statement for the second quarter, an estimated net loss of $476,000 after drawing $800,000 from a special reserve established at the end of 1935, to cover losses anticipated on certain film productions. In the corresponding quarter a year ago, the company reported an estimated net income of $796,000.

PITTSBURGH, July 23. -- Business in the Pittsburgh district showed a little improvement last week according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The index adjusted for seasonal changes and for trend advanced from 93.2 in the week ended July 11 to 93.9 last week.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 23 (AP). -- This little university town tomorrow will turn back to its crinoline days of 100 years ago for a two-day celebration honoring William Holmes McGuffey, a local professor who compiled the MeGuffey Readers which played so large a part in educating pioneer America.

Two men were found dead in the Rockaways early yesterday morning, both believed to have been victims of hit-and-run drivers. One motorist was arrested later and held without bail and the police are searching for another.

The effectiveness of the warranty proposed by the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., to have the seller guarantee the originality of design of his merchandise was disputed yesterday at the hearing on this matter before the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway.

LONDON, July 23. -- The House of Commons demonstrated today that it cannot sit up all night without losing its temper. After being in continuous session for twenty-eight hours debating the government's measure for assisting the unemployed, there was a disturbance unequaled since the Eighties when on one occasion the whole Irish party was suspended by the Speaker and had to be dragged from the House by the police.

A king of the cannibal islands, with a shock of kinky hair stylishly aureoled about his head and brandishing a war club and a warrior's shield, was loose in New York yesterday. But the blase citizenry peered suspiciously at his bare legs and the singlet he wears instead of trousers, and demanded, yawning, "What's he advertising?"

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 23. -- Three colorful players from the Atlantic seaboard and a capable Californian swept into the semi-finals of the fifteenth annual national public links championship over the rigorous blue course of the Beth-page State park Golf Club.
GIBRALTAR, July 23 (AP). -- Spanish Fascists, whose war planes sent steel splinters whistling into Gibraltar, accepted tonight a British ultimatum to prevent further damage on the Rock.
TOPEKA, Kan., July 23. -- The notification address of Representative Bertrand H. Snell was as follows:

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- That long overdue artillery fire by the Yankees echoed today over Sportsman's Park as the McCarthymen hammered themselves free of their longest losing streak of the year and battered four of the Browns' hurlers to win by 15 to 3.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 23 (AP). -- Government land and air forces concentrated forceful attacks on rebel strongholds in Saragossa tonight.

It is no injustice to attribute to Republican criticism the newly discovered zeal of the Democratic party for the civil service. That is the way things frequently happen in American politics. One party grows lax in some respect. The other opens fire on it. The first party then hastily re-forms its lines.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The Civil Service Commission stated today that President Roosevelt's order placing all first, second, and third class postmasters under civil service "goes far beyond any previous one in applying the principles of the merit system to these appointments."

May we ask readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES to consider what 102-degree heat does to babies and little children sweltering in the tenements of the lower West Side? Night and day they are the victims of merciless heat, seeking a breath of air on the fire-escapes, in areaways -- anywhere to escape from the broiling streets and the sizzling tenement rooms.
PARIS, July 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- William W. Swift of Tennessee has been appointed to help Commissioner Robert E. Healy in presiding over the public hearings in connection with the investigation into investment trusts and companies by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which start next Monday, it was announced today.

BERLIN, July 23. -- The upward movement on the Boerse was interrupted today by a widespread reaction that depressed prices to the extent of 2 to 3 points. A few specialties continued strong, notably Aku, which gained nearly 4 points, and shares of department stores, which profited from the expanding purchasing power.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- With estimates on the wheat crop in Canada being steadily lowered and trade estimates commencing to center around 240,000,000 bushels for all Provinces, considerably more attention is being paid to the world situation.

The dollar continued yesterday to better its position in terms of most leading currencies. The, demand from Paris for dollars was again feature of a quiet market. The franc declined 5/8 point to 6.613-16 cents, and the other gold currencies were down in sympathy, the guilder 8 points to 67.98 cents and the Swiss franc 2 points to 32.70 cents.

HENDAYE, Franco-Spanish Border, July 23. -- Even after discounting the more obvious optimism of both rebel and government quarters in Spain, it appears that the government forces are now on the offensive generally and, apart from holding Madrid and Barcelona, have gained the upper hand in Guadalajara, Almeria, Gijon and Toledo.
REBEL HEADQUARTERS AT PAMPLONA, Spain, July 23 (AP). -- Spain's northern rebel army settled down tonight for a long, slow military campaign to drive the Leftist government from power.

A correspondent mentions that what was "under the table" more than what was on it caused nervousness among the three Powers gathered in London yesterday. Every recent international conference has been marked by the same anxious effort to keep the lid on. The one characteristic of each successive meeting is that it is always "preliminary," held for no better reason than to be adjourned until the next. The real business is constantly postponed.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23. -Melville Smith and his nephew, Lesueur Smith Jr., of Pelham dropped out from among the leaders in the Larchmont Yacht Club's yacht race in Long Island Sound this afternoon to rescue a boy who had taken a sailing dinghy out alone to watch the races and had capsized in the choppy water.
Governor Landon's speech of acceptance of the Republican nomination for President was hailed here last night by party leaders as a clear-cut expression of "American and party principles."

Belated covering of July obligations before trading ceases in the contract at noon today brought an advance of 1/4 cent in the near month on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, ending with prices unchanged to 5 points higher. Notices for 2,800 bales were circulated, but demand for July contracts beeam, so urgent that the spot month went to a premium of almost a cent over October at one time.

WASHINGTON, July 23 . -- Payrolls in manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries rose in June, continuing the rise which began in January, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today to Secretary Perkins.

A legal problem arising from the confessed thefts by a trusted employe of the Matteawan Manufacturing Company, who was also an officer of the Midnight Mission, which involved both in four years' litigation with the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, has just been solved by a decision of the Court of Appeals.

MADRID, July 23 (Passed by the Censor). -- Spain's economic structure caused the civil war. There are in this country only two extremes, great concentrated wealth and extensive poverty, with nothing in between.

BOSTON, July 23. -- Ruling that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration had no power to regulate agricultural products within a State, Federal Judge Elisha H. Brewster today denied an injunction asked by the AAA against more than a score of milk dealers in the Boston area accused of violating a Boston milk marketing agreement.
The WPA Living Newspaper's "Injunction Granted!" will open tonight at the Biltmore after six postponements.
CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP). -- The Red Sox stacked up seven runs in the fourth inning today and took the last game of their series with Cleveland, 9 to 8.
Two large apartment houses were among properties in Manhattan taken over by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday.

ALBANY, July 23. -- Dr. Francis E. Townsend told an audience of more than 1,000 persons here tonight that a move for a constitutional amendment for his $200-a-month old-age pension plan would be started after the November elections.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 23. -- Mayor W. Burdell Banister and other prominent residents of this town condemned today the sculptured figure of a soldier designed for the top of a Spanish-American War memorial to be erected in Summerfield Park here.

SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 23.Honors were more or less divided between the stables of Mrs. H. R. Benson of Princeton, N. J., and the Raymar Farm, owned by Mrs. Martin L. Cohn Jr. of Elberon, N. J., as the first annual Jersey Shore horse show opened on the windswept and spacious Boxwood Farm grounds today.

Higher prices for the grains and livestock sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices 0.8 point higher for the week ended on Tuesday, the index rising to 125.1 from 124.3 [revised] the Tuesday previous. Besides higher prices for wheat, corn and flour, and for steers, hogs, lambs and lard, gains were made by butter, coffee, cocoa, lemons, copper and zinc.

An increase of $70,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System is reported for the week ended on Wednesday, lifting the total to 2,990,000,000. The gain the week before was $40,000,000. The increase this week is due in part to further retirement of money previously put into circulation through the cashing of the veterans' bonus checks.

MADRID, July 23. -- General Emilio Mola's rebel forces in Northern Spain, which had been reported advancing on the capital, were driven back eight miles from Somo Sierra, in the mountains north of Madrid, today. While retreating, they cut telephone communications.

LONDON, July 23. -- In one of the shortest conferences between statesmen within remembrance, a complete agreement upon calling together the five Locarno powers as a first step in an effort of all European nations to "consolidate peace by means of a general settlement" was reached at today's three-power meeting in Downing Street.

Food manufacturers cannot "knowingly and confidently" comply with the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price-Discrimination Act "unless and until its doubtful terms have been interpreted by the Federal Trade Commission for the purposes of its enforcement," it was announced yesterday by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.

When one of our Reserve systems raises deposit reserve requirements, and at the same time our other reserve system, bearing the incognito of Reconstruction Finance Corporation, lowers them, both laymen and experts will be puzzled over the meaning of the deep hocus-pocus.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23. -- A1though the national open polo championship will not be started for more than a month, two sides of high-goal players began preparations for the event by engaging in a fast practice match to feature today's activity at the Meadow Brook Club.

His head crushed by four blows which had been struck from behind with some heavy weapon, Morris Florea, a city marshal, widely known in Harlem for thirty years, was found fatally injured in his office across the street from Harlem court yesterday morning.

Declines were the rule yesterday in more active trading in local commodity futures markets. Hides and coffee were strong. In the cash markets wheat, oats, hides and eggs advanced, while cotton, corn, silk, rubber and tins declined.

ZANDVOORT, THE NETHERLANDS, July 23. -- Pitted against Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, Reuben Fine of New York was successful in drawing his game in the fifth round of the international masters tournament at the Grand Hotel tonight.

LONDON, July 23. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange continued today in a cheerful atmosphere, although business became more quiet because of the approaching holidays. British funds were among the firmest groups, new issues being rapidly absorbed.

MADRID, Friday, July 24. -- The Spanish Government, harassed by rebels in both north and south, announced in an early morning broadcast today that the revolters were "withdrawing in all parts of Spain" and that "every hour brings a new victory."

The importance of periodic examination of the body structure for the protection of growing children and of athletes in active competition was emphasized in two symposiums yesterday at the fortieth annual convention of the American Osteopathic Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Mayor La Guardia named Paul J. Kern, his legal assistant, yesterday as a Municipal Civil Service Commissioner and filled two vacancies on the bench.
DETROIT, July 23. -- Father Coughlin commenting on his open letter of apology to President Roosevelt, said today:
NEWARK, N.J., July 23. -- The Bears gained an even break in their series with Montreal when they defeated the Royals today, 5 to 1, behind the effective pitching of Spurgeon Chandler.

Rain falls alike on the just and the unjust. Drought takes its toll of laissez-faire economics in our arid West and of planned economics in Soviet Russia. From the Soviet capital Mr. DENNY reports an acute food shortage.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Hogs generally sold 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight higher here today in the face of larger receipts, and some sales of desirable butchers were regarded as much as 25 cents higher. The top prime was up 5 cents from yesterday's level at $11.10, while the average was 10 cents higher at $9.85.

In making provision for overtime pay and for a basic forty-eight-hour week, the steel industry, it is believed in Wall Street, is looking to the future. Already, with operations at 70 per cent of capacity, the industry is employing 500,000 workers -- more than ever before in peacetime.

A farewell dinner was given by Mrs. Harden L. Crawford in theI Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for her son-in-law and daugh-I ter, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Ballantine, who left later on the Europa. Other guests vere Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Borden, Mr. and Mrs. Harden L. Crawford Jr., Mr. and rrs. C. Clay Crawford and Miss Julia L. Crawford.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP). -- Officers who took Dayton Dean, confessed Black Legion "executioner," to a marsh near Pinckney, Mich., today, said upon their return tonight they had considered the possibility of draining a pond there. They denied Dean had told them seven bodies would be found in the marsh, however, as reported earlier in the day.

Flags of thirteen foreign nations flew side by side yesterday morning as 1,300 children from the Daily Vacation Bible Schools throughout the city gathered at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine for the second annual special service dedicated to peace.

The automobile industry's 1935 operations, both from the viewpoint of the number of units produced and the value of output, were at a level almost 200 per cent above the depression bottom of 1932, it is shown in the 1936 edition of Automobile Facts and Figures, annual publication of the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

Newspapers should show sharp gains in motion-picture linage, if the policy followed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, following the opening of "San Francisco" is adopted by other film producers, Donahue Coe, advertising agency handling the M.-G.-M account, pointed our yesterday.

With most of the interest centered in women's wear lines for Fall, trading in the wool goods markets was moderately active this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. While mills are reported maintaining operations, there is some disposition by manufacturers to resist current wool prices, and "some fears exist that present or advanced wool prices might tend to decrease consumption somewhat," it is stated.

A uniform arrangement for overtime compensation was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation for the second time in its history. The plan, to become effective on Aug. 1, will concern about 150,000 of its 220,000 employes.
LONDON, July 23. -- The rating committee and the underwriters of Lloyd's today announced further increases in war risk rates for cargo to or from Spain or Spanish Morocco.

MARSEILLES, France, July 23. -- More than 1,100 French refugees, mostly athletes and sport fans who had gone to Barcelona for the Workers' Olympics, were brought to Marseilles today. Among them were French tourists who had taken refuge in the French Consulate.

The Dodgers yesterday administered a great shock to the nerves of Professor Casey Stengel and the champion Cubs by winning a ball game so suddenly in the ninth inning that even the 1,932 paying spectators were stunned into momentary silence.

Business activity in the first six months of this year showed a marked improvement over conditions in the corresponding period in 1935, with substantial increases being recorded in all major indexes of production and distribution, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 22, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,478,000,000, the same amount as reported for the preceding week and an increase of $11,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

As a result of larger check exchanges in many of the major cities, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose 7.8 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago. In the previous week they declined 14.3 per cent. The total for the twenty-two principal cities throughout the nation, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., was $5,729,407,000, against $5,315,471,000 last year.
A dejected Wilmer Allison returned from Wimbledon when the United States liner Washington docked early yesterday.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 23. -- The Senate adjourned for the week tonight with the State's unemployment relief problem still unsolved.

Straying far afield from the conventional repertoire in his choice of the second opera to be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer, Alexander Smallens hit upon Rimsky-Korsakoff's "The Czar's Bride" to serve the purpose. In certain respects this selection proved a canny one.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- Following is the invocation delivered at the opening of the Landon notification ceremonies this evening by the Most Rev. Dr. Francis Johannes, Bishop of the Leavenworth Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church:

If the peoples of the Near East whom Dr. JAMES L. BARTON befriended when they were in dire need of friends in the earth were to add to the catalogue of their saints, many of them would no doubt name him. As a young man he was Christian missionary in the Near East near the Euphrates River.

An organization of SpanishAmerican and World War veterans to support the Democratic ticket "all down the line" was launched at the Hotel Commodore last night with the election of Milton Solomon of Brooklyn as city-wide chairman.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 23. -- Colonel R.E. Beebe, commander of the Eighteenth Infantry and supervisor of C.M.T.C. training here, announced today that forty-eight fourth-year students, all from New York and New Jersey, have been appointed cadet officers in the C.M.T.C. regiment now here.
Marin-Marie, the young French yachtsman and painter, who occasionally breaks the monotony of normal life by journeying the seas in small boats, took off again yesterday for a solo adventure.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- Directors of the Federal administration's drought relief program asked Western railroads today to help drought-ruined farmers by reducing freight rates on feed for starving cattle.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Three youths convicted of a $10 robbery received five lashes each with a doubled five-foot length of three-quarter-inch rubber hose in the chamber of Boys Court today. The whippings were given at the order of Judge J.M. Braude in lieu of jail sentences.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- The twenty-ninth annual flower show under the auspices of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society opened this afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school. The number and arrangement of exhibits surpassed all previous shows.
Governor Lehman formally upheld Judge Jonah J. Goldstein yesterday in his fight against Tammany Hall for election to the Court of General Sessions.

ABOARD THE S.S. MANHATTAN, IN HAMBURG HARBOR, July 23. -- While the Manhattan was warping into the pier at the end of her long journey at midnight tonight, the American Olympic Committed dropped Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, star back-stroke swimmer, from the team for violation of training rules.

TOPEKA, July 23. -- In a formal acceptance tonight of the Republican nomination for President, Governor Landon promised that, if elected, he would restore the American Government to an efficient and constitutional basis and follow a policy of economy in government expenditures without curtailing relief for those who need it.

OSWEGO, N.Y., July 2 (AP). -- The seventy-fifth anniversary of the Oswego State Normal School, known throughout the educational world for the "Oswego movement" in education, was observed today with ceremonies which will continue three days.

The Federal grand jury in Newark was advised yesterday that it had authority to investigate the Paul W. Wendel kidnapping case and it decided at once to begin hearing evidence to determine whether there was a violation of the Lindberg Kidnapping Law.

A CLOUDY sky was drooping over the Frisch plantation in Westchester County. Already the Giants had walloped the Cardinals twice in a row at the Polo Grounds. A third game was in prospect and it was suspected that Farmer Frisch would be in no jovial mood.
LONDON, July 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

With a perfect demonstration of how the game of baseball should not be played, the Giants tossed away two runs in the opening stanza of their engagement with the Cardinals yesterday and spent the remainder of a dreary afternoon at the Polo Grounds futilely seeking to recover from this dismal start.

John T. Smith, a heavy investor in midtown realty along Fifth and Madison Avenues, added to his holdings yesterday by purchasing the five-story business building at 394 Fifth Avenue. The structure occupies a lot 18.4 by 100 feet and was acquired from the Renrae Realty Corporation through William A White Sons, brokers.

ON BOARD SCHOONER LIBERTY, OFF YARMOUTH, N.S., July 23. -- President Roosevelt spent about seven hours trolling for tuna today in the Soldiers' Rip grounds near here, but without success. This was not unusual, since one catch by a sportsman using rod and a line may require several days of effort.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 23. -- Rebels in Spanish Morocco still control the entire zone, despite the shelling of towns by government warships.

BOSTON, July 23. -- Winning his fifth race in seven starts since he donned the colors of Mrs. E.I. Wade, Up and Up, chestnut son of Upset, drove to a length and a half victory over the Corsicans Stable's Wacoche in the Norfolk Purse, mile and seventy-yard feature, before 10,000 fans at Suffolk Downs today.

TRENTON, July 23. -- The State Board of Medical Examiners announced today the results of the June examinations, showing that 124 candidates were successful in the tests for physicians and surgeons, sixty-one osteopathic licenses, fourteen for chiropodists' licenses and three for chiropractors.

LENOX, Mass., July 23. -- The annual Lenox Horse Show will open tomorrow at the Hanna Farm, midway between Lenox and Stockbridge, and will continue through Saturday. There are 325 entries, with 100 horses in forty-eight classes.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 23. -Believing that the vote of Connecticut's electors may be pivotal in the Presidential election and taking precaution against failure to count it, Governor Wilbur L. Cross decided today to call a one-day special session of the Legislature to advance to Dec. 14 or earlier the statutory date for canvassing the election returns.

Reasonable objection may be made to the bringing about of high prices by artifically created scarcity through limitation of planted acreage. This method has, however, some advantage over the method of bringing about scarcity by destruction of the crop after the expenditure of time, expense and labor in producing it, for, under the first method, the farmer can at least spend time in other more profitable ways than by raising a crop to be destroyed.

A proposed budget for the city's schools of $142,479,896 for 1937, an increase of $5,378,839 over the allotment for 1936, was announced last night by Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, chairman of the committee on finance and budget of the Board of Education, as having been approved by his committee for submission to the board.

Five boys were rescued yesterday afternoon from a foundering home-made raft in Flushing Bay, about a mile and a half off Twenty-third Avenue, College Point, Queens, by two radio-car policemen in a commandeered motor launch. A few minutes later the raft disappeared under the swell of a passing boat.

The net income of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in the second quarter of this year amounted to $7,936,660, after provision for income and other taxes, interest and estimated depreciation, according to the financial statement released today.

The tariff issue between the Democratic and Republican parties, which used to be fought out in the industrial centers, this year will obviously be moved onto the farms. This change is as typical of the shifts of economic opinion and interest which have taken place in the country as anything that could be cited.
HENDAYE, July 23. -- Government forces were reported tonight to have reoccupied the resort town of San Sebastian after a violent battle, which lasted all day.
There was a general feeling of satisfaction discernible among the big game fishermen in town yesterday, especially those who spend part of each Summer cruising the waters off Montauk.

The Democratic party will marshal six Democratic Governors from coast to coast on a radio network Tuesday night to reply to the acceptance speech of Governor Landon, it was announced at national headquarters last night.

The price trend of listed bonds was higher over a broad front yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange despite the slower trading pace. The secondary issues in the corporate section and also the high-grade loans, including Treasury issues, participated in the mild improvement and responded to the better demand with fractional to point advances.

The municipal ferryboat Rockaway was back in service yesterday, plying its East River route between Astoria and East Ninety-second Street, Manhattan. Commissioner Frederick J.H. Kracke of the Department of Plant and Structures had won at least a temporary victory over Park Commissioner Robert Moses, whose contractor was prevented on Wednesday from razing the ferry house and tearing up the adjacent roadway only through the intervention of Mayor La Guardia and the Police Department.

TWA, the "Lindbergh Line," operating from coast to coast with passengers, air mail and express, is endeavoring to buy the assets and contracts of Braniff Airways, Inc., which operates between Chicago and the Gulf of Mexico, it was ascertained here yesterday.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., July 24. -- The fifty-sixth annual General Conference of Christian Workers, to be held here Aug. 1-17, draws special significance from the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist, founder of the Northfield Schools and the Summer religious conferences.
LONDON, July 24 (AP). -- Battle lines were drawn today for the challenge round of the 1936 Davis Cup tennis competition starting tomorrow between the cup-holding English team and Australia.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP). -- Robert S. James was convicted of first-degree murder tonight for the rattlesnake-drowning death of his seventh wife, Mary. As the jury did not recommend imprisonment, death on the gallows was mandatory.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 24. -- The Nassau County grand jury late today indicted Police Chief Philip B. Kohut, Captain Thomas McGowan and Sergeant Thomas Moore, all of the Long Beach police force, for neglect of duty. The indictments grew out of a recent raid on a gambling establishment that had been operating for nearly a year only one block from the Long Beach headquarters.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- Senator Glass told reporters today that it was "utter nonsense" to interpret a recent speech he made "as indicating I am going to 'take a walk'" from the Democratic party.
LONDON, July 24. -- "I wish I had done the job properly."

BOURG-MADAME, France, July 24. -- A column of 6,000 men composed of a loyal regiment and armed citizen militiamen left Barcelona today to join two other loyal Catalan columns now before Saragossa, where the rebels have fortified themselves.

United States and Foreign Securities Corporation reports as of June 30, 1936, net assets of $38,852,500, with investments in shares of United States and International Securities Corporation calculated at $1 a share, and before deducting Federal excess profits tax and surtax on undistributed profits, and $865,000 for taxes on unrealized appreciation on investments.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Republican workers directed their attention today to the plans for the ceremonies in the Chicago Stadium at 7:30 Thursday night when Colonel Frank Knox will be notified formally of his nomination for Vice President.

One State and fifty-one municipalities will consider bids next week for a total of $9,361,374 in new bonds. This compares with the revised total of only $6,502,446 in new State and municipal financing this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $22,114,960.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., July 24. -- The large Elks clubhouse, which has for years been an interesting point for travelers driving up the west shore of the Hudson River, was sold today to M.E. Gresser of New York City.

A letter Police Commissioner Valentine wrote to l7-year-old Michael Antonio on June 25, commending him for his aid in helping the police capture two bandits, came in mighty handy to Michael yesterday when he appeared in court on a separate matter.
BERLIN, July 24. -- The Reich Government was formally notified today of the conclusions reached at the three-power conference in London through the envoys of the three powers here.

Representative MARTIN of Massachusetts, Eastern manager of Governor LANDON'S campaign, must have begun life as an Infant Phenomenon. Speaking of JOHN HAMILTON'S travels among the Yankee Republicans, he says:

Under clouded skies but in an atmosphere of cheery and cooperative friendliness in which their recent differences were jocularly referred to by Borough President Lyons of the Bronx, Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Moses formally dedicated last night the new Crotona Park swimming pool in the Bronx.

The Sinking Fund Commission, it was reported yesterday, will vote on Wednesday for immediate termination of ferry service between the foot of East Ninety-second Street, Manhattan, and Astoria, Queens. Park Commissioner Robert Moses, as executive officer of the Triborough Bridge Authority, will then resume the work of removing the East Ninety-second Street slip and razing the old ferry house.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Fuller gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. C.P. Greenough Fuller, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Fuller Jr. and James C. Fuller. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies entertained at dinner there for Mr. and Mrs. Hunter Marston, Miss Emlen Knight Davies and A.K.E. Jonsson.

MANILA, P.I., July 24. -- Three thousand veterans in the Philippines are still waiting for the United States Treasury Department to establish some means of paying the bonus. The bonds were received two weeks ago, but most of the banks refuse even certification, since no payment office for the Philippines has been established.
LONDON, July 24. -- Winston Churchill declared last night that Great Britain might easily become a Nazi State.

In addition to reporting record earnings of $29,473,736 for the first six months of this year and declaring a dividend of $4 a share, Chrysler Corporation provided news yesterday by actually computing the tax on undistributed income, and deducting this estimated levy from its income.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Bearish sentiment predominated in the grain trade today and with a relatively light speculative interest prices declined on the Board of Trade under rather persistent commission house and local selling which disclosed a lack of aggressive support.

LENOX, Mass., July 24. -- At Uplands today R. Jay Flick, president of the Lenox Horse Show Association, and Mrs. Flick entertained 100 at luncheon in compliment to the judges and exhibitors at the two-day show which opened this morning. With Mr. and Mrs. Flick are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ingersoll Ingalls Jr., Miss Theresa Schuck of Birmingham, Ala.; Lewis E. Waring and Edward Childs.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Wilmer Allison, the veteran Texan who captained America's unsuccessful Davis Cup team, said today he was through with "serious" tennis and would not defend his national singles championship at Forest Hills in September.

LONDON, July 24. -- Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France, who remained in London overnight after the completion of yesterday's three-power conference, had a further session with British leaders today at a luncheon at the French Embassy.

PARIS, July 24. -- There are too many hypotheses attached to the London three-power decision to call another Locarno conference for it to receive any warm welcome in France. It may be the right road to that illusive peace which so many successive Ministries have sought, but -- and here a great many "buts" are being attached.

MARSEILLES, France, July 24. -- Tales of terror in Barcelona were told today by fifteen Americans who with French refugees arrived here today on the steamer Djenne. They expressed fears for numerous Americans who still are in the city.

" Battle Hymn," the WPA Experimental Theatre's paean to old John Brown of Harper's Ferry, appears to be the only play departing the local scene this evening -- at least, the only one definitely listed to leave. It quits Daly's Sixty-third Street Theatre, where it opened on May 22.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The government carried to the Supreme Court today its fight to have the constitutionality of the Public Holding Company Act of 1935 tested through the Electric Bond and Share case instead of through lawsuits brought by the North American Company, American Water Works and Electric Company and five other utilities.

TRENTON, July 24. -- The State Financial Assistance Commission -the name under which the State house commission was authorized by the Legislature to administer a fund of $6,000,000 to help municipalities provide emergency relief -granted $5,000 today to Atlantic City and $1,400 to Pleasantville, also in Atlantic County.
HONGKONG, July 24. -- Five military airplanes roared over Canton this morning bringing from Northern Kwangtung Province General Yu Han-mou and his staff.
LONDON, July 24. -- A letter George Andrew McMahon wrote to Sir John Simon, Home Secretary, read, in part, as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- From $125,000,000 to $160,000,000 will be spent by the Resettlement Administration from new relief funds. Although much larger than the $85,000,000 set aside by Congress for "rural rehabilitation," the sum is not sufficient to carry out the comprehensive permanent anti-drought program contemplated by President Roosevelt.

Unsettled weather conditions over the metropolitan area had local baseball officials in a quandary yesterday up to about noon, when they decided to take matters in their own hands. The concluding game of the series between the Giants and Cardinals at the Polo Grounds and the scheduled encounter between the Dodgers and Cubs at Ebbets Field were both called off.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 24. -- Mrs. William H. Woodin gave a dinner tonight for Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius, who is visiting her daughter, Mrs. Juan Terry Trippe and Mr. Trippe, at their dune house here.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 24. -- This city threatened today a tax strike in retaliation against New Jersey for leaving the unemployment relief problem in the hand of the municipalities.

The friction which has developed in connection with the Republican-Fusion nomination for the office of President of the Board of Aldermen is ill-advised and unnecessary. It will be difficult enough to win against the Democratic organization even if all the original Fusion forces are united; divided, there is not a chance of a victory.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 24. -- The captain of the American Export ship Exmouth related experiences with the Spanish revolution.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- Signs of a business pick-up this Fall "stronger than had been expected" were reported by the American Federation of Labor today in its monthly business survey.

With the same vim and conviction that stirred loud cheers at the Democratic convention in Philadelphia, young Mrs. John Galleher of Leesburg, Va., took over yesterday the post of head of the Young Women Democrats, and predicted that President Roosevelt would capture the vote of her age group.

AS originally planned, this was to have been, in part at least, home news from abroad, but the Davis Cup challenge round starting at Wimbledon today is now entirely in the realm of foreign affairs. United States citizens can go quietly about their business while Great Britain and Australia settle the matter of the lease of the Davis Cup for the coming tennis year.

Charles Slaughter, chairman of the special sugar committee of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange which has been exploring the possibility of introducing a "world market" sugar contract on the Exchange, has sent to all members of the Exchange rules and regulations governing trading in such a contract.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 24. It will be East vs. West tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the fifteenth annual national public links championship over the strenuous 6,710-yard course of the Bethpage State Park Golf Club.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 24. -- Wholesale deportations of the Finnish population in the Ingrian district of Soviet Russia, in the neighborhood of Leningrad, have been accelerated in recent weeks, according to statements in the Finnish press.

VIENNA, July 24. -- The eve of the second anniversary of the assassination of Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss finds almost all houses in Vienna draped in black. At dusk the windows of all public buildings and many homes showed burning candles.

MADRID, July 24. -- The Guadar rama Mountains, about fifty to sixty miles north of Madrid, were cleared of rebels today, according to a government statement. It also declared that near Guadalajara an advance of rebel troops from Sara gossa marching on the capital had been stopped, the rebels dispersing after sustaining heavy losses.

CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP). -- The Indians fired their heaviest-hitting barrage of the season at the Athletics today and picked up half a game on the American League leading Yankees, who were idle, with a 16-to-3 victory.

Mayor La Guardia told a luncheon of more than 100 Brooklyn civic workers yesterday that the proposed $5,000,000 Brooklyn central library project for which they were working would have to give precedence, as far as he was concerned, to schools and hospitals.

The security prices of eight consistent national advertisers for the period 1931 to 1935 rose 45 per cent, while those of eight organizations in the same fields with smaller or negligible national advertising expenditures increased only 11 per cent, according to a survey released yesterday by Platt-Forbes, Inc.
