The largest attendance at any of the ten exhibitions held at the WPA Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, was reached at the show devoted to easel paintings by eighty WPA artists, which ended yesterday.

HENDAYE, on Franco-Spanish Border, July 24 (AP). -- The United States warship Oklahoma arrived at San Sebastian tonight to evacuate foreigners, but many of them already had been removed by British and French ships.

The dollar continued firm in terms of all leading foreign currencies yesterday, gaining at the expense of the French, Dutch, Belgian, Scandinavian and Japanese rates. The franc was held below Thursday's closing price throughout the day, sinking to 6.60 5/8 cents, the lowest since July 11.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 24 (AP). -- Barcelona labor unions ordered their members to go back to work today in an effort to overcome the chaotic effects of the Spanish revolution.

John Kieran recently quoted Marse Joe McCarthy as saying "what the fans like to read is more personality stuff; short notes, hit-and-run stuff." That is correct. And it occurs to me that the fans also would like to read some criticism, criticism handed out where it is due -- and overdue.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 24. -- Janet Sue, the property of Miss Elsie P. Holdsworth of Seekonk, Mass., was declared the five-gaited saddle horse champion in the $250 Monmouth Hotel stake event, one of the main attractions of the closing day of the Jersey Shore benefit horse show on the picturesque Boxwood Farm estate of Mr. and Mrs. William Buchsbaum today.

WADING RIVER, L.I., July 24. -- An elusive night-prowling animal, awesomely referred to as "It" and believed by some persons to be a baboon, is on the loose in this vicinity, alarming hundreds of natives and Summer residents with ear-splitting shrieks and sudden appearances and disappearances.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP). -- An economy survey intended to help the twelve Federal Reserve Banks pay normal dividends without dipping into their surplus funds has been ordered by the Reserve Board.
SALZBURG, Austria, July 24 (AP). -- The rap of Arturo Toscanini's baton tomorrow will mark the opening of the famous Summer Musical Festival. The opera will be Beethoven's "Fidelio."

Father COUCHLIN doesn't make the claim that he smiled when he called President ROOSEVELT a liar. On the contrary, he was so much in earnest that he did not quite know what he was saying. In the good priest's own words, he succumbed to "heat of civic interest and righteous indignation."
MADRID, July 24 (AP). -- A list of refugees in the United States Embassy here was prepared tonight by the embassy. The names follow:

BERLIN, July 24. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh provided a counterpart to his speech yesterday warning the world against the destructive power of the modern airplane when in a toast today at a luncheon given to him by officers of the Richthofen Pursuit Squadron, he said:

How any one can desire a return to the do-nothing policies of the Old Dealers is beyond me. That day is past when things must be allowed to run their course. If that theory were to have been applied when Mr. Roosevelt came into office and followed to its conclusion, the country would have found itself inextricably involved and the people on the verge of open rebellion.

Bonds were firm to slightly higher in routine trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. There were no important group movements to attract undue attention, the main body of corporate loans holding within a narrow price range.

The cure of epilepsy in certain classifications by an absolute fast, continuing sometimes as long as twenty-five days, was claimed yesterday by Dr. H.W. Conklin of Battle Creek, Mich., in a paper read before the fortieth annual convention of the American Osteopathic Association at its closing session in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 24. -- As a result of a well-earned victory over Paul Keres, Estonia's youthful champion, in an adjourned game from the fourth round, Reuben Fine of New York recovered the lead in the international chess masters' tournament at the Grand Hotel today.

MOSCOW, July 24. -- The flight of a Soviet plane over 5,753 miles of dangerous Arctic territory in storms and fogs, though ended short of its goal which was to set a world record, is hailed here as another demonstration of the skill and courage of Soviet aviators and of the genius of Soviet airplane builders.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24. -- Rough weather prevented the three America's Cup class boats Rainbow, Weetamoe and Yankee from having another test off the Brenton Reef course today under the auspices of the New York Yacht Club.

The departmental trial of Patrolman Edward M. Shulebov was finished by Deputy Commissioner Michael A. Lyons yesterday after the patrolman, who claimed the four $100 bills found May 28 in an assembly room at Police Headquarters, had offered his own explanation of certain aspects of his personal affairs. Decision was reserved.

LONDON, July 24. -- Floyd Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, is sailing for the United States on the Aquitania on Wednesday after having paved the way here for the repatriation of 24,000,000 worth of British electricity shares now in the hands of his utility companies in the United States.

TRENTON, July 24. -- Two persons were killed, two severely injured and a score of others suffered minor injuries at 2:20 o'clock this morning when wind, accompanying a thunderstorm, wrecked a large tent in which a "walkathon" was being conducted on Nottingham Way in Hamilton Township, near here.

LONDON, July 24. -- King Edward will make his first visit abroad since his accession when he embarks tomorrow on the British Admiralty yacht Enchantress for France to dedicate the Canadian national war memorial at Vimy Ridge Sunday.
BERLIN, July 24. -- Following the example of the United States, Britain, France and Italy, Germany today dispatched warships to Spain.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 24. -- The anti-Semitic Iron Guard yesterday successfully prevented the police conducting its leader, Corneliu Codreanu, to be examined in connection with the brutal assassination in a hospital of Jon Stelescu, Mr. Codreanu's former aide and subsequent founder of the Crusaders, a rival Fascist organization.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Favorable reports on business conditions in June and the first three weeks of July were continued in the periodical review of the Federal Reserve Board, issued today. Where declines in production, employment and trade are usual during this period, this year the volume was maintained and in some cases increases were recorded.

ALBANY, July 24. -- One hundred and forty-three Cornell scholarships have just been awarded by the State to high school students in all except two counties, the State Department of Education announced today.

ROME, July 24. -- The French and Belgian Ambassadors and the British Charge d'Affaires called in a group this morning on Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano, to whom they delivered the official text of the resolution adopted at the London meeting of those three of the Locarno powers.

Apparently the British motorship Nunoca, with thirteen passengers and nine members of the crew, must be given up as lost -- vanished at sea in an area where shipping traffic is heavy and where fine weather conditions prevailed. She sailed from Grand Cayman, a small island south of Cuba, July 4, and was due at Tampa, Fla., two weeks ago.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 24 (AP). -- Several hundred men and women from all sections of the State mingled "My Country, 'Tis of Thee" with strains of the "Internationale" as they held the State Capitol tonight for reinforcements summoned to augment the "militant jobless army" demanding $100,000,000 for the unemployed.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission exempted today from registering as over-the-counter dealers brokers and dealers in mortgages whose business is confined exclusively to handling entire mortgages and not part of an issue of such obligations.

A "careful and conservative" course was recommended to members of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, which yesterday outlined seven suggestions to follow in activities which might be affected by the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination law.

Dr. Leon Luria, a physician, of 901 Fiftieth Street, Brooklyn, who has an office at 531 Seventh Avenue, pleaded not guilty in the Felony Court yesterday to a second-degree grand larceny charge in an alleged fraudulent accident claim. At the request of Lyon Boston, Assistant District Attorney, Magistrate Farrell set next Tuesday for a hearing, and released him in $2,000 bail.

" Side-Line Observer" claims that the answer to the question whether "the recovery" -- i.e., "from $40,000,000,000 national income in 1932 to $60,000,000,000 in 1936 -- has been aided or retarded by the present administration" is "simple and practical." It is to let the Republican administration take charge, where-upon "business confidence would return with such a rush that there would be no holding back the tide of business resulting from it."

TOPEKA, July 24. -- Governor Landon, Republican nominee for President, and John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, were cheered today both by reports that the Governor's acceptance had been received with favor throughout the country and by assurances of additional support from anti-New Deal Democrats.

While the air between the tenements, factory buildings and the Ninth Avenue elevated is not so fresh, we call it "fresh air" because it's part of the Hudson Guild's Summer program which gives our neighborhood children planned amusement in the open, so that they may stay out of their stifling tenements.

Walter P. Chrysler, chairman of the board of the Chrysler Corporation, announced yesterday that the company's net profit for the six months ended on June 30 was $29,473,736, equivalent to $6.83 a share on the common stock, after providing for the surtax on undistributed profits, on the basis of profits earned and dividends paid during the period.

Victor F. Ridder, who will retire on Aug. 1 as local WPA Administrator, took issue yesterday with Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, who gave his approval in Washington on Thursday of picketing by dissatisfied relief workers of local WPA administrators to enforce their demands.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The Alaska Juneau Gold Mining Company was declared guilty of unfair labor practices by the National Labor Relations Board in a decision announced today, which held that a strike for a closed shop was not illegal.
BERLIN, July 24. -- A spontaneous rush of support by her team-mates and coaches buoyed Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett's hopes of reinstatement on the United States Olympic team today.

MARSEILLES, France, July 24. -- Mrs. George Haven Putnam, widow of the American publisher and one of the refugees brought here by a British destroyer, said tonight she had seen dozens of churches and convents burning along the east coast of Spain.

I was greatly annoyed to read in THE TIMES of July 17 that one of our athletes found an anti-Nazi pamphlet on board the S.S. Manhattan. The perturbation of the ship's officers is understandable and their zeal in starting an investigation is highly commendable.

EL PASO, Texas, July 24 (AP). -- John Astor Squiers, 39 years old, and Ada Mordaque Stoude, 38, both of New York City, were married yesterday by proxy by Judge Justo Salaises of the Civil Registry in Juarez, Mexico.
HAGERMAN, Idaho, July 24 (AP). -- Senator Borah said in an address here today that the Federal Constitution stood as a "challenge to the whole world-wide conspiracy against freedom and liberty."

MELVIN VILLAGE, N.H., July 24. -- With three former national champions, a Walker Cup, any number of lesser golfing lights and the one and only George Herman (Babe) Ruth in the field, the second annual Bald Peak invitation tournament which started today on the scenic course overlooking Lake Winnipesaukee took on all the aspects of an event of major affluence.
WASHINGTON, July 24. -- At the suggestion of President Roosevelt, a conference was called today on up-stream engineering to discuss long-range drought-relief planning through "Little Water" control.

The return of more favorable weather conditions this week was accompanied by a decided rebound in consumer buying from the rather restricted proportions during the heat wave of the two weeks preceding, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
A mortally wounded man captured his murderer yesterday at the end of a five-block chase that began with a payroll hold-up of the Globe Sales Manufacturing Company at 624 Broadway.

MUSSOLINI denouncing dictatorship, STALIN deriding communism, would hardly seem stranger than Dr. SCHACHT'S characterization of the methods of foreign trade that Germany has taken the principal part in inaugurating under his direction:

DETROIT, July 24 (AP). -- The Red Sox pulled the Tigers out of third place in the American League and into a tie for fourth today by coming from behind to take a 7-4 ten-inning decision over the world champions with a three-run attack in the extra frame.

ALBANY, July 24. -- Seventeen counties in up-State New York have received more than $400,000 for the planting of millions of young trees in reforested areas since 1929, the Conservation Department revealed today. The money spent was for labor, taken mostly from those on relief rolls and later aided by CCC workers.

One of the best speed contests of the Summer season is promised at Empire City today in the renewal of the Fleetwing Handicap, with $3,500 added, over the short six-furlong course. This race, and the East View Stakes for juveniles over the same distance, with $2,500 added, will be the last stake offerings of the meeting.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24. -- The Newark Bears dropped both ends of a double-header for the first time this season tonight when thet succumbed to the Toronto Maple Leafs before 7,500 fans. The scores were 4 -- 1 and 8 -- 2.

To the end that the sidewalks of Flatbush should remain unobstructed and undefiled, Gaston Koch, militant civic leader, spent a harrowing day in the Flatbush court yesterday. He engaged in spirited debate with Magistrate Sabbatino in the court room and with a local merchant outside, was arrested for disorderly conduct and spent two-and-a-half hours in the gloomy atmosphere of the detention pen.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizingfa Committee, asserted today that the United States Steel Corporation's announcement of time-and-a-half for overtime after employes have worked forty-eight hours a week was "misleading," as it "really covered the extension of the forty-hour week to forty-eight hours."

Operations of the Continental Baking Corporation and subsidiaries in the twenty-six weeks ended on June 27 resulted in a net profit of $1,367,455 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges. This is equivalent to $3.41 each on the 409,900 shares of 8 per cent preferred stock.

Illness has necessitated the removal of John Barrymore from the role of Baron de Varville in "Camille," Greta Garbo's first film in more than a year, and Lionel Barrymore has been substituted, according to work from the coast. The cameras are scheduled to begin turning on this production on Monday at the Metro lot.

So scattered are the local night-club events during these torpid Summer evenings that some sort of arrangement might be made to have a whistle blown every time one of them occurs. At that, the consequent clamor would be so infrequent and slight that the slumbers of no one would be disturbed, with the possible exception of those of the man assigned to blow the whistle.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 24. -- A grand jury investigation of the charge that a bribe was solicited in connection with a State horse racing bill during the last session of the New Jersey Legislature was recommended today by a Senate committee which investigated the charge.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 24. -- Professor W.L. Clevenger of North Carolina State College was held today for questioning in the murder of his niece, Miss Helen Clevenger, 18-year-old co-ed of New York University.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign xchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

MADRID, July 24. -- In a radio address to the nation last night President Manuel Azana said that the rebels were making the same mistake Napoleon made "when he tried to subjugate us more than a century ago."

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Predicting that President Roosevelt this Fall would exceed his 1932 electoral vote, Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee declared today that the President would even carry Kansas, Governor Landon's State, as he did four years ago.

Art Jarrett, band leader husband of Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, told The Associated Press yesterday he was greatly "disappointed" that American Olympic officials had barred his wife from the Olympic swimming team.

Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued to make a notably good showing during the week, retail executives reported yesterday. The comparison with the 1935 period, which was a week of abnormally had weather, showed substantial increases for leading department stores here.

A great improvement in the employment of merchant seamen is shown in the semi-annual report of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, published yesterday by the Rev. Harold H. Kelley, superintendent. In the first six months of the year 1,700 jobs were found for seamen through institute channels, as against 930 for the same period last year.
A few days ago I read a eulogy of James J. McEntee, a member of the old famous Twenty-second Regiment Engineers relay team.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 24. -- Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County ruled today that Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers had not forfeited her rights to the use of Port of Missing Men, the estate at Southampton of her late husband, Colonel Henry H, Rogers.

Governor Landon's acceptance speech was extremely gratifying to New York Republicans, according to their public and private declarations here yesterday. While they were restrained in their expressions, it was evident that they felt that the candidate had sounded in firm terms the keynote of what they considered the basic issues of the campaign.

Delegates from hundreds of Lutheran churches in the metropolitan area will attend the annual Lutheran Day celebration next Saturday in the auditorium at Ocean Grove, N.J. The hall seats 10,000 people and the Lutherans usually fill it.

LENOX, Mass., July 24. -- Miss Joan McCreery, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. McCreery of Greenwich, Conn., won the A.S.P.C.A. Good Hands Cup this afternoon at the opening of the two-day Lenox horse show, midway between Lenox and Stockbridge at the Hanna Farm.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 24. -- Mrs. Paul Morton gave a dinner tonight at Windswept, her home on Lake Agawam, for her grandniece, Miss Catherine Butch, who is visiting her. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Dwight F. Davis Jr., Arthur D. Weekes Jr., Orton Porter Jackson, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Morton Smith, Miss Amelia Overall, James Parrish Lee Jr. and Frederic Carey.

ALBANY, July 24 (AP). -- New York's Public Service Commission sharply criticized today parts of the Interstate Commerce Commission's proposed safety regulations for motor carriers, and ordered all buses engaged in either interstate or intrastate traffic to comply with its own rules rather than those of the Federal body.

LONDON, July 24. -- The full text of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's Berlin speech was not reported in London. Also, we do not know how his immediate hearers and the Nazi press received it. However, the impression made upon all well-informed British quarters with which I have been in contact is that Colonel Lindbergh's frank, truthful and courageous words have rendered a notable service to Europe, and perhaps to the entire world.

HENDAYE, France, July 24. -- Discrepancies between the reports of the contending parties in Spain have reached a fantastic pitch. From Madrid sources favorable to the government come details of crushing defeats inflicted on the rebels, while the insurgents contend they are steadily closing in on Madrid from several sides.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER LIBERTY, July 24. -- President Roosevelt anchored the Sewanna at Westport, N.S., on the tip of Digby Neck, tonight after a five-hour, thirty-mile cruise northward in the Bay of Fundy from Yarmouth.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Early sales of bogs here today ware at about steady prices, but the market rapidly weakened and at the last sales were off 15 to 25 cents a hundred-weight with a slow demand. An early top of $11.10 was paid, or the same as on Thursday, but it was hard to obtain $10.90 at the close of the market.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- Eight colts and three fillies are scheduled to run tomorrow in the $30,000 added Arlington classic, mile and a quarter race which many consider the West's most important test for 3-year-olds. Estimates were that as many as 40,000 would attend the contest, which, it is predicted, will confirm the position of Granville as best of the division.

Scholarships totaling $3,700 have been awarded to thirteen Columbia University students for the study of Italian during the academic year 1936-37, it was announced yesterday. The funds were provided by a committee of business and professional men in this city, headed by Generoso Pope, publisher of Il Progresso Italo-Americano.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Executives of steel companies denied last night that the new arrangement for overtime compensation, announced by their companies, would mean any extension in the number of hours worked each week by employes.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24. -- Paul H. Wendel, whose "confession" to the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. caused a delay in the execution of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, testified today before the Federal grand jury investigating his story of how he was abducted and tortured into signing the confession which he repudiated before the Mercer County grand jury.
Real estate trading in Manhattan and the Bronx was mild yesterday when brokers reported a few scattered sales and leases.
MADRID, July 24. -- Rebel attackers, repulsed in their drive against Madrid by a government semicircle of steel in the Guadarrama Mountains, were reported fleeing in disorder tonight.

Magistrate Earl A. Smith in West Side Court yesterday discharged the five men who had been arrested in a raid on an allegedly disorderly house at 120 Riverside Drive July 14. In Women's Court one of the three women arrested at the same time, all of whom had been convicted, was sentenced to 100 days in the Kingston Avenue Hospital.

PARIS, July 24. -- A well-dressed woman in the gallery of the Chamber of Deputies today so far permitted her political feelings to master her as to let her voice be heard above the tumult on the floor, causing a suspension of the sitting.

LONDON, July 24 (Canadian Press.) -- Surrey was the only team to take maximum points in English County cricket matches concluded today and as a result climbed three notches in the table. Leadership, however, remains unchanged.

WITH LOYALIST FORCES AT ENDARLAZA, Northern Spain, July 24 (AP). -- Government troops held control of the north central coast of Spain tonight after a spirited clash in which fifty-five rebels and an undetermined number of loyalists had been killed.

A leader on the English best-seller lists is a book about America and Americans by Arthur Bryant, the biographer of Pepys. The title is "The American Ideal." Mr. Bryant analyzes the lives and philosophies of Jefferson, Lincoln, Emerson, Theodore Roosevelt, Walter Hines Page, Alan Seeger and Vachel Lindsay.

ON BOARD LINER EXETER AT BARCELONA, Spain, July 24. -- The liner Exeter of the American Export Lines, under the command of Captain Stanley Ransone, docked in Barcelona today under orders from the United States Government to evacuate American families and other foreign residents to Marseilles.

With Tammany Hall determined to fight Governor Lehman and get a winning vote in the primary for Assemblyman Saul S. Streit for the nomination for Judge of General Sessions, the Governor received a new plea yesterday to inject himself into the primary election.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 24. -- The first invasion of the East by Joe Hunt of Los Angeles ended in defeat on the wet turf of the Longwood Cricket Club today at the hands of the same player who inflicted Robert Riggs's only setback in seven weeks at Spring Lake.

Among the hundred actors who skip and scream through "Injunction Granted!", which the WPA living newspaper put on at the Biltmore last evening, is a clown who makes supercilious faces and noises when a capitalist or judge holds the stage.

PARIS, July 24 (AP). -- The Spanish rebels will remain in their present positions until they "assemble the necessary material," General Emilio Mola, insurgent leader in Northern Spain, said in an interview published today in the newspaper Le Matin.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- American citizens were evacuated today from several danger points in Spain, with the arrival of United States and foreign vessels, but the situation remained uncertain in San Sebastian and Bilbao, according to diplomatic and consular reports received by the State Department.

MEXICO, D.F., July 24. -- President Lazaro Cardenas today refused the request of labor leaders that he end the strike of electrical workers in the Mexican Light and Power Company by taking it over until workers and employes reached an agreement.
BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 24. -- Armed guards on patrol at several Lake George boat houses made this the strangest eve of a Gold Cup regatta in its thirty-three long years.

The widespread attention that the prefabricated all-steel house at Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street has been attracting is a gratifying sign of the interest that has been awakened in the general public by the housing problem. Public authorities have tended to concentrate too exclusively on slum clearance and multi-family dwellings.

LONDON, July 24. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today were quieter than yesterday, with prices firm in undertone despite some irregularity from profit-taking. British Government issues were firm following the encouraging remarks regarding taxation by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

MADISON, Wis., July 24. -- Although Wisconsin was excluded from the primary drought area designated by the Department of Agriculture, the State received a promise of $500,000 of Federal funds for drought relief when R.G. Tugwell, Under-Secretary of Agriculture, conferred with Governor La Follette and other Federal and State officials here today.

Apparently those in charge of the campaign for the re-election of the present incumbent of the White House must be having sleepless nights, as otherwise they would not have started the whispering campaign to brand Governor Landon as not being in sympathy with those of the Jewish faith.

While emptying the bullets from his pistol before shutting his cage and leaving for the day, John E. Nilsen, a teller in the East River Savings Bank branch at West Ninety-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, shot himself fatally yesterday afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24. -- With the number of entertainments that have been arranged ending with a subscription dance at the Clambake Club tomorrow evening, the weekend is to be a lively one for members of the Summer colony. Among those who are planning to entertain over the week-end are Mr. and Mrs. George Eustis Paine, Mrs. Moses Taylor, Mrs. Dudley Davis and Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 24. -- Heavy rain today caused abandonment of the overnight bivouac planned at Brown's Farm for the Citizens Military Training Camp provisional regiment being trained here by officers of the 305th Infantry under Colonel Walter W. Metcalf.

It is not my intention to quarrel with the factual evidence presented in the first part of your recent editorial "Father Coughlin's Facts." The philosophic implications in the latter part of the article are, it seems to me, more vulnerable.

For the second consecutive week new bond financing consisted largely of public utility loans, with borrowing by those companies this week making the total of new offerings $63,827,000, of which $53,827,000 were utility issues. Last week $109,208,000 in new loans was placed on the market, of which $51,608,000 was in public utility obligations.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 24. -- A new type of porcelain, its surface done by "hot frost," was announced today at the color conference at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of New York will receive the residuary estate of Mrs. Rosa Recio Garcia, late of 318 West 107th Street, who died on July 17, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- An issue of $5,500,000 of the Chicago Illinois Midland Railway Company's bonds will be sold to a syndicate including Halsey Stuart Co., Harris Hall Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Field Glore Co., Edward B. Smith Co., and the Lee Higginson Corporation, according to information received here today.

The Olympic team has arrived in Germany. Avery Brundage now can rest comfortably, happy in his victory over "un-American" forces which attempted to prevent the United States from competing in the Olympic Games.
It's not often that two sportsmen decide to take time out for a two-day deep-sea fishing expedition and then come back to town each with a broadbill swordfish to his credit.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- Seven WPA officials in Oklahoma were discharged today by order of Aubrey Williams, Acting WPA Administrator, for "political activity" in that State's Democratic primary last week.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull joined with consular representative of South and Central America yesterday in praising the contributions of Simon Bolivar to the cooperation of the nations of North and South America. He spoke at exercises commemorating the 153d anniversary of the South American liberator.

The Swedish American liner Gripsholm will sail today for Gothenburg with the following passengers: G. Hilmer Lundbeck, Mrs. John F. Hylan, Mr. and Mrs. John F. Sinnott, Edward B. Bennett, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Gavin, Mr. and Mrs. O. Clement Swenson, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Leslie and Mrs. H. van Rensselaer Kennedy.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The expulsion of Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett from the United States Olympic team created a major sensation here. German sympathies are apparently all with the American Olympic Committee. The Nazi organ Angriff tends to moralize on the matter, making the following comment:

Passenger revenues of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad increased about 16 per cent in June, compared with June, 1935, according to Washington advices quoting Daniel Willard, president. Low rates for passenger travel took effect on June 1.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The Department of Justice will not press charges of mutiny against the crew of the Panama-Pacific liner California, who delayed the ship's sailing from San Pedro last March by striking for higher wages. This was learned today after conferences at the department and at the Department of Commerce.

VATICAN CITY, July 24 (AP). -- A transatlantic telephone conversation between the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and Vatican officials aroused speculation today among prelates who acknowledged that the radio priest's "liar" attack on President Roosevelt had created a "painful impression" here.

Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission temporarily closed its hearings here yesterday on charges of restraint of trade against the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc. James W. Bennett presided as trial examiner.

The Al-Star basebalt game does not seem to attract the public imagination as it was thought it would. Various reasons are ascribed -- lack of public knowledge of available seats, counter-attractions and so forth. But the real reason would seem to be a missing interest in a contest of this sort.

Mixed conditions prevailed yesterday in the local commodity futures markets in moderate activity. Cottonseed oil futures were firmer and rubber, hides and tallow lower. In the cash markets cotton, rye, lard and tins advanced, while declines appeared in wheat, corn, oats, flour, wooltops, silk and rubber.

Six men were indicted for second-degree manslaughter yesterday by the Bronx County grand jury in connection with the collapse of an apartment house under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, on June 19 when eighteen persons were killed.

BERLIN, July 24. -- The American Olympic team arrived at its Berlin goal today to receive from its German hosts a spontaneous demonstration and full-hearted welcome that dwarfed into relative insignificance the greetings that have been tendered to all the teams preceding it.

Directors of the Radio Corporation of America declared yesterday a dividend of 87 1/2 cents a share on the new $3.50 dividend cumulative first preferred stock for the third quarter of 1936, payable on Oct. 1. The action was taken because the board may not meet in August.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 24. -- Mrs. Lansing P. Reed, Miss Julia C. Reed and Miss Mary P. Reed of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have arrived at the Mount Washington Hotel at Bretton Woods. Other arrivals are Mrs. James A. Thomas of White Plains, N.Y.; Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Baker, from Lake Placid; Mr. and Mrs. James E. McDonald, from Lake George; Mrs. Thyra Ensley and George Griffith of Brooklyn.
QUEBEC, July 24. -- Shareholders of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., soon will be called on to decide whether to accept an offer made by one of two syndicates for their interests, it is reported here.

The case against Polly Adler, who has been arrested sixteen times on vice charges, was dismissed yesterday by Magistrate George B. DeLuca in Women's Court, after "Uncle David," who was in her Central Park West apartment the night she was arrested, testified he went there only for a drink and conversation.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 24. -- Between threatening squalls and calms there were 225 starters today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week regatta. The number broke the record for a Friday.
BOURGMADAME, France, July 24. -- The period of extreme violence in Barcelona has ended, according to information reaching this border town.

Five hundred officers and patrolmen of the Honor Legion of the Police Department took a day's vacation from duty yesterday and cruised up the Hudson River to Bear Mountain as the organization held its first annual outing.

THE come-back has become the vogue in Hollywood. Conscience, perhaps, partly accounts for the presence in casts these days of names which gave Lens-Land its earlier glory. Certainly Hollywood owed the vanguard of its first corps a living.

DR RUCKMICK'S work is an extremely scholarly and exhaustive survey of the findings and speculations concerning emotions and feelings, from the earliest pre-Socratic philosophers up to the present time. As a compendium of facts it is worthy of a prominent place on the bookshelf of every psychologist and student. So extensive are the author's investigations that no major conclusions are outstanding, though in the last chapter such are attempted.

Mayor La Guardia has arranged to deliver the commencement address at the seventy-fifth graduation exercises of the New York State Merchant Marine Academy on Sept. 29. The address and presentation of diplomas will take place on the floor of the Marttime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 25. -- In a radio speech at Ponce today Senator Luis Munoz Marin made a final appeal for a Liberal party boycott of the next election in protest against colonialism, and he promised to effect independence for the island if his program was followed.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Detroit radio priest, said tonight that he intended "no curtailment" of his activities in the Presidential campaign as a result of the perturbation his attacks on President Roosevelt had created within the Catholic Church.

A recent editorial in THE TIMES sees President Roosevelt as resigned to cuts in relief costs and suggests that his sympathetic hand can make these cuts with less likelihood of violence than could a Republican administration.

OCEAN CITY, N.J. -- The thirtieth annual Baby Parade is scheduled for late in August, the exact date to be determined during the next fortnight. It is expected that the Baby Parade this Summer will surpass any past effort.
The Federal Power Commission suggested last week for the betterment of railroads the electrification of 12,000 track-miles of main line now operated by steam.

WHO really determines the policies of the nations and shapes their destinies? Are the actual rulers great statesmen, in a democracy, of powerful dictators, such as Mussolini, Hitler, Stalin, in the countries that have rejected the democratic principles?

The first thirteen railroads ofI the United States to report for June showed aggregate operating revenues for' the month 17.5 per cent higher than in June last year. Net operating income rose 39.3 per cent.

THE second volume of these diaries kept for his own immediate gratification and for the consolation of his old age by the Horn John Byng -- who was Viscount Torrington only for a fortnight before his death -- is in no way behind the first in sociological and topographical interest, while it vastly increases our knowledge of the writer's personality.

PARIS, July 23. -- The season's most practical bathrobes, noted on Northern beaches, are regular long-sleeved, hooded coats in colored oiled silk lined with contrasting Turkish toweling. A novel swimsuit is an elastic silk tricot maillot entirely covered by tiny multi-colored taffeta-kid flowers.

RICHMOND, July 25. -- Fifth district wholesale trade for the first half of the year was above that of the same period in 1935 in all five lines, the Richmond bank reports. Dry goods, with a 12 per cent gain, made the best record.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 25 (AP). -- Tucked away in an unimposing building on a side street here is New York State's new Crime Research Laboratory where technicians are waging an unceasing war on crime.

The 49-year-old Lake Champlain Y.C., whose famous clubhouse at Burlington, Vt., was getting more dilapidated with each Winter's ravishes and which was further wrecked by the ice jams last Spring, is to have the official dedication of its new clubhouse on Friday and Saturday.

PREDICTABLE as Winter snows are the aestival emergings of our art colonies. Their recurrence is sure, and all too often the wayfarer knows, alas, with uneventful preciseness what he may expect to find in a given spot at a stated time.

WHEN Detective Sergeant McCoun invited School-master Franklin Russell to sit in on the investigation into the death of Dr. Carson he little thought that Russell was to take complete charge of the investigation.

Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's Mower, outsider in a field of five at 8 to 1, gave 15,000 racegoers at Empire City a thrill and a surprise yesterday as he defeated some of the best sprinters in the country to capture the Fleetwing Handicap over the short six-furlong course.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 25. -- Herman Bruggeman's patience has at last given out -- after nine years. During that time on an average of once a year Mr. Bruggeman's grocery store front has been wrecked by automobiles.

SINCE Amiel's "Journal" has so long been a classic, it is important now merely to note the differences between this new edition and the older ones, and, furthermore, to review the values of this curious self-analysis covering 17,000 pages in folio.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25 (AP). -- The discharge of seven WPA officials for alleged political activity drew charges today that the inquiry was "Governor-controlled" and timed to help Governor E.W. Marland in the Democratic run-off primary next Tuesday for a seat in the United States Senate.

Supremacy of the Pirates over the Dodgers this season was demonstrated again at Ebbets Field yesterday in a manner quite satisfactory to Pie Traynor but not at all pleasing to Professor Stengel and the 4,700 aans present.
Herr GREASER'S gesture of farewell at Geneva recalls to Rabelaisians that of Panurge competing with the Englishman in sign language:

A MOTOR traffic safety contest, in which employes of each participating company will compete against employes of all other participating companies, will be staged on a large scale by the Detroit Industrial Safety Council.

Unable to return to shore against the powerful currents of the East River off 154th Street in Beechhurst, Queens John Samanski, 28 years old, of 20 Box Street, Brooklyn, turned and swam with the current across the river last night to safety on the shore of Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

The Joint Council Knitgoods Workers Union, planning a strike of 8,000 knitgoods workers to prevent the employers of that industry from increasing weekly work hours from thirty-five to forty, threatened yesterday to stage a demonstration against the United States Re-employment Service, which the union charged was acting as a "scab agency" in strikes already called against several knitgoods employers.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 25. -- Mayor W. Burdell Banister and a majority of the village trustees expressed disapproval this afternoon of a proposed Spanish-American War memorial statue which the Works Progress Administration has been preparing for Summerfield Park.

LONDON. A FORTNIGHT of play going in the heat of Summer has yielded, among much else of less interest, a welcome rerival of the Capek brothers' "Insect Play" and one new piece of outstanding value -- "A Bride for the Unicorn," by Denis Johnston, Irish dramatist, as yet chiefly known in London as the author of "The Moon in the Yellow River."

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Beach and country clubs have been busy during the last week and this week-end promises to be another record breaker at the shore. Hotels are filled to capacity and the social calendar has on it a number of important events.

DAVID DARRAH, for seven years Italian correspondent for The Chicago Tribune and now its London correspondent, has returned to England after having arranged with Hale, Cushman Flint of Boston for immediate publication of his first book, "Hail Caesar," in which he describes the personalities, events and conditions in Italy up to the time of his expulsion from that country by Mussolini last year.

MARY GARDEN, famous opera star, was making her first tour of a motion picture studio. She was admitted beyond the "No Visitors" sign and ushered to the sound stage where "Suzy" was being filmed. She accepted a chair by Director George Fitzmaurice beside the camera.

ON BOARD SCHOONER LIBERTY OFF GRAND MANAN ISLAND, N.B., July 25. -- President Roosevelt returned to the westward side of the Bay of Fundy today, sailing before a stiff breeze that enabled him to make a thirty-five-mile run in four hours and a half, the best time he has made on any leg of his vacation cruise.

WITH weather conditions more favorable, retail trade throughout the country showed a further upturn last week. Rain in the brought areas improved sentiment materially and released some buying that was held back, while purchasing of vacation and travel merchandise increased volume in many sections.

MALVERN, England, July 25. -- The eightieth birthday of George Bernard Shaw tomorrow was observed with a special performance tonight of "St. Joan." Wendy Hiller appeared in the title role at the opening of the eighth annual Malvern Festival.

HAMBURG, N.Y., July 25. -- Before a crowd of 20,000 followers, Father Coughlin, leader of the National Union for Social Justice, today in a speech full of irony demanded defeat of Representative Mead of the Forty-second Congressional District.

WE all have grown so accustomed to railing at Hollywood that we are prone to forget how valuable it can be. It is only when one sees such a picture as "The Green Pastures" that one appreciates fully the cinema's service to the public.

And it came to pass in those days that the cows in the land were many -namely, more than 26,000,000 cows in the year 1934. And they were divided into two classes, each after its kind -- to wit, the DC cows and the AC cows.
MADRID, July 25 (AP). -- Forty United States citizens, who took refuge in their embassy under the Stars and Stripes, cooperated today to make their improvised living quarters agreeable.

DES MOINES, July 25 (AP). -- Berry Halden, Chariton editor, won the Republican nomination for United States Senator at the special State convention today to select a candidate for the seat of Senator Louis Murphy, Dubuque Democrat. Mr. Halden won on the fifth ballot with 1,682 votes.

A SKILLED craftsman in an airplane factory near Paris started the "stay-in" strike movement which has swept France and Belgium during the past weeks and accomplished what the French Minister of the Interior has described as the "greatest social movement that has taken place since the French Revolution.

PARIS, July 25. -- The French Government announced after an emergency Cabinet meeting tonight that the Ministers had unanimously decided "not to intervene in any manner whatever in the internal conflict in Spain."

J.E. Baker, whose commission as economic adviser to the Chinese National Government expired last month after twenty years of almost uninterrupted work, was in New York last week in behalf of the China International Famine Relief Commission, of which he is a director.

RICHMOND, Va., July 24. -- Those who construed Senator Glass's address last week at the Patrick Henry bicentennial as an attack on President Roosevelt should revise their opinions, friends of the Senator say, since he has just characterized such an interpretation of his remarks as "nonsense."

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 25. -- Max Marston of Philadelphia and Alick Gerard Jr. of Southampton, L.I., will meet tomorrow in the thirty-six-hole final of the seventeenth annual Shenecossett men's invitation golf tournament.

THOSE who have been following the gradual progress being made in piano recording and reproduction should find particular interest in three Chopin pieces played by Josef Lhevinne (Victor 14024). One may quarrel with the infrequency with which disks by this pianist are released, but if they are to be only occasional, no fault can be found with the choice of material here.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Prices on the Boerse were strong today in spite of profit-taking near the close of the session. As a result of peace in the European iron and steel industry the heavy industrial shares were especially in demand, with gains of 1 to 2 points frequent and the turnover in Mannesman and Vereininglestahl shares being considerable.

LONDON. THERE recently was published among the personal advertisements of The Times a cri de coeur from a housewife. There must surely be, she said, many women and girls still willing to undertake private domestic service, yet she found the quest for suitable assistance in the home almost hopeless.

TORONTO, Ont., July 25. -- After nearly fifteen years of preliminary trials the district of Patricia, in Northwestern Ontario, promises this year to show a crop of new records and also to reveal a most promising development in Canadian mining history.

The principal offering last night at the Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was the initial performance there of Paul White's First symphony in E minor and conducted by the composer himself.
AMERICA will be plugged in on the "forty nations switchboard" at Berlin through which several hundred stations throughout the world will eavesdrop on the Olympic Games opening on Saturday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Charles Jewtraw, Valentine Bialis and Jack Shea, former Olympic skating stars, who won their laurels in Winter meets here on ice thirty inches thick with the mercury playing around 30 below zero, are to be among the judges of the midsummer Silver Skates Derby, finals of which are to be skated on the Olympic Arena ice sheet here on next Saturday night before a fashionable Summer throng.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 25. -- A Briton from the Isle of Man, who since his World War days, when he was a Royal Flying Corps aviator, has driven as a professional nearly everything that makes speed -- planes, automobiles, motorcycles and boats -- made history in America's oldest motorboat classic on Lake George today.

NAPLES. AN outstanding contribution to the literature of music history has been made this year by two eminent Neapolitan musicologists, Guido Pannain and Andrea Della Corte, with their exhaustive work, "Storia della Musica dal 1600 al 1900," recently published in two large, illustrated volumes by U.T.E.T., Editori, Turin.
ST. PAUL, July 25 (AP). -- A Federal court jury tonight convicted John P. (Jack) Peifer, night club owner, on a charge of conspiracy in the $100,000 kidnapping of William Hamm Jr., St. Paul brewer.

FOR peasant families long attached to the soil the Italian Government has special honors. Recently the most remarkable instance of fidelity to the earth (Fedeli alla Terra), as the Fascists put it, came to light. Giuseppe Pierantoni, awarded a prize by Premier Mussolini, is the cultivator of a plot of land which has belonged to his ancestors for 918 years.

Mayor La Guardia's attack last week on New York's five Republican county leaders apropos of their candidate for Aldermanic President highlights a question of politics which has been increasingly thrust into prominence since the Mayor took office as a successful Fusion candidate on Jan. l, 1934.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP). -The Cubs increased their National League lead to three games today, beating the Phillies, 17 to 4, while the Bees defeated the Cardinals.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- In a blazing quarter of a mile, turned in between the far turn and the top of the stretch, Granville today burned out the challenge of Mr. Bones and rushed on to a decisive victory in the $35,400 Arlington Classic, run for the eighth time and watched by 35,000 persons.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 25. -- President Robert C. Clothier of Rutgers University announced today a list of faculty appointments, reappointments and promotions.

MARSEILLES, France, July 25. -- Spanish women who fought like furies, shaming their men comrades in Barcelona battles, were described today by an American woman when the American Export Line's steamship Exeter, bringing refugees from the Catalan capital, reached here today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Plans are being completed for the annual horse show under the auspices of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club, which will take place on Aug. 8 on the clubhouse grounds on North Sea Road. Entries will be drawn, as in previous seasons, from well-known exhibitors from Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey.

Mrs. Cushman has an engaging way of linking up the part played by charming country cottages, rescued from dilapidation, in the crises of married life. In "But for Her Garden," a rustic ruin figured largely in the heroine's problems of marriage. In "The Bright Hill" a downtrodden wife finds the end of her rainbow in a tiny New Hampshire cottage which she rescues from rural desolation.

MOSCOW, July 24. -- It seems only yesterday that ordinary Soviet citizens, even of undoubted loyalty to the regime, could not hide a certain apologetic enviousness when discussing Soviet accomplishments in relation to similar accomplishments in the Western World.

STEEL is in the minds of business men and labor leaders today as an attempt to unionize the industry is undertaken again with more vigor and more money than ever before. If the effort causes some shivers of apprehension to travel down the backs of both labor and industrial management, it is because every steel war has been bitter, with wounds that have burned long after the struggle was over.

WHERE and what are the biggest trees in the world? Foresters and timber cruisers classify the sizes of trees in three ways, as to height, basal diameter and volume. Ordinarily, however, when we speak of bigness in trees we mean height rather than girth or bulk.

AVOIDING the usual disclaimer that any of his characters are pictures of real persons. Francis Wallace frankly dedicates his book "To the boys, and girls, of the fight mob -- whose only regret will be that I haven't spelled their name right." His prizefight story begins in a Miami hotel room with an exchange of blows between the heavyweight champion and a bellhop.

The military uprising in Spain is the final outburst of latent Fascist, clerical, and aristocratic forces which for many months have sought to undermine the Left Republican government at Madrid. Ever since the Popular Front, comprised of Syndicalists, Communists, Socialists, and Republican parties, won its victory in the elections of Feb. 16, there have been rumors that the army would use force to annul the decision of the people.

ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.J., July 25. -- Al Diss, son of Vice Commodore Daniel B. Diss of the Island Heights Yacht Club, sailed Tamwock to victory today in the Rodman Wanamaker Trophy contest for catboats over a 12 1/2-mile course. He finished 1 minute 50 seconds ahead of R. Gale in Mary Ann.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 25. -For the first time in four years this city has been able to look forward to the opening of the Music Festival, which began tonight, without fear of violence from across the German frontier, which is only ten minutes away by automobile.

THE ghost of gold, believed to have been laid low by the measures of "national emergency" of the last few years, has again risen to disturb the peace of mind of both advocates and opponents of an international gold standard.

MADRID, Sunday, July 26. -- The Spanish Government, in an international broadcast early today, contended that the nine-day-old rebellion was clearly dominated by loyal forces and that rebel centers would be seized within a few days.
CAMBRIDGE, July 25. -- The award of six major prizes at Harvard University was announced today.
BROOKLINE, Mass., July 25. -- Frank Parker of Spring Lake added his name today to a long list of distinguished winners of the eighth Longwood Bowl going back to 1921.
NAPLES, July 25 (AP). -- Bishop Gallagher on arriving here today denied absolutely that his visit to the Vatican had anything to do with Father Coughlin's activities, and said:...

Those young fellows walking down the road, carrying fishing poles, are not being overlooked in Pennsylvania. Not so long ago the State stocked a pool at Allentown with catfish, perch and sunfish for the exclusive use of boy anglers.

PATERSON, N.J., July 25. -- Charles "Mickey" Norman Jr., who will be 5 years old Tuesday, is still a fickle smoker. The robust lad, who became addicted to the use of the weed when he was 2 years old, is still unable to make up his mind on the relative delights to be gained from a pipe, a cigar and a cigarette.
JERUSALEM, July 25. -- The Arab High Committee, meeting today, found itself facing a dilemma.

VIMY, France, July 25 (AP). -- A vast pilgrimage, headed by King Edward of England, converged on Vimy Ridge tonight.

Between the Mediterranean and the Black Sea lies the world's most historic waterway, known as the Straits. It consists of the Dardanelles, the Sea of Marmora and the Bosporus. It includes Constantinople, now called Istanbul, with its Byzantine memories.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 25. -- The second formal review of the 1936 Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp will be held tomorrow at 5:15 P.M. on Division Hill, the C.M.T.C. parade grounds. Awards to the best-drilled companies will be made.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 25. -- Bank clearings continued large at Kansas City this week, despite the continued dry weather, which has placed the corn crop in this area in a critical condition, and has handicapped retail trade.

TOKYO, July 25. -- The Japanese military air force will be reorganized and enlarged into a virtually independent arm of service as from Aug. 1 under a new headquarters, which will have almost the same status as the War Office and the general staff.

MANCHESTER, England, July 25 (Canadian Press). -- A vigorous onslaught by England's batsmen in the first day's play of the second test match with India put the mother country in a good position to obtain a big first-innings lead when play is resumed Monday.
In common with all my countrymen, I look forward to the America that is to be.
HENDAYE, France, July 25 (AP). -- Fighting died down along this stretch of the Spanish frontier today. Only a few artillery shots were heard.
BERLIN, July 24. -- "The biggest show on earth" will get off to a rousing start here on next Saturday that would have warmed the cockles of the heart of one Phineas Taylor Barnum.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A ten-point attack on Governor Landon's labor record was made today by Labor's Non-Partisan League, which asserted that "the record of the candidate of reaction is not a labor record -- it is an anti-labor record."

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- During the past four months the WPA has dropped, about 750,000 people from its rolls. A large proportion of this reduction has taken place in agricultural areas in response to the need for seasonal farm labor.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25. -- Wraith, pacing gelding owned and driven by William H. Lockwood of Brooklyn and Cynara, trotting mare, the property of Louis Schmieder of Elizabeth, scored the outstanding victories in the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -With the refusal of the twelve unions forming the Committee for Industrial Organization to appear for trial before the executive council of the American Federation of Labor on Aug. 3 and answer a charge of forming a dual or rival organization, the stage appears to be set for suspension of these unions as a preliminary toward reading them out of the federation at the November convention.

ST. LOUIS, July 25. -- During the 1934 drought, Rexford G. Tugwell, Resettlement Administrator, placed St. Louis in the center of the new American desert which he then saw in the making. The forecast seems less fantastic in 1936.

ZANVOORT, The Netherlands, July 25. -- At the close of tonight's play in the sixth round of the International chess masters tournament at the Grand Hotel, Reuben Fine, the American entrant, was still in the lead, although he gained but half a point from his encounter with Ernst Gruenfeld of Austria.

Clubfoot, that sinister figure of Valentine Williams's earlier books, limps menacingly across the stage in his latest story and proves himself to be a sort of merchant prince in espionage. For Clubfoot has been exiled from Nazi Germany. He is a man without a country now, buying and selling the important secrets of all nations.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 25. -- Justice Frank T. Lloyd, sitting in the Supreme Court here today, denied applications for writs of habeas corpus made by twenty strikers and sympathizers, including Powers Hapgood, an organizer for the Committee for Industrial Organization, arrested here recently in connection with RCA-Victor strike disorders.

TELEVISION engineers working to perfect their science in field tests from the 10-kilowatt image transmitter atop the Empire State Building in the first month of their observations have found New York's air full of "electrical freckles."

CHADWICK, N.J., July 25. -- While several hundred bathers looked on, a Naval Reserve mechanic was thrown out of his plane to death this afternoon when the pilot made a sudden manoeuvre to avoid hitting a bird a short distance off the beach here.

MOST Wodehouse enthusiasts are ready with an anticipatory chuckle at the mere sight of the jacket on a new Wodehouse book. The latest sports a cover showing a young man in spats, unseated as to trousers, but firmly ensconced atop a wardrobe, prepared to ward off further attacks from a ferocious Alsatian dog.

A broad attack upon homewares merchandising problems, which in the past have affected the profit showing and have caused sections handling these goods to become known as the "alibi departments," was seen here yesterday, following the organization last week of the Housewares, China and Glassware Buyers' Group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WHEN La Argentina brought to a close her sixth American season in December, it was recorded in these columns: "There could be no doubt from the reaction of the house that the dancer's return next season will be awaited as eagerly as usual."

WOMEN whose hands are becoming dry and calloused through gardening or gripping golf clubs and tennis racquets are receiving a few hints from an expert on how to keep their hands in condition for more urbane activities in the Fall.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 25. -- The annual flower show of the Westchester and Fairfield Horticultural Society, with the garden clubs of Greenwich, Old Greenwich, Riverside and Rye cooperating, will be held on Sept. 23 and 24 in the State Armory.

Former Representative Ruth Baker Pratt has taken over an office close to that of Miss Natalie Couch at headquarters of the Republican National Committee, 41 East Forty-second Street, and will help to coordinate the work of various women's organizations.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP). -- Rain continued its assault on the drought today. The downpour covered most of Indiana and Illinois and reached over into Iowa.

TROY, N.Y., July 25. -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today announced the winners of the five scholarships awarded annually to applicants on the basis of highest marks in Regents' examinations in subjects required for admission. The competition is State-wide.

BUDAPEST, July 24. -- The most noticeable Hungarian reaction to the Austro-German agreement has been revival of the strength of the pro-German supporters of Premier, Goemboes. Six months ago Mr. Goemboes's illness -- which though not dangerous probably will prevent him from again playing an active role in Hungarian politics in the face of the merciless attacks of his opponents -- caused his supporters' stock to sink.

ALL the significant manifestations of music are not necessarily revealed in the principal temples of the art. The major opera companies and symphony orchestras on occasion devote time and money to productions for which there is no apparent demand.

Citing the new safety record made by New York City's automobile drivers in the first five months of this year, Mayor La Guardia moved yesterday to obtain a reduction, in line with that record, of casualty and liability insurance now charged to automobile owners.

BEING told that a lifelike segment of Madison Square Garden, with spectators, had been fixed up on the Paramount lot, 1 went out there, impelled largely by nostalgia. Except that there was a sky instead of a roof, it looked like the real thing.

FORT NIAGARA, N.Y., July 25. -- This historic border post was host today to more than 500 Legionnaires, replendent in colorful uniforms, who with their wives and children invaded the reservation to celebrate American Legion Day with 600 Western New York boys of the Citizens Military Training Camp.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., July 25. -- Structural alterations on two buildings at Lawrenceville school have been started to permit the introduction of a new system of small-group instruction this Fall, it was disclosed today.

BERLIN, July 25. -- With a lavishness and panoply of ceremony no other Olympics in history have had, the eleventh modern Olympic Games will start in the magnificent stadium here Saturday when the ringing tones of Chancellor Hitler boom forth the news in one simple sentence that the meet is formally declared open.

The motor, steel and electrical equipment stocks led the share market generally higher yesterday. Nearly two-score issues attained new high marks for the year. Trading on the Stock Exchange was fairly active during the two-hour session, amounting to 611,000 shares, against 557,000 the Saturday before.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The United States has been put in an embarrassing position by German recognition of the Italian conquest of Ethiopia, it was privately admitted in diplomatic circles here today. The recognition of the new empire by a major power is held to place the United States in a position where she soon will be forced to recognize the conquest or withdraw her legation from Addis Ababa.

LENOX, Mass., July 25. -- The second and closing day of the eleventh annual Lenox horse show provided interesting competition today. Prominent among the exhibitors with at least four prizes apiece were Miss Eleonora R. Sears of Beverly Farms, Mass.; Mr. and Mrs. Darwin S. Morse of Green Meads Farm, Richmond, Mass.; Miss Fredericka Fry of Greenwich, Conn., and the Misses McCreery, also of Greenwich.

NAPLES. THE famous headaches of Gaetano Donizetti have given birth to several anecdotes, in part imaginary and in part true. It is well authenticated, for example, that splitting headache accompanied the composition of the final tenor aria of "Lucia" -- (Tu che a Dio spiegasti l'ali").

POLAND SPRING, Me. -- The qualifying round of the Arthur H. Fenn Memorial Cup tournament will start tomorrow with match play and will continue through Friday. The women's championship for the Emily Rockwood Cup will be played here during the first week of August.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- With the cry of "A plague on both you parties!" dissident politicians are organizing a third-party movement in Illinois. If plans now taking shape work out as expected, it will be the most extraordinary combination of political diversities ever witnessed in the State.
Several persons were killed and others critically injured in automobile accidents yesterday in this city and the suburbs.

Ceuta is the headquarters of the Spanish Foreign Legion, or Tercio de Extranjeros, as it is known throughout Spain. The commander-in-chief of this independent branch of the Spanish Army is always the military governor of Morocco.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Unless influences outside the normal operations of business processes intervene, "the course of 1936 may show this as the best year in physical volume of business since 1929," according to a summary of national business affairs made public today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Eddy Brown, president of the Chamber Music Society of America, announces a series of concerts next season to be given at the Fifth Avenue galleries of the Grand Central Art Galleries. The Fasquier Trio of France will make its New York dbut at one of these events Jan. 12.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A gain of two seats in the Senate, but losses in the House in the November election, were predicted today by Chairman Farley of the Democratic National Committee.

SHORT-WAVE Station W2XAD, Schenectady has increased its schedule by adding one daily and three-quarters hours. The transmitter operates daily, including Sundays, on 15,330 kilocycles, or 19.56 meters, from 10 A.M. to 3:45 P.M., Eastern standard time.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- With tourist travel at its height and the movement of fruits and vegetables to both overseas and transcontinental markets approaching its seasonal peak in the State, general business is enjoying an upturn in California such as has not been experienced for several years.

IN the Olympia Stadium on the western fringe of Berlin the five-ringed Olympic flag will be hoisted to the top of the pole at 4 P.M. next Saturday and the games celebrating the Eleventh Olympiad of modern times will be officially under way.

Sales figures mounted to high levels last week as retail buyers from all sections of the country, anticipating one of the most active Fall buying seasons in several years, thronged the major branches of the wholesale markets to obtain all types of merchandise.

The calling of numerous lots of foreign securities was a feature of the announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity. Domestic refundings continued light, most of the operations covering municipal bonds. Redemption dates for the new listings were all in forward months.

BOSTON, Mass., July 24. -- New complications following hard upon the court's order for liquidation of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company now trouble the city of Manchester. The people of that industrial center of New Hampshire had discounted in advance in some degree what was recognized as an inevitable calamity.

Robinson, 44-year-old stockbroker indicted on the complaint of a Brooklyn insurance broker who said he had been defrauded of more than $105,000 in cash and securities, was held without bail yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig in the Court of General Sessions for a further hearing tomorrow.

ST. JEAN DE LUZ, France, July 25. -- The slaying of the Norwegian Consul's wife and her nurse in San Sebastian, Spain, by boys barely big enough to hold rifles was reported tonight by refugees reaching here from that city.

Formidable millions of little marine animals known as teredos are waiting outside New York Harbor ready to dash in and cause millions of dollars' worth of damage to maritime property, according to marine biologists and others who have studied the problem in recent months.

MADRID, July 25 (Passed by the Censor). -- Another illustration of the social and political reconstruction that is rapidly getting under way in Spain as a result of the military uprising against the government is provided in today's issue of the newspaper ABC.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25. -- Race week at the Larchmont Yacht Club wound up today in a blaze of glory. There was buoyant sunshine, a splendid breeze and a fleet of 283 craft in competition.

At least one enviable distinction belongs to the 1932 Olympic Games at Los Angeles. Never before was there such a concerted assault on records by the athletes of the world. All but three Olympic standards were swept aside as nineteen new records were established.

President Roosevelt and Billy Rose, both New Yorkers, are men of outstanding popularity in Texas these days, Leon O. Moses, Assistant Attorney General of that State, said yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

HONOLULU, Hawaii, July 25. -- Heavily laden with building materials and carrying a group of new colonists chosen from the personnel of the Kamehameha Boys School, the Coast Guard cutter Itasca departed yesterday for Baker, Howland and Jarvis Islands.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- The world is short more than half a billion bushels of wheat, it is estimated. Practically every major wheat belt in the world, including that in the United States, produced less than a normal crop this year. There will not be enough wheat threshed this year to provide consumers with their normal ration of bread.

A suit by Amos Sulka for the cancellation of a $30,000 note given to the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, of which he was a director, and for the return of 1,600 shares of A. Sulka Co. put up as collateral was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Goddard.

NEWPORT, R. I. -- With the arrival of August at the end of the coming week the major entertainment of the Summer will get under way here. The social colony, as well as the army and navy contingents, will Be particularly active next Saturday night, for which two outstanding events are planned.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- The State Department today issued the following list of Americans evacuated from Spain.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- A studio party with dancing was given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Herter and their grandson, Everit Herter, in the studio at the Creeks.

A REVIVAL in American rail travel that promises before the end of the year to achieve history-making proportions is revealed by a midsummer survey of rail activities. With 1929 figures already surpassed on many lines, close observers of railway developments are predicting that 1936 will set a new standard for travel comparison.

THE first requirement for the production of native operas is that they be written. That would seem to be axiomatic. The trouble has been in the past that many young men and women who set themselves the task of writing an opera have no conception of the problems of the stage or the voice.

AIRLINES, the country over, are doing the best business in their history. They have met the menace to their existence contained in the curtailed air mail rates provided by "temporary" legislation which followed the cancellation of air mail contracts more than two years ago, by providing such speed and luxury of passenger travel and such facilities for air express as to greatly increase these factors in their business.

About 25,000 cases, representing from 75,000 to 100,000 men, women and children, have been dropped from the relief rolls in New Jersey since the State turned administration of direct relief back to the municipalities on April 15, it was learned yesterday.
DALLAS, July 25. -- There is little evidence of the usual midsummer recession in business in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District.

THE seventh annual gladiolus show of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society will be held this year in Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, on Aug. 7, 8 and 9. In the more than eighty entry classes in the schedule sections are provided for amateurs, novices, professional gardeners and commercial growers.

EASTPORT, Me., July 24. -- The world's greatest plan to force the ocean's tides to make electricity for man's use is being put away with moth balls and camphor as rapidly as the ingenuity of its directors will permit. The process of putting away, however, is almost ostentatiously motivated by the feeling that the Passamaquoddy project will be revived one day, and the sooner the better.

The attitude of persons who would require aliens to become naturalized citizens under threat of deportation is opposed by Nathaniel Phillips, president of the National League for American Citizenship. He declares in a statement that citizenship is cheapened and degraded "when we make naturalization the basis for compulsory bargaining."

There has been so much discussion in the press concerning the constitutionality of acts of Congress granting assistance and subsidies to the States, individuals, and in particular to farmers, that it seems pertinent to advert to such acts proposed in the Congress in 1790, a time when many of the framers of the Constitution were members.

NEXT Friday President Roosevelt will spend a day on Canadian soil with Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of the senior Dominion of the British Commonwealth. For the first time an American President will visit a Governor General in Canada. For the second time an American President will officially set foot in the Dominion -- President Harding once spent a few hours in Vancouver on his way home from Alaska.

THERE is a phenomenon of the depression which has been commented upon frequently, though perhaps not enough. By the thousands, in numbers sufficient to constitute a wave of migration, young people have been trailing forlornly back to the homes which sent them forth so confidently.

In time for the Olympic Games, a new edition of Baedeker's handbooks for travelers, "Germany" (Das Deutsche Reich, sixth edition, Leipzig, 1936), has made its appearance in German. While the last English editions of Northern and Southern Germany, published in 1925 and 1929, respectively, were printed in two separate volumes, this new guide appears as a single book.

READING, Pa., July 25. -- The 195th year of the old Catholic Mission at Bally, this county, will be celebrated tomorrow with a district assembly of the Holy Name Societies Union of Berks and near-by counties. It is the third oldest Catholic church in Pennsylvania.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 25. -- Representatives of the nation's scientific societies will come to Williamstown in October to participate in the centenary celebration of Mark Hopkins's induction as fourth president of Williams College.

ST. LOUIS, July 25. -- Scattered showers in the Eighth Federal Reserve District this week materially reduced the high temperature, but they were not of sufficient magnitude to afford any great betterment to the crop situation. It is stated that the loss by the drought in this district approximates the total of the 1934 drought and bids fair to exceed it if relief is not near at hand.

HOLLYWOOD, July 21. DESPITE our own little private heat wave -- Southern California's worst in many years -- we are in the midst of a theatrical boomlet or at least we are approaching one. After a successful engagement of six weeks "Call It a Day," with a cast headed by Violet Heming and Conway Tearle, has given way at the resplendent El Capitan Theatre to a production of "Parnell," which opened Sunday afternoon last.

FEW of our modern highways are as efficient as the automotive equipment passing over them. Engineers have developed the automobile so that it travels easily at high rates of speed, but highway engineers have not as yet been enabled to build highways sufficiently safe for the average driver.

A NUMBER of Little girl diaries have been published, from that of Anna Green Winslow, who lived more than a hundred years ago, down to "The Diry" of present day Sylvia McNeely; nevertheless there is a place for this little volume, which has the charm of complete spontaneity and the engaging quality of unspoiled and unself-conscious childhood.

Net profit of the Sun Oil Company and subsidiaries in the first half of this year amounted to $3,474,811, allowing for the deduction of depreciation charges, depletion, interest, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits. After dividend requirements on the 6 per cent preferred stock, the earnings are equivalent, to $1.57 each on 2,023,542 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of June.

The rules promulgated last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission to govern unlisted trading on registered Exchanges were regarded in Wall Street as representing another victory for the New York Curb Exchange over the opposition of the local over-the-counter fraternity to the extension of such trading privileges.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 25. -- Weetamoe, with her owner, Chandler Hovey, at the helm, won the concluding race between the America's Cup class sloops under the auspices of the New York Yacht Club today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 25. -- Mrs. Charles S. Whitman gave a buffet luncheon at Rockland this afternoon before the opening of the retrospective art exhibit of the work of old Newport artists at the Art Association.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- While industrial activity continues at a relatively high level, some indications of seasonal recession recently have been observed, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of business.

THE Westport Artist's Market, Inc., opened its fifth season July 11 in new quarters in the Brick House, corner of Burr Avenue and Boston Post Road. It was formerly at the Old Nash House. Among the artists showing work are George Wright, J. Mortimer Lichtenauer, John Steuart Curry, Harry Townsend, Justin Sturm and John William Fenton.
