RUMORS of some rather clever strategy behind the signing of James Cagney by Grand National, the concern that has arisen from the ashes of Pathe, are beginning to disturb the film city. Until now the industry has been guided by the procedure laid down by the producers' association, and throatcutting has been done only according to the rules of the organization.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Because of the increasing popularity of its new clubhouse, opened early this month, the Lake Champlain Yacht Club at Burlington is enlarging its plans for the annual regatta this year and will extend it from one day to two.

RYE, N.Y., July 25. -- After a lapse of three years, polo was resumed at the Westchester Country Club today when the local quartet, headed by Merrill Fink, scored an impressive 9-7 victory over the South Shore Polo Club of Long Island.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., July 25. -- Descendants of the Pilgrims who fled from religious persecution in England in 1620 have called on their fellow Congregationalists in Great Britain for a union of free churchmen in democratic countries to preserve the political, academic, land religious freedom which they say is under attack from autocratic governments.

QUEBEC.-- A regime which has been in force in Quebec since the earliest days of the seventeenth century will come to an end on Nov. 11 when tithe-payers of the Province will see the Province take over all seigniories.
Soviet Russia is using chemistry to destroy religion, Rudolf Selden reports in the current issue of "Industrial and Engineering Chemistry," the organ of the American Chemical Society.

WHAT is the part of Christian missions in the new day? That question, and the answer to it, form the theme of Dr. Latourette's book. Facing the universality of change in the world's present existence, he writes from a frankly realistic point of view which is, nevertheless, far removed from pessimism.
SEATTLE, Wash., July 24. -- Politics in the State of Washington are at furnace heat this week.

Bonds valued at $20,000, which were stolen by safe cracksmen from the government safe in the post-office at Braidwood, Ill., were found in the possession of Albert Montlake, 45 years old, of 7,746 Kingston Avenue, Chicago, the police charged yesterday in Felony Court.

CHANGE: A year ago last Thursday Haile Selassie celebrated his forty-fourth birthday by providing a raw meat feast for his chiefs and warriors in Addis Ababa. Last Thursday he quietly celebrated his forty-fifth birthday at Worthing, England. King Edward sent him a message congratulating him on the anniversary.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Officials today reported that intense heat had caused a 65 per cent increase in the number of deaths in principal cities.

IN their passionate desire to find a way of escaping war, men will persist, says Dr. Beard, in oversimplifying war's "cause." They tell themselves, he explains, that "wicked men make war -- political or economic men, or both," and that if these wicked men could only be stopped from their wickedness, all the peace-loving citizens who make up the great body of humanity could go about their peaceful pursuits, in peace.

ALBANY, July 24. -- This Summer's drought, which has become nearly State-wide in New York, is an extremely serious matter in relation to the agricultural life of the State. The word "life" is used advisedly, since nearly all of agriculture is based primarily upon biological, or life, processes.
BOSTON, July 25 (AP). -- Home runs produced the scores today as the Bees defeated the Cardinals, 3-2, in the first game of their series.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 25. -- Entrance of architecture into the field of long-term civic planning is believed by experts to be the chief significance of completion at Syracuse University of a master rehabilitation plan for the city of Syracuse and Onondaga County.
BERLIN, July 25 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh today indulged his passion for the scientific side of flying so freely that he missed a scheduled yachting trip.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- The four seeded combinations, including the top-ranked pair, Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., made their way into the semi-final bracket as the annual men's two-day invitation doubles tennis tournament began on the Maidstone Club courts today.

WITH a word of commendation from President Roosevelt the National Youth Administration has been launched on its second year. An appropriation of $71,250,000 -- $21,500,000 more than that for the last fiscal year -- permits Director Aubrey Williams and his aides to expand NYA services for a year-round average of 500,000 needy youth between the ages of 16 and 25.

CALLING television "a highly specialized branch of the communications family tree," research leaders now declare the time has arrived to formulate standards for its growth. They aim to avert a wild spread of the television branches so they will not become tangled with others in radio -- chiefly, sound broadcasting.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- A historic Holmesdale, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Weston, of Holmes Road, the tenth annual Pittsfield Horse Show is to he held next Friday and Saturday under the auspices of the Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club.

THE pioneer aviation enterprise in the islands, Philippine Aerial Taxi Company, has completed its first 1,000,000 miles of safe flying. When a Bellanca roared in from Baguio the other day to place the mark in the company's log book its ships had been in the air for 8,652 hours and 16,800 passengers had been carried.

MANILA, July 25. -- President Manuel Quezon announced yesterday the most important change in Philippine educational policy since American occupation. He said he would immediately recommend passage of a universal compulsory education law requiring those now in elementary schools to complete their courses, and after a three-year interim would provide for general compulsory education patterned on the United States plan.

THE valuable census compiled annually by The Publishers' Circular is a census of book production only, not of book distribution or circulation. It supplies, under classified headings, the number of new books listed in the publishers' catalogues, but it tells us nothing of the number of copies printed and sold, so we cannot learn from it which classes of books attract most readers.
MADRID, July 25. -- The government announced tonight that it had recaptured the city of Albacete, in Southeastern Spain, from the rebels.

TOPEKA, July 24. -- Governor Landon made his formal bow to the country here this week and entered on what might be called a new, and undoubtedly the most important, phase of his campaign for the Presidency.

AN audience of 10,000 successfully launched the cooperative Washington Summer concert series last Sunday at the Water Gate Site on the Potomac. Alfred Wallenstein, guest conductor in this first of the seven-week series, directed eighty jubilant players, who believed this enthusiastic turnout meant the success of their venture.

MADAME NEMIROWSKI is one of our first-rank novelists, recognized in America since "David Golder" was published in New York. Her robust talent has qualities of force as well as of delicacy. She is known as an acute observer of the modern scene in its welter of conflicting interests and fierce passions.
WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Administration investigators report that the cost of living for a family of moderate means is higher in Washington than in fifty-eight other representative cities.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Shocked by the disclosure that a former naval officer stands charged with selling secrets to a foreign power, although he was dismissed for "scandalous" conduct as the result of a court martial, officers of the service go quietly about their business of safeguarding the navy, more determined than ever to prevent "leaks" that might damage the country's first line of defense.
CLEVELAND, July 25 (AP). -- The Athletics outbatted the Indians today to defeat the Tribe, 15-12, dropping Cleveland a full game in the American League pennant race, as New York defeated Chicago.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 25. -- More than 300 engineers, including many from New York and other States, heard discussions on a variety of professional subjects at the Connecticut Engineering Congress here today.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, July 25. -- Reproductions of costumes from 1886 to 1936 featured the second half of the good-will tour of the Long Island Tercentenary Cavalcade through the streets of this village and Lynbrook this afternoon.

At the end of the first week of bloody fighting, it becomes possible to begin to estimate the proportions of the stark tragedy of the Spanish people. This civil war -- like many of those of the nineteenth and earlier centuries, fierce and uncompromising -- is different from those struggles between regions or political factions for control of the central government.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., July 25. -- Halting habeas corpus proceedings started to free him, Professor W. L. Clevenger, held for questioning in connection with the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger, his niece, said today that he preferred to remain in jail until investigation of his part in the case had been completed.

A radio "workshop." under auspices of the Educational Radio Project of the Office of Education, United States Department of Interior, and the General Education Division of New York University, has been established this Summer at the university, according to an announcement yesterday.
BERLIN, July 25. -- Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett heard taps sounded to her Olympic swimming career today and then countered with a bitter verbal broadside at officials of the American Olympic Committee.

Running counter to usual seasonal trends, industrial output and distribution have increased instead of declined in practically all parts of the country this month, according to the monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

The recent rebellion in South China was unimpressive as a war, but it yielded a famous victory, nevertheless. Internally its results will be lasting and decisive. Externally its results are more doubtful even if they exert a temporary influence and on first appearance seem to be lasting.

COATESVILLE, Pa., July 25 (AP). -- Ray Murphy, in a "farewell" address today as National Commander of the American Legion, urged members to take up "the greatest program of unselfish service this or any other organization ever undertook."

One of America's most active and skillful amateur pilots who has won many competitions for spot and dead-stick landings, Luis De Florez, has just returned on the Hindenburg from a trip to Germany, converted to a program of airship building for the United States.

ATLANTA, July 25. -- Improvement in all major lines of industry was maintained in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. Crop conditions generally were considerably more favorable, with generous rains falling in most sections of the district.

WITH electricity playing an ever-increasing role in modern life, it was to be expected that eventually it would find its way into the garden. Not until comparatively recently, however, has it begun to be employed there on a scale commensurate with its use inside the home.

INSPIRED by the unprecedented success of the Italian Art Exhibition in the Petit Palate last Summer, the Paris Municipality is at work on plans for another ambitious art show for 1937. Four centuries of French art, from the Renaissance to the present day, will be the subject of this undertaking, which will be held at the same time as the International Exhibition of Art and Technics.

Offsetting the glare of the spotlight which will be focused on the women in Olympic sports in Berlin for the rest of this month and most of August, there will be considerable attention paid to the women in tennis at home for that same period and right through the beginning of September.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 25. -- Troop movements involving 5,600 New York State National Guardsmen will take place tonight and tomorrow as the various units, which include 3,500 infantrymen from the metropolitan area, move out of the State reservations, Camp Smith and Pine Camp to make way for the replacement troops.

DETROIT, July 25 (AP). -- The Red Sox, with two big barrages of base hits, mowed down the world champion Tigers today in the second game of their series, 18 to 3. The Red Sox moved into third place and Detroit dropped to fifth.

BERLIN, July 25. -- The American Olympic team started to train today to get in its best shape for the Olympics a week away, but training has not turned out to be the bitter business that the non-athlete imagines.

LONDON, July 25. -- Sir Arthur Keith, whose views on the question of race grow more controversial with his advancing years, tonight delivered the presidential address to the British Speleological Association at Buxton, Cheshire.

BELLPORT, L. I., July 25. -- Rough seas, backed up by a twenty-knot wind, played havoc with the fleet of fifteen Stars that competed today in the third of a series of four races to select crews to represent Great South Bay in the forthcoming world and North Atlantic championships.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24. -- Whether Philadelphia is to see another grand jury investigation of an alleged alliance among its police, certain public officials and racketeers, specifically gamblers, presumably hinges on an inquiry to be made by a special squad of investigators appointed at the end of a week of charges and countercharges.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 25. -- A field of seventy-one players that started in the Northern New Jersey tennis championship at the Westfield Tennis Club today was reduced more than one-half with one default and one casualty among the seeded players.

IN the Fall of 1878 Sam Bass and Joel Collins took a herd of cattle north from the Rio Grande over the Dodge Trail (also known, says Mr. Gard, as the Fort Griffin or Jones Plummet Trail) into Kansas. Sam, an Indiana lad who had been left an orphan at 13 and had run away from an unsympathetic uncle to become a cowboy, was now 25 years old.

The quiet of old Williamsburg matches the beauty of its restoration. At least that is the firm opinion of two New Yorkers who have just returned from what might be called a patriotic pilgrimage to Virginia. In the comfortable inn on the Duke of Gloucester Street we spent two nights in the recent burning spell of weather -- and the heavenly stillness was so refreshing that it seemed to almost reduce the temperature.

Distribution of 500,000 sheets, pillow cases and towels and 60,000 articles of clothing manufactured by the WPA sewing projects has begun and thousands of home relief families will be benefited, it was announced yesterday by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

FROM the pious accounts of early commentators it is apparent that the tobacco plant was a deceiver, employed by the devil to delude the simple American Indian before he was driven out of his Eden by the Europeans with their flaming swords.
An article in THE TIMES gives in outline the project of the British Government to provide gas masks for every British subject.

Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, challenged yesterday the recent statement by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, that President Roosevelt would receive more electoral votes in November than he did in 1932.

A move to enlist civic, religious, industrial and labor interests in a study to develop constructive liquor control methods was started here yesterday by the Retail Wine and Liquor Guild, association of liquor retailers headed by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin.

A sharp advance in Liverpool stimulated increased activity in the new-crop deliveries on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, and, after a gain of almost $1 a bale, the list ended 10 to 14 points higher than Friday's close. Several blocks of cotton were taken from the ring by brokers for commission houses that sold out a line of the long staple in taking profits around 12 1/2 cents ten days ago.

Women students at Teachers College, Columbia University, have formed an "equal rights" committee to seek permission for members of their sex to attend the annual men's steak dinner, traditionally the most popular social event of the college's Summer session.

It was a good thing for Bill Granard, the star reporter of the Globe, that he had an independent income of his own and that his city editor admired Bill's way of handling news. For Bill had a high-handed manner of holding out on sensational news which some bosses might have disapproved.

I have read with some amazement the letter which appeared over the name of Leila M. Blomfield in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 12. In it she takes Topics of The Times to task for recent comments on the "Hew Deal" in New Zealand and appears to ascribe the economic difficulties of that country to interference with the sacred principles of laissez faire.
The old ferry house at Ninety-second Street and East River, a structure reminiscent of Horatio Alger days, was the scene last week of an exciting and amusing battle.

THE Chautauqua Symphony, which is giving an average of six performances a week this Summer at the Chautauqua Institution, Chautauqua, N.Y., will be conducted tonight and Tuesday night by Howard Hanson. Georges Barrere, regular conductor of the orchestra this season, will appear as soloist on the Tuesday program.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- The Coast Guard tentatively approved today station assignments for its seven new-type cutters, one of which now is undergoing trials.

The Bite of a dog caused the death of a child in Queens yesterday and a sudden outbreak of nonfatal bites led the police and health authorities in various parts of the metropolitan area to take precautionary measures.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 25. -- Mayor Charles D. White proposed this week the formation of a committee to censor the "moral tone" of Atlantic City, for its own protection against malicious talk.

DUBLIN, July 24. -- What the Irish Free State's attitude toward Great Britain would be in the event of another war is of more than academic interest in view of the present relations between the European powers. From a purely military strength standpoint this small State is not likely to count for much, but as a hostile territory on Britain's flank it could constitute a serious embarrassment to the British.

WILDWOOD, N.J. -- An innovation in local vacation entertainment will begin tonight when the Wildwood Choral Society, a mixed chorus of eighty-five voices, gives its first open-air concert on the beach.

GOSHEN, N.Y., July 25. -- Hollyway, 6-year-old bay gelding, son of Hollyrood Walter, owned by Michael Schneider of Milwaukee and driven by Harry McKay, today won the free-for-all pace, feature event on the getaway Grand Circuit racing program at Historic Track.

A couple married four days found themselves in difficulties at police headquarters yesterday as charges of grand larceny were placed against both and an added Sulivan Law violation count against the bridegroom.

Seven Connie Morgan books have already appeared and the author has some nineteen other books to his credit. The list includes such titles as "Blood on the Yukon Trail," "The Yukon Kid," "The Gun Brand," "Raw Gold," thus indicating the type of story that Mr. Hendryx provides in such profusion.

President Charles A. Morrell of the Delaware River Yachtsmen's League has invited all members of the organization to participate in the annual Riverside cruise of nine days, which gets under way Aug. 1.

BANGOR, July 25. -- The sale by auction in Bangor this week of 46,000 acres of timberland at 50 cents to $2.35 per acre and a total of $28,468, recalls the time when public sales of parts of the State's forest domain were held at stated intervals or at such times as the treasury needed money.

WOODBURY, L.I., July 25. -- Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. Robbins Jr. were hosts tonight at Ben Robyn Farm, their country home in the West Hills Colony, at a ball for the benefit of North Shore Holiday House. The guests, about 500, included members of house parties in the Cold Spring Harbor, Oyster Bay and Woodbury Summer colonies and many of them came from dinners around the countryside.

Joseph Cohen, 23 years old, who stands 5 feet 2 inches and weighs 100 pounds, cowered in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday as the investigation began which may send him to the electric chair.

In the current issue of Cosmopolitan DEEMS TAYLOR has been composing a serenade to "Chores.'' According to his liberal definition of the word, they include not only cooking, dusting and bed-making, which are daily vexations Mr. TAYLOR has mastered, but carpentry, woodworking, masonry and electrical wiring, which are skilled trades.

ATLANTIC CITY ,N.J. -- Stretched out along the eight miles of wide, flat beach is perhaps the world's largest cabana colony. Each day finds the cabanas the setting for a number of social affairs. Protecting the guests from the warm rays of the Summer sun, they have proved ideal for card and cocktail parties.

ONE of the opportunities too often overlooked by amateur gardeners is that of midsummer propagation of shrubs and plants. Many things which the small-house owner without a greenhouse cannot propagate in Spring or Winter can be successfully handled at this season of the year if suitable simple equipment is arranged for.

LONDON, July 24. -- The outstanding factor in the European situation only a few months ago was the rearmament of Germany. There is now an equally impressive new factor: the rearmament of other nations hitherto as sincerely devoted to peace as Germany professes herself to be.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- Miss Anne Schuyler Richardson was a dinner hostess tonight at the Crossways, the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson, for Miss Maureen Virginia Smith and Bernard M. Shanley 3d, whose marriage will take place here next Saturday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary.
NEWARK, N.J., July 25. -- Silas Johnson, former pitcher with the Reds, limited Newark to four hits and scored a 9-0 victory today. It was the third straight triumph for Toronto over the Bears.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Colonists at this resort are looking forward to the elaborate program just announced for the annual celebration of General Robert E. Lee Week, beginning Aug. 23. This observance is in honor of the great leader of the Confederacy, who passed the last three Summers of his life here with his family at their cottage in Baltimore Row.
Officials of the Cunard White Star Line at 25 Broadway said yesterday that the Queen Mary had a chance to break the record across the Atlantic set by the French liner Normandie last Summer.

ALBANY, July 25 (AP). -- Arthur W. Harrington, district engineer of the United States Geological Survey, said today that heavy rains are "badly needed" to prevent a serious water shortage in New York State.

TWENTY-SEVEN years ago Sigrid Undset published this novel in Nor way, but until now it has never been published in America. The decision to publish it now was a sound one. This simple story of passion and vengeance during the Middle Ages is more than an early exercise in the field where Mme.

A couple of Harvard scientists -- W.F. Wells and H.W. Brown -- have been trying for years to find out what happens when a person sneezes and what can be done about it. Last week they reported these conclusions:

SEABRIGHT, N.J. -- The forty-ninth annual invitation tennis tournament, which opens at the Seabright Yawn Tennis and Cricket Club tomorrow, is engaging the interest of Summer residents and bringing many visitors to this resort.

PARIS, July 25. -- Coming to France for the first time since his accession to the throne, King Edward VIII tomorrow in the presence of President Lebrun will unveil on Vimy Ridge the Canadian National Memorial erected to the memory of those who on Easter Monday, 1917, wrenched that vital position from the enemy and to the memory of all the other thousands of Canadian soldiers who lie buried in France.

THERE is nothing in the least ironic about the title of Lesley Merrick's very delightful travel book, "A Good Time." The trip around the world whose story is here told was one she heartily enjoyed from first to last, and the reader enjoys it with her.

M.D. SOLOW, who organized the Noble Dog Foundation last year, has issued a statement calling the attention of motorists to a change in the motor-vehicle law which, according to Commissioner Harnett, makes it a misdemeanor for any one who knowingly runs over a dog to leave the scene of the accident without reporting it.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- The more ardent fans in a crowd of 15,000 at Comiskey Park gave themselves over to a session of target practice today as the Yankees opened their visit with a victory over the rampaging White Sox. The score was 5 to 3.

MELVIN VILLAGE, N.H., July 25. -- Since that memorable day in 1913 when he won the United States open championship by beating Harry Vardon and Ted Ray, the two invading stars from England, in a play-off. Francis Ouimet, affable Bostonian, has won many a golf match, yet none perhaps ever gave him quite as much satisfaction as he got today
GIBRALTAR, July 25 (AP). -- Three loyal Spanish warships and rebel-held forts at Ceuta, Morocco, traded shell for shell today in the Straits of Gibraltar, but fog frustrated the combatants.

Featured by thirty-seven stake events, and with approximately $250,000 available in purses, the month-long meeting at Saratoga will begin on Wednesday, to run until Aug. 29. It is the opinion of horsemen that before its conclusion there will be a clear indication as to a 2-year-old champion and that the matter of the championships in the 3-year-old and handicap divisions will have been further clarified.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25. -- The Pacific Westbound Conference has set contract rates for the coming cotton season, according to word received from its secretary, E.J. Watts. During the season from next September to August, 1937, the rates will be 30 cents a hundred pounds to Japan and 35 cents a hundred pounds to Shanghai.

RAYMOND GRAM SWING, former editor of The Nation, told the recent Institute of Public Affairs at Charlottesville, Va., that radio may destroy American democracy unless its programs are better edited and political broadcasting is separated from commercialism.

The number of voluntary and cooperative groups operating in the food industry increased in fourteen months from a total of 775 to 809, while the total membership in these organizations gained from 103,334 to 110,040 retail stores, according to a survey just completed by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

Columbia University's collection of bookplates now numbers more than 8,000, according to Mrs. Clara T. Evans, librarian of the Ware Library in the School of Architecture, who in a report made public yesterday predicted a revival of activity in this field among contemporary artists.

IN the quiet of midsummer, and before any one could really know much about it, Alex Yokel. Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart have got a musical show well under way. More than that, perhaps, for half of it is already completed, and auditions are now being held for the whole.

MEXICO, D.F., July 25. -- Representatives of the employers and employes agreed today to end the strike of 3,000 electrical workers which plunged the city in darkness and threatened disaster to the health of the population.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Officials here were concerned tonight over the continued safety of 148 Americans who have taken refuge in the United States Embassy in Madrid. Eric C. Wendelin, Charge d'Affaires ad Interim in the Spanish capital, informed Secretary of State Cordell Hull in the first direct telephone conversation that all routes to the border were cut off.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 25. -- Superior all the way, largely because of their teamwork, fine hitting and speedy mounts, the Ox Ridge riders today won the annual Hempstead Cups polo tourney at the Meadow Brook Club for the second successive season.

TOPEKA, July 25. -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, one of Governor Landon's chief rivals for the Republican nomination for President, will come here Tuesday to confer with the nominee on campaign plans, Mr. Landon announced today at a press conference.

More claims for reduction of real estate assessments were disposed of by the Law Department in the first six months of 1936 than during all of 1935. Corporation Counsel Paul Windels announced yesterday.

CARRYING hunting-packs filled with scratch-pads instead of flintlock and muskets, a band of intrepid sportsmen set out from the Coast recently in search of open game. They had no worries confronting them about closed seasons or poaching restrictions, for they were not after pheasants, quail or deer.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 25. -- The reorganization plan for the Willys-Overland Company was filed today in Federal court here and is expected to be acted on soon by Judge George P. Hahn. It provides for a $6,350,000 company with working capital of $3,500,000.

SYDNEY. THE fallen elm leaves that litter the pretty, tree-lined streets of Bacchus Marsh, Victoria, each year have taken on a new value this Autumn. The Town Council's street cleaners are bagging the leaves for sale to an unnamed German chemical company.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 (AP). Convinced that Robert James intended to kill himself with a razor blade which was found in his pocket, officers carefully guarded tonight the barber convicted of drowning his seventh wife after torturing her with a rattlesnake.

NEW YORK to Bermuda in four hours" -- that phrase, or another conveying the same information, will soon be displayed in the catalogues and windows of travel bureaus all over the United States. Within the next six weeks, if governmental red tape does not delay the program, New York will be linked with Bermuda by planes of Imperial Airways and Pan American Airways.

If 1936 follows the traditional pattern of an election year, we have now reached a point -- with both acceptance speeches made -- when an interlude may reasonably be expected before the campaign begins in earnest. There will, of course, be no let-up in the run of routine news.

NOW is the happy season for Sea Scouts. On many inland rivers and lakes, or along coastal waters, they are casting off their lines, unfurling sails, steering through wind and wave and current, for their rendezvous. In Sea Scout parlance the rendezvous is the annual regatta, which brings together boys from many miles around for a period of fun and a contest in seamanship.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 25. -- The cottage colony is being augmented this week-end by the arrival of many visitors for the racing season, which opens next Wednesday.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The approach of August finds the Bar Harbor and other Mount Desert social colonies displaying a lively interest in flowers and shrubs, for the Mount Desert Flower Show will be held at Seal Harbor next Sunday.

A law passed by the legislature in 1925 requiring the approval of the Board of Estimate for any transit unification plan proposed by the Transit Commission is the main cause of the years of delay in consolidation, according to a report just issued by the Citizens Budget Commission.

ST. PAUL, July 24. -- As the Presidential campaign starts, the quite general opinion among farm leaders, politicians and others who keep closely in touch with trends of political thought is that Representative William Lemke's third- party candidacy will be a factor in the Northwest States only where the race between President Roosevelt and Governor Landon turns out to be close.

THERE are thousands of exiles who -- veterans of the war -- are today casualties of the peace. Emilio Lussu is one whose life has been a supreme adventure in moral -- indeed, in physical -- courage. Henley the poet -- in his rhetorical phrase -- would describe him as an "invictus."

MANY a gardener has been proud of new plants obtained from a climbing rose branch which, without design, lay along the ground and took root. This is a recognized form of plant propagation, known technically as "layering."

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 25. -- The Edgartown Yacht Club's thirteenth annual regatta today on Nantucket Sound drew a new record fleet of 190 craft. The events were sailed in a southwest breeze, which increased from six knots at the start to nearly fifteen at the finish.

BOSTON, July 25. -- All business indices are pointing upward, not because of inflation but because of sound improvement in economic conditions, Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said in an interview this week in his Summer home at Hyannisport.

DURING these dog days, when in the garden one flower after another finally gives up the fight, the lasting qualities of the antirrhinums or snapdragons are conspicuous. Despite adverse conditions, they still produce a few spikes of bloom.

HYANNIS, Mass., July 25 (AP). -- Joseph P. Kennedy, former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, ignored protests of friends and went ahead today with plans to publish a book on the New Deal knowing well that it "will probably get my head kicked off."

BEGINNING with the year 1900 Professor FitzGibbon has traced the relations between the United States and Cuba up to 1935, step by step, in a clear, concise and impartial manner. After so many recent attacks on American imperialism in Latin America, it is refreshing to come across a book written from an objective and impersonal point of view, which attempts to present in all fairness each changing phase of the relations between the two countries.

WITH the exception of the area within, say, fifty miles of New York City, there is not another section of the country more abounding in Summer theatres than that roughly triangular segment which would have its base upon a line drawn from Boston to the southwest corner of Rhode Island and its apex in the general and watery vicinity of Nantucket Shoals Lightship.
BALDWIN. L.I., July 25. -- Upward of 5,000 automobiles were blessed during the annual observance of St. Christopher's Day at the church of that name in Baldwin at a late hour tonight.

THE Good-Will Court, described as "a radio program which brings the drama and human appeal of real legal cases told by the people involved to real judges sitting unofficially," will be made available to a nation-wide WEAF network audience beginning Sept. 20.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 25 (AP). -- Experiments of the War Department with a mechanized combat force will have an actual test Aug. 1 to 15 in the second army manoeuvres at Fort Knox, Ky.

THE ancients, Professor Hertzler repeats with emphasis, have indeed stolen most of our good ideas. More them 2,000 years before the Christian era -- more than 2,000 years before Aristotle -- a social consciousness is dearly to be seen in the records which have come down to us from vanished civilizations.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 25 (AP). -- Investigation of two PWA sewer projects in Buffalo and Niagara Falls, costing $17,500,000, was closed today with a grand jury's report that it found no evidence of a conspiracy to defraud the government of large sums.
RYE, N.Y., July 25. -- Two dances took place here tonight. The one at the Westchester Country Club attracted more than 300 members and guests.

IT was the luncheon hour in the clubhouse at the Empire City track. Having studied the menu carefully through his pince-nez, Racing Secretary John B. Campbell said that he would have a shrimp cocktail, a couple of lamb chops, a salad and tea. His assistant, Francis P. Dunne, adjusted his spectacles and said he would have a tomato juice cocktail, an omelette, a salad and coffee.

A NEW American political alliance is in the making -- a coalition of four colorful and diverse elements united by the decision of four powerful leaders and a single strand of mutual interest in the theory that "the more abundant life" will come with more abundant money.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Chicago's reputation of former years has been wiped out by a reduction in all types of crime, largely through speedy and aggressive administration of justice, according to State's Attorney Thomas J. Courtney.

IN the Summer of 1932, Dr. Arnold Fanck. German producer of mountain films, led an expedition to Greenland for the purpose of "portraying the life of the icebergs on the screen." He took with him a large and expert corps of assistants and advisers, and the undertaking had an aim of scientific exploration, in addition to its primary object of making picture dramas of Arctic wonders.

THE Federal Communications Commission has been called upon to decide whether the broadcasting of off-the-scene versions of professional baseball games without permission of the baseball clubs is "piracy" or ingenuity.
Some important dividend meetings set for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

The boom in the breeding and showing of thoroughbred dogs which has been evident for more than a year has resulted in an all-time high figure for registrations with the American Kennel Club for the first six months of this year.

AUSTIN, Texas. VISITORS to the Texas Centennial Exposition at Dallas this Summer should push their cars 200 miles further to Austin to see another of the State's greatest wonders -- a university campus which in a decade has been transformed from a cluster of wooden shacks to marble halls -- all through the magic agency of oil.

PARIS. DRESSING for evening in broad daylight is a problem not limited to America, where there is daylight-saving time. Paris grappled successfully with this problem at the recent night racing on the brilliantly illuminated Longchamp course.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The cotton ginner has long recognized as one of the most important of his unsolved problems the excess moisture in seed cotton. Federal scientists tell us that one-third of the long staple cotton and one-fifth of the shorter staple cotton suffer damage in the ginning process as a result of too much moisture.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25. -- Racing in a southwester, forty-eight yachts took part in the series sailed under the burgee of the yachting department of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach today. As usual, the start was off the Speonk shore.

THE grade school and junior high school children of New York City will see a lively and stimulating picture of what it means to earn one's living in the city's major industries and services when they return to school this Fall.

BERLIN, July 25. -- As a reward for negotiating the Austro-German peace pact Chancellor Adolf Hitler today elevated Franz yon Papen to the rank of "Ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary on special mission in Vienna."

A six-ton trellised-covered trailer, with tiers of flowers, interesting plants, garden implements -- identified by their proper names and uses, and other reminders of life in the country, will start a tour of city playgrounds at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

RECENTLY Dr. Thomas Herbert Norton, nationally known chemist, of White Plains, gave credit for excellent health on his eighty-fifth birthday to "an abundance of outdoor exercise." Dr. Norton, who once took an 8,000-mile walking trip through Europe, has long been enthusiastic about the benefits of walking, and an increasing number of hobbyists today share his enthusiasm.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25. -An extensive collection of first editions of American State documents owned by the Harvard Law School, ranging from the 1660 compilation of the General Laws of the Massachusetts Bay Colony to the first draft of statutes for the younger States, is now on public display in the law school library as a feature of the Harvard Tercentenary "open house."

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- A new jury is to be impaneled on July 27 in the government's effort to convict Pedro Albizu Campos, president, and seven other members of the Nationalist party on charges of conspiring to recruit soldiers, incite rebellion and overthrow the government of the United States in Puerto Rico.

AMONG the recent or still current exhibitions in local museums there are three in particular for which catalogues of far more than transitory or just immediate interest were prepared. They should be put on the list of books that will continue to have reference value.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Sports events will vie with social affairs during the coming week at the White Mountain resorts. Preparations already are under way for some important events for early August.

When Alf M. Landon has a speech to write he neither dictates nor uses a typewriter. His method -- it might be called the horse-and-buggy method -- is to sit down with pencil and big yellow scratch pad.

Approximately 55,000 boys and girls received help and guidance last year from the Big Brother and Big Sister Federation, Inc., bringing the total aided by the organization in the past decade in the United States, Canada and overseas stations to more than 500,000, Rowland C. Sheldon, executive secretary, announced yesterday.

Enjoying their most active period in many years, manufacturers of durable goods expect to close the current year with a recovery to at least 65 per cent of the huge volume they enjoyed in the boom years, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

CAPE MAY, N.J. -- One of the outstanding events of the Summer here will take place during the coming week when the eighth annual flower show and hydrangea festival will be held in the newly renovated beach front casino.
CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa. -- All South Africa is surprised at the complete failure of the Wine Growers Association to market African wines and brandies in the United States.

Commodity futures prices for the week ended on Friday were mixed, although changes either way were mostly small. For most of the week, sugar futures were under moderate selling pressure and final prices were lower than a week before.
LONDON, July 25. -- The British Government will take another stride toward reconciliation with Italy next week by ending the last remaining pledges of mutual assistance in the Mediterranean.

IN the words of the biblical declaration regarding the poor, the United States seems to have the problem of business regulation with it always. A half century ago the formation of pools and trusts throughout industry led to widespread demand for their suppression, resulting in the passage of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law of 1890.

Since Charles F. Chapman, racing czar of the American Power Boat Association, made known that the National Sweepstakes regatta to be held at Red Bank, N.J., would be a three-day event instead of the customary two, officials, business leaders and yachtsmen of that borough are cooperating to make the event to be held Aug. 22-24, as important as the Gold Cup regatta at Lake George.

ROME, July 25. -- The German Ambassador, Christian August Ulrich von Hassel, called on Colonel Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, this morning to communicate the German Government's decision to suppress its Addis Ababa legation, replacing it with a consulate general.
El Liberal, a republican newspaper published in Madrid, contained some extremely unorthodox Society Notes last week. For example, these:

Narrow and mixed price movements prevailed in routine trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade loans, including United States Government issues, were firm to slightly higher. Secondary corporate bonds drifted lazily through the two-hour trading period, prices fluctuating irregularly within narrow limits.

IN 1878, at the age of 18, Francis Jehl went to work with Thomas A. Edison, when the Menlo Park Laboratory had been in existence for only two years. He was on the laboratory staff during the development of the incandescent lamp, and worked with the inventor on that and a number of other inventions over a period of years.
DETROIT, July 25 (AP). -- The wounding of an Ecorse Negro factory worker in 1935 was described tonight by Dayton Dean, confessed Black Legion "executioner," as a "prank" of the legion.

MELBOURNE, Australia. July 25. -- Australia begins its financial year with a more favorable outlook than any since the onset of the depression. Satisfactory seasonal conditions are accompanied by good prices for all primary products.

THE whole field of musical art, says Lawrence Gilman in his foreword to this "Encyclopedia of Recorded Music," is being "covered with breath-taking swiftness by the gramophone." The manner in which important music is recorded, he adds, has become musical news; and present-day music-recording, in its technical excellence and its wide scope, is a development of incalculable benefit to music-lover and student.

THIS brilliant book is a skillful attempt to give form and significance to the evolutionary confusion and turmoil that make the history of the Third Republic to date. We are still too near it to realize its general aspect, but Monsieur Bertaut's pictures, and dexterously selected data, make us live through its successive phases, and through certain of its earlier episodes in particular, with a vividness that is at times even painful.

DALLAS, Texas, July 25 (AP). -- Governor James V. Allred, one-time sailor, whose political fortunes have been a Texas sensation in recent years, spread-eagled a field of four to take a 14,219 majority in his race for renomination in the Democratic primary election tonight.

Last November psychologist Dr. GEORGE W. HARTMANN of Teachers College, Columbia University, ran for office in Allentown, Pa., on the Socialist ticket. Aware of the hopelessness of his candidacy, he decided to enrich what he calls "the organized corpus of "knowledge about political psychology."
Your reports and discussions of the Austro-German agreement have, as usual, been beneficently full. But there is one point which has not received adequate treatment in your columns.

DURING the Eighteen Sixties Edward Everett Hale was one of our most popular magazine writers. His father was a nephew of Nathan Hale. Young Everett grew up in the stimulating intellectual atmosphere of Boston and knew all the distinguished men of his day.

The scene of this remarkable story is laid in a place very much like Rockefeller Center, but the author, probably out of consideration for the owners and tenants of that project, has located it in another part of New York City. The story opens with the murder of a man without a face, and a peculiar feature of it is that this man. remains unidentified until the last chapter of the book.

Joseph Potter, a minor thug who was linked to the "arsenal gang" by a lawyer's card found in his pocket, died in Flushing Hospital yesterday after having been taken for a ride and dumped on a lonely road in Whitestone, Queens.

THE new wallpapers suggest a definite American style in the making, a style in which color and cheerfulness of pattern predominate, rather than conventional dignity. At no time in the past have so many fine designs been available in wallpaper of American manufacture.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 25. -- Governor Earle was accused today by the Republican State Committee of promoting this week's "hunger march" on the State Capitol for political purposes and of attempting to have the State pay the bill for feeding and housing the "marchers" without having the transaction appear on the Treasury Department's records.

Mixing brain with brawn in almost equal parts, the Giants made a rather miraculous escape from the caverns of the second division yesterday when they jammed three runs across the plate in the last half of the ninth inning to toss 10,000 onlookers into a delirium and the Reds into the doldrums.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP). -- The United States Army was shown today to have increased its actual fighting man-power by more than 28,000 men during the past year.

HERBERT W. SCHNEIDER is the Professor of Religion at Columbia University, who, fortunately, does not spend all of his time reading the Holy Scriptures. His two earlier books on Italy: "The Making of the Fascist State" and "Making Fascists" (written in collaboration with S.B. Clough) have contributed in no small degree to the enlightenment of public opinion in the Englishspeaking countries.

ANOTHER group exhibition (eleventh in the series) has opened in the Temporary Galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, 62 West Fifty-third Street. It will continue through Aug. 10 and then the galleries will be closed for three weeks so that necessary repairs may be made before the beginning of the Autumn season.
YORK HARBOR, Me. -- Members of the York Harbor Summer colony are finding the end or July a gay period.

TOKYO, July 25. -- Technical changes in War Office administration intended "to drive home the necessity of stricter discipline, to protect military secrets and to unify the personnel administration" are effected by an imperial ordinance taking effect on Aug. 1.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 25. -- England took a great stride toward her fourth consecutive Davis Cup championship today when her big guns -- Fred Perry and H.W. (Bunny) Austin -- hammered Australia's Jack Crawford and Adrian Quist into defeat in the opening singles matches of the challenge round.

A NOTABLE improvement in informational books for children has come about through the recognition of the value of pictures in explaining mechanical processes, and the growth and cultivation of agricultural products. "

The general outlook for trade and industry continues promising, and the stock market is and persistently moving upward. The week witnessed an outpouring of very favorable corporation reports covering operations in the second quarter, and the market's action clearly indicated that by no means all of the good news had been discounted.

OFF FOR EUROPE: Despite a scattering of strikes, the troubles of the sharecroppers, the tug-of-war between craft and industrial unionists, and the drive for unionization of steel and rayon workers, our Secretary of Labor, Frances Perkins, does not consider the domestic labor situation critical.

Plans for the first aerial cruise trips -- fourteen and twenty-one day all-expense flights to Rio de Janeiro -- were disclosed yesterday by Pan American Airways. Sixteen such flights will be made from Miami, the first to start on Aug. 16 and each Sunday thereafter until the series has been completed.

Jose Iturbi, Spanish conductor, said last night that he believes his countrymen "need a strong man to come forward and guide us" and defined the type of "strong man" as "a man with backbone." But he denied having voiced the belief that the "strong man" should be a Fascist dictator.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25. -A notable exhibition of rare early American antiques and decorative arts was opened today at Harvard, in connection with the university's tercentenary celebration.

TOMORROW night's program at the Stadium will feature Bach's concerto in A minor for four pianos, with Harold Bauer, Rudolph Ganz, Jose Iturbi and Mischa Levitzki as soloists. On the same program the four pianists will also be heard at two pianos in Manuel Infante's "Danzas Andalusas," which will be given its first performance in New York.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP). -- "Flying boxcars" will start a national all-freight air express in September under plans which the Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., is reported to be developing.

BEFORE leaving Hollywood, James Hilton, the author, thought seriously of returning to England by way of the Orient so that he could get a chance to see the Himalayas, among whose glacial peaks the scenes of his novel, "Lost Horizon" -- which has just been turned into a motion picture by Columbia -- take place.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 25. -- Marshall H. Eldredge, East Weymouth (Mass.) professional driver, piled up 2,275 points to defeat Clinton R. Ferguson, Waban (Mass.) amateur in two days of outboard racing on the Mohawk River, the closing tests of which were held this afternoon.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., July 25. -- Marshall H. Eldredge, East Weymouth (Mass.) professional driver, piled up 2,275 points to defeat Clinton R. Ferguson, Waban (Mass.) amateur in two days of outboard racing on the Mohawk River, the closing tests of which were held this afternoon.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 25. -- Carl W. Timpson, medalist in the Rockaway Hunting Club's annual invitation golf tournament, reached the semi-final round of the competition by registering a pair of triumphs today.

For sixty-two members of the United States Olympic team, representing America in international competition is no new thrill. Two athletes have been on four Olympic teams, ten on three and fifty on two.

AT a time when travel has not only increased in volume but is spreading more widely across the world, it was a nappy thought of Mr. Curtis to make a list of books of special interest to travelers. That is what this little volume is.

Andre Jesserun, durable Washington Heights welterweight, will oppose Tony Falco of Philadelphia in a ten-round bout at Dyckman Oval tomorrow night. The fight will head a card arranged for the benefit of the Jewish Memorial Hospital and promises to attract a large crowd.
MALVERN, England, July 25. -George Bernard Shaw, 80 years old tomorrow and "too busy to die," said tonight he would like to see Communist States in "all of Europe and America."

Detectives of the Bronx Park station continued their search yesterday for the remaining two of six men indicted Friday by the Bronx County grand jury for second-degree manslaughter as a result of the collapse of an apartment house under construction at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, on June 19, when eighteen persons were killed.

Many of the leading American track and field stars who failed to gain berths on the Olympic team will be seen in action at Randalls Island again on Aug. 15 and 16 when the first annual World Labor Athletic Carnival will be held.

A fifty-cent bet that he could walk six blocks on the Grand Concourse, the Bronx, without a pair of trousers proved costly yesterday to John Phillips, 22 years old, of 324 Grand Concourse. He was arrested before completing his trek and fined $2.

One square mile of the Atlantic Ocean, seventy-six feet deep, carried a potential treasure of $73,094,600 as it was pumped through the bromine plant of the Ethyl-Dow Chemical Company at Kure Beach, near Wilmington, N.C., during the past year, the Ethyl Gasoline Corporation announced yesterday.
OLD LYME, Conn.LYME is the Summer White House of Academe. Here, in this sweet, untroubled countryside, art may drowse, at rest, nor fear the curt rough challenge of reveille.

LONDON, July 22. -- Theatrical interest shifts next week from Piccadilly to the provinces -- to Malvern, notably, where Sir Barry Jackson's festival opens Saturday [yesterday]. On that day Wendy Hiller and "Saint Joan" will honor the eightieth birthday of Mr. Shaw, whil falls on the following day.

AGAIN the celebrated "Three Mesquiteers" ride forth from their 3-Bar-O ranch. And again lead-slinging trouble awaits only their coming. Tucson Smith rides over to Godwin, county seat of Cougar County, to visit his old friend Sheriff Poddy Cameron.

HOLLYWOOD. IT may be that "The Plough and the Stars" will be in Spencer Tracy's life what "It Happened One Night" has been in that of Robert Montgomery. Montgomery remembers with chagrin and bitterness that he declined the Capra film because he considered the story had and the role not substantial enough for him.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 25. -- Australia now faces a situation recalling in miniature that which confronted the United States after the Supreme Court's invalidation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

TOKYO, July 25. -- Japan has long been possessed of a spy mania which has become world famous, and it is at the height of its glory at the moment. It may be expected to be intensified by the recent spy investigations in the United States, notably the Thompson and Farnsworth cases, involving the alleged sale of American naval secrets to Japanese agents.

THIS is a competent first novel about migratory workers in canneries. It is written by a young man who has traveled pretty well all over the country and has put in time himself in the steamy, clattery, bustling air of a fruit cannery.
PARIS, July 25 (AP). -- Ambassador Claude G. Bowers tonight elected to remain at his refuge in Fuenterrabia, near San Sebastian, convinced he is quite safe.

THROUGH Summer diversions and cool retreats still beckon, many travelers are already making plans for world tours extending into the Winter months. Travel bureaus and steamship lines will shortly issue new descriptive pamphlets with alluring pictures of places that may have been missed on past jaunts.

ON Thursday and Friday evenings, the Philadelphia Ballet will make its New York debut at the Lewisohn Stadium, presenting two ballets to music of Maurice Ravel, with choreography by Catherine Littlefield. The first will be the full three-act version of "Daphnie and Chloe," which has never been presented in New York, and the second will be the famous "Bolero."

ROME, July 25. -- Bishop Michael Gallagher of Detroit asserted here tonight that Father Charles E. Coughlin's political activity was a matter "entirely of my own supervision and not one in which the Vatican would take any initiative."

MOST men, whether they confess it or not, read detective stories and crime classics and many collect examples of such literature as a hobby. The following of intricate plots appeals to their analytical powers without being too great a strain on the intellect, while mystery and action thrill the senses and stir the imagination.

THIS story has every appearance of autobiography, heightened by an introverted and sensitive imagination, very "sincere," very youthful, very badly written, revealing, a piece of unconscious humor for exquisites and sophisticates, indeed for any matured literary mind.

The statute imposing the tax upon undistributed earnings of corporations, enacted in the Revenue Act of 1936, places upon corporate management the burden of choosing either to distribute the corporate income of the taxable year or to pay a surtax thereon for failure to have distributed.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 25. -- Buell Patrick Abbott, the 24-year-old Hollywood actor who shunned hill-billy roles in the movies to play comedy parts and devote more time to playing golf, today captured the fifteenth annual national public links championship at the Bethpage State Park Golf Club.

AROUND August arises the question of a new hat. Straws are faded and frazzled by now. Velvet, felt, antelope -- these are the contestants for Fall championship. The reports are that antelope will be liked very much. Velvet and felt are used separately, and, in many hats, together.

The condition of State-chartered banks is steadily improving, their total resources having increased more than $3,000,000,000 last year, the State bank division of the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. Its survey was based on data supplied by the Banking Departments of the various States.

With thousands of buyers here for Fall merchandise ranging from homewares and apparel to dress accessories, sustained activity in the wholesale markets here overshadowed retail developments in the local business picture last week. Retail trade here, however, continued notably brisk, with gains ranging around 15 per cent or more noted for department stores here.

RUMSON, N.J., July 25. -- Two teams which will compete in the tenth annual twelve-goal polo tournament opening tomorrow at Monmouth County Country Club clashed mallets today on Herbert Memorial Field at the Rumson Country Club. The Monmouth County C.C. quartet outplayed Rumson by a score of 11 to 4.

WASHINGTON, July 25. -- A protest against the proposed action of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor in calling to trial the twelve unions allied with the Committee for Industrial Organization has been adopted by Dressmakers Local 22 of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union in New York City, C.I.O. headquarters announced today.

The combined efforts of the National Labor Relations Board and the various unions representing licensed officers on merchant ships to clear up the question of which unions are qualified to act for officers in labor matters resulted in good progress last week and plans were effected to broaden the voting gradually to include all lines.

PALMYRA, N.Y., July 25. -- Described in the history of their faith as the place where the angel Moroni first appeared, the Sacred Grove, near here, today was the scene of a pilgrimage of 1,000 members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.

ISTANBUL. -- The period wherein every Turkish citizen was required to register a surname in accordance with the law promulgated eighteen months ago has expired and any person who has failed to perform this duty will be called upon to pay a fine of 2, and have a surname assigned to him.

MYSTERY mingled with mild romance is the theme of Anne Gardner's latest novel. Chance dropped a pretty, curly-headed schoolgirl from the South into a luxurious New York penthouse which simply seethed with sinister influences. Young Verilea's job was to be social secretary to the mistress of the apartment, a beautiful and wealthy widow whose nerves were on the verge of breaking down.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24. -- Most Pennsylvanians doubtless concluded that when Governor Earle and Senate Republican leaders finally compromised last week on $45,000,000 as the amount to be raised for direct relief in this State until Jan. 31 the end of a long period of tiresome bickering was in sight.

THERE is a growing echo in Summer communities in New York, New Jersey and other States to the protesting voices of the Yonkers residents who object to having their Sunday morning peace of mind disrupted by an invasion of female hikers clad in shorts and halters.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- The second of a series of bridge-teas for the benefit of the Poor and Health Center of Bolton Landing will be held at the home of Mrs. Edwin W. Jenks on Tuesday, Aug. 11; the third, Aug. 18, at the home of Mrs. Leon Janinet, and the fourth, Sept. 3, at the Fort William Henry, with Mrs. James L. Hand as hostess.

It takes a great athlete to win an Olympic championship, but to repeat this feat is an even greater mark of fame. In the forty-year history of the modern Olympics this achievement has been accomplished by eighteen athletes.

IF you draw a line roughly along the 100th meridian from the Canadian boundary nearly to the frontier of Mexico and another line along the eastern foot of the Rocky Mountains you separate from the rest of this year's drought area a territory with marked characteristics of its own.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25 (AP). -- A strange sort of pulse, discovered in red blood corpuscles, was reported to the conference on spectroscopy and color which ended a week's meeting at Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

Further clarification of the Federal Government's attitude toward business and its future policy is essential in respect to regulation, to direct competition with private enterprise and to corporate taxation for the actual reopening of the investment market for strictly new capital flotations, according to the opinions of leading investment bankers, given last week.

Leading banks here suddenly reduced quotations on the German travel mark yesterday by 2 1/4 cents, this action featuring an otherwise dull foreign exchange market in which most leading European currencies gained moderately at the expense of the dollar.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. -- Many cottagers are arriving today and tomorrow to be in residence for the racing season, which opens Wednesday. The opening of the track will bring the Saratoga season to its peak.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 25. -The 1936 Salzburg Music Festival, which is now the most fashionable and popular music festival during the Summer on the Continent, opened tonight before a very brilliant and variously assorted audience which came from everywhere and included many New Yorkers.

LINCROFT, N.J., July 25. -- Entrants from the stable of Miss Elsie B. Holdsworth of Seekonk, Mass., romped off with the principal honors today as the second annual Lincroft charity horse show, a two-day affair, got under way on the picturesque estate of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kaiser.

CHICAGO, July 25. -- Mercantile distribution increased its gains over last year and was ahead of last week in dollar totals as well. Gains with the large retail stores ranged from 10 to 20 per cent, with a few of the stores advancing their August fur sales to take advantage of the active consumer demand. Wholesale houses also reported increased sales totals, some running as high as 30 per cent over last year.

THE announcement last week by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler that motor-vehicle accidents in the city had been reduced by more than 31 per cent since the inauguration of the department's systematic safety campaign in 1933 is fresh and encouraging evidence of the fact that continuous, discriminating effort, instead of sporadic and sensational drives, can diminish the number of persons killed and injured by automobiles.

CONSIDERING the extensive output of meritorious Czech compositions, it remains somewhat inexplicable that so large an amount of it is practically unknown in this country. Here lies a rich field, slightly explored, which might well be taken cognizance of by operatic and orchestral organizations, chamber music ensembles and concert artists in search of new material to exploit.

During the last few months Great Britain has become increasingly armament-conscious. Although powerful circles in that country are pro-German there has Been little real opposition to the policy that the steady rearmament of the Nazi Reich must be met by the steady rearmament of Great Britain.
FORTY-FIVE MILLION Americans -- somewhat less than a third of the population of these literate United States -- are without access to public libraries.

LAKE HOPATCONG. -- Plans will be completed this week by the Hopatcong Borough Citizens Committee, headed by Councilman Herbert Meyer, for the first water carnival to be held here in recent years. The date is Sunday, Aug. 16. The event, which will include swimming, diving, canoe tilting and canoe races, will be held on the River Styx.

TAMPA, Fla., July 25 (AP). -- The Coast Guard investigated today a report that wreckage which might have been part of the missing British motor-ship Nunoca was seen about seventy miles west of Tampa in the Gulf of Mexico.

Although it is nearly a year from completion, Orchard Beach, on the Long Island Sound side of Pelham Bay Park, the eighth of eleven new city aquatic recreational centers, was formally opened to the public yesterday and dedicated by city officials.

NEWARK, N.J., July 25. -- About 500 men and women, mostly gray-haired or in other ways showing signs of advancing age, heard Dr. Francis E. Townsend and the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith address a mass meeting in the Mosque Theatre at Newark, N.J. tonight.
HERALD HARBOR, Md., July 25 (AP). -- The Tyson family of Chestnut Hill, Pa., won honors today as amateur outboard racers competed in nine events at the ninth annual tri-city regatta.

MELBOURNE, Ark., July 25 (AP). -- Democratic Senate Leader Joe T. Robinson of Arkansas charged today that Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas was employing "old foxy procedure by which it is sought to create a straw enemy and then violently attack and overcome him."
PARIS, July 24. -- Whatever the outcome may be, the struggle launched this week has brought Spain's effort to establish a Liberal constitutional republic to an end.

IT would be heresy to consider stories of this genus, no matter how superficial, under the general head of light fiction. Blooded families in which blood always tells still make a solemn subject, whatever the treatment. Some one ought to think up a special, semi-dignified name, however, with which to dispatch this particular brand in a nutshell.

CONSIDERING the extensive output of meritorious Czech compositions, it remains somewhat inexplicable that so large an amount of it is practically unknown in this country. Here lies a rich field, slightly explored, which might well be taken cognizance of by operatic and orchestral organizations, chamber music ensembles and concert artists in search of new material to exploit.

During the last few months Great Britain has become increasingly armament-conscious. Although powerful circles in that country are pro-German there has Been little real opposition to the policy that the steady rearmament of the Nazi Reich must be met by the steady rearmament of Great Britain.
FORTY-FIVE MILLION Americans -- somewhat less than a third of the population of these literate United States -- are without access to public libraries.

LAKE HOPATCONG. -- Plans will be completed this week by the Hopatcong Borough Citizens Committee, headed by Councilman Herbert Meyer, for the first water carnival to be held here in recent years. The date is Sunday, Aug. 16. The event, which will include swimming, diving, canoe tilting and canoe races, will be held on the River Styx.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 25. -- The Connecticut College for Women, the Lawrence and Memorial Associated Hospitals and the Allyn Museum are to receive a total of $1,100,000 in bequests by the will of Miss Virginia Palmer ou this city, who died on July 14. Other gifts total $560,000.

OXFORD, Ohio, July 25. -- The closing exercises today of the McGuffey centennial celebration held by the McGuffey Society of America, on the campus of Miami University, were well attended by many gray-haired fathers, mothers and grandparents. Among the thousands who came from dozens of States were relatives of McGuffey, whose first reader came off the press 100 years ago this month.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 26. -- John Hearst entertained a party this week-end at Montauk on his yacht Pirate. Thomas Chadbourne is here on his Sea Flay. Dr. Edward Weston, Anthony Fokker and Z.G. Simmonds Jr. are others at Montauk with their yachts.

"Wondrous things yet remain to be read out of the Book of God," the Rev. Dr. James Richmond Aitken, pastor of Old Church in Edinburgh, Scotland, asserted in his sermon yesterday morning at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Net income of the Schenley Distillers Corporation and subsidiaries in the first six months of this year amounted to $3,065,948 after provision for interest, depreciation, contingencies, Federal income and capital stocks taxes, but before provision for Federal surtaxes on undistributed earnings.
VIMY, France, July 26. -- It was as ruler of the British dominions beyond the seas that King Edward VIII at Vimy Ridge today unveiled the Canadian National Memorial to 60,000 World War dead.

BERLIN, July 26. -- In an article welcoming the Olympic Games guests to Germany, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Economic Minister and president of the Reichsbank, likewise appeals to the world for commercial credit to enable Germany to replenish her depleted raw material supply.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP). -Cleveland divided a double-header with Philadelphia today by taking the nightcap, 8 -- 5, after the Athletics won the lopsided opener, 13 -- 0. The Indians were held to six hits by Buck Ross in the first game.

BOSTON, July 26 (AP). -- Before a paid attendance of 41,598, the largest crowd in National League Park since 1930, the Bees and Cardinals divided a double-header, today. The Bees won the first game, 4 -- 3, and the Cards took the second, 8 -- 5.
VIMY, France, July 26. -- The text of King Edward's speech at Vimy Ridge follows (the first two paragraphs of the speech, spoken in French, are here translated):

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 26. -John F. Riddell Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club repeated his triumph of a year ago by defeating T. Suffern Tailer of Piping Rock in the final round of the Rockaway Hunting Club's invitation golf tournament today. Competing against the same player who was his opponent in the 1935 final, Riddell triumphed by the margin of 2 up and 1 to play.

In so far as Stock Exchange prices moved ahead again last week, they presumably took their cue from the further statistical testimony to industrial recovery. Railway freight loadings, which in the preceding week reported increase of 28 1/2 per cent above 1935, last week reported gain of 21 5/8.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Following are the names and addresses of persons from the Northeastern United States known to have been evacuated from Spain or to be safe in the United States Embassy at Madrid, as taken from a revised list given out today by the State Department here:

Prices of cotton futures moved uncertainly last week. Moderate gains on Monday and Tuesday were followed by a partial recession from these levels on Wednesday, after which the market strengthened slightly. Net changes for the week on the New York Cotton Exchange were an advance of 26 to 33 points.

LONDON, July 25. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 so 100, stood at 71.7 on July 22, compared with 70.6 a fortnight before, 70.2 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

In one of the largest industrial property deals in the metropolitan area in some time, the McKesson Robbins Co., wholesale distributors of liquors, drugs, pharmaceuticals and chemicals, has leased the four buildings formerly occupied by the Osborne Company at Summer Avenue and Halleck Street, Newark, N.J.

POTSDAM, Germany, July 26 (AP). -- Germany's former Crown Prince, who once flew with the Wright brothers, and Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who spanned the Atlantic, met today at historic Cecilienhof Castle.

A plan of recapitalization for the Amalgamated Leather Company has been approved by the directors, and will be submitted to stockholders at a special meeting on Aug. 26. Clearing up of accumulated unpaid dividends of $105.25 a preferred share is contemplated through the exchange of the 49,600 preferred shares at one share of present preferred for one of new $50 par $3 cumulative dividend preferred and five shares of new common stock.

GIBRALTAR, July 26. -- Moroccan troops commanded by rebel leaders in Southern Spain, left Algeciras this afternoon bound for Malaga. At Guadiano the invading rebels met a force of 300 Communists. Severe fighting ensued and more than 100 Communists and 20 troops were killed.

Seven hundred and eighty-one conventions and trade exhibitions were held in New York City during the year that ended April 30, the Merchants Association of New York reported yesterday. They brought more than 500,000 visitors, each of whom spent an average of $85 during their stay of about four and a half days, or a total of about $45,000,000.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER LIBERTY, Seal Harbor, Grand Manan Island, N.B., July 26. -- President Roosevelt prepared today for an early close of his vacation cruise while his schooner Sewanna rocked at anchor on the white-capped waves of this open harbor.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 26. -- Professor W.L. Clevenger, who was held for questioning in the murder of his niece, Miss Helen Clevenger, has "departed" from the county jail, but is remaining in Asheville.

NEWARK, N.J., July 26. -- Toronto made it five in a row over Newark by taking both ends of today's double-header before 5,000. The scores were 1 -- 0 and 2 -- 1. Newark scored a total of four runs in the series.

HAMILTON, Ohio, July 26 (AP). -- Nine members of one family were killed when their automobile was struck by a fast Pennsylvania passenger train at an unprotected crossing here late today. A tenth member of the family was severely injured.

IN the old days on the Western frontier the young men sang a song in which they bragged that they'd left home for good and that they wouldn't go back home unless they were dragged there in irons. While they lived they'd live with the buffalo, they sang, and when they died they'd die and be buried with a bottle. The attitude behind that song stands up when there is a frontier or a boom.

The Spanish rebellion had a depressing effect upon the foreign exchange market last week. While the reaction was moderate, it was obvious that bankers and dealers were cutting their demands to routine requirements, meanwhile adopting an attitude of caution pending solution of the disturbances.

Yesterday was moving day for the Manhattan General Hospital. Fifty-two patients were transported from the institution's old quarters at 161 East Ninetieth Street to the hospital's new location in the building of the old Lying-In Hospital at 207 Second Avenue.

MELVIN VILLAGE, N.H., July 26. -- After twice saving himself by spectacular recoveries, Eddie Driggs, three-time New York State champion, today won the annual Bald Peak invitation tournament with a sensational chip on the home hole for a birdie 4 to beat Mark Stuart, former metropolitan titleholder, 1 up.

Led by Eddie O'Sullivan, Lou Burns and Eddie Gordon, the New York Curb Exchange team swept to an overwhelming victory in the sixth annual Manhattan Athletic League track and field championships at Castle Hill Athletic Field, Bronx, yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, July 24. -- The downward movement of wholesale prices in the Netherlands, which has been in progress ever since the introduction of a deflationary policy here, seems to have come to an end. The index for wholesale prices in June was at 61.6, compared with 60.9 for the same month last year.

ST. LOUIS, July 26 (AP). -- Al Thomas pitched six hitless innings and his Brownie mates made sixteen safeties to snap the Washington jinx and win the second game of a double-header, 9 -- 3, today, after dropping the first, 9 -- 2.

MILWAUKEE, July 26 (AP). -- One man was injured and two others were arrested in a riot at a German day picnic in Washington Park here today. A score of policemen broke up the melee, but not until the Nazi swastika had been torn from its mast. Authorities said that some seventy-five persons were involved.

VIENNA, July 26. -- Probably as a consolation to the Hapsburgs for the Austro-German agreement, with its rumored private clauses under which the Hapsburg question has been shelved for a period of years, restoration of former Hapsburg property confiscated by the republic has begun.

OMAHA, Neb., July 26 (AP). -- Nebraska corn growers, who had despaired of saving any of their normal crop of 226,000,000 bushels, today were cheered by weather forecasts from Chicago of local showers in some sections tonight and tomorrow.

At the Massachusetts Democratic pre-primary convention Governor CURLEY was recommended for Senator unanimously, except for the dissenting voice of Senator COOLIDGE'S son-in-law, Mr. ROBERT GREENWOOD, Mayor of Fitchburg. In spite of the frosty outlook, Mr. COOLIDGE waited till last week to declare that "to all intents and purposes" he won't be a candidate for re-election.
