Residents of the Staten Island and Brooklyn shores, who are accustomed to see unusual ships and boats of every kind, were startled last week by the appearance of the new full-rigged brig Isobel II sailing up and down the Narrows with as much sail as is usually carried on a boat twice her size.

CAMP DIX, N.J., July 26. -- Before 6,000 persons, the largest crowd ever to attend a C.M.T.C. ceremony here, the second formal review of the 1936 Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp was held here this afternoon on the parade grounds.

ALBANY, July 26 (AP). -- Controller Morris S. Tremaine said today that he had sent checks amounting to $3,954,702.07 to New York State counties, representing their share of alcoholic beverage tax collections for the three months ended June 30.

PARIS, July 25. -- Now that the 14,000,000,000 francs borrowed previously from the Bank of France has been consolidated by the recent convention, the Treasury now is easier, as a large volume of taxes is collected at this time of the year. Also, the issue of new Treasury bonds is reported to be showing appreciable results, although only subscriptions paid for with banknotes taken from circulation can, in reality, obtain fresh resources for the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Establishment of a Federal administrative court to permit segregation of and uniform decisions upon 276 classes of semi-judicial cases now ruled upon by seventy-three Federal agencies under delegation of power by Congress to the government's executive branches was recommended in a report to the American Bar Association today by its special committee on administrative law.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary passed the Ambrose Channel Lightship at 12:30 o'clock this morning with a new record for the westward crossing of the Atlantic.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 26. -- A group of Tyringham Summer residents were entertained this, evening by Dr. and Mrs. Walter W. Palmer with a picnic at Council Rock on the Gilder farm, which two centuries ago was a favorite meeting place of the Indians.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., July 26. -- A supper dance was held at the Cave Grill, Bretton Woods, last evening. Mr. and Mrs. Lyle Phillips chaperoned a group that included the Misses Virginia Wise, Betty Osborne and Virginia Ryan.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 26. -Giving one of the best performances of his polo career, while his team-mates cooperated brilliantly, John R. Fell led the Aiken Knights to a 12-to-6 triumph over East Williston in today's high-goal match at Bostwick Field.

The Rev. Dr. arry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, told his congregation in his sermon yesterday morning that "some forms of atheism awaken resentment even in the most indulgent minds."

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- As Spanish rebel troops beat again at the cordon surrounding north-coast San Sebastian, the United States Summer Embassy and all Americans remaining here were removed from that city today by order of Ambassador Claude G. Bowers.

STOCKHOLM, July 26 (AP). -- President Roosevelt's commission to study European cooperatives today virtually completed its study of Sweden's vast system of retail stores, factories and modern housing projects.

PALMYRA, N.Y., July 26. -- On the spot where a century ago, according to his testimony, Joseph Smith dug up the golden plates that founded a new religion, the Book of Mormon was portrayed in an elaborate pageant tonight.

The outlook for world peace or for peace in America is definitely worse than it was eight years ago, Norman Thomas, Socialist Presidential candidate, declared last night in a talk at International House, 500 Riverside Drive. He accused both major parties of ignoring the danger of war.

The one thing that seemed impossible four years ago now seems about to be realized -- the existence of a world shortage of wheat. The current world production of wheat is estimated in the grain trade at 4,640,000,000 bushels. With 635,000,000 bushels carried over from previous years, this gives an aggregate supply of 5,275,000,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- While the combined value of sales in June of stocks and bonds on national securities exchanges at $1,447,926,966 was an increase of 1.1 per cent over May's figures, the value of stock sales, including rights, fell below the May level, according to a summary issued today by the Securities Exchange Commission.

ROME, July 26. -- The Ministry of Press and Propaganda confirms the substance of the report from Aden, telling of a great fire in the Italian East African port of Massaua. It declares, however, that the details given are inaccurate and greatly exaggerated.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- The Yankees check-mated the forward rush of the White Sox by taking two games from the band of Jimmy Dykes today before the season's record crowd of 50,000 at Comiskey Park. The second contest was marred by one of the most disgraceful scenes enacted on a baseball diamond in the modern history of the game.

This is an age of confusions in which the individual can be smothered in conflicting philosophies unless he sets himself right with God, Bishop Adna Wright Leonard of the Pittsburgh Methodist Area said yesterday morning in his sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

PARIS, July 26. -- For an observer who seeks to situate the sanguinary events in Spain in relation to general European troubles it seems that the present struggle must serve either as a dress rehearsal for a still vaster conflict or as a frightful example that may prevent that larger war.

Four firemen were overcome by smoke and another man was injured at 10:30 o'clock last night in fighting a smoky two-alarm fire which had spread from the rear of a one-story building at 675 Bergen Avenue, the Bronx, and a three-story frame building at 677 Bergen Avenue to another three-story frame building at 2,986 Third Avenue.

HANKINSON, N.D., July 26. -Fifteen thousand farm men and women from three States who had come to Hankinson today to hear Father Coughlin eat the New Deal alive and skin the Republicans went home disappointed tonight.
PARIS, July 25. -- Money market conditions here have eased somewhat, with call money at 2 3/4 per cent and loans on government bonds for longer terms at 3 1/2 per cent.
TOKYO, Monday, July 27. -- War Minister Juichi Terauchi yesterday propounded the principle that funds for defense should be obtained by borrowing and social reform funds by increasing taxation.

LINCROFT, N.J., July 26. -Tupelo, Julius Bliss's well-known aged chestnut gelding, gained the initial leg on the Lincroft Farm Challenge Cup, one of the prized trophies in the second annual Lincroft Charity Horse Show, which came to a close today on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kaiser.

The city's employes went on an old-fashioned field day yesterday. More than 350 men and women participated in a program that ranged from sack races to the gruelling mile run in the athletic carnival staged under the auspices of the Mayor's Committee on Municipal Athletic Activities at Randalls Island Stadium.

Two plays now rest on the Fall shelves of Sidney Harmon. Joining E.P. Conkie's "Two Hundred Were Chosen," already there, is a work known as "But for the Grace of God." Leopold L. Atlas, who wrote that "Wednesday's Child" in which Frank M. Thomas Jr. appeared a few seasons ago, is the author, and the scene is described simply as "American."
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, July 26 (AP). -- Fascist rebel rule and daily firing squads at dawn, reports from Spanish Morocco say, have plunged the civil population into terror.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26. -- Argentina's foreign trade declined 10 1/2 per cent during the first six months of this year compared with the corresponding period of 1935, according to the Bureau of National Statistics in a summary issued today.
The remaining members of the staff of the American Museum of Natural History who will take part in the scientific study of big game fish in Nova Scotia waters left New York over the week-end.

No individual is released from personal responsibility to God by collective approach to a social problem, the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, pastor of Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, the Bronx, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Calvary Methodist Church, 1,885 University Avenue, the Bronx.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 26. -- With the departure over the weekend of the 305th Infantry, Colonel Walter W. Metcalf, commanding, which has been conducting the training of the Citizens Military Training Camp provisional regiment here for two weeks, the schedule for the remaining four days of the camp will be under supervision of officers and personnel of the Twenty-sixth Infantry.

BERLIN, July 25. -- After a dull opening, the Boerse this week was predominantly firm but substantial. Gains were confined to isolated specialties, as well as commercial bank and steel stocks, in both of which there was heavy buying.

More than 3,180 classrooms and accommodations for 131,231 students have been added to public school facilities in New York State by the PWA, it was revealed yesterday by Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, in a report to Administrator Harold L. Ickes.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 26. -- The favored first-seeded combination of Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., won the final of the Maidstone Club's men's invitation tennis doubles tournament before a packed gallery today.

TOPEKA, July 26. -- Support of hundreds of thousands, perhaps of several million, anti-New Deal Democrats is counted upon by the campaign managers of Governor Alf M. Landon to put the Republican nominee for President in the White House, it was said here today.

"Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell, is perhaps the fastest selling book in recent publishing history. Macmillan reports that in one day last week it booked orders for 10,753 copies, and all book stores save one reporting for the New York best-seller list this week gave this novel as their best seller.

BERLIN, July 26. -- This city has been seized with an Olympic mania since the arrival of the American team. Competent observers who have spent the best part of their lives in Berlin assert that the greatest crowd in the history of Unter den Linden filled that famous avenue to overflowing today, almost a whole week before the opening of the games.
HANKINSON, N.D., July 26. -The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin called today for a repudiation of farm debts if Representative Lemke, Union party candidate for President, is not elected.

Disguising themselves as champions, Professor Casey Stengel's Dodgers yesterday astonished and gratified nearly 15,000 Flatbush fans by scoring a double knockout of the Pirates and dropping the Bucs to the lower compartment of the first division.

Announcement of a series of radio broadcasts, to be presented each Monday evening for the next two months, starting Aug. 3, was made yesterday by Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee. The general topic of the broadcasts, which will deal with both the State and national campaigns, will be "Common Sense in Government."

WITH THE REBEL FORCES AT PAMPLONA, Spain, July 26 (AP). -- The rebel central war junta claimed a Fascist victory in the Guadarrama Mountains today. The victory, insurgent officers said, was executed by the advance column of General Emilio Mola's forces.

Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, will appear as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next week on Monday and Tuesday nights, Aug. 3 and 4, at the Lewisohn Stadium, it was announced yesterday. On those nights the violinist will play two concerti, the Mozart D major and the Glazunoff. Jose Iturbi will conduct.

THE TIMES published recently an article showing the per capita cost of police protection in the nation's cities. New York, despite its size, had the relatively small figure of $7.20, compared with Jersey City's $8.32. No consideration is given to the "hidden costs," which must be reckoned in a true analysis.
Selling and leasing contracts involving theatre properties in the Bronx and Yonkers featured realty activity in the city and outlying sections over the week-end.
Flanked by an admiring throng of 36,000, the Giants put on a spectacular show at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but unfortunately found the performance too long even for their new-found strength.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -- The Federal Trade Commission has announced that hearings would be held tomorrow in Boston and on Wednesday in Philadelphia on its complaint, charging the Fashion Originators Guild of America, with headquarters in New York, of attempting to "create a monopoly in the ladies' garment and dress goods trade."

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 26. -- Aleck Gerard Jr., 20-year-old Southampton star, leaped into golf stardom today by handing Max Marston, Philadelphia veteran, a 9-and-7 beating in the final of the seventeenth annual invitation tournament of the Shenecossett Club.
May I recall the gallant struggle which one of New York's oldest institution, The Sheltering Arms, at Amsterdam Avenue and 129th Street, has been making to continue its care of homeless children?

CAMDEN, N.J., July 26. -- Howard Myers, 22 years old, of Delanco, member of a roadhouse orchestra, was burned to death early this morning after his automobile had collided with a car driven by Vincent D. Canarote, 25, of Philadelphia, in Pennsauken Township, near here.

BERLIN, July 25. -- Germany's banks and newspapers, although commenting unfavorably on the condition of Federal finances in the United States, are emphasizing that the mounting budget deficits and the increase in the public debt there cannot legitimately be used as political amunition by the Republicans in the Presidential campaign in view of the part played by the veterans' bonus, for which Congress alone was responsible.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 26 (AP). -- Facing almost certain defeat in the quest of the Davis Cup, Australia rallied its forces today in an effort to prolong the challenge round series with England.

Dr. Butler has undoubtedly expressed the misgivings not only of many Republicans but of a great army of conservative Democrats who, following the lead of Mr. Baker and Mr. Douglas, are attracted by the anti-monopoly pledges of the Republican platform but draw back in horror when asked to accept the isolationist Middle West attitude toward foreign affairs and foreign trade.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. F. Griswold Flagg of Radnor, Pa., who are occupying the Rocks, the Clews estate, gave a large tea there this afternoon.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 26. -- Fred L. Boelsen, 21 years old, a roomer at 439 East Eighty-seventh Street, Manhattan, arrested yesterday in a stolen car, admitted late today that he is the long-sought "phantom" burglar of Nassau County.

THE United States athletes took their final pre-Olympic tests on Randalls Island. The Britishers went through their paces in the White City Stadium in the London area. The Germans staged their trials in Berlin. The track surfaces were doubtless different at these scattered places. It was very hot on Randalls Island. It rained during the White City festivities.

GIBRALTAR, July 26. -- British refugees from Malaga declared today they had peered through shutters of their locked hotel to see "children wearing red ties and red shirts" shoot down scores of Fascists and priests.

BERLIN, July 26. -- The fear that the American Olympic track and field team would not be able to round into peak condition in time for the opening of the games on Saturday was allayed today when the athletes engaged in their best and most satisfactory workout since arriving in Olympic Village.

WARSAW, Poland, July 26. -- A very optimistic view of the Danzig situation is taken by the official Polish Political Information in comment on the recent exchange of notes between Warsaw and Berlin regarding the German cruiser Leipzig's snub to Sean Lester, the League of Nations High Commissioner in Danzig, and the press attack on Mr. Lester by Albert Forster, Nazi leader in the Free City.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- A most interesting situation has developed in the world's wheat markets with traders inclined to the belief that world wheat prices are likely to work irregularly higher, although they anticipate some sharp price recessions in profit-taking movements.

Three persons aboard the 18-foot sailboat. Alert were pitched into Long Island Sound yesterday afternoon when the craft was rammed amidships by the oil tanker Marshall B. Hall of 675 tons, splintered and sunk in midstream.
CHICAGO, July 26. -- The first section of the Republican campaign year book was made public today by the Chicago headquarters of the national committee. It will be ready for distribution on Aug. 1.

Taking advantage of the increased activity in home building, manufacturers of electrical appliances have laid plans for an aggressive promotional and advertising campaign to extend through the remainder of the year. The Electrical Housewares Committee will promote in October electrical buffet serving and in December will concentrate its activity on the second National Electrical Housewares Week.

By his recognition Saturday of the new status of Ethiopia, HITLER promptly reciprocates MUSSOLINI'S blessing of the Nazi "peace" with Austria. In diplomacy, as in everyday life, one hand is useful in washing the other. But the significance of this interchange is greater than its illustration that international relations, stripped of the high-sounding language of the diplomatists, are sometimes not unlike ordinary human relations.

ALBANY, July 26 (AP). -- Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported today that the State's public employment offices had filled 77,168 jobs in private industry during the first half of 1936, an increase of 45.7 per cent over the similar period for last year.

PITTSBURGH, July 26. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 72 per cent of capacity, up 2 points from the rate of the two preceding weeks. The rate exceeds the average in May and June, when tonnage was the largest since early in 1930.

In a letter to THE TIMES, S.L.G. Knox argues that America's attempt to collect the war debts, from President Wilson's day to this, has been all wrong; that our war debtors should never have paid us anything at all, because after we entered the war in April, 1917, we contributed very little in the way of combatants and casualties, as compared with our war debts.

The difficulties encountered by foreign correspondents in obtaining accurate information concerning the developments in Spain were described yesterday by Robert Jones, correspondent of The San Francisco Chronicle, in a short-wave broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System from Hendaye, on the French side of the Spanish frontier.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 26. -Philip Krumchuk, 8 years old, of Bond Street, in the New Cassel section of this township, was recovering today from a tree-climbing expedition from which he returned by ambulance via the Meadowbrook Hospital.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 26. -- Paced by the brilliant H.W. (Rube) Williams, veteran Texas star, who was displaying his talents for the first time in a year on Long Island, a quartet of Westerners arrayed in cowboy apparel administered a sound 10-4 setback to the Roslyn four, led by Earle A.S. Hopping, at Schiff Field today.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported an increase of 6.6 per cent in passenger revenues in June, the first month in which the fare reductions ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission took effect. The Pennsylvania is one of the railroads which is opposing the new 2-cent-a-mile schedule in the courts.

GENOA, Italy, July 26. -- Tales of horror in Barcelona were brought here tonight by a group of monks, priests and nuns who escaped from a monastery and convents and reached here with some 1,300 refugees aboard the steamer Principessa Margareta.

BERLIN, July 26. -- Cablegrams and a box of handerchiefs showered in on Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, ousted Olympian, today, as the backstroke champion grinned and said she would stay in Berlin a while.

PODEBRAD, Czechoslovakia, July 26. -- First prize in the international chess masters tournament in progress here since the first week in July, was won tonight by Salo Flohr of Prague, famous internationalist, notwithstanding the participation of Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, until recently champion of the world.
WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The Spanish Embassy tonight issued a statement denying that the present government in Spain is Communist or Syndicalist.

The fifty-first anniversary of the death of General Ulysses S. Grant was commemorated yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Laura B. Prisk. "Mother of National Flag Day," three veterans of the Civil War, and about 100 spectators.

Public utilities supplying gas, electricity, water and telephone service in this State paid $670,000 in 1935 for membership fees, club expenses and donations to charitable and other organizations, according to a report made public yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

Ideal midsummer weather, warmed by a brilliant sun and at the same time cooled by pleasant breezes, drew huge crowds to the beaches and resorts of the metropolitan area for the fourth sunny Sunday since July 4.

Reflecting the optimistic attitude of retailers generally throughout the country on the Fall outlook, the wholesale apparel markets here last week were kept going at an active pace to supply the steady demand for merchandise. Encouraging reports were received from stores already sponsoring advance promotional events and a substantial improvement in general retail business is expected for the forthcoming season.

Dependence upon prayer alone will not help solve life's problems, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer declared in a sermon yesterday morning at high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 26. -- Transportation of the New York State National Guard units involved both train and motor truck as the Seventy-first Infantry of Manhattan and the 174th Infantry of Buffalo replaced the outgoing infantrymen of the 165th, or "Old Sixty-ninth" of Manhattan, and the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn at Camp Smith today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 26. -- David Day, arrested here in connection with fraudulent check passing, will be taken to New York City tomorrow for investigation of a homicide there committed Aug. 29, 1934. Pawtucket police have sent word here that he is wanted in that city to answer to a forgery charge.

LONDON, July 26. -- The British Government is ready to transform the provisional consultation of general staffs, now proceeding, into a permanent military agreement with France and Belgium when it becomes honestly convinced that all attempts to conciliate Germany have failed.

The Governors Island polo team won a thrilling two-period overtime contest yesterday when it conquered the Monmouth County Country Club quartet, 9 to 8, in an Eastern League game played before 2,500 spectators at the victors' field. Robert Shillaber scored the deciding tally midway in the session after the first additional chapter of five minutes had failed to break the tie.

BIRMINGHAM, England, July 26. -- At a meeting of the national assembly of the Oxford Groups, arranged to synchronize with the unveiling of the Canadian war memorial at Vimy Ridge in France, this afternoon the Rev. Dr. Frank N.D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Groups, broadcast a radio message to the world.
ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 26. -- Youth scored a double triumph in the seventh round of the international chass masters' tournament at the Grand Hotel today.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 26. -- Purple Heart decorations recently bestowed upon seventeen New Jersey soldiers who were wounded in service were pinned upon their recipients at Camp Hoffman today in a public ceremony by Governor Harold G. Hoffman.

MADRID, Monday, July 27. -Heavy losses by Spain's Fascist rebels, especially in the Guadarrama Mountains -- which the government declares will be the "tomb of fascism" -- were claimed early today by the Madrid regime.

I have read a lot about the Democratic party giving jobs to its own or to prospective Democrats and a great hue and cry is made about it, when we all know or should know that a dog-catcher cannot have a job in this Republican community unless he and his grandfather and his great-grandfather voted the true ticket.

Traffic on the Interborough subway and elevated lines during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1936, was 1.57 per cent heavier than in the preceding twelve months, representing a gain of 15,903,229 passengers, according to a report made public yesterday by Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the company.

A big seaplane with nine men on board crashed into the ocean yesterday afternoon while circling the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line five miles east of Nantucket Lightship. One man, Edward Ramsdell, Boston Post photographer, was fatally injured.

The Federal Government must provide $300,000,000 annually for the public schools if education is to be maintained on a level adequate to the needs of the country, Dr. Paul R. Mort, director of the Advanced School of Education in Teachers College, Columbia University, reported in a survey made public yesterday.

LONDON, July 24. -- The influence of the Bank of England's large gold purchases is becoming apparent in the money market, which, before the acceleration of this movement, was in danger of experiencing a reduction of its credit supplies owing to the rapidly rising note circulation, occasioned largely by Continental European hoarding.

BERLIN, July 26 (AP). -- The knotty problem of the selection of an American athlete to carry the Stars and Stripes in the opening Olympic parade next Saturday has not yet been solved, but it is understood the honor will go to Alfred A. Jochim, Union City, N.J., telephone worker who is a member of the gymnastic team for the fourth time.

LONDON, July 26. -- The Cyclops of Homer's Odyssey revived a Babylonian myth already a thousand years old it has been discovered by Dr. Henri Frankfort, field director in Iraq of the University of Chicago's Oriental Institute.

LONDON, July 24. -- One of the most surprising features in the current financial situation is the considerable expansion of Stock Exchange business in a period when, normally, activity subsides under the influence of the advent of the holiday season.

MADRID, July 26 (Passed by the Censor). -- A government air force squadron bombed rebel positions at Palma, Majorca, today, causing many casualties among the rebels and much damage. Loyal submarines captured officers who tried to flee in launches.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 26. -- "Never before have we had so many promising and talented youngsters ready to take their places among the important playwrights of tomorrow, but never has it been so hard for them to get a start," said Barrett H. Clark, director of the play service for the Dramatists Guild, in a lecture here tonight at the Mohawk Drama Festival on the Union College campus.

MINSK, White Russia, July 26. -The first cash award under the Soviet's new family law for increasing the population was made here today by the Council of People's Commissars of the White Russian Republic. It was of five thousand rubles and went to Nikita Kazimiroff, a wandering gypsy tinsmith, who, after his wife a year ago presented him with a fifth child, decided to settle down and raise a family.

LONDON, July 24. -- It is evident from the latest return of the Bank of England that Continental European hoarding of British currency notes is diminishing, or has temporarily ceased. Despite this the Bank continues to buy gold heavily, and currently is adding to its metallic reserves at a rate which considerably exceeds that of the expansion of circulation.

BOSTON, July 26. -- An excellent New England tuna fishing season, despite President Roosevelt's luckless seven hours Thursday, is indicated by the arrival of more than 400 tuna at the Boston fish market last week from New England fishing ports, says the New England Council.

CARTER GLASS has made valiant efforts to keep his profile off the half-dollar pieces of the realm, but without success. These are the special 50-cent coins issued in connection with the 150th anniversary of Senator GLASS'S home town, Lynchburg, Va.

LONG VALLEY, N.J., July 26. -A clamless clambake and a nudistless nudist peeking game were today's highlights in Farmer Will Searles's anti-nudist campaign. More than 400 persons from many parts of New Jersey and New York arrived for the fun during the afternoon.

Karl D. Hesley, State director of the National Youth Administration, announced yesterday that the student aid program would be continued during the coming school year in substantially the same form as last. He estimated that between 9,000 and 10,000 high school students and more than 4,500 college students in the State would receive financial aid.

The significance of the $1,000,000 Canadian War Memorial at Vimy Ridge, unveiled and dedicated by King Edward VIII, was pointed out by Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of King's University, Halifax, N.S., in an address yesterday morning at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street.

HERALD HARBOR, Md., July 26. -- Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen, N.J., national professional outboard champion, fought off the challenge from C. Mulford Scull of Ventnor, N.J., today to win top honors in the closing events of the two-day Tri-City regatta.
CHICAGO, July 26. -- Wheat prices on outside markets advanced sharply early in the week, but later ran into hedging sales which caused general recessions.

DALLAS, Texas, July 26 (AP). -- Governor James V. Allred, whose advance to political prominence has embraced periods as a bottlewasher, bootblack and sailor, today watched his majority in the Texas primary grow to proportions which virtually assured his re-election.

The Republican national campaign in the East will get under way this week under the direction of Representative Joseph W. Martin of Massachusetts, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Martin, who has been spending a few days in New England, will be back at headquarters in the Liggett Building, 41 East Forty-second Street, today.

The Cunard White Star Line, Ltd., is planning to open negotiations with several British shipyards for the construction of two new liners, probably for the New York-Southampton-London service, according to advices received here from abroad.
Mrs. Farrar Says Number Is the Largest Ever to Work for the Party's Candidates.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP). -- The Red Sox made a clean sweep of their three-game series with Detroit by humbling the Tigers today, 10 to 3, with the aid of Jimmy Foxx's twenty-eighth and twenty-ninth home runs of the season.

SOUTH WINDSOR, Conn., July 26. -- With large relief rolls still being maintained in all the Connecticut cities and with considerable forces enrolled in Federal work projects tobacco growers of the Connecticut Valley tonight reported a serious shortage of labor.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee expended $300,000 in 1935 for the rehabilitation of Jews in Germany, according to the annual report of the committee's activities in that country made public yesterday by Joseph C. Hyman, executive director.

The mysterious aerial acrobat who twisted and gyrated at the end of a parachute limned against the clear blue sunset sky over the Hudson River as night fell on Saturday was identified yesterday as John Kornschutz, 48 years old, of Willow Street and Van Buren Place, North Bergen, N.J.

The French move to nationalize the manufacture of arms comes at a time when all nations are building armaments on a scale and at a speed without precedent in time of peace, supposing that the existent state of international tension and alarm can be called peace.
BERLIN, July 26 (AP). -- There will be no more "Heil Hitler" or stiff-backed Nazi salutes around the American camp in the Olympic Village -- at the express request of the Americans.

Laying a heavy pall of smoke over the neighborhood for blocks around, a spectacular fire partly destroyed the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, at Belmont Avenue and East 187th Street, the Bronx, about 4 o'clock yesterday morning.

BARCELONA, Catalonia, Spain, July 26. -- Barcelona's loyalist government today reported that a column of Leftist militia, marching from Barcelona, was fighting rebel troops at a point about fifty-three miles from Saragossa.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP). -The Chicago Cubs, blanked in the opener, 4 to 0, got their revenge on the Phillies today in the second game of a double-header by blasting out six home runs for an 18-to-5 victory before 20,000 fans.

Pointing to St. Peter as a model, the Right Rev. Stephen E. Keeler, Bishop Coadjutor of Minnesota, yesterday morning urged his listeners to show similar courage, sympathy and understanding during the present political and economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin tomorrow morning public hearings in its investigation of all the investment trust and investment companies in the United States. It will be one of the most far-reaching inquiries undertaken by the commission since its creation.

ST. JEAN DE LUZ, France, July 26 (AP). -- Two American girls, brought to France on the British destroyer Verity after a week in besieged San Sebastian, Spain, said tonight they were "never really frightened."

BOSTON, July 26. -- Joseph Volk, alias Joseph White, wanted in New York for questioning in a payroll murder there last Friday, was arrested tonight in a telegraph office at Congress and High Streets nine minutes after New York police telephoned Captain William Lewis, in charge of the Boston Bureau of Criminal Investigation, that Volk was in Boston awaiting a wired money order from his father.
VIMY, July 26. -- The message of the Canadian Prime Minister, W.L. Mackenzie King, read at the Vimy dedication service today by C.G. Power, Minister of Pensions and National Health, follows:

Fifty-two writers, musicians, painters and sculptors have been selected by the Edward MacDowell Association as fellows for this year and will spend the Summer, or part of it, at the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., it was announced last night by Ernest Schelling, president of the association. The fellows selected are:

PARIS, July 26. -- The conflict in Spain is serving in France to increase the bitterness between the Nationalists and the Popular Front, parties and to accentuate the similar division that is tending to split all Europe into opposing camps.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- Hog prices moved within a wide range last week with ample supplies and an active call early but an irregular market later. The top price for the week was $11.10 a hundredweight. There were ample supplies, as the new regulations of the government are making farmers more disposed to sell.

Deposits in mutual savings banks of the United States passed the $10,000,000,000-mark on July 1 last, and were only about $10,000,000 less than the record established in 1932, according to figures made public yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

LONDON, July 27. -- R.C. Hawkins, chairman of the board of the Grand Trunk Senior Stocks Company, said today that his board had put forward a compromise plan in the Grand Trunk Railway controversy and that the proposal had been placed before the Canadian Government.

Rain fell at Ebbets Field early yesterday afternoon and threatened continuously thereafter, but the extraordinary Dodgers, like those faithful servitors of the postal service, refused to permit anything to stay them from their appointed rounds.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 27. -- Losing his adjourned game from yesterday's seventh round to E.D. Bogoljubow of Germany, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, today sustained his first defeat in the international chess masters' tournament at the Grand Hotel.

MOSCOW, July 27. -- A project recently described in the Finnish press for linking Western Europe and Scandinavia with the Soviet Union via Finland by means of a commercial airline was denounced in the official press here today as masking a plan to establish a chain of military air bases that could be effectively used against the Soviet Union.

The belief that Erie County, which takes in all of the city of Buffalo, will go for Governor Landon by a majority of between 40,000 and 50,000 in the November election was expressed here yesterday by two Republican leaders from that section, at a conference with Joseph W. Martin Jr., head of the Eastern Republican headquarters in the Liggett Building, 41 East Forty-second Street.

Brown, Young Co., Inc., will offer to the public today 24,000 shares of preferred stock and an equal amount of common stock of the John Irving Shoe Corporation in units of one share of preferred and one share of common at $28.50 a unit or at the market, but not to exceed $30 a unit.

It is hard for most of us to shudder at a painted devil. In Georgia you have to do it if you're a good Democrat. Governor TALMADGE, whatever his diabolical intentions, seems impotent to carry them out. Senator RUSSELL can have no doubt of his own re-election.

May I say a word for the down-trodden stockbroker? For the past three years we have been meekly inarticulate. We have heard ourselves reviled as money changers, economic royalists, and, by inference, as scoundrels. Anything and any one connected even remotely with Wall Street has been assailed with hostile propaganda; and, for the most part, we have taken it all and kept our mouths shut.

DALLAS, July 27 (AP). -- Representative Blanton has been forced into a run-off campaign for the first time in his twenty-year career in Congress and tonight he blamed this situation on "paid agitators" and overconfident friends.

BERLIN, July 27. -- The German Embassy at Madrid, it was announced here tonight, lodged an energetic protest with the Spanish Government against the destruction of the home of the German Labor Front and German school at Barcelona.

People are using the old-fashioned name for tragic events in Spain. They call it civil war. The newer name, preferred by those who think they see deeper into the situation, is class war. It is useful to have it established that class war and civil war are the same thing, as they are bound to be.

ST. PAUL, July 27 (AP). -- Alvin Karpis, formerly No. 1 "public enemy," received a life sentence today on his plea of guilty to conspiracy in the $100,000 kidnapping of William Hamm Jr., and indicated through his attorney that he would be willing to enter a similar plea in the $200,000 abduction of Edward G. Bremer. This was the maximum penalty.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 27. -- By a vote of 102 1/2 to 101 1/2, the Liberal party after an all-night session decided early today at Yauco to sustain the leadership of Senator Antonio R. Barcelo, the party president, in a proposal to participate in the November election.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- Paced by Hal Finney, the Athletics exploded twenty-five hits and defeated the White Sox, 15 to 8, today. It was the fourth straight setback for the White Sox, who previously had won seventeen out of twenty-one games.

MINEOLA, L.Y., July 27. -- Despite the reported willingness of Fred L. Boelsen, said to have admitted committing 200 burglaries in Nassau County, to aid the police, they were able today to recover but little of the loot taken in the robberies.

Declaring he had not yet received the Mayor's letter, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, yesterday declined to comment on the Mayor's plea for a lower automobile insurance rate for New York City in line with the better safety record made during the first five months of this year.
We talked to a man who flew to Florida to fish over the week-end, and who was back at his desk in New York yesterday morning.

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation reports for the six months ended June 30 consolidated net earnings available for dividends of $9,757,387, equivalent, after dividends on the outstanding preference stocks, to $3.16 a share on the 2,836,923 shares of common stock outstanding in the hands of the public after distribution of a 20 per cent dividend on May 28.

Holders of the 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Schulte Retail Stores Corporation have been advised in a letter by General Samuel McRoberts, chairman of the protective committee for the issue, that the corporation's losses were attributable largely to its real estate operations.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- More than 25,000 applications have been received for tickets to the Chicago Stadium Thursday night for the ceremonies of notifying Colonel Frank Knox of his nomination as running mate of Governor Landon. Chauncey McCormick, chairman of the Illinois Citizens' Committee, which is handling arrangements, declared tonight.

MADRID, July 27. -- Five Americans who were staying in the United States Embassy here left this morning by train for Valencia, where they arrived safely tonight, according to a telephone message from the United States Consul there. These Americans are Mr. and Mrs. James Hepburn of Baltimore, Richard Aldworth of Chicago, Miss Alice Atkinson of New York and Miss Marie Orsen of Deerfield, Mass.
John Erskine, author and president of the Juilliard School of Music, described modern education yesterday afternoon as "medieval" and said that its chief fault lay in the over-emphasis on "culture."

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The tension concerning the position of Americans in Spain was relaxed today with advices to the State Department reporting that many had left the country and that the situation surrounding those in Madrid and at other points was less grave.

Donald Budge, standing on the pier alongside the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary on which he and Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant had just arrived yesterday, announced that he had solved the trick of beating Fred Perry, England's tennis ace.

LONDON, July 27. -- The Italian conquest of Ethiopia became a closed incident today, as far as the British Government is concerned. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons that the period of uncertainty following the raising of sanctions was now over and there was, therefore, no longer any need of continuing British assurances of protection to Turkey and Yugoslavia in the event of attack by Italy.

Substantial gains in passenger revenues in June, when reduced fares took effect, were reported by the New York Central and Baltimore Ohio railroads yesterday. The first named company opposed and the last named accepted the order of the Interstate Commerce Commission which brought about the reductions.

Frederick F. Greenman was designated last night as the Republican candidate for Congress from the Seventeenth Congressional District at a meeting of the Republican County Committee of the Fifteenth Assembly District at 122 East Eighty-third Street.
OTTAWA, July 27 (Canadian Press). -- The official arrangements for the eight-hour visit of President Roosevelt with Lord Tweedsmuir at Quebec on Friday were outlined today by the State Department.
TOPEKA, July 27. -- Governor Landon divided his time today between politics and the business of the State.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing of 136,470 additional shares of common stock of the Allegheny Steel Company, to be issued in connection with the acquisition by Allegheny of 24,545 shares of common stock of the West Leechburg Steel Company.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 27. -- Roger Durivage of Montreal, the Canadian junior champion, and Joseph L. Abrams of New York gained the quarter-finals of the Northern New Jersey tennis championship at the Westfield Tennis Club today, joining William Lurie of New York, who reached that round yesterday.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 27. -- While Professor W.L. Clevenger returned to jail temporarily today for examination concerning the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger, his niece, Daniel H. Gaddy, night watchman at the hotel where she was slain, resumed the spotlight of the inquiry.

BERLIN, July 27. -- Torrents of rain descended on the gay and festive Olympic scene this afternoon, washing out training activities in the Olympic Village, handing another setback to the German staff furiously at work refinishing the main stadium track and giving the diplomats a chance to substitute caucuses for outdoor speechmaking.

Litigation which threatened to deprive members of the exclusive Atlantic Beach Club of the right to enjoy the white cabana dotted sands and the ocean surf fronting the clubhouse is believed now to have been avoided through the filing of the reorganization plan of the Island Park Associates, Inc., in the Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 27. -- Twenty-four persons held in the Camden County jail more than a week on charges growing out of disorders during the strike at the RCA Manufacturing Company's plant were released this afternoon under bail totaling $185,000.
DETROIT, Mich., July 27. -- Anti-Roosevelt Democrats have been invited to a conference here to discuss how best to oppose the President in the coming campaign. The tentative date is Aug. 7.

OTTAWA, July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Savings deposits in Canadian chartered banks on June 30 amounted to $1,504,792,828, a decrease of $22,000,000 from May 30, but an increase of $80,000,000 from June 30, 1935, the banks reported today to the Minister of Finance.

Disquieting are the charges and counter-charges that European Powers are beginning to take sides in the Spanish conflict. There is no legal obligation to prevent the French Left Government or the Russian Communist regime from supplying military airplanes or other munitions to the Madrid authorities.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 27. -- A team of amateurs provided the professionals with a few lessons today when Jerry Roche of Bayside and Captain E.F. Carter of the Sands Point Club collaborated in an amazing 33, 30 -- 63 for first honors in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day best-ball amateurpro tournament at the Sound View Golf Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody stepped out of the ranks of major tennis tournament competitors today -- shattering hopes of enthusiasts for another meeting between the one-time "queen of the courts" and her greatest rival, Miss Helen Hull Jacobs.

The semi-annual pamphlet report of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. shows that for the six months ended on June 30, earnings applicable to the common stock amounted to $36,107,371, or $3.27 each on the 11,052,395 (average) shares outstanding.
LIMA, Peru, July 27. -- The following communique was issued by the Ministry of Government this morning:

Encouraged by further reports of high second-quarter corporate earnings and favorable dividend action, and by the continued optimistic tone of the trade and industrial news, the stock market pushed forward yesterday into new high ground for the year.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced $1 a bale in the early trading yesterday, but the recent sharp recovery of 1/2 cent a pound attracted selling on a scale that not only wiped out all the early gain but left the list with a net loss of 1 to 7 points on the day.

An ancient tenement, tenantless now, save for a caretaker and a wistful bean sighe (banshee) who walks o' nights in pallid cerements, was offered yesterday to Joseph Dunninger, head of the Universal Council for Psychic Research, as a testing ground on the hoary issue of ghosts.

BERLIN, July 27 (AP). -- America's chances of winning what promises to be the greatest race of the Olympics -- the 1,500 meter -- took on a bearish note today when Glenn Cunningham came down with a bad case of sore legs.

The record-breaking voyage of the Queen Mary, on which they arrived from England earlier in the day, rapidly faded to nothing but a memory yesterday noon as twenty-six British Boy Scouts, en route to Canada for a camping stay, sat down for their first meal in an automat.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Registration statements becoming effective under the Securities Act of 1933 in May dropped to $328,100,000 as compared with $751,000,000 in April, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. The decrease was due chiefly to a slowing down of large refunding offerings.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Tuesday, July 28. -- A din raised by hundreds of "hunger-marchers" massed in the galleries kept the State Senate in session until 1:59 this morning as motion after motion to adjourn was drowned out.

After half a mile or so of New York traffic, members of the Junior Motor Car Club of Great Britain, who arrived yesterday on the Queen Mary with thirty-three cars, adopted a motion unanimously to ride as passengers or go afoot while in the city.

The Queen Mary crossed the Atlantic in four days eight hours and thirty-seven minutes -- the fastest time ever made on the westward voyage by a passenger vessel. Yet Sir EDGAR BRITTEN, her commander, declines to claim the blue ribbon for her, and this because her average speed of 29.61 knots for the crossing was a mere .03 of a knot below that of the Normandie.

Lease by the Childs Company of a store in the building under construction at the northeast corner of Forty-second Street and Eighth Avenue was announced yesterday. The lessor is the 428 Corporation, a subsidiary of the United Cigar Stores Company.

The Museum of Modern Art yesterday opened in two of the fourth floor galleries a small exhibition consisting of paintings from a private collection in New York. This added attraction will continue through Sept. 6.

ALBANY, July 27. -- In the year since the opening of the new Saratoga Spa, 129,211 treatments have been given at the Roosevelt, Washington and Lincoln Baths, Pierrepont B. Noyes, chairman of the Saratoga Springs Commission, reported today to Governor Lehman.

Ruth Gordon will appear next week at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge, Mass., in "The Church Mouse." . . . The productions of the Harbor Summer Theatre, located on Governors Island, will henceforth be shown the last two days of the week at the City Theatre, near Roseville Station, Newark.
The finance and budget committee of the Board of Education submitted yesterday a tentative budget of $142,509,894 for 1937, representing an increase of $5,420,837 over the 1936 budget.

Your remarks in "Topics of The Times" on Diego Rivera's Rockefeller Center murals, interesting and apropos as they are, suggest however, what few seem to realize, that in spite of casting out Rivera's Lenin, his classical prototype is still "glorified" in "so conspicuous a monument to the capitalist system" as is the Center.

GIBRALTAR, July 27. -- More than 600 have been killed thus far and about 1,200 wounded in a fierce engagement now going on between Spanish Government troops and insurgents at Estepona. Of the dead, 400 are put on the government side.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Light receipts of hogs and an advance of 1/2 cent in the price of fresh pork loins to an outside quotation of 23 cents a pound wholesale today stimulated buying and most of the losses on Friday's hog prices were erased. Sales were steady and at the best figures of late last week.

A fresh demand for secondary railroad loans marked otherwise quiet and routine trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Speculative interest was centered among the rail liens, where gains ranging from fractions to several points were recorded in fairly heavy volume.
WESTFIELD, Mass., July 27. -- Former Governor Joseph B. Ely declared today that he would attend the Detroit meeting of "Constitutional" Democrats. He has an-

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on July 22 shows a decrease for the week of $68,000,000 in total loans and investments, increases of $99,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, of $111,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and of $15,000,000 in time deposits, and a decrease of $144,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

It has been evident for at least a year that this country had not only emerged from depression, but was passing into a period of reasonably continuous industrial recovery. Competent economists recognize that the turn for the better began in the middle of 1932; but, for various reasons, recovery was interrupted in the early and later months of 1933, and again in the Summer and Autumn of 1934.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Desiring to continue the present emergency freight rates permanently, the railroads today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to clear up technicalities so that this plan could be carried into effect.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP). -- Jim Bottomley batted a pair of doubles and a single in four times up today and furnished a punch that gave the Browns their second triumph in two days, a 7 -- 5 decision over the Red Sox.

WADING RIVER, L.I., July 27. -- With interest in the capture of "It," this community's No. 1 mystery, paralleling in a modest way that which attended the alleged profusion of sea serpents in many waters a few years ago, citizens today organized a sort of zoological posse to track the beast down.

ST. JEAN DE LUZ, France, July 27 (AP). -- United States Ambassador Claude G. Bowers came to this French border point by automobile tonight to spend the night, but declared he had "no intention of abandoning my Spanish post for the present."

Captain Sir Edgar T. Britten, master of the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, said yesterday that the blue pennant for a record crossing would not be claimed from the French liner Normandie this voyage.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin said today that in his speech at Hankinson, N.D., yesterday he had not urged farmers to repudiate their debts should Representative William Lemke, Union party candidate, be defeated for the Presidency.

Two 13-year-old boys who slipped out of the Catholic Protectory in the Bronx yesterday morning managed to realize the dream of a lifetime by spending the day at Coney Island with a huge roll of bills, but they ended in the Williamsburg police station.

MADRID, July 27. -- The Spanish Government, pressing new offensives against insurgent strongholds, claimed tonight in a radio broadcast that "the rebel government has been mastered by the republican government."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 27. -- Adding further laurels to a family name well known in golf circles, Mike and Willie Turnesa of Fairview today captured top honors in the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur best ball tournament at Bonnie Briar as they collaborated handsomely for a 33, 30 -- 63 to set a sizzling pace for thirty-four other combinations.

Paintings, lithographs, craft work and sculptures by New York children in the free classes of the WPA Federal Art Project will be included in an international children's art exhibition in Cheltenham, England, to open Thursday at the World Congress of the New Education Fellowship.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- Drought blight increased in the Corn Belt today, with three of its big producing States revising crop expectations downward.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, who won from his admirers the title of "Iron Man Eaton" during the 1935 Assembly campaign because of his ability to cover ground and deliver any number of speeches in a short period of time, has written out his recipe for fudge for publication in The Woman Republican, official organ of the Women's Division of the Republican State Committee.

Merchandising of a product so as to create new business, instead of fighting for established business, was urged yesterday by William O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, in an address before the season's final luncheon session of the Sales Executives' Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Three thin, eager little boys waited anxiously at the Children's Aid Society's medical department while Nurse Bates gave a group of children, who had been sent from our Jones Children's Center, a final check-up before sending them to camp. Peter, 12; Richard, 11, and John, 9, had just come along hoping we could squeeze them in with the rest of the children.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 27. -- Organized protest from many quarters arose here today against the first army airplane bombing practice held at Fort Tyler, off Gardiner's Island.

LONDON, July 27. -- The stock markets here were irregular today, with profit-taking, owing to the approaching holiday season. British funds remained cheerful although the volume of business was small.

ROME, July 27. -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's announcement in the House of Commons today of the death of the agreements he concluded for Great Britain last December with various Mediterranean States was received in Italy with sincere and undisguised satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of investment trust and investment companies in the United States, whose total assets aggregated about $8,000,000,000 in the peak days of the boom and dwindled to less than $3,000,000,000 on Dec. 31, 1935, began today with plenty of fireworks to enliven the proceedings.
MADRID, July 27 (Passed by the Censor). -- Fighting is still going on intermittently in the Guadarrama mountain passes north of Madrid.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, through one of its principal officials, declared today that the six-cent fare to and from Jersey City and Hudson County to the Hudson Terminal in Manhattan was perfectly legal.

One of the largest tasks of its kind ever undertaken in this city was completed over the week-end by the WPA with the removal of its main offices from the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, to its new quarters at 70 Columbus Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- In his first talk before members of the Chicago Board of Trade today, Secretary of Agriculture Wallace assured a small group of grain traders that while he believed speculation had played too large a part in the board's activities, he realized it could not be stopped by wrecking the places where it tended to concentrate.

The little cargo-passenger steamship Exermont backed into her berth at the American Export Line's pier in Jersey City yesterday afternoon, landing the eight survivors of the party of nine that gave the Queen Mary an air greeting at Nantucket on Sunday afternoon.

A taxicab driver accused of reckless driving and a man defendant in a domestic dispute aroused the ire of two city magistrates yesterday. Sitting in different courts, the magistrates revealed their judicial displeasure by indicating that both defendants deserved to be shot.

L'ETANG ISLAND, N.B., July 27. -- With the same disregard for schedules that has marked his thirteen days of cruising in the schooner Sewanna, President Roosevelt today made a brief anchorage at Campobello Island, his Summer home, displayed to Mrs. Roosevelt a set of sideburn whiskers grown on his trip and then hoisted anchor to sail ten miles farther north and anchor here for the night.

Fifteen policemen, led by an inspector, a captain and a sergeant, held back an excited crowd of 500 neighbors in Sunnyside, Queens, yesterday as a city marshal and three assistants, armed with shears and crowbars, charged a home barricaded with sand bags and barbed wire to carry out a dispossess order.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation will meet at 3 P.M. today to receive the report on its earnings for the second quarter, and to take action on the preferred dividend. It is reported in Wall Street that the net profit for the three months was equal, after full dividend requirements on the $7 preferred stock, to about $1 a share on 8,703,252 common shares.

Louis and Max Steinberg, owners of the building at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South, the Bronx, in the collapse of which eighteen workmen were killed, surrendered yesterday. They were indicted last Friday with four other men for manslaughter in the second degree.

One of the characters in Spenser's "Faerie Queene" is made to say that "the way to win is wisely to advise." That was the secret of the victorious life of WILFRED FRY. Not only was he a successful adviser in his business relations, which had a national and international range.

EASTPORT, Me., July 27. -- After an inspection of the Passamaquoddy tide-harnessing power project, which is soon to be abandoned by the Public Works Administration because of lack of funds, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, said tonight that he planned to lay before President Roosevelt a program for development of the $1,500,000 Quoddy village as a WPA activity.

Development in the near future of the upper Fast Side along modern lines, with harmoniously designed apartment dwellings and improved shopping centers, theatres and commercial buildings, was predicted yesterday by Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, at a luncheon of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce in Claremont Inn, Riverside Drive at 124th Street.

PARIS, July 27. -- After having taken more than a passive part in the fighting in Barcelona most of the members of the American Popular Olympics team will sail for home Wednesday on the liner Normandie. They are all now in Paris except Julian Raoul, bicycle racer, who has not been heard from since he sailed from Glasgow for Barcelona direct before the games began in order to avoid coming through France.

Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions, on the recommendation of District Attorney Dodge, discharged on her own recognizance yesterday Mrs. Garnet M. McCabe, 49 years old, who on the night of Jan. 12, 1933, was alleged to have killed her husband, Evert, vice president of the United Parcel Service, Inc. Mr. McCabe was shot five times in their apartment in the Woodstock Towers of Tudor City.

Frank C. Walker, close friend of President Roosevelt, has been named chairman of the finance committee of the Democratic campaign, National Chairman James A. Farley announced yesterday at a press conference at Democratic headquarters here.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,500,000 of State of Minnesota Department of Rural Credit certificates of indebtedness on a bid of 100.06 for a 1.85 per cent interest rate.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 27. -- The rain, which came down in bucketsful about an hour before "Fidelio" opened the Salzburg Festival on Saturday and subsided sufficiently by the end of the performance to let the audience disperse without a second wetting, gave way to a Sunday of cloudless skies.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 27 (AP). -- Governor Lehman told a conference of police officials tonight that "laws by themselves will not fulfill the necessities" of the crime situation.

Because of the threatening weather all day, the appearance of four piano soloists in the Bach concerto, which was scheduled for last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, was postponed until tonight. The pianists are Harold Bauer, Rudolph Ganz, Mischa Levitzki and Jose Iturbi.

More than one-third of the government employes under Mr. Roosevelt were not under civil service in 1935, against approximately 20 per cent under his two predecessors. Under Hoover, 467,000 out of 583,000 were under civil service, while according to the 1935 record only 455,000 out of 719,000 were under civil service.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The Republican National Committee said today an analysis by James R. Howard, former president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, showed "New Deal tinkering with the nation's food supply" had affected both the diet and the pocketbook of the citizen.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 27 (AP). -- Tropical storms buffeted the Louisiana-Mississippi coastline and the Bahama Islands tonight, the gulf disturbance diminishing in force after crossing the coast but the Atlantic storm picking up intensisty while moving slowly toward Southeastern Florida.

Warners' film adaptation of Hervey Allen's "Anthony Adverse" will have its local premiere on Aug. 26 at the Strand Theatre. For a time it looked as though "Anthony" would be awarded to the Radio City Music Hall, but the Warners have finally decided to favor their own Broadway house.

Directors of the Jewel Tea Company yesterday declared the regular quarterly dividend of $1 on the common stock, payable Sept. 30 to stockholders of record Sept. 16. It was stated that this advance of fifteen days in the customary date of dividend payment is made on account of the Revenue Act of 1936, so that the company's dividend year and tax year will correspond.

Directors of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York at a meeting held early yesterday morning declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, against 25 cents a share paid in the five preceding quarters. The rate had been 50 cents quarterly, having been reduced from 75 cents quarterly in June, 1934.

BERLIN, July 27. -- The head of the Olympic ticket distributing office, Hans Lessing, still rather dazed from overwork, now estimates that an average of 40,000 foreign spectators will be present at the games daily. This compares with the daily seating capacity of the scheduled events, varying between 100,000 and 250,000.

MANCHESTER, England, July 27 (Canadian Press). -- India gave England a real taste of its batting power in the second session of the second cricket test match today. Behind by 368 runs on the first innings, the touring team's opening batsmen were still at the wickets at the close of play with the total at 190.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from a five-week trip abroad. He brought back a decoration from Versailles, where a street was named for him.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP). -- Declaring that the administration of justice is too bewildering, two groups today advocated changes in the nation's legal system.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 27. -- The Australian Davis Cup team remained in the running for the international tennis trophy it last won in 1919 when Jack Crawford and Adrian Quist pulled out a bitterly fought doubles victory over the English combination of Pat Hughes and Charles Tuckey today.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Two Federal agencies, the WPA and the RA, moved today to supply relief jobs and "doles" to Kansas farmers, as Governor Landon announced plans in Topeka for an independent State drought program.

DEAL, N.J., July 27. -- Equaling the course record with a 38 -- 40 -- 78, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, the State champion, enjoyed a three-stroke lead at the end of the first round of the women's fifty-four-hole New Jersey Shore tournament today.

Frank J. Prial announced yesterday that he would decide "within two or three days" whether he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Aldermanic President against Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, the organization choice.
CHICAGO, July 27. -- General Charles G. Dawes made the prediction today that by the beginning of next year steel finishing plants would be operating at capacity.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, Commissioner of Baseball, said today he had received no response to his $5,000 reward offered for information leading to the conviction of the grand-stand assailant of William Summers, American League umpire, felled by a bottle during the White Sox-Yankee double-header yesterday.

PARIS, July 27. -- Warm appreciation of the work done by the American steamship Exeter in taking off not only American but German and other nationals from Barcelona is expressed by the employes of the Petit Parisien who were trapped by the revolution while on a vacation in Southern Spain.

A generally firmer tendency developed yesterday in quiet trading in the local commodity futures markets, with tin, sugar and cocoa as weak spots in the group. Sugar futures were fairly active, 11,000 tons changing hands. The September was 2 points lower, the December unchanged, and other months down 4 to 5 points.
OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 27 (AP). -- The Grand Circuit came to Maine for the first time today with a track record equaled and 3,000 spectators at the rebuilt one-mile "kite" track.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27. -- Making his first appearance of the season in singles, Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York defeated Walter Senior of San Francisco, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, today as a brilliant field of ranking men and women players started out in the forty-ninth annual invitation tennis tournament on the velvet turf of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

DETROIT, July 27 (AP). -- Kaye Don said today he would like to defend here in 1937 the Gold Cup he won for Detroit in a lonely victory at Lake George Saturday after the only other starting boat was forced out of the race.

The four hundredth anniversary of the death of ERASMUS of Rotterdam should be observed around the globe, for he was the "banner-bearer for the new way of thinking." The inscription upon the banner was, "The entire world is one common fatherland" -- though his world then embraced only Europe.

CLEVELAND, July 27. -- Perry A. Frey, police prosecutor, sent a telegram today to Governor E.W. Marland of Oklahoma recommending an immediate pardon for Carlton B. Chilton, 41, who escaped twenty-three years ago from an Oklahoma reformatory after serving one year of a two-year sentence for bank burglary.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday net earnings for the quarter ended on June 30, 1936, of $88,108,372, equal after preferred dividends to $2 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding during the quarter.

While the number of buyers arriving in the wholesale markets here yesterday continued large, the indications were that the peak of initial arrivals for the Fall season has now been passed. Most manufacturers are well satisfied with the results thus far, with volume in women's apparel, accessory and homewares lines ranging from 15 to 20 per cent over last year at this time.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 28. -- Continuous recurrence of trade disputes with virtually all countries to whom Japan's exports are expanding, has caused business leaders to decide that centralized control is necessary.
The Federal Government is fighting the Dutch elm disease in the metropolitan district from the air, as the cotton planters of Texas fought the boll weevil.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 27. -- The Olympic torch arrived here today. After a ceremony lasting one hour the runners continued toward the Hungarian frontier, where they will arrive at 6 o'clock tomorrow morning.

Dr. Abraham Benjamin, 56 years old, of 307 East Broadway, for more than a quarter of a century a practicing physician on the lower East Side, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to serve fifteen months to two and one-half years in Sing Sing for a fraudulent accident claim.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 27. -- The Rev. George Gardner Day of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., former rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, Williamstown, was the honored guest at a tea and reception given by the Right Rev. Robert Lewis Paddock, retired Episcopal Bishop of Eastern Oregon, and Mrs. Paddock today at their Summer home on Buxton Hill, Williamstown.

DETROIT, July 27. -- The towering figure of Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe cast its shadow across the path of the Yankees at Navin Field today to snap the league-leaders' winning streak after four straight and give the Tigers their first triumph in four games before a crowd of 13,000.

Edmund Fauchot, 33 years old, of 830 Rhinelander Avenue, the Bronx, a man with a criminal record of seventeen arrests and numerous prison sentences, was shot in the head shortly before 1 P.M. yesterday in front of 88 Oliver Street, near Cherry, in the heart of one of the most congested districts of the lower East Side.

Mrs. Marion Cassidy's Bill Farnsworth, one of the most consistent performers among the platers this season, ran to his form again yesterday and captured the Whitestone Purse, which featured the racing at Empire City.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 27. -- Back at old St. Andrews, one of his big happy hunting grounds of golf, Bobby Jones shot and marched like the emperor of old again today, scoring a 32, 40 -- 72 as a thrilled gallery of 3,000 looked on.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 27. -- Mark Graves, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, declared here today that "during the more than thirteen and one-half years of Democratic administration of State affairs under Governors Smith, Roosevelt and Lehman, more constructive legislation in the interest of agriculture, labor, industry and finance was enacted, than during any like period in the history of the State."
LONDON, July 27. -- King Edward and Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin have changed their holiday plans because of disturbed conditions in Europe.

BUFFALO, July 27 (AP). -- The W. Stanley Hayes Rink of Buffalo, defending champions, were defeated by the J.A. Brodie Rink of St. Catherines, Ont., as the twenty-sixth international lawn bowling tournament opened here today, 16 -- 11.

The Wyndham, a fifteen-story apartment house at 42-48 West Fifty-eighth Street, was taken over yesterday on a $100,000 bid at a foreclosure auction sale by the New York Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff. Five other Manhattan properties and two in the Bronx also were listed for sale.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- Jay Berwanger, Riley Smith, Paul Tangora and Dick Smith, whose exploits brought them All-America honors, and seven other stalwarts who contributed to 1935's college gridiron history will oppose the professional champion Detroit Lions in the third annual all-star battle under floodlights at Soldier Field Sept. 1.

MOSCOW, July 27. -- Soviet purchases from abroad, which have declined from the peak of more than 1,000,000,000 gold rubles annually at the height of the first Five-Year Plan to less than 250,000,000 at present, are to be still further reduced. This was announced by A.P. Rosengoltz, Commissar for Foreign Trade, in an address at a closed meeting of foreign trade executives, which was made public today.

BERLIN, July 27. -- The American swimmers have had no time trials since they settled down in the Olympic Village, but they have shown enough to Robert J. H. Kiphuth to make that generally pessimistic gentleman believe that they will be able to turn back the Japanese at last.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27. -- At least 100 guests are expected to attend the dinner at the Newport Country Club on Thursday night, the eve of the first day of the tenth annual invitation golf tournament at the club.

Home owners and apartment dwellers will have to pay higher prices for wallpaper this Summer, the first time since 1933 that an advance has been put into effect, wholesalers, retailers and decorators attending the opening of the first public wallpaper exposition at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday were told.

Sterling Securities Corporation, which is controlled by the Atlas Corporation, reports net assets as of June 30 of $19,486,550 after provision of $944,000 for normal Federal income taxes that would result from the realization of appreciation of investments.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday, in a unanimous decision, upheld Federal Judge Patterson in his recent ruling that a broker's duty to his customer was not a bar to his complying with a subpoena calling for production of his business records.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 27. -- John Kinder, former State open champion and Charles Whitehead, holder of the New Jersey amateur championship, captured the New Jersey P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Crestmont Golf Club when they collaborated in scoring a 61, eleven strokes under par.

Children and adults on the lower East Side had an opportunity yesterday to see the types of flowers, herbs and vegetables that are grown in the country. The Park Department exhibited more than 100 plants for their enlightenment in Roosevelt Playground at Stanton Street, between Chrystie and Forsythe Streets.

The terms that the delegates of the International Tin Committee offered on behalf of the signatory countries for a renewal of the restriction agreement after the end of this year have been rejected by the Government of Siam, according to advices received by cable yesterday at the Commodity Exchange, Inc., from Bangkok and Singapore.

Children and adults on the lower East Side had an opportunity yesterday to see the types of flowers, herbs and vegetables that are grown in the country. The Park Department exhibited more than 100 plants for their enlightenment in Roosevelt Playground at Stanton Street, between Chrystie and Forsythe Streets.

The terms that the delegates of the International Tin Committee offered on behalf of the signatory countries for a renewal of the restriction agreement after the end of this year have been rejected by the Government of Siam, according to advices received by cable yesterday at the Commodity Exchange, Inc., from Bangkok and Singapore.
Value of Dollar in ]Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- How the span of life in this country has increased since the beginning of the present century was illustrated today when the Census Bureau reported that whereas thirty-six years ago the average life of a white man was 48 years, and of a white woman 51 years, the averages are now 59 and 63 years.

James J. Braddock will defend his world's heavyweight championship against Max Schmeling in the Long Island City Bowl in September. The match, listed for fifteen rounds, and a natural ever since Schmeling's surprising knockout over Joe Louis last month, was made yesterday following more than three weeks of conference between the Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Twentieth Century Sporting Club.

BERLIN, July 27. -- Trading on the Boerse was inclined today toward profit-taking and prices sagged, but the turnover was small and many issues showed good resistance. Heavy industrials continued their upward movement at the opening, some, like Mansfeld, registering small gains, but the majority closed fractionally below the previous close.

BOSTON, July 27. -- The Federal Trade Commission opened hearings here today on a complaint charging unfair methods of competition to the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., and affiliated organizations.

BERLIN, July 27. -- An accident which nearly cost the life of Colonel Ernst Udet, the most famous living German war ace and stunt flier, today marred Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's visit to the Heinkel Airplane works at Warnemuende.

Harry Fields, 242, Philadelphia, threw Matros Kirilenko, 215, Russia, in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 3,000 spectators watched Fields end the bout with a body scissors in 52:07.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 27. -- The first two trains since the rebel outbreak left here today for the French border. They were besieged by a crowd, including foreigners, seeking to leave Spain.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- The stronger world's statistical position of wheat today became a major influence in the market and, with decreased hedging pressure from the Southwest, resulted in an advance of about 2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish in the Chicago Board of Trade before profit-taking checked the bulge.
