Mary Ellen Chase, author of "Mary Peters" and "Silas Crockett," who has been making a long stay in England, will arrive here early in August with a book about England virtually finished. She has not yet decided on a title. Macmillan will publish the book.

Exception must be taken to the attack of Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College on the teachers' unions. The weakness of the dean's position is clearly shown by the fact that he drags the red herring of "the Soviet idea" and that of being "unduly influenced by foreign experience" across the trail instead of considering the matter on its own merits or demerits.

With a drizzling rain washing out the fourth game of their series with the Reds at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Giants will conclude their current brush with Chuck Dressen's Cincinnatians in a doubleheader this afternoon, the first game starting at 1:45.

Louis J. Ehret, son of George Ehret, the brewer, was sharply criticized yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for his attempt to repudiate an obligation for $117,000 contracted on two notes in 1932 when he purchased stock of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, of which he was a director.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Ambassador Claude G. Bowers informed the State Department tonight that he was taking the unusual step of making a ship his floating embassy. The Ambassador informed the department that he had gone to Saint Jean de Luz, France, today to communicate with his colleagues and that he would return to his home at Fuenterrabia, Spain, tomorrow and board the Coast Guard cutter Cayuga at once.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, which is in process of reorganization, made a net profit of $734,492 in the twenty-six-week period to June 27, according to a report of the Irving Trust Company, as trustee, which had been prepared for submission to Federal Judge William Bondy.

Louis J. Ehret, son of George Ehret, the brewer, was sharply criticized yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for his attempt to repudiate an obligation for $117,000 contracted on two notes in 1932 when he purchased stock of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, of which he was a director.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Ambassador Claude G. Bowers informed the State Department tonight that he was taking the unusual step of making a ship his floating embassy. The Ambassador informed the department that he had gone to Saint Jean de Luz, France, today to communicate with his colleagues and that he would return to his home at Fuenterrabia, Spain, tomorrow and board the Coast Guard cutter Cayuga at once.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, which is in process of reorganization, made a net profit of $734,492 in the twenty-six-week period to June 27, according to a report of the Irving Trust Company, as trustee, which had been prepared for submission to Federal Judge William Bondy.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 28 (AP). -- Josh Lee, youthful Representative in Congress and former Professor of Public Speaking, who countered with a fluent tongue and a ready smile charges that he used WPA workers to further his campaign, apparently was swept into the Oklahoma Democratic Senatorial nomination today.

Dedicated to the enlistment of 1,000,000 women voters to support Governor Landon and Colonel Knox at the polls in November, national headquarters of the Independent Coalition of American Women were opened yesterday with brief exercises at 485 Madison Avenue.

The report in yesterday's TIMES that deposits in mutual savings banks in this country have passed the $10,000,000,000 mark and approached the highest point on record, is another certain indication of the progress of recovery. It is particularly reassuring to note that the number of new accounts increased so rapidly during the first half of 1936 that a new high record has been set in the total number of individual depositors.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 28. -- A central feature of Friday afternoon's annual village fair, proceeds of which will care for trees and greens here through the coming year, will be in keeping with the Long Island tercentenary being celebrated this Summer.
LONDON, July 28. -- Alfred Duff Cooper, Minister of War, announced today the government's intention to create a new infantry section of the supplementary army reserve.

The Long Island Railroad announced yesterday that it would accept without appeal to the courts the decisions of the Public Service Commission and the Transit Commission denying it commutation fare increases of 20 per cent in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and of 15 per cent within the city.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 28 (AP). -- Calumet Evelyn, world champion double-gaited mare, set a new Grand Circuit trotting mark for the 1936 season by stepping off a mile on the kite-shaped track here in 2:01 1/4 today.
In reading the Mayor's address at the meeting of the Brooklyn Public Library I was surprised to find that he put schools and hospitals ahead of libraries.

CHICAGO, July 28. -- Serious as the present drought is, Middle Western farmers as a group are much better off than in 1934, according to a study of the agricultural situation made public today by the Corn Belt Farm dailies.
BERLIN, July 28. -- Operators on the Boerse continued to take profits today and prices sagged, although the turnover remained merely nominal.

A drop in the city's general death rate and infant mortality rate last week was reported yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice. The 1,182 deaths for the week marked the lowest number to be recorded for a seven-day period since the first of the year.

MADRID, July 28. -- There was continuous fighting in three sectors today. The government, in announcing the last rebel nest at San Sebastian, the Loyola military barracks, had surrendered, said military stores in the barracks, including artillery and engineering equipment, were taken over by the loyalists.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP). -- A four-run rally in the ninth, climaxed by Dolph Camilli's second homer of the game and his nineteenth of the season, gave the Phillies a 5-to-3 victory over the Cubs today.

It is amusing to read Roscoe Peacock's criticism of Arthur Krock for "over-simplification" in discussing the attitudes of the Rights and Lefts toward Mr. Roosevelt. Mr. Peacock, over-simplifying the conclusion to be arrived at beyond all question, asserts that Mr. Krock makes of Roosevelt an "ultraconservative," whereupon Mr. Peacock belabors this over-simple man of straw with Roosevelt's own phrases.

PITTSBURGH, July 28. -- Good operating results in June for the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, continuing the remarkable comeback from the first quarter of this year, when its net loss amounted to $933,279, helped the company to earn $1,115,733 in the second quarter, thus wiping out the firstquarter loss and leaving a net profit for the first six months of 1936.

With the wholesale quotations on some lines of imported Scotch whiskies showing a drop of 5 per cent, fear spread throughout the market here yesterday that a serious price war might be renewed as the result of dissatisfaction over present conditions among members of the Wholesale Board of Trade of the New York Institute of Wine and Spirit Distributors, Inc.

Of thirty-one railroads communicating with the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, twenty-three are increasing this year's newspaper advertising budget over the 1935 figure, the bureau reported yesterday, thus insuring a substantial advance over the $3,500,000 spent last year.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 28. -- J.P. Morgan's yacht Corsair is expected to leave Glen Cove tomorrow morning with the banker, his nurse and some members of his family on board, the same date that the banker, before his illness, had expected to sail on the Queen Mary.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 28. -- Sigmund Romberg's tuneful operetta, "B1ossom Time," fashioned from the music of Franz Schubert, was the third operetta presented here tonight on Zach's Bay, under the direction of Fortune Gallo. The production attracted a capacity audience of 10,000 persons, seated in the Jones Beach Stadium on the shore.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad notified today the Interstate Commerce Commission that its proposed issue of $29,500,000 refunding and improvement-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series E, would be sold to Morgan Stanley Co., and associated underwriters at 97 1/2 per cent of the principal amount and accrued interest, with the understanding that they would be offered to the public at 99 1/2.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 28. -- The performance tonight of "Don Giovanni" was far and away the best of the festival to date. It has homogeneity, sustained tensity and tingling dramatic life which one has vainly sought even in the "Fidelio" which Arturo Toscanini led on Saturday evening.

The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced that it had completed negotiations for purchase of the twenty-story Ley Building at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES last June 23.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. July 28 (AP). -- Two sailors were killed and nine others injured today in a broadside six-inch gun explosion aboard the U.S.S. Marblehead, light cruiser, at sea off Southern California during gunnery exercises. The victims were brought here tonight.

The estate of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 12-year-old daughter of Reginald C. Vanderbilt, is worth $3,837,088, according to a report of Francis J. Quillinan, attorney, who was appointed special guardian by Surrogate James A. Foley to examine accountings filed by the late George W. Wickersham and Thomas B. Gilchrist as general guardians of the child's property.

TODAY'S book is the work of a man who departed this life in 1781. His name is Wilfred Brandon. The book was dictated from the Etheric plane to Edith Ellis, actress and dramatist. It is published by Knopf for $2, and is entitled "Incarnation, A Plea from the Masters."
ALBANY, July 28 (AP). -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. held today that "conviction of public intoxication is conviction for a criminal offense justifying commitment to Napanoch."

The Earl and Countess of Lincoln, Sir Malcolm and Lady Perks, Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt and her sister, Lady Furness; Mrs. Lewis Cass Ledyard Jr., Kaye Don, racing automobilist; Jesse L. Lasky, Jesse L. Lasky Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Adam L. Gimbel, Mrs. Leopold Stokowski and Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, are among the travelers sailing this afternoon for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

PARIS, July 28. -- Harsher things were said in the Chamber of Deputies today by Gaston Gerard, former Under-Secretary of State for the Tourist Industry, and others about the way France treated tourists and about the conditions of travel than any foreign journalist or visitor would ever dare say or write.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP). -- In a finish that was so close a picture was required to determine the winner, Mrs. John D. Hertz's Count Arthur conquered Nellie Flag from Warren Wright's Calumet Farm in the mile handicap today at Arlington Park.

CHICAGO, July 28. -- Offerings of hogs here were smaller today, and, with a fairly good demand for desirable kinds, the market was strong to 10 cents a hundredweight higher with the top of $11.20 up 10 cents from Monday and equal to the outside figure so far this year, established last February.

BERLIN, July 28. -- In conformity with orders issued by the Propaganda Ministry, following reports from the commander of the battleship Deutschland, now off the Spanish coast, that the battle chances in Spain were still fifty-fifty, the German press assumed a very reserved attitude today.

Increases of 200 per cent in building, payment of the soldiers' bonus, doubling of the number of marriages since 1935 and the return of the dining room as an integral part of the average city dwelling are contributing factors to a "sensational rise" in the furniture business throughout the United States, and particularly in this city, according to Frederick Daum, merchandise manager of Spear Co., with stores here and in Pittsburgh.

Patents for his newly invented process of welding ferrous and nonferrous metals by means of an invisible ray have yielded Dr. Antonio Longoria of Cleveland about $6,000,000, the inventor declared yesterday when he arrived in New York City.
JERUSALEM, July 28 (AP). -- Arab terrorists, twenty of their number reported slain, retreated into the hills of Nablus tonight before British infantry and war planes.
James W. Gerard officially withdrew yesterday his offer to bet $20,000 to $10,000 that President Roosevelt would be re-elected, but it cost him $3,400 to do it.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28. -- South Shore, standing off a late rally on the part of the Vipers, took the last of the semi-final matches in the Wheatley Cups tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today, winning, 6 to 5, on Hitchcock Field.

Budget requests for 1937 by the city's five county clerks for a total of $950,785, an increase of $107,027 over this year, were reviewed at hearings held yesterday by Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen. County Clerk Jenkin R. Hockert of Queens was the only one to refrain from asking that salary reductions be ended for himself or exempt employes.

ORANGE, N.J., July 28. -- Vincenzo Pallelo, 44 years old, of 547 Glebe Street, Orange, was sentenced today to stay away from his family but to continue to support them for two years by Police Judge Martin McHugh.

HAVANA, July 28. -- An amnesty that will liberate political prisoners with the exception of officials of the Machado regime who were convicted by sanctions courts and those convicted of terrorism was unanimously approved by the Senate tonight.

The walls of Horticultural Hall in Rockefeller Center last night were papered with poems and each poem had to do with a garden. Submitted in the contest held by the National Poetry Center, they will be on exhibition until next Monday.

PARIS, July 28. -- Equal pay with men for equal work and increased participation of women in government were among the demands of speakers today at the congress of the International Federation of Business Women here.

GIBRALTAR, July 28. -- Moroccan troops attacked a band of armed Communists in the La Linea district near Gibraltar below the hill called "the Queen of Spain's chair" early today and dispersed them, causing heavy losses.

BERLIN, July 28. -- Hans von Tschammer und Osten, Reich sports dictator, today reached an agreement with Baldur von Schirach, Hitler Youth chief, which makes it impossible for any German boy under 14 to engage regularly in athletics unless he joins the Nazi party's political youth training organization.

ALBANY, July 28. -- Nine committees authorized by the recent Legislature, with appropriations aggregating $142,500, were organized here today. Among them was one headed by Senator John J. McNaboe, Democrat, of New York County, to investigate alleged Communist activities in the public schools and colleges of the State.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 28. -- Clinching victory with Fred Perry's straight-set triumph over Jack Crawford, England today completed her conquest of Australia in the challenge round to win the Davis Cup, emblematic of international tennis team supremacy, for the fourth straight year.
Attorney General Homer S. Cummings conferred yesterday with James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, and pledged himself to take an active part in the battle t o re-elect President Roosevelt.

The city of Pittsburgh, Pa., awarded yesterday two new issues of bonds, aggregating $2,800,000, to a banking syndicate headed by Graham, Parsons Co., in a sale marked by exceptionally close bidding on the part of eight separate groups.

WINNIPEG, July 28 (Canadian Press). -- Possibility of a stalemate in the battle for control of Manitoba's Legislature loomed tonight in the tabulation of votes cast in yesterday's provincial general election.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Moulton of New York, who passed much of the early season at the Muenchinger-King, have returned there and tomorrow will give a large buffet luncheon for their friends at the Sachuset Golf Club. The luncheon will be served in Russian style.

HEADQUARTERS OF GENERAL MOLA AT BURGOS, Spain, July 28 (By Courier to Hendaye, France). On this side of the Spanish front it looks like victory. Madrid has during the past two days been announcing over the radio the retreat of General Emilio Mola's force, but there is no evidence of a retreat here.

LONDON, July 28. -- A bullet-riddled barrier between rebel and government forces at Seville, Spain, for three days, the British motor vessel Palacio, 1,346 tons, had many visitors today seeking stories of the Spanish civil war.

Samuel Samuels, 44 years old, who has police aliases of Wilson and Fielde., but said he merely was an itinerant peddler of women's apparel in certain apartments on the middle West Side, with a furniture business at 148 West Twenty-third Street as a sideline, was indicted yesterday on compulsory prostitution charges.
PATERSON, N.J., July 28. -- A strike of more than 200 small businesses will be started here tomorrow morning against half a dozen larger businesses that supply them with raw materials.
MILLVILLE, N.J., July 28. -- Mrs. Ruth M. Lewis, Millville City Relief Director, was arraigned today before a justice of the peace here on a charge of failing to provide shelter for a needy family.
Compensation of the officers of three companies were disclosed yesterday in annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission. The individuals and their salaries were given as follows:
Favorable earnings were reported in the financial statements of three independent steel companies which yesterday announced results of operations in the second quarter.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP). -- Earl Averill rapped out his eighteenth and nineteenth home runs of the season and Odell Hale got No. 10 today as the Indians scored a 6-to-3 victory over the Senators.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., July 28. -- President Roosevelt completed his vacation cruise late this evening. After two weeks in which he skippered the small schooner-yacht Sewanna he dropped anchor in Friar's Bay within a few hundred feet of the beach at the foot of a hill topped by his Summer bungalow.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP). -- Carlton B. Chilton, 41, who escaped from an Oklahoma reformatory twenty-three years ago, received today from Governor E.W. Marland of Oklahoma a thirty-day parole.

Mr. STERLING EDWIN EDMUNDS, a St. Louis writer and lecturer on international law, has invited the "Constitutional Democrats" of thirty States to a conference in Detroit Aug. 7. On that day of the year LEONIDAS died. Even if Mr. EDMUNDS be but the voice of JIM REED, it is good to hear of him.

Captain Ronald Cheyne-Stout, director of the Central Park Zoo, was severely clawed last night by a pet lioness named Curley while he was inside the cage showing the animal to a visitor, Count Carl V. Koenegseck, director of the Berlin Zoo.
WITH GENERAL MOLA'S ARMY AT ROBREGORDO, July 27 (By Courier to Hendaye, France). -- Fascist forces won a victory over the defenders of Madrid to capture the mountain village of Robregordo today.

ALBANY, July 28 (AP). -- Speaking before Albany County Republican women at Bethlehem today, Senator Fearon declared that Southern and Western States joined in the Democratic convention movement to draft Governor Lehman because he permitted New York State to provide "funds for relief and to bolster up a political machine in the solid South and Democratic West."

TRENTON, July 28. -- Supreme Court Justice Harry Heher signed an order today requiring Governor Hoffman to show cause on Oct. 6 why service should not be set aside in the case of some of the defendant companies named jointly with Boake Carter, radio commentator, in the Executive's $100,000 libel suit.

Remington Rand, Inc., declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividends of 15 cents in cash and 1 per cent in stock on the common stock. J.H. Rand Jr., president, estimates net income for the June quarter will be less than $35,000 under the results for the same period in 1935, after absorbing all strike expenses and idle plant burden.

MADRID, July 28 (Passed by the Censor). -- In the absence of definite news from the various battlefronts, a bloodless radio propaganda war is being conducted in Spain. From Madrid the government is broadcasting its news reports by long wave and these are being relayed from Barcelona, Valencia and other long-wave stations in sectors of the country where forces loyal to the government are in control.

DETROIT, July 28. -- The Yanks battered and bruised three Tiger pitchers with such abandon today at Navin Field that they tired of the pastime and started knocking each other all over the lot. They won the game, 16 to 6, but were fortunate to escape serious injuries.

BERLIN, July 28. -- Air Minister Hermann Goering and Mrs. Goering gave a luncheon in their Berlin palace today for Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Mrs. Lindbergh at which the American visitors and their official host met for the first time.

BERLIN, July 28. -- America's most feared Olympic track and field rival, Finland, checked in at the Olympic Village today amid the blare of bands and the deep-seated conviction that, Don Lash to the contrary, the Finns are going to show the United States how distance running really is done.
WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Governor Landon is on record as having approved an exclusively Federal work relief program.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern Republican campaign manager, estimated yesterday that between 1,500,000 and 2,000,000 Democrats would bolt their party this year and vote for Governor Alf M. Landon for President.

Twenty Department of Sanitation inspectors started a week's clean sidewalks crusade yesterday in Flatbush, Brooklyn, against dog owners who violate Section 227 of the Senitary Code. Fourteen summonses were issued to owners for appearance Friday in Flatbush Court before Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 28. -- Defeat awaited Gene Mako in his first match following his return from abroad and disaster also overtook Robert Riggs, the national clay court and junior champion, today in the invitation tennis tournament at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

A total of $929,000 Republic of Cuba 5 per cent bonds of 1904 have been drawn for redemption at par on Sept. 1, 1936, Speyer Co., fiscal agents, have announced. In addition, the firm has bought in the market for cancellation through the sinking fund, $107,000 of the bonds.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad reported yesterday an increase of 1.5 per cent in passenger revenues in June, the first month in which the low passenger rates became effective. This gain was not as great as the increases reported by the Eastern trunk lines, which ranged from 6.6 to 16.7 per cent.

MANCHESTER, England, July 28 (Canadian Press) -- India's touring cricket tonight claimed a well-earned draw with England in the second test match of the year. The visitors scored 203 and 390 for five wickets against 571 for eight wickets, declared. England won the first test by nine wickets.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 28 (Canadian Press). -- The Vineyard Haven (Mass.) Yacht Club, fighting to gain permanent possession of the Prince of Wales international junior yacht racing trophy, advanced today to the second round of the annual Lake Milo series by eliminating the Royal Nova Scotia Yacht Squadron of Halifax.

When EDWARD M. SHEPARD spoke at the "solid establishment" of the Saratoga Springs Reservation in 1911 he said that he could not mention the share that GEORGE FOSTER PEABODY had in this great and beneficent State undertaking, of the dedication to it of his skill and experience in business and public affairs and in general helpfulness to mankind -- and for one reason: that Mr. PEABODY was "before us."

CHICAGO, July 28. -- The world's wheat markets continued on the upgrade today, with all deliveries in Liverpool selling at a new high mark for the season and Winnipeg coming within a fraction of the best level so far. There was no material pressure, and while profit-taking checked the advance, closing trades here were at gains of 1 1/8 to 2 1/4 cents a bushel.

Although Johan August Karlsson, also known as Noren, was declared dead by a district court in Sweden because he had not been heard from since 1883, when he came to this country and settled in Chicago, he is still alive in the eyes of the Surrogates' Court of New York City.

NAPANEE, Ont., July 28 (Canadian Press). -- Two American women were fatally injured today when cars in which they were touring were in collision on the Montreal Toronto highway a few miles west of here.
It looked yesterday as if the world's lightweight crown will be going begging for a wearer within a week or so.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., July 28. -- Trailing by one stroke going to the last hole, young Charley Mayo Jr. played a sensational mashie shot to give himself and his father a tie with Bill Tobin and Bill Dowie of Plandome for the annual Long Island amateur-pro best-ball championship today.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 28. -- Detailed revelation of the methods used in the prevention and detection of crime would handicap police efforts, Dr. Carleton Simon, criminologist of the New York State Association of Police Chiefs, told 200 members of the organization today at the opening session of the annual convention here.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 28. -- In connection with the forty-ninth annual invitation tennis tournament which opened at the Seabright and Cricket Club on Monday, a Governor's dance, at which tennis stars will be guests of honor will be held at the Tennis Club tomorrow night.

In one of the most fantastic games ever staged at Ebbets Field, which has been an incubator of baseball oddities for years, the Pirates yesterday were carried into the tenth inning to win a contest by an unearned run, 9 -- 8, that they appeared to have had safely won in the fifth.

Nine Manhattan properties and tea in the Bronx were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Among the Manhattan parcels were two six-story buildings on a Park Avenue block front between 130th and 131st Streets, an eight-story loft structure at 39-41 East Twelfth Street and a ten-story building at 545-51 West Fifty-second Street.

PARIS, July 28. -- The French Treasury faces an increase in the deficit of more than 3,000,000,000 francs before the year end, Abel Gardey, reporting for the Finance Committee, told the Senate today in presenting a supplementary credits bill.

Reporting the largest six months' earnings in its history, the International Business Machines Corporation showed a net profit of $3,832,001 after all charges and estimated Federal normal taxes, but before provision for surtax on undistributed profits, according to the semi-annual statement announced yesterday.

Although the net profit of $12,862,423 reported by the United States Steel Corporation for the quarter ended on June 30 fell somewhat short of predictions, the financial community can draw much satisfaction from the report, as well as from the increased dividend on the preferred stock.

Popular sympathy seems to have gone out to ELEANOR HOLM JARRETT, who was removed from the Olympic team because, to use her own untutored words, she likes champagne. In the course of the debate .ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S remark on General GRANT'S brand of whisky is being extensively quoted.

CHICAGO, July 28. -- Dedication of a massive stone archway as a memorial to Major Gen. Leonard Wood, founder of the Citizens Military Training Camps, was the chief event of Patriots' Day ceremonies held at Fort Sheridan today. General Charles E. Kilbourne, commander of the Sixth Corps Area, made the dedicatory address. About 500 visitors and the 900 members of the C.M.T.C. attended the ceremonies.

Although drought conditions in Oklahoma continued unrelieved, highly favorable private crop advices from several States and reports that the American Cotton Cooperative Association made the indicated yield 12,854,000 bales caused a decline of $1 a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

While a group of commodity futures advanced yesterday in moderate trading here, including Rio coffee, rubber, silk, copper, tin and hides, other staples stood still or declined slightly. On the cash markets, cotton eased, while all the grains, butter, lard, tin, rubber and silk advanced.

TRENTON, July 28. -- The State Relief Council, which will be superseded officially on Saturday by the State Financial Assistance Commission, held its final meeting today and turned over to the latter body a balance of $1,793,845.

Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday the appointment of the staff of the new Brooklyn Cancer Institute at the Kings County Hospital. The division is receiving its final equipment and it is expected that it will be put into operation Sept. 15.

TOPEKA, July 28. -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, chief rival of Governor Landon for the Republican Presidential nomination, came to Topeka today, expressed his belief that President Roosevelt had been "stopped" and that Governor Landon would be elected, and after a luncheon conference with the Governor announced that he would take an active part in the Republican speaking campaign.

MADRID, July 28 (Passed by the Censor). -- A decree issued by the Ministry of Education today authorizes all Governors and Mayors of every province and city in Spain to confiscate all buildings and also all scientific and teaching equipment belonging to religious orders.
ST. LOUIS, July 28 (AP). -- Johnny Marcum, Bill Werber and John Kroner were three important cogs in the Red Sox 5-to-2 victory over the Browns today.
Plans for new buildings and alterations in existing ones were filed by architects yesterday in scattered sections of Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Four pianists deployed on the Lewisohn Stadium stage last night, playing the solo parts in the Bach Concerto in A minor as well as Infante's "Danzas Andalusas" without orchestra. The largest audience of the season, estimated at 13,000, was attracted by this exhibition and performance.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,960,950 barrels, compared with 2,978,350 in the preceding week, a decline of 17,400, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Declines of 11,000 and 8,900 barrels, respectively, in Oklahoma and California were the important changes.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The General Motors Acceptance Corporation of New York, which engages in the financing of sales of products of General Motors Corporation and its subsidiaries, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933, covering $100,000,000 of debentures.

The share market encountered profit-taking in some volume in the final hour yesterday and the list closed irregular. Earlier in the day, however, prices edged higher, carrying THE NEW YORK TIMES railway and industrial stock averages to new high levels for this year.

Although the trading pace in bonds was stepped up considerably yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, little real progress was made by underlying issues toward higher levels. On the average, listed corporation bonds were virtually unchanged on the day, trading in which was featured only by a brisk demand for a few selected secondary railroad liens.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Loans and increases in loans totaling $31,009,499 were authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in June exclusive of commitments with other Federal agencies, said the corporation's monthly report today.

In view of the sharp gain in operations, which carried earnings of the United States Steel Corporation in the second quarter of this year to the highest level for any three-month period since the third quarter of 1930, directors of the company declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the preferred stock, doubling the quarterly rate paid since the beginning of 1933.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 28. -- Taking a gallery of "hunger marchers" unaware, the State Senate adjourned this evening until 2 P.M. tomorrow to seek Governor Earle's approval of a compromise plan to finance relief, social security and flood control and break up a legislative deadlock of nearly thirteen weeks.
BORDEAUX, France, July 28. --In every hotel, restaurant and cafe of Bordeaux waiters struck today because they don't want tips.
The Rev. John J. Wynne will tomorrow complete sixty years as a member of the Jesuit Order. He is one of the oldest in membership of the Jesuits or Society of Jesus in the United States.

Two blocks bounded by Laurel Hill Terrace and Amsterdam Avenue, 186th to 188th Streets, on Washington Heights, have been sold by the Barney Estate Company to the Shakbro Realty Corporation, Morris Schachnow, president.

EATONTOWN, N.J., July 28. -- Monmouth, Rumson Country Club and Norwood Polo Club were victorious in their first-round matches in the Monmouth County Country Club's annual twelve-goal polo tournament today.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- A new public works program, embodying 352 projects calling for Federal grants of $22,742,034 and secured loans of $2,142,000, was announced today by Secretary Harold L. Ickes, as PWA Administrator. All the works were approved by President Roosevelt.

The Finns believe that Finland is fated to be the Belgium of the next war. Evidently the Germans and Russians think so, too. The Moscow official press protests against the project for a Finnish air route running from Stockholm via the Aland Islands to Helsingfors and thence via Talinn to Leningrad in much the same language employed by Berlin in complaining recently of the surveys for Russian landing fields in Czechoslovakia.

Harold L. Ickes, Federal PWA Administrator, yesterday informed Arthur S. Tuttle, PWA director for New York State, that President Roosevelt had given his approval to the first five allotments, totaling $3,498,295, for projects in New York City under the new 1936 PWA program.

For the fourth consecutive year England retains the Davis Cup. Once a particular country has won the cup, indeed, it seems able to hold it for a considerable period. Thus, beginning in 1920, the United States won for seven consecutive years, then France for six consecutive years.

Two openings are scheduled for today. The Paramount will present "Rhythm on the Range," with Bing Crosby and two newcomers, Bob Burns and Martha Raye. "Bengal Tiger," with Barton MacLane and June Travis, will move into the Strand.

With what sorrow must the true patriot have listened to Mr. Landon's acceptance speech Thursday night! With what anguish must the loyal and thoughtful citizen view the political principles and political leadership of our times! Pious platitudes with no depth either of feeling or insight were the content of Mr. Landon's remarks -- a poor and insignificant rehash of the confused and muddled conservatism of the Republican platform.

BERLIN, July 28. -- Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett got a thrill she described as "bigger than that of winning the Olympic gold medal" when she met former Crown Prince Frederick Wilhelm and was shown by him all over Netherlands Palace.

Winning two games in one day on their home grounds, an accomplishment which had eluded them in five previous attempts this year, the Giants enjoyed a novel experience yesterday at the Polo Grounds and sent the troublesome Reds on their way with a double setback that was warmly greeted by some 14,000 onlookers.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP). -- Rains and breezes drove the temperature below the 100-degree mark generally in the midwestern drought area today and showers repaired some damage to crops in Kansas.

Johnny Clinton, West Side welterweight, added a triumph to his long string by winning a unanimous decision from Ray Napolitano, 143 3/4, of Greenpoint, in the feature bout at the New Queensboro Arena before 3,500 persons last night.
PARIS, July 28. -- Interpellations regarding France's arms policy toward Spain were postponed by the government today until Friday. Deputy Domange protested without avail.

Compilation of plans for the first steam turbine locomotive to be operated in the Americas was announced yesterday by the Union Pacific Railroad. Steam is to be used to turn rotary motors as on the large Atlantic liners, instead of it propelling the engine by means of the pistons and driving rods, which have characterized this mechanism for more than 100 years.
MIAMI, July 28. -- A tropical storm moved across Florida's extreme southern tip tonight, leaving the east coast resort belt unscathed.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday continued to be above the thousand mark, the total was below the preceding week, when the peak of the buying season was reached. Last week's arrivals, however, were above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 28 (AP). -- Breezing across the finishing line fourteen minutes ahead of the defending Erne, Aphrodite, six-meter sloop of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club, Toronto, today won the first race in the international Silas R. George Cup series.

Out of the Atlantic Avenue catacombs in Brooklyn at 4 P.M. yesterday climbed a police and press safari -- dog-tired, dusty, but still determined, after three hours of weary search, to find an entrance to the long-abandoned Atlantic Avenue tunnel, century-old abode of legend and mystery.

A net income of $2,285,845 is reported for the year ended on June 30 by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, excluding $62,754 revenues in suspense and accrued interest there-on, equivalent to $3.07 a share on 744,575 average no-par capital shares outstanding.

NEWARK, N.J., July 28. -- Newark advanced to within one game of Buffalo in second place in the International League tonight when the Bears snapped their losing streak with a double triumph over the Bisons.

Directors of Southern Kraft Corporation authorized yesterday a series of transactions in connection with the offering later this week of $14,500,000 of first leasehold and general mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds due 1946.

Three men who were appointed by the President on July 14 to make a survey of the Panama Canal and write recommendations on the question of tolls charged vessels transiting the waterway, sailed yesterday for the Canal Zone on the Panama Railroad steamer Ancon.

TOKYO, July 28. -- Sir Robert Clive, the British Ambassador, saw Vice Foreign Minister Kensuke Horinouchi today in reference to the result of the inquiry of Kazue Kuwashima, director of the East Asiatic Affairs Bureau, into smuggling in North China.

Six Democratic Governors raked Governor Landon fore and aft politically last night in a coast to coast radio broadcast from their home States. They called his acceptance speech vague, contradictory, confused and laden with beclouding generalities.

Sanitation commissioner William F. Carey was asked yesterday to issue immediate orders calling for the cessation of dumping raw garbage at 111th Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Corona, Queens, a dump bordering the World's Fair site at Flushing Meadows Park.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP). -- The White Sox ended their four-game losing streak today by pounding Carl Doyle and Stewart Flythe for twenty hits and a 19-to-6 victory over the Athletics. The triumph evened the series at one game each. League victory of the season.

Although it was not published until July 9, four days before the count closed, Aldous Huxley's "Eyeless in Gaze" is ninth on the list of fiction best sellers issued yesterday by Baker Taylor, wholesale book dealers. Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind," published on June 30, is first.

CHICAGO, July 28. -- Death took fewer victims on American highways in the first six months of 1936. The toll in automobile traffic accidents was 500 less than for the corresponding period of 1935, according to the National Safety Council.
WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended temporarily today the effectiveness of the following oil loyalty offering sheets and called hearings for Aug. 10:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 28. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, compared the records of President Roosevelt and Governor Landon in fulfilling their promises to balance budgets in an address tonight before the Republican Editorial Association of Indiana.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Plans have been made to evacuate Americans and other foreigners from Madrid to Alicante or Valencia on Thursday morning by special train protected by armed guards, the State Department was advised today by Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the United States Embassy in the Spanish capital.

RUMSON, N.J., July 28. -- Adding an 80 today to her first round of 78, Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont continued to lead the field in the New Jersey Shore medal play golf tournament. Her total of 158 was six strokes better than that of Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, Fresh Meadow, who held second place with 164. The second day's play was held at the Rumson Country Club.

Your editorial comment on the acceptance speech of Governor Landon was interesting. It must be remembered, however, that in 1933 the nation was solidly behind President Roosevelt and the New Deal. All great statesmen place love of country before loyalty to their party else they are not great statesmen.

Voting unanimously yesterday to revoke a permit issued by the Commissioner of Buildings in Queens for a six-story apartment house that is 90 per cent completed, the Board of Standards and Appeals wrote a new chapter in the record of the jurisdictional conflict between the Department of Buildings and the Board of Buildings on one hand, and the Tenement House Department, one of the parties to the action, on the other.

ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, July 28. -- With the exception of E.D. Bogoljubow of Germany, who lost, all of the leaders in the international chess masters tournament at the Grand Hotel were successful today in the eighth round.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28. -- Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson gave a tea today at Lenoir, her home in Ox Pasture Road, for a group of women active in the arrangements for the silver and white hall which will be held Aug. 7 at Canoe Place Inn for the benefit of the Southampton Country School.

ATLANTA, July 28. -- The South is hopeful. Its economic atmosphere contrasts strangely with the drought-afflicted Northwest. Cotton crop prospects appear to be excellent and Arkansas reports the best crop outlook in many years.

LONDON, July 28. -- Operations today on the London Stock Market were generally dull, although British funds were firm, the exception resulting from further consideration of the hint of the Chancellor of the Exchequer that the worst of the taxation had been seen.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, July 28. -- Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair, has had a lengthy talk with President Eamon de Valera, in which the Free State's prospects of being represented at the fair were discussed.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 28. -- Mrs. Charles C. Griswold of New York gave a garden party this afternoon at Hillhome, Stockbridge, for eighty members of the Lenox Garden Club and their guests. The hostess was assisted by her daughters, by Mrs. James W. Sanders and by her sister, Mrs. Austin W. Ackroyd.

It is still daylight as the music lovers file in at the various entrances to the Lewisohn Stadium these evenings. Refugees from Fascist-ridden European countries, workers from the East Side and the Bronx, office clerks, students of music, important business men who find seats at tables in front of the podium, city officials, among them the Mayor -- it is just the heterogeneous, cosmopolitan crowd that New York always produces.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 (AP). -- A group of steel workers rejected today the offer of their employers to pay time-and-a-half for overtime work, a plan begun last week by the United States Steel Corporation, and joined by virtually all major units of the industry.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 29. -- With stand-by orders issued to the government military leaders in Hunan, Yunnan and Kweichow Provinces, it is understood that the Kwangsi Province leaders must announce obedience to the Central Government before Saturday or a large-scale punitive expedition will be launched against Generals Li Tsung-jen and Pai Chung-hsi.

LONDON, July 28. -- The House of Commons cheered today as the Financial Secretary to the Treasury, W.H. Morrison, announced that the sister ship of the Queen Mary would be built by John Brown Co. on the Clydebank.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. N. Y., July 28. -- The annual charge on Saratoga was in full sweep tonight as thousands poured into this quiet community by train, motor and other means of conveyance for the opening tomorrow of the month-long race meeting.
MARSEILLES, France, July 28. -- United States Vice Consul Longyear left here today by hydro-airplane for Palma, Majorca, to inquire into the status of Americans reported stranded there.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 29. -- Three thousand changes in the army list taking effect Aug. 1, represent the conclusion of the cleanup the army has been conducting since the February mutiny.
Awards to the Police Department pistol team that won the New England police team championship at Providence on July 17 were presented yesterday at headquarters by Commissioner Valentine.

Opening today at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street, the show of water-colors and of work by artists of the project's graphic school evinces still further evidence of the vitality of the work executed in this field of the WPA. Nearly a hundred artists are represented, and many of the names are pleasantly familiar to New York gallery-goers.

The informal opinion by the Interstate Commerce Commission, holding the six-cent fare on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad between Jersey City and New York is justifiable, will be challenged in a new proceeding requesting a public hearing on the question, it was announced yesterday by Joseph F.S. Fitzpatrick, Jersey City lawyer.

The Log Cabin Stud's Mr. Chips, which has been knocking at the door of victory for some time, finally came up a winning effort yesterday and sprang a surprise on the players and the layers alike by winning the Richmond Handicap, at a mile and seventy yards.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Salt water fishing gains in impetus whenever the bluefish are running. A fine fighting fish to be caught in the offshore waters of Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut, it has the added attribute of also being delectable to the taste.
An unequaled opportunity to popularize architecture, sculpture and painting will be afforded by the 1939 World's Fair, according to William Orr Ludlow, fellow of the American Institute of Architects.

BEATING the barrier by a few steps, Racing Secretary John B. Campbell was off to Saratoga before the horses finished running at Empire yesterday. But before he left he was caught in conference with his cheerful assistant, Francis P. Dunne. It was packing time around the office and Mr. Campbell had a bag of such imposing dimensions that Mr. Dunne said:

The directors of the Sperry Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share, payable on Aug. 20 to holders of voting trust certificates for common stock of record at the close of business on Aug. 10. On July 1, 1935, and Dec. 29, 1935, the corporation paid 25 cents.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Wright gave a dinner and bridge tonight at the Clovers, their home, to celebrate Mrs. Wright's birthday. Guests were Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw, Mr. and Mrs. John C. King, Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Coulter, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Wrenn and Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bourne Miller.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- A corn crop smaller than for any year since 1881 was predicted by Secretary Wallace today if recent high temperatures and general lack of precipitation prevail throughout the corn belt the next week or ten days.

Lightning struck and killed John F. McCleary, 20 years old, on his father's farm in Sewell, N.J., yesterday. McCleary, who was picking tomatoes in a field with two farm hands, looked up to watch an airplane battling the storm just as a bolt flashed down. The two farm hands were uninjured.

DETROIT, July 29. -- Before another large gathering at Navin Field today the Yankees again treated the Tigers to an exhibition of rough-riding as they buried Mickey Cochrane's staggering crew under a 13-to-3 landslide. A crowd of 13,000 fans saw the skirmish, bringing the attendance for the three games played thus far in this series to 42,000.

The New York Association for the Blind has sent, during the month of July, about 200 blind men, women and children to the vacation homes supported by the association. Here they receive a much needed respite from the heat and noise of the city, and at least 300 more greatly need this opportunity.

LONDON, July 29 (Canadian Press). -- Canadian veterans today heard the Prime Minister, Stanley Baldwin declare that if no better means than war could be found to settle disputes "the world deserves to perish."

CHICAGO, July 29. -- The grain markets soared upward again today on the broadest buying movement that has been seen in some time. When trading closed on the leading exchanger all deliveries of wheat in Duluth, Minneapolis, Kansas City, Liverpool, Rotterdam and Buenos Aires were in new ground for the season, while the distant futures of wheat in Winnipeg were at the highest figures on record.

The concert given at the Lewisohn Stadium last night by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Jose Iturbi, was the occasion of the New York debut of William Harms, young Kansan pianist, who came forward in the Liszt concerto in E flat.

A 35-year-old member of the rabbinate in England, who formerly was a supervisor of kosher food on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania and was, according to his own story, in line for that position on the Queen Mary, was sentenced yesterday to serve a year and a day in prison.

LONDON, July 29. -- The control of one of the most important British companies in foreign hands was repatriated today when Floyd Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, completed the sale of the holdings of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation in the Greater London and Counties Trust, Ltd., to Lazard Brothers for about $25,000,000.
CLEVELAND, July 29 (AP). -- The Indians walloped the Senators, 11 to 6, in the first game of a doubleheader today and came from behind in the seventh inning to take the nightcap, 6 to 5.

MADRID, July 29 (Passed by the Censor). -- The United States Embassy here said today no definite reply had been received from the Spanish Government to the request presented by the entire diplomatic corps for a special international train to Valencia for evacuating foreigners here.

According to our dispatches, Governor LANDON is on record as having approved, as recently as January, 1934, a work relief program centrally administered from Washington. In a letter written to the President at that time he warmly endorsed CWA, which was essentially similar to, and the direct forerunner of, the present WPA.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., July 29. -- Alumnae of Mount Holyoke College are formally advised of the election of Dr. Roswell Gray Ham to the presidency in an article by Alva Morrison, president of the board of trustees, appearing in the Mount Holyoke Alumnae Quarterly.

LONDON, July 29. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange today reflected a better feeling among traders, but the turnover remained somewhat restricted. British funds were advanced by the success of the Plymouth loan. French securities were dull in the foreign department.

The White Lady, or Vanishing Spectre of Yorkville, stuck her phantom fingers in her phantom ears in the Haunted House on East Eighty-sixth Street at midnight last night and shuddered in fear between the falling plaster in the crumbling walls of the house.

LONDON, July 29. -- The official report on the exhumation of Napoleon's body at St. Helena in 1840 and its transference to French authorities was bought by Maggs Co., dealers, today for 46 at an auction at Sothebys.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 29. -- Gaining a draw in a difficult test with E.D. Bogoljubow of Germany, the only conqueror of Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world champion, in the international chess tournament, Reuben Fine of New York was still in first place by a comfortable margin at the close of play in the ninth round tonight.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 29. -- The United States Consulate, under Acting Consul General Lynn W. Franklin, continues daily evacuations of Americans by British destroyers and otherwise. The consulate is also evacuating nationals of Cuba, Finland, Chile and Panama.

BOSTON, July 29. -- Arthur Black, special master, recommended to the Federal court today that $7,779,000 of $11,379,000 in outstanding bonds of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, now being liquidated, receive priority over $3,600,000 in bonds held by the Amoskeag Company, a holding concern.

An increase of 11.8 per cent in the amount of money spent in general magazine advertising during the first six months of 1936 will be shown in figures compiled by Printers' Ink, published today. In the 104 magazines checked, the advertising volume was $73,834,643 as compared with $66,028,161 for the corresponding period of last year, when 123 magazines were queried.

Officials of the Bronx Zoo, at a public hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen, urged approval of their request for a 1937 appropriation $139,592 greater than the 1936 allotment. Of this increase, they said, $130,000 was urgently needed for repairs to various buildings.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 29. -Miss Anna McDonough, 70 years of age, of 287 West Fourth Street, New York, died in the Greenwich Hospital last night as a result of injuries received from a fall shortly before down a flight of stairs in the home of Mrs. John Curry of Riverside, whom she was visiting.

The Association of Long Island Commuters announced yesterday that it was prepared to go to the courts to force the Long Island Railroad to make immediate refunds of excess fares collected from its passengers during the last two months.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29. -- Notables from many cities witnessed the inaugural of the racing season here this afternoon from clubhouse boxes.

LONDON, July 29. -- The British Government has opened a new credit of 10,000,000 to Russia. At the Board of Trade offices today an agreement was signed authorizing the British Treasury to guarantee bills issued for that sum by the Soviet trade delegation in London.

Mr. and Mrs. Andre de Coppet gave a bon voyage supper party last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Mrs. Daniel Haynes, who will sail Saturday on the Conte di Savoia. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Sanford, Mr. and Mrs. William John Warburton and Mr. Haynes.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 29. -- A distinguished turnout of society welcomed the return of racing to the beautiful Spa course today and the occasion was marked by the running of two famous stakes, the Flash, which had its sixty-second running, and the American Legion Handicap.

The Board of Elections was notified yesterday by Thomas B. Dyatt, Assistant District Attorney, that the New York County grand jury had indicted five Negro residents of Harlem for alleged forgeries of signatures of purported voters in the Democratic primaries of the Nineteenth Assembly District last April.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 29. -Johnny Farrell of Baltusrol, former national open golf champion, turned back the pages of time today. The genial professional paired with August F. Kammer Sr. to win the New Jersey State pro-amateur best-ball championship with a thirty-six-hole score of 134, ten under par.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- A drive to increase the number of Republican Senators in the next Congress was begun today with the opening of headquarters here of the party's Senatorial committee. Senator Townsend of Delaware and Senator Steiwer of Oregon, chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the committee, mapped a series of conferences in connection with States west of the Mississippi and with plans to aid in the fight against the New Deal.

The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday net assets as of June 30, of $45,301,026, after deducting the provision for normal Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation of investments, but without provision for any surtax on undistributed profits which may be chargeable for this year.

The advisory committee on control of silica dust in rock drilling, appointed last Week by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews, held its first meeting yesterday in the State Building, 80 Center Street.

William E. Dodd, United States Ambassador to Germany, sailed yesterday for his post in Berlin on the Washington of the United States Lines. He has been here since May 1 and for five weeks lectured on "Critical Moments in American History" at the University of Chicago Summer session.

The Board of Education proposed yesterday to transfer its main office from 500 Park Avenue, at Fifty-ninth Street, to the former clubhouse of Lodge 22, of the Elks, at Livingston Street and Boerum Place, Brooklyn.

The city of San Francisco, Calif., will be in the market on Aug. 3 with a new issue of $344,000 of Hetch-Hetchy water bonds, to mature from June 1, 1939 to 1971. Bidders have been asked to specify a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

BERLIN, July 29. -- The Olympics have failed to attract the number of foreign visitors expected. Tickets are pouring back here, with no sale, from all parts of the world. They are coming into local offices of travel agencies, however, rather than to the Olympic Organization Committee.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 29. -The plan of the Austrian Government to broadcast to Germany the Salzburg festival performances has run afoul of Arturo Toscanini. It has just leaked out from circles in close contact with the Italian conductor that Mr. Toscanini has threatened to leave Salzburg immediately, never to return, if any performance conducted by him is broadcast to Germany.

BERLIN, July 29. -- With a deep Olympian peace permeating the German scene and 67,000,000 Germans eager to play hosts to visitors from fifty-three nations, all things not immediately concerned with the eleventh Olympiad are officially declared taboo.

MADRID, July 29 (Passed by the Censor). -- The loyal destroyer Alsedo returned to Malaga today after bombing the rebel forts at Melilla in Spanish Morocco. It was slightly damaged by rebel shells, but it reported that it had brought down two rebel airplanes.

MOSCOW, July 29. -- The possibility of renewal of Soviet-Canadian relations was seen here yesterday as W.D. Euler, Canadian Minister of Trade and Commerce, departed with his party after several days' stay, during which he conferred with A.P. Rosengoltz, Foreign Trade Commissar; L.N. Rubinstein, representing the Amtorg, and other Soviet officials.

JERUSALEM, July 29. -- While the Jews in Palestine are not displeased by Colonial Minister Ormsby-Gore's statement in the House of Commons today concerning the terms of reference of the royal commission, the Arabs are keenly disappointed.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Allocation of $1,050,000 for surveys of seven flood control projects, from funds authorized by President Roosevelt on July 17 from the Relief Appropriation Act of 1936, was announced by the War Department today. An additional $150,000 will be retained by the Chief of Engineers for later allocation.

Buying of steel has gathered momentum sufficient to sustain production through August at approximately the present rate, 71 1/2 per cent of capacity, Iron Age states in its weekly summary, issued yesterday. The current rate, which is a half point higher than last week's, may be the peak of mid-summer production, the magazine states.

The attack on Governor Landon made by six Democratic Governors over the radio on Tuesday evening was replied to yesterday by Republican State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton. He declared that, "though the task assigned to them by Farley was to try and search out any weaknesses in the program of Governor Landon, they couldn't do it, they didn't do it, so Farley and Michelson will have to try it again."

Assailing Sterling Edmunds, St. Louis attorney, for his fight against the child labor amendment, Miss Mary W. Dewson, head of the women's division of the National Democratic Committee, issued yesterday a denunciation of his calling a conference of Constitutional Democrats at Detroit. In a press conference at the Hotel Biltmore she designated him as the central figure in the fight to keep minors at work.

About 400 WPA workers, employed on the Federal project for urban study of consumer purchases, with offices at 44 East Twenty-third Street, will go on strike tomorrow in protest against the order from the Labor Department in Washington, in charge of the project, to dismiss employes on Aug. 15.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 29. -- An art committee brought here by WPA authorities agreed today with the artistic judgment of village officials and rejected "on esthetic ground" the much-disputed model for a Spanish War memorial statue for Summerfield Park.

If Casey Stengel retired last night to dream of dozens of baseballs bouncing about his room, that phenomenon could be understood by every one of the 12,000 fans who watched the astonishing Flatbush athletes perform at Ebbets Field yesterday.

Holders of bonds of the Republic of El Salvador will receive today, as a result of their assenting to the debt-readjustment agreement, a payment of $850,000 to be applied to interest and sinking-fund requirements on the various issues. This is the largest single cash payment that has come out of Central or South America for bondholders since 1929.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 29. -While "hunger marchers" today retained possession of the Senate gallery, which they have occupied for more than a week, the Senate was informed at a fifteen-minute session today that a "substantial agreement" had been reached by the quarreling legislators on providing money to finance unemployment relief until Jan. 31.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 29. -- Five firemen were injured, a dozen more were overcome by smoke and property damage estimated at $100,000 was caused by a fire which wept three-quarters of the block bounded by the Boardwalk, National Boulevard, Broadway and Jackson Boulevard at 5 o'clock this morning.

TRENTON, N.J., July 29. -- The State Board of Tax Appeals dismissed today appeals by the Universal Insurance Company and the Universal Indemnity Insurance Company for reduction or cancellation of personal property taxes levied by the city of Newark.

PATERSON, N.J., July 29. -- A strike of small enterprise against the next higher level of business began here today when 175 small silk mills known as "family mills" signed an agreement and stopped work for the half dozen brokers or converters who supply them with the raw silk which they weave.
Governor Lehman will confer today with James A. Farley, National Democratic Chairman, on ways of carrying New York State for President Roosevelt and the State ticket.
CANNES, France, July 29. -- Juan, Prince of the Asturias, Spanish heir presumptive, has denied reports that he intends to go to Spain, according to well-informed sources here.

GRUNAU, Germany, July 29. -- Delighted with everything about lovely Grunau except its weather and their own doubtful condition, America's Olympic oarsmen, from single sculler, Dan Barrow of Philadelphia, to Washington's towering eight, settled down today to a program of two hard workouts daily.

Turning and dodging through the narrow paths of parliamentary procedure, Mayor La Guardia proved too wily yesterday for the members of the Board of Estimate who were trying to manoeuvre him into moving for consideration of the new City Charter at special election instead of at the general election in November.

MEXICO, D.F., July 29. -- Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina and his daughter, Frances, who had been house guests of United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels, an Edward Roesler of the brokerage firm of Laidlaw Co., New York City, were among about fifty travelers held up yesterday on the Cuernavaca road, eighty miles from this capital, by twenty-seven armed bandits.

John R. Hall, president of an industrial engineering company bearing his name, director of several large corporations and former banker, fell to his death between 2:45 and 3 P.M. yesterday from the courtyard window of his room on the sixteenth floor of the Hotel Roosevelt.

For the first time since he became Works Progress Administrator, Victor F. Ridder ordered yesterday the dismissal of a WPA employe for political activity. The incident was also the first of its kind in New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Sales of goods by both manufacturers and wholesalers rose substantially in June, compared with June of last year, according to a joint survey by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce and the National Association of Credit Men, made public today.

A suit said to affect sixty-four teachers was heard yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Rosenman yesterday in an action by Mrs. Clara R. Brahey to invalidate an order of the Board of Education removing her as a history teacher in junior high school.

LONDON, July 29. -- The determination of the British Government to do nothing to irritate Germany or give Chancellor Adolf Hitler a fresh excuse for ignoring the invitation to the Locarno conference, was manifested in the House of Commons today when Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden refused to use any harsh language about the refortification of Helgoland in violation of the Versailles Treaty.

Earnings and dividends of the United States Steel have been so generally accepted -- during its thirty-five years of corporate existence -- as reflecting the financial trend, that Monday's report for the June quarter and the increase of the preferred stock dividend may be regarded as signs of the times.

The Chrysler Corporation yesterday announced that it was distributing a bonus of $2,000,000 to its employes. All employes who were on the payroll in any part of the fourth quarter of last year will receive a minimum of $25, the statement said.

There is a great likelihood that the world's heavyweight championship bout between James J. Braddock and Max Schmeling, scheduled for the Long Island City Bowl in September, will be an afternoon fight. Joe Gould, Braddock's manager, and James J. Johnston, in charge of boxing at Madison Square Garden, yesterday agreed on Sept. 26 as the tentative date for the fight.

Faced with the possibility of disorganized conditions in the wholesale branch of the liquor industry, representatives of leading distilling organizations assured retailers here yesterday that they will maintain their present quotations throughout this territory under the terms of the State Fair Trade Act.

The first public financing for the Southern Kraft Corporation, a subsidiary of International Paper Company, will take place today with the offering of an issue of $14,500,000 of the corporation's first leasehold and general mortgage 4 1/4 per cent bonds, due in 1946, at a price of 98 1/2.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- A.C. Compton's Microbe, piloted by Jockey Nick Wall, scored in the featured six-furlong handicap event at Arlington Park today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 29. -- J.P. Morgan boarded his yacht Corsair, in Long Island Sound off his estate at East Island near here this evening for a trip to Europe. The ship lay at anchor late tonight waiting to sail with the outgoing tide.
There was much ado about nothing yesterday afternoon along the shores, upon the waters and in the air above the waters of Sheepshead Bay.

BLACKSBURG, Va., July 29 (AP). -Chester C. Davis, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System and former AAA Administrator, warned tonight of the danger he said threatened America "when a mad priest, an impractical dreamer and a political charlatan combine to inflame" the uninformed and the distressed.

Now that Mayor La Guardia is so strongly advocating Mr. Berle for the office of President of the Board of Aldermen, in opposition to the duly selected and accredited Republican candidate, Mr. Morris, let us look at Mr. Berle's record as Chamberlain.

Stock prices weakened yesterday under the weight of profit-taking and a little short-selling, with the net result that the decline was the widest of the month. Leading issues were down 1 to 3 points. The closing, however, was steady.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 29 (AP). -- Ed Lasater, with the veteran Sep Palin in the sulky, took two of the three heats in the National 3-Year-Old Stakes, a dress rehearsal for the Hambletonian, at the Grand Circuit races today.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29. -- The annual invitation golf tournament of the Newport Country Club will open tomorrow with a field of more than ninety entrants. T. Suffern Taller Jr., who was the winner last year for the fifth time when he defeated Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., 3 and 2, in the final round, is entered again.
MADRID, July 29. -- The republic ordered tonight a merciless purge of enemies within its government and Leftists guardedly admitted that the rebels menacing Madrid might be able to wage a long siege.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 29. -- A rain storm broke over Seabright this afternoon and, after a lull, another storm broke on the courts of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, to keep the largest crowd of the week milling in excitement over the best day of tennis provided here in years in the invitation tournament.

ESTES PARK, Col., July 29 (AP). -- Nancy Jo Landon was called from the party celebrating her fourth birthday by a long-distance telephone call today from her father, Governor Landon, Republican Presidential nominee, who was in Topeka, Kan.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Jacob Harris of 98 Darlington Road. Deal, N.J., complained today to the Interstate Commerce Commission that the fifteen-cent surcharge imposed by the Pennsylvania Railroad on passage from New Jersey to the Pennsylvania Station, New York City, was discrimination against persons coming from near-by New Jersey points and a violation of the Interstate Commerce Act.

JOHN ERSKINE, in his remarks the other day to Summer session students of Columbia and the Juilliard School of Music, was not the first to criticize much of our modern education for its merely passive quality. "The deeper "objection to culture, that is, to the "knowing of the best that has been "said," he declared, "is that it ex"cuses us all from living if we merely "contemplate the lives of other men."

Cardinal Manuel Gonsalves Cerejeira, Patriarch of Lisbon, and the Rev. Dr. Carneiro Mesquita are due to arrive today on the Conte di Savoia of the Italian Line. Others aboard are Prince and Princess Rodolfo del Drago, Nicholas Bucci, Mr. and Mrs. Standish Backus Jr. and Captain Guglielmo Maggini.

LISBON, Portugal, July 29 (AP). -- Radio broadcasts from Spanish rebel stations claimed tonight that the important cities of Huelva and Ayamonte had fallen into Fascist hands and that all of Galicia had been wrested from government forces.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- The White Sox, coming from behind with a six-hit attack and four runs in the seventh inning, defeated the Athletics, 7 to 5, today to go ahead in the current series, two games to one.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today an opinion by its general counsel, John J. Burns, that if a corporation declares a dividend payable either in cash or stock, it need not register under the Securities Act of 1933 the stock which shareholders accept in lieu of cash.

BERLIN, July 29 (AP). -- Count Henri de Baillet-Latour of Belgium, president of the International Olympic Committee, declared at the group's inaugural session today that politics and religion have been kept out of the Olympic Games.

MARSEILLES, France, July 29. -- Herbert W. Butler, an engineer of the General Motors Corporation's plant in Barcelona, Spain, tonight gave an account of how the company's property had been confiscated by the Catalan government.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval to issue $16,000,000 ten-year 4 per cent collateral notes to be dated Aug. 1 of this year and to mature Aug. 1, 1946, the proceeds to be used for meeting indebtedness, chiefly a note made to the RFC and now banker-owned.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- The cool weather desired by the Middle West for weeks prevailed generally today, but too late for acre after acre of its corn.

PITTSFIELD, Mass, July 29. -- Colonel E. Parmalee Prentice, sonin-law of John D. Rockefeller, celebrated his birthday today, an[ ill his honor Mrs. Prentice had a large luncheon party at Mount Iope Farm, Williamstown. The birthday cake had seventy-three candles.

Plans for construction in the city filed by architects yesterday included a few alteration projects in Manhattan and several new frame dwellings in Queens. Operations in the latter borough also included plans for a church rectory and a small garage.

LONDON, July 29. -- William G.A. Ormsby-Gore, Colonial Secretary, announced in the House of Commons today the appointment of a Palestine royal commission under the chairmanship of Earl Peel, with Sir Horace Rumbold as vice chairman.

Commodity futures markets here were mixed in quiet trading yesterday. Sugar futures were under pressure and sold at new low levels for the movement. In the cash market, all the grains, lard, tin and silk were higher, while cotton and rubber were lower.
ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP). -- The Browns climbed back into seventh place today by defeating the Red Sox, 9 to 3, as the White Sox won from the Athletics.

The sidewalk bar is another tribute to New York enterprise and American ingenuity. Drunks may be thrown into a taxicab with greater convenience. As a matter of fact, the "Stag at Eve" may "drink his fill" and fall from the sidewalk bar into a waiting taxi.

IF the Department of Agriculture is interested, Scientist Floyd Caves Herman of the Cincinnati Reds wishes to report that Japanese beetles are swarming in the outfield of the Philadelphia National League ball park. Babe has been to Japan and says he could not possibly be mistaken in his identification of these insects.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- Henry C. Steneck, president of the defunct Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, was ordered tonight by Vice Chancellor J.O. Bigelow to pay $40,000 to six investors in guaranteed mortgage certificates, issued by the mortgage department of the trust company.

BERLIN, July 29. -- Prices on the Boerse were irregular today, but the general trend was downward except in the heavy industrials, which improved near the close, Vereinigtestahl rising nearly 2 points and Rhenish Steel, Mannesmann, Harpener and Kloeckner about 2 1/2 points each.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 29. -- Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Fabyan, Miss Carolin Babcock, Mrs. Marjorie Van Ryn, Mrs. Mary Greef Harris, Mrs. Dorothy Andrus, Mrs. Sylvia Herotin, Miss Jean Burritt, Miss Catherine Wolf and Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson are among the thirty noted tennis players to arrive here on Monday to take part in the annual Women's Invitation Tennis Tournament at the Maidstone Club.

Several leases for expansion were included in the business rentals reported yesterday. The Glassoloid Company, maker of pictures, frames and display advertising novelties, took a floor of more than 25,000 square feet in 511-19 East Seventy-second Street, the space being 5,000 square feet larger than the firm's present quarters.

The Magazine of Wall Street and Mr. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican campaign committee, ask who are the "economic royalists" and "princes of privilege" alluded to by President Roosevelt. A glance at the reports of the Federal Trade Commission supplies a partial answer to the question.

BIG BAY, Mich., July 29. -- Following a custom he established a few years ago, Henry Ford will observe his birthday tomorrow at his lodge in the Huron Mountain Club acres, west and north of here on the rugged Lake Superior coast.

The copper producing companies outside of the United States which are operating under the restriction plan entered into about two years ago announced yesterday in London that, effective on Aug. 1, they would reduce their curtailment program to 25 per cent from 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The prospects of Americans and other foreigners for leaving Madrid were surrounded with uncertainty today because the Spanish Government had not given assurances of safe passage, the State Department was informed by Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the United States Embassy there.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 23 per cent for the week ended July 25, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase, reflecting the continued sharp increase in local retail trade, compares with a rise of 20 per cent for the preceding week.

Under the heaviest liquidation of the month, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke more than $1 a bale yesterday and ended at the bottom with net losses of 21 to 26 points. Tuesday's surprisingly large estimate unsettled sentiment in view of the excellent crop accounts coming from various parts of the Cotton Belt and many foreign and domestic holders seemed disposed to even-up obligations in advance of the August government report.

MONTREAL, July 29. -- Although today's announcement by the American Newspaper Publishers Association that the price of English-manufactured newsprint had been fixed for the next two years at 10 a long ton caused great interest in Canadian newsprint circles, it was declared that it had no important implication in the Canadian newsprint industry.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 29. -- Two Asheville detectives were sent today to Washington to check up on information regarding the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger, 18-year-old New York University co-ed, who was beaten and shot in her hotel room here.

The Sinking Fund Commission voted yesterday to suspend operation of the Astoria Ferry to Ninety-second Street, Manhattan, on Saturday, thus putting a quiet end to a controversy which assumed serious proportions last week between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and F.J.H Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures.

BERLIN, July 29. -- The independent Protestant leaders in Germany have failed in a move to bring home to foreign guests during the Olympic Games the truth about Christianity's plight in Germany as they see it.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

A disquisition on the risks in golf as played by the average player, on the stance of Willie Park and of famous old Tom Morris, who drove a ball "like an old woman mowing hay," was printed on the editorial page of The New York Law Journal yesterday.
