Bright prospects for the ending of all city pay cuts next year developed yesterday when the Board of Estimate designated Mayor La Guardia and Controller Frank J. Taylor to act as a committee to negotiate for a reduction of the $20,000,000 reserve in the 1937 budget.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Fifteen lake seamen, including Captain Charles D. Brown of Port Huron, Mich., perished early today when the 1,070-ton gravel ship Material Service suddenly heeled to port and plunged to the bottom of Lake Michigan a quarter of a mile outside the South Chicago breakwater.

Senator VANDENBERG, who probably could have had the Republican Presidential nomination this year if he had decided earlier that it was worth seeking, displayed during his visit to Mr. LANDON at Topeka a certain confusion natural in the circumstances. He found the campaign "distinctive in that it has a number of major issues," and then proceeded to enumerate a series of group discontents instead.

Earnings of the American Commercial Alcohol Corporation for the six months ended on June 30 were the largest in the history of the company, according to the semi-annual statement to be made public today by Russell R. Brown, president.

VIENNA, July 29. -- Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg reaped tonight the first fruit of the Austro-German peace pact in the form of the biggest Nazi demonstration ever seen in this capital. The demonstration was staged as the Olympic torch was carried through Vienna.
The traveler returned from the land of pines, seeking to recapture its mood, finds his mind is a blur of contrasting impressions.

Representative JOSH LEE has beaten Governor MARLAND in the run-off primary for the Democratic nomination for Senator by more than 100,000 votes. The result was indicated by his long lead over the Governor in the regular primary. He worked his way through the University of Oklahoma, served as a private in the war, became head of the department of elocution at the university, got a M.A. in political science at Columbia.
The resignation of Edward A. Haggenmuller as sales manager of the rug division of the Artloom Corporation was announced yesterday by C.S. Newton, president.

Conflicting price trends marked fairly active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. While high-grade issues maintained a steady to firm undertone, outside influences were reflected in the price fluctuations among the more sensitive corporate bonds.

The New York County grand jury is expected to hand up an indictment before Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions today in its investigation of fake accident claims, recently opened at the request of the Appellate Division and the Bar Association.

PARIS, July 29. -- Marcel Rochas has opened the Winter fashion campaign by shortening skirts for all hours. He would have little girls wear shirt waist dresses of lame or metal gauze with pleated skirts just below the knees and tailored long coats or jackets for even formal evenings.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Four parades of Republican workers, in which it is estimated that 8,000 persons will participate, will converge tonight on the Chicago Stadium from all wards of the city as a feature of the ceremony of notifying Colonel Frank Knox of his nomination for the Vice Presidency by the Republican National Convention.
LONDON, July 29. -- The award of contracts for two new British battleships was announced today in the House of Commons by Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The troubles of the Rio Grande Oil Company and its absorption by the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation featured today's investigation of the affairs of the Interstate Equities Corporation of New York by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

DEAL, N.J., July 29. -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont added an 81 today to her first two rounds of 78 and 80 to win the New Jersey Shore fifty-four-hole golf medal-play tournament with a total of 239 strokes. This equals the tournament record, set by Miss Charlotte Glutting last year.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 29. -- (AP). -- Moving rapidly northward through the Gulf of Mexico, a tropical storm with two deaths charged against it neared the extreme western coast of Florida tonight.

FORT NIAGARA, N.Y., July 29. -- Colonel Hiram M. Cooper, commander of this old army post, declared that there was a possibility that this country might be involved in a war within two or three years, as he bade farewell to the officers of the 307th Infantry, Organized Reserves.

The city was served yesterday with papers in a suit to restrain it from submitting the three-platoon system for the Fire Department to a referendum at the November election. The suit, started as a taxpayer's action by William Church Osborn, who is head of the Citizens Budget Commission, will be filed in the County Clerk's office today and a hearing is scheduled for tomorrow in Special Term, Part I, of the Supreme Court.

Comment on the Canadian war memorial on Vimy Ridge naturally deals with a poignant contrast. There was the ideal of a sane and fraternal world for which the Canadians paid such a huge price at Vimy, and there is the look of the world today.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The Central Vermont Public Service Corporation of Rutland, Vt., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $7,300,000 of first-mortgage bonds, Series B, due on Aug. 1, 1966, on which the interest rate, price to the public, underwriters and underwriting discounts or commissions are to be furnished by amendment.

Twenty-three thousand dollars worth of stolen bonds and certificates, including $10,000 in industrial securities taken by the late John Dillinger's gang in Racine, Wis., in 1933, have been recovered, the police announced here yesterday, with the arrest of Albert Montlake, 45 years old, a New York pickpocket.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP). -- The Pirates battered three of the Bees' pitchers for seven runs in the seventh inning to win the second game of a double-header, 10 to 4, today, after losing the first game, 4 to 1.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- Scoring seven runs with two out in the second inning, Newark made it three in a row over Buffalo today. The score was 8 to 5 and the victory enabled the Bears to create a virtual tie for second place.

On the Chicago bench, watching the Giants take batting practice yesterday at the Polo Grounds, Charley Grimm, manager of the pace-setting Cubs, advanced the thought that the Terrymen should not be counted out of the National League pennant race.

Following his recent purchase of various parcels at the northeast corner of Eleventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street for improvement with a one-story garage building, the buyer, an investing client of Isidore Ehrman, attorney, extended his holdings at that point yesterday by purchasing 708 and 710 Eleventh Avenue from the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

STERLING, Ill., July 29. -- The violent three-week-old strike at the Northwestern Barb Wire Company, the first in the nation-wide drive to unionize the steel industry, was ended today by agreement, according to Robert Pilkington, Federal arbitrator.

GIBRALTAR, July 29. -- After warning British ships to keep well clear of Spanish Government warships to avoid being hit by his aircraft, General Francisco Franco, rebel commander-in-chief, made a determined effort today to clear the Straits of Gibraltar of all warships interfering with the free passage of his Moroccan troops to the southwest coast of Spain.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 (AP). -Counsel for Mary Astor declared tonight that he would put the movie star on the witness stand to dispute accusations made by her divorced husband that she was morally unfit to care for their 4-year-old daughter.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., July 29. -- A long-range program for development of hydro-electric power through cooperation of the United States and Canada was given by President Roosevelt today as a principal topic of the conversations which he will hold at Quebec Friday with Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, and Prime Minister King.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the State Department had received no confirmation of reports of seizures of American property in Spain.

Because of the city government's failure to effect any reform in county offices thus far this year, as provided for in the amendment to the State Constitution adopted last November by a 3-to-1 vote, candidates for the office of Sheriff of Richmond County will be selected as usual at meetings tonight of the Republican and Democratic County Committees.

The Crescent Theatre at Niantic, Conn., closed its season on Saturday evening, canceling the production of "Mary, Mary, Quite Contrary," which was scheduled for this week with Blanche Yurka in the leading role. . . . "Cousin Adelaide Is Psychic," a new comedy by David Woodbury, will be tested next week, beginning Tuesday evening, at the Mary Young Theatre, Centerville, Mass. . . .

RKO Radio's picturization of Maxwell Anderson's "Mary of Scotland" will have its premiere today at the Radio City Music Hall. The film was directed by John Ford and adapted to the screen by Dudley Nichols, the same director-writer combination that turned out "The Informer" last year.

BERLIN, July 29 (AP). -- Ray Clemons of Duke, Okla., despite losing the last of four tryout tests by a narrow margin to Charles McDaniel of Bloomington, Ind., today was named Uncle Sam's standard bearer in the Olympic light-heavyweight wrestling competition.

A banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., and including Kuhn, Loeb Co., Edward B. Smith Co., and others, will offer to the public today a new issue of $29,500,000 of refunding and improvement-mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series E, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company.
Many of the cooperative organizations in this country established new sales records in the first six months of 1936, according to a report listed yesterday by the Cooperative League.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The announcement by Sir Samuel Hoare that Britain would lay the keels for two new battleships early next year drew from the Acting Secretary of the Navy, Admiral William H. Standley, today the comment that "actual laying of the keels won't concern us until next Jan. 1."

BERLIN, July 29. -- Joe Church, featherweight, and Howell King, welterweight, each the No. 1 candidate in his division on the American Olympic boxing team, were aboard the United States liner Manhattan, which sailed for New York today, the Olympic competition finished in so far as they are concerned.
With the aid of a constable and several attendants, Judge Morris Umansky remained yesterday de facto judge of the First District Court in Union City, N.J.
The fight for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, which has become to be desired more keenly in the past few months, began to take more definite shape yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP). -- A reorganization plan was filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company.
ROME, July 29 (AP). -- Not an official word in Italy marked the fifty-third birthday today of Premier Mussolini, protagonist of youth.
SOLOMON'S ISLAND, Md., July 29. -- A fishing launch carrying Senator Vic Donahey of Ohio and a party of friends was struck by lightning near here today.
TOPEKA, July 29. -- Governor Landon was told today by two New York Republicans that he would win the all-important forty-seven electoral votes of New York State.
An increase in apartment rentals, many of them to begin next Oct. 1, was reported yesterday. The lessees included the following:

TRENTON, July 29. -- Governor Hoffman said today that he would hold a public hearing on New York State's requisitions for the extradition of Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives, and Ellis H. Parker Jr., who are under indictment in Brooklyn on charges of kidnapping Paul H. Wendel.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- Prices of hogs soared 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight here today, with packing sows in the lead, the practical top of $11.30, being 10 cents above Tuesday and 95 cents above the low of two weeks ago. Small lots sold at $11.35. Today's top quotation was the highest since September, 1935.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows:

The news of the seizure of United States properties in Spain was one of the factors in yesterday's stock marrket decline. Information concerning the nature of the seizure was so sketchy as to make it difficult for one company, the General Motors Corporation, to decide whether to make a protest to the State Department.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 29. -- Serious legal difficulties have again arisen between the government and the Chilean Electric Light and Power Company, which is controlled by the Electric Bond and Share Company through the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc.

The extremists, uncompromisingly anti-clerical and anti-capitalist, are tightening their hold on the Spanish Government. The decrees reported yesterday, affecting the religious teaching orders and private industry, are unmistakable signs that the Cabinet, either under pressure or by design, is putting into practice more doctrines selected from the programs of its most radical supporters.
Sweeping relentlessly on, the Giants bowled over the Cubs for the second successive afternoon at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and great is the consternation in the National League this morning.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 30. -- Sidney B. Wood Jr. and the defending trophy holder, Gregory Mangin, fifth and sixth, respectively, in the national ranking, both went down in defeat today and for the first time in memory two unseeded players came through to the final of the invitation tennis tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

The number of passports issued through the New York Passport Bureau of the State Department in the fiscal year 1935-36 was approximately 10 per cent higher than in 1934-35, Ira F. Hoyt, chief agent in charge of the bureau at the Sub-treasury Building in Wall Street, said yesterday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30. -- Henry Eugene Williamson will make his last run as a motorman on the main line of the Long Island Railroad tomorrow. When he pulls into Hempstead Station from Brooklyn at 6:04 P.M. he will have ended fifty years of service with the railroad.

Stock prices recovered irregularly yesterday but not to the extent that the Wednesday losses were retrieved. Buying was highly selective in character, but in the main the tone was steady, with some disposition on the part of traders to regard the setback of the day before in the light of a necessary "corrective" after the several weeks of steadily advancing prices.

Your editorial of July 23 under the title "A Quick Change" is unlike the usual moderation and reasonableness with which your editorials deal with current subjects. Accordingly, I am surprised that you should print an editorial which would come more typically from the pen of Charles Michelson.

No one can say how soon the pomp and the glory will depart from Manhattan, but the Board of Education may move almost any day. The shift will be in the general direction followed by the changing center of gravity in New York City.

LONDON, July 30. -- Another link in the rearmament chain that is being rapidly forged in Great Britain is the creation of a new volunteer reserve for the Royal Air Force, Viscount Swinton, Air Minister, announced in the House of Lords today.
Cracksmen, wielding sledge hammers and chisels, cracked three small safes in the loft building at 202 Canal Street some time early yesterday and got about $200 in petty cash.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 30. -- Eighteen boys in Middle Western and Southern States, selected for ability and character from more than three hundred high school and private school graduates, have received prize fellowships to enter Harvard College this Fall.

Retail store locations in Manhattan, the Bronx and outlying sections of the metropolitan area were leased in large numbers yesterday. The shop rentals formed part of a large volume of business space renting reported by brokers and renting agents.
PARIS, July 30 (AP). -- Two men who tried to dispose of securities stolen in the $1,507,938 theft from the Bank of Manhattan in 1935 were convicted today in police court of receiving stolen goods.

Republican leaders in New York State last night hailed the acceptance speech of Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, as a forceful indictment of the New Deal, and declared that the speech illustrated the excellent team-work between Colonel Knox and Governor Landon.
It was a Brooklyn citizen who came up demanding justice for Manager Casey Stengel, the Pagliaccio of the ball parks. He was allowed to plead his case and took off in full flight as follows:

Governor Lehman conferred yesterday with James A. Farley and after they had decided upon Sept. 28 and 29 as the dates for the Democratic State convention, the National Democratic Chairman revealed that the State and national campaigns would be launched tomorrow, weeks in advance of the usual time.

Thirty representatives of dispossessed families of Sunnyside, Queens, brought their protest against dispossession by the mortgage holder on their homes yesterday afternoon to the central office of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, at Thirty-second Street and Seventh Avenue.

Governor Lehman has declined to take any part in the movement headed by former License Commissioner Sidney S. Levine to block the nomination of Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens as Democratic candidate for Aldermanic President, it was disclosed yesterday.

Directors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company declared yesterday the usual extra dividend of 25 cents on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly dividends of $1.50 on common and $1.75 on the first preferred stock.

More than 800 teachers and school administrators attending the Columbia Summer session from all sections of the country listened to educators from Harvard, New York University, Columbia and the public schools of this city and Philadelphia join in criticizing Teachers' Oath Laws and in urging unionization of all teachers at a meeting last night sponsored by the Columbia chapter of the Teachers Union.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 30. -- John D. Rockefeller complained today about smoke from the town dump near his estate, but the township committee decided tonight it would not do anything about it.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 30. -- Pennsylvania's relief deadlock, caused by the thirteen-week battle between the Republican Senate majority and the Democratic-controlled House, was broken late today as an agreement was reached on a plan to provide $45,000,000 for unemployment aid and $5,500,000 for social security, flood control and other needs of the State administration.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Application for a code of fair competition for the petroleum industry has been filed with the Federal Trade Commission and experts have been set to work to determine how many of the trade practice rules sought by the off marketers may be granted within the letter and spirit of the anti-trust and other laws.

Although the drought in upper New York State may reduce milk production, the current advertising campaign will be carried on without change. Because of the reduction in the appropriation from $400,000 to $250,000 the drive will run for only five months instead of eight.

The complete elimination of five practices which occasionally have been employed in the primary cotton textile markets were recommended to members of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York yesterday, in order to assure the industry's full compliance with the provisions of the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination law.

Eleven fortune tellers, half of them clad in the colorful peasant costumes of Romany, met yesterday morning on a Hudson River excursion steamer to discuss ways and means of having Governor Lehman legalize their profession. Brokers and investment people who "predict'' stock quotations inspired them to seek redress.

Things often turn out well even for the most reckless speculator -- provided the market goes up. In that event luck passes for wisdom. Our own Government and the Canadian Government, with their ill-advised ventures in cotton and wheat, are now being bailed out of those ventures by a rising tide of recovery and a totally unforeseen drought.

Although Sept. 26 was tentatively agreed upon as the date when James J. Braddock would defend his heavyweight title against Max Schmeling in the Madison Square Garden Bowl, the fight will be held on the night of Sept. 24, it was learned yesterday.

TOPEKA, July 30. -- Governor Landon made public today a letter to Norman Thomas, Socialist nominee for President, in which the Governor amplified the declaration of his labor policy made in his acceptance speech by saying that the right of labor to organize necessarily included the right of a labor union to promote by lawful and proper means the organization of an unorganized industry, with the right to send in an organizer.

HENDAYE, France, July 30. -- The Spanish rebel radio station at Seville, in a broadcast heard here tonight, declared the Madrid government had asked General Francisco Franco, the rebel commander-inchief, for a truce to negotiate for the surrender of Madrid.

The Philadelphia Ballet Company last night made its New York debut at the Lewisohn Stadium before an audience which showed sufficient advance interest in the event to bring its numbers up to the neighborhood of 10,000. The program consisted of two ballets, both with music by Maurice Ravel.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Whether it is more important to have soap and towels for school children or additional truant officers was the question raised by one of a score of critics of the 1937 budget of the Board of Education at a public hearing last night in the hall of the board.

ALMOST all the adjectives of praise ought to be trotted out for Walter D. Edmonds's "Drums Along the Mohawk" (Little, Brown, $2.50). It seems to me to be the best work of its kind we have -- and "of its kind" means something in American literature. Cooper, Simms, Bird, Mrs. Child, Miss Sedgwick and Paulding, to mention no others, have written upon the same general subject; the first two won immortality therewith.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 30. -- With the adjourned games postponed until tomorrow, the tenth and semi-final round of the international chess masters tournament at the Grand Hotel was put on the schedule for today and by tonight all six games had been decided.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Following is the text of a special crop report of the Agriculture Department outlining in brief the drought conditions in all parts of the country:
Following the great feast of base hits which they enjoyed in the first game of Wednesday's double-header, the Dodgers yesterday suffered the worst famine of the campaign.

ST. ANDREWS, N. B., July 30. --President Roosevelt left here on a special train tonight for Quebec to pay a state visit to the Governor General of Canada and hold conversations with Canadian officials on topics of mutual interest, including cooperative efforts to develop hydro-electric power.

NEWARK, N.J., July 30. -- Declaring that an industrial organizer had a "perfect right" to carry on his work in a city where a strike was being conducted, Federal Judge William Clark today ordered the bail of Powers Hapgood, an organizer for the Committee for Industrial Organization, who was held on a charge of rioting in connection with the recent RCA strike in Camden, reduced from $5,000 to $100.

A unanimous opinion of the Special Sessions Court in Jamaica, Queens, handed down yesterday afternoon by Justice Nathan P. Perlman, held that "chance, not skill" was the controlling factor in the Grand National Treasure Hunt. The opinion, concurred in by Justices Lawrence T. Gresser and Bernard A. Kozicke, declared that judicial approval of the treasure hunt "would cause a flood of other projects sponsored by persons whose motives are not so good."

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- Work-relief officials said today that at the present rate of expenditure the $1,425,000,000 voted at the last session of Congress would last out virtually all of the present fiscal year, which ends June 30, 1937.

Price movements were mixed in active trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar, coffee, tallow, cottonseed oil, silk and wooltops were stronger and other staples easier. On the cash markets all the grains, cotton, dairy products and lard advanced, while tin and rubber declined.

The steel industry has encouraging prospects for the near future, Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday in issuing the report for the second quarter of the year. Orders received this month have been more than sufficient to support the present rate of operations, 67 per cent of capacity, he continued, while unfinished orders, amounting to $89,561,632 on June 30, were the largest in several years.
PENSACOLA, Fla., July 30 (AP). -- Hurricane warnings blinked through rain squalls along the Western Florida and Eastern Alabama coast tonight.

While jobbers continued to place some fair-sized orders in the primary dry goods market during the week, the volume was considerably below that of the recent most active weeks. Their sales to retailers, however, have been so heavy that many jobbers expect to return to the market earlier in August than they had previously planned.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- A new rule was adopted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission on registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933, providing that if any person who has not personally signed a registration statement and is named in one as being, or about to become, a director or partner, his written consent to the use of his name must be filed with the registration statement.

PARIS, July 30. -- The congress of the International Confederation of Business and Professional Women reached a climax tonight with a 15-minute address by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, and an unscheduled French suffragettes' demonstration which threw the gathering into temporary turmoil.

W.W. McLellan received $34,750 as president of McLellan Stores Company for the thirteen months ended Jan. 31 last, according to data filed by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and made public yesterday by the Stock Exchange.

DETROIT, July 30. -- Myril Hoag, Yankee outfielder, was operated on for a blood clot on the brain tonight at the Harper Hospital. Dr. Fred Schreiber performed the operation, which consisted of the puncturing of the skull in three places to relieve pressure.

Edward J. King, broker, who died last Oct. 11, left an estate appraised yesterday at $3,228,081 gross and $3,110,901 net. He designated Mount Sinai Hospital as one of fourteen charities sharing in the estate. As residuary legatee the hospital gets a bequest appraised at $902,369.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 30. -- After a day of strange golf in the opening round of the New Jersey State open championship at the Crestmont Golf Club, four players were tied for the lead with par scores of 72 and four others were in second place only a stroke behind.

Class I railroads had more new freight cars on order on July 1 than correspondingly in any other year since 1929, according to the Association of American Railroads. The orders on July 1 were for 28,089 cars, compared with 2,428 on July 1, 1935, and 17,813 on July 1, 1934.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- Mrs. Marian Firth Geer gave a reception this afternoon at Redbrook, her home in Nyack Road, for her sister, Mrs. William Bernard Littell of Morristown, N.J., who has joined her for a visit, and for Mrs. Walden Pell, who motored over from Mistletoe Way, her home in Cedarhurst, L.I., for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Spanish Government has refused to guarantee safe passage for Americans and other foreigners in Madrid to Alicante and Valencia for evacuation on ships. As a result those who wish to leave will have take their chances in special coaches on regular trains.

The two twelve-story apartment houses occupying the block front on the west side of Avenue A, from Third to Fourth Street, were bought in at foreclosure auction yesterday by Louis Shulsky, plaintiff in the action against the 55 Avenue A Corporation and others.

Several witnesses were examined yesterday by counsel for the Federal Trade Commission in its case against a group of liquor companies in this area, whose use of the term "distiller" is considered "unfair competition."

DETROIT, July 30 (AP). -- Robert Penland, a steel factory worker, denied from the witness stand today that he had been flogged by the Black Legion for failure to attend meetings regularly, but admitted that he had been escorted to an Oakland County field with what "felt like a gun at my back," and "warned" to be on hand at future sessions.

CONNEAUT, Ohio, July 30. -- Two towering waterspouts, lashing wildly from side to side, raced shoreward from Lake Erie today, caused slight property damage and endangered many of Conneaut's 10,000 citizens.

BERKANE, French Morocco, July 30. -- Two of the latest type of Savoia Marchetti bombing planes, piloted and manned by Italian officers and soldiers, were forced down near here today by engine trouble.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., July 30. -- Hundreds of spectators surrounded the speakers' stand and the C.M.T.C. provisional regiment of 1,250 candidates was drawn up on the main parade ground as this year's Citizens Military Training Camp was officially closed this morning with a regimental review by Lieut. Col. Elley P. Denson, post commander, addresses by the commanding officer and State Senator Benjamin Feinberg of Plattsburg, and the awarding of medals and trophies for proficiency.

A hit-and-run driver, who, according to the police, had his license revoked in June when he was arrested for driving while intoxicated, was captured last night after a two-mile chase down the Harlem River Speedway as he was fleeing from the scene of an automobile accident at the entrance to the speedway, Nagle Avenue and Dyckman Street.
TOPEKA, July 30. -- The text of the letter written by Governor Landon to Norman Thomas was as follows:

SHANGHAI, July 30. -- If Generals Li Tung-jen and Pai Chung-hsi carry out their reported intention of establishing an independent government in Kwangsi Province on Saturday, the central government is expected to institute a tight blockade of all the province's borders, preventing entrance of foods, war supplies, salt and all other necessities.
LONDON, July 30 (AP). -- Reports received here from Spanish rebel sources in the last twenty-four hours indicated today that the insurrectionists were gaining ground.

MADRID, July 30. (Passed by the censor) -- The government decreed today the confiscation of the entire Spanish merchant marine, which includes lines operating between Spanish and North American and South American ports. The ships will be placed at the disposal of the navy for the duration of the revolt.
ST. LOUIS, July 30 (AP). -- Wes Ferrell allowed one less hit than Al Thomas today, but lost control in the eighth long enough for the Browns to defeat the Red Sox, 4 to 3.
BIG BAY, Mich., July 30 (AP). -- In the seclusion of a many-roomed "cottage" in the woods of Huron Mountain, on Lake Superior, Henry Ford noted that today was his seventy-third birthday anniversary.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 30. -- The Toronto Argonauts piled up a total of 31 points, as the Royal Canadian Henley regatta opened today, to take the lead over the West Side Club of Buffalo. The Americans collected 22 points on an 8-3-1 basis.

VIENNA, July 30. -- As a resut of the pro-Nazi demonstration here last night in connection with the passage of the Olympic torch, the government has canceled the administrative amnesty promised for the end of the month.

BERLIN, July 30. -- Ernest Lee Jahncke of New Orleans, the lone American member of the International Olympic Committee to oppose the staging of the coming games in Germany, was ousted from that body today and his place taken by Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee and president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States as well.

LONDON, July 30. -- In the opinion of persons familiar with conditions in Morocco, the ending of the rebellion in Spain either way will not solve the diplomatic tangle or curb the native forces let loose around Tangier.

Although Knickerbocker Village has been exempted from taxes by both the Board of Estimate and the State Housing Board, the City of New York informed Supreme Court Justice Rosenman yesterday that it intends to try to collect taxes on the ground that the buildings are not being used for the purposes described in the State Housing Law, and therefore are not exempt.

The Republicans could ask for nothing better than the poll of every registered voter in Maryland which The Baltimore Sun and The Evening Sun are preparing to take. There the New Deal and the President have been under heavy fire in the press. The senior Senator, Mr. Tydings, though supporting Mr. Roosevelt for re-election, has been a vigorous critic of the administration.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP). -- Keeping nine hits well scattered, Vernon Kennedy, ace White Sox right-hander, defeated the Athletics, 7 -- 4, today for his tenth consecutive victory and his fourteenth triumph of the season. One of the hits was Bob Johnson's sixteenth homer.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Wholesale prices advanced fractionally in the week ended on July 25, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100 rose to 80.2 from 80.1 the week before, and with 79.2 on July 27, 1935.

MADRID, July 30 (Passed by Censor). -- The exodus of Americans from Madrid continues. Sixty United States citizens and ninety British subjects took advantage of extra coaches added to the regular train at 10 o'clock this morning for Valencia.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (AP). -- The Reds and Phillies divided a double-header today, the visitors winning the first, 5 -- 0, while the Phils snared the second, 5 -- 4.

Earnings and the volume of purchases of the Commercial Credit Company for the first half of this year were the largest for any six-month period in the company's history, according to the concern's semi-annual statement.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a campaign in cooperation with Canadian authorities to check the sale from the Dominion into the United States of securities in violation of the Securities Act of 1933.

ST. JEAN DE LUZ, France, July 30. -- Just a ten-minute stroll from this colorful little Basque fishing village and seaside resort will land you in Spain. But a ten-minute stroll from here may also land you in a ditch in Spain, a dead stroller.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The high cost of syndicate participations during the peak of the depression stood out in today's investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the ups and downs of the Interstate Equities Corporation sponsored and financed by the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation.
Leaves from a Maine vacationist's notebook.

Mayor La Guardia is asking an appropriation $87 smaller than he received in the 1936 budget for running his own office in 1937. At a hearing yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen it was disclosed that the Mayor wants $104,625 for 1937, compared with $104,712 in 1936.

PARIS, July 30. -- Creed revealed today a stunning collection which features a completely tailored modern version of the costumes of eighteenth-century beaux. Suits with flaring tailcoats are worn with long waistcoats of brocade, striped tie-silk or velvet, with jeweled buttons.

Having had experience as President of the United States Civil Service Commission for one year, during the first of President Harding's administration, and also having had the experience of serving as First Assistant Postmaster General for more than seven years during the administrations of Presidents Harding, Coolidge, and a short time under President Hoover, I am impelled to write you briefly concerning what I have observed here in Washington during the administration of President Roosevelt.
SEA GIRT, N.J., July 30. -- Commenting on the Haber-Umansky controversy at his Summer quarters here today, Governor Hoffman said: "It is a very funny situation".
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

ROBBINSVILLE, N.C., July 30. -- A virgin forest in the Blue Ridge Mountains near here was dedicated today with simple but impressive ceremonies to the memory of the soldier-poet, Joyce Kilmer, who was killed in action on July 30, eighteen years ago.

A battered old sedan was sacrificed yesterday to test the efficiency of the fire-fighting equipment of the Holland Tunnel. The fire drill, shortly after 2 P.M. in an empty lot at Thirteenth and Provost Streets, Jersey City, near the entrance to the tunnel, lasted about four minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Payments by the Secretary of Agriculture under the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act constitute taxable income to the recipients for Federal income tax purposes, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.

Bank clearings of the nation's twenty-two leading cities in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $4,637,981,000, against $4,779,242,000 in the corresponding time last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- Starting in where he left off a year ago, Gene Homans, former Walker Cup star, set the pace for a field of eighty-four competitors in the annual invitation tournament of the National Golf Links of America today.
PARIS, July 30 (AP). -- Rebel fliers today were reported organized into a "Battalion of Death."

The first accounting of a trust fund of $5,000,000 created by Andrew Carnegie on April 19, 1911, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday, disclosing that the total income has been $5,487,679. Mr. Carnegie named the Home Trust Company as trustee of the fund and executor under his will because Robert A. Franks, for many years his financial secretary, was president and Mr. Carnegie held all the stock.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Predicting that "dammed-up forces of recovery will burst forth in a magnificent prosperity" with the election of Governor Landon to the Presidency, Colonel Frank Knox formally accepted tonight the Republican Vice Presidential nomination in an address declaring that the "preservation of free enterprise" was the issue in this campaign.
LONDON, July 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- Francis Newton, Hamilton King and Willis J. Whittemore are among the members of the Guild Hall's art committee who are arranging an exhibition of paintings to be opened in the two large galleries there on Tuesday.

Beginning tomorrow, Long Island Railroad passengers who hold the refund coupons or canceled tickets which were issued by court order beginning June 23 will receive a rebate of the difference between the original fare and the present two-cent rate.

NEWARK, N.J., July 30. -- Bill Harris, veteran Buffalo right-hander, pitched his second no-hit, no-run game of the season tonight when he blanked the Newark Bears, 4 to 0, in the second game of a double-header. The Bisons also won the first game, 4 to 1, after having lost five consecutive games.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt was host at the Piping Rock opening for Miss Wendy Iglehart of Westbury and Representative Parker Corning and Mrs. Corning. Ogden Phipps entertained there for John R. Fell Jr., Edward M. McIlvain, John T. Ryan and George H. Bostwick.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $60,000,000 to $3,050,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to yesterday's statement of the system. The gain the week before was $70,000,000. This week member bank reserve balances jumped $81,000,000 to $6,016,000,000, whereas the week before the gain was $63,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Plans for a coordinated program to meet the drought situation were drafted today by Secretary Wallace, simultaneous with the publication by regions and States of a detailed report on crop conditions. Both of these will be presented to President Roosevelt soon after his return to Hyde Park.
PARIS, July 30. -- For the ninth time in its history the Chamber of Deputies passed the Woman Suffrage Bill today. It has always previously been rejected by the Senate.
CHICAGO, July 30. -- The text of Senator Steiwer's address notifying Colonel Frank Knox of his nomination as the Republican candidate for Vice President tonight, follows:

HENDAYE, France, July 30. -- While the Madrid government contends that it is gradually wearing down its opponents in the north, declaring that the enemy is tending to break up into small bands and is adopting guerrilla tactics, the insurgents announce that they are completing arrangements to advance on Madrid.

PARIS, July 30. -- Formal denial of reports that airplanes and ammunition had been supplied by France to either governmental or rebel forces in Spain was made by Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos before the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee today.

CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP). -- The Indians pounded five home runs, two of them by Hal Trosky, today to defeat the Senators, 11-8, and sweep the four-game series. Stone contributed a Washington homer in the third inning with two mates aboard.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Prices of hogs declined around 10 cents a hundredweight here today, the demand early being rather slow, but buyers came in later and the market cleared up well. Included in the receipts were some hogs from Southern States which sold as much as $1 under the quotation for Northern corn-fed animals.

Kelvin Rodgers, the 3 1/2-year-old Australian boy who traveled 9,000 miles to have a nail removed from his lung, and his mother, Mrs. Marjorie Rodgers, were conducted on a special tour of the National Broadcasting Company studios and Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon.

The Rev. John J. Wynne observed quietly yesterday the sixtieth anniversary of his entrance into the Jesuit Order. He began the day by offering a mass of thanksgiving in the little chapel of the administration building of Fordham University, with which he is connected and where he resides.

BERLIN, July 30. -- Prices on the Boerse were rather firm today. Led by heavy industrial issues, which overcame the recent reactionary trend near the close yesterday, the market resumed its interrupted movement upward.

The city's debt-incurring power within the constitutional limit was $336,860,928.26 on May 1, 1936, according to a pamphlet issued yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor. The pamphlet served notice, however, that sums already authorized and reserved for various purposes totaled $103,210,230.77, thus leaving only $233,650,607.49 of unencumbered borrowing power.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30. -- The third and last chamber music concert under the direction of Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead took place this evening before a large audience at Camp Soleil, home of Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren, who was on the program as harpist in a duet with one of the guest artists of the evening, George Brown, 'cellist.

A new high since February was recorded by The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices, which advanced to 126.7 on Tuesday from 125.1 the preceding Tuesday. The rise reflected primarily higher prices for the grains and flour, and livestock and their products, while butter and eggs, bananas, potatoes and tea were also higher.

Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, former head of the New Jersey State police, announced yesterday at New Brunswick, N.J., that he would appear before the Federal grand jury in Newark today when the jury resumes its investigation into the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.
PATERSON, N.J., July 30. -- The small silk manufacturers who began a strike against the large wholesalers yesterday received reinforcements today from two new fields.

Senator William H. King of Utah, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a member of several other committees, sailed with his family yesterday on the Colombian liner Haiti for a combined business and pleasure trip to Haiti and Puerto Rico.

D. Joseph De'Andrea, Brooklyn Republican, was sworn in yesterday afternoon as city magistrate by Mayor La Guardia in a ceremony at the Summer City Hall. Paul J. Kern, the Mayor's legal assistant, was inducted into office as member of the Municipal Civil Service Commission at the same time.

BARRINGTON, N.J., July 30. -- Part of the membership of the Barrington Presbyterian Church will hold services on Sunday in the Fire House here as the result of a split growing out of the Modernist-Fundamentalist controversy.

LONDON, July 30. -- A North Atlantic mail and passenger air service agreement between Great Britain, Canada, the Irish Free State and Newfoundland was announced in the House of Commons today by Sir Philip Sassoon, Under-Secretary for Air.

LONDON, July 30. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today reflected brighter views among traders. British funds maintained their recent gains. Foreign securities were idle and foreign rail issues were quiet.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 for securities with estimated gross proceeds of $523,439,000 became fully effective in June, bringing the total for the first six months of 1936 to $2,664,947,000, or almost as much as the $2,677,000,000 for the full year 1935, according to an analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, July 30. -- The British Government is disturbed over the position of Tangier, where the placing by the International Commission of Control of policing arrangements of both the port and the town in the hands of commanders of warships at present in port has apparently given offense to the French Government.

William Harris Jr. has picked up "Corner Pocket," the Robert Rossen play that has been known also as "Behind the Eight Ball." Telling a saga of the poolroom boys, it is due somewhere along Broadway with October, the cast and sundry details being yet indefinite.
PARIS, July 30 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

GIBRALTAR, July 30. -- A heavy concentration of British warships is being made at Gibraltar. The Queen Elizabeth, flagship of the Mediterranean Fleet, is due here soon from Malta, where she was revictualled and refuelled.

VICTOR F. RIDDER takes leave tomorrow of one of the most difficult, most thankless and most important offices created in consequence of the depression. For more than nine months he has served as Works Progressive Administrator for New York City, charged with responsibility for the enormous expenditures and the manifold activities of that ubiquitous agency.
CHICAGO, July 30. -- The text of the address of Colonel Frank Knox accepting the Republican nomination for Vice President was as follows:

A 36-year-old bank teller, who insists that he is innocent, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury and became the first person in this district to be accused under the 1935 amendment to the Federal Banking Law, which extends government protection against fraud to all State banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Two separate movements to bring about conferences with the Federal Trade Commission with a view to obtaining definite interpretations of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act were started here yesterday by the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee and the Toilet Goods Association.

The pages of the Social Register have at last gone really doggy. In its 1936 Summer issue a 4-year-old red-haired Pekingese dog has achieved the recognition for which social climbers without number have struggled and intrigued in vain.

Casualty insurance companies which have been waging an extensive campaign to eliminate fake accident claims were informed yesterday in a presentment handed up by the expiring July New York County grand jury that the campaign should begin at home, for, the statement charged, corruption exists in some of the companies which have been victimized in such claims.
Ernest Hemingway is in Montana working on a new novel which Charles Scribner's Sons expect to publish early in 1937.

EATONTOWN, N.J., July 30. -- The Evergreen Farms poloists of Elberon and the Norwood Polo Club of West Long Branch won the right to compete in the final of the Monmouth County Country's Club's annual 12-goal tournament on Sunday by taking hard battles today.

William Steinberg of 4,520 Broadway, has been elected president of the New York State Organization of Retail Liquor Store Associations, Inc., to succeed Lawrence S. Garry, who has retired from the retail liquor store business, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the group, 11 West Forty-second Street.

Tightening administrative units, apparently with the intention of driving gamblers out of the city and getting stricter police discipline generally, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine issued an order yesterday that will place five deputy police commissioners on night patrol, beginning tomorrow.

Mrs. Dorothea Longcope Livermore, former wife of Jesse Livermore, Wall Street operator, appealed in Domestic Relations Court yesterday for a summons to obtain money from Mr. Livermore for hospital expenses for their 17-year-old son, Jesse Jr. Justice Stephen Jackson refused to issue a summons and advised Mrs. Livermore to carry out the regular procedure provided by the court.

LONDON, July 30. -- King Edward has chartered Lady Yule's luxury steam yacht Nahlin, 1,391 tons, for a cruise of three or four weeks along the Dalmatian coast and in the Eastern Mediterranean, it was officially announced at Buckingham Palace today.

The announcement by the Democrats of plans for the early start of their campaign in this State was hailed yesterday by the Republican leaders as an admission of weakness on the part of their opponents.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 30. -- Visitors were arriving at Pittsfield tonight for the two-day horse show which will open at Holmsdale tomorrow. There are 280 entries with ninety-two horses in fifty classes. Dr. Edgar Powell of Philadelphia, who will judge saddle classes and horsemanship, and Miss Powell are with Mr. and Mrs. Brenton Crane Pomeroy.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reports a net income of $9,098,865 after expenses and taxes for the twelve months ended on June 30, compared with $9,335,620 in the preceding year. Earnings were equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to 12 cents each on 5,267,147 common shares and scrip, compared with 17 cents in the previous twelve months.

Twenty craft had been entered last night for the Bayside Yacht Club's annual race for auxiliaries around Block Island and return, which will start at noon today in the mouth of Little Neck Bay on the North Shore of Long Island.

A persistent demand for secondary railroad loans with speculative interest, focused on a few selected issues of Southern carriers, featured otherwise quiet and routine trading in listed bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace slackened considerably, both in corporate issues as well as in United States Government obligations, the latter fluctuating irregularly within narrow price limits.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reports a net income of $9,098,865 after expenses and taxes for the twelve months ended on June 30, compared with $9,335,620 in the preceding year. Earnings were equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to 12 cents each on 5,267,147 common shares and scrip, compared with 17 cents in the previous twelve months.

Twenty craft had been entered last night for the Bayside Yacht Club's annual race for auxiliaries around Block Island and return, which will start at noon today in the mouth of Little Neck Bay on the North Shore of Long Island.

A persistent demand for secondary railroad loans with speculative interest, focused on a few selected issues of Southern carriers, featured otherwise quiet and routine trading in listed bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The trading pace slackened considerably, both in corporate issues as well as in United States Government obligations, the latter fluctuating irregularly within narrow price limits.

Beginning Aug. 15 the Bronx Gas and Electric Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company will send rebate checks to their consumers, of electricity, the Public Service Commission announced yesterday. The rebate checks will represent the difference between temporary rates established by the commission in the Fall of 1934 and the rates collected by the companies between that time and the date of the recent Court of Appeals decision upholding the commission's order.

A committee of insurance companies headed by George S. Van Schaick, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, will press a proposal to give the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad a share in the control of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, it was disclosed yesterday after a conference between Mr. Van Schaick and Oscar Ewing, counsel for the committee.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 29, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,468,000,000, a decrease of $10,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $3,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1935.
GENEVA, July 30. -- More potatoes and milk and less white flour and sugar are among the diet recommendations made in the second volume of the League's report on nutrition appearing today.

Exhaustive research experiments upon live horses are to be conducted by the New York State Racing Commission beginning this September in an effort to learn more of the methods of doping horses and the effect drugging has upon the animals.

DETROIT, July 30 -- A promised victory hopped away from the Yankees at Navin Field today as they closed their four-game series with the Tigers before a jubilant gathering of 17,000 in a torrid ten-inning struggle. Consequently Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe hung up his second triumph over the league leaders in four days and his third straight conquest of the Yanks.

BERLIN, July 30. -- The International Congress for Leisure and Recreation, meeting in Hamburg as a sort of pre-Olympic Games event, came to a close today with a festive session in the Hamburg Music Hall.
Both Democratic and Republican county organizations on Staten Island met last night and named their candidates for the September primaries to county, State and national offices.

BERLIN, July 30. -- The American Olympic team will go into the games here in much better physical shape than they were when they entered those at Amsterdam eight years ago under the handicap of the same rainy, cold and uncertain weather that has been experienced to date in Berlin.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 30. -- Frank Graves was held for involuntary manslaughter today on the eve of his retirement as a Lackawanna Railroad locomotive engineer, after fifty years without an accident. Mr. Graves's engine struck a track laborer at Clifton yesterday, and the man died today in Passaic General Hospital here of a fractured skull.

The ratio of reserve for the New York bank was at the highest point of the year to date. None of the items in yesterday's statement of the twelve reserve banks reached a new high or low figure for the year.

The chance suspicions of a plain-clothes patrolman, who took the license number of a New York car i he saw on a visit to a small Pennsylvania town four days ago, resulted yesterday in the surrender of Mrs. Bobby Wilson, 30 years old, of 200 West Eighty-sixth Street, who was being sought on an indictment of compulsory prostitution.

Declaring that he never wrote the letter that prompted Victor F. Ridder, Works Progress Administrator, to dismiss a WPA foreman for political activity, Dr. Maxwell Ross, Democratic leader of the Twenty-third Assembly District in Brooklyn, yesterday challenged Mr. Ridder to prove that the letter was genuine.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 30. -- Declaring war on the movement to give the State control of municipal Police Departments, members of the State Association of Chiefs of Police today closed their three-day convention. They named State Police Inspector A.B. Moore of Troy to lead the drive against State supervision.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 30. -- Dr. Dennis R. McElhinney, 56 years old, one of the best-known physicians and surgeons in Union County, hanged himself this afternoon by a rope from a beam in a garage he rented at 61 Cherry Street here.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- Charges that he had disclosed military secrets to Japan were formally denied today by John S. Farnsworth, discharged naval officer, who pleaded innocence in the Federal Court here to a double-edged grand jury indictment.

LONDON, July 30. -- The Anglo-Russian naval discussions, which have been proceeding at intervals for the last two months, today reached a favorable but provisional conclusion the final embodiment of which in a bilateral treaty now depends on the attitudes of Germany and Japan.

While prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday rather nervously over a 15-point range and broke into new low territory for a few moments shortly after midday, the decline to around 12 cents a pound attracted sufficient buying to bring a recovery of 4 to 5 points on the day.
BOSTON, July 30 (AP). -- The Pirates scored two runs in the eleventh inning today on two hits, two sacrifices and two errors and defeated the Bees, 5 to 3.

BOSTON, July 30. -- A bad actor at the post. Mountainy Man, took the bit in his teeth at the break and wore down five rivals to capture the mile and a sixteenth Elks handicap before 16,000 fans today at Suffolk Downs.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 30. -- In much the same way as they won in the semi-final round, by staving off a late rally, the South Shore riders won the Wheatley polo cups by defeating Fauquier-Loudoun, 6 to 4, today in the final on Phipps Field.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Organized labor will ask the next Congress to amend the Walsh-Healey Government Contracts Law in order to "plug up the loopholes" which were opened by the House amendment. This plan was announced today by President William Green of the American Federation of Labor.

In issuing the report of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the second quarter, Eugene G. Grace, president, remarked yesterday that the company was employing 81,706 men, "by quite a bit the largest number ever on its payroll." He pointed out that all industries save one-building construction -- were employing their "full complement of men."

Summer visitors to these parts of New Jersey are considerably surprised by the unusual numbers of the mosquito this year. They are told that the increase is due to a decrease in appropriation for the liquidation of the pest. The decrease in appropriation was about a fifth of what was necessary, but the increase in mosquito-crop is about 100 per cent.

TRENTON, July 30. -- The controversy between Morris Umansky and Isador Haber as to which is entitled to sit as judge of the North Hudson District Court was carried to the Supreme Court today. Mr. Haber, recently appointed by Governor Hoffman to succeed Judge Umansky, after the Executive accepted a "resignation" the latter denied submitting, instituted quo warranto proceedings.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 3O. -- Ira (Babe) Hanford, who sprang to fame by riding the Kentucky Derby winner, Bold Venture, did another impressive job today over the Spa course when he took Goldeneye along the fence and won the Seneca Claiming Stakes with him by half a length.

The three new films opening to day are: "Three Cheers for Love," with Eleanore Whitney, Robert Cummings, William Frawley and Roscoe Karns, at the Roxy; "The Final Hour," a melodrama from the Columbia studios, with Ralph Bellamy, Marguerite Churchill and Lina Basquette, at the Rialto, and "Grand Jury," featuring Fred Stone, Louise Latimer, Owen Davis Jr. and Moroni Olsen, at the Palace.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 31. -- If Arturo Toscanini's "Fidelio" of the current festival did not wholly measure up to last Summer's, his first "Falstaff" tonight certainly did. It differed in some particulars of casting from the extraordinary performance of a year ago, but the presentation, taken by and large, was in every respect as dynamic and as perfectly coordinated and as stunning a piece of sheer virtuosity.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Trading of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in July was the most active of any month since April. Sales for last month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 34,786,729 shares, compared with 21,428,377 in June, and 29,429,387 in the same month a year ago.
NEWARK, N.J., July 31. -- Driving Bob Weiland, league-leading pitcher, to cover, the Newark Bears snapped their losing streak tonight with a 7-3 triumph over the first-place Rochester Red Wings.

A monument will be dedicated at Mount Hermon, Mass., at the annual Summer Laymen's Conference, which will open Aug. 14 and continue for four days. The monument will commemorate the golden jubilee of the founding of the Student Christian Conference at Mount Hermon.

ALBANY, July 31. -- Governor Lehman tonight directed a special term of the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, to be convened Thursday in Rochester to hear an appeal of Remington-Rand, Inc., employes from a temporary injunction granted by the Onondaga Supreme Court limiting the number of pickets at any Remington-Rand plant to four persons.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 31. -- Calling the position the "toughest job I have ever held," J. Buckley Bryan, district director of the Works Progress Administration, resigned today to accept appointment as engineering aide to the director of the State budget.

Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission continued the examination yesterday of representatives of various firms in the liquor industry to aid in the government's case against the use of the term "distiller" by a group of firms who, the commission contends, are not actually engaged in the process generally known by that name in the industry.

Petroleum Concessions, Ltd., organized by the Irak Petroleum Company, has obtained an oil concession in Saudi, Arabia, it was learned yesterday. The concession, which extends for sixty-two miles along the Red Sea, also includes the Farsan Islands.
LONDON, July 31 (AP). -- George Andrew McMahon, who wrote King Edward he suffered "tortures of a damned soul," was remanded to Brixton prison today to await trial for hurling a pistol at his monarch.

LEWISBURG, Pa., July 31. -- Days of chunky canal boats in Pennsylvania, tall sailing vessesls in the port of old Philadelphia, early coal miners and roving Indians were relived at the Pennsylvania Folk Festival here tonight in Bucknell University's Memorial Stadium.

BERLIN, July 31 (AP). -- Rudolf Ismayr of Germany, 1932 Olympic middleweight weight-lifting champion, will take the Olympic oath tomorrow on behalf of all the athletes. The oath, representing the highest ideals of amateurism and sportsmanship, says:
CHICAGO, July 31. -- Representative William Lemke said today he thinks about $500,000 would do for the limit the Union party's platform promises it would put on any citizen's annual income.

BARCELONA, July 31. -- Juan Casanovas, President of the Catalan Parliament, who is a member of the Catalonian Left party called the Esquerra, has agreed to form a new Catalan Government and has chosen eight of the fourteen other members of the Cabinet from that party. Three others are Socialists.

Despite the gradual increase in member-bank reserves in July, the New York City banks near the end of the month still had a smaller aggregate amount of excess reserves, in proportion to their reserve requirements, than the rest-of-the-country members of the System, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions, published by the New York Federal Reserve Bank.

Is there no way of preventing musical and other artistic events from being turned into a field day for news photographers? At the concert given by the WPA at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday evening the antics of these photographers with their flashlights made it well-nigh impossible for the audience to enjoy the music.

HENDAYE, France, July 31. -- Although gunfire can be heard within four miles of the frontier here, the fighting that is now going on in that northern corner of Spain is only local and an offshoot of the struggle still going on for San Sebastian.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Medalist Gene Homans survived the two opening rounds of the annual invitation tournament at the National Links of America today, but he had to go to the last green to triumph in one of them.

Two openings are on today's schedule. "I Was a Captive of Nazi Germany," an original story by Isobel Steele, who also enacts the leading role, will begin its engagement at the Globe with a preview showing tonight. The Cine-Roma Theatre will offer "The Blind Girl of Sorrento," adapted from the Italian novel of Francesco Mastriana, with Dria Paola and Corrado Racca heading the cast, beginning this morning.
QUEBEC, July 31. -- Following are the texts of the addresses made here today on the occasion of President Roosevelt's visit:

Hopelessly enmeshed in some rather tantalizing left-handed pitching by one Larry French, the Giants' big drive became utterly becalmed at the Polo Grounds yesterday while a Ladies' Day gathering of 13,000 looked helplessly on.

One of the oldest American steamship companies, the Nelson Line, officially went out of business yesterday after operating for seventy-six years. A subsidiary of the Charles Nelson Lumber Company, a West Coast concern, the steamship line has been operating successfully in the intercoastal trade for many years and, until the failure of the parent company cut down transportation activities, maintained a fortnightly service between coasts with fourteen ships.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Machinery for the enforcement of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Chain Store Bill, approved by the President on June 19, was put in motion here today following a conference between Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice officials.

OSSINING, N.Y., July 31. -- Bishop James Edward Walsh of Cumberland, Md., has been elected superior general of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, it was announced today at the society's headquarters at Maryknoll here. He succeeds Bishop James Anthony Walsh, to whom he was not related, who died on April 14.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31 (AP). -- Tomorrow's primaries will indicate the political trend in Kentucky as well as determine what candidates will represent their parties in the November election.

Although the Works Progress Administration is 25 per cent ahead of the schedule set by the Manhattan Borough President's office in removing car tracks in the midtown area, completion of the project is being delayed by restrictions on night operation of noisy drills and hammers.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 31. -- A ball will be given tomorrow at the Naval Training Station for the benefit of the Army and Navy Y.M.C.A.

GENEVA, July 31. -- Swiss hotel and business interests are unhappy at losing 5,000 expected guests as a result of the recent decision of the organizing committee of the International Peace Campaign, a peace demonstration that was to have been held here from Sept. 3 to 6, to transfer the meeting to Brussels.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 31. -- Pedro Albizu Campos, leader of the Puerto Rican Nationalists, and seven followers were sentenced today to terms of two to six years in prison following their conviction on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government of the United States.

I do not think that the letter written by W.L.W. in last Saturday's TIMES was concerned with either Avery Brundage's place of residence or how his trip to Berlin was financed. His attack was directed, am I see it, against excessive interference with the affairs of our Olympic athletes by committee men and others.
CHICAGO, July 31. -- The Republican national headquarters today centered attention upon plans for a platform campaign, which will get into full blast around Labor Day.

For the United States Treasury the month that ended yesterday was the best July in recent years. Even in boom times July is normally a "deficit month," due to the fact that no quarterly installment of the income tax -- on which the Government relies heavily -- happens to fall due.

A marked change in new financing occurred in July. Bond offerings which, while still the largest medium of new securities, declined sharply from the preceding month, while stock flotations were the largest for any month since May, 1931.

All records for individual contributions are being broken by the Republican party in the Landon-Knox campaign, Robert H. Thayer, city chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- An assertion that Labor's Non-partisan League expected to swing the votes of 3,500,000 organized and unorganized workmen and their families for President Roosevelt was made today by Major George L. Berry, chairman of the league.

Max Jaffe, WPA plumbing foreman who was dismissed by Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator, for alleged "political activity," was reinstated without comment yesterday by Mr. Ridder after the foreman appeared at WPA headquarters and in a notarized statement disclaimed any connection with politics.

Mr. Krock's column this morning is devoted to a discussion of the charge of usurpation alleged to have been made by Mr. Landon in his Topeka speech. Now I have read Mr. Landon's speech with care, and I fail to find in it any charge of usurpation whatever.

Three breweries launched large advertising campaigns this week, promoting beer in cans. Jacob Ruppert Co. introduced their beer in keglined cans, product of the American Can Company, while Beverwyck Breweries, Inc., Albany, and the Horton-Pilsener Brewing Company advertised the cap-sealed cans made by the Continental Can Company.

LONDON, July 31. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were quiet on the eve of the August bank holiday, although prices remained firm. British funds were steady and the foreign list was quiet excepting further improvement in the German group.

Edward Morris, who was once a chauffeur for Daniel Guggenheim but later became wealthy from operating a chain of gasoline stations, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell to serve a year and a day in prison and to pay a fine of $2,500 for his failure to pay an income tax in 1929.
QUEBEC, Que., July 31. -- The first official visit ever paid by the head of the American State to Canada could not fail to be recorded as a major event in the history of the North American Continent.

ROME, July 31. -- Italy today abandoned her aloofness from European affairs, maintained since sanctions were applied last November, and returned to a policy of European collaboration. Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano informed the French Ambassador and the British and Belgian Charges d'Affaires that the Italian Government would be pleased to participate in a conference of the five Locarno powers.

ALGIERS, Algeria, July 31. -- It is now confirmed that five Italian Savoia-Marchetti planes, certainly some and probably all of which were manned by Italian military pilots and carried arms, flew over Algerian territory en route to Spanish Morocco yesterday.

ROBREGORDO, Northern Rebel Headquarters, Spain, July 31. -- A former New York schoolboy is leading some of Spain's Fascist fighters on the northern front. Jose Sainz, whose father once owned a garage in the Bronx, led his blue-shirted Fascists into battle today side by side with regular army troops.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Closing the first phase of its investigation of investment trusts and trust companies that subsequently were merged into or bought and dissolved by the Equity Corporation, the Securities and Exchange Commission asserted today that the Interstate Equities Corporation of New York, since merged into Equity, sustained losses of $20,566,527 while the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation was the directing force behind it.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 31. -- The estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers of New York and Southampton will not have to pay Miss Helen M. Berets of Bridgeport, Conn., a pension of $175 a month for life, according to a decision handed down today by Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County.

CLEVELAND, July 31. -- A near-capacity crowd of 21,000 fans flocked to League Park today, most of them women guests of the management who stormed the portals as early as 8 A.M., loaded down with food, coffee containers and cushions.
Moses L. Annenberg, publisher, announced yesterday his purchase of The Philadelphia Inquirer and its real estate for $15,000,000.

The Chase National Bank, acting for the fiscal agents, is inviting tenders for the sale to it at a price below par of sufficient Argentine Government external 6 per cent bonds, State railway issue, due Sept. 1, 1960, to exhaust the sum of $377,414 to be available in the sinking fund.

The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, pastor of the Central Congregational Church in Brooklyn and nationally known radio minister, left an estate of less than $10,000, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31. -- Discovery will get another chance for a comeback tomorrow when he starts in the historic Saratoga Handicap at the course where he carried his greatest impost of 139 pounds to victory. In recent races the Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt champion has failed under 138 and 136 and he will be tested again under 132.

VATICAN CITY, July 31. -- Pope Pius this morning received Bishop Gallagher, head of the Detroit diocese, in his Summer residence at Castle Gandolfo. The Bishop remained in conversation there only twelve minutes, during which it is stated that no reference was made by either side to Father Coughlin.

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, July 31. -- With the completion of two unfinished games from the eighth and ninth rounds today, all is in readiness for the eleventh and final session of the international chess masters' tournament tomorrow at the Grand Hotel.

ROBLEGORDO, Northern Rebel Headquarters, Spain, July 31. -- The rebel army of General Emilio Mola smashed its way forward tonight on its march toward Madrid. The column with which this correspondent traveled reached the outskirts of Buitrago, thirty-eight miles from the capital, late today.

Elwood P. McEnany, will retire on Sept. 1 as a general partner in the firm of Bond, McEnany Co., and will become a special partner on that date, it was announced yesterday. Eli B. Springs 2d, a partner in that firm, also will be made a special partner on Sept. 1. Mr. Springs recently sold his seat on the New York Stock Exchange to William Ullman for $139,000.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31. -- A disclosure that Paul H. Wendel contradicted his "confession" to the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. immediately after he made it but that this denial had been suppressed was reported to have been made today to the Federal Grand Jury here.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 31. -- Despite another day of golf which produced numerous birdies over a Crestmont Golf Club course baked hard by the recent hot spell, there still was a deadlock for the lead today as the half-way point was reached in the New Jersey State open championship.

The Spanish civil war seems to be degenerating into a competition in savagery. "I take no prisoners," was the grim reply of rebel commander Colonel JOSE PALACIOS last Wednesday to the action of the Government at the beginning of the revolt in arming the masses for its desperate struggle for survival.
BOSTON, July 31 (AP). -- Wally Berger's two home runs today did little to aid the cause of the Bees as the hard-clouting Pirates blasted two Boston pitchers for fourteen hits to win, 10 to 5.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- The 40-year-old village fair, proceeds of which are used to keep village greens and trees in condition, was opened here today to a large attendance.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 31. -- Governor Lehman tonight made public a letter he received from President Roosevelt in relation to a flood-control compact between the State of New York and the Federal Government and the allocation of Federal funds to enable an immediate start of work on remedial measures for the protection of the Central and Southern New York areas.

It seems unfortunate that a promising member should be dismissed from the United States team for violation of Olympic regulations. As an American, I consider the decision of Mr. Avery Brundage sound for the honor of America and for the honor of the traditional spirit of the Olympics.

LOS ANGELES, July 31 (AP). -- An assertion that Mary Astor "wilfully abandoned" her 4-year-old daughter, Marylyn, "for a married man -- George Kaufman," came tonight from counsel for the screen actress's former husband, Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, in the suit over the custody of the child.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 31 (AP). -- Cardinal Prince, Dominion Grattan and Dillon Hall turned the special Old Orchard pace into the fastest three-heat race ever paced in New England today. Each of the trio, here for the first Grand Circuit meeting in Maine history, lowered a State record that had stood forty years.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Ninety-two Americans and other nationals were rescued this morning by the steamer Exochorda of the American Export Line from Palma just before the island city was bombarded from the air, presumably by government planes, the State Department was advised in a message from the master of the steamer.
GIBRALTAR, July 31. -- News from Seville says that a column of rebel colonial troops from Seville has captured Baena, near Cordoba.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31. -- The city of Newark filed with the Essex County Board of Taxation today a petition asking that the personal property assessments of the Public Service Corporation be increased from $5,500,000 to $155,500,000 for this year, it was announced by A. F. Minisi, Newark Director of Revenue and Finance.

At Highland Falls, N.Y., just where 9W turns abruptly up a steep hill, construction work is under way and because of its unguarded condition I came near to a tragic ending of a trip. Pipe openings had been filled with earth and packed down, but these had stones in front of them to warn one away.
