Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to the Department of Investigation and Accounts, announced yesterday that he had obtained from Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate in Brooklyn an order requiring Mrs. Jessie L. Shelubov to appear on Aug. 4 and answer questions regarding entries in her bank account.

How does Governor LANDON find time to read amid his labors and visitors? He is even reading that brilliant, solid and digressive work, "The "Endless Adventure: Personalities and "Practical Politics in "Eighteenth-Century England," by the late Mr. F.S. OLIVER.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Ten world records, including Jesse Owens's 26 foot 8 1/4 inch broad jump, and five record-equaling track and field performances were approved today by the International Amateur Athletic Federation record committee of which Avery Brundage of Chicago is chairman.

PENSACOLA, Fla., July 31. -- A midsummer hurricane whirled out of the Gulf of Mexico across a sparsely settled area forty miles east of here today, inflicting heavy damage on some coastal property and leaving three vessels unaccounted for.

Following an all-day demonstration in protest against the dismissal orders affecting 150 workers on the Federal project for urban study of consumers' purchases, several pickets threw themselves prone in the street yesterday in an effort to prevent the departure of an automobile bearing Victor F. Ridder, WPA Administrator, from his office at 70 Columbus Avenue.

Profit-taking and more than a suspicion of short-selling weakened stock prices yesterday. Most of the day the market displayed good resistance, although not to the extent that might have been expected in view of the strong market for the grains. Motor, farm equipment and various of the specialty stocks were the weakest, some losing 1 to as much as 5 points on the day.

PARIS, July 31. -- Official reticence is being observed as to what the French Government will do regarding Italian violation of air conventions in sending a squadron of armed airplanes across French territory to help armed rebels in a foreign country [Spanish Morocco].

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 31. -- The Pittsfield Horse Show ball was held tonight at the Pittsfield Country Club, with more than 200 attending. It was preceded by a dinner for an equal number, with the Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club, of which Donald M. Weston is president, as host.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP). -- An abortive plot to put typhoid germs in milk delivered to Jews was charged to the Black Legion today.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock [11 A.M. New York Daylight time] Adolf Hitler, as the German Fuehrer and the chief host to the world-wide gathering assembled here, will open the eleventh modern Olympic Games in the great stadium which is to be the scene of their chief events.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP). -- A barrage of safe line drives that included Jimmy Foxx's thirtieth homer with two on the bases cashed in on Lefty Bob Grove's seven-hit pitching today to give the Red Sox a 7-to-3 victory over the White Sox in the opener of their series.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 31. -- A 24-year-old college instructor who never has ranked better than fifteenth nor carried off before a major singles tournament prize today added his name to the distinguished pantheon of winners of the Seabright Bowl.

ALLENHURST, N.J., July 31 (AP). -- Vice Chancellor Alfred C. Stein issued a temporary order last night restraining Monthly Income Shares, Inc., of New Jersey, of Jersey City and ten other parties from dealing in securities in or from New Jersey.

Risking police bullets in a desperate attempt to escape, three hold-up men raced from a Brooklyn factory building yesterday and engaged in a rough-and-tumble fight with two radio patrolmen in a rear courtyard. Two of the suspects were captured, but the third got away.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- All deliveries of grain in the world's leading markets advanced today to new high levels for the season on the crest of a wave of general public buying which restored the dollar quotation on corn futures for the first time since September, 1930, and put white cash corn in the sample market on the Board of Trade to $1.15 1/2 a bushel, the highest price since 1925.

Absence of relief in the drought sections of Oklahoma and reports that the tropical disturbance had reached the Eastern Gulf Coast moving into Alabama caused a further recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. October rose to around 12 1/4 cents a pound when the upturn of a quarter cent from Thursday's low seemed to complete the covering movement and the list eased off to end unchanged to a gain of 1 point.

Chugging off under motors, some without even sails up, twenty craft started yesterday from the mouth of Little Neck Bay, on the Long Island side of the Sound, in the Bayside Yacht Club's 225-mile race out around Block Island and back.

Strength in cocoa, coffee, sugar and silk futures and easiness in hides were a feature in the trading on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. On the cash markets tin declined, while all the grains, cotton, lard, dairy products and cocoa advanced.

Acceptance of processing tax refunds from converters on the basis of the plan proposed by the Textile Fabrics Association, which calls for the filing of an inventory of goods on hand as of Jan. 6, 1936, was recommended to members of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute yesterday by the board of directors.

With early Fall shows as scarce as ever, the Shuberts will attempt to counteract that grim situation with "Days of Grace," the play by Edwin L. Gilbert. It is to go into rehearsal next Thursday. John Warburton of the screen, who is to take part, will arrive in the East on Monday.

The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries (excluding Philadelphia Gas Works Company) have reported a consolidated net income of $28,683,537 for the twelve months ended on June 30, equal to $1.07 a share on the common stock after preferred dividends, compared with $30,146,288, or $1.13 a share, in the previous year.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 1. -- The Japanese public was awakened at 6 A.M. today by the radio announcing Tokyo had been selected for the 1940 Olympics. The result gives enormous pleasure to the Japanese, who have become one of the world's most sports-minded people within the last twenty years.

Under a clouded moon, but in an atmosphere of civic pride and achievement, Mayor La Guardia and other city officials formally opened last night the new McCarren Park swimming pool on Lorimer Street, between Driggs Avenue and Bayard Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, July 31. -- Alarmed by news that Italian fighting planes had been dispatched to Spanish Morocco for the use of the rebel general, Francisco France, the French Government desires that a conference should be called immediately for Britain, France and Italy to discuss the problem of neutrality in the Spanish civil war.

GRANT, Neb., July 31 (AP). -- Sterling Walrod Powell, 16-year-old farm boy, was arrested here today on a Federal charge for sending a $25,000 extortion letter to the father of Shirley Temple, child film star.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey granted yesterday injunctions to five New York public utility corporations restraining the Government of the United States from attempting to force them to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission in accordance with the Public Utilities Act of 1935.

BERLIN, July 31. -- The Boerse continued firmish today, but interest shifted from the shares of heavy industrials and specialties, Heavy industrial issues were softened by profit-taking, but losses were narrow, with Harpener even finishing fractionally higher.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente denied yesterday the application by Robert Walton Goelet to compel License Commissioner Paul Moss to approve the location of a motion-picture theatre in a building to be erected by Mr. Goelet at 61 East Fifty-third Street.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 31. -- The Toronto Argonauts placed in eight of ten events today to roll up 35 points and virtually clinch championship honors in the three-day Canadian Royal Henley Regatta at the end of the second day of rowing.

Captain Liddell Hart, English authority on military affairs, has signed a contract with Random House for the publication of a new, concise history of the World War. Although the book will contain only 260 pages, the effort has been made to cover every campaign, every innovation in mode of attack and defense and every change of leadership.

Local department stores extended this week the gains in sales volume, which have been marked since the middle of the month. Consumer response to fur, cloth coat and August furniture promotions was reported good, with the demand for Summer merchandise prolonged much later than usual and expected to continue for a fortnight or so more.

In your editorial note appended to my letter of criticism concerning the manager of the New York Giants which you printed last week you mention that Mr. Terry brought his club home in first place and to a world championship in 1933, second place in 1934 and third place in 1935 and you add that "No National League manager has a better record over the same period."
SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., July 31 (AP). -- Colonel E. H. R. Green, whose property holdings have been valued by friends at upward of $80,000,000, died apparently without making a will.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Two Governors of drought-stricken States came here today and made personal appeals for more Federal aid to their States. A third Governor sent a plea for a compulsory 50 per cent freight rate cut on feed concentrates to help farmers of the West to maintain their livestock.

PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, July 31. -- A vessel carrying supplies up the Fly River to Dr. Richard Archbold's expedition from the American Museum of Natural History, which is about 550 miles from the stream's mouth, broke her propeller shaft when she was 150 miles up the river.

FAIR HAVEN, N.J., July 31. -- A thief whose taste for mischief matched his nerve appropriated Fair Haven's only police car early this morning, used it to impersonate an officer and to commit a robbery in Rumson, stole new license plates for it in a Little Silver private garage, topped off his adventure by leaving the garage in flames, and then vanished -- all in about an hour.

A Rough Rider attack on the President's Administration was to have been expected from Colonel KNOX in accepting the Republican nomination for Vice President, and that is the sort of speech he made. Sparking phrases and vigorous utterance supported a good delivery and made it apparent that the Colonel will be a dashing commander of the vigorous party attack on the stump.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 31. -- The anti-Fascist reaction in Barcelona and the Catalan region has entered the stage of a reign of terror. Barcelona is outwardly calm, but underneath the surface lurks a terrible story of house searches by Leftist "purification squads," the seizure of individuals or whole families and their subsequent assassination in lonely spots, and the murder of nuns and priests.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Confidence that the Democrats would retain control of the House after the November elections, and with a large majority, was expressed today by Speaker Bankhead and Representative John J. O'Connor, acting Democratic floor leader.

SALEM, Ore., July 31 (AP). -- A thrice-convicted murderer, 50 years old, was killed, and two other prisoners were wounded when inmates of the Oregon penitentiary rioted nearly three hours here today in protest against a court ruling refusing freedom to a prisoner.

Based on reports so far issued, the oil companies completed the best first six months from an earnings standpoint in years. Increases ranged from 40 to more than 100 per cent above the same period of last year. In view of the recently enacted tax on undistributed earnings, the consensus of opinion is that most earnings this year will be passed on to shareholders in the form of dividends.

LONDON, July 31. -- Germany and Italy have accepted invitations to the proposed Locarno conference. This news reached London this evening just after Parliament had adjourned for three months, government offices had been virtually deserted and members of the Cabinet had scattered to various parts of England, Scotland and Wales for the Summer holiday.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had filed with the Federal Communications Commission a schedule of reduced interstate long-distance rates, effective Sept. 1, 1936, and estimated to save its patrons $7,500,000 annually.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31. -- Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin entertained with a luncheon before the races today at her villa for Mrs. E. Vassar Baker, Mrs. Elsie Moore Torlonia, Mrs. William A. Prime, Lady Doverdale and Mrs. Chauncey Olcott.

QUEBEC, July 31. -- The President of the United States, the Governor General of Canada and the Prime Minister of the Dominion cemented the ties of friendship between the two nations in addresses here today.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP). -- The battle for seventh place in the American League between St. Louis and Philadelphia found the Browns in a strategic position, after their 12-4 defeat of the Athletics today.

PASSAIC, N.J., July 31. -- Funeral services will be held at 11 A.M. Sunday for Louis William (Bridgie) Webber, former New York gambler, whose testimony helped to send Police Lieutenant Charles Becker and four gunmen to the electric chair for the murder in 1912 of Herman Rosenthal, a gambler.

BOSTON, July 31. -- Coming from behind to score his second straight victory at this track, Edward Bruner's Aneroid romped to a length-an-a-half victory in the Cape Coder, mile and seventy-yard feature of today's Suffolk Downs card. He was timed in 1:41 2-5, one-fifth off the track record, and paid $9.60 for $2 in the mutuels.
" Best salt-water fishing in years," is the consensus among veteran travelers of the deep-sea lanes in these parts.

Three properties in Manhattan and three in the Bronx were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One of the Manhattan parcels was taken over by the State Mortgage Commission and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
MADRID, July 31 (AP). -- Troops of the rebellion announced tonight that they were marching against Madrid and it appeared that the crucial battle in the two-weeks-old revolt was near.

LONDON, July 31. -- Both houses of Parliament adjourned today until Oct. 29, with the proviso that they may be summoned to reassemble on five days' notice any time before that date in the event of an international crisis.

Except for slightly higher discount rates for bankers' acceptances, quotations for money in July were unchanged for the second consecutive month. Four maturities of bankers' bills were raised 1-16 of 1 per cent on July 22, following three days of split bids.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Financial assistance for the repatriation of forty-six Puerto Rican school teachers who were in Barcelona at the outbreak of the revolution but who have been evacuated and are now stranded in France, was provided at their request today through a loan of $8,000 arranged by Governor Blanton Winship and the Commissioner of Education of Puerto Rico, against their pension funds.

Closing July with the strongest consumer demand recorded for the period in six years, the majority of cities throughout the country showed sales increases of 5 to 10 per cent over the figures for the preceding week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- With the announcement that the real drive for the re-election of President Roosevelt would begin about the end of next week, Postmaster General James A. Farley this afternoon relinquished his Cabinet post for three months to head the Democratic campaign as National Chairman.

GRUNAU, Germany, July 31 (AP). -- With Donald Bruce Hume stroking the boat again after a two-day layoff because of a chest cold, the University of Washington eight- oared crew rowed its first time trial over the 2,000-meter Olympic course today.

Secondary and lower-priced domestic corporation bonds were the center of interest in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Under the leadership of the railroad loans, spirited demand developed in some sections of the corporate list, which carried the combined price average for that group up 0.14 point on the day.

TOPEKA, July 31. -- Representative Chester C. Bolton of Cleveland, chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, told Governor Landon at luncheon today that the outlook for the election of both the national ticket and a Republican House of Representatives was very encouraging.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company and the Budd Wheel Company, both of Philadelphia, filed today registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of $12,500,000 of securities in a plan of liquidation of the Budd Realty Corporation.

BAYONNE, N. J., Saturday, Aug. 1. -- Mrs. Helen MacKnight, 40 years old, was found beaten to death with an axe about 6 o'clock last evening in the kitchen of her home at 826 Avenue A. The body was discovered by her husband, Edgar W. MacKnight, works superintendent of the General Cable Company factory, here.

Fully capable of achieving the task when the opportunity presented itself, Dizzy Dean singled in the tenth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday, thereby driving home two of his St. Louis team-mates and clinching his seventeenth victory of the current campaign.
P.T. Barnum at his best was just a piker. The Educational Alliance demonstrated that yesterday in its annual circus on the roof of its building at East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

VIENNA, July 31. -- The Fatherland Front tonight held a mass demonstration protesting the Nazi outburst of Wednesday on the arrival of the Olympic torch. Tonight's manifestation served to show a considerable cooling-off as regards the Austro-German agreement, only recently concluded.

The upward movement of commodity prices in a gradual return to the 1926 price level, the arbitrarily selected norm of the economists, and a threatened shortage in foodstuffs as a result of drought conditions are factors bringing about a new consciousness of the cost of living, it was revealed yesterday.

PARIS, July 31 (AP). -- An end of inequality between the sexes was demanded tonight in the name of 100,000 women. Delegates representing them at the International Federation of Business and Professional Women unanimously adopted resolutions at the closing session endorsing the equality movement.

QUEBEC, July 31. -- Colorful pageantry marked the whole visit of President Roosevelt here today. Soldiers in scarlet jackets and plumed brass helmets and lines of infantry wearing tall busbies formed honor lines through which the President was driven in a motor car, seated beside Lord Tweedsmuir, the latter resplendent in court uniform and feathered hat.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP). -- The Phillies and Reds divided a double-header today. Cincinnati won the first game, 12 to 2, when Ray (Peaches) Davis held Philadelphia to six hits, while his mates slapped three hurlers for 14 safeties. The Phils won the nightcap, 7 to 2.

Reflecting seasonal inactivity in the market for tax-exempt securities, next week will be one of the dullest periods of the year to date as to volume of new State and municipal financing, there being scheduled for award a total of only $3,964,071.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman heard argument and reserved decision yesterday in the suit of William Church Osborn, head of the Citizens Budget Commission, for an injunction restraining the Board of Elections from submitting to a vote at the general election in November the proposition creating a three-platoon system in the Fire Department.
RENO, Nev., July 31. -- Mrs. Caroline Townsend Chapman obtained a divorce today from Richard D. Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., on grounds of cruelty. The suit was uncontested.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Reflecting seasonal inactivity in the market for tax-exempt securities, next week will be one of the dullest periods of the year to date as to volume of new State and municipal financing, there being scheduled for award a total of only $3,964,071.

Every year, come August and the race meet at Saratoga, a first-team of Broadway entertainers (with a few second-string substitutes) and a large cheering section of the regular night-club clientele repair to the famous watering place for the fun and profit that may -- or may not -- be had.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman heard argument and reserved decision yesterday in the suit of William Church Osborn, head of the Citizens Budget Commission, for an injunction restraining the Board of Elections from submitting to a vote at the general election in November the proposition creating a three-platoon system in the Fire Department.

The Naumburg Symphony Orchestra last night gave the third in its series of four concerts on the Mall in Central Park before an audience of 5,000 persons. The orchestra was led by Lajos Shuk, conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, and the guest-artist for the evening was Miss Rose Dirmann, soprano.
RENO, Nev., July 31. -- Mrs. Caroline Townsend Chapman obtained a divorce today from Richard D. Chapman of Greenwich, Conn., on grounds of cruelty. The suit was uncontested.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Every year, come August and the race meet at Saratoga, a first-team of Broadway entertainers (with a few second-string substitutes) and a large cheering section of the regular night-club clientele repair to the famous watering place for the fun and profit that may -- or may not -- be had.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Japan will commemorate the 2,600th anniversary of the founding of its empire with the holding of the Olympic Games in 1940. The International Olympic Committee in a secret session today awarded the Summer games to Tokyo by a vote of 36 to 27, the minority favoring Helsingfors, Finland.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, offered today to make any sacrifice, even to resigning the post which he has held since 1924, to heal the breach that divides the industrial and craft union forces within the federation.

MADRID, July 31. -- With the departure of seventy-two Americans last night and nine more today for Valencia there were still seventy-four living in the United States Embassy tonight. Most of these Americans are established residents here who do not wish to leave the country.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges was in rare form today, scattering eight hits and striking out seven men as the Tigers defeated Washington, 8 to 2.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Charles Downing Lay of New York and Stratford, Conn., today became the first American winner of a 1936 Olympic Games medal. Mr. Lay's plan for Marine Park, Brooklyn, won the silver medal in the section for architectural designs and models of the Olympic Art Exhibition.

New bond financing this week amounted to $66,060,168, representing a well-diversified list of loans in four major classifications. This compares with a total of $63,778,000 last week, and with $49,825,000 this week last year.

As a result of the large increase in earnings in the first half of 1936, directors of corporations, taking cognizance of the new national tax law as it applies to undistributed income, voted bigger dividends to shareholders in July. Dividends declared in the month aggregated $261,774,877 for 880 corporations, compared with $294,880,158 in the preceding month, when 1,350 companies made declarations, and with $172,504,763 by 785 companies in July, 1935.

BERLIN, July 31. -- The rain and cold, which Head Coach Lawson Robertson had declared were ruining his track and field charges, let up today and the sun came out to thaw the frozen muscles of the athletes. There was general rejoicing.

On July 26 The Associated Press reported Father COUGHLIN as telling an audience of farmers in North Dakota that if LEMKE was not elected President "there is only one thing to do -- "repudiate your debts, and if anybody "tries to enforce them, repudiate them "also."
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Democratic National Chairman Farley said today that Negro voters "control the balance of power" in Pennsylvania.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 31. -- John F. Peifer, former night club proprietor, killed himself by taking poison in his cell today two hours after he was sentenced to thirty years' imprisonment for his part as the "fingerman" in the $100,000 kidnapping of William Hamm Jr., St. Paul brewer.

JONES BEACH, L. I., July 31. -- Plaid tams and tartans flashed in the floodlights and the shrill stirring music of bagpipes echoed across the waters of Zach's Bay tonight as the clans of old Scotland appeared from behind painted hills of heather on the water stage to take part in a program presented by the Scottish Clans of Greater New York.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- Reports that negotiations were under way for sale of The Philadelphia Inquirer were frequent in the last few years. On most of these occasions, William Randolph Hearst was mentioned as the prospective purchaser, but Moses L. Annenberg, the new owner, has denied that Mr. Hearst is associated in any way with the present transfer.

PARIS, July 31. -- Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos declared in the Chamber of Deputies today that all the roads were open for a European agreement and that French policy would be directed toward avoiding the creation of two opposed blocs in Europe.
Purchase by a syndicate of a Riverside Drive apartment house featured deals in Manhattan yesterday.
SEATED in a rustic chair under a Westchester tree. Onkel Franz Frisch gazed up at a blue sky and, under occasional spurring, rambled along in a tale of life with the St. Louis Cardinals.
The Democratic National Committee announced yesterday that Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, would broadcast an address on Monday night on Governor Landon as a "practical progressive."

Vermont's teeming poets and prose writers, past and present, have been the subject of more than one recent book. Sometimes the estimate of the Green Mountain State's output in authors, if memory serves, has mounted into the hundreds.
PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- The Bryn Mawr Horse Show will open at the Polo Grounds, Bryn Mawr, on Sept. 23 and continue through Sept. 26.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Germany today formally accepted the invitation to attend a five-power conference to discuss a Western European pact to replace the Locarno treaty, repudiated by the Reich on March 7.

PATERSON, N.J., July 31. -- A substantial number of the small silk manufacturers who are striking for higher prices will probably reopen their plants early next week under a new scale giving them a cent a yard increase in weaving prices.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 31. -- Westchester County lacks adequate airport facilities, is short in suitable dwelling units and juvenile delinquency forms a large proportion of the crime in its cities, according to a report of the Advisory Committee on County Planning sent today to the Board of Supervisors by the county engineer.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 31. The "machine age" triumphed over man here today, and the result was a "payless payday" for about 2,300 employes of the Westchester County government.

KNIGHT INLET, B.C., July 31. -- The main peak of Mount Waddington, hitherto considered unconquerable, was climbed July 21 by Fritz H. Wiessner of New York and William P. House of Pittsburgh it was learned here today.

The Hudson River Day Line, operator of six steamers and owner of property at Indian Point, filed a petition yesterday in Federal court asking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

The Curtis Publishing Company reported a net profit for the first half of this year amounting to $4,107,871, after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. Providing for dividend requirements on the $7 cumulative preferred stock, on which there are arrears, the earnings equaled 60 cents each on 1,790,466 no-par shares of common stock.
PASADENA, Calif., July 31 (AP). -- Upton Sinclair tonight made public a telegram to Governor Landon propounding a question to the Republican Presidential nominee on the latter's labor views.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- A favorable upward trend in scholarship funds, student earnings, placement of alumnae and prospective placement of seniors was reported by Miss Fredericka Belknap, director of the personnel bureau at New Jersey College for Women, in her annual report to Dean Margaret T. Corwin, made public today.

THE world's first photograph was made by Nicephore Niepce, a Frenchman, in the year 1822. That is the statement with which Georges Potonniee begins his "History of the Discovery of Photography"; and although the invention of photography, like most other inventions, presents a somewhat complicated question, the correctness of that statement is acknowledged by authorities, surprising as it may seem to the lay public.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The Summer vacation period in the Poconos and along the Delaware River is at its height and practically every resort in the district is well filled with vacationists. Week-end visitors have caused such an overflow at some centers that private homes have been pressed into service.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 1. -- United States Senator Robert Rice Reynolds of North Carolina today told of his experience last Tuesday when he and his 25-year-old daughter Frances, in company with fifty tourists, were held up by twenty bandits on the road from this city to the Pacific port of Acapulco.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Fred Orsinger of the Bureau of Fisheries started a campaign today to combat the theory that fishermen tell tall tales.

"DAUGHTERS of the Revolution," read the Chinese characters engraved over the huge granite gateway. The great steel gates clang open, and a broad graveled drive is exposed curving up along a low foothill of the Purple Mountain.

A SERIES of musical events has been planned for this Summer at Vichy, France. Every Monday night there are classical concerts, under the direction of prominent orchestra leaders from many countries. Wednesday nights are given over to light and comic operas, such as Jacques Ibert's "Anglique" and Offenbach's "La Belle Helene."

A SMASHING blow in the face, received by Mr. Bushell from a wild denizen of the Papuan jungle, was the beginning of a beautiful friendship, and provided an unusual opening for this record of adventure. Mr. Bushell picked himself up and handed the savage a retaliatory uppercut, which had the effect of cementing the bond of friendship.

JUGGINS, whose real name of Lucy Belle was seldom heard Blue Harbor, because, as her father said, she was as round and as brown as a little brown jug, was a true daughter of the Maine coast. At the age of 8 or thereabouts she knew all there was to know about lobster fishing, and she carried on her own flourishing business in cunners for cats and snails and angleworms for freshwater fishermen.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- A bridge is being built across the chasm which has yawned in the Democratic party of Illinois since the April primary, when the forces of Governor Horner defeated the regular organization. Governor Horner announces that he has reached a complete understanding with Pat Nash, national committeeman, who is also chairman of the Cook County Democratic Committee, and the reputed "boss" of the party.
UNCLE SAM'S pearl oysters are gone -- stolen from the bottom of Kanoehe Bay. They were planted there six years ago; they grew, but most of them have disappeared.

LITCHFIELD Conn. -- Litchfield and the surrounding towns are sending many entries to the horse show, the gala event of the season, scheduled for Aug. 8. This annual event, always marked by sportsmanship and fine performance, will have variety and many new features.
ROME, July 31. -- The developments in Spain are being watched with close attention by the Italian public because it is thought far more than the future of Spain hangs in the balance.

There seems to be some reason and perhaps justification for the feeling by Charles C. Alexander Jr. and Joseph Irwin of the Red Bank regatta committee that the field for the sweepstakes event may stamp it as the premier motor-boat race of the 1936 season, especially in view of the recent fizzle at Lake George of the Gold Cup class.

Jimmy Leto, Hartford welterweight, will encounter Gustave Eder, 147-pound champion of Germany, in the main bout of ten rounds at Ebbets Field on Wednesday night. Leto is seeking a chance at the world's welterweight crown held by Barney Ross and hopes to jump into the front rank of challengers with a victory over Eder.

Special agents of the Long Island Railroad assigned to the refunding of excess fare to holders of refund slips and used tickets had a comparatively easy time of it yesterday when the company began its job of returning to its patrons the difference between the rate charged them since June 2 and the two-cents-a-mile tariff ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission on that date.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Winner of the Longwood Bowl invitation tournament a week ago, Miss Alice Marble of Palm Springs, Calif., today added another notable conquest to her record in her first season of play in the East since 1933.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's forceful warning that disaster may only be averted by calling an economic conference reminds us that Sir Samuel Hoare, George Lansbury, the labor leader, and others made similar proposals. No action has been taken by governments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A larger number of employes on the payrolls of the civil executive branch of the Federal Government than at any time since the peak reached during the World War was shown today in the Civil Service Commission's report for June.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The strike declared here last Wednesday by several hundred small "family mills" against the half-dozen large wholesalers who supply them with raw silk is the latest spasm -- some think it is the last -- in the struggle of silk weavers who used to work for wages to survive as individual business men.

NO one could accuse Cameron Rogers of picking a hackneyed setting for this lively romantic tale. He has written of Manila, in the year 1621 -- a period when the power of Spain in the Philippines was at its impressive height.

SOME psychologist has flippantly said that the average American cannot absorb a new idea after his twenty-fifth birthday. If this is so, it imposes a great burden upon those who can, and it behooves them to be up and doing and at frequent intervals to take stock of their old ideas and decide whether they are still serviceable in this swiftly changing world of ours.

WHETHER American literature gets a "square deal" in Great Britain or not, there can be no doubt that too little is known, on this side of the Atlantic, of the history of the United States. Arthur Bryant whose reputation has been gained as a historian of seventeenth-century England, has been attempting to repair this defect.

The observations of T.F.K. Burgoyne in his letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES are well reasoned and interesting. In one instance, however, the correspondent errs when he says that Poland will be drawn into the Italian-Austrian-German bloc against Russia.

MADRID, Aug. 1 (Passed by the Censor). -- An increasing air of confidence was evident in the capital today as reinforcements of soldiers and sailors detrained from Valencia amid cheering and set out to strengthen the city's ring of defensive forces in the surrounding mountains.

CHANA ORLOFF showed recently at the Leicester Galleries; a Chana Orloff strengthened since her last appearance in New York. Richer and not so mannered as before, her works concern themselves less with decorative effect.

LONGVIEW, Texas. THE cattle rustler -- scourge of the Old West -- is again operating in the Southwest. But he presents a sharp contrast to the burly, lawless "bully" of a past generation. And no longer do cattle owners shoulder their "Long Tom" rifles, form a mounted posse, hunt down the marauder and hang him without benefit of the law.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 1. -- J.P. Morgan, although the largest individual taxpayer in Glen Cove for many years, has saved the payment of taxes on $136,000 of assessed valuation, annually, it was revealed this morning, when the 1937 roll, opened to the public, showed a tract of seventeen acres at Dosoris, that has been omitted from the map until now.

WE should like to tell our little readers here something about the glories of the Commonwealth of Texas, its grandeur, history, cotton and oil and jack-rabbit output and high degree of culture. But it has all been told before.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Johnny Farrell of Baltusrol and ictor Ghezzi of Deal tied today for the New Jersey State open golf championship when they completed the seventy-two-hole test over the par 72 Crestmont Golf Club course in 286, two under regulation figures.

LEWES, Del., Aug. 1. -- "We'll look for guns, for copper, and for teakwood," says Charles N. Colstad, leader of the New England group of submarine salvagers, who are soon to resume the effort to find and raise the treasure sloop "De Braak," which has lain at the bottom of the sea 139 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The progress the Investment Bankers Conference Committee makes in setting up and developing its proposed voluntary nation-wide organization to promote fair practices and aid in bringing about a more effective control in the over-thecounter markets is being watched closely here, as the results will be of importance in connection with future policies of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
New world marks will be the goal for many of the track and field performers at the World Labor Athletic Carnival to be held at Randalls Island on Aug. 15 and 16.

If early purchases are any indication of Fall business, there is an excellent season ahead, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Initial purchases have been increased in most instances.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1. -- The Democratic party continues to sweep ahead of the Republican party in registration of Pittsburgh voters.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The Milton Boat Yards trophy in the first annual invitation race of the Wee Scot Racing Association, held today in Hempstead Harbor by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club, was won by Miss Dorothy Quortrup in Sunshine, when no other boat finished the morning event within the time limit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The farm belt, crippled by drought for the second time since the Roosevelt administration came into power, is again to become the political battleground on which a national election will be lost or won. Crops stand withered in the fields.

Transactions on the Cotton Exchange contracted yesterday to smallest proportions in several weeks, but absence of selling pressure left the list 4 to 9 points up on the day. The tropical storm in the South caused heavy rains in southeastern sections of the belt, with 4.54 inches at Montgomery and 2 to 7 inches at many stations in Alabama and Georgia.

BY redefining Negro population in the South, "with greater exactitude than is done in the census," Mr. Allen has discovered an area of "continuous Negro majority," and has been fascinated by the revolutionary possibilities of a movement to complete the unfinished task of the "Bourgeois Revolution" which began in 1860 and lasted until 1877, with the establishment of a Negro Republic.

Starlight, the savage protagonist of this tale for older children and adults, is a powerfully built Canadian timber wolf, left on his own in early cubhood, and it is his existence, minutely portrayed in all its phases, which provides the narrative's movement.

CREDIT the Norwegian press with an assist for a batch of items about Kirsten Flagstad, the dramatic soprano of the hour. The most significant is that she intends to become an American citizen, because the principal part of her artistic career is carried through in this country.

This mystery novel is frankly experimental, the outcome of a quest for novelty. Believing that the detective story "has a place in literature," the author has apparently sought to adapt the literary "stream of consciousness" method to the uses of crime fiction.

The Democratic "New Deal" party has built up a campaign fund of more than $3,800,000,000, mostly derived from tax funds, to promote the re-election of President Roosevelt, the National Republican Committee charged yesterday.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 1. -- A number of Ambassadors to Spain, now cut off from their San Sebastian Summer establishments, have set up temporary headquarters in a hotel here. In the hotel are the Italian, Czech, Belgian and German diplomatic representatives.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- D. Sefton Delmer, a staff reporter of The London Daily Express, who claims to be the first British journalist to penetrate Somosierra Pass, a key position to Madrid, declares in a dispatch from the headquarters of Colonel Garcia Escamez, in charge of the insurgents' advance on the capital from the war-wrecked village of Robregordo at the mouth of the pass, that he has never seen greater devastation.

WHEN a whole people transforms itself into a fighting force, makes arsenals of its homes, hospitals of its theatres and schools, snipers' nests of its towers and windows and battlefields of its streets, it is writing history on a scale of such magnitude that events cannot be described or grasped in terms of what happens from day to day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Church groups sympathetic to organized labor offered their services today to the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and to the Committee for Industrial Organization in an effort to prevent a "calamitous" split over the craft-industrial union issue.

In its main purpose thee tax imposed upon undistributed corporate earnings as enacted in the Revenue Act of 1936 is reasonably comprehensible; any doubtful phrases contained therein are no doubt capable of administrative interpretation. Despite'the clear intent of the legis-. lation, -however, .there-appears 'to-be absel/t as' of'the time of'its impoSition the necessary basis of fact to justify the levy.

DALLAS, July 31. -- Thomas Landsay Blanton of Abilene, who is in serious danger of losing the Congressional seat he has held for many years, blames his present political troubles upon those who are seeking revenge because of his economy measures against the District of Columbia.

What does a Presidential campaign cost? As national, State and county committees swing into their stride for the coming election, that becomes a pertinent question, for one hears of fabulous sums about to be spent for radio, advertising and organization work, not to mention those "invisible expenses" which are not placed on the records and of which national chairmen prefer to know nothing.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Driving a car while intoxicated was the major offense of twenty-nine drivers in the Manhattan district and sixty-three in the Brooklyn district during the two weeks which ended July 16, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced this today.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Two regattas of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association were held today. In the morning the Bay-head Yacht Club sponsored five events. In the afternoon championship contests were conducted under auspices of the Mantoloking Yacht Club, further down the bay.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1. -- The Pennsylvania of the Panama Pacific Line, which left here this afternoon for New York by way of Acapulco, Panama and Havana, took out 600 passengers, including many homeward-bound Eastern tourists and numbers of Californians on vacation trips.

Instead of offering the larger opportunities as sources of better-grade merchandise for American stores that was anticipated at this time, there is a tendency for European countries to contract as markets due to higher prices, political unrest, dissension and monetary instability, according to I.A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, who recently returned from a survey of conditions abroad.
VIENNA, Aug. 1 (AP). will take an important part in programs of the ninth International Dental Congress, opening here tomorrow.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The United States' participation in the Gordon Bennett International Balloon Race in Poland on Aug. 30 depended tonight on one entry, at present a doubtful one, on the eve of a match race tomorrow night between the two balloons which led the national event a month ago from Denver.

With the expectation of being on the ballot in forty States -- an increase of seven over 1932 -- the Communist party of the United States, under the leadership of Earl Browder, general secretary and Presidential candidate, will start an intensive campaign this week in an attempt to establish itself as an important factor in American political life.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- A full program of sports and social events has been planned for early August in the White Mountains. Today a round of golf events includes exhibition matches at the Mountain View House, Whitefield; the Maplewood Club, where exhibition golf and baseball are Sunday features; Grays Inn Golf Club and the Wentworth Hall Club at Jackson.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Tournament polo comes back tomorrow to one of the famous clubs of the past when the first match of the Eastern-New England Intra-Circuit championship is to be played on the field of the Narragansett Polo Club.

These incidents from the daily life of Sah-mee and Moho, small brother and sister, comprise an introduction for 7 and 8 year old readers to the tribal life of the Hopi Indians. Through their eyes we see the men of the tribe setting out through the desert on a rabbit hunt; the women at home, baking cornbread; a feast for a new baby; the building of a new pueblo.
The conflict in Spain grew last week into something much more than civil war. It took on grave international significance, exposing the jumping nerves of Europe to still another strain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The seizure of the Ford and General Motors plants at Barcelona, Spain, by the Central Committee for Anti-Fascist Militia of Catalonia was officially announced by the State Department today.

Continued improvement in the retail outlook has encouraged retail executives to give more serious attention to plans for expansion than at any time since 1929. While this is by no means a general trend as yet, it was held significant yesterday that real estate developers with attractive locations for suburban branch stores, and owners of establishments which can be fitted into department store groups on favorable terms, are getting more of a hearing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- The Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago today announced the discovery of a new set of sculptures, declared to be among the finest examples of ancient art yet unearthed, in its excavations of Persepolis, Iran, a city built by Darius the Great and his son, Xerxes of Persia, and later destroyed by Alexander the Great of Macedon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A prediction that President Roosevelt would allot another $7,000,000 for continuance this year of the WPA "People's Theatre" program was made today in authoritative administration quarters.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Senator George R. Fearon sharply criticized tonight the Roosevelt administration's "spending of untold billions while at the same time persecuting private business and loading them down with taxes so that they could not recover."

It is a lucky thing for the thousands who spend vacation cruises in the Barnegat Bay region that they have Toms River. Here is a haven that America's early colonists used -- and probably the Indians long years before them -- and now comes the rejuvenation of yachting along the Jersey coast, which makes this splendid harbor one of its principal centers.

In connection with the appeal in Domestic Relations Court of Mrs. Dorothea Longcope Livermore, former wife of Jesse Livermore, Wall Street operator, for funds from Mr. Livermore to pay hospital expenses of their son, Jesse Jr., Samuel P. Gilman, attorney for Mr. Livermore, on behalf of his client, yesterday denied that Mr. Livermore had failed to provide for his son.

Stocks drifted aimlessly in yesterday's half-day session in the slowest trading since June 27. Profit-taking of the day before was not continued in any volume, and the demand for stocks was by no means urgent. The closing was steady and mixed, with THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty issues down slightly on the day.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Dr. Franklin Thorpe swore out an affidavit today charging that his former wife, Mary Astor, had perpetrated a fraud upon the Superior Court in her fight for sole custody of their 4-year-old daughter, Marylyn.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 (AP). -- John F. Gilchrist of New York City has been appointed Special Deputy Motor Vehicle Commissioner to direct a study of highway traffic problems preparatory to establishment of the State Traffic Commission, Mark Graves, Tax Commissioner, said today.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 1. -- George Eastman, the camera manufacturer, who gave the University of Rochester something like $50,000,000, began his gifts in 1902 with a statement he was not interested in higher education.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Tennis week, which marks the climax of the social season here, will begin tomorrow with the opening in the afternoon of the forty-sixth annual invitation tennis tournament held on the courts of the Meadow Club under the sanction of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association.

The improvement in credit conditions in Latin America, indicated in the first quarter of the year, has been broadened in the second quarter, according to the survey of credit and collections released yesterday by the foreign department and Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Cubs nipped the Bees, 1 -- 0, in an eleven-inning thriller today, the Hub's tightest game of the year.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1. -- Despite depressing reports of drought losses, general business in the Eighth Federal Reserve District is encouragingly active. Retail sales are from 10 to 18 per cent ahead of last year, with good collections. Indications point to an excellent demand for Fall goods.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., July 30. -- For a fortnight just ended President Roosevelt has indulged in the rare luxury of doing precisely what he pleased in the environment he has loved best since early boyhood.

WITH THE REBEL ARMY AT ROBREGORDO, Spain, Aug. 1. -- At the rate of progress being made by three of their columns, fighting side by side on a front four and a half miles long, Spanish rebel officers admitted today that at least ten days would be consumed in wresting control of Madrid-bound roads from loyalist troops.

THE remarkable success which the French have had in opening more than sixty of their finest chateaux to tourists is having its effect in other countries. Already the Belgians have opened twenty-two of their chateaux, and now the English are planning to open to public view the most historic of their great country houses.
OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Maine's first Grand Circuit meeting ended today with an unknown 3-year-old filly, Clova, trotting the mile kite-shaped track in 2:03 and 2:04.

CHELSEA, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP). -- New gadgets are getting a final overhauling on Uncle Sam's latest and most modern lightship, soon to take up her vigil on Nantucket Shoals. She will replace Lightship 117, seven of whose crew were drowned on a foggy morning two years ago when the White Star liner Olympic ran her down.

YOU enter the rear courtyard at 422 West Forty-sixth Street through a battered but decorative wrought-iron gate, and the first thing you see there will be the crowded clothesline of the impassive Chinese laundryman whose establishment fronts upon the street itself.

WHEN the public schools shut up shop in Summer one other educational agency steps in to help fill the gap. Though the temperature may hover around the 100 point and all who can manage to do so have escaped from the city the public library keeps on going.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The foremost paddlers in the country, with the exception of the ten men now in Germany representing the United States in Olympic competition, will vie in the seventh annual national canoeing championships on Lake Sebago tomorrow.

WHAT could be more attractive to the seasoned Boy Scout than pitching his tent under the stars and seeing America between nightly campsites? Hundreds of older Scouts are now traveling over the country in specially conducted tours, covering a thousand miles or more.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Thirty-one yachts in eleven divisions set sail off the port of Rochester today in the Lake Ontario fleet's sixteenth annual long-distance handicap race for the Freeman Cup. The course will take the contenders 100 nautical miles to Youngstown, N.Y., on the Niagara River, via the port of Cobourg, Ont., on the Canadian shore.

PERHAPS no volume at once so basic and so fraught with human interest has issued from the Pacific Coast as "Rim of Christendom," by Herbert Eugene Bolton. It is the first complete and authoritative life of Eusebio Francisco Kino, the forceful and fearless seventeenth-century Jesuit priest, yet written.

THE first of the Winter models to be launched are always the furs. It seems odd that, at the peak of the Summer heat the cold-weather garments are ready for our inspection, but the far-sighted woman orders her coat early.

All of the lock masters along the Champlain Canal from Waterford to Whitehall are reporting the busiest season in recent memory of pleasure craft passing through for vacation cruises on Lake Champlain. Burgees of most of the yacht clubs in the metropolitan area are to be found in such popular overnight harbors as Ticonderoga, Crown Point, Westport, Partridge Harbor, Essex, Burlington, Plattsburg and Rouses Point.

Mr. FARLEY'S assertion, after Thursday's conference at Governor LEHMAN'S house, that "we are starting the campaign in every State on Aug. 1," may mean much or little. He refers specifically to organization of Democratic clubs or groups, for work in conjunction with the national committee.

THE radio "cabin" of the S.S. Queen Mary is a mecca for wireless men whenever the giant ship is in port. And there is so much to see that every visit reveals something novel that may have been missed at earlier inspections of this Radio City of the sea.

THIS year many landlubbers will be making their first acquaintance with the sea and ships. Numerous articles have been written on the subject by experienced "cruisites," but let us look at it from a seaman's point of view, and, incidentally, correct a few wrong impressions.
A course in cosmetic hygiene will be given next semester at the School of Education of New York University, it was announced yesterday, by Dean John W. Withers of the School of Education.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 31. -- Conservative opposition to the Roosevelt administration in California has expressed itself openly and vigorously in opposition to the migratory labor camp program of the Resettlement Administration.

IT is comforting to note that the dance, which has long been branded as the most illiterate of the arts, is taking steps in various directions to free itself from this opprobious epithet. One of these steps is seen in the announcement by the H.W. Wilson Company that it is to bring out in November a bibliography of dancing, made by Paul Magriel and concerned largely with works available in American libraries.

THIS is the country of rebellion. A few miles from this hilly town Thomas Jefferson nourished the ideas that resulted in the Declaration of Independence. In this vicinity Patrick Henry mused upon the desirability of death over serfdom. The near-by countryside is dotted with markers recalling the engagements which occurred during the war between the States.

GARDENERS who are bent on securing a succession of bloom with plenty of color at all seasons are often at a loss to know what to select for the hot weeks of midsummer. Among the stanch and true perennial herbs which can be counted on for mass bloom during this period are the several bergamots or monardas -- the beebalm of old gardens.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The entries from Louis Kaiser's Terre Haute Farm of Bethel, Conn., enjoyed the lion's share of the honors as the second annual two-day Elberon Horse Show opened on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Weil today.

TELEVISION from the Empire State Building is reaching Westchester and delivering the images clearly, according to one of the official observers. And despite the fourteen control gadgets he finds the receiver comparatively simple to operate.
JUST as history repeats itself, radio again played an important role in the latest Spanish revolution, as it did during the previous uprising in October, 1934.

Generally firmer prices ruled here in the markets for commodity futures in the week ended on Friday, tin and sugar being among the weak exceptions. In the cash markets all grains, dairy products, wool tops, cocoa, lard, silk and rubber advanced, while cotton, raw sugar, gasoline and tin declined.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Donald Hawley of Orange, former New York University ace, and Eddie DeGray of Brooklyn, North Carolina University captain, gained the final of the Northern New Jersey tennis championship at the Westfield Tennis Club today.

WITH the vacation travel tide at its highest in several years, the railroad station becomes, in these August days, the greatest popular gathering place in the land. Full streams of free and footloose wayfarers flow in and out by way of ferry, bridge, tunnel, steamship dock, bus terminal and airport, but the main flood pours through the railroad station.

ENCOURAGING results have been obtained during recent tests conducted by the United States Coast Guard of a cathode ray radio direction finder submitted by the Airplane and Marine Direction Finder Corporation of Lindenhurst, L.I.

THE TIMES editorial in today's issue, captioned "World Wheat Shortage," points out clearly one result of the shortsightedness of planning by government bodies as compared with the play of natural forces. In the long run, and very often in the short run, too, the combined results of each person's intelligent self-interest are better for all the people than the more or less disinterested decrees of politicians.

Apple growers are destroying thousands of bearing trees because of inadequate foreign markets, E.W.P. Hearty, chairman of the foreign trade committee of the International Apple Association, said yesterday. He spoke at a meeting of the directors of the World Two-Way Trade Fair, to be held in the Port Authority Building in November.

BECAUSE of the success of the festival of American music last May by the Westminster Choir School of Princeton, N.J., the board of directors of the school has decided to make the festival an annual event. To assure a large representation of American composers in these annual festivals of choral and chamber music, the National Association of American Composers and Conductors will cooperate with the school.

SO far as planting and cultivating are concerned, the garden reaches its lowest point -- outside of the Winter months -- during August. This is especially true when the customary hot, dry weather of July extends over into that period which may combine the most undesirable features of both late Summer and early Autumn.

GRANT, Neb., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Sterling W. Powell, 16-year-old farm youth who admitted writing a letter threatening the life of Shirley Temple, child film star, unless her father paid him $25,000, was free under $1,000 bond tonight to await action of a Federal grand jury.

SALEM, Ore., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Seven hundred howling prisoners shattered window panes, banged cell doors and turned the Oregon penitentiary into bedlam today in a shouting demand for food, denied them after a fatal riot yesterday.

Asey Mayo has left Cape Cod. But not permanently. Fate has lured him to the Berkshires in mid-winter, for no more serious purpose than to win a silly-sounding bet for a friend. Hurrying up by plane from Jamaica in a linen suit and white shoes, he is at once lost in a blizzard, and walks into murder in a snow-bound world.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke offered a five-fold program tonight with a promise that he would put it into effect if the Union Party elected him President.
VALPARAISO, Chile, the largest port on the west coast of South America, will celebrate 400 years of existence this coming September.
IT is the unanimous verdict of all students of economics that there are serious evils existing under capitalism. No sane man questions this conclusion."

Professor John Gilmore of the School of Agriculture at Stanford University, California, who returned last week on the steamship Santa Clara of the Grace Line from four months spent in Chile as agricultural adviser to the Chilean Government, said that we had been "trying to help Chile escape the agricultural ills which now beset the United States."

JUAREZ. -- From Matamoras, near the Gulf of Mexico, to Tiajuana on the Pacific, the Mexican border towns are preparing anew to open the gambling resorts that were closed by order of President Lazaro Cardenas immediately after his inauguration.

Looking forward to the best Fall season in five years, retailers in the department store field anticipate a general sales increase of 12 per cent over 1935 during September, October and November, with the estimated gains for some principal cities ranging up to 20 per cent, according to the results of a nation-wide survey issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Business activity generally showed a further improvement in July after allowance for the customary seasonal contraction, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- With farm prices at the highest general level since 1930 as a result of the protracted drought, market analysts today forecast that 1936 farm income might be the largest in six years, barring further serious crop losses.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- In an indirect way the French Government today permitted aid to Madrid by authorizing Frenchmen to fight against Spanish Fascists. The government authorized citizens to fight in the civil war provided they carried "regular passports." Diplomats said the passport stipulation effectively limited volunteers to those who met with the approval of the Spanish Leftist government.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 1. -- All good Harvard men know the words of "Fair Harvard," but not one in a thousand knows the name of the man who wrote the lines, largely because the author is not credited in any of the Harvard songbooks.

IT'S a pleasure to work hard, and I'm greatly indebted to my associates" are the reasons John Root gives for his remarkable rise as a scenic designer. Mr. Root is very modest. Mr. Root has also designed and supervised the execution of most of the scenery seen in the two-year history of the Red Barn Theatre in Locust Valley (in addition, of course, to his work on Broadway).

Recent explosions on motor yachts, even though accidents and fatalities such as occurred last month at Whitestone, L.I., are rare, have served to emphasize the importance and significance of the studies which have been in progress for several months by the Motor Craft Committee of the Marine Section of the National Fire Protection Association.

THREE outstanding areas, encompassing at least 860,000 acres, will soon become a part of the National Park system. These regions -- the Everglades of Florida, Isle Royale in Lake Superior and Big Bend of Southwestern Texas -- have been approved, and only title to the land remains to be acquired.

IN spite of its title, and the colored representations of jacket and frontispiece, this book is not concerned with sea shells as we commonly use that term. What Mr. Verrill is writing about is shell animals of the sea. Some of them even have no shells.

"COMPARATIVELY speaking," began the Englishman. Then he shook his head. "No," he decided, "there is no true basis for comparison. The fundamental factors are too different. Our two continents have less in common than they had a few years ago. We live in the same world -- you cannot escape that fate! -- but as far apart in outlook as a fortieth-story window from the ground floor.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 1. -- Information reaching the French border bears out previous reports that a woman, known throughout Spain as La Passionaria, is playing a major role in the War Ministry in Madrid. She is regarded as a messiah by the workers, whom she has championed since her entry into politics ten years ago.
The New York and Metropolitan District circuit cricket game played at Hoboken yesterday between the Brooklyn eleven and the Crescent A.C. went to the New Mooners by a margin of 57 runs.

Times have greatly changed since Dr. Gustavus Augustus Eisen, an authority on ancient relics, who has published some 150 scientific works and delved deeply in the fields of geology, geography, anthropology and archaeology, came here sixty-three years ago.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Gladys MacKnight lighted another cigarette shortly after 4 o'clock this morning, pushed aside a ham sandwich, settled herself more comfortably in her chair and, with the calm deliberateness of one who weighs the import of every syllable, made a graphic confession of the murder last evening of her mother, Mrs. Helen MacKnight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The productivity per employe of the printing, publishing and allied industries has reached such a high level that these industries can contribute very little toward reducing the large number of unemployed workers, according to a report of the Council for Industrial Progress, made public today by George L. Berry, Industrial Coordinator.

Three months from this Tuesday we vote, thereby precipitating ourselves -- if the orators are to be believed -- past the crossroads on which we now are poised, listening to a lot of campaign importunings and observing a plethora of political manoeuvres. Last week, as the campaign neared the three-month stretch, there was much electioneering activity.

FORT NIAGARA, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The 600 Western New York boys of the Citizens Military Training Camp battalion here have gained over a ton in weight during their twenty-four days of training, according to a medical report to Colonel Hiram M. Cooper, post commander.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 1. -- A gasoline explosion and fire aboard a 40-foot cabin cruiser, used as a tender to the America's Cup Class sloop Weetamoe endangered close to $1,000,000 worth of yachts in the harbor today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Battles for the Gubernatorial nomination are the major races in Missouri's primary election Tuesday.

The steamship Magallanes of the Spanish Line arrived yesterday with sixty-eight passengers for New York and 103 in transit for Mexican ports. She is the first Spanish ship to arrive here from Spain since the revolt began.
The schedule for the newly organized American Professional Football League has been announced. The season will open Sept. 20 and extend to Nov. 29.

A RAPID-FIRE story of private and public intrigue in Mexico, "Under Pressure" lives up to its title. Joyce Sewell, its 20-year-old American heroine, bears up valiantly under the pressure of official and unofficial opposition to her efforts to claim her lawful inheritance, an enormous and beautiful hacienda called La Barranca.

THIS is a mystery novel which is going to be talked about; and that not alone for the brilliance and sardonic humor which have already made Richard Hull's crime stories famous. Over "Murder Isn't Easy" will rage, unless we are much mistaken, some furious discussion -- how far is the author justified in the trick by which he brings his story to its "unguessable" end?

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 1. -- State police today examined Anna Balls, 34 years old, of this city, in an effort to solve the mysterious slaying of Thomas Bradshaw, 42 year old, a deputy game warden of Sugar Notch. According to the woman's story, he was killed late last night while they were seated on a log in a clearing near Bear Creek.

FORT RILEY, Kan., Aug. 1. -- Governor Landon today stepped out of his role as a Presidential candidate and, as Governor, reviewed the Sixtieth Field Artillery Brigade of the National Guard, which is encamped here.

INGENIOUS and amusing, old-fashioned mechanical penny banks in their varied forms are becoming collectors' items -- Americana. These painted metal toys incorporate human and animal figures which can be made to perform by inserting a penny.

DAVE OLIVER was a Universal newsreel reporter before he became a screen comedian by the simple expedient of giving himself his own screen test. It happened this way: Bored to desperation by the routine of filming 1936 Irish Sweepstakes winners, Dave donned a silly little hat, went before his own camera and created a burlesque character, John Q. Dohp, a ticket-holder who lost.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary completed a westward crossing of the Atlantic last week in less time than any ship ever took before -- but her owners are not claiming the blue speed-record pennant from the French liner Normandie.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- With more than one million votes east during the first week of the nation-wide contest, Bernie Bierman of Minnesota tonight held a commanding lead in the poll to select a staff of coaches for the squad of former college stars which will battle the Detroit Lions at Soldier Field the night of Sept. 1.

A FEW months ago they revived Lady Gregory's "The Rising of the Moon" at the Abbey Theatre -- that pleasant, half-poetic, half-comic little play about the Fenian who in trying to escape from the police finds himself, on the quayside, sitting on a barrel side by side with the sergeant in charge of his pursuers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Former Governor Myers Y. Cooper of Ohio said tonight he would serve as aide to John D.M. Hamilton, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, in directing the campaign to elect Governor Landon to the Presidency.

MOST of us are content to advertise our egos as democrat, aristocrat or plutocrat. The clan of Sitwell has devised a less ordinary standard of distinction. They appear as idiosyncrats, if the word be permitted, and Edith, the sister, in her Who's Who biography, sets forth that "in early youth" she took "an intense dislike to simplicity.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 1. -- The forty-fifth midsummer series opened auspiciously today with the first of the Eastern Yacht Club's trio of regattas equaling last year's grand total of 357 starters and breaking the first day's record by twenty-four boats.
KNOXVTLLE, Tenn., Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today the Norris Dam powerhouse in Northeastern Tennessee has been put in operation.

How do people look with rifle and revolver behind a barricade? This question may occur to THE TIMES reader this morning as he laces on his shoes for a game of tennis or steps into the car for a long drive in the country, or gets his nickels at the subway booth on his way to Coney Island.

A MILLION or more brick walls, indoors and out, are resounding this Summer to the dull thud of rubber balls batted violently by enthusiasts of every age, ranging in status from street urchin to bank president. The simple-looking but deceptive game of handball is a hobby which has claimed millions of participants, though few spectators.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Disposed strategically in the lower Hudson Valley and moving as methodically as an army are the field units of New York State's biological survey.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1. -- The lead of the Yankees in the American League pennant race soared back to nine and one-half games today as they inflicted their second straight defeat on the Indians before a gathering of 15,000 at League Park.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. -- As a climax to the yachting season in island waters the New York Club cruising fleet will visit Edgartown. Their arrival on Aug. 15, after a run from Mattapoisett, will mark their first visit to Edgartown in more than half a century.

MUCH as Mayor La Guardia may wish to reward the city's 800,000 motor vehicle owners for a five months' low record of accidents by having automobile insurance rates reduced, the prospects of any such decrease in the immediate future are not very rosy.

Hundreds of delegates, representing the more than 100,000 residents of Eastern Nova Scotia who have been reached by the cooperative organizations and the cultural clubs of the Xaverian Movement of St. Francis Xavier University of Antigonish, will meet at the university to take part in its fourteenth annual rural and industrial conference on Aug. 19, 20 and 21, it was announced yesterday.

The slightly more liberal attitude of the Federal Trade Commission toward certain trade practice conference rules was regarded yesterday as one of the chief reasons why so many industries have again decided to try self-government through the commission.

AN exhibition of manifold interest opened on Wednesday at the Federal Art Project Gallery, 7 East Thirty-eighth Street. Water-colors and drawings by artists of the Easel Painting and Graphic Arts Project of the WPA comprise the material displayed, and more than 100 works in all are on view.
BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The government air force announced today that the rebel garrison on the Island of Cabrera in the Balearic chain had surrendered after a heavy bombardment.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1. -- The Soviet Union observed the twenty-second anniversary of the outbreak of the World War by filling its press today with warnings of a new conflict and predicting that, should imperialist governments precipitate it they would unloose revolutionary forces among their own people that would destroy them.

THE National Association of Gardeners, with headquarters at 1,270 Sixth Avenue, New York, will hold its twenty-sixth annual convention at Hotel Douglas, Newark, N.J., from Aug. 18 to 20. Several prominent estate owners, a number of leading horticultural concerns of Northern New Jersey and the Park Commissions of Essex and Union Counties are cooperating with the convention committee in preparing the program.

DELPHOS, Ohio, Aug. 1. -- Among the thousands gazing into the heavens from city housetops and open places to get a look at the Peltier comet are many who ask, "How is it this man Peltier finds comets when the astronomers in big observatories, with far more powerful lenses, miss them?"

In sharp contrast with conditions which prevailed last year, when record packs were produced, the country faces a heavy drop in the output of many types of canned fruits and vegetables as the result of the widespread damage to crops by the drought in most of the leading producing centers, distributors stated here yesterday.

GENEVA, July 31. -- Prospects for reform of the League at the September Assembly, judging from recent developments, seem more likely to be determined before then by the evolution of Anglo-French and Nazi-Fascist policies rather than by the various proposals for revision of the covenant, which the League of Nations sections in the different foreign offices are now dutifully elaborating.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (By Wireless). -- Sir Hubert Wilkins has learned to his keen disappointment that he cannot obtain a British-made submarine for his projected under-ice voyage through the North Polar region in 1937. His plans have been balked by Great Britain's action in speeding up her new naval construction program.

IN a collection of old books and early Americana in the Alexandria (Va.) Library, long neglected and now being classified, one of the eleven known copies of Captain William Bligh's diary of the voyage of H.M.S. Bounty has come to light.

EVENING SHADE, Ark., Aug. 1. -- A slight mix-up involving $200, the Resettlement Administration, the Townsend Pension Plan and a second-hand merry-go-round has just about made George E. Marlin, Maxville farmer, an independent business man.

ATLANTA, Aug. 1. -- Substantial increases in both wholesale and retail sales were reported in the Sixth Federal Reserve District this week. A group of leading department stores revealed the volume of trade exceeded the same period a year ago by 15 to 20 per cent and wholesale orders were approximately 12 to 16 per cent greater than in the 1935 period.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Rev. George W. Knepper, pastor of the High Street Church of Christ, invited a union picket who paraded before the building today "to make himself perfectly at home and be comfortable."

In one important respect the campaign of 1936 begins with the traditional roles of the two major parties reversed. The advocates of centralization and the apostles of home rule have shifted sides. It is the Republican party, historically the advocate of a strong central Government in Washington, which now complains that the Roosevelt Administration is "constantly" seeking to usurp the rights "reserved to the States."

CARMEL, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- With 297 entries in the thirty-three events scheduled, the two-day horse show of the Putnam County Driving and Riding Club opened today before a large crowd which saw Paps, a bay mare, owned by Jack Spratt of Westbury, L.I., win the open jumping and thus qualify for the $200 event tomorrow.

GENEVA, Aug. 1. -- The World Jewish Congress, opening here Aug. 8, will devote one special session to the present situation in Palestine, its organization committee announced here yesterday after the arrival of its head, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- A gray sky that threatened rain without ever really fulfilling that threat lowered today over the opening ceremonies of the eleventh and greatest Olympic Games of modern times. It was not a misfortune, because there stood out in sharper relief all the brilliant coloring of this most picturesque of ceremonies, which comes only once every four years.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Dr. Walter A. Maier of the faculty at Concordia Lutheran Theological Seminary, St. Louis, charged here tonight in an attack on the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin that "the voice behind that radio priest is the voice of his church."

ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, Aug. 1 -- Fulfilling general expectations, due to his 1-point lead and the further fact that he was pitted against one of the tail-enders in the race, Reuben Fine of the Marshall Chess Club of New York, today captured the first prize in the international chess masters tournament at the Grand Hotel when he drew his game in the eleventh and final round with G.R.D. van Doesburgh of Bussum.

THIS is the year's big week for fanciers of the gladiolus in the metropolitan district. At their annual show, opening next Friday at 2:30 P.M. at Horticultural Hall, Rockefeller Center, new gladioli of every form, size and color from the world over will be displayed.
