CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- William L. Hutcheson, president of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, was credited tonight with having the inside track for one of the key appointments of the Republican campaign, that of chief of the labor section.

THE salty poetry of Wilbert Snow is already known to many readers. And where known it is prized as something distinctive. In the present book Mr. Snow presents what he likes best out of his several collections.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 1. -- With some of the best known Protestant clergymen in this country and Great Britain on the program the General Conference of Christian Workers, founded by Dwight L. Moody, opened here this evening.

In the five weeks that have elapsed since the enactment of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Act, the efforts of large retail combinations "to secure additional discounts and similar concessions have decreased perceptibly," according to a report sent yesterday to the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and chairman of the fair trade practice committee of the board.

SPRING LAKE, N.J. -- With gayety and good-fellowship as the keynote, this resort colony is stepping up its activity as it has not done in many years. Supper clubs, grills and hotels are gay with week-end programs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The old combination of Discovery and Johnny Bejshak proved unbeatable today in the historic Saratago Handicap as they came through the stretch together to win the $10,900 mile-and-a-quarter test for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt before 12,000 persons, including Governor Lehman and Lord Beatty.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., Aug. 1. -- The Buffalo West Side Club's powerful crew today won the final for senior eights at the Royal Canadian Henley Regatta and shared honors in the feature events of the closing card with Herb Miller of the Toronto Argonauts, who carried off the championship singles title.

Tammie, the indomitable little Scottie, who on one famous occasion quite firmly declined to be left at home while his family went picnicking, makes his second appearance in this picture book. This time his bewhiskered black nose is sadly out of joint.

THIS adventure story of a search for lost Atlantis is jacketed in fulsome praise from England, where it is a best seller. Various English critics found it exciting, thrilling, well written, absurd, inimitable, irresistible -- to a thesaurus-exhausting degree.

The most intensive scrutiny of manufacturing, selling and shipping costs, which American business has ever undertaken, will be one of the chief results of the Robinson-Patman anti-price discrimination law, which, more than any piece of legislation previously enacted, demands that sellers justify every quotation on their price lists, accountants and management engineers agreed here yesterday.

THE COUNTRY WIFE" -- with Ruth Gordon as that astonishing young lady -- is starting its second season of imminent production. Just a year ago they were all saying that almost any Monday would find the show right on Broadway, but Summer is the season for conversation and nothing much came of it.

A NEW chamber-music organization, to be known as the Coolidge Quartet, has just been established, according to announcement made by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress. The personnel of the string ensemble consists of William Kroll and Nicolai Berezowsky, violins; Nicholas Moldovan, viola, and Victor Gottlieb, 'cello.

BOSTON, July 31. -- Leaders in both political parties hold that Massachusetts, Democratic for six years, is good fighting territory today. The Republicans are unified and enthusiastic. They are advertising their "rejuvenation," while the Democrats are divided.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- All of the drama in today's grandiose opening of the Eleventh Olympic Games was not to be found on the flamboyant red and green floor of the Olympic Stadium. More persons heard than saw the opening ceremonies anyway.

OUR prize play competition has been open only a little over two months, and yet we have already received over a thousand communications. They have poured in from almost every State in the Union, but the greatest number come from the larger Eastern cities and the small towns surrounding them, with New York well in the lead. Outside of Ohio, Wisconsin, California and Texas, the Western States lag far behind.

More than 1,000 bridge players, including virtually all of the nation's ranking stars, will gather at Asbury Park, N.J., tomorrow for the opening of the tenth Summer tournament of the American Bridge League. Seven championships will be decided in the eight days of play.

RABAT, French Morocco, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Italian fliers seized in French Morocco when they were forced down ostensibly during a flight to rebel headquarters in Spanish Morocco were delivering supplies from a private Italian concern, their chief pilot was quoted today as having said. Six of the eleven fliers taken into Custody by French officials in Afrt Continued on :Page Whlr-one

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- August brings to a head Summer activities in the colonies along the eastern shore of Lake Champlain and among the Green Mountains of Vermont. Hotels and tourist resorts report the best season in half a dozen years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Bill Dietrich, bespectacled righthander who was picked up on waivers from the Athletics by the White S0x twelve days ago, allowed only two of the Red Sox to get on base today, and the Chicagoans evened the series with a 3-0 triumph.

THE common problem of the one-room rural school united representatives of thirty-seven nations of all shades of political feeling in a harmonious conclave in Geneva last month. American delegates, returning from the fifth International Conference on Public Instruction, report that politics was forgotten as officials from five continents discussed their similar struggles to give the country child something more nearly approximating city educational opportunities.

RADIO showmen are watching the several community sing broadcasts to see if the idea "catches" with the unseen audience. Some of the program scouts are willing to believe that mass singing is already a new radio "vogue"; others call it a "cycle" and they are hopeful the idea might spread to win such popularity as the amateur hour as a new fad.

SYDNEY, Australia. -- Australia's action in making drastic tariff changes is admittedly an experiment and follows the year-long investigations of Sir Henry Gullett, Minister of Trade Treaties, in various parts of the world.

THE Alpine climbing season is now in full stride, and the mountain huts in Switzerland, Austria, the Dolomites, the Chamonix-Mont Blanc country and along the Italian side of the frontier are more crowded than ever.

FABIEN SEVITZKY, as director of the fourth annual music festival at Little Boar's Head N.Y., presented a three-day program of symphonic, choral and operatic works, including a production of "Cavalleria Rusticana," which was both staged and conducted by him.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- A formidable list of entries is being completed for the Middle Atlantic States Tennis Tournament, to be held from Aug. 11 to 15. Matches will be played on the courts at Surrey and Newport Avenues.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Under a handy ride from Jockey Freddy Smith, B.N. Kane's Go Quick earned brackets in the Lexington Handicap, mile and a furlong feature of the week-end program today at Suffolk Downs. The victor returned $13 for $2 in the mutuels.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos informed the Cabinet Council today that the Foreign Office was making an inquiry into the mission of the Italian planes forced down in French Morocco. He declared the Foreign Office was following the matter closely and would report as soon as there were any developments.

A PHILOSOPHER of that school called Getters of the Last Laugh, Anne Nichols is known to the excitable show business as a serene lady untroubled by, for instance, the opinions of dramatic critics. Just now, you would think, she ought to be quite as serene as ever, since a play of which she is producer and co-author is going amiably along at the Lyceum.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 1. -- A new track record was created by A.X. Barnhart's chestnut racing mare, Wedgemere Widow, in the first heat of the Class A trot or pace on the light harness racing program at the Borough Park track today.

When John J. Honigmann wrote his criticism of THE TIMES comments on "Father Coughlin's facts," specifically the function of Federal Reserve notes, he would have saved himself considerable effort, intellectual effort, if he had understood what the Constitution means when it empowers Congress "to coin money [and] to regulate the value thereof."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The latest development toward the "dairymen's dream" of complete electrification, an electric eye that grades milk according to color, was announced today by the research laboratory of the New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Rutgers University.
MADRID, Aug. 1. -- Every man capable of carrying a gun was mobilized at Saragossa to fling his strength against loyalist troops marching on the city from the East and the West.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Conditions existing on U.S. Route 9 between Albany and Saratoga are a "blight on the countryside and a growing peril to motor traffic," the State Planning Council declared today in making public the results of a survey recently conducted by engineers of the council.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- After making a study of flood control and relief problems in three New England States, President Roosevelt arrived at his home here at 10:41 o'clock tonight.

Though engineers have damned it for economic reasons, the President has lost neither Faith nor interest in Passamaquoddy. It would be unjust to attribute his declared intention of harnessing its tides solely to the improvement of his political chances in Maine.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- The sideshows and the circus ended for the athletic army tonight with the conclusion of the magnificent spectacle of the opening Olympic ceremonies. Tomorrow parade uniforms will give way to running togs, measuring tapes will replace the measured cadence of marching feet and starters' guns will sound instead of the blare of martial music.

Charging that "waste of manpower and money" on WPA projects was destroying the morale of the unemployed and contending that only a transfer of responsibility from the government to private contractors could avert a "national calamity," Joseph S. Byrne, Brooklyn lawyer, made public yesterday his resignation as chairman of the WPA's council of the plumbing and heating industries here.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 1. -- Finishes in the fourteenth championship events of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound provided so many surprises that committeemen and officials were still discussing them after all had come ashore at the Stamford Yacht Club tonight.

ABOUT a year ago a prominent theatrical figure gave friendly warning to Hallie Flanagan: "Organize a Federal Theatre? Don't you know theatre people? Why, they're unstable, dishonest, temperamental individualists!

TOPEKA, July 31. -- Hopeful of a favorable result of the election and confident in his ability, if elected, to restore the Federal Government to a constitutional and efficient basis and to put the nation on what he regards as the true road to recovery by less governmental interference with business, Governor Landon remains for the present in Topeka, preparing for his first invasion of the East.

LONDON, July 31. -- Prospects that the proposed five-power Locarno conference will be held in the Autumn have been materially brightened by the sudden acceptance by both Germany and Italy of the invitations extended to them last week by England, France and Belgium.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The dinner dance held tonight at the Beach House of the Apawamis Club in Rye attracted a large gathering.

PARIS. THE beach parade which at present encircles the coasts of France and Italy with bright leis of naiads shows a reaction in favor of the ultra-feminine costume. Venus 1936 rises from the foam in gauzy draperies with necklaces of flowers, birds, shells or hippocampi.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 1 -- The Wyantenuck Country Club golf tournament ball tonight, with more than three hundred present, was an outstanding society event of the South Berkshire season. One hundred dined at the Club.

SUMMER is the most difficult time to have a generous display of bloom in the shrub border, since the majority of species bloom in the Spring. But the usual very drab and uninteresting mid-season effect may be avoided if a special effort is made to select those plants which bloom during the months of July and August.

ENGLAND and France will be represented at the ten-day White Top folk conference which opens tomorrow at Marion, Va., and at the White Top folk festival on White Top Mountain, near Marion, Aug. 14 and 15. Major Raven-Hart of France has arrived to attend the conference, classes and festival, while the English Folk Dance and Song Society is represented by Captain and Mrs. Kettlewell, for many years prominent in the folk music movement in England.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- All Americans, except John Hughey Woodruff, lanky Pittsburgh negro 800-meter star, drew comparatively soft berths today when the International Amateur Athletic Federation, revising a previous decision, announced the draw for preliminary heats in the Olympic 100-meter dash and 800-meter run.

Motor accidents in the United States killed 15,390 persons in the first six months of 1936. That is 500 -- or 3 per cent -- fewer than in the corresponding period of 1935. (Statistics compiled last week by the National Safety Council.)

A COLLECTION of unpublished poems by A.E. Housman is to be issued in October by Alfred A. Knopf. These poems were discovered after Housman's death in Cambridge last April and were secured by Blanche W. Knopf during her recent visit to England.

WHEN President Roosevelt visited Canada last week he was only doing as the first citizen of the United States, something which he has been in the habit of doing fairly regularly as an ordinary citizen, bent on a sailing 'and fishing holiday.

Conditions for the women's national sailing championship, to be held by the Cohasset Yacht Club on Massachusetts Bay, have been sent out by the North American Yacht Racing Union to the yacht associations and clubs.

SOME interesting planes for special purposes have been delivered of late. Amelia Earhart has taken delivery in California of her special Lockheed Electra, purchased through the cooperation of Purdue University of Lafayette, Ind., with which she is associated as consultant in aeronautics.

WITH a fanfare of trumpets, they hoisted the five-ringed Olympic flag to the peak above a packed stadium it Berlin. The games are under way. What the eyewitnesses of the imposing scene have to say will be found elsewhere. This is an account of how it sounded to the ear at a great distance.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The new $114,000 postoffice here was dedicated this afternoon at ceremonies which also marked the laying of the cornerstone of the building erected with PWA funds.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Two large dancing parties and many dinners were held here tonight, the liveliest of the Summer season thus far.

The new Lloyd's Register of Shipping, the 103d annual issue since the reconstitution of the society in 1834, is now being circulated to subscribers, it was announced yesterday. The 1936-37 edition, as it is called, includes a detailed record of upward of 31,000 steamships, motor ships, sailing vessels and non-propelled craft.
BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The International Maritime tennis championships, held annually at the Bar Harbor Club, will get under way tomorrow and thus begin a lively week.
Two aspects of British foreign policy -- desire for peace and cooperation with Germany on the one hand and fear of Nazi rearmament and aims on the other -- became more pronounced last week.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 1. -- The past forty-eight hours have brought about a sudden change in the Palestine Arabs' policy, particularly in their attitude toward the forthcoming royal commission of inquiry.

As we approach the seventh anniversary of the downturn in business which marked the opening of the depression in America, the new high records being established by a number of industries in the face of continued widespread unemployment make important a reappraisal of the extent of recovery to date, its character, and the outlook for further progress.

SHAWANO, Wis., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Shawano County authorities issued a first degree murder warrant today for La Verne Marks, 19-year-old minister's son who, Tacoma police said, has confessed slaying his chum, Robert Bernstein, 24, "on impulse."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Elaborate refinancing plans for four department-store subsidiaries of the Federated Department Stores, Inc. -- Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn; Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., New Fork; William A. Filene's Sons company; Boston; F. Lazarus Co., Columbus -- were disclosed today in the application for registration of 140,000 shares of $100-par 4 1/4 per cent convertible preferred stock filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Federated Stores.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A second controversy in thirteen months over administration of the Virgin Islands was climaxed today by the transfer of Federal Judge Albert Levitt.
PARIS, July 31. -- Throughout Europe, divided as it is into Left and Right camps far more even than by national frontiers, the sound of gunfire in Spain during the past week has echoed ominously.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The efficiency of the State Department and the foreign service has been strikingly demonstrated in the emergency precipitated by the revolution in Spain, which required the government to conduct the first evacuation of Americans from a European country since the World War.

One of the benefits of being a good golfer is the opportunity to widen your circle of friends. Golfing friendships of junior days can last through the years until you find yourself, still competing, a senior.

Activity increased last week in the calling of bonds for redemption before maturity, when notices exceeded in number the calls made a week before. The prepayments, principally for public utility, foreign and railroad bonds, are to be effected in later months. Several small refundings lifted the total for July slightly.

Trade improvement continued along all major fronts in the metropolitan area last week. Retail trade bettered the showing of the previous week, with department store sales volume locally estimated at 15 to 17 per cent above the comparative 1935 week.

A membership drive under the sponsorship of Dr. Sigismund S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, has been inaugurated to raise $17,000 for the Social Service Auxiliary of the Cancer Institute, 124 East Fifty-ninth Street, which is confronted by a financial crisis.

The first two units of a Democratic motor trailer caravan of sixty vehicles, fully equipped to spread the New Deal gospel from coast to coast as part of the campaign to re-elect President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner, were sped on their way yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman.
ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The tenth annual national bridge championship tournament will be held in Convention Hall here beginning Monday and continuing through Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- Industrial activity in the Federal Reserve district has been well sustained since April at the highest level since 1930. The Reserve Bank's adjusted index for June rose to 86, compared with 85 in May, 88 in April and 74 a year ago.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:
OMAHA, July 31. -- The Corn Belt is hoping that it has seen the worst, if not the last, of the drought.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reflected the midsummer holiday atmosphere as pivotal issues drifted about aimlessly in narrow price limits. Although the market for domestic corporate loans remained steady to firm, speculative interest in secondary and lower-priced issues was suspended, as the mid-week advance in many railroad liens was halted.
PARIS, Aug. 1. -- In view of the attitude of certain other powers, France reserves the right to send arms to Spain, it was announced tonight in a statement issued by the Quai d'Orsay.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Tigers went into third place today, displacing the Red Sox, downing Washington, 13 to 4, in a slugging spree led by Al Simmons, who hit two home runs and two singles in five times at bat.

Contrary to the usual seasonal trend, business in general showed further improvement last week, with no indications of any serious recessions to come this month. Operations in many industries continued at the highest level since 1930 and, in some instances, the 1929 rate was even surpassed, particularly in the consumer goods branches.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- During two periods in July when direct relief was cut off for more than half a million Pennsylvanians, 68.1 per cent of the Philadelphia families who had been relying on thee County Relief Board for their existence lived on credit obtained from neighborhood merchants, friends, relatives, neighbors and landlords.

EASTPORT, Me., July 31.--President Roosevelt's surprise visit to the Passamaquoddy tidal power generation project on Thursday left the interested natives encouraged for the distant future of the scheme but resigned to the closing down of the work early next month.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Democratic and Republican county chairmen of twelve counties neighboring Schenectady, as well as Mayors of various political allegiance, are to meet in mirth and harmony for once, at least, during the present political campaign if President Dixon Ryan Fox of Union College succeeds in a conciliatory plan which became public today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Mathematicians at Princeton University and the near-by Institute of Advanced Study are apparently becoming "chess-minded." For it was learned today that during the last college year they not only succeeded in perfecting three complicated variations of ordinary chess, but in addition mastered a 4,000-year-old Japanese game resembling chess.

THIS tale is a variation of the ancient theme of the rivalry between the sea and their women folk for the hearts of men that live by boats and ships. It's a sentimental tale localized to the fisher folk of Pembrokeshire in Wales.

Moscow, July 31. -- The thoroughness with which the Soviet Union is manipulating every element of its social, industrial and economic machinery to prepare against a threat of war is shown in the decision announced this week by A.P. Rosengoltz, Commissar for Foreign Trade, to reduce further Soviet imports and his declaration that the Soviet Union did not want credits except on the most favorable terms.
HENDAYE, France, Aug. 1. -- Oyarzun, a key village near the border which has been in the hands of the Spanish insurgents, has been completely destroyed by loyalist artillery, it is learned.

Contrasting the health of the 17,000,000 industrial policyholders of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company during the first half of 1936 with that of the general population, statisticians of the company report that the death rate for the insured group almost equaled the record low established in the first six months of 1935, while data available for the country at large indicated a substantial increase in the mortality rate as compared with a year ago.

PRESENT signs point to a most interesting and crowded program for the National Air Races at Los Angeles. Moved from their Cleveland habitat by extensive enlargements of the municipal airport there, they will run for four days, beginning Sept. 4, in the State which has seen some of their most successful holdings.

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 1. -- Newton D. Baker, general chairman of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, will give the principal opening address at the Institute of Human Relations to be held here, Aug. 7 to 11.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Many dinners were given tonight before the supper dance at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran entertained at their home, Ranley House, for William M. Chadbourne, who has joined them for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- New official indications of rising prices because of the drought today coincided with expansion by Federal agencies of the officially designated emergency area in two States and announcement of additional relief projects for the sun-baked areas.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- The fifth annual Lake Placid figure-skating operetta will be presented next Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings on the ice of the Olympic Arena, with a special operetta matinee for children on Saturday afternoon.

DUSHORE, Pa., Aug. 1 (AP). -- One man was killed and another probably fatally wounded near here late today during an exchange of shots after they had been arrested by a game protector on charges of violating the State Fish Laws.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Dr. C.W. Chamberlain, Professor of Physics at Michigan State College, planned today to install in his home a heating plant of his own devising which uses air as "fuel."

THE royal chateaux of Touraine are known, by reputation at least, to nearly all visitors to France, but comparatively few travelers realize how rich are all the French provinces in beautiful castles and manor houses, and how many of these there are which can be visited.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- President Albert Lebrun today received the new Spanish Ambassador, Alvaro de Albornoz. In his address to the French President the envoy made a direct reference to his country's perilous situation and appealed for France's sympathy and friendship for his government.

The courage of protest is not dead in Germany. Addressing themselves in scathing words directly to HITLER, Evangelical leaders once more dauntlessly challenge those Nazi forces which, to insure their own supremacy, would destroy Christianity itself -- Catholic as well as Protestant -- in the Reich.

THE British Government has decided the future of broad- casting for the next ten years, basing its decisions on the recommendations of a special Broadcasting Committee, appointed by the Postmaster General in 1935. This committee, in turn, was influenced largely by the wishes of the British Broadcasting Corporation, expressed in evidence given by Sir John Reith, the Director General.

The broad recovery in earnings of steel companies in the first half of this year has carried the steel industry to the point at which a much larger proportion of total sales will be available for shareholders than in the last six years, numerous steel executives say.

NEARLY 9,000 boys and girls are studying, this Summer, in New York City's eleven tutorial high schools, organized and supervised by the Board of Education and conducted by WPA tutors. These are the first free Summer high schools that the city has had since 1932, and probably the first strictly tutorial high schools.
MR. NISBET has found a new name for the Mr. W.H. who was the "Onlie Begetter" of Shakespeare's Sonnets and his little book opens up once again this unsolved mystery of the Elizabethan literary world.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Agreements under which retailers would qualify in the prosperity plan of Alberta's Social Credit government were distributed today by Provincial Secretary E.C. Manning.

SHANGHAI, China. -- New complications loom between China and all of the treaty powers which still have pacts providing for extraterritoriality. China plans to institute an income tax and official announcements from Nanking declare that the tax will be collected from all foreign residents as well as from Chinese.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The Wyantenuck Country Club at Great Barrington is to celebrate its fortieth anniversary with a dinner and entertainment at the clubhouse next Saturday night. Earlier in the day the stockholders will hold their annual meeting and luncheon.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- More than 5,000 visitors are expected at camp Smith tomorrow for the program arranged by the 71st Regiment, commanded by Colonel F. Terry, for the celebration of "visitors day," an annual event of the Manhattan unit on the reservation here.

PERHAPS it is the comic influence to which we have been subjected this week; perhaps we still are suffering from vacation's end. Anyway, this hardly seems the proper time to urge the legitimate stage to look to its laurels, or deplore the double-feature menace, or comment upon the new cycle of war pictures about to be rolled across the nation's screens.

THE Summer theatre, which is now at the height of its season, has become one of the country's proudest businesses, or professions, or artistic trends, or rackets -- the correct word being dependent solely on the point of view. This week and next, and so on until the frost leaves a white wig on the fields, actors will be speaking their lines in competition with the crickets and whippoorwills.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- In its own good time, but not soon enough to correct a human error or restore the good humor of scores of disgruntled county employes, the safe in the office of County Treasurer William S. Coffey automatically unlocked itself at 9:05 o'clock this morning.

LONDON, July 29. -- The new season starts next week, but with only one new play. It is Barre Lyndon's first effort, "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse," a melodrama in which Ralph Richardson, Joan Maude and Meriel Forbes are to take part. At the Haymarket.

THE annual contract bridge tournament at Asbury Park, N.J., begins tomorrow afternoon. Conducted by the American Bridge Leage, this is usually the largest tournament of the year and draws the most representative crowd of players.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A display hanging on a wall in the executive offices of Charles A. Harnett, New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, portrays the history of automobile plates in the Empire State.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Taking another step in its program of settling peasants on land provided under easy terms of payment, the Paraguayan Government today took over enough acreage in the Departments of Caballero, Sapucay and Caazapa for the settlement of 15,000 families.
On Sept. 6 two anniversaries occur dedicated to the immortal deeds of youth in the cause of freedom.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 1. -- Opposing troops in Spain's civil war fought today for control of the northern seaboard. Rebel sources said that General Emilio Mola, the insurgent commander in the north, intended to clear out the loyalist strongholds there before concentrating his strength in a march across the Guadarrama Mountains to Madrid.
With the membership roster at a new peak and a record number of boats in the fleet, the officers of the Halloween Y.C. have decided to renovate the clubhouse located in Cummings Park, Stamford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Following a fire-hazard survey made in January, plans have been approved for the expenditure of $78,000 to better the fire-protection facilities at the White House. The plans include the installation of a manual fire-alarm system in the mansion, fireproofing of the motion-picture booth often used in White House entertainments, installation of new electrical equipment and the removal of old electrical and structural work, regarded as a potential fire hazard.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Samuel Goldwyn announced today that he had given Eddie Cantor a release from his motion picture contract. Asserting that Mr. Goldwyn's delay in starting a picture starring him was costing him money, the comedian recently announced he intended to ask for his release in court.

TOKYO, Aug. 1. -- No news ever received from abroad has given greater pleasure to the Japanese people than that from Berlin announcing the International Olympic Committee had awarded the 1940 games to Tokyo. The feelings of the Japanese today are like these of a rural town which has captured a national convention.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Hollyrood Perry, fast trotter from the Carpenter Stables, and Colorado Scott, 3-year-old pacer, owned and driven by J. Bruce Hay of South Orange, won the feature events of the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.

A family curse, an old house honeycombed with secret passages, and a supernatural manifestation that presages doom -- these were once prime material for the writer of mystery stories. In recent years they have been somewhat neglected, but Mr. Davis has dragged them to light again and, believe it or not, he has concocted a good story out of these outworn devices.

A four-story addition to the chemistry building at the Main Center of City College will be erected by the WPA, it was announced yesterday by Dr. H.G. Bohlin, assistant curator at the college. An approved WPA project, the cost of the new wing is estimated at $75,000.

It is twelve years since "The Cask" was first brought out here, and the publishers have had a happy thought in giving it a 1936 edition. This early story by Freeman Wills Crofts has lost nothing in the passage of time: indeed, it seems almost better than ever.

MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 1. -- Fifty-one American refugees arriving here this morning aboard the American export liner Exochorda brought stories of havoc wrought in the Balearic Islands by the Spanish Government's bombardment of the rebels.

The professional dignity of more than 500 educators was cast to the winds last night when, without using knives or forks, they ate one-pound T-bone steaks at the twentieth annual men's steak dinner of Teachers College, Columbia University.

Important events scheduled at the two new major courses slated to be opened this Fall are expected to have a strong bearing on the competition for the national automobile racing championship crown this year, according to Ted Allen, secretary of the contest board of the American Automobile Association.

SPANISH stamps have taken on a new significance for philatelists with the bitter outbreak of a fresh civil war in that turbulent land. For in these issues, which have changed with the various changes in government, may be read much of the history leading up to today's fierce struggle between the Leftist government and the Fascist government.

IN many places this year the 100th anniversary of Winslow Homer's birth is being, has been or will yet be celebrated. No one who saw it can soon forget the splendid selection of water-colors that was placed on view some months ago at Knoedler's, in New York.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. -- Social affairs and recreational activities for the Summer colony have gained momentum with the inaugural of the racing season. The first of a series of programs of music and dance to be presented at the theatre at Saratoga Spa will take place this evening.

Stricter enforcement of traffic rules was considered the best means of checking accidents by more than 100 of 125 traffic experts who answered a questionnaire in a nationwide survey conducted by the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York.
VALPARAISO, Fla., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Coast Guard cutters and planes searched today for three fishing boats missing after yesterday's tropical hurricane.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Mayor Rolland B. Marvin, a candidate for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, declared in a letter made public today that he was for a "sound social security program for New York State -- without a party label."

BROADENING volume was the report on retail trade for the week from almost all except drought affected areas. The month closed at an accelerated pace, helped in some cases by earlier pre-Fall promotions. Consumer demand has turned definitely toward better grades of merchandise.

While Max Butcher limited the Reds to three hits, the Dodgers blasted eighteen from the offerings of three Cincinnati hurlers at Ebbets Field yesterday and obtained a new deal in their home appearances against Charley Dressen's crew.
PARIS, Aug. 1. -- Thousands of Paris workmen and their families are leaving for the mountains or the sea because of concessions made to them in the recent strikes.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 31. -- That 110,000 majority by which Josh Lee was nominated for the Senate over Governor E.W. Marland on Tuesday was the harvest of twenty years of hard work.

The New York and Metropolitan District Cricket League match at Livingston, S.I., yesterday between the Veteran St. George eleven and the Staten Island C.C. resulted in a draw, the Veterans declaring their innings closed with 207 runs for eight wickets.

ALTHOUGH he has gained a considerable name for himself by his contributions to magazines and newspapers, Mario Soldati has not published a book between his "Salmace," which made a very favorable impression when it appeared in 1929, and his latest work: "America primo amore" ("America my first love," Florence, Bemporad).

The Arnold Bernstein Line announced yesterday that with the departure from New York of the liner Geroistein on Aug. 15 the company will begin a direct service to Rotterdam. The company's regular port is Antwerp and the extra call at Rotterdam was accepted in shipping circles as the line's reply to competitors in a long-drawn-out disagreement over conference conventions.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation, in its report for the six months ended on June 20, shows a net profit of $4,666,330, after interest, depreciation, Federal and State income taxes, but exclusive of the surtax on undistributed profits, and before depletion.

BETS OFF: When the liner Rex aailed for Europe about a fortnight ago tt carried off our former Ambassador to Germany, James Watson Gerard, in a most defiant mood. Vrall Street, said Mr. Gerard, was surely bluffing when it quoted odds of only 6 to 5 on Mr. Roosevelt.

GRAND COULEE DAM, Wash., Aug. 1 (AP). -- A gigantic earth-freezing plant -- large enough to freeze fifty pounds of ice daily for 4,000 families -- will create a frozen auxiliary "dam" at the Grand Coulee project.

Further details of the recent decree issued by the Council of People's Commissars and the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union revising the system of instruction in some 600 institutions of higher education attended by approximately half a million young men and women are found in Trud, the official central organ of the Russian labor unions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- Pennsylvanians can only hope that there is no "catch" in the assurances from Harrisburg that at last, after nearly thirteen weeks of negotiations, denunciations, threats, political byplay and compromise, the Legislature and Governor Earle have agreed on how to raise $45,000,000 for unemployment relief.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 1. -- The New England amateur golf championship was saved for the right-handed swingers today when Johnny Levinson of Chicago and Kennebunk, Me., defeated Southpaw Spencer Brainard of New Haven, another Yale product, 3 and 2, in the eighteen-hole final at the Portland Country Club.

SAMUEL GOLDWYN is being beset on two fronts but remains strangely tranquil in the face of it all. Sued for $5,000,000 by Paramount, a sum that might create trepidation in even stouter hearts, he is awaiting the outcome with some anticipation for, by it, all producers' agreements may be upset.

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Aug. 2 -- Hopes that the crisis brought about by the determination of the Kwangsi regime to resist Nanking's domination in the south might be settled by negotiation have been abandoned upon receipt of tidings that Kwangsi armies have crossed Kwangtung's borders at three points.

WHEN Herbert L. Stone, who is known to all yachtsmen from one end of the Atlantic seaboard to the other, writes a foreword to any book about boats, that book requires no further guarantee. "American Sailing Craft," by Howard L. Chapelle, has Mr. Stone's endorsement, so any words by the reviewer as to the technical soundness of Mr. Chapelle's pages would be superfluous.

SWIFTER, more comfortable and more economical than ever before, giant buses stream endlessly through New York City's exits, tying the metropolis to the rest of the country with gaudy, moving links of red, yellow, gray and blue.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J. -- The thirty-first anniversary of the founding of the Lake Hopatcong Yacht Club will be celebrated next Friday night with a nautical card party. Mrs. H.E. Carver, Mrs. C.E. Shipman and Mrs. H.C. Baker will be the hostesses.

BERLIN, July 31. -- Many visitors to Germany this Summer have put the question, "What has become of the church struggle?" The answer is simple. The government has won the first battle and is resting and waiting for another opportunity to carry its still uncertain program further.

ARCHIBALD RUTLEDGE, who already has eight books of verse to his credit, is, by special act of the State Legislature, Poet Laureate of South Carolina. His is a low and melodious voice rather than a strong one. He seems to us to be something of the troubadour, in this book "Brimming Chalice" at least; but a troubadour not content to remain purely objective in treating a theme.

Mrs. Evans turns the tables on the two children whose adventures enlivened the story of "Araminta." Readers of the first book will remember that it was Jerome Anthony, short for John George Jerome Anthony, who initiated city-bred Araminta the pleasures of country life.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 1. -- Passengers arriving from Tangier this afternoon declared foreign seaplanes were seen constantly arriving at various ports in Spanish Morocco, especially Melilla. Aircraft are also arriving at Tetuan.

Following the usual mid-Summer respite there will be a renewal of activity in the dog-show world this month. Important exhibitions are scheduled for New England and New York State. In addition numerous specialty fixtures will attract Eastern fanciers.
PARIS, Aug. 1. -- Lucile Paray features variations of the swallowtail silhouette for all hours in her new collection.

Affiliation with the American Labor party, formed recently by Labor's Nonpartisan League, headed by George L. Berry and John L. Lewis, was voted yesterday by the State convention of the People's party, the right wing Socialist organization, which met at the People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

The share market underwent an adjustment of its technical position last week. In other words, professional traders were disposed to claim profits, an orthodox move following a sustained advance. However, no "important" holdings appeared to be disturbed, and "public" participation in the market on borrowed money has been relatively small.
A New York City school teacher, who, in her retirement, satisfied her own urge for travel, made arrangements in her will to extend the benefits of travel to several friends, it was learned yesterday.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 1 (AP). -- The national junior and boys' tennis championships opening Monday on the Culver Military Academy courts have attracted a nation-wide entry list of eighty-four juniors and fifty-five boys. Titles in singles and doubles in both divisions will be determined during a week of play.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- A tennis exhibition by nationally ranked amateurs is scheduled for this afternoon on the newly surfaced courts of the Hotel Sagamore, Bolton Landing. Spectators are expected from the seventeen resort colonies on the lake.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -When Secretary Morgenthau returns from a month's vacation early next week he will face two significant problems involving future governmental financing. The first is whether the usual mid-September financing will be necessary.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Summer residents of all the Hamptons will gather at the Maidstone Club tennis courts next week to watch progress in the annual women's invitation tournament, in which ranking players from all parts of this country and from France and Canada will take part.

THE Bahama Islands off the southeastern coast of Florida, known for two centuries as a health resort and popular with sportsmen because of the big fighting fish in the surrounding waters, are experiencing a building boom, motivated, in part at least, by financial causes.
JOHN BUCHAN, in his "History of the Great War," put into a few lines the unadorned story of the victory of Vimy Ridge:

NAPLES. THE institution of Summer open-air concerts continues to make strides in Italy, in hand with the progress of al fresco opera, drama with music and dance festivals. In Southern Italy, recent additions to the list, or revivals of old customs, are the Maschio Angioino of Naples, the Pine Grove of Taranto, and the Royal Gardens of Palermo.

An experimental ultra-short wave radio telephone link between the new astronomical observatory on Palomar Mountain, Calif., and the California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, is being established by the Bell Telephone Laboratories in cooperation with the institute.

THIS is a metaphysical novel with a spiritual message. Newton's idea of the fluxions of an atom is carried forward by this author until we are told that "things," visible and invisible, animate and inanimate, act as a kind of crucible in which "spiritual alchemy takes place."

NEWPORT, R.I. -- After two dances and a host of dinner parties last night to round out the past week in a regular whirl, the members of the Summer colony are ready for another busy week as August opens. More cards are out in advance for dinners and luncheons than any other week this Summer.

BERLIN, Aug. 1 (AP). -- All conjecture about whether America, England or New Zealand will provide the next Olympic 1,500-meter champion now appears to have been overlooking one very important factor -- namely, Luigi Beccali.

MAKE no mistake about it: this book does not simply tell you how to endure loneliness; it tells you how to cure it. For the woman who lives alone and doesn't like it here are signposts to show the Way Out. And not mere philosophical maxims, mind you, or precepts about improving your state of mind: this author's ideology does not disdain material considerations; and her book is amusing, sensible, worldy-wise, and very practical.

DIFFERENT kinds of foam baths long have been used at beauty salons to refresh and relax tired clients. A beauty expert has now devised a pasteurized milk powder for a foam bath at home after a hard day at the office or after a shopping tour.

BOSTON, Aug. 1. -- Nearly 200 outboard motor boats raced over the placid Charles River today in the annual William Randolph Hearst regatta. One record was broken and another refused because the boat was underweight.

ROME. THE Summer music life of the Italian capital was again ushered in this year by the resumption of the outdoor concerts of the Augusteo Orchestra in the basilica of Maxentius, adjoining the Roman Forum. These popular ministrations are finding increasing favor from year to year; they draw large sections of the general public, especially among the working classes, which infrequently find their way to the regular Winter series, thus accomplishing an important educational function.

As the civil war in Spain enters its third week conflicting reports from the capital and from the rebel "fronts" tend to obscure the real military situation. Two points, however, seem to be clear: first, the rebel plan for a quick overthrow of the republic has failed; second, a long struggle is in prospect before peace is restored to the peninsula.

OF more than 200 new projects contemplated by the National Park Service, three will be established as national monuments during the ensuing year, if present plans are consummated. They are the Green River area, located in Northwestern Colorado and Northeastern Utah, near the dinosaur monument; the Escalante and Capital Reef area, also in Utah, and the Zion River area, adjacent to the present Zion National Park in Utah.

C. Granville Gibson, Member of Parliament for Leeds, who is making a world tour as Deputy President of the Association of British Chambers of Commerce, corroborated reports of the new prosperity in England on his way through this city.

IN Columbia Masterworks No. 261, Marguerite Long returns to domestic lists after a considerable interval. Hitherto, so far as American re-pressings are concerned, the French pianist has occupied herself with Chopin, reputedly her specialty, and Debussy.

BERLIN, July 26. -- It looks as if half the Olympic visitors to Berlin have received or are to receive a badge of office. The Olympic hierarchy of functionaries and the army of camp followers have become so complicated that only an expert can make out what all the insignia mean.

IF one wants to know what is the most useful library in the world, the answer is The New York Public Library. Or if there is any doubt as to which is the greatest university library in this country, it may be resolved in favor of Harvard University.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Gene Homans, former Walker Cup player and metropolitan amateur champion, won the annual invitation tournament of the National Golf Links of America for the second year in succession by defeating Prescott S. Bush, ex-president of the U.S.G.A., 3 and 2, in the final round today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Claude Passeau pitched the Phillies to an 11-to-3 victory over the Cardinals today, holding the St. Louis team to six hits and only one earned run.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- A debate over whether the American delegation received the German equivalent of the "Bronx cheer" shortly after passing Chancellor Hitler in the parade of the nations, opening the eleventh modern Olympics, shook the press section as the athletes left the Olympic Stadium today.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea said tonight a chemist, questioned about a reported Black Legion typhoid epidemic plot, has declared a high-ranking legion officer inquired also how to make hand grenades and kill people with poison gas and hypodermic needles.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Prosecutor Duncan C. McCrea said tonight a chemist, questioned about a reported Black Legion typhoid epidemic plot, has declared a high-ranking legion officer inquired also how to make hand grenades and kill people with poison gas and hypodermic needles.

OF more than 200 new projects contemplated by the National Park Service, three will be established as national monuments during the ensuing year, if present plans are consummated. They are the Green River area, located in Northwestern Colorado and Northeastern Utah, near the dinosaur monument; the Escalante and Capital Reef area, also in Utah, and the Zion River area, adjacent to the present Zion National Park in Utah.

As the first step in a campaign of public education designed to obtain for the City Tenement House Department an increase from the present budgetary appropriation of $871,085 to the 1933 allowance of $1,277,188, the tenement house committee of the Charity Organization Society published yesterday a pamphlet entitled "Rats, Children and Houses."

TRAVEL plans for Labor Day are already in the making. Whether the last long Summer week-end carries one to Cuba or Nova Scotia, to near-by beach or mountain resort, it is sure to be among the gayest of the season.

BY the end of 1936 the automobile industry expects to have produced and sold the amazing total of 13,575,683 cars and trucks in the United States and Canada since the depression's lowest year, 1932. This figure includes the 4,600,000 units which car makers estimate will be their output this year.

The city's work of repaving the car track areas in the midtown section after rails are removed by the WPA will get under way tomorrow and proceed at the rate of two blocks a day, the Manhattan Borough President's office announced yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The veteran international star, Devereux Milburn, had one of his best days of the season on Whitney Field of the Meadow Brook Club today, leading the White poloists to an easy 8-to-1 triumph over Elbridge T. Gerry's Red combination.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The refusal of John Borg, publisher of The Bergen Evening Record, to join in a public discussion of State issues drew a tart reply from Governor Hoffman today. The Governor invited Mr. Borg, Arthur Sinnott of The Newark Evening News, James Kerney Jr. of The Trenton Times and Boake Carter, a radio commentator, to take part with him in a special broadcast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, today criticized Governor Landon's latest explanation of his labor views as a policy "designed to isolate workmen from the trade union movement."

LYING in the very shadow of Manhattan's skyscrapers, yet rich and varied in the attractions it offers to vacationists, sportsmen and tourists, Long Island is playing host this Summer to unusually large and enthusiastic holiday crowds.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 1. -- Sixteen of the 988 members of the freshman class at Harvard College attained the rank of "highest distinction" in studies in the past year, it was announced by the dean's office here today. Grades required for the ranking are a minimum of 3 1-2 A's and 1-2 B.

WOLCOTT, Conn., Aug. 1. -- A little stone schoolhouse built in this village more than 100 years ago will be officially opened Thursday with an old-fashioned picnic as a permanent memorial to Bronson Alcott, father of Louisa May Alcott, the novelist, and notable in his own right as a pioneer educator.

OLD Tio Pepe, talking gently to his little donkey as he came into Mexicali, knew that the smuggler Tranquilino McCoy had passed that way ten minutes before. And over on the other side of the International Gate the American Border Patrol officers had learned that the half-creed outlaw was up to his old tricks.

CENTS A SNE: Au argument that had to be referred to a magistrate's court in New York developed last week between Cyprus Pavolos, street-corner shoe-shiner, and Louis Greenberg, his customer. Pavolos contended that the nickel Greenberg gave him for a shine was only half pay. Magistrate Farrell ruled: "Five cents is all you are entitled to, If you want a dime, get a store."

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Sixty yachts, the largest fleet that has raced so far this Summer in a regatta on Moriches Bay, took part in the second championship race of the August series under the auspices of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach off the Speonk Shore today.

FAR from the watchful eye of the old-fashioned, stereotyped art teacher, fifty high school and college students are having an adventurous seven weeks this Summer trying their hands at designing all sorts of household impedimenta from ash trays to radiator covers.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Scientists at Brown University have found a way to prolong the youth of lower animals by regulating their food supply and thereby nearly doubling the animal's active life-span.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman motored from Albany this afternoon to attend the races and had as guests in the Governor's box his son, John Lehman, and the latter's guest, Edward Flashman of New York; Parole Commissioner Joseph J. Canavan, Mrs. Canavan and Miss Virginia Canavan of Brooklyn.

The big drive on the west bank of the Harlem swung sharply back into high gear yesterday as the Giants, riding handsomely on the crest of a home run by Dick Bartell and a brilliant piece of left-handed pitching by Al Smith, flattened the invading Pirates at the Polo Grounds, 6 to 0.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 1. -- With more than a fourth of Kentucky's 4,296 precincts tabulated, M.M. Logan, aged 62, was holding a lead over four opponents tonight in his race for the Democratic nomination as United States Senator.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July 27. -- A new commercial trade deal between Brazil and Germany goes into effect on Aug. 1.

Mayor La Guardia revealed the existence of a racket yesterday in which seven civilian telephone operators of the Fire Department were accused of having accepted bribes from certain fire adjusters' agencies in exchange for immediate reports on the locations of fires.

Salt water fishermen of this area who enjoy roaming from place to place and dabbling at different forms of angling may pick up valuable bits of information from the fishing guides published by several of the Long Island clubs and obtainable at tackle stores and railroad terminals.

LONDON July 31. -- The Goodwood race meeting yesterday and Cowes yachting week, ending Aug. 8, usually mean the end of the London season, but in this unusual year, when the weather remains wintry, when entertaining is brilliant in spite of court mourning, when the influx of American visitors is greater than in many years, it seems certain that London will continue to be a center of attraction.

BARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- Music has served many purposes, but probably seldom has been employed as the basic feature of a surprise party. Such, however, was its novel function at the musicale given this afternoon for Richard Aldrich, music critic emeritus of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at Rokeby, his residence near this place.

Rivalry between the two most powerful public utility groups in the East will come to a head when representatives of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and of the Associated Gas and Electric System enter their bids for 712,411 shares of common stock of the Jersey Central Power and Light Company at public auction in Jersey City at 12:30 P.M. on Sept. 10.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- Dr. J. Leslie Davis, specialist in disease of the ear, nose and throat, who formerly served as Professor of Laryngology at the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Medicine, died tonight at Jefferson Hospital following an operation for an intestinal obstruction. He was 63 years old.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Five silk converters settled today with striking family manufacturers a few hours after the strikers had received assurances that eighteen large commission shops would join the stoppage Tuesday unless they received the price scale set up by the Silk Commission Manufacturers Association, sponsor of the strike.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 1. (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers said in a speech today that voters "have the opportunity of saying to the Chief Executive of this State that you want no Governor who is pledged to support the policies of the national administration."

VICKSBURG, Miss., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Louis Mize Jr., 24, faced murder charges today after officers, trying to patch up a domestic rift, said they saw him shoot to death the companion of his 21-year-old wife.
SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP). -- At least five forest fires were burning in Michigan's Upper Peninsula today and all available forces, including the military, were mobilized for the fight.

The four short stories in this volume deal with four adventures of Captain North, detective and spy-hunter of the United States Army. One of the adventures takes place in Shanghai, one at an African post of the Foreign Legion, one in Havana, and the fourth on the high seas.

BOOKS that purport to be general histories of art have been known to omit the Orient in toto, perhaps without even bother ing to explain that such omission was intentional. The present authors, at any rate, have clearly indicated the scope essayed, thus disposing in advance of any misunderstandings that might arise or regrets that might be experienced by the reader.

HOLLYWOOD. FOLLOWING the main titles on every picture is a credit card giving the names of those associated with the venture. Generally the last listing but one -- and in very small type --reads "Film Editor" and gives the name of the man or woman who took 100,000 feet of celluloid, much of it bad, and resolved it into 8,000 feet of drama which had to be good.

PRAGUE, July 31. -- Hardly was the Austro-German agreement concluded when rumors began to thicken that Germany was determined to force Czechoslovakia into a bilateral pact which would have the effect of detaching her from Russia and the Little Entente.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania, as chairman of the Democratic Senatorial campaign committee, said tonight that "prosperity regained is the proof of performance the Democrats will submit to the voters in their appeal for continuance in office and election of a greater Democratic majority in the Senate."
Some important dividend meetings set for this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the last distributions ordered by the directors follow:

CALCUTTA. LIKE their sisters the world over, the women of India practice the cult of beauty and its treatment. They will spend hours preparing their appearance according to their own standards, and their intense desire to look attractive is the more striking because of their restricted social lives.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Colonel Royden E. Beebe, commander of the Eighteenth Infantry and supervisor of the Citizens Military Training Camp here, made public today the list of medals, awards and prizes which will be competed for by members of the 1936 C.M.T.C. regiment.
WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, ridiculing reports that his church might silence him, pointed to his "Roman collar" today and declared it was not "in the moth balls."

TOKYO, Aug. 1. -- Japan must have more money and is racking her brains how to get it, but, at the same time, the chief spenders of the Japanese Empire, the army and the navy, are plunging forward with plans for still greater expansion and costly undertakings.
CARACAS, Venezuela (AP). -- The women of Venezuela have started a fight to prevent themselves from becoming mere creatures "of luxury and pleasure."

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- A sham air raid on Chanute Air Field, 100 miles south of Chicago, in which eighteen bombing and fourteen attack planes of the regular army participated, marked the opening of the huge concentration of regular army and National Guard troops in the Central West today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Confirmation of heavy damage to the corn crop by intense heat and drought was received today in the first estimates by local statisticians, which reduced the yield 660,000,000 bushels from the July indication and suggested only fifteen bushels an acre from the 98,500,000 acres planted this Spring.

WITH its charts, diagrams, definitions and tabulations of information, this fat little volume is a remarkable compendium of useful and interesting knowledge. But it is really more than that. It fully lives up to its sub-title's claim as a cruising companion.

THIS book is important. It tells more than it purports to tell. The history of any city parish, however notable, is rarely of much interest to any one outside the pariah bounds. But parsons and laymen, far from Gramercy Park, and of persuasions other than Episcopalian, will find this story illuminating and discomforting.
PARIS, July 30. -- Jane Blanchot shows amusing jabots made of a single, colored ostrich plume to match the trimming on dressy velvet berets for formal wear.

ARTHUR WHITING, who died on July 21, had lived in New York for forty-one years, during which time he had been a singular influence for good music and good taste. He was a pianist -- a good one, but not a great one -- and a composer of originality but no great pretensions.

W.F. McGrath, passenger manager of the Anchor Line in New York, announced last week that the first year of operations as an independent concern had exceeded the expectations of the owners, who took over the company from the Cunard Line in 1935.

FOR a Jewish rabbi to write an even faintly sympathetic study of Herod is an act of charity. Time and many a scholarly burrowing have disposed (one hopes) of the malicious fable that Herod slew "the innocents"; an occasional writer has been moved to portray with forbearance what a seventeenth-century biographer called "the wicked life and woeful death" of Herod; historians have generally ceased to berate old bones.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Arlington Park's thirty-day racing season ended today in a blaze of glory.

TOPEKA, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Party turnouts in the home State of Governor Landon were the chief concern of most political leaders tonight as a lusterless campaign for Tuesday's Kansas primary ended save for last-minute appeals.

OCEAN travelers on a great modern liner, comfortable in the knowledge that iron and steel provide security against the hazards of the deep, rarely give thought to the complications which modern ship construction has introduced into the science of navigation.

WASHINGTON. TRAVELERS strolling through Washington's new government palaces this vacation season, or pausing on the Eastern or Western tour to mail letters in some local postoffice, are likely to encounter sights all but unprecedented in the history of public construction in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the first applications for establishment of mutual or subsidiary holding companies under the Public Utility Act of 1935.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The rovers, who park their houses wherever fancy dictates, started rolling into Sandusky tonight for the annual Summer conclave of the tin can tourists of the world.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The official opening of the modern daylight garment factory on Jersey Homesteads, the Federal Resettlement Administration project five miles southeast of this borough, will be held tomorrow afternoon. The exercises will start at 2:30 o'clock, with Benjamin Brown, member of the Boarder Sponsors and Advisors, and recognized as the father of this cooperative enterprise, presiding.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Driving Norbert Kleinke to the showers with a home-run attack in the first two innings, Newark made it two in a row over the league leading Rochester Red Wings today. The score was 11 to 3.

HELSINGFORS, Aug. 1 -- The International Olympic Committee's decision to give the 1940 games to Japan caused the keenest disapointment throughout this country especially as the nation right to the last moment believed the committee favored Finland.

LONDON. MORE than 1,000 British workmen are toiling to complete Buckinghamshire's second vast film city. the Pinewood Studios at Iver, due to open in a couple of months' time. Set in forty acres of pleasant grassland, the studios will be unlike any others here or in America.
WARSAW, Aug. 1. -- Poland will seek an outlet for her surplus population in Africa and South America and may demand colonies when German colonial claims are discussed.

JOHN DILLINGER, Homer Van Meter, John Klutas and other public enemies now dead and gone tried to avoid recognition by having their faces lifted and their fingertips burned, obliterated and otherwise changed. The result was failure.

A NEW diet fashion has arrived in New York and spread from the home to the restaurant. Like most such fashions, it professes to make people healthier and to keep down their weight and it has affected, to some degree, marketing methods, social affairs and medical treatment in hospitals and sanitariums.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, July 31. -- The project to extend the Northern European international air routes by a direct line from Western Europe through Scandinavia and Finland to Russia, which several air companies believe to be required by the rapidly increasing traffic, seems to be doomed to failure on account of Soviet resistance.

WITH admirable clarity and unimpeachable logic, Professor Madden presents a thesis which will go far toward maintaining the already satisfactory rapprochement between the hand that shakes the cocktail and the foot that caresses the brass rail.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 1. -- A loyal column from here has put to flight enemy cavalry and captured Sastago and Quinto, towns forty and thirty miles, respectively, from Saragossa. Aircraft cooperated in the operations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Federal Trade Commission's "interpretation" of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Chain Store Bill, now being distributed to interested persons, is a collection of testimony before Senate and House committees during consideration of the bill and some of the debate during general discussion on the floor of the two houses.

WOOSTER, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP). -- A jury of seven men and five women returned a verdict of guilty tonight against nine of eleven men charged with unlawful assembly in connection with the closing of The Weekly Press newspaper plant at the near-by village of Rittman on July 17.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Apparently disturbed by reports of Republican gains in some farming States, political strategists of the Democratic party are promoting the idea of a Roosevelt-for-Agriculture Committee to act as a spearhead in an intensive campaign to win the West to the Democratic standard.

W. Earle Andrews, general manager of the New York World's Fair 1939, Inc., will head a party of engineers and city officials which will fly to Texas Wednesday morning in a chartered plane to inspect the Texas centennial expositions at Dallas, Fort Worth and other Texas cities.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Many parties made the week-end a festive one here. All the Saratoga Lake houses were taxed to capacity by dinner parties.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Athletics and the Browns ended their four-game "crucial series" for last place all square today by dividing a Sunday double-header that left the Browns a game and a half on top.

WESTWOOD, N.J., Aug. 2. -Westwood's newly completed synagogue at Washington and St. Nicholas Avenues, Temple Emanuel, named for the late Charles Emanuel of Westwood, was dedicated this afternoon with the formal opening of its great door and the holding of services by Rabbi Herbert Tarzen.

For the third consecutive year tax collections in Yonkers will show an improvement over the preceding year, and on the basis of the experience to June 30 returns this year will be approximately 5 per cent above those in 1935, Mayor Loehr will announce today.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- Mohammed Ahned Mesbah, an Egyptian government employe from Alexandria, established a new Olympic weightlifting record tonight to win the lightweight championship after Tony Terlazzo of York, Pa., had taken the featherweight title with a lift of 687 1/2 pounds.

DUQUOIN, Ill., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Six miners who tried to drag three companions out of a carbon monoxide gas pocket were overcome and all nine died last night in the Union Collieries' Kathleen mine at Dowell, five miles south of here.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 2. -- A little band of New York garment workers, pioneers in the quest for group security through cooperative effort, took over from the Federal Government today responsibility for the successful conduct of Jersey Homesteads, the experimental industrial and farm village built for them by the Resettlement Administration.

LONDON, July 31. -- The rise in the United States industrial averages to the level of 1930 prompts comparison with the British recovery as expressed by stock prices. The British low point of the slump was in June, 1932, when the Bankers Magazine's industrial share index sank to 78.9 of the 1921 average.

MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 2. -The U.S.S. Quincy, newest American cruiser, arrived here today with 140 United States citizens rescued from various Spanish ports. The grateful passengers gave Commander William F. Amsden and his officers and crew a vote of thanks.

The proverb about the ill wind may have originated in a period of droughts and dust storms. The present dry spell has provided a perfect illustration of it. It has ruined thousands of farmers, but for the farmers as a body, for those whose crops have been successful, it has meant a rise in prices, and probably in total farm income, to the highest levels in six years.

The annual dumping of firearms, knives, brass, knuckles, slot and pin-ball machines and other knick-knacks picked up by the police, as well as slugs not wanted by the transit lines, will take place Wednesday with due ceremony. This always is an occasion for celebration, and Mayor La Guardia and Police' Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine will make the voyage into Long Island Sound.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- Charles G. Poore of THE NEW YORK TIMS Book Review department, who was in Madrid when the Spanish revolt began, arrived in Paris today, being one of the first foreigners to reach here traveling the whole distance from the Spanish capital by rail.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 2. -There are persistent rumors here that another revolt has broken out in Honduras and that the rebels are concentrated near the Nicaraguan frontier. The rebels' reported slogan is "The Constitution, free suffrage and down with the succession."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 2. -- A woman who described herself as Madam Zorah Heigary, a Persian princess, registered at a hotel at Forty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, was to be arraigned tomorrow in the Newark Family Court on a charge of failing to pay a $20 taxicab bill.

The second anniversary of the death of Paul von Hindenburg, President of Germany, was observed yesterday morning at a memorial service at the Evangelical Lutheran Zion Church, 339 East Eighty-fourth Street.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2. -- The Yankees tied their season's record for overtime play at the Municipal Stadium today as they batted the Indians to a 4-4 tie in sixteen innings before the year's second largest crowd.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- President Roosevelt assumed today the active role of field marshal of his campaign for re-election, announcing that he had summoned to a conference at Hyde Park house tomorrow every major leader of the Democratic forces, from Chairman James A. Farley downward.

The Christian church was described as a living, vital objective and spiritual reality in the sermon yesterday morning by the Right Rev. Warren L. Rogers, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Ohio, who preached at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Add to the month's' slim list of metropolitan openings the name of "First Love." This is one by Norma Mitchell, former actress and co-author of "Cradle Snatchers" and "Post Road," and Guy Andros; and on Aug. 17 it is to start a preliminary engagement at the Boulevard Theatre in Jackson Heights.

LONDON, July 31. -- Within the next few weeks, with the holiday season in full swing, financial activity will be considerably subdued. But despite this probable period of enforced inactivity, stock market sentiment holds up and is cheerful.

Perfect Summer weather for motoring and the beach continued yesterday for the fifth successive Sunday. Automobiles stretched in endless moving lines on all highways. The beaches drew crowds of more than 2,500,000.

The world carry-over of American cotton, that is, the world stock on Aug. 1, was approximately 7,106,000 bales, according to a preliminary estimate of the New York Cotton Exchange Service. This compares with 9,041,000 bales last year, 10,701,000 two years ago and a maximum in 1932 of 13,263,000 bales.

BEACON, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Forty persons made a terrifying descent from the top of Mount Beacon at 2:30 o'clock this morning when the cable car of the Mount Beacon Incline Railway in which they were riding became enveloped in flames that destroyed a section of the steep road, causing a loss estimated at $50,000.

Shipments of all types of hosiery in June amounted to 8,846,704 dozen pairs, an increase of 1,334,153 dozen pairs, or 17.8 per cent over the total for the corresponding period last year, it is reported by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. In the first half of this year shipments totaled 55,971,165 dozen pairs against 52,904,662 dozen pairs in the comparative period in 1935, a gain of 5.8 per cent.
Leasehold deals involving buildings on Fifth Avenue provided the items of chief interest in realty activity reported in the city over the week-end.
Ernest Sutter, national intercollegiate titleholder from Tulane University, heads the 1936 ranking list issued yesterday by the intercollegiate committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Jascha Heifetz will be heard as soloist in two violin concertos at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight and tomorrow night -- the Mozart concerto in D major and the Glazunoff work in the same form. This brace of concerts will also mark the last appearance of Jose Iturbi as conductor at the Stadium this Summer.

The Class I railways of the United States in the first six months of this year had a net railway operating income of $238,243,934, or 22.3 per cent more than that of $194,776,454 in the first half of 1935, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.

In a report on the relief of transients, a matter of concern to local relief authorities and private welfare organizations ever since the Federal Government abolished this type of relief, the Governor's Commission on Unemployment Relief called upon the State of New York to urge the Federal Government to assume responsibility for this problem.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- The brilliant pageant of the opening of the eleventh Olympic Games is now history. Today the games are down to the solid purposes for which they are designed -- contests of speed, strength, skill and endurance.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 2. -Trying to keep out of the rain and listening for several hours to the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra play French music under Monteux have been today's principal diversions at the Salzburg Festival.

With Henry Myers, former Erasmus Hall High School captain, leading its forces, the Dragon Club of Brooklyn made a clean sweep of the five first places in the A.A.U. swimming and diving meet at Broad Channel Park yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 2. -- The substantial success of the Soviet Union's efforts to overcome the meat shortage that followed the first overhasty collectivization of agriculture was indicated today in a decree sharply reducing State requisitions on peasants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Gunpowder may kill more men in the next war, but medical officers of the armed forces said today they believed science would curb war-born plagues, even those which might be deliberately cultivated by a ruthless belligerent.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 2. -Registering fifty-two bullseyes, Lester G. Chapin of Rockville Center regained the men's Southern New York State archery championship with 1,184 points, the result of 174 hits, today.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 2 (AP). -Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, today addressed questions to the Presidential candidates of the two major political parties involving their attitudes on labor questions.

Traffic regulations in New York are exceedingly bad. Other cities have made considerably more progress in certain directions. In Baltimore, in Detroit and in many progressive cities where traffic is very heavy the "boulevard stop" system has been adopted. This has been advocated for New York by many traffic experts, but so far New York has failed even to seriously consider the proposal.
