Don Manuel G. Cerezeira, Cardinal Patriarch of Lisbon, Portugal, who arrived in New York last Thursday and has since been a guest at the rectory of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Jean Baptiste, Lexington Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, celebrated the 8 o'clock mass at that church yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Susie, a highly trained gorilla, observed her tenth birthday with a party today as 16,000 persons jammed the Cincinnati Zoo, where she has "resided" during her seven years in this country.

LONDON, July 31. -- New circulation and gold records are disclosed in this week's return of the Bank of England, the former rising 4,976,071 to 448,570,759, and the metal increasing 4,222,329 to 340,948,244.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- In the observance of its annual "Visitors' Day," while encamped for training, the Seventy-first Regiment of Manhattan, commanded by Colonel George F. Terry, was the host to 7,000 visitors today at Camp Smith.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 1. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.7, which compares with 83.2 the week before, 83.3 two weeks before, 83.8 three weeks before and 83.1 four weeks before.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP). -The Cardinals moved within two percentage points of first place by defeating the Phillies in both ends of a double-header today before 25,000, the largest local National League crowd in twenty years. The scores were 13 to 4 and 11 to 8.

Topics of The Times this morning asserts that "Russia lost more men in her civil war than she did in the World War." Official figures given out both by the Czarist regime for the war period and by the Soviet regime for the subsequent period are an approximation of the truth: World War -- Killed, 4,500,000; wounded, missing and died of starvation, 10,000,000. Civil War -- Killed, wounded and missing, between 75,000 and 100,000.

WARWICK, N.Y., Aug. 2. -George Ketchum, retired country newspaper publisher who remembers the exciting days of the Tilden Hayes campaign when he was a printer in Park Row, turned reporter this afternoon and proved that he could get a beat as well as any of the modern city reporters.
Mr. SEWARD was going to end the war between the States in thirty days. Colonel MCCORMICK of The Chicago Tribune sets a little longer limit for national salvation, but the days are passing swiftly by:

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 2. -- Cadet officers were in command of the third formal review of the 1936 Camp Dix Citizens Military Training Camp, held today before about 7,500 friends and relatives of the candidates and several high ranking officers.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- In spite of tricky winds and thermal, or rising, currents which were few and fickle, a remarkable performance for a utility glider was turned in this afternoon toward the close of the soaring meet of the Metropolitan Soaring Association, held from Mount Meenacha, 900 feet above the valley floor.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- Marcelle Dormoy launches a new silhouette in her burghers' coat for dressy afternoon wear. It is long, beltless and straight in the front and flares right from the shoulders in the back. It is developed in dark green velvet trimmed with unusually placed bands of mink.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh ended a twelve-day stay in Germany today without having met Chancellor Adolf Hitler, although it was disclosed they had sat almost within speaking distance of each other at the Olympic Games.

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Whales, which somewhat disconcerted tuna and swordfishermen yesterday, were still disporting in the swell off the South Shore today, but were apparently working their way seaward, to the especial relief of commercial anglers.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 2. -- The prices of all grains rose sharply last week to levels not reached in the last two years, as a result of news of the drought damage to crops in the United States. Soft wheat closed yesterday at 12.05 pesos a quintal, which is equivalent to 97 5/8 cents a bushel, an increase of 7 1/8 cents in the week.
TOPEKA, Aug. 2. -- Governor Landon will begin tomorrow what promises to be a busy four or five days of conferences before his departure to join his family at Estes Park, Col.

Net declines in cotton futures amounted to 24 to 36 points in the active positions on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, with the market principally under the influence of new crop factors, outstanding among which was a crop estimate of about 12,800,000 bales issued last Monday by the American Cotton Cooperative Association.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 2. -The new government of the Catalan President, Luis Companys, is now composed of a Council General enlarged to fifteen members, of whom ten represent Left parties, three are Socialists and two are technicians.
MADRID, Aug. 2 (AP). -- A heavily armed human chain tonight guarded the long, circuitous railroad to Madrid from the French border.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. McCormick gave a dinner for thirty-six at the Craig cottage, which they have leased this season, afterward taking their guests to the Maidstone Club for backgammon and dancing.

Dwight F. Davis, former Governor General of the Philippines, and Mrs. Davis; James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, and Mrs. Walker, and Ruth Draper, entertainer, are among the passengers arriving from Europe today on the French liner Normandie.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -Headed by Sidney B. Wood Jr. and including four other members of the first ten, a field of thirty-two players will start tomorrow in the annual Southampton Invitation Tennis Tournament on the turf courts of the Meadow Club.

NORWAY, Mich., Aug. 2. -- Small industry and private enterprise haven't a chance for a survival in the United States under present conditions, William Lemke, Union party candidate for President, declared before the Upper Michigan Farm Union here this afternoon.

For more than a century and a half the United States has maintained an army and navy personnel that have remained strictly within their constitutional sphere. At no time have they attempted to set themselves as the government of this country.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- With the first four days of the Saratoga meeting over, it seems clear to President George H. Bull and his colleagues that the current session will be the best in five years. An analysis made over the week-end shows that the attendance and wagering are running well ahead of recent years, and the outlook is especially rosy because of the caliber of the competition which impends.

For five hours at Ebbets Field yesterday nearly 18,000 Flatbush fans were entertained by as many different kinds of baseball as there are Reds and Dodgers and when the spectators filed out at sundown they probably were reasonably content, having seen the Dodgers win one and lose one.

CARMEL, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Dancing Partner, a gray gelding from the Tipperary Stables at Waterbury, Conn., was declared the champion hunter at the closing session of the two-day Putnam County Driving and Riding Club horse show today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The spot on the dome of Statuary Hall in the United States Capitol, from which bounces an echo of a whisper spoken many feet from those who hear it, has been discovered by an ingenius Washington high school physics instructor and one of his pupils.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 2. -F. Thompson Brooks in Sue scored his second victory in as many races today as he led the International Star Class sloops home by a margin of nearly nine minutes in a fleet championship contest for the Grover Trophy.
MUNISING, Mich., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Rain brought help and cheer today to crews combating nearly a dozen scattered forest fires in Michigan's upper peninsula and near-by Canada.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Charging that Harold C. Keyes, a former Secret Service operative and at present a private detective of New York City, had sought employment with the German Government with the idea of aligning Christian Americans against Jews, particularly in New York, Representative Samuel Dickstein of New York today made public a letter addressed to Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn requesting that the license of the detective be revoked.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 2 (London Times Dispatch). -- According to British refugees from Granada a wholesale massacre of persons owning or even suspected of possessing property, whether farmers or traders, was carried out in Loja, a town between Granada and Malaga, by mobs of armed peasants who have been incited by bands from Malaga.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Bullish grain markets prevail all over the world, creating a situation that a majority of men in the trade have never experienced. Prices have advanced sharply and trade expectations are for higher levels, particularly in wheat, the world over.

MADRID, Aug. 2. -- A smashing, decisive offensive from the north which would drive rebel forces back under loyalist guns commanding the Guadarrama Mountain passes was forecast tonight by Julio Alvarez Delvayo, right-hand man of Francisco Largo Caballero, chief leader of the Socialist defense forces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Wheat prices in Kansas City led the upward movement on the principal markets last week, there being net gains of 10 3/4 to 11 1/8 cents a bushel compared with a week ago, with September finishing at $1.14 5/8.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The White Sox thrilled 28,000 fans today by spotting the Red Sox nine runs in the second game of a double-header and then fighting their way uphill to a 12-11 twelve-inning victory after easily scoring a 9-1 triumph in the opener.
HENDAYE, France, Aug. 2. -This correspondent has just returned from a trip across the border into Spain, where a visit was made to the San Sebastian front.

Edgar W. MacKnight, whose wife, Helen, 47 years old, was killed by their 17-year-old daughter, Gladys, in their home at 826 Avenue A, Bayonne, N.J., late Friday afternoon, took steps yesterday to protect his daughter's interests. He engaged an attorney in her behalf and said he would stand by the girl.

Benjamin Parochniach, who is a big lad for his 16 years, walked into the East Thirty-fifth Street police station shortly after 11 o'clock last night, filled with remorse, and told the police that he could no longer live the life of a hold-up man.

William M. Young's Fishers Island class sloop Venturon of the Larchmont Yacht Club was the winner of the Bayside Yacht Club's 225-mile race out around Block Island and back. That was determined yesterday afternoon when all the craft she had to give time handicaps to had come in.

The League of Nations was praised by the Rev. A. Neville Davidson, minister of St. Mungo's Cathedral, Glasgow, Scotland, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, as an institution inspired by a dream of human brotherhood.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP). -Joseph Anderson, chief counsel for Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, who is suing Mary Astor, motion picture actress, for the custody of their daughter, Marylyn, said today he had subpoenaed George Kaufman, the playwright, as a witness in the hearing.

Official entries for the tenth international lifeboat race are expected to be filed this week and the selected crews will start training immediately for the competition in September, it was announced yesterday by the International Lifeboat Racing Association, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

The taxi driver turned off the drowned crooner on the radio and turned to the deafened passenger. "Hear that?" he inquired tautologically but proudly. "That's the gov'ment "keepin' WPA musicians busy. We "just pay 'em for practicin'. And "there's another bunch of WPA fel"lows tearin' up the old car tracks.

Herr GOEBBELS told the Olympic journalists that nobody expects them to write against their convictions, but they in turn must respect the convictions of the new Germany. But how are the foreign reporters to know what these convictions are?
Colonel Knox's acceptance speech should have convinced all of the independent voters of the ridiculousness of the Republican platform and campaign.

The protective committee that represents more than 80 per cent of the holders of guaranteed preferred stock of the Bush Terminal Buildings Company announced yesterday through White Case, counsel, its rejection of the reorganization plan proposed by Irving T. Bush, president of the Bush Terminal Company.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 2. -- As a forerunner to the annual race week program of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association which starts tomorrow and continues until Saturday, the thirty-sixth annual invitation regatta of the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club was held today.

NEWARK, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The Bears ended their home stay today by dividing a double-header with Rochester before a crowd of 9,000. The league leaders trounced the Bruins, 15 -- 2, in the first game, but the home team came back and won the second game, 1 -- 0, behind Kemp Wicker's sterling pitching.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 2. -Winning Ways, the handsome 8-year-old chestnut mare belonging to Louis Kaiser's Terre Haute Farm of Bethel, Conn., was declared three-gaited saddle champion at the second annual Elberon horse show on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. L. Victor Well today.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Despite a dull opening and several reactions stock levels this week have continued to advance. Boerse interest was concentrated on steels and specialties in the several industrial groups, the principal gainers being Harpener Coal, Mannsfeld Copper, Goldschmidt Chemicals, Harburg Rubber, Aschaffenburg Cellulose, AKU Rayon and Westdeutsche Department Stores.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 2 (AP). -United States Senator M.M. Logan today poised his 5,806 State-wide plurality against this city's uncounted ballot boxes which held the answer to whether former Governor J.C.W. Beckham wrested from Mr. Logan in yesterday's Democratic primary the Democratic nomination to succeed himself.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 2. -- At general exodus of yachts from Station 10 of the New York Yacht Club and the shores of adjoining estates took place today and yesterday as members of society followed their annual custom of cruising for the first ten days of August until the start of the New York Yacht Club's annual trip out of New London on Aug. 12.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Verner Z. Reed Jr. gave their first large entertainment of the season at their new home, Terra Mare, today, a luncheon with music for fifty guests.

MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 2. -- Mrs. Marion Hay was one of the first Americans to reach here from Madrid since the revolution's outbreak. She was among a group of Americans, most of them students, who arrived here on the cruiser Quincy from Valencia after a long trip from the capital by train.

The lifting of reserve requirements of member banks and the resulting elimination of part of the excess reserves, while an important step in the direction of credit control, is not, however, the final answer to the question of inflation, according to the August monthly bank letter of the National City Bank of New York.

Movement of markets last week had less visible relation than usual, either to one another or to the course of industry. Attention was chiefly paid by financial observers to the somewhat reactionary stock market, under relatively large transactions, and to the emphatic further rise of grain.

Forth from Billy Ray's Baymen's Rest yesterday went the host of the establishment, which caters to the clam diggers and fishermen of the Canarsie shore, and his 16-year-old niece, Marjorie Dillon of 1,490 East Ninety-fourth Street, Canarsie, and Jack White, a fisherman.
MADRID, Aug. 2 (Passed by the Censor) -- The Ministry of the Interior in a communique today said the government had had only satisfactory news from the various battlefronts.
Research in rail transport is proceeding on a vast scale, according to L.W. Wallace, director of the division of equipment research of the Association of American Railroads.

Christianity should be sensitive about social problems, but Christians more than others should stand against violence as an agency of social change, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, said yesterday morning in his sermon at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

Asked upon his arrival in this country recently whether he believes that some of the gold which has flowed to the United States in the last year will return to Europe on an ebb tide, MONTAGU NORMAN, Governor of the Bank of England, replied:
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 73 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the preceding week and 3 points from two weeks before.

Dancing has been simplified to such a degree that it is just as much part of a young person's life as "baseball, football and all other sports," Mrs. Montie Beach, first woman president of the Dancing Masters of America, declared yesterday.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 2. -The plan among merchants to strike against the government's new exchange control bill was abandoned last night when the authorities announced that the right to strike was recognized only for labor. The police warned that owners of all shops that were closed would be arrested and in the cases of foreigners deportation might follow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Farmers secured the top prices for the year for their hogs for three days last week, when packers paid $11.30 a hundred weight, establishing a general average of $9.95. Outside markets in several instances took advantage of the high prices here and shipped their stock to this market.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Father Coughlin declared here this afternoon that under the New Deal "the forgotten man has been remembered" in time to pay the government's bills. He spoke at an outdoor rally, which he said was attended by 25,000 persons.

The church of Christ is illogically blamed for some of the world's existing evils, the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Colorado, said yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Such an accusation, fostered by Russia and echoed elsewhere, is as groundless as blaming hospitals for epidemics, he asserted.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2. -- The local cotton market was more active last week although most of the volume was traceable to liquidation in advance of the end-of-the-season statistics now due. There also was hedge selling against holdings of spot.

The world needs spiritually minded men and women in high places and in positions of power, the Rev. Dr. Henry Hallam Tweedy, dean of the Divinity School at Yale University, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.

Thomas J. Pendergast, for many years "boss" of the powerful Democratic organization in Kansas City and dominant figure in the Missouri State organization, sent final instructions to his lieutenants yesterday from his sick-bed in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he has been confined with a heart ailment since June.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 2. -- A moderate sou'wester came in late this afternoon to bring home the sixty-seven boats sailing in the Norwalk Yacht Club's third annual special regatta after a day of listless drifting in light airs.

The first white marlin to be caught in Montauk waters this season was hung up on the dock of the Montauk Yacht Club on Friday by Rolph Floyd, sportsman of New York and New Canaan, Conn. It was the second of the jumping-jacks accounted for in near-by fishing grounds, a 110-pounder having been taken off the Jersey coast several weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Lard prices moved to new high levels on Saturday on speculative buying and in sympathy with grains. Expectations of a decrease in stocks for July failed to materialize, as there was an increase of nearly 11,000,000 pounds, a total stock of 58,392,394 pounds here against 47,756,003 last month and 24,228,923 last year.

Two United States Senators, Burton K. Wheeler of Montana and Elbert D. Thomas of Utah, returned yesterday on the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines after attending the Inter-Parliamentary Union meeting in Budapest, Hungary, from July 3 to July 8.

Arrival of more buyers this month than were here during the same period last year was predicted yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York on the basis of reports received from convention and trade exhibition groups.

One skimpy infield hit that bounced off Colonel Bill Terry's glove in the first inning seemed all that had stood in the way of Carl Hubbell pitching the second no-hit game of his career, as the famed Giant left-hander baffled the Pirates for eight and two-thirds innings at the Polo Grounds yesterday while 15,000 looked on utterly spellbound by the sheer brilliance of the performance.
Ciro Terranova, the Bronx merchant who cannot down his underworld reputation as "the artichoke king," was arrested again shortly before 11 o'clock last night on a vagrancy charge.
NORWAY. Mich., Aug. 2. -- Representative William Lemke said in an address here today that he wanted only one term as President because "I'll do the Job so well that any one can do it after that."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- American ships are still hurrying to remove United States nationals from cities in war-troubled Spain, Claude G. Bowers, the United States Ambassador, reported to the State Department today.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 2. -- Rebel forces today took Guadarrama, thirty miles from Madrid, according to dispatches to rebel commanders on the other side of the border. The Guadarrama position would bring them the closest to the capital they have been so far.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Calling the American Iron and Steel Institute's recent statement on wages in the steel industry "an extraordinary example of the misuse of statistics," John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, declared today that false deductions had been drawn from figures accurate in themselves.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The French Government's appeal to Italy and Britain for the rapid adoption and rigid observance of an agreed arrangement for non-intervention in Spain was delivered to the British Foreign Office today in the form of a note from the French Embassy.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -Mr. and Mrs. John Farr gave a large buffet supper tonight at Gables, their home here, for Mr. and Mrs. E. Morgan Gilbert, who are passing their first season here.
PARIS, Aug. 2. -- France will ask a formal explanation of the appearance in Morocco of Italian airplanes, which are believed to have been en route to join Spanish rebels.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- The Bourse was heavy again this week, and government stocks in particular showed considerable weakness. Signs of recovery appeared several times, but were short-lived. The heaviness was due principally to liquidation by speculators, who stand to lose severely owing to the fall of prices.

The first of the monthly index numbers, published by Dun's Review, shows advance in average commodity prices during the month of 2 per cent. The index number is 2 1/8 per cent above the average at the opening of the year and 5 3/4 per cent above the low of 1936, touched in June.
MADRID, Aug. 2. -- Loyal aviators aided the Madrid government today in a series of raids that were reported to have caused much damage to the rebel forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Members of the American Federation of Labor's executive council, arriving here today for tomorrow's "trial" of the twelve dissident unions associated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, were unable to indicate the outcome of the momentous meeting, but hoped that some formula might be devised to work out an amicable arrangement that would satisfy both the craft and the industrial union groups.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Bees, although outhit both times, defeated the league-leading Cubs twice today, winning the first game, 4 to 3, and the second, 3 to 2, before a crowd of 26,000. With the Cardinals triumphing twice, Chicago's lead was cut to two percentage points.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- The drought burned into its third month tonight with increasing threats of a general food price boost.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 2. -- Concerts were given today at many of the White Mountain resorts, and a number of parties were held before and after the music.

LONGPORT, N.J. Aug. 2, -- Five persons narrowly escaped drowning today when they were taken by Coast Guardsmen from a bridge abutment to which they clung after the speed boat in which they were riding sank in thirty feet of water. The near-tragedy occurred in the Longport Inlet.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- The Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company reported today for the six months ended on June 30 a net operating income of $685,835, after all charges, but without provision for the new Federal undistributed profits tax.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 3. -Although the Nanking authorities and Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's headquarters at Kuling continue silent, reports from Canton and Wuchow declare that Nanking has given the Kwangsi Province leaders until Wednesday night to accept government appointments.

HITLER and MUSSOLINI maintain their united front. Acceptance by the two dictators late Friday night -- at almost exactly the same hour and with similar implied reservations -- of the invitation of Great Britain, France and Belgium to a Locarno conference can hardly have been a mere coincidence.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- The Bank of France's additions to its gold reserves last week were the result of sales by the British Exchange Equalization Fund. The foreign exchange markets were exceptionally quiet, with the volume of transactions light.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 2. -- Polo came back to one of its capitals of the past today with the opening match of the intra-circuit championship on the No. 1 field of the old Point Judith Polo Club, now the Narragansett Polo Club.

The Cleveland Graphite Bronze Company reports, for the twelve months ended on June 30, a net profit of $1,016,337, after all charges, equivalent to $3.16 each on its 321,920 shares of common stock outstanding. This compares with a net profit of $1,057,588, or $3.29 a common share, for the twelve months ended on June 30 of last year.

Consistent Fall purchasing by visiting buyers created another active period in the wholesale apparel markets here last week. With retailers concentrating on their Fall requirements, many lines of merchandise were viewed and ordered for the coming season. Stores inaugurating advance coat promotions reported that in some instances the sales were not as heavy as anticipated, but, as more stores begin to feature these items and the season advances, buying is expected to improve.

Andre Jessurun and Tony Falco, welterweight rivals, are set for their ten-round bout which will feature the boxing program at Dyckman Oval tonight. The card has been arranged for the benefit of the Jewish Memorial Hospital Building Fund and promises to attract a large crowd.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- No important occurrence was noted in the political and economic fields this week, with interest here centered on the Olympic Games. In foreign affairs the government-instructed press is concentrating on the civil war in Spain, displaying marked sympathy for the rebels.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- Germany's long vigil came to an end today. While frantic "heils" burst forth in exultation, Hans Woellke was crowned the Olympic shot-put champion -- the first men's track and field winner the Reich ever has produced.

The endorsement of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman by the People's Party, the right-wing Socialist organization, affiliated with the American Labor party, was assailed as a betrayal of Socialist principles and the interests of labor in a statement issued yesterday by Harry W. Laidler, Socialist candidate for Governor.

CAMPHOFFMAN, SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 2. -- New Jersey engineer guardsmen were on parade here today when the ceremonial phases of the annual encampment of the 104th Engineers, under command of Colonel Orison M. Hurd of Paramus, were started.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- To foreign "financial and political uncertainties" and the attraction of improved business conditions here Secretary Roper today attributed 1935's huge flow of gold to the United States.

ONE of the odd features of the heavyweight program of the near future is that the ultimate result might be another fight for the championship between Jack Sharkey and Max Schmeling. This is a dreadful thought to haunt those who go to big fights.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 2. -More yacht racing records went by the boards in the Marblehead regatta today when the Boston Yacht Club started twenty-four craft in its annual long distance race in Massachusetts Bay, four more than last year, and 182 boats sailed in the Pleon Yacht Club's junior event, ten better than last year and believed to be a national mark for juvenile sailing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Pioneers soon will regain the privilege of staking out homestead claims on the public domain as they did in the days of the covered wagon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- An awakening came to the oats trade here last week such as it has not experienced in years. From a most indifferent attitude by specialists there has been a change to unusual activity and prices advanced 8 to 9 3/8 cents a bushel within a week, and closed at the highest point of the season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- It is many years since the oldest men in the corn trade have experienced a condition like the present. The crop has gone backward instead of advancing, as predicted a month ago. Hot dry weather has not only killed tassels but has stopped growth.

LAKE SEBAGO, N.Y., Aug. 2. -The Washington Canoe Club's well-balanced squad of sixteen paddlers won ten out of eighteen events to score an overwhelming total of sixty-four points and successfully defend its national team title on Lake Sebago today.

Eddie Cantor's release from his Samuel Goldwyn contract involved a cash consideration, it became known yesterday, intended as reimbursement for the producer's efforts to please Cantor with stories of one kind or another after having refused to let him appear in "Three Men on a Horse" for Warners. Neither party would discuss the details of the termination of the contract further.

The sharp increase in newspaper and magazine linage this year has brought the paper industry back to a point where operations are once again on a profitable basis, paper trade executives said here yesterday. At the same time the current heavy purchases of book paper and newsprint indicate the extent of the gains which publishers expect in the Fall season.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 2. -C. Everett Bacon of Montclair, N.J., and Lake George was re-elected president of the Lake George Club for a year's term this afternoon. Other officers elected, also Summer residents, were:

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2. -Led by Raymond Guest, who filled the No. 2 position in grand style and scored seven goals, the Aiken Knights recorded a 9-to-5 victory over the Hurricanes in today's highgoal polo match at Bostwick Field.

Plans for August campaigning by the women's division of the Democratic National Committee, made public yesterday by Mrs. Charles W. Tillett Jr., head of the speakers' bureau, include speaking tours by Senator Hattie Caraway of Arkansas and former Governor Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming.

Destructive as well constructive forces are essential to rebuild the world in accordance with the teachings of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Ray Freeman Jenney of the Park Central Presbyterian Church of Syracuse, said yesterday in a sermon at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, the unsuccessful Republican Gubernatorial candidate in 1924, indicated yesterday his willingness to accept the party's nomination to oppose Governor Lehman "if the people wished it." The nominee, he declared, should be one who will strengthen the Landon-Knox ticket.
A book on the Constitution, started by the late James M. Beck and completed by Merle Thorpe, is announced for publication by Macmillan on Sept. 1. The title is "The Menace to the Union."

With the declaration that it would wage a vigorous campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman and the development of a permanent organization for independent political action, the American Labor party announced yesterday that Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, New York regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, had accepted the post of State campaign director for the party.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,494,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

DETROIT, Aug. 2. -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association said in a statement today that average earnings of automobile factory workers were 16 per cent higher this year than in the 1935 production season, and 52 per cent higher than in 1934.

Declaring that his anti-noise campaign was not conceived as a "nine-day wonder in this town," Mayor La Guardia prodded the Police Department yesterday to intensify its efforts to reduce noise in the city.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Mrs. William E. Borah, extremely interested in her husband's political activity, admitted today that, like any one else, she has to read the newspapers to find out what he's doing.

The crisis in Spain continued to dominate unfavorably the course of foreign exchanges last week. The possibility that there might be an extension of the area of hostilities was not overlooked and much apprehension prevailed in banking quarters on this score.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- France's appeal to Britain and Italy for a neutrality agreement on Spain among the powers and her reservation of her rights to ship arms to the Spanish Government awaited action by other governments today.

Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, returned to New York yesterday from a swing around seven up-State counties and issued an announcement of committees selected to take a prominent part in the organization of women voters to support the Landon-Knox ticket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The Chinese Nationalist movement is the most powerful barrier to Japan's advance, because of the failure of Britain, the United States and Russia to achieve unified resistance to Japan's threat to their common interests in China, said a report issued today by the Foreign Policy Association.

Something new happened in Union Square yesterday afternoon. Under the auspices of the Police Athletic League of the Crime Prevention] Bureau, a roller skating carnival, in which 150 boy and girl members from congested districts in the five boroughs of the city participated, was held in the streets bounding the park, which is usually given over to radical oratory.
I am sure you will wish to correct some misstatements in John A. Jordan's letter regarding the candidacy of A.A. Berle, who is in France for a well-earned rest.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 2. -Johnny Farrell of Baltusrol, former national open golf champion, scored his first tournament victory in five years when he won the New Jersey open championship today at the Crestmont Golf Club, defeating Victor Ghezzi of Deal in a play-off.

It is doubtful if any Olympian festival, from the first in 776 B.C., has had a more impressive opening than that of 1936 A.D. And the new amazement is that the very scenes were carried almost instantly (more swiftly than the messages of the gods by Mercury) across continents and seas and presented by telephotography to the sight of men, women and children of differing race, nation and language thousands of miles away.

Grace Abbott, former chief of the United States Children's Bureau and chairman of the special survey committee of the American Association of Social Workers, made public yesterday a report on relief conditions in Illinois. The report declared that want and despair would befall more than 160,000 families and individuals in that State within the next ten days if the Legislature failed to provide promptly additional State funds to help cities and towns give adequate relief.

VERA, Spain (With Rebel Troops Advancing Toward San Sebastian), Aug. 2 (AP). -- General Emilio Mola began today a determined drive to crush government forces on the extreme northern front of Spain's civil war.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- In Tuesday's debate in the Senate on the state of public finances, it was argued that the fresh expenditures proposed by the government would mean an increase in the budgetary deficit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today announced the arrest of John Sullivan, wanted for a $14,507 bank robbery on Jan. 31, at St. Charles, Ill.

HAVRE, Mont., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Seven hundred tired fire-fighters left the blackened Little Rockies Mountain Range today "because there's nothing left to burn," while the forest-fire menace grew worse in other Western drought areas.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Banks here view the United States business outlook as favorable, noting substantial profits by the United States Steel Corporation and gains by General Electric and other leading industrial enterprises in the first half of the year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Best hogs met with a good demand at fully steady prices here today, but other kinds were slow and generally lower. The quality of the offerings was regarded as the poorest of the season. Only a few lots were good enough to sell at the top quotation of $11.25 a hundredweight, which was 5 cents under Friday's best, while the day's average was off 5 cents at $9.90.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Washington Park opened its thirty-one day Summer race meeting today with the Chicago Handicap going to Infidox. The track's new camera, housed in a giant 128-foot tower far above the finish line, was called upon to decide the inaugural feature as well as several of the supporting events.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Still retaining hope for a negotiated settlement of the craft-industrial union dispute, dimmed by the failure of spokesmen for the twelve pro-industrial unions to appear for trial, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor today began taking testimony.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- With the drought in its third month and no general rains in sight, more than a score of Federal and State agricultural experts met here today to present first hand reports on livestock feed crops in ten Central Western States. Some observers predicted the corn harvest would total only 1,500,000,000 bushels, or about a billion bushels less than the average yield.

Checking by cable with Spain yesterday, leading importers of sherry declared themselves reassured regarding the safety of existing stocks there. So far the warfare has touched sherry-producing regions only to a minor extent and confidence is expressed that, if the fighting can be halted before the new vintage is started around Sept. 1, prices and supplies will remain normal.

James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, returned from abroad yesterday with Mrs. Walker on the French liner Normandie. He said he was still a Democrat and would vote the ticket, but did not wish to take part in the campaign.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Vice Chancellor William A. Kays, in Jersey City, denied an application yesterday for a writ of habeas corpus in the case of Ciro L. Mei, 15-year-old Union City, N.J., boy, known as Jerry May, by which counsel sought to have the boy, now held on a murder charge, placed in the jurisdiction of the Juvenile Court.

John A. Brown, chairman of the Socony Vacuum Oil Corporation: Lady Fenton, Major John A. Herbert, M.P., and his wife, Lady Mary Herbert, Reginald P. Croom-Johnson, Arthur S. Vernay, explorer and hunter, and Dr. R.M. Hopkins are among the passengers arriving today from Europe on the Cunard-White Star liner Aquitania.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Seeded players in both divisions raced through their matches as expected today at the opening of the national junior and boys' tennis championships on the courts of the Culver Military Academy.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The French appeal to the British Government for non-intervention in Spain, which was received by Viscount Halifax, Lord Privy Seal, at the Foreign Office yesterday, was communicated today to Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, and other key men in the Cabinet at their various holiday retreats in England.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Army Air Corps made contracts today for 150 of the most powerful airplane engines of their type produced in the world.
SEATTLE, Aug. 3. -- Speakers at the National Conference of Catholic Charities today urged a moral revival among "the inheritors of a crazy-quilt civilization" that followed the World War.
Active American seamen stand to gain greatly by the new laws in aid of merchant shipping. Careful analysis of them reveals the following provisions:

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 3. -World's motor-boat racing marks were shattered five times today on Lake Quinsigamond. Two others were equaled and a new American mark was set in an orgy of speed records as a third-day aftermath of the Charles River regatta at Boston yesterday and Saturday, which brought out 246 entries, the largest fleet of outboard hydroplanes in the last two years.
The parqueted floor of the grand ballroom at the Hotel Roosevelt took a terrific beating yesterday as the fifty-third annual convention of the Dancing Masters of America got down to business.

Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, arrived in New York on the Normandie yesterday, less than three weeks after his departure on the same vessel. During his trip he arranged the sale of all British properties of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The balloon "Goodyear X" defeated the "Great Lakes Exposition" in a match race today with a better margin than it had in the national balloon race a month ago.

It is difficult today, when commercial passenger flights across the English Channel area matter of daily schedule, to understand the thrill caused by LOUIS BLERIOT'S cross-Channel flight of 1909. But the achievement was, for its day, even more amazing than LINDBERGH'S great New York-to-Paris flight eighteen years later.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Eclipsed by interest in national political affairs, the mild primary election campaign in Governor Landon's home State moved through final stages tonight with lack of opposition determining many party candidates in advance of Tuesday's balloting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, continuing its investigation of investment trusts and investment companies, began today an inquiry into the origins and operations of the Eastern Shares Corporation, the Reliance International Corporation and the Reliance Management Corporation, all of New York, and the American, British and Continental Corporation of New York and London.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 3. -- After nine months of silence, a radio message has been received from the British East Greenland expedition under the leadership of L.R. Wager, which left Aberdeen, Scotland, April 7, 1935, aboard Sir Ernest Shackleton's old ship, the Quest.

Advertising volume of the major media in July showed substantial gains over the corresponding month of last year and indicated that the second half of 1936 may improve on the excellent showing made in the first six months, according to a survey here yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Aug. 4. -Because of disrupted communications, the exact situation existing along the Kwangtung-Kwangsi Province border remains indefinite, but it is believed that Kwangsi troops have driven Kwangtung loyalists from the southwestern section of Kwangtung and are driving slowly toward the sea so as to break the Central Government's blockade.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Mrs. Carl H. and Robert Lester today won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother and son championship at Baltusrol, their home course. Collaborating in a 78, the Lesters not only dethroned Mrs. John D. and Richard Chapman, but clipped six strokes from the record set in the first annual event last year.

City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr., who returned from Europe yesterday morning on the Normandie of the French Line, talked over his possible part in the November campaign for Aldermanic President in the afternoon with Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall in Pelham Bay Park.

MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 3. -- Rival factional fighting within the Left Front ranks, gang warfare and plain murder have resulted in Barcelona from the collapse of regular authority and the arming of the roughest elements in the city, according to American refugees who reached here today aboard the British destroyer Gipsey.

Special Sessions Justice Alfred Hofman of Queens, indignant because of having to make a four-hour trip to the office of Mayor La Guardia in the Summer City Hall for nothing as a result of a hoax telephone call, made two vain efforts yesterday to have Irving Tell, Assistant District Attorney assigned to the court, cited for contempt.

A petition designed to bring the German oppression of Jews and non-Aryans formally before the League of Nations as an "issue of international concern" was made public here and in Paris at the same time yesterday.

LIMERICK, Irish Free State, Aug. 3. -- The Duke of Grafton, who was 22 years old last Saturday, died at the Limerick Hospital early today as a result of burns suffered when his racing automobile crashed into a wall while he was competing in the Limerick International Grand Prix yesterday.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Patsy Tomaino, 16, employed at the Hollywood Gold Club, Deal, won the New Jersey caddie championship at the Forest Hill Field Club today with a 36-hole total of 81, 77 -- 158, and Victor Peck of Hopewell Valley captured the State caddie masters' title with 69, 80 -- 149.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3. -- The Soviet Union aligned itself emphatically, though unofficially, on the side of the beleaguered Spanish Government today with a gigantic demonstration by factory workers and office employes in Red Square.

Selznick International is making little progress in its search for a modern Tom Sawyer, according to advices from the Coast. William Wellman, who will direct the Mark Twain romance, has interviewed 2,000 youngsters without success and now a rather frantic canvass is being made of playgrounds and beaches.

Pierre Thoreaux, recently appointed master of the French liner Normandie, completed his first transatlantic voyage as commander of the vessel when the Normandie docked here yesterday from Havre and Southampton with 1,379 passengers.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Missourians vote tomorrow in a primary election expected to measure the strength of the Thomas J. Pendergast Democratic organization of Kansas City.

Kip Farrington has been around enough fishing "hot spots" to get pretty blase by now. But yesterday this globe-trotting angler was bubbling over with superlatives after a week-end visit to the recently discovered white marlin grounds off Ocean City, Md.

Men from the office of Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, led by Undersheriff Arthur Jaeger, spent yesterday on the Corona meadows evicting occupants of property condemned to make room for the World's Fair.

The fire adjusters accused by Mayor La Guardia of having bribed civilian telephone operators of the Fire Department in exchange for immediate reports on locations of fires will be tried by the State Insurance Department and if found guilty their licenses will be revoked.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Democrats of Westchester County refused tonight to endorse Surrogate George A. Slater, Republican incumbent, for renomination, and named William J. Sheils of New Rochelle to oppose him. Mr. Slater has held the office for many years.

Macmillan reports that its sales of "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell, are now established at about 6,000 copies sold daily. The present printing, carries the number of copies to 226,000. The publisher expects to distribute 500,000 copies.

WITH REBEL FORCES NEAR VERA, Spain, Aug. 3 (AP). -- An American movie camera man described today the movement of the residents of one Spanish village to and from their homes to avoid the gunfire of opposing forces in the civil war.

NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 3. -- Closing ceremonies for the Citizens' Military Training Camp at Fort Niagara were held this afternoon in the presence of a gathering of parents, prominent citizens and members of patriotic organizations of Western New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- While the Department of Agriculture began today the purchase of cattle to meet the drought emergency in Western States, the Works Progress Administration authorized the employment of 89,000 destitute farmers in stricken sections, embodying an increase of 5,000 each allotted to Nebraska, Kansas, Kentucky and Missouri. These four States were only recently designated as emergency drought areas.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3. -- The news that the Great Northern Paper Company had announced an increase of $1.50 a ton to $42.50 for newsprint in its 1937 contracts was a disappointment to those who had been trying to organize the Canadian paper industry to press a more substantial increase, and newsprint bonds broke 4 points today on the market here.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill gave a barbecue tonight on the grounds at the Orchard, her home here, for Miss Ethel Wickham, who is passing the Summer at Bonnie Bourne. A bridge party followed the barbecue.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Playing in the face of high cross-winds, which ruined many a tee shot, fifty-seven combinations took part in the weekly Long Island amateur-pro best-ball golf tournament at Seawane today, with top honors going to Charles H. Mayo Jr. of Lido, Long Island amateur champion, and the veteran Willie Klein, Wheatley Hills professional.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has made good, or is about to make good, deposits of $9,943,085 held by the public in banks which failed, according to Leo T. Crowley, chairman, in his report for the period from Aug. 23, 1935, to June 30, last.

Milton (Big Boy) Gillespie, 23-year-old Negro truck driver who delivers oranges to Washington Market from a warehouse at Warsaw, N.C., sat trembling in the Elizabeth Street police station last night while Lieutenant Christian Zimmers tried to decide if it is against the law to carry a 59-inch rattlesnake in public.

A banking group headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., and including Lee Higginson Corporation, Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; Edward B. Smith Co., Field, Glore Co. and the First Boston Corporation will offer to the public today an issue of $7,000,000 of Chicago Union Station Company guaranteed 3 1/2 per cent bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1936, and maturing on Sept. 1, 1951.

BOSTON, Tuesday, Aug. 4 (AP). -Newell Paige Sherman, 26 years old, was put to death just after midnight in the electric chair at the State prison for the murder of his wife, the mother of their two children. He drowned her in Lake Singletary, near Worcester.

Since the President led the way in 1932, every American political gesture is now dramatized to the limit. At least three separate news releases are employed to chronicle the pilgrimage of a minor conservative Democrat to Governor Landon's standard, and Alfred E. Smith's logical journey's-end may produce as many as a dozen.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Seabiscuit, the son of Hard Tack, a long-shot winner here some years ago, was himself something of a surprise today as he took the Mohawk Claiming Stakes, following a trip from Suffolk Downs, East Boston.

VVASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The salaries paid their executives, terms of management contracts and financial statements of more large corporations were thrown open to public inspection by the Securities and Exchange Commission today as orders were handed down denying further confidential treatment of information supplied by fourteen concerns.

BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 3. -- After an airplane view of desolation wrought in North Dakota by the drought, John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, declared here tonight that although Federal relief of sufferers from drought and other disasters had always been apart from politics in the past, the New Deal viewed it as political capital.

A virtual embargo on all trade between Germany and this country will result from the new German order barring private barter deals and the use of Aski marks in the purchase of goods for export from Germany, foreign traders asserted yesterday. Both importers and exporters were anxiously awaiting detailed official reports of the new order to learn the full extent of its application.

In announcing details of the proposed plan for readjustment of its capital stock structure, B.F. Goodrich Company reported yesterday an estimated net profit for the six months ended June 30 of $2,650,000, equal to $1.40 a share on the common stock after allowing for preferred dividends.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3. -- This city, whose very name conjures up pictures of icy blasts swirling around a snow-encrusted Kremlin, is experiencing an unprecedented heat wave which is causing intense discomfort and much minor illness.
MADRID, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Loyalists and rebels pushed the battlefront of Spain's civil war into the north today, the rebel troops withholding for the moment direct attack on Madrid.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 3.--T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II again was dismasted in the opening race of the famous Cowes Regatta today.

HARRISBURG, Tuesday, Aug. 4. -- After a gallery of "hunger marchers" had spent several hours calling for "action," the State Senate voted unanimously early today to end the special session of the Legislature at noon Thursday.

SATURDAY, A.M. It is contagious as the mumps, this book of T.H. White's ("England Have My Bones": Macmillan, $2.50). I can't resist trying to write about it as White writes about fishing, snakes, airplanes and such. Who White is I don't quite know. He is obviously an Englishman, and, according to the jacket blurb, a poet and a novelist.

The New York Public Library's budget estimate for 1937, to provide for free circulating libraries and sub-branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond, as well as the Municipal Reference Branch, is $1,664,593, an increase of $301,450 over the allowance for 1936, according to figures submitted by Frank L. Polk, president of the library's board of trustees, to the Director of the Budget.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Urgent warnings to all Americans still in Spain to leave the country while this government is still able to provide evacuation facilities are being circulated by United States diplomatic and consular agents, Secretary of State Cordell Hull disclosed today.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 3. -A fleet of 381 boats sailed today off Marblehead in the Eastern Yacht Club's second regatta. Seventy-seven large boats started in the afternoon from the outside line and 258 from the inside line off the Corinthian Yacht Club, while forty-six small fry in six classes raced in the morning.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- The Ceuta (Morocco) radio station controlled by the Spanish insurgents, announced tonight that officers and crew of the German battleship Deutschland were landing there this afternoon.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 3. -- A Federal grand jury has indicted twenty-three major oil companies, three trade journal publishing companies and fifty-eight individuals on charges that they violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, it was announced here tonight by United States District Attorney John J. Boyle.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The Reichs-bank's statement as of July 31 shows the following changes from the preceding week. Figures are given in thousands of marks:

The Metropolitan Water District of California has issued a call to bankers for bids for a new issue of $14,184,000 of water works bonds, award of which will be made on Aug. 28. The bonds will be dated Sept. 1, 1936, and will mature on Sept. 1, 1951 to 1986.

Soviet Russia is to have more barber shops, apparently as part of the latest Five-Year Plan. It seems to be in the Russian tradition that whet the nation makes a big forward step it cuts off its whiskers. Every schoolboy knows that PETER THE GREAT, nearly two hundred and fifty years ago, took a short cut through the beard problem, so to speak.

Governor Landon will address a rally of Republicans in Madison Square Garden on Oct. 29, it was announced yesterday by Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican leader. The big meeting in the Garden will climax a major drive of the party to capture the forty-seven electoral votes of New York State.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Jay Flick had a dinner party at Uplands, Lenox, tonight for Haersma de With, Minister to Washington from the Netherlands, who is at the Lenox Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- A day of arduous endeavor for the favored array ended with the defeat of Hal Surface of Kansas City, Mo., today as the forty-sixth annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament started on the turf courts of the Meadow Club.
Employment in the shipbuilding industry now equals 100 per cent of the total for the period 1923-25, the norm accepted by the Department of Labor for durable manufactures.
BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- Riding in the form that marked his efforts for the first half of the current Suffolk Downs meeting, Johnny Longden scored four victories to feature the card at that track today.

The hold which Jascha Heifetz has on his audiences was amply demonstrated last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. Approximately 15,000 persons -- a record attendance for the current season -- greeted the violinist in his first of two engagements at the uptown amphitheatre.

Maintaining a sulky petulance because one of the detectives who had arrested him had torn his fancy silk shirt, Ciro Terranova, the celebrated artichoke merchant of Pelham Manor, appeared once more in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Eight wholesale merchandising events which are expected to bring 25,000 to 30,000 buyers to Chicago this week opened today in the Merchandise Mart and downtown hotels. The events comprise Chicago's annual Fall market opening held in conjunction with the Interstate Merchants Council convention under the auspices of the Chicago Association of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- In a second decision radically affecting the revenues of the leading railroads of the country, the Interstate Commerce Commission today denied the petition of Class I railroads to continue, after Dec. 31, 1936, emergency freight rates authorized in 1935 which added $104,500,000 annually to the operating incomes of those roads.

Penetrating a veil of humidity that hung over New York most of yesterday, the rays of a hot sun sent the Weather Bureau's mercury to a high mark of 92 at 5:05 o'clock in the afternoon, equaling a record for the date that had stood for ten years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Henry H. Timken, a director of the Timken Roller Bearing Company, disposed by gift in June of 25,225 shares of the company's common stock, worth at current market prices approximately $1,639,625, it was disclosed today in the Securities and Exchange Commission's summary of changes in shareholdings reported from July 1 to 10.
PARIS, Aug. 3. -- Although the franc weakened today in terms of sterling to 76.15 and 15.16 1/2 for United States dollars, the securities markets were much firmer than last week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -Forence Hazelwood, 15 years old, daughter of Charles F. Hazelwood of the Wall Street banking firm of Estabrook Co., was killed today when the horse she was riding in Saxon Wood Park bolted and threw her to the ground.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3. -- Investigation of the Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company by the State shows that the company is sound on life policies and all other policies except non-cancellable disability policies. Settlement of claims on the latter class is expected to be covered on the adjustment basis previously announced and hence will not react on life policies or the company's condition.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 3. -- Chairman Hamilton, an hour after he had landed here this morning, was assailing Chairman Farley and the New Deal's policies on relief and agriculture, picturing the dairy farmer, producing between one-fourth and one-fifth of the agricultural income of America, as Secretary Wallace's "forgotten man."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Mary Astor, film actress, testified today that she once told her divorced husband, Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, that he was aware of her relationship with George Kaufman, dramatist, and he condoned it. Miss Astor added that she told her former husband:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Westchester County will have to appropriate an additional $240,000 for relief, old-age pensions and other special services this year, the Board of Supervisors was informed at its monthly meeting today. The board appropriated $75,000 for current needs for home relief and hospitalization and created eleven new positions in the division of old-age pensions at salaries totaling $5,360 for the rest of the year.

Since a tax on tea was the precursor of a revolution on this continent, it is not wholly humorous that some of the most fevered charges in the Kentucky Democratic primary, just concluded, concerned State levies on what might be called necessary luxuries. Lipstick and frozen confections are taken as everyday things, within the reach of all, until they become, as in Kentucky, objects of special taxation.

The Warner Brothers' music publishing subsidiaries, which withdrew from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers on Jan. 1 after a dispute over music royalties, were reinstated by the society yesterday at a meeting of the directors.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- An "aggressive" campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt, to start immediately, was planned this afternoon at a two-hour conference between the President and Democratic leaders at Hyde Park House.

Although it seems that the Federal Trade Commission has been using the system for years, five New York residents, picked at random, were mildly surprised yesterday to receive in the morning mail subpoenas requesting them to appear before that body and testify about a subject of which they might know little or nothing.

In its report for the six months ended on June 30 the Coca-Cola Company shows a net profit of $8,137,773, after Federal income taxes, dividend requirements on the Class A stock and other charges. No provision was made for the Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

HAVANA, Aug. 3. -- Representing the Chase National Bank of New York, the American bondholders contractors' group this morning met with Secretary of the Treasury German Wolter del Rio for the first of a series of conferences which, it is hoped, will lead to the establishment of an acceptable formula for the resumption of servicing of the defaulted public works bonds and bankers' credits.

WINNIPEG, Aug. 3. -- Lacking a clear majority over all parties and with a majority of only five over its Conservative rivals, the Liberal Progressive party, headed by Premier John Bracken, will probably unite with Conservatives under Errick Willis to form a coalition government in Manitoba.

SO far, so good. Jesse Owens must have been in a bit of a hurry in that 100-meter final at Berlin. Ordinarily he lets his rivals get a fair start on him in his sprint races. Possibly he does that to make it a fair race and give the spectators a thrill. But a Berlin yesterday he forgot to be polite. He dusted right to the front.

TOPEKA, Aug. 3. -- Immediate steps for the preservation of the livestock breeding herds of Kansas, existence of which is threatened by the drought, were urged today by Governor Landon in a speech broadcast from station WIBW. The Governor pointed out that over a twenty-year period the value of the State's livestock products had totaled $2,738,352,141 and that the future of banking and business in Kansas was bound up in the preservation of these herds.

Efforts will be made by the New York Curb Exchange to expand substantially its unlisted trading department upon the effectiveness on Nov. 27 of the new rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission governing unlisted dealings on registered Exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The government ended the first month of its fiscal year on July 31 with a deficit for the month of $123,221,873, against $448,626,133 on the same date the year before, the Treasury announced today.
Retailers and manufacturers of various types of clothing figured in many space leases announced yesterday. Several firms in the garment district expanded their quarters.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, Aug. 3. -- A tri-motored Italian monoplane roared out of Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, this morning and dropped seven bombs in the Straits of Gibraltar around the loyal cruiser Libertad, which was engaged in shelling the fortress at Tarifa, Spain.

Bobby Pastor, young New York heavyweight, earned the decision over Billy Ketchell of Philadelphia in the main bout of eight rounds before 3,000 at Dexter Park, Brooklyn, last night. Pastor, at 184, was six and one-half pounds heavier than the Quaker City boxer.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Detroit turned back Cleveland, 9 -- 4, in the only major league game played today to push the Indians ten games behind the pace-setting Yankees.

MADRID, Aug. 3 (Passed by the Censor). -- Daily newspapers reappeared on the streets of Madrid tonight for the first time since yesterday noon. Accounts of what had happened on the various fronts in the thirty-six hours that had elapsed meanwhile did not agree as to details, but all agreed that the government forces were winning everywhere.

BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Gotthard Handrick, German army officer who is the favored competitor, led the field in the Olympic modern pentathlon today after a long session of fencing which ended in some confusion as to how the bladesmen fared.

GENEVA, Aug. 3. -- The statistical yearbook of the League of Nations, which came out today, contains some fascinating reading. It is a unique treasure mine, both in extraordinary and ordinary facts, and in figures, about a changing world.

The American Locomotive Company received orders for thirty-nine engines and shipped nineteen in the first half of 1936, William C. Dickerman, president, made known in his semi-annual report yesterday. The company had thirty-nine locomotives on order on July 1, all of which were expected to be shipped in the second half of the year.
Suburban homes provided one of the features of realty trading as reported by brokers in the metropolitan district yesterday. Dwellings in various parts of the suburban area figured in the dealings.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin denied yesterday two motions to punish judgment debtors for giving testimony said to be false in proceedings to collect on the judgments against them. The court was asked to fine or imprison the debtors, two of whom were a 70-year-old woman and her daughter, and the third the president of a lumber company.

Enactment by States of laws conforming to the Federal Robinson-Patman law, was advocated yesterday by Frank H. Foy, director of the National Association of Retail Grocers of the United States, in a speech before the opening session of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Food Merchants Association, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3. -- The Soviet Government is increasing pressure on light industry factories to try to catch up with the people's needs. As a matter of fact, production of such goods is higher now than ever before in Russia.
Value of Dollar in JExchango The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

Although some brokers felt that the dividends declared yesterday by General Motors Corporation on its common stock were unduly conservative, in view of the earnings of $2 a share in the second quarter, the payment was generally regarded as quite logical.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Secretary Ickes's radio speech tonight, in which he discussed Governor Landon, was as follows:

The compilation by the Police Department of a "trouble list" of children who show tendencies toward waywardness in their relationship with the public school system was advanced yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine as a practical step in meeting the city's juvenile delinquency problem.

The fathers of the girl and youth accused of the hatchet murder last Friday of Mrs. Helen MacKnight, 47 years old, in her home at 826 Avenue A, Bayonne, visited them yesterday in their cells in the Hudson County jail, Jersey City. Attaches and lawyers described the meetings as tearful.

The market for listed bonds came virtually to a standstill at intervals yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was the slowest for a full five-hour period since June 29, while leading issues drifted lazily about within narrow limits. Total transactions amounted to only $7,616,900, as compared with $13,116,600 on Friday.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Aug. 3.--John M. Gundry Jr. of Cleveland was seriously injured in an automobile accident Saturday night while returning to the home of his father-in-law, Anthony J. Drexel, at Cable Beach.

" Dorian Gray," an adaptation of the Oscar Wilde classic, has closed its run at the Comedy Theatre. It opened July 20 and its continuance through this week was in doubt until yesterday. There is a possibility that it will resume its career later on, but in that event there will be several cast changes.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The Maidstone Club's annual invitation tennis tournament, in which ranking women players from all parts of the country take part, began this afternoon and will continue through Saturday. The players are being entertained by East Hampton hostesses.
Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, assailed yesterday the poll of The Farm Journal which recently showed Governor Landon leading President Roosevelt.

BRETTON WOODS, N. H., Aug. 3. -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes, who have occupied a cottage at Pecketts on Sugar Hill since early July, leave tomorrow on a trip to Maine resorts and the Maritime Provinces. They plan to return in September.

Details of the refunding plan for Atlantic City, N.J., agreed upon by the protective committee for holders of bonds of the city and the city officials, were announced yesterday by the committee. As of July 31, 1933, tax revenue and tax title bonds were outstanding in the amount of $4,480,000, of which $525,000 were held in the city sinking fund.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents. These dividends are equal to the regular and extra distributions ordered in the preceding quarter, which, together, constituted the largest cash payment made by the corporation at one time on its common stock.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- Mrs. Walter Belknap James opened her home, Rockhurst, this afternoon for a piano recital by Miska Merson, Hungarian pianist. Two hundred guests were present and Mrs. James was hostess of a tea after the recital.

Most commodity futures were higher on the markets here yesterday. Hides, sugar and wool tops eased. On the cash markets, cotton declined, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, butter, lard, tin and silk advanced.

Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in New York County, has been investigating the widespread poultry racket, it was revealed yesterday during contempt proceedings before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 3. -- Alleging that the verdict against Pedro Albizu Campos and others convicted of conspiracy to overthrow the government had been contrary to the law and the evidence and that the defendants had not had a fair trial because three jurors had been biased, Representative Vito Marcantonio of New York argued this afternoon before Judge Cooper for a new trial.

MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 3. -- Two hundred "Communists" armed with rifles, shotguns, pistols and stones besieged the house of Mayor Maillaux of St. Zacharie about twenty-five miles from here all last night and this morning. Shots were fired and at least four of the Mayor's supporters, one a woman, of the French "Popular party," formerly the Croix de Feu, were wounded.

Further liquidation in the process of preparing for next Saturday's government crop estimate eased prices on the Cotton Exchange 15 points yesterday, but a late rally left the list only 3 to 6 points lower than on Saturday. Commission-house interests released October contracts and the near month again dipped below the 12-cent level to 11.99 cents, but recovered 10 points on light trading.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission of $1,300,000 of 5 per cent mortgage sinking-fund bonds and several blocks of common and preferred shares of the Hamilton Manufacturing Company was sought in a statement filed today.

Fall lines of handbags, costume jewelry and gloves were shown by 148 exhibitors yesterday at the opening of the National Fashion Accessories Show at the Hotel New Yorker. About 300 buyers were on hand for the opening.

Ever since weekly statements of freight transported on the railways began last Autumn to show much the largest business since 1931, particular interest has been taken in the railway earnings of 1936. In no calendar year since 1931 had Class I railways as a whole reported net income from all sources sufficient to meet their aggregate fixed charges.
I read with interest a letter to THE TIMES from W.H. Nutter of Boston, who pleads for the sympathy of the country for Wall Street and stock brokers, and urines support for Mr. Landon.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Mrs. Caroline O'Day, Representative at Large from New York and vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, announced her candidacy for re-election here today at a conference with Democratic women from Cattaraugus, Chautauqua, Erie, Genesee and Niagara Counties.

Tony Falco, Philadelphia welterweight, outpointed Andre Jessurun of Washington Heights in the feature bout of ten rounds at Dyckman Oval last night. A crowd of 6,000 persons saw the battle, which was staged for the benefit of the equipment fund of Jewish Memorial Hospital.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Five American catch-as-catch-can wresters won and one lost today in Olympic competition.

OYSTER BAY, L,I., Aug. 3. -Miss Margery A. Bavier, representing the Larchmont Yacht Club, won three straight races today in the series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound. The last contest was started this evening and finished just before dark across the Sound off Greenwich Point.
BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- Gradually the proportions of this German Olympic effort and the extent of the preparations made for it are becoming realized by foreign visitors. This takes time.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- New cottagers arriving today from New York were Mr. and Mrs. Nelson I. Asiel, who leased the villa of Mrs. Leland Sterry Sr., and Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Guggenheim, who will occupy the villa of Mrs. Webster Curran Moriarty.

Mr. Sopwith sought unsuccessfully to capture the America's Cup in the last series held for the trophy off Newport in the Fall of 1934. At that time he challenged with his first Endeavour and acted as the skipper. Mrs. Sopwith, who was timekeeper on her husband's craft, was the first woman listed as a member of the crew of an America's Cup yacht in an international match, as far as the records show.

Covering practically all types of merchandise, Fall orders placed in the local merchandise market yesterday by visiting buyers and through the mail were estimated to run about 10 to 15 per cent ahead of last year. Not only was women's and children's apparel bought heavily, but dry goods staples, such as cotton goods and blankets, house furnishings and men's and boys' clothing and furnishings, sold freely.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Paul Runyan, metropolis professional, turned in an individual card of 69 to set a new competitive record for the course, in the weekly pro-amateur golf tournament conducted by the Westchester P.G.A., at Mount Kisco Golf Club today.

Inasmuch as the Supreme Court has ruled frequently that Congress cannot legislate control of acts strictly in intrastate commerce, the Robinson-Patman Act cannot in any manner be interpreted as applying to purely intrastate transactions, the National Retail Dry Goods Association said yesterday in a bulletin analyzing the effects of the law on retail business.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 3. -The first settlements in the strike by operators of 4.000 "family" silk! looms in this city, which began last J Wednesday in an effort to raise the price 25 per cent, were announced tonight by Abraham Brenman, counsel to the Silk Commission Manufacturers Association.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- One hundred and thirty-three boats, one under the record, took part in the opening-day program of the twenty-first annual race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association today. The fleet gathered off the Babylon Yacht Club at noon and after the customary salutes the regatta committeemen had luncheon as guests of the local club.
BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- America's Olympic soccer team literally went down fighting today in losing a 1-0 decision to Italy before a crowd of 7,000, including the Italian Crown Prince Umberto.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- American vessels in the North Atlantic carried more passengers during the first six months of 1936 than during the same period of 1935, James Craig Peacock, director of the Shipping Board Bureau of the Department of Commerce, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on July 29 shows a decrease for the week of $68,000,000 in total loans and investments, an increase of $43,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $72,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- School administrators and pupil personnel workers opened a five day conference at Cornell University today, studying ways and means of assisting the "unadjusted" pupil in and out of school.

After his recent conference with ex-Governor LOWDEN about an agricultural policy, Governor LANDON said that he hoped one might be worked out so satisfactory to all parties that it could be "taken out of politics." This is an engaging but, we fear, a forlorn hope.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The Boerse, at the opening today, suffered a sharp reaction, the decline being most marked among the heavy industrials, causing losses as high as 5 points in this section. This reversal was ascribed to disappointment over the one-half of 1 per cent dividend increase by Hoesch, a larger rise having been expected, but the reaction soon became general throughout the list.
