Frank Leto, 14-year-old bootblack who lives with his widowed mother at 1,103 First Avenue, and his friend, George Cummella, 15, also a bootblack of 1,149 Second Avenue, were defrauded yesterday of $7 and last night they were roaming the east side searching for a well-dressed, dignified man wearing a grey pin-striped suit.

Poisonous fumes felled twenty-two persons yesterday after a fire had melted the gas line of an air-conditioning unit in the fur storage vault of J. De Leo Co., Inc., on the seventeenth floor of 130 West Thirtieth Street.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The opening round of play in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today saw the favorites come through in every match played.
PARIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- France felt "free" tonight to move war supplies into Spain if her proposed neutrality agreement with Great Britain and Italy was not accepted quickly.

Hundreds of persons who have been released from Federal prisons and are now on probation may be recommitted as a result of a decision handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The views of "Governor" Landon, "Oil-Man" Landon, and "Candidate" Landon, were discussed tonight by Secretary Ickes in his first contribution to the speaking campaign for the re-election of President Roosevelt.
PARIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- France felt "free" tonight to move war supplies into Spain if her proposed neutrality agreement with Great Britain and Italy was not accepted quickly.

Hundreds of persons who have been released from Federal prisons and are now on probation may be recommitted as a result of a decision handed down yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

Speaker Irving M. Ives of the Assembly and Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse, aspirant for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, delivered sharp assaults on President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman last night.

With the foreign exchange market dull, interest yesterday centered on a meeting of dealers to discuss problems relating to business in the peseta in view of the banking moratorium in Spain. It is not so much the contracts between banks here and banks in Spain that are causing the difficulty, since settlement could be arbitrarily delayed.

With the warning that he would tolerate no "loafers," boondoggling or "politics," Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, army engineer, assumed the office of Works Progress Administrator for this city yesterday upon the retirement of Victor F. Ridder, who served as WPA chief since last October and now returns to his publishing business.
The fifty-third annual convention of the Dancing Masters of America went political yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- Lyolene stages a dramatic return to the Paris couture through a sports group designed for Rosineparis. Her two-piece dresses with unusual flared and gored skirts and pockets at one side of the tops are feminine and practical.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Several of the players who will figure in the national polo championships later this month began preparation for them today with practice matches on the fields of the Meadow Brook Club. Three games were sandwiched in between showers, with several spots in them full of fast action.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Julius S. Rippel, foreman of the Federal grand jury investigating the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, said today that he stood by his statement of last night asking witnesses in the case not to attend the scheduled extradition hearing before Governor Hoffman Thursday, in spite of the Governor's explanation that he was willing to sit for a month, if necessary, to hear the evidence.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents on its stock. On June 12 a dividend of 25 cents was paid. According to Vincent Bendix, president of the company, this dividend is not an increase in the regular rate but merely the declaration of a dividend. Owing to the Revenue Act of 1936, he said, the company's policy of declaring regular dividends has been discontinued.

Macmillan believes that an all-time record for the sale of a new fiction title was set last week by Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind." In one day this novel of the South during the Civil War sold 50,000 copies. A total sale of less than that will often keep a book on best seller lists for weeks.

A story of stray bullets, sniping and looting in the streets of Barcelona was told here yesterday by athletes who went to the Spanish city for the People's Olympics. They returned on the Normandie Monday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Drought and intense heat cut nearly 700,000,000 bushels from the United States corn crop in July, as indicated by estimates of five local statisticians, the greatest loss ever sustained in this or any other country within such a short time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Instructions have been given by the State Department to all its diplomatic and consular officers in Spain to give every attention to American property rights and interests after having given first consideration to the safety of American nationals.

One of the blessings promised by the Union party is that it will never permit any citizen more than a certain income. Asked the other day just how large this maximum income might be, Mr. LEMKE, the party's candidate for President, said that he thought about $500,000 would do for the limit.

Mayor LA GUARDIA does well to remind the Police Commissioner that he expects the anti-noise campaign to be kept up in full vigor. It was not begun as a mere pleasing gesture, and is to be continued in dead earnest. Undoubtedly there has been something of a lapse from the first efforts at enforcement and their results.

MADRID, Aug. 4. -- A workers' army division under General Mangada, after recapturing San Rafael in artillery and infantry action which was reported to have left the small town little more than a pile of debris, succeeded in isolating the rebel garrison holding Leon Pass today.

Judge William Allen of General Sessions, following a half-hour argument yesterday, reserved decision on a motion to inspect the minutes of the June grand jury that indicted Robert Edward Edmondson, pamphleteer, on allegations that he libeled the Jewish religion, Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard and Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Evening Bulletin in a copyrighted story today said that Frederick L. Jenckes, former head of the Manville-Jenckes Company, has publicly guaranteed to cover the wager offered at East Providence Sunday by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, of $25,000 at 3 to 2 that Representative Lemke, Union Party candidate for President, would lead Landon in the November election.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 4. -- A record entry of 146 boats for the annual race week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association competed today in the second of a six-day program. In addition, the number of sight-seeing boats also exceeded the usual spectator fleet.

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 4. -- The progress of General Emilio Mola's rebel army has been slower than he expected some days ago, but on returning to Burgos after a few days' absence one finds that the line has nevertheless been advanced further toward Madrid.

A third postponement of the Tony Canzoneri-Lou Ambers lightweight championship bout was sanctioned by the New York State Athletic Commission at its weekly meeting yesterday. Originally scheduled as an outdoor attraction for July 16 and later put off until July 30 and Aug. 6, the fight now is planned indoors at Madison Square Garden on the night of Sept. 3.

DENVER, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Charles M. Armstrong, State Treasurer, was designated the Republican nominee for Governor today by an overwhelming vote in the party's State Assembly a few hours after he denied that he "propositioned Governor Johnson to give him (Johnson) a $10,000 bribe" for granting clemency to convicted members of a safe-blowing gang.
Communicable diseases in New York dropped during the week ended Aug. 1, the Health Department reported yesterday.

BROCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP). -- A community divided within itself prepared today for the trial of Idaho, the mongrel pup charged with causing a boy's death by drowning. All the fanfare of an important criminal case attended the preparations.
BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Rebel advances on all fronts with heavy casualties among government forces were claimed here tonight.

The market value of all shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $3,154,526,993 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average share price of all listed stocks on Aug. 1 was $40.30, compared with $38 at the beginning of July.

An issue of State of West Virginia road bonds was awarded yesterday to Brown Harriman Co., Inc., on a bid of 100.0099 at a net interest cost of 2.2348 per cent.' The bonds consist of $120,000principal' ' ' amount of bonds due on Sept. 1, 1936 to 1941, inclusive, as 2 per cents, and of $380,000 due on Sept. 1, 1942 to 1960, inciusive as 2s.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Secretary Ickes said today that he hoped President Roosevelt would modify his order under which public works under the new $450,000,000 PWA program must use relief labor exclusively.

The bond market was steady in most branches yesterday, with trading at a somewhat better pace than on Monday, $8,384,300 worth of bonds changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, against $7,616,900 the day before. Of the total $571,300 represents United States Government bonds, against $526,900, and domestic bonds were $6,923,000, compared with $6,219,000.

SEATTLE, Aug. 4. -- After announcing last Saturday night that he was through with politics, Representative Marion A. Zioncheck drove to the State Capitol at Olympia this afternoon and filed for re-election as Representative from the First Congressional District.
BERLIN, Aug. 4 (AP). -- America's wrestlers won one first and three second places in final Olympic catch-as-catch-can wrestling competition today.

MINEOLA, L.I. Aug. 4. -- Robert Walsh, 93-year-old veteran, who fought with Theodore Roosevelt's Rough Riders in the Spanish-American War, died today in Nassau Hospital of a fractured skull suffered when he was attacked last night in Great Neck by a man who robbed him of $26.

Because of yesterday's heavy registrations, the number of buyers reported in the market in the last week was well above the figures for the preceding week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listing, in THE TIMES.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 4. -- Dr. and Mrs. Stewart Lee Jeffrey of New York and Coconut Grove, Fla., observed the sixteenth anniversary of their marriage with a party at the Mount Washington Hotel, Bretton Woods,

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- A 21-year-old Philadelphian who came here to go swimming and who was coaxed into joining three Chicago contract-bridge players in a pick-up team, found himself a member of the championship combination at the close of play in the national mixed team-of-four competition of the American Bridge League tonight.
MACON, Ga., Aug. 4 (AP). -- A 17-year-old girl claimed by two families as a result of a baby mix-up, left today the one which reared her in favor of the other which she had not seen until a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Suspension of some of the unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization by noon tomorrow was indicated as a strong possibility tonight at the close of the second day's session of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, which has been considering charges that the C.I.O. unions are seeking to build up a rival labor organization.

Declaring that the organized independent grocers are gradually 'eating into" the business of the large chain store organizations, John Barrus of the Curtis Publishing Company yesterday urged retailers to support nationally advertised brands of food products.

GREELEY, Col., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Representative William Lemke of North Dakota, Union party candidate for President, said tonight that destruction of democracy in this country was inevitable unless issues now before the people were disposed of rightly.

DENVER, Aug. 4. -- John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, told a Colorado audience tonight that farmers and cattlemen have been the chief complainants against the Roosevelt administration's reciprocal trade agreements.

The Merchandise Reporting Company, Inc., resident buyers, will hold on Aug. 11 a "round table discussion" on advertising by retail ad representatives. A "Fall fashion commentary" is scheduled for Aug. 12.

This being Wednesday, note two new films on Broadway. "The Road to Glory," a Twentieth Century-Fox picture at the Rivoli, was adapted from a story and screen play by William Faulkner and Joel Sayre and once was identified as "Wooden Crosses."

On several journalistic visits to Palestine I have studied the complicated Zionist question -- studied it until my head was awhirl and my heart heavy with sympathy for both sides. Two incontrovertible facts always emerged; and I venture to suggest that these be held in mind by all who consider the subject.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- President Roosevelt will probably spend most of his time when not traveling this Summer at Hyde Park House, making it his headquarters in preference to the White House in Washington.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- The world corn crop is expected to be about 900,000,000 bushel below normal production. Every major corn-growing region on the globe, with the exception of Argentina, has shorter crops this year than the five-year average from 1929 to 1933.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP). -- William Hutcheson of Indianapolis, president of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, was appointed director of the Republican National Committee's labor division today. His selection was announced by Arthur M. Curtis, assistant to Chairman John D.M. Hamilton.
VaIue of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on thedates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

A drop in quotations for the German mark and a weakening of the French franc featured yesterday a quiet foreign exchange market. Now that the use of discounted marks and barter arrangements in German-American trade has been forbidden, several classifications of "blocked" marks are declining.
ATHENS, Aug. 4. -- An article today in the economic periodical Ikonomolagos Athinon seems to indicate a revolt against the German trade policy of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the Reich Economics Minister.
The first statement made by Lieut. Col. SOMERVELL, the new Works Progress Administrator for this city, goes straight to the point in defining his conception of his job:

Eastern leaders of the Republican campaign to elect Governor Landon hit back yesterday at criticisms of the Republican candidate voiced by Secretary of the Interior Ickes. At the same time, Melvin C. Eaton, State chairman, announced that a meeting of the Republican State committee would be held in Syracuse on Aug. 19 to issue a call for the State convention and select Presidential and Vice Presidential electors.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Many dinner parties will be given before the preview of the new motion picture "Nine Days a Queen," with Cedric Hardwicke and Nova Pilbeam in the leading roles, which will take place the night of Aug. 13 let the Southampton Theatre for the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.

gtores figured prominently as lessees in the midtown area yesterday and in some instances large space was contracted for. The Interstate Broadcasting Company leased at 730 Fifth Avenue through the Cross Brown Company with Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., who also rented at 452 Fifth Avenue, to Brown Wells, Inc., as broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- A steady increase in public ownership of electric utility plants since 1929, matched by a drop in the number of privately owned units, was disclosed today In a report of the Federal Power Commission.

O.P. Van Sweringen, president of the Alleghany Corporation, formerly the top company in his railway holding structure, has bought 2,200 shares of the company's preferred stock with $30-warrants and $423,000 of its 5 per cent bonds of 1950, stamped in assent to its reorganization plan, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- A protest against the French Government's intention of transporting, stone by stone, the Gothic chapel of Chauvire le Chatel to the Metropolitan Museum in New York was lodged in the Chamber of Deputies today by Deputy Drouot, representing the Haute Saone region, where the chapel now stands.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- The opening round of the scheduled three-round cellar championship battle between the Dodgers and Phillies went to Professor Casey Stengel's leather pushers today by a 6-5 decision, but they were hanging on the ropes at the finish.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- The defeat of Mrs. Sylvia Henrotin of France by Miss Helen Pedersen of Stamford, Conn., was the outstanding development today in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Replying to the indictment brought against the National Petroleum News and Platt's Oilgram by a Federal grand jury in Madison, Wis., alleging a conspiracy to fix oil prices, Warren C. Platt of Cleveland, publisher of both papers, asserted tonight that they had printed the prices as news.

Alfred A. Cook, chairman of the judiciary committee of the Bar Association, declared yesterday that he wanted to make clear that the Bar Association endorsement of Judge Morris Koenig for re-election to the General Sessions bench was based upon Judge Koenig's experience and not upon any bipartisan "deal."

Your Tokyo correspondent's dispatch informs us that the Japanese Air Force is to be reorganized as a single department of aviation. That will leave our own air force as the only one divided into two parts between the army and the navy. The Japanese Air Minister will be directly appointed by the Emperor, with rank equal to that of the Secretaries of War and of the Navy.
WILLIAMS BAY, Wis., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Peltier's comet in the northern sky puzzled astronomers before dawn today by losing its tail.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 4. -- After five races had been concluded this afternoon in the series to determine the women's championship crew of Long Island Sound the Larchmont trio of Miss Margery A. Bavier, skipper; Miss Sarah Whiting and Miss Allegra Knapp came out clearly victorious.

BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- A patient vigil of the Yankees was rewarded at Fenway Park today as the league leaders launched a three-game siege of the Red Sox playground. They finally caught up with Robert Moses Grove and subjected this erudite southpaw and his red-hosed mates to a 4-to-2 setback, the first conquest of the Boston flinger a Yankee team has scored in two years.
BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- Bringing tales of terror, twenty-six refugees from Spain, most of them Americans, arrived in Boston today aboard the American Export liner Exeter.

It is encouraging to read that Mayor La Guardia has written to the State Superintendent of Insurance with a view to having automobile rates for personal injury and property damage reduced. About a year ago the Mayor gave assurance that he would give the problem his attention.

In announcing a dividend of 25 cents a share on capital stock, the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., estimated yesterday consolidated earnings in the first half of this year at $20,000,000 after all charges, reserves, losses from foreign exchange operations and normal income tax, but not including the surtax on undistributed earnings.

There is a new player in the match for the Republican nomination for Senator in New Hampshire. Governor BRIDGES, Mr. GEORGE MOSES and Senator KEYES must be pleased to meet him. Mr. JOSEPH MOORE, a lawyer of Canaan, has announced his candidacy. Mr. MOORE is for the Townsend Plan as "the soundest, speediest and most economical plan yet offered "; but it isn't sound, speedy and economical enough.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP). -- With Tommy Bridges pitching five-hit shutout ball and the Tigers continuing their heavy hitting, Detroit defeated Cleveland today, 9 to 0. It was Bridges's fourteenth victory this season.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Four radio networks in the future will flash warnings over land and sea in a concerted effort to reduce the life and property toll taken by tropical storms in Florida.

All the elements of professional automobile racing entered into the boys' Soap Box Derby held at the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City yesterday afternoon. There were injuries, spills, an enthusiastic crowd estimated at more than 25,000 persons, and even a disqualification of the winner.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Riding a swelling crest of ballots that followed his personal endorsement by T.J. Pendergast, Major Lloyd C. Stark took a commanding lead over William Hirth, State farm leader, in their race for Missouri's Democratic Gubernatorial nomination late tonight.

INDEPENDENCE, Kan., Aug. 4. -- Governor Landon came back to his home town today and cast his ballot in the State primary election in the same district in which he was beaten for precinct committeeman six years ago. It was his first visit here since his nomination for the Presidency.

Your editorial deprecation and a reader's approval of ex-Controller General McCarl's making campaign use of his official experience prompt a reminder that is widely needed wherever taxpayers' money is being spent.

BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- Mrs. A.W. Abbott's Dancing Doll drove to a length victory over Bien Fait from the Corsicana Stable to pay $9.60 for $2 straight, while being timed in 1:11 2-5 for the six furlongs of the Brockton Purse before 15,000 at Suffolk Downs today.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Charges by The Star that British civil airplanes had been sold to Spaniards and delivered in Spain in the past few days could not be confirmed in official quarters tonight. The Air Ministry stated that exports of military machines were supervised, but that there were no restrictions on exports of civil aircraft.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 4. -President Roosevelt turned momentarily today from a detailed study of drought relief and its cost to criticize sharply those who have pictured his proposed inspection trip into the West as a political tour.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (A). -- Two of nine prominent Chicagoans accused of price-fixing in the oil industry surrendered here late today and were released in bonds of $5,000 each.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 4. -Mrs. Harrington Mills of Washington, Mrs. Harold H. Hackett and Mrs. R.G. Monroe, both of New York, and Mrs. Joseph J. NIorsman of Chicago were judges of costumes at the annual Mother Goose party for children held on the lawn at Saranac Inn this afternoon.

MADRID, Aug. 4 (Passed by the Censor). -- More than 7,000 Fascists are imprisoned in Madrid, including many priests, army officers and noblemen. As there is not sufficient room in the regional prison, the women's prison is housing many of these Rightists.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The London Stock Exchange reopened quietly today after the bank holiday, speculative activity being dampened by the foreign situation and the approaching end of the account, although a number of firm features were in the list.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Workers on the rolls of the WPA in three projects directed by the Bureau of Internal Revenue have already discovered $16,494,811,75 additional revenue due the government, the Treasury Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Resettlement Administration has put at 125,000 the number of rural families which it expects to aid before another crop can be raised. It is now financing about 32,000 families and the large majority of these have been receiving grants.

The preparations for "Daughters of Atreus" move forward. Robert Turney, who wrote it, and Frederic McConnell, who is to direct, are in town conferring with Delos Chappell; and Jo Mielziner, the designer, arrives on the Queen Mary on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- A secret study of means to circumvent any "undue speculation" in supplies of feed grains and forage was started today by government drought relief authorities.
In my wanderings through the amazing streets of New York City I unexpectedly hit upon New York's first flat mentioned in many books on old New York but never definitely located.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The British Labor party is actively soliciting funds to help the Spanish Government fight the rebels. It began its efforts soon after the outbreak of hostilities and has received money from many British labor unions and individuals to swell the International Solidarity Fund.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 4. -- A lively squall struck a portion of the Eastern Yacht Club's big fleet of 374 boats this afternoon, sinking one, capsizing two and bringing about the dismasting of a fourth, besides inflicting much damage to spars, rigging and canvas.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The Royal Yacht Squadron today cabled to the Near York Yacht Club Britain's six-teenth challenge for the America's Cup on behalf of T.O.M. Sopwith, who plans to race for the coveted trophy with his new Endeavour II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended today the effectiveness of nine offering sheets of royalty interests on the ground that the sheets were incomplete or inaccurate in one or more respects. In setting hearings on the offerings, the commission announced that these might be avoided by amendment or correction.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- Fear of complications resulting from the dragging on of the civil war in Spain and the partisan attitude of outsiders have unfavorably influenced operations and prices on the Bourse. It is becoming evident that neither side in the Spanish quarrel has ammunition or force enough to push matters to a quick conclusion.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The paddock sales of yearlings which opened tonight brought many new visitors here for the racing. They include Mr. and Mrs. George Sloane, who joined Mr. and Mrs. Harry F. Guggenheim, F. Skiddy von Stade and Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Turnbull of New York and Representative James Simpson Jr. and Mrs. Simpson and Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Albert of Great Neck, L.I.
Residences, stores and apartment properties in various parts of Westchester figured in active dealing reported for that county yesterday.

Charges against three millinery houses for paying fees to about a dozen commission buying offices, in alleged violation of the Robinson-Patman law, were filed yesterday with the Federal Trade Commission by Joseph H. Dryer, president of the National Council of Traveling Salesmen's Associations of America.
MADRID, Aug. 2 (London Times Dispatch). -- A fortnight has passed[ since the first flash of revoltl started a conflict that is shaking! this republic to its foundations. I All is trmoil and strife.
DUBLIN, Aug. 4. -- Dublin's famous horse show opened today with a fine array of Irish bloodstock in the judging rings and a record attendance for the first day.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Trevor Hill gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis to celebrate Mrs. Hill's birthday. The other guests were Dr. and Mrs. Richard N. Pierson, Mr. and Mrs. John M. Whitaker, Dr. and Mrs. John Harry Iselin, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred W. Paine.

Harry Balsamo, promising Harlem middleweight, moved a step nearer a bout for the championship last night at the Queensboro Arena by knocking out Paul Pirrone of Cleveland in the opening round of a scheduled ten-round feature bout before 4,500 spectators.

The protective committee for Hudson River Day Line first mortgage 6 per cent bonds made public yesterday a plan of reorganization for the company, which has been in receivership since 1933. The plan provides for participation of all bondholders, maritime lienors, unsecured creditors and stockholders, and to become effective must be approved and accepted by holders of two-thirds of each class of claims and by holders of a majority of each class of stock.
BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- The reaction in prices on the ]3oerse continued I today, but the setback seemed to I slow down toward the close. Some i issues were able even to improve from the day's low marks.
The last stumbling blocks faced by Under-Sheriff Arthur Jaeger in his task of evicting occupants from the World's Fair site were being removed last night.

AURIESVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Here in this quiet little Mohawk Valley village thousands of Catholics will assemble Aug. 16 to honor the memory of the North American martyrs -- seven members of the Society of Jesus, slain by the Iroquois nearly three centuries ago.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- A $1,500 yearling of last year, which already has proved himself a bargain, earned an additional $2,025 today when the Bostonian colt Maedic was first in the fifteenth running of the Saratoga Sales Stakes. On the opening day this fellow won the Flash for the Maemere Farm, and he made it two in a row by a couple of lengths.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Twelve-year-old Louie was home again today, after an absence of two years, and was being entertained with the welcome for a long-lost son. Louie, a homing pigeon owned by H.P. Urbain of 1,204 Hall Avenue, this city, was liberated two years ago in the Jungles of Colombia, South America, and had been given up for lost by Mr. Urbain.

Testimony is abundant to support ex-Mayor WALKER'S statement that Tammany Hall's "brains" lie buried with CHARLES F. MURPHY. Certainly since the death of that leader the masters of the machine have made blunder after blunder, the latest -- and that which evoked Mr. WALKER'S epigram -- being the refusal to designate Judge GOLDSTEIN for renomination.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Aug. 5. -- The Central Government's growing strength and prestige resulting from its success in extending its sway over Southwest China were emphasized today in news from Peiping.

Commodity futures markets here were irregular yesterday, in quiet trading. Coffee, rubber and hides showed sharp declines, while price changes either way in other commodities were small, In the cash markets silk, wool tops and butter were higher and wheat, corn, rye, oats, cocoa, lard, cotton, rubber, hides and tin were lower.

While surgeons performed two operations at Woman's Hospital, 141 West 109th Street, yesterday, firemen answering a "still" alarm extinguished a blaze in the main kitchen on the sixth floor and in a storeroom on the floor above.

Plans for buildings filed by architects in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens consisted largely of dwelling and tenement projects. Manhattan construction activity was confined to plans for altering existing structures.

The long-awaited reply of District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn to the Drukman special grand jury's charges demanding his removal from office was expected to be on Governor Lehman's desk in Albany this morning, the final date set by the Governor for the District Attorney's explanation.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The White Sox battered two relief hurlers for six runs in the last two frames and beat the Browns, 8-2, in their series opener today behind the steady pitching of Ted Lyons.

The report of the Radio Corporation of America and subsidiaries for the second quarter of 1936 showed a consolidated net profit of $477,088, covering $431,143 Class A preferred dividends but not the $805,242 dividends paid on the new $3.50 convertible first preferred stock. This compared with $671,111 earned in the second quarter of 1935.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- A committee of railway presidents and attorneys will meet here on Friday, it was announced today by the Association of American Railroads, to consider procedure to be followed in the light of the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission today denying the petition of the Class I railroads for modification of outstanding orders that would enable the railroads to make permanent present emergency charges.

It is always interesting to get the reactions of a sportsman who has taken a whirl at some new fishing experience. Hence, we give you M.M. Zimmerman of this city, who brings a breath of the cool Canadian northland, where he sought the noble Atlantic salmon.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The All-Continent Corporation was ordered today to show cause at 10 A.M. next Tuesday before Robert E. Steedle, Federal referee, why its books and records should not be turned over to him for audit in the William Fox bankruptcy proceedings.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Sidney B. Wood Jr., former Wimbledon champion and the highest ranking player in the field, was eliminated from the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today, along with Wilmer Hines and David Jones.

" According to a report on good authority (from hospitals and casas de socorro) the dead in Barcelona amounted to between 6,000 and 8,000 in four days after the fighting started," says Professor Walter W. S. Cook of New York University, who has just returned from a six weeks' tour of Spain.

ROME, Aug. 4. -- Premier Mussolini is pondering the reply the Italian Government is to make to the French suggestion that Britain, France and Italy maintain the strictest neutrality in the Spanish civil war.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Serving of warrants on twenty-three of the country's mayor oil companies and sixty-one others named in an indictment charging violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law through price-fixing was started today as the latest step in a broad government inquiry into alleged, illegal practices in the industry.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- This reporter took an airplane trip today, narrowly missed the Capitol dome and knocked a chunk out of the Washington Monument -- all without leaving terra firma.

Special detectives, who have been watching loiterers in the theatrical district since a murder in a subway station and in a hallway a few months ago, trapped a former pugilist early this morning as he lured a drunken man to a house on Forty-ninth Street and stole $61 from him and charged the prisoner with assault.

TANGIER, International Zone, Morocco, Aug. 4. -- Staff officers of the German battleship Deutschland and the destroyer Luchs, which arrived yesterday at Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, landed and were received by General Francisco Franco, Spanish rebel leader, at his headquarters.

IT appears now that the Olympic arrangements at Berlin are not quite perfect. Twice there have been following winds that caused the officials to toss out what would have been world's records by Jesse Owens. If that's the prevailing wind in the Berlin territory, they should have run the sprints in the opposite direction.

Economic unrest, resulting in strikes and bloody clashes between strikers and the army and police, has been growing steadily in Greece for several months. The strike movement, originating with tobacco workers, started in May and has been marked by attempted general strikes in various cities.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The Charge d'Affaires of the French Embassy in London received from the Foreign Office this afternoon the British Government's favorable reply to the appeal from the Quai d'Orsay for a policy of non-interference in the Spanish civil war.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- Glen Cunningham's leg soreness, about which he has been complaining since arriving here, won't be with him when he starts the 1,500-meter eliminations tomorrow, Dr. Herbert Lawson, American team physician, predicted today.

Although the idea that large corporations will divert a part of their income to advertising, market and product research, , in order to escape the tax on surpluses is no longer hushed, as it was when first advanced, doubt was expressed yesterday that any company would admit such a procedure, when 1937 advertising budgets are made public, it was said here yesterday.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,948,000 barrels, compared with 2,960,950 in the previous week, a decline of 12,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 20,300 barrels in the daily average output of California was the most important change.

If there remained any doubt as to Freddy Fitzsimmons's eligibility for a regular starting assignment with the Giants it was thoroughly dispelled yesterday at the Polo Grounds. In complete command from start to finish, the veteran right-hander set down the Bees with five hits as he pitched the Terrymen to a 4-1 triumph for his third victory of the season and kept the rejuvenated New Yorkers in the thick of the pennant race.

BAY SHORE, L.I., .Aug. 4. -- Two golfers from the western end of the island finished one-two in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day event for amateurs at the South Bay Golf Club today and neither one was proud of his score.
LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Britain's total of unemployed persons was lower in July for the sixth consecutive month, according to figures of the Ministry of Labor, issued tonight.

The stimulation of amateur athletics among organized labor as a profitable means of utilizing the greater amount of leisure now enjoyed by workers was advanced yesterday by Jeremiah T. Mahoney, former president of the National A.A.U., as the underlying purpose of the World Labor Athletic Carnival which will be held at Randalls Island, Aug. 15 and 16.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The names of twenty-three major oil companies, three trade publishing companies and fifty-eight individuals indicted on changes of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Law for alleged gasoline price fixing were made public today by the Department of Justice after the government moved to serve warrants on them out of the Federal District Court at Madison, Wis.

MONTREAL, Aug. 4 (Canadian Press). -- Montreal and Newark split a double-header tonight. Big Chad Kimsey pitched a 3-1 victory for the Royals in the twilight encounter of seven innings, and the Bears outslugged the Royals to win an eleven-inning struggle under the floodlights, 10 -- 8.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- For the first time since William Collins Whitney established the Whitney dynasty on the turf, yearlings from the stud he set up more than thirty years ago were sold at public auction here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Hopping on Monte Weaver's offerings for five runs in the first two innings, the Philadelphia Athletics defeated Washington today, 5 to 3, for their second triumph of the season over the Senators.

Offering to the public will be made today of $5,500,000 Chicago Illinois Midland Railway Company first-mortgage twenty-year sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent Series A bonds due on March 1, 1956, at 99 1/2 and interest, yielding about 4.54 per cent to maturity.

Secretary ICKES had no difficulty on Monday night in proving that Governor LANDON said things and took positions in 1933 and 1934 very different from what he is now saying and advocating. Almost any public man would be open to a similar charge during the same time.

The library of books on magic built up by the late Dr. Samuel Cox Hooker, chemist, at one time a director of the American Sugar Refining Company and an outstanding amateur magician, has been given by his heirs to the Society of American Magicians collection in the New York Public Library.
HAVANA, Aug. 4. -- By a unanimous vote the Senate defeated today Representative Evelio Pou's bill, which passed the Chamber June 3, for permitting the free exportation of alcohol.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

SEATTLE, Aug. 4. -- Leaders attending the National Conference of Catholic Charities turned today to a discussion of the "evil influence on youth" of dance halls, taverns and "bad" radio programs and music, speakers before the committee on youth activities sounding warnings that rural pastors must join the city clergy in the fight against improper motion pictures, books, radio programs and some entertainment places.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Miss Marion Miley, tall Lexington (Ky.) star, played another steady round today, while her chief rivals ran into trouble, to take the lead at the halfway mark of her campaign for a second Women's Western 72-hole golf derby triumph at the Midlothian Country Club.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 4. -- This resort is experiencing its greatest Summer season in history, according to hotel men, merchants and city officials, all of whom are welcoming the returning prosperity.

To look down from a high window in the small hours at the spangled lights of Manhattan is a little as if the firmament were upside down and one gazed down instead of up at the stars. This is the time the cleaners are at work in the office buildings and the midtown towers blaze like pillars of light supporting an inverted heaven.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- A program of preliminary flood-control work in New England and the Middle Atlantic States was put into shape by Federal officials today for submission to President Roosevelt "within twenty-four hours."

The New York World's Fair 1939, Inc., the organization sponsoring the World's Fair here in that year, filed its first suit yesterday when it brought an injunction action against the World's Fair News, Inc., Joseph F. Coufal, president, and John W. Seymour, treasurer.

TRENTON, Aug. 4. -- State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. reported today that factory employment in New Jersey increased 10.4 per cent in June compared with the same month last year; total weekly payrolls advanced 17.1 per cent, and average weekly earnings rose 6.1 per cent.

The final fortnight of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium will be inaugurated tonight with a concert under the direction of Willem van Hoogstraten, who returns to the amphitheatre's podium for the fifteenth consecutive year. He will be the regular conductor for the rest of this Summer's events.

The main body of stocks drifted aimlessly again yesterday. The dullness was relieved only by a spurt in farm-equipment shares in the afternoon on news of beneficial rains in the drought area. It was this news that weakened grain prices, corn dropping the 4-cent limit, the September option to $1.06 1/8 a bushel; wheat futures sold off 2 7/8 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel on the day, September to $1.10 1/4.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Frankie Frisch's Gas House Gang from St. Louis, led by Johnny Mize, unloosed a twelve-hit blast at Curt Davis today and roared into first place in the National League by a 6-1 triumph over the Cubs.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 4 (AP). -Joseph Hunt, lanky Los Angeles tennis hope, easily smashed his way into the fourth round of the national junior tennis singles championships today by routing Stacy Hill of Cincinnati, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3. Hunt, runner-up in the Seabright Invitation tournament last week, is seeded first.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Charles D. Beckwith, whose efforts to use his Davenport Neck property in New Rochelle as a beach club have brought him into long drawn out conflicts with his neighbors and with the city of New Rochelle, lost again in Supreme Court here today.

MADRID, Aug. 4 (Passed by the Censor). -- Premier Jose Giral told newspaper men this evening that the government forces had broken through to the other side of the Guadarrama mountains in a new battle against the rebels threatening Madrid.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, women's New York State ruler, toured the Wheatley Hills Golf Club's course with a fine 81 today to lead a field of eighty-six entrants and win the low gross award at the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day medal handicap tournament.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- The United States stole away what to date had been distinctly a German show by winning four of the five championships contested this bleak afternoon, as the greatest Olympic Games of them all swung through their third day.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and member of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor, arrived from Europe yesterday on the Aquitania and departed immediately for Washington to attend the meeting of the council, at which member unions of the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis, are being tried for dual unionism and "insurrection" against the A.F. of L.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- To the French Government's suggestion for collective neutrality among the Mediterranean powers in the Spanish civil war the British Government replied today in a note that is being described as broadly affirmative and cordial and as containing some new suggestions.

Editorial comment in a number of newspapers throughout the country charges James A. Farley with having been responsible for he appointment of lifeguards "who couldn't swim." The truth is that Mr. Farley had nothing to do with it and it is utterly unfair to charge him with that.

While praising Governor Landon's expressed views on labor rights, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, at the same time yesterday sharply criticized living and working conditions in lead and zinc mines in Kansas.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 4. -- Dozens of State highway police guarded all entrances to the Illinois State House today with orders to exclude a band of about 350 unemployed, members of the Illinois Workers Alliance, Who chose the reconvening of the Legislature as the time to demonstrate in behalf of their own relief program.

Mrs. Anna C. Van Reyper Romaine Rule was finally evicted last evening from the residential property that had belonged to her family off and on for 275 years. Her three-story, old-fashioned frame house at 2,838 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, was tumbled down by wreckers almost about her ears.

A disastrous rate war in the South African trade, which has been going on for more than a year, apparently will have to continue until one of the competitors in the war is eliminated. This view of the situation was taken in shipping circles yesterday as a result of a decision handed down by the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Collectors of customs and American consular officers in Germany were instructed by the Treasury today to give information on invoices of exports from that country as to whether any subsidies or other benefits had been paid on goods shipped to the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Supplies of hogs were larger and, while the general market was steady to 10 cents lower, underweights and pigs lacking finish were discounted sharply, some sales showing a decline of 25 cents a hundredweight. Sows were mostly 10 to 15 cents lower.

United States Senator William H. Dieterich of Illinois assured James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, yesterday that factional strife among the Democrats in Illinois was ended and that President Roosevelt would have a safe plurality in the Presidential election there.

Edgar W. MacKnight and Dr. Ernest Rogers, husband and brother of Mrs. MacKnight, who was killed last Friday by hatchet blows in her home at 826 Avenue A, Bayonne, left here by train yesterday with the body.

The lure of city jobs with their assured income and promise of pensions incited a crowd of 2,000 men and women to wild disorder yesterday morning in the north lobby of the Municipal Building. The melee was so serious that police reserves had to be called to restore order.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 (AP). -- The first perfect score in the history of the event today gave Charles F. Leonard Jr. of St. Petersburg, Fla., first place in the pistol shooting contest of the Olympic modern pentathlon championship and advanced him to third place in the pentathlon standings.
Officials of the New York Yacht Club yesterday announced receipt of a cablegram from the Royal Yacht Squadron, making formal announcement of a challenge for the America's Cup.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 4. -Small and medium-sized shops closed in the stoppage declared last Wednesday by the Silk Commission Manufacturers Association are going back to work almost as fast as the clerical staff of the organization can enroll them as members and issue working permit cards.

Leading a large number of deals involving housing properties in lffanhattan yesterday was the sale of the Henry Schniewind residence at 8 East Seventy-ninth Street, ear Fifth Avenue, to the Washington Realty Syndicate, Gustave Nassauer, trustee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4. -- With Mrs. Walter Gurnee Dyer as general chairman, the annual fair for the benefit of the Newport Hospital took place this afternoon and this evening on the hospital grounds. It is estimated that at least $4,000 will be realized.

Frank J. Prial, former Deputy Controller, will announce his independent candidacy today for the office of Aldermanic President in the Sept. 15 primaries, according to a report which was strong in political circles last night.

ANSONIA, Conn., Aug. 4. -- The cornerstone of one of the first public high schools to be built in the United States along new architectural lines was laid here this afternoon in the presence of State and local officials. The school, being built with PWA funds, will fill an urgent need, as the present high school building here, originally constructed for 200 students, now is serving more than 600.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, reported today that New Jersey banks gained $8,000,000 in resources in the six months ended on June 30 and that the total was $49,000,000 more than a year ago.

Representatives of the investing public will be called by the New York Stock Exchange into its discussion of the Securities and Exchange Commission's report on the segregation of broker-dealer functions, it was indicated yesterday in a letter to members of the Exchange from the special segregation committee headed by Howland S. Davis.
On his first day of work in two months, Aleck Krunocky, 22-year-old WPA laborer, picked what appeared to be $1,060 in gold coins out of the waters of the East River yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Officers and directors of the Ox Fibre Brush Company, Inc., of 522 Fifth Avenue, New York, were cleared here today by Supreme Court Justice Patterson of charges of waste and mismanagement in the affairs of the company. The court ordered, however, that they should return to the company money paid as dividends to Milton W. Gatch from 1929 to 1932.

Although unprecedented in the history of the Stock Exchange, the action taken yesterday by its special segregation committee in inviting expressions of opinion from representatives of the investing public was expected to meet with the approval of Exchange members.
Apartment houses and a school building changed hands in the Bronx yesterday. In some of the deals a fairly large proportion of the purchase price was paid in cash.

Beginning this week of the Federal Government's drought cattle-buying program has created little alarm in the tanning industry, it was stated yesterday by the Tanners' Council of America. Trade reports, it was announced, indicate more apprehension over the future decline in the slaughter of cattle than concern about present liberal supplies.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange here broke yesterday more than $1 a bale under active commission-house liquidation as holders evened up outstanding interest preparatory to the season's first government crop estimate on Saturday. With an indicated yield of 12,511,000 bales reported yesterday by a Memphis agency, an evident tendency to raise yield ideas created selling pressure and carried quotations below 12 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to Russia, has taken offices in the State Department as consultant on "special work" to Secretary Hull and will not return to Moscow for an indefinite period.

BERLIN, Aug. 4, -- For a while this morning, the Olympic yachting regatta was in danger of being postponed. There was a storm over the fjord at Kiel at 10:30, when the first race was to have started, and continued stormy weather was feared.
A scorching sun sent the mercury to a record high for the date yesterday, but a storm that broke late in the afternoon brought temporary relief and a promise of cooler weather.

Consolidated net profit of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on June 30 amounted to $6,538,613 after all deductions, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 89 cents a share on 5,456,117 common shares, against $6,161,245, or 82 cents per share, the preceding year.

TOPEKA, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Former Governor Jonathan M. Davis, Townsend advocate, trailed Walter A. Huxman, Hutchinson attorney, for the Democratic nomination for Governor tonight as returns in the Kansas primary election mounted.
Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post urged Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen yesterday to grant the Tenement House Department an increase of $153,486 in its budget for 1937.

Free transfers will be issued on virtually all bus and trolley lines in the Bronx beginning Sept. 1, according to plans filed with the Transit Commission, it was announced yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx. At present passengers pay an extra fare when changing from trolley to bus or vice versa.

The Crucible Steel Company of America reported yesterday for the six months ended June 30, last, net earnings, after depreciation, interest and taxes, of $1,262,512, which is equal to $5.05 a share on the 250,000 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock outstanding.

Examining witnesses at random to determine the meaning of the terms, "distiller" and "distilling" in the minds of the average person, counsel to the Federal Trade Commission continued its case yesterday against a group of liquor companies in this area whose use of these terms is considered "unfair competition."

Retail failures increased in the week ended on July 30 as compared with the previous week, but the number was under the weekly average so far this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Insolvencies declined in the manufacturing and wholesale lines, the agency states.

BERLIN, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Art Jarrett, actor-husband of Eleanor Holm Jarrett, arrived today and announced plans to arrange a conference with Avery Brundage, president of the American Olympic Committee, for the purpose of gaining his wife's reinstatement to the Olympic swimming team, if that still is possible.

WASHINGTON spent the night in the Higgins house. British troops were quartered in the First church. Judge Jones of the Supreme Court went to school at the Academy. Vice President Smith's aunt lived a few doors away. The first grist mill in the county stood near Mill Pond. The State turnpike used to be called Gannon's Alley.
Some of the newspaper men at the Olympic Games think that Chancellor HITLER has been at some pains to avoid shaking hands with the winning Negro athletes on the American team.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The drought which still holds the principal food and feed producing areas of the country in its withering grasp was pronounced officially today to be the worst in the nation's history. The extent of relief operations and the financial burden involved still remain to be determined.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Evidence of traced telephone calls given to the Federal grand jury here was understood today to have placed Ellis Parker Jr., son of the Burlington County Detective, in the immediate vicinity of the Sheepshead Bay house in which Paul H. Wendel was held a prisoner, and to have confirmed earlier testimony that both Parkers were in New York at the time of the kidnapping.

Governor Landon's prospects for election are so good that women particularly should be encouraged to enter the race for public office this Fall, Miss Natalie Couch, director of Republican women in the East, said yesterday at her first general press conference at 41 East Forty-second Street.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 5. -- With eighteen State troopers armed with nightsticks standing guard over the closed betting booths, dog racing was held at the Long Branch Kennel Association track tonight for the first time in almost two years.

MADRID, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The loyalist government, claiming new victories in the Guadarrama Mountains north of Madrid, quoted a purported rebel radio broadcast to indicate the weakening of the Fascists.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- The Boerse evidenced a slight recovery in prices today, and while the volume of public and professional trading was light, it sufficed to give the session a more confident tone than that prevailing yesterday. Shares of steel and mining favorites were chiefly in demand, and uniform gains of 1 1/4 points were chalked up for Hoesch, Kloeckner, Rheinstahl and Stahlverein; 1 3/4 for Schuckert and 1 1/2 for Siemens.

Former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President of the Board of Aldermen, while City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. announced that he would not be a candidate for any nomination for that post.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Formation of the Committee for Industrial Organization to further the support of unions in the mass production industry on an industry-wide basis was announced in November by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and the chiefs of seven unions which have favored a vigorous policy on industrial unionism at the last two conventions of the American Federation of Labor.
MANASQUAN, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Dogs brought to this resort by Summer visitors must be kept off the beach and boardwalk, according to an order issued here today by Mayor Lloyd C. Riddle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The United States Embassy in Madrid has been equipped and stocked with food sufficient to care for all Americans remaining in that city, the State Department was advised today by Eric C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Ernest Lee Jahncke, New Orleans sportsman, charged today he was dropped from the International Olympic Committee "solely because of my opposition to America's participation in the Berlin games."

Mrs. Curtis Bok of Philadelphia, of the family of publishers, has deserted the Republican party to aid in the re-election of President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday by Miss Mary W. Dewson, head of the Democratic women's division. Mrs. Bok, an experienced lecturer, opened last night a series of nation-wide broadcasts entitled "Happy Days."
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- Round two of the cellar championship battle also went to the Dodgers today, leaving them facing tomorrow's final only a half game behind the Phillies.

To his colleagues in the Senate ARTHUR CAPPER is "the man who has both ears on the ground." He is envied as a political barometer. He can hear what the Grass Roots are saying. At almost any given moment he knows what the Kansas farmers want. His farm papers give him a certain advantage, but he seems to have some mysterious extra-sense that divines rural opinion.

New corporate bond financing this week consists almost exclusively of railroad borrowing, the offering today of $20,000,000 of Pennsylvania Railroad general-mortgage 3 3/4s bringing the total of new loans for this group for the week to $32,500,000.

The Flintkote Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the thirteen weeks ended on July 18 net profit of $1,156,246, which was equal, after eliminating extraordinary income received in settlement of patent infringements and other claims, to $1.72 a share. This compares with earnings in the corresponding period last year of $1,172,386, or $1.60 a share.

In a move to end the open showroom evil in the floor coverings industry and put a halt to individuals who pose as merchants but maintain no regular places of business, the Associated Metropolitan Floor Coverings Dealers, yesterday suggested a standard of practice for adoption by wholesalers, rug manufacturers, and others selling goods to retail stores.

President ROOSEVELT has expressly repudiated the insinuation that his forthcoming trip to the drought-stricken area has something to do with his political plans. With emphasis he declared that it would be a great "disservice" to attempt to put a partisan meaning upon an effort to help great numbers of people overwhelmed by a national disaster. All this is proper and dignified.

In view of thousands of men, women and children on the sand and in the water at Brighton Beach at about 5 P.M. yesterday, a woman fully dressed and with a child in rompers in her arms ran through the rolling surf and plunged into the water.

Colonel Knox, Vice Presidential candidate, will head a corps of speakers to tour Maine early in September, it was announced yesterday by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern Republican campaign manager. Mr. Martin at the same time was assured by Daniel F. Field, Maine Republican National Committeeman, that Maine would give strong support to Governor Landon.

The body of a man identified as that of William Hessler, 30 years old, known to the police as a "shakedown artist," was found bound with rope and stuffed in a trunk in a vacant, weed-grown lot at Percival and Court Streets, in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today was generally quiet and prices ended irregular. British funds were fairly well maintained. Greek bonds declined as a result of developments in Greece.
In the long list of Bronx apartment properties reported yesterday in new ownership were several corner houses. Private dwellings, as well as multi-family buildings, appeared to be attracting buyers.

Senator BORAH, to placate whom the Republican platform-writers borrowed the drastic Bryan anti-monopoly planks of 1900 and 1912, will naturally approve the blanket indictment in Wisconsin of numerous large oil companies, their executives and several trade journals on charges of price-fixing in violation of the Sherman Act.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5. -- Making the first stop in a 10,000-mile flight over the polar route to Moscow, two Soviet aviators arrived here today from Los Angeles.

The daily rate of steel ingot production this week is estimated at 158,000 tons, or only 19 per cent below the record of 195,255 tons a day established in June, 1929, according to the Iron Age summary released today. The magazine found that output, now at 72 per cent of capacity, compared favorably in tonnage with that of some of the best months of previous years since 1923.

The Philco Radio and Television Corporation accused the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiary, the RCA Manufacturing Company, in Supreme Court here yesterday of using agents of a detective bureau to furnish liquor and entertainment to women employes of the Philco Company to obtain confidential information about the manufacture of radio sets.
DALLAS, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Vice President John Nance Garner told a cheering group of Texas home folk tonight he wanted to "get out of this business of the government in business."

WITH GENERAL MOLA'S REBEL ARMY AT ROBREGORDO, Spain, Aug. 5. -- Two days of hand-to-hand fighting, so desperate and so constant that exhausted troops burned the bodies of fallen comrades for want of opportunity to bury them, have brought the insurgent advance to within thirty-five miles of Madrid tonight.

With modern cars, it seems that we have outgrown certain traffic rules, just as we have outgrown the twenty-miles-per-hour speed limit. Passing on straight roads is permissible where there is sufficiently clear vision ahead, and this appears to be the only rule consistently followed by careful drivers.

ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 5. -- Following the publication of a royal decree enforcing martial law and dissolving the Chamber of Deputies and the occupation of Athens by troops, the twenty-four hour general strike called by Leftist trade unions was crushed early today and the capital resumed its normal aspect save for frequent patrols.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 5. -- General Francisco Franco, Spanish rebel commander-in-chief, succeeded in breaking through a government patrol in the Straits of Gibraltar today with a considerable force of Foreign Legionaries and native Moroccan troops.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 5. -- The Marblehead racing fleet hit a new high when 402 yachts crossed three starting lines today in the Boston Yacht Club's single-day regetta, twenty-one more than on Monday and forty-five more than last year's record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The weekly crop bulletin issued by the Department of Agriculture today said that only in limited areas, chiefly in the Ohio Valley, were crop advances noted during the last week.
MADRID, by Plane to Hendaye, France, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Red Cross officials estimated today that 35,000 persons had been killed so far in the most savage political revolt in Spanish history.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Playing with a brand new set of clubs, purloined from her father, Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today led a field of thirty in the weekly tournament of the Long Island Women's Golf Association at Deepdale.

Herman M. Albert, Register of Bronx County, has recommended that he receive a $4,000 salary increase next year, it developed yesterday at a hearing on the city budget for 1937 held by Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen in the Municipal Building.

Advertisers who have begun to lay out tentative plans for their 1937 budgets are faced with rate increases by many of their media, as a result of sharp circulation gains, plus added operating costs, it was pointed out here yesterday. The rise in newsprint announced by one large mill this week presages a general advance, which will be added to the operating expenses of newspapers, for instance.

DON'T worry any more about the big money, John Dos Passos says in effect. Don't dream about it, don't hope for it. Grow up, find something else to work for, put the thought of the money away. Even if you succeed in getting a load of it, if you manage to step into the channels -- speculation, the movies, advertising, the new industries -- through which it flows, it probably won't do you any good.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Roy Parmelee pitched five-hit ball today as the St. Louis Cardinals subdued the Cubs, 4 to 1, to extend their league lead to two full games over the second-place Chicagoans, National League champions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Philadelphia Athletics made it two in a row over Washington today, drubbing the Senators, 9 to 6, by getting off to an early start and then withstanding a late rally by their rivals.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Mrs. Mary Greef Harris of Kansas City, Mo., and Mrs. Dorothy Andrus of Stamford, Conn., seventh and ninth respectively, in the national ranking, were eliminated from the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.
ROME, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Bishop Gallagher hopes to impress a "pretty picture" of Father Coughlin's political activities on official minds within the Vatican before he leaves Rome for his Detroit home.

The new commercial building at the northwest corner of East Ridgewood Avenue and Chestnut Street, Ridgewood, N.J., has been purchased by Fay H. White, an executive of Loew's, Inc., for investment. The building is known as the Whelan Building for Whelan Drugs, principal tenant, and brokers said it occupied one of the four most valuable corners in the Ridgewood business district.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP). -- About 500 people will be forced to find new homes when waters from a dam to be built by the City of New York will wipe the 100-year-old town of Lackawack off the map, burying it under 200 feet of water.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Father Coughlin said today he had not communicated with Bishop Michael J. Gallagher, his church superior, now in Vatican City, but anticipated no changes in his plans for the national political campaign.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 5. -- County Judge Cortland A. Johnson here today imposed a sentence of not less than fifteen years nor more than thirty-five years on Fred L. Boelsen, 21 years old, of 41-77 Westmoreland Street, Little Neck, L.I., who pleaded guilty today to two indictments charging burglary, grand larceny and criminally receiving stolen property.

Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, made public yesterday plans for a two-deck vehicular tunnel for Second Avenue, to run from Fifty-fourth to Sixty-fourth Street to ease traffic congestion near the Manhattan approach to the Queensboro Bridge.

BEIRUT, Syria, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Miss Margaret Dodge, daughter of Bayard Dodge, president of the American University, and Mrs. Dodge, was married to Johnson Garrett of Baltimore today in the chapel of the university. They will sail on Saturday for the United States, and will make their home at Rockland, Md.
ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- The death of former Judge Andrews of the Court of Appeals, following closely that of his wife, brought the following tribute from Governor Lehman:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Secretary Wallace today replied to assertions he attributed to John Hamilton, Governor Landon's campaign manager, that prevailing low prices for cattle were the result of stock imported under the Canadian trade agreement.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Charles M. Schwab of New York and Bethlehem, Pa., who has been taking the cure at the Roosevelt Baths and stopping at the Gideon Putnam for the last three weeks, departed today by motor for his Summer home at Loretto, Pa.
PERRY, Me., Aug. 5. -- The world is full of pigs in clover, but Perry pigs are feasting on pie -- many kinds of pie, served daily.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 5. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, accused the Roosevelt administration at a press cenference today of using relief and Civilian Conservation activities for political purposes. He cited a letter from Governor Leslie A. Miller of Wyoming, a Democrat, replying to an applicant for a job as non-technical foreman with the CCC and an application blank accompanying the letter, of which he exhibited photostatic copies.

The Stock Exchange's monthly compilation of quoted value, as of Aug. 1, for all stocks listed on the Exchange, works out to an average valuation per share of $40.30, which compares with a similar average of $38 on July 1 and of $23.73 on April 1, 1935, when the continuous rise began.

A letter from President Roosevelt, made public yesterday by the United Palestine Appeal in connection with its forthcoming publication, the United Palestine Appeal Year Book for 1936, declares the Jews have a right to settle in Palestine.
MONTREAL, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press). -- The Newark Bears won their series with the Montreal Royals tonight with an 8 -- 6 victory. They split yesterday's doubleheader.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 5. -- Determined to wipe out government forces along Spain's northern seaboard, rebel troops today launched a powerful artillery attack against Tolosa, south of the seaport of San Sebastian.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Fred D. Kaplan, an attorney, and Dr. Richard H. Ecker, a dentist, both of New York, finished ahead of a field that included most of the country's top-flight contract bridge players today to win the national championship for men's pairs at the American Bridge League's Summer tournament here.

The appointment of Louis A. Johnson of Clarksburg, W. Va., a former national commander of the American Legion, as head of the Democratic veterans' drive was announced yesterday by National Chairman James A. Farley. Mr. Farley also announced the naming of Jack Dempsey as New York State head of the sports division of the Roosevelt campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The day of promiscuous free passes on the railroads is only a memory now, but the Interstate Commerce Commission nevertheless revealed today that, through March 31, 3,074,586 persons obtained orders for transportation on the railroads this year without paying fares.

Strong indications that racketeering by corrupt trade unions and racketeering in the garment district will be the next targets of Thomas E. Dewey, Special Prosecutor, were manifested yesterday as two extraordinary grand juries were selected in the Supreme Court to carry on the investigation.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. (AP). -- At the end of the Olympic catch-as-catch-can wrestling competition, in which the United States won only one gold medal but captured the unofficial team title, open dissatisfaction was expressed in the American camp today over what were termed questionable decisions against several United States finalists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Recovery gains since the present administration took office ranging from 37 per cent in cotton to 1,297 per cent in "net corporation profits" were reported today by Ernest Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.
PARIS, Aug. 5. -- France sought tonight to clamp an arms embargo on Spain as the first step toward preventing the civil war from becoming an international conflict.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, candidate for the Democratic nomination for the General Sessions Bench, declared last night that he welcomed an inquiry by the Bar Association into his charge that a "political deal" had prevented his designation by Tammany.

Unusually large appropriations for "non-recurring" expenses are shown in the report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company for the year ended on June 30. The report shows that $2,918,332 was set aside for expenses of re-capitalization, opposition to the Wheeler-Rayburn Bill, investigations, legal cases and other causes in that period, compared with $2,557,740 in the same period a year previously.

A group of residents of North Bergen, N.J., filed a petition with the township commission yesterday asking for the removal of a Talmud Torah, Jewish religious center and school, at 1,154 Fourth Avenue, a residential street of semi-detached houses.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- The imprint of American domination, so indelibly stamped on the men's track and field program to date, stood forth in bold relief again today as the eleventh Olympic Games moved through their fourth day. The United States won three of the four finals to make its championship harvest nine out of fifteen.

Movements of prices in the share market remained indecisive yesterday. Buying continued to be highly selective in character and switching operations afforded no clue to any positive sentiment. For the most part, traders in their present temper prefer to "reserve decision," and the net result is an irregular market.

A 10-year-old boy sat in the offices of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, yesterday morning and bravely tried to smile through the tears that were welling in his eyes.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,350,000 of independent school-district bonds of the city of Fort Worth, Texas, on a bid of a 108.079 for 4s. The bonds, dated Feb. 1. 1934, and maturing on Feb. 1, 1952 to 1964, were reoffered by the successful syndicate at prices to yield from 3.25 to 3.45 per cent, according to maturity.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- A total of forty-seven yearlings were sold tonight for $61,700, an average per head of $1,213, on the second night of the annual vendue. Many of the yearlings were from the Belair Stud of William Woodward, which sold twelve head for $20,500, or an average of about $1,708.

While fifty boy members of the Police Athletic League cheered, Jack Dempsey, aided by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, released yesterday from the observation tower of the Empire State Building 500 toy balloons to promote "P.A.L. Week," conducted by the Crime Prevention Bureau of the Police Department.

Old PETER STUYVESANT'S slumbers at St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie must have been rudely disturbed yesterday morning by a sample of Dutch history in the two big newspapers of his own New Amsterdam. It concerned an old lady in Jersey City who was evicted from her ancestral home.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- One of the most successful collections in the Paris couture showings of Winter styles is that of Mine. Alix. It contains sports clothes interpreting Oriental silhouettes in Scotch plaids. She launches flat-soled suede shoes for sports and daytime wear.

" Spring Dance," the Philip Barry play which is due to open at the Empire Theatre on Aug. 25 -- thus being the first new one of the season-will spend a preliminary week at the Ridgeway Theatre in White Plains. Louise Platt is to have the part played by Imogene Coca in the first, or Dennis, try-out, Miss Coca being unavoidably detained by a run-of-the-play contract with "New Faces."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- On the representation of the German Government that no subsidies were being paid to exporters of cameras, calf and kid leather and surgical instruments, the countervailing duties on these products were removed by the Treasury today.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Aug. 5 (AP). -- War game manoeuvres of 22,000 soldiers began today when opposing "Red" and "Blue" forces encamped at opposite ends of the 75-square-mile sham battle area near here, awaiting the declaration of theoretical war at midnight.

The latest Republican attack on Secretary HULL'S reciprocal trade agreements is Mr. HAMILTON'S complaint that "the United States has not won a treaty yet." He means that we have been outsmarted in the concessions we have granted to other nations. That is a thesis which would be difficult to prove.

Multi-family buildings proved attractive to investors yesterday when sales were reported in the Marble Hill and Yorkville sections and on Washington Heights and the Upper West Side. Some of the sellers were induced to part with their properties by substantial cash offers.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 5. -- William Shankland Andrews, former judge of the State Court of Appeals, was found dead in his bedroom at Wolf Hollow, his Taunton estate, this morning. He was the victim of a peculiar accident, his neck having been broken when he fell from his bed, apparently in an effort to reach a glass of milk on a table beside the bed. He was 77 years old.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Bunching four runs on as many hits and three errors in the seventh, the Reds came from behind tonight to defeat Pittsburgh, 6 to 4, in the sixth night game of the major league season before a rain-dampened crowd of 6,373.
BARCELONA, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Government forces claimed victory tonight over a rebel self-termed Black Legion on the northern Sastago front in Aragon.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Aug. 5. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, declared here tonight that President Roosevelt four years ago paid tribute to an "economic democracy" which he now terms "economic royalists." He addressed Republican County Chairmen and party workers from all over the State, after flying here from Cheyenne, Wyo.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows: Quotations are in cents:

It would seem as if, in the talk of intervention by European powers in the affairs of Spain, sight was being lost of the fundamental facts -- namely, that a government constitutionally elected and friendly to those powers is attempting to put down a rebellion.

TAKING the 200-meter run at Berlin yesterday, Jesse Owens made it game and set.
