On a track that had been well watered by intermittent showers ever since the start of the games, he ran the distance in 20.7 seconds, showing that despite weather conditions he and the track were still in pretty good shape.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- New activity in the credit market interpreted as reflecting marked economic and industrial recovery was described today by Marriner Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who came here to make a report to President Roosevelt.

POINT O' WOODS, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Records in number of entries in the annual race week cruise of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association continued to be broken today when no less than 153 boats started in this, the third day of the cruise.

The municipal ferryboat Manhattan crashed at full speed into the piling of a ferry slip at the St. George, S.I., terminal, at 9:40 o'clock yesterday morning, injuring a dozen passengers, two of them seriously, and doing $25,000 damage to the boat and to the dock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 was given by the Securities and Exchange Commission today to the Minnesota Tribune Company of Minneapolis, the Dental Oil Company and the Reno Oil Company of West Virginia.

There is a possibility that David Wark Griffith may return to the screen for Paramount. He has been conferring, reports from the Coast say, with Adolf Zukor concerning a nebulous idea which, in the discussions, has been referred to as "The Rebirth of a Nation."

Former Governor Smith will not attend the conference in Detroit tomorrow of a group of prominent Democrats who have "walked out" on President Roosevelt and his New Deal policies, it was announced yesterday.

As the smoke clears in the deadly civil strife consuming Spain, two facts become plain. The first uncensored dispatch from Madrid, published in yesterday's TIMES, confirms the impression that no central power exists strong enough to overrule the extremists on either side. Whatever the outcome, neither reconciliation nor compromise is possible between the forces battling for control of the Government.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The scale weight of 126 pounds, which is a heavy burden to most horses, was considered so slight an impost for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Discovery that he went to the post today in the Wilson at odds of 1 to 25, the shortest price in many years of New York racing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Establishment of a new modern record for exports of iron and steel products in June was announced by the Department of Commerce today. Including scrap, the month's shipments totaled 294,951 tons, valued at $10,147,811, compared with 286,333 tons, valued at $6,993,087, in June, 1935.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 5. -- Miss Grace A. Harrington, 62-year-old postmistress at West Point, is making a last stand like her father who died with Custer at the massacre of the Little Big Horn in 1876.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Four more of the nine Chicagoans named among fifty-eight persons indicted by the Federal grand jury at Madison, Wis., on charges of conspiracy to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Law in the petroleum industry, surrendered here today before United States Commissioner Edwin K. Walker.

There is no occasion for business men to be thrown into a state of panic or alarm by the Robinson-Patman Law or the uncertainty about its interpretation by the Federal Trade Commission, Jacob K. Javitz, of the law frim of Javitz Javitz, yesterday told members of the National Notion Association at a luncheon meeting in the Advertising Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- A strike of 6,500 WPA workers on the municipal airport project ended this afternoon when the strike committee signed an agreement ratifying an earlier vote of workers to go back to their jobs. The strike collapsed less than twenty-four hours after the leaders had called upon WPA workers throughout the city to walk out.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Secretary of State has granted a charter to the Noblemen's Club, Inc., the New York organization which seeks "to provide and maintain an address and meeting place for men and women of authentic nobility who are in the United States temporarily or permanently."
BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP). -- By winning the 200-meter dash, Jesse Owens became the fourth American to capture three or more championships in one Olympic meet.

The pot of gold proved to be just a rainbow yesterday for Aleck Krunocky of 431 East 122d Street. The $1,060 in gold coins he found in the East River on Tuesday while working his first day as a WPA laborer in Carl Schurz Park after four months of fruitless search for work were counterfeit.

Flying scale models of airplanes had their first showing here yesterday at the first meet of the Metropolitan Model League, which was held under the auspices of the National Aeronautic Association, at Van Cortlandt Park. At previous model contests scale models have usually been judged on the ground solely for their fidelity of detail and construction.

Paul Blanshard, commissioner of accounts, began an investigation yesterday into the fake telephone call eight days ago which took Justice Alfred J. Hofmann from the bench in Special Sessions on a futile trip to Mayor La Guardia in the Summer City Hall on Pelham Bay.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Republican designation of T.J. Pendergast as the issue in Missouri's Fall campaign provided an immediate aftermath tonight to the State's primary election.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- For forty-seven years Mr. Blackman had been associated with The Philadelphia Inquirer. He was one of the men with whom the late James Elverson St. surrounded himself upon entering the field of daily journalism with the purchase of The Inquirer from the Harding interests.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 12 per cent for the week ended Aug. 1, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase, reflecting the steady gains in retail trade, compares with a rise of 23 per cent in the preceding period.

The mammoth circus of Play School 188 came to town yesterday, put on a gala parade through the streets of New York's lower east side and induced at least 600 adults to witness the "stupendous" performance under the big top in the school auditorium at 131 Lewis Street.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Sir Christopher Bullock, Permanent Secretary to the Air Ministry and member of the Air Council, was dismissed tonight by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin following an inquiry into allegations that he had used his official position in an endeavor to succeed Sir Eric Geddes as chairman of Imperial Airways.

Commodity futures prices were generally lower yesterday in quiet trading here. The losses were mostly small, however. In the cash market, wheat, corn, rye and oats were higher, while cotton, silk, cocoa, rubber, eggs, wool tops, tin and lard were weaker.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Triumphing in the second play-off for the title, W.J. Tobin, Plandome amateur, and his partner, Bill Dowie, today attained the Long Island amateur-professional best-ball championship for 1936.

LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 6. -- Sir Percival Phillips, wiring The London Daily Telegraph from Gibraltar, says that the most significant news of the Spanish situation at present is the beginning of an anti-government drive from Seville toward Madrid.

BERLIN, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Reversing the customary procedure whereby world records made by Americans must await approval at the convention of the Amateur Athletic Union, Avery Brundage, president of the A.A.U., cut the red tape and today arranged approval of this year's outstanding marks by the International Amateur Athletic Federation forthwith.

There was less selling pressure yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and a steadier market left the list with gains of 6 to 9 points. While all new-crop months improved slightly on the day, the August broke sharply under light trading to close 70 points lower than on Tuesday.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 5. -- College degrees as guarantees for well-paying, permanent jobs have lost much of their former value because of the changing industrial picture, the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart of New York said in an address before the National Conference of Catholic Charities.

The Atlas Corporation, in issuing yesterday its semi-annual report showing its condition on June 30, announced that the directors had placed the common stock on a semi-annual dividend basis and had ordered a payment of 40 cents a share.

" Swing" music, which started to become popular about last New Year, but which has never been clearly defined in the mind of a large part of the public, has been crystallized into a definite form and has been followed by the "swing" dance.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- Arthur Jarrett announced late tonight his intention of taking legal action against the American Olympic Committee upon returning to New York with his wife, Eleanor Holm Jarrett, who was dismissed from the Olympic swimming team on its arrival in Germany.
Contrary to the laws of chance, skill and gravitation, our Giants continue to soar.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Plans for the benefit bridge, fashion show and tea to be held at the Maidstone Club on Sept. 1 for the East Hampton Neighborhood House will be discussed tomorrow afternoon at a meeting of committee chairmen at the home of Mrs. Louis Faugeres Bishop Jr.
As a consistent reader of your editorials over a period of years, I have lately been very much disappointed in the evidence of a diminishing degree of open-mindedness and fairness in your attitude.

The United States is lagging behind her natural competitors in the construction of fast freight ships, in the opinion of Victor J. Sudman, president of the Black Diamond Line. He said yesterday that the time had arrived when the supporters of the American Merchant Marine should "rub their eyes and awaken" to this country's position in ship building.
LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The following is the second uncensored dispatch about the Spanish civil war from a correspondent of The London Times. This one was filed from Valencia.

A summation of drought damage to crops in my section would be typical of what one expected from Western Kansas or North Dakota, where aridity is taken for granted. Yet I farm in Central-Eastern Missouri in the Corn Belt, a belt favored for many years by timely and copious Summer rains and abundant sunshine.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer to the public today an issue of $20,000,000 of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company general-mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series C, due on April 1, 1970, at 101 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield 3.67 per cent to maturity.

Conflicting price trends characterized yesterday's slightly more active trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade investments, under the leadership of United States Government loans, were firm to moderately higher, while mixed price movements ruled in selective trading among most of the secondary domestic corporation bonds.

When the 1936 Republican platform was adopted it was immediately evident that the edge had been taken off the most active of the pre-convention accusations against the President -- that he had reversed many major pledges in the Democratic platform on which he was elected.

Acting for the first time upon information from an issuer that its security was worthless, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange suspended from dealings yesterday common stock of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, which was selling, in odd lots, at approximately $12 a share.

Felix de Iturriaga, Spanish Consul and Acting Consul General here, resigned his posts last Saturday, it was revealed yesterday with the arrival of the new consul and acting consul general, Luis Careaga. Mr. de Iturriaga resigned because he apparently was "not in sympathy" with the present Spanish Government, according to Fernando Porrell, chancellor at the consulate general at 515 Madison Avenue.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- Luck in the matter of the weather, which has been all on the side of the Nazis since they obtained power in Germany, seems to have failed them in these Olympics. Until now it has been almost assured that for any big German fete day the weather would be ideal.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Cleveland Indians defeated the champion Detroit Tigers, 6 to 4, today in a ten-inning game that was a pitchers' battle between Johnny Allen and Elden Auker for the first nine frames.

TOPEKA, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Kansas Republicans and Democrats, with their intraparty contests decided, directed attention today to the general election campaign and the chances of carrying Governor Landon's home State for the national ticket.

Eight men and three women, including a Brooklyn physician, who were indicted recently in the new Accident Fraud Bureau's investigation of frauds on insurance companies in compensation claims by the so-called Hurwitz gang, entered pleas of guilty yesterday in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Regulations under the 1936 Revenue Act for the collection of taxes on undistributed earnings of corporations probably will be submitted to Secretary Morgenthau for approval within a few days.

Organized efforts among independend retail grocers to meet chain store competition through sound merchandising and better service, were urged by Hector Lazo, vice president of the Cooperative Food Distributors of America, at yesterday's session of the thirty-fifth annual convention of the New York State Food Merchants' Association, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, defending itself against the charge that the investigation in progress of the investment trust and investment companies of the United States is unconstitutional and illegal, charged in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia today that the suit instituted by Frederick T. Fisher of New Canaan, Conn., to halt the investigation by injunction was not being prosecuted in good faith.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- (AP). -- Miss Marion Miley of Lexington, Ky., shot enough good golf-today over the Midlothian Country Club course to retain the lead in the Women's Western 72-hole medal play derby, but saw her margin reduced from three strokes to one by Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Best hogs sold generally steady to strong here early today, but the demand was not aggressive and later the market weakened, prices being 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds lower in final trading, with packing sows and lights off most.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- The annual flower show of the Newport Garden Association and the Newport Horticultural Society at the Casino was opened today by Mayor Henry S. Wheeler, who inspected the exhibits with Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster, general chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The American Liberty League, in a statement today concerning its position during the political campaign, asserted that it did not endorse any party or candidate, and that it has not and will not contribute to any campaign fund.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 5. -- A new song of a shirt diametrically opposite in context to Hood's poem of economic suffering, was on the lips of social credit sponsors tonight as they pointed to what they called the successful starting of Premier Aberhart's "prosperity" certificate system.

Willem van Hoogstraten, who will be the regular conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the final fortnight of the Stadium season, ascended the podium last night for the first time this Summer at these concerts.

BROCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- A lustrous-eyed mongrel pup, accused of drowning a boy, slept through most of his trial for life here today while 500 men, women and children muttered, gaped and fidgeted in the weathered Village Hall during an unparalleled "legal" proceeding.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5. -- Bound northward on the great circle course which will eventually carry them 10,000 miles up the Pacific coast, across the Bering Straits, over the Siberian wilds and into Moscow, the two Soviet aviators took off from San Pedro Bay for Alameda without incident.

The Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, held its thirteenth annual music-memory contest last night on the Mall in Central Park. Despite the overcast skies and the few drops of rain which fell, an audience of 10,000 persons attended, with more than 2,000 taking part in the contest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Here are the statements of the four principal figures in the controversy between the A. F. of L. and the C. I. O., issued after the vote of the executive council suspending the ten groups supporting the industrial union movement:...

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- One of Europe's danger spots was removed, at least for the present, when Germany and Lithuania signed today a new trade treaty on the basis of reciprocity, together with several supplementary agreements regulating payments, border intercourse and their nationals' labor rights.
LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Sir Christopher Bullock, in a statement tonight, said:

The will of the late Colonel Edward H.R. Green, who inherited a large portion of the estate of his mother, Hetty Green, on her death in 1916, was filed for probate at Port Henry, N.Y., on Aug. 1 and left the entire estate to his sister, Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks, it was learned yesterday.
It seems to me that THE TIMES editorial "Extremism in Spain" confuses the actual issue involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today suspended ten affiliated unions with more than 1,000,000 members, effective on Sept. 5, unless they withdraw from the Committee for Industrial Organization, which was held to be an attempt to set up a dual or rival labor movement.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:
KIEL, Aug. 5 (AP). -- England took the lead today in the first day of actual competition in the Olympic yachting regatta on Kiel Bay.

Suits by James F. Egan, public administrator and New York administrator of the estate of Ivar Kreuger, promoter of match companies, to recover property alleged to have belonged to Kreuger were disclosed in the Supreme Curt yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Little by little the franc is losing ground against sterling and dollars in the foreign exchange market, today's rates being 76.16 francs to the pound and 15.17 3/4 to the dollar. Forward rates moved to 73.16 and 14.60, respectively.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 5. -- A sale for the benefit of Berkshire blind was held today at the Sedgwick mansion in Stockbridge. Tea was served in the garden. Mrs. William Ellery Sedgwick was the hostess today and assisting hey were Mrs. Robert G. Stewart, Mrs. Percy Musgrave, Mrs. John Butler Swann, Mrs. H. Augustus Lukeman, Miss Louise Edey and Mrs. Ira M. Dixson.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- With play in the singles at a standstill, thirty-two teams started out in the Southampton invitation tennis doubles at the Meadow Club today, and at nightfall all of the favored pairs were still in the running after two rounds of competition.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 5. -- The Madrid government's claims that the Guadarrama ridge has been lost by the rebels are denied by the insurgent command at Burgos, where it is contended that although the fighting has been severe, no ground has been lost and General Emilio Mola's forces still hold the slopes on the Madrid side of the range.
BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- America has taken a tumble, but its shoulders are still off the mat in the art of catch-as-catch-can wrestling, which is about as rough a sport as there is on the Olympic program.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 5. -- It was stated positively in well-informed Vatican circles that so far as the Holy See was concerned there would be no interruption to the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's political activities.

Covering the salt-water front: Kit Miller, interrupting his slippered ease at his cottage in Bay Head, took phone in hand yesterday to inform this department that a bit of a nor'easter was kicking up a fuss along that part of the Jersey coast. . . . It might put the quietus on fishing for a few days, he lamented . . . .

ST. JEAN DE LUZ, France, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Four American refugees from the northern coast of Spain reached here today aboard the United States Coast Guard cutter Cayuga, Ambassador Claude G. Bowers's "floating embassy." Fifteen citizens of other nations also were brought here on the Cayuga which made a week-long cruise under Ambassador Bowers's direction to make sure that all Americans desiring aid were evacuated.

The challenge of the Royal Yacht Squadron for the America's Cup on behalf of T.O.M. Sopwith and his new Endeavour II probably will not be taken Up by the New York Yacht Club until the end of this month, or at least until after the King's Cup race off Newport on Aug. 20, which will wind up the club's cruise.

The folly of throwing overboard good pistols of the police regulation type struck Mayor La Guardia so forcibly yesterday that he suggested to Commissioner Valentine that he retain usable weapons seized by the police and sell them to newly aappointed policemen for $10 each, instead of the $25 they have to pay for new ones.

The news that the syndics of Cambridge University Press have broken a rule of four centuries and have accepted a new novel for publication is reported by Ronald Mansbridge, American representative of the press, who has just returned here from England. The title of the novel has not yet been chosen, but it is the work of Susan -Iicks Beach and will appear next: Spring.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 5. -- In his dismissal from the Police Department today, Detective Thomas Brown, former St. Paul police chief, was charged with actual participation in the conspiracy to kidnap William Hamm Jr., and Edward G. Bremer, wealthy St. Paul business men.

TOPEKA, Aug. 5. -- Efforts of Governor Landon to obtain reduced freight rates on shipments of water and feed to farmers in the drought areas of Kansas brought results today. The Western trunk-line committee at Chicago submitted to him a satisfactory plan for emergency rates on feed shipments and the Santa Fe Railroad reduced its rates on water shipments 50 per cent.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5. -- Henry Ford has expressed interest in buying the Noah Webster house, which is owned by Yale University, to the extent of paying a deposit.

Gordon K. Douglass of Lake Hopatcong, N.J., the Canadian canoe-sailing challenger for the International Challenge Cup now held by the British, sailed for England on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday. He will meet the British defender, as yet unnamed, in a two-out-of-three series off Hayling's Island, starting Aug. 20.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5. -- The Soviet Government agreed today to the French proposal to join an agreement with France, Britiain, Italy and Germany to refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Spain.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP). -- A driving rain ended a two-act clouting bill in a 9-to-9 tie today after the Browns had knocked White Sox offerings all over Sportsman's Park to win the opener, 16 to 4.

The National Association of Manufacturers will launch today an advertising campaign to carry the story of American Industry to the people, C.M. Chester, president, announced yesterday. The first of a series of five full-page advertisements will appear in Chicago newspapers and will be run over the next few weeks in cities throughout the country, the financing to be done by individual manufacturers in each community.

The Minneapolis Journal, County Attorney GOFF, Chief of Police FORESTAL and Mayor LATIMER have lately been congratulating Minneapolis on its crime record. Two years ago HOMER S. CUMMINGS, United States Attorney General, branded the Twin Cities as "the crime center of the nation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Because of the market crash of October, 1929, the Reliance International Corporation and the Reliance Management Corporation, the first an investment trust and the second a management organization, sustained losses that totaled $12,470,067, of which $6,977,666 was charged against Reliance International and the remainder against the management corporation, it was testified today at the Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of investment trusts and investment companies.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- The German and American Armies have beaten the world's crack military athletes. For the first time in the history of the revived Olympic Games the modern pentathlon today was taken away from the repeatedly victorious Swedish Army.

Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York returned yesterday from England and Ireland with high praise for the housing programs of these countries and predicted that his Housing Bill, which will be resubmitted to Congress at the next session, would be passed. He returned on the United States liner Manhattan.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6. -- There was a moderate decrease in business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's adjusted index fell from 95.8 per cent of normal in the final week of July to 94.3 last week.

ROME, Aug. 6. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano communicated orally to the French Ambassador today Italy's reply to the French proposal for a preliminary understanding for non-intervention in Spanish affairs. The Italian reply, along the lines every one expected, offers adhesion in principle to the thesis of nonintervention followed by a demand for further information on various points.

EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 6, 1936. Pie story front page today's TIMES possibly humorous but groundless as to fact. Indeed so fictional as to appear malicious and slanderous. Positively state that no pie or similar commodity has ever been purchased in any quantity in any manner at any time during the Quoddy project.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the last week of July again exceeded $3,000,000,000, an increase of $1,000,000,000 since the middle of June, the Federal Reserve Board stated in its monthly bulletin issued today.

TOPEKA, Aug. 6. -- On his first campaign trip East Governor Landon will not only speak at his birthplace, West Middlesex, Pa., Chautauqua Lake, N. Y., and Buffalo, but will also confer with New York Republican leaders in the last-named city.
About 250 members of the Lotos Club attended a dinner there last night in honor of Charles Michelson, publicity director for the Democratic National Committee.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Convened in extraordinary session on order of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, today speeded the appeal of striking Syracuse Remington Rand, Inc., employes from a temporary injunction limiting strikers to four pickets.

If any one had told me a month ago that I, a country-bred Southern girl, would drive a car in New York traffic, I would have answered in no uncertain terms that they were crazy. But I have timidly ventured out in my Tennessee car (with the AAA's sanction and a guest license) and have found delight at every turn.
GENEVA, Aug. 6 (AP). -- A delegation of thirty Americans arrived today for the opening of the first World Jewish Congress on Saturday in the assembly hall of the League of Nations.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The 1936 consignment of Glen Riddle Farm yearlings, including many of the get of Man o' War, passed under the hammer in the auction ring tonight and brought excellent prices before one of the largest turnouts in several seasons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Five of the eight killed in the crash of the Chicago and Southern airliner were residents of Chicago while a sixth, the co-pilot, Russell Mossman, 36, of New Orleans, formerly lived here.

Acting for a group that had acquired a large block of the bonds, Nathaniel Benjamin Godfrey yesterday bought the fifteen-story Tuscany Apartments at 116-122 East Thirty-ninth Street at auction on a bid of $350,000, the upset price fixed by the court.

The schism within the American Federation of Labor resulting from the conflict between the executive council and the Committee for Industrial Organization headed by John L. Lewis drew comment from labor leaders here yesterday on the order of the executive council suspending ten unions unless they withdraw from the C.I.O. within thirty days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The total of authorizations and commitments made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation up to July 31 was $11,293,677,792, Chairman Jones announced today. This included $859,828,843 disbursed to other government agencies and $1,799,981,085 for relief purposes.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 6. -- Telephone and telegraph communication with Greece is closed. Only a few censored telegrams are being sent out. Greek telephone stations refuse outside calls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Secretary Morgenthau declared today that the increase in the reserve requirements of member banks decreed by the Federal Reserve Board, effective on Aug. 15, would have no effect "one way or the other" on Federal Government financing.

Still happy for having captured her first Wimbledon title in eight attempts, Miss Helen Jacobs, America's queen of the tennis courts, arrived yesterday aboard the United States liner Manhattan to start preparations for the defense of her American championship at Forest Hills next month.
ROME, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Bishop Joseph Schrembs of Cleveland pictured the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin tonight as a protector of American institutions.
BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP). -- America's Olympic swimmers turned in to rest tonight after their last time trials two days before they meet Japan's powerful team to decide world supremacy.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- The victories of the Negro members of the American Olympic team are the sensation of Europe. How thoroughly the Olympic spirit has spread here is seen in the fact that to date only the Nazi newspaper Angriff has spoken of them disparagingly, and only in the government box has there been other presumptive evidence of racial feeling.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6. -- Eight occupants of a Chicago and Southern airliner were killed when the twin-engined monoplane, with full power on, crashed and was demolished in a fogbound valley three miles north of Lambert-St. Louis Field shortly after 10 o'clock last night.

The Fletcher Trust Company, the Indiana Trust Company and the Union Trust Company of Indianapolis, all of Indianapolis, have written to holders of the Indianapolis Gas Company's first consolidated mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due in 1952, asking them to advise whether they favor the formation of a bondholders' committee, and if so, their suggestion as to a possible member of the committee.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and the retie of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York Bank also reached a new high figure for the year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- An amended plan for reorganization of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway Company has been agreed upon by the general mortgage bondholders' committee and the railway, it was learned today.

Declaring that one of the greatest difficulties in the current investigation into rackets is that of dealing with evasive witnesses, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook sentenced one such individual yesterday to thirty days' imprisonment for criminal contempt of court.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Aug. 6. -- Since Governor Landon was nominated for President, Utah has taken a swing toward the Republican ticket, according to reports given today to John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, by county chairmen and other party workers in the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Although Attorney General Cummings dropped criminal prosecutions for alleged income-tax violations against several members of the Louisiana organization headed by the late Senator Huey Long, the Treasury will continue its effort to collect by civil action the amounts claimed, it was stated at Secretary Morgenthau's office today.

Not for many years has the organized labor movement in this country been so deeply divided as it is today. Ten powerful unions, numbering about one-third of the entire membership of the American Federation of Labor, have had notice served on them that they will be suspended next month unless they withdraw from Mr. LEWIS'S Committee for Industrial Organization.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- A Spanish Embassy official, while not denying that many Frenh citizens were going into Spain to enlist with the government forces, said today that Madrid was discouraging foreign volunteers as much as possible.
EASTPORT, Me., Aug. 6. -- People of Eastern Maine were indignant today over the story published in newspapers charging extravagance and waste in the disposition of food at Quoddy.
WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 6. -- Mass emigration as the solution of Poland's Jewish problem is advocated by the Foreign Ministry in a statement issued today by the official agency Political Information.

OF late there have been several popular accounts of life among the Eskimos, and at least one has sold widely. Thus the ground has been prepared for this new book by Dr. Kaj Birket-Smith of the National Museum, Copenhagen -- "The Eskimos" (Dutton, $5) -- translated from the Danish by W.E. Calvert and Professor C. Daryll Forde.

TRENTON, Aug. 6. -- After a public hearing, as bitter as it was brief, Governor Hoffman reserved decision today on New York State's request for the extradition of Ellis Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives, and Ellis Parker Jr., a former State employe, to answer indictments in Brooklyn, charging them with kidnapping Paul H. Wendel.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine gave a luncheon today at Valmay Cottage for Mrs. Charles Garfield F_tng of Chicago. Mrs; Charles W. Dempster of Chicago also was a guest.

The city of Holyoke, Mass., awarded yesterday a new issue of $350,000 of short-term notes to Leavitt Co. on a 0.39 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $1.75. The notes will be dated Aug. 7, 1936, and will become payable on Nov. 27, 1936.

Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will arrive today on the Europa. Dr. Koussevitzky will conduct his orchestra in the three concerts of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival next week.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The death last night of a month -old baby in Burlington County Hospital has stirred up a heated controversy on New Jersey's handling of the relief problem.

Members of the New York State Food Merchants Association, Inc., at the closing session yesterday of their annual convention at the Hotel Commodore, adopted a resolution to oppose the enactment of any legislation which purposes to raise the cost of any legitimate food product in order to benefit another food product or industry.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 6. -- An irate 23-year-old college student, whose supper had been dumped from the table in his moored 25foot cruiser by the wash of a passing speedboat, turned the usually peaceful waters of the Connetquot River into a shooting gallery last night.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- Harassed by criticism and amendment of his projects in the Senate and by constant sharpshooting by the Opposition in the Chamber of Deputies, Premier Leon Blum today tested out the solidity of his majority in one of the most acid speeches he has ever delivered in the lower house.
PARIS, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Wm. A. Krahe Son, Inc., sold for Maria Ronzoni a three-story brick building at 36-09 Thirtieth (Grand) Avenue, Long Island City, to the Alda Realty Corporation, David Davis, president. The seller was represented by Mario J. Cariello.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- When Phoebe Omlie left Washington airport today for Memphis to bury her husband-flier, Captain Vernon Omlie, one of the famous romances of the air came to an end.

GENEVA, Aug. 6. -- The movie and radio are dislodging the Frenchman from his proverbial cafe, aperitif and vin ordinaire, according to the third volume of the League of Nations report on the problem of Nutrition, out today. This volume deals with nutrition in various countries.

The American Power and Light Company reports a consolidated net income of $9,302,104 for the twelve months ended on June 30, equal to $5.25 a share on the combined 793,581 shares of the $6 preferred and the 978,444 of $5 preferred stock, both of no-par value, compared with $5,911,340, or $3.33 a share correspondingly on the preferred issues, in the preceding year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- In the face of deplorable weather conditions, including a chilling wind from the northeast and almost continuous rain, the finest competitive tennis of the week was seen on the Meadow Club courts today as play in the Southampton invitation tournament came down to the semi-finals in singles and doubles under leaden skies.

The share market moved yesterday with the same caution and indecision that had characterized proceedings in the previous few days. The closing was irregularly higher, whereas the day before a similarly narrow market resulted in slightly lower prices.

An investing syndicate purchased the new six-story apartment house at 91-99 Payson Avenue from Payson Estate, Inc., Abraham Ruth, president, for cash over a mortgage of $220,000. There are seventy-one apartments in the building, which rents for $60,000 a year.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York City charged here today that failure by the State of New Jersey to provide an adequate relief program was creating a serious condition for New York City, principally in the protection of the health of its citizens.

THAT was a remarkable operation performed by John Edward Lovelock in the Berlin Stadium yesterday. The visiting interne from St. Mary's Hospital, London, practically cut the legs off his eleven rivals in the "metric mile" and made a deep incision in the former world's record. While slightly painful to his breathless pursuers, the operation was a complete success.

CANNES, France, Aug. 6. -- The baptism of the newborn daughter of the Prince and Princess of Asturias will take place on Saturday in the parish .church of Notre Dames des Pins in the strictest privacy.

American Steel Foundries declared yesterday a dividend of $1.75 a share on its preferred stock, payable on Sept. 30 to stock of record Sept. 15. This is an increase of $1.25 from the previous quarterly payments, which were begun when the rate was reduced to 50 cents in March, 1933.

Crestfallen but silent on the reasons for their dismissals, Joe Church and Howell King, the boxers who were dropped from the United State Olympic team last week, returned yesterday aboard the United States liner Manhattan, the ship on which they sailed for Germany in July.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Another stake, the third of the meeting, fell to the Maemere Farm of De Witt Page when his filly Maecloud was home first through the mud today in the $3,875 Schuylerville, one of the oldest stakes in the East for juvenile fillies.

Evidence of "beating the gun" in the offering of new security issues has been obtained against more than sixty Wall Street firms in the course of a five-month study by a staff of investigators attached to the regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, 120 Broadway.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug, 6, -- Excellent bidding, including a liberal number of psychics, gave the youthful New York contract bridge team of Charles Vogelhofer and S. Garton Churchill an early lead in the national masters' contract pair championship of the American Bridge League here today.

The city experienced yesterday a sharp drop in temperature accompanied by rains which were so severe in the Bronx that streets and cellars were flooded over a wide area, slowing up pedestrian and vehicular traffic in the morning.

MADRID, Aug. 6. -- Spanish loyalists tonight claimed the surrender of rebel Cadiz in the South, smashed toward Saragossa and dug capture of 2,000 Fascists, and dug in for two more months of warfare to quell the twenty-day-old rebellion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Establishment of a "moving picture propaganda bureau" by the Works Progress Administration, and the making of a contract with Pathe News, Inc., to produce an indefinite number of films at a cost of $4,280 per 600 feet, were charged in a statement issued today by the Republican National Committee.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Two stars from the Southwest and two from the West Coast today swept into the semi-finals of the national junior tennis championship tournament. Two rounds were played in both the junior and boys' singles in order to make up for time lost yesterday because of rain.

ALBANY, Aug. 6. -- Complaints brought to Governor Lehman that Negro inmates of the Hudson Training School were being discriminated against were sent today to Victor F. Ridder, chairman of the Board of Social Welfare. The Governor suggested that "this matter be immediately considered by your board and that you take steps to correct any instances of discrimination against Negro girls in the institution.''

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- In official circles it is said that the negotiations for a neutrality pact are going forward successfully, but in reality France is finding it just as hard to get a strict non-intervention agreement as regards Spain as the League of Nations found it to get sanctions applied against Italy.

Although dry goods wholesalers continued to hold down orders this week, they were busy trying to get quick shipments of goods previously bought in order to fill the demands of retail accounts. Retail purchases throughout the country are holding up at an unusually high rate, jobbers said, and a difficult delivery situation is expected before the end of this month.

Record shipments of non-acetate rayon yarn during July resulted in a further reduction of surplus stocks in the hands of producers to the lowest level in six years, or since figures were first compiled, according to the current issue of The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 6. -- In a race distinguished by confusion, disqualifications and bumping of marks of the course which caused six skippers to drop out of the picture, twenty Star Class boats entered the championship flight of the Commodore Corry Trophy competition today.

Failure of the committee on admiralty and martime law of the American Bar Association to make recommendations for legislation on safety at sea is vigorously criticized in a minority report filed yesterday by James W. Ryan, admiralty lawyer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 6. -- Miss Audrey Gray, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Gray, who are occupying Sea Cove on Price's Neck this Summer, was the guest of honor at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse at Eastbourne Lodge tonight.

MAMARONECK, Aug. 6. -- Memories of the late John G. Anderson, one of America's foremost amateurs some twenty-odd years ago, again were revived today at the Winged Foot Golf Club, in the organization of which he played a leading role.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Turning in a splendid round of 79, only three strokes over women's par, Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden annexed the low gross prize at the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament on the Green Meadow links today.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- A five-way division of the spoils marked the fifth day of the Olympic track and field program in the sun-flooded Reich Sports Field Stadium today as the United States, Germany, Japan, New Zealand and Italy captured a championship apiece.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Gilam C. Keasey, Corvallis, Ore., will reign at least another year as champion archer of the United States.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Grain markets were erratic again today with prices on the Board of Trade breaking early, only to rally later. September wheat here and at Minneapolis and October at Winnipeg advanced to new high levels for the season before being checked by profit-taking.

The 1,403 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $43,980,902,150 par value as of Aug. 1, had a total market value of $41,685,172,818, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of July 1, there were 1,415 issues, aggregating $44,163,734,954 par value, which had a total market value of $41,618,750,056.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Expressing "deep regret" to Attorney General Cummings because of spying activities of Secret Service men on agents of the Bureau of Investigation of the Justice Department, Secretary Morgenthau announced today the demotion of Joseph E. Murphy, Assistant Chief of the Secret Service, and Grady L. Boatwright, head of its St. Paul office.

The National Supply Company of Delaware and its subsidiaries, including Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., for the quarter ended June 30, reports a net profit of $1,341,250 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, flood loss expenses, guaranteed dividends on the National-Superior Company's preferred stock, provision for dividends on the cumulative preferred stock of Spang, Chalfant, and other charges. No provision was made for Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

Alderman Newbold Morris, Republican designee for President of the Board of Aldermen, made public yesterday a letter of endorsement from Samuel Seabury, one of the prime movers in the campaign that led to Mayor La Guardia's nomination and election on a Fusion ticket.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Gas House Gang from St. Louis, with Dizzy Dean in the lead, set back the Cubs, 3 -- 2, today on the strength of Rook Johnny Mize's homer in the eleventh to take a three-game lead in the National League pennant chase.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System showed no net change for the week ended Wednesday, according to the System's weekly return, marking the first time since mid-June that the total was not increased. The total of such reserves stands at $3,050,000,000.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 6. -- Information received today from Athens through trustworthy uncensored channels indicates that well informed circles as well as public opinion in the Greek capital consider an alleged Communist plot a very poor blind for Premier John Metaxas's abrupt dictatorial coup d'etat.

Steel ingot production in July amounted to 3,922,731 gross tons, or 73 per cent more than in July, 1935, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. In June, 1936, production amounted to 3,984,845 gross tons.

It is hard luck to be a nation in the making in times when the most stabilized Governments find it hard enough to keep afloat. This is the fate of modern Greece, ancient as a land but very young as a State, politically not much more mature than Elizabethan England. While it was still learning the A B C's of self-government, the new kingdom was riven apart by the World War.

A blonde showgirl who has been dancing at Long Island roadhouses was the center of the investigation yesterday of the ice-pick murder of William Hessler, garbage man and "shakedown artist," as Brooklyn police sought to link his death with the recent murders of two other men operating an extortion racket.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Joseph Anderson, attorney for Dr. Franklin Thorpe, former husband of Mary Astor, said today that the surgeon had admitted a previous marriage. The woman's name, Anderson said, was Laura Adams. Dr. Thorpe is defending a suit brought by Miss Astor, screen star, who asks complete custody of their 4-year-old daughter, Marylyn.
Plans for the Queens midtown vehicular tunnel at Thirty-eighth Street, the sixty-first set prepared by engineers, were approved yesterday by the New York City Tunnel Authority.
Trading was mixed yesterday on the local commodity futures markets, with prices mostly steady. On the cash markets cotton, cocoa, silk and rubber advanced, while wheat, rye, oats and lard declined.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- William Hale Thompson, former Republican Mayor of Chicago, will run for Governor of Illinois on a third-party ticket headed by Representative Lemke, the Union party's candidate for President. This announcement was made today by Newton D. Jenkins, three times unsuccessful candidate for the Senate.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- In accordance with similar authority granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Public Service Commission announced today it had authorized all common carrier railroads to continue, until the end of the year, the emergency increases in freight rates lawfully in effect for intrastate traffic.

HUNTINGDON, Pa., Aug. 6 (AP). -- A Pittsburgh to New York Greyhound bus overturned twice in a driving rainstorm on a mountainside twelve miles west of Huntingdon early today, killing two persons and injuring thirteen.

At least I am one of the oldest readers of THE TIMES. For seventy years have been reading newspapers, and if I remember correctly, THE TIMES has always been one of them. THE TIMES was a friend and associate full of common sense and intelligent reasoning and correctly stated the news.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- In all its history Berlin has never had so many polyglot visitors. Every hotel is crowded beyond normal capacity and all the best-known restaurants spend most of the dinner hour turning them away because no more can get inside.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Former Representative Gordon Browning won the Democratic nomination for Governor of Tennessee in today's State-wide primary.

Every day and in every way the coming election in this city looks more like a tangled web. Issues, parties and candidates are sadly jumbled. One might wonder why there is so much excitement and bickering about the election of a President of the Board of Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Paralleling the division in organized labor's ranks on the craft-industrial union issue today was a division of opinion among labor leaders on its effect on the political campaign and on the fortunes of the Republican and Democratic candidates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Six river and harbor projects involving an expenditure of $8,184,042 in New York State districts were among a score of such contracts announced today by the War Department. The largest, for $3,385,000, was awarded to the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation of New York, for construction of a turbo-electric seagoing hopper dredge Goethals, for New York District No. 1.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Turning today to a detailed study of election prospects, President Roosevelt received assurance from the campaign managers of the House and Senate that he would have strong Democratic majorities in both branches in the next Congress.

Voters of 105 municipalities in twenty-six States in July approved municipal bond issues aggregating $9,685,255, compared with $6,248,390 of bonds approved in June, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for July, 1935, was $11,383,140, compared with $1,807,500 in July, 1934, and $27,836,852 in July, 1933.
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Vernon Omlie was Memphis' foremost aviator and one of the most experienced pilots in the South.
Central Park West was one of the areas in which considerable activity was reported in apartment leasing yesterday. The following were included in the day's list of rentals:
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The White Sox ended their series today by defeating the Browns in both games of a double-header by 9 -- 6 in the first game and 4 -- 1 in the second.
KIEL, Aug. 6. -- Frank B. Jewett Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., and the California Tech Yacht Club today manoeuvred into sixth place in the Olympic Monotype Class race, coming up from eleventh.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Top grades of hogs were scarce again today and sold at steady prices, compared with the average of the previous day. They were about 10 cents a hundred-weight under the high and an equal amount above the low of Wednesday.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The United Piece Dye Works, with large plants in this' city, Lodi and Hawthorne, N.J., and present and former members of its board of directors were named defendants today in a Chancery Court action through which a stockholder seeks return to the company of more than $1,000,000 which he says was improperly paid officers of the company in the form of bonuses from 1923 to 1931.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The International Reform Federation of Washington and London, at the opening on Aug. 13 of its world-wide anti-war campaign, will urge President Roosevelt to call a world peace conference.

Despite the bitter fight between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, fully 95 per cent of the nation's "labor vote" will be cast for President Roosevelt's reelection, it was predicted yesterday by Daniel J. Tobin, chief of the labor division of the Democratic National Committee.

PUEBLO, Col., Aug. 6 (AP). -- Swift-moving flood waters, fed by an early morning cloudburst, overflowed Eastern Colorado tonight, spreading damage through the State Hospital for the Insane and carrying a new threat of inundation to near-by Walsenburg.
TORONTO, Aug. 6 (Canadian Press). -- In a free-hitting game tonight the Maple Leafs defeated Newark in the ninth inning, 7 -- 6.

Aside from a weakening in the French franc, the net changes yesterday in the principal foreign exchange rates here were inconsequential. The French rate declined 3/8 point to 6.58 7/8 cents, and the discount quoted on 90-day forward transactions was widened by 3 1/2 points to 31 points.

MARSEILLES, France, Aug. 6. -- The Barcelona plants of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company have been sovietized, according to American refugees who reached here today on the British hospital ship maine.

Restoration of their salaries to levels prevailing before pay cuts went into effect was asked yesterday by three of the five District Attorneys of the city in budgetary requests for 1937 submitted to Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen.

While the big Olympic contests are on this week there are competitive games and sports at home which may mean as much in the lives of tens of thousands of boys and girls. There are three times as many individuals between the ages of 10 and 18 taking part in the Police Athletic League recreational and character building activities as there were players and spectators last Saturday in the great stadium in Berlin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- A twelve-ton magnet, which Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago hopes will enable him to measure the energies of the cosmic rays up to forty billion volts and determine whether the particles are positively or negatively charged, is nearing completion.

TRENTON, Aug. 6. -- Mrs. Harold G. Wortley of 118 Parker Place was injured fatally and four other women were hurt, two seriously, when an automobile in which they were riding crashed into a pole on the State highway near Windsor today.
Russell Darbo, blind University of California student, until yesterday was the unheralded hero of a cross-country hitch-hiking adventure, in which his only companion was Mia, a shepherd dog.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Rookie Jake Wade all but pitched the Indians out of second place in the American League today, holding them to seven hits as the Tigers clubbed a 9-0 triumph, their third in the four-game series.

A book largely based upon, and frequently quoting from, the diaries of Earl Haig has been written by Duff Cooper, Secretary of State for War in the British Cabinet and one of Field Marshal Haig's staff officers in the World War. The book is entitled "Haig" and will be published by Doubleday, Doran early next month.
BARNSLEY, England, Aug. 6. -- All but one of the fifty-seven miners who were at work in a coal pit near here are believed to have lost their lives early today in an explosion of undetermined origin.

TRENTON, Aug. 6. -- Denying the validity of an undated resignation he admitted writing and contending no vacancy therefore existed which permitted Goveror Hoffman to appoint Isador Haber as judge of the North Hudson District Court, Morris Umansky today filed answer in the Supreme Court here to the quo warranto proceedings instituted by Mr. Haber challenging his right to continue in the judgeship.

In its official statement disclaiming the endorsement of any political party in the campaign and announcing that it will contribute to none, the American Liberty League has stated what are technical facts. But these are far less important than the atmosphere in which the facts were stated and the implications arising from them.
PARIS, Aug. 6. -- Stung by criticism from public school teachers regarding the government's military program, the Senate today retaliated by adopting a bill for the compulsory teaching of patriotism.

The new swimming pool in Colonial Park, 146th Street and Bradhurst Avenue, Harlem, constructed by the Park Department with WPA funds, will be dedicated and opened to the public at 8:30 tomorrow evening.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 6. -- The Southern Spanish rebels are preparing drive to Madrid. Held up thus far only by failure to get reinforcements from Morocco, General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, rebel leader in Seville, as recruiting citizens for his Fascist army both in Seville and Granada, and with the safe arrival at Algeciras yesterday of 3,000 regulars and Foreign Legionaries from Morocco he is now preparing the advance.

James A. Farley, in his capacity as leader of the State Democratic organization, issued a call yesterday for a meeting of the new Democratic State Committee, to be held the morning of Aug. 18 in the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 6. -- Miss Mabel F. Kelly, Miss Mary Hughes, Mrs. David Baird and William F. Beisheim won prizes at the contract party at the Mount Washington today. Fifty professional and amateur golfers attended a golfers' luncheon and played in a match there.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- The phenomenal 300-meter sprint that carried Jack Lovelock to victory over Glenn Cunningham in the closing stages of the 1,500-meter run has been in his possession for several years but was kept a dark secret until today, the New Zealander revealed to The Associated Press correspondent in the dressing room after the race:

The appointment of Francis E. Rivers, Negro lawyer and former Assemblyman from Harlem, as director of the Negro voters unit of the Republican national campaign in the East was announced yesterday by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts, Eastern manager of the Landon-Knox campaign.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler believes that a general European war can be averted "by common sense," and he is also convinced that a new peace system "based on reason and justice" must supplant the League of Nations.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. On board are Joseph E. Widener, Phili adelphia sportsman, accompanied !by P. A.. B. Widener; Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Lav School, with dCrs. Pound; George 1. Burr, lew York investment banker; Arthur I. lIeigs, architect.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- Maggy Rouff features a successful personal version of the eighteenth century waistcoat jacket cut off square across the front. It is less flaring than those seen at other couture openings this season. She shows it in tweeds or rough woolens for mornings and in panne velvet or broadcloth for dressy afternoon or evening wear.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,470,000,000, an increase of 92,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $6,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1935.

May I express my appreciation of your editorial headed "Lindbergh's Warning" in your issue of July 24? Colonel Lindbergh's striking utterance in behalf of peace is, I believe, applauded by all Americans and it should help us to realize the gravity of the present world situation. But there is something further which needs to be emphasized in this connection.

Forrest Towns gave the United States its ninth gold medal in sixteen events by winning the 110-meter high hurdles final in 0:14.2 after equaling his own world record of 0:14.1 in the semi-finals. Fritz Pollard was third behind Don Finlay, Great Britain. Roy Staley was eliminated in the semi-finals.
Architects filed plans for a variety of construction work in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens yesterday.

The Pierce-Arrow Motor Corporation is planning to start production within a few weeks of an automobile trailer for the tourist trade. This will represent the first invasion of the trailer manufacturing industry by an automobile manufacturing company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- A demand that American property in Spain be respected and that if any is requisitioned provision be made for prompt and full compensation to the owners was made of the Madrid government in a formal note presented yesterday by Erie C. Wendelin, third secretary in charge of the United States Embassy, on instruction of the State Department.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government increased $4,742,107 and deposits by chartered banks rose $1, 828,655 in the week ended Aug. 5, the bank reported today. The statement follows:

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $5,451,260,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compared with $5,596,320,000 for the similar period last year, a decrease of 2.6 per cent.

A fight for one-third of the $5,000,000 estate of Edgar S. Appleby, 73-year-old lawyer and realty dealer, was started in Surrogate's Court yesterday when Sonia G. Appleby filed notice that she had elected to share in the estate as the surviving spouse under the Decedent's Estate Law.

Imports of cotton cloth from all countries in the first six months of this year amounted to 63,766,000 square yards, a figure in excess of the total for the entire year 1935, the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York pointed out yesterday in commenting on statistics released by the Department of Commerce.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- A historical tableau of Cleopatra's court took place on the ice of the Olympic arena here tonight as the annual Summer figure skating operetta completed the first of four week-end performances.
MADRID, Aug. 6 (Passed by the Censor). -- In an article entitled "Money, Money, Money," in the newspaper Informaciones tonight, the Socialist leader Indalecio Prieto says:

In the days of King SOLOMON we should have had a much easier approach to the case of L0UISE MADELINE PITTMAN-GARNER of Atlanta-Macon, Ga. On one side of the room we should place Mr. and Mrs. JOHN C. GARNER of Macon facing a huge executioner with a drawn sword.
BERLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Van Oyen of Germany today captured the Olympic rapid pistol shooting title. Hax of Germany was second and Ullman of Sweden third.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- A moderate increase in wholesale prices for the week ended on Aug. 1 was reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Further recovery occurred in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, which brought an improvement of about $1 a bale from the low prices of the week, and left the list 6 to 11 points higher. Moderate trade price-fixing readily absorbed light offerings, and an extension of the drought area, centered in Oklahoma, into Texas and Arkansas, exerted a steadying influence on both foreign and domestic markets.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- A large throng of prominent society people attended the yearling sales tonight at which yearlings sired by the great Man o' War, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Riddle, were sold.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The New Jersey relief problem flared up anew today when this city received only $300 from the State instead of an expected allotment of $7,000 for August relief needs. The small allotment was vigorously attacked by municipal authorities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The country's meat supply will be curtailed, next year as a result of the lack of animal feeds in the drought area, just as it was diminished in 1935 as a result of the 1934 drought, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

Jerome A. Jacobs, 48 years old, a lawyer: Harry S. Hechheimer, 63, a disbarred attorney, and Raymond Derringer, 39, a motion-picture operator, went on trial in General Sessions yesterday on charges of extortion and attempted extortion made by Harry Bannister, an actor.
Further complications developed yesterday in what appeared to be a two-sided conflict for the $80,000,000 estate left by the late Colonel Edward H.R. Green, according to The Associated Press.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Mrs. Anita Dilg Reinhardt, 36-year-old wife of Arthur E. Reinhardt, president of the Bronx Consumers Ice Company, was under a nurse's care in her home at 27 Dante Avenue, here tonight, after having shot and seriously wounded her husband as he slept about 2 o'clock this morning.
GENEVA, Aug. 6. -- Jacob Baker of Washington, head of President Roosevelt's inquiry on cooperative enterprise in Europe, told the press here today:
HAVANA, Aug. 6. -- The House of Representatives passed today the Vasconcelos Amnesty Bill, which had passed the Senate on July 28.

MADRID, Aug. 6 (Passed by the Censor). -- A rebel radio station reported tonight that General Francisco Franco, the insurgent commander-in-chief, had succeeded in landing 3,000 regular troops from Spanish Morocco on the mainland after an aerial and naval combat in the Strait of Gibraltar between rebel and loyal airplanes and the rebel gunboat and the loyal cruiser Lepanto.

With all territories showing gains over last year, engineering awards in July totaled $226,595,000, an increase of 113 per cent over July, 1935, according to The Engineering News-Record. Last month's total consisted of $65,382,000 for private work and $161,213,000 for public contracts.

A continuance of the demand for store space was indicated in commercial leases reported by brokers yesterday. Retail shops were taken by merchants in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Rentals included the following:

Employes of the Securities and Exchange Commission who have just completed a five-month survey of the extent of the practice of "beating the gun" on new issues are reported to be in something of a quandary what to do with their findings. Some of the most important houses in Wall Street have been found guilty, it is understood, of violating the Securities Act of 1933 and are, therefore, liable to heavy civil and criminal penalties.

DETROIT, Aug. 6. -- A group of "Jeffersonian Democrats," headed by former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri and including men once high in the councils of the Democratic party, will meet here tomorrow to determine how they can best employ their political resources to prevent the re-election of President Roosevelt.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- Two incidents connected with the Spanish civil war have inflamed the German press against Left elements supporting the Madrid government and further increased the Reich government's coolness toward the French neutrality proposal.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 6. -- A cold northeast rainstorm broke the drought in Eastern Massachusetts today, but it materially dampened the ardor of a thousand or more yachtsmen in this port, with the result that the big fleet of yesterday was cut to 231 starters in the first of the Corinthian Yacht Club's trio of regattas.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6. -- Sixteen suits alleging negligence by twenty-three officers and directors of the defunct Baltimore Trust Company in losses of the bank aggregating $16,000,000 were filed by the receiver today, who seeks to recover as much as possible of this sum for the depositors.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Edward F. MacCaulay, 60, of Schenectady, an expert mechanic and former automobile dealer, was selected today as New York's "safest driver."

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- Colonel Sir Donald Banks, Director-General of the Postoffice, was tonight appointed Permanent Secretary to the Air Ministry, succeeding Sir Christopher Bullock, whom Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin dismissed yesterday following the report of a civil service inquiry into allegations that he had used his official position in an attempt to succeed Sir Eric Geddes as chairman of Imperial Airways.

Senator KEYES of New Hampshire will not be a candidate for re-election. He has served three terms with satisfaction to his constituents. He has attended to their business in Washington conscientiously. If he has added little to the enormous stream of talk in the Congressional Record, he has worked steadily and usefully on such important committees as Appropriations, Finance and Naval Affairs.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- Colonel Sir Donald Banks, Director-General of the Postoffice, was tonight appointed Permanent Secretary to the Air Ministry, succeeding Sir Christopher Bullock, whom Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin dismissed yesterday following the report of a civil service inquiry into allegations that he had used his official position in an attempt to succeed Sir Eric Geddes as chairman of Imperial Airways.

Constructive forces assumed yesterday the market leadership in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Under the leadership of persistent strength in United States Government loans, five of which soared to new high levels since their dates of issue, other types of issues joined in the upward movement, responding to a brisk demand with substantial gains.

Independence of the Presbyterian Church of the United States was expressed by the newly formed Presbyterian Church of America yesterday at the first meeting of the New York and New England Presbytery which was held at the Sherman Square Hotel.

The nomination of Judge Morris Koenig of General Sessions in both the Republican and Democratic primaries, assuring his re-election, is "most essential to the public welfare and a proper recognition of a very vital principle of government,'' the judiciary committee of the New York County Lawyers Association declared yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, his preliminary work on a mechanical heart apparatus completed, turned his attention to aviation problems today. He arranged to meet an American aviation official to discuss new connections between American and European airlines.

The trial of two men, a father and a son, accused of using the mails to promote the sale of Irish Sweepstakes tickets, failed to get under way yesterday in Federal court because it was impossible to get twelve jurors who had not purchased lottery tickets.

Ciro Terranova, 47-year-old merchant who has been known as "the artichoke king," was freed yesterday in the Bronx on two of three charges brought against him by policemen who arrested him last Sunday for vagrancy, driving without a license and disorderly conduct.

The organization of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, with headquarters at 36 West Forty-fourth Street, was announced here yesterday by Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar of New York and Boston, attorney and monetary authority, who has been elected president of the group.

THE foot-and-mouth mystery in Olympic Games is still there for any ethnologist who cares to study it. The Berlin results have added plenty of material for serious study of the effect of the spoken word on the running foot, or vice versa.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 7. -- Blocked by Southerners from an outright declaration of support for Governor Landon, but no less determined to help prevent President Roosevelt's re-election, about forty "Jeffersonian Democrats" from twenty States meeting in conference here decided tonight to leave the methods to Anti-New Dealers in the various States.

The one-story building containing twelve stores at the southeast corner of Commonwealth and Lafayette Avenues, the Bronx, has been sold by the Atlantic Assets Corporation to Commonwealth Estates, Inc., for investment through Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., broker.

Mayor La Guardia ordered Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday to prevent betting at the dog races that will open tonight at a new track at the Sunrise Highway and Cross Bay Boulevard, Queens. He also gave special instructions to send the pickpocket, confidence and bunco squads to the scene, to prevent an influx of "racketeers and thugs" into the city.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 7. -- The Kentucky breeder, Arthur B. Hancock, who for several seasons has been getting an unusually successful response from purchasers of yearlings, tonight topped his own previous records by selling forty-six head for a total of $186,450.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Taking the position that Colonel Edward H.R. Green died a resident of New York State, authorities are now hoping to claim part of the $80,000,000 estate left by the son of Hetty Green.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups in June have been announced by the Department of Commerce, and they are compared with those of the preceding month and with June, 1935. Exports as given in the tables that follow cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

Although the margin of gain in retail distribution over the total volume a year ago for the country as a whole was narrowed this week, the expansion of buying in the wholesale markets was extended, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Allowing for the further recession in some of the drought-affected districts, the agency says, retail sales continued about even with the total of the week preceding.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today was again very quiet and restricted. International politics overshadowed all other considerations. British funds declined. Spanish and Greek loans receded further in the foreign department, while German issues fell because of fears of German intervention in Spain.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania arrived by airplane this afternoon from Harrisburg, Pa., to join Mrs. Earle and their son, George Earle Jr., at the Gideon Putnam for the rest of August. Also arriving by airplane for the week-end racing features were Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, Miss Hope Gimbel and Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lasker of New York.
SEATTLE, Aug. 7. -- Representative Marion A. Zioncheck jumped from his fifth-floor office in the Arctic Building here tonight and was killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7. -- A stolen automobile driven, police said, by an intoxicated young woman, killed a woman pedestrian today and seriously injured a man. The victims were Mrs. Mary Breslin, 58, a charwoman, and William Bucher, 40.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- A heavy undertone developed in the world's grain markets today, with more or less evening-up in preparation for the official Canadian report on the condition of wheat and other Spring-sown crops, due after the close tomorrow and the estimate of the United States Government on prospective yields on Monday.

The Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, whose common stock was suspended from dealings on Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, when the company made known that the equity was worthless, announced yesterday in a letter to stockholders that it planned to take over operation of its traction properties on Oct. 1.

In a telegram yesterday to this column from Louisburg, N.S., headquarters for the American Museum of Natural History swordfish research expedition sponsored by Michael Lerner, Captain Tom Gifford describes the capture on rod and reel by Mr. Lerner of two swordfish, both of which topped the accepted Atlantic record of 505 pounds.

DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 7. -- A trust fund to be known as "The President's Fund," to "further the intellectual life of the college," was provided by Dr. Ellen Fitz Pendleton, former president of Wellesley, in her will filed in probate court here today.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP). -- A divided verdict, convicting three men and freeing three others on charges of false imprisonment, ended today the first Black Legion trial since the terroristic activities of the hooded society were disclosed more than two months ago.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Americans at the meeting of the International Swimming Federation today succeeded in putting over two proposals dealing with the method of starting races and the amateur standing of Summer lifeguards.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Losing his grip on a sand and gravel barge in the Passaic River as a watchman waved a two-foot length of hose over him, Vito Cefrondella, 15 years old, of 113 South Sixth Street, was carried by the tide under the barge at the foot of Coal Street this afternoon, and drowned.

In your editorial of Aug. 3 you say that "when England was on a gold basis in the poor benighted days before the war and had not yet been taught the wonders of managed money, the Bank of England got along with a reserve, in the neighborhood of 20 to 25 per cent."

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 7. -The tide of contenders in the midsummer series began to ebb today, with 385 yachts, sixteen less than Wednesday, crossing the three starting lines, seventy-nine outside, 262 in the harbor and forty-four little fellows in the morning, all sailing in the second regatta of the Corinthian Yacht Club.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Archie Williams, 20-year-old California Negro, today climaxed his rocketing ascent from the novice ranks by winning the Olympic 400-meter championship, thus giving the United States its tenth men's track and field title of the games.

Russell Darbo, blind University of California student who made a 3,400-mile hitch-hiking trip across the country without benefit of notoriety, found himself yesterday the focal point of a barrage of cameramen when news about his adventure became known.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Because the Interstate Commerce Commission "does not look with favor" upon interlocking directorates, the commission suggested today that William W. Farrell of Chicago should sever his connections with the New York Central if he wished to continue as a director of other railroad systems.

In February former Mayor THOMPSON of Chicago came out of the cave of retirement which too long had hidden him from the admiring world. He was going "to help bring back the Republican party." In April Mr. C. WAYLAND BROOKS was nominated for Governor by the Republicans.

United States Government obligations and numerous domestic corporation bonds were carries to new high levels yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the broadest and most spirited advance in several weeks. The movement was marred only by the sharp break in Italian dollar loans and sympathetic declines in other sections of the foreign list.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Gordon Browning, Democratic nominee for Governor, today increased his wide margin of victory in yesterday's primary, which was marred by violence that left four persons dead.

The Spanish crisis again brings to the fore the thorny question of neutrality.
