The State Department's notification that it will hold the Madrid Government accountable for damage done to property of American citizens is merely filing a claim. It does not imply that the American Government will intervene to protect property, or even the lives of citizens who elect to remain in the war zone after they have been warned to leave.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 7. -- Two Loyal Spanish Provinces in the North were reported on the verge of surrender tonight, with the seaport of Gijon almost in ruins and 300 of its inhabitants dead. [Gijon is 190 miles west of San Sebastian.]

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -Frank Parker of Spring Lake and Gregory Mangin of Newark advanced to the final round of the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today and will meet tomorrow at 11 A.M. for the trophy held by the former.
ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Power-boat drivers conquered rough water and cross-winds today to topple three world records at the opening of the fifteenth annual Miles River regatta.

In Arthur Krock's article in today's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES the New Deal attack on the American Liberty League is carried forward, though with more finesse than employed by Messrs. Farley and Ickes of the Roosevelt Cabinet. Not only does Mr. Krock assume to speak for the New Deal, he also assumes to speak for the Republican party and its management.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The Reichsbank informed American banking representatives today in Berlin that henceforth the use of registered marks was barred from German-American trade. This action follows the exclusion of "aski" marks and barter from that trade, and represents a further step toward complete cessation of trade between the two countries.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7. -- With half of Russia's grain crop now harvested, it is evident that the early season hopes for a substantial increase over the previous year's harvest will be disappointed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The fight by American Hair and Felt Company stockholders to hold an investment in the concern, against the wishes of the management, which proposes to call the common stock and reissue it to tanners, became more significant today as the shareholders' protective committee called for more proxies.

An increased demand for business property in Brooklyn was indicated in deals closed yesterday. The McInerney-Klinck Realty Company reported banks disposing of properties along Flatbush Avenue and saw a return of interest on the part of investors and speculators to the area.

Next week will see the last of the Summer edition of' the "Folies des Femmes," which is to shut up shop on Aug. 15 at the French Casino. Afterward it will go on a tour of the so-called key cities before settling down for the season at the French Casino in Miami Beach.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the annual silver and white ball which was held tonight at Canoe Place Inn for the benefit of the Southampton Country School. Huge clusters of silver and white balloons were used in the decorations and the women guests had been requested to wear silver or white costumes.

No development of the early stages of the national campaign has been more interesting than an unmistakable shift in the position of the Republican party on the silver question. Six months ago Republican criticism of the Administration's silver-purchase program was almost savage.
Sales contracts involving commercial and residential properties on the West Side were reported by real estate brokers yesterday.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Zeppelin Hindenburg, with fifty passengers aboard, is expected to land here not later than 10 A.M. tomorrow on its sixth visit to the United States, according to a wireless message from Captain Ernst Lehmann to officials at the Naval Air Station.
With New York about to celebrate an important anniversary of the National League, one thinks of the great players that have made the names, Giants and McGraw, almost synonymous.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, the validity of whose subpoenas is now the subject of injunction proceedings in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, filed in that court today a series of briefs, in which it maintained that it had the power to subpoena and that the injunction proceedings were not brought in good faith.
Colonel Green's will was written when he was active in the railroad business in Texas and helping his mother to manage her vast estate.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 7. -Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Crane entertained 200 tonight at a ball at Sugar Hill, Dalton, in honor of Miss Cooley Graves and Arthur Eaton Crane, who are to be married tomorrow afternoon in the garden at Gravesleight, Pittsfield.

The Stock Exchange provided an old-fashioned railroad market yesterday, with prices advancing in a manner reminiscent of the days when rail traffic was expanding to the record total of 1929. Many new high levels were attained, the influence of this group extending to the rest of the market.

Pacific Eastern Corporation and Shenandoah Corporation, investment trusts affiliated with the Atlas Corporation, reported yesterday increases in the net assets available for their capital stock in the first six months of this year.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Colonel Frank Knox will start tomorrow on a campaign tour which will take him to thirty-five States, during which he is scheduled for seventy speeches. Clarence J. Brown, national committee representative on Colonel Knox's staff, said the itinerary was the "toughest, fightingest schedule ever laid out for a candidate."
MELILLA, Spanish Morocco, Aug. 7. -- The general staff of the Spanish Rebel army is organizing here a Riffian corps, which is being sent over to Spain to fight the Madrid government forces.

The stock market shook off yesterday the lethargy that had prevailed for nearly a fortnight and resumed its advance in determined fashion. Led by the railway shares, leading stocks gained 1 to 3 points on the day, with the steels, chemicals, railway equipments, the motors and various specialty stocks making the best showing of the industrials.

GENEVA, Aug. 7. -- Delegates from thirty-two countries, representing more than 6,000,000 of the 16,000,000 Jews in the world, have arrived for the first World Jewish Congress, opening here tomorrow night, Dr. Stephen S. Wise, its president, told newspaper men at a reception today.

TOPEKA, Aug. 7. -- Governor Landon said today that he would accept the invitation of President Roosevelt to attend a drought conference of Governors of Middle Western farm States some time in September, thus assuring a personal meeting of the Presidential candidates of the two major parties.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 7 (AP). -Frederick L. Jenckes of this city telegraphed the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin today that he would be willing to limit a $25,000 Lemke-Landon voting bet to Rhode Island, and fixed Aug. 18 as the time limit for the radio priest to raise his share of the wager.

The Monsanto Chemical Company and subsidiaries report a net profit of $2,068,583 for the six months ended on June 30. This is after deducting Federal income taxes and charges and after providing for subsidiary preferred dividends, and was equal to $1.85 each on 1,114,410 shares of capital stock, including those just issued for additional capital.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 7. -- Bermuda welcomed heavy rains today which came at a time when there was beginning to be a fear of water shortage. More rain is expected and thus the danger of a shortage apparently is ended.

Everything from a murderous-looking cast of huge false teeth to model airplanes turned up yesterday afternoon in a hobby contest among needy children of the Lower East Side, sponsored by the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

Large expenditures for newspaper advertising have been scheduled by the forty-four local units of the National Kitchen Modernizing Bureau, in its nation-wide campaign to bring kitchens up-to-date, it was announced here yesterday. Kitchen planning contests are being advertised widely in newspapers, with emphasis on electrical appliances.

Thousands of gladiolus blooms of varied hues and sizes, including a recently developed fragrant type, filled the tables and corridors of Horticultural Hall in Rockefeller Center yesterday at the opening of the seventh annual show held under the auspices of the Metropolitan Gladiolus Society.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Department of Commerce officials, who have been making their own studies of unemployment figures since 1933, estimated today that 9,550,000 persons are out of work.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- In a four-ring circus augmented by a colorful ceremony in which all countries honored Dr. James A. Naismith of the University of Kansas, founder of the game, the Olympics' first basketball competition started today with ten games. The United States and the Philippines drew a bye.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 7 (AP). -- The final of the national junior tennis tournament became an all-California affair today as Joseph Hunt of Los Angeles and Julius Heldman of Hollywood swept through their semi-final matches. They will meet tomorrow for the title.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 7. -- An airplane piloted by a Briton, John Owen Cathcart, made a forced landing last night at Pilsen Airdrome. Its two passengers were Spaniards, Urutia Usaula and the Marquis Luca de Tena. The airplane came from Rome.

The Secret Service of the Treasury Department is a very fine body of men, indeed, which gets no publicity because that would interfere with its efficiency. The Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice is a very fine body of men also, which gets publicity because its chief has found that useful in increasing its efficiency.

ATHENS, Aug. 7. -- Telephone and telegraphic communication with the outside world was reopened today. Within Greece, however, the press censorship was made more severe, the censor being an army general.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7. -- The Giant express steamed out on Baker Bowl today, remained throttled down for a few rounds and then touched off an explosion that almost reached Olympian proportions.

Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday declared invalid the will of Stephen Mahan, 90-year-old inmate of the City Home on Welfare Island, which bequeathed most of his $7,000 estate to Louis J. McNally, former superintendent of the institution, and his family.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- A match that went thirty-two holes for what is undoubtedly a tournament record completely overshadowed everything else that took place in the John G. Anderson Memorial competition at Winged Foot today.

Check exchanges at the principal clearing houses of the country in July amounted to $27,178,376,656. This was a loss of 4.6 per cent compared with the turnover in June, but was 3.9 per cent in excess of the figures for July, 1935.

Sharp advances in grains carried The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices to the highest point since Jan. 28, or 127.9 on Aug. 4 from 126.6 (revised) the Tuesday before. Advance of grains, butter and eggs reflected the persistence of the drought.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- A sharp attack on President Roosevelt and other leaders of the Democratic party whom he accused of deceiving the country into accepting communism as its form of government was made by the Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith at a luncheon at the National Press Club today.

A tax lien on the seven-story apartment house at 415 West 118th Street brought out 119 bids at foreclosure sale yesterday, the lien finally going to Donald Crichton, attorney, 240 Broadway, on a bid of $27,600. The bidding started at $10,000.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -The remarkable winning streak of Miss Helen Pedersen carried her to another notable conquest today in the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club.

PEEP-HOLE literature should not be wholly despised. For nearly all books fall into that general category, the difference between them consisting of the different aspects of some one else's business that the peeper is permitted to see. The author of a serious biography lifts the curtain from his subject's intellect and personality, revealing him at the stern task of acquiring fame sufficient to warrant the revelation.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- The State Banking Department announced today it had taken over the affairs of the Bath Beach Credit Union, 8,612 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn. This action was to insure its orderly liquidation, according to the department.

A plan for the reclamation of Rikers Island under which its dump heaps would be converted into brush-covered slopes, was submitted yesterday by Park Commissioner Moses to Mayor La Guardia, the Board of Estimate and the World's Fair Committee.

It is interesting to read William T. Ellis's statement that the natives of Palestine are not Arabs but the aboriginal Canaanites. Now this is news, to the Jew as well as to the Canaanite, to the latter especially, inasmuch as he has been universally misrepresented in the press as an Arab, on the flimsy pretext that he speaks Arabic.

The American Federation of Labor, in true Pecksniffian style, arrayed in all the habiliments of majestic supremacy, acting in the combined capacities of judge, jury, prosecutor and complainant, is sitting in judgment on the "rebel" brethren and has pronounced them guilty, as charged.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Harold Smallwood, University of Southern California quarter-miler from Ventura, Calif., who today underwent a successful emergency operation for the removal of his appendix, probably will return home with the American team Aug. 28, Dr. Graeme H. Hammond of New York announced tonight.

District Attorney William C. Dodge and Police Commissioner Valentine opened a drive yesterday on a group of independent coal dealers who since the start of the depression, it was alleged, have directed the bootlegging into this city of millions of tons of coal stolen by idle miners from commandeered shafts in three counties of Pennsylvania.

A swing toward Frank J. Prial as candidate for the Democratic nomination for Aldermanic President against Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens was recorded yesterday in the Sheriff's own county of Queens.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 7. -- Race equality and academic freedom were stressed as important principles in education at Harvard by Dr. Kirley F. Mather, director of the Harvard Summer School, in an address of welcome today to a group of Nazi students from secondary schools in Germany, now touring New England.

In the two years since its reorganization the Dodge Publishing Company has published no fiction. The first novel to appear on its list will be "Shanghai Deadline" by Laselle Gilman, a manuscript importation from China. Mr. Gilman is an American journalist living in Shanghai.

When Will Durant suggests in his recent article in The Saturday Evening Post on education that the dead languages be buried, he exposes himself again to the -- shall we say slight criticism of being superficial? Such people do read translations. Perhaps Mr. Durant also likes to hear his opera and symphonies from phonograph records or the radio, or even the movie, that is if he cares for music sincerely?

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 7. -- With thunderous broadsides, Spanish Loyalist ships today and tonight cut General Francisco Franco's Rebel Moroccan troops off from the insurgents on the peninsula, sinking a Rebel transport and destroying a gunboat during the first of two heavy bombardments of Algeciras.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The market for hogs was unsettled today with the best 190 to 225-pound averages selling steady to as much as 10 cents a hundredweight higher. The best sows were steady while off-quality stock of all weights and light lights were weak to as much as 10 cents lower.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Arthur E. Reinhardt, president of the Bronx Consumers Ice Company, who was shot and seriously wounded early yesterday morning by his wife, was "somewhat improved" today, although his condition was still serious.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Aided by the first triple play of the season here, Dennis Galehouse turned back Chicago's bid for second place in the American League today by limiting the White Sox to seven hits. The Indians won, 8 to 1.

SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 7 (AP). -Campaigning in the territory of the government's vast Grand Coulee power and reclamation project, John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, told an outdoor audience tonight Governor Landon of Kansas "will carry on the policy of reclamation and conservation" if elected President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The Republican National Committee charged in a formal statement today that the Public Works Administration in Indiana was soliciting funds from contractors and builders with whom it had dealings to pay for advertisements which were described as PWA "propaganda."

Understanding of the problems of people in other countries and States is one of the greatest contributing factors in national and international harmony, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told members of the Greater New York division of the Good Neighbor League at a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Well-informed sources said today that fifty or more armored trains may be required to move the bulk of the government's $10,600,000,000 gold hoard into the strong box now nearing completion at Fort Knox, Ky.

BOONVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 7. -Deploring the "legal no man's land" created for the New England dairymen by the decision in the Boston milk market case, Secretary Wallace declared here today that the government "believes that the Federal courts ultimately will show an increasing willingness to face" problems in the dairy industry.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The saddle horses of Mrs. Ralph K. Trix of Lake Placid and those of Roger A. Young of Bronxville shared the spotlight as the three-day Sagamore Horse Show opened today.

The French franc fell below the gold export level yesterday and $1,550,000 in gold was engaged in Paris for shipment to New York, the first engagement since June 19. The franc has fluctuated nervously in recent weeks as the efforts of the Popular Front government in France to re-establish French finances have generally been viewed with skepticism, and more recently by the uncomfortable position in which France has been placed by the rebellion in Spain.
PORT HENRY, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The 180-word will of Colonel Green was made public today by the Surrogate's office, as follows:
Ever since Joe DiMaggio broke into the major leagues he has been heralded as a superhuman, a great ball player, the best outfielder in the league and a coming all-time star.

There has been much speculation, and there will be more, regarding what might be called the exchange of rapiers in the coming election. How many Democrats will vote for LANDON? Will Republicans in great numbers vote for ROOSEVELT? The material for answering these questions is as yet very scanty and vague.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 7. -- Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge of Paris gave a dinner at the Mount Washington Hotel here tonight for the Bretton Woods Boy Singers, who afterward presented a program in the ballroom. Frank R. Hancock, baritone, directed the concert and Allan Stewart of New York, tenor, sang.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Aug. 7 (AP). --Three "Red" bombers engaged in a thirty-minute "battle" with "Blue" anti-craft artillery here tonight in a demonstration for General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the United States Army.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- A young man believed by the police to have been "joy riding" in an automobile stolen from William Randolph Hearst Jr. was killed instantly about 6 o'clock this morning in a collision with a motor truck on the Albany Post Road five miles south of here.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7. -Mrs. Bruce Bromley, who is summering at Wainscott, will be a speaker at the Republican Women's Club luncheon, to be given at the Maidstone Club on Tuesday, Aug. 11. Mrs. Bromley is a sister of Faith Baldwin, the writer.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7. -- J. Gentry Daggy was elected president of the National Security Traders Association at the closing session of its convention here today. Atlantic City was selected for the 1937 convention.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 7. -- A seasick pirate was brought in today when a 17-year-old youth who made off with the $15,000 auxiliary yawl of James D. Cox Jr., a Summer resident of Magnolia, ran up a distress signal because he thought he was dying of some sudden strange malady and called for rescue.

Scores of children everywhere, but not an official in sight, was the order of the day yesterday morning when the Park Department quietly declared open the swimming pool at Betsy Head Park, Dumont and Hopkinson Avenues, in the heart of Brownsville, Brooklyn.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $17,625,395, to be represented by two States and 100 municipalities. This compares with the revised total for this week of only $6,114,071. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $22,196,383.

Bizet's "Carmen" was the third and final opera production for the current season last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The strong appeal of the opera and the excellent cast attracted an audience of 12,000 persons, by far the largest assemblage to attend an opera at the uptown amphitheatre this season.

The American Woolen Company announced yesterday that it had dropped discounts entirely on its blanket lines and that hereafter, they would be on a net basis. The action was taken presumably as a result of the Robinson-Patman Law.

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Disapproving the endorsement of William T. Lemke as candidate for President by the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin and several units of the National Union for Social Justice, the officers of the Hicksville unit of the union have resigned in a body.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador, said today there was no possibility of any form of Anglo-American political alliance. He spoke at the English-Speaking Union garden party.
The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- One of the most surprising upsets in contract bridge history was scored here today when a team that had barely managed to squeeze into the list of qualifiers eliminated the Four Aces in the first round of the knockout team-of-four championship of the American Bridge League.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -Pitcher Earl Whitehill smacked a double in the tenth inning to drive across the winning run today as the Senators defeated the Red Sox, 3 -- 2.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 7. - Seventeen persons arrested in connection with disorders during the recent strike at the RCA Manufacturing Company's plant here were exonerated in a presentment returned today by the April grand jury.

One of the largest loans negotiated recently on income properties in Manhattan was granted yesterday by the Prudential Insurance Company of America to the Trinity Church Corporation. The church group borrowed $7,000,000, on which it will pay interest at the low rate of 4 per cent.
HARTFORD, Tenn., Aug. 7. -- The romance of a blue-eyed mountain girl, wooed and married by a New York artist, was the talk today of this little village far up in the Smokey Mountains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- A "vigorous and sustained" campaign to enact standard drivers' license laws and other uniform traffic legislation will be started immediately in every State now lacking such legislation, according to W.H. Cameron, managing director of the National Safety Council.
MADRID, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Catalan Government at Barcelona reported to Madrid today that Loyal troops were marching on Huesca and had captured several villages on the heights overlooking the town.
MADRID, Aug. 7. -- This once gay capital of Spain still presents a carnival spectacle of bright colors and laughter, but it is a fantastic carnival of fear.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Swinging their sticks desperately against hopeless odds, the United States field hockey team today held India's champion team to a 7-0 victory in Olympic competition. France and Belgium tied, 2 -- 2, in another match.
For flouting the rules Mrs. Jarrett was dropped from the Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today threw open for public inspection reports disclosing compensation paid a group of corporate executives last year. The information had been filed with the request that it be kept confidential.
Business leases announced yesterday included several contracts for space by concerns that are expanding their facilities.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Lawson Robertson, coach of America's Olympic track and field forces, decided definitely tonight to call on Jesse Owens, Ohio State's Negro triple-winner, for duty in the 400-meter relay competition tomorrow and Sunday.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Behind the peaceful facade of the Olympics are raging a dozen or more little battles in the committees over rules. In these battles, rightly or wrongly, the Americans think they usually get the short end of the decisions, and maybe they do.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Harry H. Woodring, Acting Secretary of War, was deluged in his office today with forty pounds of white feathers in a one-man peace demonstration by Woody Hockaday, 50-year-old former Wichita, Kan., business man.

William Green, as president of the American Federation of Labor, in presenting a charter of affiliation with the federation to the American Newspaper Guild last night, declared that the internal fight in the ranks of American organized labor centered not on the question of craft versus industrial unionism but on one of democratic principles.

The names of eight representatives of the American Labor party, New York State affiliate of Labor's Non-Partisan League, who will attend the league's first national conference in Washington on Monday, were announced yesterday by Elinore M. Herrick, State campaign director.

Declaring that he was dissatisfied with their work, Police Commissioner Valentine dismissed nine members from his own confidential squad yesterday and returned them to uniformed duty. One had been an acting lieutenant.

With the first government crop estimate of the season due after the close of the market at noon today, evening-up operations continued the feature of trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Fluctuations held within limits of 10 points with a steady demand from mill quarters which left the list 1 to 4 points higher than on Thursday.

Three United States Senators are sailing today for Europe on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by their wives. They are Senators Royal S. Copeland of New York, Warren R. Austin of Vermont and Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware.

For the second consecutive week, new bond financing consisted largely of railroad issues, with three new loans by the carriers accounting for $32,500,000 of the total offerings of $35,467,000 placed on the market this week. This compares with $66,060,168 in new bonds offered last week, of which $29,500,000 were for the account of railroads, A-year ago this week new bond financing amounted to $40,693,000.

KIEL, Germany, Aug. 7 (AP). -- America's sails were set for a different wind than blew in Kiel Bay today, and as a result United States entries fared badly in all four divisions of the Olympic yachting regatta.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Long Island Sound skippers gave their local rivals a dusting in the Star Class today in Great South Bay's annual race week and one of them, Johnny Arms from Pequot in Andiamo III, stepped out to lead on points in the Commodore Corry Trophy series.

MADRID, Aug. 7. -- The board of directors of the Madrid Mortgage Bank has been dissolved and in its place a committee of four from the Communist party has been appointed. The Communist newspaper Mundo Obrero says it has received the following cable from the "Jimmy Collins group of aviators" of the United States:
LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The preliminary draft agreement for non-intervention in Spain, which France is submitting to the great powers, was received at the British Foreign Office today.

TOPEKA, Aug. 7. -- Governor Landon today made public his itinerary for the first two days of his first Eastern campaign trip, on which he will make formal speeches at his birthplace, West Middlesex, Pa., on Aug. 22, at Chautauqua Lake on Aug. 24 and at Buffalo on Aug. 26.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Formal notice that the San Francisco-Oakland Bridge would mean abandonment of the familiar ferries between the two cities was given to the Interstate Commerce Commission today, when the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway asked permission to do away with its ferries and connecting trackage.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- President Roosevelt plans to invite Governor Landon to confer with him late this month or early in September on drought relief problems, in company with other Governors of Middle Western States. The formal invitation will go forward as soon as the President has set definite dates for a series of such conferences on a tour to the drought areas, planned to start about Aug. 25 or 26.

Prices in the commodity futures markets were moderately firm yesterday in dull trading. On the cash markets, cotton, silk, rubber and coffee advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, lard and tin declined.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Further widening of the breach between craft and industrial union adherents within the American Federation of Labor to the point of a complete and irrevocable split in the next three months will probably be followed by a convention of all unions sympathetic to the program of the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was reported in labor circles today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The consolidated bondholders' committee representing investors in the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company has decided that the proposed reorganization plan for the railway is unsatisfactory, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Construction of one or more slum-clearance low-cost housing projects in New York City, with a Federal subsidy of 45 per cent of the total cost and a Federal guarantee of the rest, is being considered here for early presentation to President Roosevelt.

What an athlete did two weeks ago, two months ago or two years ago doesn't count with the average fan -- and that goes double for the average fight fan. What Louis did before the Schmelling bout is forgotten. He had a poor fight and, as a result, many fans now think that he is no longer an outstanding figure in pugilism.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- Lanvin launches a sensation in her horoscope dresses, embroidered, quilted or appliqued with celestial symbols. An astrologer at Lanvin's will cast the client's horoscope so that each model may be individually adapted to harmonize with the buyer's personal destiny.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 7. -- Amid the cheers of several hundred "hunger marchers" the Pennsylvania Legislature, after an all-night session, finally approved a $45,000,000 General Relief Appropriation Bill today and adjourned sine die, nearly fourteen weeks after it convened.

A series of special services under the auspices of the National Salvation Army officers will be conducted in Ocean Grove, N.J., beginning this evening and continuing through Monday. For the first time in more than quarter of a century the Salvation Army flag will fly from the Ocean Grove masthead.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- A sharp protest with a most emphatic demand for indemnity for the killing of four Germans by the sentence of an alleged anarchist tribunal near Barcelona was sent direct to the Spanish Government today through the German charge d'affaires in Madrid.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- President Roosevelt plans to invite Governor Landon to confer with him late this month or early in September on drought relief problems, in company with other Governors of Middle Western States. The formal invitation will go forward as soon as the President has set definite dates for a series of such conferences on a tour to the drought areas, planned to start about Aug. 25 or 26.

MILTON, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Mrs. Mary Vann, 40, was convicted today of being "an accessory before the fact in a conspiracy to commit murder" by hiring two Negroes to attempt to wreck the railroad train on which her 60-year-old husband was engineer.

Red Cross estimates at Madrid place the number of dead in the civil war at 35,000. This agrees closely with the insurgent figures given out at Burgos, which are 3,000 less. Nevertheless, there is some reason for thinking that both sides exaggerate the toll of life, heavy though it undoubtedly is.

Mrs. Henry Morgenthau Jr., wife of the Secretary of the Treasury, assumed an active role in the drive to re-elect President Roosevelt yesterday as she accepted the post of radio director for the women's division of the Democratic campaign.

Dominic Didato, alias Terry Burns, a small-time bookmaker, who was found shot dead in front of a restaurant at 90 Elizabeth Street late Thursday night, was identified yesterday as a former associate of Charles (Luciano) Lucania.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Gordon Selfridge Jr., department store executive; his sister, the Vicomtess de Sibour, and her husband have just returned from a holiday flying trip to Spain in Mr. Selfridge's own plane, piloted by the owner.

The government's recent action in removing barriers to the free flow of movement of bonded imports between New York and New Jersey sections of the Port of New York, was praised yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, as "evidence of the cooperation of the Federal Government with the States in recognizing the commercial unity of the Port District."

What is an individualist to do in this campaign? I have voted for every Democratic Presidential candidate since 1884 because that party was nearest my ideals (though not very near) on such questions as the tariff, special privilege and personal rights. Now I am confronted with six Socialistic tickets.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt will send out his champion, Discovery, to shoulder 143 pounds tomorrow in the Merchants' and Citizens' Handicap for the most formidable task in years for a thoroughbred over a route.

TORONTO, Aug, 7 (AP). -- Si Johnson, recently sold to the Cardinals by Cincinnati, pitched Toronto to a 2-0 victory over Newark tonight in his valedictory appearance in the International League. Johnson, who was optioned to the Leafs by the Reds, leaves for St. Louis tomorrow.

The insurance companies which hold bonds of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railway demand that the Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific cede part of their control in the line to some other railway or railways, George S. Van Schaick, vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday.

Norman Taurog is scheduled to leave Hollywood today for Callander, Ont., to arrange for the filming of the new picture with the Dionne quintuplets. The cast of "The Country Doctor," with Jean Hersholt, Dorothy Peterson, Slim Summerville, John Qualen and Michael Whalen, have received assignments for the new picture.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama cheeks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Attendance at the Olympic Games just one week after the opening has passed the million mark. By Sunday at the latest the number of admissions will be well beyond 1,247,580, the total attendance during the whole sixteen days of the Los Angeles Olympics in 1932, even if only the tickets already sold are used.

The announcement that one of the large automobile companies -- the Pierce-Arrow -- will begin the production of trailers within a few weeks is a signal that the trailer has "arrived." It is not a new invention; but it is only within the last two years or so that it has become really popular and that its possibilities have been recognized.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 7. -- Samuel Butler, prominent oil operator of Eastland and a brother of Brig. Gen. Smedley D. Butler, retired, was the victim of an extortionist who threatened to "wipe out" his children unless a large amount of money was thrown from a passenger train, it was learned today.

NEWARK, N. J., Aug. 7. -- The Federal grand jury that has been investigating the alleged kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, former Trenton lawyer, in New York in the last days of the Hauptmann case, was reliably reported today to have voted indictments against six persons.

Fourteen families who have occupied for more than twenty years a strip of land on the Gravesend Bay side of the west end of Coney Island yesterday won suits brought by a real estate company to have them ousted.

MADISON, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Miss Gail Wild of Baltusrol, one of the rising threats for the impending women's national championship at Canoe Brook next month, today won the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Braidburn Country Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Cubs regained their batting form and won a ball game, 14 to 5, from the Cardinals today, finally stopping the pennant-bound rush of the Gas House Gang, but in winning they suffered a big loss.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- In line with its proposal to buy 500 steel gondola cars, 500 steel flat-cars and twelve locomotives, the Northern Pacific Railroad asked today the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of an issue of $3,000,000 of 2 1/4 per cent equipment trust certificates.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Pirates took a firm grip on fourth place in the National League today, winning both ends of a double bill from the Reds, 5 to 1 and 1 to 0, before a ladies-day crowd of 11,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7. -- The thirty-second annual show of the Rhode Island Kennel Club will be given tomorrow. Many Summer colonists will show their dogs and many dinner and luncheon parties are planned for the day. A dance at the Clambake Club given by Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert, will end the day's activities.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 8. -- Conditions in Palestine, far from improving, are feared to be taking a turn for the worse.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Ensconced in a luxurious car of French manufacture, former King Alfonso of Spain entered Germany from Czechoslovakia tonight as Reich officialdom wrestled with the question of neutrality in relation to Spain's civil war.

UNDER the direction of John Barbirolli, the young English conductor who is to be one of the chief conductors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season, students of the Royal Academy of Music appeared at the New Scala Theatre in London, England, recently in Sir Alexander Campbell Mackenzie's ballad opera "The Cricket on the Hearth.

SINCE the first good road, in the modern sense of the word, was constructed in 1911, thousands of miles of hard-surface pavements have been laid throughout the country. Millions of dollars are being expended every year in exchanging the dirt road into concrete and asphalt.

FORT KNOX, Ky., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Four days of the Second Army's war practice manoeuvres ended in an armistice today as opposing Red and Blue forces battled furiously with blank ammunition over the McClellan ridge sector east of Fort Knox.

Price changes in commodity futures markets here for the week ended on Friday were mixed and, although on certain days movements were brisk, the week ended without notable changes. Copper and silk were slightly higher, while cottonseed oil, hides, rubber and wool tops declined.

THE New York Hippodrome Opera Company, Alfredo Salmaggi director, will open its fourth season Friday night, Aug. 21, at the Hippodrome. Thirty-two principals have been engaged, of whom sixteen are American born and eleven Americans by citizenship papers.

The second presentation of Bizet's "Carmen," which was postponed Friday night at the Stadium on account of rain, was given last night before an audience of 6,800. Alexander Smallens was again the conductor and the cast was identical with that of the previous performance except that Edwina Eustis assumed the title role instead of Bruna Castagna.

Frank L. Nowasatka, 32 years old, owner of the Shamokin Coal Company, 505 Broome Street, and William Slutsky, 50 years old, who said he was in the real estate business and lived at 317 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn, charged with bringing stolen coal into this State, were arraigned yesterday morning before Magistrate Michael A. Ford in the Felony Court and held in $500 bail each for examination on Tuesday.

THOSE among us very moderns who still believe that creative work is done only on the Left Bank, or its theories promulgated from the chair of the Writers Congress, from a soap box in Union Square or, perish the thought, because of the relief rolls of the United States Government, would do well to read the thrilling struggle of Dame Laura Knight, one of the great women artists of our time.

PARIS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Debt relief for small business men for the remainder of the year was voted tonight by the French Chamber of Deputies. Another, but longer, debt suspension plan for the assistance of farmers is pending in Parliament.

SEVERAL months ago, having been impressed by the recurrent reports from Hollywood of producers' squabbles, players' wrangles, writers' revolts and directors' dissatisfaction, this department ventured the uncertain prediction that the new season's pictures would reflect the film city's state of mind.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Theatrical activity grows greater next week. On Monday Sydney Carroll has two openings. One, at the Ambassadors', is the musical show "The Two Bouquets," with Gertrude Musgrove. The other is the return engagement of "As You Like It," with Margaretta Scott, at the Open Air Theatre.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 8. -- A moderate to fresh southeaster wafted 375 racing craft across three starting lines today in the Corinthian Yacht Club's third regatta and the concluding event of the greatest race week Marblehead has ever known.
One hundred boys from Washington, D.C., most of whom had never visited this city before, spent a crowded day here yesterday in sightseeing, ball-playing, dining and movie-going.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- A bullish construction placed on the Canadian Government's report which made condition of Spring wheat in the three Prairie Provinces 45 per cent of normal was largely responsible for a strong rally in North American markets today following an early break.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- Myrtlewood, the queen of American sprinters, raced to an easy victory in the $5,000 added Lakeside Handicap before 20,000 spectators at Washington Park today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Regulations issued today by the Treasury dealt chiefly with administering the central feature of the new corporation tax law, which imposes a surtax ranging from 7 to 27 per cent on corporation profits not distributed in dividends.

A stranger from the Pacific Coast, a nature-lover, who has had some firsthand experience with Western and Southern "original forest" -- which includes birds and animals in proportion or balance, just as nature placed them, has harbored a wish to see an "original forest" of the Northeast in the same undisturbed condition.

Specific plans for the Roosevelt-Garner campaign in every State will be mapped by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, in a series of conferences to be held in the next two weeks with party leaders from every part of the nation.

THE TALL MAN" is a first book. And with one long and easy bound it jumps to the first rank among books of its kind. It is, moreover, a genuine novelty among mystery stories. With no evidence of strain or effort, with as much freshness and nonchalance as if genuine novelty in a detective thriller were a commonplace achievement, Gavin Douglas has lightly produced this perfectly entrancing masterpiece.

KAUFMAN, Texas, Aug. 8 (AP). -- County Judge Ben Brooks said today that he expected Mrs. Mabel H. Green to be present in his tiny court room Monday when legal proceedings start regarding the disposition of her husband's estate, estimated at $80,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 8. -- The regular fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for July 31 shows the following changes, in paper pesos:

LAKEHURST, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Completing her sixth voyage to the United States, the Zeppelin Hindenburg landed at the Naval Air Station here at 7:05 o'clock this evening, after a daylight "swing" along the coast from Chatham, Mass., to Washington, D.C.

WITH tourist demands bringing out the largest number of Great Lakes cruises in ten years, Midwestern resorts are piling up peak figures. Recreation spots in Wisconsin and Minnesota are turning vacationists away, according to late reports.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Closing a busy and varied week at Hyde Park House today with a final political conference in which he received assurances that the great majority of "first voters" would support his candidacy for re-election in November, President Roosevelt tonight sought relaxation at the annual informal clambake given in his honor by the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Morgenthau at their farm about twenty miles from here.

THIS is the month of the parade of deserted dollars. Throughout the State of New York the savings banks will comply with the legal requirement to advertise annually the unclaimed deposits which have accumulated during the preceding twelve months.

F.X.A. Eble, former United States Commissioner of Customs land managing director of the "Buy American" movement sponsored by the Made In America Club, Inc., denied yesterday that the movement is hurting American trade in a reply to George F. Bauer, chairman of the National Committee for Reciprocal Trade, who charged that those urging buy-at-home movements were retarding recovery as well as the foreign trade program of the country.

DURING the four centuries Machiavelli and his doctrines have been nice subjects for wordy argumentation. The majority of readers have known the man's reputation only through his most famous book, "The Prince." Like the "Republic" of Plato and the "Utopia" of Sir Thomas More, "The Prince" of Machiavelli is one of those rare brain-children with which all respectable minds claim acquaintance.

POLITICAL attention in the months ahead will be focused on the two leading Presidential candidates. Yet at least one candidate for local office will be watched by observers outside his own State. That man is Herbert H. Lehman, Governor of New York since 1932 and now seeking re-election.

HOLLYWOOD. THE origin of the "Goldwyn gags" appears to be unknown. But they are traditional in Hollywood and wherever stories are told about the movies. Whenever any one lets fly a solecism or deliberately designs one it is Credited immediately to Samuel Goldwyn.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Daniel Gaddy, hotel night watchman, who failed to punch his clock near Helen Clevenger's door at the hour police believe she was killed, began his fourth week in the Buncombe County jail tonight -- still "held for questioning."

HERE on America's Western frontier a great political combat is in prospect. As a prelude to this encounter Idaho Republicans and Democrats will troop to the polls on Tuesday to nominate two unusual public figures for the United States Senate. Unless an overwhelming surprise occurs, sundown of Aug. 11 will see William E. Botch and C. Ben Ross in the lists for the Senate seat the former has occupied since 1906.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 8. -- More than a hundred county representatives of the Secretary of War, led by Dr. Adolph Lippe Boyce of New York and Ruford Franklin of New Jersey, civilian aides to the Secretary of War, arrived here today to inspect and review the Camp Dix Citizens' Military Training Camp.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The first Olympic water polo match almost did not take place today. Nobody could find the Uruguayan team, which was supposed to play Belgium. Then when the team finally was located in the dressing room nobody could make the players understand what was wanted.

ONE does not usually associate a saint with the Borgia family. The latter enjoys an evil reputation in history, thanks largely to the title-tattle of scribes, contemporary and modern. The Borgia family is one of the com posite bogies of history which really needs to be rehabilitated.

IN this land of kaleidoscopically sudden changes of temperature it has been difficult to bring chrysanthemums through the intense heat of Summer into bud and flower before the frosty nights of Winter lull them into dormancy.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- While powerful floodlights cast a ghostly glow over the Reich Sports Field Stadium in the gathering darkness this evening, Glenn Morris of the United States came churning down the homestretch with a driving finish that carried him to the Olympic decathlon championship and a new world record.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The Tigers and the Browns divided a double-header today, Detroit winning the first game, 9 -- 7, and St. Louis the second, 10 -- 5, before a crowd of 39,000.

SOIL erosion" is a term daily becoming more familiar. Usually it is employed in connection with agricultural lands, but the gardener who must attempt to do his planting, or part of it, on a slope soon learns that for him, too, it presents a very real problem.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The National Life Guard championships will be held here on Aug. 26, with approximately 100 young athletes who protect the lives of bathers at resorts and beaches in all sections of the country competing.

MAXIMUM engine power with lowest possible fuel consumption is the goal toward which all car manufacturers are striving in the development of their products. This feature will assume increased importance the coming year, when the industry is expected to emphasize economy of operation as a foremost selling argument.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Happy the Great, veteran trotter owned by William A. Harkhurst of Maplewood, and Hollyrood Perry, fast trotter owned and driven by Eugene Carpenter of Newark, scored the outstanding triumphs in the weekly matinee at Weequahic Park today.

With initial Fall buying on the major merchandise lines having passed its peak, manufacturers, looking over their sales records for the last month, estimated yesterday that gains ranged from 10 to 15 per cent in the men's wear and home furnishings lines to as high as 35 per cent in some women's apparel and dry goods fields.

IF you leave New York in the early evening you get off the train at Abingdon, Va., the next morning, and in all of a minute and ten seconds you can tell that songwriter what he wants to know, in case he is still asking. It is true, suh, what they say about Dixie.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 8. -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, discussing "Would-Be American Messiahs" at Crescent Park here tonight, declared that "it will be a calamity if labor puts its trust in Roosevelt rather than in its own organization, or if labor should compromise its essential de mand for plenty, peace and freedom at so cheap a price as he and his party have offered."

PAULA, the heroine of this short novel, is that phenomenon rare enough in modern fiction: a romantic woman, and authentic of her kind. Moreover, Miss Wilhelm has worked out a fluid style, always tender and often lyrical, which is peculiarly fitting to the portrayal of the inner states of her leading character.

KING EDWARD VIII of England, beginning his first vacation since he ascended the throne, is to take a cruise that will carry him along one of Europe's most picturesque coast lines -- Dalmatia and the lands of the Eastern Mediterranean.

The annual American Ballad Contest for amateur barber shop quartets, which proved so popular on its inception last year and which will get under way again with elimination contests the latter part of this month, has prompted the Department of Parks to try other forms of amateur entertainment centering in the city's parks.

ALTHOUGH there has been no gathering on street corners, and incipient riots are not visible to the naked eye, there have been premonitory rumblings. In the privacy of salons, and in school class rooms, the academicians of the stage and of educational circles have been saying their say ever since the announcement was made that Irving Thalberg was going to make a film version of "Romeo and Juliet."
CERBERE, France, Aug. 8. -- The Surete Nationale Commissioner stationed here asserts there have been no munitions or other war material or troop movements from this border point to Spain.

HAVING long since dedicated her talents to the concoction of flamboyant fairy tales, Vicki Baum has this time surpassed herself. It is hard to believe, in fact incredible, that any one could take seriously her newest and most tropical romance.

MUCH work is now being done on the relocation and reconstruction of New Jersey's Route 25, one of the State's principal highways, which extends from Jersey City to Camden. Construction has been begun on the realignment of this route between Burlington and Crystal Lake, in Burlington County.

MONTREAL, Aug. 7.--After fourteen years in office, the Liberal Progressive government led by Premier John Bracken failed to obtain a majority over all other parties in the Manitoba Provincial elections of a week ago. In the Quebec Provincial elections on Aug. 17, another Liberal government, after an even longer period of power, appears likely to fare still worse.

HOULTON, Me. -- One year ago the farmers of Aroostook County, Me., were dumping the unsold remainder of their 1934 potato crop after the market had hit an all-time low of 11 cents a bushel. This Spring potato prices to growers rose to the highest level in years when they reached $4 a barrel, after a Winter during which farmers were glad to sell their crop for around $2.

PORTSMOUTH, R.I., Aug. 8. -- Before one of the largest gatherings of enthusiasts that have witnessed the final judging of an all-breed dog show this season, the splendid all-white poodle bitch Champion Edelweis du Labory of Salmagundi, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Justin W. Greiss of Hamilton, Mass., today won the special prize for best in show at the thirty-second annual exhibition of the Rhode Island Kennel Club.
Leaves from an angler's notebook. . . .

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- A 1936 cotton crop of 12,481,000 bales was forecast today by the Federal Government's Crop Reporting Board, based on Aug. 1 conditions when better-than-average yields were indicated for the South as a whole, and record yields promised for several major producing States.

There is real horror in this mystery novel, and real originality in its plot. And its domestic atmosphere is one in which -- far more compellingly than against a background of gangsters and dives and dark alleys -- a thoroughgoing creepiness can have its way.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Although about 500 families will be forced to move from the old village at Lackawack when it is buried under 200 feet of water to create a new reservoir for New York City, they appear not to be greatly concerned about it so far and few have chosen sites for their future homes.

AS mysterious as the filtrable viruses which cause influenza, infantile paralysis and foot-and-mouth disease and which reveal virtually nothing under the most powerful microscope is bacteriophage. Years ago Dr. Twort in England and Professor D'Herelle of Yale discovered independently something which could not be seen under the miscroscope but which seemed to attack bacteria -- literally devoured them.

ALTHOUGH H.G. Wells is now his 70th year, his imagination is still active. He is employing it, as so often before, on the future rather than the past. The Listener publishes a short obituary he has written of himself in the conventional style adopted by the press in such notices.

While the first attempt to clarify the complexities of the Robinson-Patman law will be made this week at the scheduled conference on Thursday between representatives of the food and grocery industry and the Federal Trade Commission, several individual companies and industries as a whole took steps last week to conform with the provisions of the law.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- The seventh annual Lake Placid horse show will open next Friday and continue through Sunday. An outstanding innovation will be the night show to be given under floodlights on Saturday.

The chances seemed good yesterday that Russell Darbo, blind University of California student who hitch-hiked across the country in thirty-three days, would return home by airplane, but Mia, the shepherd dog companion in his adventure, was to be considered.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 8. -- The White Mountain resorts welcomed hundreds of newcomers today for the week-end. Events attended by large groups included a matinee at Chase Barn Theatre at Whitefield, by the Yale Forty-Niners, who presented "Post Road."

THE title of this fragile little novel was well chosen. There are actually only three characters in the story. And of the three, Saha, the dainty little Chartreuse cat with her lady-like ruff and her golden eyes, is by far the most real.

PARIS. THERE is something non-chalant about the smartest casino dresses -- even those for grand gala nights -- designed by Paris couturiers. They are in close harmony with the carefree spirit of Summer holidays.

MR. HARPER'S books are popular with young people because of their well-worked out plots and interesting characters, and since he sets his stories in places and among people that he knows thoroughly, they gain an atmosphere of truth and sincerity that is very pleasing.

ONE is always hearing about the typical English novel, competent, polished mid second-rate. As a perfect illustrative specimen one can recommend "Venus Over Lannery," by Martin Armstrong, which runs almost startlingly true to type.

CALAIS, France, Aug. 8 (AP). -- So strict was the insistence on King Edward's traveling incognito that a British flag flown at the St. Iglevert Airport, near here, was ordered down today just before the monarch's airplane landed.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- Leaders of the confessional movement in the German Evangelical Church have been holding in Berlin this week a series of significant meetings in which some of the best known "fighting parsons" frankly discuss the problems confronting their church in the Nazi State.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Raced for annually since the turn of the century, the historic Sewell Cup, Barnegat Bay's most coveted yachting trophy, was won today by Ferdinand P. Schoettle with his Lotus.

Announcements last week of bonds called for redemption before maturity covered a more diversified list than in the preceding week. The calls were about as numerous as in the previous period, but were for smaller amounts. Additional retirements for August consisted entirely of municipal obligations, raising the month's total to $162,730,000, compared with $661,048,000 in July, and $233,146,000 in August, 1935, in corresponding weeks.

THE People's Symphony Concerts, an organization, which for the last thirty-six years has presented prominent artists in recitals at popular prices for the people of New York, announced a series of six artists' recitals for the 1936-37 season at Washington Irving High School.

REBEL HEADQUARTERS, Burgos, Spain, Aug. 8 (AP). -- General Emilio Moia, northern commander of Rebel forces, began moving reinforcements to the Guadarrama front in the mountains and preparing the terrain for an advance against the capital.

Here social readjustments are brought about, not through force or hloodshe.d but through the ballot. Tolerance is. an essential in a true democracy, even' 'i;$he midst of agitation and ever conflicting points of view.

LONDON. A BEAUTIFUL new star is studying to become the Grace Moore of British films. She is blond, blue-eyed, Finnish and in her early twenties and her name, unless she decides to change it, is Aulikki Rautawaara.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Sherman Gerard, 12 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gerard of Patchogue, was killed today and his 5-year-old brother, Harold, was injured when their father's truck, in which they were riding, was in collision with a milk truck operated by Charles Ackerson of Blue Point.

NOW that an armistice has been declared in the six months' battle over broadcasting copyright music controlled by the Warner Brothers and subsidiary companies, the program directors are enjoying their first real breathing spell since the first of the year.
OLNEY, Ill., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Sylvester Plumlee, a 63-year-old WPA worker, was "honeymooning" today with what he said was his tenth wife.
BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- Five weeks from next Monday Maine will elect a Governor, a Senator, three Representatives and a full quota of State officers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The hunger marchers" who besieged the State Capitol on the reassembling of the Legislature last Monday were better disciplined and more responsive to reason than some who have made trouble for the lawmakers and administrative officials of other States.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- Following up its own acceptance of the non-intervention policy suggested by France, the British Government is now exerting itself to aid the French in bringing Portugal into line. Portugal has notified the French that she is sympathetic, but so far she has not given what can be called acceptance, even in principle.

Operators in the recently formed Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association conferred at several meetings in New York last week on details of the new organization, an outgrowth of the disrupted Intercoastal Conference which disbanded several years ago after a long period of disagreement.

One of the most serious handicaps to the greater use of air transportation is the difficulty in taking-off and landing at central points. It is like the great ocean liners coming to New York -- they all want to dock as close to Broadway as possible, which means the use of the North River piers.

ENCOURAGED by the rising business index the radio industry looks forward to the 1936-37 season as one of the most prosperous in its history. Estimates are heard that sales of radio sets in the year will total 7,000,000, a million more than the best previous record.
OMAHA, Aug. 7. -- A museum of political oddities might contain a display of the situation growing out of the sudden death of Senator Louis Murphy of Iowa.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The annual father-and-son tournament, scheduled for next Saturday, has been replaced by a mixed foursomes tournament, to be played on the Homestead course. The annual Summer swimming carnival is scheduled for Aug. 21.

IT is generally recognized that the real causes of many accidents never get into official records. It may be reported, for instance, that an accident resulted from some one's driving too fast for conditions, but it may have been the condition of the driver's stomach or head or nerves, rather than highway or traffic conditions, that was really responsible for the crash.

MOTION-PICTURE timing was first used, so far as the Olympic Games are concerned, at Los Angeles in 1932. The results were so strikingly superior to the old method of averaging the indications of three stop-watches that it was decided to adopt cameras at Berlin.

AT noon tomorrow the Sheriff of Nottingham, England, will be the host at luncheon to the greatest gathering of chess players that has assembled for a tournament in the twentieth century. Why not say "the greatest of all time"?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union and secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization, today protested against the action of the executive council of the American Federation of Labor in ordering the suspension of ten national unions.

NEWPORT, R.I. -- This is yachting week. Newport will greet on Thursday the New York Yacht Club fleet on the first of two visits the club will make here this year on its annual cruise. Already a number of entertainments are being arranged by the Summer colony yachtsmen in honor of their visiting brethren during their two-day stay, for they will leave on Saturday morning for Edgartown.

THE Harvard Tercentenary Exhibition at Cambridge, Mass., devoted extensively to furniture, silver, pewter, glass, ceramics and allied arts and crafts of the period 1636-1836, brings together also a considerable number of early portraits and prints.

THIS atlas of the history of China -- it is nothing short of that -- is not only an invaluable book but a remarkable one. It begins with the pre-historic sites of China; its first map in the history of recorded time shows the beginnings of ancient China, of 1900 B.C.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Harold Halsted of Westhampton on Moriches Bay proved his class as a Star boat sailor today by carrying off the Commodore Corry trophy, the big prize of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's twenty-first annual race week, for the second time in three years.

NOT long ago an old airplane, crashing in the Arizona desert, was damaged beyond profitable repair. Motor and propeller, however, remained intact, and the owner cast about for a way to turn these into some account.

IN the first six months of 1936 forty-five additional fliers of the Air Corps, the Reserve, National Guard, the navy and from civilian life have joined the mythical Caterpillar Club by making emergency landings by parachute. This brings the total membership to 805 and the total jumps to 843 since the club was started on July 21, 1919.

OVER the country the average of retail trade for the week probably showed some letdown from recent high gains. New York and Chicago reported less active demand. Retailers here were quick in saying, however, that the lull was probably only a temporary one and that no interruption of the basic upward movement was in sight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Pete Appleton limited Boston to five hits today as the Senators shut out the Red Sox, 2 -- 0, for their second straight triumph.

TOKYO, July 25. -- The new Russian Army, in the opinion of Colonel Hikosaburo Hata, who has just returned to Japan after serving for two years as military attache in Moscow, "has splendid planes, but not enough pilots; powerful tanks, but not enough trained man power to make the best use of them."

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 8. -- The Nicaraguan Congress has given the most liberal concession it has ever granted to Kenneth H. Mathe son, representing the American and Honduran Rosario Mining Company. The concession provides for the development of mines in the famous Pis Pis district of Eastern Nicaragua.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug, 8. -- Another internationalist returned to action in Long Island polo today when Michael G. Phipps, No. 2 of the American team which successfully defended the Westchester Cup in London last June, made his first appearance of the season here in a round-robin on Belmont Field at the Meadow Brook Club.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J. -- The citizens' committee of Lake Hopatcong, headed by Councilman Herbert Meyer, has completed arrangements for a program of water sports to be held this afternoon in River Styx. Several thousand spectators are expected to view the water spectacle from the River Styx bridge and from Bon Air Lodge, where the events will be held.

HORSE lovers, thousands of them, will converge next Wednesday on the little town of Goshen, N.Y., for the running of the Hambletonian Stake. This greatest of all trotting races is a magnet for every one in trotting. Named for Hambletonian, father of the trotter, which is the only definite American contribution to the sporting horse, it is a race which the owner of a trotter seeks to win above all others.

IS it possible for man to predict the future? The rational answer might seem to be that he never has done so, wouldn't act the way he does if he could see beyond the end of his nose, probably wouldn't be any happier if he could predict and, finally, can't predict.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The vacation season in the Poconos has reached its peak and every effort is now being directed to special entertainment for the thousands of people who have flocked in to spend the last few weeks of the vacation season in the mountains.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Ray Mangrum, Pittsburgh professional, jumped into the lead of the Oregon $5,000 open golf tournament today with a par-shattering 67 to bring his score for the first thirty-six holes to 137. Par for the 6,391-yard course is 72.

The season's first government cotton crop estimate of 12,481,000 bales appeared yesterday after the close of the New York and New Orleans Exchanges. When trading was resumed in Chicago, however, October broke 37 points as a result of a larger indicated yield than had been expected, closing at 11.78 cents, compared with 12.07 before the report was issued.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Wheat in the United States has parted company with its companion of many years: huge price-depressing surpluses. Unfavorable weather, not for a year alone but for a record-making span of four years, has supplied the wedge severing the old and troubled relationship.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The two teams that have been cutting the most capers so far in the John G. Anderson Memorial tournament at Winged Foot came a cropper this afternoon.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, Canal Zone, Aug. 8. -- I, Rene Belbenoit, am a fugitive. I write this under cover and on the run. I have no country, I have no home. I was a journalist before I became a convict. I speak and write only French and there is nothing for me in my profession outside of France, where I dare not return.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7. -- In the face of "hunger marches" on the State Capitol and a special session of the Legislature to provide additional unemployment relief, Greater Pittsburgh, including all of Allegheny County, with a population of around 1,400,000, experienced a strange interlude this week in which visions of a possible labor famine a few months hence were evoked.

As to the first question, the answer is definitely yes. Even if drought was not in politics a week ago, it is there now, if only as the result of the discussion of who put it there.

ACCORDING to Mr. A. Hamilton Gibbs, "the finding of heaven on this earth * * * is the fundamental need we have." To some of us this may sound like a rather large order, but since it has in fact very little to do with the pleasant little romance he unfolds, that makes no difference and need not deter any would-be reader.

IN the Brooklyn Museum Quarterly (July issue) Sheldon Keck offers readers some packed and informative comment on fifteenth century painting with special attention to the craftsmanship and technique which had so large a part in the production of masterpieces of that time.
