BOMBS crash and machine guns crackle in the ancient cockpit of Palestine; Great Britain names a royal commission to investigate the revolt of the Arabs against her rule. The Zionists, as wards of the British, are involved, but only incidentally. This revolt, simple in its fundamentals, has roots which stretch far beyond the borders of Palestine.

SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (AP).--Nicholas Sokoloff, representing Amtorg, Russian trading agency, said tonight that the Russian fliers, Sigismund Levanevsky and Victor Levchenko, en route to Moscow via Alaska and Siberia were forced down by poor visibility at Bella Bella, B.C., at 3 P.M., Pacific time.

PARIS, Aug. 8. -- Pending the outcome of the international negotiations for a neutrality accord, the French Cabinet decided today to continue the embargo it has maintained on shipments of arms and war materials to Spain.

THE Presidential campaign is under way, aggressively so, after a lull that in itself has been deceptive. Behind is the excitement of the convention period. Behind are the ceremonies of notification. The candidates are now ready to take their causes to the people.

The news from Spain is rich in names that are familiar to schoolboys the world over -- Granada, Seville, Gibraltar, Cadiz, Barcelona, Toledo, Saragossa. But the particular section of Spain which the world knows most intimately has not figured in the dispatches by name.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 8 (AP). -- John Hadjukovich, prospector, flew here today with word that he and two companions found the Arthur F. Hines plane, missing with Hines and three passengers almost a year, on a barren mountain range 175 miles east of here.

With corporation earnings rising rapidly, expenditures for scientific and industrial research carried on by large organizations have expanded steadily this year, with sharper gains looked for in 1937, according to comment by executives here yesterday.

DR. MIGUEL MARIANO GOMEZ, the youngest President ever elected by Cuba, is the man of the hour in Havana today. This is a crucial moment in the history of the island republic. Whether it goes on in peace or reverts to the turmoil and chaos which have marked the past five years will depend mainly upon the force of character, the political skill and the qualities of statesmanship exhibited at the Presidential Palace.

TRAINING in the Gregorian chant will be a feature of the Summer session extension courses of the Plus X School of Liturgical Music, New York, which begins this Wednesday at the Academy of the Sacred Heart, Detroit. The session will continue until Aug. 29.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 8. -- Two hundred and fifty members and their guests attended a dinner dance held tonight at the American Yacht Club here. The hosts included Commodore John B. Shethar, William Crow, H.H. Nicols and Mrs. George Lauder.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Three families who have estates on the exclusive Westchester Country Club grounds today began a court battle with neighbors over "sixteen to twenty" dogs. The animals, they complain, have made the day and night "hideous," driven away servants and made it impossible to keep favored guests more than one night.

DETROIT, Aug. 8. -- Declaring their intention of administering a "disciplinary" defeat to President Roosevelt next November, and thereby to return the Democratic party to its "rightful heirs," forty or more "Jeffersonian Democrats" ended a two-day conference today after setting up a temporary organization to coordinate independent Democratic anti-New Deal movements and sentiment throughout the country into a national cause.

CINDERELLA'S pumpkin, turned into a coach, scarcely underwent a greater metamorphosis than that befalling the American high school this Summer. On green hillsides and parched plains from coast to coast little red high school houses are disappearing, at the magic touch of the $464,000;000 wand of the PWA.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8. -- The Canadian Government today received and referred to its legal experts a request from the Edmonton Chamber of Commerce that the issuance of taxable "prosperity certificates" in Alberta by the Aberhart government be prohibited as a contravention of Federal control over currency.
THE porter at Kitzbuhel was much perturbed when the foreign lady took a slow train.

Last week was again a very active one in the wholesale markets, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by the McGreevy, Werring Howell Company, resident buyer. The Accessories Show created a great deal of interest and many buyers timed their visits here for the event.

AFTER the thermometer was invented and became an indispensable instrument in medical practice, physicians observed that the body temperature rose and fell rhythmically in the course of twenty-four hours. Plants, too, have their daily rhythms and of these the most familiar is the position assumed by a leaf as the day waxes and wanes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Owing to the establishment of the Works Program and other administrative changes in the handling of relief the number of families and persons receiving general relief as reported to the WPA declined from more than 5,000,000 in the early months of 1935 to an estimated 1,930,000 in March, 1936, according to Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The commission broad silk weaving business, with its "family shop" and attendant evils, is blamed for reducing silk manufacturing to the lowest of levels among industries.

The first meeting at which members of the New York Stock Exchange will have an opportunity to express their views on the Securities and Exchange Commission's program for segregating the functions of broker and dealer probably will be held on Wednesday at the Exchange by its special committee on segregation, of which Howland S. Davis is chairman.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- The first week of Winter fashion openings shows strongly the influence of the Baron Gros Exposition of early Napoleonic paintings and Napoleona. The way was already paved for these styles by Directoire trends launched in previous couture collections.

DURING the latter part of this month thirty-five aviation cadets of the Naval Reserve will join the United States fleet and take their places with naval aviators of the regular service in the aircraft squadrons. This will be the first group of cadets in this new corps of the navy to complete their training at Pensacola and be ordered to duty afloat.

Archibald T. Johnson of Duane, Morris Heckscher, Philadelphia, counsel for the reorganization committee of the Syracuse Lines, New York State Railways, has informed Jonathan M. Steere, chairman of the committee, that a hearing is to be held on Tuesday before Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant in Malone, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Awards were announced by the Navy Department today to forty-six ships of the fleet, ten aircraft squadrons and one submarine base for excellence in gunnery and torpedo performances.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 8 (AP). -- With her small shoulders squared in grown-up dignity, Helen Osborn, aged 11, faced a throng of prospective foster parents today and seriously discussed adoption of her four small brothers and sisters -- left homeless by a stepfather's sudden rage.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Several of the top notchers entered in the Eastern grass court tennis championships moved through their first-round formalities in all-conquering fashion today, registering straight-set triumphs over lesser lights as play opened in the annual competition at the Westchester Country Club.

VISIT the Riverton section of Cook County, Ill., an area bounded by Belmont and Crawford Avenues and Ninety-fifth Street, Chicago, and the Cook County line, any warm Summer night and you will find no smudge fires, no mosquito netting, no pungent odor of citronella.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- On the first anniversary of the Federal Social Security Act, its administrative board today counted 1,152,000 aged and unfortunate persons, in every State, on its assistance rolls.

JOHN BUCHAN -- who is, in another aspect of his public life, Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada -- has written some fifty volumes of history, fiction and biography. Of these the majority are fiction and a few of them, like "Prester John," are already well on the way to becoming classics.

ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug, 8 (AP). -- Cloudless weather and a bright sun, ideal conditions for sailing craft, and water just choppy enough to provide power boats thrills marked the closing program today of the fifteenth annual Miles River Yacht Club regatta.

A NUMBER of letters by Camille Saint-Saens, which hitherto were hidden away in the archives of the Paris Conservatory, have just been brought to light and published in the Revue des Deux-Mondes. Some of these letters are from the prolonged correspondence carried on between Saint-Saens and the music critic Camille Bellaigue, from 1889 until 1921.

RECENTLY there has been much discussion of the art of cheating in card games, particularly in contract bridge. Several published articles have stated unequivocally that cheating is prevalent in bridge everywhere, but particularly so in the bridge clubs of New York.

TOKYO, Aug. 8. -- Japan will welcome a revival of friendship with Britain but will not pay too high a price. The price expected is not only recognition of Manchukuo but recognition of Japan's special position in China, says the newspaper Asahi in its second article discussing conditions for renewal of Anglo-Japanese friendship.

EVERY now and then some esthetic atrocity, like dunking dolma in kitchen bouquet, offends the sensibilities of the otherwise reserved and imperturbable Count Philip d'Esco of Rumania and Hollywood. Whereupon the Count drops whatever may be occupying him in the property department of Twentieth Century-Fox and delivers himself of a few thousand well chosen words, while production pauses and less technically minded directors tear their hair.
Glenn Morris set world record of 7,900 points as Americans swept first three places in decathlon; Bob Clark was second and Jack Parker third.

Signal honors came yesterday to Irving (Bump) Hadley at the Yankee Stadium as he white-washed Connie Mack's Athletics with the stimulus of a seven-hit fusillade that thrilled some 13,500 fans. The score was 4 to 0.

Forty years ago, that is to say early in August, 1896, a heat wave enveloped New York and in the following ten days struck down people in the streets and filled the hospitals with casualties. As many as 564 died in the metropolitan district.

NEW handbags to carry one's first Fall sports outfit are generous in size and acquire their appeal from strong basic designs, which are simple and undecorated. One big, unadorned purse over a foot long at the bottom is about eight inches high and has a large, square top handle to give it individuality.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- Since the Middle Ages, when religious strife divided every country in Europe within itself and split the Continent into rival Catholic and Protestant camps, there has not been such a turmoil of spirit as has been climaxed with the outbreak of civil war between the Right and Left in Spain.

IT is hardly possible to ignore Texas in any long view of the United States. At the moment it is in the throes of an oil boom, or there is one on the way -- there always is. But even if one had somehow missed it before, no watcher of the public prints could fail to be impressed with its bigness and vitality.

SALZBURG, Aug. 8. -- The performance of "Die Meistersinger" under Arturo Toscanini at the Festspielhaus this evening not only climaxed this year's festival but perhaps climaxed all Salzburg festivals. Despite all manner of problems and obstacles created by extremely limited stage space and the absence of technical facilities in the festival theatre, tonight's representation was a glorious work, the stage direction of which was in the hands of Dr. Herbert Graf.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Now that the executive council of the American Federation of Labor has suspended, effective Sept. 5, ten unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization, representing about a third of the federation's membership, the cleavage in the labor movement has widened.

WASHINGTON. -- Should Governor Landon fulfill the predictions of his most ardent supporters and gallop to a victory over President Roosevelt next November, he would still be faced with a problem which has been the undoing of good men before him -- a mustang Congress.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The Harbor Club at Seal Harbor will hold its tenth annual open tennis tournament this week. The men's and women's singles will begin tomorrow. The winners last year were William G. Foulke 2d and Miss Ann Page.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Compliance in principle of Great Britain and all the important Continental powers with the French Government's appeal for non-intervention in the Spanish civil war has, for the time being at least, staved off the much greater menace to European peace than was deemed inherent in either the Ethiopian war or the military reoccupation of the Rhineland.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the annual ball tonight to mark the close of the Meadow Club's invitation tennis tournament. The visiting tennis players were guests of honor at the dance in the Colonial ballroom and Japanese room.

Unfavorable weather early in the week reduced trade activity in the New York metropolitan area. From the high level at the end of July gains fell to an average of shout 6 per cent over a year ago, although that figure may have been increased by results toward the close of the week.

TIME was when the saying, "Man works from sun to sun but woman's work is never done," conveyed a literal truth. That was in the days of the wood-burning stove, the cast-iron skillet and the icebox that had to be filled every day by an iceman who left muddy tracks on the kitchen floor.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- Performing with all that unerring delicacy of touch demanded of one riding the Niagara rapids on a barrel stave, Carl Hubbell had the Phillies swinging in vain at the inviting target provided by their right-field wall today and safely brought the Giants home to port in the second game of the series, 3 to 2.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Following closely on the Essex County Republican Committee's endorsement of O. Byron Brewster of Elizabethtown, Supreme Court Justice, for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination, the Clinton County Republican Committee has adopted unanimously a resolution backing him and urging delegates to the Republican State convention to give consideration to his availability.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- A phenomenal final-round score carried the contract bridge team of Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine from tenth place to victory in the masters' pair championship of the American Bridge League here today.

The growth of national barriers to international trade has greatly increased the importance of correct documentation of foreign trade shipments and thereby increased the volume of such work handled by the Merchants Association, according to the annual report of the foreign trade bureau of the association, made public yesterday.

UVALDE, Texas. THE President has his stamp collection for his principal hobby. In that he has a great host of fellow-enthusiasts. But the pet hobby of Vice President Garner has few followers; for his pet collection is of gavels.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert entertained at the Clambake Club tonight with a large dinner dance. More than 100 guests attended the dinner and many others came in for dancing later from other dinners.

MEN alone, with rod and gun, men weary from the grinding routine of modern civilization, are setting off these days for the North Woods, for the cold, rockbound, pine-ringed lakes. Boys, by twos and threes, disappear down the leafy trails whose Summer green, whose Summer mystery, is an allurement to adventure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Federal planning consultants are now assigned to forty-four State planning boards, according to a recent report of the National Resources Committee. Though the Federal Government does not pay subsidies to the State boards, it does pay the expenses and salaries of the consultants who are assigned to this particular work.

In a report on "Can Delinquency Be Measured?" published by the Columbia University Press for the Research Bureau of the Welfare Council of New York City, Dr. Sophia M. Robison concludes that severe poverty is not a crucial factor in causing delinquency among children.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With horse shows, tennis tournaments and theatricals on the wane as Summer diversions, bridge parties for charity are now in vogue among the Summer residents of the North Jersey shore.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Communism, birth control and salacious films were condemned at the opening of the semi-annual session conference of the national officers and directors of the Catholic Daughters of America here today.

The use of equipment trust certificates to finance purchase of motor trucks and omnibuses by highway transport companies was predicted yesterday by Ernest L. Nye of Freeman Co. He described the announcement of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that it was prepared to make loans for such purchases as "a helpful and constructive contribution to improve transport."

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The Count de Sibour took off from Heston Airdrome today en route to Granada, Spain, where he will undertake to transport about eighty marooned British, French and American citizens to Tangier, in the internationalized zone of Morocco.

WARSAW, Aug. 7. -- Two million peasants are expected to take part on Aug. 15 in the celebration of the anniversary of Poland's great, victory over the Bolsheviks sixteen years ago. This miracle on the Vistula -- the eighteenth decisive battle in the world's history, as Lord d'Abernon described it -- was, so the peasant leaders say, a victory of Polish peasants and Polish workers, led by Wincenty Witos, the farmer-Premier.

THE TIMES of July 27 contained a reply to my letter on war debts. Thomas H. Green criticizes my omission of authorities to support my statements, so I give them below. Mr. Mellon had no part in making these loans. Albert Rathbone, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who had direct charge of these transactions, has described them in detail in Foreign Affairs for April, 1925.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Major George L. Berry, chairman of labor's Nonpartisan League, declared today that advance reports from the forty-eight State chairmen who will meet here Monday indicated the election outlook was at variance with current polls and showed a "tremendous sweep of labor sentiment for President Roosevelt."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- Members of both the Southampton and the East Hampton Summer colonies are taking an active interest in the ambitious Ballet Caravan to be presented this afternoon in the gardens of the Playhouse, on the estate of Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse at East Hampton, for the benefit of the scholarship fund of Smith College.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Twelve-year-old Florence Moynihan of White Plains qualified for the competition in the national fixture next November by winning the Good Hands Cup for junior horsemanship at the second session of the Sagamore Horse Show today.

William T. Ellis's letter on Palestinian problems in THE TIMES calling attention "to two major considerations of fact that are beyond debate" makes interesting reading. The first of his finalities is that the Arabic-speaking people of Palestine are descendants of "the mixed race whom the Old Testament calls Canaanites."

AT 300 may a nation be said to have come of age? The other day John Drinkwater, bringing a British point of view to bear upon the moot question of America's maturity, remarked: "When you are 300 years old you ought to know as much about the game as when you are 700."

In the clash and confusion of events to Europe, we see again how impossible it is neatly to define and classify political movements that are diverse and puzzling. It is convenient to affix a name to each one, as if that explained everything. But here too names are not things.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A return to direct steam drive and innovations in design and weight distribution are expected to make the two new battleships slated to be built next year speedier than the comparable battleships of any other nation.

The Thames River at New London is properly excited today about this afternoon's outboard regatta being sponsored by the Connecticut Power Boat Association. Trophies or cash prizes are being awarded to amateurs and professionals in Classes A, B, C and F.

Any apprehension that might have been felt in financial circles over the possible repercussions of the Federal Reserve Board's action in raising member bank reserve requirements 50 per cent has virtually vanished as the Aug. 15 deadline for meeting the new requirements approaches, it was apparent in banking quarters last week.

Distribution in the Times Square area of a circular designed to further the Police Department safety campaign has been started by members of Traffic Precinct D, whose commander, Captain John O'Leary, is the author.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7. -- Several thousand unemployed families came off the relief rolls in Ohio's industrial counties this week as the State began the job, now complete in New Jersey and under way elsewhere, of restoration of unemployment relief to local hands and partly to local financial support.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7. -- The paternalistic nature of the Soviet Government was strikingly illustrated this week in the decree by the Commissars of the Russian Federated Republic almost doubling the number of hairdressing establishments -- which here include in one shop both men's barber shops and women's beauty parlors.
GENEVA, Aug. 8. -- The first World Jewish Congress opened here tonight in the hall where the League of Nations Assembly meets.

Aram Kapigian of Philadelphia came through with a victory yesterday in the defense of his title as the sixth annual Armenian national tennis championships got under way at the Sunrise courts in Sunnxyside, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A campaign by the Daughters of the American Revolution for strict enforcement of teacher's oath laws, starting with the Fall school term, was announced today by Mrs. William A. Becker, president-general.

With the booking of two Negroes charged with homicide, the police announced yesterday the solution of the killing on July 23 of City Marshal Morris Florea in his office at 149 East 121st Street. Florea was robbed of $800 and beaten with a hammer.

NEXT: The long-haired, bewhiskered Bolshevik of the post-war cartoons is to be liquidated. The Council of People's Commissars last week announced a two-year tonsorial plan. This year, 2,860 new barber chairs are being installed throughout the Russian Soviet Socialist Republic; in 1937, according to the plan, another 5,648 chairs will come into use.

WHILE tempted to smile at first at the naivete of this book, and to question the necessity of its having been written, one soon begins to feel a respect for its simple-minded author, and to realize that we are in the presence, to quote the publishers' note, of "a nature of particular sweetness."

MADRID, Aug. 8. -Moroccan Rebel troops, hardened in north African hill campaigns, tramped northward toward beleaguered Madrid tonight. That word, reaching the capital from Rebel headquarters in Burgos, to the north, hastened rather than delayed slashing government attacks on three fronts.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The Wyantenuck Country Club tonight celebrated its fortieth anniversary, with 200 attending a dinner and entertainment. Mr. and Mrs. John H.C. Church and John L.E. Pell, charter members, were present and Mr. Pell arranged the program, which included a skit conducted by Mrs. Church entitled "The First Ten at Locustwood."

DROUGHT, pests, storms and other untoward visitations are no new experience for the farmer of the Northwest. Nor have they shaken his confidence in himself or in the land that he tills. He accepts the devastations of nature as a logical balance to the years when crops are abundant and the fat livestock wade knee-deep in luxuriant pasture.

SOON the tocsin will sound. The Summer holidays will be over and the march back to school and college will be on. Girls may look pretty swell as they fall in line, for togs are marvelous and they are American.

SEVENTEEN first editions of works by Beethoven, with corrections and marginal remarks in the composer's own handwriting, were discovered recently by a Hungarian collector in a Budapest second-hand bookshop. According to the Pariser Tageszeitung, the bibliophile Patai, who made the discoveries, purchased them for a few pennies each from the unsuspecting dealer and had difficulty in keeping him from erasing the notes made by Beethoven on the margins.

The impact of the drought on business will be limited chiefly to the West Central States, it is indicated in a survey made last week by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., through its nineteen district offices. The area embraces the States of Montana, Wyoming, North and South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Iowa, Missouri and Oklahoma.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- A quadrennial problem in the careers of Presidents who run for re-election has arisen in aggravated form for President Roosevelt, reach definite stature in the past week he began to guide with one hand an "aggressive" campaign for re-election while directing drought-relief activities with the other.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 8. -- From ten different countries, including the United States, Cuba, France, Germany, Holland, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, Poland, Russia and Great Britain, the world's leading chess masters have gathered for the opening Monday of the international congress, arranged in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Nottingham Chess Club.

PRAGUE. -- There are British and French statesmen who believe that Hitler's next move will be to put pressure on Czechoslovakia to accept German patronage. The sturdy little republic lies right across the path of the German advance in a southeasterly direction toward the Danube and beyond it into the Balkans toward Constantinople.

ALTHOUGH the Scout movement strives to have every Scout at camp, there are always some boys who cannot get away and many who can get away for only a small part of the Summer. For such Scouts a special stay-at-home program has been developed in many communities.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The polo season, always one of the most colorful features of the Summer at this resort, got under way last week at the Greenbrier Polo Club, and this week two series of matches will be played, with what promises to be an outstanding game next Sunday.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The National Socialist regime's first domestic goal, namely, official elimination of unemployment in Germany, came into sight today when the Labor Office announced that the number of registered jobless had decreased another 144,000 during July, reducing the remaining total to 1,170,000.

KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Glendhu, 6-year-old chestnut mare, and The Thruster, 5-year-old chestnut gelding, both owned by Sydney S. Gilbert of North Salem, N.Y., romped off with the principal honors in the third annual Mount Holly horse show today on the picturesque estate of Robert P. Lamb.
HAVANA, Aug. 8. -- The first thirteen, including four women of an estimated eighty Havana political prisoners affected by the amnesty law left Principe Fortress and the women's prison this afternoon.

MOSCOW. -- The Soviet Union is determined to keep a closer check upon imports than ever before. That is the meaning of the speech made to foreign trade executives here July 27 by A.P. Rosengoltz. the Foreign Trade Commissar.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- How much thoroughbred bone and muscle can stand was the question that came to the fore today as Discovery failed gallantly under 143 pounds in the Merchants and Citizens Handicap, with the Middleburg Stable's filly Esposa the winner under 100 pounds.

ENCOURAGED by increasing opportunities to study art through exhibits, lectures, art; "tours" and free courses of instruction, persons of all ages and of widely divergent vocations are turning to painting as a hobby.

VIENNA, Aug. 7. -- "If peace between Austria and Germany was to endure, the Austrian Government had to take into account the existence, solidarity and indestructibility of the Nazi movement, in Austria. Any continuation of persecutions would have resulted in unrest and desperate struggle."
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Idaho voters Tuesday will settle intra-party differences featured by Senator William E. Borah's lone-wolf campaign for a sixth term.

TORONTO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- After dropping the first game to the Leafs, 5 -- 4, the Newark Bears, behind the three-hit pitching of Marvin Duke, blanked Toronto, 3 -- 0, in an abbreviated second game today. It was the Bears' first victory in nine starts against Toronto.

YORK HARBOR, Me. -- With a continuous round of entertaining in private homes, at clubs and on yachts -- a program including charity events, and sports -- the York Harbor season continues in full swing. A larger Summer colony is in residence here than in any recent year.

Before a gathering of 10,000 spectators, practically all of whom were attired in bathing suits, Miss Gertrude (Trudy) Ederle was honored yesterday at the special A.A.U. swimming meet at Manhattan Beach, held to commemorate the tenth anniversary of her conquest of the English Channel.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 7. -- In the uplands of Central Wyoming and in two mountainous areas along the Pacific Coast work on four great Federal dams -- Seminoe, Alcova, Bonneville and Grand Coulee -- proceeds without let-up.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Music may soothe the savage breast, but it is plainly a pain in the ear to some jungle beasts.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. -- The coming week will be festive for the Summer colony and residents of this resort, where the racing has attracted many prominent New Yorkers. Tomorrow evening a colorful water carnival will be given at the recreation unit at Saratoga Spa, with synchronous and fancy diving in the $30,000 pool, and a pageant of Father Neptune.

An American news agency asked Adolf Hitler last week how war could be avoided in Europe. "By common sense," replied the Fuehrer. He was also asked if he thought that peace could be guaranteed by the League of Nations. No, replied Herr Hitler. "A new system, based on reason and justice, is needed," he said.

THOSE who believe in aristocracy as opposed to democracy -- and their number is unfortunately increasing in Europe -- are in the habit of pointing to the benefits which art and artists enjoyed under the patronage of prince in the past.

A NOVEL experiment in educational broadcasting is being made in New York City in the Radio Workshop. It is sponsored jointly by the educational radio project of the United States Office of Education and the general education division of New York University.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 8.--What has been causing plaster to fall off walls, ceilings to crack and pottery to break in homes in Llewellyn Park, will soon be determined. Officials of the Orange Quarry Company, which does blasting on Eagle Rock Mountain, blame trucks rumbling along Eagle Rock Avenue.

THIS personal record of the late novelist and moralist comes as a certain relief after so much of the rubbish that has been written about Lawrence, either by women engaged in scratching at his grave or at each other or else by Mr. John Middleton Murry.
SEATTLE, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The five-story plunge of Representative Marion A. Zioncheck was attributed by friends tonight to worry over a psychiatrist's advice that he take a long rest from politics.

UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN archaeologists recently have found death masks in burial mounds in Northwestern Wisconsin which indicate burial customs similar to those of the Incas. Professor Ralph Linton reports a belief that the masks are a record of aborigines who came from Mexico or further South.

Here is murder in the Ozarks -- but not a mountain feud. The first victim is a rascal who has taken to itinerant preaching and faith healing as a means of attaining some extremely worldly ends; and while he swayed large crowds to mass hysteria from his pulpit in the dusk of the forest, the "Reverend" Jim Berber had a number of very bitter enemies.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7. -- Sales to the 2,000 retail dealers in convention here were reported the best since 1929 in practically all lines. Shoes and women's wear were in special demand, and wholesale houses handling these lines report marked activity.
CENTENNIAL week opens today at Alexandria Bay, N.Y., with a water pageant depicting scenes from the history of the early village and of the neighboring Thousand Islands.

The Presidential candidates of all political parties, with the exception of Governor Alfred M. Landon, will speak at the sixth annual forum on current problems of The New York Herald Tribune on Sept. 22 and 23 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday. Governor Landon will send his message from Topeka.

Observers of European politics attach more than ordinary importance to the recent visit of King Christian of Denmark to South Jutland, where the Danish population welcomed him with acclaim. Taken in connection with the recent organization of the "Young Border Defense," the visit of the Danish ruler can mean only that Denmark is prepared to resist any encroachment upon her soil.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Julius Heldman, young Hollywood (Calif.) southpaw, today combined brilliance and accuracy to win the national junior tennis singles championship, defeating Joseph Hunt of Los Angeles in a spectacular upset, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1. Heldman's unexpected victory climaxed a week of play at the Culver Military Academy.
Harlem turned out in force last night as Mayor La Guardia and Park Commissioner Robert Moses formally opened the new Colonial Mark Swimming Pool, Bradhurst Avenue and 146th Street.

Overcoming the cautious tendency that had existed for several days, following the remarkable activity and strength in July, the stock market at the close of last week resumed its advance with a show of confidence. THE NEW YORK TIMES railway stock average reached a new high for the year, and the combined average of industrial and railway shares rose 2.38 points on the week, the widest gain since the week ended on July 18.

Max Schmeling is back in this country again, eager for the chance to make pugilistic history. The German fighter arrived from his native land yesterday aboard the airliner Hindenburg and will prepare himself for the task of meeting. James J. Braddock for the world's heavyweight championship.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The pistol matches shot alternately in New York and New Jersey by teams representing the Twenty-seventh Division, New York State National Guard; the Forty-fourth Division, New Jersey State National Guard; the Seventy-seventh Division Organized Reserves, and the Quartermaster Reserve team were fired at Camp Smith today by five-man teams.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A preliminary count of petitions by the Secretary of State indicated today that the Union party failed by about 46,000 signatures to qualify for recognition as a full-fledged political organization on the November Ohio ballot.

RESIDENTS of the model apartments that occupy the block centering at 504 Grand Street are rounding out the fifth year of a cooperative venture which challenges the oft-expressed theory that "slums are made by the people who live in them."

Edward Everett Hale 3d, an actor, late of the "Cyrano" company of Walter Hampden, and a grandson of the author of "The Man Without a Country," returned from Philadelphia yesterday to The Players, 16 Gramercy Park. He returned by train in one hour and fifty-nine minutes.

MADRID, Aug. 8. -- It is announced by the Interior Ministry that the past two nights' orders for complete darkness in Madrid and cessation of all traffic on the streets after 10 o'clock will be repeated tonight and for several nights to come.

WHILE many bulbs are not planted until late September or October, there are several which it is advisable to set out just as soon as they can be obtained. The Madonna lily, for example, does best if put into the soil in August.

With the possible exception of a convention of deaf mutes, nothing could appeal more to Mayor La Guardia's anti-noise crusaders than the usual major contract bridge tournament. The players insist that each card table be set up in an individual room. They lock doors, rigidly exclude kibitzers and never raise their voices above the whisper necessary to announce a bid.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8. -- For the third successive year, Frank Parker won the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today and gained permanent possession of the massive challenge cup.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- Casey Stengel is almost convinced tonight that the fourth game of a Brooklyn winning streak is a goal his Dodgers are incapable of attaining. Today for the seventh time this season they made the effort and failed, the Bees setting them back by 4 -- 2.

Dr. Townsend says retirement at 60, President Roosevelt says 65. But the average American citizen says, "Why retire? Why admit my age? I feel as young as if I were 50. What will I do if I cannot continue my usual routine and remain in my habitual groove?"

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- The more than 5,000,000 scientific specimens of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia will be increased with the collections from twenty expeditions and field trips now being sponsored by the academy, it was announced today by Charles M.B. Cadwalader, the managing director.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 8. -- M.J. Van Sweringen of Cleveland, the one-time news boy, who in 1929 shared a personal fortune of $128,685,577 with his bachelor brother, O.P. Van Sweringen, after coming into control of an empire of railroads, coal mines and street railways, was worth $3,067.85 when he died Dec. 12.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8. -Miss Gracyn Wheeler of Santa Monica, Calif., sixth ranking player of the country, won the invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.

During the past Winter we have discovered monuments which possess a more than special interest. They belong to two periods: the first centuries of the third millennium and the 200 years from 2100 to 1900 B.C.
POINT BARROW, Alaska, Aug. 8. -- Hungry Eskimos east of here are beginning to eat their sled dogs, Dr. Henry W. Greist, Presbyterian medical missionary, reported today.

Mr. GORDON GAMMACK, a reporter on The Des Moines Register, reports in it his sociological observations in the untutored East. The darkness of that region is even greater than we feared. A year ago Mr. GAMMACK "asked several "dozen persons where they thought "Iowa was."
ATHENS, Aug. 8.--Premier John Metaxas, military dictator of Greece, said today that "the whole Greek people must be disciplined."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8. -- The volume of sales during market week just closed scored a gain of 25 per cent over last year. The gain was due in part to the increasing interest of Eastern buyers in goods manufactured on the Pacific Coast.

Here, in pictures, with simple explanatory text, is shown a school day of first-grade boys and girls. The author is connected with a progressive school and the activities and photographs are authentic.

BOSTON, Aug. 8. -- Business conditions in New England continue favorable. There has been no letdown this Summer in manufacturing activity. Retail trade continues to run 10 to 15 per cent ahead of the volume a year ago.

BOSTON Aug. 8 (AP). -- Making his move from the rear, Paul A. Shaw's Gov. Sholtz rolled over the field like a tidal Wave to win a nose victory from J.W.Y. Martin's Dark Hope in the Beacon Hill Handicap, $5,000 added feature, before 25,000 at Suffolk Downs today.

AMERICAN listeners who do not find time to tune in the daytime network rebroadcasts from the Olympic Games need not miss all the show. The evening short-wave transmissions from Berlin are replete with interesting sidelights "auf Deutscher weise."

That the United States is destined to take undisputed leadership in the production of thoroughbred dogs is indicated by a comparison of registration figures of the American Kennel Club and those of the English governing body. While Great Britain has been the leader in the past and has been the greatest source of supply for the rest of the world, it is evident that she will have to take second place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Development of a new army airplane containing "new aeronautical engineering developments which cannot be described at this time" was announced by the War Department today in the award of a contract to the Curtiss Aeroplane and Motor Company of Buffalo, for the production of three of them for service tests.

IN the introduction to her compilation, "The Book of Humorous Verse" (now reissued by the Garden City Publishing Company, $1.69), Carolyn Wells says that only "a hope of immortality and a sense of humor distinguish man from the beasts of the field"; and, not to appear too dogmatic, she admits one possible exception -- the laughing hyena.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- One of the largest parties of the day here was the tea given after the races by Controller and Mrs. Morris S. Tremaine and their son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. James G. Tremaine, for George H. Bull, Racing Association president.

OTTAWA, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The most disastrous drought in the history of several agrarian provinces, the government reported today, has made deep inroads on Canadian crop prospects. A nation-wide survey of the effects of the July heat showed the outlook for Spring wheat in the Prairie Provinces declined 45 per cent, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported.

THE eighteenth century, in England, was the period of Correct Taste. They were quite sure that they knew, in those days, what Correct Taste was, and they tried, with general success, to "substitute the certainty of the Correct for the more doubtful True (or Good)."

BUCHAREST. -- Rumania is engaged in a national debate on the question of the direction of her foreign policies. In newspapers, drawing rooms, cafes and all places where people gather and exchange ideas one hears criticism, defense and appraisal.

FROM the time that Colonel M. Papadiamantopoulos of the Greek Army fired off his pistol in the village of Marathon on an April day in 1896 the Olympic marathon races have been producing quaint winners and odd tales.

TOPEKA, Aug. 8. -- Governor Landon will make six short trips in Ohio and two in Pennsylvania on his first Eastern campaign trip, in addition to the twenty-one platform appearances west of the Mississippi announced yesterday, he disclosed today in making public his detailed schedule from Chicago to Chautauqua Lake.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Dr. J.H.J. Upham, president-elect of the American Medical Association, recommended today a "back to the farm" movement for young doctors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The market week just ended was the most successful since 1929 in point of dollar sales, while buyer attendance reported by some of the firms set all-time records. Buying was particularly active in women's ready-to-wear and domestics, in gift and novelty items, where the number of visitors was running 33 per cent or more ahead of last year, and in women's millinery.

TOPEKA, Aug. 7. -- This week's Kansas primary results are furnishing to political commentators considerable material for speculation about the things the voters of this section may do when they get around to casting their November ballots.

ACCORDING to figures just released by the United States Department of Agriculture, New York leads all other States in the planting of forest-tree seedlings, supplied under the Federal- State cooperative agreement, with a total of more than ten million.

The civil war in Spain has resulted in the destruction of virtually all of the church art in the vicinity of Barcelona, according to reports received here yesterday from Professor Walter W.S. Cook, chairman of the New York University Graduate Department of Fine Arts.

THE chief event of the Summer dance season will take place this week when the annual Bennington Festival comes to a climax with four performances in the State Armory here by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their concert group, supplemented by thirty-five members of a workshop group from the Bennington School of the Dance at Bennington College.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The journey to Scotland for the Twelfth, when the grouse shooting starts, is the sign for tweeds and shooting equipment to appear in West End shops, and all next week special night trains will be run to Scotland. This season promises to be one of the best in recent years and the plans of King Edward VIII include a brief visit to Balmoral in September.

TO write a story which creates passionate curiosity and, from page to page, suspends our breath in expectation of what is coming next, while, at the same time, gradually revealing a character true to human nature -- this is what Claude Aveline accomplishes in "Le Prisonnier" (Emile-Paul, 298 pp., 15 francs).

BEGIN AGAIN" is topflight light fiction, not of the exciting, dashing variety, but belonging to the well-bred, humorous and beguiling school. It is amusing and lighthearted enough for reading in the hottest dogdays, but it is also intelligent and well written.

WINNIPEG, Man., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Freddie Haas of New Orleans, 20-year-old star, was entirely too good around the greens for 22-year-old Bobby Reith of Winnipeg today and scored a smashing 8 and 7 victory to win the Canadian amateur golf championship.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- Traveling incognito as the Duke of Lancaster, King Edward today flew to Calais and boarded the Orient Express en route to Sibenik, Yugoslavia. There he will embark in Lady Yule's yacht Nahlin, which he has chartered for a cruise of the Eastern Mediterranean.

NOTHING in either George Orwell's "Down and Out in Paris and London" or "Burmese Days" could have led one to anticipate so big a jump in quality as is represented by "A Clergyman's Daughter." "Burmese Days," though too obviously bitter and too savagely prejudiced to be classed as first-rate fiction, was a well-integrated novel.

Music is playing an important role at the Great Lakes Exposition in Cleveland, where almost nightly the Great Lakes Orchestra offers symphonic programs in the huge Sherwin-Williams shell near the heart of the city. Under evening skies, with Lake Erie as a background, the shell is illuminated in various colors, which are changed to suit the mood of the music.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Fourteen new courses will be added to the undergraduate curriculum at Princeton University next year and the upper class program of the Politics Department will be completely revised, it was announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university.

THE Nassau Philharmonic Orchestra, directed by G. Porter Smith, will be presented by Fortune Gallo, Monday night, Aug. 17, at the Jones Beach Stadium, in a concert of symphonic music, with Albert Spalding, violinist, as soloist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- A steam engine run by the sun will be demonstrated by Dr. C.G. Abbot, noted scientist and secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, to the third World Power Conference during the week of Sept. 7, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The belief that "political generals" will cripple Soviet Russia's huge army in "the next war" was expressed by former General Nicholas N. Golovine, who was a Czarist officer, in an article appearing in The Infantry Journal.

PARIS, Aug. 8. -- Mainbocher shows the season's largest and most varied collection. He launches a tailored version of the Louis. XV flaring coat in two- thirds length. Buyers all fell upon one ensemble having this coat in wine red wool over a black broadcloth frock.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Witnesses differed today regarding the extent of foggy weather prevailing when eight men were killed near here Wednesday night in the crash of a Chicago and Southern luxury airliner.

HUNGARY on Aug. 23 will unveil on Liberty Plaza, before the American Ministry, in Budapest, a statue of Harry Hill Bandholtz as a tribute to a man whose efforts to see fair play were of signal benefit to Hungary after the World War.

Murray Baron, general manager of the joint board of the Suitcase, Bag and Portfolio Makers Union, was named yesterday afternoon as the candidate of the Socialist party for President of the Board of Aldermen at the city convention held at party headquarters, 21 East Seventeenth Street.

CONNERSVILLE, Ind., Aug. 8. -- Colonel Frank Knox, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, told "what his party has to offer" tonight by outlining a program he said would "unleash recovery" and return "millions of unemployed to honest work."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Ten hits, two of them home runs by Babe Herman, did not bother old Jess Haines today as he punched across three tallies himself in a seventeen-hit Cardinal splurge that beat the Reds, 11 -- 4.

When those who control so-called private business try to stop the extension of public business, they sometimes try to make it appear that private business is the normal and reasonable way of doing the world's work, whereas public business is something new, unknown, fearful and dangerous.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- In the historic Columbia Club, stronghold of Indiana Republicanism since the days of President Harrison, Colonel Knox made a luncheon talk today en route from Chicago to Connersville.

A BRAVE new world lies at the feet of the gramophonic explorer, but one that is bewildering indeed; its extent and fertility can be surmised only vaguely. * * * The contemporary sphere of recorded music is almost as innocent of accurate maps and guide books as the terrestrial globe of Columbus.

To the accompaniment of the heaviest Saturday trading since July 11, the stock market extended the strong advance of Friday and closed at the best levels of the week. Steel, motor, railway, copper and electrical equipment issues were leaders.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 8. -- Following the silencing of the Algeciras fortifications, which are believed to have been wiped out in yesterday's naval bombardment, Spanish Loyalist forces in Malaga intend to make a week-end attack on Algeciras and La Linea.

In a study of the nation's traffic problem, Fortune magazine declares that half of the 3,000,000-mile highway system on which the United States has spent $15,000,000,000 since the turn of the century is "unfit for modern motor traffic." The article also estimates that only a fraction of 1 per cent of United States main roads begins to approach the fundamental requirement of "automatically correcting the driver's mistakes."

A MOVEMENT is afoot among American engineers engaged in television experimental work to advocate greater detail for image broadcasts on the ultra-short waves. This would mean the use of wider channels and transmitters capable of sending out pictures on a broader band than are now generally used.
BERLIN, Aug. 8 (AP). -- With sixteen nations in addition to Hawaii registered as charter members, the first World's International Baseball Federation was completed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The economic well-being of the nation would be menaced by a return to "pre-depression conditions" in the iron and steel industry, the Council for Industrial Progress asserted today in announcing its conclusions from a study just completed.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- There was one of the best finishes of the large sloops this season in the championship regatta today of the American Yacht Club. After covering thirteen and one-half miles from Scotch Caps to Captain Island and over to Oak Neck, the 50-footers and 12-meters came on together in a group despite a sagging easterly breeze.

Buying of copper abroad was reported to be in good volume yesterday, with the price equivalent to 9.60 to 9.625 cents a pound, c.i.f. European base ports. On Friday it was 9.475 to 9.55 cents a pound. The domestic price was unchanged at 9.75 cents a pound.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- America's defeat by the Netherlands in water polo today by 3 to 2 means almost certainly its elimination in the first round of the Olympic meet, in which sixteen nations are entered.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 7. -- The victory of Norman R. Hamilton over Representative Colgate W. Darden on Tuesday in the Congressional primary held in the Norfolk-Portsmouth-Suffolk District was a victory for a newspaper publisher who is 100 per cent for the New Deal and 100 per cent antagonistic to Senator Harry F. Byrd and the Democratic "organization."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The White Sox slipped up to within half a game of Cleveland in second place in the American League today by defeating the Indians, 9 -- 7.
BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The Olympic swimming tournament opened today with a general slaughter of Los Angeles records and some near world record performances.

Only half of the adult population is able to read with ease, Miss Miriam Tompkins of the Columbia University School of Library Service declared yesterday. She reported the results of a nation-wide survey of literacy and the reading habits of the American public, conducted by Columbia, the University of Chicago and the American Library Association.

Adios, until recently the universally used Spanish word for good-bye, means literally to God; stemming from a more religious day, it is a contraction of I commend you to God. The word is now in disfavor. The reason for its unpopularity was explained last week in one of the few uncensored dispatches that have come from that section of rebellion-torn Spain which is controlled by the government.

MADONNA lilies have contributed their loveliness to the flower parade of this season, and now it is time to think of planting more of them for next year. The white Madonna, or Annunciation, lily (Lilium candidum) is one of the most satisfactory of all the lilies to grow in the average garden.

Forest fires followed by floods, dust and erosion destroy more wealth in a year than all the perils of the sea, and yet inventors concentrate mainly on safety on the sea: Berquists with the Norway light, and Sarnoff by radio. There is Jagger of Hawaii with his seismograph for tidal waves, and the Queen Mary, with photo-electric cells, senses a ship or an iceberg ahead.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 8. -- A widening of development and exploration is reported in the Northern Ontario gold fields. This activity draws an impetus from the steady returns each month by the older producers and by certain among the newer mines.

ARCHITECTURE, painting, sculpture, drawing and en-engraving, poster and cartoon art, the theatre, the motion picture and handicrafts -- these are the topics discussed in this survey of artistic accomplishment in Soviet Russia. She reported the results of a nation-wide survey of literacy and the reading habits of the American public, conducted by Columbia, the University of Chicago and the American Library Association.

The word is now in disfavor. FORTY years ago -- forty years, a fourth of the time during which the American Constitution has been operating -- Major William McKinley and a young unknown Nebraskan, William Jennings Bryan, rather scornfully dubbed by his opponents as "the boy orator of the Platte," were running for President of the United States.

Trading in bonds quieted down yesterday to the pace of a typical week-end session, following the spirited advance on Friday. Prices, however, held steady to firm with good buying carrying many of the secondary corporation issues to higher levels.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- Golf matches and excursions to various peaks of the vicinity comprise the principal events of the week in the White Mountains. Chief among the links activities will be the sixteenth annual tournament at Crawford Notch for the Henry J. Wright Trophy, starting tomorrow.

While the concerted action taken by groups of retail druggists cooperating with manufacturers, under the terms of the New York State Fair-Trade Law, has been responsible for a sharp reduction in predatory price-cutting on drug and toilet preparations here, the enactment of similar lairs has failed to bring about stabilization in several of the other States, distributors here agreed yesterday.

The Italian liner Rex sailed yesterday for Mediterranean ports from the foot of West Eighteenth Street with 1,500 passengers half an hour late. The time was lost through the strong flood tide that forced Captain Francesco Tarabotto, the master, to move his ship 200 feet astern toward the pierhead and bring her back twice before he could have enough sea room to get out into the river without damaging his vessel.

CAPE TOWN, Union of South Africa. -- The government proposes to rush a Noxious Weeds Bill through Parliament this session with a view to making one more effort at getting rid of the khaki bush, or Mexican marigold, the thistle, and a few other unwelcome guests.
DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 8 (AP). -- Governor Olson tonight authorized mobilization of the Duluth National Guard for eventualities growing out of a rampant forest fire in the Markham-Palo district.

Stimulated by the widespread interest of retailers in special market week events, wholesale buying reached the highest level since 1929 in some of the leading trading centers of the country last week. All lines of merchandise for Fall and Winter were in strong demand as buyers thronged the markets in Chicago, Kansas City, St. Louis, San Francisco and other sections.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Tonight at the Maidstone Club a dinner for fifty was given by several officers and committee members of Guild Hall for Leighton Rollins of Boston, Mr. and Mrs. J.W. Austin. Mrs. John Pinkney Wemple and William Raymond and 32 student at the studio of acting here.

OUT at Roosevelt Field, where everything that is in the interest of flying gets consideration, they have been doing a little safety figuring of late, based on the low rates of insurance on flying which prevail in the airsurance plan of the United States Aircraft Insurance group and similar policies of the Aero Insurance Underwriters.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The week-end movement of New York State guardsmen receiving Summer training in the Camp Smith and Pine Camp areas, involving 6,500 men, was under way today. Most of the men were transported by train instead of motor trucks because of the need for trucks for the conveyance of artillery units to and from Pine Camp.

SEATTLE, Aug. 8. -- A spirit of "cooperation" manifested by Governor Landon's announcement that he will attend a conference of Governors of some of the drought States to be called by President Roosevelt was praised today by the Republican chairman, John D.M. Hamilton, who drew a comparison with President Roosevelt's actions in the latter days of the Hoover administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Some of the complexities of the 1936 Revenue Act, relating principally to the taxation of corporate undistributed earnings, were simplified by the issuance today by the Treasury of a set of regulations covering points which, in advance of the actual filing of returns at the end of the year, officials believed might cause misunderstanding.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Building activity in the United States in June was the greatest for any month in seven years, the Federal Home Loan Bank board reported today.

IN Bali, a happy people creates an art which is one with religion, in an everyday vitality of growth and abundant life. In Cambodia, the dead ruins of Angkor Wat, in a harmonious perfection from which the very suggestion of life has vanished, point to the whole cycle of an art's evolution and mortality.

THE speed of the modern plane already makes it possible to extend the limits of a short vacation to include the far places of the world. Bound for Rio de Janeiro in the shadow of Sugar Loaf Mountain, a new type of cruise will start a week from today from the Dinner Key base of Pan American Airways at Miami.

Just as many New Yorkers were beginning to think that the city's noise abatement drive had itself begun to abate, Mayor La Guardia put new life into it last week. He reminded Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine that the drive was not intended as a "nine-day wonder," but as a permanent program, and as such must be continued as "part of the daily routine work of every man in the Police Department."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- The Newport Hospital and ten other institutions are possible beneficiaries under the will of Edward Colling Knight Jr. of Philadelphia and Middletown, R.I., which was filed for probate today in Middletown. It was dated May 1, 1936.

ANNOUNCEMENT by the Union Pacific Railroad of plans for construction of the nation's first steam turbine locomotive heralds the entry of one more contestant in the increasingly spirited race for American rail leadership. Already the century-long supremacy of the standard steam locomotive is being challenged on many fronts.

THIS novel might suitably enough have been called "Journey's End" had not Mr. Sherriff already used the title for his much applauded play; but if the title is apt for both, it is very nearly all they have in common. "Greengates" is leagues removed from war and youth; it concerns an elderly couple of blameless and prosaic habits, and how they solved the only important problem that ever came their way.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Led by Firenze Clifton's Beau, winner of the hunter title, the stable belonging to Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., easily dominated the eighth annual horse show staged by the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club today.

THE masterly craft of cutting diamonds has changed scarcely at all since the fifteenth century, when that precious gem began to be used for personal adornment in Europe. The simple tools which are needed today are very like those which the great Louis de Requem worked with in 1475.

RADIO drama, which had its start among the Broadway playwrights, seems to be drifting more and more toward Hollywood. Several of the shows which were staged in New York in order to be close to the actors have now gone West and are cast near the film lots from which the screen stars are beckoned to go on the air.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6. -- On this coast a great deal is expected of the recently enacted Ship Subsidy Bill. Generally unnoticed at the time of passage in the closing days of the Congressional session, the measure is now hailed as likely to start something in the nature of a shipbuilding boom in Western shipyards.

THE King and people of Britain are today welded into the solidarity of a totalitarian State. Sir Arnold Wilson declares the objective. "Our first business," he says, "is to insure peace," and it is with this unfinished business that his book deals.

Among innumerable foolish projects which the government has wasted money on during the Roosevelt administration there is none quite so bad as the Maine scheme to harness the tides to produce power. The army engineers told the President that Quoddy is a monstrosity.

MOSCOW, Aug. 8. -- The Soviet press, which had been filled with accounts of demonstrations by Soviet workers for the Spanish Government and with accounts of these workers' contributions for Madrid's cause, has suddenly dropped the subject entirely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Industrial employes and other wage earners now have organized 1,600 cooperative thrift and loan associations under Federal charters, as authorized by an act of Congress in June, 1934. Over 150 of them are in the State of New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The upward trend of business activity shows no general slackening, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Carrying out a mission personally imposed on him by Representative Zioncheck, Kenneth Romney, sergeant-at-arms of the House, set about today to "unscramble" the business affairs of the Representative.

PROFESSOR SISSON has not recovered those lost plays of Shakespeare's age, for they have long been irrecoverable, but he has an astonishing amount of information to give us about them. They are known now only because they occasioned lawsuits.

DALLAS, Aug. 8. -- A continued increase in the volume of both wholesale and retail buying, a steady upturn in building operations and gradual improvement in other lines of business marked this week's activities in the Eleventh Federal Reserve District.

IF indications mean anything in this business, the season of 1936-37 will go down through history as the year of Maxwell Anderson repertory. Not content with two plays scheduled for the Winter, he has now finished a third, and last week, after a few days' brooding over the garden, he was beginning to eye his desk again.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Replying to the Republican National Committee's criticism of the WPA motion picture program, Deputy Aubrey Williams, WPA Administrator, said today that the committee would seek to deny to a responsible agency of government "the right to tell its story through the same medium which Presidents Coolidge and Hoover used to tell the stories of the Departments of Commerce, State, Postoffice, Treasury, Agriculture, Interior, Labor, War and Navy."

EVEN in Colonial times antique grandfather clocks were never very plentiful. Now, because of their growing scarcity, they are much sought for and the finest examples are sequestered in museums and large private collections.

THIS is the season for calling on urban neighbors. From remote points beyond Yonkers come thousands to take a Summer's look at the most agile chameleon of them all, New York. They come by bus, by train, by boat, singly and in gigantic excursions.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.--This week's outstanding musical event in the Berkshires will be the third annual symphonic festival on Thursday, Saturday and next Sunday Mrs. Margaret Emerson's estate, Holmwood, at Lenox. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Serge Koussevitzky, will play on Thursday and Sunday evenings and on Saturday afternoon.

PASADENA, which aspires to the distinction of being the great center of learning on the Pacific Coast, what with the California Institute of Technology, the Mount Wilson Solar Observatory and the Huntington Library and Art Gallery in its environs, is the latest battleground for the oft-disputed question of how much respect must still be shown to the venerable Three R's in modern education.
SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 8. -- General Francisco Franco has just arrived here by plane from Morocco to direct from this spot a final concerted Rebel drive on Madrid from the west, north and south.

GUADARRAMA, GOVERNMENT HEADQUARTERS, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Spain's bitterest civil war, with brother against brother, is producing an endless list of incidents of heroism, sorrow and sacrifice, on the shell-scarred battlefields in this mountain war zone, where thousands of young Spaniards are giving their lives for a political cause.

UNDER the somewhat flexible title "Manhattan Rivieras" Contemporary Arts has launched an August exhibition of paintings by members of the sponsored group and guest artists. As might be anticipated from the title, the artists have been preoccupied with the problem of depicting some relief spots and escapes from the city swelter; and they have assembled an attractive group of canvases.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, the swimmer whose drinking and parties cost her a chance to defend the Olympic 100-meter back-stroke championship, ran afoul of officialdom again today under mysterious circumstances.

MANILA, -- The first two bills passed by the Philippine Assembly and signed by President Manuel Quezon are carrying on the idea of social reform and amelioration of suffering which has been given impetus in the Philippines within the last three years.

TO test airplane tires scientifically for proper design, weight and inflation, engineers at Wright Field, Dayton, have built a vehicle of original design. Loaded with lead bars of approximately the same weight, plus its unloaded weight, as the airplane on which figures are sought, the wagon is drawn over all kinds of terrain.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- Germany is rather a breath-taking experience for her visitors this Summer. They are overwhelmed by the magnificence of the Olympic carnival and the spectacle of an entire nation drilled to show its guests a good time.

William Randolph Hearst, publisher, sailed yesterday for Italy on the Rex of the Italian Line, accompanied by his son George. There were sixteen in the party.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP). -- It took Billy Herman's third double and fourth hit today to give the Cubs a surprise 3-to-2 victory over the Pirates, but for more than two hours it looked as if he were doubling in vain.

THE present-day English novel (when it goes far enough), like the present-day House of Commons, seems to be afflicted with the jitters. "Miracle in the Drawing Room" is a minor variation on the theme being generally sounded through serious English fiction today, but it is as nervous and perturbed as the best of it, and often a good deal more.
BERLIN, Aug. 8 (AP). -- This tremendous popularity is beginning to grate on Jesse Owens's nerves.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 8. -- Rumors of an offer by Germany to Czechoslovakia in order to hasten the conclusion of a pact similar to the treaty of friendship and non-aggression already existing between Germany and Poland are discussed openly in a statement issued by the Czechoslovak press department.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 8. -- Two Spanish Government airplanes flew over Burgos yesterday, but did not bomb the city. The flight was taken as a warning, however, and in the evening an air-raid drill was organized. All traffic was stopped, lights were extinguished and the people took to shelter for a half hour.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The Boerse recovered slightly today from the slump of the preceding sessions this week. The firm tendency resulted from a small volume of fresh buying and from strength shown by exchanges in other countries. A more optimistic view of the foreign situation also accounted for the modest recovery.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 8. -- Mrs. Allen Gray Dunnington received today an uncontested divorce from Walter Grey Dunnington of New York on the ground of cruelty. They were married in Orange, Va., on June 25, 1925. Property rights and the custody of two children were settled in an agreement.

The Darby Petroleum Corporation shows a net profit for the six months ended on June 30 of $263,749, after allowances for taxes, interest, depletion, depreciation, undeveloped leaseholds surrendered, abandoned wells, dry borings and other charges.
