Sales of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States last month totaled 163,459 units, a new record for a July, it was announced yesterday. This compares with sales of 108,645 units in July, 1935, and 189,756 in June, 1936. In the first seven months of this year the sales totaled 1,127,910 units, compared with 757,480 in the corresponding time last year, a rise of 49 per cent.

The campaign fund of the Republican National Committee is $1,200 richer and the Orange County Republican Committee is $500 ahead because James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany and honorary chairman of the Democratic National Committee, made his famous offer to bet $20,000, at odds of 2 to 1, that President Roosevelt would be re-elected.

Three United States Senators, Royal S. Copeland of New York, Warren R. Austin of Vermont and Daniel O. Hastings of Delaware, sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rex bound for Palestine and accompanied by their wives.

GLASGOW, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press). -- The nine-month Scottish soccer football campaign opened today with all thirty-eight clubs seeing action. Interest centered mainly around Celtic, the champion, and the cup-holding Glasgow Rangers. Playing at home, Celtic downed St. Johnstone, 3 -- 2, and Dundee held the Rangers to a scoreless draw at Don's Park.
A great stimulus to the profession of legally avoiding taxes has been given, perhaps unintentionally, by the 1936 Tax Law.
KIEL, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Germany won two out of the four yachting class races today in the fifth day of Olympic sailing, fortifying her position in total points scored for the gold medals.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Golf matches are attracting sports lovers summering in Vermont, with unusual opportunities for match play during this month. The tri-State golf championship, in which the twelve best golfers from Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine will compete, is to be held Wednesday at the Rutland Country Club.

Eight men were arrested last night in a raid on the opening of the new Queens Kennel Club dog race track at Sunrise Highway and Cross Bay Boulevard, Howard Beach, Queens. The raid followed Mayor La Guardia's insistent orders to the police to prevent dog-race gambling in New York City.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- The French efforts to obtain an international neutrality agreement entered a new phase today. The Quai d'Orsay, encouraged by support from London, has begun negotiations with a number of European powers.
ROME, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Santa Claus has dropped United States bonus bonds at the door of 20,000 ItaloAmerican World War veterans.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 9. -- This colorful city of the conquistadores, the headquarters of the southern army, was virtually emptied of regular troops today because all available men had been rushed to the front for what appears to be an important drive for Madrid.

The drought which now burns man and beast in the Great Plains States and the Prairie Provinces of Canada has already brought irretrievable disaster to the diminished wildfowl. A bulletin of the United States Biological Survey, issued July 30, says in part as follows:

Following what police described as a dispute over who should be served with a portion of roast beef in the Horn Hardart restaurant at 170 West Seventy-second Street, summonses for disorderly conduct, returnable in West Side Court today, were issued to three women last night at the West Fifty-eighth Street police station.

ROME, Aug. 9. -- The Italian protests against the death of three citizens in Spain, authoritative sources said tonight, will be kept apart from this nation's attitude toward neutrality in the Spanish civil war.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 9. -The Hollywood Golf Club of Deal, N.J., won the Arthur Lehman Memorial trophy today as its representatives turned in the lowest total of 241 to lead the twenty-two clubs in team competition at Quaker Ridge.

BURGOS, Northern Rebel Army Headquarters, Spain, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Hundreds of singing, shouting Spanish Rebel troops clambered onto trucks today for a dash to the Guadarrama Mountains and an attack on Madrid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Smithsonian Institution today received "birthday" greetings from President Roosevelt and Secretary Ickes, marking tomorrow the ninetieth anniversary of its creation.

A delegation representing the American Labor party, New York State affiliate of Labor's Nonpartisan League, left yesterday for Washington to attend the first national conference of the league, which has made the re-election of President Roosevelt its chief objective in the present campaign. Heading the New York delegation was Luigi Antonini, vice president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and State chairman of the Labor party.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- World-wide interest has spread so rapidly in the grain markets with strong bullish sentiment that it has carried prices up faster and to higher levels than seemed possible within so short a time. Recently most of the grain markets in the world were in a position where buying was limited to immediate requirements and advances of more than a cent or two a bushel a day were unusual.
BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- A roomful of weeping Japanese surrounded Kitei Son, young college student, who lay swathed in a blanket after his record-breaking victory in the Olympic marathon today.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The pilot of a chartered airplane, the crew and passengers of an East Boston ferry, and the driver of an Animal Rescue League ambulance were drafted today in an attempt to save the lives of two dogs, one of which died.

Fritz Lang, whose "Fury" caused some commotion at Metro by proving to be a box office success in defiance of the predictions of studio executives, has transferred his allegiance to the Walter Wanger unit of United Artists, according to a wire from Hollywood.
BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 9. -- Advances toward the Rebel city of Saragossa were reported today by several Loyalist commanders.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Officers and directors of the Catholic Daughters of America, in semi-annual conference at the Hotel Traymore here today, voted to fight vigorously against communism and atheism on a nation-wide scale.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 72.4 on Aug. 5, compared with 71.7 a fortnight before, 70.6 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- Even the sun came out for the climax of the 1936 Olympics today. Under a cloudless Summer sky, a record crowd gathered for the marathon, the most widely advertised Olympic event, and the relays -- always full of uncertainties and thrills.

A sharp percentage increase in the number and circulation of motion-picture, mystery, pulp, radio and romance magazines since the middle of 1929 to the end of last year is revealed in a "Trend Study of 158 'General' Magazines," released today by the magazine committee, headed by W.W. Tomlinson, of the Association of National Advertisers.

In the coming election citizens of New York City will vote not merely for a President and Congressmen but, among other things, on the proposed new city charter and on the question, submitted separately, whether proportional representation shall be adopted in the election of the council set up by that charter.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Younger members of the Summer colony, headed by Miss Sallie Mellon, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon, will act as ushers at the preview of the new motion picture, "Nine Days a Queen," which will take place next Thursday night at the Southampton Theatre for the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 9. -Steps in the process by which a confession was obtained today from Martin Moore, Negro hallboy, in the murder of Miss Helen Clevenger, were described by Deputy Sheriff Tom K. Brown, brother of the Sheriff, who revealed that Moore at first tried to fasten the crime upon L.D. Roddy, the Negro bellboy who had been held for a time as a witness.

The Governor's Commission on Unemployment submitted a report to Governor Lehman yesterday in which twenty-six of its thirty-one members recommended that work relief be not adopted as a permanent method of meeting the problem of large-scale unemployment. Major Allen Wardwell is chairman of the commission.
President Hoover and Franklin D. Roosevelt, as President-elect, held three conferences in the pre-inaugural period of 1932-33. War debts, foreign policy and the bank crisis were discussed.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- Nervousness over the international situation induced heavy selling of stocks here almost the whole of this week. As there were few buyers, quotations dropped heavily, with the result that the six days of trading obliterated the gains made in the last quarter of the year.

MADRID, Aug. 9. -- The first government data released on prisoners in Madrid today placed the number at more than 4,000. Eighteen hundred of these, including Generals Fanjul, Fernando Capaz and Villegas Montesinos and six colonels, are in the city's "model jail."

GENEVA, Aug. 9. -- Secretary of Labor Perkins arrived here tonight from Paris to visit the International Labor Office, which the United States joined in 1934 -- an action for which much personal credit is given here to Miss Perkins.

WITH THE LOYALIST ARMY NAVALPERAL, Spain, Aug. 9. -- An army of 1,5OO, including forty-five women, drove off a Rebel attack against this Guadarrama Mountain city today and accounted for 800 Fascist dead. [Navalperal is thirty-eight miles west and slightly north of Madrid on a direct line.]
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Indians won a double-header from the White Sox today. They took the opener, 9 to 1, then bunched hits in the second and third innings to annex the nightcap, 5 to 2.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Wendell W. Anderson gave a dinner in the Cave Grill tonight for Mr. and Mrs. R.E. Jordan, who arrived yesterday to visit them.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 9. -- A confession by a Negro hall boy, obtained after two New York detectives had been assigned to the case, today solved the killing of Miss Helen Clevenger last July 16 in her room at the Battery Park Hotel.

Mary Ellen Chase, author of "Silas Crockett," arrived here this week after a year in England, and went immediately to Blue Hill, Me., her birthplace, for a short holiday before resuming her classes in English literature at Smith College in September.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Monday, Aug. 10. -- A strong Middle Western team, headed by Louis J. Haddad of Chicago, carried off the team-of-four championship of the American Bridge League at the closing session of the league's Summer tournament here early today.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 9. -- Temperatures far above the 100-mark returned to four Midwestern States today after a brief respite, claiming two lives and setting new heat records.

OLD, WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 9. -- In a game that at times reached the brilliant speed of championship play, Greentree turned back Aurora, 9 to 7, at Bostwick Field today in the first test game among teams preparing for the national tournament starting Aug. 29.

PERSONS who read Gale Wilhelm's "No Letters for the Dead" (Random House, $2) will note immediately after finishing that they feel terrible. It will occur to them that no happiness, no security that they have is accompanied by any guarantee of permanence. Tomorrow the gutter, they will moodily reflect. Next day, the grave.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- The blare of trumpets rent the air at the Reich Sports Field Stadium this afternoon and 110,000 persons leaped to their feet in tense expectancy. All eyes were turned toward the cavernous mouth of the marathon tunnel awaiting the approach of the winner of the greatest Olympic championship of them all.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Dark Hazard, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Seward T. Potter of Glens Falls and ably shown by Bob Hoge of Cleveland, today won the three-gaited saddle stake and championship at the third and final session of the most successful renewal of the Sagamore horse show.

MONTREAL, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Montreal and Newark divided a double-header today as the Bears paid their final visit of the schedule. Newark edged out the Royals, 6 -- 5, in a loosely played first game before 5,000 fans, and then succumbed to a sixteen-hit attack by the Montrealers in the nightcap, 12 -- 0.
The purchase by Maurice Epstein of five buildings in Fourteenth and Thirty-fourth Streets for modernizing featured realty activity in the city over the week-end.

Julius B. Kahan purchased the two fifty-foot houses at 253-59 Park-side Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash over a mortgage of $109,000 and resold the buildings to Adrian Equities, Inc., Harry Radin, president, for investment. Goodman Mabel, attorneys, represented the buyer.

Of the Commerce Department's "Balance of International Payments" report for 1935, published in full last week, numerous separate items had been previously published. Only with this complete statement, however, is it possible to ascertain exactly how its quite unprecedented "visible balance of trade" was met by the United States.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- The total capitalization of 1,487 stock corporations formed in New York State in July was $22,020,046, the Division of Corporations of the Secretary of State's office reported today. This is $4,000,000 more than in the same month of 1935.

DETROIT, Aug. 9. -- Administration-inspired efforts to elevate Frank Murphy, on leave from his post as High Commissioner to the Philippines, to the Governorship of Michigan are said here to have grown into a formidable threat to remove from Washington one of the stanchest supporters of the philosophy of the New Deal, Senator James Couzens.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- The financial markets still are heavy and inactive. The usual decrease in the turnover during the Summer is accentuated this year by fears growing out of the nation's economical financial difficulties, and the international political situation.

DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Russell Van Atta hurled the Browns to a 4-3 victory over the Tigers today, and gave the Hornsby team a two-to-one edge in a three-game series. The teams split a doubleheader Saturday.

Norman Bel Geddes this morning jots down the second of his Autumn productions: Hope Barnett's play, "Lenin." This will be along in due time, after "Iron Men" by Francis Gallagher, and that, in turn, will follow the opening of Chicago's version of "Dead End."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 9. -The Florida Works Progress Administration has announced that "encouraging" results were obtained during the recent hurricane with apparatus developed at the University of Florida to "point out" storm centers.

With the arrival in the wholesale markets of another large contingent of buyers, manufacturers experienced an active demand last week for all types of apparel, accessories and other merchandise for Fall. Reorders received in the market indicated a wide acceptance of new merchandise offerings at preseason sales events.

Kitei Son, Japanese youngster, won the classic marathon title in the new Olympic record time of 2 hours 29 minutes 19.2 seconds as the track and field competition closed. Johnny Kelley was the only American to finish. Ellison Brown and Bill McMahon dropped out.

A year ago at the passing of AE we were saying our word of tribute to the memory of this "many-sided Irishman " -- the great poet and writer of prose, the painter, journalist and co-worker with Sir HORACE PLUNKETT for the cooperative commonwealth, adding that he "had a title to our remembrance.''

As an American seaman I was somewhat surprised to read the rather lengthy letter "With Our Flag at Sea" by R.L. M'All. To the uninformed the law relating to seamen recently enacted seems to be for the benefit of seamen. Such is not the case.

The Yankees' fire started late at the Stadium yesterday against the doleful Athletics, but it swung through four big innings and carried them to a twin triumph before a gathering of 50,685, an amazing turnout under the circumstances.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- Captain Rupert Savile was the second Briton killed in the Spanish civil war. The first was Chief Inspector Fernandez of the Ford automobile plant in Barcelona, who was shot in street fighting.

Speaking from London yesterday afternoon over the Columbia Broadcasting System in this country, the Rev. Dr. Frank N. D. Buchman, founder of the Oxford Group, described his movement as a "revolution of God-control, where God really guides you and your nation."
CERBERE, France, Aug. 9. -- Having obtained a temporary permit to cross the frontier yesterday evening, your correspondent went to Port Bou, the first Spanish town across the border.

More progress in social reconstruction would be made in one generation than has been made in the last 500 years if man could learn to apply spiritual laws to modern affairs, the Rev. Dr. William A. Weber of New Brunswick Theological Seminary said in the morning sermon yesterday at Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street.
CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The last formal review of the 1936 Camp Dix citizen's military training camp took place today before the largest crowd ever to visit the C.M.T.C. regiment.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Liquid Carbonic Corporation today reported consolidated net profits of $625,491 for the three months ended June 30, the third quarter of the company's fiscal year. This included profit of $66,574 on the sale of securities.

Kirsten Thorborg, Swedish contralto, has been engaged for next season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The signing of a contract between Edward Johnson, general manager of the Broadway house, and Miss Thorborg was confirmed yesterday by Edward Ziegler, assistant general manager, in a communication from Vineyard Haven, Mass., to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

For more than two years it has been evident that the apparent phenomenon of Germany's industrial recovery under HITLER has been due primarily to the Government's rearmament program and that this program has been financed by means of heavy borrowing, the extent of which is now concealed from the German people.

A 13-degree drop in the temperature from last Sunday shifted the interest of Mr. and Mrs. New York City and their children yesterday from the beach to the highways and byways of automobile travel. There was no need to escape the heat. There was every reason for taking advantage of the first cool Sunday since 'way back in June. It was an ideal day for a picnic.
TOPEKA, Aug. 9. -- That he may work with less interruption on the three speeches he will make in the East, Governor Landon has canceled two appointments for tomorrow.

Of more than 125 officials in charge of traffic regulation throughout the country seventy-six favor new laws to take unfit drivers from streets and highways, they said in replying to a questionnaire sent them by the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York, it was reported yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 9. -- More than 175 members and guests attended the weekly dinner dance at the Riverside Yacht Club last night.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Forty Cincinnati hits blasted the Cardinals from first place in the National League today and 27,500 spectators booed as the Reds took both ends of a double-header, 10 -- 2 and 12 -- 5. The Cubs took over the league leadership by two scant percentage points and set the stage for a hard three-game series opening here tomorrow.
A 26-year-old paroled convict was killed and two policemen were wounded about 3 o'clock yesterday morning following a pistol battle in St. James Park, the Bronx. A companion of the victim escaped.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- American Olympic officials spent a worrisome day today as a result of some adverse comment over the dropping of two Jewish sprinters from the 400-meter relay team, as well as the latest reverberations in the celebrated case involving Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett.
VIENNA, Aug. 9. -- King Edward VIII of Britain, en route with a party of friends for a cruise in the Adriatic and Eastern Mediterranean aboard the yacht Nahlin, arrived at Ljubljana tonight.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9. -- Nationwide production of steel last week was estimated here at 72 per cent of capacity and the estimate for the preceding week was revised from 73 to 72 per cent.

THE German winner of the Olympic heavyweight weight-lifting event at Berlin received added recognition from local authorities by being appointed a State Tax Collector. With a fellow like that around, it begins to look very bad for delinquent taxpayers. When he knocks on the door and says "Pay, or else!", the thing to do is pay up and live.

GENEVA, Aug. 9. -- The World Jewish Congress, opening its business session here today, heard a proposal for a permanent organization for the Jewish people of the world. Attached to the organization would be two central bureaus, one for migration and the other for Jewish relief. A supplementary proposal was for the establishment of a central Jewish People's Fund to be administered by the relief bureau.

The unparalleled peacetime concentration of eighteen destroyers, now lying in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, heralds a two weeks' training period at sea for more than 1,500 reservists from the Eastern States and Middle West. They are to leave port about Aug. 21 for a cruise to San Juan, Puerto Rico, and Guantanama Bay, Cuba.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The annual sales for the blind will open here on Tuesday morning at the Casino and continue until the end of the week. On Friday and Saturday they will be held at the Grand Union Hotel. The benefits will end with an illustrated lecture on Sunday to aid The Seeing Eye.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9. -- Colonel Bill Terry solved a vexing problem today that had been tormenting him since last April.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that traffic over the platforms of the Union Inland Freight Station 1, Manhattan's first inland station, had increased 763 per cent since October, 1932. The station occupies the basement and first floor of the Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Forty-seven yachts sailed here today on the first squadron of the American Yacht Club cruise, from Rye, N.Y., a distance of twentyseven and one-half miles, and Van S. Merle-Smith's twelve-meter sloop Seven Seas spreadeagled the fleet.

SEATTLE, Aug. 9. -- After covering eight States in the first week of his airplane tour through the West, John D.M. Hamilton, Republican chairman, declared today that political conditions in the mountain States so far visited indicated that "the prairie fire for Governor Alf M. Landon is spreading into the timber line."

The award of scholarships for post-graduate study of three women chemistry students was announced yesterday by the Women's Service Committee of the American Chemical Society of which Lois W. Woodford of Stamford, Conn., is chairman.

MADRID, Aug. 9 (Passed by the Censor). -- In a radio broadcast from Premier Jose Giral's office in the Marine Ministry, Indalecio Prieto, Socialist leader, who has been assisting unofficially in the government's efforts to overwhelm the Rebels, said today:

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The German ban on foreigners' special accounts and private barter in trade with the United States has drawn unfavorable comment here as denoting a new step in an economic war. The Thuringian State Bank complains that the American countervailing duties reduce Germany's total export of toys by 25 per cent.

Hymn-singing Christianity is not enough, Dr. Samuel Henry Prince of the Department of Social Science, King's University, Halifax, N.S., said yesterday in the morning sermon at St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, 122 West Sixty-ninth Street.

Complete uniformity of opinion within the church is not an essential to the fulfillment of the church's function, the Right Rev. Irving Peake Johnson, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Colorado, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, the largest church of its denomination in the world and for many years the pastorate of the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, must not be permitted to fail through lack of interest, the Rev. Dr. Edward D. Staples, associate minister, declared yesterday morning in his sermon.

Facing eviction from his home in Sunnyside, Queens, J. Charles Laue, secretary of the City Department of Taxes and Assessments, held a wake yesterday afternoon and evening. More than 200 friends and neighbors visited the home at 39-61 Forty-eighth street, where the Laue family have lived for the past nine years.

The night was dark, the tide rips were swirling, and a half moon hung over the warehouses along the East River when the Police Marine Division received a report a little after Saturday midnight that a boat had stranded on rocks in Little Hell Gate.

The problems of the world will never be solved until men realize the one practical philosophy of life is that of Christian discipline, the Rev. E.N. Porter Goff, vicar of Immanuel Church, London, England, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.
KIEL, Germany, Aug. 9. -- Germany clinched her first Olympic yachting gold medal by triumphing in the Star Class, and took the lead in the Eight-meter Class by winning today's race.

A white splotch marred the ivy-trimmed frame of Arthur Fortwongler's second-floor rear window at 122 East Thirty-eighth Street yesterday, It marked the spot where a bottle of milk of magnesia shattered Saturday night about 10:30 o'clock.

Dog racing, under the option system, which made an abortive start in Queens Saturday night, will seek the protection of a Supreme Court order prohibiting the police from interfering before it resumes. The Queens Kennel Club, Inc., started races Saturday night at a former auto speedway at Cross Bay Boulevard near Sunrise Highway with a distinguished group of police and public officials and several hundred other spectators present.
LONDON, Aug. 7. -- While the holidays are exerting a restraining influence on business in the security markets, they are maintaining a remarkably strong tone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Nearly $50,000,000 will be paid in cash when the first bond issue of the Home Owners Loan Corporation matures on Saturday, John H. Fahey, chairman of the Home Loan Bank Board, announced today.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Mrs. iatthew :Bolles of Seville Avenue said today that she intended to move from the fashionable neighborhood in which she has lived for two years, but not until after she has demonstrated to neighbors that she is entirely Within her rights in keeping a number of German Spitz dogs on'her property.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- The last Bank of France report dated July 31 shows a further increase of 110,000,000 francs in gold holdings. As in previous weeks it is felt here that this increase is due principally to gold sales by the British Exchange Equalization Fund.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- One of the largest of a number of large home luncheons given today was that at which Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren entertained at Champ Soleil.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Permanent drought conditions in large parts of the Great Plains States make imperative complete removal of the land there from crop cultivation and its use for light grazing until grass has had an opportunity to cover it completely, according to a land study made public today by the Resettlement Administration.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- With advance detachments of the 107th (old Seventh) Regiment of Manhattan and the 108th Infantry of Syracuse arriving at Camp Smith here last night preparations got under way for the two weeks of intensive training that will begin tomorrow, when both the New York City and the mid-State guardsmen will take up rifle practice.

CAMBRIDGE, Aug. 9. -- The average food chain in 1934 paid out 76 per cent of sales for the net cost of goods sold, incurred total operating expenses amounting to 23.4 per cent of sales, and earned a net profit from merchandising operations of 0.6 per cent of sales, according to a report issued by the Bureau of Business Research of the Harvard Business School.

Only eighty-five days are left to save your country. Are you going to save it? Are you a member of The Volunteers ? This force, organized by Colonel McCORMICK of Chicago as an army of national salvation, is growing wonderfully. Governor LANDON is an honorary member, though his approval seems curiously cold.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 9. -Tommy Goodwin rapidly is becoming one of the most logical candidates for national golf honors that the metropolitan district has to offer.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 9. -- Increased uneasiness is felt here over the position of twenty-six Americans stranded in Rebel Granada since July 18. A telegram received here tonight from Tangier, International Zone, Morocco, declared that a plane being sent there from England to rescue the foreigners in Granada had not arrived and that no word of its time of arrival had been received.

The centrality of God in temporal affairs, requiring prayer on knees rather than narrow ritual, was emphasized by the Rev. John S. Whale, president of Cheshunt College, Cambridge, England, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

During the greater part of last week, stock market and grain market hesitated. In each, the reason apparently was doubt as to how far the preceding rise had already "discounted" legitimate expectations -- in the one market, for great industrial activity for Autumn; in the other, for exceptional harvest shortage, especially of corn.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP). -The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, Michigan priest, told a sweltering crowd today that he would fight against endorsement "of any third party" by his National Union for Social Justice.

Susie, the Dalmatian mascot of Engine Company 20 at 243 Lafayette Street, was on the job yesterday morning, and as a result helped to save the company's headquarters from a roaring blaze that ruined the fourth floor of a paper warehouse next door and did $10,000 worth of damage.

A moratorium on preaching for one or two years is urged by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming in his annual statement as rector of Trinity Parish, made public yesterday. The statement introduces The Trinity Year Book, which requires 350 pages to report on the multifarious activities of the "Mother Church" at the head of Wall Street, together with its seven subsidiary chapels in the city.

BAYONNE, France, Aug. 9. -- Captain Rupert Savile, a British subject, was killed by a shell from the insurgent cruiser Almirante Cervera while he was cruising in his yacht Blue Shadow off the north coast of Spain.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -The pledges of governments are not being kept because the churches have failed to adapt themselves to service as a modern educational force. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, said here today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Seven years ago Ernest R. Swanson was a 6-foot-3-inch policeman, thumbing traffic on a downtown street corner; today he announced perfection of an "aerostereograph" -- expected to revolutionize map making.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 9. -- Argentina's newest cruiser, the Veinticinco de Mayo, of 6,800 tons, is speeding toward Spain to attempt to force the Spanish Government to recognize the old South American thesis that diplomats have the right to extend asylum to revolutionists.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Aug 9. -- Joe Louis shook Max Schmeling's hand today, and when he let go, nothing happened. The German heavyweight, who bounced his right off Louis's jaw times without number in their fight at the Yankee Stadium last June, paid a visit to the Brown Bomber's camp to watch the Detroit Negro go through his paces in preparation for his bout with Jack Sharkey a week from Tuesday night.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Discovery of a method to artificially produce theelin, one of the two female sex hormones, was announced today by the school of chemistry and physics of Pennsylvania State College and reported in the current issue of the Journal of the American Chemical Society.

MOSCOW, Aug. 9. -- The purpose of the projected flight of Sigismund Levanevsky, pilot, and Victor Levchenko, navigator, from California to Moscow was revealed here today as the blazing of a trail for an eventual commercial airline connecting the United States with the Soviet Union via the Arctic regions.

No less than $10,000,000,000 is the sum which the Federal Government is putting into Kentucky. Yet it would be well if Chairman HAMILTON scans all the details before crying out indignantly in behalf of the Republican National Committee.

Governor Lehman, who elevated Jonah J. Goldstein from the magistrate's court to the General Sessions bench to fill the unexpired term of the late Judge Rosalsky, has announced that both his vote and his hopes go with Judge Goldstein in the latter's Democratic primary battle with Tammany Leader Dooling's designee for the party nomination for the full term.

OCEAN CITY, Md., Aug. 9. -Angling history is being written at this busy little vacation resort, the Asbury Park of the Del-Mar-Va Peninsula. Before long Ocean City may rank in importance with such sport fishing Meccas as Montauk, Block Island, Bimini and Wedgeport.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 9. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh presented a model of his artificial heart to the Danish nation today. The gift was accepted by Albert Fischer, director of the Rockefeller Biological Institute here, where the model is installed in a small laboratory.

ROME, Aug. 7. -- The market for industrial stocks and the State's securities is stationary with an exceedingly limited volume of business being transacted, as always is the case at this time of the year. Nevertheless, quotations are more than 10 per cent higher than at this time a year ago and they have an upward tendency.

JOLIET, Ill., Aug. 9. -- Nathan Leopold, one of America's most notorious criminals, was engaged today in an argumeht with the Department of Justice over a parole system. He carried on his end of the debate from the Illinois penitentiary cell where he must spend the rest of his life for slaying Bobby Franks twelve years ago.

The two days' meeting of anti-Roosevelt Democrats at Detroit is significant but cannot be called formidable. It is not an open and organized bolt. No alternative party or candidate is suggested. The threat to the Roosevelt Administration is indefinite and half concealed.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The money market here has returned to a condition of pronounced ease. Signs of credit restriction which accompanied the earlier expansion in note circulation have entirely disappeared under the influence of the Bank of England's large gold purchases, and there is little doubt it is the intention of the authorities to maintain the present easy conditions.

Except for the English pound and the Scandinavians, all other European exchanges were lower last week. Heaviness in the French franc was ascribed to the acute financial conditions in France, while the civil war in Spain contributed to the unsettlement of the peseta and other units.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- A slight increase in mortality in the State for the first six months of this year as compared to figures of a year ago was announced today by Dr. J.V. Deporte, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health.

Civilizations which are built upon the worship of many gods have in them the seeds of disintegration, the Rev. Robert H. Dolliver said yesterday in his sermon at the John Street Methodist Episcopal Church, 44 John Street.

SEATTLE, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Silence tonight enveloped two noted Russian fliers, Sigismund Levanevsky and Victor Levchenko, forced down by murky weather at isolated Bella Bella on the British Columbia coast.

The cotton market was largely a "pre Bureau" affair last week. Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved in a range of about 30 points and, when trading ended before the issuance of the government report on Saturday, the quotations showed a net decline for the week of 5 to 16 points.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt left for Washington late tonight after his associates in the temporary White House offices here had manifested strong feeling over what they called an unfair statement made at Seatle by John D.M. Hamilton, Republican chairman.

BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- A bit of red fire ought to be touched off in Flatbush tonight to celebrate the Dodgers' sudden leap out of the National League cellar, a dismal spot they had occupied continuously for many weeks, although sharing it with the Phillies for the last two days.
BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- One of the world's fastest swimmers, Peter Fick of the United States, failed badly today in the Olympic 100-meter free style, the first swimming final of the 1936 games.
The airship Hindenburg sailed last night for Germany on her twelfth crossing of the North Atlantic this season.

BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The United States opened its drive for the Olympic basketball championship today by crushing Estonia, 52 to 28, in a second-round match. The Americans had drawn a bye in the first round.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- A crowd of 40,000 saw the Cubs swing back into the lead in the National League pennant fight today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Pirates, 9-2 and 10-1, while the Cards were losing two at St. Louis.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Tomorrow's program of events for the ninth day of competition in the eleventh Olympic Games (subtract five hours for New York daylight-saving time):

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The securities markets here this week seemed to remember that it was a diplomatic quarrel over the question of who should rule Spain that precipitated the Franco-Prussian War in 1870, for they regarded as serious the present international situation created by the peninsular struggle and sold stocks heavily.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Widespread progress in the competitive process of cutting down the field in the Eastern tennis championships was continued today on the Westchester Country Club's immaculate grass courts as the headliners either prolonged their winning ways or made triumphant debuts in the current tourney.

Although four sound and constructive influences are continuing to bring improvement in the automobile business, a fifth factor -- government expenditures to stimulate purchasing power -- is artificial and undesirable and should be terminated as soon as possible, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, declares in its pamphlet report to stockholders for the first half of this year.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The renewal by banks here of the 40,000,000 credit to France for a further three months aroused little interest in the City, although the operation helped to increase the weakness which again is apparent in the franc.

VALHALIA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Firmly convinced that they had been made martyrs to their cause by some kind of a political plot, about fifty members of the National Union for Social Justice from the Twenty-second Bronx Congressional District waited until early this morning for buses to get back home.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today there was "no immediate prospect" that the agency's $6,000,000 profit in the last year would lead to a reduction in its premium rates.

The Right Rev. and Right Hon. Arthur Foley Winnington-Ingram, Lord Bishop of London, strolled yesterday through the vaulted arches of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where he preached on a visit ten years ago when the cathedral was only partly completed.

BERLIN, Aug. l0 (AP). -- Charpentier and Lapebie of France were the winner and runner-up respectively today in an Olympic 100-kilometer bicycle road race marked by numerous spills and such confusion at the end that it was impossible to determine where the Americans finished.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Idaho votes tomorrow in a primary election climaxing one of the most bitterly contested State campaigns in years. National interest in the balloting, which involves only major party tickets, hinges largely upon three factors:

TANGIER, Aug. 10. -- The carrying out of the order to all Spanish warships to leave the internationalized harbor of Tangier and not put in here again has removed one especially unwelcome guest, the surveying vessel Tofino, aboard which the Spanish Communist party of Tangier, having disposed of all the officers, held its meetings in the security of international waters.

Disturbed by the extent of racketeering and other organized crime and by the "appalling" number of business men giving false or evasive testimony in fear of reprisals, the special New York County grand jury that was dismissed last week has taken the initiative toward organization of a permanent nonpartisan committee of prominent citizens to combat these conditions.

The "best sport" in the activities of the Children's Aid Society during 1936 fidgeted yesterday afternoon at the office of the Lower West Side Children's Center, 219 Sullivan Street. Being interviewed was something new.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 11. -- The navy's estimates, now almost complete, will contain appropriations for the cost of laying down new battleships, following in the wake of Britain and the United States, the newspaper Asahi reports.
BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- Jesse Owens will turn professional if there is enough money in it, he announced today before leaving for Cologne, where he was scheduled to run tonight.

While breakfast-table commodities and hide and metal futures advanced in light dealings yesterday, other staples were lower on the commodity futures markets here, with all price changes small and transactions below average. On the cash markets, tin alone rose, while cotton, wheat, corn, rye, oats, butter, lard, rubber and wool tops declined.

Although the government's cotton crop estimate on Saturday was almost 500,000 bales greater than had been generally expected, the primary dry goods markets were not seriously disturbed by the figure yesterday. A possible shading of prices here and there and some delay in early Spring commitments were the only untoward results predicted by both sellers and buyers yesterday.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 10 (London Daily Mail dispatch). -- The urgent necessity for Spaniards to rally to the Rebel movement as the only thing that can save the country from Bolshevism was stressed by General Gonzalo Queipo de Llano in an interview at Fascist headquarters here.
MONTREAL, Aug. 10. -- Nearly 200 candidates for the ninety seats in the Quebec Legislative Assembly filed nomination papers today for the general elections Monday.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The British Government after a long wait has received from its Charge d'Affaires in Lisbon definite reasons from the Portuguese Government for its hesitancy in joining the other powers in a non-intervention policy regarding the Spanish civil war.

Jesse T. Straus, United States Ambassador to France, and Mrs. Straus; Albert Sarraut, former Premier of France; Frederick W. Mansfield, Mayor of Boston, and Mrs. Mansfield; Miss Edna Ferber, author; Grace Angelau, singer; Colonel A.J. Trujillo, Professor Etienne Dennery, Jean Laurent and Andre Touzet are among the passengers arriving tonight from Europe on the Ile de France of the French Line.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- It has become increasingly apparent in the last few days that, despite the French Government's determination to adhere to its self-proposed neutrality agreement, more and more Frenchmen and foreigners are using Paris as a center for sending aid to the republican Spanish forces.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, will confer today in Washington with President Roosevelt on the campaign, and upon his return to headquarters here the following day will intensify the drive to re-elect the President.

Exactly 163 hopeful acers, each with a single object in mind, fired away at a little tin cup 155 yards away, but at the conclusion of the day's activities not one had succeeded in sinking the pellet as the fifth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one tournament was launched at the Bayside Links in Queens yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 10. -- The news announcing the ruling out of Peru's 4-2 victory over Austria in Olympic soccer by the International Football Federation in Berlin caused indignant crowds to assemble here as well as in Port Callao today to protest the decision.

ASHEVILLE. N.C., Aug. 10. -- Handcuffed and closely guarded by deputy sheriffs, Martin Moore, 22-year-old Negro giant, who has confessed to the slaying of Miss Helen Clevenger, 18-year-old New York University co-ed, was led into General County Court here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Grain traders placed a decidedly bullish construction on the government report on corn, oats and barley, as the returns were well below recent private estimates. Corn showed a prospective yield of 133,000,000 bushels less than had been anticipated, while oats were 34,000,000 bushels short and barley 49,000,000 bushels.

What would the first of the marathon runners, PHEIDIPPIDES, have said if he were told that some day, 2,426 years later, to be precise, the 26 miles 385 yards from the battlefield to the Athens market place would be run fastest by an Asiatic?

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Hogs showed a stronger undertone here today with the general market steady to 15 cents a hundred pounds higher, although some of the best lights were up as much as 25 cents from last week's low closing level. The top of $11.30 was 5 cents above last week's and equaled the best mark of the season.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 10. -- The International Scientific Congress was opened in the Houses of Parliament this morning by its president, Dr. Albert Fischer, and the rector of Copenhagen University, Professor Axel Nielsen. Two hundred and fifty of the world's leaders in all branches of science met to discuss recent achievements.

BUFFALO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The Bisons continued their stampede toward first place tonight as they defeated the Newark Bears, 11 to 0, to score their third shutout in four starts. Their eleventh triumph in the last twelve games advanced them within two games of the topnotch Rochester Red Wings, who were idle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- President Roosevelt will make an important speech on foreign affairs Friday night at Chautauqua, N.Y. It will be given in the course of a flood control inspection trip arranged today soon after the President's return from Hyde Park.
DRESDEN, Germany, Aug. 10 (AP). -- A group of barnstorming American track and field stars won five events to take top honors in a meet here tonight.

The late LINCOLN STEFFENS was in his early newspaper days a keen reporter and later showed a talent for investigating municipal corruption. He became also something of a historian and a writer on public affairs. His autobiography, published a few years ago, combined in some of its later chapters a slight mingling of poetry with fact, particularly when he wrote of his contacts with THEODORE ROOSEVELT and other politicians.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, announced yesterday from her office at 45 Broadway that the board has authorized certification to the Secretary of the Treasury of a Federal grant of $1,958,376 to cover the Federal share of expenditures for old age assistance in New York State for the quarter ending Sept. 30.
VERA, Spain, Aug. 10. -- General Emilio Mola's big offensive against Madrid is now announced for Wednesday or Thursday. This will be the third time a definite "tomorrow" has been announced.

WEST POINT, Aug. 10. -- The "deadline" for receipts of applications from candidates for postmistress at West Point pased today, with the status of Miss Grace A. Harrington, the incumbent, still in doubt.

VATICAN CITY, Aug. 10. -- The Osservatore Romano, official organ of the Holy See, states that the Vatican has made an energetic protest to the Madrid Government against "sacrilegious acts and profanations" being committed in Spain.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The German reply to the French memorandum proposing a non-intervention policy by the big powers in the Spanish struggle will be communicated to the French Ambassador, Andre Francois-Poncet, within the next forty-eight hours or so, it was indicated today.

SEATTLE, Wash., Aug. 10. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, in an address here today, assailed the alleged use of public money for WPA propaganda in the movies, reiterating charges made last week by his committee.

In the face of a new bolt to Frank J. Prial, who will be a Candidate for the Democratic nomination for Aldermanic President against Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, James C. Sheridan, Queens Democratic chief, confidently predicted that Sheriff Brunner would be nominated in the primary election.

MOSCOW, Aug. 10. -- A million Muscovites today welcomed home the three aviators whose non-stop Arctic flight of nearly 6,000 miles won them the titles of "Heroes of the Soviet Union," with the fervor that the Soviet knows so well how to show for those it wishes to honor.

GENEVA, Tuesday, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The Polish delegation to the World Jewish Congress charged early today in a statement presented at the third day's session that Poland's 3,500,000 Jews were being terrorized and made paupers.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 10. -- Angered by the Spanish factions' endangering of shipping and neutral Gibraltar territory in their fighting, Great Britain virtually blockaded Gibraltar Harbor last night with the huge battleship Queen Elizabeth in the center of the entrance, constantly playing searchlights on near-by waters.

The Yankees yesterday were the victims of a strange parallel as old cast-offs came back to plague them. Jimmy De Shong, who was a Yankee until last Winter, muffled the refrain the Yankee bats have been singing of late, let his old pals down with eight hits and piloted the Senators to a 13-4 triumph that was more annoying than painful to the McCarthymen.

ROME, Aug. 10. -- Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano received the French Ambassador tonight and gave him the Italian reply to the new and more detailed proposal for non-interference in Spain submitted by the French Government last night.

We must conclude that a man whose legs are spread to jump in two directions is apt to jump in either direction. So that as we view Governor Landon's stance, it becomes necessary for us to fasten ourselves firmly to our own perch and thereby assure ourselves that we will be where we wish to be at the take-off.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP). -- No rain, no crops; no crops, no canned goods.

HAWTHORNE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The suspension of three members of the Volunteer Fire Department of this borough has been ordered by Public Safety Commissioner John C. Houman as the result of filing of affidavits charging them with setting fire to an unoccupied shack on Rock Road.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- Felix Piseck, secretary of the Central New York Milk Producers Federation, said tonight that the organization would call a "milk holiday" in nineteen counties of the State "without much notice" unless the State Board of Milk Control "acts immediately to increase the price paid producers to $3 a hundred.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The Bees came from behind with a three-run attack in the eighth today to hand the Phillies their eighth straight defeat, 9 -- 7.

SIBENIK, Yugoslavia, Aug. 10. -- King Edward, traveling as the Duke of Lancaster, cruised today among the beautiful islands off the Dalmatian coast as thousands of tourists, many of them Americans thronged the coastline for a glimpse of him.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern manager of the Landon campaign, will journey to Maine on Saturday to discuss with leaders there the plans for a final drive to win the State election for the Republicans.

Morris S. Blumstein, a lawyer, was arrested yesterday in his office at 277 Broadway, accused of attempting to obtain $1,000 from an unnamed lawyer under a pretext that he would suppress evidence against the second lawyer in the Queens County Bar Association's investigation of ambulance chasing.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Aug. 11. -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek departed from Kuling for Kiukiang this morning. It is believed that from there he will travel by plane to Canton, where he is expected to bring about a final settlement of the Kwangsi dispute.

Hulda Lashanska, soprano, appeared last night as guest artist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. The overcast skies resulted in an assemblage of small size. The orchestra was under the direction of Willem van Hoogstraten.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Sixteen leading players of the metropolitan district started competition today at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in the second annual invitation tennis tournament for junior girls, with the four seeded stars winning.

Attacking the Roosevelt "boondoggling" and spending policies in a State-wide radio broadcast from WEAF last night under the auspices of the Republican State Committee, F. Trubee Davison, former Assistant Secretary of War, said it would be "healthy" to have Governor Landon in the White House for the next four years.

SOUTH HADLEY FALLS, Mass., Aug. 10 (AP). -- "Buddy" Fraser, an airplane pilot of Brooklyn, is in Holyoke Hospital witch undetermined injuries suffered today when an airplane, which he was flying from Lamb's Grove here, struck a fence and plunged about twenty feet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Aug. 5 shows decreases for the week of $33,000,000 in total loans and investments, $73,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $169,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $68,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks.

The replies of five Presidential candidates to a questionnaire asking their views on "public education in the next four years" were read last night at a meeting sponsored by The Social Frontier, progressive teachers' magazine, in the Horace Mann auditorium of Teachers College.

THE world is full of miracles. There are things on earth that can be explained only after communion with the supernatural. Are you aware, for example, of the fact that William Shakespear is mentioned in the Book of Psalms? You aren't? Well, watch closely.

After exhausting two panels of talesmen in an unsuccessful effort to find twelve men who had never purchased lottery tickets, the Federal Government was able yesterday to proceed with the trial of Oscar Stevenson and his son, Lincoln, who are accused of being agents here for the sale of Irish Sweepstake tickets.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 10. -- Guests of the Mount Washington Hotel attended miniature horse races there tonight, followed by many suppers in the Cave Grill. A conference held there today by members of New England and New Hampshire automobile clubs was preceded by a stag supper in the Cave Grill and was attended by a group of White Mountain Hotel managers.

CAMP JERICHO, Vt., Aug. 10. -- More than 130 cavalry reserve officers from New York City, up-State New York and New Jersey are here for the first camp in the history of the Sixty-first Division when officers of all its units have gathered for training at the same time.

Two teams tied for first place in the Long Island Golf Association's one-day amateur-pro best-ball tournament over the Pomonok Country Club links yesterday. They were Joe Kelly and Pat Doyle of Clearview and Philip Sarro and Ernest Catropa of Peninsula, each with a card of 66.
BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The Boerse opened the week on an irregular note but the reactionary trend of the last few days apparently ran its course and the close today was firm.

CLINTON, Conn., Aug. 10. -- Wind courting, so often the way to win a sailing race, failed today on the American Yacht Club cruise run from Port Jefferson, L.I., to Duck Island Roads. Instead, the rule of the shortest distances and straight course applied.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- A study of means to preserve the nation's beaches from destruction by wind and tide has been begun by army engineers.

Offshore fishing being what it is, subject to the whims of wind and weather, the week-end visit to Ocean City, Md., in quest of white marlin developed into a patient but fruitless wait for a lull in the northeaster that struck along the Virginia Capes last Friday.

Mrs. William Joshua Barney, former supporter of President Roosevelt, was announced yesterday as the New York City chairman of the Independent Coalition of American Women, which is opposing the President's re-election. Mrs. Willis T. Hanson, State chairman, made the announcement.
BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- Although technically the Olympics still have almost a week to run, the great exodus of competitors already has begun. The Olympic Village soon will be half empty.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 10. -- Nottingham's long-heralded international chess masters tournament, bringing together a galaxy of the world's outstanding stars, got off to a good start today and, after two sessions of the first round, results had been recorded in five of the seven matches.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- State chairmen and committeemen from forty-eight States today formed as a permanent body Labor's Nonpartisan League, enthusiastically endorsed the candidacy of President Roosevelt and planted what speakers referred to as the possible seeds of a liberal party, if one is deemed necessary, in 1940.
Steps to improve the efficiency of the WPA and eliminate weaknesses in organization and operation were taken yesterday by the authorities here and in Washington.

A long lease has been taken by the Hudson Terraplane Company on the two-story building which the Mutual Life Insurance Company will erect at the northeast corner of Broadway and Fifty-fifth Street, on the site of the old Sonoma Apartments.

The President in time will write some campaign speeches, and if he avails himself of one opportunity thereby presented he will make the first favorable impression he has made for many months on a financial and industrial group in this country which is now united against him.
A two-hour mock funeral yesterday afternoon marked the eviction of three more Sunnyside home owners.

GENEVA, Aug. 10. -- The roles played in recovery by American "deficit financing," the British banking policy and German and Japanese arming are analyzed in the League of Nation's current year book on "Money and Banking," just out.

The stock market closed irregular yesterday after some sections of the list had displayed fair strength at intervals during the day. Profit-taking and switching operations gave the market an uneven appearance, but individual issues in various groups managed gains of a point or two.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice has sent out invitations for one of her monthly musicales on Saturday afternoon at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown. It will be held at the same hour as the Boston Symphony matinee at Lenox.
LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The new account opened quietly with the stock markets reflecting the uncertain international political output, although the general undertone continued firm.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The third day of competition in the Eastern grass court tennis championships passed into history at the Westchester Country Club today and at the same time made history for the season.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Mrs. Robert H.R. Loughborough gave a reception this afternoon at the Beach Club for Prince and Princess Rudolpho del Drago of Rome, who are here for a brief visit with the Princess's cousins, Mrs. Edward L. Keyes, Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes and Mr. Loughborough, before leaving for California.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- All restrictions on government drought relief employment were swept aside today the WPA announced its intention to "meet the needs of impoverished farmers on a disaster basis."

Reporting a sales volume increase of more than 14 per cent compared with last year, Ralph K. Guinsberg, president of the I.B. Kleinert Rubber Company, yesterday told fifty sales and company executives gathered at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for their annual sales meeting that the company contemplates a considerable expansion in advertising in 1937.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The largest sale in point of numbers this season was held tonight, with fifty-two head passing under the hammer. The youngsters were consigned by Willis Sharpe Kilmer and brought $115,850, an average of about $2,228.

Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, made a personal appearance in Federal court yesterday to urge judges to impose stiffer sentences upon owners and operators of illicit stills, who in the past have been escaping with short jail terms or suspended sentences.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10. -- A gesture of sportsmanship by Charlie Grimm, manager of the Cubs, today probably cost his team the first game of an important series with the Cardinals and, with it, the National League lead.

A mystery involving the disappearance of Miss Jane Carey, 20 years old, of 243 Ocean Street, Lynn, Mass., from the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary was made known yesterday when the ship reached New York from Cherbourg.

MADRID, Tuesday, Aug. 11. -Loyal troops smashed through [ i southern Rebel lines, the govern-] [merit reported today, and captured [the strategic town of Adarnuz, ] twenty-one /niles northeast of Cordoba. Two pieces of the Rebels' artillery and several machine guns were i seized during the engagement. ] Leftist commanders consolidatedI their positions outside the Rebel-{ dominated city of Cordoba andl planned a fresh onslaught against{ the important provincial capital. { /
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The establishment of a national cemetery by the War Department in Nassau County was opposed today by the County Board of Supervisors at an executive meeting held here.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation opened it two-day congress today by approving a history-making collection of twenty-seven world record track and field performances dominated by Americans.

Add to the list of openings for October, 1937 -- yes, 1937: a new play, at present untitled, by Eugene O'Neill. Start the list of January, 1938, with another new play, also untitled, by the same Mr. O'Neill. Both have been finished, a year or more before their arrival dates, but the author doesn't want them on until he has completed at least half of the cycle of which they are a part.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Department of Justice officials reported today that a parole would be granted to Joseph W. Harriman, New York banker, effective Aug. 27.
BERLIN, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Hungary defeated the United States, 3 to 1, in an Olympic field hockey game today. The Hungarians led, 3 -- 0, at half-time.
HENDAYE, France, Aug. 10. -- Details are now known of the shooting of several Germans and Italians in Barcelona, which led to strong protests by their governments.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- The Soviet Government, the newspaper the Matin said today, is selling precious stones and platinum to obtain foreign currencies with which to support the Leftist government of Spain.

Colonel William Harold Terry's face was very red last night, and small wonder. He had been compelled to watch Professor Casey Stengel's impudent Dodgers demolish a seven-game winning streak and halt an ambitious New York pennant drive before an Ebbets Field crowd of 11,000, at least half of which appeared to be the colonel's well-wishers.

BERLIN, Aug. l0. -- The Olympic spirit which has ruled in the Berlin games thus far has been rudely shattered by an international incident which began with mobbing by spectators at a soccer game between Austria and Peru last Saturday, led to the withdrawal of the Peruvian football team today and ended, according to press reports, with anti-German and anti-Austrian demonstrations in Lima, Peru.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Charges that strikebreakers with criminal records were taken from New York to Camden in the recent R.C.A. strike to interfere by violence with peaceful picketing, in violation of the recently enacted Byrnes law, were submitted today to Federal Judge William Clark and United States Attorney John J. Quinn in letters from the Essex Trades Council asking for an investigation.

Trading in foreign exchange continued quiet yesterday, with the franc responding to the foreign dispatches over the week-end indicating that Europe in general, and France in particular, may not be entangled any further in the Spanish situation than at the moment.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- At this stage of the Olympic drama, with the track and field competitions completed and many minor events decided, in come the lightning calculators, each with his own version as to how each of the nations has come out.

The landings on the three upper floors of a four-story brick tenement at 264 Seigel Street, near White Street, in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn, collapsed at 9:30 o'clock last night, marooning twenty-seven persons in their flats and injuring one man slightly.

Stone Webster, Inc., and subsidiaries have reported a consolidated net income of $1,307,442 for the twelve months ended on June 30, or 62 cents a share earned on 2,104,391 capital shares, contrasted with a net loss of $1,134,925 the year before.

CAPE CHARLES, Va., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Mrs. Henry Stiles, 23, of Bird's Nest, was killed instantly this afternoon when she jumped from a moving truck to save her 6-year-old son from death beneath the wheels of approaching automobiles. The boy escaped injury.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The state of mind of the United States is one of greatest confusion, Dr. Boyd H. Bode, Professor of Education at Ohio State University, told the International Conference on New Education and Fellowship at Cheltenham today.
KIEL, Germany, Aug. 10. -- Germany and the Netherlands split the first two of four Olympic yachting gold medals today, the latter winning in the Monotype Class and Germany in the Star Class.
Among the arrivals on the Queen Mary yesterday was Henry L. Stoddard, former New York newspaper publisher, who said that he had returned from Europe to assist in the campaign for Governor Landon.

KAUFMAN, Texas, Aug. 10. -- Mrs. Mabel H. Green, widow of Colonel Edward H. Green, railroad magnate who inherited a fortune from his mother, Hetty Green, today was named permanent administratrix of the estate, valued at $80,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The Tariff Commission and the administration were charged today by Representative Rogers of Massachusetts with delay in erecting adequate tariff barriers against Japanese textile imports.

It was inevitable that, following the news the President had invited Governor LANDON with other State Executives of the drought area to confer on the problem, instant political analysis would be started by the professionals. Chairman HAMILTON was not slow in making a point of Mr. LANDON'S announcement that he would cooperate in the interest of Kansas by reminding that, in 1933, President-elect ROOSEVELT declined certain suggestions for joint action from President HOOVER.

The State of Michigan Highway Commission awarded yesterday a new issue of $919,000 of covert highway refunding bonds, Wayne County's part, to Cray, McFawn Co. of Detroit, on a bid of 102.11 for a fixed interest rate of 2 per cent.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- The White Elephants will be at home on Saturday, Sept. 5, at 11 o'clock in the evening at the Newport Country Club. Thus read the invitations that have been issued by Miss Penelope Winslow and her committee for the annual bal masque given at the clubhouse by the young people of the colony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- A reduction of $235,402,000 in the gross assets of the forty-three operating Joint Stock Land Banks which are in liquidation was accomplished between May 1, 1933, and June 30, 1936, the Farm Credit Administration reported today.

The President's letter to Major BERRY on the occasion of the first meeting of the chairmen of labor's Non-Partisan League restates, in militant terms, general objectives he has previously enunciated. Since the chief one -- "the "restoration and preservation of hu"man liberty and human rights" -- is also listed by Governor LANDON and the Republican platform as their main aspiration, it becomes a matter of specifications.

The claims of both the advocates and opponents of spelling reforms are extravagant and unreasonable. Ever since the well-known list of "One Hundred Spelling Demons" was compiled in 1919 educators have known that the majority of spelling errors exist among these few words and that the much-touted "spelling grind" can be cut down to adequate teaching of these few spelling difficulties.

COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Jesse Owens, here to show 35,000 spectators how he won four Olympic gold medals, was defeated tonight in an international track and field meet by Ralph Metcalfe of Chicago in the 100-meter dash.
TOPEKA, Aug. 10. -- Governor Landon is not an isolationist. He believes in peace and harmony among nations and the carrying on of trade relations and friendly intercourse.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 10. -- Governor Landon decided definitely today to leave tomorrow night for Estes Park, Col., and join his family at the McGraw ranch for an eight-day rest before starting his first Eastern campaign trip on Aug. 20. The Governor will be accompanied by J.M. Nye, his personal aide; Ross Bartley, his press representative, and about twenty newspaper reporters and photographers.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Three thousand weary firefighters tonight checked the progress of forest and brush fires in the Minnesota and Wisconsin north woods. With the drought continuing, however, forestry officials tightened control lines in the danger zones.

The War and Navy Departments have plans for the deepening of the principal East River channel so that first-line battleships can pass from New York Harbor to Long Island Sound on their way up the coast without having to leave the shelter of Long Island, it was disclosed yesterday.

DAYTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Howard Hughes, sportsman flier, landed his "flying laboratory" .transport plane at Wright Field at 5:44 P.M. today, Eastern standard time, after flying non-stop from Los Angeles, and made preparations for a takeoff at 4 A.M. tomorrow for New York.

The Briggs Manufacturing Company reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net profit of $6,874,102 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before provision for the Federal surtax on undistributed profits.

With the title, "God in a Rolls Royce: The Rise of Father Divine Madman, Menace or Messiah?" a book length study of the Negro leader will be published by Hillman-Curl on Aug. 21. John Hosher is the author.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- A luncheon for prominent visitors here for the races was given today by Seth W. Morton at his cottage, Blowing Park. His guests were Peter A.B. Widener 2d, William F.R. Hitt, Frederick Johnson, Charles H. Thiero, Addison D. Kelley, F. Skiddy von Stade, George H. Bull, Robert A. Fairbairn, Sydney J. Smith, Charles H. Strube, Austin Purdue, Morris S. Tremaine, Eugene Rockwell Pike, Baylor Hickman and Warner Morton.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Three juveniles raced in the featured Troy Claiming Stakes today and two of them changed owners as a result, but not the winner. This was Benjamin Lissberger's Juliet W., a High Time filly which started in front and finished the same way at the end of five furlongs and a half.

Games at Philadelphia, Green Bay and Pittsburgh on Sept. 13 will inaugurate the National Football League season, according to the schedule released yesterday by President Joe F. Carr. The New York Giants will meet Philadelphia, the Chicago Cardinals will oppose the Green Bay Packers and the Boston Redskins will face the Pittsburgh Pirates.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Mack Abbey, small black colt by Mr. McElwyn, dam Abbacy, by The Abbe, owned by R.J. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C., and driven by the Hoosier reinsman, Sep Palin, won the Langhorne 2-year-old pace featuring the first day's Grand Circuit racing program at Good Time Park today before a fair-sized crowd.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Lester W. Herzog, up-State Works Progress Administrator, said today "we know of nothing better than work relief" in a statement in which he disagreed with the majority report of Governor Lehman's commission on unemployment relief.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Smashing home when his cause seemed lost, Mrs. H.H. Mohr's Bob's Boys scored by a nose in the Lynn Press Club Purse, mile-and-a-sixteenth feature at Suffolk Downs, before 10,000 persons today to pay the good price of $15.80, almost 7 -- 1.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10. -- A bench warrant was issued today for George S. Kaufman, the playwright, when he failed to obey a subpoena calling for his appearance as a witness at the trial of the action in which Mary Astor, film star, and her former husband, Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, are struggling for the custody of their daughter, Marilyn.

MIDDLEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP). -- State Senator Fearon asserted tonight that uncertainty over administration policies was preventing industry "from forging ahead and providing jobs for any large number of those out of work."

Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato gave James C. Cummings, 16 years old, of 514 Quincy Street, Brooklyn, a suspended sentence for unlawful entry yesterday after he had learned that Cummings's elder brother would receive a death sentence for murder on Friday and that another brother was incarcerated in Clinton Prison, Dannemora, N.Y., for robbery.

Apparently afraid to descend a fire escape, Benjamine Paternoster, 57 years old, returned to his burning apartment in a three-story frame building at i67 Wyckoff Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday and was burned to death. His son, Benjamin Jr., 18, who went to his rescue, was burned seriously and another man received minor injuries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to George L. Berry, President of Labor's Non-Partisan League, read at the league's first national convention today, was as follows:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Senator Rush D. Holt, Democrat, of West Virginia, was announced today as the keynote speaker of the first national convention of the National Union for Social Justice, opening Friday, which the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin has said would make Cleveland's Republican National Convention a "sideshow" in comparison.
COXSACKIE, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Two men were killed tonight when an airplane carrying newspapers to Albany crashed on a farm two and a half miles south of here.
BERLIN, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The United States was eliminated from the Olympic water polo tournament today when it lost a hard-fought 4-to-3 decision to Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Ignoring usual seasonal trends, business activity showed no signs of slackening in July, and gains of previous months were either maintained or extended, the Department of Commerce said today in its monthly survey of current business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Reiterating its earlier objections to the St. Louis, San Francisco Railroad reorganization plan of 1932, the committee of prior lien bondholders of the road objected today to consideration of that plan or any other at present and asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss the proposal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Defiance of the demand that the Committee for Industrial Organization disband by Sept. 5 was voiced here tonight by members of that organization, who held a special meeting to discuss the ultimatum of the American Federation of Labor's Executive Council.

GENEVA, Aug. 10. -- Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, explained today that she had come to Geneva "primarily to further the cooperation of the United States with the International Labor Organization" and particularly to see how the United States could utilize the "very valuable" expert services of the I.L.O. in drafting and administering labor law and in research, and in drawing on and profiting by the experience of other countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- July's heavy drought toll was recorded today in new grain estimates as the Department of Agriculture predicted the smallest corn crop in fifty-five years, a wheat crop barely adequate for domestic requirements, "greatly reduced" supplies of fruits and vegetables and a need for "extensive readjustment of livestock numbers and of feeding practices."

Mayor LA GUARDIA has summoned a number of citizens of this community to meet with him today to consider a fundamental problem of democratic government. That problem is how to cope with modern crime systematically organized on a business basis.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 10. -- The fall of Badajoz into Rebel hands is expected soon. During the past forty-eight hours the fighting has been severe. The garrison has not received help from Madrid and recent reports across the frontier indicate its situation is desperate.
MADRID, Aug. 10 (Passed by the censor). -- An aristocratic mansion in Madrid has been taken over by the toreros' union as a home for superannuated bull-fighters.

With the exception of corn, the gain report of the Department of Agriculture, released after the close of the market yesterday, was about what the trade had been expecting. Because of the drought, however, crop prospects on Aug. 1 were substantially below those of a month earlier.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Bernie Bierman, whose mighty Minnesota elevens have swept all opposition aside for the last two seasons, will direct the College All-Stars against the Detroit Lions, champions of the professional football world, at Soldier Field, Sept. 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Word reached here tonight that Dr. Leslie Elmer Fuller of Evanston, Ill., professor at the Garrett Biblical Institute, Northwestern University, had been drowned while on a venturesome canoe trip with his two sons and two other youths in Northwestern Canada.

The signal for the start of the world premiere of Warners' "China Clipper" at the Strand tonight will be a greeting by radio from the China Clipper of Pan-American Airways, which should be aloft over Manila headed for the United States at the time the Strand projectionist is ready to start showing the picture.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Two international athletes, one American and the other English, were on board the Queen Mary when the Cunard White Star liner docked here yesterday. The American was Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., chairman of the United States Polo Association, returning after managing the successful American team against England in London, the Briton was Fred Perry, arriving to play in the national singles tennis championship at Forest Hills.

Ciro Terranova, 47 years old, who formerly was known as the artichoke king, was freed of a disorderly conduct charge yesterday by Magistrate Peter Abeles in the Bronx magistrate's court.
