Bronx policemen have been instructed by the Police Commissioner to arrest Terranova whenever they get the chance, but so far he has not been convicted of anything.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10. -- The home club, represented by Bob Kunhardt, Bill Middleton and Miss Cecelia Whittelsey, gained a one-point lead today as the eighth annual junior invitation sailing series for the Commodore Law Trophy got under way at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

The signal for the start of the world premiere of Warners' "China Clipper" at the Strand tonight will be a greeting by radio from the China Clipper of Pan-American Airways, which should be aloft over Manila headed for the United States at the time the Strand projectionist is ready to start showing the picture.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug 10. -- The new Catalan Government, from which the Socialists are excluded and which took office when its Left coalition predecessor fell Thursday after a six-day tenure, has assumed all the power of a sovereign State.

The breach between former Governor Alfred E. Smith and his past political associations was appreciably widened yesterday as it was disclosed that he would not be a delegate to the Democratic State Convention.

MONTREAL, Aug. 10. -- Holders of $24,087,200 of the Beauharnois Light, Heat and Power Company's 5 1/2 per cent bonds of 1973, of which $32,968,920 are outstanding, voted unanimously today in favor of an extraordinary resolution sanctioning several changes in the trust deed securing the issue.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (AP). -- James A. Wilson, executive assistant to the director of the International Labor Office at Geneva, predicted today that "within a few years workers of practically all the industrial nations of the world will have a 40-hour work week."

Harry Bannister, theatrical producer, testified yesterday in General Sessions that he had paid $2,000 to three men who went on trial before Judge Morris Koenig and a jury on charges of extortion and attempted extortion.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in July amounted to 950,851 tons, or 64,786 tons more than in June, it was announced yesterday. In July, 1935, shipments of the corporation amounted to 547,794 tons.
The suggestion that preaching the halted for a year or two, made public on Sunday by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, fell among empty pulpits yesterday in this city.

" Individualist" finds himself, this year, a voter with "no place to go." A distinguished coterie of similarly disgruntled former Democrats gave voluble evidence of their dissatisfaction with things as they are within the ranks of Democracy.

THE National League baseball race is now as warm as the weather but over in the American League it's a breeze for the Yankees, although Manager J. Vincent McCarthy hates to have anybody even whisper such a thing where his ball players might get wind of it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Death of the NRA at the hands of the Supreme Court, the Commerce Department reported today, did not wipe out the "real gains" achieved under its minimum wage, maximum hours and child labor code provisions.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- Union workers of the Ohio Fuel Gas Company and its affiliate, the Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company, went on strike today and left only skeleton crews to prevent a shutdown of gas service to the entire city.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 10. -- King Edward arrived by train this morning at the port of Sibenik, where 20,000 persons from all parts of the Dalmatian coast had gathered in picturesque local costumes to greet him. He immediately boarded the yacht Nahlin, which steamed southward.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- British interests have regained control of Mosul Oil Fields, Ltd., which, with its subsidiary, British Oil Development, Ltd., owning a concession of about 45,000 square miles from the Iraq Government, last year passed into Italian hands.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange reflected yesterday a continuance of the usual midsummer week-end influence. While the market was not without a few individual features, trading was routine in character as prices among the pivotal issues fluctuated within relatively narrow limits.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Myles Coen, Scarsdale professional and his amateur club-mate, Ray Korndorfer Jr., carded a fine 66 to take first honors in the weekly Westchester pro-amateur tournament at the Fenway Golf Club today.
BERLIN, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Carl Vinciquerra, Omaha (Neb.) light-heavyweight, was eliminated from Olympic competition by Anin of Egypt today when he lost a decision on points.

CERBERE, France, Aug. 10. -- Two hundred French volunteers recruited among the Leftist parties have passed through Cerbere on their way to Barcelona to serve in the Catalonian armies fighting against the Rebels. The authority for this statement is Julien Cruzel, Mayor of Cerbere and de facto consul in this region of the Catalonian Government.

The apparel markets started the week yesterday in an active manner, with mail orders heavy and fairly substantial commitments made by the large number of visiting buyers. Reorders developed in good quantities for both fur and fur-trimmed coats.

The application by Knickerbocker Village, Inc., lower East Side housing project, for a summary order canceling an assessment of $7,000,000 on the land and buildings in its project or limiting the assessment to $1,850,000, the amount assessed for the land alone, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman.
A 125-foot section of the Fulton Fish Market, for many years a landmark of the lower Manhattan waterfront, collapsed into the East River at 12:05 A.M. today.

Joseph J. Baker, attorney, announced yesterday his resignation as president of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, a post he has held for fifteen years. Nathan S. Jonas, who founded the institution thirty-five years ago, has been named to succeed Mr. Baker.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The State Milk Control Board announced today an increase of 1 cent a quart in the price of milk to consumers, effective next Sunday. Three-fourths of the advance will go to producers and the remainder to dealers.

Plans for eighty-eight homes to be erected by Brooklyn builders featured the filings yesterday with the Building Bureaus in New York boroughs. Several dwellings also were projected for Queens. The plans included the following:

R. Hoe Co., Inc., in a preliminary statement as of June 30, covering the third quarter of the current fiscal year, report a net profit of $32,315 after all interest charges and full depreciation. This contrasts with a net loss of $59,958 for the same quarter of last year.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The number of factory workers in this State increased 0.8 per cent and payrolls rose 1.9 per cent from the middle of June to the middle of July, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Midi Takaoka, 22-year-old Japanese actress known as Neda Taka, died today with a slashed throat in what was reported by Detective Captain Hubert Wallis as a love triangle involving two American men.

It didn't do Joseph Costentino, who is 50 years old and not Irish, a bit of good to grind out the strains of "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling" and "It's a Long Way to Tipperary" on his hand organ last Saturday morning.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Mrs. Vernon H. Brown gave a luncheon today at her home. Among the guests were Mrs. James N. Wallace, Mrs. C. Gordon Hutchinson, Mrs. John Farr Jr., Miss Ruth Stillman, Mrs. William Saint Lawrence, Mrs. Harold M. Wall, Mrs. Henry Martin Polhemus, Mrs. William F. Cogswell, Mrs. Johnston Livingston and Mrs. Franklin S. Richardson.

WILLIAMSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 11. -- A disclosure that Neil M. Erickson, a silicosis sufferer, and his family of four, had been living on $2 in weekly food orders since the State turned back the relief problem to the municipalities in April, brought criticism of State authorities today from officials of Monroe Township here.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- Anasthasius I. Mikoyan, Soviet Commissar for Internal Supply, is now en route to America accompanied by Mrs. Mikoyan and nine engineers to inspect American equipment for food preparation with the object of making purchases to assist in the development of the Soviet's expanding food industries.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- A new system by which Soviet technical school graduates will serve a sort of apprenticeship before stepping into responsible posts has been inaugurated by G.K. Ordjonikidze, Commissar for Heavy Industry, for enterprises under his direction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- A threatened shut-down of many mills in New York's Oswego Basin because of insufficient water supplies was reported to Secretary Ickes today by the Geological Survey. Indicative of the widespread effect of the drought, the same report said that Mississippi traffic above St. Louis was "now practically at a standstill."

Until now, it has been the settled policy of American trade unions not to form a separate political party. In vain have the lure and success of the British Labor party been held up before our workingmen. They have reasoned that their strength could best be exerted from a position of political neutrality.

Although the more prominent stocks are generally at or close to their highest levels of the year, the secondary stocks as a whole are lagging far behind. The complaint most frequently heard among holders of stocks these days is, "the market is going up, but my stocks are not doing anything."

Reports were current in Wall Street yesterday that Field, Glore Co. and A.G. Becker Co. were negotiating for the purchase of all shares of the Middle West Corporation held by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company and by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as collateral for loans to the Central Republic Trust Company.

The action of former Governor Smith in deciding to shun the Democratic State Convention was hailed yesterday by Landon leaders as a distinct asset to the Republican forces seeking to carry New York State.

Charley Robert Lockhart, tiny Treasurer of the State of Texas, sat in his hotel room yesterday, his heels just reaching the edge of the chair, and talked of finances, politics and the relative merits of blondes, brunettes and redheads.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Descendants of families that settled here when Cold Spring Harbor was an important whaling port are up in arms over the proposal of the Cold Spring Harbor Improvement Society to establish a whaling museum here, it was learned today.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The forty-five-foot trawler Nellie B. Parmenter took on salvage and diving equipment today preparatory to leaving for the Delaware Capes to seek sunken treasure.

Probably the most favorable comment that could be made on yesterday's stock market is that it turned dull on the decline. The list moved irregularly throughout the day and the mild advancing tendencies of some stock groupings were held in check.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Ivy Paul Andrews pitched a brilliant three-hit game this afternoon to give the Browns a 7-2 victory over the White Sox. His comrades pounded Sugar Cain for thirteen hits, including Julius Solters's twelfth home run of the year.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Four political parties filed designating petitions for the general election without opposition as far as could be learned today from the Nassau Board of Elections here.

The (London) Observer estimates that twelve million persons -- more than a quarter of the total population of Britain -- have gone on holiday. This high ratio is the more surprising in that only one person in twenty-one owns his own car and so the great throngs are dependent, except for their feet, upon facilities offered by railway companies, buses, coaches, boats,

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The State Department affirmed tonight this nation's intention to remain completely neutral in the present Spanish civil war, in a public statement interpreted here as an attempt to bring moral pressure to dissuade American interests from selling materials of war to either side.

TOLEDO, Spain, Aug. 11. -- Besieged for twenty-one days behind the six-foot walls of the ancient Alcazar, 1,200 Rebel Civil Guards were reported tonight to have taken desperate steps to defeat starvation.

VATICAN CITY, Aug 11 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's political activities were discussed officially by Pope Pius XI and Bishop Michael Gallagher of Detroit, Vatican prelates disclosed today, but were explained satisfactorily.

KIEL, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The Olympic sailing committee awarded the gold medal in the six-meter class to Great Britain tonight after a quarrel among the contestants had caused postponement of proposed sail-offs in both the six and eight meter classes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the fate of sure oblivion was fast bearing down on the deepsea sailing fleet flying the ,American flag.
SEATTLE, Aug. 11. -- While thousands stood silent, Representative Zioncheck was buried at Evergreen Cemetery this afternoon after one of the largest funerals ever held in Seattle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission's authority to subpoena witnesses in the pending investigation of investment trusts and investment companies was sustained today in the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia when Justice Bailey handed down decisions denying the applications of Frederick T. Fisher of New Canaan, Conn., for injunctions restraining the SEC from issuing subpoenas in connection with its investigation of the Equity Corporation and its predecessor companies.
BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Three American boxers won and one lost and was eliminated today in Olympic competition.

ROME, Aug. 11. -- The Spanish Embassy in Rome was the scene today of a miniature reproduction of the struggle now going on in Spain when an attempt to take possession of the embassy office was made by Jose M. Aguinaga, who had been appointed Charge d' Affaires by the Madrid Government on the resignation of Ambassador Manuel Aguirre de Carcer.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 11. -- At Mitchell Hall, Williamstown, today the Williamstown Garden Club, of which Mrs. William Warren Tracy is president, held its third annual flower show. Mrs. Tracy gave prizes for floral arrangements by children and Miss Laura E. Dwight was donor of a cup for the winner of the most points.

In Monday afternoon's Government crop report, interest converged on corn, which was known beforehand to have suffered most severely by the drought. For that crop the Washington estimate was close to the lowest of last week's private estimates. As against a 2,224,000,000-bushel yield estimated a month ago and 2,291,629,000 actually harvested last year, the Agricultural Department now places the probable corn yield of 1936 at 1,439,135,000.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Buyers of hogs here balked today at paying advanced prices, with the best selling at $11.25, or 5 cents under Monday's top, while the day's average was unchanged at $9.90 a hundred pounds. The general market was steady to 10 cents lower despite smaller receipts at the leading markets, 260 to 300-pound butchers showing the most strength.

John Coefield, a vice president of the American Federation of Labor and general president of the United Association of Journeymen Plumbers and Steam Fitters, was named yesterday as head of the labor division of the Eastern campaign forces seeking election of Governor Landon.

Gains were the rule in active trading on the commodity futures markets here yesterday, although rubber, silk and hides declined and coffee was hesitant. On the cash markets, corn, cocoa, cotton, lard, tin and wool tops advanced, while wheat, rye, silk and rubber declined.

PARIS, Aug. 11. -- The improvement made yesterday on the Bourse was strengthened today, and although the rise in prices were small, they were general. Both the progress that is being made in reaching an international agreement regarding Spain and in getting various parliamentary bills through both houses by a method of moderate compromise have led to a more optimistic outlook than was apparent last week.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- A Washington dispatch to The Baltimore Sun states that President Roosevelt, moving with secrecy and dispatch, today stepped into the Maryland campaign for his re-election, acting personally to bring the Democratic leaders of the State to their toes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Denial that White, Weld Co. acquired an option for purchase of 10,000 shares of A.O. Smith Corporation common stock as a "manipulative device" to affect prices on the New York Curb Exchange was made today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, and two former United States Secretaries of State, Frank B. Kellogg and Henry L. Stimson, accompanied by Mrs. Kellogg and Mrs. Stimson, are among those sailing for Europe this afternoon on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 11 (AP). -- Slowly mounting returns from today's Democratic primary gave Senator Joseph T. Robinson a better than two-to-one margin over the combined votes of two opponents, while a close fight appeared in prospect for the Gubernatorial nomination.

A total stranger will often become an old acquaintance under a little closer scrutiny. Among the very new things now in the public eye and ear is "mass-consciousness." Suppose we call it popular consciousness. Immediately the so-called revolt of the masses takes on a familiar aspect.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 11 (By Courier to Gibraltar). -- Twenty heavy German Junker bombing planes and five German pursuit planes manned by German military pilots arrived at Rebel headquarters in Seville today. The airplanes had been landed from a ship at the Rebel port of Cadiz and were then flown here.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 11. -- At daybreak this morning Spanish Rebel troops attacked once more in the direction of Irun. Heavy shooting and gunfire were heard across the French border. The positions appeared unchanged, however, early this afternoon.

The Clark Equipment Company declared yesterday a dividend of 30 cents on the common stock and the regular quarterly dividend of $1.75 on the preferred. In preceding quarters, 20 cents was paid on the common stock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today receipt of bids on State and municipal 4 per cent bonds offered at public sale. The securities were bought by the RFC from the Public Works Administration and were offered for sale in line with the policy adopted some time ago.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- Creating a Democratic Congressional contest in the primaries in President Roosevelt's home district, Edward J. Bowen of Poughkeepsie filed today an independent designation for Representative in the Twenty-sixth District, which comprises Dutchess, Putnam and Orange Counties.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- Television both outdoors and indoors, broadcast over a distance of seven miles, was demonstrated today to an audience of sixty guests in a home at suburban Rydal.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Wally Berger's twentieth home run of the season gave the Boston Bees a 5-to-4 ten-inning triumph over the Phillies in the second game of their series today.

Your editorial "Dog Days" gave a very clear idea of some of the problems of stray dogs and cats. Some zealots would build them $100,000 shelters, while others would have them shot on sight. They have no control over their own destinies, and "would be better off if they could simply be treated as what they are: the most intelligent, faithful and devoted of animal companions."

A plot 135 by 135 feet adjoining the Beechmont Towers apartments at 30 Eastchester Road, New Rochelle, was purchased by Thirty Eastchester Road, Inc., owner of the apartment, from Mrs. Dora Malakoff for landscaping and development with tennis courts, a playground and garden for use of tenants, it was announced by Riker Co., Inc., broker in the transaction. Cost of the land and the improvement is estimated at $25,000.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The Reds and Pirates broke even today in a double-header battle for fourth place in the National League. The Bucs took the opener, 6 to 3, and dropped the second, 7 to 3, retaining their game and a half margin.

Until yesterday Joe Cascarella, late of Boston but now a Washington pitcher, was just another fellow named Joe to the Yankees. Twice in the spangles of Tom Yawkey's Red Sox he had been lulled to sleep by the song of Yankee bats.

A recent letter to THE TIMES declares that "there is absolutely no good reason why State or national government should fix the rate of wages in any industry." Also, "the agitation for minimum wage laws has no basis in logic or facts."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Broad revisions in the policy governing Federal grants to municipalities to assist in construction of public works, under which the sole gauge would be the actual number of persons removed from relief rolls, were explained by President Roosevelt at a press conference today.

Charles (Luciano) Lucania, New York City's Public Enemy No. 1 until his recent imprisonment at Dannemora, began yesterday his expected fight in the courts to escape the sentence of thirty to fifty years imposed by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- A group of "idea men" whose job it is to "unsell" President Roosevelt and his New Deal to the American people and break whatever "buyer resistance" there may be to Governor Landon and his promises is being assembled at national Republican headquarters to start what bids to be a unique campaign in the history of American politics.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 11. -- A picnic supper on the rocks in midriver and a corn roast were attended tonight by a large group from the Mount Washington, who went after dinner to the picnic grounds on the Ammonoosuc, later returning for dancing in the Cave Grill.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- The fleet of the New York Yacht Club on its annual cruise will come here tomorrow afternoon from New London. Commodore W.A.W. Stewart arrived in advance of the fleet on the Queen Mab today. Former Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt is to give a dinner in honor of the flag officers.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Rebel forces tonight advanced to within three miles of Irun, on the Bay of Biscay, after a day of fierce fighting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Of 2,563,185 workers employed on WPA projects on May 15, 2,152,690 were men and 410,495, or 16 per cent, were women, according to an analysis made public today by Aubrey W. Williams, Deputy Administrator.

The arrival of $6,545,200 gold from abroad was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which also reported that $113,000 gold had been engaged in India for shipment here. The arrivals reported yesterday included $1,977,200 from India, which was additional for Monday; $3,632,100 from Mexico, which came in yesterday and was at once placed under earmark; $836,000 from India and $99,900 from Russia.

SEBENIC0, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11 (AP). -- King Edward, on a leisurely yachting cruise through the Adriatic, went fishing with native anglers today, but what he caught was kept as secret as a matter of state.

A special Department of Justice agent arrested a farmer of Alton, Iowa, yesterday on a charge of sending extortion letters through the mails to Mrs. Oliver Harriman, it was announced here by Emil K. Ellis, attorney for Mrs. Harriman and counsel for the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, of which she is head.

Mike Belloise, 128, whom the State Athletic Commission regards as the world's featherweight champion, registered a nine-round knockout over Joe Doherty, 127, South Brooklyn, in a non-title bout at the New Queensboro Arena last night.

Colonel Edmund L. Daley, War Department district engineer, revealed yesterday that his office would make a survey -- to be completed by next May -- of the East River from the Brooklyn Navy Yard to Throgs Neck to determine the advisability of deepening the channel.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,963,800 barrels, compared to 2,948,000 in the preceding week, a gain of 15,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute, An increase of 36,400 barrels in the daily average output of California was offset partly by decreases of 16,350 and 8,800 barrels respectively in Kansas and Oklahoma.

A decision affecting the promotion of several school teachers here was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman. The court denied an application by Mrs. Clara R. Brahdy, former history teacher in the junior high school, to compel the Board of Education to reinstate her and rescind its order returning her to her former post in the grade schools at a reduced salary.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to the public today a $1,000,000 issue of Public Service Company of New Hampshire first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, Series E. dated Aug. 1 and due on Aug. 1, 1961. The offering price will be at 104.125 plus accrued interest.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, the new WPA Administrator for New York City, disclosed yesterday that he has accepted the resignation of Mrs. Sarah S. Dennen, director of women's activities with jurisdiction over 10,000 women, for "the good of the service."

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 11. -The Princeton Preparatory School, founded in 1873 by Princeton University as a preparatory department of the college, will not reopen this Fall, it was announced tonight by Headmaster Harry B. Fine.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 11. -- A military court composed of colonels, lieutenant colonels and majors sat on the prison ship Uruguay today and condemned to death General Manuel Goded and General Alvaro Fernandez Burriel, who were accused of military rebellion. It is understood that they will be executed tomorrow morning.

It is natural enough that the European press should be deeply interested in Governor LANDON'S views on foreign policy. In response to requests for light on his position, the Topeka correspondent of The Kansas City Star has written an article to which the Republican candidate has given his approval.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The names of two Japanese naval officers, former attaches of the embassy here, were mentioned in an indictment reported by a District of Columbia grand jury today charging former Lieut. Commander John S. Farnsworth with conspiring to sell important naval defense information to the Japanese Government.

So far as is known, no arms or munitions have been shipped from the United States to either side in the Spanish conflict. The only action taken by the American Government has been to file a formal reminder with the Madrid government that it is responsible for damage done to American property during the disorders.

ATHENS, Greece, Aug. 11. -- One of the chief ambitions of the new dictatorship in Greece seems to be the organization of an airtight censorship over the telephone and telegraph both inside and outside the country. The regime also forbids newspapers to print any editorial matter or political news except communiques.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 11. -- A temporary restraining order prohibiting the sale of $8,000,000 in public power bonds and any move to begin a municipal power distribution plant by the city of Chattanooga or the Chattanooga Public Power Board was signed today by Chancellor J, Lon Foust.

Within nine days of the twenty-fourth anniversary of his indictment on a first-degree murder charge in the shooting of Herman Rosenthal, the gambler, in the midtown district in July, 1912, John Reich, also known as John Rich and Jack Sullivan, moved in General Sessions yesterday to have the indictment quashed.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 11. -Although the winner of the eighth annual junior invitation sailing series for the Commodore Robert Law Trophy will not be determined until tomorrow as a result of the postponement of the fifth race, the contending teams narrowed down to three today at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

Visiting buyers reported in the market in the week ended yesterday numbered well above the thousand-mark for the fifth consecutive week. The total was also above the figures for the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

C.L. Poole Co., Inc., dealers in eggs and butter, have purchased the five-story building at 180 Duane Street which they have occupied under lease since 1922. The purchase was made for all cash, according to the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker in the transaction. The building is on a lot 25 by 127 feet and will be held free of encumbrances by the new owners.

Coley Taylor and Samuel Middlebrook have been examining the records to discover the unkind things said about Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln. They found that virtually all the fundamental charges that have been made against President Roosevelt are merely repetitions of the charges earlier made against Washington, Jefferson and Lincoln.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11.--The general executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America appropriated $100,000 to the organization fund of the Committee for Industrial Organization today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission received nineteen offering sheets of various oil interests last week, it announced today. The offerings were as follows:
PARIS, Aug. 11. -- The United States is being kept informed of the neutrality negotiations here, but no invitation has been extended for the Washington government to endorse the French proposal.

DALLAS, Ga., Aug. 11 (AP). -- An accused wife-killer being transferred from the jail to the court house was shot to death on the public square here today. The shooting threw into a momentary panic a crowd gathered for his trial and a gathering waiting to hear a political speech.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Great Britain still recognizes the validity of treaties with Portugal for mutual military support running back six centuries. Assurance to that effect was given to Lisbon today by the British Ambassador, Sir Charles Wingfield, as part of the British Government's effort to convince the Portuguese Government that it will be safe for it to adhere to the nonintervention agreement concerning the Spanish civil war.

Relying upon small contributors for the bulk of its campaign funds, the Democratic party faces the 1936 election drive in far better financial condition than in 1932, Forbes Morgan, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, asserted yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley reserved decision yesterday in the special term of court at Jamaica, Queens, on the temporary injunction sought by Joseph Lyttle, dog racetrack operator, to restrain the police and the Sheriff and District Attorney of Queens County from interfering with the operation of the track at Sunrise Highway near Cross Bay Boulevard, Ozone Park, Queens.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11. -- Last week's comparative calm in Palestine appears to have been merely a respite. Arab terrorism and vandalism have increased in vigor in the past few days and many lives have been lost in various parts of the country as a result of Arab sniping.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 11. -- Former General Nicolas Rodriguez, chief of the Gold Shirts, Mexican Fascist and anti-Semitic organization, was deported this morning by airplane to El Paso, Texas, after having been detained all night at police headquarters.

ST. LOUIS Aug. 11 (AP). -- Short-stop Leo Durocher and Coach Buzz Wares were put out of the game to climax a bitter argument as the fighting Cardinals lost their National League lead to the Cubs, 6 to 4, in ten innings today.

The press recently reported the speech of a prominent political leader who denounced the stirring of class hatreds and passions, but who himself used the terms "foreign" and "imported" as epithets for ideas which he disliked.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- John Marcum handcuffed most of his former Philadelphia team-mates today when he gained his seventh victory of the season by hurling the Boston Red Sex to a 4-1 triumph. The ex-Athletics righthander held the opposition to six hits, three of which were made in the ninth.

Following Monday's decline, which resulted from a liberal estimate by the government of crop prospects, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and closed with gains of 5 to 10 points. Instead of selling pressure, the market felt the influence of the highest temperatures in the Southwest in several years and mill buying readily absorbed all contracts offered.

Short casts: What with the salt-water fish putting on their customary mid-season show, fresh-water angling is pretty much in the background. . . . Still, a few items are at hand concerning the activities of the lake and stream habitues.

GRUNAU, Germany, Aug. 11. -- Germany's acceptance of an inferior status as a naval power apparently has not extended to her oarsmen. The huge Olympic rowing regatta opened today on the tree-banked Langersee with the Reich's sweepswingers completely dominating the show.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 11. -- Senator Borah, bidding for a sixth term, took the lead for the Republican Senatorial nomination over Byron Defenbach, backed by Townsendites, in early returns tonight from Idaho's State-wide primary.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- More than 400 Republican women heard Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, vice chairman of the State committee, declare tonight at a dinner of the Republican Educational League that "the civil service system of the United States is being corrupted by President Roosevelt, and is being replaced by a monster spoils system."

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 11. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh made his first public appearance as a scientist today when he and Dr. Alexis Carrel displayed their robot heart to eager, excited members of the international congress of experimental cytology.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Confirmation of the long-expected news from Berlin of Joachim von Ribbentrop's appointment as Ambassador to Great Britain was received at Whitehall today without regret but also without any appreciable enthusiasm.

GENEVA, Aug. 11. -- Addressing the World Jewish Congress tonight, Rabbi M.L. Perlsweig, head of the World Zionist Organization's political information department, accused the British authorities in Palestine of "political ineptitude so gross as to be almost unbelievable."

Chain stores last month recorded their best percentage of increase in sales for any similar period this year or since 1929, according to the monthly compilation issued yesterday by Hammons Co., and Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc. Continuing the gains which began in March, the first twenty-five companies to report for July did an aggregate business of $218,335,123, an increase of 19 per cent over the same month last year.

Directors of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 15, the first payment since one also of 20 cents on May 15, 1935.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Gilmour Young, national secretary of the Townsend Old-Age Pension movement, announced tonight the dismissal of three senior officers of the organization and the closing of all regional offices Aug. 15.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 11. -- When play ceased tonight in the second round of the international chess masters' tournament at the University College, Dr. Max Euwe of the Netherlands, newly crowned world champion, held the lead in the field of fifteen experts, thanks to his victory over Professor Milan Vidmar of Yugoslavia in twenty-nine moves.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Joachim von Ribbentrop, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Special Ambassador at Large, today was appointed Ambassador to Great Britain as successor to the late Dr. Leopold von Hoesch, who died suddenly in London last April.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Aug. 11. -- The dirigible Hindenburg established a new speed record for the eastward transatlantic crossing when she landed at the airport here at 10:28 P.M. (5:28 P.M., New York time). The flight from Lakehurst, N.J., took only 42 hours 53 minutes.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 11.--On a day of stirring competition that kept the packed gallery tingling with excitement, five favorites were eliminated from the Eastern grass-court tennis championships today at the Westchester Country Club.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- An immediate increase in the price of milk to producers and a corresponding increase to consumers is expected to result from the hearing today before the State Milk Control Board on the best method of relieving drought-stricken milk producers.

For the second successive month Spencer Tracy has won the award of the Screen Writers Guild for the most distinguished performance of the month, this time for his portrayal of the role of Father Tim Mullin in "San Francisco." In June he won the honor for his work as Joe Wilson in "Fury."
BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Prices on the Boerse today were very firm, with the turnover small. The public apparently is holding on to what it has bought, and even small orders produced large upturns.

The attitude of Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State Chairman, toward continuing in his present office was disclosed yesterday as a vital factor in the drive of various candidates for the Republican nomination for Governor.

A recent news item in your columns bears the heading "Standley Says United States Plans Battleships to Match Britain's," and further states that the admiral, when asked whether he thought the United States would build two more battleships to keep pace with Britain, replied, "There is no doubt in my mind that two ships will be built."

All fabrics that promise to achieve acceptance for dresses in their price class will be tested for the members of the Dress Creators League of America, Inc., by the Better Fabrics Testing Bureau of the National Retail Dry Goods Association as the result of arrangements completed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- To enable the Public Service Company of New Hampshire to complete a reorganization which will make it an operating company instead of a holding company, the Securities and Exchange Commission granted to the corporation today an exemption from the Holding Company Act of 1935 for an issue of bonds and preferred stock.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 11. -- Today was Hugo Wolf's day in Salzburg. At noon a handful of invited guests, with Bruno Walter prominent among them, attended the unveiling of a memorial tablet to the great song composer on the house in one of the narrow streets back of Trinity Church where Wolf lived in 1881, poor and miserably unhappy, while occupying the post of second conductor at the Municipal Theatre.
Samuel Fassler, Manhattan's Building Commissioner, appeared yesterday before Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen and asked for a salary increase of $2,710 for himself in the 1937 city budget.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP). -- The Indians strengthened their hold on second place and gained a game today on the New York Yankees, leaders in the American League, by defeating the Tigers, 6 to 5.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company will sell its 14.3 per cent stock interest in the Middle West Corporation to the Chicago Corporation for about $5,700,000, it was said here today on excellent authority.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 11. -- The Bellport Bay Yacht Club crew, skippered by Miss Joan Earle of Brooklyn Heights and Bellport, annexed the women's championship of the Great South Bay by scoring its fourth and fifth successive victories today.

Trading In bonds expanded somewhat yesterday, with special activity in United States Government securities. Prices were steady as a rule, although government issues were mixed and industrial issues fared somewhat poorer than rails and utilities.

TOPEKA, Aug. 11. -- Governor Landon left tonight to join his family at McGraw Ranch in Estes Park, Col., under orders from his physicians to rest until he leaves that place on his Eastern trip on Aug. 20.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Henry L. Deforest's Seawanhaka schooner Nadji furnished a surprise today by defeating all the racing sloops on the squadron run of the American Yacht Club from Duck Island Roads Breakwater, which is off Clinton, Conn.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- The United States in its turn scored en all-medal Olympic swimming victory today, winning the gold, silver and bronze medals in the springboard diving. Dick Degener was first with 163.57 points, Marshall Wayne was second with 159.56 and Al Greene was third with 146.29.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- The London Stock Exchange was firm and brighter today, with less anxiety among traders over the foreign situation. European shares were steadier in the foreign department, with German issues fractionally higher, but Spanish securities again lower.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11. -- With reports current that the motion-picture industry was exerting pressure to stop further hearings in the legal controversy between Mary Astor and her former husband, Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, over the custody of their daughter, Marilyn, counsel for the litigants announced tonight that a settlement out of court was in sight.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- A sensational round of golf played by Miss Charlotte Glutting, member of the American Curtis Cup team, featured the qualifying round of the annual New York State women's championship over the Mohawk course today.

"Yes, Madam?" has run into difficulties which will delay its Broadway opening and may even -- should the worst happen -- postpone its arrival indefinitely. It seems, according to Jack Curtis, that when he and Carleton P. Hoagland decided to offer the musical comedy to America they made a verbal agreement with Jack Waller, English producer and co-author, relative to certain changes.

BUFFALO, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Boosting their winning streak to five straight by beating the Newark Bears, 6 to 4, before 10,000 fans tonight, the Bisons moved to within a half game of the league-leading Rochester team. The Red Wings lost a double-header to Syracuse in the afternoon.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 11 (AP). -- District Judge R.P. Hill awarded yesterday to the Midway Oil Company a share in the British American Oil Producing Company's Piersol and Russell leases in the North Oklahoma City oil field. The leases are valued at $2,500,000.

Praising eighty-five taxicab drivers who received awards yesterday from the Police Department for aiding police work, Mayor La Guardia said the best automobile drivers in the country were behind the wheels of New York's cabs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- A miscellaneous lot of yearlings passed under the hammer tonight, thirty-nine head bringing a total of $79,850, or an average of about $2,047. The sellers were the Greenwich Stud, Inc.; Horace N. Davis, Bosque Bonita Farms, Charles Nuckols, J.L. Tarlton, Earl H. Sande and others.

Dick Degener, Detroit; Marshall Wayne, Miami, and Al Greene, Chicago, finishing in that order, gave United States sweep in springboard diving championship, duplicating the blanket triumph in 1932 Olympics. Japan's quartet, Yusa, Sugiura, Taguchi and Arai, set new world record of 8:51.5, winning 800-meter men's relay championship and beating United States four by 20 meters.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

THIS is the great day in the land of Goshen, a pleasant rolling country just over the river and not far away. The city folk wouldn't know much about it because this is strictly a country affair -- a truly rural sport. It's trotting. Or rather trottin', to put it correctly. It is Hambletonian day at Bill Cane's Good Time Park at Goshen, N.Y., with $35,000 at stake for the big match.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- A contest for the Republican nomination for State Senator in the Twenty-sixth district became a certainty today with the filing of a petition in behalf of Joshua M. Fiero Jr. of Yonkers, who will contest the organization's selection of C. Van Ness Wood.

Are the excesses in Spain a sample of what is to come to a world which refuses to reason and to learn by experience? Wars in the past were, for the most part, the concern of soldiers. Wars in the future will be the concern of every man, woman and child. No single human being can be isolated or protected.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 12. -- As the time for framing the budget approaches the army is making it clear that defense appropriations must have precedence over everything else.

Infectious diseases in New York City dropped sharply in the week ended last Saturday, the Health Department reported yesterday. Infant mortality continued low, seventy-three deaths being reported for the week. This gave a rate of 38.4 to each 1,000 live births.

The prosecution rested its case yesterday in General Sessions in the trial of Jerome A. Jacobs, lawyer, Harry S. Hechheimer, disbarred attorney, and Raymond Derringer, motion picture operator, on indictments alleging they extorted $1,800 from Harry Bannister, theatrical producer, in December, 1934.

Invitations are now being mailed to debutantes of the coming season for the Velvet Ball and Debutante Cotillion to be held on Oct. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children. Committees have been formed and preliminary plans are now being made.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Sigmund Romberg's operetta "My Maryland," a Shubert production, was presented here tonight on the Zach's Bay stage under the direction of Fortune Gallo. On the shores of the bay an audience of 8,000 persons filled the Jones Beach Stadium.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- The Peruvian Olympic soccer team, which has withdrawn from the games because the football authorities decided it should replay its match with Austria, is leaving tomorrow morning for Paris.

Howard Hughes, holder of the transcontinental speed record, completed a leisurely one-stop flight from California yesterday morning. He landed his "flying laboratory" transport plane, which had itself set a coast-to-coast mark under control of D.W. (Tommy) Tomlinson more than a year before, at Floyd Bennett Field at 10:20 A.M.

The two and a half story gray building that for twenty-nine years has been the center of the receiving and wholesaling activity at Fulton Fish Market was doomed yesterday following the collapse of a 125-foot section shortly after midnight Monday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- A long list of conferences on widely separated topics today marked the second of a three-day visit to the White House, in which President Roosevelt is trying to clear his slate of a month's accumulation of work, and prepare for departure on another series of trips.

OLD LYME, Conn., Aug. 11 (AP). -- A competing offer was withdrawn today and the Florence Griswold Association saw success ahead in its fight to save the white-pillared mansion of the "patron saint" of the Old Lyme art colony.

Through the cooperation of retailers, manufacturers and others, to whom the National Better Business Bureau and the Linen Trade Association appealed last June in launching a drive against the misbranding of fabrics as linen, the situation in large trading centers is now well in hand, the Linen Trade Association reported yesterday.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Ten colts and fillies will take the word tomorrow in the eleventh Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-old trotters over the mile course of Good Time Park. The blue ribbon event of the light harness turf will be trotted in mile heats, the best two out of three, and will carry a value of $35,644.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 11. -- Following conferences with State leaders and county chairmen today, John Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, declared that Oregon was in the best shape for the Landon-Knox ticket of all the Northwestern States.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- The minimum age of service in the Soviet armed forces was reduced by a government decree tonight from 21 years to 19.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Starting blocks may yet be admitted to the International Amateur Athletic Federation's rule book, it was indicated today at the final session of the federation's two-day meeting.

While business failures declined in the retail and manufacturing groups in the week ended Aug. 6, compared with the previous week, there was an increase in the wholesale division, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Retail failures showed a decline of thirty-nine from the average so far this year, while in the manufacturing group there was a drop of fourteen from the average. The detailed report is follows:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 11. -- Argentina reported an important international victory today with the announcement that the Spanish Government had permitted the Argentine Ambassador to take five Spanish revolutionists to France.
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Belgium may be the next country destined to spring a surprise upon Europe.

Mr. HUGH ALCORN, State's Attorney of Connecticut, is again a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor. His first speech in the campaign was before a meeting of county Young Republican clubs. If he didn't make their flesh creep they can confidently stroke the arm'd rhinoceros or the Hyrcan tiger.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- Members of the Summer colony attended the first of the programs at the theatre at Saratoga Spa tonight, when Anna Sokolow and Lil Leandre, members of Martha Graham's group of the staff of Arts in the Theatre, gave a dance program.
MADRID, Aug. 11. -- Government forces from Burcia besieging Cordoba are reported to have carried out a heavy artillery bombardment today.

New complications in the trial of claims arising from the condemnation of property at the World's Fair site in Flushing Meadows brought further criticism yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn, who only last week warned that the proceeding would have to be expedited.

Dr. Wendell C. Bennett, archaeologist and a curator of the American Museum of Natural History, returned yesterday from Peru on the motorship Santa Barbara of the Grace Line after spending six months along the northern border studying the pre-Inca civilization.

An issue of $5,000,000 of Commonwealth of Massachusetts registered 2 1/4 per cent water bonds was awarded yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by the National City Bank and the Bankers Trust Company, which bid 100.7499 for the bonds.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- Of all the peoples at these Olympics, both as competitors and as spectators, the Japanese are the most fanatical and the most emotional. Apparently the Olympic Games are less a matter of sports for the Empire of the Rising Sun than part of its program for increasing its prestige in a world largely Caucasian.

A delegation representing Federal projects ordered merged with the regular WPA organization in this city will leave for Washington today to protest against the merger. This action was decided upon last night at a meeting at 17 Charles Street of representatives of unions and organizations employed on the projects.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 11. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute in New York today exhibited the functioning of their robot heart to members of the international congress of experimental cytology.

In an effort to prevent a strike of Pacific Coast maritime workers and the tie-up of commerce upon the expiration of the existing wage and working contract on Sept. 30, the Pacific Coast Waterfront Employers Association has asked union officials to start negotiations for a new contract as soon as possible.

The plan of the city administration to withdraw tax exemption from the Knickerbocker Village model housing project on the East Side, if successful, will bankrupt virtually all the low rental housing created in New York City under the State Housing Law in the last ten years, Aaron Rabinowitz, vice chairman of the New York State Board of Housing, said yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Hector Bywater, the naval expert, writing for The Daily Telegraph tonight, says the present struggle in Spain hasn't yet thrown any new light on the bomb-versus-warship problem.

Half an hour after Bernard McHugh, 21 years old, had been honorably discharged from the United States Army he was picked from a line-up of more than 200 soldiers by Kendall Horstman of 42 West Seventy-second Street as the man who early Monday had robbed him of $1,800 in cash and jewelry.

Two malevolent influences were at work yesterday in Ebbets Field, and the one operating against the Dodgers proved the stronger, with the result that nearly 10,000 fans witnessed the first 1936 Giant victory in the Flatbush terrain, while Professor Casey Stengel's boys failed for the eighth time this year to extend a winning streak to four games.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Mrs. Rupert Savile, wife of a retired British naval officer killed during bombardment of his yacht by a Spanish Rebel ship, described the shelling today as "the most terrible moment of my life."

KULING, Kiangsi Province, China, Aug. 11. -- A final settlement of the South China problem can be effected without resorting to force, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek declared in an exclusive interview yesterday.

Organization of a nonpartisan citizens' committee to assist law-enforcement agencies in wiping out racketeering in this city went forward rapidly yesterday after a conference of leaders in the movement with Mayor La Guardia and Thomas E. Dewey, special rackets prosecutor, at the Summer City Hall.
A general strike in the knitgoods industry of the metropolitan area was called yesterday by the Knitgoods Workers Union, affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 11 (AP). -- A new outbreak of brush fires and three serious blazes in Beltrami Island forest late today offset the work of forest fire fighters just when they had blazes in the northern tinderbox area under control.

A small group of spectators at the Bayside links in Queens early yesterday morning for the second-day shooting in The World-Telegram's fifth annual hole-in-one golf tournament thought for an instant that they were witnessing an actual ace in the making when young Tommy Strafaci sent his fourth shot on a line toward the pin.

GENEVA, Aug. 11. -- Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, said today the United States would go ahead under all circumstances with some of the New Deal's outstanding social policies. She was speaking at a luncheon given for her by E.J. Phelan, assistant director of the International Labor Organization.

No more significant news has come out of Europe in recent days than the report that Belgium, of all countries, may prove the obstacle to the conclusion of an agreement to take the place of the violated Treaty of Locarno. Belgium is said to be preparing to demand of the coming Five-Power conference a recognition of her neutrality in any future war.
There is no "Red menace" in the WPA here, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The story of an adventure into the investment trust field by Charles F. Kettering, noted inventor and vice president and head of the Research Department of the General Motors Corporation, featured today's investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the organization and operations of the Yosemite Holding Company of Detroit.
MADRID, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Action by the American Embassy, it was asserted here tonight, has resulted in an end to indiscriminate seizure of American properties.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Agents of the Rockland County District Attorney and Sheriff, besides township and State police, raided the Orangeburg Dog Track near here tonight, arresting two men, summoning twenty others before the grand jury and halting the races after eight of the scheduled ten contests had been witnessed by the 10.000 spectators.

CAIA, Portugal, Aug. 12. -- Badajoz, opposite Caia across the Spanish border, which is now surrounded by General Francisco Franco's Rebel troops, has been subjected to a terrific bombardment by his airplanes since 4 o'clock this afternoon.

Colonel Frank Knox speaks about the "Dammed-up forces of recovery" and expects us to believe that a mere change of administration will solve all of our problems. As a matter of reality we are very skeptical of Republican prosperity which left us holding worthless paper that once represented stocks, bonds and real estate.

Sixty-four players qualified over five district courses yesterday for play in the metropolitan handicap golf championship, which is being conducted by the Metropolitan Golf Association for the second year. The eligible performers will start match play at the Crestmont Golf Club, West Orange, N.J., on Sept. 21, with the final scheduled for Sept. 23.

Restoration of salaries of judges and attaches of the county courts of Kings and Queens to the pre-pay-cut levels was asked yesterday in formal budgetary requests for 1937 submitted to Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen. The county courts of the Bronx and Richmond, however, seek no blanket pay rises.

Although there has not been any sweeping movement to make stock prices conform to revised earnings reports resulting from the drought, it is apparent that individual issues from day to day are reflecting in upward or downward movements the inevitable changes in buying power, volume of business, and commodity prices.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 (AP). -- An attempt by the State to collect $705,000 more from the Gulf Oil Corporation on its 1933 capital-stock taxes headed toward the courts today after a hearing before the Board of Finance and Revenue. The company paid $48,000.

MADRID, Aug. 12. -- The evacuation of Madrid's foreign colonies is progressing. Large numbers of French and Germans are leaving daily, the British and American colonies have been reduced to a little more than 100 each and few Italians remain.

A total of twenty-six out of thirty-seven main store departments in New York increased their advertising linage for July over the corresponding month of last year, according to figures issued yesterday by Media Records. The total for the month was 1,786,023 lines as against 1,519,621 for July, 1935, an increase of more than 17 per cent.

OLD LYME, Conn., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The ancient mansion where Miss Florence Griswold, "patron saint" of the artists who founded the American Barbizon school of painting, was born eighty-six years ago will be made a museum, Dr. Matthew-Griswold said today.

EDMONTON, Alta., Aug. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Premier Aberhart laid plans today for a special session of the Alberta Legislature to start Aug. 25 as protests came from various sources against the policies of his government.

During all the first part of August the Presidential campaign has seemed dull and stagnant. Little has occurred to interest or stir the public. Doubtless this appearance of indifference or lifelessness will continue until well toward the end of the month. But behind this outer semblance of inertness a great deal of active political work has been going on.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The August estimates by the Department of Agriculture of this season's corn crop in the various States are given in the table that follows. Estimates by States for the 1936 corn crop are compared with the August indication in the short-crop year 1934, and with actual estimated production in the normal year 1935.

HONGKONG, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, military overlord of the Central Chinese Government, established headquarters today in the Whampoa Military Academy at Canton. He arrived in the Southwestern city last night to take a personal hand in subduing rebellious Kwangsi Province.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Two men were shot in a fresh outbreak of violence while leaders in the Remington-Rand strike prepared for a mass meeting to petition Governor Lehman to replace police guards at the plant with National Guardsmen.

MATTITUCK, L.I., Aug. 12. -- An inquest to determine the cause of the sudden death of Spencer S. Wickham, Mattituck weekly newspaper publisher, was adjourned here tonight by Coroner J. Mott Heath to enable William J. Lindsay, an investigator attached to the Suffolk County District Attorney's office, to continue his investigation. Dr. Heath announced the inquest would be resumed next Wednesday night.

Without making a direct appeal for votes, Senator Joseph T. Robinson, the party leader in his branch of Congress, has on his record easily won renomination from the Democrats of Arkansas and thus justified the political wisdom, at least, of his faithful championship of the New Deal.

DELLACH, Austria, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Alfonso of Spain, who left his throne in a bloodless rebellion five years ago, conferred with two of his sons tonight and was believed to be debating his chances of returning to power in the midst of the present civil war.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- A shake-up in the personnel of Dr. Francis E. Townsend's old-age pension organization was followed today by announcement of expansion of the Chicago headquarters of the movement and efforts to press a $1,000,000 accounting suit against the leader of the $200-a-month movement.

CANNES, France, Aug. 12. -- Denial of any political motives was made today by James Haislip of St. Louis, in whose airplane two Spanish Monarchists recently flew to Czechoslovakia to confer with former King Alfonso.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 12. -- By far the largest fleet that has gathered here in years came into the mouth of the Thames River this afternoon and tonight for the rendezvous of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise. Both in number and in tonnage it swelled the long stretch of anchorage on the west side of the harbor to the overflowing point in appearance.

Paul Kerby made his third appearance of the current season last night at the Lewisohn Stadium as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The English conductor was enthusiastically received by an assemblage of 5,000 persons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, tonight termed James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, the "blue pencil man" of the New Deal. In a speech, Mr. Hamilton declared that the retirement of Mr. Farley as Postmaster General on leave was a "most constructive step" and that with the "official censor" away from Washington "some real facts" are coming out in government reports.

I was very much impressed by the reported interview in this morning's TIMES with the leader of the Spanish Rebels, General Franco, in which he denies any Fascist aims, but rather declares his aim to be the establishing of a democratic government to "restore peace, justice and democracy, with favor to no one class."
Alterations in Manhattan and projects for new dwellings in Brooklyn featured plans filed in the city yesterday. Architects also submitted specifications for several homes in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Launchings scheduled for this month of three of the new warships being built to give the United States the strength permitted under present treaties have been postponed by continuing delays in naval construction.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A government "go ahead" signal for unlimited plantings of wheat and corn for 1937 was discussed by AAA officials today as the drought cut deeper into the current grain crops.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh got his first inspiration for the design of his now famous artificial heart and lung while he watched for the first time the throbbings and pulsations of the heart of a living animal under anesthesia at the research laboratories of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Pete Sivess, the Phillies' rookie pitcher from Dickinson College, weakened in the ninth today and the Boston Bees pushed over two runs for a 4-to-2 victory to sweep the three-game series. It was the Phils tenth straight defeat.

An upset price of $8,505,200 is recommended as the purchase figure for the collateral deposited for the $50,000,000 issue of debentures of Kreuger Toll in a report filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Murray H. Klinger, referee appointed to take testimony and report on that question, to protect the debenture holders.
A Federal appropriation to finance neighborhood and regional planning and to "develop an adequate national program of reconstruction" was proposed yesterday by the American Institute of Architects.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 12.--Walter D. Davis, the impresario whom the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin drafted to help him make good his boast that the first annual convention of his National Union for Social Justice would make the Republican convention "look like a sideshow," stirred a witches' broth here this afternoon by declaring that Dr. Francis E. Townsend and the Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith would harangue the convention "only over his dead body."

Boston, Mass. The city of Boston, Mass., asked bids for various issues of bonds, aggregating $6,260,000, award of which will be made on Aug. 20. The bonds will be dated Sept. 1, 1936, and will mature on Sept. 1, 1937 to 1966.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Charges by City Supervisor Robert C. O'Grady of faulty construction in connection with the $1,730,500 PWA beach reclamation project here resulted today in plans for an official investigation of Mr. O'Grady's complaint, made yesterday in a letter to City Treasurer August N. Gandia.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 12. -- Declaring that "your enemy and mine, the employer," would be the chief beneficiary of the controversy, should it continue, between the Committee for Industrial Organization and the American Federation of Labor, President William Green of the federation defended its course today at the convention of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance and the International Bartenders League.

Representatives of more than 300 trade unions will meet this evening at the headquarters of the American Labor party in the Hotel Claridge, Forty-fourth Street and Broadway, to plan the party's campaign in this State, the chief objective of which is to carry the State for President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Labor's Non-Partisan League asserted today that the Landon administration in Kansas was dominated by two leading interests, "the school book trust and the light and power trust."

The splendid isolation Greta Garbo has maintained may become considerably more isolated, if not more splendid, should portents noted by The Associated Press portend in the direction Hollywood believes they do. The direction is the South Seas.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 12. -- A birdie 4 on the first hole enabled Mrs. John S. Hess of the North Hempstead Golf Club to win the low gross prize in the Long Island Golf Association's women's one-day tournament today at the Lakeville Club.
ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Richard H. Depew and Beckwith Havens will observe tomorrow their twenty-fifth anniversary as airplane pilots. They are two of the world's oldest living pilots.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation came out yesterday with a bid to retain control of the world's heavyweight champion. James J. Johnston, boxing impresario for the Eighth Avenue arena, revealed that he had offered a fiat guarantee of $300,000 to the winner of next month's fight between James J. Braddock and Max Schmeling, to defend the championship under the auspices of the Garden in 1937.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12. -- Predictions that drought would provide an efficacious if two-edged means of reducing Canada's burdensome wheat surplus were fulfilled today when official statistics showed that the excess had fallen from 203,272,000 bushels at the end of the last crop year to 108,747,000 at the end of this one.

ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- A Moreland Act investigation of the State Tax Department, with special reference to gasoline tax refunds, has been going on under cover for ten days or more on the orders of Governor Lehman, The Knickerbocker Press states in a copyrighted article.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Federal authorities, raiding premises of a machinery concern here today, seized four alcohol stills they said had previously been taken up as illicit by State liquor agents but resold by the State Finance Department in good condition to dealers.

The La Follette Senate committee investigating labor spying, strike-breaking agencies and other interferences with the rights of labor began a nation-wide effort yesterday to determine the extent of such activities.

A new and enlarged bureau of commercial frauds for the city and a local ordinance controlling all retail stores which plan to liquidate, were advocated yesterday by James J. Wilson, Assistant District Attorney and chief of the Bureau of Rackets and Frauds of New York City, speaking before a luncheon meeting of the National Linen and Domestic Buyers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- All grain markets advanced sharply today as the result of short covering and some reinstating of lines that recently were sold out. There was no material pressure either here or abroad, and trade reports indicated that the recent sharp recession had improved the technical position considerably.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- La Salle Street interest in the doings of major stockholders of Middle West Corporation turned to speculation on whether or not the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is negotiating seriously for sale of its 5.2 per cent interest in the company, which rose out of the ruins of Samuel Insull's once mighty utility "empire."

Tolls collected on the interstate tunnel and bridge facilities of the Port of New York Authority in the first seven months of the year totaled $6,037,551, an increase of $389,269, or 6.9 per cent, over the corresponding period a year ago, according to a report issued yesterday by the Authority.

LENOX, Mass, Aug. 12. -- There was considerable entertaining today. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Martinet, who are at the Lenox Club, were the honored guests at a dinner given by Giraud Foster at Bellefontaine, Lenox.

Bus companies operating under city franchises carried 28,206,751 more riders in the quarter ended March 31, 1936, than they did during the first three months of 1935, according to a report made public yesterday by the Transit Commission. The gain in percentage was 41.43.

The Macmillan Company has been totaling up on the materials used in manufacturing its best seller, "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell. Some forty-five tons of board and 34,000 yards of cloth have been used in the physical make-up of these books, they find, and about twenty-four carloads of paper.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Phillips Petroleum Company of New York has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, under the Securities Act of 1933, covering 296,681 shares of no-par value common capital stock
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Wonders never seem to cease in golf, particularly in women's tournaments.

Jerome A. Jacobs, an attorney, and Harry S. Hechheimer, a former lawyer, denied yesterday in General Sessions, where they are on trial with Harry Derringer, a motion picture operator, on a charge of extortion, that they had ever shared in. money paid by Harry Bannister, theatrical producer.

A Chilean president and a Board of directors, of whom a majority will be Chileans, henceforth will administer the Chilean properties of the Electric Bond and Share Company, according to advices from Chile made public yesterday at the office of the company here.

A "sellers' market" in steel continues, with ingot production at 71 per cent of capacity, according to Iron Age. Steel sheet manufacturers could book orders for delivery in October, the magazine said yesterday, but they are declining such business because prices may be advanced further for the fourth quarter.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 12. -- Zane Grey recently warned Australia that if she did not exploit her tremendous asset in fisheries some one else would. He also predicted that fish could be made as valuable an asset as Australia's wool, pointing particularly to the possibilities of tuna fishing.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, still in the championship picture after more than twenty years of campaigning, will encounter Lee Wykoff, young St. Louis grappler, in the feature wrestling match on the card that will serve to open the New York Hippodrome as a sports arena tonight.
While the fishing season marches on to a climax, some of the shooting lads, with an eye to the rapidly approaching hunting campaign, are keeping in trim by stalking the wary woodchuck.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen to the Board of Water Supply, a life job which, however, pays a salary of $2,000 less than his present annual one of $12,000; the promotion of Leo J. McDermott, Mr. McGahen's assistant to the post of Budget Director and the promotion of Kenneth Dayton, an assistant to the Commissioner of Accounts, to Assistant Director of the Budget.

WASWHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- An expenditure of $2,481,000 for the improvement of New York Harbor to facilitate the movement of liners of the Queen Mary and Normandie type and $50,000 annually for maintenance was recommended today by Major Gen. Edward H. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Warning that the fight for pensions for widows and orphans of men who have died from causes not connected with war service was "aptly defined" as a foot in the door toward pensions for all, the National Press Club Post of the American Legion presented to the District of Columbia executive council last night a resolution calling for the abandonment of the program.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Rosalind, bay filly by Scotland-Alma Lee, won the eleventh Hambletonian Stake for 3-year-old trotters today before a brilliant crowd of 45,000 followers of the light-harness sport at the Good Time track.

Germany's action in prohibiting the use of "Aski-marks" and other forms of blocked accounts in financing her trade with America has been variously interpreted, as a reprisal against the American imposition of countervailing duties on imports from Germany held to be subsidized, and as an acknowledgment by Germany of the correctness of the American position.

The seven-story elevator building containing 136 rooms and two stores at 67-69 St. Nicholas Avenue, near West 114th Street, was sold by the Bulkley Estate to an investor represented by Bernhard Steinman, attorney. Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers, arranged the sale of the property, which is assessed for $105,000.
PARIS, Aug. 12. -- Hopes of a renewal of the Franco-Polish alliance, I

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Officials were confident today that American business men would respect the neutrality policy of the United States in regard to the civil war in Spain, and would not engage in any munitions traffic that would complicate the position of this country.
The Yanks finally caught up with Bucky Harris's Senators at the Stadium yesterday, turning back the enemy, 11 to 7, to salvage one game from the wreck of the three-game series.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 12.--Queena Mario, opera star, received an uncontested divorce today from Wilfred Pelletier at a private hearing before Judge T.F. Moran. She charged cruelty.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP).--After Wes Ferrell had driven in a 6-4 victory over the Philadelphia Athletics with a pair of successive home runs in today's opening game, the Red Sox failed to follow his batting lead and were shut out, 6 --0, by Harry Kelley in the nightcap.

With the hope of offering better plays, as well as encouraging American playwrights in their work, the WPA's Federal Theatre Project expects to begin next month a borough theatre system. In doing so it will change the make-up of the Municipal Theatre division, which now carries on scattered functions through some twenty units, and will work toward the creation of community theatres in the several boroughs.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12. -- Open charges today that Trotskyist elements still remaining in the Soviet Communist party have conspired with spies of a certain unnamed but easily guessed Fascist power provide an official explanation at last of the new clean-up now going on in the Communist ranks.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Northwoods tinder box, threatening a repetition of the 1918 holocaust, when damages amounted to $60,000,000, sent several forest fires out of control again today as State officials acted to arrest persons charged with starting blazes in the woods.

As the scene of action in the fifth annual World-Telegram hole-in-one golf tournament shifted to the sixth green at Grassy Sprain at Yonkers yesterday, the actual ace still eluded the hopeful aspirants and Dell Sharbutt's four-inch shot at Bayside two days ago remained the best among a total of 526 players, each of whom had five attempts.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 12. -- Government forces tonight defeated Rebels besieging San Sebastian and Irun as a prelude, Loyalist leaders said, to an offensive against General Emilio Mola's rear guard.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange today was in a generally cheerful atmosphere. British funds were quiet but steady. German securities strengthened in the foreign department because of the more hopeful European outlook as viewed by traders, and the Japanese list was higher.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Joseph Anderson, attorney for Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, said tonight that "the entire matter of a settlement" in Mary Astor's suit against her former husband for custody of their daughter Marilyn has been discussed, and "Miss Astor's attorney and I will submit it to Judge Knight in the morning."

BERLIN, Aug. 12.--The demand for passage on the Hindenburg has so far exceeded the accommodations that the Zeppelin Company is planning to install eight more cabins with accommodations for two passengers in each.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brewster Mack of New York arrived at the Mount Washington. Miss Nine Struthers came from a girls' camp to visit the Misses Bunnie and Sara Struthers, and their grandmother, Mrs. Max Grunder of New York, who are season guests there.

NICE, France, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Chance Vought, 9, and his younger brother, Peter, 8, both of New York, were injured seriously today when the automobile in which they were riding with their governess and a chauffeur was in collision with another car and plunged into a dry bed of the Var River.

A banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co. will offer to the public today a new issue of $16,000,000 of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company ten-year 4 per cent collateral trust notes, at par and accrued interest. Others of the offering syndicate include Lee Higginson Corporation, the First Boston Corporation, Brown, Harriman Co., Inc.; Mellon Securities Corporation. Blyth Co., Inc., and Lazard Freres Co., Inc.
TOLOSA, Spain, Aug. 12 (By Courier to Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port, France) . -- Fifty Loyalist defenders were killed as Spanish Rebel forces captured Tolosa yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission began suit yesterday in Federal court to restrain the A.M. Andrews Investment Corporation. Pirnie, Simons Co., Inc., and others from using the mails to sell stock of Dictograph Products. Inc.
