The commission charges that the defendants operated for the purpose of "creating a false and misleading appearance of active trading."

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 12. -- Asked by newspaper men to comment on the victory of Senator Borah in the Idaho primary election, where incomplete returns indicated the renomination of the veteran Senator by a vote of four to one, Governor Landon said today:

Influenced by reports of crop deterioration over a widening area west of the Mississippi as high temperatures and dry weather continued, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward more than $1 a bale yesterday to end with gains of 18 to 22 points.

Invitations were extended yesterday to thirty prominent citizens to form the nucleus of the permanent committee to assist the law-enforcement agencies in their fight against racketeering which is being set up as the result of a recommendation by the extraordinary grand jury that went out of existence last week.

A banking group composed of King, Crandall Latham, Inc., and Burr Co., Inc., will offer today by means of a prospectus 15,000 shares of common stock of the Sun Ray Drug Company at $16 a share and 10,000 units at $41 each, each unit to consist of one share of 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of $25 par value and one share of $1-par common stock.
OTTAWA, Aug. 12. -- Details of an Arctic wedding at which a Guelph (Ont.) nurse was married to an Anglican missionary came over the air today to the radio branch of the Marine Department.

The Eastman Kodak Company reported yesterday for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 13 a net profit of $8,081,870, including a $176,244 profit on sales of securities and after depreciation, reserve for Federal and foreign income taxes and other charges.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Hogs advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundred pounds today to the highest level since Sept. 27, 1935, with several lots changing hands at $11.40, or 15 cents above Tuesday's top price. The sudden drop in receipts at leading Western markets more than offset reports of a slow demand for fresh pork and brought in all interests as buyers.

Virtually all classes of listed bonds moved forward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, with a slightly smaller turnover. There was no let-up in the demand for United States Government long-term obligations as continued buying carried seven issues to new all-time records in fair volume.

Application to list securities of eight companies were approved yesterday by the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange. Two of the applications were for issues heretofore not traded on the exchange while six were for additional amounts of listed securities.
HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Elaine Barrie, 21-year-old actress, broke her "engagement" to John Barrymore today, but kept the veteran screen lover's 8 1/2-carat diamond ring.

Representatives of civic and cultural groups joined with business and financial leaders yesterday in honoring Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to the United States, on the eve of his departure for his new post in Moscow.

WARSAW, Poland, Aug. 12. -- General Marie Gustave Gamelin, Chief of the French General Staff, arrived here today to put the Franco-Polish military alliance to probably as severe a test as it has had in the fifteen years of its existence.

SHANGHAI, China, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Reinforced Japanese troops, it was reported here tonight, were poised for a fresh invasion of Suiyuan Province in Inner Mongolia -- adding new tension to the strained relations between Japan and China.
GRUNAU, Germany, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Don Hume, stroke of the American eight-oared crew, nearly collapsed after the last terrific drive in the trial race today.
A contrast between the baseball of the "horse and buggy" days of 1876 and that of the streamlined present is on the schedule for today at the Polo Grounds.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Miss Grace Harrington, postmistress at West Point, was notified today by the United States Civil Service Commission that her application to enter the open competitive examination for this position was disapproved because she failed to meet specific requirements as to residence.
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 12. -- Republican voters in the primary yesterday put William E. Borah once more into line for the Senatorship he has held for thirty years.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Skillful manoeuvring of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's Atlantic boat by Robert Kunhardt, a Greenwich High School junior, today enabled the home-club craft to capture the final race of the eighth annual junior invitation sailing series for the Commodore Robert Law Trophy.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Twenty-one primary contests for Congressional nominations and five for State Senate are revealed today in complete records at the office of the Secretary of State, involving candidates whose districts extend beyond county boundaries.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- After winning the Olympic gold medal in the springboard diving contest thirteen-year-old Marjorie Gestring of California gave an interview this evening -- a quite grownup interview which was broadcast by herself.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Five times within a stroke of defeat, Miss Helen Pedersen rallied to add another notable conquest to her long string for the season today in the Eastern grass court championships at the Westchester Country Club.

The Board of Education yesterday adopted its final tentative budget for 1937 amounting to $142,664,920, an increase of $5,575,863 over the budget allowed for this year. Of the total amount $88,350,857 will come from city funds and $54,314,063 from State and Federal funds.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- Holding their opponents to three points in the second half after a hard battle in the first, the American basketball team today conquered the Philippines, 58 -- 23, in the quarter-final round of the Olympic tournament.

An offer by Controller Frank J. Taylor to redeem $5,000,000 of an issue of 4 per cent city revenue notes failed yesterday to bring a single one of the $1,000 notes into the Finance Department offices. Mr. Taylor held that this gave further support to his contention that the city credit rating has been restored.
The Superior Portland Cement Company declared yesterday a dividend of 27 1/2 cents on the Class A preferred stock on account of accumulations. On July 1 the company paid a like amount.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The advisory group of the State Milk Control Board adjourned today after a four-hour session without indicating its decision on farmers' appeals for higher income from milk and increased retail prices.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- Nervous fluctuations on the Boerse today, despite the nominal turnover, led to a reaction that was almost as sharp as war yesterday's recovery. Declines of one to two points were frequent.

Thrills and suspense were piled one on another at Ebbets Field yesterday in one of the greatest Giant-Dodger battles staged in many a long day, a contest that wound its way through twelve innings and consumed three hours and five minutes before Colonel Bill Terry raced across the plate with what proved the winning run.

President Roosevelt's new activity belies Democratic optimism and constitutes a frantic attempt to stop the anti-New Deal tide, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern Landon manager, asserted yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. John W. Herbert 3d gave a large reception this afternoon at Chateaubrien, their home, for Mario Korbel, the sculptor, who is visiting Mrs. Philip Allain Cusachs at Hedgerows. During the afternoon the recently completed sculptured busts of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert's two young daughters, Joan and Joyce Herbert, were shown.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The Departmental Committee appointed by the British Government in March to investigate the so-called unit trust or fixed-trust movement, which in five years attracted about 50,000,000 of small investors' money, reported tonight that legislation should be enacted to give these investors the same general protection that they would receive under the existing law if they were direct holders of underlying securities.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Voters in every State of the nation were told today by officials of the Union Party that "in some manner" they would get an opportunity to vote for the third party ticket.

Crossing streets against lights continues to be the greatest menace to pedestrian safety, according to figures for the first seven months of the year released yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Exports in June, which are valued at $184,908,000, increased to all the grand divisions except Southern North America. They compared with $170,244,000 in June last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 12. -- Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas is arranging to leave here Aug. 28 to attend the September session of the League of Nations Assembly, which will take up the question of recognizing the Italian conquest of Ethiopia.

GENEVA, Aug. 12. -- A proposal was made today to finance by an individual tax the permanent world organization that the World Jewish Congress is meeting here to create. This was made in the commission that is drafting proposed statutes for the organization.

Contracts for the leasing of office, showroom and store space in buildings in the city and vicinity covered a wide area yesterday. The business leasing activity extended from Manhattan to Brooklyn and Jersey City.

Jack Medica lowered Olympic record to 4:44.5 in winning men's 400-meter free-style title, with Ralph Flanagan fourth. Miss Marjorie Gestring led American sweep in women's springboard diving finals as Miss Katherine Rawls and Mrs. Dorothy Poynton Hill placed second and third, respectively.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press. -- R.C. Matthews's Canadian cricket team suffered the first defeat of its English tour today at the Oval, famous London ground, when the Grasshoppers, a team of Surrey amateurs, scored a 57-run victory. The teams played twelve a side, the Grasshoppers making 203 runs against 146.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12. -- The pitching combination of Larry French and Clay Bryant held the St. Louis Cardinals to five hits today, but two of them were home runs that sent the Chicago Cubs down to second place in defeat, 5 to 3, as their rivals again moved to the top.
ANNISTON, Ala., Aug. 12 (AP). -- National Guardsmen were withdrawn today from Calhoun County where racial feeling flared after the shooting of three white men at a Negro house near here.
NEWPORT, N.Y., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Stanley A. Piseck, president of the New York Milk Producers Federation, Inc., said today:
MADRID, Aug. 12. -- The government, summarizing its position tonight, insisted that substantial gains were apparent in its campaign to put down the rebellion.

VIENNA, Aug. 12. -- A successful end to negotiations between Austrian and German delegations in Berlin concerning tourist traffic and trade regulations was announced tonight in a governmental communique.

TRENTON, Aug. 12. -- Monroe Township, where a family of four is reported to be living on $2 a week in food orders, has made no application to the State Financial Assistance Commission for aid, State Relief Director Arthur Mudd said today.

GENEVA, Aug. 12. -- The United States Government is contemplating inviting world powers to a textile conference which the governing body of the International Labor Organization is expected to convoke at its November session to meet in the United States.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Communities in Cumberland, Camden and Burlington Counties grappled with relief problems today in the face of dwindling funds for the care of their needy.

It cost a New York motorist $15 to kiss his wife as they were driving through Westport, Conn. His offense did not consist in fracturing the old Blue Laws of the New Haven Colony, but in violating the rules of the road.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The Western filly Floradora, counted on vainly by the Chicagoans to turn back Granville in the Arlington Classic, was first in the fifty-seventh Alabama today in a three-horse field. The daughter of Bull Dog won by four lengths, but Danny Brammer was knocking on her all the way down the stretch so that there would be no mischance in the victory.

GRUNAU, Germany, Aug. 12. -- Sprinting furiously in the last 200 yards in a superb display of controlled power, the unbeaten University of Washington Huskies overhauled Great Britain's Leander crew 150 yards from the finish on the Langersee this evening and won by 20 feet to place the United States on the threshold of its fifth consecutive Olympic eight-oared rowing championship.

Alice Duer Miller accepted yesterday the chairmanship of the authors' committee for re-election of President Roosevelt, it was announced by Miss Mary Dewson, women's director for the Democratic National Committee.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Vernon Kennedy pitched the Chicago White Sox to an 8-3 victory over the Browns today to account for his sixteenth triumph.

THERE may be a few sturdy survivors around who can go all the way back through the years as the National League puts on a Sixtieth Anniversary celebration at the Polo Grounds today. This observer, man and boy, could go back only about half way.
Gustave Eder, the German who holds the welterweight championship of Europe, stopped Jimmy Leto of Hartford in the ninth round of a ten-round bout at Ebbets Field last night.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- The biggest baseball crowd ever gathered in Europe or the United States saw the "world champions" play the "United States Olympic team" in the Olympic Stadium tonight. It was a demonstration game and drew 100,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Although the "timing" plan used in connection with the registration of $30,000,000 bonds by the New York Edison Company in June was successful, the Securities and Exchange Commission has decided that it is not to the best interest of the public to permit this program to be followed as a general rule.

Stock prices advanced on a broad front yesterday, led by steel and railway shares, with the coppers and various equipment groups and specialty issues not far behind. Alcohol shares were active and higher, particularly in the early trading, while the motor issues closed no better than irregularly higher.

From Chicago comes word that Republican national headquarters is considering a campaign plan described as "unique in the history of American politics." It would consist of using all the mechanics of modern salesmanship -- newspaper advertising and publicity, radio, billboard and motion picture -- to "humanize" the issue of taxes and the national budget, so that those voters who pay no direct Federal levies may be made "tax-conscious."

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 12. -- Seeking a week of relaxation before his first campaign trip East, Governor London arrived at Estes Park at noon today. He went at once to the McGraw ranch, where he Joined Mrs. Landon, their children, Nancy Jo and Jack, and his daughter, Peggy Anne Landon.

Salvatore Spitale, an intermediary in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, was sentenced to five days in the workhouse by Magistrate Wieboldt in Flushing court yesterday. He had pleaded guilty to a traffic violation charge after an adjournment had been granted until Aug. 20 on a vagrancy count.

ROME, Aug. 12. -- Postponement of the Locarno conference is regarded by Italian circles close to the government as necessary and almost certain as a consequence of the Spanish revolution. The date tentatively fixed was for some time in September but it is now thought that the five Locarno powers will not be ready to meet until a month later at the earliest.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Tommy Bridges gained his fourth straight victory over the Indians today as the Detroit Tigers won, 7 to 4.

A four-story office and storage building will be constructed at the southwest corner of McCarter Highway and Green Street, Newark, N. J., for the Westinghouse Electric Supply Company, 152 Mulberry Street, Newark, by the Balcom Realty Corporation of Philadelphia.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 12. -- Rain of the traditional Salzburg brand descended on festival visitors this morning when they picked their way under streaming umbrellas to the Festspielhaus for the first concert conducted this season by Arturo Toscanini.

A plan to appropriate more than $5,000,000 for new equipment for the Department of Sanitation has been worked out by Mayor La Guardia and Controller Taylor, the Mayor disclosed yesterday at the opening of the first of a series of eighteen section stations being built for the department by the Works Progress Administration.

The list of the French liner Ile de France, leaving today for Havre via Plymouth, includes the Duchess of Richelieu, Mme. Levesque, Professors Percy Chapman and Maurice Edgar Coindreau of Princeton, Dr. Pierre F. Brodin, Mr. and Mrs. George D. Wick, Dr. and Mrs. Peter C. Goldmark, Mr. and Mrs. Rollin H. Wilbur, Charles Lucet and Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Bachman.
BUFFALO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Aided by three home runs, Buffalo defeated Newark again tonight, 5 to 4. It was the Bisons' sixth consecutive victory. A crowd of 9,000 saw the game.
BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- America did it again today. For the fourth time the United States shut out the rest of the world and took all three medals in an Olympic event.
PARIS, Aug. 12. -- Action on the French proposal for neutrality in the Spanish civil war is waiting tonight on Germany's reply.

Asserting it was merely an interurban road rather than part of a general system of transportation, the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, operators of the Hudson tubes to Jersey City and Newark, sued United States Attorney Lamar Hardy yesterday in Federal court to prevent enforcement of the Railway Labor Act on the company.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 12. -- The second test match for the coming national open polo championship took place at Greentree Field on the Whitney estate today, with a fast moving Templeton quartet outriding Greentree, winners of the open last year, 11 to 8.
Two former Secretaries of State, Henry L. Stimson and Frank B. Kellogg, sailed for England yesterday afternoon on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. They were accompanied by their wives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Formal agreement between the United States and Argentina upon Dec. 1 as the date for the opening of the Pan American Peace Conference at Buenos Aires was announced today at the State Department.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Mrs. Ethel V. Mars, proprietor of the Milky Way Farms, again was the leading bidder at the yearling sales tonight when forty-five head passed under the hammer for a total of $115,000, or an average of about $2,555.

Officials of the Commodity Exchange Administration commenced yesterday a public hearing here to consider suggestions of administering the Commodity Exchange Act passed at the last session of Congress. It is understood that this will be the last of a series oil such hearings held by the order of the Secretary of Agriculture.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 11 (by Courier to Gibraltar). -- General Francisco Franco, the Rebel commander-in-chief, is preparing to launch an insurgent air fleet, including twenty newly received German Junker bombers, five German pursuit planes and seven Italian Caproni bombers, on Madrid in order to destroy the airdrome and the radio station in an attempt to bring the violent civil war to a quick close.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- A dinner was given by Mr. and Mrs. S. Griswold Flagg at the Rocks tonight.
BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- Four American boxers today joined Jackie Wilson of Cleveland in the quarterfinals of the Olympic boxing championships as Arthur Oliver, Chicago heavyweight, was eliminated.

The third Berkshire festival opens tonight at Holmwood, the estate of Mrs. Margaret Emerson, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass., with a concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky. Further programs by the same forces will be offered Saturday afternoon and Sunday night.

BERLIN, Aug. 12. -- The German answer to the French note proposing non-intervention in the Spanish civil war will be delayed until the Spanish Left government in Madrid has given a satisfactory reply to the German protests regarding the execution of four German nationals by a Spanish revolutionary tribunal in Barcelona, it was indicated in official quarters today.

The Republican candidate for Governor of New York, when nominated, must convince the people of the State that he has the courage to administer State affairs economically "instead of merely talking economically, as does Governor Lehman," Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers declared last night.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- A controversy between descendants of old Cold Spring Harbor whalers and the Village Improvement Society over establishing a whaling museum on the town dock here was ended at a public hearing before the Huntington Town Board today when the society withdrew its application for a lease on the dock.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 12. -- More than twenty two-man teams competed over a stretch of more than ten hours on the Lido Country Club's course today, but in the end there was no title decision in the Long Island Golf Association's amateur thirty-six-hole best-ball championship tourney.

The syndicate that a few months ago acquired the United States Electric Power Corporation's note to the Chase National Bank and promised to make the principal collateral available to the corporation's stockholders at the cost to them of the operation has carried out the plan by causing the offer to these stockholders of 1,239,096 Standard Power and Light common shares for an aggregate amount of $3,507,157, including transfer taxes.

A RED cloak and an old pamphlet -- these are the images that appear most frequently to the reader of Herbert Gorman's "The Mountain and the Plain" (Farrar Rinehart, $3). The cloak stands for action. Under its spread in this book will be found adventure in the old horse-and-pistol style. Weary horsemen outside a hostile city perform a daring ambuscade with the chances a thousand to one against them -- and win through.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The following New York firms were in a list of applications for registration of brokers and dealers made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission today:

Whether a theatrical license is required for a theatre where broadcasts are given which are attended by large invited audiences is to be decided in a suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the Dry Dock Savings Institution as owner of the New Amsterdam Theatre.

Round, firm spheres of snow soared over the parched soil of the Sears, Roebuck Co. parking space at Bedford Avenue and Beverly Road yesterday afternoon as 200 members of the Flatbush Boys Club engaged in the first Summer snowball fight ever staged in Brooklyn.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Much entertaining is in progress here on the eve of thei Travers, the midsummer derby, one of the richest features of the racing meet here, to be run on Saturday. Many guests are arriving daily.

Passenger traffic on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in July was "very good," H. S. Palmer, former president and a trustee in bankruutcy for the company, said yesterday. The New Haven is one of the railroads that are opposing in the courts the order of the Interstate Commerce Commission which caused fares to be reduced on June 1.

Tuesday was a cloudy day for the Townsendites. They lost in Arkansas and Idaho. Wednesday was sunny. In Florida they nominated a Democratic candidate for Senator who is the Doctor's disciple; and in Tennessee they seem to have won by the narrowest of squeaks the Democratic nomination for a successor to Speaker BYRNS.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

Bernard E. Hopper and John H. Savage will become general partners of Watling, Lerchen Hayes, Detroit investment brokers, on Sept. 1. Joseph H. Hayes on that date will retire as a general partner and will become a limited partner.

Commodity futures markets here were mixed in quiet trading yesterday. Coffee futures were easier and tin fell sharply. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, flour, cocoa, lard, cotton and wool tops were higher, while tin was down.

Fresh from a conference with President Roosevelt, James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, laughed yesterday a series of conferences with party leaders from every State. At his first talks he received encouraging reports from leaders in New England, North Carolina and Pennsylvania.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has sold to an investor the large apartment house at 1,236 Virginia Avenue, occupying the blockfront, between Newbold and Ellis Avenues. The six-story building, which is about seven years old, contains ninety-one suites and six stores. It is reported as fully rented.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- With his desk cleared of all pending business as a result of three days of intensive work, President Roosevelt is prepared to leave tomorrow morning for a quick tour through parts of Pennsylvania, Ohio and New York.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 12. -- General Manuel Goded and General Alvaro Fernandez Burriel paid the penalty for treason when, at 6:20 A.M. today, they were executed by a firing squad in the historic fortress of Montjuich, the scene of innumerable military executions.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas increased 10 per cent for the week ended Aug. 8, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The rise, which has been somewhat lower than that for recent weeks and indicates some slowing down in retail activity, compared with an increase of 12 per cent in the previous period.

This pleasant suburb has been my home for thirteen years. I have seen the saplings in its green gardens grow into trees and its children into young men and women. Now a shocking thing is happening. Instead of more garden apartments, the land has been sold to builders who are covering almost every foot of the sites they buy with the apartment houses they erect.

BOSTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Irving Trust Company of New York began a legal attempt today to obtain payment from the fortune left by John Hays Hammond, a mining engineer and inventor, of a debt of $1,838,755, representing part of a judgment obtained against one of Mr. Hammond's sons, Harris.

Captain Fritz Krone, master of the North German Lloyd liner Berlin, which arrived yesterday from Europe, issued a warning to bathers along the entire New England coast and the shores of Long Island to look out for man-eating sharks, which he had observed in great numbers.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 12. -- Winning a brilliant game from E.D. Bogoljubow of Germany, an expatriated Russian, Mikhail Botwinnik of Leningrad, Soviet chess champion, assumed the lead in the third round of the international chess masters tournament at University College today.

Heavy orders for machine tools resulting from Europe's preparation for war will keep the machine tool industry in this country at capacity for at least eighteen months, Charles Stilwell, vice president of the Warner Swasey Co., Cleveland, said yesterday on his arrival on the Ile de France.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The six-hit pitching of Bill Swift, who drove in the first two Pirate runs, featured Pittsburgh's 6-to-1 victory over Cincinnati today.

Senator BURKE of Nebraska, addressing a gathering of his fellow-Democrats at Omaha, startled them by avowing that on one important point he agreed with Governor LANDON. This is that the true hope of reducing unemployment lies not in Government public works or appropriations for relief but in the revival of industry.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $120,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $3,170,000,000, according to the weekly report of the Reserve System, issued yesterday. This was the last report that will be published before the increase of 50 per cent in reserve requirements becomes effective at the close of business tomorrow.

William E. Taylor makes a blanket indictment in his letter of the Republican platform and the acceptance speech of Governor Landon. I believe that criticism expressed in such general and sweeping terms loses most of its effectiveness. Had he singled out the plank on foreign relations, for instance, as an example of inefficacy and retrogression, I am sure there are many who would heartily concur with him.

The Polo Grounds on the banks of the Harlem was festive yesterday. League pennants flew with Old Glory from atop the Giant concrete and steel stands, boxes were gayly bedecked in bunting and where Mayor La Guardia sat leaning on the railing of his box the orange, white and blue of the city flag added to the color scheme.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -- The Presbyterian Church in the United States of America went into court today in an effort to prevent seceding militant Fundamentalists from using the name "Presbyterian Church of America."

James A. Farley, Democratic national chairman, received leaders yesterday from South Carolina, Kentucky, West Virginia, Minnesota, Tennessee and Delaware and were told that all these States would be in the Roosevelt column in November.

Reynolds Co. and Ames Emerich Co., Inc., will offer today by means of a prospectus an issue of 50,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent $50-par cumulative preferred stock of the Sunray Oil Corporation at $50 a share. The offering will be made subject to prior subscription by holders of the common stock of the corporation.

A southbound four-car passenger train of the Third Avenue elevated line of the I.R.T. telescoped a southbound five-car work train just north of Seventy-third Street at 10:10 o'clock last night, killing the motorman of the passenger train, painfully injuring nine passengers, five of whom were taken to hospitals, and causing bruises to several others.

EDMONTON, Alta., Aug. 13. -- Business men of Edmonton who have tried to block the issuance by Alberta's Social Credit Government of taxable "prosperity certificates" by appeals to King Edward and Prime Minister Mackenzie King accomplished their purpose temporarily and partly today by appealing to the courts.

CHELTENHAM, England, Aug. 13. -- A fortnight's meeting of the seventh New Education Fellowship Conference ended here this evening on a keynote struck by Mrs. Beatrice Ensor, who said that "the evolutionary process and time will force us to world fellowship, but achievement of this goal can best be hastened by educators."

The American International Corporation has reacquired 7,973 shares of its common stock, raising treasury holdings to 60,955 shares, according to a digest of the monthly reports to the New York Stock Exchange of the reacquired stock of listed corporations.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Governor Lehman has protested to the War Department, it was disclosed here today, that bombing practice by army airplanes is ruining the fishing in Gardiner's Bay off old Fort Tyler. A copy of the Governor's letter, which was sent to Secretary of War Dern on Aug. 5, was received yesterday by James H. Hildreth, Superintendent of the State Bureau of Marine Fisheries, who lives here.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- One hundred and fifty-eight members and guests of the New York Athletic Club took part in the Winged Foot organization's final one-day golf tournament of the season at the Tamarack Country Club today and at the close of the session, which began early in the morning and ended at sundown, Ray Billows, 1935 New York State amateur champion, held the major share of the laurels.

A protective committee for minority preferred stockholders of the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company has been organized, comprising Arthur Gwynne, Charles E. Kimball Jr., John Vanneck and Walter Breslay, with Vincil Harmon, 72 Wall Street, as secretary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The United States still has a substantial creditor balance in relation to United States investments abroad compared to foreigners' holdings in this country, exclusive of the war debts, according to a statement released today by Ernest G. Draper, Acting Secretary of Commerce.

Shipping men yesterday hailed the action of Major Gen. Edward H. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers, in recommending to the Senate Commerce Committee the deepening and widening of the Hudson River and the widening of the anchorages and of Ambrose Channel, as an aid to navigation.

Arthur J.W. Hilly, former Corporation Counsel, summing up yesterday for a father and a son, the first defendants in this district to be accused of being agents for the sale of Irish sweepstake tickets, criticized the Federal lottery laws.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- With the arrival of the New York Yacht Club fleet on its annual cruise this afternoon, former Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, who ad arrived in advance of the main fleet on the Winchester, was host at a dinner for Commodore W.A.W. Stewart and other flag officers of the club at Beaulieu.

The appointment of a committee of three members of the drug industry to promote the business relationship among wholesalers and retailers with manufacturers who have a sales policy that is profitable, "for the purpose of promoting their products in preference to all others," was recommended yesterday by Ira J. Shapiro, president of the Allied Wholesale Druggists Association, Inc.
Major Gen. William C. Rivers touched an interesting subject when he spoke of coordinating our national defense machinery in his letter published in THE TIMES of Aug. 5.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 13. -President Roosevelt tonight undertook a personal study of Pennsylvania and New York flood regions in order to acquaint himself with plans to combat a situation by which the streams in those areas periodically become torrents that sweep everything before them.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Although top heavy with Westchester contestants, the classy field of 112 entrants in the Green Meadow Golf Club's invitation tournament today was paced by Long Island's amateur champion, Charles H. Mayo Jr., who shot a 73 to take the qualifying medal.

ALBANY, Aug. 13. -- Investigation of the Gasoline Tax Refund Bureau of the State Tax Commission by Deputy Attorney General Joseph M. Mesnig, operating as a Moreland Act commissioner under appointment of Governor Lehman, went on today behind closed doors in the office of Attorney General Bennett.

Julian Wood, a deputy tax commissioner in the Bronx, was suspended from duty yesterday by Mayor La Guardia after an investigation by the Accounts Department had shown that Wood, in addition to his city job, worked as a full time employe of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad from 1924 to 1929.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 13. -John Hamilton, Republican national chairman, spent today in conferences, including one with Herbert Hoover, over the situation in California. At a breakfast in San Francisco he met county chairmen and party workers, and afterward drove to Palo Alto to meet Mr. Hoover in the former President's home.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Discovery that the human mind is equipped with a "governor" which recurrently "blocks" mental processes long enough to provide "enforced resting periods" when fatigue handicaps a brain worker, was announced today by the University of Chicago.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- Stilted high before a fine southwest breeze, with a large parachute spinnaker helping her along, the America's Cup defender Rainbow swept past Brenton Lightship off the harbor here this afternoon, the leader on the first run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, that from New London, Conn., a distance of 37 1/2 miles.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- British warships and steamships up to yesterday had evacuated from Spain 3,078 nationals of forty countries -- l,213 men, 1,395 women and 470 children. Of those, 542 men, 722 women and 208 children were British subjects -altogether 1,472.
LONDON, Aug. 13. -- Here is a picture of Europe as painted by Bernard M. Baruch after a six-week tour in an interview given to The Evening Standard tonight:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The legal and constitutional basis for the suspension order directed by the American Federation of Labor's executive council against the ten unions affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization in the event that the craft-industrial union dispute is thrown into the courts, was disclosed here today in a letter sent by President William Green to the heads of the dissident unions whose organizations comprise about one-third of the federation's membership.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, cool but courteous to his new-found allies in the third party movement, the Rev. Gerald L. K. Smith and Dr. Francis E. Townsend, claimed seven States for William Lemke and listed three others as "debatable" on his arrival here today for the convention of his National Union for Social Justice, opening tomorrow.

Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State from 1929 to 1933, has written a book explaining our problem in the Far East that Harper will publish in September. The title is, "The Far-Eastern Crisis." He describes, among other things, the delicate negotiations that led up to the formulation of the Stimson Doctrine, the policy to which the United States is still committed.

Princess Catherine Obolensky, estranged wife of a Russian prince, went to Yorkville Court yesterday morning to appear as complainant against a woman beggar and remained to appear in the same role against a bill collector.
GENEVA, Aug. 13. -- Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, summing up today before leaving her impressions of her first visit to the International Labor Office, told the writer:

A plan to honor "The Unknown German-American" in Madison Square Garden on Oct. 4 was announced yesterday by an executive committee arranging for the annual German Day celebration. According to the announcement, the presence of Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador, is assured.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 13 (AP). -- On the theory that nations will not fight if they really understand each other, two-score distinguished men placed on a council table tonight the overlapping problems of the countries bordering on the Pacific.
PEIPING, Aug. 13. -- A vast program of industrial development was pictured here today as Japan's justification for her interest in the far-flung territory of ancient China.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Aug. 13 (AP). -- Colonel Frank Knox told West Virginia Republicans here tonight that his aim for the future was "a real share-the-wealth development in this land."
PARIS, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- Secretary Roper sailed for the United States aboard the Washington tonight after a three weeks' trip through Britain and Germany. He was accompanied by William A. Julian, United States Treasurer, with whom he has been traveling.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has gone to the aid of the Brooklyn Public Library with a set of plans whereby the unfinished central building on Flatbush Avenue and Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn, may be completed at a cost of $2,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported a consolidated net income of $22,938,850 for the twelve months ended on June 30, after $1,999,000 provision for gas revenue in dispute, an increase of $4,785,419 over the preceding year, when $2,123,000 was provided for disputed gas revenues.
TOPEKA, Aug. 13. -- "The lowest tax levy and the lowest amount of tax charges against general property in Kansas for more than a decade" were announced today by the State Tax Commission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- In a drive against smuggling of narcotics Secretary Morgenthau today tranferred 570 men from the customs border patrols to the customs agency service and created four customs patrol districts with headquarters at Buffalo, Jacksonville, El Paso and Havre, Mont.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Swift Co.'s major holdings in public stockyard market companies were ordered sold today under provisions of the Packers' Consent Decree of 1920.

The preliminary statement of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiary companies for the first six months of this year shows a net profit of $5,827,425 after depreciation, and obsolescence, depletion, interest charges and Federal income taxes.

GENEVA, Aug. 13. -- The World Jewish Congress adopted eight resolutions by acclamation today and tonight covering the Palestine problem, the German boycott, emigration generally, anti-Semitism, the German Jewish question, refugees, relief and Soviet Russia.

THE TIMES correspondent, Mr. KLUCKHOHN, who reached Seville from Gibraltar a few days ago, had the opportunity to bring out for the first time in dispatches to America the exact truth about German and Italian bombing planes now at the disposal of the rebel leaders.

A pouring wind-whipped rainstorm early last night broke a day of muggy heat that seemed much hotter than the high of 88 degrees. Lightning struck several times in a brief but furious thunderstorm, but no serious damage was reported.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Sons of Teddy brought the principal prices in the sales ring tonight as thirty-nine head passed under the hammer for a total of $86,100 or an average of $2,208. This was one of the leanest averages so far this season.

An "indictment" of New York City's slums, noise, unemployment, accidents, few playgrounds and general poverty amid plenty was handed down yesterday by a "jury" of twenty seventh-grade pupils in the Summer demonstration school of Teachers College, Columbia University.
Health Commissioner John L. Rice urged Budget Director Rufus E. McGahen yesterday to grant the department $5,867,664 for the coming year, an increase of $1,483,273 over the 1936 allowance.

BENNINGTON, Vt.. Aug. 13. -- Doris Humphrey and Charles Weldman tonight presented two new dance compositions in extended form as the climax of the Bennington festival in the State Armory here. Both works have been composed as part of the annual workshop project of the Bennington School of the Dance, an autonomous unit of Bennington College, which sponsors the festival.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- A funereal quiet hung over the outdoor Trail Side Museum of the American Museum of Natural History at Bear Mountain Park this morning. The museum staff, from Director William Carr down, sorrowed, while even the various animals and birds in their cages seemed subdued.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Justice Jennings Bailey of the United States District Court today issued a temporary injunction ordering postoffice officials to impound mail sent to the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., of which Mrs. Oliver Harriman of New York is president.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 13. -- The North Pacific sockeye salmon, an orderly creature which never forgets its birthplace, apparently lost its way home this year, at the expense of American fishermen.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- The comeback campaign of Miss Alice Marble of Palm Springs, Calif., met with a stunning setback today on the turf courts of the Westchester Country Club.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Aug. 13. -- A justice of the peace was asked to serve as art critic in a suit brought here today by J.J. Muller, Manhattan portrait painter, against Mrs. Sadie Rich of this community. The suit, contested in Lawrence Court before Justice of the Peace Leslie J. Ekenberg, was for $200, which Muller declared Mrs. Rich owed him for a portrait of her that he painted in August, 1935.

Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley in Jamaica denied yesterday the request for an injunction sought by Joseph Lyttle, dog track operator, against Police Commissioner Valentine and the Queens authorities to restrain them from interfering with his methods of conducting the track.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- In a statement issued through the Republican National Committee tonight, Representative Bacon, Republican of New York, Eastern campaign manager for the Republican Congressional Committee, characterized the administration tax announcement as "a political gesture pure and simple."
The Conklings and the Blaines, Republican feudists of another generation, have got together at last, but now they are supporting a Democrat, President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Germany has informed the State Department in a note delivered by Ambassador Hans Luther that she has yielded to the insistence of the United States Treasury by lifting subsidies from her exports to this country.

LONDON, Aug. 13 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Felix M. Warburg, New York banker and philanthropist, today was named chairman of the American division of the executive committee of the Council for German Jewry .

Featuring a dramatization of the early history of the Statue of Liberty, the New York University Radio Workshop held its first commencement exercises over a nationwide hook-up of the Columbia Broadcasting System last night. The script was written by Gordon Hubbel, a student at the workshop and educational adviser to CCC camps in Buffalo.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- The Orangeburg Dog Track near here, which was closed last night by a police raid on charges of gambling, was reopened this evening under the protection of an injunction against police interference. A temporary stay was obtained this afternoon by Edwin Wiggins, counsel to the Associated Enterprises, Inc., of Paterson, N.J., operator of the track, from Henry Merritt, special Orange County judge, in Goshen.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- Germany's reply to the French proposal regarding non-intervention in the Spanish civil war has not yet been received at the Quai d'Orsay. The reason for the delay given by Berlin was that negotiations were under way with Madrid for the release of German commercial planes which had been requisitioned there.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 (AP). -- An agreement whereby little Marylyn Thorpe will live with her mother, Mary Astor, film actress, nine months of the year, and with her father, Dr. Franklyn Thorpe, the remaining three months, was approved today by Judge Goodwin J. Knight in Superior Court.

Walter L. Johnson, a partner in the firm of Shearson, Hammill Co., and president of the New York Cotton Exchange Clearing Association, Inc., who was the first speaker at the public hearings yesterday preliminary to the promulgation of general rules and regulations for the administration of the Commodity Exchange Act, urged that any proposed rules affecting the customer's situation be not extended to the clearing association.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 13. -- Defeating their respective opponents in the fourth round at University College, Mikhail Botwinnik of Russia and Dr. Max Euwe of The Netherlands, newly crowned world champion, today retained their places at the head of the list of fifteen competitors in the international chess masters tournament.

William Hutcheson, president of the International Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners and labor director of the Landon campaign, asserted yesterday that President Roosevelt was linked to the forces of John L. Lewis that are seeking industrial organization of workers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Mrs. Blanche Noyes of Irvington, N.J., was appointed today an air-marking pilot for the Bureau of Air Commerce by Eugene L. Vidal, the director. Mrs. Noyes has been flying since 1929 and was one of the first ten women pilots to receive an air transport license.

Railroads in the United States have no intention of quitting the field of transportation "despite the criticism that has been leveled at them," said John M. Fitzgerald, vice chairman of the committee on public relations of the Eastern railroads, at a luncheon yesterday of the Brooklyn Rotary Club at the Hotel Bossert.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 13. -- An audience of 5,000, including in its ranks not only persons musically and socially influential but individuals from every walk of life, attended the opening concert of the Berkshire Symphony Festival given this evening at Holmwood by Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits with the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government declined $621,176 and deposits by chartered banks fell $2,902,839 in the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Al Thomas checked the White Sox with seven hits today as the Browns pounded a 7-to-3 victory to take the three-game series, two games to one.

CLEVELAND , Aug. 13 (AP). -- Johnny Allen, Yankee pitching cast-off, limited the Tigers to four hits today as he hurled the Indians to an 8-0 triumph, his ninth straight victory and fourteenth of the season. Allen fanned six Tigers to take the league's strike-out lead with a total of 121.

A committee has been formed to prepare and submit a plan of reorganization for the United Cigar Stores Company of America, which also owns and controls the Whelan Drug Stores, according to an announcement yesterday. The properties for some time have been administered under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The navy, now engaged in almost doubling its aerial fighting strength to meet requirements of a treaty strength fleet to be achieved by 1942, moved today to cope with an increasing shortage of pilots.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Before Miss Grace Harrington, postmistress at West Point, can be supplanted, several important decisions must be made by officials in Washington, according to information obtained today from the Civil Service Commission.

NO drums at Pompton Lakes No firing off of cannons to indicate that the big show was about to start. No carnival, scene as Joe Louis emerged from his training quarters. Where there used to be signs and arrows indicating the way over the Jersey hills to the ringside, the distant trees and fence posts are now bare of invitations and helpful hints for tourists.

PERPIGNAN, France, Aug. 13. -The peril of poison gas attacks has now entered the Spanish civil war, according to a refugee, Fernando Padilla. The Rebel leader, General Francisco Franco, is said to have sufficient poison gas "to wipe out the entire population of Madrid."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Diplomats who are charged with informing their home governments of the trend of American policy are looking forward to the speech on foreign affairs that President Roosevelt will deliver tomorrow night at Chautauqua, N.Y.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday fell below those of the preceding week, but were above the totals of the corresponding week in 1935 for the first time in three weeks. The aggregate reported to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for twenty-two leading cities was $4,785,771,000, against $4,545,189,000 in the corresponding time last year, an increase of 5.3 per cent.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 13 (AP). -Counsel for the Southern Tenant Farmers Union said today that civil suits seeking damages for the alleged flogging last June of Miss Willie Sue Blagden, Memphis social worker, will be filed soon in Federal court at Jonesboro, Ark.

The International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries, excluding the International Hydro-Electric System and subsidiaries, reports a consolidated net profit of $665,217 for the second quarter of in contrast to a loss of $865,415 1936, in the 1935 period.

After boarding the outward bound Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary in a fruitless search for an alleged narcotics smuggler and causing the big liner to slow down as she slipped out of port Wednesday afternoon, Federal authorities located their quarry, Marie Wendt, 25-year-old Eurasian, that night as she was about to board the liner Deutschland at its pier here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Seeking to make the airways safer, the Bureau of Air Commerce will institute a wider system of aviation "traffic control" Saturday.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Bill Malcolm, pro at the Essex County Country Club, today won the New Jersey section of the World-Telegram's fifth annual hole-in-one tournament, when he placed one of his five tee shots 1 foot 8 1/2 inches from the cup.
BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- Two Cleveland boys, Lou Laurie, flyweight, and Jackie Wilson, bantamweight, remained tonight to fight for the United States in the semi-finals of the Olympic boxing tournament.
James R. Ullman steps forward this morning to announce a season of four plays. In order, they are:

Income derived from manufacturing amounted to $11,748,000,000 in 1935, according to preliminary figures announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Salaries and wages represent more than four-fifths of the income disbursed in manufacturing, the report stated, while dividends account for about 15 per cent, and other items, such as interest and rent, for only 5 per cent.

CERBERE, France, Aug. 13. -- A detachment of French Mobile Guards has arrived here to give more effective protection to the French side of the frontier against the influx of undesirable aliens, peseta smugglers and other dealers in contraband who take advantage of nightly fogs to pass themselves and their merchandise across the difficult mountain pass from one country to the other.
Auctioneers offered eight properties in Manhattan and two in the Bronx at foreclosure sales yesterday, when all ten parcels were bought in by the plaintiffs.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 13. -- A Rebel bombardment of San Sebastian from the air today led to a government threat to execute 700 Rightist hostages if the city were shelled from the sea.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP). -- Staging two amazing spurts after being six runs behind in the seventh, and three entering the last half of the ninth, the Bisons dashed on to a 10-9 triumph over the Newark Bears tonight to tie Rochester for first place in the International League.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- All Americans who had been isolated in Granada since the outbreak of the Spanish revolt were evacuated to Seville today, whence they will go to Cadiz and be taken on board the United States battleship Oklahoma tomorrow, the State Department was notified by Herbert O. Williams, consul at Gibraltar.

Mr. and Mrs. Lathrop C. Haynes were hosts at dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for their daughter, Miss Harriet Haynes, and Cyrus Hall Adams 3d, whose marriage will take place today in Christ Church, Bronxville.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 13. -- Evacuation of several northern Minnesota border settlers before an advancing Canadian forest fire came simultaneously tonight with a State command ordering Sheriffs of nine counties to close all secondary roads to regular traffic.

War bulletins from the Green-Lewis front make one realize, almost with a shock, how rapidly the English alphabet has been fading into the background. There are days when the most popular uppercase items in the news are Mr. GREEN'S A.F. of L. and Mr. LEWIS'S C.I.O. Of the famous monograms that once made up the staple of the day's reading only WPA is running well.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- A pretty blonde from the Netherlands succeeded a pretty brunette from New York as Olympic back-stroke champion today when Miss Dina Senff beat her countrywoman, Miss Rita Masternbroek, by a scant touch, with Miss Edith Mottridge of the United States a similar distance behind, and Miss Alice Bridges, another American, a like margin further back in fourth place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Food manufacturers and staff members of the Federal Trade Commission conferred today on the meaning and implications of provisions of the recently enacted Robinson-Patman bill, clarification of which was desired by the trades and industries affected.

Retail prices generally moved up during July, after remaining firm to slightly easier for several months, according to the Fairchild Publications Retail Price Index, which stood at 88.1 on Aug. 1. This shows an increase of 0.2 per cent above the previous month and 3.4 per cent above Aug. 1 a year ago.

The new screen fare due along Broadway today includes "His Brother's Wife," with Barbara Stanwyck and Robert Taylor, at the Capitol; "Charlie Chan at the Race Track," with Warner Oland, at the Roxy; "I'd Give My Life," adapted from Willard Mack's "The Noose,"
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

The share market worked irregularly higher yesterday most of the time, following a slow start, but encountered a wave of profit-taking in the last half hour that more than wiped out the earlier average gains. The net result was that THE NEW YORK TIMES average of twenty-five industrial issues and the combined average of railway and industrial shares suffered their widest declines of the month, amounting to 2.14 points and 1.19 points, respectively.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Saratoga's sylvan paddock, with its century-old trees and broad acres, today was the locale of burning feed-box tips for the twenty-fourth running of the Sanford Stakes, but once more the best horse won and left backers of will-of-the-wisps wondering how they could have been talked off the winner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Permission for the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to assume obligation and liability, jointly and severally, with the Delaware Hudson Company as guarantor for $1,093,000 of first improvement mortgage 3 per cent bonds, series A, of the Wilkes-Barre Connecting Railroad Company, was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Aug. 13 (AP). -Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, speaking at a party rally tonight, accused Governor Lehman of "willingness to let the people of New York State to pay in taxes the cost of New Deal experiments in other States."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- A $28,000,000 bond issue, of which all but about $1,000,000 will be used to absorb former offerings, was proposed to the Securities and Exchange Commission today in a registration statement from the Louisville Gas and Electric Company.
TOKYO, Aug. 13. -- Tamekichi Ota, who arrived from Moscow last night to retire from the diplomatic service, slyly ridiculed Japanese fears of a Russian attack.
A man calls up to ask: "Why is it that we couldn't get blues out of Shark River yesterday and another boat comes in with a big mess?"
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP). -- E.W. Duffy's Sir Jim James, paying $25 for $2, galloped to a head victory over Colonel E.R. Bradley's Bootless in the feature mile event at Washington Park today.
The Long Island Railroad has slipped a few jokers under the belt of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany Hall, is ill and has been confined to his Summer home at Belle Harbor, Queens, it became known last night. Mr. Dooling has been ordered to take a complete rest and no one is being allowed to consult him on political matters. He has been ill several weeks.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- George Lansbury, former leader of the Labor party, who recently returned from a peace mission to the United States, suggested tonight that President Roosevelt be asked to call world conference for the purpose of making the Briand-Kellogg pact effective.

GRUNAU, Germany, Aug. 13. -America demonstrated conclusively in today's rowing that it has nothing to offer in the Olympic finals tomorrow but the Washington eight and the single-sculler, Daniel Barrow Jr. of Philadelphia, who will probably make a three-way fight of it with Switzerland's E. Rufli and Germany's Gustav Schafer.

OWENSBORO, Ky., Aug. 13 (AP). -- More than a thousand persons, the vanguard of an expected crowd of 10,000, gathered tonight around the gallows where Rainey Bethea, a Negro, will drop to his death at sunrise for attacking a 70-year-old white woman.

Business in the wool goods market continues spotty, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday. A number of mills, having run out of orders for Fall merchandise, are beginning to curtail and do not expect to resume full time operations until next month at the earliest.

The Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices declined slightly during the week, dropping 0.2 point to 127.7 for Tuesday, Aug. 11. Lower prices for the grains except barley, and for bananas, butter and eggs, cotton and gasoline more than offset higher livestock and beef prices.
BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The United States and Canada today qualified for the final of the Olympic basketball tournament, America by beating Mexico, 25 -- 10, and Canada by thumping Poland, 42 -- 15.
BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The American field hockey players valiantly flung their sticks against the Afghanistan team today but lost, 3 to 0, in an Olympic consolation game.
BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- In these throngs of countless thousands, who has got the biggest kick out of the Olympics? It is a question that interests many observers.
The national ticket of the Socialist party, led by Norman Thomas, will poll about 3,000,000 votes in this election, in the opinion of George A. Nelson, candidate for Vice President.

Plans for a one-story and basement store building were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 301 to 305 East Fifty-eighth Street, northeast corner of Second Avenue, to the Phebe Construction Corporation, represented by Roy Berlin, attorney.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Many dinners were given in advance of the preview of the new motion picture, "Nine Days a Queen," with Cedric Hardwicke and Nova Pilbeam in the leading roles, which took place tonight at the Southampton Theatre for the benefit of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- No new taxes will be sought at the next session of Congress, administration fiscal policy framers announced after a conference with President Roosevelt today.

Two years ago this Summer the ill-fated M. BARTHOU paid a visit to Warsaw in the effort to mend French fences to the east, severely jolted by the German-Polish pact of Jan. 26, 1934. His reception was chilly and his proposal for a pact of mutual guarantees among the Powers of Eastern Europe was politely shelved.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- A number of British civil aircraft were flown today for delivery to purchasers in various parts of Spain and Portugal. The largest were two Fokker three-engine monoplanes, normally accommodating sixteen passengers, which left Croydon piloted respectively by Captain Neville Stack, famous long-distance airman, and Captain S.A.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- The Bank of France's virtually hereditary board of regents, representing "the 200 families" of the large stockholders, held its last meeting today. It disbanded after the meeting, and next Monday the bank's management will be taken over by a new council of twenty members, provided by the law voted recently by Parliament for "democratization of the bank."

Millinery and dress shops were prominent among lessees of store space, and lofts were taken by manufacturers of garments and clothing accessories, brokers reported yesterday. A floor in 695 Fifth Avenue was leased for Fall occupancy by Baroness Cacace, who will open a millinery and dress shop.
All departments of the money market remained quiet with quotations for all classifications unchanged.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- A bullish construction placed on the official Canadian estimate on the carryover of wheat in that country issued late on Wednesday was reflected in a good advance in prices today. Futures on the Board of Trade were 1 1/8 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel higher, while Winnipeg gained 1 1/2 to 2 1/8 cents.

A truly American institution, harness racing, reached its high point for the season when the filly Rosalind won the Hambletonian, the classic race for 3-year-old trotters during the course of the Grand Circuit meeting at Goshen, N.Y. The standard-bred trotting horse, of which the pacer is an offshoot, is like the Boston terrier in dogs, a purely native product.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- Trading was cheerful again today on the London Stock Exchange, although some profit-taking caused an irregular tendency in the session. British funds responded to investment buying. German securities maintained yesterday's gains in the foreign department and Spanish issues recovered somewhat.
Two-way radio telephone service for craft in New York Harbor and near-by waters will become available commercially next Thursday morning, the New York Telephone Company announced yesterday.

Overriding the protest of George J. Gillespie, president of the Board of Water Supply, the Municipal Civil Service Commission ruled yesterday, after a hearing, that thirty-three responsible positions in the water board must be placed under civil service.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers obtained yesterday the award of a total of $2,784,500 of general bonds of the city of Cleveland, Ohio, on a bid of 100.03 for $2,138,000 as 2 3/4 per cent unlimited tax bonds, and $646,500 as 2 1/2 per cent limited tax bonds.

The Very Rev. George E. Epp of Cleveland, Bishop of the Central Area of the Evangelical Church in America; Dr. Gustav Struve, secretary of the German Embassy in Washington, and Mrs. Struve; Mr. and Mrs. G.B. Darling Jr. and Captain and Mrs. Paul B. Kelly are among the passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the New York of the Hamburg-American Line.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Aug. 3. -Residents of this borough who strode out of the Borough Hall last night happy in the belief their opposition had shelved an ordinance proposed by the Board of Health prohibiting the sale and delivery of raw milk here, received an unexpected shock this evening.

BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP). -- One hundred thousand spectators, including Chancellor Adolf Hitler, witnessed a dazzling military spectacle presented by the German army, navy and air force tonight in the Olympic Stadium.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- The tax announcement by the administration in Washington received criticism tonight from the Republican National Committee.

ROSLYN, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Another in the series of test matches for the teams preparing for the national polo championship was played at Schiff Field in Roslyn early this evening. It concluded just before thunder shower fell and with Aurora, starting very fast, defeating the Hurricanes, 12 to 8.

United States Government bonds again were carried to the highest levels since their respective issues yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Although the turnover in Treasury obligations amounted to only $631,600, compared with $666,200 on Wednesday, the persistent demand lifted fourteen of the nineteen issues traded to new record highs.

SPEAKING of prophets, as we were only the other day, what about Ralph Bates and E.P. Dutton Co.? Mr. Bates has written a novel about Spain called "The Olive Field." Dutton releases it today ($2.50). Had author and publisher consulted the stars, or their own prophetic souls, they could hardly have hit upon a book better calculated to arouse interest.

Mrs. Emi Klamt and her daughter, Ada Verowa Klamt, filed an injunction suit in Federal court yesterday against James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, several other individuals and the American Natural Color Films, Inc., to restrain them from exercising ownership or control over an optical device for making photographs in natural tones.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Waite Hoyt, making his first start since an operation forced him to the sidelines in the early weeks of May, pitched seven-hit ball today as the Pirates defeated the Reds, 5 -- 4. The triumph gave the Pirates three out of four in the series.
John Timlin, Republican leader of Staten Island, announced yesterday his endorsement of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens for the Republican nomination for Governor.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 13. -- Senator Edward R. Burke announced today that he was seriously considering resigning his post as Democratic National Committeeman for Nebraska.

There is much propaganda going about in these days put forth by the Republicans and the Liberty League, and, sad to relate, some of our business men are becoming befuddled by it, but the farmers and the majority of us Southerners are still in possession of our common sense.
Brooklyn now has a ghost, too, and last night the police had to be summoned to disperse a crowd of nearly 1,000 persons who had assembled to look for it.

ALBANY, Aug. 13. -- An increase of 25 cents a hundred pounds for fluid milk to the producer was granted today by Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Agriculture. At the same time he indicated the possibility of another increase being granted later.

Soon Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State under Herbert Hoover, once Republican nominee for Governor of New York, will be whiffing the Caledonian moors and getting all the information he wants on United States happenings from the third of a column which is given to these daily by The Scotsman.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, five-time holder of the world wrestling championship, and Lee Wykoff of Columbus, Ohio, dedicated the New York Hippodrome as a sports arena last night by engaging in one of the strangest wrestling matches of the present sports era.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Greyhound, 4-year-old gray gelding by Guy Abbey and Elizabeth, winner of last year's Hambletonian Stake, trotted to a world record for three heats in winning the Progressive Stake today at the Good Time track.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Aug. 13. -- The Soviet newspapers' vigorous campaign against Finland in connection with the Finnish project for commercial landing fields in eastern parts of the country has drawn an exceedingly strong protest from the Finnish Government.

The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York was named residuary legatee of the estate of Mgr. John P. Chidwick, it was disclosed yesterday when the property was appraised at $44,058 gross and $39,132 net. Mgr. Chidwick was pastor of St. Agnes Church when he died Jan. 13, 1935, but was best known as the chaplain of the battleship Maine when it sank in Havana Harbor in February, 1898.

PEIPING, China, Aug. 13. -- Although Japanese authorities here and in Tientsin disclaim any official knowledge of conditions in East Suiyuan, they declare no Japanese reinforcements have been sent to that region.

Metal Textile has declared a dividend of 10 cents on the common, and a participating dividend of 10 cents on the preference stock. Dividends of 10 cents on the common toek were declared three and six months ago.

Mrs. Dorothy Poynton Hill, Los Angeles, won platform diving championship; Miss Velma Dunn, Los Angeles, was second; Miss Kaethe Koehler, Germany, third, and Miss Cornelia Gilisen, New York, fifth. Miss Dina Senff, Netherlands, won 100-meter back-stroke championship, with Miss Rita Mastenbroek, Netherlands, second; Miss Alice Bridges, Uxbridge, Mass., third, and Miss Edith Mottridge, Las Angeles, fourth.

The Follansbee Brothers Company filed yesterday in the Western District Federal Court of Pennsylvania a plan of reorganization under Section 77b of the National Bankruptcy Act, providing for the raising of more than $5,500,000 new capital through the sale of $4,500,000 new first mortgage convertible 5 per cent bonds and 70,000 shares of new common stock.

Three million dollars' worth -- at bootleg prices -- of marijuana weed, which is used in cigarette form as a narcotic, was burned in a vacant lot in Brooklyn yesterday in the presence of Police Commissioner Valentine, Captain Joseph Mooney of the narcotic squad, and other police officials.

REBEL HEADQUARTERS AT TORREMEJIA, Spain, Aug. 13. -General Francisco Franco's Foreign Legion and Moors are fighting their way through a raging hell of shots and sniping as they push on in an effort to take Badajoz, west of here and north of Merida, and to join General Emilio Mola's northern Rebel army.
Value of Dollar in Exchange The dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the dates indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Treasury officials said tonight the countervailing duties would be lifted as soon as possible after assurances were received that the German practice of extending bounties or premiums to exporters had been terminated.

No matter what more momentous things furrow the highbrows, the generous eye is now fixed tenderly and anxiously on Syracuse. That capital of the Onondagas has two Republican magnates, two Dromios. Mayor MARVIN and Senator FEARON can't both get the Republican nomination for Governor.
If anything further was needed to substantiate the charges made by Arthur Krock in his article on the Liberty League, that letter from Representative James W. Wadsworth supplies it.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 13 (AP). -- After having been forced to take refuge in a tunnel while three Spanish Rebel planes bombed a gasoline depot near by, Daniel Garcia-Mansilla, Argentine Ambassador to Spain, and Erik Wasin, the Swedish Minister, arrived here safely late today.
LONDON, Aug. 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Except for wool-tops futures, which were down slightly, and raw hides, which were irregular, gains were scored in all staples on the local commodity markets yesterday in fairly heavy trading. On the cash markets cotton, tin and wool-tops eased, while all the grains, flour, lard, sugar, cocoa, silk and rubber advanced.

In a letter to The Los Angeles Times, made public yesterday, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, further clarified his recent correspondence with Governor Landon concerning organized labor and denied that Governor Landon had fully answered him. Mr. Thomas's letter follows:

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Declaring that there was no "justifiable reason" for withholding payment to Jesse Howland Sons, Inc., contractors on the jetty and a bulkhead work under way here. City Treasurer August N. Gandia gave the concern today a check for $107,679.30.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 13, -- Miss Katherine Sylvester, the little radio singer who made herself famous yesterday by defeating two favorites, one of them the defending champion, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, got the gong today in the quarter-final round of the women's New York State championship at Mohawk.

Defense and prosecution rested yesterday in the trial in General Sessions of Jerome A. Jacobs, lawyer; Harry S. Hechheimer, resigned attorney, and Raymond Derringer, motion-picture operator, on extortion charges made by Harry Bannister, theatrical producer and former husband of Ann Harding, motion-picture actress.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, an increase of $6,000,000 compared with the preceding week and the same amount as reported for the corresponding week in 1935.

Police Commissioner Valentine congratulated Sergeant Thomas Martin and Detective John J. Quinn Jr. of the Homicide Squad yesterday on the part they played in obtaining the confession of Martin Moore, 22-year-old Negro held in Asheville, N.C., as the slayer of Miss Helen Clevenger, Staten Island girl.

Rate reductions that will save about $848,000 a year for consumers of electricity in Westchester County were ordered yesterday by the Public Service Commission to go into effect Sept. 1. The orders were directed to the Westchester Lighting Company and the Yonkers Electric Light and Power Company.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Prices for hogs advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight today to a new high level since last September, the top of $11.55 being 15 cents above that on Wednesday, but still 70 cents under the seven-year top established eleven months ago. The day's average was 20 cents higher, at $10.20.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The Franco-Polish staff talks in Warsaw apparently have provoked no perturbation in official quarters here. There is no inclination to invest them with implications suggesting a new orientation of Polish foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Secretary Wallace devoted his press conference today to contradiction of critics' assertions that the administration's farm policy, added to the effects of this year's drought, would result in a shortage of foodstuffs. He ascribed these claims to "amateurs'' who are going about the country scaring people.

While the volume of orders placedI by dry goods jobbers wa restricted this week, as had been expected, I wholesalers will be back in the mar-! ket within another two weeks toi replenish their Fall stocks, they in-I dicated here yesterday. The cotton crop estimate failed to affect the markets adversely and prices held very steady during the week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a new directory of all stocks eligible for trading on Exchanges as of June 30 last, beginning with Albany, Perforated Wrapper Company and ending with Zuma Mining Company.

The Giants celebrated the National League's sixtieth anniversary at the Polo Grounds yesterday in their own approved style. Before a crowd of 18,000 fans they hammered the forlorn Phillies into submission by a count of 6 to 4, advancing to a point two games back of the second-place Cubs and three behind the league-leading Cardinals.

The Guaranty Trust Company as trustee for the Chesapeake Corporation 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds, due in 1947, has notified the New York Stock Exchange that in July $1,119,000 of the bonds were canceled and 25,449 shares of common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company were withdrawn from the collateral pledged under the indenture.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The Boerse continued weak because, it was said, of the strained international situation. Prices became steadier near the close of the market and some specialties were able to show small gains, although losses of between one and two points predominated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The drought is currently reflected in rising prices of wholesale foodstuffs and increased prices on other commodities. The composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (based on the 1926 average) for the week ended on Aug. 8 was 81.1, the highest since November, 1930, when it was 81.3.

While the volume of orders placedI by dry goods jobbers wa restricted this week, as had been expected, I wholesalers will be back in the mar-! ket within another two weeks toi replenish their Fall stocks, they in-I dicated here yesterday. The cotton crop estimate failed to affect the markets adversely and prices held very steady during the week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a new directory of all stocks eligible for trading on Exchanges as of June 30 last, beginning with Albany, Perforated Wrapper Company and ending with Zuma Mining Company.

The Giants celebrated the National League's sixtieth anniversary at the Polo Grounds yesterday in their own approved style. Before a crowd of 18,000 fans they hammered the forlorn Phillies into submission by a count of 6 to 4, advancing to a point two games back of the second-place Cubs and three behind the league-leading Cardinals.
