The Guaranty Trust Company as trustee for the Chesapeake Corporation 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds, due in 1947, has notified the New York Stock Exchange that in July $1,119,000 of the bonds were canceled and 25,449 shares of common stock of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company were withdrawn from the collateral pledged under the indenture.

BERLIN, Aug. 13. -- The Boerse continued weak because, it was said, of the strained international situation. Prices became steadier near the close of the market and some specialties were able to show small gains, although losses of between one and two points predominated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The drought is currently reflected in rising prices of wholesale foodstuffs and increased prices on other commodities. The composite index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics (based on the 1926 average) for the week ended on Aug. 8 was 81.1, the highest since November, 1930, when it was 81.3.

A sharp increase in the number of house magazines from the low point reached in 1933 to the present was reported yesterday in a survey by the publications department of Blanchard Press, Inc. From a high of nearly 575 in 1929, the number of such house organs dropped to a low of 280 near the close of 1933.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Herbert Hoover termed the Republican Presidential campaign a fight to "turn destructive change into constructive progress," and National Chairman John D.M. Hamilton described Washington "royal economists" as enemies of America, in addresses prepared for a campaign rally here tonight.

The Spanish drama seems to be moving toward a tragic climax. The warning that our embassy in Madrid may have to be closed, and the notification to Americans who have taken shelter there that they remain in that city at their own risk, confirm the reports that the struggle has reached a desperate point.
The phenomenal achievements of Jesse Owens in the present Olympic Games have been the object of paeans of praise, and rightly so.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- With an all-time record of sixty-five new laws passed in a ten-week session, the French Parliament adjourned for the Summer vacation at 7:45 A.M. today. Its last sitting lasted, with interruptions, twenty-three hours.
BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- The United States basketball team won the first Olympic championship today on a court swept by wind and rain and deep in mud.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- A suit to collect $880,000 from thirty-two former directors and officials of the Foreman-State National Bank was filed in Federal court here today on behalf of Patrick J. Falvey, Glidden, Iowa, a stockholder of the Foreman institution, which was taken over by the First National Bank in 1931.
CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Following is the text of the address made here tonight by President Roosevelt:

The stock market closed lower yesterday, many of the leaders off a point or two, with a few of the more volatile issues down several points as profit-taking continued and a moderate amount of short-selling was indulged in. The saving factor was that the trading pace slackened materially on the decline. The turnover on the Stock Exchange aggregated 1,070,000 shares, compared with 1,398,000 the day before.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 14. -- Alison V. Armour of New York arrived at the Mount Washington Hotel on a motor tour of the mountains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Total wheat supplies in the United States were said today by the Department of Agriculture to be "large enough for the usual domestice requirements." In its midsummer wheat outlook, the department predicted that shortages in red spring and durum wheat would require continued imports of these types.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 14 (AP). -- A wind-fanned blaze threatening the whole of Isle Royale, Mich., and another near a settled region at McGrath, Minn., tonight clouded Northwoods Forest fire conditions, which generally were favorable after widespread rains.

LISBON, Portugal, Saturday, Aug. 15. -- Portuguese troops patroling the Spanish frontier fired on a group of Loyal Spanish militiamen who, the Portuguese said, were attempting to cross the border, it was announced early today.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora signed an order yesterday directing Walter T. Ott, industrial analyst, of 303 Fifth Avenue, and Francis J. Kelly, an employe in his organization, to appear in special term of the Supreme Court on Aug. 24 to explain the sale of stock to the public in a greyhound racing association known as the Nyack Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Another official reminder of the Tax Act of 1936 to business men went out from the Bureau of Internal Revenue today in the form of a long list of regulations relating to the computation and payment of the so-called "windfall tax" upon formerly impounded or unpaid agricultural processing taxes.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on June 30 a net income of $7,029,374 after charges, taxes, reserves, canceled leases, abandonments and dry holes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 49 cents a share on the 13,944,886 shares of common stock outstanding, exclusive of treasury shares.

Speeding up of the campaign for Governor Landon in the Eastern States is due next week, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern campaign director, said yesterday as he departed for Maine to participate in a rally there.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Richmond made public yesterday a plan to provide a rapid transit line between Staten Island and Manhattan, using the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad, the Bayonne Bridge, the Jersey Central Railroad and the Hudson Manhattan Railway tubes.

The largest audience of the season, numbering more than 16,000 persons, attended the postponed concert featuring Harold Bauer, pianist, and Albert Spalding, violinist, with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Willem van Hoogstraten, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium.
SEATTLE, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Police reported three persons beaten and five arrested today in disorders attending the strike of Newspaper Guild workers at the Post-Intelligencer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- For the second consecutive month since the lowered pasenger rates went into effect in the East, the Class I railroads in that section showed a substantial gain in passenger operating revenue over the same period last year, according to revised estimates for July made public by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- When Rainbow, the America's Cup defender of two years ago, came boiling over the finish line at Brenton Reef Lightship today, with Harold S. Vanderbilt at her helm, her owner-skipper won his seventh Astor Cup, an achievement no other yachtsman even has approached.

New life insurance production for the first seven months of 1936 was 4.3 per cent below the same period of last year, according to a report made yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.

James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, received confident predictions yesterday that President Roosevelt would carry Hew Hampshire and Georgia and was told also that the President had the best chance of any Democrat in many years to win in Delaware and Vermont.

For three innings yesterday at the Polo Grounds Claude Passeau, husky right-hander on the pitching staff of Jimmy Wilson, wouldn't let the Giants get as far as first base. But he slipped a cog then, found he couldn't keep the Terrymen off the paths, and finally drifted from the scene to make room for a pinch-hitter when the Giants had sealed the doom of the Phillies for their fourth straight.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Contrary to expectations, Miss Charlotte Glutting, the New Jersey champion and Curtis Cup player, will not be one of the finalists in the New York State women's championship final tomorrow.

GRUNAU, Germany, Aug. 14. -- The University of Washington shell leaped like a thing alive in the final ten strokes, broke away from the close pursuit of the Italian and German boats in the last lunge and won for the United States today its fifth consecutive Olympic eight-oared rowing championship.

GENEVA, Aug. 14. -- The World Jewish Congress adopted today the main principles of its organization on a permanent basis, empowering the executive committee, which is to be elected, to draft statutes and put them into force. It also voted a $75,000 budget to finance during the first year the work to which this session has committed the congress.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 14. -- The news of the alleged Trotskyist plot in Soviet Russia reached Oslo so late that the press barely had time to insert the Soviet communique.

IRUN, Spain, Aug. 14. -- In an effort to force the departure of the menacing Rebel cruiser, the Almirante Cervera, San Sebastian Loyalists seized scores of suspected Fascists today and threatened to execute them at the first shell of a sea offensive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- National banks, on June 30, held $8,447,364,000 in direct and fully guaranteed United States Government obligations and $1,824,660,000 in obligations; $1,824,660,000 being in turing after 1949, according to an announcement today by the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The United States Government today redoubled its efforts to induce Americans to leave war-torn Spain and to rescue those Americans trapped there by the bitter fighting between government and Rebel forces.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- A "complete reorganization" of the Police Bureau was declared today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson to be his aim as he issued orders for an enlargement of his headquarters squad, which at his request has been investigating vice and gambling conditions.

Charles F. Morgan of Jenks, Gwynne Co., who was the first speaker at the resumption of hearings yesterday preliminary to the promulgation of rules and regulations for the administration of the Commodity Exchange Act, said that "it is a law and will have to be lived up to" and that the administration has a difficult problem in its administration.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- Describing yesterday's attack on the battleship Jaime I, from information since received, Sir Percival Phillips cabled The Daily Telegraph tonight that the remarkable accuracy of the attack on the battleship and the weight of the bombs dropped [which are said to have been 625 pounds] show that General Francisco Franco no longer is dependent on old former commercial planes and pilots whose skill as bombers hitherto has not equaled their courage.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin said tonight his election bet with Frederick Jenckes of Providence, R.I., was off.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP). -- Frank N. Decker, lawyer-dairyman, in a speech at Syracuse today urged abolition of New York's Milk Control Law and called price increases granted to producers this week "altogether inadequate." He said the law guaranteed "a profit to the distributor at the expense of the producer and consumer, either or both."

As an old-time baseball scribe whose knowledge of the game harks back to the halcyon days of Jim Mutrie's Giants, when Buck Ewing, Roger Connor, Tim Keefe, Mickey Welsh, Johnny Ward and other stars dominated the baseball firmament, permit me the privilege of answering Ike Falk's inquiry in your columns, "Has there been an ambidextrous pitcher in the major leagues in the last sixty years?"

In the Nebraska Democratic primary last Spring former Representative TERRY CARPENTER, to the general surprise, was nominated for Senator. He takes to eccentric notions like a duck to water. Among many other titles of honor he has been called the Milo Reno of Nebraska.

Reams of inanity have been prevalent in the press recently as a result of the failure of Reichsfuehrer Hitler to greet and congratulate Jesse Owens for his Olympic triumphs. Writers who previously had never mentioned fair play and the Negro in the same columns jumped on the band-wagon for a short ride in the reflected glare of the publicity that sought out this unusual athlete.

Jimmy Williams, 14 year old Brooklyn boy, who wrote to Mayor La Guardia a few weeks ago asking for a better home for his family, is going to live in a Brooklyn house with a yard and plenty of space for his pigeons.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- Adolph Kiefer, 18-year-old Chicago boy, took his place in the Olympic hall of fame today, winning the 100-meter backstroke from a field of great swimmers with the ease and nonchalance that are the rare privilege of only the greatest athletes.

Continued improvement in conditions during July brought the national business index 4 per cent nearer normal, or to a point only 10 per cent below normal, according to the monthly survey of 147 trading areas of the United States, released yesterday by the research division of Brooke, Smith French, Inc.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 14. -- This city, which has been engaging in a "tax strike" and withholding tax funds from the State because the unemployment relief burden was turned back to the municipalities, received a check for $46,491 today from Arthur Mudd, chairman of the State Municipal Financial Assistance Commission.

ANAMOSA, Iowa, Aug. 14. -- Johnny McGrath shook off the memory of twenty-five months in the State Reformatory today and turned to that job promised by the friend who got him out, James J. Braddock, heavyweight boxing champion.

A jury will hear the $47.80 suit brought against the New York Central Railroad by Philip Davis, attorney, who charged that he had to stand on a train from Albany to New York on July 12. Justice Isidor Buxbaum decided yesterday afternoon, after a hearing in the Ninth District Municipal Court, that the case should go to trial to determine the facts at issue.

Governor Lehman in Albany notified District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan in Brooklyn yesterday to appear at the executive chambers on Aug. 26 to defend himself at a public hearing of the special Drukman grand jury's charges seeking Mr. Geoghan's removal from office.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan and Silas Strawn of Chicago scoffed today at promises of the Roosevelt administration that taxes may be reduced and that no new taxes are probable.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Mass executions of prisoners and slaughter by incendiary airplane bombs were stories of horror told by refugees from Spain.
It seems to me that the people of this country have more than a casual interest in what is now happening in Spain. Civil war in Spain is a threat to democracy all over the world.

Ten charities received a large part of the estate of Jane Noyes Smith, who died May 22, 1935, the appraisal showed yesterday, when the value was fixed at $168,375 gross and $156,646 net. The bulk of the estate was in securities worth $151.597.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Judge Goodwin J. Knight of the Superior Court termed his patience "practically exhausted" today as he declared the Astor-Thorpe child custody case closed and threatened George S. Kaufman with a jail term.

Borrowing by railroads for the third consecutive period led all other major groups in the volume of new bond financing, the marketing of $16,000,000 of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad (Nickel Plate) on Thursday lifting the total of new bond financing for this week to $29,523,500.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A plan for farm relief designed to bring about greater stability of farmers' income and prevent violent fluctuations in consumer food prices is being shaped by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration for presentation to the next session of Congress.

Most commodity futures declined yesterday under the weight of profit-taking. Trading was not heavy. Copper, hides, wool top and tallow futures moved against the trend. On the cash markets silk advanced and all the grains, cotton, rubber, tin, antimony and cocoa declined.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- A round of festivities is in progress here on the eve of the running of the midsummer Derby, the Travers, at the race course tomorrow.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 14. -- Three army fliers were killed when their two-motored bomber on a practice flight crashed into a corn field and burned near New Kent Court House, thirty-five miles from this city, late last night. A fourth leaped to safety in a parachute.

Twelve men who were qualified to act as jurors because none of them ever had bought a lottery ticket, deliberated five hours yesterday and brought in a verdict of guilty against a father and son, accused in Federal court of being agents for the sale of Irish Sweepstake tickets.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Countervailing duties on imports from Germany to the United States were removed today in a formal order issued by the Treasury Department.

Outstanding athletes from all sectors of the country as well as several from Canada will converge upon Randalls Island today and tomorrow for the first World Labor Athletic Carnival. Numerous record holders and champions of varying rank are among those who will compete in the twenty-three open events.

A monumental amphitheatre with the stage set in a lagoon and including an indoor auditorium, promenade and space for exhibits was suggested yesterday by Park Commissioner Moses as an appropriate display of the State at the World's Fair in Flushing Meadows.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The Cubs advanced within half a game of the league-leading but idle Cardinals today by trimming the Reds, 7 to 5, in the first of a four-game series. The game was played in a steady drizzle before 1,380 paying fans.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Competing against twenty-seven entries, Imp Bartender, owned by Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Mayer of Port Chester, N.Y., won the open jumpers' class in the seventh annual Lake Placid Horse Show today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- A study, which may lead to important changes in the Federal tax structure at the next session of Congress, was undertaken today by Congressional experts under administration orders.

Selling pressure from spot quarters against the moving crop and from European sources attributed to the conditions in Spain caused a decline of $1 a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. The market felt the weight of contracts from the start and ended around the bottom.
With the Giants out of the way, the Dodgers yesterday went back to their winning habit by trouncing Bill McKechnie's Bees, 4--2, in a regulation nine-inning game and before fewer than 1,500 fans.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- A new high price since September, 1935, was paid for hogs today, with load lots bringing $11.60 a hundred weight, or 5 cents above the best figure of the previous day, and small lots brought $11.65. Light lights were 15 to 25 cents higher, but the general market was little better than yesterday, the average price showing no change at $10.25.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices In New York City:

The Rev. Roy A. Welker of the Congregational Church at Bay Shore, L.I., will present greetings from the more than 6,000 churches of the National Council of Congregational and Christian Churches tomorrow morning at Pioneer Park in Walla Walls, Wash.

The letter of Bishop Oldham "Why More Battleships?" would be an excellent letter, if it were simply interrogatory, and did not contain sentences such as "Here lies the most dangerous and sinister of suggestions" -- referring to Admiral Standley's statement that this country needs battleships to match Britain's.

As part of its 1937 sales program the Cadillac Motor Car Company yesterday leased large space for showrooms in the former Rolls-Royce Building at 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. The new quarters, consisting of the store, basement, mezzanine and second floor, will more than quadruple the space occupied by Cadillac in 10 East Fifty-seventh Street and will be used as a regular branch for sales and show purposes.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Triumphantly through the first two rounds into the semi-final of the annual Green Meadow Golf Club invitation tournament today swept four of New York's leading linksmen, three of them present champions and one an ex-titleholder.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Urgent instructions were sent by the State Department today to Charles A. Bay, United States Consul at Seville, Spain, to make most emphatic representations looking to the safety and rescue of J.C. Ambler of San Antonio, an American citizen who is a member of the staff of the Rio Tinto Mining Corporation and who is reported held as a hostage in the Huelva Mines by Spanish Communists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The 500,000 members of the United Mine Workers of America were asked by their International Executive Board to contribute at least $1 each to a campaign fund for the re-election of President Roosevelt in a circular to be published in tomorrow's issue of The United Mine Workers Journal.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14. -- The famous old steam engine 999, which in 1893 set a world's speed record for locomotives which has never been beaten, came to the rescue of President Roosevelt's special train here today.

Investigations conducted by Columbia University and the University of Chicago show "startling deficiencies in our literacy." It is declared that 50 per cent of our country's adult population "is unable to read with ease." This must be a good deal of a guess with a measure of such variableness.

A finding by officials of the Interstate Commerce Commission that the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad requires $1,435,000 to $4,294,000 for rehabilitation is expected in informed circles to provide an obstacle to speedy reorganization of the company. The company has been in bankruptcy since April, 1933.

Using house paint as a medium, biscuit tins for palettes and youthful fancy for design, three boys have just completed their first joint mural in the play yard of the Gramercy Boys Club, 535 East Sixteenth Street.

The question whether the right of appeal may be denied an impoverished man because he is unable to pay for a court record was presented to the Federal Court of Appeals yesterday by Gene McCann, stock broker, who last March lost a $45,000,000 suit against the Stock Exchange and about 600 other defendants.

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 14. -- Invitations were sent out today to party leaders and candidates in States through which Governor Landon will travel on his trip to the East and return to join the Presidential candidate on the train for a series of conferences.

The motorman who was killed in the crash was blamed yesterday by the Transit Commission for the Third Avenue elevated line wreck Thursday night in which a southbound four-car passenger train ran into a five-car work train north of Seventy-third Street. Nine persons were injured when the two wooden trains came together.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 14. -- Bronislaw Huberman, the violinist, has resigned from the teaching staff of the Vienna State Academy in order to devote himself more fully to the new symphony orchestra he is founding in Palestine, the first concerts of which will probably be conducted by Arturo Toscanini.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Holding that the New Jersey relief situation was placing the State in a bad light and that municipalities could not carry the burden placed upon them, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of this city requested today a special session of the Legislature to raise funds for relief.
What good is a beautiful and impressive Triborough Bridge if the motorist cannot find his way to it or off it without a compass and maps?

BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Backed by lusty hitting and air-tight support, Bob Grove today hurled the Red Sox to a 9-0 triumph over the Senators to score his fourteenth pitching victory and his sixth shutout of the season.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Mrs. William Hockenjos of Lake Hopatcong, women's New Jersey Golf Association champion, annexed another of that organization's one-day events at the Hackensack Golf Club today when she went around in 84, seven strokes better than the gross total of her nearest rival, Mrs. A.J. Stump of Crestmont.

A.E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, in his reply to the charge of the Liberty League that the President is doing everything in his power to socialize the electric power industry, points out that the tendency in some European countries is toward public ownership and that therefore the same tendency is to be expected here.

TRENTON, Aug. 14. -- Denial was made today by Ralph Sickler. chairman of the Monroe Township committee, that Thomas Eriksen, 11 years old, of Williamstown, N.J., died of starvation, as had been reported to State Relief Director Arthur Mudd.

A promising proposal made by the retiring Extraordinary Grand Jury has now moved beyond the range of theory and become a fact. On the basis of firsthand experience with organized "racketeering" in this city, the grand jury recommended that a permanent committee of representative citizens be appointed for the purpose of supplementing the efforts of the regularly constituted authorities in dealing with this major problem.
The film feature opening today at the Globe is "Shakedown" with Lew Ayres and Joan Perry. To the Cine-Roma comes "The Serpent's Fang," an Italian mystery film with English subtitles.

The Rev. Gerald L.K. Smith, on the eve of his departure for the convention of Father Coughlin's Union for Social Justice in Cleveland yesterday, declared that the fact that the radio priest would not tour the country with him and Dr. Townsend should not in any way be interpreted as a repudiation of anything or anybody.

Counsel for both sides summed up yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Jerome A. Jacobs, lawyer; Harry S. Hechheimer, former lawyer, and Raymond Derringer on charges of extortion and attempted extortion. One indictment alleges they extorted $1,800 in December, 1934, from Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, the motion picture actress, and the second charges they attempted to extort another $1,000 from him later.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The story of staggering losses sustained by Chain and General Equities Inc., an investment trust company acquired by the Equity Corporation of New York in December, 1932, was disclosed today by the Securities and Exchange Commission at a public hearing in its investigation of investment trusts and investment companies.

June consumption of apparel-class wool increased materially and was well above the normal level, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers pointed out in its statistical study released yesterday. For the six-month period ended June 30 the amount of wool entering into the production of clothing, blankets and other wool products was 6 per cent less than in the corresponding period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Names of forty-four underwriters who will handle a $100,000,000 debenture issue for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation were revealed when the corporation today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement.

A communication from EMMA GOLDMAN on the editorial page of The Herald Tribune day before yesterday sums up vividly, if in miniature, the painful moral dilemma which the civil war in Spain provides on a large scale for lovers of freedom everywhere.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby threw practically every one but the batboy into the game today, but the Browns failed to overcome a formidable Cleveland lead and lost to the Indians, 12 to 10.
BETHANY BEACH, Del., Aug. 14. -- Frank Knox says that whatever the Democrats may do about a dirty campaign he isn't going to be dirty, because a man can't throw dirt without having his hands in dirt,

Messrs. Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera "The Pirates of Penzance" was staged under difficulties yesterday afternoon in East Broadway in which little East Side buccaneers pranced about a stage the size of an elevator and sang in brogue above the noise of trucks and children in the street.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., came from behind to defeat Frank Parker today in the semi-final round of the Eastern grass court championship at the Westchester Country Club.

A moisture-laden southeast wind blowing in from the ocean yesterday brought humidity as high as 95 per cent and discomfort to the city's residents. The average temperature for the day, 80 degrees, was only 6 above normal, although it seemed much more to persons in the street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The contract for the construction of the superstructure of the Ten Eyck buildings in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was awarded today by the Housing Division of the PWA to Starrett Brothers Eken of New York City with a bid of $7,556,400.

The Hotel Ansonia, built in 1904 by W.E.D. Stokes as one of New York's largest residential hotels, soon will undergo a change which real estate men consider is significant and indicative of improving conditions in this type of property.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- Mrs. Olga Jensch-Jordan, who placed fifth in the women's springboard diving, demonstrated to the crowd that a lady athlete can also be a good mother. This earned her a round of applause.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 14. -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, arriving here today, predicted that a bolt of lifelong Democrats from the Roosevelt New Deal policies would produce some surprising results.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Encouraging reports on increased home financing together with an attack on the high taxes on real estate marked the executives' meeting of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the Mohawk Valley Country Club near here today.

The engagement of an additional $2,355,000 gold in Paris for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, lifting to $11,055,000 the total of gold engagements in the current flow from France. In addition $840,000 gold was engaged in India to be sent here.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- A departmental committee of experts representing the Foreign Office, the Board of Trade and the Air Ministry was set up today to consider the desirability of preventing the export of British commercial planes to Spain and to devise a method for such an embargo.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14. -- The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, who has frequently been termed a rabble rouser, turned to what he described as "intellect rousing" today when he expounded his economic credo to 11,000 of his followers, meeting in the first session of their first national convention.

Led by the proposed sale of $45,000,000 of State of Pennsylvania notes, the volume of new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to $66,405,485, the largest total of such bond offerings for a week to date this year. These operations will be represented by two States and thirty-nine municipalities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Jamestown Telephone Corporation of Jamestown, N.Y., has been ordered by the Federal Communication Commission to reply within thirty days to questionnaires previously sent to and hitherto ignored by it or to justify its failure to do so, in writing, with the alternative of defending at a public hearing its contention that it is not subject to the jurisdiction of the commission.

The bond market relinquished yesterday much of the buoyancy that had characterized the previous two days and gave way to reactionary tendencies, which were most pronounced among the convertible and more sensitive domestic corporation issues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Ann Cooper Hewitt, taking the witness stand in a surprise move against two physicians accused of mayhem conspiracy, testified today that she was tricked into submitting to the operation by which she was sterilized.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Permission to intervene in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company's reorganization proceedings was granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to a committee representing the Mutual Savings Bank group, with Myron F. Converse as chairman.

Among those unfamiliar with conditions in Spain, there naturally prevails a certain confusion with regard to the present situation in that unfortunate country. But the importance of events in Spain to the world at large is so great that it is imperative for every thinking person to have a clear grasp of the factors involved.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries report a consolidated net income of $12,945,118 for the year ended on June 30, equal, after preferred dividends, to 51 cents a share on the common stock, compared with $9,957,310, or 26 cents a share, for the preceding year.

ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- Two appointments to the State Planning Council were announced today by Governor Lehman. Dr. Carl E. Ladd was named chairman to succeed Provost A.R. Mann, resigned. Dr. Ladd is dean of the State College of Agriculture at Ithaca and head of the Governor's agricultural advisory committee.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- In a cozy room in a cottage on a sunny hillside Jack Sharkey faced his opponent and, raising his big fist, he said sharply: "Take that!" It was the king of clubs and his opponent was stout John Buckley, the manager of the heavyweight herbalist. Mr. Buckley was tastefully adorned in a dark blue shirt and white flannel trousers, plus suspenders.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14. -- An enthusiastic and cordial welcome was given to President Roosevelt today when he visited this city for four hours to drive through its principal thoroughfares, inspect two major WPA projects and see the Great Lakes Exposition.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- Had a Rip Van Winkle or any one else slightly out of touch with things dropped into the sweltering stands of Shibe Park today he would have had extreme difficulty deciding which of the teams disporting under the broiling sun was making a spread of the American League pennant race.

Passengers sailing today for Europe on the French liner Paris include Frederick P. Close. justice of the Supreme Court of New York; James Dempsey, Nathaniel Spear Jr., the Rev. George Johnson, Dr. Robert T. Phillips, David Gordon, Mr. and Mrs. E.M. Crone, Alfred Beckman, Bernard Sobel, Robert A. Young and David Corcoran.

The recently expanded statistical service of the Interstate Commerce Commission informed investors yesterday that estimates filed by companies which produce 94 per cent of Eastern railroad revenue disclosed an average gain of 19.4 per cent in passenger traffic earnings in July, compared with July, 1935.
OWENSBORO, Ky., Aug. 14 (AP). -- Ten thousand white persons, some jeering and others festive, saw a prayerful black man put to death today on Daviess County's "pit and gallows."

ROCHESTER, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Three delegates to a hotel workers' and bartenders convention here, and a woman bystander, were wounded by a fusillade of bullets tonight as they emerged from a downtown restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Restrictions on shooting of migratory game birds "equally as rigid and drastic as those in force last season," were announced today by the Biological Survey and simultaneously proclaimed by President Roosevelt.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Highwayman, the Chestnut Peter colt owned by Dr. S.F. Bullis of Nassau and driven by John Broderick, won the 2-year-old trot, feature of the getaway Grand Circuit program at Good Time Park today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- A $10,000,000 seed purchase program to help farmers whose grain for next season's planting was destroyed by drought was framed today by administration officials.
KEANSBURG. N.J., Aug. 14. -- Nearly 200 children were led to safety tonight from a fire which destroyed a motion picture theatre at East Keansburg, near here.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 14. -- Calling the political and military activities in Spain a clear-cut class struggle of the workers against their capitalist enemies, the executive council of the Socialist party here today issued an appeal for funds and sympathy to aid the Spanish Government.

The New York City Tunnel Authority has adopted a final plan for the midtown vehicular tunnel under the East River and is sending it to the War Department for approval, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- Contracts for more than 700,000 yards of textiles for the Army clothing factory, on which bids were opened here Aug. 6 under invitation 37-10, were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot today, including the following items:

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The charge that a "suggestion" had been made that he be replaced by a Catholic has been made by Lamont F. Hodge, Superintendent of Schools of Yonkers, it was disclosed today.

Copper prices abroad again established a new high level yesterday for the current movement, when the metal sold at the equivalent of 9.75 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base ports, or 2 1/2 points above the high on Thursday. In the domestic market the price was unchanged at 9.75 cents a pound.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 14. -- The French passenger steamer Eubee and the British cargo steamer Corinaldo collided in a fog early this morning off Cape Mostardas, 106 miles north of Rio Grando do Sul, Brazil. The Eubee's 200 passengers and 36 of the crew were safely transferred to the Corinaldo, which is standing by the disabled passenger vessel until the arrival of aid.

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Two young men in repentent moods after observing injured and dying auto victims in nearby hospitals informed Police Judge Louis Eugene Tepp in village court tonight that they would hereafter obey traffic laws.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday at the Summer City Hall that his ideas of economic adjustment could not be put into effect nationally before seven to ten years had elapsed. Discussing the report of the Governor's commission as a permanent State policy, the Mayor said:
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 14. -- A policeman was killed and five other persons were injured here today when two ambulances crashed at Jefferson Avenue and East Jersey Street.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 14 (AP). -- The Omaha Western League Baseball Park was destroyed, a dozen dwellings were burned and at least sixteen persons were injured in a fire of undetermined origin which broke out at the park early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Social Security Board celebrated its first birthday today with its officers apparently in a mood of quiet gratification over the results accomplished. Although the Social Security Act became law by President Roosevelt's signature a year ago today, the board did not receive any Congressional appropriation to start its activities until Feb. 11.

MOSCOW, Aug. 14. -- The Soviet Government charged tonight that its former War Commissar and revolutionary zealot, Leon Trotsky, sought to foster a rebellion from his Norway exile. The government jailed ten of his asserted colleagues and indicted, besides these, six persons already in prison.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Forest fires have taken one life, possibly two, and sent two persons to a hospital severely burned, as they raged unabated tonight in British Columbia, Alberta and Northern Ontario.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- With the approval of President Roosevelt, $4,228,377 has been allocated for flood reconstruction work in Pennsylvania, Maine, Massachusetts and West Virginia, to be expended largely in the replacement and repair of bridges damaged by last Spring's floods.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 14. -- The close race for highest honors between Dr. Max Euwe of The Netherlands and Mikhail Botwinnik, Soviet champion, in the international chess masters tournament at University College today, switched slightly in favor of the world champion, who notched his fourth straight victory at the expense of C.H.D. Alexander of London.

Economy in the wrong place is, if anything, more wasteful than unnecessary spending. A case in point may be found in the budget of the Tenement House Department. Between 1931 and 1936 successive retrenchments cut it from more than $1,500,000 to less than $900,000.

Greater protection for port facilities worth hundreds of millions of dollars will result from the new Federal regulations for the construction and operation of tank ships carrying inflammable liquids in bulk, according to Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- Jackie Wilson, Negro bantamweight from Cleveland, qualified tonight for the finals of the Olympic boxing tournament by beating Ortiz of Mexico as Lou Laurie of Cleveland, the other American survivor in the semi-finals, was eliminated from the flyweight division by Matta of Italy.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 14. -Loyalist militia of the Popular Front continued their gains on the Basque coast today. Airplanes and artillery cooperated well and drove the Rebels from several mountain positions.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14. -- A subscription dance was held at the Lenox Club tonight. Many of the 200 present were visitors who have arrived for the marriage tomorrow of Miss Elizabeth Lanier Fenno to Samuel Adams Clark.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- Higher cables from Liverpool gave the wheat market a firm start today but there was not the snap to the buying which has characterized trading of late, and it took but relatively little pressure to start prices downward.

The WPA's Negro Theatre, which has attracted considerable attention by offering such programs as "Macbeth," is now the sole property of Harlem. From its inception until yesterday, John Houseman had been its active head, but from now on a board of three Negroes will be responsible for the selection of plays and their production at the Lafayette Theatre.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 14. -- Former Judge Clarence L. Cole of this city, counsel for Mrs. Eva Fox, wife of the former motion picture capitalist, filed today with Robert Steedle, Federal referee, his answer to the petition of Hiram Steelman, trustee in the William Fox bankruptcy, to have the books of the All-Continent Corporation turned over to him for examination.

Dr. Lin Yutang, author of "My Country and My People," is coming to America in the early Fall to spend a year here, writing and lecturing. The ninth printing of his book, Reynal Hitchcock report, has come from the press.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 14. -- Spanish Rebel leaders are willing to make peace only on the unconditional surrender of the Madrid government, it was reported on good authority, after preliminary conferences on this subject here. Rebel leaders said they believed Germany and Italy were willing to back them in the international field on this point if a showdown should come.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Increased reserve requirements for the Federal Reserve System's member banks, amounting to about 50 per cent and announced by the Reserve Board on July 14, will become effective after the close of business tomorrow.

A new floor show went on last night at Ben Marden's Riviera, that spot being on the far side of the George Washington Bridge. Benay Venuta, radio and musical comedy singer -- it was she who followed Ethel Merman in the cast of "Anything Goes" -- is the main attraction.

THE similarity between revolutionary France and Fascist Italy may not be very great, but it is great enough to permit this morning's column to embrace both G.J. Renier's "Robespierre" (Appleton-Century, $1.50) and David Darrah's "Hail Caesar" (Hale, Cushman Flint, $2.50). In fact, Dr. Renier's little book about the French leader is as wine to Mr. Darrah's cake.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 14. -- Although fiercely attacked throughout the day, Badajoz had not yet fallen into the hands of the Spanish Insurgents, according to the latest information received here. General Francisco Franco claims only to have occupied the lower quarter of the town and to be fighting his way to the center, which he bombed intensively with high explosives and propaganda.

While trying to avert a misunderstanding with the Park Department, which had frequent clashes with the WPA during the administrations of General Hugh S. Johnson and Victor F. Ridder, Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator, found time yesterday to make a report on the large flow of building trades and construction workers from WPA rolls into private industry.

Beset by illness and threatened with a real drive against his leadership, Tammany Chieftain James J. Dooling faced a new attack yesterday as various Tammany groups sought creation of a steering committee to direct the current primary campaign for the organization.

A railroad flagman who for more than twenty years has waved red flags by day and a red lantern by night to warn persons on the busy West Side of the approach of oncoming railroad trains was killed yesterday in an automobile accident traceable in part to an old city requirement.

Most intelligent people have reasons for at least some of their actions and these reasons can seldom, if ever, be reached on a basis of pure introspection. Therefore it would seem rather unreasonable to tell the citizen who bolts his doors at night or who, in times of disorder, buys a revolver, that he has ceased to be his own master, since these procedures are "dictated from without.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Granville, son of Gallant Fox, moves into the graveyard of favorites tomorrow, when he will defend his championship as best of the 3-year-olds in the sixty-seventh Travers. This is the oldest race run in this country and through its long history form has taken a beating.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 14. -- Vigorously denouncing war and those nations which raise the threat of it by "violating with impunity" their treaties and pledges, President Roosevelt set forth his foreign policy tonight as one based on the maintenance of peace and neutrality regardless of any pressure that might be exerted abroad or at home.

MADRID, Aug. 14. -- Continuing its policy of detaining those suspected of Fascist sympathies, the Leftist government today arrested General Garcia Antunez, former Minister of the Interior, and a number of others.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Complaints that Toronto dealers were subjected to unfair competition by companies started on credits from United States concerns were voiced at today's hearing of the Royal Commission's investigation of conditions in the anthracite coal industry in the Dominion.

In many parts of the city neighborhoods are taking on the appearance of desolation due to the many buildings that have been abandoned by the owners and in which the mortgagees are unable or unwilling to invest additional money. There is no remedy in sight, unless the problem is treated in a common sense manner.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- The newly formed democratized council of the Bank of France, at its first meeting Tuesday to assume the administrative control relinquished yesterday by the bank's hereditary regents, will put into operation a new plan of administration and set the date for the annual assembly to take place late in September.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- A new problem confronted the Foreign Office today in the case of thirty-seven British nationals and one American being detained at the Rio Tinto Mines, where all are employed as mining officials and experts.

Architects filed plans yesterday for making changes in several Manhattan buildings. The bulk of the alteration work will be done in tenement houses, although the largest change involves an expenditure of $75,000 in fitting up a Forty-second Street structure for a restaurant and billiard parlor.

GRUNAU, Germany, Aug. 14 (AP). -- The victory of Washington's eight today ended a regatta marked otherwise by Germany's unprecedented achievement in capturing five successive finals, thereby rowing off with the team title for the first time in Olympic history.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- John Jacob Astor and Mrs. Astor entertained at a party today at Chetwode in honor of his twenty-fourth birthday. Mr. Astor's aunt, Mrs. Lorillard Spencer, was present, as were Mrs. Astor's mother, Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr., and Mr. Banks, and Mrs. Astor's sister, Miss Virginia Middleton French and a number of friends.

High temperatures in many sections of the country this week, which caught retailers short of Summer goods, caused a slackening in consumer buying, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Few cities reported an increase in distribution for the week, compared with the previous week, and at some centres the decline amounted to 3 to 5 per cent, the agency states.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S address at Chautauqua last evening was on a high level of statesmanship and moral fervor. Devoted exclusively to foreign relations and the maintenance of peace, it was a measured utterance which should have a great effect in this country and should carry a weighty message across the seas.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- The Olympic basketball tournament ended tonight with an American victory over Canada by 19 -- 8. As a result the United State became the gold medalist and Canada automatically the silver medalist. Mexico took the bronze from Poland with a 26-12 triumph in a match played Just before the final.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Consuls of the United States and Polish Governments made representations to the Palestine Government today regarding the safety of their nationals in the city of Safed.

A dispatch from the News Bureau of Nova Scotia, official agency of the provincial government, reports the capture yesterday in Liverpool Harbor of a 788-pound tuna by Dr. J.R. Brinkley of Del Rio, Texas.

THIS little book is presented as an "informal" guide to New York, and it is both a useful and interesting one. Starting from Rockefeller Center, which she describes excellently, the author sets out with her brother on a tour of the city.

IT is no easy matter to classify this new story of Mr. Laing's. It deals with a mystery and a most baffling one, but it is not in the least like the conventional mystery yarn. The central figure is a British ship's doctor attached to a steamer plying between England and India.

Retail trade improved last week in this area after dipping in the previous period. Stores estimated the average increase at 15 to 18 per cent over a year ago. For the half month the gain should be around 12 per cent. Furniture and fur promotions continued to draw the most active consumer response.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 15. -- Allegations that the Tennessee Valley Authority was building its $29,000,000 Chickamauga Dam not to promote national defense or for flood control, but for the "primary purpose of producing electricity for the purposes of sale and profit," are contained in an answer to a property condemnation suit to be filed in the Federal district court Monday.

KIRKLAND LAKE, Ont., Aug. 15. -- Tons of rock crashing down on a slope in the huge Lake Shore Mine today brought death to three miners at this town, 150 miles north of North Bay in Ontario's gold belt.

WHEN Tuskegee Institute in Alabama announced recently that it was going to train Negro cooks in the Southern culinary tradition and, with the endorsement of the American Hotel Association, in general dietetics as well, a question was raised which always stirs up regional rivalry among American epicures.

THIS is the story of a young man who broke away from "sealed pattern," and who found zest for his mind and satisfaction for his spirit in the world that lay just outside. The pattern was that of the young English army officer in India.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Mae Scheible, who jumped a $10,000 bond after conviction in a New York trial at which she was pictured as "$100,000-a-year vice queen," was captured by justice agents today at Murphy, Calif., in the Mother Lode mining region.

HERE, in a capsule, Dr. I.S. Falk gives the definition of health insurance. In over 400 pages of carefully considered material, he elaborates the idea on the basis of past experience of other nations and future possibilities for the United States.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. -- As in previous seasons, a number of events in behalf of philanthropic undertakings have been planned for the late Summer, as well as several outstanding musical and artistic projects. Especially have exhibitions of paintings, etchings and sketches by Southampton artists been included in the program.

RICHMOND, Aug. 15. -- Fifth District retailers apparently are headed for the biggest year in their business since 1929. Cumulative sales for the year are running 10 per cent above the figures in the first seven months of 1935 and no letdown is in evidence for almost half of August.

DR. DMITRY N. BORODIN calls our attention to Lyssenko, member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and apostle of "yarovization." In English "yarovization" means "vernalization," or bringing about the condition of Springtime.

EVERY generation of Spaniards in the last hundred and thirty years has experienced a war or a revolution. They have all been lost wars; all -- except the one that made this republic, whose future is uncertain -- defeated revolutions. Each one has been worse than the one before, working toward the present terrifying climax. And as the climax approached, the prophetic upheavals have come closer and closer together.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Intention to complete the Works Progress Administration's 506 airport projects in 438 localities was announced today by Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator. The estimated cost is $71,540,999, of which the WPA is to supply $40,690,290, the remaining funds being furnished by local sponsors.
WHAT ship's that?" hailed an officer from the poop of His Majesty's double-decker Serapis on the evening of the 24th of September, 1779.

SAARBRUECKEN. -- One year and a half after the Saar plebiscite this territory no longer enjoys its position as a somewhat spoiled international corner of Western Europe, but is compelled to share all the restrictions, hardships and sacrifices nowadays demanded in Germany.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H, -- Music lovers in the White Mountains are going to Whitefield today for the fifth concert in the White Mountain music festival series for the benefit of the Morrison Hospital at Whitefield. Paul Althouse is to give a song recital, with Theodore Haig at the piano.

Five women fliers, it was revealed yesterday, have been leading a drive for "air-marking" the communities of the United States. The program is now 58 per cent complete. When it is finished, which probably will be in a few months, there will be a roof-top marker every fifteen miles in any direction over the entire nation.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Eighty yachts sailed in the annual invitation regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach off the Speonk Shore today. While it was the largest fleet that has sailed so far this Summer on Moriches Bay, it was seven boats under last year's record fleet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Despite a slackening in automobile production and steel-mill activity, manufactures, in the aggregate, sustained early this month the rate that obtained in July, the Department of Commerce reported today. Automobile production declined, with the closing of-assembly lines for change over to new models.

The Gdynia-America liner Pilsudski will call at Quebec and Montreal next month, carrying the Polish flag to those ports for the first time in its post-war history. The ship will sail from New York Sept. 15, proceeding along the St. Lawrence to dock at Quebec early the morning of Sept. 19 and at Montreal later the same day.

Supine indifference by the people of New York City to depredations of organized criminals has been transformed suddenly into a stern racket-consciousness. This transition, effected after a year of revelations by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, has brought into existence a voluntary body of prominent citizens organized into what may be regarded as a civic vigilante committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- American farmers received $462,000,000 more for products marketed during the first six months this year than in the like period last year.

THE Berkshire Festival being held at Holmwood, Mrs. Margaret Emerson's estate, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass., will close tonight with the last of three concerts presented by Serge Koussevitzky and his Boston Symphony Orchestra.
HENDAYE, France, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Uncensored advices from Madrid today portrayed the Spanish capital in fear of a new reign of terror should it be taken by the Rebels.

Consumer response to August coat sales has been 10 per cent better than a year ago in the first two weeks of these events, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., announced yesterday, following a telegraphic canvass of stores holding fur-trimmed coat sales.

OXFORD, Md., Aug. 15 (AP). -- A nip-and-tuck battle between two of Maryland's foremost Star Class skippers left W. Mason Shehan Jr. of Easton, with a 3-point lead tonight in the race for the Lipton Trophy, one of two outstanding prizes offered at the sixth annual Tred Avon Yacht Club regatta.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Wraith, black pacing gelding owned and driven by William H. Lockwood of Brooklyn, and Catherine Nelson, trotting mare owned and driven by Dr. John Young of Montclair, turned in the outstanding performances of the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- A storybook horse raced to a brilliant victory in the $5,000 added Prairie State Stakes at Washington Park today, when Orientalist, claimed by Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago for $5,000 at Arlington Park a month ago, scored by a length.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- A taxpayers' division has been organized by the Republican National Committee to compile and disseminate facts concerning the increase of taxes, direct and indirect, under the New Deal.

MORE and more frequently orators in the Presidential campaign have been emphasizing their stand in educational matters. The most conspicuous recent instance is that of Governor Curley of Massachusetts, who pledged that his first official act if he is elected to the United States Senate will be to start a movement to give military training to the boys of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Will the greatest naval construction race in history start on Jan. 1, 1937? That question is drawing keen discussion in the capitals of all first-class powers. Today the answer appears to he "yes." The London Naval Limitation Treaty of 1930 ceases to apply at midnight of Dec. 31 and immediately each signatory will be free to build as many warships as it pleases -- or can afford.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15. -- Connie Mack, patriarch pilot of the Athletics, made a startling discovery today. For years old Connie has been waving his famous score card, wigwagging his players here, there and everywhere, in the manner of a person dusting off his desk.

THERE are several distinctive things about this tense, very modern novel. It is a story of New Zealand -- by no means a common setting; it is wholly concerned with love in its most romantic and idealistic sense; the circumstances of the relationship which it describes are unusual, even extraordinary.

BOSTON, Aug. 15. -- Retail trade in New England is running 5 to 10 per cent ahead of a year ago, a somewhat smaller gain than has characterized recent weeks. The extreme heat has been a factor in causing a slight deceleration of the rate of improvement.

PARIS. -- Haile Selassie, Emperor of Ethiopia, when he passed through Paris to and from Geneva as a voluntary exile, was greeted officially and aroused general public sympathy. It is not known whether he will ultimately take up residence in French territory, but if he does he will be but following the precedents set by the long line of African sovereigns who have been ousted from their kingdoms by European nations.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 14. -- Georgia presents the anomalous spectacle of preparing to vote overwhelmingly for the New Deal in the November election after having given what may be a decisive vote in the September primary to the severest critic of the administration now vocal in the nation.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Pirates set back the league-leading Cardinals, 7 to 1, today with a seventh-inning uprising that netted five runs and broke up a tight hurling duel between Big Jim Weaver and the veteran Jess Haines.

FORT SILL, Okla., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Carlton B. Chilton, who walked away from the Granite, Okla., reformatory twenty-three years ago while serving a two-year sentence for bank theft, faced return from Cleveland tonight, after Governor E.W. Marland refused his plea for clemency.

The Independent Coalition of American Women, a non-partisan anti-New Deal organization, will start a movement on Thursday to organize Greater New York against the Roosevelt administration. A meeting to arrange the campaign be held that day at national coalition headquarters, 485 Madison Avenue.

SHANGHAI -- The great improvement in the economic status of North China and the vast betterment of the living conditions of the people, which the Japanese Army so confidently prophesied would be accomplished with the occupation and cooperation of Japan's North China army, have so far failed to materialize.

THE vast richness of the English language is a truism. How it acquired so great a wealth from other tongues is less generally known. Nor do most of us know, indeed, how far flung are the nets that have caught some of the dearest treasures of English speech.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- History may record that as a result of the Italo-Ethiopian war and the Spanish civil war one of the most significant contributions of the administration of President Roosevelt to the conduct of foreign affairs has been the definition of American neutrality.

With the sailing of the motor ship Santa Barbara early yesterday morning the Grace Line ships in service to the West Coast of South America bade farewell to Pier 33, foot of Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn. Beginning with the sailing of the motor ship Santa Maria on Aug. 21, the Grace Line ships for Ecuador, Peru and Chile will sail from Pier 57, North River, at West Fifteenth Street.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- With Joe E. Brown's debut at the Palladium Music Hall on Monday as the only event in sight, next week and the rest of August will be quiet theatrically. The season will start in earnest with a rush of new productions in September.
BERLIN, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The American Olympic Committee today approved excursions of three teams to compete against German talent early next week.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The next-to-last workout in Joe Louis's preparations for his fight with Jack Sharkey was held today before the critical eyes of the largest press delegation to see the Bomber in action since he started training.

With the volume of advertising allowances granted to department stores, dry goods and specialty shops amounting to only 3 1/2 per cent of the total spent for newspaper advertising, store executives yesterday foresaw no "marked change" in their practices, even if ad subsidies are completely dropped as a result of the Robinson-Patman law.

ANOTHER commemorative coin -- the specially minted half-dollar issued to mark the Long Island Tercentenary -- was put into "circulation" last week, but few of the specimens are likely to find their way into the marts of trade, for already they are valued at $1 each.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Several dinners were given before the Lake Placid horse show tonight, the first show here under flood lights.

AIN TABUN is a village in the Emek (Valley of Jezreel), the northern plain of Palestine, consisting of a fertile strip of ground lying between bare and bleak mountain ranges. The Emek presents a panorama of serried fields, vineyards and plantations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 15. -- Details of an international conference on "The Future of the Common Law," for which high court officials and leading lawyers of the British Empire and the United States will convene here next week, have been announced by Roscoe Pound, dean of the Harvard Law School.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. -- The entire cruising squadron of the New York Yacht Club is anchored in the Edgartown Harbor this week-end, while skippers and their guests seek recreation ashore. The organization of Summer residents sponsoring the Reading Room has extended its privileges to the yachtsmen, and a reception is to be held there this afternoon in their honor.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- A driving head finish at the end of a mile and a quarter over a muddy track confirmed the top-weighted Granville's claim to the 3-year-old championship before 20,000 persons today.

A LIVELY battle of the airwaves, with longer shows pitted against each other to win listeners' attention, seems destined as the bulwark of the broadcasters' Fall campaign. Major Bowes's amateur hour and "Showboat" will bid for attention Thursday nights between 9 and 10 o'clock, while Kate Smith will be at the helm of an hour show spotted against Rudy Vallee's variety show an hour earlier the same evening.

CHESTERTOWN, Md., Aug. 15. -- Skimming over the choppy waters of the Chester River at almost a forty-nine-mile-an-hour clip in his Hi Ho II, George Ward, Wilmington (Del.) speed boat driver, cut two minutes from his own world record for Class E runabouts today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- Wheat made an easy start and a strong finish on the Chicago Board of Trade today. Local operators sold early on a decline in the Liverpool market equal to 1 3/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, but commission houses absorbed the surplus in the pit on resting orders.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 15. -- Breaking 144 out of 150 clay birds from 21-yards rise, Clarence B. Platt, Bridgeton, N.J., veteran, won the sixteenth annual T. Clarence Marshall handicap, featuring the closing day of the Marshall trapshooting classic, today over the Yorklyn Gun Club traps.

White's Star, Shucks, were among the winners today in the Huguenot Yacht Club's annual regatta, one in the Y.R.A. championship series.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15. -- Real estate activity and values topped an active week on the Pacific Coast, with several new projects started. The principal one was the groundbreaking for a new $2,500,000 building in San Francisco to house the furniture exchange.

BRANT BEACH, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Dr. John S. Eynon, a surgeon of Chester, Pa., and a companion, Duane Van Horn of Plymouth Meeting, Pa., were killed this evening when an airplane owned and piloted by Dr. Eynon crashed on the beach here a quarter of a mile from a camp where his young son is spending the Summer.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Miss Jean Bauer of Providence, R.I., celebrated her twenty-fifth birthday today by winning the seventh annual New York State women's golf championship.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press). -- English batsmen led by Walter Hammond, veteran Glouces-tershire international player, punished opposing bowlers severely today in the third and final cricket test match at The Oval between England and India.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 15. -- A request for a tugboat, "crash boats," and a suitable harbor for launching seagoing targets on the eastern tip of Long Island has been sent to Washington by army authorities here.

Dr. Ramon Grau San Martin, former President of Cuba, is not satisfied with the amnesty for political offenders recently granted by the new Cuban Government and announces he will not return to his homeland until the civil authorities have demonstrated their supremacy over the army.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Nine members of the British Walker Cup team received an enthusiastic sendoff at Glasgow last night when they embarked for the United States on the Anchor liner Transylvania. Cecil Ewing, the only Irishman chosen, went aboard at Dublin, completing the party.

Continued active buying of rugs and furniture at a time when stores normally have covered Fall requirements, is due to the anxiety of retailers to protect themselves against price advances due in both markets next month, manufacturers agreed here yesterday.

DUBLIN, Aug. 14. -- President Eamon de Valera now is awaiting the results of two by-elections in Galway and Wexford, which will constitute important verdicts for or against his policies during the last four years. So vital does he regard these contests that he is prepared to declare a general election forth-with if the electors provide any evidence that the country is turning away from his leadership.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Dr. F.E. Townsend expressed the opinion today that "the inference is pretty strong" that James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, and R.E. Clements, ousted pension movement secretary, backed a court suit against directors of Old Age Revolving Pensions, Ltd.

FLEEING from the scene of a mail robbery and double murder in Winnipeg, of which he appeared to be, but was not, guilty, young Gary Frazier gets to the little mining town of Saghelia in the northern part of British Columbia.
BIRATOU, Franco-Spanish Frontier, Aug. 15. -- Loyalists were successful early today in holding back Rebels who fought for five hours on a six-mile front to capture Irun.

THE unquenchable zeal of the visionary is one of the items in the make up of Benjamin S. Moss. NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 15. -- Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world champion, and Mikhail Botwinnik, Soviet champion, were still leading in the international chess masters' tournament after they had drawn their games in the sixth round today.

OMAHA, Aug. 14.--The government crop report for August fully confirmed the worst fears of the Corn Belt as to the damage done to its major crop and added a few million extra bushels of loss. Iowa, foremost of corn-growing States, will produce the shortest crop since the great drought of 1894.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The Marquess of Lothian will compare what he believes is the only possible way to world peace with the United States Constitution in the first of a series of articles in The Sunday Observer tomorrow, entitled "A New League or No League."

THESE admirably translated and edited "Tales From a Finnish Tupa" are an outstanding addition to folk literature available for children. WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Long range plans intended to soften the devastating blows of the current drought and future ones as well drew the attention today of Federal agencies on several fronts.

THE nineteenth season of the Stadium concerts closes this Tuesday night. The last three concerts are under the direction of Willem van Hoogstraten, with whom Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, will appear tomorrow night as the final soloist of the series.

THE stocky, rapidly graying man under the "covered wagon" canvas in the roomy old Governor's office of the Kansas State Capitol has had a lot of visitors lately. The country has been coming to Topeka; now Topeka, in the person of Alfred Mossman Landon, is going to the country.
