Business conditions were spotty last week, with high temperatures and the usual seasonal influences holding down retail buying in many sections of the country. While retailers failed to maintain recent gains in many centers, reports received yesterday from the various Federal Reserve districts indicated that buying generally was ahead of the volume in the corresponding period last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Converted into traveling Swiss-cheese laboratories, two automobiles have carried Federal specialists this Summer on a mission of instruction to cheese makers in Ohio and Wisconsin, the two States that produce three-fourths of the Swiss type of cheese now made in the United States.

OCEAN GATE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Youthful skippers of the seven affiliated yacht clubs of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association ran into some stormy weather today in the eighth of the series of weekly races held under the auspices of the Ocean Gate Club on the Toms River course.

The General Outdoor Advertising Company, Inc., reports, for the quarter ended June 30, a net profit of $358,301 after depreciation, interest, amortization and other charges. No provision, however, has been made for the Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

THE section of U.S. 6, the Roosevelt Highway, between the Bear Mountain Bridge Plaza in Bear Mountain Park and Central Valley, which has been under construction for the last three months, is now open to traffic, it is reported.

Declaring that the expenditures of the Sheriffs' offices in the five counties were almost entirely waste, Mayor La Guardia asked Budget Director Leo J. McDermott yesterday to wield the pruning knife on their 1937 budget requests.

MADRID, Aug. 15. -- If the army and Fascists are decisively defeated everywhere in Spain by the Red militia, there will be no obstacle whatever to the establishment of the proletarian dictatorship desired by the Socialist leader, Francisco Largo Caballero.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Washington's Huskies, Olympic eight-oared crew champions, had to wait half an hour today to get their gold medals and an oak tree which they intend to plant on the Seattle campus, but in the words of Jim McMillin, No. 5 oar and next year's captain, "It was worth coming nearly 7,000 miles."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Governors of cotton-growing States pledged cooperation today in a movement started by Governor J.M. Futrell of Arkansas to solve the South's 70-year-old farm tenant and sharecropper problems.

Showers shortly after 8 o'clock last night brought temporary relief to the sweltering city after three days of high temperatures. A sudden drop In temperature accompanied the rain, bringing the thermometers from a high of 86 degrees to a low for the day of 73 degrees.

AFTER forty years of existence and twenty international shows that not even the World War could interrupt, Venice has opened once more its Biennial Exhibition of Art. The eight original countries taking part in it -- Italy, Spain, Belgium, Holland, Hungary, France, England, and Germany -- have in the course of these years increased to no less than sixteen through the addition of Denmark, Czechoslovakia, Russia, Greece, Poland, Switzerland, Austria and the United States.

LOUISEVILLE, Que., Aug. 15. -- A disastrous accident in which a speeding freight train struck a truck carrying a shouting, singing group of men and boys homeward from a political meeting claimed twenty-five lives early today and turned this village, 100 miles from Quebec, into a place of mourning.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The "Old Seventh" Regiment, now the 107th Infantry of New York City, commanded by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, will revive here at Camp Smith tomorrow a colorful military ceremony in the consecration of a new set of national and regimental colors by the regimental chaplain, Major Roelif H. Brooks, rector of St. Thomas Church.

EVIDENCE that television engineers are looking well into the future before attempting to design an image service for the country is found in reports last week of the Philco television demonstration at Philadelphia.

This is a sea story replete with heroism, barbarity, revenge, pirates, privateersmen and savage fights to the death. Its action transpires on the deep and ashore in the West Indies during the brief war between the United States and France early in the nineteenth century.

In his letter to the President last week Secretary MORGENTHAU painted an optimistic picture of Federal finances. Thanks to the continued improvement of business, he said, the Treaty's revenues are rising at a rate which surpasses expectations. With continued recovery, we are "steadily approaching" a point at which these revenues will be entirely adequate to cover the expenditures of the Government and to reduce the public debt.

NOW that America is traveling again, tourists once more are flocking to America's great scenic attraction, Niagara Falls. Hotel men and transportation officials estimate that 1936 will set a new mark for visitors to the mighty cataracts.

Women leaders of the Republican party in the eighteen States of the Eastern division will meet here tomorrow to discuss national campaign issues and report on progress on behalf of the Landon-Knox ticket.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 15. -- The Spanish Rebel radio stations behind the government lines became active today when General Francisco Franco's forces began a final clean-up in western Badajoz Province, preparing to wheel on Madrid from Merida in conjunction with General Emilio Mola's northern army.

AS a rule actors and manuscripts for Summer theatre productions are easy to get. A Summer impresario, providing he has a theatre and some money, usually decides on a play which is a little box-office something in one set and with a small cast.

Many of the Republican strategists who are now hard at work on plans to dramatize Governor LANDON and sell him to the American people must have been small boys at one time or another. As such, they stood up on the platform over the dead body of JULIUS CAESAR and declaimed, "I am no orator, as BRUTUS is; but, as you know me all, a plain blunt man that love my friend."

HOW loud is a noise? How safe is safety glass? How much dust is dangerous? How much gas is poisonous? These are some of the questions for which answers have been or are being prepared, in terms of exact measurements by the American Standards Association, a body uniting fifty-four trade organizations, technical societies and government departments in a quest for uniform standards of industrial safety and efficiency.

Whether or not, as a result of this season's harvest shortage, the Agricultural Department may virtually have to suspend its policy of crop restriction, the season's experience certainly shows the hazards of meticulous "planning." In the Department's Yearbook for 1935 the short crops of 1934 were sorrowfully discussed, but Secretary WALLACE found one distinctly comforting consideration.
To the children of New York, milk means life; to the farmers of up-State New York, milk means livelihood.

Aram Kapigian of Philadelphia and Harry Kasabach of Ann Arbor, Mich., who have monopolized the honors in the Armenian tennis championships for the last four years, will meet for the title today at 1:30 P.M. at the Sunrise Courts, Queens.

PLANS have been completed for the third annual Gardener's Vacation Course, which will be held this year at the E.W. Edwards Store Annex, in Syracuse, N.Y., on Aug. 28 and 29. This garden event has been a success for the past two years, and an increased attendance is expected, particularly as the course will be combined with the Regional Flower Show of the Association of Garden Clubs of Central New York.
The laugh in the rubber "currency," distributed widely by sidewalk peddlers as "baloney dollars," bounced back rather abruptly yesterday against the alleged printer of the "money."

WHEN Arnold Dolmetsch first started on his memorable voyage of discovery (well over thirty years ago), his followers were more numerous than they are today. They included young men of the intelligentsia, and London hostesses who formed a generous but somewhat odd audience; they were ready to accept anything Mr. Dolmetsch chose to give them with equal thanks; as long as he vouched for it, the thing was good.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Minimum amounts of insurance which bus and truck lines operating in interstate commerce must carry were fixed today by the Interstate Commerce Commission under authority of the new Motor Carrier Law.

RONALD MANSBRIDGE of the Cambridge Press department of the Macmillan Company returned recently from a visit to the Cambridge University Press in England with news of considerable activity there. The most astounding news in his budget is that the syndics of the Cambridge University Press have broken a rule of four centuries and have accepted for publication the manuscript of a novel.

LONDON, Aug. 15.--America's Olympic track and field forces shifted their base of operations today, but met with the same signal success they had enjoyed in Berlin. Before 90,000, England's largest track crowd, the United States squad easily conquered the massed strength of the British Empire, 11 to 3, in White City Stadium at Shepherd's Bush, which was the site of the 1908 Olympics.

AN exhibition of painting and sculpture by children of the Associated Experimental Schools closes this evening at the Hessian Hills School, Croton-on-Hudson. The assembled work is drawn in part from the exhibition of paintings by children of North America, held in the Mezzanine Galleries of the RCA. Building last November and now touring the United States.

MADRID, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Most of Spain's historic and art treasures have come through the civil war virtually undamaged. The Alhambra at Granada and historic cathedrals at Toledo, Burgos and Seville have emerged without serious injury.

THE Goldman Band, under Edwin Franko Goldman, which closes its season on the Mall in Central Park tonight, established new attendance records this Summer, having played to almost 2,000,000 persons. During the season, which began June 17, sixty concerts were given and the average nightly audience numbered from 20,000 to 30,000.

INASMUCH as Carlos Chavez will appear as guest conductor for a fortnight next February with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, extra interest attaches to the pronounced success scored by him at the recent opening concert of the ninth season of the Symphony Orchestra of Mexico, given under his direction in Mexico, D.F.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15. -- The National Union for Social Justice in convention assembled voted 8,152 to 1 today to get behind the third party candidacies of William Lemke and Thomas C. O'Brien, but on the advice of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, their omnipotent leader, the delegates turned their backs unanimously on proposals that they endorse the Union party or its platform.

MOTORISTS who have driven over the parkways in the New York metropolitan region, on the Mount Vernon Memorial Parkway at Washington or on the freeway to the Norris Dam and the new town of Norris, Tenn., are invariably enthusiastic about this modern and efficient type of highway.

IT was not so long ago that the size of the piano created a decorative problem sometimes virtually impossible to solve for the small home or apartment. Now there are models especially suited to the modern interior. Baby grands are being made more compact than ever; and there are small pianos which, when closed, take the form of a table by no means large.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 14. -- Friends and adherents of Senator William E. Borah have been immeasurably heartened by the results of the primary election in Idaho. They point to the wide divergence between the primary margins of Borah and his Democratic opponent, Governor C. Ben Ross, as indication that the Senator will win a sixth successive term.

The job of reclaiming the 1,130-acre World's Fair site in Northern Queens from the grip of great ash mounds and the swampy shores of the Flushing River is being rushed day and night. It is proving to be one of the greatest topographical "face-lifting" projects ever attempted hereabouts.

THE universally known August flowering hydrangea, so popular in American gardens, has a distinguished relative in the climbing hydrangea. In fact, there are two climbing hydrangeas, both hardy perennial shrubs, and both are desirable plants.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The example set by President Roosevelt in cautioning American citizens that their dealings with belligerents in the Ethiopian war would be at their own risk was followed today by the British Government with reference to citizens of this country and the Spanish civil war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Cotton consumed during the twelve months ended on July 31 was reported by the Census Bureau today to have amounted to 6,348,423 bales of lint and 731,490 of linters, compared with 5,360,867 and 719,028 the preceding year.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 15. -- Retail trade dropped slightly this week from the levels of the previous week. Merchants reported trade spotty in all sections of the Ninth Federal Reserve District.

THIS book is a real guide to modern architecture, and as such it should be heartily welcomed by the general public and widely read. For the author really tells "what it is all about." And although he demolishes one pet architectural theory after another, he is quite as hard on the falsities and imitations and conventionalities of the "modern school" as on any other.
The American Manganese Producers Association has protested to the State Department in Washington that the trade agreement concluded recently with Russia is an "illegal and unauthorized document."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15. Horses belonging to Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, N.Y., annexed two championships in the twelfth annual show staged under the auspices of the East Hampton Riding Club on its own grounds today. A large gathering saw Conference, a brown gelding, triumph in the open jumper class, and Tupelo, the aged chestnut gelding, win the hunter crown.

SWELTERING weather and sunny skies are not likely to turn one's thoughts in the direction of planting; and even with an early change in temperature and more moisture it will still be a bit early for most Fall planting. But there are a number of items on the gardener's list that either must be put in within the next two or three weeks, or are better planted then than later.

BY rights this piece should have been written a week ago, but we never have been able to remember anniversaries. It was not until we received a red-ringed calendar, anonymously mailed, and noted the pout on the corporate face of the Warner Brother's that we recalled August's significance in the screen world.

ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- With a prospect that mills along the Oswego and Susquehanna Rivers will be forced to close down because of low water conditions in the Oswego Basin, the Hudson River is flowing along at an almost normal level without any hindrance to navigation or to cessation of mills that use the water power above Albany.
Special police at the Polo Grounds faced a hard task yesterday. They had difficulty shooing the crowd out on the streets after the Giants and Phillies had concluded their third game.

The City College Summer session will end Tuesday, following an eight-week term. Regular classes at the uptown and downtown branches of the college closed yesterday for more than 5,500 students attending the special semester. Final examinations are scheduled for tomorrow and Tuesday.

Seven thousand engineers and technical workers employed on WPA projects here will receive wage increases averaging $500 each per year under a revised salary scale established yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

THERE has been a theory about lately that the reading public -- or that part of it which subscribes to the popular magazines and the lending libraries -- is in a mood to be distracted and dazzled. In the last few years, so the theory runs, they have had more than enough of the hard facts of life; now they demand glamour.

Surrogate James A. Foley denied the application for preference in the payment of annuities from the estate of the late Irving I. Bloomingdale, former vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., to his divorced wife as against his widow, in a ruling yesterday on the construction of the will.

GLASGOW, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press). -- Aberdeen, Falkirk and Motherwell drew into the lead in the Scottish Football League today, when they turned in second victories of the season to take four points each. The Dons blanked Arbroath, 4 -- 0; Falkirk won at Dumfries from Queen of South, 4 -- 1, and Motherwell took a 4-3 decision over Hearts at Tynecastle.

SEABRIGHT, N.J. -- The polo matches which open this afternoon at the Rumson Country Club are attracting attention in the Summer colonies hereabout. Mrs. J. Ford Johnson and Abram Elkus have donated the prizes for the tournament, held in the memory of W. Strotcher Jones.

The stock market closed steady yesterday in quiet trading with some of the industrial groups pointing higher as railway issues declined. Trading in the half-day session amounted to 366,000 shares on the Stock Exchange, compared with 767,000 the Saturday before.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 14. -- Kentucky rural Democrats took to registration with enthusiasm when they were required, by a new law, to put their names in a book before they could vote in the Congressional primary. Not only a lively contest for the nomination for United States Senator brought them out, it would seem, but an eager desire to cast their votes in the Presidential race.

THE lethargy with which the industry usually views the formation of new independents is noticeably missing in the town's attitude toward Grand National. Regarded as a potentially important concern, both the citizenry and the major studios are scanning each announcement made by this outgrowth of Pathe with keen interest.

CROSSING the continent by day coach -- an adventure reserved in the old days for the very hardy -- has become a commonplace under the joint influence of sharply reduced fares and vastly improved day coach facilities.

Whether Joe Louis suffered lasting effects from the terrific beating he took from Max Schmeling two months ago is expected to be demonstrated when the Brown Bomber returns to the same fighting locale Tuesday night for a struggle against Jack Sharkey, Boston's former heavyweight champion of the world.

HOLLYWOOD. WHILE the screen's performers rarely are said to lack animation --they usually lean more toward the flamboyant and obvious--there is one actor in Hollywood who must remain motionless and speechless and still participate liberally in the proceedings.
I have been grieved to learn of the death of Arthur Whiting last month and I would like to add a note of personal appreciation to the other testimonials.

A SPECIALIZED library containing more than 200,000 volumes on a single subject -- the educational history of the world -- has been built up by the Office of Education, Department of the Interior. So complete is this library that the usually self-contained Library of Congress is listed among its daily borrowers.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 15. -- A unique conference convened here tonight and began immediately to wrestle seriously with the explosive economic and political problems of the powers that rim the Pacific.

VOLUMES in memoriam of distinguished scholars are numerous in Germany, less frequent in this country. The present volume with its 763 pages (149 in Hebrew type) exceeds all in size that the reviewer knows. It recalled to him the notable volume in memory of George Alexander Kohut's distinguished father, "Semitic Studies in Memory of Alexander Kohut," published in 1897, itself containing 650 pages.

GENEVA, Aug. 15. -- After having laid the framework for a permanent organization and having elected officers to carry it on, the first World Jewish Congress adjourned tonight until 1938 amid speeches and messages expressing satisfaction with the week's sessions and confidence in the future.
BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 15.--Tennis Week at the Mount Washington Hotel here will open tomorrow with exhibition matches and a round of social activities starting Monday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- Miss Eleanor Young. debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Young of New York, made her official social bow tonight when she was presented at a large dance given by her parents at Beechwood, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Astor, which the family has occupied the last two seasons.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Senators overcame an early three-run lead by driving Lefty Fritz Ostermueller from the mound today and then piled it on hard to defeat the Red Sox, 11 -- 5, and reward Jimmy de Shong with his fourteenth pitching triumph.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 15. -- "March in Review," the command that rang over Camp Dix eighteen years ago to start in motion the 36,000 men of the war-strength Seventy-eighth Army "Lightning" Division in their final review before Major Gen. James H. McRae on the eve of the division's departure for France, was heard again this afternoon as more than 1,000 veterans of this division assembled for their traditional review.

PLAYTHINGS once caressed by small fingers hold a special charm for hobbyists who collect toys of long ago. How diversified such a collection may be made is shown by an exhibit of items which amused youngsters of yesteryears, now on view in the children's division of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
MANILA, P.I., Aug. 15 (AP). -- A swift-moving typhoon hurtled down on the Northern Philippines tonight as distress signals ware picked up from two ships, driven aground ahead of the onrushing storm.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- For golfers, pro and amateur, many roads this week will lead to the Adirondacks.
BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- The Olympic boxing tournament was concluded tonight with the crowning of eight champions, from the flyweight to the heavyweight class.

Apropos the statement by the Rev. Dr. Fleming of Old Trinity that there should be a moratorium on preaching for a space of two years, allow me as a layman to say that there ought to be a stop put upon sermons of a certain type -- "topics," the Hyksos kings, apostolic successions, character delineation in a best seller and similar dissertations.
The dog-days lethargy disappeared from the Presidential campaign last week and things began to pop.

THIS is the story of Barry Cameron, city editor of a big newspaper in a Western city which, for convenience in his narration, he calls Gomorrah. Against the orders of his boss, Barry published a sensational political story, then resigned before he could be fired and hit out for the Yukon gold fields.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The State Department reported today that the following Americans were evacuated from Palma yesterday by the cruiser Quincy:

PARIS. -- Since the formation of the Popular Front Government the workers of France have occupied the center of the political stage. Carried forward by the momentum of their triumph at the polls, they launched a sudden and sweeping offensive on their employers and won a great victory for the working-class.

LYNCH, Neb., Aug. 15 (AP). -- University of Nebraska scientists are wondering what manner of man lived 4,000 years ago in the prehistoric city unearthed near here by archaeologists headed by Dr. Earl H. Bell of the university.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Novel Sunday afternoon entertainments on the Berkeley Continental terrace are attracting many members of the North Jersey shore colonies. The program for this afternoon is a coiffure pageant, in which juniors, debutantes, fashion matrons and modern grandmothers will display the latest styles in headdress.
BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- The Olympic decorations have become a trifle weatherworn. The showers of the last few days did it.

Cruising yachtsmen have the coming week-end made to order for them. Several hundred boats instead of following the usual routine of going to Lloyd Harbor for another lazy Saturday and Sunday, or to Croton Point, will head down Jersey way for a double attraction.

SCIENCE never having equipped radio with an electric turnstile, a box office or a pay-as-you-enter system, the broadcasters lack an accurate count of the unseen audience in tune with a particular show. To offset the mystery various barometers of "delayed applause" have been devised so that from week to week it may be known whether Major Bowes is in the lead or whether the Showboat has sailed ahead.

ROME, Aug. 14. -- The Osservatore Romano, the Holy See's official organ, has several times had occasion in the last few weeks to write about the Spanish situation and it is noteworthy that not once has it referred to "the Spanish Government," but only to "the Madrid government."

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- A lady in a red hat kissed Chancellor Adolf Hitler before some 30,000 people gathered in the Olympic swimming stadium this afternoon. The best that can be ascertained about her identity is that she gave the name of Carla de Uriese and her address as California.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The hope of State prison officials that they might transform Clinton prison at Dannemora from the convicts' idea of "Siberia" to a model institution is likely to meet delay through a shortage of bricklayers. Thomas H. Maxwell of New York, in charge of construction work on the new $400,000 addition to the jail, says that the WPA is responsible for the shortage.
Following a slight increase in the preceding week, the volume of bonds called last week for redemption before maturity declined.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Saying "it is altogether possible that our Constitution does need revision," Chairman John D.M. Hamilton of the Republican National Committee declared in a speech here tonight that the security of the people was endangered by a desire which he attributed to some New Dealers to replace the Constitution with "some other mechanism."

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 15. -- Canada's rise to prominence as a base metal producer in the last ten to fifteen years, and the importance of the expansion to the Canadian mineral industry as a whole, was recorded this week in a report published by the Dominion Department of Mines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- With the development of a cotton bag in which to package raw sugar, it is believed that another use has been found for a product of the cotton industry. At present imported jute, most of it from India, provides the material for most sugar bags.

Work on the Queens Midtown Vehicular Tunnel under the East River will begin about Sept. 15 and will be completed in 1940, the New York City Tunnel Authority announced yesterday. At the same time it made public the details of a tunnel plan bearing its official approval.

EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 15. -- A monument marking the fiftieth anniversary of the Student Christian Movement in America, Great Britain and Canada, was dedicated today at Mount Hermon, where in 1886 some 200 students representing eighty-nine colleges came together for religious meetings under the leadership of Dwight L. Moody, famed evangelist and educator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- In honor of Jeff D. Milton, this country's first border patrolman, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has given his name to its new forty-eight foot Diesel-powered harbor boat in San Francisco.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 15. -- As regards the Moscow Communique alleging he instigated from exile in Norway a plot against Joseph Stalin's life, Leon Trotsky today issued a statement denying all the charges and asserting the Communique was the "greatest fabrication in the history of world politics."

SARATOGA SPRINGS. -- This week is crowded with events in which society and leading figures in racing are interested. This evening Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney is sponsoring the illustrated lecture which Elliott S. Humphrey, vice president of the Seeing Eye of Morristown, N.J., will give at the Grand Union Hotel.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The events of the coming week will work to a climax on Saturday, when the Bar Harbor Club holds its annual water sports carnival and members of the colonies in Bar Harbor, Northeast Harbor and Seal Harbor gather at the pool's edge to cheer their favorites.

Price changes on commodity futures markets here for the week ended on Friday were mixed, with gains in cottonseed oil, tallow, wool tops, sugar and cocoa, and losses in coffee, rubber, silk and hides. On the cash markets, corn, rye, oats, flour, lard, raw sugar, silk and cocoa advanced, and wheat, cotton, wool tops, rubber and antimony declined.

The municipal stadium on Randalls Island, where many a fond hope of Olympic glory was dashed last month, again rocked with frenzied cheers of rabid track and field enthusiasts yesterday as the World Labor Athletic Carnival offered the left-behinds an opportunity for redemption.

TEMPORARY Summer homes, especially rented cottages, rarely have gardens which may be counted on for cut bloom throughout the season. If the house is occupied by the owner he often arrives too late to attend adequately to the planting; and if it is rented, there are obvious obstacles to any extensive gardening program on the part of either owner or tenant.

Southern drawl, French patois and Evangeline costumes injected an exotic note into the life of the city yesterday as sixty-three members of the Louisiana Association of Acadians, representing every parish in their State, paid a brief visit to New York en route to Grand Pre, the little Nova Scotian village from which their ancestors were exiled by the British in 1755.

The fifth of the gay "Snipp, Snapp, Snurr" story-picture books which are popular with little children. In order to earn the money to buy the yellow sled displayed before their longing eyes in the shop window, the three boys agree to help their mother in every way they can for two weeks.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Carlos M. de Heredia gave a dinner tonight at Wheatleigh. Her house guests for the music festival, of which she is vice president, are Mrs. Nicholas Brown of Newport, l Miss Elen Bullard of Boston and Governor Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island.

MAYOR LA GUARDIA was seated behind his desk in the Summer City Hall, the old Bartow mansion on Pelham Bay Parkway. There was a vase of flowers on the desk before him, something that would have been incongruous downtown but was quite in keeping here, with the view through the open French windows to a terraced garden.
PARIS, Aug. 15 . -- The dilatory tactics of Italy and the Reich appear tonight to have successfully blocked the French effort to obtain an international convention for non-intervention in Spain.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- Herbert Lee Pratt of New York, who had been stopping at Claridge's before going to Scotland, is entertaining at House Gifford Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Fletcher, Mr. and Mrs. Reeve Schley, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, Mr. and Mrs. Morris Kellogg, Mrs. Pratt McLane and Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Powell Jr.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Charles F. Chandler gave a tea at her Easton's Point lodge today.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 15. -- Following a full day of competition in the broiling sun on the polo field of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, the honor of best in the annual dog show was given to the snow-white Sealyham terrier, Champion Wolvey Noel of Clairedale, owned by the Clairedale Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. W.O. Penney of Riverhead, L.I.

At least fifty experienced technicians assigned to the WPA project in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn, will receive 10 per cent salary increases this week as a means of inducing them to remain on the job rather than seek work in private industry, it was revealed yesterday by A.J. Brehm, in charge of all construction and civilian personnel.

REGARDING Henry Varnum Poor as one of America's significant artists, Forbes Watson, in The American Magazine of Art for July, traces the artist's development from parental opposition through years of struggle, ceramic work and study to the successful completion of six of his twelve murals for the Treasury Department Art Projects.

BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- Mayor Frederick W. Mansfield arrived home from Europe Thursday to find that Boston, noted for its beans, has taken up the game of beano and that a serious gambling scandal demanded swift attention. The game of beano, it is said, has developed into a racket of such proportions as to call for widespread inquiry.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Socialist party of Pennsylvania voted, 58 to 32, tonight to disaffiliate from the National Socialist party. The vote came after three hours of bitter debate. Left wing members threatened to form a new party.

SO much has been written on Shakespeare lately, and so much of importance, that this little book would pass unnoticed if it were not for the irresistible subtitle, "A Marxist Interpretation." We have had books on Shakespeare by Catholics, Puritans, Anglicans and Freudians, by Baconians and Oxonians, by lawyers, botanists, doctors and sportsmen.

The Golden Wings is the name of a flying club, and it is there that the murder with which this story deals is committed. The Coroner's jury calls it suicide, but Glyn Morgan, the Welsh detective, knows better. He even knows within twenty-four hours who committed the murder, but he has no evidence to prove it.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 15. -- Old Home Week, an institution now in its thirty-seventh year, is being observed under auspices of the New Hampshire Old Home Week Association by a hundred towns, more than a third of those in the State.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, tonight said the recent closing of the huge Amoskeag Mills here was a result of "the shift in the textile industry from New England to the South."

In connection with its drawing showing the location of the Queens Midtown Tunnel and its approaches, the New York City Tunnel Authority made public yesterday the following detailed-explanation of its proposed method of handling traffic on the Manhattan side.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Philippine Clipper is on its way to Manila, 8,000 miles away, but flying across the Pacific Ocean is "old stuff" now. Pan American Airways has completed 560,000 miles of aerial navigation over the widest ocean without a mishap.

BANFF, Alberta, Aug. 15. -- Miss Georgia Engelhard, daughter of and Mrs. George H. Engelhard of 1,211 Madison Avenue, New York City, has added another achievement to her climbing records in the Canadian Rockies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Extension of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's lending power for another year was projected today in administration discussions, in view of a sustained demand in certain fields for the agency's accommodations.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15. -- East Hampton has welcomed scores of out-of-town visitors for today's annual horse show, the most brilliant ever given at the Riding Club here in the twelve years since it opened.
When a 13-year-old girl becomes an Olympic champion it is bound to serve as a boom to those who believe in teaching sports to children early.

Plans for the Autumn season of field trials for spaniels and retrievers are being formulated and already a large number of dates has been claimed and approved. The schedule indicates the most active season in the history of the sport in this country.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- All efforts here to get correct information on the activities of the groups reported to be trying to swing the labor vote away from President Roosevelt have been futile. Men connected with the Ohio Manufacturers Association say vaguely that something of the kind is in the air, but assert that they do not have data concerning it.

Although somewhat skeptical of the government's announced intention of planning no further taxes next year, business men were cheered yesterday by the administration's recognition of the uncertainty created by the possibility of increased levies. The general opinion was that if the promise is kept, industrialists will operate with more confidence.

CORNING, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP). -- The flood control council of Central Southern New York, in its first anniversary meeting here today, heard announcement that President Roosevelt has approved a $2,568,000 flood control program for South-Central New York and was told by its executive committee that "security against floods is well within realization."

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- The New Deal farm program was indicted on four counts today by George N. Peek, who charged that under the administration's operations "agriculture has definitely lost ground in its fight for equality with industry."

A device for cooling and air-conditioning automobiles was demonstrated yesterday by Dr. John M. Gibbons, a physician, of 430 East Eighty-sixth Street. Similar in size to an automobile heater, it makes possible the cooling of a closed car whether the vehicle is moving or standing.

AS Hugo and Dumas long ago discovered, the French Revolution affords an almost unequaled opportunity for the writer of lusty fiction. If it is romance, exaltation, terror, heroism that one wants, there it is. But no writer of our own time can approach the crisis of a century and a half ago without consciousness of the crisis in the face of which he lives.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- Three of four British-owned Fokker planes which aviation authorities said they believed were en route to Burgos, Spain, for delivery to the Fascist Rebels were reported forced down tonight in France.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Robert Riggs, 18-year-old Los Angeles junior, provided one of the major upsets of the tennis season today when he defeated Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, third in the national ranking and member of the Davis Cup team, in the semi-final round of the Eastern Grass Court championships at the Westchester Country Club.

That both President ROOSEVELT and Governor LANDON are old Chautauquans brings that now historic institution into deserved national notice. It renews its youth like the eagle's. Its renaissance has been made possible through the grateful and loyal devotion of many who have enjoyed its privileges in the past.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Thanks to the presence of an array of divers who swept the springboard competition and who took first, second and fifth in the platform test, the United States regained the Olympic men's swimming laurels with the completion of the aquatic meet today.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- The Boerse, which had been weak the larger part of this week, made something like a recovery today. The turnover was small but fractional gains predominated, some issues rising as much as 2 points. Heavy industrial shares were firmish, Cloeckner adding nearly 2 points, although the day's best prices were shaded around the close.
BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Mid-August finds the Summer colonists in the Lake Champlain and Northern Vermont area hurrying to complete a full schedule of events for the last two weeks of the month.

THREE years ago New York City had parks -- a great many parks, little and big, green oases, more or less scarred, strewn about its five boroughs, dotted over its 300--odd square miles of territory and tucked about the ragged edges of its nearly 1,000 miles of waterfront. Like most things in New York of a public nature, these parks were the results of sporadic bursts of civic interest and of haphazard growth.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- An atmosphere of uneasy apprehension can be felt in the national headquarters of the Townsend movement, at 720 North Michigan Avenue in this city, where Gilmour Young, national secretary, presides.

TUNA, those grotesque, saucer-eyed, blue-green torpedoes of the deep, are roaming the fishing lanes of the North Atlantic Coast in countless legions these days. Their proximity is a challenge to the sporting instincts of men who love to fight a game fish with rod, reel and line.

DEBATING, both as academic subject and as academic sport, has changed and developed in the past few years. Formerly the theory of debate was taught, academically, as a course in argumentation in the department of English; only recently has it been "delegated to the curricula and sphere of the speech department."

TO leave the earth in some strange hermetically sealed vessel, to rush through space from planet to planet at velocities never before achieved, to see with one's own eyes the features of that other face of the Moon which is forever turned from the Earth -- surely the imagination is capable of no more magnificent flight.

Miss Erma Young, the 21-year-old visitor from Choteau, Mont., who has been whirled about the city for the last two or three weeks making her essay "Why I Want to See New York" come true, has admitted that she had been hopelessly caught in the web of her own prize-winning effort.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- About 7,444 women are employed on Works Progress Administration health projects in thirty-nine States, New York City and the District of Columbia, caring for needy persons who are ill and carrying on disease-prevention campaigns, it was announced today.

AS Irvin Cobb suggests in his foreword to this biography, not many people even remember the name of Petroleum V. Nasby nowadays. Yet in his time he was one of the most influential writers in the country: when he died in 1888 Harper's Weekly, looking back upon his "humorous, earnest, good-natured and incisive satire" during the Civil War period, declared that "his pen was sharper than a hundred swords."

FRITZ MAHLER, the Viennese conductor, who will make his American debut this Friday night as director of the performance of "Carmen" which opens the Hippodrome opera season, already has taken out citizen's papers with the intention of becoming a permanent resident in this country.

GENEVA, Aug. 14 -- The visit of Secretary Perkins hero this week marks a rare American entry into the permanent "Olympic" contests for world laurels in practical politice and creative statesmanship which Geneva unfailingly provides.

NOW that the wave of enthusiasm over the latest major feat of Soviet aviation -- the far north flight of the ANT-5 -- has somewhat subsided and with the crew rewarded and decorated, Russian aeronautical circles and Arctic specialists are tackling the question: Is the ANT-25 the model that will prevail as the means of long-distance air travel in those regions?

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 15. -- High goal players filled in the time between test matches for the open championship and the international contests with play in the members' polo at the Meadow Brook Club today. Two of the three matches were cut-in games, and the third, in which eight high-goal men played, sometimes went at an easy pace but often flared into fast polo.

THIS is a novel about life in Spain during the past few years; obviously its news value must for the moment take precedence over its value as literature. Through reading it we can better understand not only certain past events connected historically with the present crisis but also the political temper and emotions of every type of Spaniard, from the grandee to the worker in the fields, from the settled reactionary to the unbridled anarchist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP).--The Securities and Exchange Commission today asked the Supreme Court to refuse to review a lower court ruling that four employes of a New York brokerage firm must testify concerning alleged manipulation of the prices of stocks.

Orders continued to be placed in good volume during the week for Fall merchandise, according to a report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Due to the warm weather, retail stocks have been depleted so that retailers are paying more attention to Fall merchandise, Although Fall millinery is selling, little consumer attention is being given to Fall dresses in the popular price ranges.

Bonds were firm to slightly higher on a typically dull Saturday on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Although trading reflected the absence of many traders from their desks for the week-end, there was sufficient demand in evidence to carry a few selected corporation loans up several points.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- The principal event of the late Summer in Litchfield will be the presentation by the Litchfield Players of Edward Chodorov's "Kind Lady." The play, directed by Dillon Ripley, president of the players, will be given at the Playhouse on Aug. 28 and 29.

Any one can catch a small tuna (meaning the school fish weighing from 25 to 75 pounds) because the tuna hooks itself. You troll a lure, you feel the strike and the fish is off on a sizzling run. In fact, strike and run are virtually simultaneous.

THIS lively saga of the adventures of the fictional gaucho, Martin Fierro, is a naive epic of the Argentina of frontier days, when cowboys flourished and Indians were a scourge. Thus allied on the one hand to our own "Westerns." the narrative by Jose Hernandez is structurally also allied to leas familiar genres, to the metrical romances, the epics and the quasi-epics of the Middle Ages.

Development of a number of private brands by liquor retailers throughout the metropolitan area has been increasingly apparent here in the last few weeks, jobbers, rectifiers and spokesmen for package stores said here yesterday. The situation is regarded by many as a natural aftermath of the destructive retail price war waged here late last Spring.

Anything may happen in today's double-header at Ebbets Field but Professor Casey Stengel will not be surprised after observing the manner in which his Dodgers defeated the Boston Bees for their second in a row yesterday by the score of 6 -- 2.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- More than 600 persons attended a dinner dance held tonight at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, in honor of the players participating in the Eastern turf court championships being held here.

GUTHRIE McCLINTIC is amassing himself a schedule. Added to the John Gielgud "Hamlet," the Maxwell Anderson "High Tor" -- plus such directorial efforts as he may provide for Miss Cornell and others -- there is now a revival of Chekhov's "The Seagull."

In conformity with recent legislation, local banks and trust companies have been publishing notices of their intention to terminate the double liability attached to their shares, effective on July 1, 1937. More than a third of the State-chartered institutions concerned have issued such notices, as have numerous national banks.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Hunters owned by Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim of Babylon, L.I., were first and second in the middle and heavy weight class at the second session of the Lake Placid Horse Show today. The blue was given to Firenze Red Tape and the red went to Firenze Brumanna.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- President Roosevelt was commended today by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom for the "conviction and spirit" of his Chautauqua address which was acclaimed as a "great speech" despite the deplored omission from it of any statements in opposition to further strengthening of the country's military and naval forces.

WILDWOOD, N.J. -- The twenty-seventh annual Wildwood Baby Carnival is scheduled for Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and is expected to be the biggest in the history of the event. Interest in the carnival has been such that for the first time in three years it has been made a three-day event, with special attractions each day.
GIBRALTAR, Aug. 15 (AP). -- An American and thirty-seven British subjects held as hostages were believed safe tonight, after an escape from Loyalists in Huelva province, in Southern Spain.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of July: Total imports 68,730,000; exports of British products, 40,080,000; re-exports, 4,990,000; total exports, 45,070,000; excess of imports, 23,660,000.

A NATIVE: At Portland, Ore., last week, the Republican National Chairman took time out to deny an alleged whisper to the effect that he was a foreigner. "I was born in Fort Madison, Iowa," proudly declared John D.M. Hamilton. "My father was born in Pennsylvania.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Westchester's amateur champion, Willie Turnesa, capably obliged one of the county's clubs today by vanquishing Charles H. Mayo Jr., Long Island's amateur titleholder, 2 and 1, in the eighteen-hole final of the ninth annual Green Meadow Golf Club invitation tournament.

A recent magazine survey of the trend in collegiate life notes that the modern student has lost much of the "rah-rah" attitude of the roaring Twenties, is now more interested in social studies and in security of livelihood. The depression is credited with scaring our youths into using their four years as a hunting ground for economic security.

The United States won both men's and women's unofficial team titles by narrow margins. Marshall Wayne and Elbert Root finished one-two in the platform diving with Frank Kurtz fifth. Noburo Terada and Detsuo Hamuro captured 1,500 free style and 200 meter breaststroke finals, with Jack Medica and Ralph Flanagan second and fifth, respectively, in the free style event and John Higgins fourth in the breast stroke.

THE main principle to be kept in mind by the radio dramatist is that he is writing for mass consumption and not for a limited audience of specialized taste, according to Irving Reis, young WABC author and director of the Columbia workshop.

The New Deal becomes an actuality for France with the enactment into law of the program of the Blum government. After a session reminiscent of the first Roosevelt Congress, the Chamber of Deputies adjourned yesterday morning with a record of achievement for a French parliament.

THE eight essays in this collection positively defy any attempt to be closely correlated or comparatively analyzed, though they can be classified as separate treatments of certain integral parts of the vast subject's whole.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- Chairman John D.M. Hamilton is to return to central Republican headquarters in Chicago within the next ten days and to keep much quieter thenceforth for the remainder of the campaign.

MADRID, Aug. 15 (Passed by the Censor). -- Arrests of high army officers continue to be made. According to nearly every newspaper in Madrid it is now clear that the general staff at the War Office was responsible for the plot that resulted in the present revolution.

Much conjecture has been focused upon the real significance of President Roosevelt's conference last Thursday with Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, and Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Red Wrings dropped both ends of a twin bill to Newark tonight. The scores were 10 to 3 and 5 to 3.

WHILE sales gains of 5 to 20 per cent were reported from major centers last week, definite effects of the drought were also cited. The St. Louis district has found volume slackening off until it is now barely even with a year ago.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Reds stepped through loopholes in the Chicago defense today to a 5-4 triumph that put a temporary crimp in the Cubs' bid for the National League leadership.

The engagement of $1,778,000 gold in India and $1,184,000 in Mexico for shipment here was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total for the week to $9,307,000, of which $4,015,000 was taken in France. $2,731,000 in India, $1,377,000 in England and $1,184,000 in Mexico.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- All that Jack Sharkey did today in preparation for his fight with Joe Louis on Tuesday night was to go through the motions. The former world heavyweight champion confined his activities strictly to exercising, eschewing sparring in order to protect the right eyelid, which was cut in training three days ago.

THE third of Columbia's rerecordings of Beethoven's symphonies under the direction of Felix Weingartner is the Seventh which -- together with the "Prometheus" overture, appended on the tenth side -- comes in Masterworks Album No. 260.

THE screen is fashion's show window." These are the words that one of Hollywood's outstanding designers used in talking with the writer. No doubt about it. Each star as she plays her pact -- here we are concerned only with stars of the feminine gender -- is an exponent of style, whether she be playing a modern role or one that belongs to a historical period.

Young American and German business men have been invited to participate in the development of an exchange system between the two countries, it was announced here yesterday by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce, which is cooperating with Berlin authorities.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 16 (Sunday). -- The United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, the union that sponsored the recent four-week strike at the R.C.A. Manufacturing Company's plant here, was credited with all except 147 of 3,163 votes cast by company employes yesterday in an election to determine their collective bargaining agency.

Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt's efforts to obtain a legacy of $100,000 bequeathed to her by her mother-in-law, Mrs. Alice G. Vanderbilt, were recorded yesterday through an order issued by Surrogate James A. Foley.

MADRID, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Spanish Government tonight ordered new socialization of industry and sought to halt the flight of capital that might reach Rebel hands. The huge oil, tobacco and other industries were confiscated by labor organizations and given over to workers to operate under State control.

ERE LONG, preparations will be complete for the first trans-atlantic heavier-than-air flight of the year. The pilot, Richard Tindall (Dick) Merrill, crack flier for Eastern Air Lines, is taking a sort of busman's holiday. At the controls of Harry Richman's specially-fitted Vultee, he expects to take the actor-pilot, who has made some air records himself, from Floyd Bennett Field to London in about half the time the crossing has formerly required.

A QUARTER century of flying and still going strong! Moreover, they are looking forward to another quarter century of the same thing. Both Richard H. Depew Jr. and Beckwith Havens, who handle Fairchild planes for the northeastern part of the country from their base at Roosevelt Field, are emphatic about that.

SEATTLE, Aug. 15 (AP). -- The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, Hearst morning newspaper which suspended publication indefinitely Thursday after members of the American Newspaper Guild called a strike, made no effort today to get out Sunday editions, which have a circulation of about 150,000.

The trustees of the $13,283,000 B-K issue of mortgage certificates in 170 properties sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company filed a report yesterday in the Supreme Court here in which they outlined a plan of operation for the period ending on Dec. 31.

THIS is a real mountain book. It is no guide for those who merely take their mountaineering by car. For although motor roads do "penetrate at important points" in Glacier National Park, "the best of its scenic displays will never be witnessed," says the author of this attractive volume, "save by those hardy enough to brave the trails."

James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced yesterday that he would confer tomorrow and Tuesday with national committeemen and women and the State party leaders from Indiana, Virginia, Pennsylvania and Maryland.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The second concert of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival, given by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, took place this afternoon at Holmwood in Lenox with an audience which, while it did not total the approximate 5,000 of last Thursday night, numbered about 3,500.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15. -- When Mayor S. Davis Wilson made his personal campaign against gambling and vice even more personal this week by issuing warrants himself for a series of raids, then questioning the prisoners and sitting as a committing magistrate to dispose of the cases Philadelphia sat at attention.

George Washington, who has sat immobile astride a bronze horse at the southern edge of Union Square for enough years to make the statue the oldest one in the city still in its original place, had company yesterday morning.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 15. -- An increase of almost $1,000,000 in the assessed valuation of property in Oyster Bay is shown on the 1937 roll just completed at the Town Hall, according to Albin E. Estberg, Assessor. The total for next year is $125,322,990, as compared with $124,345,429 for 1936.

ARISTIDE BRIAND, speaking of another French statesman, once remarked: "The trouble with X is that he knows history. He lives in a cemetery. He takes himself for Mirabeau one day, Danton the next, Robespierre the next. He governs in the past. And the result is he neglects to understand the present, although it's right in front of his nose."

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Outstanding among sporting events of the Summer will be the annual Lenox Kennel Club Dog Show at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club next Saturday. There will be more than 500 entries. Miss Kate Cary is giving a trophy for the best dog in the show.

Dr. Fleming in advocacy of "a moratorium of one or two years on preaching," which he declares "would be a godsend, heartily hailed by both pulpit and pew," will no doubt call forth opinions not only from his colleagues of the Episcopal Church, but more especially from denominations which for generations have known and demonstrated the wonderful efficiency of inspired preaching.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The second annual Showmen's Variety Jubilee, sponsored by the Atlantic City Chamber of Commerce, Sept. 8 to 14, will be staged on what is expected to be a far more elaborate scale than any of the old pageants.

EMANUEL LIST, Metropolitan basso, who recently sang at the Salzburg Festival, will not sing in Europe again this year, but will record the second act of "Tristan und Isolde" in Vienna with Lauritz Melchior and Kirsten Flagstad before sailing for this country on the S.S. Harding in October.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered, in an amendment to its rules, that persons seeking exemption under the Securities Act of 1933 for oil and gas offerings, must file an offering sheet regardless of whether the proposed sales are to be to dealers, banks, trust companies or insurance companies.

The stock market's professional following elected to take profits last week, with a resultant decline in share prices that sent the average level back to where it was in mid-July. The fact that the trading volume was slow at times attested to the fact that little if any liquidation of investment holdings took place.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Earl Caldwell's right-hand slants completely fooled the Indians today as the St. Louis Browns handed Cleveland a 4-0 whitewashing to even up their series at a game each.

Considering the fact that not one of the world's eminent economists has been able to offer a sound plan which would return the many deranged national economic systems to sound functioning, the assumption seems justified that the science of economics itself has at one time been emasculated and has never regained its pristine potency.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Mary Astor tonight picked up the threads of her screen career, interrupted by a court fight with her divorced husband, while a pair of guards kept watch over 4-yearold Marylyn Thorpe, innocent center of the storm.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Mr. and Mrs. Talbot Taylor, who have resided in France for many years, have just arranged to dispose of their property, St. Vigor, at Viroflay, near Versailles. They intend to occupy their place near Nice the year round.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The first map to show the discovery of the New World, the first map to give it the name of America and Captain John Smith's map of New England, dated 1614, are included in a historical exhibition of cartography arranged for the Harvard tercentenary by the Institute of Geographical Exploration.

NEWPORT, R. I. -- This is tennis week at this resort. The city is in readiness to entertain the players who will compete in the annual invitation tournament of the Newport Casino and there is every indication that the event will draw one of the largest galleries in recent years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15. -- Trade of the larger retail department stores expanded somewhat with the second week of August, sales running between 12 and 15 per cent ahead of last year. Demand for women's apparel, including fur coats, expanded appreciably in response to heavy advertising, which offset the effects of the warm weather.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The first old-age colony in the United States -- fourteen WPA-constructed houses deep in the South Jersey pine woods, near here -- will be ready for twenty occupants within two months, it was announced today.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse, a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, called today for a 20 per cent reduction in the cost of State government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Student aid will be paid only for performance of some useful work, under the National Youth Administration's $70,000,000 student aid program, Richard R. Brown, deputy executive director, announced today

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 15.--President Roosevelt's three-day trip through Pennsylvania, Ohio and New York on a "non-political" tour of regions which were stricken with serious floods last March ended in Northeastern Pennsylvania this afternoon with one of the most impressive popular demonstrations that has marked his administration.

LAKELAND, Fla., Aug. 14. -- What happens to a candidate whose friends are so confident of his success that they neglect to vote when the opposing candidate is making such promises as $200 a month to the aged was impressively demonstrated Tuesday.
BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- These Olympics have been notable not only in themselves but for the effect they have had upon all who have participated in them and watched them.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- It is taking longer than they had expected for Premier Leon Blum and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos to get other European governments to consent to keep from mixing in Spanish affairs and supplying arms and ammunition for use in the civil war in Spain.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau, Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, and Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, conferred with President Roosevelt at the White House.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 15. -- After being held on the starting line twenty-one minutes, Edward Bruner's 3-year-old Aneroid, a rank outsider in the bulky field of seventeen, came out of the tuck today to win the $3,500 added Blackstone Valley Handicap, six-furlong feature of the inaugural program of Narragansett Park's thirty-seven-day midsummer meeting.

PORTBOU, Spain, Aug. 15. -- The Leftists in this otherwise sleepy border village celebrated the Assumption, feast of the reception of the Virgin Mary into heaven, by hoisting a Red flag over the town's only church, which remained closed all day.

One second after Franklin Delano Roosevelt had been elected President of the United States on Nov. 8, 1932, the Pantocratic party of the United States was born; and on March 4, 1933, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was inaugurated as the first President of the United States of and under the Pantocratic party.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Tired of hero worship and "pretty sick of running," Jesse Owens went to sleep tonight with a sheaf of cables from American promoters offering him fantastic prices for personal appearances serving as his pillow.

THE committee in charge of the annual team-of-four tournament for a cup given by Harold S. Vanderbilt has announced the dates for the 1936 renewal. Play will start Wednesday night, Nov. 18, and will continue in sessions on Thursday night, Friday afternoon and Saturday night.

LONDON. LADY YULE, whose yacht King Edward VIII has chartered for the holiday cruise he is now making, is one of the richest women in the British Empire, one of the richest, perhaps, in the world. Yet she is one of the least known persons in Great Britain, for she avoids the limelight, living simply and quietly.

PARIS, Aug. 13. -- The final week of the Winter openings finds the leaders of the Paris couture defying adverse conditions and paving the royal road to coronation elegance. Evening gowns are in rich velvets, cloque lames, painted metal cloths, brocades and elaborate bead, jewel and metal embroideries.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- Old White Week, one of the most notable fetes of the year at this spa in the Alleghanies, will be staged here this week.

RIO DE JANEIRO. -- An administration bill drawn by the Brazilian Minister of Labor, Industry and Commerce is now going the rounds of the committees in Congress. The bill is divided into two parts: one deals with the nationalization of insurance companies and the other with the creation of the Bank of Reinsurance.

NO less than five performances at three different European festivals have been observed by this writer since he wrote in the music columns of THE TIMES of the wonderful production of "Lohengrin" which opened the Baireuth Festival on the 19th.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. AMONG the twenty-five national parks Yosemite, in the snowcapped Sierras of California, remains a favorite with tourists. Year after year thousands of "repeaters" return for their vacations. New visitors pour in, filling public camp-grounds, lodges and hotels.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Acting WPA Administrator Paul Edwards announced tonight that Harry M. Lewin, attorney, speaking for ten actors and actresses, denied they ever had charged corruption and vice to the WPA administration in Massachusetts.

Next Tuesday will be "Nordica Day" at Farmington, Me., where the homestead in which the famous soprano was born has recently been redecorated. Groups are coming from many parts of the State to see the Nordica collection at the homestead and attend the concert to be given in the evening by Esther May Barrett, soprano, at the Normal Gymnasium.

THOUGH as these lines are written the major event of the Bennington Festival, which will consist of two new productions by Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their groups in the State Armory, has not yet taken place, the two smaller events in the series have been given in the little theatre of Bennington College.

AS political lightning flashes across the national horizon, teachers are taking an increasing interest in the affairs of government and their relation to the classroom. At Teachers College, Columbia University, for example, where 8,000 men and women from schools in the forty-eight States have been studying this Summer, political discussion has been vigorous and unflagging.

MADRID, Aug. 12 (Delayed; Uncensored). -- Leftist militiamen executed 733 priests, Rightists, Royalists and avowed Fascists in the first three weeks of the civil war, according to information obtained by the writer from doctors, from wives of Monarchists and Right Wing Republicans and other fairly reliable sources.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- Jack Creavy of Albany will defend his title in the sixth annual Sagamore invitation tournament, which starts on Thursday and continues Friday and Saturday on the Sagamore Golf Club links. C. Everett Bacon of Bolton Landing and Montclair, N.J., who won the title the four previous years, and was runner-up last year, heads the committee in charge, assisted by Dr. William G. Beckers and Peter D. Kiernan.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 15. -- Advancing Spanish Rebels tonight occupied Endarlaza, the gateway to the northern Spanish city of Irun, after a day's fighting. They stopped, however, before the town of Behoria on the outskirts of Irun.

ALONE and unarmed he defied the British Empire." That sentence may be taken as an epitome of the war career of "The German Lawrence" and his work with Persian chieftains and tribes. But it sums up only a part of the amazing and tragic life of this amazing man, and it falls far short of suggesting the richness and depth of interest in this author's treatment of his biography.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. AMONG the twenty-five national parks Yosemite, in the snowcapped Sierras of California, remains a favorite with tourists. Year after year thousands of "repeaters" return for their vacations. New visitors pour in, filling public camp-grounds, lodges and hotels.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- A sharp falling off in the movement of hogs here and in the West last week, with more favorable weather conditions, brought about an advance of 35 to 50 cents a hundredweight in the price of most good 190 to 300 pound averages.

After every one had pretty much guessed that he would do just that, Billy Rose now rises to say that in the Summer of 1937 he will woo the nation with a "World's Fair on Wheels." It is to open in May and will boast such equipment as a movable Casa Ma+/-ana, industrial exhibits, "An American Cavalcade" and a new musical treatment of the circus.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The Tigers made it a clean sweep in the four-game series by winning both ends of a double-header from the White Sox today, taking the first game, 6 -- 4, and the second, 8 -- 6.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Stock prices continued to decline this week and the volume of trading was sharply lower, even leading industrial issues being, at times, unquoted. The declines were not severe, however, and some paper and pulp and brewery stocks were firmer.

Commenting in THE TIMES of Aug. 9 on the powers' "No Intervention Due in Spanish Rebellion," Edwin L. James asserts that "a good deal of credit should go to Premier Blum. * * * It would be to belittle Mr. Blum to say that he gave way before the threats of the French Right.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Property valuations in the town of North Hempstead have increased almost $5,000,000 over the assessments of last year, according to the report compiled by the Board of Assessors at Town Hall and the roll just completed, and open to the public. Andrew B. Westervelt is chairman of the board.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 17. -- The possibility of reorienting Japan's policy toward Russia in connection with the forthcoming change in Ambassadors is seen by the press here. The newspaper Asahi announces Foreign Minister Hachiro Arita intends to have the situation re-examined by the Foreign Office and army chiefs in conference with the incoming and outgoing. Ambassadors, with a view to ending the present deadlock.

In a large measure, your editorial appraisal of the new Labor party is correct. You see in the Non-Partisan Labor League, the speeches of its spokesmen and resolutions adopted at the national conference in Washington, the beginning of a new political alignment in this country and the development of an American Labor party.

The New York Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, representing the United States in the international match with the Ulster United eleven of Toronto at Randalls Island yesterday, succumbed by 3 to 1 after a grueling contest.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 16. -- Arthur Rodzinski of the Cleveland Orchestra and the New York Philharmonic, received an ovation at the Mozarteum this morning when he conducted the Vienna Philharmonic in a concert of comparatively modern and largely unfamiliar music.

Mayor La Guardia has promised to investigate a "racket" existing on local piers in the handling of water-borne freight which has resulted in the divergence of shipments to the New Jersey side of the harbor, it was announced yesterday by the Merchants Association.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Mrs. Henry Lorillard Cammann and her sister. Miss Louise B. Willard, gave a reception this afternoon at Lougret Lodge, their home at North Sea, for Mrs. William Vernon Booth, who returned recently from Europe and who has joined Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine at Valmay Cottage for the remainder of the season.

MADRID, Aug. 16. -- Sentries of 15 and 50 guarding the road from Madrid to the Guadarrama front, girls who serve in the lines as well as in domestic duties behind the lines, pleasant villas shattered by shell fire -- these are some of the pictures a visitor to the front carries away with him.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 16. -- Five thousand persons attended the final concert of the Berkshire Symphony Festival this evening at Holmwood in Lenox. This figure represents the average attendance at each of three concerts of this astonishingly successful festival.

CLIFF HAVEN, N.Y., Aug. 16. -Speaking here tonight at the Catholic Summer School of America on "Our Responsiblllty," former Governor Alfred E. Smith defined it as the reservation of the Constitution, war against communism, socialism, fascism and every other kind of "ism," and dedication of all persons to a life-long struggle for preservation of every liberty of the family.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 16. -- Defense plans for the America's Cup are being formulated as a result of the cabled announcement from the Royal Yacht Squadron that it was forwarding a challenge On behalf of T.O.M. Sopwith and his new Endeavour II.
BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- A German monopoly on all the gold there is in Olympic horsemanship, was completed at sundown today as the curtain was rung down on the eleventh Olympic Games.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 16. -- Whatever November may show that Americans think of their New Deal, nations of the British Commonwealth are emphatically for it and some are emulating it or preparing to do so, according to Oliver L. Lawrence of the British Royal Institute of International Affairs.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- Standing squarely behind his Negro protege, Jesse Owens, triple Olympic winner, Larry Snyder, coach of Ohio State's track and field team, accused the Amateur Athletic Union today of not caring "whom it sacrifices to get its 10 per cent."

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Official grain crop estimates for Aug. 1 indicate a yield 570,000 tons less than the July 1 forecast, as a result of bad weather during harvesting. Anticipated yields for all cereals except oats and Winter barley show declines, which are serious only in the case of Winter rye, where the decline was 6 per cent.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- Charged with taking an unauthorized "run-out" on a scheduled trip to Sweden with a team of American track and field stars, Jesse Owens, Ohio State's Negro triple Olympic winner, was suspended today by the Amateur Athletic Union.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- A colorful ceremony marked the formal consecration at Camp Smith today of a new set of colors for the 107th Infantry, the "old Seventh" of New York. The ceremony was the first of its kind held by the regiment in 105 years.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 15. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84, which compares with 84.3 the week before, 83.7 two weeks before. 83.2 three weeks before and 83.3 four weeks before.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- The body of Mrs. Mary Louise Trammell, 24 years old, formerly of Knoxville, Tenn., strangled and beaten, was found late today by her husband in their room at the State Hotel.

ON home soil Germany finally broke into the list of Olympic track and field winners. Here's the order in which the various nations joined up: 1896, Greece, United States and Great Britain; 1900, France and Hungary; 1904, Canada; 1906, Ireland; 1908, South Africa; 1912, Finland and Sweden (and how!); 1924, Australia; 1928, Japan; 1932, Argentina; 1936, Germany.

That co-starring team of Merle Oberon and Miriam Hopkins which proved so popular in "These Three" will not be divided by Producer Samuel Goldwyn. The word from Hollywood yesterday was that he had purchased Ferenc Molnar's "Angel Making Music" for the twain.

A "woeful lack" of knowledge on the part of school children of what constitutes crime or juvenile delinquency is disclosed in a survey just completed by the National Crime Prevention Institute, Rowland C. Sheldon, executive director, announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14. -- There was more activity in the cotton market last week with a fair volume of speculative trading and some buying by foreign interests. The demand, too, was supplied by short covering, and a moderate amount of hedge-selling against the increasing movement of the Texas staple.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP). -- The fading Rochester Red Wings lost more ground in the International League race when they dropped their second successive double-header to the Newark Bears today. The scores were 5 -- 3 and 8 -- 1.

While two members of the clergy, in their sermons yesterday, continued the attack on the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming's proposal for a moratorium on sermons, a third clergyman went even further than the rector of Trinity Church and declared that the day would come when the church would not be needed, and a fourth held that the need of the age was "more and better preaching. "

Patrolman Frederick W. Gruber of the East Fifty-first Street police station, was struck by an automobile driven by a New Jersey WPA worker at about 10:40 o'clock last night as he was leading an aged blind man across Forty-second Street between Madison and Vanderbilt Avenues.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- Striking documentary evidence of corruption in municipal government 3,500 years ago has come to light with the translation of a set of cuneiform texts constituting by far the earliest known detailed court record of the trial of a racketeering public official.

Isn't it nearly time for another Paul Revere to ride through the land to awaken some of the alleged patriots whose vision is so impaired that they see great inconvenience in some of the army's necessary activities and miss the possibilities of greater loss if such activities were not undertaken?
LONDON, Aug. 14. -- United States and Canadian wheat-crop estimates, although bullish enough, proved to have been largely discounted here and prices dropped sharply after issue of the figures.
As you know, the passing of Godfrey Gloom, the late Jeffersonian, was not unmourned by a small group of relatives. I encountered one of these, Gervasius Gloom by name, the other day.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The view that the Bank of England's note circulation would reach its peak in the August bank holiday week was confirmed by the decline of u4,121,508 which occurred this week. In the corresponding week last year, however, the circulation decreased u6,300,000.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices in Great Britain for July, based on the average of 1930 as 100, is 93.6, compared with 92.6 in the preceding month and 88.1 in July, 1935. The current price level is the highest since November, 1930, while the rise since July, 1935, is 6.2 per cent, which is the largest increase for any month this year.

While there were fewer visiting buyers operating in the wholesale markets here last week, manufacturers received a substantial volume of reorders for apparel and accessory lines. Mail requisitions were reported the heaviest so far this season in some departments.

Mayor La Guardia took a serious attitude yesterday toward the newly developed sport of ricksha racing. He refused to start a race from City Hall to Asbury Park on Sept. 2 on the ground that pulling a ricksha was not a sport but a "symbol of human degradation."
