NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Gordon M. Wagner, president of Father Coughlin's National Union for Social Justice in the Twenty-fifth Congressional District, resigned from the office today and severed all connection with the organization.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- The Soviet decision to hold a public trial for Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kamenef, F. Evdokimoff, Professor Smirnof and a dozen other ex-Trotskyists on a charge of high treason will presumably put an end to reports that the Kiroff murder in the Winter of 1934 was a personal crime of passion rather than a political assassination.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public and which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,156,484,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Wherever the exiled TROTSKY may hide, on an island in the Bosporus, in the forest of Fontainebleau, in a Norwegian village, he continues to haunt the Kremlin. Visitors in Russia today see the face of STALIN everywhere. In the new ikon corners in schools, factories, clubs, shops and homes, his image grows larger and larger as those of LENIN and MARX grow smaller and smaller.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 16. -- San Sebastian and Irun may be taken by the Rebels tomorrow or may hold out for a few days, but their fate seems sealed. Probably they will resist to the end, for their defenders have been warned by the wholesale executions in Badajoz that they can expect no quarter from the victorious Rebels.

Doubts rise in the mind of the incompleat angler as to whether even the fish had a break when part of the old Fulton Market collapsed into the East River the other day. The incubated and air-cooled lobsters, halibut and mackerel mass-produced for the New York market, are they able to swim?
GALWAY, Irish Free State, Aug. 16. -- The largest constituency in the Free State has given its verdict in favor of President de Valera's policy in the by-election just concluded here.

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- The French investigation of the airplane crash at Biarritz yesterday leads to the conclusion that British private interests are endeavoring to supply commercial airplanes to Spain. Nothing has transpired to prove to which Spanish faction the planes are destined, but the pilot of another plane which was forced down at La Rochelle has been held for questioning.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 16. -- The time has come for Protestants, Catholics and Jews to unite to preserve their religious liberty, institutions and life, the Rev. Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, general secretary emeritus of the Federal Council of Churches, asserted here today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Van Wyck Loomis, who only too rarely has the pleasure, today beat his Interclub Class rivals in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's special regatta, sailing Nixie to an easy first place over nine others.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The eleventh modern Olympic meet came to a picturesque close tonight under the floodlights of the great stadium with a huge choir singing Beethoven melodies, with trumpets sounding its knell, with a battery firing a farewell salute and a crowd far exceeding 100,000, the seating capacity of the big bowl, joining in the final chorus and linking arms in a typical burst of German sentiment.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 16 (AP). -- The State Financial Assistance Commission announced today that fewer than 100 of New Jersey's 564 municipalities had applied for advances from its $6,000,000 relief fund in the last six weeks.

Cotton futures ended last week 20 to 25 points below the close of the preceding Saturday, but were 8 to 15 above the lows established on Monday, when prices opened about 30 points down in adjustment to the government crop report issued at noon the end of the week before.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Moving swiftly and with smooth co-ordination, especially in the first half. Templeton rode to an 8-to-5 victory over Aurora today at Bostwick Field in another of the series of test matches for the coming national open polo championship.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- The Bank of France's report for Aug. 7 showed a gain of 47,000,000 francs in holdings of gold, while sight liabilities declined almost 700,000,000 francs, owing to the return of notes after the month-end. The ratio of gold reserve to note circulation was slightly higher.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Although the world, as a whole, has recovered about half of its economic losses suffered during the depression of the last seven years, the upward movement is being retarded and the standard of living will ultimately suffer because of "unhealthy stimulants," in the form of nationalistic policies and rearmament expenditures, a report of the Foreign Policy Association says.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Polo came back to the Sands Point Club and Gerald Balding returned to the Greentree team today, and the result was a smashing display of power by last year's open champions as they turned back the Hurricanes, 15 to 2, in a test match for the coming national fixture.

Germany has notified the United States that all subsidies on products exported to this country have been abrogated, and on the basis of this assurance our Government has removed the countervailing duties which were imposed on certain German goods about a month ago. For the present, at least, a controversy which aroused much interest has been ended.

AMSTERDAM, Aug. 15. -- There is growing confidence here in a further recovery in the United States, based on satisfactory reports of key industries. It is estimated this may continue although the midsummer this year will be succeeded by active electioneering, and despite the serious reduction in principal crop yields.

Powerful acceleration of both the national and State Republican campaigns in this State is expected to result from the visit to Western New York by Governor Landon of Kansas, it was indicated yesterday at Republican national headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.

Governor LEHMAN'S conduct in regard to the strange sequels of the Drukman murder has been true to his essential characteristics: energy and courage accompanied with patience and a judicial mind. He has not feared the political implications of a case that drips with politics.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16. -- Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 71 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate of the preceding two weeks, but equaling the average rate in May, the highest for a month since early in 1930.

With sharp increases in August magazine linage and with radio program schedules generally completed, the Fall season for both these media promises to be a very active one. While details on this month's newspaper linage are still lacking, publishers expect that newspapers will also show sharp gains in the Fall.

WITH REBEL FORCES ADVANCING ON SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Spanish Rebels operating in this sector began today an effort to defend the Tolosa and Oyarzun fronts across intervening mountains. The troops from Tolosa have been split into two columns.

In his West Virginia speech last week Colonel KNOX struck what was, for him, a comparatively new note. He avowed himself a believer, to a certain extent, in the doctrines of "share the wealth." He is convinced, that is to say, that there should be a wider and fairer distribution of the profits of industry and business.
MADRID, Aug. 16. -- Spain's government, stumbling into the closing days of a month of civil war, announced tonight the seizure of a vast store of clerical wealth.

The Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, ended its nineteenth season of concerts last night on the Mall in Central Park before an audience estimated at 30,000 persons, who gave the conductor long and earnest applause.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 16. -- At the Stockbridge Golf and Tennis Club last night 200 persons attended a dance. Among those who gave dinners before the party were Mr. and Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas, Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay C. Hoguet and Mr. and Mrs. John M. Deely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- A movement to unite "progressive elements" for the re-election of President Roosevelt was announced today by former Senator Smith W. Brookhart in declining an Iowa Farmer-Labor nomination for United States Senator.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- A total of 4,500,000 admissions was sold for the Olympics just ended, according to an official report issued tonight by the German Organizing Committee. This, of course, gives no clue to the number of spectators attending the games for longer or shorter periods.
MOSCOW, Aug. 16. -- Moscow and Leningrad received a grim glimpse today of what the Soviet Union is doing in preparation against war in the air.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The rampaging Browns dropped Cleveland a half-game further behind the Yankees by pounding sixteen hits off three Indian hurlers for a 9-2 victory today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16. -- Further charges against Gregory Zinovieff and Leon Kameneff were made public today. They include an allegation that "Trotskyists" were active in a movement in the Ukraine in 1934 for secession of that region from the Soviet Union.

In Isaiah, God arraigned the world for community sins such as prevail today, the Rev. Dr. Olin McKendree Jones, minister of the Glen Avon Presbyterian Church, Duluth, Minn., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street near Broadway.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- One refrain that beat through the Olympic Games with the maddening monotony of an African tom-tom was the deep-throated roar of "Deutschland." Sometimes it was a joyous token of triumph and at other times it was a pleading for a victory.

BERLIN, Aug. 16. -- The German Olympic team and the German Olympic Committee were Adolf Hitler's guests at a reception in the Chancellery last night. The Fuehrer cordially thanked his guests for their achievements and also discussed the problems confronting German sports in connection with the Olympics in Tokyo in 1940.
The Giants and 15,000 fans took a sorrowful farewell of the futile Phillies at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and there was a feeling of genuine regret in the camp of Colonel Bill Terry.

POLAND, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Dairymen and their women folk from twenty-nine counties roared their willingness today to participate in a milk strike if such a move is deemed necessary to obtain a flat price of $3 a hundred pounds for all milk.

MONTAUK, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Senator and Mrs. Thomas H. Cullen of Brooklyn, who are spending the Summer here, entertained at dinner tonight at Montauk Manor in honor of Judge and Mrs. George Martin, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Donahey and Miss Ann McCulley.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The Reds shuffled the National League pennant race today, taking both games of a double-header from the Cubs, 4 to 3 and 5 to 4, to drop them into third place and permit the Giants, who won from Philadelphia, to replace them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The navy will begin its 1937 warship construction program Wednesday when Admiral William H. Staindley, Acting Secretary, opens bids and estimates for twelve destroyers and six submarines.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 16. -- Fire hydrants adjacent to New Hyde Park, Stewart Manor, Garden City Park and Floral Park are popular rendezvous these days for the residents of those villages, who go to them for fresh, drinkable water that can be used for cooking without tainting the food.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., won the Eastern grass court tennis championship today at the Westchester Country Club.

CLEVELAND. Aug. 16. -- A broiling sun had beat down all afternoon on the uncovered speakers' platform in the Cleveland Stadium, and persons who saw Father Coughlin after he retired to his hotel room said later that he was suffering only from the heat and the strain of the three-day convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Miss Ann Cooper Hewitt denied tonight an attorney's charge that she was a "tool" of conspirators, and made ready to face the lawyer from the witness stand tomorrow in the trial of two physicians who sterilized her.

While local predictions of showers this morning, an overcast sky and cooler weather gave New Yorkers hopes for a break in the four-day hot spell, word came from the Midwest of another unexpected heat wave moving slowly eastward.
SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 16. -- F. Thompson Brooks of the Island Heights Yacht Club showed the way in the International Star Class when he sailed his Sue in the regular Sunday races today.

LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 16. -- The Armstrong Cork Company reported today a net income of $1,876,399 for the first half of 1936 after interest, depreciation, flood loss at the company's Pittsburgh plant, Pennsylvania's income tax, and allowance for normal Federal income tax.

Vera Brittain, author of "Testament of Youth," writes from London that for the last six weeks she has done ten hours work a day completing the final draft of her new novel, "Honourable Estate." The manuscript will be mailed to Macmillan within a week and will be published early in November.

MANILA, Monday, Aug. 17. -- Distress calls from a third ship, a British vessel carrying forty passengers, and reports of heavy damage and two deaths reached here today in the wake of a typhoon sweeping northern Luzon Island.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16. -- Argentina's entire economic outlook has been changed by the sharp increase in corn prices as a result of the poor crop and the drought in the United States.

SWEDESBORO, N.J., Aug. 16. -- A 22-year-old thug, who according to police was a member of a Camden, N.J., gang known as "the Band of Forty Thieves." was shot fatally here early this morning when he attempted to escape from Patrolman Angus MacKinnon, who had arrested him when he fled from a store he had burglarized.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Training days are over for Joe Louis. The Detroit Negro wound up his preparations for his ten-round bout with Jack Sharkey at the Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night by engaging in a spirited workout today, and now he has nothing left to do until he steps into the ring with the Boston sailor.

PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Bitter drops of perspiration fell on the Quaker Hill golf course near here today as the White Hopes, the one-game-a-year baseball team of the White House correspondents, went down to defeat by a score of 15 -- 12 before Lowell Thomas's Debtors and Creditors, despite the most strenuous possible rooting by President Roosevelt.

Among the maps announced for inclusion in the historical exhibition of cartography arranged for the Harvard Tercentenary is the first map to give the New World the name "America." The original was made in St. Die, a little city in the eastern part of France where a small group of scholars carried on their researches and made eager use of the new art of printing.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- Firenze Clifton's Beau, brown gelding owned by Mrs. M. Robert Gugenheim of Babylon, L.I., won the hunter championship at the concluding session of the Lake Placid Horse Show today. The reserve ribbon went to Mrs. Gugenheim's Firenze Red Tape.

MADRID, Aug. 16 (By Courier to Hendaye, France. Uncensored). -- "Rusia chica!" [Baby Russia]. That is the ominous slogan of powerful Communist elements among Spain's Government militia, now clamoring with discontent over the administration's slow conduct of the civil war.

CORNWALL, Ont., Aug. 16. -- The reading of a telegram from Governor Lehman of New York warmly espousing the St. Lawrence Waterways plan was a feature of an international demonstration in favor of the project here today.

Those who are in need of leadership should accept God's offer to be their shepherd, the Rev. Dr. D.E. Hart-Davies, visiting preacher from Edinburgh, Scotland, said yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Normal relations of the three coordinate branches of the government have been dislocated under the present administration, the American Liberty League charged today in a pamphlet entitled "Delegation of Legislative Power to the Executive Under the New Deal.

Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, reports a net loss of $5,580,821 for the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1936, after the full Manhattan 5 per cent dividend rental, payable if earned, and all expenses, taxes and charges.

After a day of hesitation, grain markets resumed their upward movement in sequence to Monday's government crop report, while the stock market declined. The Washington estimates did not greatly alter views which had previously been entertained of the general situation.

Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens defended his office yesterday against the charge that all Sheriffs' offices in this city were ovemanned and wasteful. To offset a report to this effect made to Mayor La Guardia by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, and forwarded by the Mayor Saturday to Budget Director Leo J. McDermott, the Queens Sheriff added up the activities of the forty-four persons on his payroll.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 (AP). -- The Cardinals came from behind twice today to defeat the Pirates in a double bill, 4 -- 3 and 7 -- 2. Approximately 35,000 fans, the largest Forbes Field crowd this season, watched the Cardinals tighten their hold on the leadership in the National League pennant chase.

Governor Lehman, falling into the spirit of the occasion, picked out a comfortable spot on the grass adjoining the pole vault pit at Randalls Island yesterday, doffed his straw hat, and with as much enthusiasm and anxiety as any of the 7,500 persons in the stands, trained his eyes on the cross-bar above.

Vandalism and other offenses at trail shelters in the Bear Mountain and Harriman sections of the Palisades Interstate Park have become more serious this Spring and Summer than ever before and have distinctly injured the attractiveness and comfort of the shelters, it was announced yesterday by the Inter-state Park Commissioners.

Head Keeper John J. Toomes stood in front of his office in the east wing of the reptile house at Bronx Park yesterday and let it be known that "Monday a week" he would celebrate his thirty-seventh anniversary at the zoo.

BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Senators defeated the Red Sox, 7 -- 6 and 3 -- 2, in a double-header today, and the teams went into a virtual tie for fifth place in the American League standing. The attendance was 16,500.

The results of work for social, economic and political reform will be great if we devote great faith to the work and if we replace prejudice with conviction, the Right Rev. Stephen E. Keeler, Bishop Coadjutor of Minnesota, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

SEACLIFF, L.I., Aug. 16. -- A.P. Deacon of Larchmont captured two races today to win the North Atlantic Coast Snipe Championship Cup. The series was held by the Seacliff Yacht Club in Hempstead harbor.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 16. -- The northward and westward thrusts from Seville of Spanish Rebels directed by General Francisco Franco have in the past two days roughly divided Spain into halves. During these operations, the Rebels swamped Badajoz, at the Portuguese frontier, in a welter of blood.

John Yearwood, who replies to my letter on unions and unionism, expresses a fear that I am "losing sight of the fact that unions and unionists can thrive only when about 10 per cent of the workers are members."

Perhaps Professor Casey Stengel should go in for astrology or numerology to find out why his Dodgers can't take four consecutive games. Yesterday, with a roaring crowd of 18,000 on hand, the Flatbush athletes won the opening game of a double-header from the Bees, 5 -- 2, behind the three-hit pitching of Master George Jeffcoat.
Nothing in the letter from Frank Jones concerning seamen alters the truth of the heading "American Seamen Will Gain Greatly by New Laws" placed over my letter to you of Aug. 4.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 16 (AP). -The Socialist party of Pennsylvania broke away from the national party today, shouting adoption of a resolution denouncing invasion of its ranks by Communists and approving a platform for education and persuasion "as opposed to force or violence."

In America undue emphasis is placed upon lifting the standards of economic life, the Rev. Dr. Edwin F. Lee, Methodist Episcopal Bishop of Malaysia and the Philippines, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Five members of the crew of the French liner Eubee were drowned but 178 passengers and 36 others in the crew were saved by the British freighter Corinaldo, with which the French ship Collided early Friday.

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 16. -- General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish revolt, came to Burgos today and had a four-hour conference with General Emilio Mola, leader of the northern Rebel army, and staff. It was said they completed plans for a simultaneous drive on Madrid from the north and south.

The belief that the American Federation of Labor will survive any final split with the Committee for Industrial Organization, while the C. I. O., like other dissident groups in the past, will ultimately disappear, is expressed by Edward J. Volz in his annual report as president of the International Photo-Engravers Union, one of the strongest craft unions in the federation.

Victor J. Sudman, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Company, announced yesterday, that his company and the Compagnie Maritime Beige would seek to have the books of the Arnold Bernstein Line audited for the years 1931-33 to determine the freight volume carried by the Bernstein ships.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 16. -- Five of the six adjourned games from the second, third, fourth, fifth and sixth round of the international chess masters tournament were played off today. T.H. Tylor of England and Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, scored victories, and three games were drawn.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The business of binding Europe by a general self-denying ordinance to abstain from giving material assistance to any party in the Spanish civil war is not going well.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- Baseball continuing to be a game wherein wonders never cease, a crowd of 29,000, Philadelphia's largest gathering since the close of Mackian supremacy in 1931, jammed Shibe Park today to see the top and the bottom of the American League tangle in a doubleheader.

The American Museum of Natural History announced yesterday it will send an expedition late this month to Christmas Island, Samoa and several islands of Hawaii to obtain material for new group exhibits for the Hall of Ocean Life and the new Whitney Memorial Hall of Pacific Bird Life.

The railroads repaid in the first seven months of this year $64,325,436 of loans advanced by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, according to J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads. This total was larger than the repayments in each of the three preceding calendar years.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (AP). -- Soviet Russia worked today to complete a wheat harvest ranging from "spotty'' to conditions described as a world record for production. The harvest was 64 per cent completed on Aug. 10, with 142,000,000 acres of grain cut.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The picture of 1,320,000 new homes to be built every year for the next ten years was drawn by the American Federation of Labor today as the outstanding need of this country, from both economic and social viewpoints.

The five-story building altered into small apartments at 25 West Sixteenth Street, plot 25 by 103.3, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been purchased by the Hamed Realty Corporation from the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- School teachers affiliated with the .American Federation of Labor learned today on their arrival here for the annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers that the membership, now more than 17.000, had increased more than 5,000 during the year, with fifty-four locals added to the organization.

The secret of managing an overburdened life lies in the acquisition of inward quiet, the Rev. Dr. James Gordon Gilkey of the South Congregational Church, Springfield, Mass., said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Although operations of steel mills in this country were at only 70 per cent of capacity in June, the steel industry employed 498,000 persons, the largest number ever recorded, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday. Total payrolls and hourly rates of pay also established new high records in June.

ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- Acquisition of 711 acres on the easterly side of Lake George in the towns of Hague, Warren County, and Ticonderoga, Essex County, for future development as a public camp site, is announced by the Conservation Department.

Young striped bass have been discovered in the brackish waters of the Hudson River near Newburgh by scientists engaged in the biological survey of the lower Hudson watershed, according to an announcement by the New York State Conservation Department.

Professor Felix Frankfurter of the Harvard Law School, who frequently has been described in Washington as an official adviser to President Roosevelt, returned yesterday from England on the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic, accompanied by Mrs. Frankfurter.

HOTEVILLA, Ariz., Aug. 16 (AP). -- Snake and antelope priests, holy men of the Hopi people, labored in an underground kiva today over the 1,000-year-old preliminary magic of their weird snake dance supplication for rain.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 16. -- Endangering Red Malaga and Madrid's southern fleet and supply base, General Valverde with 2,500 insurgent troops fought his way through the mountain gorges directly south of Antequera today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The story that Claude G. Bowers, the American Ambassador to Spain, had sought to exercise command of the American vessels sent into Spanish waters to rescue Americans, and that as a result the State Department had found it necessary to suggest to the Ambassador that he could be of more service ashore than afloat, were denied here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- Governor Landon, the Republican nominee, slightly increased his lead over President Roosevelt during the last month among farmers polled in the Farm Journal's Presidential straw vote, while Representative William Lemke, candidate of the Union party, bettered his position.

Fifty-four English schoolgirls and three grammar schoolboys arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic for a tour through Canada. They will leave tonight for Montreal after dinner at the New Weston Hotel, where rooms were reserved for them.
HENDAYE, France, Aug. 16. -- A Spanish Rebel war airplane dropped three bombs on the frontier French village of Biriatou tonight, apparently by accident.

The National Civil Service Reform League made public yesterday, from its headquarters at 521 Fifth Avenue, a letter asking President Roosevelt to issue an executive order forbidding any person employed in a relief agency to request or furnish any political endorsement in connection with any such employment.

The first duty of every Christian is to deal honestly, truthfully and realistically with the facts of life and with the vision of God, Dean Luther A. Weigle of the Divinity School of Yale University said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church. Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16. -- Chief among the social events here today was the luncheon given by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas at the Clambake Club. There were between seventy and eighty guests.

Returning to set light in his jewelry store at 171 Eighth Avenue, at the corner of Nineteenth Street, Samuel E. Segal of 315 West Nineteenth Street scared away four safe robbers at 9:45 o'clock last night, preventing the theft of jewelry valued at $5,000.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y, Aug. 16. -- Exhibitors at the seventh annual horse show of the Lake Placid Horse Show Association, which closed this afternoon, were guests tonight on a moonlight cruise about Lake Placid aboard the steamer Doris.
New courses this Fall in the School of Architecture will include the study of city noises, it was announced yesterday by Professor George M. Allen, who will direct the course.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 16. -- The Rev. James A. Smith, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here, served notice to the women of his parish at all five masses this morning that he would not tolerate abbreviated costumes in his church and told of forcibly ejecting a young woman who came to church for confession last evening dressed in white slacks and a halter and a red bandana around her head.

After several months of consultation the New York Chapter of the Knights of Columbus announced yesterday afternoon that it had completed a settlement of the awards in connection with the disputed "Title Sweepstakes" contest of last Winter and had mailed checks, aggregating $22,500, to 200 prize winners.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 16. -- J. Kearney Rice 3d gave a cocktail party for twenty guests today at the Mount Washington, where he joined Mr. and Mrs. J. Kearny Rice Jr. In their party also are Mrs. Mary Haff of New York and F.O. Bridenbach of Plainfield, N.J.

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 16. -- Governor Landon today directed that time be provided during his visit to West Middlesex, Pa., his birthplace, next Saturday for a reunion with four elderly women who knew him when he was a baby.
LONDON, Aug. 14. -- Prices on the Stock Exchange again are swinging upward. This development, although not surprising to the City generally, is considered most encouraging.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 16. -- Between 25,000 and 30,000 followers of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin sat under a blistering sun in the Municipal Stadium here today and cheered the promise of Representative Lemke, third party candidate for President, whom they have endorsed, to remake America politically and physically.

Cleveland has entertained three national party conventions this year. After the Republicans and the Socialists came the tumultuous gathering on last Friday and Saturday of the thousands who responded to the call of Father COUGHLIN and of Dr. TOWNSEND. They had no Presidential candidate of their own to put up.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 17. -- At the annual meeting today of the Stockbridge Exhibition Committee, Miss Marie O. Kobbe was selected chairman. The other members are Mr. and Mrs. John C. Johansen, Miss Matilda A. Brownell, Mrs. D. Percy Morgan, Mrs. William Marshall Bullitt, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Watson and A. Sterling Calder.

It is a Republican postulate, laid down in the 1936 platform and subscribed to by its national candidates in speeches, that, in addition to discouraging free business enterprise, the effect of New Deal economic policy is to benefit foreign nations at the expense of American citizens.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Two boys in their 'teens, making their first appearances in national public parks tennis competition, stole the show from seasoned performers as the fourteenth annual meet opened today under a blazing sun.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- The Boerse opened the week today in a hesitant mood, then turned weak later in the day. Some commentators here attribute the market's persistent weakness not only to the strained international relations but also to fears concerning the mounting costs of production in Germany.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP). -- During the first half of 1936 Germany tried to square up trade accounts with the United States, and 19,000,000 marks were lopped off the traditional unfavorable trade balance, a report today showed. The balance now stands at 50,900,000 marks, instead of 70,000,000 as at the end of 1935.

Building plans filed yesterday included apartment houses for both Manhattan and the Bronx, in addition to a theatre project for the former borough and dwellings for Brooklyn and Queens. Details of the plans were as follows:

VALHALLA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The firemen of Valhalla made public today their unhappiness over the inconsiderate action of the adjoining town of North White Plains in copying the shrill tones of their fire siren.

A fashionably dressed blond- haired girl, a little over 5 feet tall and weighing no more than 95 pounds, was booked in the Sheepshead Bay station last night on a charge of assault and robbery. She was accused of having robbed three persons in apartments during the day.

Picturing President Roosevelt as "heartless" and his administration at Washington as heedless to the claims of disabled and needy veterans, Edward J. Neary, Past New York State Commander of the American Legion, announced yesterday that a drive would be started immediately to win the support of the 750,000 war veterans in this State for Governor Landon.

WELLSBORO, Pa., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Lyle West, 14-year-old farm boy, wept in his cell tonight after a grand jury held him on charges of involuntary manslaughter and pointing firearms in the death of his 8-year-old chum, Hugh Townsend.
One hundred buyers, stylists, milliners and dress designers returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from the Parish fashion shows.

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- Neither Germany nor Italy has as yet replied with anything like a definite acceptance to the French proposal for a pact of non-intervention in the Spanish civil war. Today, however, Ambassador Charles de Chambrun in Rome was assured that the Italian Government's reply would be forthcoming, perhaps tomorrow.

Variously described as a law which would bring a marked rise in living costs and put retailers out of business and as a measure assuring lower prices and the salvation of small independent business men, the Robinson-Patman act was the subject of discussion at the regular luncheon meeting yesterday of the Sales Executives' Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Three witnesses testified for the prosecution yesterday at the start of the Special Sessions trial of Chester W. McNally, a lawyer, and F. Chester Steup, secretary of the Yorkshire Indemnity Company of New York, on two "informations" that they demanded and received $900 to award a $4,200 indemnity claim on the company.

TORONTO, Aug. 17. -- Benito Mussolini Graziano was born yesterday and upset his parents' hope to tie the score for first place in the $500,000 Millar baby derby. They had expected twins, which would have put them right up with the leaders, each of whom reports ten entries.

Governor Landon will carry Maine in November by more than 60,000 votes, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern Landon manager, asserted yesterday upon his return from Maine, where he conferred with leaders over the weekend.

The Bryant Park Open-Air Reading Room, the youngest offspring of the New York Public Library, observed its first anniversary yesterday, and Miss Ruth Wellman, superintendent of the extension division, saw to it that the occasion lacked nothing that goes to make a birthday party.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Testimony that Ann Hewitt was sterilized without her permission and that one of the surgeons later denied that the operation had been performed was given today at the trial of Drs. Tilton E. Tillman and Samuel G. Boyd, accused of a mayhem conspiracy.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- Count and Countess Laszlo Szechenyi will entertain tomorrow at their home, the Breakers, at a luncheon for all of the players in the Newport tournament, which opened today. It will also be a farewell party for Count Szechenyi, who is Hungarian Minister to Great Britain. He will leave on the dirigible Hindenberg Wednesday.
YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 17. -- Japan wishes to enter into a treaty with the United States and Great Britain to guarantee permanently the independence and neutrality of the Philippine Islands.

Cooperation of European governments as exhibitors in the New York World's Fair of 1939 can be obtained only through agreements by the local fair sponsors to build international exhibition halls, Grover A. Whalen, president of the exposition, informed the executive committee of the organization yesterday at its weekly meeting in the Empire State Building.

In connection with reports that the Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an investigation into alleged manipulation of the common stock of the Deisel-Wemmer-Gilbert Corporation, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, S.T. Gilbert, president of the corporation, issued yesterday the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- More than 2,000,000 persons on farms and in rural communities will be in need of direct Federal relief before Winter as a result of further crop damage throughout the Middle West and Northwest States, according to a summary made today by relief officials of latest reports from the field.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- A dinner dance was held tonight at the Piping Rock Club for the benefit of the Saratoga Golf Club, of which George H. Bull is president. Mrs. Chauncey Olcott was chairman.

Marked increases in advertising will feature the launching of the 1937 automobile models beginning early in October, it was predicted in well-informed quarters here yesterday. Increases ranging up to 25 per cent or more in the cases of individual manufacturers were cited as likely.

WHEN Max Schmeling swiped J. Louis on the side of the face in June he not only raised a large lump on the Louis facade but he also changed the whole complexion of the fighting front. Before that the mere suggestion of a bout between Jack Sharkey and Joe Louis would have sent ringsiders into roars of derisive laughter.

WASHINGTON', Aug. 17. (AP). -- Ernest G. Draper, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, predicted today that unless there was some major change in present business trends, national income produced this year will be close to $60,000,000,000.

Details of the proposed acquisitions of the Ducktown Chemical and Iron Company by the Tennessee Corporation, and of the Tavern Rock Sand Company by the Pennsylvania Glass Sand Corporation were disclosed yesterday in applications to list additional securities, approved by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- A defense of the "Norris plan" for reorganization of the Chicago Elevator Properties, Inc., a subsidiary of the Rosenbaum Grain Corporation, was mailed today to holders of the company's bonds by the protective committee headed by H.L. Harker.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17. -- Isaac I. Kashdan, New York State champion, playing in the first section; Maurice Fox of Montreal and W. Suesman of Providence, R.I., in the second, and A.E. Santasiere of New York, Harold Morton of Providence and J. Levin of Philadelphia in the fourth, kept their slates clean today in the national open chess tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A set of rules governing trade practices in the ladies' handbag manufacturing industry was promulgated today by the Federal Trade Commission. The rules govern an industry, the commission said, which employs between 12,000 and 15,000 persons and which had an estimated total sales volume in the year ended March 25, 1935, of $33,000,000.

One international polo adventure reached its end yesterday and another starts today with the arrival in port of the first lot of ponies to be used by the Argentine in the matches against the United States next month at Meadow Brook.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Chronicle said in a copyrighted story today that a gold mine was operating near Jungo, Nev., for which the owner has turned down offers aggregating $10,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17. -- Heading for New York and a round-trip flight to London, Harry Richman, night club singer, and Dick Merrill, transport pilot, took off from Grand Central Air Terminal in their $100,000 Vultee monoplane, "Lady Peace," today.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Senator Theo G. Bilbo interrupted a political speech he was making today to engage in a fist fight on the speaker's stand with A.G. Favre, chancery clerk of Hancock County. Neither landed a square blow.

Clothing firms contributed a major share of the business leasing reported by brokers yesterday. Both lofts and stores appeared to be in good demand. Several large contracts for manufacturing space in Brooklyn were listed. The commercial rentals were as follows:

Gibraltar, according to the books, is Jebel-el-Tarik in the Arabic tongue, the Hill of Tarik, and TARIK was the commander under whom the Moors entered Spain in 711. There they remained a matter of 800 years until expelled by FERDINAND and ISABELLA who thus liquidated, as we would say today, the domination of Christian Spain by the infidels.

Departing in only five instances of any consequence from its original conclusions, the New York City Charter Revision Commission filed yesterday afternoon with City Clerk Michael J. Cruise the final draft of the document under which it believes this city properly could be governed.

Aside from a further advance in representative bonds of sugar companies, trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange lacked yesterday the buoyancy of recent five-hour sessions and became routine as prices drifted quietly within narrow limits.
SEATTLE, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, still closed on the fifth day of a strike under leadership of the American Newspaper Guild, said in a statement today:

MOSCOW, Aug. 17. -- Gregory Zinovieff and Leon Kameneff will be tried as bandits, not as political offenders. When they face the military tribunal of the Supreme Court Wednesday night on charges of plotting the assassination of Joseph Stalin and other Soviet leaders it will be in a setting as undramatic as possible and they will be stripped of the glamour they once wore as high leaders of the Soviet.

SAINT JEAN DE LUZ, France, Aug. 17. -- The story of how 500 screaming Rebel hostages held by Leftists burned to death at Bilbao in a warehouse fire started by shells from a Rebel cruiser was told here tonight by sailors of the German destroyer See-Adler.

LONDON, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Forced to follow on in the third and final cricket test match against England, India, at the end of the second day's play today with seven wickets in hand, required 93 runs to avoid defeat by an innings. Against England's total of 471 for eight declared, the touring team made 222 and 156 for three wickets.

No less than four combinations found themselves in a tie for top honors with 65s in the Long Island Professional Golf Association's one-day amateur-pro best-ball competition staged over the picturesque Oakland links in Bayside yesterday.
MADRID, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Spanish Government troops drove on tonight in their "victory march" across the island of Majorca.

POTSDAM, Germany, Aug. 17. -- The 150th anniversary of the death of Frederick the Great was observed today, with ceremonies terminating tonight with a concert of sacred music in the old garrison church in the presence of a large gathering of veterans of the old imperial army, officers of the new Reich defense forces and party leaders.

Governor Lehman yesterday appointed Charles K. Burdick, dean of the Cornell Law School, and former Supreme Court Justice James V. Coffey of Troy, N.Y., as his advisers in the hearings on the removal charges against District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, which are scheduled to begin on Aug. 26.

Plans or a world's heavyweight championship battle next month between James J. Braddock, the title-holder, and Max Schmeling, German fighter who formerly held the crown, were jeopardized yesterday when it became known that Braddock is suffering from an injured left hand.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER EFFIE M. MORRISSEY, off Greenland, Aug. 17. -- We have had an unusually fine summer in Northeast Greenland. An unusual condition has come about this season. I suppose it happens only once in a seafarer's life in the Arctic -- open water from Cape Farewell to Shannon Island.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Increases in the volume of loans to farmers and in voting stock held by them was reported today by production credit associations of the Farm Credit Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The forecast of drought relief for 75 per cent of the farm population of the Dakotas made today by Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, was based upon reports from Howard O. Hunter, Assistant WPA Administrator, and Howard Drew, field representative, who conferred at Chicago on drought damage in those States.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Petitions for allowances aggregating $2,705,051 have been filed in Chancery Court in the settlement procedure of the Missouri-Kansas Pipe Line Company (Mokan) receivership.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- A daughter of Sun Beau, Sunset Girl, captured the featured Kentucky Claiming Stakes today to continue the success the Milky Way Farms' 2-year-olds have enjoyed this season. She went to the post indifferently supported in a field of eight, but was a decisive winner by three lengths at the end of the five furlongs and a half.

The foreign exchange market yesterday was narrow and dull, although the French franc and a few of the other important foreign currencies gained slightly against the dollar. The franc increased its small margin of safety over the gold-export point by moving up 1-16 point to 6.58S/R cents, and there were no further engagements of gold in Paris for shipment here.

FRANKFORT-ON-THE-MAIN, Germany, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Members of the American Olympic swimming and water polo teams acquitted themselves well in a meet tonight, but a group of the Japanese aquatic stars, who are touring Germany in three groups, met defeat at the hands of German swimmers.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, in a statement issued yesterday, called upon President Roosevelt to issue an executive order to Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, against "the continued use of political endorsements as a requisite to WPA jobs."

Notice was given over the weekend by the Curb Exchange that, by proposed amendment of its constitution, it was taking steps preparatory to expanding its unlisted department in accordance with the provisions of the new rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 17. -- The Foreign Legionnaires of General Francisco Franco, Spanish Rebel commander, were repelling counter-attacks by Loyalist forces at Merida today, according to reports reaching here.
An old heavyweight ring warrior and a comparative youngster will fight tonight, if weather permits, for a foothold on boxing's comeback trail.

TRENTON, Aug. 17. -- Asserting that a crisis exists in New Jersey's emergency relief situation and that conditions are making for fiscal chaos in the municipalities, Governor Hoffman said today he considered a special session of the Legislature advisable.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 17. -- In a north-northwest breeze of from 10 to 12 knots the first race in the annual Long Island Sound junior championship series was sailed today and the Cold Spring Harbor crew carried off top honors.

A few hours after a colloquy in Essex Market Court with the Rev. Dr. Harry L. Bowlby, general secretary of the Lord's Day Alliance of the United States, Magistrate Michael A. Ford predicted yesterday that Sunday laws would go the way of other unenforced restrictions written long ago into legal codes and never repealed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- A four-way check system to ascertain personal campaign expenditures by candidates for President, Vice President and the Senate has been developed by the special Senate committee investigating campaign funds. The committee is headed by Senator Lonergan.

The volume of bankers' acceptances outstanding showed less than seasonal decline in July, according to figures announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank. As of July 31, the total outstanding was $315,528,440, a decrease of only $903,292 from the month before, and a decline of $5,362,306 from the end of July, 1935.
The dollar on the local foreign exchanT, e market, based on quotationc far tha French franc on the da*,s indicated, compares as follows (quotations are in cents):

Three seamen of the Panama Pacific Line steamship Pennsylvania were arrested aboard her yesterday morning and charged with felonious assault on the high seas, which the authorities said indirectly resulted from the strike on the steamship California of the same line last Spring.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Women of the Summer colony, headed by Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin, are interested actively in the plans for a bridge tournament for the benefit of the Roosevelt House which will be held here the night of Sept. 2 at Mrs. Claflin's home in the Shinnecock Hills.

MANASQUAN RIVER, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Maurice O'Connor, Branch Brook professional, scored an individual 71, one stroke better than par, to win the sweepstakes, held as part of the New Jersey P.G.A. one-day tournament at the Manasquan River Country Club today.

Miss May Moffitt, who had been employed for the last eleven years as a companion to Mrs. J.F. McClunn, a Summer resident of Monmouth Beach, N.J., whose home is at 58 Ocean Avenue, died of a heart attack yesterday while battling a strong current in the surf at Monmouth Beach.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on Aug. 12 shows decreases for the week of $21,000,000 in total loans and investments and $43,000,000 in deposit balances standing to the credit of domestic banks and increases of $69,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $71,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.
SEVILLE, Spain, Aug. 17. -- This Rebel city has come to feel that the presence of the Italian destroyer Antonio da Noli here means that an ally has come to help the insurgents.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- Most of the members of the American Olympic team seem homesick after less than a month in Europe. The American officials left here assumed that everybody would want to get on the last boat available, the Manhattan, sailing on Aug. 26.

Though Broadway still finds itself locked fast in the grip of Summer, hardly a day slips by without tangible indication that Autumn is approaching fast and a new season is being hatched. Yesterday there came word from the office of Delos Chappell that Oct. 14 has been set for the opening date of "Daughters of Atreus," the Robert Turney play, and that the Forty-fourth Street Theatre will be the house.

A sudden squally rainstorm toppled rising temperatures of the heat wave 18 degrees within an hour yesterday, but after the storm had passed the mercury rose again to within 1 degree of the high of 86 for the day.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers and including Kidder. Peabody Co., Graham, Parsons Co., F.S. Moseley Co., Bear, Stearns Co., Hallgarten Co., Shields Co., Wertheim Co. and Speyer Co. will offer to the public today $4,500,000 of an authorized issue of $10,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent debenture bonds of the Allied Stores Corporation.
United State Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- A suit seeking to block the Federal Reserve System's order, effective today, requiring a 50 per cent increase in reserves maintained by member banks, is before the Federal District Court here. The action was brought by A.B. Nordskog.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 17. -- Dr. Max Euwe of the Netherlands and M. Botwinnik of Russia drew their games today in the seventh round and held their places at the top in the international chess masters' tournament.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 17. -- Martin Moore, 22-year-old Negro hotel hall boy, was indicted this afternoon on charges of first-degree murder and first-degree burglary in connection with the death July 16 of Miss Helen Clevenger, 18, New York University co-ed, of Great Kills, S.I.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Prices of hogs advanced here today 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds to a new high level since September, 1935, with sales at $11.85. This price was 25 cents above the best made on Friday, with the day's average up 20 cents at $10.45.

In Topics of The Times you write of two important factors that ought to be taken under advisement by the city authorities in connection with our congested traffic, particularly at crossings. It is only too true that most of our accidents and deaths occur at the crossings where even the greatest of caution on the part of pedestrians brings no greater safety than if one trusts to luck entirely.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 17. -- Beating a storm and eight horses home in the fourth race at Narragansett Park today, Mrs. Charles Crane's Ladfield scored by a length over Mrs. Ray Pollard's Fickle Chance in the Uxbridge Purse, six-furlong sprint for 3-year-olds and upward.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The action of Mayor La Guardia of New fork in rebuking yesterday as "un-American" the proposed ricksha relay between New York and Asbury Park threatened to develop into an international incident here tonight.

Following the reaction of over $2 a bale in the closing days of last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and recovered 9 to 14 points. Influenced by reports of damage over a wide area, with no relief in drought sections and a storm approaching the Texas coast, commission house interests were heavy buyers, readily absorbing offerings at improved levels.

Chairman HAMILTON, interrupting his perambulatory oratory to look into political conditions, found in California a dark party prospect which the August primary registration figures sustain. Ever since 1932 the Democratic registrants in that State have been outnumbering the Republicans, and the latest returns reveal them in a very large and increased majority in the State as a whole.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 17. -- Rebel forces attacked Irun and San Sebastian by land and by sea tonight, with one column of the insurgent troops holding newly won entrenchments outside Irun and another column battling government soldiers near Alza, only four miles from San Sebastian.

United States Senators Carter Glass and Harry F. Byrd of Virginia, at times sharply critical of President Roosevelt's New Deal policies, will support the President actively for re-election, National Chairman James A. Farley was told yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Aug. 17. -- A two-week Summer school of traffic began classes today at Harvard's Bureau of Traffic Research, arranged in cooperation with the International Association of Chiefs of Police and the Automobile Manufacturers Association.

THERE are various kinds of American literary histories. Professor Cairns compiled a catalogue sort, extremely useful for reference purposes. Professor Parrington began a broader synoptic sort, which, unfortunately, he did not live to complete. Ludwig Lewisohn, among others, has written a personal sort, not always reliable so far as dates and data are concerned, but crammed with acute and crotchety analysis.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- Gregory Mangin of Newark, N.J., sixth in the national ranking, fell a victim to one of the tennis season's biggest form reversals today as the annual invitation tournament started on the turf courts of the Casino.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 17. -- City Commissioner George E. Brunner asserted today that in the handling of the relief problem Governor Hoffman and the legislature had shown themselves to be "bullheaded and sore," and that they had refused to provide adequate State aid because Camden and other municipalities had been showing up the "flagrant squandering" and the "political racket" of the old emergency relief administration.

The penultimate concert of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium last night was duly distinguished by the appearance of Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist, as soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Willem van Hoogstraten.
EASTON, Pa., Aug. 17. -- Eleven persons were injured, two seriously, when a Greyhound bus, carrying thirteen passengers, crashed into a truck on the Delaware Water Gap road ten miles north of here.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The stock markets here continued generally firm today on receipt of excellent trade reports. British funds were steady. Domestic railroad securities were supported and foreign issues were undecided. Among the internationals, International Nickel strengthened on dividend expectations.

Representative LEMKE'S address to a large outdoor audience at Cleveland on Sunday outdid all the writers on all Utopias anywhere or at any time. His picture of the transformed America which will emerge as soon as he is elected President was all bold highlights.
AMARILLO, Texas, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Crop and soil conservation experts of the Southwest today told the President's Drought Commission that dry weather on the Great Plains "can be whipped."

MONTREAL, Aug. 17. -- Three firemen were killed tonight and thirty-five others injured, two critically, in a fire which swept a three-story dry goods store at St. Catherine and Amherst Streets, in Montreal's main business area.

With more than six weeks still remaining before persons in the age group between 65 and 70 become eligible for old-age security payments, the City Department of Public Welfare already has on file, as eligible effective Oct. 1, the applications of 4,306 men and women for such aid.

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 17. -- Governor Landon made public today the names of those who will accompany him as advisers on his Eastern trip, which will start on Thursday. All are from Kansas or Missouri. They are:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A new revolver of tremendous power, which J. Edgar Hoover says might wreck an automobile engine with a single shot, is being tested by the Bureau of Investigation which he heads.
SACRAMENTO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Fifty of California's fifty-eight counties registered a Democratic majority for the August primaries, Secretary of State Frank C. Jorban disclosed today.

Amerine Shaker, 14 years old, and her sister, Lorraine, 9, were credited by the police yesterday with having saved the life of an 85-year-old woman whose dress caught fire white she was using a cleaning fluid in her furnished room at 139 Pacific Street, Brooklyn.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Miss Rena Breen, 21 years old, of New York, admitted here today that she was the young woman "dragged" from a pew in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by the pastor last Saturday evening because she wore slacks and a halter.

More than fifty patrolmen from midtown station houses were summoned about 9:30 A.M. yesterday to quell a strikers' demonstration in the vicinity of Sixth Avenue and West Twenty-fifth Street, in which three persons were injured. Three men and four women were arrested.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The White Sox made only seven hits off Johnny Allen and Thornton Lee today, but they combined the blows with eleven walks and three errors, to defeat the Indians, 7 -- 3, in the opener of a three-game series. It was the seventh time in eight games at Comiskey Park this season that the White Sox turned back the Tribe.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17. -- Told that Pennsylvania was the pivotal State in the Presidential campaign, members of the Republican City Committee began their local drive today, endorsing unanimously the national, State, Congressional and legislative tickets.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The world's most modern anti-aircraft weapon, a gun capable of firing twenty-five shells three inches in diameter per minute, was studied by President Roosevelt in the grounds before his home today in an impromptu demonstration by an army unit which was on its way to Summer manoeuvres.

Amid the thunderous cheers of more than 40,000 persons, many of them children, Mayor La Guardia formally opened last night the eleventh and last of the city's giant swimming pools constructed by the Park Department with WPA funds. Located in the heart of Brooklyn's Red Hook section, a region of factories and slums, the swimming pool's opening drew a large part of the population of the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The Florida East Coast Railway, now in receivership, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application to abandon 125 miles of its line extending from Key West to Florida City station. Part of the line for which permission to abandon is requested was damaged by the hurricane which swept the Florida east coast last year.

The intimate World Cinema, closing its lengthy first run of that now famous early Laughton film, "Wanted Men," will set a new course today with a screen presentation of "Murder in the Red Barn" or "Maria Marten." It will be the first showing in this country of the screen version, made in England with Tod Slaughter and Sophie Stewart.

Before the City of New York finally selects an anthem suitable in melody and lyrics to the tempo of the metropolis, the approval of the general public will be sought, according to plans announced yesterday.

DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Descendants will encircle the Fairbanks homestead here on Wednesday to celebrate the 300th anniversary of its construction by Jonathan Fairbanks. From every State in the Union, Hawaii, Alaska and Mexico, 800 members of the Fairbanks family in America are expected to gather for the annual meeting of the incorporated association. Last year 500 attended.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Aug. 17 (AP). -- John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, told stockmen of the Southwest tonight that they might expect to contribute with their taxes to "government-subsidized competition" to the grazing industry.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP). -- Martin H. Carmody of Grand Rapids, Mich. Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus, urged citizens of the United States and Canada tonight "to maintain an organized line of common defense" against forces seeking to undermine government and religion.
ORANGEBURG, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The majority of the New York football Giants reported at the Blue Hill Country Club today for the first workout of the season.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 17. -- A 13-year-old boy was drowned and an 8-year-old companion saved today when a home-made canoe in which they were paddling down Mill River Creek with two other boys overturned as it was driven against the piling of the Pearl Street bridge.

BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- The master of the American Export liner Excambion, arriving today from Mediterranean ports, reported his ship had been boarded at sea Aug. 8 by Spanish Loyalist officers from a submarine which first fired a shot across the bow to halt her.

Most commodity futures advanced slightly in moderate trading yesterday. Rubber, silk and copper futures were easier. On the cash markets corn, rye and lard made new high prices and wheat, oats, flour, cotton, wool tops and beef advanced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Merger of the Empire Gas and Electric Company, the Elmira Light, Heat and Power Corporation and the New York Central Electric Corporation with the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation has been approved by the Federal Power Commission.

In pursuance of the efforts of the Fusion administration to reorganize the five decrepit and wasteful county governments stepping on one another's feet, Mayor LA GUARDIA asked the Department of Investigation and Accounts to inquire into and report the actual conditions in the offices of those governments.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Favorites survived the opening day's play of the twelfth annual Essex County Club women's invitation tennis tournament, halted today by rain before all first-round matches were played.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP). -- "Terrible" and "scandalous" said Jesse Owens's wife and mother today of the Amateur Athletic Union's suspension of the Negro Olympic star. Both agreed that he should turn professional.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The State Department declined to make known today its attitude toward the proposal of the Uruguayan Government that the American republics unite in an effort to mediate the civil war in Spain. Under-Secretary of State Phillips reserved all comment, on behalf of the department, pending official receipts of the Uruguayan proposal.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Reports that the press division of the Republican National Committee in Chicago is slated for a major shake-up were emphatically denied tonight at the committee's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- A report urging development of a long-term housing program, with government aid for low-income projects at rentals not to exceed $6 a room a month, including heat, water and light, was submitted today to the Public Works Administration by the executive committee of the Chicago General Advisory Board on Housing, appointed by the PWA.
Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association, returned from Europe yesterday on the French liner Normandie optimistic over the outlook for the coming season.

Republican leaders, including Chairman Melvin C. Earon of the Republican State Committee, are looking forward to the meeting of the committee to be held at Syracuse tomorrow as furnishing a fresh starting point in the drive to win back control of both of the State administration and the Legislature.

Thirty-five minutes after Judge Morris Koenig had finished his charge in General Sessions yesterday Jerome A. Jacobs, 48 years old, a lawyer; Harry S. Hechheimer, 63, a former lawyer, and Raymond Derringer, 39, a motion-picture operator, were found guilty by a jury of extorting $1,800, in 1934, from Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, the motion picture actress.
Residential and business properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn were included in the urban realty turnover reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade made a tame start and a strong finish. An early decline of around 1 cent a bushel in wheat in sympathy with lower Liverpool cables and better weather conditions for harvesting in Europe was followed by a rush of commission house and local buying which lifted prices here and at Winnipeg around 3 1/2 cents from the low point.

Concerning the imminent advance in retail milk prices as reported in THE TIMES, Helen Hoffman of the All People's party in Harlem said that even a fraction of a cent increase in the price of milk to the consumer means an increase in the death rate; while A.L. Harris, representing International Workers, testified, "A 1-cent increase in the retail price might mean an increase in infant deaths among poor families.

A worried, little brown animal that may have been a mink, a ferret or just a rat, has become the uninvited guest of a radio shop at 1.737 Washington Avenue, near 174th Street, the Bronx. It arrived about 10 o'clock last Saturday night, pursued by a group of men and boys armed with baseball bats and other dangerous weapons.
MONTREAL, P.Q., Aug. 17. -- After thirty-nine years of unbroken rule Liberalism was swept out of office in today's provincial election in Quebec.

David F. Houston, former Secretary of the Treasury and Secretary of Agriculture in the Wilson administration, and now president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company; Sir William Wiseman and Miss Sheila Wiseman and Sir Francis Younghusband, explorer and lecturer, are among the passengers arriving today from England and France on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Louis J. Castellano, special master in the reorganization proceedings of the Prudence Company, Inc., submitted yesterday to Federal Judge Moscowitz in Brooklyn an amended plan for reorganization of the company's guaranteed collateral-trust 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds due on May 1, 1961, under which it is proposed to borrow $2,000,000 which would be paid at once to the public bondholders.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- War Minister Werner von Blomberg announced tonight in a proclamation to the Reich's armed forces that soldiers won twelve of Germany's thirty-three gold Olympic medals, six of the twenty-six silver and six of the thirty bronze.

From the standpoint of the Germans, there is now no doubt that the Olympic Games were a very great success. A total of 4,500,000 admissions was sold compared with 1,247,000 at Los Angeles four years ago; the setting, the arrangements for running off the games and the handling of the crowds have earned general praise; and finally, the Germans themselves won the largest number of medals and the highest number of points.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -- A quicker and cheaper route for steamships to use in voyaging between the American Northwest and Japan is being charted by the Coast and Geodetic Survey.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 17 (AP). -- The Southern Tenant Farmers Union called on Governor J.M. Futrell of Arkansas today to prove his "sincerity" in initiating a movement to solve the South's seventy-year-old sharecropper and farm-tenant problems.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP). -State totals to be used in computing benefit payments to sugar-beet farmers under the 1936 agricultural conservation program were announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

MADRID, Aug. 17 (Passed by the Censor). -- General Joaquin Fanjul and Colonel Tomas Fernandez Quintana, leaders of the revolt in Madrid, were executed by a firing squad in the patio of the model prison of Madrid at 5:30 A.M. today.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Members of the various American Olympic squads, with a day on their hands before leaving on a special train for Hamburg tomorrow to catch the President Roosevelt for home, took the opportunity today to attend the big military festivities at Potsdam in observance of the 150th anniversary of the death of Frederick the Great.

On Nov. 3 the people of this city are to vote on the adoption of a new charter. The final draft of it, filed yesterday in compliance with the law, makes certain changes in the text which was published several months ago. The more important of these changes can best be understood by recalling the main outlines of the original plan which the Charter Commission recommended.
John Farrar reports that "Lost Morning," the new novel by DuBose Heyward, which will be published on Thursday, has had the largest advance sale of any of Heyward's books.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Edna Brewer, a 4-year-old bay mare owned by the Peninsular Farm of Fremont, Ohio, won the $2,000 added 2:22 pace, feature of the opening Grand Circuit harness racing program today at the Illinois State Fair.

Oaths of office were administered yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to three city officials whose appointments he announced last week. They are Rufus E. McGahen, former Budget Director; Leo J. McDermott, who was his assistant, and Kenneth Dayton, formerly an Assistant Commissioner of Accounts.

The securities markets suffered yesterday from comparative inaction. Stock prices drifted lower, including the quotations on steel and copper shares in the face of fresh reports of improvement in these industries. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to only 832,000 shares, the smallest total for a five-hour trading day since June 30.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 17 (AP). -- Directors of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared today an extra dividend of 70 cents a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly disbursement of 90 cents. On June 15 a similar extra dividend was paid.

A slightly slower pace of activity featured the start of the week in the women's apparel and accessory markets here yesterday. Mail reorders reflected the increasing headway being made in August sales activity. Although no particular increase is noted in number of units sold at retail, dollar volume is ranging some 10 per cent ahead due to the better call for coats and suits in the brackets at $59.50 and higher.

Five members of the Young Communist League, in costumes ranging from a barrel to a top hat and cutaway coat, at noon yesterday picketed the front of the Liggett Building, 41 East Forty-second Street, in which are located the headquarters of the Republican National, Finance and State Committees, while members of a rush-hour crowd of nearly 1,000 persons booed and challenged loudly.

CERBERE, France, Aug. 17. -- A picture of the situation and conditions in Barcelona was drawn on his arrival here today by a French Sorbonne professor, who for fifteen years has held the Chair of Jurisprudence at Barcelona University.

MADRID (Uncensored Dispatch by Air to Hendaye, France), Aug. 17 (AP). -- Disloyalty of its aviators has become a main obstacle to the Spanish Government in its campaign to crush the Fascist rebellion.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 17. -- The heat and his exertions in behalf of Representative Lemke, third party candidate for President, sent Dr. Francis E. Townsend to bed today, preventing his appearance at a court hearing here, just as the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin, the other chief backer of the North Dakotan, recovered sufficiently from his exhaustion to go home to Royal Oak, Mich.

Eight Girl Guides from Paris arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie wearing the dark blue uniform of France adorned with the fleur de lis, for a month's tour of the United States under the joint auspices of the Carnegie Foundation and the Girl Scouts.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The amateur days of mercury-heeled Jesse Owens are over if "good legitimate offers" await him in the United States, both Owens and Larry Snyder, his coach turned adviser, plainly indicated tonight.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 17. -- Messengers from Badajoz brought news across the frontier today of a desperate attempt by the Madrid government militia to drive a wedge between the Rebels' northern and southern forces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Approval was given by the War Department today to the revised plans for the proposed bridge to be built across the Hudson River from Tarrytown to Grand View-on-Hudson. While some objections of the navigations interests to the original plans for the bridge have been met in the revised designs, it is understood that the proposed clearances are still opposed by some shipping companies.

ALBANY, Aug. 17. -- Kenneth F. Fee, Director of the Division of Milk Control, announced tonight that officials of the New York Milk Distributors Association, Inc., representing dealers in up-State cities, had requested Agriculture Commissioner Peter G. Ten Eyck to increase the price of milk to the consumer 1 cent a quart.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The Yankees lost a couple of things on arriving here today, but nothing of great moment, so that it may be reported without fear of refutation or contradiction that Marse Joe McCarthy is still able to digest his meals in good order and enjoy his cigars without chewing them to shreds.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Dr. Townsend rested in bed in his hotel today, according to Dr. Earle, Congress Hotel physician, who said he had ordered him to "rest and relax" for several days to overcome strain "due to heat and physical exertion."

Invoking a decision by the Federal Court of Appeals that a United States judge cannot properly impose a prison and a probation sentence at the same time and that a convict must serve such probation time in a cell, a narcotics seller asked Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday to modify a six-year prison and two-year probation term.

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, declared yesterday that no theatre fire or disaster had occurred in New York City for decades solely because of the supervision of his department and that of the Fire, Building and other city departments. The statement was made before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.

The threat of up-State dairy farmers to strike unless they receive a flat rate of $3 a hundredweight for raw milk will probably result in a cent-a-quart rise in milk prices in the cities of the State, Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, president of the New York and New Jersey Milk Institute, said yesterday.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 17. -- The Notchland Players, from the Notchland Little Theatre, Crawford Notch, appeared before a large audience at the Mount Washington tonight, giving three one-act plays, "Fixins," by Paul Green; "When the Sun Rises," by Dorothy Allen, and "A Marriage Proposal," by Tchekoff.

Operations of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and subsidiaries in the first half of this year resulted in a net profit of $3,598,683 after depreciation, interest. Federal income taxes, subsidiary dividends and other charges. Allowing for dividend requirements on 752,854 shares of $7 cumulative preferred stock on which there are dividend arrears, the profit is equivalent to 62 cents each on 1,540,400 no-par shares of common stock.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Aug. 17. -- After slackening their improvement pace in the first three months of 1936, sales of "prosperity goods" spurted spectacularly in the second quarter, led by those of two outright luxury lines -- sporting goods and luggage, the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company reported today.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Chester Sanok of the Forest Hill Field Club of Bloomfield, N.J., won the metropolitan caddie championship at the Ridgewood Country Club today when he added a brilliant, par-equaling 72 in the afternoon to a morning round of 81, for a total of 153.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Setting the pace for the field of thirty-six women golfers in the second annual Briar Hills invitation tournament, Mrs. Mark McGarry of Westchester Hills took the medal honors with a score of 38, 44 -- 82 today.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 17. -- Driving through half a gale and winding up in a thunderstorm, the New York Yacht Club fleet made the run here today from Edgartown, over on the island of Marthas Vineyard.

Republican women leaders of sixteen Eastern States gathered here yesterday for a major campaign conference and reported to Miss Natalie Couch, manager of Landon's campaign among women of the East, that a swing toward Governor Landon was evident in almost every one of their home areas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Foreign service officers are continuing their efforts to evacuate American nationals from Spain as rapidly as possible, according to reports to the State Department today.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- Five fast, new British airplanes, believed to have been destined for the Spanish insurgents, were held tonight at Portsmouth Municipal Airdrome and their owners ordered not to let them leave the country.
The Democratic State Committee, with James A. Farley presiding, will meet today at the National Democratic Club and endorse the candidacies of President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman.

A banking group headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank submitted yesterday the highest bid for a new issue of $5,000,000 of general bonds of the State of Missouri, offering 102.579 for 2 1/2s. The bonds, which will be dated Sept. 1, 1936, and will mature on June 15, 1955 to 1957, will be reoffered at prices to yield from 2.25 to 2.30 per cent, according to maturity.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- After a six weeks' tour of Europe members of the United State Cooperative Commission appointed by President Roosevelt arrived in London today to complete its investigation in the country where cooperatives have reached their greatest dimensions.
