Sir William Wiseman, member of Kuhn, Loeb Co., bankers, who returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania from a two-month vacation in England, said that although there was much war talk in Europe he did not believe the civil war in Spain would lead to a general war.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Two New Jersey golfers and one from the Empire State put together subpar cards of 71 to tie for the lead at the end of the first day's play in the Lake Placid $3,000 open tournament at the Lake Placid Golf and Country Club today.

Six persons, including three young children and a cripple, were saved from drowning shortly before midnight last night by a quick-witted tugboat captain who threw his vessel to the side of the New York Barge Canal in Brooklyn just as the automobile in which the six were riding plunged over a string-piece.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Tigers split a double-header with the Browns today, winning the nightcap with a twenty-hit barrage, 15 -- 3, after St. Louis took the first, 10 -- 7, by scoring six runs in the eighth.

Completing a survey of work already done in putting the eight-acre area on Staten Island in a condition suitable for use as a free-trade zone, Richmond Borough officials said yesterday that the zone should be ready for operation by Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- The Chicago Corporation, an investment company, and A.G. Becket Co., investment bankers, announced today the purchase of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company's 14.3 per cent interest in the Middle West Corporation. The price was $12 a share.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- Another of California's unusually strong crop of young players distinguished himself today at the Casino, when Robert Herman defeated John McDiarmid of Princeton in the Newport invitation turf court tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation to issue and sell not exceeding 57,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds to be dated Aug. 1, 1936, and to mature on Aug. 1, 1966, and to bear interest not exceeding 4 per cent a year.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 18. -- A factory worker's story of how he dug a tunnel from a storm sewer toward a Flint bank vault to obtain money for his wife, only to abandon the plan after they separated, landed the couple in jail here today.

A man who attempted to interfere with a policeman with the statement "I'm the district leader here" was sentenced yesterday to two days in jail after being found guilty of disorderly conduct by Magistrate Samuel Katz in Harlem Court.

Mr. DENNY writes from Moscow that when LEO KAMENEFF and GREGORY ZINOVEIFF face a military tribunal tonight it will be not as political offenders but as bandits. But isn't this a good deal like Alice in Wonderland with the verdict first and the evidence later?
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Three fishing boats, lashed by a tropical gale off the coast of lower California all last night, were reported out of danger today.

The evolutionary growth of voluntary and cooperative companies has established the methods of these retail groups in the food-distributing organization in a common classification with those of the corporate chains, according to Gordan C. Corbaley, president of the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

The lowest general death rate for any one week since September, 1935, and the second lowest infant mortality rate for a single week in the city's history were reported yesterday by the Health Department for the week ended last Saturday.
DALLAS, Aug. 18. -- Republican party workers from all parts of Texas heard John D.M. Hamilton, national chairman, say tonight that the threat in the November election was "change by usurpation."

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 18. -- General Francisco Franco's Rebel drive east, which is being carried out by detached companies of swift-marching Moroccan troops. Foreign Legion men and motorized units, has extended beyond Merida, thirty miles east of Badajoz. If' the Madrid radio is to be beContinued on l'age Three

Spurred on by the hysterical anxiety of two worried mothers, detectives and patrolmen of the Wakefield Avenue precinct in the Bronx broke into Public School 19 about 11 o'clock last night to find 3-year-old Alice Burns and 4-year-old Kay Walker asleep in each other's arms.

Among the passengers returning yesterday on the motor ship Vulcania of the Italian line were six doctors who are members of the Italian-American Physicians Association returning after spending six weeks in Italy visiting the hospitals and medical schools as guests of the government.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 18. -- In striking contrast to previous years when J.P. Morgan, members of the Pratt family and other prominent estate owners appeared to protest assessments on their holdings, today's grievance day session at City Hall was uneventful.
ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Newark pounded three Albany pitchers and took advantage of the Senators' misplays to win tonight's International League game, 12 to 4.
A business building in Chappaqua and residences in various communities figured in yesterday's reports of Westchester realty deals.

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 18. -- Governor Landon persisted today in his decision to confine the advisers who will accompany him on his Eastern trip to a group of Kansans and one man from Missouri. The Governor announced one addition to his personal party, former Senator Henry J. Allen of Kansas, now on a speaking tour in Ohio, who will board the special train at Canton Saturday morning.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 18 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- Fifty thousand Jewish residents of Tel Aviv attended the funeral today of two nurses killed by Arab snipers yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- Germany was again able to improve her balance of trade when she succeeded in reducing imports in July by 4 per cent, as compared with the preceding month, while increasing her exports by not less than 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The British Government has made representations to the United States against the Coast Guard's seizure of the British-registered steamship Miserinko off the New England coast March 14.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 18. -- Two of the three adjourned games were disposed of tonight in the international chess tournament at University College. The first was won by Samuel Reshevsky of New York from Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, who was a pawn behind after sixty-one moves. This success enabled the American champion to take fourth place, next to Reuben Fine, the other American.

The regular New York County grand jury, at the request of District Attorney William C. Dodge, began an investigation yesterday of the hoax telephone call last July 29 which took Justice Alfred J. Hofmann from the Special Sessions bench to Mayor La Guardia in the Summer City Hall on Pelham Bay, the purpose of which still remains a mystery.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 18. -- A marine terminal on Bayonne's New York Bay shorefront was a step nearer realization today with final adoption by the city commission of the revised contract between the city and Central District, Inc., which, under the terms of the agreement with the Public Works Administration, will have charge of the construction work.

The Giants have the right to vision a pennant. They proved it yesterday before 48,672 paying spectators, the largest crowd ever to assemble at the Polo Grounds for week-day baseball, by taking both ends of a double-header from the Dodgers to go a game and a half ahead of the Cubs and pull up close on the heels of the first-place Cardinals.

BOSTON, Aug. 18. -- The question of the constitutionality of the Social Security Act was raised in an advance report of a committee of the American Bar Association which will be presented at the annual meeting at the Hotel Statler Monday.

Bitter argument between John C. McDermott, Assistant District Attorney, and lawyers for ten material witnesses in the New York County grand jury's investigation of the alleged Pennsylvania coal theft conspiracy, marked a hearing yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthal, for reduction of bail for the ten men.

Jack Sharkey's dream of another chance to gain the world's heavyweight title he once held was shattered last night in the Yankee Stadium by the thudding, devastating fists of Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber.

With the announcement yesterday of the appointment of the Simpers Company of Philadelphia as the advertising agency, the $750,000 cooperative merchandising and advertising campaign of the Anthracite Industries, Inc., of New York will get actively under way.

ALLEGAN, Mich., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Lieutenant William W. Harding and his mechanic, Private Francis Maier Plummet, plunged to their deaths today from a blazing pursuit plane which Harding had attempted to land. They jumped at an altitude too low for their parachutes to open.

NEWPORT, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Stanley Piseck, president of the New York State Milk Producers Federation, announced today he would ask dairymen in the Middle West to withhold milk from the Empire State in the event that New York farmers call a milk strike.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Amid warm farewells from German friends and strains of "The Star-Spangled Banner," played by an army band, a large contingent of American Olympic athletes started today on the first leg of the homeward journey.

Many hundreds of WPA employes could not be found at the addresses where they were supposed to live and some of the addresses were found to be non-existent, it was disclosed yesterday in a report on a special survey on absentee employes submitted to the WPA and released by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator.

The weighing of Jack Sharkey and Joe Louis at the New York Hippodrome yesterday was effected without untoward incident. They presented themselves at noon on schedule, Sharkey going to the Hippodrome from his quarters in the Park Central Hotel, while Louis arrived by automobile from his Pompton Lakes training camp.

TORONTO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The peoples of the United States and Canada stand united against "the onrushing tide of radicalism, pagan philosophy and atheism that besets the world," delegates to the international convention of the Knights of Columbus were told today by Supreme Knight Martin Carmody of Grand Rapids.

This week Anne Morrow Lindbergh's "North to the Orient" goes into its second year of publication. Harcourt, Brace, the publishers, report that the book continues to have an extraordinary sale -- that more than 55,000 copies have been sold so far in 1936.

Sales of Sears. Roebuck Co. for their seventh period of the year, !ended on Aug. 13, were reported yesterday as continuing on a record breaking level, making the total !for the year to that data the largest iof all corresponding periods {n the ,company's history.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 18. -- The Rebels sent a second column south from Loja toward the Loyalist port of Malaga today. The first Rebel column, proceeding south from Antequera, is fifteen miles north of Malaga and is waiting to carry out a joint attack, Rebel headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Captain Tamon Yamaguchi, whose replacement as Japanese naval attache here was announced today in Tokyo, has been accredited to the United States Government since August, 1934.

DUBLIN, Aug. 18. -- With announcement tonight of the victory of Denis Allen, Fianna Fail candidate in the Wexford by-election, President de Valera's administration has won its second notable victory in less than a week. The by-elections in Wexford and Galway were made important tests of political feeling with regard to Mr. de Valera's policies of the last few years, and both constituencies have given unmistakable verdicts of supporting the Fianna Fail.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- Hugh Ruttledge, leader of the 1936 Mount Everest expedition, which was beaten by bad weather, has made his last attempt to scale the world's highest peak, he announced after his arrival here from India.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- Operations on the London Stock Exchange were further restricted today, with prices irregular. British funds were firm, although demand was light. German securities were higher in the foreign department and Spanish issues lower.

A casual remark made at a hearing yesterday concerning fees for attorneys and others before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell disclosed that plans are under way for the payment of a 10 per cent dividend, amounting to $9,800,000, to the 20,000 stockholders of the bankrupt International Match Company.

Tenement House Commissioner Post in submitting his budget for 1937 calls attention to the fact that owing to the economy act of the Mayor he was forced to drastically reduce departmental inspections. It has now reached the point where, unless an increase is allowed, he will be unable to inspect the tenements in accordance with the charter provision.

TRENTON, Aug. 18. -- State Relief Director Arthur Mudd returned today to fifteen municipalities, including Newark, their form applications for continuous monthly grants from the State Financial Assistance Commission. He said the local officials in each instance had failed to follow his instructions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Rufo Swain, Negro and a small-time gambler, confessed tonight, according to Police Captain Daniel Gilbert, that he choked and beat to death Mrs. Mary Louise Trammell, 24, in her hotel room Saturday night.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 18. The Mohawk drama festival, which keeps culture alive during the in-between seasons on Union College's campus, dipped this evening into the works of Spoon River's mightiest anthologist. The occasion was the first performance -- and while at it, the first one anywhere -- of Edgar Lee Masters's "Moroni."
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Rip Radcliff's triple and a single by Luke Appling in the tenth-inning today gave the White Sox an 11-to-10 decision over the Indians, their second straight in the series.

Stock prices closed irregularly higher yesterday but the improvement was accomplished in labored fashion. The market continued to be mainly in professional hands, with profit-taking, switching operations and a small amount of investment buying accounting for most of the activity.
Joe Louis weighed 199 3/4, and Jack Sharkey 197 1/4, for their ten-round fight at the Yankee Stadium last night. Arthur Donovan was the referee, and the judges were Charley Lynch and Eddie Forbes.
ROME, Aug. 18. -- Premier Mussolini, who was back at his desk in the Palazzo Venezia today, was expected to give an answer tomorrow to France's proposal for noninterference in Spain.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Governor Floyd B. Olson, only Farmer-Labor Governor in the United States, came out tonight for the re-election of President Roosevelt in a statement dictated from his bed in St. Mary's Hospital here.

Lullabies, ha-cha dance tunes and sentimental old favorites echoed shrilly in three boroughs yesterday as the Park Department picked the youngsters who will compete in the grand finals of its junior amateur singing contest at the Central Park Mall on Sept. 2.

GLENS FALLS, Aug. 18. -- The legislative commission named to select a site on the shores of Lake George on which a monument to Father Isaac Jogues, discoverer in 1646 of Lake George, is to be built, will meet tomorrow to discuss sites and receive information and suggestions from interested persons and organizations.
MADRID, Aug. 18. -- Government military leaders tonight buttressed this capital against an expected onslaught from the adjacent Guadarrama Mountains.

A decline in Liverpool under hedging operations had an unsettling influence on prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here, and although unfavorable crop accounts increased in volume, the market was under pressure and ended with losses of 12 to 17 points.

A comedy-romance from the Paramount workshops, "Yours for the Asking," will move into the Paramount today. The film co stars George Raft and Dolores Costello Barrymore. They are supported by such reliable folk as James Gleason, Lynne Overman, Edgar Kennedy, Reginald Owen, Richard (Skeets) Gallagher and Ida Lupino.

United States Government bonds resumed yesterday their upward course on the New York Stock Exchange as nine of the long-term obligations reached new high levels since their issuance. In the meantime, other higher-grade issues maintained a firm undertone, while speculative interest in the lower-priced corporate loans showed signs of reviving,

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The second concert in the Saratoga subscription series took place tonight at the theatre at Saratoga Spa. Miss Florence Hartley and Miss Betty MacKeown of New York gave a joint recital of songs and operatic selections.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Various interests in the Utica lines of the New York State Railways Company have agreed upon a plan of reorganization under Section 77b, and Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant of Malone has set Sept. 14 as the date for a hearing on the plan in Syracuse.

The two Senators from Virginia, Messrs. GLASS and BYRD, declare their loyalty to the Democratic party. Both of them have opposed and voted against some of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S policies. Senator GLASS in particular has been one of the President's severest critics. When the Administration bill for stopping the contractual payment in gold of interest on Government bonds was before the Senate, Mr. GLASS exclaimed: "This is open repudiation."

BURGOS, Spain, Aug. 18. -- Charges that government loyalist troops had used poison-gas bombs against their own countrymen were made at Rebel headquarters here tonight. The Rebels announced that two-thirds of Spain already was in their grasp.

Captain Thor Eckert, vice president and general manager of the Arnold Bernstein Line, issued a statement yesterday to correct what he termed misleading statements published in connection with a ruling in Brussels that the Bernstein Line had violated a foreign pooling agreement.

In a conflict between parents over the Roman Catholic and Mohammedan religions, Justice Justine Wise Tulin of Domestic Relations Court ruled that three of four children be placed in a Protestant foster home as "a mutual meeting ground for both parents," it became known yesterday.

It was a different Joe Louis who reached his dressing room last night, the same room he had to be carried to after the Max Schmeling fight. He was smiling, and at once attempted to answer the questions that were fired at him concerning his knockout of Jack Sharkey.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- Yielding to renewed diplomatic pressure from France and Great Britain for cooperation in an embargo on deliveries of arms or war materials to Spain, the German Government has formally notified France it is prepared to join such an accord on condition that all States possessing industries for the manufacture of war materials and aircraft become loyal parties to the agreement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The prosecution closed its case late today against Drs. Samuel G. Boyd and Tilton E. Tillman, accused of conspiracy in sterilizing Ann Cooper Hewitt, as the defense, which called the case part of an extortion plot against the girl's mother, indicated that it would seek a directed verdict of acquittal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Tight situations have developed in cash and September corn, the latter soaring today 4 cents a bushel to $1.16, the maximum upturn permitted for one day under the regulations of the Board of Trade. Both cash and future prices for corn went to premiums over wheat for the first time since 1930.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18. -- Bus drivers and mechanics of the Pennsylvania Greyhound lines were called out on strike in the Pittsburgh district tonight, threatening a tie-up of 100 bus routes of lines operating daily through this city.

Four persons, including a physician and two graduate nurses, were under arrest yesterday on charges of participating in the performance of illegal operations on women in a private house at 2,746 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, where, it is believed, more than 100 such operations were performed since the beginning of the year.

The September corn contract rose yesterday above the September wheat contract and closed at a level 2 points higher. This is the first time since 1930 that a corn futures contract has bested wheat in price. The cash price of corn hovered momentarily above that for wheat in 1934, traders recall, but the situation is rare enough to cause much comment in grain and other financial circles.

Scattered through the news dispatches are sidelights that illuminate the tragedy of Spain even more vividly than the reports of wholesale massacre and shattered cities. Monday, for instance, while butchery filled the headlines, two correspondents painted a strange picture of peace behind the battle lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The necessity of expanding its livestock purchase program to include market stabilization operations in sheep and lambs was conceded today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

After nearly forty years in power the Liberal party of the Province of Quebec has at last been beaten decisively. Sharp warning came last November when a Legislature was elected in which the Conservatives and the insurgent Liberals of l'Action Nationale Liberale, united as the Opposition under Mr. DUPLESSIS, the Conservative leader, left the Government only a narrow plurality.

PEIPING, Aug. 18 (AP). -- A diet of watermelon and rice cakes was too much -- or too little -- for four youthful United States marines held in barracks today after an asserted attempt to trek almost 2,000 miles across Asia.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Francis Hartman Markoe gave a buffet supper tonight at Shelmar, his place in Water Mill. During the evening there was an impromptu entertainment by the guests, including divertissements by Miss Anita Zahn and a group of the Duncan dancers.
PARIS, Aug. 18. -- In the same room where the Council of Regents used to meet the new general council of the Bank of France met today for the first time and inaugurated the new regime.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 18. -- Governor Landon would hardly recognize his native town with its usually placid, tree-bordered streets alive with cars, its flag-stop railroad depot turned suddenly into a big-town station and his old home glistening white with a new coat of paint.
FILER, Idaho, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Senator Borah said here today that it is "a grave mistake to assume prosperity will return to this country prior to the time it reaches the American farmer."

MADRID, Aug. 18 (Passed by the Censor). -- One month after having armed its workers to defend its constituted authority, the Madrid government today began transforming its proletarian militia into a regular republican army.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The 1936 sales were concluded tonight with the disposal of brood mares with foals, a stallion and eleven yearlings in what was the most successful year for breeders since 1931. According to the calculations of the auctioneers, 467 yearlings passed under the hammer in recent weeks for $1,163,325.
BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Phillies ended their fourteen-game losing streak, the longest of the major league season, today as Claude Passeau shut out the Bees with three hits for a 7-0 victory.

The Social Security Board, celebrating the first anniversary of the act under which it was created, calls attention to the notable progress already made. Approved old-age assistance plans are now operating in thirty-six States, the District of Columbia, and Hawaii.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 18. -- The Rebels' attack on San Sebastian and Irun by land and sea received a setback this evening when the cruiser Almirante Cervera was struck by a shell from one of the defending forts and left immediately for Ferrol to obtain repairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The largest shipments of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States during July went to the Far East, according to the monthly report issued today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull as chairman of the Munitions Control Board.

ROME, Aug. 18. -- Italy's mighty air fleet was in a state of readiness tonight, and pilots were ordered to be prepared for flight at a moment's notice, as well-informed sources said Premier Mussolini would openly help Spanish Fascist Rebels if France continued openly aiding the Socialist Madrid government.

Yesterday's TIMES reported that an organization known as the Republican Service League has set out to win the "Soldiers' vote" in this State for Governor LANDON. Its appeal will be made on the ground that Republican Administrations have been more generous than Democratic Administrations in granting benefits to war veterans.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Robert Steedle, Federal referee, today ordered that the books and records of the All-Continent Corporation be turned over to Hiram Steelman, trustee in the William Fox bankruptcy proceedings, for examination and audit.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Miss Laddie Irwin, girls' junior champion of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, won the association's one-day tournament today when she scored an 85 over the Maplewood Country Club course.

Chief Justice Frederic L. Kernochan yesterday urged Budget Director Leo J. McDermott to grant increases of $3,750 in 1937 to himself and to the fifteen justices of the court. He explained that whereas the salaries of most city judges were cut 10 per cent under the Economy Act of a few years ago, those of the Special Sessions justices were reduced 30 per cent.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- A group of leading lawyers deliberated tonight on the details of a long-range plan for establishment of compulsory liability insurance for all commercial and private aircraft.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Dean of Locust Valley, L.I., gave a tea at Peckett's on Sugar Hill for fourteen guests from the Mount Washington today. Mr. and Mrs. H.H. McClintic gave a cocktail party and Mr. and Mrs. Wendell Anderson were dinner hosts in the Cave Grill, where many suppers were given following a concert in the ballroom tonight.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 18. -- On top of the cruelties perpetrated by both sides in General Francisco Franco's push eastward from the Portuguese border came charges from two Spanish sources today that poison gas had been employed and might henceforth be regularly added to the terrors the civilian population of Spain is now enduring.

SEATTLE, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Post-Intelligencer, closed since Thursday by an editorial strike, rejected tonight Mayor John F. Dore's suggestion that differences with the Seattle chapter of the American Newspaper Guild be settled by arbitration.

License Commissioner Paul Moss reserved decision yesterday on an application for a permit to build a motion picture theatre at 55 Fifth Avenue. The application was opposed at a hearing by the Fifth Avenue Association and representatives of property owners in the neighborhood.

The Rev. Charles Coughlin says, in essence: "We are a Christian organization in that we believe in the principle of love thy neighbor as thyself. I challenge every Jew in this nation to tell me whether or not he believes in that principle. Since the Jewish doctrine of a tooth for a tooth and an eye for an eye has failed, I ask the Jews to accept Christ's principle of brotherhood."
Various housing and business properties on the West and East Sides changed hands in the Manhattan realty turnover reported yesterday.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 18. -- Three cowboys sought the hand of an unknown lady in London today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18. -- The Daughters of the American Revolution were characterized as "the most dangerous enemies of the free schools in America" by Louis M. Hacker, Columbia University lecturer, in an address here today before the annual convention of the American Federation of Teachers.

Miss Edith Lawrence, a writer, among the passengers of the Red Star liner Pennland, which docked in Hoboken yesterday, described the horrors of the Spanish civil war. She was a resident of the foreign section of Terreno, just outside Palma on the island of Majorca, and was evacuated with other foreigners by the British warship Repulse.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 18. -- The Rev. Reginald Mallett, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, White Plains, N.Y., has accepted a call to Grace and St. Peter's Church, to take effect Oct. 15, Tazewell T. Thomas, chairman of the vestry committee on clergy, announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18. -- Further requests for establishment of a central committee of employes' representatives to bargain with the officials of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation have been handed to the steel company.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,070,400 barrels, compared with 2,963,800 the week before, a rise of 106,600, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Output was 133,500 barrels above the calculation of 2,936,900 barrels daily for August by the Bureau of Mines.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP). -- A "dark horse" from Detroit made himself a favorite to win the men's singles of the National Public Parks tennis championship with a startling upset today of Bill Lurie of New York, who had been seeded No. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Secretary Wallace, replying today to an attack by John D.M. Hamilton against the administration's soil conservation program, charged that the attitude of the Republican National Chairman confirmed "previous indications that the interests now dominant in the Republican party are at heart opposed to any effective national program for agriculture."

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18. -- Mrs. Mary Sidebotham Thayer, 56 years old, of Haverford, Pa., whose husband, Harry C. Thayer, stock broker and former All-America football player, died two weeks ago, was killed this evening in an automobile collision at Margate, four miles from here.

ALBANY, Aug. 18. -- The decision dismissing William P. Hayward as principal of the Theodore Roosevelt High School, made by the New York City Board of Education, was overruled today by Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education, who remanded the case for an adjustment permitting the principal to retire.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Joe Morris of Philadelphia, sailing Arrow II, was off to a flying start today in his attempt to take the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship and the F.T. Bedford trophy to the Delaware River.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Bob Grove gained his fifteenth victory of the season today as the Athletics fell before the Red Sox, 6 to 2.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press). -- England won the third and final test cricket match against India today by nine wickets. The mother country scored 471 runs for eight declared and 64 for one against the touring team's 222 and 312. The first encounter resulted in victory for England by a similar score and the second ended in a draw.

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- Leon Jouhaux, French labor leader, who returned yesterday from a flying visit to Madrid and Barcelona, said today that the massacre of government supporters at Badajoz was accomplished by a trick.

President Roosevelt once challenged opponents to advocate scrapping any of his program. This they seem to hesitate to do. Republicans would scarcely have inaugurated parts of the New Deal but shrink from taking benefits away and now seem willing even to "do something for silver."

CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Si Johnson, former Cincinnati pitcher, held his old teammates to nine hits tonight as the league-leading Cardinals won from the Reds, 4 to 1, in the last floodlight contest of the major league season.

David L. Lawrence, Democratic State Chairman of Pennsylvania, charged yesterday at the Democratic National Committee headquarters here that steel companies were coercing their workers into registering in the Republican column in his home State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Questioned about statements that President Roosevelt favors the industrial unionists in the American Federation of Labor's family row, William Green, federation president, said today nothing had occurred to "change my admiration for the President."

A plea for cooperation among fraternal organizations in social welfare activities to reduce crime was made by Governor Lehman yesterday at the annual session of the Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows of the State of New York in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Sixteen stiff and hungry little pronghorn antelopes completed an airplane trip of about 2,000 miles tonight when they landed at Newark Airport.
Representatives of the large milk distributors of the city were warned yesterday against increasing the price of milk by their counsel at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MATTAPOISETT, Mass., Aug. 18. -- Forty-five large canvas creations competed out in Buzzards Bay this afternoon in the eighty-fifth annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club. It was the largest gathering in one of these events since the pre-World War days.

ROCKVILLE CENTER, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Charley Mayo Jr., the Long Island amateur champion, added another trophy to his collection today when he led a field of sixty-eight in one of the regular one-day amateur tournaments of the Long Island Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Federal Power Commission has approved the merger of the Empire Gas and Electric Company, the Elmira Light, Heat and Power Corporation and the New York Central Electric Corporation with the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 18. -- The arrest here of six men on charges of gambling for penny stakes in a "rummy game" was termed ridiculous today by Police Judge Martin J. McHugh, who dismissed the complaints.

Arrangements made by E. Gerli Co., Inc., raw silk importers, for the development of increased trade in Italian silk, are of an "entirely private nature, without benefit of help or direct connection with the Italian Government," it was announced yesterday by Paolino Gerli, president of the company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The note from Uruguay suggesting mediation by the Pan-American governments in the Spanish civil war was received by the State Department today from Jose Richling, the Uruguayan Minister here, and was taken under consideration.

TRENTON, Aug. 18. -- Denying an application for an injunction to restrain Monmouth County officials from interfering with operation of the Long Branch Kennel Club's dog racing track, Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan said today he was not convinced it was not the intention of the club to carry on betting.

The Federal Trade Commission's case charging restraint of trade against the Millinery Quality Guild, Inc., a membership corporation engaged in designing and manufacturing women's hats, opened yesterday with a denial for adjournment asked for by counsel for the guild.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 18. -- At least 100 men, women and children were killed or wounded in today's bombardment of San Sebastian by the Rebel battleship Espana, a usually reliable source reported tonight.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement of Aug. 15 shows the following changes from the preceding week. Figures are given in thousands of marks:
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 18. -- Regulations based on Ecuador's recent drastic exchange control decree, published today, require licenses for all imports after Aug. 1.

Recently you published a letter from one of your readers trying to clarify the issues presently at stake in Spain's civil war. In my opinion he added to confusion when he stated that the fighting was on one side, the government side, pro-communism, and on the other, the Rebel cause, anti-Communist.

Representative Bertrand H. Snell, Republican leader of the lower house of Congress, scoffed yesterday at the Roosevelt administration's pledge of no new taxes next year. He declared similar pledges had been made in previous years only to be broken each time.

Otway H. Chalkley was elected president and Alfred E. Lyon first vice president of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., at a meeting of the directors of the company here yesterday afternoon. Mr. Chalkley, who for several years had been first vice president, was elected to succeed Leonard B. McKitterick, who died recently.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The Yankees suffered another first-round knockout today and while the thing still is not serious, Manager Joe McCarthy is willing to concede its continued performance has become a trifle boring.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 18. -- In the first higher court ruling involving interpretation of the State Anti-Injunction Law of 1935 the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, unanimously affirmed today a temporary injunction limiting strikers at the Syracuse plant of Remington Rand, Inc., to four pickets.

OLD FORGE, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP). -- On the heels of a hay fever expert's recommendation that a ragweedless area be set aside for hay fever sufferers, the State began today a scientific study to find out if such an area exists in the Central Adirondacks.

In a statement released yesterday by the National Conference of Jews and Christians, leaders in the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish faiths in American expressed resentment at the speech of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin in which he challenged the Jews to affirm their belief in the principle of brotherly love.

BY way of preparing for the advent of the Argentines who galloped all over the British brigade in the Olympic polo final at Berlin, Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., Elbridge T. Gerry and Tommy Hitchcock gathered around the luncheon table yesterday and began to draw plans.
Two roomy aircraft, one a land plane and the other an amphibian, are to be delivered soon to two members of the Vanderbilt family, it was disclosed last night.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Jockey Jimmy Stout, a sort of martyred hero with the colony here since his Travers victory, for which he was fined by the stewards, brought off the first triple of the session today with Sir Damion, Count Arthur and Our Reigh.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- New reports of drought damage drove corn prices skyward today from yesterday's ten-year record levels. September futures sold for $1.16 a bushel, up the 4-cent limit for the day, the market providing one of those rare occasions when corn quotations were higher than those for wheat, as in 1930.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Captain Gua Suhr's mighty bat gave the Pirates a 3-to-1 victory over the Cubs in the second game of a double-header today, after Pittsburgh dropped the opener, 5 to 4.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Amir Hassman, a 47-year-old Arabian who believes, he said, that "a man who breaks promises soon breaks friendships," started today to make good a debt of $29.10 to Paterson.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 18. -- An intimation that "bureaucracy development" under the New Deal had the "makings of a dictatorship" was made in an address here today by John Hamilton, Republican National Chairman. He said the dominant issue was whether the American Government was to be one of laws or of "men who have fallen victim to the presumptuous idea that they alone are capable of directing the private affairs of 130,000,000 hitherto free citizens."

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- If the United States wants to keep ahead of the sport procession it will have to go in for national physical training and organization on the same scale as Germany and other European countries, in the opinion of Avery Brundage, chairman of the American Olympic Committee.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Guy Scotland, bay gelding, carried off the feature 2:24 class trot in the second day of the Grand Circuit harness racing program at the Illinois State Fair today, winning the second and third beats.

HENDAYE, France, Aug. 18 (London Daily Mail Dispatch). -- San Sebastian, Irun, Bilbao and Gijon -- towns still held by the government forces -- have been scenes of horror during the past few days. Communists and anarchists, in rage at approaching defeat, have begun a wholesale massacre of hostages, men women and children, seized from among their political opponents.
LAMAR, Colo., Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Federal committee investigating conditions in the drought country tasted dust today in the heart of the Southwestern dust bowl.
MOBERLY, Mo., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Rescue workers in crews of five toiled in a narrow air shaft of a coal mine tonight in an attempt to save four men trapped by fire in the main shaft.

Tammany Hall was plunged into turmoil yesterday as James J. Dooling, Tammany chief, ill and beset by threats against his leadership, suddenly announced the appointment of a committee of three district leaders to direct affairs during his sickness.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- The resummoning into active service of the surviving members of a pioneer "women's council of 100," appointed in 1919 by Will Hays, as chairman of the Republican National Committee, was announced today by Mrs. Robert Lincoln Hoyal, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee.

With the forces of President Roosevelt in complete control, the Democratic State Committee endorsed the candidacies of the President and of Governor Lehman yesterday, fixed the time and place for the State convention and selected a slate of forty-seven Presidential electors, including six members of the newly formed Labor party.

Building work started during July in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains reached the highest monthly figure since June, 1931, according to figures announced yesterday by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

The Sperry Corporation and its subsidiaries had a consolidated net income of $1,657,305, including a profit of $1,055,204 on sales of securities, according to the semi-annual statement issued yesterday. This equaled 85 cents a share on the 1,949,111 capital shares outstanding. In the first half of 1935 the net income of $809,751, including a profit of $57,183 on sales of securities, equaled 42 cents a share.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 18. -- A wave of cattle rustling -- in the modern, if not the Western, manner -- has started on Long Island, it was disclosed here today with the arrest of a pig-sticker who, it was alleged, had turned rustler.

Most futures were higher in active trading on the commodity markets here yesterday. Copper declined and sugar, cocoa and wool top futures were mixed. On the cash markets, corn, lard and oats sold at new high prices and wheat and rubber advanced, while cotton, Straits tin and butter declined.

Passengers departing for Europe today on the French liner Normandie include Mrs. Lyman Beecher Stowe, Professor James Harvey Rogers, member of the Economic Committee of the League of Nations; Professor Andre Morize of Harvard University, Chauncey B. Tinker, lecturer at Harvard; Basil Rathbone and Nigel Bruce, actors; Marc Connelly, playwright; John C. Wilson, and Mr. and Mrs. John A. Appleton.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported yesterday for the seven month ended on July 31, a net lncome of $21,000,436, equal to $2.74 a share on common stock, against $14,866,155, or $1.94 a share, in the same period last year.

CHEYENNE, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Senator Carey, seeking renomination on the Republican ticket, had almost a five-to-one lead over his Townsend-endorsed opponent, A.F. Brubaker, in the first scattered returns from the Wyoming primary election today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Government experts "guessed" today that it won't be long before the housewife lays out from $11 to $12 for the same basket of food she now buys for a ten-dollar bill.

Conflicting opinions of medical experts and the determination of the State Athletic Commission that justice be done, yesterday left the proposed world's heavyweight title bout between James J. Braddock, the champion, and Max Schmeling, German challenger, in status quo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Margin requirements on corn required by the Clearing Association of the Chicago Board of Trade, which deals with brokers and individual members of grain organizations, will be increased tomorrow morning from 3 to 4 cents a bushel, as a result of action taken today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 18. -- Information published by the Patria that the South American headquarters for Soviet activities now had been established in the Chilean city of Concepcion caused a stir in official circles today. The Soviet headquarters retired from Montevideo some time ago and later was expelled from Buenos Aires by the Argentine police.

New York State "must and will" find a way to enforce minimum wage laws for women and children, Governor Lehman told delegates to the thirty-seventh convention of the International Photo-Engravers Union yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18. -- Julius Cohen, part owner with his brother of the bankrupt dry goods store in the fire at which three firemen lost their lives and thirty-five were injured last night, was arrested today on a charge of arson.

More than $5,700 in cash and pledges was promised for the aid of Spanish Loyalists last night at a mass meeting held in the Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the New York State district of the Communist party.

Business failures increased in theI retail, wholesale and manufactur-[ { ing groups in the week ended Aug. I 13, as compared with the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet i Inc. Retail defaults, however, again dropped below their average for the i first thirty-three weeks of this year.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, continued his presentations of the Shubert productions of operettas here tonight on the mammoth stage on the waters of Zach's Bay. The fifth operetta offering of the current season was Emmerich Kalman's popular Viennese work, "Countess Maritza.
LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The news of Germany's conditional acceptance of non-intervention in Spain greeted Anthony Eden when he returned to the Foreign Office today after a fortnight's holiday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (AP). -- President Mikhail Kalinin, in a pre-trial discussion of Soviet Russia's sensational counter-revolutionary plot arrests, today charged that Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff and the fourteen others seized by authorities had joined with the "bitterest enemies of the Soviet Union" in a conspiracy to overthrow the government.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- On the eve of the Republican State Committee meeting, which will bring leaders from all parts of the State to this important political clearing house for central New York, there is every indication that any proposal for a showdown on candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination will meet stubborn resistance.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week, but well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week 1,053 registrations were published, as against 1,296 in the previous week and 948 in the same period last year.

A SENSITIVE person might be excused, in view of what we have all suffered within recent months, for holding up his hand at the mention of feminine memoirs and saying "No, oh no. No more, thank you!" Yet here is a volume of memoirs by a famous lady that deserves hands lifted in applause, not in protest. It is Dame Ethel Smyth's "As Time Went On" (Longmans, Green, $4).

A large number of leases in the Park Avenue district were included in the long lists of apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Activity in buildings along West End Avenue also was noted as leasing for Fall occupancy began to grow heavier.

The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was less than in the preceding week, but well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week 1,053 registrations were published, as against 1,296 in the previous week and 948 in the same period last year.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The American flag was lowered at the Olympic Village today when the last members of our Olympic team departed, almost all of them bound for Hamburg to sail tomorrow on the United States liner President Roosevelt.

A large number of leases in the Park Avenue district were included in the long lists of apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Activity in buildings along West End Avenue also was noted as leasing for Fall occupancy began to grow heavier.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Airplane pilots who fly over Boulder Dam each day on transcontinental trips say that the lake created by the dam is slowly changing the climate of Southern Nevada and Northeastern California.
YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 18. -- This was a day of solemn warnings as the Institute of Pacific Relations cast aside all badinage and came to grips with the most serious issues of the Pacific nations.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Miss Helen Jacobs, America's top ranking woman tennis player, resumed today where she left off at Wimbledon in June and quickly attained the third round of the Essex Country Club's twelfth annual invitation tournament.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The players in the twentieth annual Invitation Tennis Tournament at the Newport Casino continue to be feted. Late this afternoon about fifteen of them were guests at a tea given by Miss Jane Pope, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope, at her home, the Waves.

VALLADOLID, Spain, Aug. 18 (Via Burgos and Hendaye). -- General Emilio Mola, leader of the northern Rebel armies, reviewed in Columbus Avenue here today the first regiment of the Spanish Foreign Legion which arrived here last night from Morocco.

Next to Senator Joseph T. Robinson of Arkansas, the chief pilot of the New Deal in Congress has been Senator Pat Harrison of Mississippi. Next Tuesday the Democratic voters of his State will hold a primary election to determine whether he shall succeed himself on his record.
Joe Louis was on trial at the Yankee Stadium last night and a crowd of 30,000 fight fans gathered in the big arena to hear the verdict.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 18. -- A section of Long Island was turned over to Argentina tonight when the forerunners of the Argentine polo invasion moved into the huge stables at the army polo center at Mitchel Field.

TORONTO, Aug. 18. -- After lying unconscious for three days and racked with thirst and the pain of a broken arm and leg for two more, Bill Tweed, an Ontario forestry service flier who had been missing since Wednesday, is in the Red Cross Hospital in Makina and likely to recover.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Net expenditures of the Federal Government from July 1 to Aug. 15 were substantially lower than in the same period of last year, while receipts were somewhat larger, the Treasury reported today. The increased receipts resulted from larger collections of income taxes and miscellaneous internal revenue, while the reduced expenditures were due to repayments to government lending agencies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Prices of hogs rose 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight early today to the highest mark since September, 1935, sales being made up to $12.05, or 20 cents above yesterday's best figure. The gain was lost later on the desirable kinds, while some under-weights were 10 to 25 cents lower, and many of the latter were unsold at the close.
Apartment properties continued to lead the Bronx market in deals reported yesterday. Large buildings on Macombs Road and University Avenue changed hands.

Directors of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation declared yesterday a special dividend of 25 cents and a quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents on the common stock. In addition a quarterly dividend of $1.50 was voted on the preferred stock. The dividends are payable on Oct. 1 to holders of record of Sept. 12.

The police began uprooting yesterday a five-acre field of marijuana which had been discovered on Barren Island, south of Floyd Bennett Airport, on which milk goats belonging to squatters in the vicinity were grazing.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Young Bob Kunhardt vindicated himself today. After astounding all hands by finishing last in the opening race yesterday, the Indian Harbor sailor came through today as runner-up in the second race and winner of the third as the annual Long Island Sound junior championship series moved forward.

Mayor La Guardia approved yesterday a suggestion by Park Commissioner Robert Moses for the construction of a two-story glass house at the 1939 World's Fair for exhibits showing the work of city departments. The endorsement was contained in a telegram to Mr. Moses, which was made public at the Summer City Hall in the Bronx.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The four top medal scorers in the second annual invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club came through the first two rounds of match play today successfully, but two of tomorrow's semi-finalists encountered plenty of opposition.
A resigned Jack Sharkey met visitors in his dressing room after the fight. The Boston Gob lost no time getting into his clothes, and as he dressed he answered the numerous questions thrust at him.

As a result of the charges filed with the Federal Trade Commission by Joseph Dryer, president of the National Council of Traveling Salesmen's Associations, against three millinery manufacturers for alleged violation of the Patman law in the payment of fees to commission buyers, an early interpretation of the law by the Federal agency has been requested by the New York Buyers' Association, composed of commission buyers, it was announced yesterday by Everett Martin, president.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Floyd (Babe) Herman, 33-year-old outfielder, walked out on the Reds today in a protest against non-payment of a bonus offered him if he "hustled."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The first unit in a "panorama of power" which will be shown to visitors at the World Power Conference here Sept. 7-12 was opened today in the new National Museum of the Smithsonian Institution.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Whether it was a longing to see their mother or just wanderlust remained undetermined tonight, but when two tow-headed youngsters, Clark and Curtis Seelig, 9 and 7 years old respectively, were picked up here early today, after a thirteen-mile walk from their Paterson home, they gave such a skillfully evasive account of themselves that police were baffled for fifteen hours in their efforts to identify the boys.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- The corn market continued its spectacular advance early today, with No. 2 white in car lots in the spot market selling at $1.37 a bushel, the highest price since 1920, while the September option was swept up 3 1/2 cents from yesterday's finish to $1.19 1/2, the best price for that delivery since 1925.

The Constellation, an old, four-masted schooner, will cast off at noon today from Toothpick Dock, at Grand Street in Jersey City, and sail down the harbor on a voyage said to have as its objective the recovery of $1,000,000 in silver lost at sea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- "Spanish chivalry" today led the commander of a column of government troops in the Balearic Islands to warn neutrals of plans for intensive bombardment of Palma by sea and air.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- A message of friendship from the American to the Japanese people was given by Admiral William H. Standley, Acting Secretary of the Navy, today, in an open-air address near the Navy Department to the officers and midshipmen of the Japanese training squadron, which is visiting American ports and is now at Baltimore.

Despite those purists who contend that a new season starts on Labor Day, this vening will mark definitely the beginning of the 1936-37 theatrical session, so far as Broadway is concerned. The attraction? What better than the initial presentation of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company of London in its limited engagement here at the Martin Beck Theatre -- Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado."
New Yorkers who delight in al fresco entertainment on midsummer nights will have a new offering during the next three weeks in the Randalls Island stadium.

To check the importation of low-grade liquor from other States, avert price wars and facilitate tax collection, the State Liquor Authority adopted yesterday a resolution prohibiting holders of retail licenses and permits from purchasing alcoholic beverages from wholesalers or distributors not licensed in this State. The regulation becomes effective Sept. 1.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Tony Manero of Greensboro, N.C., national open champion, tied the course record with a blazing 69 and went one stroke ahead of Matt Kowal, Utica, and Clarence Clark, Bloomfield, N.J., to take the lead half way through the Lake Placid $3,000 open golf tourney at the Lake Placid Golf and Country Club today.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The government took decisive action today to prevent any British war material or aircraft, whether civil or military, from reaching either of the combatant factions in Spain.

Lehman Brothers will offer to the public today at $104 a share 125,000 shares of 4 1/4% per cent convertible preferred stock of Federated Department Stores, Inc., a holding company which owns or controls seven department and specialty stores, including Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., in New York and Abraham Straus, Inc., in Brooklyn.

In one of the largest transactions in several years involving vacant land on Long Island a group of developers and builders yesterday announced the purchase of nearly 2,500 lots facing the Belmont Park race track and fronting for more than half a mile on Hempstead Turnpike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Proposals by the New York Stock Exchange to remove securities from listing and registration resulted today in hearings on these requests being ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 19. -- Nineteen power companies operating in the Tennessee Valley filed a plea today in Federal court here for a temporary injunction to hold the power program of the Tennessee Valley Authority at its present status and prevent its further development.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 19 (AP). -- The first official announcement of the seriousness of Governor Floyd B. Olson's condition was made tonight in a statement signed by three Mayo Clinic physicians.

Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Eastern campaign manager for Governor Landon, declared yesterday that disclosures concerning the local WPA bore out Republican claims of wide maladministration of relief under President Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Prices of hogs continued today the slump that developed late yesterday. Early sales generally were at prices 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday, and the close showed losses of 15 to 25 cents, with underweights down as much as 50 cents.
The following statement was issued by the Hearst General Management in this city yesterday:

" Puzzled Traveler" states that the ten-trip bearer ticket was canceled when the reduced rate of 2 cents a mile went into effect on the Long Island Railroad. That is true. The tentrip tickets carried a rate of 2 1/2 cents a mile.

Ronney Householder of Los Angeles won the twenty-lap sweepstakes, one of the features on the midget automobile racing program last night at the Madison Square Garden Bowl. Lou Schneider placed second and Bob Swanson third.

President DE VALERA was ready to call a general election if the by-elections in Galway and Wexford went against him. His policies and administration won easily in both constituencies. It was made evident in the campaign that the Cosgraveites compose an Opposition that agrees with the vital measures of the Fianna Fail, internal and external.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Bill Samanchik, 25-year-old law student from Passaic County, and Eric Lenaeus of Branch Brook today reached the final of the second annual New Jersey State Public Links championship. They will play for the title vacated by Mike Cestone in a 36-hole match tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19. -- Calmly aware that executioners' rifles answer confessions such as theirs, sixteen conspirators -- including two who once helped rule Soviet Russia -- admitted today plotting a reign of terror to seize power in the U.S.S.R.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- The New Jersey Democratic organization opened its national campaign this afternoon in Olympic Park here, with Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, State leader and vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, assailing certain business and industrial leaders for ingratitude toward President Roosevelt.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer plans a rousing opening tonight for the Norma Shearer-Leslie Howard "Romeo and Juliet" at the Astor. Floodlights will play on the theatre front and the many invited notables will be expected to pause before a WHN microphone on the way in.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The toll that Saratoga has taken through the years of champions and favorites today brought low the Western juvenile champion, Case Ace, as E.R. Bradley's Billionaire upset him and others in the Saugerties Purse.

ST. NAZAIRE, France, Aug. 19. -- The Leftist crew of the Spanish liner Cristobal Colon, which has been wandering in the Atlantic under government orders during the civil war, took command of the ship and its remaining 344 passengers tonight.

With business recovery prompting many manufacturers to go after department-store distribution in a bigger way, it is vital that a complete promotional plan be developed in cooperation with a department-store advertising man before the line is introduced, according to an analysis issued yesterday by Platt-Forbes, Inc., of this city.

We have been repeatedly reminded that Congress has the power to coin money and to regulate the value thereof. Nothing, it will be noted, is said as to the nature of the "money" or the manner in which the "value" is to be "regulated."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grafton Mortimer gave a luncheon today at their home on the ocean for Mrs. Mortimer's sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Amory L. Haskell of Red Bank, N.J., and Palm Beach,

ESTES PARK, Col., Aug. 19. -Governor Landon will leave here tomorrow morning on the first trip of his campaign, during which he will make major speeches at West Middlesex, Pa., his birthplace, and at Chautauqua and Buffalo.

The first transparent woman was put on private view yesterday at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center. She will be on public view tomorrow and thereafter for about two months, revealing to the eye the location of the thyroid, lungs, liver and other glands and organs, as well as the circulatory system of the blood.

Interest in religion may be at a low ebb, but what controversial issue in these controversial times has been so widely debated as the suggestion for a moratorium on sermons? Columns of letters published in newspapers all over the country bear witness that great numbers of people have decided ideas about preaching and the topics suitable for the pulpit.

" It is the same thing year after year -- pledges of no new taxes, and then come the taxes," is the comment of Representative Snell, minority leader of the House, on the White House conference last week concerning government revenues. Except for one word, the comment is just.

The State Transit Commission sent a report yesterday to Alexander H. Kaminsky, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the Homicide Bureau, on a survey by its experts of the recent Third Avenue elevated wreck near Seventy-third Street.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 19. -Moving to meet the growing relief need in the Western drought area, President Roosevelt approved today an increase in the number of Works Progress Administration subsistence jobs there from 90,000, the current figure, to a minimum of 120,000 or a maximum of 150,000.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 19. -- It was "visitors' day" in the Atlantic Coast Star Class series today as John Abberley and John Middlebrook of Central Long Island Sound won easily to take the lead on points with Rhythm. James Smith and John Hughes from Western Long Island Sound finished second in Sunny and David and Bruce Steere of Nantucket placed third with Valiant.

With Mayor Frank Hague watching, Police Lieutenant Joseph Lynch lowered himself on a rope and rescued a screaming, kicking woman as she clung to the sill outside a fourth-floor window at Jersey City Medical Center yesterday morning.

DEWITT, Iowa, Aug. 19 (AP). -Representative William Lemke of North Dakota, Union party candidate for President, asserted today that the nation's domestic market was "being sold to international horse traders" on the "mistaken idea that foreign trade is essential to progress."

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 19. -- Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia today defeated Sir George Thomas of London in the only adjourned game pending from the seventh round of the international chess masters' tournament and moved into seventh place in the competition.

GENEVA, Aug. 19. -- The mandates commission's report on Palestine, given out tonight along with the minutes of the June session thereupon, brings out the commission's vain efforts to get from the British information about the Arab uprising or a promise to give that information to the commission either at the November session or at any definite time.

WPA authorities in this city released for publication yesterday a report which may cause some misunderstanding unless several points are noted. The report described a check on 2,084 employes out of a total of 244,000 on the rolls of WPA last April. The 2,084 investigated were employes who had been absent from their jobs for three days or more.

TRENTON, Aug. 19. -- Threats of another "hunger march" on the State Capitol were made here today by leaders of the unemployed as Newark joined with Elizabeth and Camden in petitioning Governor Hoffman to summon a special session of the Legislature to provide additional relief funds for 1936.

Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas picked up sharply during the week ended on Aug. 15, a rise of 18 per cent over the comparative 1935 period being shown in the report issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The figure compares with a gain of 10 per cent for the week ended Aug. 8.

The Marine Cooks and Stewards Union has summoned members who are employed on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania to meet on the ship today when the issue of union membership or affiliation with the non-union group will be discussed.
LONDON, Thursday, Aug. 20. -- A correspondent of The Daily Express crossed the Franco-Spanish border today after a tour by automobile and train from Madrid. Describing what he saw in Madrid he said:

Fists flew at Tammany Hall yesterday as the district leaders gathered in heated conference and eventually decided to bow to the wishes of James J. Dooling, the Wigwam leader, and accept the rule of the committee of three chiefs named by him to hold power during his illness.

WUPPERTAL, Germany, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Miss Helen Stephens, women's Olympic sprint champion, won two events, finished second in another and was member of the American relay team which finished second to Germany today in West Germany's greatest women's track and field meet, witnessed by a crowd of 35,000.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Miss Rosalie Knapp of the Women's National Club established a new women's record of 75 for the Sands Point Club course today in leading home a brilliant field in the one-day tournament sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Lee Ross and Harry Kelley pitched the Athletics to a double victory over the Red Sox today, Ross winning the first game 5 to 4, in thirteen innings, while Kelley got his triumph in the regulation distance by a 7-to-2 score.

Seventeen dead men were carried on the WPA rolls here in the period from March 4 to April 3. This was revealed yesterday in the report of a special inquiry into the reasons why 2,084 employes were absent in that period.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 19. -- Sponsors of the Music Mountain concerts at Falls Village, Conn., gave a tea this afternoon following the matinee by the Jacques Gordon String Quartet. The hostesses were Mrs. John R. Sanford, Mrs. Frederick H. Wiggin, Mrs. Theron Rockwell, Misses Emily H. Whitney and Louisa Munroe.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 19. -- State Republican leaders who came here today to attend a meeting of the State committee, hopeful that the gathering would bring developments to break the deadlock between two rival candidates for the Gubernatorial nomination from Onondaga County, Senator George R. Fearon and Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of this city, left for their homes tonight with their hopes unfulfilled.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Robert Grimm and Kenneth Smith of Oceanside won the Long Island Golf Association amateur handicap best-ball championship in a playoff today by defeating George T. Dunlap Jr. and E. Leonard Beard 3d of Pomonok over the Lido course.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Aug. 19. -- Neither by entreaties nor arguments could a group of the Women's United Front movement induce United States Senator William H. King to talk with Pedro Albizu Campos, now in jail for sedition. Some days ago Mr. King said that he was inquiring into the conspiracy trial of Albizu and other Nationalists as well as the party's independence methods.

Miss tee Abbott, progressive Republican and social worker of Chicago, was named yesterday as the chairman of a national committee of welfare leaders who will work for the re-election of President Roosevelt.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 19. -- President Eduard Benes, speaking in German today at Reichenberg, Northern Bohemia, declared that Czechoslovakia, although willing to grant the utmost concessions to her minorities, must reject any external attempt to interfere with the republic's domestic affairs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- District Attorney George V. Dorsey of Rockland County told Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley today that the Orangeburg dog-racing track would not have been raided last Wednesday and Thursday if Governor Lehman had not urged county authorities to enforce the law.

Matthew Woll, third vice president of the American Federation of Labor, told delegates to the thirty-seventh convention of the International Photo-Engravers Union yesterday that employers were "laughing up their sleeves" at labor's split over the Committee on Industrial Organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- With the exception of the fourth section, in which Jacob Levin, former University of Pennsylvania player, is showing the way, New York chess experts held top places today in three divisions of the preliminary play for the open championship of the American Chess Federation.

Tammany Hall finds itself suddenly confronted with what the British call "putting the Great Seal in commission." It is a sort of interregnum. It may be thought of as a form of temporary regency. Mr. DOOLING, the leader of Tammany, is ill and may not be able to resume his political duties for several weeks.

In your issue of Aug. 13 you had an editorial on the extent to which every voter pays taxes without knowing it, but I must quarrel with your last sentence. You state: "But neither the Republicans nor the Democrats have been bold enough to propose in an election year to broaden the base of the income tax."

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 19. -This is a full week for Bruno Walter. On Monday evening he conducted another performance of Gluck's "Orpheus and Eurydice." This morning he gave at the Festspielhaus the second symphony concert he has conducted in Salzburg during this festival. Friday morning he will do the third and that evening he will pilot another performance of Hugo Wolf's "Der Corregidor."

The Department of Trade and Commerce of the Dominion of Canada, which has had a New York office in 25 Broadway for four years, has leased new quarters in the British Empire Building, Rockefeller Center. D.S. Cole, Canadian Trade Commissioner, is in charge.
BARCELONA, Aug. 19. -- The Catalonian Government moved tonight virtually to secede from the rest of Spain.
TOKYO, Aug. 19. -- The newspaper Asahi's campaign for an Anglo-Japanese understanding appears to be fading out as a result of criticisms leveled at the proposal in the British press.

A rise in steel ingot production this week from 71 to 72 1/2 per cent of capacity, a new high level for the year, is reported in The Iron Age summary to be given out today. The magazine cited also sharp gains in the price of steel scrap, scarcity of coke and sustained demand for finished steel products that is preventing producers' backlogs from being rapidly reduced despite the high rate of output.
SCOTT CITY, Kan., Aug. 19 (AP). -- The President's Drought Commission came out of the Dust Bowl today with the declaration that "things are not so bad as we had expected."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Satisfied that there was really nothing very disturbing going on behind them, our dawdling Yankees opened the throttle today and once more went thundering down the road that most certainly should lead to a New York world series next Fall.

Eighteen passengers of a Central Avenue bus were injured, none seriously, in Jersey City at about 10:45 o'clock last night when the steering knuckle of the vehicle broke. The bus swerved off Johnston Avenue, near Washington Street, and then over the curb, across a sidewalk and onto the tracks of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, which run parallel to Johnston Avenue.

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- Trading on the Boerse was nervous and prices were rather weak today, but some resistance developed near the end, making the closing better than the session's lowest figures. Net changes, therefore, were small.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- Photographers intent on taking pictures of Mayor La Guardia of New York caused an interruption in tonight's orchestra concert at Robin Hood Dell when Albert Spalding, the violin soloist, stalked off the stage in exasperation, followed by Jose Iturbi, the conductor.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Racketeers in New York City have been falling over themselves to pay income and corporation taxes to the State, Mark Graves, head of the Department of Taxation and Finance, indicated today in announcing that a quarter of a million dollars had already been received and that about $2,000,000 more was expected.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 19. -Henry Sturgis Morgan, younger of the two sons of J.P. Morgan, has purchased 100 acres of land on Eaton's Neck near Northport, L.I., to develop as a golf course and as a place of recreation for his children, it was learned here today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Remember the world champion St. Louis Cardinals of 1926? Rogers Hornsby was the manager.

PAWTUCKET, R.T., Aug. 19. -- Following up her victory at Saratoga in the only start she made there, Mrs. C.S. Howard's Coramine earned $3,675 for her California owner when the filly won the third running of the Shawomet Stakes today at Narragansett Park.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Charlie Lacey drove a smart bay gelding, Little Pat, owned by the Biery Farm of Butler, Pa., to victory in the $1,550 Review Futurity for 3-year-olds pacers, feature of today's Grand Circuit program.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Continuing their efforts to trace assets, creditors' counsel in the William Fox bankruptcy proceeding today asked Robert E. Steedle, Federal referee, to order Herbert Leitsteen. Fox family bookkeeper, to prepare a financial statement of Fox holdings as of Jan. 1, 1930.

The Board of Elections, the bipartisan board that counts the election and primary votes in the city, submitted yesterday to Budget Director Leo J. McDermott a 1937 request for $1,920,100, a figure $297,684 below the 1936 allotment of $2,217,785.

Engagement abroad of $5,983,000 gold for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount $3,414,000 was taken in France, reflecting a fresh wave of weakness in the French currency; $1,979,000 in Canada, $389,000 in England and $201,000 in India.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Paul Runyan, who tomorrow will begin the defense of his Westchester open championship, today demonstrated that he is ready for the test when, paired with Guy Mayer, one of his pupils at Metropolis, he helped capture the Westchester amateur-professional best-ball golf crown, showing the way to a fine field of forty-one teams over his home course.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Eight men and eight women remained tonight in the quest for singles titles in the national public parks tennis tournament.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy again delayed his answer today to the French proposal for non-intervention in the Spanish civil war while he went harvesting in the reclaimed Pontine marshes. At the same time Rome issued an indignant denial of reports of military and air measures taken in connection with events in Spain.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- With seas slapping over her bow and splashing on her deck, the America's Cup Class sloop Weetamoe today broke all sailing records for the course on the last squadron run of the New York Yacht Club cruise.

Plans were filed by architects yesterday for tenement houses in Manhattan and the Bronx and dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens. Several projects for making alterations in existing buildings also were submitted.

MADRID, Aug. 19 (From a resident by Courier to France). -- For four weeks this city and all Spain have been living through horrors and savagery. War by comparison is a clean thing. Civil war never before has been waged with such cruelty and such disrespect for life and decency.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Aug. 19. -Colonel Frank Knox, Republican nominee for Vice President, declared in a speech here tonight that recovery would become "a fact instead of a debate" if business received some assurance that "there will be no further violent and sudden interferences with the vital implements of industrial enterprise."

United States Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland, often an opponent of New Deal policies, pledged full support yesterday to President Roosevelt and predicted to James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, that the President would carry his home State.

Assailing Governor Landon as the candidate of the American Liberty League, William Randolph Hearst and the du Ponts, James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, charged last night that the Republicans were basing their battle on a campaign of fear which was "counterfeit" and "insincere."

MOBERLY, Mo., Aug. 19. -- Doggedly fighting the double menace of gas and cave-in, weary coal miners bored through a debris-littered shaft tonight toward four fellow-workers, trapped for more than twenty-four hours behind a collapsed tunnel, 100 feet below the surface.

America managed to get away with the one Olympic pie event that threw every other performance into the shade. It was not on the official program. A German woman won the gold medal for throwing the javelin, and another German woman was first in tossing the discus.

Whatever influence "Old Guardsmen," Hoovercrats and persons suspected of "corporate" affiliations may have with the President or Administration if Governor LANDON is elected, unspoiled sons of Kansas will have control of the candidate's train as he rides to the East on a speechmaking tour this week.
