A plaster model representing sculptor's conception of the original appearance of the mutilated head found embedded in clay at Hennebecker's farm, North Haverstraw, N.Y., on May 2, arrived yesterday at police headquarters, where photographs were taken of it for distribution to detectives throughout the city.
Theatres cannot be used by broadcasting companies for radio programs unless theatrical licenses are obtained for them.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Vagabond King, owned by Adolph Wilson of Dayton, Ohio, took three straight heats in the feature three-year-old trot at the Orange County Fair today.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 19. -- Secretary Wallace asserted here today that the Federal Government would spend $10,000,000 immediately to buy seed grain that would be sold back to the farmers in the drought area next Spring, thus shutting out speculators and "holding grain closer to the farm."
ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Newark defeated Albany in both games of a double-header tonight, 7 to 3 and 6 to 4, and sent the Senators tumbling into last place in the International League.

Dr. Charles V. Noback, Bronx Zoo veterinarian, went shopping yesterday for an array of pots, pans, funnels, powdered milk and an eggbeater, necessitated by the arrival by air Tuesday night of six baby pronghorn antelopes.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 19. -- The New York Yacht Club fleet, now or its annual cruise, returned to New port this afternoon. During the evening there was considerable entertaining on the larger boats, whil other yachtsmen were guests at parties ashore.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $23,174,109 after all deductions for the twelve months ended on July 31. This equaled, after preferred dividend requirements, $2.42 a share on 5,503,193 no-par common shares.

Just before revolution broke out in Spain. Houghton Mifflin asked the American Ambassador, Claude G. Bowers, how he found time to write the books that he sends them to publish. He has sent back the explanation that in ordinary times he obtains two hours for work by foregoing an afternoon siesta, and three more between 6 and 9, the hours Spanish custom gave to stimulating the appetite for a late dinner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Navy got an active start on its 1937 building program today when bids were opened for the construction in private yards of six destroyers and three submarines.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- General Marie Gustave Gamelin, Chief of the Army General Staff, returned to Paris today from his visit to Poland, where, according to all accounts, he was greeted with enthusiasm as the head of the French Army, but where also, it is stated authoritatively here, he confined his conversation to army matters and left politics and policies alone.

More than $4,000,000,000 was added to the national income of the United States in 1935 as compared with 1934, according to a report of a study made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. As compared with a national income of $50,899,000,000 in 1934, the figure for 1935 was $55,000,000,000.

The annual graduation exercises of the Police Academy will be held at noon today at the academy training field, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx. Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine will address the 189 rookies and welcome them to the force, which they will join immediately after the ceremonies as probationary patrolmen.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Greentree's riders won another test match today among the teams preparing for the national polo championship, which starts a week from Saturday, but they took it only after the hardest sort of a fight.

In his first purchase of a property in the garment are in decade Benjamin Winter, operator, yesterday acquired the thirteen-story loft building at 88 West Thirty-eighth Street for cash over a mortgage of $250,000. A modern structure erected originally for the printing trades, it occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet and was sold by the Braker Memorial Home, an institution for the aged.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Regional conferences at which it is hoped to work out a soil conservation program for 1937 that would pay farmers for repairing lands damaged by drought, but not encourage them to increase the production of cash crops, was announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

ROME, Aug. 19. -- The difficulty of reaching an accord between France and Italy regarding non-interference in Spain was emphasized today when, after another meeting between Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano and Count Charles do Chambrun, the French Ambassador, it was learned that "the conversations are continuing."

District Attorney William C. Dodge was accused yesterday at a hearing before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler of being more interested in the operators of the Pennsylvania coal fields, in his grand jury investigation of alleged coal bootlegging into this city, than in the citizens of New York.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, who has been with President Franklin Delano Roosevelt on his trip through the flood district, is returning to the Gideon Putnam tomorrow to join Mrs. Earle and son, and her mother, Mrs. J. Bailey Browder.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Mrs. James M. Robbins of Mount Kisco scored two upsets today to win the second annual invitation tournament of the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club, succeeding Mrs. J.J. Lawlor of the Westchester Country Club, who did not defend.
Pausing to chat with fishermen on a drive through upper Westchester and Putnam Counties several days ago, one often heard the expression: "Lake's working, fishing's not so hot."

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 19. -- America's touring athletes won three of the seven events in which they competed in a post-Olympic track and field meet today. The stadium was less than half filled because of the showery and chilly weather.

BERLIN, Thursday, Aug. 20. -- Spanish Government war vessels stopped and searched the German steamer Kamerun seven and a half miles off the Spanish coast, near Cadiz, according to a government news service dispatch released yesterday.
PARIS, Aug. 19. -- The Madrid government was reported tonight to be planning to seize upon France's threat to abandon her neutrality stand as an opportunity to win allies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Customs service business in the fiscal year ended on June 30 showed an increase of 13.4 per cent over the preceding year, the Treasury announced today. Entries for the year numbered 2,712,954. Of that total there were 324.013 dutiable consumption entries and 69,929 warehouse entries, representing increases of 13.9 per cent and 23.6 per cent respectively.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- Mayor S. Davis Wilson, calling his police commanders before him this afternoon for an emphatic and sharply worded address of warning, ordered them to sever any tieups they might have, political or otherwise, or leave their posts.

SEATTLE, Aug. 19. -- Harvey J. Kelly, general labor counsel for Hearst newspapers, announced tonight that three unions under contract to The Post-Intelligencer had protested against the Seattle Central Labor Council's action in listing the publication as "unfair."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- New rules to insure confidential treatment of papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and certain reports of examiners to the commission itself were announced today, effective at once.

Under the leadership of steel shares the stock market advanced with some show of confidence yesterday and closed firm. The net result was that the gains in prices on Tuesday and Wednesday offset the losses of Monday, and for the first time in six trading days THE NEW YORK TIMES railway stock average showed a gain.

LAKEHURST, N.J., Thursday, Aug. 20. -- The dirigible Hindenburg took off on her eastbound transatlantic voyage at 2:33 o'clock, Eastern daylight time this morning, thus embarking on her return trip to Germany seven hours and four minutes after she came to rest at Lakehurst last night.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 19. -- A threat of war was seen today by the Russian delegation to the Institute of Pacific Relations in a Japanese statement yesterday and was answered with the sharp re-joiner that "force could not be resorted to against the U.S.S.R. by anybody whatsoever, with any measure of success."
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 19 (AP). -- New Orleans and Spartanburg (S. C.) Junior American Legion baseball teams moved into the semifinals of the Southeastern district tournament here today.
The campaign of Alfred M. Landon to be elected President of the United State of America is based largely on the proposition that the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt is a failure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- A compromise settlement of income tax differences between the government and the estate of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, executed for kidnapping Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., was disclosed today at the Board of Tax Appeals.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 19. -- Tennis week opened here today as many social events were planned during the invitation tournament which is being played on the courts of the Mount Washington Hotel. A tea dance and a collegiate night in the Cave Grill were features of the opening day.

Detective Edward F. Hoolahan of the West Twentieth Street station shot and seriously wounded a prisoner who attempted to escape from him yesterday on Eighth Avenue near Twenty-second Street. One of the four Bullets Hoolahan fired struck Joseph Hallam, 16-year-old bystander who lives at 351 West Twenty-second Street, and in

One striking incident of the protracted drought was the rise in corn for September delivery, on Tuesday's Chicago market, to a higher price than was reached the same day by wheat. For corn, Tuesday's high price was $1.16 per bushel; for wheat, $1.14. This was a very unusual and abnormal dislocation of relative values.

Passenger revenues of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad last month were 22 per cent larger than in July, 1935, Daniel Willard, president, said yesterday. This compared with an increase of 16.7 per cent in June, when the Eastern railroads reduced their basic fares.

Because of indications of fraud and irregularities, the Board of Elections yesterday rejected the designating petition of Horatio T. Boxill, who sought the Democratic nomination for Assemblyman in the Nineteenth Assembly District in Harlem, and turned the matter over to the office of District Attorney Dodge for investigation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19. -- An amazing story of a series of plots both within and without this country to "decapitate" the Soviet regime by assassinating all the principal leaders was unfolded today and tonight as Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff and fourteen others went on trial charged with organizing terrorist groups.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- After two were out, the Browns crowded seven runs across in the second inning and then added enough later in the game for a 13-to-8 victory today over the Tigers.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Trading on the London Stock Exchange was quiet today, although the price undertone was firm. British funds were good as a result of renewed buying prompted by the heavy over-subscription of the Kenya loan and also by foreign support.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Kansas State budget is balanced only on paper, according to a report made by Leslie Doud, Labor's Non-Partisan League chairman for Kansas, to George L. Berry, president of the league, which is supporting President Roosevelt for re-election.

John A. Marcone, a special investigator for the Department of Public Welfare, was accused yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court of attempting to extort payment from the son of two old-age pension recipients for keeping them on the pension rolls.
BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- Mystery surrounds the death last night of Captain Fuerstner, constructor and organizer of the Olympic village and its officer in command and its administrative official.

SEDALIA, Mo., Aug. 19. -- On the final lap of his airplane tour of the West, John D.M. Hamilton, Republican National Chairman, in a speech to 4,000 party workers today, charged the New Deal with use of relief funds to build the "greatest political machine in history."

His confidence restored through the masterful manner in which he knocked out Jack Sharkey in three rounds, Joe Louis yesterday was looking eagerly again toward the world's heavyweight title, with an outside possibility of getting a chance at the crown sooner than he expected.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 19. -- Prominent jurists from three countries heard Dean Roscoe Pound of the Harvard Law School defend the common law today and express the opinion that the administration was resentful of judicial curb.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Relief Pitcher Bill Swift won his own game today, giving the Pirates a 5-to-4 victory over the slipping Cubs.

The market for high-grade bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange presented a satisfactory basis for the public offering today of $100,000,000 of General Motors Acceptance Corporation 3 and 3 1/4 per cent debentures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- A 25 per cent reduction in railroad rates on cattle shipments from all counties in Oklahoma and eighty counties in Kansas to feeding points in Texas was authorized today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

GIBRALTAR, Aug. 19. -- Moral assistance and whatever material aid is possible were pledged to Spanish Rebels by the officially outlawed French Croix de Feu organization of Fascists in a series of conferences in Seville between one of its officers and General Francisco Franco, Rebel commander-in-chief, and his staff.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 19. -- The Manchester Chamber of Commerce, through its president, Joseph H. Geisel, served notice today that it would take the lead in combating any effort on the part of interests inimical to the industrial welfare of the city to buy and junk the profitable units of the defunct Amoskeag Mills.

After submitting various exhibits in the Federal Trade Commission's charge of restraint of trade against the Millinery Quality Guilds, Inc., counsel for the organization of designers and manufacturers of women's hats requested at yesterday's hearing, held at 45 Broadway, that further hearings be adjourned to permit the drafting of a stipulation in agreement with the allegations in the commission's complaint,
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 19. -- Martin Moore, confessed slayer of Miss Helen Clevenger, 18-year-old Staten Island girl, went on trial for his life here today before a thirteen-man jury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Establishing a post-repeal record, liquor taxes in July amounted to $60,018,409, a gain of $12,752,211 over the same month last year and of $9,879,741 over June, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.
HOENEFOS, Norway, Aug. 19. -- Leon Trotsky, whose alleged followers are on trial in Moscow charged with a plot to overthrow the Soviet government, derided the proceedings tonight as "humbug."

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 19. -Lyman Crossman won two matches to enter the semi-finals of the Westchester-Fairfield junior tennis tournament at the Stamford Yacht Club today. But he was forced to three sets in both cases by John Benn of New York City and Ledyard Sobek of Norwalk.

Officials of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania postponed the sale of the $45,000,000 of State tax-anticipation notes until Sept. 1, at the "request of the respective bidders," it was announced yesterday. Although the notes were not general obligations of the Commonwealth, but payable from specific revenues, the requests for the postponement arose from the question as to the legality: of the notes in certain Eastern States.
Sales of various residential and business properties in Westchester were reported yesterday.

Few cases involving the Securities and Exchange Commission have caught the interest of Wall Street traders as have the efforts of Vincent J. McMann to prevent Engel Co., members of the Stock Exchange, from submitting records of his transactions to investigators for the commission. It is realized that the suit strikes at the root of the commission's inquisitorial powers.

In his Chautauqua address last week President ROOSEVELT said that he felt distinctly "less cheerful" about foreign affairs than concerning our own immediate difficulties. This was a hint which he followed up Tuesday by telling the correspondents at Hyde Park that he was proposing to cut short his trip next week.

May I draw attention to an apparent innovation in the laws of our country which seems to have been overlooked by our contemporary commentators? Yet the matter is of considerable importance to all of us who now make a living by means of our typewriters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Judge Raglan Tuttle today suddenly dismissed mayhem conspiracy charges against the two physicians who sterilized Ann Cooper Hewitt, but the prosecutor said the way was left open for further action against them.

By the margin of a disputed home run, the pennant-chasing Giants yesterday completed their Polo Grounds sweep of the three-game series with the Dodgers, sending Casey Stengel back to Brooklyn with his temperature at the boiling point.

Directors of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation yesterday increased the quarterly dividend on its common stock to $1, placing the issue on an annual basis of $4, compared with $3.60 previously paid.

The Allied Stores Corporation reported yesterday for the quarter ended on July 31 a consolidated net profit of $314,377 after depreciation, interest and provision for subsidiary preferred dividends but before Federal income and undistributed profits taxes. A profit of $125,300 on the repurchase in May of funded indebtedness of a subsidiary was not included. In the three months ended on July 31, 1935, there was a loss of $422,959.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Charlie Stetson of the Pequot Yacht Club and his crew of Bob Gordon and Bertram Ainsworth today captured the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship as the five-race series came to a close.

May I draw attention to an apparent innovation in the laws of our country which seems to have been overlooked by our contemporary commentators? Yet the matter is of considerable importance to all of us who now make a living by means of our typewriters.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Judge Raglan Tuttle today suddenly dismissed mayhem conspiracy charges against the two physicians who sterilized Ann Cooper Hewitt, but the prosecutor said the way was left open for further action against them.

By the margin of a disputed home run, the pennant-chasing Giants yesterday completed their Polo Grounds sweep of the three-game series with the Dodgers, sending Casey Stengel back to Brooklyn with his temperature at the boiling point.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Joseph Schenck left London today by airplane for a short vacation at Biarritz thus temporarily interrupting the negotiations with Robert Rubin for the long discussed merger between the Gaumont British Picture Corporation, Twentieth Century-Fox Film and Loews, Inc.
KUTZTOWN, Pa., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Billy Bull, Melfa, Va., horseman, drove two winners in the three races today at the Kutztown Fair.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -France's three remaining representatives were eliminated from the invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today as five Californians gained the quarter-finals along with Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, Frank Parker of Spring Lake and John Van Ryn of Philadelphia.

The howling of dogs became the subject of judicial processes in two suburban communities yesterday and in one case a judge asserted that he would determine whether the animals made enough noise to constitute a nuisance by going out some night to listen to the sounds coming from the premises named in the complaint.
IRUN, Spain, Aug. 19. -- This battered Loyalist stronghold feared tonight that at any moment its streets might become a battlefield.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 19 (AP). -- A newly found batch of yellowed papers, searchers said today, may hold the key to the century-old mystery of Marshal Ney.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 19 (AP). -- A unified national Farm Labor party for the Congressional campaign of 1938 and the Presidential campaign of 1940 was set today as the goal of the liberal parties of Minnesota and Wisconsin.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- S.L. Molay's Fire Advance galloped to victory in the Lake View Handicap today at Washington Park, conquering Sam Holman's Our Bud by a nose in a spectacular photo finish.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- A charge that freedom of speech was "being locked out of the schools," partly through the adoption of teachers' oaths which are "stifling academic freedom," was made today at the convention of the American Federation of Teachers.

MADRID, Aug. 19 (Passed by the Censor). -- "It is not true that the Spanish civil war will last for a long time because the country is equally divided between the belligerent camps," says the newspaper Ahora today.
Employment in the construction industry in this State recorded its fifth consecutive monthly advance in July, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Bees drove two Philadelphia pitchers to the showers and bombarded a third to break their four-game losing streak with a 9-to-1 victory over the Phillies today.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Standing upon a ledge at the head of Lake George near Lake George Village, members of Jogues Memorial Commission, designated by the Legislature to select a site for a monument to St. Isaac Jogues, Jesuit priest and explorer, this afternoon indicated strong leanings toward that location for the memorial to the first white man to look upon the lake.
Six Manhattan properties and one Bronx parcel were sold at foreclosure auctions yesterday, as follows:

CERBERE, France, Aug. 19. -- Florence Miller, San Francisco dancer whose family lives at 2,004 Eighteenth Avenue, Oakland, Calif., saved her life by dancing for the Leftists at Barcelona at $1 per day and a meal ticket.

David M. Solomon, 32 years old, a lawyer of 996 Lenox Road, Brooklyn, and Morris Blitzer, 39, of 313 Rivington Street, were arraigned in the Felony Court yesterday on perjury charges growing out of their testimony in December, 1934, in the State Compensation Bureau's inquiry in an indemnity claim.

Much concern is felt in many sections of the city over the fight now being waged by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to condemn the property now occupied by the MacLean estate, 2,122 Fifth Avenue, and reduce it to a sandlot playground.

A suit asking $2,000,000 damages based on allegations that the play "Dead End" is a plagiarism from her play entitled "Money" was filed in Federal court yesterday by Edna Buckler of 140-40 Beech Street, Flushing, Queens.

While the gain in lumber consumption in the second quarter of this year was slightly above the usual seasonal increase, national stocks on July 1 were 1 per cent in excess of those on April 1 but 3.2 per cent below the total on Jan. 1, according to a report issued yesterday by the special lumber survey committee of the Timber Conservation Board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- William K. Vanderbilt, a lieutenant commander in the naval reserve, was listed among 117 naval officers to whom decorations and awards of foreign governments were forwarded by the Navy Department today under authority of an act of Congress of May 19, permitting them to accept the honors.
Six Manhattan properties and one Bronx parcel were sold at foreclosure auctions yesterday, as follows:

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Standing upon a ledge at the head of Lake George near Lake George Village, members of Jogues Memorial Commission, designated by the Legislature to select a site for a monument to St. Isaac Jogues, Jesuit priest and explorer, this afternoon indicated strong leanings toward that location for the memorial to the first white man to look upon the lake.

Most commodity futures were irregular or lower yesterday in the local markets, although cocoa futures advanced slightly. In the cash markets, cocoa set a new high record and cotton and butter gained, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, lard, standard tin and silk declined.

Passenger revenues of the New York Central Railroad increased about 20 per cent in July, compared with July, 1935, according to unofficial estimates made public yesterday. This compared with an increase of 11.2 per cent reported for June, when reduced rates took effect in the East.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The United States reaffirmed her neutrality with reference to the civil war in Spain in a note tonight from William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, to Jose Richling, the Minister of Uruguay, declaring her inability to accept the suggestion of the Montevideo government for mediation of the strife in Spain by the American republics.

TRENTON, Aug. 20. -- The Republican factional fight in New Jersey over supplying relief for the needy flared up anew today when Governor Hoffman attacked the Essex County legislators for refusing "to recognize the necessity for action" and for preferring "to chase economic butterflies."

Your correspondent, Mr. Clear, is quite right in saying that both the Tenement and Multiple Dwellings Laws have failed. This is proved by the fact that after thirty-five years during which the "reformers" have had a free hand we still have the tenement house evil with us.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 20. -A new plan of reorganization for the Richfield Oil Company of California and the Pan American Petroleum Company, in receivership since 1931, was filed today in the United States District Court. Judge William P. James authorized the submission of the plan to bondholders and unsecured creditors, two-thirds of whom must ratify it before the plan is adopted.

The four-masted schooner Constellation, her white sails billowing in the afternoon sun, sailed down New York Harbor yesterday in quest of a sunken treasure reputed to include the crown jewels of Emperor Maximilian of Mexico and gold and silver bullion valued at between $4,000,000 and $26,000,000.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Dr. Charles Lutz, 48 years old, Bronx physician, committed suicide this afternoon at his home on Trinity Path, Pound Ridge, by shooting himself through the head with a revolver, according to County Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire.

The Regional Labor Board began yesterday its investigation of the charges of the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association that contracts signed by the United Licensed Officers Association as the alleged spokesman of the officers of ships of the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation and the Panama Railroad Steamship Company were improper.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 20. -- Mrs. Mary Reed Baird, known to the whole town as "Auntie Baird," canned peaches in her picturesque cabin today unmindful of the excitement aroused by the coming visit of Governor Landon, whom she attended as a nurse in his infancy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The drought will cost agencies of the Federal Government about $100,000,000 in relief expenditures above needs foreseen by Congress when it voted $1,425,000,000 for relief during the current fiscal year, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, estimated today.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 20. -- All the leaders competing in the international chess masters tournament at University College gave satisfying exhibitions today in their ninth-round matches. At the close of play, Mikhail Botwinnik of Russia had a half-point lead in total games.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Launching his defense of the Westchester open golf championship today at Metropolis, Paul Runyan assumed a one-stroke lead over the field with two fine rounds for a score of 143, the result of 35, 35 -- 70 in the morning and 34, 39 -- 73 in the afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Grain markets showed an easy undertone from the start today and there was a noticeable lack of the aggressive short covering which was felt yesterday. At no time were corn prices as high as at the close of the previous day, and persistent commission-house selling in small lots carried the market steadily downward.

I did not believe in rabies once, either. When the dog with which our dog played was pronounced rabid, and shot, I thought it was a crime. Some months later our own dog disappeared for three days, came back, obviously in a daze, hardly recognized us, rushed out, snapping at other dogs, bit my wife and daughter, and, when chained, stood shaking his head and drooling -- all the classical symptoms.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 20. -- A Van Houten City Line Bus, carrying thirty-two passengers, most of them mill workers, struck a large oak tree that leans from the curbing in Howe Avenue at Grove Street, here, at 7 o'clock this morning and the occupants were showered with broken glass as the right side of the roof was torn off.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 20. -- The Woolgrowers' organization has entered the Japanese tariff controversy with an appeal to Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons to reopen negotiations with a view to an early settlement.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Declaring that this year's platforms of the major parties are worse than the average and that so far the speeches of the political leaders have not improved upon the platforms, Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, attacked both Democrats and Republicans today for "pandering to the popular habit of voting against something rather than for something."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Deposits in national banks the were highest on record on June 30, totaling $26,200,453,000, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Whether the Spanish Government warship that searched a German steamer committed piracy or acted within its rights appeared tonight to hinge on a delicate point of international law.

ROME, Aug. 20. -- A picture of united Central European military cooperation will be presented to the world by Premier Mussolini at the annual war manoeuvres of 200,000 men beginning at Avellin next Tuesday, military sources said.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 (AP). -The Pirates spotted the Cubs seven runs in the first two innings today and then went on to defeat the pennant-holders, 8 -- 7, in eleven innings.
MADRID, Aug. 20. -- Loyalist forces, in an effort to break the narrowing semi-circle around Madrid, battled fiercely tonight to drive a wedge between the northern and southern Rebel armies.

After early liquidation had carried prices on the Cotton Exchange into new low ground yesterday, with October dipping below 11 1/2 cents for a moment, the market developed decided resistance and recovered nearly $1 a bale before the close.

PEIPING, China, Aug. 20. -- General Sung Cheh-yuan, head of the Hopei-Chahar Political Council, has agreed with the Japanese Ambassador, Shigeru Kawagoe, upon the principle of Chino-Japanese joint economic development in North China.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- A "forthright statement" from Governor Landon on the question of Federal support for education was sought by telegraph today by the American Federation of Teachers at its annual convention.

Only a system of State economy divorced from the budgetary principles of the administration in Washington will produce a balanced New York State budget, Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Westchester County said last night before the Tenth Assembly District Republican Club on West Twenty-eighth Street.

BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- The German Government has issued orders to its warships patrolling off Spain to shoot if Spanish Government ships again interfere with German merchantmen outside the three-mile limit.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin G. Merrill of 969 Park Avenue and Merlebrook House, Bedford Hills, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their youngest daughter, Miss Elise B. Merrill, to Edwin B. Katte of Elmsford, N.Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Katte of Irvington-on-Hudson.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 (AP). -While three naval destroyers sped to the rescue Coast Guard headquarters here intercepted a wireless message tonight from a ship which said the crew of a vessel indentifying itself as the San Joaquin was taking to lifeboats.

Roosevelt Avenue, near Woodside station, presents a problem to the passerby who must thread his way among encroaching fruit and vegetable stands and their attendant hawkers, customers and litter. Police have found it, futile to hand out summonses, as the merchants enjoy some strange power gaining postponements until a suspended sentence can be arranged.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System amounted on last Wednesday to $1,810,000,000, compared with $3,170,000,000 a week before, according to the weekly Federal Reserve report, issued yesterday, which was the first report to give effect to the 50 per cent increase in reserve requirements that took place last Saturday.

PARIS, Aug. 20. -- Germany succeeded in showing the world a well-trained army and a strictly disciplined people during the Olympic Games but did not hesitate to break most of the Olympic commandments, according to four members of the International Committee for the Preservation of the Olympic Ideal who arrived here today.

That some of the Spanish crown jewels were pledged here for a loan by the Count of Covadonga, former Spanish Crown Prince, was disclosed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church. Statements concerning the alleged loan were made during a hearing on an application for a temporary receivership for the British Motors, Ltd., of 463 Park Avenue, which has employed the Count.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 20. -- The early convening of two world conferences, one on arms limitation and the other on economic problems, was recommended tonight at the conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations by the French delegation, led by Albert Sarraut, former Premier of France.

MOBERLY, Mo., Aug. 20. -- Grimly forcing their battle against death, rescue crews tonight had dug to within an estimated six or seven feet of the bottom of a caved-in mine shaft where they hoped to penetrate into a 500-yard tunnel and rescue four miners entombed nearly sixty hours.

As an antepast of the Harvard tercentenary, American and British lawyers are holding a three-day conference on the future of the common law. Dean POUND reviewed the doctrine and technique of the common law, its tradition and the attacks upon that tradition since the sixteenth century:

IRUN, Spain, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Three 100-pound bombs were dropped in the center of Irun tonight by a trimotored Rebel airplane. The populace was panic-stricken, but no casualties were reported immediately.

Salvatore Spitale, whose aid was sought in the underworld search for the kidnapped Lindbergh baby, was portrayed in the Flushing (Queens) magistrate's court yesterday as a respectable business man with an income of $6,000 a year from investments and a liking for golf.

In yesterday's trading in stocks it was noteworthy that the sword-rattling of certain European powers was stimulating a demand for munitions issues, rather than unsettling the market as a whole. Airplane stocks were strong, while attention was focused again on platinum, which metal is used in the manufacture of shells and which advanced on Wednesday $10 an ounce to $53, the highest price since 1920.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 20. -- Governor Landon arrived here tonight, cheered by the reception he received during the first day of his speaking campaign. About 20,000 persons heard him along the route of his special train through Colorado and Nebraska, and by their cheers impressed him with their approval of his attack upon the Roosevelt administration for "extravagance."

Mayor La Guardia, speaking last night at the thirty-sixth annual dinner of the International Photo-Engravers Union at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, said it was the "sincere hope of every friend of American labor that its present differences will be settled in the bosom of the labor family."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Clarence Clark of Bloomfield, former New Jersey champion, won the Lake Placid $3,000 open golf tournament at the Lake Placid Golf and Country Club today with a three-under-par total of 285 for 72 holes, finishing with a sparkling subpar 69.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 20. -- The western battlefront -- if the irregular line of contact between General Francisco Franco's insurgents, operating from Badajoz, and the Madrid government's militia can be so called -- in the past forty-eight hours has moved in some places forty miles nearer the capital.
An order designed to check absenteeism of employes on the WPA was issued yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell.

More indictments were revealed yesterday in the investigation by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau, into ambulance chasing and bogus accident indemnity claims. A physician, a lawyer and an alleged "runner" for lawyers in accident cases were named in three separate bills, which had been handed up to Judge Allen in General Sessions the day before. All pleaded not guilty.

Persistent strength in United States Government long-term loans again was the feature of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. New high marks since their issuance were recorded by ten of the outstanding Treasurys, as net gains ranging from 1-32 to 8-32 point ruled throughout the group at the close.

Sir SAMUEL HOARE, speaking for the British Government, said on Wednesday that it would not think of intervening in the Spanish civil strife, even if asked to do so. Probably every other European nation would today take the same stand. It is a question quite different from that of maintaining strict neutrality, which most European countries now seem resolved to do.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 20. -Several of the players who will take part in the coming open championship participated in members' polo at the Meadow Brook Club today. Among the spectators were some of the Argentines who arrived today on the Bremen.
Spanish anarchists and syndicalists are now publishing in New York two weekly newspapers which have gained considerable influence in Spain, especially in Catalonia.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20. -- A moderate decrease in steel operations and in coal production caused a slight setback in business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.
Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia were ten American refugees from Spain.

Thirty days in any European country will cure any American citizen who is worried about conditions in the United States, according to Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, who returned from Europe yesterday on the Washington of the United States Lines.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens yesterday directed Andrew K. Johnson, chief engineer of the Queens Highway Bureau in charge of construction, to make a complete engineering study of the proposal to build a bridge over Jamaica Bay from the Rockaway Peninsula to connect with the extension of Van Wyck Boulevard and provide a new cross-borough arterial highway in Queens.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area from Aug. 1 to 14 showed an increase of 6.8 per cent over the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The rise is smaller than was expected, and was held to reflect a falling off in volume during the first week of the period as business last week showed a marked upturn.

WALDWICK, N.J., Aug. 20. -Through an inadvertency of WPA workers this borough almost lost all the water in Waldwick Lake, the source of its water supply and one of the best fishing places in the county.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The Gas House Gang of Cardinals, inspired by Dizzy Dean and Pepper Martin, pulled a game and a half in front of the National League pack today by coming from behind to down the Reds, 4 to 2.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 20. -- A broad memorial program to celebrate the one hundredth anniversary of Mark Hopkins's induction as fourth president of Williams College was issued today to 7,000 alumni in all parts of the world by the centenary committee, of which O. Dickinson Street, '01, of New York City, is director.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- State Senator Lester H. Clee of Essex County and Assemblyman Henry Young Jr., leader of the Essex delegation in the State Assembly, were away today on vacation and could not be reached for comment on the Governor's telegram to the Newark City Commission regarding a special session for relief.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20. -- The number of attempts to assassinate Joseph Stalin in the past two years rose to four tonight when Valentine Olberg, one of sixteen defendants including Gregory Zinovieff and Leon Kameneff being tried for alleged terroristic activities, testified he was to have bombed Stalin in the course of the May Day parade this Spring.

The list of the Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line, due today from Channel ports, includes Dr. and Mrs. Albert A. Ripperger, Antonie Strassmann, woman flier; Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Jannings Jr., Mr. and Mrs. E.L. Cheyne, Dr. and Mrs. Paul Livingston, Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Knight, Professor and Mrs. Adolph Schultz and Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop A. Harvey.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20. -- One of the important artistic events of the season took place here this afternoon when an exhibition of paintings and sketches by a group of Southampton artists opened with a large reception and tea at Four Fountains, the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien Hamilton Tyng in Halsey Neck Lane.

Objections filed by twenty-eight public utility companies, here and up-State, to assessments made by the Public Service Commission in connection with the costs of proceedings held in May, were heard yesterday by W.T. Wilkinson, examiner of the commission's staff.

The engagement of $526,000 gold in India and $352,000 in England for shipment here was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The bank reported the arrival here of $4,729,400 of gold, consisting of $2,479,300 from India, $1,979,000 from Canada and $271,100 from England.
Senator BORAH tells his Idaho constituents that it would be a grave mistake to believe that prosperity will return to this country before it reaches the farmer. To this he adds:

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 20. -President Roosevelt promised today in a conference on the problems raised by the drought to begin soon after the elections in November a study of proposals to provide crop insurance for farmers and maintain for them a reliable supply of credit on reasonable terms.

Plans for Fall promotions by distillers and wine distributors this year are more elaborate than at any time since the months following repeal, executives of liquor houses asserted yesterday. Appropriations will run 10 to 15 per cent higher for all types of advertising from September on.

Two barber-shop quartets were selected last night in Washington Square Park to represent Manhattan in the finals of the second American Ballad Contest, which will be held Sept. 10 in the Mall in Central Park. The final contest, arranged by the Park Department, will have competitors from all five boroughs, Westchester and Long Island.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20. -- Death for Communist leaders to pave the way for a Fascist regime in Russia was the picture unfolded tonight in the trial of sixteen persons charged with fostering a terrorist plot against the Soviet.

I believe it is not true, as Mrs. Helen S.K. Willcox said in a letter to THE TIMES, that most of the farmers favor the classified plan of selling their milk. At the legislative hearing in the Spring the one point that was emphatic was that the various producer interests represented there wanted the abolition of the classified plan.

On behalf of myself and a few thousand people who were at the Lewisohn Stadium concert, Aug. 18, I should like to register a protest against selfish forms of advertising. On this occasion an airplane sponsored by a prominent motion-picture corporation deliberately encircled the Stadium several times, carrying a lighted sign which informed the indignant audience that pictures of the fight would be shown at all their theatres the following day.
Police Commissioner Valentine threatened yesterday to drop discourteous policemen from the force if the attitude of his department toward the public did not improve.

In a book entitled "I'm For Roosevelt," published today, Joseph P. Kennedy, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, defends the increase in the national debt under the New Deal on the ground that it has raised per capita income by $190 a year.

Corrupt use of WPA funds for political purposes in West Virginia will be a large factor in swinging that State into the Republican column, Walter Simms Hallanan, National Committeeman from West Virginia, declared here yesterday.

SILVER BAY, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Nation-wide cooperation in not only the operation of the Social Security Act, but also the formulation of "constructive changes" in the new law was urged tonight by John G. Winant, chairman of the Social Security Board, in an address delivered here before the conference on industrial relations.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- Responding to a challenge of Mayor S. Davis Wilson to "clean up or get out," the police continued their anti-gambling raids today while New Jersey authorities prepared to deal with a possible influx of racketeers from this city.
There is a touch of the fantastic in this Nova Scotia tuna fishing.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 20. -- Uruguay's suggestion for a united American move for peace in Spain has met unanimous acceptance in principle, but there seems to be now no way it can be put into practice.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The turf writers annual dinner tonight at Arrow Head Inn attracted society and prominent racing owners. Plaques were awarded to the four men whose service to racing this year has been most outstanding.

PARIS, Aug. 20. -- French diplomatic circles, dissatisfied with delays in direct conversations, are tonight inclining toward reverting to their original idea of calling an international conference for nonintervention in Spain.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The red-funneled excursion steamer City of Keansburg left here for New York at 9:20 o'clock tonight, her rails packed with 1,877 singing followers of Father Divine, who had brought them to Ulster County today to introduce them to a "Land of Promise."

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 20. -Three New Yorkers this afternoon gave testimony for the State in its fight to send Martin Moore, 22-year-old Negro, to the gas chamber for the slaying of Miss Helen Clevenger, 18-year-old New York University co-ed.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The "schoolboy brigade" faded from the national public parks tennis tournament today as the singles list was reduced to the four semi-finalists. Among the youngsters to lose was M.C. Hopper, Tulsa, who was beaten by MacNeill Smith of East St. Louis, Ill. The score was 0 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.
Supporters of Frank J. Prial and Judge Jonah J. Goldstein, who are fighting the Democratic organizations in the primary election, found further encouragement yesterday in the strife in Tammany Hall.

Argentina's polo team, here for the series for the Cup of the Americas, to be played at Meadow Brook, landed yesterday afternoon from the North German Lloyd liner Bremen and went directly to the scene of action on Long Island, where part of their ponies had preceded them and the rest are expected tomorrow.
OSLO, Norway, Aug. 20. -- Leon Trotsky, receiving journalists today for the first time since his arrival in Norway, declared:

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Two children, a brother and a sister, were killed and thirteen other persons were injured this morning when an Iowa autoist became confused in downtown traffic and ran his car over the sidewalk and into a store window.

BINGHAMTON, Aug. 20. -- Republicans of Tioga County flocking to their annual outing today at Lounsberry, near Owego, heard attacks on the New Deal and predictions of party success in State and nation.
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 21. -- Unconfirmed reports reaching London early today said that a revolt had broken out in Portugal and that it was believed President Oscar Carmona had been killed.

Dr. GILKEY, in a sermon reported this week in THE TIMES, gave some very wholesome and alleviating advice, presented in four rules addressed especially to those who (fortunately) find themselves very busy in these days when so many haven't the opportunity to be busy -- in a profitable way.

With the return today of Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse on the Champlain from a vacation in Ireland, Vinton Freedley will be in a position to go ahead with his final plans for the production of "Red, Hot and Blue!" the musical comedy which the duo have written in collaboration with Cole Porter.
PENN YAN, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP). -Mayor Rolland B. Marvin of Syracuse said in an address at a Republican rally here tonight:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A request for a thirty-day continuation of the proceedings in the Western Pacific Railroad reorganization was made of the Interstate Commerce Commission today by T.M. Schumacher, chairman of the company's executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- An assertion that Republican campaign promises to reduce government expenditures could only be realized by "taking it out of the hides of the unemployed," was made today by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator.
BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- The whole story of the sudden death of Captain Wolfgang Fuerstner, the "non-Aryan" army officer who built and organized the Olympic Village, has now come to light.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Philo T. Farnsworth of Philadelphia presented to the Federal Communications Commission today facts in connection with his proposed development of television which, according to officials, constituted a "very good showing" in support of his application for a permit to construct an experimental television transmitting station in Springfield Township, near Philadelphia.

Deposits in the 151 banks in New York City reached a high record on June 30, amounting to $16,576,477,500, according to the American Banker. This meant a gain of more than $2,000,000,000 in a year and a rise of more than $560,000,000 since Dec. 31, 1935.
Statements concerning the strike at The Seattle Post-Intelligencer were issued here yesterday by both the American Newspaper Guild and the offices of the Hearst newspapers.

A good demand for apartments in buildings on Park Avenue was indicated in lists of new tenancies issued by brokers and renting agents yesterday. Houses on the West Side also attracted a number of new tenants.

BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 20. -- A land and air bombardment of Palma, capital of Majorca, was begun today by Catalan government forces. All foreign vessels left the harbor in response to a warning from Captain Bayo, commander of the Catalan expedition.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 20 (AP). -- Attorney General Cummings challenged Republican leaders today to produce a "bill of particulars" on their governmental program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Despite small receipts, prices of hogs declined today from 10 to 25 cents a hundred-weight. Continued unfavorable reports of the demand for fresh pork dominated the action of buyers. The top of $11.50 was 30 cents lower than yesterday and the average was off 20 cents at $10.10.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- American railway trains are running at higher speeds and this country has the fastest trains in the world for distances of 800 miles or more, the Association of American Railroads asserted in a statement issued today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- Miss Ulrica Hubbard, who has been spending the Summer with her grandmother, Mrs. Drexel Dahlgren, was introduced tonight by Mrs. Dahlgren at a large dinner dance at her home on Bellevue Avenue. She was the second young woman of the season to make her debut.

Despite the recent increase of 25 cents a hundredweight in the creamery price of raw milk granted to producers, an additional 20-cent rise was announced yesterday in various up-State markets in which distributors have raised the price to the consumer.

" Seven Sinners," the new Gaumont-British melodrama with Edmund Lowe and Constance Cummings, will have its first American showing today at the Roxy. The Palace offers Irvin S. Cobb and Jane Withers in "Pepper," as part of a double bill and the Rialto is following the scent of the werewolf with "The Crouching Beast," British-made, with Fritz Kortner and Wynne Gibson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week-ended Aug. 19, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,476,000,000, unchanged from the preceding week and practically the same as reported for the corresponding week in 1935.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 20. -- With Winston Guest at back, Templeton rode with its regular line-up for the first time this season and galloped to an 11-to-5 triumph over Roslyn today in another test match preparatory to the coming national polo championship.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 20. -Mrs. Emmet Whalen, the Westchester Hills golfer, who has been doing well in local tournaments all season, today won the low-gross honors of the Westchester-Fairfield Association one-day tournament with an 83 at the Mount Kisco Golf Club.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 20 (AP). -Glenn Cunningham, second to Jack Lovelock in the Olympic 1,500-meter run, today bettered the listed world record for 800 meters when he was clocked in 1:49.7 in winning the event at an international track and field meet.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 20. -- A statement that Mexico was shipping arms to aid the Spanish Government was published today in the newspaper Universal, but met denials from the Mexican Government and the Spanish Embassy.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 20 (AP). -- Rain today cut the Grand Circuit harness racing program at the Illinois State Fair to two events, leaving a six-race schedule for tomorrow's final program.

John J. McGrath. 34 years old, boyhood friend of James J. Braddock who received a parole from the Iowa State Reformatory at Anamosa last week after a plea by the heavyweight boxing champion, arrived here yesterday and went to the Braddock suite at the Mayflower Hotel.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
It will cost $23,691,183 to operate the city's Wefare Department next year, more than double the 1936 expense, Budget Director Leo J. McDermott was informed yesterday. The 1936 total was $11,619,655.

Charles Gilbert, 10 years old, of 703 Park Avenue, Brooklyn, whose sight is impaired, was overjoyed yesterday morning when his missing dog, Rex, was reported found. He was disappointed later when he learned that Rex had run away again.

BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- Following the disclosure of the suicide of Captain Wolfgang Fuerstner, vice commandant of the Olympic village, the government denied today that recent charges in the anti-Semitic publication Judenkenner to the effect that he was "not entirely Aryan" had been responsible for his demotion from the post of commandant of the village.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Deposits in the Bank of Canada by the Dominion Government increased about $3,000,000 and deposits by chartered banks decreased about $5,000,000 in the week yesterday, said the bank's report issued today as follows:

The city of Boston awarded yesterday several issues of bonds aggregating $6,260,000 to a banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company on its bid of 100.169 for 2 1/2s, or at an interest cost to the city of 2.4746 per cent. The bonds will be dated Sept. 1, 1936, and will mature on Sept. 1, 1937 to 1966.

Improvement in the world economic outlook continued during June, according to the monthly review of foreign economic conditions in The Annalist issued today. World industrial activity rose further to a new six-year record, while commodity prices showed a pronounced tendency to advance.

MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The wide ramifications of the English cooperative organization came under the inspection tonight of President Roosevelt's three-man commission, which is making a survey of the movement in Europe.

After a week's ownership the garden type apartment house at 808 Adee Avenue, in the Pelham section of East Bronx, was resold yesterday by Netter Netter, attorneys, to the Barnes Realty Corporation. Occupying the block front from Barnes to Matthews Avenues, the building contains 284 rooms laid out in seventy-two apartments of two, three, four and five rooms.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The England shows the following weekly statement of the Bank of changes, in pounds sterling:

IT is a great temptation to speak of Carl Sandburg's newest book, "The People, Yes" (Harcourt, Brace, $2.50), in positives, comparatives, superlatives. I should like to come right out and say that "The People, Yes" is a magnificent poem, better than anything we have had for a long time and the best that the author has ever done.

The Republican platform dodged the real issue on relief, as it did on other public questions. "Confusion, partisanship, waste and incompetence" were charged against the Democrats -- all with ample basis. But, once again, the record is barren of detail how these are to be eliminated from the most difficult administrative task ever undertaken in this country.

About 2,000 umbrellas, many of which probably will be offered for resale at subway stations throughout the city on the next rainy day, were sold at auction yesterday by the Independent Subway System, with hundreds of other lost articles.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- With the field in the stretch in the Willsboro Purse today, two horses were driving head and head in front. Both were indifferently backed, but it is safe to say that most of the thousands at the Saratoga course were rooting for Evening Hour, the Jack High filly which eventually got home first by two lengths.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- A mishap that occurred when he was leading John Van Ryn two sets to love and 2 -- 0 in the third chapter came near eliminating Bryan M. Grant Jr. from the invitation tournament today in the quarter-finals.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 20. -State Treasurer George E. Hall had a unique problem today -Nebraska's Treasury has too much cash on hand.

TRENTON, Aug. 20. -- The American swimming team might have chalked up a few extra points at the last Olympics if it had had as a member one Joseph Dvorak, 21 years old, of 564 Center Street, this city, who startled the police and several hundred spectators today in an interstate swim across the Delaware River with police in pursuit.

The General American Transportation Company and subsidiaries yesterday reported for the first six months of this year a net profit of $1,030,589 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges, but exclusive of undistributed profits tax.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The Tigers, defeating the Browns, 8 to 4, for an even break in a four-game series, today pulled up within 5 percentage points of the idle Indians in second place.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Attorneys for William Fox's many creditors tried unsuccessfully today to trace two $200,000 checks as the effort continued to unravel his finances and possible assets in the Fox bankruptcy proceedings here.

The Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for International Match Corporation, filed yesterday with Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, a petition for authority to declare and pay a dividend of 10 per cent on all claims that have been allowed finally as valid against the estate.

New York's bars may yet become places where a man may rest one foot on a brass rail and indulge in a little serious drinking without the distractions that now beset him even in the best of alcoholic beverage dispensing spots.
PARIS, Aug. 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

TORONTO, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press). -- A resolution calling upon the Washington government "to remonstrate against the persecutions carried on by the Mexican Government against religion and the denial of human and divine rights of the Mexican people," was adopted at the final session today of the international convention of the Supreme Council, Knights of Columbus.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20. (AP). -- Supreme Court Justice Harlan F. Stone declared today that constitutional law was faced with the perpetual question of defining the line which marks the boundary between "the appropriate field for individual liberty" and that of "government action for larger good."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The differences between the old and new laws against unfair price discriminations in interstate commerce, involved in the amendment of Section 2 of the Clayton Act by the Robinson-Patman Bill enacted at the last session of Congress, are reviewed and discussed by the Federal Trade Commission in a statement made public today.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Bill McKechnie gambled on two pitching youngsters today because of the crippled condition of the rest of the Bees' pitching staff, and they produced by holding the Phillies to six hits for a 3-to-1 Boston victory.

Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, the star swimmer who was dropped from the United States Olympic team soon after its arrival in Germany, returned home yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by her husband, Arthur Jarrett, still hoping to compete in the future as an amateur and still expressing a liking for champagne in moderate amounts.

A decrease of 0.65 per cent in credit collections during July is shown in the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The decline compares with an increase of 1.66 per cent in June and of 1.62 per cent in July, 1935.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- Jose Iturbi, pianist and conductor, admitted today that he "blew up" during last night's orchestra concert at Robin Hood Dell, but said it was "all a misunderstanding."

Constance Rourke's "Audubon" has been chosen by the Book-of-the-Month Club as one of two selections for November. The publication date has been put over from Sept. 17 to Oct. 29. Harcourt, Brace are the publishers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Asserting that thirty-five or forty electoral votes west of the Mississippi would insure the election of Governor Landon to the Presidency, John Hamilton, the Republican national chairman, gave a "pep" talk today at a conference of workers at national headquarters.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Home talent as represented by Harry Meislahn and Reeve Bowden in Sunbeam assumed control of the Star Class Atlantic Coast championship series today, to the surprise of hardly no one. What was somewhat unorthodox, however, was that they did it in light, spotty airs.

In planning for the coming World's Fair in this city many projects are, of course, temporary. But it ought to be possible to include some features and buildings that would be permanent. Among such Assemblyman MOFFAT recommends that a part of the money voted by the State shall be used for the erection of a museum of science and industry.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Opinion here seems divided on the legality of the action of the Spanish Government in searching the German steamer Kamerun and the British Government is seeking further information from Madrid as to whether the government there had actually established a blockade of the coastal areas in the hands of the insurgents in terms of international law.

BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- The reaction on the Boerse continued today, with nervous fluctuations and a shrinking turnover. Losses predominated, but prices became steadier near the end of the session, some issues registering slight gains.

The Lautaro Nitrate Company, Ltd., producer of Chilean nitrates, has prepared a plan for the resumption of interest and sinking fund payments on its debt, after a four-year suspension of such distributions, it was announced yesterday by Medley G.B. Whelpley, chairman of the company and a partner in the banking firm of Guggenheim Brothers.

An unsuccessful attempt to bring about the intercession of the Central Trades and Labor Council in the suspension of twelve unions of the American Federation of Labor threw a meeting of the council last night into a hubbub. The meeting, held at 210 East Fifth Street, was adjourned in the midst of a heated discussion and futile attempts by officers of the organization to bring about order.

That noise on the far side of Eighth Avenue last evening was the contented purring of the local Savoyards, welcoming back to their secondary home shores the members of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company. It was also the opening of the theatre season, but to the average Savoyard that fact is of no consequence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Wholesale commodity prices for the week ended on Aug. 15 were unchanged from the preceding week, the index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, based on the 1926 average as 100, standing at 81.1, compared with 80.5 for the same week last year.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 20. -- Many parties were given tonight at the Cinema to see "Show Boat," and the annual barn dance at the Mount Washington brought out a large assemblage in rustic costumes. Among those attending were Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Sierck, Mr. and Mrs. W. Ross Harper, Misses Doris Low, Lolita Silo, Peggy Sanderson, Virginia Penfield, Frances Pew and Jane Adams.

The Tide Water Oil Company (New Jersey) has organized, under Delaware laws, a wholly owned subsidiary titled the Tide Water Oil Company (Delaware), in connection with an internal corporate rearrangement of certain assets and operations.

Associated Gas and Electric interests filed yesterday in Federal Court here a plan for reorganization of the National Public Service Corporation, as holders of 32 per cent of the corporation's debt. The plan, if sustained, will prevent the offering at auction, scheduled for Sept. 10, of the principal collateral securing the debt of the corporation.
BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- At the time the German Government made public its ultimatum to the Spanish Loyalist regime today, the Foreign Office issued the following communique:

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, R. W. Pressprich Co. and Estabrook Co. will offer today to the public a new issue of $3,000,000 of Northern Pacific Railway Company 2 1/4 per cent serial equipment trust certificates at prices to yield 0.50 to 2.30 per cent, according to maturity.
United States Senator William Gibbs McAdoo assured James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, yesterday that California would give President Roosevelt a large plurality at the election this year.
Various realty deals in anticipation of the opening of the city subway extension to Jamaica were reported in Queens yesterday. Several construction projects were included.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN, Aug. 20. -- Within a few days Governor Landon must decide how his name shall appear on the ballot in some States. He and his advisers were reported to be in doubt as to whether it should be "Alf M. Landon" or "Alfred M. Landon."

SEATTLE, Aug. 20. -- For the seventh consecutive day, Seattle went without its morning newspaper today as pickets continued to surround the plant of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, refusing to permit union printers, pressmen, stereo-typers, mailers and other employes to enter the building.

Although clearings in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday were below the total of a year earlier, they compared more favorably with those of the preceding week. The only loss, which was reported by this city, was chiefly responsible for the lower aggregate.
MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 20 (AP). -Former President Emilio Portes Gil, under sharp fire for months, quit tonight as head of he powerful National Revolutionary (Government) party.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- New York chess players maintained their fine showing in the qualifying series in the annual open tournament of the American Chess Federation today. Additional matches in the eighth round and some in the ninth were decided.

Regardless of any action that may be taken by the State Athletic Commission today, there will be no fight for the heavyweight crown between James J. Braddock, titleholder, and Max Schmeling in September, according to Joe Gould, manager of the champion.

The air of unreality enveloping Soviet trials for conspiracy and sabotage reaches the heights of fantasy in the process now going on in Moscow. It was promised that the proceedings would be as undramatic as a trial of bandits, but for drama calculated to leave the outsider breathless and "to "rock and shock the whole Soviet "union," as our correspondent says, the Russian imagination never conceived anything weirder than this judicial action.

Sharply higher prices for grains, flour, cattle; beef and hay have carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to the highest level of the year, the index rising to 129.0 on Tuesday from 127.4 (revised) the Tuesday previous.

How long, O leader of Onondaga! might be the Ciceronian cry of Senator FEARON, as with his "pledged delegations" from small counties melting hourly he awaits the choice of CLARENCE KING between himself and his fellow-Syracusan, Mayor MARVIN, both applicants for the Republican nomination for Governor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 20. -- An estate valued at $600,000 by her attorneys was left by Mrs. Mary L.C. Earle of Old Westbury, L.I., who died in London July 25, and whose will was filed here today. Outright bequests and other provisions for several religious, charitable and medical institutions were made.

A score of Negroes, most of them residents of the Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, scattered like chaff before the wind about 10 o'clock last night when a three-foot black snake, the principal "prop" of a snake-oil and horoscope salesman's act, bit a member of the audience and fell wriggling to the sidewalk at Lewis Avenue and Chauncey Street.
CLLEVELAND, Aug. 20. -- Dickie, an inquisitive dog, dozed at the end of a chain tonight as a legal controversy developed over his penchant for searching in garbage cans.

Brokers' loans as reported by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City fell $7,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $936,000,000, according to the weekly condition statement of the banks, published yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Aug. 20. -- Two hundred and five midshipmen of the Japanese Navy, who have completed their regular course and are making a world voyage in two cruisers, visited the Naval Academy today and were entertained by the commandant and United States midshipmen.

President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman have expressed their appreciation of the support of the People's party, composed of former Right Wing Socialists, Louis Waldman, State chairman, announced yesterday.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 20. -Eight more New Jersey municipalities joined tonight in the request to Governor Hoffman and State legislators for a special session to enact new measures for the relief of the needy.

The share market yesterday yielded much of the small advantage that it had gained the day before, closing irregularly lower. There continues to be a lack of aggressive investment demand, and in the market's professional following there is still a disposition to move cautiously.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- Gerard B. Lambert today won the race for the King's Cup, premier yachting trophy of this country, for the third time. He was the winning owner in 1929 and 1933 with his sloop Vanitie, and this afternoon he sailed his America's Cup class sloop Yankee to a 1-minute-and-32-second victory over R.B. Lanier's smaller Class M sloop Istalena.

Judge Jeremiah T. Mahoney, former president of the Amateur Athletic Union, issued a long statement last night charging Avery Brundage, present head of the A.A.U. and the American Olympic Committee, and other officials with committing "grievous errors" in handling the United States Olympic team on its trip to the Berlin games.
Insurgent members of the Eastern and Gulf Sailors Association will demand an election to determine the right of the present executive staff to continue in office, it was learned yesterday.

As an added precaution against Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania's latest move for freedom, Thomas E. Dewey, Special Prosecutor of Rackets, despatched six warrants for his arrest yesterday to the warden of Dannemora prison, where Lucania is serving a term of thirty to fifty years' imprisonment.

While Mayor La Guardia looked on, firemen rescued an unconscious 4-year-old Negro boy shortly after 11 o'clock last night from the top floor of a blazing five-story tenement building at 365 Cherry Street, between Gouverneur and Montgomery Streets.

The hammer-and-sickle flag of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics was raised on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday for the first time when Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, and Anasthasius I. Mikoyan, Commissar for Food Industries, were escorted to the gallery of the Exchange by Charles R. Gay, its president.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 20. -- Proposals for curbing what it termed newspaper and radio "hippodroming" of American criminal justice as in the Hauptmann and Mooney trials are contained in the report of the American Bar Association's committee on criminal procedure to be presented to the associatiaon at its annual convention starting Monday in Boston.

WEARING a gray suit and a panama hat with the brim turned down, Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants strolled into the restaurant, hung up his hat, pulled up a chair and said cheerfully:

People still call them breathing spaces out of force of habit, but music seems to be displacing fresh air as the major interest. Wherever in New York or its vicinity there is a big open space, the recent Summers have brought a concert band or a symphony orchestra or an operatic performance.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- A movement is under way among grain interests for cooperation in attacking the constitutionality of the Commodity Exchange Act, it was reported today after representatives of the Kansas City Board of Trade had conferred with leading commission men and officials of the Chicago Board of Trade.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Discovery will run again tomorrow when he will have four competitors and Saratoga's mud to deal with in the Whitney Stakes. As Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and trainer Bud Stotler watched the rain deluge the racing strip, they were more concerned, however, with how it would affect the non-mud runner Swiftply in the Adirondack Handicap today than the big horse in the mile and a quarter drive tomorrow.

The snappers are in Long Island Sound. These greedy baby bluefish provide good fun because they are so numerous and bite avidly. Snapper fishing at this time of the year brings the rowboat fans out in droves on both sides of the Sound.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Indians defeated the Browns, 4--2, today for their first victory in five starts.

KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, Germany, Aug. 21. -- The Preussische Zeitung presents today a sensational report of alleged Soviet naval armament in the Baltic. It claims that at least forty Soviet submarines are now stationed in the Baltic, each of 900 tons and equipped with eight torpedo tubes, two guns and mine-laying equipment.

There will be no general war in Europe, in the opinion of Thomas W. Lamont, partner of J.P. Morgan Co., who returned to his office yesterday after a ten-week vacation abroad. Departing from the long-standing practice of the Morgan partners not to grant formal interviews, Mr. Lamont met reporters at his office, 23 Wall Street, yesterday afternoon and talked freely about the troubled political situation abroad.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Aug. 21. -- When a new army bombing plane, on a routine night-flying mission, struck a bank of clouds near here last night two enlisted men aboard thought the plane was going to crash, so without giving the matter a second thought they "bailed out."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The veteran Red Lucas, making use of perfect control, protected a one-run lead and pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-to-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 21. -- William Fox, the former motion-picture magnate, was examined before a notary public here today and occasionally heckled as he replied to the questioning. Many of the points put to him on his involved financial affairs went unanswered, Mr. Fox merely exercising his rights at such a hearing.

The Greek Government has made an offer to the League Loans Committee, London, to transfer 40 per cent of the interest on its external debt for the fiscal years 1935-36 and 1936-37 on condition that the committee discuss with it in the interval a permanent settlement, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Speyer Co.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press). -- Canada will dominate the export wheat market until December, says a summary issue today by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics based on returns for the end of the crop year July 31. The only competition of importance facing Canada until December will be from Danube countries.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Mayo Clinic physicians said tonight that Governor Floyd B. Olson had taken a turn for the worse after apparently rallying earlier in the evening. The physicians said Governor Olson was in no immediate danger, but that he was steadily growing weaker.

Three of the important animals of the North American continent have broken into the news in the last few days. Fortunately, this time, it is not a story of further depletion -- the familiar tale of reckless disregard for the future which has cost this country most of its larger game species, formerly so abundant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The cotton-spinning industry was reported today by the Census Bureau to have operated during July at 119.8 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 111.0 per cent during June this year and 73.5 during July last year.

Seven properties in scattered sections of Manhattan were bought in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One of the forced sales involved two six-story apartment buildings on a Central Park West corner.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- The busy round of entertaining that has marked tennis week here this year will reach its peak tomorrow night when Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice give their tennis ball at Miramir, which promises to be the largest and one of the most elaborate of the week.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 21. -John Cunniff, 30-year-old former caddie of Branch Brook, today won the qualifying medal in the first annual metropolitan public links championship when he scored a 70, two under par, over his home course.

The earnings statement for the June quarter of the Pan-American Petroleum and Transport Company and unites, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, showed a net profit of $993,168 after depreciation, depletion and normal Federal income taxes, but before provision for possible surtax on undistributed income.
