SYRACUSE, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Stanley A. Piseck, president of the New York Milk Producers Federation, Inc., flew to Wisconsin today for "negotiations toward keeping Western milk from New York City in case of a New York milk shed strike."

In the face of acrimonious debate over the last three years' unprecedented Federal legislation and activities, your editorial "Self-Made Issues," noting the absence of sharply defined issues between the two leading parties, is a surprising underestimate of the current campaign's significance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- For what was said to be the first time since the outbreak of the Spanish revolution, American nationals at a possible danger point have been left without the direct services of consular officials as a result of the departure, by direction of the State Department, of Robert D. Longyear from Palma in the Balearic Islands yesterday on the United States battleship Oklahoma.

Marketing of $100,000,000 of 3 and 3 1/4 per cent debentures of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the second largest block of securities to be offered by one company at one time under the Securities Act, lifted this week's total of new bond financing to $120,545,000.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP). -The world's greatest clay target bombardment started on a quarter-mile front today as the Amateur Trapshooting Association launched its thirty-seventh Grand American program.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 21. -- On the result of the run-off primaries tomorrow in the race between Colonel Ernest O. Thompson, chairman of the Railroad Commission, for renomination, and Frank Morris will depend whether a flood of crude oil shall be turned loose in Texas or the industry shall continue to be stabilized by proration of production.

VERA CRUZ, Mexico, Aug. 21 (AP). -- A heavy cargo of war materials was loaded tonight on the Spanish liner Magallanes amid ominous rumors it would never reach Loyal Spanish Government forces. Rebel sympathizers here said the ship and its freight of Mexican arms and munitions would be fair game for Rebel bombing planes.

BOSTON, Aug. 21. -- The slender margin of less than a foot that meant the difference between a fair or foul hit at National League Field today menaced the longest winning streak of a Giant team in years.

Reorganization of the local WPA administrative staff, involving the dropping of 300 employes from the payroll at a monthly saving of about $35,000, was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Invoking a "moral" embargo against exports of war materials to Spain, the State Department indirectly has advised inquiring munitions dealers that sales to either faction in the Spanish conflict would be incompatible with America's neutrality policy.

Six of the fourteen New York executives of major oil companies who were indicted last July 28 with many others in Madison, Wis., on charges of price-fixing in the Midwest were arraigned in removal proceedings yesterday before Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 21. -- The Madrid government's forces took up the offensive on the western front today and from the Guadarrama Mountains protecting Madrid in the north to the key city of Cordoba in the south there was heavy fighting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Great Britain and Germany want to make reciprocal trade agreements with the United States, said Secretary Roper when he reached Washington today after a holiday trip spent largely in those two countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Plans for a Labor Day labor meeting in every State in behalf of the candidacy of President Roosevelt were announced today by Major George L. Berry, national president of Labor's Nonpartisan League, who said that these mass gatherings might turn into "the greatest political spectacle of our time."

Nothing could better illustrate the unusual character of our bank position than the fact that, whereas the Reserve Board's increase of 50 per cent in reserves required to be held by member banks went into effect last Saturday, not a ripple has occurred in the money market.

WILLISTON PARK, L.I., Aug. 21. -- The United States Government insists that William B. Clayton of 40 Cornell Street, here, died in the World War. Mr. Clayton, however, insists, as did Mark Twain, that the report is grossly exaggerated.
Recently I drew up the standing of the major league clubs for each of the sixteen years from 1920 through 1935.

YOSEMITE, Calif., Aug. 21. -Only war by a united China can settle the differences of that country with Japan, Dr. Hu Shih, China's most noted philosopher and educator, said to this correspondent today.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Twenty-two men described as officers of the Black Legion were indicted today on criminal syndicalism charges based on allegations that they plotted an armed uprising to take over the Federal Government.

VALLADOLID, Spain, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Reinforeed Rebel troops started forward today in the Guadax rama /[ount-.i,.q. Rebel headqu-ters were shifted here from Burghs and the advance troops of the wellarmed, weU-dJseiplined army fere prepared to march tomorrow on the

ONLY yesterday the newspapers carried a story involving Father Divine. Up in Kingston, N.Y., American Legion officials, watchful as usual of the national honor, succeeded in forcing a woman known as Fair Angel to furl an oriflamme announcing not only that there were forty-eight States in the Union but that Father Divine was God.

As a climax to months of investigation by Federal agents, three men were arrested in New York late yesterday, charged with being members of a vast inter-State vice syndicate whose operations spread through New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Financial aid to individual railroads from the Public Works Administration as part of the recovery drive had mounted to more than $200,000,000 a week ago, according to figures ascertained today. Total authorizations had reached $201,029,000 but, because of recissions now in progress, this sum had been cut to a disbursement of $200,529,000.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- President Roosevelt signed an executive order today to help distressed farmers by increasing from $200 to $400 the maximum amount the Farm Credit Administration may lend to individuals for Winter wheat seed.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 21. -- Diplomatic relations between Bolivia and Paraguay were declared re-established in a formal agreement signed this afternoon by their delegates to the Chaco peace conference.

Broadway storekeepers were enlisted yesterday in a campaign to keep the streets of Manhattan's best-known thoroughfare clean, when Mayor La Guardia asked them to cooperate with the Sanitation Department.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 21. -President Roosevelt plans to make no political speeches before October, thereby limiting his actual campaign for re-election, as he defines active "political" efforts, to the month immediately preceding the national elections.

Almost 1,000 naval reservists of the metropolitan area will be embarked today on fourteen destroyers for a two weeks' training cruise. The embarkation is described by officers at the Third Naval District as the largest concentration of naval reservists in this area since the World War.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 21. -Greyhound, winner of the 1935 Hambletonian and star of the Baker stables, St. Charles, Ill., raced a 1:57 1/4 mile in the free-for-all class trot during the closing day of Grand Circuit racing at the Illinois State Fair Grounds today.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week amounts to only $22,808,291 for forty municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $72,705,485 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings this year now stands at $23,533,812.

A vigorous campaign to eliminate the floating vote in the coming election, calling for a survey of all the city's lodging houses every two weeks and wholesale prosecutions of lodging-house keepers who do not comply with the law, was started yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

Unsettled by news from abroad, prices on the Cotton Exchange turned downward yesterday and under increased selling pressure closed at the bottom with losses of 11 to 12 points. Besides the effects of events in Spain, the market reflected estimates of increases in competing growths and the possible curtailment of export demand for cotton grown in the United States.

Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to the United States, will sail today for Rome on the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia to take up his now post as Ambassador to Russia. Also sailing on the ship are Katharine Cornell, the actress; Count and Countess Di Carpeneto, Commander Carlo Tucci, Mr. and Mrs. Remo Zenosi, Mr. and Mrs. E.M. Cravath, Mme. Denise Bourdet, Milton F. Untermeyer and Mrs. Eleanor M. Morton.

Use of billboard advertising in England is currently showing an increase of 20 per cent, with a record demand for space anticipated for the period of the coronation of King Edward VIII, it was reported here yesterday by Arthur Hyams of the Borough Billposting Company, London, the largest billposting concern in England, who is here on a five-week visit.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 21. -Argentina's invasion of this country's polo center was practically complete this evening. The last load of ponies came in aboard the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, fresh from their Olympic triumph, and the full list of forty-eight was bedded down in Mitchel Field stables tonight.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 21 (AP). -America's barnstorming Olympic track and field stars won five more events today in the concluding program of a three-day international meet.

PARIS, Aug. 21. -- Italy's answer to the French note is announced here as an acceptance of the French proposal for neutrality in Spain. Diplomatic quarters believe the Italian reservations may be held over for secondary consideration but that they will no longer prevent an agreement against arms shipments.
Official city papers were transported yesterday from Floyd Bennett Airport, at the southerly tip of the city, to the Summer City Hall, at its northerly extremity, in thirty-five minutes.

If I correctly interpret Mr. Krauthoff's letter to THE TIMES, he accuses Governor Landon of inconsistency on two counts. First, that Pittsburg, Kan., did not extend and improve its waterworks system on a cash basis, and secondly, that Governor Landon countenanced the borrowing of funds under the National Industrial Recovery Act, thereby subjecting himself to the charge of a right-about-face in his present attitude toward that particular policy, at least, of the present administration.

The Italian Superpower Corporation's report for June 30, issued yesterday, showed total assets of $31,218,299, compared with $30,690,953 a year previously. Investments were carried at $29,285,285, cost or declared value, and had a market value of $28,175,962 on the reporting date, against $29,207,350 and $30,837,397, respectively, correspondingly in 1935.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

The midshipmen's practice cruise squadron, reduced in size to two battleships, the Wyoming and Arkansas, because of the Spanish emergency, arrived in New York yesterday afternoon and took up anchorage in the Hudson River off 129th Street for a week-end visit.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- The German Stock Exchanges, which had been booming ever since the programs got under way for the National Socialist creation of employment and for rearmament, but which had shown considerable nervousness lately, experienced today something like a "Black Friday," which sent many quotations on the Boerse tumbling to low figures that had not been registered on the shares for years.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2l. -- The Whitney family is entertaining guests in honor of the running tomorrow of the Whitney, a race in memory of leaders of Saratoga racing for years, the late William Collins Whitney and his sons, the late Payne and the late Harry Payne Whitney.
LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 21. -Peace and quiet mark the internal situation in Portugal. The army and navy are prepared to crush uprisings in sympathy with the Leftists of Spain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled today that the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, being "still an integral part" of the New York, New Haven Hartford, could not receive an exemption that would remove it from the power of the National Railway Labor Act.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 21. -When Miss Frances Robbins of Southampton rode her upstanding brown gelding Brian Boru over the outside course today in the annual North Shore Horse Show she was not only going after the blue ribbon in the class for qualified hunters but she was aiming for permanent possession of the Meadowbrook Masters Trophy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- A brief to substantiate charges that the Commodity Exchange Act is unconstitutional, made here in a complaint in the Federal District Court on Aug. 15, was filed today with Judge John P. Barnes on behalf of William S. Moore and all members of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange by Walter Bachrach and Arthur Magid.
Referring to an article in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES by Waldemar Kaempffert on timing games, averaging the times of three stop watches is never done.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Arrangements to produce a dramatization of Sinclair Lewis's novel "It Can't Happen Here," have been completed by the Federal Theatre division of the Works Progress Administration and are only awaiting final approval of government officials.

Frank J. Prial, civil service leader, won a preliminary round yesterday in his battle for the Democratic nomination for the Aldermanic Presidency from his organization opponent, Sheriff William F. Brunner of Queens, when he drew first position yesterday on the primary ballot.

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- A furious anti-Russian campaign continued to sweep Germany tonight. It was authoritatively said that the Ambassador of at least one foreign power expressed uneasiness over the situation to the Foreign Office.

MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 21. -- The march of California's woman's tennis brigade continued today as Miss Helen Jacobs, Berkeley, and Miss Alice Marble, San Francisco, tossed aside Bay State foes to provide an all-Pacific Coast final tomorrow in the Essex County Club's invitation tournament.

While the movement of merchandise through retail channels was less active, industrial operations showed the broadest upswing in more than a month, with the rate generally at the highest level reached since 1930, according to the trade review of the week issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A committee of the American Bar Association has prepared a report on what it describes as the "hippodroming" of American criminal justice by newspapers and the radio. By this phrase it means sensational handling of the news of celebrated criminal cases.

Weakness was the rule yesterday in the local commodity futures markets, with few exceptions, among them copper and cocoa, which advanced. In the cash markets, wheat rose and cocoa made a new high record, while cotton, corn, rye, oats, lard, eggs, tin, silk and rubber were lower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Changes in the holdings of officers, directors and principal stockholders of many corporations whose securities are listed on the New York Stock Exchange were reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
United States Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York City:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- The American Federation of Teachers, ending its annual convention today, defeated a move which would have closed the doors to affiliation with John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization and then, by a unanimous vote, called for a boycott of all agencies of communication under the control of William Randolph Hearst.

An abrupt change in investment and speculative sentiment was reflected in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Seemingly, without specific reason, other than a seasonal overbought position, investment values underwent what appeared to be a drastic reappraisal of potential possibilities in view of the forthcoming national election.

William O. Morse protests against what he terms my "blanket indictment" of the Republican campaign platform and the acceptance speech of Governor Landon, saying that statements so sweeping lose most of their effectiveness, and concludes that my opinions were influenced by sentiment rather than by reason.

ON BOARD GOVERNOR LANDON'S SPECIAL TRAIN EN ROUTE TO WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 21. -- Speaking to a wildly cheering crowd of about 15,000 at Cedar Rapids this afternoon, Governor Landon hit indirectly at President Roosevelt by declaring that politics should be kept out of attempts to solve the drought problem.

ROME, Aug. 21. -- The Italian Government accepted with two reservations tonight the French proposal for neutrality in Spanish affairs. It formally pledged itself to forbid direct or indirect exportation of arms to Spain, to apply this measure to all contracts for the supply of arms now being fulfilled and to cooperate with other interested powers for reciprocal communication of all measures taken to render this pledge effective.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to permit Chicago to be included in the Eastern standard time zone. At the same time it did move the zone boundary westward from Detroit to the shores of Lake Michigan.

WEST MIDDLESEX, Pa., Aug. 21. -- The face of Governor Landon looked out from nearly every window in his native village tonight as Republicans and Democrats alike prepared to welcome the Republican nominee tomorrow for the opening of his Eastern campaign.

Two business men and two bankers joined in a radio broadcast under the auspices of the Democratic National Committee last night to set forth the reasons why they were supporting the re-election of President Roosevelt.

Aroused over the negligence involved in having two small girls locked in a city school building last Tuesday night, Mayor La Guardia asked the Board of Education yesterday to fix responsibility for the incident and to take drastic action against the officials responsible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 21. -A plea to fellow-jurists was made here tonight by Frederick E. Crane, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, "to think for ourselves and, in the spirit of the common law, make the law fit new conditions and new problems."

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug. 21. -- Interest centered today in the tennis match at the invitation tournament at the Mount Washington, many assembling in the galleries and on the lawn. The tennis players were entertained in the Cave Grill by the younger set tonight and several participated in an all-day ping pong tournament.
WILDWOOD, N.J., Aug. 21. -- One hundred thousand persons lined the Boardwalk here this afternoon, for the twenty-seventh annual baby carnival.
ALBANY, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The "Scotland Yard" branch of the New York State Police prepared today for a new offensive against reckless motorists who cause fatalities on the highways.

WARSAW, Aug. 21. -- A demand that Polish warships be sent to Spain was put forward here tonight as a result of the killing of Mr. Nagiera, a Consul for Poland but a Spanish citizen, by Spanish anarchists in Valencia last night. The news caused great embitterment here, and the Polish Government ordered its Minister in Madrid to file a strong protest and demand immediate explanations and punishment of the culprits.

MADRID, Aug. 18 (London Times Dispatch, Uncensored). -- Despite the fatalism of Madrilenos and the present relative tranquillity a great shadow of uncertainty hovers over the Spanish capital. The knowledge that a long, bitter struggle lies ahead has made its mark upon the people.

The reassuring remarks of Thomas W. Lamont on the European political situation will be read with great interest in the financial community. In any circumstances the opinions of this Morgan partner are a matter of moment in Wall Street, where every shred of gossip about "what they think at the Corner" is likely to be passed about with ceremony and received like a benison.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22. -- Six Soviet leaders, including four world-famous Bolsheviki who were intimate friends of Nikolai Lenin, are now under investigation as a result of testimony given by Gregory Zinovieff, Leon Kameneff and others of the sixteen now on trial for an alleged terrorist plot against Joseph Stalin and his chief associates.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21. -- With the qualifying rounds nearing an end, a number of New Yorkers stand to advance into the finals of the open tournament for the championship of the American Chess Federation, play in which continued today.
Business and dwelling properties changed hands in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

WILLIAM E. RUSSELL, who died prematurely forty years ago, several times won his election as a Democratic Governor in Republican Massachusetts. He was an extraordinarily skillful campaigner, with engaging personal traits and a shrewd knowledge how to hit a local audience between wind and water.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 21. -America's fastest single engine motor boats, speedier than even the Gold Cup racers, began arriving on truck and trailer this afternoon for the three-day regatta known as the National Sweepstakes which will get under way tomorrow noon on the North Shrewsbury River here.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (AP). -Superior Judge Henry M. Willis late today vacated orders by Presiding Superior Judge Douglas L. Edmonds appointing the State Insurance Commissioner, Samuel Carpenter, as liquidator of the old Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company and approving a plan of reorganization submitted by Mr. Carpenter.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- In one of the best tennis matches of the year, Frank Parker of Spring Lake defeated Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta today to gain the final round of the Newport invitation tournament with Robert L. Riggs of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Henceforth, subject to certain conditions, no detailed description need be given of any security issue which is to be retired within a reasonable time after the effective date of the registration statement, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today in amending its instructions for registration statements filed on Form A-2 under the Securities Act of 1933.
BETHEL, Vt., Aug. 21. -- Sinclair Lewis, commenting tonight on the proposed production of "It Can't Happen Here" under the WPA Federal Theatre Project, said:

BERLIN, Aug. 21. -- The German Government, it was announced today, has lodged formal protest in Moscow and Madrid over what is alleged to be anti-German agitation by Russian and Spanish broadcasting stations. Both governments, it is charged, are employing their official stations to discredit Germany in Spain through dissemination of hostile radio news. Moscow is accused of directing this anti-German campaign on the air.

Police were called to Yorkville Court yesterday to quiet seven women prisoners who refused to be fingerprinted after they were found guilty by Magistrate Hulon Capshaw of disorderly conduct. They had been arrested Aug. 5 while picketing the Peerless Wig Company, 40 East Nineteenth Street.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 21. -- The seventh annual North Shore Horse Show, which opened here this morning, was attended by more than 500.

The first of the forty-seven closed mortgage guarantee companies to be reorganized and reopened will be the Union Guarantee Mortgage Company, it was indicated yesterday in a report filed in the Supreme Court. The report was made by Alexander Pfeiffer, who was appointed referee to conduct hearings and report on a proposed plan of reorganization submitted by a committee of creditors.

Some weeks back, four of Hollywood's better known writers set about writing a screen adaptation of Don Marquis's "Tablecloth Millionaire," as a favor to the author, who is ill. Their good deed completed, Gene Fowler, Nunnally Johnson, Grover Jones and Patterson McNutt have sold the treatment to Paramount on Mr. Marquis's behalf.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 21. -One hundred and twenty-five guests, mostly from New York City and Brooklyn, escaped in their night clothing from the Kiamesha Mansion, a large Summer hotel at Kiamesha, two miles from here, when that structure burned at 5 o'clock this morning.

Alfredo Salmaggi and his New York Hippodrome Opera Company returned to the Hippodrome Theatre last night for a series of week-end opera productions at popular prices. The initial offering was Bizet's "Carmen," and the assemblage, despite the sultry weather, was large and enthusiastic.

The recent proposal of Secretary WALLACE and other advisers to the President that the Government go into the business of insuring the farmer against crop losses raises a number of interesting questions. In principle, there is no reason why the farmer should not be insured against damage to his crops just as he is against the hazard of fire to his barns or the theft of his automobile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Treasury's action of Aug. 14 removing, countervailing duties against ten articles currently imported from Germany, originally applied to offset subsidies which the American Government held the German Government was supplying to its exporters, has not solved the trade problems existing between the two countries, conversations with experts revealed today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -Tired after their grueling racing on the New York Yacht Club cruise, the large craft skippers left for home ports today. The talked-of aftermath of two days of competition among the big fellows off here failed to appeal to them.
